column2: CLEVELAND, June 7 -- Lower costs for television, radio and air conditioning cabinets, which account for one-half of their selling price, may result from the first peacetime application of atomic energy to plastics.

CHESTERTOWN, Md., June 7 -- President Eisenhower asserted today that Government should provide essential services and welfare without a "greedy" and busybody intrusion into functions of the individual.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The White House confirmed today that President Eisenhower sent a friendly telegram to Representative James B. Utt, Republican of California, who is using it in his campaign for renomination in a primary election tomorrow.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 7 -- Gen. Henri-Eugene Navarre, outgoing French commander in Indochina, declared tonight that Tonkin's Red River delta was not in immediate danger. He expressed the view that his successor might have more trouble in the near future with Vietminh regiments approximating two divisions in the plateau area of central Annam.

Governor Dewey has called the Legislature into special session on Thursday to consider the excellent plan recently proposed for rehabilitating the Long Island Rail Road and to enact some correctives to the election district reapportionment law.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that sales of natural gas by the Phillips Petroleum Company to pipelines that distribute it in interstate commerce are subject to regulation by the Federal Power Commission.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs had continued to drop.

More space is being given in household refrigerators to frozen-food storage. Many new models can accomodate fifty to 100 pounds of frozen products. Thus the city family, and even the "kitchenette" household, can keep on hand a quantity of frozen foods that a few years ago could be held only if one had a freezer or a locker in a frozen-food plant.

The protectionists of the House, having won their battle against three-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act at this session, are now chopping away at what remains of the President's program to liberalize the channels of international commerce.
A convicted robber yesterday quoted William Howell as saying that Joseph S. Fay, labor extortionist "knew about" the murder last August of Thomas F. Lewis, Bronx labor leader.

PARIS, June 7 -- Maurice Thorez, leader of the French Communist party, told his followers today to spare nothing in their effort to unite the working class and all other "democratic and national" forces in a common front.

WASHINGTON, June 7--The United States action late last week of increasing its subsidy to exporters of wheat by 10 cents a bushel under the International Wheat Agreement has the effect of cutting the price by an equal amount.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Farmers' organizations today spoke out vigorously in favor of a House-passed bill to legalize trip-leasing of trucks, but the Association of American Railroads called the legislation a "tremendous backward step."
NOVOSIBIRSK, U. S. S. R. June 2 -- A hydroelectric dam is being erected here to harness the Ob River.
OTTAWA, June 7 -- Canada cut the export price of its top grade wheat by 10 1/8 cents a bushel today in a move to bring it to a competitive price level with the United States.
GUATEMALA, June 7--A former United States Air Force major fled Guatemala Friday with Col. Rodolfo Mendoza Azurdia, former Guatemalan Air Force chief.

In Quebec, a bottle of an alcoholic beverage cannot be reproduced in advertising in newspapers, magazines or on television. So, when Molson's Brewery, Ltd., well-known producer of ale, decided to put a beer on the market it had to work out a trademark that would serve as a bottle would in advertising in this country.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 7 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali inaugurated the first commercial flight of the Government-owned Pakistan International Airways tonight.

John Burton Houck, Edward C. Diehl, Charles L. Kaeser, John Maslin, Sheldon Leicher, Lester J. Kovar, John F. McDonnell, Harold F. McGinnis and John J. McGuire, in the Hord Hill Apartments at University Heights.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers will place on the market today $20,000,000 of sinking fund debentures of the Fruehauf Trailer Company, the nation's largest manufacturer of truck trailers.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 7 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen told Syracuse University graduates today that "the prime purpose not only of President Eisenhower's foreign policy but of all his policies is the achievement of an honorable and lasting peace."
Two apartment houses and an adjoining vacant plot in the Bronx have been purchased by a group of investors headed by Philip Monka, operator, from the estate of Jacob Eidenbach.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Following is the text of an Atomic Energy Commission letter in which the commission said it could not permit attorneys for Dr. Oppenheimer to make oral pleas for his reinstatement but would consider written arguments:
The trade shopping season for women's fall apparel opened yesterday but there were fewer retail buyers in New York City than last year.

LOS ANGELES, June 7--A new Navy jet attack bomber that reverses the trend toward ever bigger and more complicated military planes was shown for the first time today at the Douglas Aircraft Company's El Segundo plant.

BUENOS AIRES, July 7 -- The Federal police visited industrial concerns in the capital today asking if they required protection. Their action followed violence among members of the metallurgical union that resulted in the fatal shooting of two union members and injuries to others.
" The Barefoot Contessa" and "Vera Cruz" have been booked into the Capitol Theatre, where they will have their premieres, in that order, after the opening of "The Caine Mutiny" on June 24.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., May 29 -- The soft coal industry is gathering statistics in the hope it can convince the public, and especially the Government, that, instead of just talking about the bituminous plight, something should be done about it.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 -- A proposed merger of the San Francisco Bank and the Central Bank of Oakland, with total deposits of more than $450,000,000, was approved today by directors of the former institution. Henry Verdelin, president of the San Francisco Bank, said the proposal would go to the stockholders this week for approval.
Keeping the elderly out of "the old people's home" is the aim of a program being carried out by the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews, 121 West 105th Street.

A touch of velvet, appearing here and there on the midsummer fashion scene, gives light and gossamer fabrics a rich and interesting accent. Later, those same accessories can be used appropriately with early fall clothes.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 7 -- The Buttery Mill on Mill Road, reputed to be the oldest sawmill in use in the United States, has at last slowed down to a standstill. It is for sale and almost certainly will soon be dismantled.
Niles City, Ohio, School District announced yesterday that it would offer for sale on June 17 $1,161,000 of bonds dated June 1, 1954, and due on June 1 and Dec. 1 from 1965 to 1978.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- New York City won the right today to take 360,000,000 gallons more of water daily from tributaries of the Delaware River.
Fire bells began ringing at almost the same time yesterday at three widely scattered points in the Port of New York area, summoning firemen to battle the flames on a total of thirteen alarms.

A glance at the map of Asia shows the strategic position occupied by Afghanistan, the buffer state between much of Pakistan and the richest portion of Soviet Central Asia. In view of this strategic position it is not surprising that Soviet efforts to woo Afghanistan and to make that country dependent on Russia have been sharply stepped up recently.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- More liberal standards for determining whether taxpayers are entitled to personal exemptions for dependants have been approved by the Senate Finance Committee.
John Francis Roche, held as the slayer of four persons, including a 14-year-old schoolgirl, was described in a 1946 Probation Bureau report as being beset with "serious neurotic conflicts."

The regional blood program of the Red Cross received 783 pints of blood last Friday. Of this total 182 came from employes of the Schlitz Brewing Company in Brooklyn. Members of Local 101 of the Utilities Division of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and other employes of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company gave 150 pints of blood at the company's offices at 180 Remsen Street.

Columbia University has established an advisory committee to further plans for a fifteen-story arts center on the Morningside campus. The project was first announced in February, 1948, but was shelved in the face of conflicting development plans.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Supreme Court swept away today the last legal obstacle to the United States' participation in the construction of a $600,000,000 St. Lawrence River power project.
A big traffic jam in the Columbus Circle area last evening spoiled the debut of one-way operations on Seventh and Eighth Avenues.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (UP) -- The Supreme Court today rejected a newspaper woman's challenge to the constitutionality of the Social Security tax on self-employed persons.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 7 -- Preliminary plans for modernizing Westchester's hazardous Hutchinson River Parkway will be completed by Oct. 15 at a cost of $203,000.
Two quiet, obviously well-informed robbers held up a hotel adjacent to the Copacabana night club early yesterday and took $26,034 in currency and $1,325 in checks.
Net income of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., and its subsidiaries declined in the quarter and nine months ended April 30 from the corresponding periods of the previous year.
GENEVA, June 7 -- The president of the National Assembly of Panama delivered a slashing attack on the United States here today for perpetuating "racial discrimination" in the Panama Canal zone.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Unemployment dropped slightly in May and employment rose appreciably, the Commerce and Labor Departments reported today.

The four-story apartment house accommodating twenty-eight families at 392 East Fourth Street in Brooklyn has been sold by Rubin Weissman to Normar Equities, Inc., represented by Joseph Jackowitz, attorney. Lennard Sons were the brokers and Louis Barnett was attorney for the seller. The property occupies a plot 80 by 100 feet and is assessed at $76,000.

Joey Maxim, 32-year-old Clevelander, received a unanimous decision over previously unbeaten Floyd Patterson, 19-year-old Brooklynite, in the main bout of eight rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.
Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, predicted yesterday that religion would prove to be the "major factor" in the decline of communism in Asia.
SEOUL, Korea, June 7 -- South Korea is pressing with increased vigor for large-scale military assistance from the United States.
CAIRO, June 7 -- Dr. Mustafa Amer, head of the Egyptian Department of Antiquities, today called 1954 a historic year for archaeological discoveries in Egypt.
WEST POINT, N. Y., June 7 -- The 634 members of this year's graduating class paraded today for the last time on the historic plain at the United States Military Academy.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., (UP) -- Brig. Gen. Wesley J. Guest, acting commanding officer of the Army's Signal Corps Laboratories here, said today he was "completely surprised" by a statement that many top scientists were quitting the laboratories in protest against security charges involving their colleagues.
GENEVA, June 7 -- The Soviet Union rejected today a compromise Western suggestion that Asian states supervise compliance with an Indochina armistice if one is reached here.
Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator and Park Commissioner will be the speaker at the 103d commencement exercises of Manhattan College this afternoon at 3:30 o'clock.

The dangers raised by the continuing delay in the creation of the European Defense Community are illustrated again by the growing demand in Germany for a policy of neutrality which would scuttle the European unification movement. This demand, first confined to Communists, Socialists, pacifists and ultra-nationalists, has now spread to industrial and intellectual circles.
Five youths, one of them 15 years old, were charged with homicide yesterday in the fatal shooting last Tuesday of a young ex-convict.

A new volume for the library's African shelf will be added on July 6 when Doubleday issues "Through Malan's Africa," by Robert St. John. It is a first hand report on the "warring factions" in the Union of South Africa--a "composite interview" with the political, social and religious leaders, as well as the English, Dutch, Africans, Negroes and Indians they lead.
BIRMINGHAM, England, June 7 (AP) -- Tony Trabert and Vic Seixas, American Davis Cup players, today swept into the semi-finals of the Priory tennis tournament.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 7 (UP) -- The thirteenth plenary meeting of the International Cotton Advisory Committee convened here today with representatives from the United States and twenty-three of the twenty-eight other member countries attending.

LONDON, June 7 (Reuters) -- Nikolai M. Shvernik, leader of the Soviet labor unions, criticized failings by four Soviet ministries in a keynote address in Moscow today to the Eleventh Congress of Soviet labor unions.
CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

ATLANTIC CITY, June 7 -- The president of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association reported here today that annual sales by the nation's wholesale electrical distributors rose from $1,200,000,000 in 1945 to nearly $5,700,000,000 in 1953.

The United States is the country that has more strikes than all the world combined. Nevertheless, when there is a strike in Latin America against an American company the strikers are immediately branded as Communist-inspired.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 7 -- The Westchester County American Legion canceled tonight an invitation it had extended to Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. to be the principal speaker at its thirty-sixth annual convention here July 9.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 7 -- Filming on Robert Stillman's production of "The Americano" will get off to a fresh start here next Monday at the R. K. O. Studio.
Unionized Sanitation Department employes threatened last night to halt the collection of garbage by posting pickets outside all departmental garages.
The Andrea Radio Corporation, Long Island City, plans to market a seventeen-inch color television set in October.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Philip Bart, general manager of the Communist newspaper, The Daily Worker, received a Supreme Court review today of his conviction for contempt of Congress.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Defense Department plans to replace man for man the 200 Air Force technicians it is recalling from Indochina this month. The move will fulfill a pledge to the Senate Armed Services Committee to bring back the men.

MANILA, June 7 -- President Ramon Magsaysay emerged from a showdown with the Nationalist "old guard" last night as undisputed leader of the party. He received a pledge of all-out support for his foreign policy and domestic rural-development program.
Arnold Bernstein, former German shipowner, is to testify this morning as his 9-year-old suit against the Holland-America Line opens in Federal Court.
The Paramount Theatre in Times Square will curtail its movie fare for several hours each Monday, beginning June 21, and turn over its stage to a nationally broadcast television and radio program.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said today the United States did not intend to go it alone in Indochina "unless the whole nature" of Communist aggression in Asia changed.

Passenger and freight business of the United States Lines this year is expected to be about as good as in 1953, John M. Franklin, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Hoboken, N. J.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 8 -- A World War II veteran who has been paralyzed for ten years from injuries received in the Battle of the Bulge will get a degree in accounting at the 188th commencement exercises of Rutgers University tomorrow.
ALBANY, June 8 -- The victors in the battle for control of the New York Central Railroad are now expected to be announced Monday morning.
BECKENHAM, England, June 8 (UP) -- Four American men scored singles victories today in the Kent lawn tennis championships and three American women were eliminated in first-round matches.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox took over first place in the American League tonight by scoring five runs in the seventh inning to whip the Philadelphia Athletics, 9 -- 3. A two-run double by Ferris Fain and a homer by George Kell -- good for two more tallies -- highlighted the big inning.
It was very disturbing to read your editorial comment covering the severance of the Third Avenue El at 149th Street.
A rule proposed by a member breed club was discussed and left open to further consideration at a meeting of American Kennel Club delegates at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday.
A coordinated highway program to minimize interference with residential neighborhoods in the northern New Jersey-New York area was advocated yesterday by the Regional Plan Association.
OTTAWA, June 8 -- Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent assured a stormy House of Commons today that neither Canada nor the United States had any desire to enter into a price war on wheat.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- President Eisenhower's proposal for lower taxes on foreign earnings of United States corporations was approved in principle today by the Senate Finance Committee.
An automatic "swing-needle" sewing machine, which can do embroidery as well as straight sewing, was introduced at the Savoy Plaza Hotel yesterday by the Singer Sewing Machine Company.

Harvey S. Firestone Jr., chairman of the board of the United Service Organizations, has expressed "deepest appreciation to the 81,000 U. S. O. volunteers who made the welfare of our service men their vital concern during the past year." U. S. O.'s services to our armed forces would be impossible without this volunteer army.

The one-story garage - type building at 93-34 170th Street in Jamaica, Queens, has been sold by the Stellar Tool Manufacturing Company to Frank and John F. Tanaski. Charles Richardson and Colony Realty were co-brokers in the transaction.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -Representative Kit Clardy, Republican of Michigan, today urged Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. to start deportation proceedings against Nathan Gregory Silvermaster and about 100 others whose names he said were on file with the House Un-American Activities Committee.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said today he was sure Roy M. Cohn would get "preferential treatment" when he reported to Camp Kilmer, N. J., this week-end for training with the New York National Guard.

A cornerstone-laying was held yesterday for George Washington Houses, a low-rent development of the New York City Housing Authority. The development is bounded by Second and Third Avenues and Ninety-seventh and 104th Streets.

City housewives usually dispatch outmoded kitchen utensils to the trash can, but women in the country, where ample space permits sentimental hoarding, may keep such gadgets for generations. This rural tendency to lay up rather than throw out has allowed one upstate resident to pursue a fascinating hobby, collecting old culinary tools.

RYE, N. Y., June 8 -- Tom Robbins of Winged Foot, winner of the title in 1951 and 1952, set the pace among 204 players in the opening round of the United States Seniors Golf Association championship today.
Unionized garbage workers added a new twist yesterday to the war of nerves they have been waging against the city to force an increase in their wages.

TRENTON, June 8 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner declared here today that development at this time of a fiscal policy to ward off a possible financial crisis in New Jersey next year was politically impractical.
GENEVA, June 8 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the addresses today by the top representatives of the Big Four at the conference here in Indochina:

Employes of member concerns of the New York Maritime Association will take part today in the opening of a three-day donation of blood for the regional blood program of the Red Cross. The semi-yearly event for the association will be conducted at the Downtown Athletic Club, 18 West Street.
A delicate job of "stabbing in the dark" is fast making scrap metal of a 200-foot steel barge lying deep in the East River.
LONDON, June 8 -- Business was restricted and price movements narrow and irregular when the stock markets here reopened today after a long holiday weekend. The close was described as firm.
Authoritative reports have it that furniture designers in Communist East Germany are likely to wind up in Siberia if they make chairs or other items too comfortable or relaxing.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 8 -- Scientific studies penetrating deep into the secrets of birth, growth and death are evolving from the combined efforts of chemists, physicists, biologists, geneticists and other scientists, it was reported here today.

A new novel by Harvey Fergusson, "The Conquest of Don Pedro," will be issued June 23 by Morrow. Set in the region of New Mexico in which Mr. Fergusson grew up, the story is about a young man who travels West for his health, settles in a small New Mexico town and becomes an influential merchant and civic leader.

ALTHOUGH heavy rains during the last two weeks of May reduced the drought threat to waterfowl in the great "duck factory" in western Canada, Ducks Unlimited reports that the breeding stock has declined to about the level that existed in 1952.

The House Agriculture Committee, now considering an omnibus farm bill, has challenged the central thesis of the whole farm program proposed by the Administration. It did this yesterday when it voted to continue through 1955 the high, rigid price supports (90 per cent of parity) on the so-called "basic" commodities.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- A member of the Atomic Energy Commission suggested today that the United States stage a "modern war in a capsule" and set off a hydrogen bomb to demonstrate before the world the urgency of the need for peace.
Emergency preparations for a transit strike Monday were ordered yesterday by Mayor Wagner. Simultaneously his labor aides strove to settle the dispute between the Transit Authority and its employes.

DENVER, June 8 (AP) -- T. Coleman Andrews, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, said yesterday that his agency was looking into the financial affairs of Senator Joseph McCarthy and would wind up the investigation within sixty days.

FIFTY years ago this midmonth the three-decked white paddle-wheeler General Slocum moved upriver from its East Third Street pier in glaring sunlight, belching smoke in thick dusky folds from twin stacks.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The House Agriculture Committee voted overwhelmingly today, as expected, for a one-year extension of high, rigid price supports. The vote was 21 to 8.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 8 -- This city's ninety delegates to the Democratic State Convention here June 25 and 26 were "instructed" tonight to cast their vote for Abraham A. Ribicoff of Hartford for the nomination for Governor.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 8 -- A top electric utility executive said here today that, except for refrigerators, nine out of ten American families are possible customers for one or more major electrical appliances. He added that three of every four families are prospects for most portable appliances.

As the Geneva conference drags through its seventh week it becomes increasingly clear that the Communists are using it as a propaganda forum, prolonging the battle of words while stepping up their military campaign. They are making just enough modifications in their first preposterous proposals to impress the unwary and to make it difficult for the free nations to break off the talks.
JERUSALEM, June 8 -- An Israeli Foreign Ministry spokesman described as "the wildest nonsense" today the idea that Israel might attack Jordan or Syria.

The joint campaign of the Tea Council here, by which India, Indonesia, Ceylon and packers in this country are promoting tea consumption. iced or hot, has been so successful that it is soon to spread to Canada.

The president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences has thrown cold water on Soviet hopes for large-scale generation of atomic power in the near future. He implied that many problems must still be solved.
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 8 -- State Attorney General Leo A. Hoegh outdistanced five other candidates yesterday to capture Iowa's Republican nomination for Governor.

Goodhue Livingston Jr., a member of the City Planning Commission, charged yesterday that the latest plan for the rehabilitation of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road, which has Governor Dewey's backing, appeared to have been dictated by political expediency.
CHICAGO, June 8 -- The wheat pit broke into sharp activity today on the news that the House Agriculture Committee had voted to extend rigid price controls on wheat, corn, cotton, peanuts and rice.
The Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday canceled plans to hold its 1955 triennial general convention in Houston, Tex., because of racial segregation.
COLUMBIA, S. C., June 8 (AP) -- George Bell Timmerman Jr., 42-year-old Lieutenant Governor, won the Democratic nomination for Governor today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 8 -- Gov. Goodwin J. Knight, Republican, was trying desperately tonight in early returns from the California primary election to duplicate a feat of his predecessor, Chief Justice Earl Warren.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Senate Democrats issued an ultimatum to the Republican leadership today to bring forward a liberal world trade program for this country or risk losing control of the whole issue.
The United Seamen's Service elected Vice Admiral Edward L. Cochrane, retired, as president yesterday afternoon at its twelfth annual meeting in the Wintehall Club, 17 Battery Place.

Most popular of the table-ready meats, frankfurters account for about a third of America's sausage sales. The lowly "hot dog" receives particular attention during the summer because it is so easy and quick to cook.

The reorganization plan submitted by the Long Island Transit Authority, while constructive on many points, fails to solve the basic question whether this road can ever be operated under private ownership and simultaneously provide reasonable service to its passengers at reasonable rates.

ATHENS, June 8 (AP) -- Alexander Papagos, Premier of Greece, announced today that representatives of holdiers of Greek foreign debt bonds will be invited next month to negotiate terms and conditions for a settlement of the defaulted Greek National external debt "within the country's economic capabilities."

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., June 8 (AP) -- Mrs. Mae Murray Jones of Montpelier, Vt., today shot a record-breaking, 33, 38 -- 71 to take a wide lead in the first round of the women's Eastern Golf Association championship at the Wethersfield Country Club course.

SEOUL, Korea, June 8 (AP) -- President Syngman Rhee accused the United States today of wasting Korean aid funds on "unnecessary administrative expenses." He proposed that he take over the United States-financed rebuilding program.
CHICAGO, June 8 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The country's current bill for direct aid to the airlines is about $80 millions annually. This is subsidy money, and is separate from the approximately $58 millions paid domestic and international carriers for the hauling of mail.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- The Administration told Congress today that bringing more workers under the unemployment compensation system would make it harder for employes fraudulently to obtain jobless payments.

The Opera Workshop of the Greenwich House Music School presented last evening an operatic program, the highlight of which was the first performance of Martin Kalmanoff's one-act opera, "A Quiet Game of Cribble." The libretto was by the composer.

PARIS, June 8 -- At the request of Premier Joseph Laniel, the National Assembly suspended today its debate on Indochina. Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, will speak on the Far East conference when the debate is resumed tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Air Force claimed today a speed record -- on the ground -- of 421 miles an hour for a sled propelled by rocket power. That speed was reached in March by Lieut. Col. John P. Stapp, hurting over a 3,500-foot track at Holloman Air Force Base, Alamagordo, N. M., the Pentagon announced.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Administration's foreign aid bill will propose that a specified proportion of non-military aid be dispensed through loans rather than grants.

Gardening at this season unquestionably is pleasant. True, most of the gardener's really hard work is being done in these pre-summer days, but then there are compensations. For example, all the big failures, the horticultural calamities -- such as the suddenly withered stalk, the wind-blown flower, the trampled (by person or persons unknown) delphinium -- are yet distant.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 8 (AP) -- Australia's John Landy failed again tonight in the cold and rain at Olympic Stadium to break Roger Bannister's 3:59.4 world mile record as he sloshed over a wet and heavy track to a 4:01.6 clocking.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 8 -- Degrees were conferred today on 148 graduates of the Princeton Theological Seminary in the school's 142d annual commencement in the Princeton University chapel.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- A Queens College professor told a House investigating committee today that tax-exempt foundations had promoted a "leftist" course in education and research while being financed, in effect., up to 90 per cent by the Government.

MILWAUKEE, June 8 -- Overcoming the jarring effects of a first-inning grand slam home run, the Giants tonight came through with a Herculean effort that swept them within one game of first place in the National League flag race.

Twenty-four nations thus far have entered films in the Fourth International Film Festival to be held in Berlin June 18-29. Among them are Ceylon, Jamaica, Austria, Canada, Finland, India, Japan, Mexico, Spain, Sweden, South Africa, Yugoslavia, the United States, France and Great Britain.

A public offering of $100,000,000 of sinking fund debentures of the Aluminum Company of America will be placed on the market today by a syndicate of 177 investment houses headed by the First Boston Corporation.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 8 (Reuters) -- The world's cotton stocks are expected to total 18,000,000 bales on Aug 1, compared with 15,500,000 bales a year earlier, the secretariat of the International Cotton Advisory Committee said today.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Democrats fought a rear-guard delaying action today against a Republican drive to end the Army-McCarthy hearings early next week.

Billy Hoeft, who has been able to win only one other game from the rest of the league, not only beat the Yankees, but also shut them out for the second time last night. Detroit's 22-year-old lefthander held the slump-shackled Bombers to two hits as his Tiger team-mates ripped into Eddie Lopat, Bob Kuzava and Tom Gorman for fourteen safeties in posting an 8-0 victory before a stadium crowd of 21,753.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles is leaving for the Middle West and the Northwest tomorrow on a speaking tour, but he has never felt less like speaking in public on the great crisis in Southeast Asia.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, urged Congress today to think seriously about the "skillful" use Russia was making of the theatre and ballet.
CHICAGO, June 8 (UP) -- Ralph Kiner blasted two home runs and Hank Sauer one today to drive in three runs apiece as the Cubs set back the Phillies, 6 to 5, before 6,777 fans.

After a full day or questioning a jury of seven women and five men was selected in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday for the trial of former Internal Revenue Commissioner Joseph D. Nunan on an income tax indictment.
A row over 729 ballots that vanished for fifty-six hours threatened yesterday to upset a run-off vote to select a union representative for 5,000 upstate employes of the New York Telephone Company.
A meeting to determine the control of the Democratic leadership in Queens broke up in tumultuous confusion last night with no decision reached on James A. Roe's status as county leader.

LONDON, June 8 -- The Soviet Union would be defeated severely if it attacked the Western powers this year, Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Commander of the Allied Powers in Europe, declared tonight.

Seventh and Eighth Avenues handled one-way traffic almost flawlessly yesterday. Kinks that showed up in the first two days of operation were ironed out for the most part and the Columbus Circle area remained as the only trouble spot. Even there conditions showed improvement since the program started Sunday.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 8 -Gen. Paul Ely assumed the top French military and political posts in Indochina today. He reaffirmed France's support of the troops fighting here and her solidarity with Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia.

THE premiere of the "Summer Comedy Theatre" fell by the wayside Sunday evening over N. B. C. television (8 P. M.). Some nice young people strived diligently to please, but unfortunately were left too much to their own somewhat limited devices. Television's layoff until Labor Day apparently has begun.

The State of Kentucky sold to investment bankers yesterday. $38,500,000 of turnpike revenue bonds to finance construction of a forty-mile expressway between Louisville and a point south of Elizabethtown.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 8 The whining of power saws and the clattering of hammers vied today with the deep groans of bulldozers on the back lot at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.
MELBOURNE, June 8 -- The Canadian Wheat Boards' cut in prices is causing concern here. The Australian Wheat Board meets tomorrow to consider the situation.

THERE were occasions when the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness served merely as the semi-finals for the season's best 3-year-old race, the Belmont Stakes. There were other occasions when the Belmont served as the third leg in turfdom's sacred Triple Crown. But what will this supreme test prove when it's run on Saturday? Don't answer.
STANTON, Del., June 8 (AP) -- Cinda, a stakes-winning mare racing for the first time in almost a year, took the Rosemont Purse at Delaware Park today.

In The Times of May 29 Senator McCarthy is quoted as saying: "I was disturbed to find that my friends in the Executive branch feel that this duty we have to expose what they are doing * * * is interpreted by them to mean that we are trying to tell them what to do. That is strictly not true."

QOUNSET, R. I., June 8 (AP) -- An engineering expert testified today that the May 26 disaster aboard the aircraft carrier Bennington was the result of "a phenomenon peculiar to hydraulic machinery, for which the cause is not yet known."

WEST POINT, June 8 -- Robert T. Stevens told members of the graduating class of the United States Military Academy here today that as long as he was Secretary of the Army they would "bear no scars from unwarranted attack or abuse." that "every one of you is respected and honored during his service."

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Senate Public Works Committee reported a bill today authorizing the Federal Power Commission to decide who should act for the United States in developing the Niagara River's hydroelectric power potential.

LYNBROOK, L. I., June 8 -- Mrs. Mabel S. Teitlebaum, retiring on July 1 after thirty-five years as a teacher and principal in the Malverne Village school system, was honored at a dinner here tonight by 300 friends and former pupils.

In your columns of correspondence under date of June 4 you publish a letter from three estimable gentlemen on the subject of the pending city legislation creating a City Commission on Intergroup Relations. These men criticize the "drastic revisions" made in the original bill, whose authorship is not disclosed, even though it was introduced by Joseph T. Sharkey.
MONTREAL, June 8 -- Steady gains in experimental telepathic communication have opened new fields for psychological study, the fourteenth International Congress of Psychology was told here today.
ALBANY, June 8 -- The Dewey Administration served notice today that Republicans would take the political offensive at the special session of the Legislature that opens here Thursday.

The two leaders in the national championship tournament at the Marshall Chess Club, Arthur B. Bisguier and Larry Evans, met last night in the tenth round. The result was a draw after fifty-nine moves.
MONTREAL, Que., June 8 -- Grain brokers and shipping men in this, Canada's main port for the export of grain, reacted favorably today to the cut in Canadian wheat prices.

In deciding against a group of property owners who feared that the erection of dams in the St. Lawrence would damage their holdings the Supreme Court has removed the last obstacle to the joint development of hydroelectric power by the New York Power Authority and the Province of Ontario.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UP) -Albert M Cole, Government housing chief, said today Congressional failure to provide an "adequate" public housing program would block the nation's efforts to clear its "worst slum areas."

CAIRO, June 8 -- A second stairway toward what may be the original entrance to the buried sun boats of Pharaoh Cheops was unearthed today by Kamal el Malakh, who discovered the first boat two weeks ago.

BERLIN, June 8 -- Dr. James B. Conant, United States High Commissioner, said today the current Communist ban on youth visits to West Berlin proved Red indoctrination had been a failure. The fact that the Communists felt obliged to hold their hands over the eyes of their youth so far as the West was concerned showed Moscow's "fear of freedom," Dr. Conant added.

A 200-foot sea-going veteran of World War II service in European waters was transferred yesterday from the United States Navy to the Royal Danish Navy. About 300 guests watched the transfer ceremony, conducted by Rear Admiral R. T. Cowdrey at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn.

ST. LOUIS, June 8 -- When the Dodgers break a winning streak they really shatter it. They were soundly beaten tonight by the Cardinals, 10 -- 3, and helped in their own destruction by giving the Redbirds six unearned runs.

Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator and Parks Commissioner, told 386 Manhattan College students who received bachelor degrees yesterday that for man to progress he must strike out along a path neither dark from lack of vision nor artificially lighted by visionaries.

Detecting an interval when he won't be tied down by picture chores, Jose Ferrer has decided to produce and direct "Under the Sycamore Tree." Mr. Ferrer, who doesn't find it burdensome to combine the functions of producer-director-star, will restrain himself this time by not appearing in Sam Spewack's farcical fable.
BEIRA, Portuguese Mozambique, May 8 -- Negro manpower is still the most sought-after commodity in this Zambezi country, where Dr. Livingstone started his anti-slavery campaign in the last century.

As conferees from Senate and House meet to reconcile their housing bills, the main point at issue will be the continuation of low-rent subsidized slum-clearance public housing. The Senate last week endorsed President Eisenhower's modest goal of 140,000 dwelling units to be built over a four-year period; the vote was 66 to 16.
Stock prices slipped 2.2 per cent yesterday in the widest one-day break since June 29, 1950, in the first week of the Korean war.
Fordham College awarded an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws yesterday to Bishop Walter P. Kellenberg of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Ogdensburg, N. Y.

Mayor Wagner got a quick turndown last night from Governor Dewey for his latest appeal for financial aid for the city. The Governor rejected a request by the Mayor that assistance for the city be put on the agenda of the special session of the Legislature opening in Albany at noon tomorrow.

GUATEMALA, June 8 -- The Guatemalan Government today suspended constitutional guarantees of freedom. Affected were the freedom of speech, press and assembly, the in violability of home and the requirement for arrest warrants.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- President Eisenhower sent to Congress today specific requests for supplemental appropriations totaling $165,737,449.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges moved irregularly yesterday, generally ignoring the sharp break in the stock market. Cocoa, potatoes, rubber, soybean oil, cottonseed oil, silk, lead and tin were higher; coffee, sugar, wool, hides, zinc and copper ended lower, and burlap closed mixed.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 8 -- No word has been received for twenty-three days from the nineteen-man Italian expedition that was attempting to climb K-2, also known as Mount Godwin Austen.
Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse, the Broadway playwriting team, have been signed to create television programs for the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Milton Stein, in a purchase for investment, has acquired the industrial property at 87 Ferry Street in Newark, N. J., from the Irwin Holding Corporation. The three-story building contains 36,000 square feet of floor space and is occupied by three tenants. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.
J. Douglas Casey, president of A. C. Allyn Co., Inc., and a director of National Can Corporation, has been elected a member of the National Can executive committee.

A proposed local law that would eliminate passengers entirely from the front seats of new stock-car taxicabs was introduced into the City Council yesterday by Councilman Sam Curtis, Brooklyn Democrat.

The Chemical Bank and Trust Company was charged yesterday with having violated an alleged pledge to Arnold Bernstein in 1937 that it would seek his release from a German prison camp before requiring him to sign over his shipping lines to a Nazi-appointed administrator.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 8 -- Bishop Clinton S. Quin said here today that he was disappointed, though not completely surprised that Houston's selection as the site of the 1955 Protestant Episcopal convention had been canceled.

GENEVA, June 8 -- A closed session on the Korean question at the conference on Far Eastern affairs was canceled today after the South Korean delegation had balked at attending such a meeting with the Communists.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today the United States favored a special inter-American meeting on the Communist threat from Guatemala. However, he added that a decision on such a matter must wait consultations with other American governments.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 8 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold pointed to the World Veterans Federation today as a proof that national differences could be submerged in the general interest of mankind.

LONDON, June 8 -- The Italian Government has been officially informed here of the results of negotiations among the United States, Britain and Yugoslavia for a solution of the long-standing Trieste dispute.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (UP) -- Mickey McDermott's two-hit pitching gave the Washington Senators a 5-2 victory tonight and knocked the Cleveland Indians out of first place in the American League.
Action on two fronts was taken by city officials yesterday against building violations creating hazards to life and health.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- President Eisenhower's chief economic adviser said today that forces were gathering for an economic recovery that seemed under way.
The Chinese Nationalist Government has begun work on a four-year plan to acquire twenty-one ships for its depleted merchant marine.
Buyers for retail stores, here to buy children's and women's wear, are being told to place substantial orders early in the season.
The main charges in the Army - McCarthy controversy now before a Senate investigating subcommittee are:
GENEVA, June 8 -- An industrialist from the United States told those from other lands today that they should learn to consider "that employes are your best customers."
ALBANY, June 8 -- The State University's ban on national fraternities and sororities on the campuses of twenty-two of its units has been upheld unanimously by a special Federal court.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said today that another hearing on the security case of John Paton Davies Jr., career diplomat, probably would be held soon.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Herbert Brownell Jr. asserted today that legislation to compel testimony of witnesses in courts and before Congressional committees in exchange for immunity from prosecution would "be a long step forward in the destruction of the Communist conspiracy in American."

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington before the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in its twenty-ninth day of hearings on the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Representative Alvin M. Bentley of Michigan confronted for the first time today the four Puerto Ricans who are charged with shooting him and four other Representatives on the House floor on March 1.
LONDON, June 8 -- Anthony Eden warned his countrymen today that failure to negotiate a peace settlement for Indochina at the Geneva conference would give rise to a grave world situation.
More than ever these days, man-made fibers are making fashion news.

Local 153 of the Office Employes International Union, A. F. L., attacked yesterday a proposed amendment to the Code of Ethics of the New York State Medical Society as "detrimental to the best interests of many tens of thousands of Americans."
GENEVA, June 8 -- Cambodia denied today Communist allegations that the United States planned to make Cambodia into a military base "capable of menacing a peace in Indochina."

Teddy Atkinson was the ace on Card Trick yesterday. The persevering jockey guided the Greentree Stable 3-year-old to victory in the Troubadour Handicap at Belmont Park, defeating the Wheatley Stable's Quick Lunch by a head.

Chancellor Henry T. Heald will confer degrees upon 6,654 New York University graduates today at the university's 122d commencement ceremonies on the University Heights compus, 181st Street and University Avenue, the Bronx.

Tentative plans for the construction of a new home for the Metropolitan Opera on Park Avenue between Fifty-second and Fifty-third Streets are under discussion, it became known last night. There is no assurance the plan will go through.
CHESTERTON, Ind., June 8 (UP) -- President Eisenhower needn't worry that his Indiana property taxes will become delinquent. They are paid up for the next seventeen years.
The nation's zinc industry, after a promising rally in March and April, suffered a setback last month.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 8 -Leaders of Iraqi opposition parties protested to the Government today against alleged "interference" in the parliamentary election campaign ending with balloting tomorrow.
BONN, Germany, June 8 Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and French High Commissioner Andre Francois-Poncet met today to prepare the ground for the final negotiation that may settle the Saar question.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 8 (UP) -- A Government expert on child care and welfare warned today that black market sale of babies was more widespread than commonly believed.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Special conditions under which aluminum scrap exports will be licensed were announced by the Department of Commerce today.

Nine thousand persons yesterday visited the Abbey Funeral Home, Sixty-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue, to see the body of 14-year-old Dorothy Westwater, victim of a brutal rape and assault. The body will be at the funeral home until a mass at 10 A. M. tomorrow.
BUENOS AIRES, June 8 -- Argentina's General Confederation of Labor accused the Communists today of having fomented the labor difficulties that are beginning to threaten the nation's economy.
MEXICO CITY, June 8 -- The beginning of an important shift in the Mexican Government's attitude toward the United States is becoming evident.
The autumn fur fashions are in the making, with the design leaders in this luxury field setting trends in their new collections, presented now, that will carry into the new year.

BOSTON, June 9 (UP) -- Jimmy Dykes, manager of the Baltimore Orioles, was suspended for three days today by the American League president, William Harridge, and also fined $50 as a result of his dispute with Ed Hurley, an umpire, in New York on Sunday.
BERLIN, June 8 -- Georg Dertinger, former East German Foreign Minister, has been sentenced to fifteen years at hard labor on charges of espionage.
BALBOA, June 8 -- After heavy rains last week-end instruments on Contractors Hill recorded slight widening of the fracture threatening a rockfall near the Panama Canal.

Refreshing, citrus-colored dresses and beach wear highlighted the Arnold Constable midsummer showing yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Soft golds, pale yellows and brilliant oranges were featured in cotton, silk and organdy dresses.

The six-story apartment house at 1229 Franklin Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by Leo Bercow and Walter Berger to an investing client of Marvin Hillman, lawyer. It is assessed at $220,000. Title insurance was furnished by the Metropolitan Tile Guaranty Company.

PALERMO, Italy, June 8 -- The struggle between communism and democracy is gradually approaching a climax in Sicily, where crucial elections are to be held next year. The Christian Democrats are widely expected to win, but all signs point to gains for the Communists.

In the early days of the current McCarthy hearings much ado was made over the necessity of getting "yes" or "no" answers from Secretary Stevens. In the latter days we have noticed an obvious difficulty on the part of Army counsel and others in getting "yes" or "no" answers from Roy M. Cohn.
CHICAGO, June 9 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies defeated the Chicago Cubs, 4 -- 0 and 14 -- 6, in a double-header at Wrigley Field today.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 9 -- San Francisco voters have authorized the consolidation and modernization of part of the city's embattled cable car system.
New York was designated by the American Automobile Association yesterday as safest for pedestrians, including jaywalkers, of the larger cities in this country.
Having gained in monetary and trade strength, Austria will soon be ready to begin a gradual easing of restrictions on dollar imports, a business leader of that country asserted yesterday.
With her backers applying body-English in the final yards, Meyer J. Kaplan's Sunshine Nell held on for a by-a-nose decision in the $33,850 Top Flight Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.
BOSTON, June 9 (AP) -- Textron, Inc., which seeks control of the American Woolen Company, won a round today in its legal battle with American Woolen management.
BARTOW, Fla., June 9 (UP) -- A well-known lawyer accused of scheming to get rich by murdering three wealthy and prominent persons killed himself today.
GENEVA, June 9 -- The effort to keep Soviet "worker" and "employer" delegates out off the International Labor Organization broadened today.

I should like to make known to your readers the opportunity for furthering an extremely worthwhile cause that cries for solution in this city. I refer to the transportation of home-bound physically handicapped people.

CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- Producers unloaded 10,000 salable hogs on the livestock market today, 2.000 more than expected. and prices fell 25 to 50 cents on both butchers and sows. Some heavyweight sows lost 75 cents.

TRENTON, June 9 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner today took to task the Regional Plan Association and other New York groups that insist the New York Thruway and the New Jersey Turnpike must be directly linked.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- The candy industry will encourage production of cocoa beans in Latin America and elsewhere to offset a shortage of output from such old producing areas as British West Africa, Brazil, Nigeria and Ceylon, Robert Schnering, president of Curtiss Candy Company, said today.

District Attorney T. Vincent Quinn of Queens said yesterday that John Roche, held in the slaying of 14-year-old Dorothy Westwater, had confessed to a killing for which another man was convicted but added that the confession was "without any basis in fact."
ROME, June 9 -- The Chamber of Deputies repealed tonight Italy's controversial "bonus seat" electoral law. The vote was 427 to 75, a result greeted by cheers from the Communist benches.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy began his own testimony in the Army- McCarthy hearings today with a discussion of how communism had declined in the United States but gained abroad since he began his own anti-Communist crusade on Feb. 9, 1950.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP) -- President Eisenhower today named Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson to direct and supervise the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation.
A dazzling floral display of hundreds of potted and cut flowers and plants gave pause yesterday to pedestrians and motorists at Fifth Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

Three Government witnesses testified yesterday about technical details of the alleged income tax evasion by Joseph D. Nuan, former United States Commissioner of Internal Revenue. He went on trial Tuesday in Brooklyn Federal Court.
Thanks to a last-hour rally led by the rails, yesterday's stock market ended a seesaw day with only a moderate loss.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- Irregular price trends marked grain trading today, but it was noticeable that wheat buying broadened on moderate setbacks and in the late trade there was a strong tone. There is little hedging against new wheat crop offerings as yet.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Democrats have decided to avoid a test in the Senate Finance Committee on their proposal for higher personal income exemptions.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 9 -- Degrees were presented to 1,410 students here this evening in the 188th anniversary commencement of Rutgers University. Dr. Lewis Webster Jones, president of the state university, urged the graduating class to go forth and help the nation regain the initiative in world affairs.

COLUMBIA, S. C., June 9 (AP) -- George Bell Timmerman Jr., winner of yesterday's Democratic primary race for Governor of South Carolina, will be the first man in 169 years elected to that office while serving as Lieutenant Governor.
PARIS, June 8 -- The replacement of the two chief editors of the French News Agency was greeted today in some newspapers as an example of Government interference with the workings of a free press.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 9 -- Prime Minister F. Malan modified today his proposals for taking the 38,000 colored voters off the white register, containing 1,600,000 names.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Ninety-four unions signed a cease-fire contract today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 9 -- United Nations staff members plan to build a $7,000, 000 international community -- homes, schools and playgrounds -- overlooking the Hudson River in Westchester County.
Cornell University Medical College graduated eighty-three doctors of medicine at exercises at the New York Academy of Medicine yesterday.
TOKYO, June 9 -- The Japanese House of Representatives voted tonight to start disciplinary action against forty-six Socialist members charged with precipitating last week's riot on the chamber floor.
A major manufacturer of electronic devices and a leading drug wholesaler are stepping in to ease financial troubles of stores that sell their products to the man in the street.
Dr. Carter Davidson, president of Union College, called yesterday for the fashioning of a different kind of hydrogen bomb for American life -- "an H-bomb of character."

LONDON, June 9 (Reuters) -- The British grain journal, Corn Trade News, predicted today the Washington wheat price cut would prove to be a preliminary to further reductions in the 1954-55 season, during which, it prophesied, the United States would slash to the minimum price under the International Wheat Agreement and demand that importing countries purchase their full quotas.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Apparently confident of support by a majority of the other American republics, the United States is prepared to call for a meeting soon of the American Foreign Ministers on the Guatemalan situation.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 2, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 9 -- Belgium sent a note to the Soviet Union today, demanding punishment of the fighter pilot who attacked a DC-3 commercial transport of the Sabena Airlines in a Soviet MIG-15 last Thursday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 9 -- The names of many actors have been mentioned in connection with the movie version of "Oklahoma."
Further proof that the City Center has a solid hit in "Carouel" was given yesterday as five more weeks were added to the musical's engagement, marking is second extension in as many ways.
LONDON, June 9 -- Two more British organizations joined today the growing list of those who have gone on record as opposed to the rearmament of west Germany.
BOSTON, June 9 (UP) -- Sammy White's ninth-inning triple, his third hit of the day, scored Jackie Jensen from first base to give the Boston Red Sox a 7-6 victory over the Baltimore Orioles today.
LOS ALA/VIOS, N. NL, June 9 (;P)--A petition from 282 Los A]amos atomic scientists today strongly criticized Government handling of the case of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer.

LONDON, June 9 -- The slump on Wall Street yesterday made for caution on the stock markets here today. Prices were lowered in all markets except Government funds and business failed to show the expansion expected at the start of a new bookkeeping account.
Time passes pretty slowly when you're a wounded G. I. in a military hospital, far from home. Nothing much to do but lie there fighting pain and worrying about your family and your future.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 9 -- Frank Strafaci of the Garden City Country Club fired a five-over-par 72, 73 -- 145 to win the William Rice Hochster Memorial invitation tournament at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- When the nine black-robed brethren of the Supreme Court disagree among themselves on the meaning and application of the law, the dissents from the majority ruling are often so vigorous the layman is forcibly reminded that the standards of judgment remain as un-stabilized as if the library shelves were not groaning with tons of legal precedents.

When Joseph N. Welch, the Army's special counsel, suggested yesterday that Roy M. Cohn should have told the Secretary of the Army, "sic 'em Stevens," he was using a time-honored American colloquialism heretofore reserved for dogs and constables.
Operations of the Celotex Corporation in the six months ended on April 30 resulted in a net income of $1,018,492, against $1,155,195 earned in the corresponding period of the previous year.

Soon now they will be home for the summer, those children -- all summer, which can get to be a pretty long time. They have been looking forward to their day of release, when the school doors will be shut tight and locked. And it is good to know that for a whole summer one will be free of the nervous strain that homework involves.

City-dwellers may find the coming week the most advantageous of the year to buy strawberries, which rank tenth in the amount among fruits we eat. The Long Island harvest is expected to reach its peak next Monday and Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Mrs. Mildred Blauvelt of the New York City Police Department, told here today how she twice joined the Communist party in line of duty.
OTTAWA, June 9 (Canadian Press) -- The Opposition leader, George Drew, said today he did not want to see United States security methods adopted in Canada in any form.

Awards in a city-wide poetry contest for junior high school pupils were presented to five winners yesterday by Elias Lieberman, Associate Superintendent of Schools, at the Board of Education's headquarters, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.
ALBANY, June 9 -- Following is the text of Governor Dewey's special message to the Legislature on the Long Island Rail Road plan to be read at the start of the special session tomorrow:
MONTREAL, June 9 -- One of the world's foremost brain surgeons described here tonight how a patient whose brain has been stimulated by an electrical impulse may "relive" long-forgotten experiences.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 9 -- Dr. Oswaldo Aranha assumed charge today of the Ministry of Agriculture in addition to the Finance Ministry.

OMAHA, Neb., June 9 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dulles said tonight that "whatever we do in Indochina should be done in pursuance of moral principles which are clear and justified * * * and which the American people understand."

Mayor Wagner said yesterday that his administration would vigorously oppose adoption of the Long Island Transit Authority's plan for rehabiliation of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road. The bill implementing the plan will be considered at the special session of the Legislature convening today in Albany.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The swansong of American music "as a cultural art" was the theme of a New York witness testifying today for Federal subsidy of the fine arts.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Army-McCarthy hearings reached a dramatic high point today in an angry, emotion-packed exchange between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and Joseph N. Welch, special counsel for the Army.

Former State Senator Frank D. O'Connor sent a registered letter late yesterday to James A. Roe, Queens Democratic leader, demanding that Mr. Roe turn over to him all money, property and records of the Queens County Democratic organization.
PARIS, Thursday, June 10 -- After an adverse vote affecting the Government's policy on Indochina, Premier Joseph Laniel asked the French National Assembly early today for a vote of confidence.

The Middle South Utilities, Inc., which has been doing a gross business of $127,000,000 a year, will better this by 8 or 9 per cent in 1954, Edgar H. Dixon, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday. The utility system operates in major parts of Arkansas, Louisiana and Mississippi.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 9 -- Nearly 100 newspaper publishers from sixty countries heard Premier Tage Erlander of Sweden, opening their convention here today, praise freedom of the press as essential to the functioning of democracy.

Snapping back from the humiliation of a two-hit shut-out the night before, the Yankees trounced the Tigers, 5 -- 1, before 8,788 paying spectators at the Stadium yesterday. Yogi Berra, Tom Morgan, Eddie Robinson and Bobby Brown shared honors in the Bomber triumph.

RUTHERFORD, N. J., June 9 -- The current thrust for power of the legislative over the executive branch of the Federal Government is alarming, Dr. Ralph A. Burns, head of the Education Department of Dartmouth College, told the 408 graduates of Fairleigh Dickinson College here tonight.

The Elmwood Hotel, a 115-room building at 108-14 West Forty-ninth Street, has been leased for twenty-one years by Belleclaire Associates, Inc., to Martin Hotel, Inc., which has purchased the hotel business there from Marx J. Carsen. Louis Schlesinger was the attorney for the owner of the property.

LOS ANGELES, June 9 -- James Roosevelt, whose marital difficulties have provided an unusual issue in California's 1954 political campaign, will have to campaign against Theodore R. Owings, City Clerk of suburban Culver City, for the Twenty-sixth District seat in the House of Representatives.
LONDON, June 9 (AP) -- Maureen Connolly of the United States and Helen Fletcher of Great Britain will open the twenty-sixth Wightman Cup tennis matches Friday at Wimbledon.
The main charges in the Army - McCarthy controversy now before a Senate investigating subcommittee are:

Counterproposals by Atlantic and Gulf Coast ship operators in answer to demands for longer vacations, increased pension and welfare payments and other benefits, were turned down as inadequate yesterday by the National Maritime Union, C. I. O.

An increase last week of 849,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 173,704,000 barrels, compared with 172,855,000 a week earlier and 151,045,000 a year ago.

Because of "cold war" pressure the people of this country are in danger of becoming "the world's oremost worrywarts -- a nation of fussbudgets." This opinion was expressed yesterday by Eric Johnson, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, Inc.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 9 -- Gen. Paul Ely was reported today to be planning to return to Paris in about a week after having taken another look at the military situation in Tonkin.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Department of Justice announced today that a large round-up of "wetbacks" would begin June 17 along the Mexican border.

The State Education Commissioner has denied Nat Holman's request that the Board of Higher Education be directed to furnish a complete transcript of stenographic notes taken at a board meeting on March 3. It was at that meeting that the board ordered Mr. Holman, suspended City College basketball coach, to retire or be dismissed.

GENEVA, June 9 -- The United States is going ahead with its plan to end the Korean phase of the conference here on Far Eastern affairs as soon as possible. However, one official said the Korean talks could not just be "chopped off abruptly."
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Thursday, June 10 -- The parties leaning toward a policy of continued cooperation with the West kept a firm hold on power in the election of Iraq's new Parliament yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Republican and Democratic leaders of the House of Representatives agreed today to postpone until next year a showdown on President Eisenhower's proposals for a liberal world trade program for this country.

A plea for more originality in design was made yesterday by a group of art experts judging the fifth Young Americans Competitive Exhibition. Praising the show as the best to date, the jury was nonetheless critical of the emphasis placed on techniques and skills rather than individual creative design sense.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Plans for a National Conference on Moral and Spiritual Recovery, to be sponsored by prominent United States educators and religious leaders, were announced here today.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Paragraphs lifted from the full context of three papal encyclicals were quoted at the Capitol today to demonstrate that such tactics, used largely in Congressional investigations, could be misleading and unfair.
MILWAUKEE, June 9 -- The Giants stormed into a tie for first place in the National League flag race tonight as, behind the superb pitching of Johnny Antonelli, they brought down the Braves, 4 to 0.

President Eisenhower, in a message to the American Jewish Congress, has sharply condemned the imprisonment of Jewish leaders in Rumania. The President asserted that "the Jewish leaders have been imprisoned not because they have violated any law, but simply because of their religion."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 9 -- The New Jersey College for Women conferred baccalaureate degrees today on 244 seniors at the thirty-third commencement exercises of the women's college of Rutgers University.

ALTHOUGH John Steinbeck is increasingly eminent, he shows no signs whatever of becoming appropriately stuffy. The pomposities of prestige arouse in him a genial hilarity. He apparently allots little time to brooding over where his books will rank in literature. He made his mark, once for all, with "The Grapes of Wrath," and anything he has had to tell us since then has been bounty.

The State of Florida has decided against selling to investment bankers all but $1,822,000 of $30,571,000 of bonds put up for sale Tuesday to finance school building construction in twenty-eight counties.

Despite the popular ground swell in France in favor of the European Defense Community, the Foreign Affairs Committee of the French National Assembly has approved a report urging rejection of this plan, which is the key both to American policy in Europe and to all further European unification.
Two hours of monkeyshines threw part of the Flatbush section of Brooklyn into an uproar yesterday afternoon.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., June 9 (AP) -- Mrs. Mae Murray Jones of Rutland, Vt., turned in her second successive sub-par round today as she took a commanding thirteen-stroke lead at the two-thirds mark in the Eastern women's golf tournament over the Wethersfield Country Club course.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- President Eisenhower will go to the country by radio and television tomorrow night to plead for support of his legislative program.
A college, free from "outside interference," providing a place for free inquiry and discussion was asked yesterday by Dr. Buell Gallagher, president of City College.

The case of Dr. $. Robert Op- penheimer was cited last night by Dr. Edwin S. Burdell, president of Cooper Union, as an example of why technicians should have knowledge of the humanities and social sciences.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 9 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that failure of the Geneva Conference would probably lead to a review of the whole Far Eastern situation at the United Nations.
RYE, N. Y., June 9 -- The first section of the field in the United States Seniors Golf Association championships ended play tonight, with Joseph M. Wells of Newall, W. Va., the leader.
ALBANY, June 9 -- Governor Dewey's program for rehabilitating the Long Island Rail Road became a major political issue tonight on the eve of a special legislative session to write it into law.
Dave Beck, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., moved yesterday to end his two-year-old feud with Martin T. Lacey, the union's most powerful leader in this city.

The suit of Arnold Bernstein for the return of shipping assets signed over by him in 1937 while in a German prison, developed testimony yesterday dealing with pressures and "advice" given him on the ship transfer.

The Paramount Theatre, which will house the "Voice of Firestone" program beginning June 21, will also be the originating point for two WABC radio programs. The latter two, however, will not curtail the Paramount's movie show.

GENEVA, June 9 -- Not much information has come out of the secret military talks that have been going on here for a week between French and Vietnamese representatives on one side and Vietminh delegates on the other.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Vic Wertz broke up Bob Porterfield's bid for a no-hitter with a single with one out in the seventh inning and scored on Dave Philley's single and an error by Eddie Yost at third tonight as the Cleveland Indians downed the Washington Senators, 1 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP) -- The woman leader of four Puerto Ricans shouted "No! No! No!" today at a defense suggestion that they might have been mentally unsound when they shot five Representatives in Congress on the House floor March 1.
The President this week asked Congress for funds to aid our ailing Merchant Marine.

The story of the man who attacked a can of aerosol-packed instant shaving cream with a can opener, and found himself knee-deep in foam, crops up now and then, but no one has ever met such a victim. The product, in one form or another, produced by various makers, seems to have caught on, despite imagined peril, making such shaving aids standard items instead of novelties.

A request asking the Federal Trade Commission to halt use by Technicolor Motion Pictures Corporation of the word "technicolor" for films made by the Eastman color process has been filed by Pathe Laboratories, Inc., the independent film processing laboratory.

Louis J. Glickman and Jack Weiler, sponsors of a seventeen-story and penthouse cooperative apartment building going up at 936 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of East Seventy-fifth Street, have obtained a building and permanent loan of $900,000 from the East River Savings Bank.

ALBANY, June 9 -- The Court of Appeals has upheld unanimously the right of the board of managers of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals to ignore a resolution adopted by a majority of the society's members present at its annual meeting.
After a fortnight of inconclusive drifting, the corporate bond market got a lift yesterday from the successful marketing of $100,000,000 Aluminum Company of America debentures.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Americans reached for fewer cigarettes in the last year.

The Citizens Union criticized yesterday the appointment of three Assembly district leaders and a former vice chairman of the Tammany executive committee to "confidential" positions in the Supreme Court, First Judicial District.

The Greenbriar, a seven-story apartment house at 68-61 Yellowstone Boulevard in the block-front from Sixty-eighth to Sixty-ninth Avenues, Forest Hills, Queens, has been sold by the builders to a syndicate of investors represented by Benjamin Duhl, attorney.

Election of a Democratic Governor and other state officers and a gain of at least five Democratic Representatives from this state in the Nov. 4 election was predicted yesterday at a luncheon conference in the Savoy-Plaza Hotel.
New Yorkers will be asked to open their homes this fall to United Nations representatives from other lands.
BONN, Germany, June 9 -- A group of West German business men delegated to explore trade relations with the Soviet Union has put off its departure for Moscow for "technical reasons."
The White Motor Company expects to win a larger share of the heavy truck market this year and to maintain profits at about the 1953 level, Robert F. Black, president, reported yesterday.

Mayor Wagner asserted last night that recent newspaper stories had overemphasized the problem of juvenile delinquency and vandalism and had given the impression that the problem was more widespread than it actually was.

A bill that would require most American deep - sea merchant ships to carry a device that automatically would alert radio officers when the vessels were being paged by other stations has been reported favorably to the House of Representatives.
MIAMI, June 9 (AP) -- A new radar set for airplanes, to help the pilot peer into the weather up to 150 miles ahead, was demonstrated for the first time publicly today.
I have just read your editorial, "The Oppenheimer Dilemma." It seems to me that the same "lack of candor" ascribed to Oppenheimer applies to you.
WESTBURY, L. I., June 9 (AP) -- Bay State Tom won the $3,500 Freeport pace by a head in 2:05 1/5 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

In statements issued almost at the same time on Tuesday the President's chief economic adviser, Dr. Arthur F. Burns, and C. I. O. President Walter P. Reuther issued sharply opposed evaluations of the economic situation. Dr. Burns thinks that the natural forces within our economy making for recovery, particularly inventory depletion, should bring about an upturn that will soon be visible, presumably without any extraordinary Government action.

LONDON, June 9 -- The British Government was reported today to be fully prepared to join the United States in beginning organization of the proposed system for collective defense in Southeast Asia at the close of the Geneva conference.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 9 -- An impartial fact-gathering service to provide information on problems arising from the United States Supreme Court decision outlawing segregation in public schools will begin operation here July 1.

CAIRO, June 9 -- Kamal el-Malakh, young Egyptologist who discovered the solar boats of Pharaoh Cheops, has been forbidden to write on archaeological subjects, including his own discovery, according to a high administrative official.
OTTAWA, June 9 (Canadian Press) -- Canada will make another cut in wheat prices if a further reduction is needed to maintain world sales, Trade Minister C. D. Howe said tonight.

In connection with the continued wrangle over Trieste -- a dispute in which the bulk of the people of Yugoslavia have no voice -- we should recall the provision in the Yalta Agreement calling for free election in Yugoslavia.

MIAMI BEACH, June 9 (UP) -- Billy Kilgore, a Miami middleweight, departed from his standard defensive tactics and blazed away with a two-fisted attack tonight to score a technical knockout over Ernie Durando of Bayonne, N. J., after nine rounds of a nationally televised bout at the Auditorium.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Legislation aimed at giving the Export-Import Bank a freere hand in making long-term loans to foreign countries will be introduced in the Senate tomorrow.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was a little more active yesterday than during previous sessions this week. Prices closed unchanged to 11 points lower than on Tuesday.
ST. LOUIS, June 9 -- Harvey Haddix tonight became the first southpaw to beat the Dodgers this year when he pitched a three-hitter to give the Cardinals a 3 -- 0 triumph before 19,383 fans.

LONDON, June 9 -- The British Government threw cold water today on reports from Egypt that India had proposed an Indian-Egyptian-British commission to help speed the evacuation of Britain's 80,000 troops from the Suez Canal Zone.

GENEVA, June 9 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the statements made today by Chou En-lai, Premier and Foreign Minister of Communist China, and Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, United States Under Secretary of State, at the conference on Far Eastern affairs:

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 9 -- Mrs. Bernard Freeman of Inwood, with a 38, 40 -- 78, captured the low gross prize at the Women's Long Island Golf Association's one-day tournament at the Nassau Country Club today. Miss Mackie lost the blind draw to Mrs. Freeman by taking a three-over-par 7 at the seventeenth.
MEXICO CITY, June 9 -- Mexico's biggest and most powerful labor organization today ordered a general strike of its 2,000,000 members to begin July 12.
LONDON, June 9 -- Somerset Maugham, British author now in his eightieth year, was made a Companion of Honor today in Queen Elizabeth's birthday honors list.

CINCINNATI, June 9 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs hit four home runs tonight to beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4 -- 3. Gus Bell got two of the homers and Jim Greengrass' circuit blow in the ninth broke a 3-3 time.
CLEVELAND, June 9 (AP) -- The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen has served wage demands on more than 300 roads, but it probably will be months before any action is taken.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- For the eighth consecutive year, the Population Reference Bureau reported today a rising rate of children among college graduates.
