A reading audience "to win an editor's respect" was described yesterday by a group of people who, for the last quarter century, have been looking over the shoulders of children at the books they read.
The office of the city's Chief Medical Examiner was put under inquiry yesterday by City Administrator Luther H. Gulick.
Deputy Under Secretary of State Robert D. Murphy offered graduates at Fordham University's 109th commencement yesterday a brief outline of United States foreign policy.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 9 (UP) -- A United States prosecutor called today for Congressional investigation of what he termed an attempt to "ring down a curtain of silence" on the axe-and-torch murders of three American officers.

New issues of corporate securities valued at more than $17,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The securities are debentures and common stock of public utility enterprises and common stock of a manufacturer of machine tools.

Clifton B. Cates, who retires from his command at Quantico on June 30 after thirty-seven years' service, took part as a regimental commander in the initial assault on Guadalcanal in the Second World War. As commander of the Fourth Marine Division he led the assaults on Tinian and bloody Iwo Jima.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 9 (AP) -- Dr. Wendell Ames of Buffalo today was elected president of the New York State Public Health Association.
The decline in the city's tuberculosis death rate is continuing this year. In the twenty-two weeks ended June 4, it was 12 per cent below the rate for the same period last year.
Eric W. Peterson has been named director of manufacturing of the American Safety Razor Corporation.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 9 -- Strong evidence for the inheritance of acquired characteristics was reported here today. This is the Russian concept of genetics that has long been pooh-poohed by Western scientists.
SEVEN managers in the American League already have gone on record as saying that the most surprising team this season has been Detroit. Freddie Hutchinson joined them yesterday and made it unanimous.

"American Thought: A Critical Sketch," a book on which the late Morris R. Cohen, the philosopher and educator, worked for twenty years, will be issued June 17 by the Free Press of Glencoe, Ill. It is a history of reflective thought in America.

The characteristic diversion created by Senator McCarthy in his attack on Senator Symington has had at least one fortunate result. It has elicited from Mr. McCarthy, for the first time so far as we are aware, a positive and explicit commitment to answer under oath questions arising from the Senatorial investigation into his affairs that took place in 1952.
A vocational high school teacher was arrested yesterday because two schoolboys had declared that he had solicited them to steal an automobile for him in return for passing grades.

LONDON, June 9 -- A sharp attack on the Archbishop of Canterbury for his views on divorce appeared today in Crockford's Clerical Directory, a book that many Church of England clergymen find indispensable for reference.

BUENOS AIRES, June 9 -- The police arrested today at least twenty persons labeled as Communists as members of the Metal Workers Union returned to work and re-established some tran-quillity on the nation's labor front.
A sculpture of an eagle in rich, black Belgian marble by the late Bessie Stough Callender is on exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in the galleries of American contemporary art.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- Any automobile dealer who buys more cars than he can sell is doing a disservice to himself as well as the country's economy, Frederick J. Bell, executive vice president of the National Automobile Dealers Association, asserted today.

Tuesday's stock market decline influenced trading on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday and future prices closed irregularly lower. Coffee, potatoes, hides, burlap, wool, silk and zinc were off.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- Railroads no longer constitute a monopoly in land transportation, but they are being regulated as though they did, N. R. Crump, executive vice president of the Canadian Pacific Railway, said today.

BUENOS AIRES, June 9 -- President Juan D. Peron's plans for a million-ton steel industry and a flood of new investments appeared today to be on the point of realization. The nation's top economic chiefs started putting the finishing touches to an agreement whereby a private Peruvian company and German interest will finance Argentina's ambitions to the extent of $125,000,000.
A "well-organized ambulance- chasing ring" was reported to have been smashed yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

MONTREAL, June 9 -- Live entertainment may end in night clubs and theatres across Canada this summer unless a dispute between two unions is solved. An American Guild of Variety Artists convention here has grappled this week with its quarrel with the Canadian Musicians Union but has failed to make headway.

BECKENHAM, England, June 9 (UP) -- Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., gained the third round in the men's singles today at the Kent lawn tennis championships by defeating Peter Molloy of Australia, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1, in a drizzling rain.
THOUSANDS of New York anglers will make a rapid switch from trout to bass next Wednesday, when the season on largemouths and smallmouths opens on Lake Erie, Lake Ontario and the St. Lawrence River.

Like many others I am deeply disturbed by the majority findings of the board in the Oppenheimer case. They come to the clear conclusion that Dr. Oppenheimer is a loyal citizen, with "a high degree of discretion reflecting an unusual ability to keep to himself vital secrets."
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy appeared today to have resolved the conflict over "one-man rule" of the Atomic Energy Commission.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Divided opinions as to a policy of port dockage charges were expressed today at a meeting of the North Atlantic Ports Association.
MELBOURNE, Australia, June 9 -- The Australian Wheat Board met today to consider the situation arising from the Canadian wheat price reduction.
BOSTON, June 9 -- So far as his law firm associates are concerned, Frederick G. Fisher Jr. is a "good lawyer" and a man of unquestioned integrity.

A derailment and small fire on a car of a Culver Line B. M. T. train entering the Stillwell Avenue Terminal, Coney Island, disrupted service yesterday morning on a small portion of that line for most of the day.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., June 9 (AP) -- The West Virginia Board of Education threw open the doors of nine state colleges today to all qualified students, white or Negro.
BOGOTA, Colombia, June 9 (UP) -- Fifteen persons were reported killed and more than twenty others wounded in two days of clashes between Army troops and university students.
MILWAUKEE, June 9 -- Paul Giel, all-America football star of the University of Minnesota and regarded as perhaps an even greater prospect as a right-handed pitcher, today was signed by the Giants.
Weber Heilbroner will open the largest store in its ten-store chain today at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in its thirtieth day of hearings on the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph P. McCarthy
A suggested policy guide for the temporary conduct of the city's labor relation was submitted to Mayor Wagner yesterday by the city's Department of Labor.
SEOUL, Korea, June 9 -- President Syngman Rhee's Liberal party demonstrated today its power to dominate the South Korean National Assembly.

Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams warned yesterday that the threat of a transit strike Monday at 12:01 A. M. had confronted the city with "a grave situation." As head of a special committee named by Mayor Wagner to deal with the crisis, Commissioner Adams listed eleven "essential" city and privately operated services that would be maintained above all others if a crippling walkout should occur.

Television's influence is revising the family dinner. Aside from the sandwiches and beer on which some husbands have been supping because Washington hearings make it difficult for their wives to do the customary cooking, many new products of the "heat 'n' eat" type are making their appearance.

BARABOO, Wis., June 9 (UP) -- District Attorney Harlan Kelley said today he had subpoenaed the "Joe Must Go" recall petitions because he wanted to find out what Leroy Gore, Sauk City editor "is trying to hide."

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP) -- The assistant House Democratic leader, Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts, urged President Eisenhower today to invite Asian leaders tot a conference at which the United States would sign a "Charter of Freedom" for all the people of Asia.

Union and management leaders of the city's private bus industry joined yesterday in tributes to Theodore W. Kheel, the Industry's impartial chairman, on his completion of five years in office. Both sides praised him for promoting more harmonious labor relations among the nine privately-owned transit lines.
QUEBEC, June 9 (AP) -- United States savings associations need more trained employes to take over executive positions, a bank official said today.
PHILADELPHIA, June 9 (UP) -- Three streaks were continued tonight as the Chicago White Sox rolled to a 9-4 victory over the Philadelphia Athletics with three homers featuring their attack.
The increased capacity of the paperboard industry will be in full use in the next year or eighteen months, according to G.J. Ticoulat, a vice president of Crown-Zellerbach Corporation.
LONDON, June 9 -- The cuts in the export price of wheat by the United States and Canada have brought dealings in the commodity virtually to a standstill on the grain markets in Britain.

PARIS, June 9 -- The Foreign Affairs Committee of the National Assembly rejected the European Defense Community treaty today, 24 to 18, with 2 absentions. Six Socialists, defying their party's directives, voted with the majority.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Two committees of the Independent Petroleum Association of America agreed at a meeting here that Congress should be asked to reduce oil imports from more than 1,000,000 barerls a day to about 800,000.
Mayor Wagner sent three fiscal bills to Albany yesterday in the forlorn hope that their passage would be recommended by Governor Dewey to the convening special session of the Legislature.

The Regional Red Cross blood program received 626 pints of blood Tuesday. Of this total, 148 pints were donated at the General Electric Company, 570 Lexington Avenue, and 101 at Consolidated Edison Company, 4 Irving Place.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 9 -- California voters have charted a political revolution. They did so at yesterday's primary election with the help of two words, abbreviated on most major party ballots throughout the state to "Rep." and "Dem."

GENEVA, June 9 -- The United States declared today that the Communists had shown no signs of willingness to resolve the three important issues now before the conference here on Far Eastern affairs on any acceptable basis.

Ralph R. McCoy, who started as an Esso service station employe at Washington in 1928, yesterday was appointed assistant marketing coordinator of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey). The appointment brings Mr. McCoy to New York from Hamburg, Germany, where he has served since 1951 as shareholders' representative for Germany, Switzerland and Austria.
Larry Evans, United States chess champion, last night defeated James T. Sherwin in fifty-one moves in the eleventh round of the national tournament at the Marshall Chess Club.

Flexible furniture that can be arranged to suit the individual's needs is the outstanding feature of a new collection introduced yesterday by Jens Risom, 49 East Fifty-third Street, where the designs are available through decorators. Both upholstered pieces and cabinets are in the group.

It is seven years since General Marshall, taking up and amplifying a suggestion previously made by former Secretary of State Dean Acheson, proposed the plan for European recovery that came to be known by his name. It was a four-year plan. The four years that passed after it was put in operation in 1948 did not end it, but they did produce a change in its nature.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Admiral Arthur V. Radford, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that the Administration's foreign military assistance program was "of great importance to national security."

Ever since the Eisenhower Administration took office Secretary Dulles has been saying that unless France and Italy ratified the European Defense Community Treaty the United States would have to undertake an "agonizing reappraisal" of its European policy.

HANOI, Vietnam, June 10 (AP) -- Vietminh rebel troops infiltrating the Red River Delta forced the French today to abandon a post only thirty miles from Hanoi. The Reds also overwhelmed a Vietnamese strong point in the Phatdiem sector and attacked a string of other Vietnamese posts.
One hundred and fifty members of the Concrete Industry Board had luncheon yesterday 28 feet below the surface of the Hudson River in perfect dryness, cleanliness and safety.
The printing and dyeing industry has turned to the Federal Government for help in overcoming what it calls a depression in the trade.
CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The Transit Authority agreed yesterday to resume formal efforts today to resolve its dispute with the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., amid rising optimism that a transit strike would be averted.

Trading on most New York commodity futures markets was featureless yesterday. Price movements were irregular, with coffee, sugar, cocoa, potatoes, burlap, zinc and copper ending lower; cottonseed oil mixed, and rubber, hides, silk, wool, lead, tin and soybean oil higher.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Saturday (including Memorial Day) totaled 612,315 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 76,977 cars or 11.2 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 163,174 cars or 21 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 71,932 cars or 10.5 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
The Nicholas Murray Butler Medal in silver for 1954 was awarded yesterday to Ernest Nagel, Professor of Philosophy at Columbia University, by Dr. Grayson Kirk, the university's president.

CARSHALTON, England, June 10 (AP) -- An irate committee arranging a week-end carnival parade barred local Communists from the festivities last night after Red objections had caused withdrawal of United States Air Force units.

GALVESTON, Tex., June 10 (AP) -- A New York grain shipping concern and the former general manager of the Galveston wharves were indicted today on charges of conspiracy to defraud the Federal Government in shipping about half million bushels of Canadian grain.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The problem of creating community life was called the challenge of our times today by the Educational Policies Commission of the National Education Association.
Atlantic and Gulf Coast ship operators and the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., were still far apart on terms of a new contract yesterday with the old agreement expiring in five days.
MOTOR car traffic quickened in Eighth Avenue when the street converted to one-way northbound flow the other day, but horse riders find, paradoxically, that it has cut their pace appreciably.

MONTREAL, June 10--A Chinese scientist who has educated a ferocious alley cat to live in harmony with a rat wondered today if something smiliar could not be accomplished among human beings armed with atomic bombs.
Westchester County, which now has no private adoption agency, will open its first service of this kind in the fall.

The Maritime Administration announced yesterday the awarding of a contract for $6,497,150 to the Bethlehem Pacific Coast Steel Corporation for the conversion of an uncompleted Mariner ship into an attack cargo ship.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 10 -- The Massachusetts Institute of Technology plans to begin the construction, within a year, of a nuclear reactor. The cost, to be privately financed, will be about $1,000,000.
It was cloudy overhead yesterday but it was all sunshine on the decks of the Hudson River excursion steamer Alexander Hamilton.

CLOSE after the silver jubilee exhibition last month that featured work by its alumni, Contemporary Arts now is holding a summer exhibition of paintings by current members. More than thirty artists are represented by one or more pictures each and no party line is drawn as to styles or subject matter.
ALBANY, June 10--Governor Dewey's Long Island Rail Road rehabilitation program was approved today at a special session of the Legislature despite united Democratic opposition.

Arnold Bernstein signed over his Red Star Line to a Nazi-dominated trustee in 1937 because he was convinced this was the only way to obtain his release from a German prison, he testified in Federal court yesterday.

CANANEA, Mexico, June 10 (AP) -- Anti-United States feeling, reported to be fanned by known Communist leaders in Mexico, burst into a riot yesterday in which a mob estimated at 3,000 persons forced the release of eight "land squatters" from jail.
Robert Moses, builder of many of New York's most modern highways and other facilities, pleaded with architects yesterday to "give us conservatives a break."

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 10 (UP)--More than 200 extremists, including top Communist party leaders, were seized today and charged with having incited army-student clashes in which fifteen persons were killed and more than forty wounded.
With their most substantial offensive display in a long time, the Yankees defeated the Tigers, 9 -- 5, before 7,058 paying spectators at the Stadium yesterday.

A Brooklyn boy's attempt to get help for two little girls with whom he was trapped in a stalled elevator cost him his life yesterday. Alan Applebaum, who would have been 8 years old today, fell four floors to his death.

RICHMOND, Va., June 10 -- Executive officials of twelve Southern states were reported to have reached agreement here today not to comply voluntarily with the Supreme Court's decision against racial segregation in the public schools.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 10 -- The engine of an Air Force F-84 jet exploded this morning while the plane was streaking over Yonkers at 3,500 feet.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) -- Raymond Blattenberger, head of the Government Printing Office, resfused today to give Congress decisions of the office's loyalty-security board on the grounds that this would violate Presidential secrecy orders.
ALBANY, June 10 -- Speculation that Governor Dewey would announce soon a desire to retire at the end of his current term was provoked today by a series of changes in State Parole Board membership.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) -- The Government Operations Committee of the House of Representatives broke a stalemate today by voting to set up a new subcommittee to continue a nation- wide investigation of alleged labor union racketeering.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse as required by White House rules:

Dorothy Westwater, 14-year- old victim of a brutal beating and rape on June 2, was buried at Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, Queens, yesterday after a funeral mass at the Church of St. Catherine of Siena. Only relatives, friends, neighbors and schoolmates were allowed into the church at 407 East Sixty-eighth Street, but 5,000 persons, many of them weeping, crowded the street outside.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 10 -- The young pride of Old Eli -- the thirty-six sturdy undergraduate voices of the Yale Glee Club -- got off to a rafter-shaking start today on their European concert tour.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- As part of a new "integrated compliance program" the Federal Trade Commission has started a selective but systematic review of some 14,000 orders and trade practice rules in its files.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) -- Trips to a national park this summer will involve stiffer entrance fees.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today forecast this year's wheat production at about 1,000,000,000 bushels -- a crop large enough to require continuance of production controls next year.

The O. A. Sutton Corporation, Inc., Kansas, manufacturer of air-conditioning equipment, announced yesterday that it had registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed public offering of 400,000 shares of common stock.
GLYNDEBOURNE, England, June 10 -- The sixteenth season of the Glyndebourne Festival -- the famous "country house opera" -- opened today with a sparkling performance of "The Barber of Seville."
SEATTLE, June 10 -- Following is the text of an address by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles to the forty-fifth annual convention of Rotary International in Seattle.
J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., suffered a sharp setback in earnings for the quarter and six months ended May 1, reflecting depressed conditions in the textile industry.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The political sensitivity of butter kept the House Agriculture Committee today from proposing an increase in dairy price supports.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Four of the five members of the Atomic Energy Commission accepted today new language in proposed atomic law revisions that was designed to end a dispute over powers of the commission chairman.
The American Woolen Company, which is reopening mills in four New England states, is releasing to newspapers a full-page institutional advertisement in which it expresses confidence in the area.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) -- The Defense Department today urged Senate approval of legislation designed to make a military career more attractive by nearly doubling re-enlistment bonuses.

How inexpert can an "expert" be? The country now has one indication of the answer in Wednesday's demonstration by Thomas M. McNiece, associate research director of the House committee investigating foundations. He was the "expert" who was so unwary as to conclude that several unidentified quotations "paralleled very closely Communist ideals," only to learn that they were quotations from Papal encyclicals -- one of them a half century old.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, June 10 -- The International Court of Justice opened hearings today into the compensation awarded eleven dismissed United States employes of the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- James B. Carey, president of the C. I. O. electrical workers' union, charged today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had told "outright lies" at yesterday's hearing.

A 45.8 per cent decrease in migration from Puerto Rico in the first five months this year, as compared with the same period of 1953, was reported yesterday to the Mayor's Committee on Puerto Rican Affairs.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Senator Hickenlooper of Iowa has made a criticism of the American press which is noteworthy in two respects. One is that too frequently it is justified. The second is that it describes a basic human inconsistency, from which politicians also are not free, that seems to be increasingly revealed in a period which could be known as the era of bad feeling in Washington.
Premier Georgi M. Malenkov has regained photographic parity with Nikita S. Khruschev, Communist party secretary, the latest Moscow newspapers indicate.

PHOENIX, Ariz., June 10 (UP) -- A prominent 23-year-old Phoenix woman was kidnapped yesterday, driven for miles in the trunk of an automobile arid then returned to her husband today after payment of $75,000 ransom, the police said.
GENEVA, June 10 -- Anthony Eden warned today that the Indochina negotiations here might be broken off unless the Communists made possible an agreement "without further delay" on three major issues.
Prices of cotton on the New York Cotton Exchange were slightly easier yesterday, closing 6 to 11 points below Wednesday's levels.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 10 -- Twelve newspaper men in the United States have been appointed Nieman Fellows at Harvard University for the college year beginning in September.

Foreign Secretary Eden has urged at Geneva that the opposing parties make further effort to narrow the ground of their differences so that some possible solution for the impasse over Indochina may emerge. At the same time Mr. Eden has rejected the fraudulent Communist proposals and supported the position of the free world at the vital point of what constitutes a "possible" solution.
Following is the text of an address by President Eisenhower last night before the National Citizens For Eisenhower Congressional Committee, as recorded by The New York Times:

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Eisenhower sought support for his lagging legislative program in both major parties tonight. This program, he declared in a speech broadcast to the nation by radio and television, is essential to a free, strong, happy America.

VIRGINIA BEACH, June 10 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt thundered around the Cavalier Yacht and Country Club course today in a five-under-regulation 64 to gain a one-stroke advantage in the first round of the $15,000 Virginia Beach open golf tournament.

The Fourteenth Street store property owned and occupied by Ohrbach's for about thirty years has been purchased by Louis J. Glickman, nationally known real estate investor. The store specializing in women's and children's apparel will move next fall to the former McCreery Building on Thirty-fourth Street, opposite the Empire State Building.
OTTAWA, June 10 -- Minister of Trade and Commerce C. D. Howe said today that the future of world trade depended largely on whether or not the United States reduced tariffs in the coming year.
The Government has started proceedings to acquire by condemnation more than twenty-six acres of land in Westchester County near New York City's watershed and the Westchester County Airport.

The basic ideas determining the policy of the United States in the struggle against Communist imperialism were outlined anew by President Eisenhower and Secretary Dulles in their statements yesterday. These ideas are steadfast and consistent. They are rightly being repeated again and again, to enable truth to catch up with the Communist "big lie" and to dispel misunderstandings at home and abroad.

OMAHA, June 10 (AP) -- Emil Kammer pitched three-hit ball tonight as Missouri's Big Seven Conference champions gained a 5-3 victory over Lafayette in the final game of the opening day of the college world series staged by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Grain futures showed a reactionary trend in early trading today. Many longs, especially in wheat, were inclined to even up pending the June Federal crop report. Wheat had a partial recovery from the low spots, with July prices relatively firm as a result of limited selling of new crop wheat by growers in the southwest.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 10 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dulles warned Communist China tonight to keep hands off free world positions in the Western Pacific.

Residents along upper Fifth Avenue, who for years have been passing the seven grim doughboys of the old Seventh Infantry monument at Sixty-sixth Street with scarcely a glance, stopped yesterday to scrutinize them. Moved to make room for a new entrance to the road across Central Park at Sixty-sixth Street, the bronze soldiers with their bayoneted rifles were looming over the sidewalk from a low trailer at Sixty-seventh Street.
ALBANY, June 10 -- The Legislature moved today to speed construction of the St. Lawrence power project by the State Power Authority.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Rules Committee of the House of Representatives today handed a rebuff to the President on public housing.

Two buildings containing a total of seventy-six apartments at 774 and 784 Fox Street in the Bronx have been purchased by a syndicate headed by Sidney Frieberg for cash above mortgages amounting to $143,000.
Angelo Ferruso, 59-year-old porter, received some unusual advice from an unexpected source in Kings County Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 10--Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 18 per cent below those in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The State Department has ordered a review of the ruling that Prof. Paul Adrien Dirac, a British Nobel Prize winner in physics, is "inadmissable" to the United States.
The old International Longshoremen's Association decided yesterday to close its books to new members.

A United States scientist who spent sixteen days in the Soviet Union returned here yesterday. He is Dr. Jason J. Nassau, Professor of Astronomy at the Case Institute of Technology, Cleveland, and director of the Warner and Swasey Observatory at the institute.
The main charges in the Army-McCarthy controversy now before a Senate investigating subcommittee are:

OTTAWA, June 10 (Canadian Press) -- Stiffening world competition and declining exports may force Canada to carry over into the next crop year the biggest surplus of unsold wheat in history. The crop year begins Aug. 1.

PAR LAGERKVIST, the versatile and prolific Swedish writer who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1951, calls himself "a believer without faith -- a religious atheist." His paradoxical and enigmatic philosophy makes him both a provocative and a baffling writer. Sometimes he is as cryptic and as subject to personal interpretation as the oracle at Delphi.
WQXR, the radio station of The New York Times, has started work on new transmitting equipment that will increase its power from its present 10,000 watts to 50,000.

The nation's steel production amounted to 7,467,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings last month. This was the largest monthly output since January, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, worldwide manufacturing and communications concern, reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $4,855,103 in the first three months of this year. This was equal to 68 cents a share on the outstanding common stock, and compares with a consolidated net of $4,832,540, or 67 cents a share, in the March quarter a year ago.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 10 -- Iraq's new Parliament will represent a minor realignment of the conservative majority that has ruled the country since its inception, but no major change in direction.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 10 (UP) -- The Air Force launched its fearsome winged torpedo, the Matador, over the Atlantic today and reported it had hit a secret target at supersonic speed.

GENEVA, June 10 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the speeches of Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary; Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, and Pham Van Dong, Vietminh Foreign Minister, and the text of the speech of Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, United States Under Secretary of State, at the Far Eastern conference today:

FRENCH LICK, Ind., June 10 -- Steel consumption in the United States may reach 200 million tons a year within the next twenty-five years, Joseph L. Block, president of Inland Steel Company, said tonight at the annual conference of the Indiana Manufacturers Association. This would be twice the production of any year prior to 1951, he noted.

G. I.'s from every town and village in the country dream of visiting New York City. But Manhattan can be a bewildering and lonely place. To help make them feel at home here, the United Service Organizations has opened an information center just off Times Square at 132 West Forty-third Street.

" Unto a Good Land," a new novel by Vilhelm Moberg, several times winner of Sweden's Bonnier Prize, will be published July 27 by Simon Schuster. It is the story of sixteen emigrants, who 100 years ago left Sweden to come to America.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Gorilla at Large," a Twentieth Century-Fox melodrama in Technicolor made by Panoramic Productions, is at the Globe. Cameron Mitchell, Anne Bancroft and Lee J. Cobb are featured in the Leonard Goldstein presentation, which was directed by Harmon Jones from a script by Leonard Praskins and Barney Slater.

Suspensions at the Fort Monmouth (N. J.) Signal Corps center under the Eisenhower security risk program have mounted to thirty-six, with fourteen of the employes involved later reinstated. No case has resulted in a final dismissal.

BECKENHAM, England, June l0 (AP) -- Hugh Stewart of Los Angeles upset Gardnar Mulloy of Miami in the third round of the Kent lawn tennis championships today and Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., won two matches to join him in the fourth round.

LOS ANGELES, June 10 (UP) -- James Roosevelt's attorney announced today that the son of the late President and his estranged wife had reached an out-of-court settlement of their marital differences. Details of the settlement were not revealed.
TORONTO, June 10 (Canadian Press) -- Holders of common stock of Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., today approved plans for refunding the company's 7 1/2 per cent preferred stock.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 10 -- The motion picture industry will have paid out $9,000,000 to writers during the fiscal year ending next Sept. 30, according to a forecast published in the current issue of the Screen Writers Guild bulletin.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., June 10 (UP) -- Mrs. Mae Murray Jones of Rutland, Vt., shot a 77 today to capture the Eastern Golf Association championship with a women's course record of 221 for three rounds at the Wethersfield Country Club.

BOSTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles swept a double-header from the Boston Red Sox today. Duane Pillette shutout the Red Sox, 9 -- 0, with five hits in the second after Joe Coleman had held them to seven hits to win, 5 -- 1, in the first.
Tentative support crept into an inactive stock market yesterday and produced good gains.
The fourth June grand jury began hearing witnesses yesterday in its inquiry into activities of alleged ambulance chasers.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- One of the unfortunate by-products of the Oppenheimer case is that the Atomic Energy Commission is now getting involved in partisan politics.

BUENOS AIRES, June 10 -- The federal police reported today the arrest of eighteen more alleged Communists, charged with being involved in the recent labor disturbances that resulted in the death of at least six metal workers in the past week.

Its agenda extremely limited but containing essential matters requiring prompt action, the New York Legislature has quickly disposed of its important business. Corrective revisions in the 1953 election district reapportionment laws were made. Specious Democratic objections to the recovery plan for the Long Island Rail Road were brushed aside.

GENEVA, June 10 -- The International Labor Conference overrode the objections of non-Communist employer participants today and voted to seat Communist "employer" delegates as "deputy" members of some of its principal committees.

There has been enough delay in getting action on a new refrigeration safety code for the city. A public hearing has been held, and the attitude of both proponents and opponents of the code has been fully aired.

President Eisenhower went to the nation last evening in an attempt to arouse interest in and support for his legislative program. He has already said that he could not conceive of anything more important to the United States today than its enactment, and there is no doubt that the President means it.

WITH only reasonable cooperation from the weather man, anglers should find plenty of action in fresh and salt water this week-end. Most trout streams are in near-perfect condition and the offshore possibilities are unusually varied.

BRISTOL, England, June 10 (UP)--Two United States men and three women were eliminated today in the West of England lawn tennis tournament. Katherine Hubbell of Boston scored the lone American victory of the day.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Export-Import Bank will get a $500,000,000 shot in the arm under a bipartisan compromise designed to end months of behind-the-scenes bickering within the Administration.
HOUSTON, Tex., June 10 -- The Playhouse, Houston's three-year-old professional arena theatre, will go dark after Saturday night's performance of "The Man."

Almost a hundred meat products in cans and glass containers are available to the home cook who, during the summer, desires to cut to a minimum time and energy spent in the kitchen. The addition of a few savory ingredients gives many of these items a less standardized quality.
BERLIN, June 10 (AP) -- Gustav Scholz, middleweight champion of Germany celebrated his return from the United States tonight with a four-round knockout of Emile Delmine of Belgium.
SEATTLE, June 10 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, deplored today disunity among Western nations in dealing with grave issues.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 10 -- The National Press Photographers Association annual Joseph A. Sprague Memorial Awards were presented here tonight to Arthur L. Witman, of the St. Louis Post-Dispatch, and Vincent S. Jones, of the Gannett newspapers.
The calling of a Civilian Defense air-raid drill next Monday morning has dropped a real problem into the laps of organized securities and commodities exchanges here.

RYE, N. Y., June 10 -- Ellis Knowles of the home club gained the lead in the second section of the United States Seniors Golf Association championship at the Apawamis Club today with a two-over-par 74.

CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) -- The third-place Philadelphia Phillies mixed extra-base power with Chicago errors for a 6-0 triumph over the Cubs today. It was the Phils' sixth victory in eight starts on their current road trip.

BOSTON, June 10 -- Frederick G. Fisher Jr. said today that his name had been injected into the McCarthy-Army hearings "because Senator McCarthy thought that this would be a clever way of embarrassing the Army."

CINCINNATI, June 10 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs swept a three-game series with the Pittsburgh Pirates by winning today's game, 6 to 0. Fred Baczewski was thee winning pitcher and Vernon Thies was the loser.
TORONTO, June 10 -- Gold-threaded stoles of many colors from India form one of the most dazzling displays at the Seventh Canadian International Trade Fair, now in its second week here
GUATEMALA, June 10 -- Foreign elements in Guatemala have taken over the plot against the Government, Maj. Jaime Rosenberg Rivera, chief of the National Civil Guard, said last night.
LONDON, June 10--Queen Elizabeth II, a slim, erect figure in scarlet and blue, joined the soldiers of her household today in the traditional ceremony of Trooping the Color.
LONDON, June 10 -- The drawing-room elegance of Oscar Wilde's "Lady Windermere's Fan" returned to London tonight in the form of an operetta by Noel Coward.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 10 -- Musician, 7-year-old black gelding owned by J. and B. Mollica of Long Island City and driven by George Phalen, won a three-horse photo finish by a neck in 2:04 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway in the Bethpage pace. This was his second victory in four starts this season.
The Mississinewa, largest tanker ever built for the Navy, will be launched tomorrow morning at the New York Shipbuilding Corporation plant at Camden, N. J.
The aircraft carrier Bennington dropped anchor in Gravesend Bay at 4:45 P. M. yesterday with no outward sign of the fire and explosions that killed 103 and injured 117 of her crew on May 26.

AMHERST, Mass., June 10 (AP) -- Amherst College announced today that Dag Hammarskjold, secretary general of the United Nations, would be one of nine persons to receive honorary degrees at commencement exercises on Sunday.
ST. LOUIS, June 10 -- The Cardinals displayed more acrimony today, but the Dodgers got more base hits, winning, 7 -- 4, and gaining an even break in the four-game series at Busch Stadium.
Brooklyn Sunday School children -- 120,000 strong -- marched through the borough yesterday in twenty-six parades.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The United States has turned down a French request that it provide Globemaster planes and Air Force crews to fly about 3,000 additional troops from North Africa to Indochina.

James P. Finnegan, former internal revenue collector at St. Louis, arrived in Brooklyn yesterday to testify in the income-tax evasion trial of Joseph D. Nunan, former Commissioner of Internal Revenue. The former Washington official is accused of cheating the Government of $91,086 in a five-year period.

No. 10,000 of the Snipe Class never will sail anywhere except on a living-room wall. In a ceremony at the New York Yacht Club yesterday, a plaque bearing that historic number was presented to Mrs. William F. Crosby, widow of the founder of the world's largest one-design racing class.

Another decline in business loans by the New York banks was reported yesterday. For the weekly period ended on Wednesday, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans shrank by $28,000,000, the reduction being due largely to repayments by sales finance companies and some in the metals industry.

LOS ANGELES, June 10 -- Capt. G. Allan Hancock, chairman of the board of trustees of the University of Southern California and one of its principal benefactors, abruptly severed connections with the institution today.

The board of trustees of the National Child Labor Committee took issue yesterday with Dr. Margaret Mead over her recommendation that 14-year-olds unhappy in school be permitted to quit school and go to work.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 10 (AP) -- A physician predicted today that researchers soon would isolate an agent in tobacco tars that he said caused cancers.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 10 -- Lester E. Barrett of Barrett Electrical Supply Company of St. Louis, was elected president of the National Association of Electrical Distributors at the forty-sixth annual convention here today.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 10 -- Pakistan and Turkey, the two countries that laid the foundation for a Mideast defense system, opened discussions today on how to erect a superstructure for it. They will also examine the strength of its foundation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 10 -- Delegates from Uruguay, Brazil and Syria attacked today legal provisions in South-West Africa that, they said, allowed punishment by whipping. The three countries are members of a United Nations committee that has been examining conditions in the territory administered by South Africa.
James A. Hagerty, political writer for The New York Times, was honored last night by Mayor Wagner and other political leaders.

NEWARK, June 10 -- Dr. Henry T. Heald, chancellor of New York University, said tonight that the American concept of freedom, democracy and justice "is built on the philosophy that the end, no matter how worthy the cause, must be achieved by the right means."
MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 10 -- Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis carded a 40, 41-81 to win the Women's Westchester Fairfield Golf Association one-day tournament at the Winged Foot Club today.

The Brooklyn Centre Holding Company, represented by Edward H. Freiberger, attorney, has purchased the South Brooklyn Sayings and Loan Association's building at 44 Willoughby Street, corner of Jay Street, in Brooklyn.
MILWAUKEE, June 10 -- There was no shaking the Giants out of their joint occupancy of first place in the National League flag race today.
OTTAWA, June 10 -- A United States note to Canada suggesting the start of negotiations for joint construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway was being studied by Canadian officials here today.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The House today voted $1,970,378,761 to finance the Labor and Welfare Departments for the fiscal year starting July 1.

This page has paid already handsome and deserved tributes to the month of June, and noted among the manifold gifts it brings a spur to the activities of the poets. A reader with a literary turn informs us that taking standard anthologies as measure it appears that, next to May, this month in the middle of the year is the favorite playground of the rhymesters.

Joey Giardello of Philadelphia, one of the leading challengers for the middleweight crown, and Bobby Jones of Oakland, Calif., fifth-ranked in the division, will meet in a ten-round fight at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Winter cruise vessels operating out of East Coast ports next season may increase both frequency of calls and length of stay at Port-au-Prince, Haiti, as a result of a conference this week among steamship officials and authorities of Haiti.
A plea by Frank Costello, the gambler, for release in bail pending determination of his appeal from a conviction for income-tax evasion was denied yesterday.
TAMALE, Gold Coast, June 10 -- An election that will make the Gold Coast the first fully self-governing state in Colonial Africa began in the northern part of the country today.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 10 (AP) -- Free world cotton stocks are expected to rise to 18,000,000 bales by Aug. 1 despite high level consumption. This was reported by the press commission of the International Cotton Consultative Committee, published today.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Eisenhower said today that the threat of communism was world-wide and truly serious, and that it could not be checked by armed strength alone.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 10 -- A "serious" fund shortage threatens to undermine United Nations Korean aid operations, the head of the program warned here today.

TORONTO, June 10 (UP) -- Canada and the United States fought to a first-round tie in the third annual Hopkins Trophy international team golf matches today as the weather alternated between sizzling heat and hailstorms.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- During the week ended June 9, member bank reserves increased $558,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
The new British cargo ship Whakatane is scheduled to arrive here tomorrow on her maiden voyage, Norton, Lilly Co., her agents here, announced yesterday.

Future historians may well term this mid-century decade the Age of Color. The search for individuality in mass living may explain the current interest in color. But whatever the explanation, American consumers are "astoundingly color conscious and are demanding more color in virtually all consumer goods," according to Faber Birren, color consultant.
A brighter outlook is in prospect for Negroes in industry, politics and education as a result of the recent Supreme Court decision against public school segregation.
VIENNA, June 10 -- Soviet authorities unexpectedly checked the movement of goods by road across the Soviet Zone boundary in Austria all along the demarcation line today.
A 1,000-pound steer, on his way to become steaks and roasts, made a break for freedom yesterday and headed back to the wide open West.

New Jersey's insect population was swelled by sixty a day or two ago, in the first phase of a resettlement program being conducted by the American Museum of Natural History. The newcomers are colorful tiger beetles, imports from Reno, Nev., which were air-mailed to the museum, then rushed out to New Jersey's pine barrens and released.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in its thirty-first day of hearings on the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

Local streets in New Jersey will be ruined by heavy truck traffic, the Regional Plan Association said yesterday, unless Gov. Robert B. Meyner reconsiders his opposition to linking the New Jersey Turnpike and the New York Truway.

In his letter published on May 26, Prof. Ralph Barton Perry reverts to a thesis which, in view of the history of the past ten years, seems to have a remarkably curious vitality. Reduced to its essentials, this thesis insists that we must try to understand the Communists and be tolerant of their aberrations, since we have to live upon the same earth with them.

The city and county of Honolulu, Hawaii, sold $3,000,000 of Kalihi Tunnel bonds, due from 1955 to 1984, yesterday to a syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation and associates. The group's bid was 100 15 for 5s, 3s and 1s, an interest cost of 2.783 per cent.

CAIRO, June 10 -- Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser gave his support today to Kamal el-Malakh, young archaeologist who discovered a solar ship of Cheops at Giza and became embattled with senior officials in the Egyptian Department of Antiquities.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Dean Stone, Washington rookie, won his fourth straight game today by holding the Cleveland Indians to seven hits as the Senators pounded Bob Lemon for an 8-4 victory.

Bassanio held off a closing bid by Resilient to win the Smithtown Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. With Sidney Cole guiding him, the Ogden Phipps color-bearer showed staying power in the mile-and-a-sixteenth event and had a margin of more than a length over the Killian Farms' representative at the finish.

The four - story apartment house accommodating thirty-five families at 26 Winans Street in East Orange, N. J., has been sold by Ernest and Marie Hepting to the Winmark Corporation, represented by Louis Selenfriend, attorney. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy swore under oath today that he never had asked anyone in the Army to grant a direct commission to Pvt. G. David Schine.

This month and next, lettuce comes to us from near-by farms and the prices are low. New Jersey, the principal source in June, now is sending in abundance a crop estimated to be a third larger than recent averages.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) -- Senator Everett M. Dirksen said today that he thought he had told Army-McCarthy investigators he might use ten minutes to "appraise" the work of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Four Republicans overrode three Democratic protests today and voted, in effect, to end the public and televised hearings of the Army-McCarthy controversy next week.

LONDON, June 10 -- Prices fell as selling pressure developed on the stock markets here today. Government funds again were the only firm section. The weakness was attributed to the setback in Wall Street and renewed uncertainty about the outcome of the Geneva Conference.

ALBANY, June 10 -- A bill correcting the 1953 Legislative Reapportionment Law and making it applicable to the election of party officials this fall was approved today by the Legislature and signed by Governor Dewey.
Homemakers who would like to adopt the energy-saving principle of sitting down while they work but do not wish to invest in a built-in work surface might consider using an adjustable ironing board.
A stumbling block has arisen in the attempt to bring Alec Guinness from London to act in "The Prisoner."
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Treasury has been repaid $99,000,000 it lent the Public Housing Administration for the financing of low-rent public housing.
WASHINGTON, June 10--Charles P. Grimes, chief counsel to the Jenner Internal Security subcommittee, resigned today under circumstances that were not made entirely clear.

The decline in rewards for military service has impaired severely the morale of the "hard core" of any armed force -- the Regulars. Many promising young officers have been resigning; both West Point and Annapolis are hard put to find sufficient suitable candidates.

" THE Big Story," which purports to relate accurately the exploits of newspaper men in tracking down criminals, appears to have been caught with one of its dramatic liberties showing. Its story of last week on N. B. C. video (9 P. M. Friday) has been pooh-poohed by a gentleman who should know -- the policeman in the case.

LONDON, June 10 -- The goodwill visit paid to the United States last year by the St. Paul's Cathedral Choir was returned tonight by an American girls' choir. More than fifty undergraduates from Smith College, Northampton, Mass., opened a tour of Europe and the Near East with a recital of sacred music in the Cathedral.

A fact-finding panel recommended yesterday that 171 newspaper machinists get no wage increase beyond the $3.75 weekly package offer made by the publishers of seven New York dailies. The panel also recommended that there be no change in the thirty-seven-and-a-half-hour work-week.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Eisenhower stated with emphasis today his determination to press for Congressional approval of his liberal foreign trade program as outlined in a special message last March.

PARIS, June 10 -- Experienced French observers feel it will be difficult for Premier Joseph Laniel to win back in Saturday's vote on confidence in his Government the fifty-nine votes he lost in a test vote early today.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Eisenhower made these main points at his news conference this morning:

TRENTON, June 10 -- The New Jersey Senate approved today a referendum at the November election on a $25,000,000 bond issue to finance construction and equipment of what would be the state's first medical and dental college.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy told fellow Senators on May I7 that his charge against H. Struve Hensel, assistant Secretary of Defense, had been an assumption made after he "added two and two."

Pan American-Grace Airways, Inc., (Panagra) yesterday offered to purchase the physical assets of the Latin American services of Braniff Airways, Inc. The price would be $5,000,000 in cash or stock of W. R. Grace Co. and Pan American World Airways, Inc., co-owners of Panagra.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Six teen-age winners of four-year scholarships awarded by a veterans organization today promised President Eisenhower to dedicate themselves to "the conquest of ignorance, hate, fear and slavery."

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- A burst of handclapping from the Democratic side of the House of Representatives today greeted an announcement by Representative Dwight L. Rogers that he had introduced a concurrent resolution to ban the televising of Congressional hearings.

PARIS, June 10 -- Autumn hats, so small that they are merely an excuse for wearing a veil, are on view at Gilbert Orcel, top Paris modist. Since there is more veil than hat, these becoming little headpieces have been dubbed "Veilettes."

DANBURY, Conn., June 11 -- Investigators became more baffled by the hour today over a boy about 12 years old who has been in Danbury Hospital since Tuesday night and who says he doesn't know who he is.

GENEVA, June 10 -- United States and Chinese representatives arranged for Americans imprisoned or detained in Communist China to send and receive mail. The meeting today was the second dealing with the question of Americans held by the Peiping regime.

OTTAWA, June 11 -- Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Minister of External Affairs, indicated today that the Western powers were considering the possibility of withdrawing from the Geneva talks on Korea and Southeast Asia.
ACCRA, Gold Coast, June 11 -- Next Tuesday's general election in the Gold Coast is expected to establish Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah as "master in his own house."

As a reader of your newspaper for a number of years I have always admired and appreciated your efforts to promote friendship between the American and Chinese people, as evidenced by your editorial stand for a free and independent China.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 11 (UP) -- Atomic scientists have developed a new, inexpensive radiation source costing less than $1,000, the University of Notre Dame disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The text of G. David Schine's long-range plan of psychological warfare against world communism, as introduced in the record of the Army-McCarthy hearings, follows:
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Contention between two House committees over which should write legislation on disposal of agricultural products abroad resulted today in two parallel bills.

MATAMOROS, Mexico, June 11 (UP) -- Nearly 100 landless farmers fought a battle with the army for 1,500 acres of a large farm today. An army major was killed and three other men were injured. The issue appeared still unsettled.
BRISTOL, England, June 11 (AP) -- Barbara Kimbrell of Los Angeles and Barbara Bradley of Reno, Nev., reached the women's doubles final of the West of England tennis championships today.

PARIS, June 11 -- The prospect tonight seemed to be that a confidence vote by a majority of the National Assembly membership would be refused to Premier Joseph Laniel tomorrow. This would mean resignation of the Cabinet and a crisis of an indeterminate length, in midst of the conference on Far East affairs at Geneva.

James P. Finnegan, former collector in the Internal Revenue Service at St. Louis, told Federal Judge Walter Bruchhausen and the jury in Brooklyn yesterday about his financial transactions with Joseph D. Nunan, on trial for income tax evasion.
DANBURY, Conn., June 11 -- Danbury Hospital's "nameless boy," believed to be a victim of amnesia, was reunited with his mother today, but it was strictly a one-sided affair.
The news dispatch by John P. Callahan that appeared in the New York Times on June 7 was grossly influenced by the purposes and prejudices of a "highly placed Middle East observer" in Karachi.
Two modern highwaymen, using automobiles instead of horses, held up a building contractor on the road in Forest Hills at 10:30 A. M. yesterday and took from him a payroll of $2,564.
CAIRO, June 11 -- Egypt and Saudi Arabia have agreed to pool their resources in war industries, armaments, defense and military training.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Washington scored five runs off Bob Chakales in the first inning, then staggered to a 9-8 victory I over Baltimore tonight despite the Orioles' sixteen hits.
LONDON, June 11 -- Britain has ordered the deportation by June 30 of Dr. Joseph H. Cort, an American lecturer at Birmingham University, on charges laid by United States authorities.
The main charges in the Army - McCarthy controversy now before a Senate investigating subcommittee are:
Japan's austerity program, involving tight credit and a deliberate policy of lowering domestic prices to increase the nation's power to compete abroad, appears to be working.
MELBOURNE, Australia, June 11 -- A hitherto unknown people has been discovered in the mountains of the Australian part of New Guinea [cross on map].

HOW many world record fish have been disposed of before being weighed will never be known, but routine weighing by a taxidermist gained the muskellunge fishing crown for Robert Malo of Port Arthur, Ont., this week.

There is rejoicing in City Hall because the Supreme Court of the United States has ruled that the city may tap the Delaware River for 800,000,000 gallons of water a day. Under the court's decision of 1931 the city was authorized to take only 440,000,000 gallons a day.

Ten American and ten British clergymen will participate this summer in a trans-Atlantic preaching exchange. The project will be administered jointly by the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. and the British Council of Churches.

William Howell denied yesterday that he had known that Edward (Snakes) Ryan intended to kill Thomas F. Lewis, Bronx labor leader, last August. Testifying at his first-degree murder trial in Bronx County Court, Howell denied also that Ryan had mentioned Lewis' name to him.
Plans for introduction on the American market of an Irish blended malt whisky were disclosed yesgterday by Desmond J. Williams, representative of the distiller.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 11 -- Broderick Crawford will star as the head of an international crime syndicate in "New York Confidential."
Effusion was checkmated by confusion yesterday when the championship Russian chess team arrived here as a pawn in international diplomacy.

When there's a United Seamen's Service Club in port, every American seaman knows he can buy food and lodging at reasonable prices, find recreation in a stateside atmos phere and receive help when detained ashore. Organized in 1942 to give seamen a break "100 years overdue," the U. S. S. presently operates eleven clubs from Pusan to Casablanca and provides shoreside services in France and Italy.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 11 (UP) -- A new type, tail-less jet fighter crashed into a school building at the huge Millington Naval Base today, killing five persons. It missed 100 sailors, who had left the structure three minutes earlier.

Many passengers were hurled to the deck, but only one woman required hospitalization, when the sightseeing ship Gotham rammed into the Manhattan bulkhead of the Harlem River at 210th Street at 4:45 P. M. yesterday. The vessel was a victim of a disabled steering engine and a mix-up in engine orders.
MIAMI BEACH, June 11 (AP) -- An airplane that can land on water and unload guns, trucks, supplies or an assault company of Marines directly onto an enemy beach was disclosed today.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 11 (AP) -- Powerful Southern California, gunning for its sixth straight title, today sent eight men into the finals of the National Collegiate track and field championships under a scorching sun at the University of Michigan's Ferry Field.

Just east of the garden of the Museum of Modern Art, a commodious, sixteenth-century style Japanese house is nearing completion. The assembling of the Far Eastern import is some what behind schedule, however, and museum officials are keeping their fingers crossed so the house will be ready for opening June 20 as scheduled.

At Belmont Park this afternoon the customers will be studying the past performances and trying to pick the winner of the Belmont Stakes. At dear old Belmont yesterday the handicappers were going over the figures and trying to pick the favorite.

Pravda, most authoritative newspaper in the Soviet Union, seems to have thrown its weight against those who have fought for more liberal policies toward writers and other intellectuals in the post-Stalinist era.
ROME, June 10 (Reuters) -- Slacks do not "necessarily introduce the devil into the body of the woman who wears them," Osservatore della Domenica, a weekly Vatican newspaper, said today.
Here is a chronology of the months' long battle between William White and Robert R. Young for control of the New York Central Railroad:

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UP) -- The Senate beat down a campaign by Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, today to cut diplomatic spending abroad despite Mr. Douglas' protests that United States policies should not be floated "on a sea of champagne."
Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. made known yesterday that he would be a candidate for the nomination for Governor at the Democratic State Convention to be held here on Sept. 21 and 22.

GENEVA, June 11 -- Taking a position similar to that she took yesterday on Indochina, Britain said today that if two basic Korean issues could not be resolved "then we shall have to admit" that the conference on Far Eastern affairs "has not been able to complete its task."

District Attorney T. Vincent Quinn of Queens offered yesterday to arange a lie detector test for Paul A. Pfeffer, serving a term of twenty years to life for the slaying of Edward S. Bates, a seaman, in Rockaway Beach last August.

The Tishman Realty Construction Company, builder and owner of Sutton Terrace Apartments, has purchased five old tenement houses facing the apartments at 405 to 413 East Sixty-third Street, between York and First Avenues.
The North American Rayon Corporation and its subsidiary reported yesterday net income of $1,166,126, for the fiscal year ended on April 3, compared with $2,857,072 for the preceding period.
The city wound up yesterday its participation in the national trials to determine whether the new Salk vaccine is an effective means of preventing poliomyelitis.

OTTAWA, June 11 -- The records of a German scientist, Dr. H. K. E. Krueger, who disappeared in the Arctic in 1930, and further relics of Admiral Peary's explorations, were found recently on northwest Ellesmere Island.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Navy announcement of the clearances was made a few hours after the Senate Appropriations Committee had directed the Defense Department to speed and improve the handling of security cases.
OTTAWA, June 11 -- Gen. Alfred Gruenther, Supreme commander of the Allied Powers in Europe, said today the West need not "cringe" before Soviet might.
The prize that financier Robert R. Young won at Albany is a century-old railroad with assets of more than $2,600,000,000 and a fine reputation for public service.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The following list includes new apartment projects in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, named by the Housing and Home Finance Agency today among private developments that received "windfalls" from loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration.
MELBOURNE, Australia, June 11 -- The Royal Commission investigating Soviet espionage was informed today by its chief counsel that names of at least seventy persons would come into the evidence.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Less than a month ago Secretary of State Dulles felt that "popular sentiment" in France was so strongly in favor of Indochinese peace "at any price" that there was a considerable chance that it would "prevail."
ALBANY, June 11 -- The New York National Guard postponed today the date on which Roy M. Cohn must report for two weeks of summer training.
Adlai E. Stevenson went to City Hall yesterday for a thirty-minute chat with Mayor Wagner and a five-minute visit to a regular meeting of the Board of Estimate.

GENEVA, June 11 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the speeches of Chou En-lai, Chinese Communist Premier and Foreign Minister, and Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, at the Far Eastern Conference today:
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The latest in personal fire escapes -- a drum containing a steel tape or cable attached to a breeches buoy -- was patented this week.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics, Chicago White Sox and Washington Senators today completed a three-way trade, involving six players and cash. Morrie Martin, the chief figure in the deal, went to the White Sox.
Strong gains spotted the stock market tape yesterday as prices for the second day pushed forward on low volume.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 11 -- United Nations delegates may get a first-hand account of conditions in the Pacific hydrogen bomb test area.

A narrative prose poem entitled "Prelude to a Journey" is the only book published today. Written by Agnes Louise Hovde and illustrated by Helen Dorothy Hovde, it is subtitled "A Story of the Ukraine." Vantage is publishing the book at $2.75.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. David Sarnoff said today that electronic devices were destined to play an increasingly important role in law enforcement.

The Ray Jalousie Corporation has leased the one-story building at 55 Union Avenue in Brooklyn from Richard Zirinsky and will use it for the manufacture, assembly and distribution of jalousie windows and doors. The lease was made through the Kalmon Dolgin Company as broker.

Young students at Brooklyn College preparing for the teaching profession should be "much wiser in the ways of children" thanks to the lively cooperation they have received from forty-six pre-schoolers.
ST. LOUIS, June 11 (UP) -- Curt LOUIS, Roberts and Vern Law hit their first major league home runs tonight to lead the Pittsburgh Pirates to an 8-to-5 victory overI the St. Louis Cardinals.
CARACAS, Venezuela, June 11 -- Venezuela's dollar income for 1953 was $1,050,000,000, the largest year's income to date, Banco Central showed in its annual report released today.

The Brooklyn waterfront domain of Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia was expanded considerably last night when members of five locals of the old International Longshoremen's Association voted to be absorbed by his union.
GENEVA, June 11 -- Representatives of the opposing Indochina commands have exchanged maps displaying information on the grouping of military forces in Indochina.

At this season, when all of us begin to think of vacations, we take pleasure once more in joining in the appeal for contributions to The Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund, which provides vacations out of the city for youngsters who would not otherwise have them.

General Electric Company's "Operation Stock Split" will reach its climax this week-end when 57,000,000 shares of common stock with a market value of approximately $2,250,000,000 will be mailed to 249,000 stockholders.
BOSTON, June 11 (AP) -- Title to eight closed mills of the American Woolen Company, has been transferred to its wholly owned real estate subsidiary, Textile Properties, Inc., a spokesman said today.

Premiums, available with or without the boxtop, have great inducement value for many persons other than children. The coffee and tea industries, well aware of this, have been stepping up promotions that involve premiums of various types.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., June 11 (AP) -- President Eisenhower expressed rueful concern today about what he called inflated property values in the vicinity of his Gettysburg farm since he purchased the place.

JERUSALEM, June 11 -- Egypt and Israel were censured in turn today by the Egyptian-Israeli Mixed Armistice Commission. The decisions were in connection with an action fought Wednesday along the Gaza strip that began when the Egyptians mined an Israeli command car and fired upon the patrol riding in it.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 11 -- Establishment of an International Finance Corporation to stimulate investments in underdeveloped countries seems no closer today than it did a year ago, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development reported today.
CHICAGO, June 11 -- The Giants, who yesterday had won a thriller in Milwaukee with a tenth-inning homer, learned today how the other fellows feel under such dramatic circumstances.
MILWAUKEE, June 11 (UP) -- Lew Burdette stopped the Milwaukee Braves' slide at five straight losses tonight .with a five-hit 1-0 shutout over the Philadelphia Phillies before 35,047 spectators.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Senator Hugh Butler, Republican of Nebraska, said today the Swiss watch industry supplied the German war machine during World War II with fuses, jeweled bearings, precision ammunition components and vital timepieces.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- All thirty-six companies that submitted proposals for the purchase of Government-owned synthetic rubber plants will get an opportunity to negotiate for the facilities in which they showed interest, the Government announced today.

The Right Rev. Charles F. Boynton, Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, presided yesterday at a service of holy communion marking the twenty-fifth anniversary of the ordination of the Rev. Dr. Otis R. Rice and his fifteenth year as chaplain and director of religious work at St. Luke's Hospital, Amsterdam Avenue and 113th Street.

With deepening concern born of the realization of their common destiny, the Western nations turn their eyes from Geneva to Paris, where the growing paralysis of the French Government is beginning to paralyze the free world's efforts at self-defense against the Communist menace.

" Pressure" to yield control of his German shipping lines, allegedly put upon him in Nazi prison by a representative of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, was described again yesterday in Federal Court by Arnold Bernstein.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today $28,861,584,486 in new defense funds for the fiscal year to begin July 1.

BOSTON, June 11 (AP) -- Larry Doby, George Strickland and Wally Westlake cracked home runs while Art Houtteman checked Boston on nine hits as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Boston Red Sox, 6 -- 2, tonight before 28,499.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson said today the United States would continue to offer cotton on the world market without an export subsidy.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (UP) -- The House Agriculture Committee voted today to authorize direct Government subsidies to dairy producers in a move to keep farmers' income up and retail butter prices down.

CINCINNATI, June 11 -- The Redlegs tied their club record by hitting five home runs tonight but the Dodgers won the game, 10 -- 8, and regained the undisputed lead in the National League, one length ahead of the Giants.
LONDON, June 11 (Reuters) -- An interim committee meeting here during the last two days to discuss the formation of an International Tin Council ended its discussions today.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- A Federal Judge today refused to halt a Federal Communications Commission hearing on allegations that Edward Lamb of Toledo, Ohio, publisher and broadcaster, once had Communist affiliations.
Robert R. Young has won control of the New York Central Railroad Company.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active yesterday, closing 8 points higher to 10 points lower.

MONTREAL, June 11 -- Prof. Edward C. Tolman of the University of California, who declared Monday that the United States was in the grip of an anti-intellectual fever, received an honorary degree tonight from McGill University here.
LOS ANGELES, Junet 11 -- John Foster Dulles branded today as "palpably false" any notion that the United States foreign policy was inclined toward a military showdown with Communist China.

Officials of the National Maritime Union, C. I O., reported some progress yesterday in negotiations with Atlantic and Gulf Coast ship operators for a new contract to replace an agreement that expires Tuesday.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 11 (AP) -- Several Vietminh battalions that marched 220 miles to help destroy Dienbienphu last month were back today at their old posts on the Thanhhoa plain in Tonkin.
ANNAPOLIS, June 11 (AP) -- Three midshipmen who had been under Navy scrutiny as possible security risks were cleared and commissioned without a trace of ill-feeling tonight.

Volume was light yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges with most of the activity limited to evening positions for the week-end. Only rubber and hides had better than normal activity. Prices closed generally lower with cocoa, rubber, hides, burlap, wool, copper, lead, tin and zinc weaker; coffee, potatoes and silk higher, and sugar, cottonseed oil and soybean oil mixed.

A 56-year-old Washington Heights housewife was arrested early yesterday morning by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on a charge that she had passed concealed documents to her sister, a Communist serving a term in a Federal reformatory in West Virginia.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Sherman Adams today foresaw "three conditions" that might develop to make President Eisenhower decline to run for a second term.

HIS name was James Arthur Lyon Fremantle and he was a lieutenant colonel in Her Majesty's Coldstream Guards. What was he doing -- in a tree -- at the Battle of Gettysburg? He was a fascinated spectator as so many of us have been (vicariously) since then in reading books from the endless parade of the Civil War's literary legions.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- A one-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, which expires tomorrow, was approved by the House of Representatives today, 281 to 53.

Reason took over yesterday and the strike call against the city-owned transit system was called off. Early next week the New York City Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union will sit down and try to travel the rest of the distance toward talking out their differences.

HOBOKEN, N. J., June 11 -- Sheldon Schultz, valedictorian of the graduating class at Stevens Institute of Technology, here, took two top awards today as honors were distributed among seniors of the engineering college on Class Day. The commencement exercises will be held tomorrow.

EASTON, Pa., June 11 --Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey told a Lafayette College graduating class of 300 today that "the time has come to strike out against the people who are peddling fear and distrust among us" and "to stand up for the ancient and enduring values which have made America great."

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in its Thirty-second day of hearings on the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- The immediate reaction of wheat traders to yesterday's bearish June crop estimate was to sell freely. This caused an early price dip, which was extended later. However partial recovery followed a buying flurry later on reported high winds and temperatures in the west end of the winter wheat belt. Buyers were slow to follow the upturns.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, June 11 -- The United States asked the International Court of Justice today for a ruling that would stress the need for international civil servants of "efficiency, competence and integrity."

Alert base-running by Phil Rizzuto and a clutch single by Irv Noren gave the Yankees first honors in their important series with the White Sox at the Stadium last night. The Bombers took the contest, 3 -- 2, to draw within three games of the league-leading Chicagoans, who had arrived with a seven-game winning streak.

LONDON, June 11 -- Stock market prices continued to fall today. An uninspired early rally on the strength of Wall Street's upturn yesterday was short-lived, and thereafter prices moved steadily lower.
O. J. Weber has been named general passenger manager of the American Export Lines, Inc.
LOS ALAMOS, N. M., June 11 -- Five hundred scientists at the Los Alamos atomic laboratory have signed a petition protesting the security finding against Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Rev. James H. Robinson, pastor of the Presbyterian Church of the Master in the Harlem district of New York, has fully and satisfactorily explained undisclosed "information" that caused the State Department to recall his passport last year, officials said today.

The Times of June 8 gave an admirable obituary of Maury Maverick of Texas, whose untimely death robs the American scene of one of its most colorful and independent figures and those who knew him of an admired friend.
BERLIN, June 11 (AP) -- Sir Michael Balcon, production chief of Ealing Studios in London, has been named the winner of the 1954 Golden Laurel Trophy.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 11 -- Steward Lad, 6-year-old bay horse owned by H. S. Hofler of Sunbury, N. C., won the Roslyn pace in 2:03 3/5 by a length from Volto Man tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Irish Hal finished third.

Today's new film is "Scotch on the Rocks," a British-made comedy presented by the Group 3 unit and produced by John Grierson, at the Sixtieth Street Trans-Lux. Ronald Squire, Kathleen Ryan, Raymond Huntley and Sebastian Shaw head the cast. John Eldridge directed from a screen play he wrote with Alfred Shaughnessy.
Your editorial on June 5 was read with great interest, particularly the portion regarding epilepsy and the promise of certain medications for its better control.
