WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Roy M. Cohn angrily threatened tonight to "get" a Democratic Senator because of his sharp cross-examination of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in the Army-McCarthy hearings.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., June 11 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt of Houston held a three-stroke advantage midway in the $15,000 Virginia Beach open golf tournament today despite a round of 60 by Wally Ulrich of Maplewood, N. J., that tied the Professional Golfers Association record.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The names of more than 200 corporations credited with getting around $40,000,000 in "windfalls" through Government-insured mortgages on new apartment projects were turned over to the Department of Justice today by the Housing and Home Finance Agency.

The food columnist's mail bag often holds a smile and occasionally a boisterous guffaw. A recent bulletin, for example, dealt with the nutrition of bees. It started off with this somewhat surprising question:
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Republican nominee for Governor of South Dakota got a bipartisan welcome at the Army-McCarthy hearings today.

Your readers, devoted and sporadic, write you only too seldom in comment on your editorials. We take the good with the less good, deriving from the former pleasure and satisfaction, from others something less than pleasure, and some with resentment, if perchance we disagree.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Mrs. Lolita Lebron, one of four Puerto Ricans who shot up the House of Representatives on March 1, testified today that she came here, not to kill anyone, but to die for her country's freedom.
LONDON, June 11 -- The initial Italian Government reaction to the new British-United States proposal on Trieste was described here today as cautiously optimistic.

LOS ANGELES, June 11 (AP) -- America's master of the mile, Wes Santee, defeated Josy Barthel, the Olympic 1,500-meter champion, in 4:00.7 and Parry O'Brien set a world shot-put record of 60 feet 10 inches in the Amateur Athletic Union district meet tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, is convinced that penny-pinching in United States diplomacy is false economy. The Soviet Union, meanwhile, he said, was spending "vast sums" and making "very considerable progress" in Cold War propaganda.
Three Filipino cadet-midshipmen received their degress in a special "pier-head" jump graduation ceremony yesterday at the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L. I.
BUENOS AIRES, June 11 -- Floyd Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, disclosed tonight that he had a double-barreled plan for aiding Argentina's economy.
TORONTO, June 11 (UP) -- The United States scored a sweep against Canada in the second round of the Hopkins Trophy golf matches today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics snapped back for a 2 -- 1 victory in the second game of a double-header tonight after absorbing a 16 -- 5 trouncing in a twilight contest that saw the Detroit Tigers smash six homers, including grand slams by Ray Boone and Al Kaline.
MINEOLA, L. I., June 11 -- Justice Philip N. Huntington in Supreme Court here today freed Mrs. Agnes Andrews, a Garden City dentist's wife, who had been serving a ninety-day jail sentence.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- F. B. Lee, Civil Aeronautics Administrator said today that a team of C. A. A. technicians had examined the British Vickers Viscount turbo-prop plane and discovered "no particular problems" that would prevent its certification for United States commercial operation.

KATONAH, N. Y., June 11 -- The first of two performances of Monteverdi's "The Coronation of Poppea" was given tonight by the American Chamber Opera Society at Caramoor, the estate of Mrs. Walter T. Rosen. An audience of 450 attended.

Senator McCarthy has performed his greatest -- and perhaps his first -- public service. In the needless and sadistic injection into the hearings of Fred Fisher's youthful encounter with the Lawyers Guild, Wisconsin's junior Senator has performed in his characteristic fashion before the eyes and ears of the nation.

RYE, N. Y., June 11 -- Scoring a spectacular birdie 3 at the last hole, Ellis Knowles of the home club tied for first place in the United States Seniors Golf Association championship at Apawamis today.
ALBANY, June 11 (AP) -- The driving licenses of 3,947 State residents were suspended last month as a result of apparently uninsured accidents, the Motor Vehicle Bureau reported today.

BERLIN, June 11 -- The West was accused today of preparing an attempt, supported by paratroopers, to overthrow the East German Government within the next few months. The charge was made during a trial in East Berlin.
NEWTON, Mass., June 11 (UP) -- The Newton Republican Club today asked to have its endorsement of Frederick G. Fisher Jr. entered into the official records of the Army-McCarthy hearings.

The one-story business building at 90-30 161st Street in Jamaica, Queens, occupied under lease by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company, has been sold by Ginsberg, Brunswick Rosenberg to M. L. Bennett and S. J. Lakin, real estate operators.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., June 11 -- Evansville manufacturers started out to solve a local problem of interesting boys and girls in their future careers, and discovered what may be a nation-wide solution -- homemade textbooks.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The United States agreed today to fly 1,000 casualties of the Dienbienphu battle home to France from Indochina by way of the Pacific.

BRANDON, Manitoba, June 11 (Canadian Press) -- Tremendous world carryovers and anticipated bumper crops in almost all producing countries cannot fail to force grain prices down, William J. Parker, president of Manitoba Pool Elevators, said here yesterday.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 11 -- Alexander Wiley, Wisconsin's senior Republican Senator, today declared the G. O. P. was "big enough to withstand honest differences."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 11 -- The International League for the Rights of Man has protested that French authorities in Tunisia put to death thirty-three political offenders between Nov. 1953 and May, this year.
LONDON, June 11 -- The Duke of Edinburgh urged local authorities today to show greater drive and imagination in providing more and better playgrounds for children in cities and towns.
Initial orders for fall fashion apparel are about on a par with those placed in the market opening period a year ago, according to New York garment manufacturers.

GERMANY, June 11 -- A conference of European powers to reunite Germany is being proposed by influential members of the Social Democratic party. The party, the chief opposition to the Government, has 151 seats in the Bundestag, the lower house of the West German pariament.
Robert R. Young entered the railroad field in 1937 when he acquired the Alleghany Corporation, railroad holding company, on the proverbial shoestring.
SAN SALVADOR, June 11 -- Guatemala, in her fourth day under the suspension of constitutional guarantees, is a tense, rumor-ridden country, susceptible to a violent outburst at any moment.
MAHWAH, N. J., June 11 -- Unless the Board of Education uses force to prevent his reporting for work, Roy S. Austin, Superintendent of Schools, intends to be at his desk every day indefinitely.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (UP) -- The chairman of a Senate committee can be removed -- but it is not easy.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent to 110.5 for the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. For the second successive week lower average prices for farm products and processed foods caused the decline, as industrial materials remained unchanged on the average.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 11 -- Five thousand Princeton University alumni will march tomorrow in a colorful mile-long "P-Rade" from historic Nassau Hall to the 218th Princeton-Yale baseball game on University Field.

DEARBORN, Mich., June 11 -- The annual meeting of the Detroit Methodist Conference adopted without dissent today a report describing "McCarthyism" as "the surface manifestation" of the same moral disease that helped prepare the ground for Hitler in Germany and for Lenin and Stalin in Russia.
ANKARA, Turkey, June 11 -- The Grand National Assembly unanimously ratified the Turkish-Pakistani treaty tonight as Prime Minister Mohammed Ali of Pakistan looked on from the galleries.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 11 (UP) -- John Landy's latest record-breaking attempt failed today when the determined Aussie won a 1,500-meter race in 3:46.4 at the rain-drenched Olympic Stadium. Landy had set out to lower the world record of 3:43.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The National Labor Relations Board today ordered a representation election within thirty days among 20,000 employes of the General Electric Company at Schenectary, N. Y. A similar election was ordered among 866 workers at Newark, N. J., plants of the company.

ONEONTA, N. Y., June 11 -- Governor Dewey charged today that the Democrats "chortle with glee" when unemployment increased and "seem to have a vested interest in depression as a means of achieving power."
The situation in Guatemala, which is likely soon to come before a consultative meeting of the hemisphere Foreign Ministers, should not obscure other developments in Latin America.
TORONTO, June 11 -- The two-week Seventh Canadian International Trade Fair closed today after playing host to more than 28,000 buyers from sixty countries.
A transit strike threatened for midnight tomorrow was canceled yesterday by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O.

Romaine, a form of Cos lettuce, is in excellent supply at low prices -- two pounds for 13 cents in some stores. It has an elongated head and coarser leaves than such forms of lettuce as iceberg and Boston. Many of its leaves are a dark shade of green, which is a sign they are richer in carotene that forms Vitamin A in the body than leaves that are pale and bleached.

When Morton Gottlieb returned here yesterday from a ten-week visit to England, he brought back with him an option to H. S. Kraft's dramatization of "The Last Tycoon," the unfinished novel by the late F. Scott Fitzgerald.
George Mason, author of the Virginia Declaration of Rights, was George Washington's friend and close neighbor, for Mason's seat, Gunston Hall, and Mount Vernon are only a few miles apart.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, demanded today that the Senate expel Senator Joseph R. McCarthy from its key councils unless he purged himself of personal charges.

Joey Giardello, Philadelphia middleweight, gained the decision over Bobby Jones of Oakland, Calif., in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. Although the award was unanimous, the crowd disapproved, and Johnny Addie's announcement of the outcome was roundly booed.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- A House Armed Services subcommittee today rejected a Senate-passed bill to authorize the long-term charter of twenty privately built tankers and voted instead that the Government build the vessels.

A traffic engineer must be a Balzac or Dickens of a sort. He must consider both the types and the individualists, the norm and the extremes. Sitting at his desk, working from his own experience with the human race, he must decide how all sorts of characters will behave in given situations.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 11 -- Mrs. Margaret Osborne du Pont of Wilmington, Del., and Louise Brough of Los Angeles, trailed by 1-5 in the third set -- just three points from defeat -- before halting Angela Buxton, and Pat Hird of Great Britain, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5, in the annual Wightman Cup tennis competition today.

Prof. James A. Storing of Colgate repeats the same cliches and banalities about Senator McCarthy's "methods" that are so fashionable in academic circles. I remind Professor Storing that Senator McCarthy is responsible for ridding us of a number of collaborators with the Communists.
Edwin A. Salmon, former chairman of the City Planning Commission, will return to city service as a $15,000-a-year planning consultant in the office of Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore.

BOTH tulips and Oriental poppies can yield fine flowers year after year only if their foliage is left undisturbed to mature and die down. True, this period of withering leaves (about six weeks for poppies, almost two months for tulips) is a time of unsightliness in the late May and June garden, but there are ways to mitigate it.

THE cycle of mural paintings in the Ajanta cave-temples, a monument of Buddhist art which, for grandeur, can only be compared in Christian art with the Sistine Chapel ceiling, must be among the most inaccessible great works of art in existence.

THE tremendous quantity of water required to sustain plant growth is one of horticulture's most amazing stories. An oak tree will sweat out 130 tons of water in a single growing season. On a hot summer day a birch may lose 1,000 pounds of water and an individual sunflower will give off a pint of water in twenty-four hours.

TRENTON, June 12 -- In 1917 a young legislator, fresh out of the Massachusetts Senate, reluctantly agreed to serve as administrator of the Boston jail. He detested the assignment and pleaded to be released of his duties as soon as possible.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, called together his chief aides today for a conference on the next steps toward bringing about united action in Southeast Asia.
PARIS, June 12 -- Francois Lacoste left France today to assume his post as the new French Resident General in troubled Morocco.

At Holloman Air Force Base, Alamogordo, N. M., the Air Force is studying the unusual forces to which pilots are subjected when they bail out of planes flying at altitudes of 40,000 feet and more at supersonic speed. Last week Lieut. Col. John P. Stapp, flight surgeon at the base, subjected himself to a test in which he had to stand a force twenty-two times his own weight.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 12 -- Elections will be contested Tuesday in three of the ten Suffolk County villages holding elections -- East Hampton, Westhampton Beach and North Haven.

TWO important new models of leading cameras have recently been introduced. One is a smaller, lower-priced Polaroid picture-in-a-minute camera, the other is a new model of the Rolleiflex 3.5, the appearance of the latter timed to coincide with the twenty-fifth anniversary of the introduction of the camera in 1929.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Spray aphids, whether green, red, brown or black, with nicotine sulfate. Green inchworms or cankerworms and caterpillars are chewing insects, controlled with sprays of DDT or lead arsenate. So are the little flea beetles. Cover the undersides of broadleaved evergreens with nicotine sulfate to protect against lacebugs.

THE United States Court of Appeals (Ninth District, San Francisco) has cleared the way for Republic Pictures to release for television exhibition a group of Roy Rogers and Gene Autry features. The Western stars, who have their own TV film programs, took the position that the Republic productions were made for theatrical showings and that the studio's intention to re-distribute them via television as commercially sponsored programs would violate contractual agreement and constitute unfair competition.
HARTFORD, June 12 -- Connecticut's regional planning statutes "should be revised" to set up "economic regions" in the state because of its fast growth, the State Development Commission believes.
PARIS, June 12 -- France is edging toward her worst crisis since liberation came ten years ago. The bare bones of national weakness are being exposed by the strains of an unpopular Indochina war.

After complacently watching stocks rise steadily for months, traders were jolted last week by the sharpest break in the market since June 29, 1950. No war scare, however, caused this latest slump and there was difficulty in finding any one cause for it. Evidently a technical position out of line with the realities in business -- after an uninterrupted advance of nearly nine months -- was a major factor.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 12 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali of Pakistan announced here tonight that Turkey and Pakistan had agreed on a "certain course of action" to develop a regional defense system under their treaty of friendly collaboration.
NOW that June and warm weather have arrived, tuberous-rooted begonias go into the garden. Tubers that were started indoors in pots or flats may be moved outdoors to the open ground or plant boxes.

THIS department last week reported Oswald Jacoby's suggestions for the opening two-bid. Mr. Jacoby would bid two spades, two hearts, or two diamonds (each forcing to game) only if the hand includes a singleton or void suit.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 12 -- New Jersey Turnpike engineers have adopted a new technique to cope with erosion on many of the steep slopes along the 118-mile superhighway.

WHITTIER, Calif., June 12 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon declared today that the United States, as leader of the free world, could defeat communism in Asia only by recognizing that the aspirations of underprivileged peoples transcended material assistance.
The seriousness of the teacher shortage in elementary and high schools was emphasized last week in a report by the National Education Association.

TOMORROW, at Windsor Castle, Sir Winston Churchill will be formally invested by the Queen with the robes of The Most Noble and Amiable Company of St. George -- named the Garter -- and installed in his knight's stall in the Royal Chapel of St. George.

SAO PAULO, Brazil -- Construction crews here in Brazil's first city (it passed Rio last year) and Latin America's biggest industrial center, are working around the clock these days to complete an ultra-modern fair ground for the scheduled July 25 opening of the continent's most ambitiously conceived world's fair.

PARIS, June 12 -- Voted down, 306 to 293, on a question of confidence, Premier Joseph Laniel submitted the resignation of his Cabinet today. After a Cabinet discussion, President Rene Coty began consultations to decide whether to accept the resignation.

CATSKILL -- What is now called the Ulster-Greene Vacationland must have seemed a poor prospect for such a career when it was first settled back in pro-Revolutionary days. It was wild country, bears were plentiful and Indians were rude. But the locals set to work.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., June 12 (AP) -- The Navy will arm its first atomic submarine, the Nautilus, with the Regulus guided missile. James H. Smith Jr., Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Air, announced this last night before the Aviation Writers Association.

THE business deal which moved the "Voice of Firestone" television and radio program over to the American Broadcasting Company's networks and which will turn the Paramount Theatre in Times Square into a broadcasting studio for several hours each Monday, also will provide the theatre district with a unique double feature.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- With the recent opening of the $6,000,000 Gilmore Street bridge over the St. Johns River, giving the city four river crossings, Jacksonville truly lives up to its slogan -- "The Gateway City to Florida."

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 12 -- Hot weather provided the long-awaited stimulus to department store business, and while the comparison with last year was not impressive in percentage figures the gains were substantial in relation to previous weeks. Demand for vacation needs and buying for Father's Day resulted in movement of seasonal merchandise.
The most effective weapon against Communist "godlessness" is American "godliness", Rabbi Zev Zahavy said yesterday in a sermon at Congregation Zichron Ephraim, 163 East Sixty-seventh Street.

Mechanical massage devices for industry employes have resulted in a marked reduction in accidents in plants so equipped, according to Owen K. Murphy, president of the Niagara Manufacturing and Distributing Company, Adamsville, Pa.

HAVING successfully inaugurated the first national non-theatrical film assembly held in America, the Film Council of America is "following through" with typical practical ingenuity. Many in the generally unorganized non-theatrical film field should find a new council publication of inestimable value.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Lou Kretlow, who won only one game for the St. Louis Browns last season, captured his first decision for the Baltimore Orioles tonight as they defeated the Washington Senators, 7 -- 3. Kretlow, who was replaced by Howie Fox in the ninth inning, had lost four games.

PRESENT indications are that 1954 will be recorded as a year of heavy air travel, but there is more to the situation than that. The current year, to travelers, may also become known as the year of the package tour.

LAST week for the first time, the Santa Fe became an active bidder for through travel between Chicago and San Francisco. Its challenger for the business was the San Francisco Chief, a new addition to its Chief family.

Round-the-clock inspection of ships at Quarantine, long sought by the shipping industry, moved a step closer to realization last week as the Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee of the House reported favorably on a bill that would provide the service.

MIAMI BEACH -- Florida's vacation places are all wrapped up in neat packages awaiting the arrival of the reduced-rate holidayers, who nowadays descend upon the Florida summer scene with the same suddenness and volume that used to mark February's rush.
WITH the growth of paperback original novels to compete with newsstand reprints, one publishing firm has shrewdly combined originals and reprints in one volume.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 12 -- "The Horse in Art" is the title of a loan exhibition of equine paintings to be held at the Santa Barbara Museum of Art during July and August. Five eastern museums are providing the paintings and drawings for those months, when the "horse is king" at the National Horse Show and when the Old Spanish Days Fiesta is held.
VIRGINIA BEACH, June 12 (AP) -- Shelley Mayfield of Chicopee, Mass., shot a 4-under-par 65 today to tie Tommy Bolt of Houston, for the 54-hole lead in the $15,000 Virginia Beach open golf tournament.

A 115-MILE section of the New York State Thruway will be ready for dedication on June 24. This section of the New York-to-Buffalo toll route extends from Lowell in Oneida County, fifteen miles southwest of Utica, to West Henrietta, ten miles south of Rochester. Therefore the four to six lane superhighway, open to passenger cars, trucks and buses, will serve Utica, Syracuse and Rochester.

WHEN my wife and I travel across the country we go by day coach. We have covered more than 50,000 miles in four coast-to-coast trips, and some shorter jaunts, that have taken us into every state and six Canadian provinces.

ALTHOUGH "Carousel" was originally scheduled to close at the City Center this evening, the engagement is being extended. The public likes "Carousel" a good deal more than "Show Boat" and "Fledermaus," which preceded it in the spring light opera season.

FREEPORT, L. I. June 12 -- New York State Conservation Department officials continued this week their hunt for a clue to the killing of tens of thousands of food fish in lower New York Bay since early May.

The last time the Foreign Ministers of the twenty-one American Republics held a special consultative meeting was in March, 1951, and the topic was the threat of communism from abroad. Next month the Ministers expect to convene again, this time to discuss the threat of communism from within the hemisphere. The danger spot is Guatemala.

VENICE -- the city Mike Todd built -- lay in ruins the other day. Of the few witnesses who turned out here for the unionized sacking of the sets of last year's "A Night in Venice," easily the most demonstrative of the lot was Guy Lombardo, a chatty, easy-going, 51-year-old manufacturer of what, in the opinion of many, is the sweetest music and the sunniest optimism this side of Heaven.

Robert Waithman's delightful article "Good-by,Lulubelle" (April 18) does not mention an older relic, still running on London's streets, than the vanishing cab of which he wrote. I refer to the Daisy-Daisy, the transformed horse-cab.

IN early December, 1946, in response to my questions about colonial policy in Asia, a British Member of Parliament made a prophecy: "You Americans have already freed the Philippines. Within another year India, Pakistan, Ceylon, Burma, Indochina, Malaya and Indonesia will also be free.

RETAIL volume on a day-today basis continues to hold up well and there is hope among the nation's merchants that the summer will bring no undue change in the economic picture. The legislative stalemate, however, has been discouraging, particularly in regard to the new tax bill.

" In spite of highly publicized distractions," President Eisenhower said in a speech last week, "Congress has been hard at work." He was referring to the fact that the McCarthy furor has far overshadowed his legislative program. On that program Congress' work, though hard, has not been entirely to the Administration's liking.
Arthur F. Bisguier defeated James T. Sherwin yesterday to retain a half-point lead in the national championship chess tournament, which moves into the final round at the Marshall Chess Club today.

In these anxious days the free world turns its eyes from one side of the globe to the other and doesn't see much that is encouraging. Korea remains divided. A fort falls and with it the allegiance of many wavering individuals in Indochina. The Geneva conference turns out to be just another long debate in which old phrases are repeated and no progress is made toward agreement.

Aline B. Saarinen's "Lively Gallery for Living Art" (May 30) was aptly headlined and her article, indeed, a lively discussion of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. It is good to read how Director Sweeney is at last giving the Guggenheim direction instead of peregrination -- although in all fairness, I think, some of the tales Mrs. Saarinen says "emanated from this remote citadel" in the past were more bizarre than the facts justified.

The problem of visas for foreign seamen, who will need them next year if they sail on ships coming to this country, will be discussed by the Seafarers Section of the International Transportworkers Federation in London next month.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 12 (UP) -- Andy Crevolin's entry of Imbros and Determine, favored at odds of 11 to 20, ran one, two today in the $121,400 Californian Stakes at Hollywood Park.

SARANAC LAKE -- America's largest park, the vast Adirondack State Park, will have even more to offer the visitor this summer than it has in the past. Its great tumbled mountains and hundreds of lakes and ponds are, of course, long-time assets.

The Council on Social Work Education has just announced the election of Fedele F. Fauri, dean of the School of Social Work at the University of Michigan, as its president, for a two-year term starting July 1. He has been active in the social welfare field for many years, and was formerly director of the Michigan State Bureau of Social Security.

At this late day everyone ought to know that diseases of the heart and circulatory system take the heaviest toll in death. For this reason the annual report of the New York Heart Association is of direct interest to all of us. The report is a record of the achievements of forty years and a forecast of the future.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 12 -- A sixteen-hit Yale attack shelled two Princeton pitchers from the mound and gave the Elis a 13-1 victory in the rubber game of the season today on University Field.

WHEN roses bloom, so do rhododendrons (and that name comes from the Greek words for rose and tree) and their near relatives are not far behind. Some species of these evergreen and deciduous shrubs have been flowering here in the Northeast all spring, but it is only in the weeks ahead that the big rhododendron festivals will occur.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 12 -- Northampton, the home of President Coolidge and Smith College, will open a week-long 300th anniversary celebration tomorrow.

Brooklyn College will confer degrees on 2,160 men and women at its twenty-ninth commencement exercises today. Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of the college, will preside at the exercises on the campus quadrangle at 5 P. M.

AT hand now is the forty-first volume of that useful perennial, "The New York Times Index," offering over a thousand pages of exact, concise references and cross-references to the news of 1953. It was a busy year. The Korea war ended.

In as exciting a horse race as any racetracker could ask for, the King Ranch's High Gun won first money of $89,000 in the $125,100 Belmont Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. He nosed ahead with two strides to go in the mile-and-a-half run and he scored by a neck.
PAUL RICHARDS took dead aim at the winning of the American League pennant as soon as training camp opened last March.

RICHARD STRAUSS would have celebrated his ninetieth birthday on June 11 and this year is marked by the first complete biographical appraisal of his life, documented by hitherto unpublished papers and augmented by letters, reviews and critical statements.
PARIS, June 12 (Reuters) -- France has decided to end a year-old dispute with the tiny mountain country of Andorra.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 12 -- Moving smartly under a southwest breeze that sprang up in the late afternoon, Sam Barton's Aries defeated Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr.'s Susan in the International Class race as a fleet of ninety-seven sailed in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's regatta today.
The land-based prototype of the first atomic submarine has made "the equivalent of a voyage across the Atlantic Ocean -- submerged all the way and at full power."

The old, creaky Long Island Rail Road, which links New York with its fast growing Nassau and Suffolk suburbs, is perhaps unique among American railroads in that it carries practically no freight. Its revenue comes almost entirely from the approximately 6,000 tons of commuters it carries to and from the city each day.

Another sun-powered battery has turned up. We say "another" because earlier in the year the Bell Telephone Laboratories demonstrated a solar battery which depended on silicon transistors. The new battery uses a crystal of cadmium sulfide about the size of a sugar cube. It was tested at the Wright Air Development Center, near Dayton, Ohio.

YAKUTSK, U. S. S. R., June 5 -- After a 800-mile flight along the upper and middle course of the Arctic's perhaps most famous river, the Lena, this correspondent arrived here at its principal port, a little too late and a little too early for the big news.

ATLANTA, June 12 -- Despite a continuing decline in employment in the Southeast, manufacturing payrolls are carrying some 200,000 more workers than were employed immediately preceding the Korean war, the regional Department of Labor office in Atlanta reported this week.

BABYLON, L. I., June 12 -- Dedication of the Captree Parkway and Bridge, completing the link between the Southern, Northern and Ocean Parkways, took place today on the twenty-fifth anniversary of Jones Beach State Park.

NOW that "The Vanishing Prairie," the second feature in Walt Disney's "True Life Adventure" series, is slated to arrive at the Fine Arts Theatre here, it should be noted that the busy producer has plans that will take his naturalists and photographers practically around the world.
HANOI, Vietnam, June 12 (AP) -- Vietnamese Roman Catholic militiamen, fighting side by side with French forces, beat back a Vietminh assault on their village eighteen miles northwest of here today.

We are in an unhappy state indeed if, to bolster our hopes for a better America, we have to rely on such thinly disguised bigotry as is portrayed in Cabell Phillips' article of May 30, "What Happens When Segregation Ends?" [Mr. Phillips' article was a case history concerned with the impacts, happy or otherwise, on the adults and children of Jeffersonville, Ind., a Southern- minded Ohio River community, when it desegregated its public schools.
The richest coal territory in the United States is the site of what will be the nation's first atomic energy electric power plant.
BONN, Germany, June 12 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and his supporters are living through days of anguish and even desperation.

IN "The Spark and the Exodus" the authors have tried to recreate one of the tragic periods of Jewish history: the Czarist oppression, the pogroms that fired the Zionist dream of establishing a home land in Palestine. This drama of Jews in exile, fleeing persecution, has been explored by master craftsmen who lived and suffered and survived their suffering to tell their people's story.

An American team of six chefs, taking with them 1,500 pounds of delicacies including 300 live soft-shelled crabs, two live turtles, avocado pears, squab, lobsters and T-bone steaks, departed by plane last night for Berne, Switzerland, to compete with chefs of thirty countries at the International Culinary Exhibition.

NEXT Saturday a record fleet of some seventy-odd yachts, manned by at least 500 yachtsmen, will sail from Newport, R. I., blow high or low on the nineteenth ocean race to Bermuda, 635 long sea miles away to the southeastward. In size, the boats will range from a few 70-footers, with crews of fourteen or fifteen, down to small but able craft 35 to 40 feet long, with crews of four or five.

LAST week we talked exclusively about things, which in our occupational hazard are equated with books. We have felt ourselves listing a bit ever since, and we propose to restore a dubious balance by talking this week about people.

BOSTON, June 12 -- Larry Doby's single with the bases filled in the seventh inning enabled the Cleveland Indians to defeat the Boston Red Sox, 4 -- 3, today and take over the American League lead before 18,917.

CLEVELAND, June 12 -- Cleveland industrial concerns will add approximately 5,200 workers to their payrolls between now and Sept. 1, according to a survey by the Bureau of Unemployment Compensation. This is viewed as encouraging, but the bureau also disclosed that there are an estimated 31,000 jobless persons in this area, an increase of 9,000 since April.

ALL my life I have been haunted with the idea that the poet should know all classes of men as one of themselves, that he should combine the greatest possible personal realization with the greatest possible knowledge of the speech and circumstances of the world.

In the Journal of General Physiology Drs. D. J. Ralson and A. P. Krueger, both of the department of bacteriology at the University of California's Berkeley campus, report that viruses can be altered by the very cells they infect.

IT is a constant source of alarm to realize how we are wasting the rich resources of the past in the dance field. Not, indeed, that we ignore the traditional forms as they have been handed down, but that we are blandly consigning the specific accomplishments of the present to oblivion without granting them the privilege of ever becoming the past to future generations.

Three young Indians in costume arrived yesterday at Pennsylvania Station from reservations in the Southwest. They were Red Fox, 17 years old, and White Eagle, 13, both from a Navajo Reservation in Arizona, and Taos Peak, 13, a Pueblo from Arizona.

TO 11-year-old Rachel Lessing the thought of moving from downtown to uptown New York was harrowing. The lower East Side, with its tenements and splendid immigrant neighbors, its pushcarts and small stores, its friendly school and fascinating library, was her whole world.

TOKYO, June 12 -- Deep repercussions of the bitter fighting in the Japanese Diet began to be felt here this week. It was this rioting that blocked Premier Shigeru Yoshida's scheduled trip to the free world nations and for the first time in Japanese history caused the police to be summoned to quiet an unruly parliament.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (UP) -- One Republican member of Congress has his own ideas about what some of the words uttered at the McCarthy-Army hearings really mean.
WALTHAM, Mass., June 12 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, tonight called Senator Joseph R. McCarthy "the source of the most effective damage being done to the United States today."

THIS is the book for which we have all been waiting impatiently for fourteen years. Claude G. Bowers was the United States Ambassador to Republican Spain from 1933 to the end of the Civil War in 1939, but, since he remained in diplomatic service as Ambassador to Chile until last year, he felt he could not fairly publish his account until he had again become a private citizen.

The Columbia University Graduate School of Business will conduct the fourth session of the Executive Program in Business Administration for six weeks, beginning today, in Arden House at Harriman, N.Y.

ITHACA, N. Y., June 12 -- Cornell University is showing "no softness" on the question of communism and subversion, its president told an alumni reunion audience today. On the other hand, Dr. Deane W. Malott declared to strong applause:
Espionage today, sabotage tomorrow, are the chief internal dangers of communism, Frank H Gordon said yesterday.

HIERONYMUS MEEKER is the recording secretary of Earth's first expedition to Mars; the expedition's ship, blown out of "our earthly galaxy" by a comet, lands on an uncharted planet. In their wanderings over this world, the marooned astronauts encounter such truly unique systems of government as a theocracy, a police state, a democracy tripped up by its panic fear of subversives and other novelties.

BACK in 1950 there was a move to merge the League of Composers with the United States Section of the International Society of Contemporary Music. It came to naught and the two organizations have continued to struggle separately. But last Tuesday a merger was finally voted.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 12 -- The Government has decided to cut the conscription period from a minimum of twenty months to eighteen.

It is difficult to pick out the lowest point in any investigation or hearing at which Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin was present. However, the award for the past seven days might go to the junior Senator's attack on Frederick G. Fisher Jr., a junior law partner of Joseph M. Welch, Special Counsel for the Army.
Reid W. Malcolm Jr. has been named director of research and development of the R. M. Hollingshead Corporation, Camden, N. J., manufacturer of chemical products.

KUTZTOWN, Pa. -- For the fifth consecutive year the Pennsylvania Dutch will play host at the local fairgrounds from July 2 to 5 to all who are curious about them and their way of life. Last year the curious came from all forty-eight states and eleven foreign countries.

HACKENFELLER'S Ape, or, if you want to get tough about it, Anthropopithecus Hirsutus Africanus, was an ultra-special kind of ape, closer to being a human being than any other kind of animal. "In the jungle, as Hackenfeller had noted, it ran erect with its hands holding on to branches overhead.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., June 12 -- Msgr. Joseph E. Schieder, director of the National Federation of Catholic Colleges, today urged graduates at the ninety-eighth commencement of Seton Hall University "not to delude yourselves, as we, your elders, a foolish generation, have done."
Poodles performed yesterday for nearly 1,000 boys and girls at the junior jamboree of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.
Madison High of Brooklyn rallied for three runs in the sixth inning to defeat Bryant High of Queens, 3 -- 1, in the Public Schools Athletic League baseball final at Ebbets Field yesterday.

CENTRE ISLAND, L. I., June 12 -- Thirty boats took part in the eighty-second annual spring regatta of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club in the Sound today, with C. F. Havemeyer's Apache winning the twelve-mile race for the cruising Division B boats.

A 7-year-old Italian orphan girl, Silvania Vittoriani, arrived yesterday by plane from Rome at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. She was met by Mr. and Mrs. Wilbert Lennard of Staten Island, who have adopted her.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 12 -- A cheering Wisconsin Republican convention went wild today over Senator Joseph R. McCarthy as he defiantly proclaimed his determination to do "my duty" even if he inflicted "scars" on his own party.

PARIS, June 12 -- The National Congress of the French Communist party, which ended here last Monday, was the first held in four years. The party had much ground to go over and it did that with considerable thoroughness and frankness.

JULIE LAWRENCE, an only child, is a lonesome one until new neighbors move into the big house next door. To her first dismay, there are no girls -- but the four boys and their parents accept her enthusiastically. The pooled creative resources of the two families help Julie and Ted to find themselves -- Julie in the sewing she is so eager to learn; Ted in his music.

The outlook for fall apparel is promising, resident offices reported, after retailers from all parts of the country completed a week's shopping of new lines offered by manufacturers. They say values seem better than a year ago and styling is more imaginative.

John J. Boyle, former lieutenant in the New York Police Department, will head the security and protection staff of the Bush Terminal and Railroad Company in Brooklyn. His appointment was announced yesterday by A. P. Timmerman, chairman of the board of the marine terminal.

IN "Religion Behind the Iron Curtain." George N. Shuster, who is president of Hunter College and has held several United States posts in Europe. reviews the common pattern Communists have followed in dealing with religion in Eastern Europe.
DETROIT, June 12 -- The automobile industry nears the half-year mark with its position not as good as most manufacturers hoped, but not as bad as some feared.

WHEN Cardinal Spellman consecrated last year the Most Rev. Joseph Oliver Bowers. S. V. D., as Bishop of Accra (British West Africa) he remarked that this was the second Negro priest to be raised to the Roman Catholic episcopate in the United States.

THIS fourth book of Conan, the giant picaresque hero of a prehistoric era, is an invaluable item for collectors of the late Robert E. Howard's works. Here are explicatory letters by Mr. Howard, by H. P. Lovecraft and a history of the Hyborean Age.
CAIRO, June 12 -- Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser inspected the solar ship of Pharoah Cheops at Giza today and said its discoverer had "inscribed his name in history for all time."
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Another split in Republican ranks involving Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, had the Senate's majority leader and a colleague at sharp issue today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 12 -- Brazilians are showing alarm over falling coffee exports.

GENEVA, June 12 -- The French Cabinet crisis has thrown the Geneva conference on Far Eastern affairs into confusion. Together with the complete deadlock on Korea and Indochina, this development may force the conference to suspend the negotiations or abandon them entirely.
Last week the men around the big table in the Senate Caucus Room were, as Special Counsel Ray Jenkins put it, "in the twilight of this drama."

SOMETIME we may have a book called "The Two Masks of John Steinbeck." Using the fashionable critical idiom, it will make the point that for the past twenty-five years Steinbeck has alternately worn the comic and the tragic masks.
An unusual series of blowouts in tires of airplanes landing at New York International Airport snarled field operations yesterday, but no one was injured.

Turkey has again advanced the cause of the free world with the unanimous ratification by her National Assembly of the defense pact with Pakistan. There was nothing unexpected about this action, but the unanimity of the Turks is a sign of strength.

ANOTHER racial barrier in professional baseball has fallen -- at least in the minor leagues. As the first Negro to be employed as an umpire in organized baseball. Emmett Littleton Ashford is proving quite a drawing card in the Pacific Coast League this season, and may presage a similar removal of barriers in the big leagues.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad today disclosed a $35,000,000 "package deal" for a project to aid in the development of Penn Center on the site of the old "Chinese Wall" in the heart of Philadelphia.

BOYS who were stirred by the news of Roger Bannister's record-breaking 3:59.4 mile will be interested to know that this absorbing collection of true tales about great champions starts with the story of Glenn Cunningham, the colorful Kansas runner who broke the world's record in 1938 with his "Miracle Mile." Time: 4:4.4 -- only five seconds short of today's new record.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 12 (AP) -- Philip Scott, a 6-year-old bay horse owned by the Gray Brothers of East Providence, L. I., won his second straight part at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The time was 2:02.

LOS ANGELES, June 12 -- Five hundred officers of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service were assembling along California's Southern border this week-end to participate in the nation's most intensive campaign ever staged against the unending influx of illegal aliens from Mexico.

SPRING sunshine, flowery meadows and a frolicsome Pekingese puppy make a fine combination in this latest book by one of our most popular author-illustrators. Puffy stumbles one day over a dandelion and bumps his nose on a seven-leaf clover.

A three-week institute devoted to "Education for American Citizenship" is to be conducted at Tufts College starting June 28. The Civic Education Foundation will cooperate in carrying on the institute, President Nils Y. Wessell announced. Designed to strengthen democratic traditions, the project will stress present-day political and economic life, human relations and international cooperation. Specialists in school procedures will give instruction in methods of teaching democratic principles.

ACAPULCO, Mexico -- City dwellers of the atomic age who dream of a tropical island and the carefree life of the beachcomber may be surprised to learn that it is not necessary to journey thousands of miles to find it.
PONTIAC, Mich., June 12 (AP) -- A second Michigan child who participated in the recent polio vaccine tests has developed poliomyelitis and her mother also has been hospitalized for observation.

Of the triad of enigmatic neuromuscular diseases -- muscular dystrophy, multiple sclerosis and cerebral palsy -- the latter is the best known to the public. Consequently, there has been greater financial support of research, professional training and direct services for cerebral palsy -- and also greater advances.

THE four-man exhibition at the Village Camera Club, 65 Bank Street, is a heartening demonstration of the results that can be achieved in a camera club when the members are encouraged to work freely in an atmosphere of mutual striving for individual standards on a mature level.

FLORAL PARK, L. I. June 12 -- A controversial plan to float a $15,500,000 bond issue to build five new schools in the Sewanhaka Central High School District in Nassau County was approved today by the voters of the district.

A fusillade of rifle bullets was fired across busy Eighth Avenue and Fiftieth Street in front of Madison Square Garden last night in what looked like a carefully planned assassination attempt that failed.
GLENS FALLS, N. Y., June 12 -- Dr. F. B. Streeter, 100 years old this week, attributes his longevity to the fact that he never took any of his own medicine.

The annual tour of the city's parks and playgrounds by the Department of Parks' Marionette Theatre will begin tomorrow with a performance at 3:30 P. M. at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium, 242d Street and Broadway, the Bronx.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 12 -- Southern California's power-packed Trojans overwhelmed their opposition today to win their sixth straight National Collegiate A. A. track and field championship with 66 17/20 points.

For those who deal with the soil there's little time now to sit back and worry about complexities. The farmer uses every hour of daylight to do such simple things as get in his early hay, cultivate the early weeds out of his corn, keep up with his pastures and keep the kitchen garden from getting completely out of hand.
A comparative study of suburban elementary school teachers has shown they are better today than they ever were. They are younger, but wiser, better trained and traveled, and more cosmopolitan.

HOT music, an art form so peculiarly American that it is generally savored more highly by Europeans, is currently undergoing a revival here, the proportions of which have been compared, by some vaulting intellectuals, with the rude strength of the idiom along Fifty-second Street in the late Thirties.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Supreme Court decision this week, holding the Federal law regulating lobbying to be Constitutional, focused attention anew on what is popularly regarded as a somewhat sinister occupation.

Re Stuart Chase's article of May 30 "Forty, Thirty -- or Five Hour Week ?" [in which Mr. Chase traces the evolution of the work week from the Middle Ages to now and concludes that the "ideal" work week depends on the economic situation, the degree of mechanization, the task and the man -- Editor.]:

HANOI, Vietnam, June 12 -- This city of 350,000, the political capital of North Vietnam and military headquarters of the Franco-Vietnamese forces in the Red River Delta, is surrounded by a field of simmering volcanoes. They may erupt simultaneously with the next major offensive by Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap's Communist-led Vietminh army.

Seldom have Wall Street analysts shown anything like their present unanimity. A poll of a dozen or so economists with leading New York Stock Exchange firms finds them in agreement that a "corrective reaction" is overdue and is actually needed "to build a firm base for a new advance."
IF nature has endowed a politician with a lively wit or an understanding humor, should he carry the gift proudly on his campaign banners or hush it up like the jail record of a close relative ?
RAGUSA, Sicily, June 9 -- This Sicilian community is an exciting place to see today for an oilfield has been found on the edge of town.
OCEANPORT, N. J., June 12 -- Master Ace, owned by Mrs. Robert L. Gerry, had to break a track record at Monmouth Park today to beat William Wickham's fine sprinter, White Skies.

UNLESS the scouting department has its signals scrambled, the intelligence this morning is that William Bendix most likely will be the manager of that baseball team in the new Allen Boretz-Ruby Sully comedy, "The Hot Corner," and Glenda Farrell will be the suffering wife.

AS peony buds burst and crickets chirp the imminence of summer, a full contingent of house plants joins my family on the porch or in the garden to enjoy a season of outdoor living. The exodus from window sills and plant shelves begun two weeks ago, now comes to an end as even African violets are moved to sheltered corners of the porch.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- One of the encouraging features of the Giants' current drive to keep themselves in the thick of the National League's pennant scramble is the alacrity with which they bounce back from adversity.

ALBANY -- Up at Lake George, the work of restoring old Fort William Henry is well under way. By July it is expected that the bastion overlooking the lake will be set up exactly as it was nearly 200 years ago, with cannons mounted above and a powder magazine below.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 12 -- Five thousand Princeton University alumni capped three days of reunion celebration today with a mile-long "P-Rade" from Nassau Hall to University Field for the 218th Princeton - Yale baseball game.

ALTHOUGH the wrestle over youngsters' homework will be suspended in most households for the summer months ahead, we'll wager memories of the struggle are still clear in many a parent's mind. The pros and cons of homework and how much time should be spent at it can be looked at a little less passionately now.
GENEVA, June 12 -- Whatever the Geneva conference may or may not accomplish, it has very clearly increased the stature of Communist China in Western Europe and, probably, elsewhere.

SEEN in the theatre, neither "The Golden Apple" nor "The Pajama Game" appeared to be unusually promising candidates for original cast recordings, and for somewhat allied reasons. The various elements of "The Golden Apple" seemed so tightly knit, so interdependent that one wondered if any one element could stand up alone.

JAMES JOYCE lived in Dublin from his birth in 1882 until his student days were over in 1902. After a brief period in Paris, he again lived there until 1904, when he left it, as he thought, for good. He actually came back on a last visit in 1912 -- and never saw the city again.

ANTONIN DVORAK'S Stabat Mater, now available on two disks from Urania, is surely one of the most poignant expressions of grief ever put into musical form. The composer was moved to sorrow by more than the text of the ancient Easter hymn; the work was written in 1877, the year during which Dvorak lost two of his children.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- It takes unusual gifts of ingenuity to make the Indochina crisis worse than it is, but Washington has devised a number of ways of doing it.

THE only known pair of the United States 1857 12c black which is imperforate between will be sold here at auction on June 28. Normally, the 12c black is perforated fifteen all around, but in this used, horizontal pair there are no perforations whatever between the stamps.

MONTPELIER -- The first fact about Vermont is that it has become a legend. Its simple green beauty, its white houses under old trees, its sense of proportion and friendliness that never intrudes on privacy, its basic honesty -- these are some facets of the legend that has penetrated to every corner of America.

ALTHOUGH the house plants have been cheerful members of the family during the bleak months of winter and early spring, by early June they sometimes seem like relatives who have outstayed their welcome.

ALBANY, June 12 -- A marked change in the political outlook of both Republican and Democratic parties appears to have taken place between the adjournment of the regular legislative session last March and the convening of a special session this week.

THE televising of the Army-McCarthy hearings will stand for many years as a record for prolonged public service programming. For those networks and stations which carried the proceedings on a live basis for so many weeks a salute and a generous word of appreciation are very much in order.

MADISON, Wis., June 12 (AP) -- A stretch drive by the University of California crew failed by a few feet today as Wisconsin gained a half-second victory in a one and three-quarter mile race on Lake Mendota.
Silks, figuratively speaking, are coming off the walls to enhance the fashion wardrobe.

TWO gratifying decisions have been made by the Metropolitan Opera Association regarding its repertory for next season. The first is that the Metropolitan will not, in exchange for the $150,000 specified in the McNair Ilgenfritz will to accrue to the Metropolitan if one of his posthumous operas, is produced there within a specified period, accept this bequest or produce the work.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 12 (AP) -- The International Federation of Newspaper Publishers has urged lower air transport tariffs for newspapers, contending that newspapers could be considered easily perishable goods.

LONDON, June 12 (Reuters) -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, First Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, said in Prague, Czechoslovakia, today that a third world war would "end in disaster for the capitalist world."

GENEVA, June 11 -- Somewhere in Europe, within the next week or so, a central bank will add to its reserves the four billionth dollar of United States aid money that neither it nor any of its counterparts was supposed to get.

ALTHOUGH the hunting season is still several months off, a number of states that have organized "hunter safety" programs are beginning their preparations now. More than fourteen million hunters will tramp the woods, fields and marshes in the fall.
SALEM, N. H., June 12 (AP) -- Tony DeSpirito rode four winners today, including the daily double, at Rockingham Park.

THE suggestion that travelers should drink their way through Europe might seem extremely exhilarating but rather heady advice. It is indeed the former, yet by no means the latter. In fact, it is rational and temperate counsel, for of all the beverages encountered on a European tour, including water, tea, coffee, milk, beer, spirits and wine, the most frequently consumed and most rewarding -- the one best bet -- is wine.

The French Government of Premier Joseph Laniel has been in power for 351 days. Since Liberation only one other Government has lasted longer. But even by French standards it has been beset by an extraordinary number of extrardinarily difficult problems. At the top of the list is the problem of the Indochina war.

The National Community Relations Advisory Council released last week an eighty-eight-page report to serve as a guide for Jewish communities throughout the country in dealing with anti-Semitic incidents.
The first issue of bonds to be secured by the toll and other earnings of the New York Thruway is about to be placed on the public market.

In his sharpest form of the season, Whitey Ford pitched the Yankees to a 2-0 victory over the White Sox before a ladies' day crowd of 31,561 at the Stadium yesterday. Their second straight triumph over the Chicagoans put the surging third-place Bombers within two and a half games of the top spot in the American League standings, in which the Indians supplanted the White Sox.

HONOLULU -- There are several contradictions between the facts and the first-time tourist's foreknowledge of the Territory of Hawaii. Hawaii is not one island but eight islands, three of them so small as to be of no significance to the holidayer, but five of them really good-size pieces of fertile subtropical real estate.
The first nation-wide Civil Defense drill, scheduled to be held tomorrow, will reveal the vulnerability of the United States -- once an isolated continent -- to serious assault.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Do crime and horror "comic" books contribute to juvenile delinquency? The answer to that question is yes, no, or maybe, depending on the point of view of whoever is talking.

American shipbuilders believe that President Eisenhower's budget request of $81,600,000 in supplemental funds for merchant ship construction holds little promise for immediate aid to the industry's present depressed condition.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- Unemployment in the Chicago area is increasing but at a rate below that of the last six months, the monthly survey of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago indicated for May. The report said a comparison with national figures indicates the Chicago area is not fully absorbing employables and hiring is most selective.

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 12 -- Richard DiCamillo, a miler, of Mount Pleasant of Schenectady and Al Oerter of Sewanhaka High School, a discus thrower, established new records during the New York State Public High School Athletic Association track and field championships today.
PALERMO, Sicily, June 12 -- No account of Sicily would be complete without reference to her most baffling, persistent and misunderstood peculiarity -- the Mafia.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Much has been written about the colonial reconstruction at Williamsburg and Henry Ford's Greenfield Village, and very little about the New England equivalents of these throwbacks into American history.

An active week marks the waning auction season in most of the galleries this week. The Parke-Bernet Galleries, which have already held their last sale of art objects, furniture and decorations for interiors, will wind up the season with offerings for gardens and terraces.

THE first practicable means of tapping the vast power of the sun has now been developed. A few weeks ago, the research arm of the telephone company, the Bell Telephone Laboratories, demonstrated a solar battery -- an ingenious device that turns the energy of sunlight directly into a current of electricity.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 12 -- Harvard College, the nation's oldest, will open its 303d commencement week tomorrow with the first baccalaureate address of Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, who became president last September.
The Zim Israel America Lines is replacing older tonnage in its trans-Atlantic trade with postwar cargo vessels that have been operating on its other routes.

MILWAUKEE, June 12 (AP) -- Senator McCarthy said today that he thought some disagreement over major issues was good for a political party and cited the farm program as an instance where free discussion would benefit the nation.
BOSTON, June 12 (UP) -- Cisco Andrade of Compton, Calif., tonight scored a ninth-round technical knockout over Carlos Chavez of Los Angeles in a nationally televised bout at the Arena.

EUROPE'S first experimental hook-up of eight countries for the exchange of thirty programs in a month, dubbed "Eurovision," made a better start than the most sanguine of those connected with the complex arrangements deemed possible.

NEW DELHI, June 12 -- The Indian Government has decided to reimpose severe travel restrictions between the French settlements and Indian territory. An urgent communication to this effect is being sent to the French Government.

MOSCOW, Sunday, June 13 (AP) -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov has extended a welcoming hand to West Germany's Free Democrats, the second largest party in Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's West German coalition Government, it was disclosed today.

ONE of the recording events of 1952 was the release by Vox of Vivaldi's Op 3, a set of twelve concertos with the joint title "L'Estro Armonico." Rolf Reinhardt was the conductor and the leading violinist was Reinhold Barchet.

BILL WALTON was 15 when his mother died and he, with his little sister, went from America to live with their unknown grandmother in England. Although the move meant a bad wrench for Bill, he determined to make a success of his life there.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- On Labor Day week-end traffic will start to flow across the great Lower Tampa Bay Bridge, which has been constructed at a cost of more than $22,000,000 and which, as the years pass, is expected to change greatly the economic character of Florida's west coast.

MILWAUKEE, June 12 -- Jim Wilson, the 32-year-old warm weather pitcher, hurled his second victory today, his second shutout, and the first no-hitter of his career with a 2-0 triumph for the Milwaukee Braves over the Phillies.

IT is fitting that in June we should all june ahead with our summer vacation plans. It is amazing, also, the things you can learn from a dictionary. June is more than the month we are now in, devoted to brides and graduations; it is, in addition and when spelled with a lower-case J, an American verb, both transitive and intransitive, meaning to drive or go briskly.

ONCE again the season of possible drought approaches and gardeners everywhere are getting their watering equipment in order. Today even the lady of the house can get into the act, for much of the modern equipment is lightweight and easy to handle.

Mr. Phillips' observation that "a few Negro pupils can be integrated into a white school much more easily than a minority of whites can be put into a predominant Negro school" brings back memories when I. as a white child of 11, was moved from a predominantly white school in the Bronx to a predominantly Negro school (P. S. 89) in Harlem.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- With neither side expecting a clear-cut favorable verdict, the Army-McCarthy hearings will move on Monday into what almost certainly will be their final week.

" The Cultural Unity of Mankind" will be the theme of the second annual Friendship Week of the American-European Friendship Association, Inc., to be held from next Saturday through June 21 at the Roosevelt School in Stamford, Conn.
While the price-conscious public fumes over cost-of-living increases, corporate executives swing the cost-cutting axe to bolster earnings in the readjustment period.

Department store sales in the United States in the week ended June 5 were 18 per cent below the same week a year earlier, according to the Federal Reserve Board. For the week ended May 29 they were 8 per cent ahead, for the four weeks ended June 5 they were 6 per cent behind and for the year to date they were 3 per cent behind like periods a year ago.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 12 -- The Helen Keller Garden of the proposed Radcliffe Graduate Quadrangle was dedicated this afternoon.
DOVER, N. J., June 12 -- At least sixty persons were injured, a few seriously, late tonight when a section of the bleachers collapsed at the Dover Speedway here.

DESPITE the trend toward off-season holidays, summertime is still vacationtime for most people. Often the season catches up with us before we know it, with the decision about where to go still to be made. For procrastinators, troubled by the difficulty of making last-minute arrangements, the package tour is a godsend.
Diplomatic observers are studying signs of a somewhat more liberal Kremlin policy toward the culture and history of non-Russian minorities in the Soviet Union.
DES MOINES, June 12 (UP) -- The acting chairman of the Democratic Conference said today his party had won new strength because of the "record" of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

RETURNING to this city from a vacation in Spain, your correspondent found that the theatre list had been enriched in his absence by several interesting exhibits -- notably the delightful "The Teahouse of the August Moon," at which -- having forced an entry by blandishment, as no tickets were to be had through more usual channels -- he hastened to spend an enjoyable busman's holiday.

GENEVA, June 12 -- The United States Government has decided not to support American employer representatives in their advocacy of withdrawal from the International Labor Organization if Soviet "employer" delegates with their fight for credentials.
CHICAGO, June 12 (UP) -- The Research Council for Economic Security said today that the nation's public assistance programs put too much emphasis on relief and too little on rehabilitation.
HANOVER, N. H., June 12 -- A record class memorial gift of $150,100 was presented to Dartmouth College tonight by the class of '29, which is holding its twenty-fifth reunion.

Chess circles here have been entertained during the past two weeks by the experts engaged in the national championship tournament sponsored by the United States Chess Federation. The competition ends today with afternoon and evening matches at the Marshall Chess Club.

THE recent word that British Lion. Britain's largest film producing-distributing combine, had been thrown into receivership, has met with mixed reactions here. In film circles it was fairly generally known that the Government intended to put a receiver-manager into the British Lion Corporation to retrieve what remains of the 3,000,000 lent it six years ago.

The Library of Congress is possibly the greatest single collection of writings ever gathered together by the hand of man. Yet the House Appropriations Committee has just cut its annual operating budget by over half a million dollars and has reminded the new Librarian that this world-famous literary collection is "the creature of tile Congress."
The monopoly that the New York Athletic Club has been enjoying in the senior metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union track and field games since World War I received a bit of a threat yesterday.

IT was appropriate indeed that W. H. Auden, writing in this column last December, should cite William Butler Yeats first of all in speaking of the difficulties of the modern poet. For Yeats has been the true example and master of virtually every young poet in England and America for more than a generation, and his long poetic career, which lasted more than fifty years, continues to exert a special fascination.

THIS week house plants begin a three-month period of rejuvenation on my rooftop terrace in Manhattan. Since all house plants, even the indestructible sansevierias (I have none), benefit from al fresco living, every, Plant that can be accommodated on the terrace---about fifty--will summer outdoors.

THE Russian chess team, possibly the greatest collection of chess talent in the history of the game, is scheduled to play the American team in New York this week. Although our players are first rate by all chess standards, the Russians are favored to win; they haven't lost a match in postwar international competition.

Twice a day, Mondays through Fridays, at 9 A. M. and at 4:45 P. M., Charles W. Jedlicka, head of the marine news department of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, sends a long cablegram to Lloyd's of London.

ARTURO TOSCANINI, without the responsibility of heading an orchestra, flew to Italy last week. What his plans beyond the summer are, probably he himself does not know. It is said that he will return in the fall, and it may be that he will conduct a concert or two.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The business barometer has stopped falling. Though their talk is well laced with caution, the official economic doctors hereabouts are using the language of optimists.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 12 -- Sporadic showers made a shambles of top-flight tennis here today as the American women's team shut out the British, 6 to 0, in the twenty-sixth renewal of the Wightman Cup competition. A thin crowd of the faithful watched the play in the ivied Wimbledon crater. Fading light and more rain canceled the seventh match scheduled for the two-day series.

Dr. Harold P. Rusch, director of the McArdle Laboratory of the University of Wisconsin, and Dr. R. K. Boutwell have partly purified a substance in croton oil, a violent cathartic, that makes slow-growing tumors flare up rapidly into cancers.

MONTEAL -- Quebec's Laurentian Mountain resort areas have planned a major drive for rounding up summer-tourist business to help offset any possible slack winter season. The result is that the vacationing visitor will find a neat package of entertainment throughout the Laurentians this summer.

BOSTON -- Vacationists coming to Massachusetts this summer will find scenic proof that the state can provide a neatly packaged sample of most of the attractions to be found on a nation-wide tour. What is more, most of them may be covered in a single day of more or less leisurely travel.

ATALE of the Kentucky mountains, "Satan's Rock" is as simple as a ballad, as exciting as a boy's first love. Griff Ruk, at 17, lives in the shadow of Satan's Rock, a thickly wooded promontory that hangs out over a lush green valley.

THE HAGUE -- In a wild moment of understatement, the Netherlands National Tourist Office once put itself on record as saying, "The Dutch cuisine * * * can be placed between the German and French ones. It is inclined to be on the heavy side * * * ."

PENN YAN, N. Y. -- The Finger Lakes area is looking forward to another busy year. As in the past, its attractive scenery, varied recreational activities and points of historical interest are expected to attract tourists seeking a wholesome family vacation.

Alumni and friends of Stuyvesant High School will observe the school's fiftieth anniversary Tuesday evening at a dinner at the Commodore Hotel. The affair, which is being sponsored by the alumni association, will mark also the start of a fund drive to provide scholarship aid for deserving students.
ROME, June 12 -- Pope Pius XII proclaimed five new saints in a majestic outdoor ceremony in St. Peter's Square tonight. It was the last of two canonization rites of the Marian year.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- United States intervention in the Indochina war may still be a possibility, but the Administration appears to be moving in the opposite direction.

A DECADE after D-Day the Department of the Army has issued a big book which faithfully records a history of successful coalition warfare in Europe from the cross-Channel attack in the pre-dawn of June 6, 1944, to the surrender of Germany some eleven months later.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- Chicago's new Central Convention and Exhibits Building will be on the Lake Michigan shore near Six-teenth Street, according to plans approved this week by the Chicago Park District Board.

UNIONTOWN, Pa. -- Ten miles east of here, surrounded by some of the finest scenery in the Appalachians, stands old Fort Necessity, now restored as the National Park Service's newest historic shrine and scheduled to be dedicated formally over the Fourth of July week-end.

THE planting and raising of goose-pimples requires a certain theatrical skill which makes no demands whatsoever upon the season of the year. A green thumb in this department may be just as well exercised in the fail or in the winter as it may be in the spring.

Tonight in New Haven, Yale-in-China, with the collaboration of the university authorities and the China Institute, will celebrate an unusual anniversary. It is the centennial of the graduation from Yale of Yung Wing, the first Chinese to obtain a degree from a Western university.

CONCORD, N. Y. -- The vacation specialists of New Hampshire -- the innkeepers, hotel managers, and motel entrepreneurs -- are real professionals whose expertise last year paid off in a second straight record-breaking season.

SASKATOON, Sask., June 12 -- Plans to carry out cosmic ray research by huge balloons flown over Saskatchewan by scientists from the United States Office of Naval Research have again been set back by high winds above the great plains of the prairie.
THIS is a competently written novel about a proper, and a slightly improper, Bostonian, which mainly concerns a woman's search for love, acceptance and security in a world of utter loneliness.

AN increasing amount of metal is being used by contemporary furniture designers in this country. Because metal is easy to fabricate by machine, it is particularly well adapted to American production methods. And a wide variety of metals is now available which the designer can experiment with.

FOUR HUNDRED years ago an Indian boy's rabbit hunt was interrupted by an event of such consequence that, in time, all Hopiland was changed. Using this Hopi legend of Chief Jaro's boyhood enslavement by Coronado's men, Margaret Phelps spins one of her best colorful, informative tales of our Southwest.

City College's Morris Raphael Cohn scholarship for 1954, a $100 grant for graduate study, has been awarded to Peter Sugar and Kenneth A. Forde. The scholarship is provided by students in memory of the late philosopher, who taught at City College for thirty-six years.
WORCESTER, Mass., June 12 -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall of Massachusetts was endorsed by acclamation today for the Republican nomination for election to a third term.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 (AP) -- Gus Zernial of the Philadelphia Athletics was find $250 today for a dugout row with Manager Eddie Joost, creating a situation that could result in trading of the outfielder or firing of the manager.
CINCINNATI, June 12 -- Bud Podbielan held the Dodgers to five singles today while the Redlegs collected thirteen hits, including a home run and four doubles, to win, 5 -- 1.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., June 12 (AP) -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. picked up today the support of five more upstate Democratic county chairmen in his drive for the Governorship nomination.

IF the swimming pool is coming to be the sine qua non of American resort hotels, that is as it should be. For Americans on vacation have from the earliest days shown a predilection for bathing of one sort or another. They were dunking themselves in water at the leading edge of the nineteenth century and they are doing it still.

UTICA, N. Y., June 12 (UP) -- The State Democratic chairman declared today that Governor Dewey's claim of "record peacetime prosperity" represented the "well-known Hitlerian technique of repeating a lie so often that people will believe it."

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. -- During the past twenty-one years the Tennessee Valley Authority has been building a series of massive artifacts that spell out something of the history of Twentieth Century man. These modern "pyramids" of concrete, steel and whirring turbines are designed mainly to generate vast quantities of electrical magic.
ST. LOUIS, June 12 (UP) -- Dick Littlefield pitched a six-hitter tonight to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 4-to-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

Some one of the growing seasons of the year, usually summer, inevitably has a dry spell and often a drought. Then, unless local ordinances forbid, gardeners must resort to artificial watering or irrigation. Sound practices and timing for the East, where normal annual precipitation averages thirty-six to forty-two inches, and for the Southwest, where the annual precipitation is fifteen inches or less. are discussed below by expert gardeners from each area.

The world wheat markets were thrown into confusion last week. In an effort to lighten burdensome stocks by increasing export sales of the grain, the United States and Canada embarked on a bit of price cutting.

" A DREAMY backward youth" is the central figure and -- turned urgently nostalgic through the years intervening between the period covered by the book and its later date of composition -- the first-person narrator of "The Charm of Hours."

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics rallied for three runs in the eighth inning today to break a tie and defeat the Detroit Tigers, 4 -- 2, but newly-acquired Sonny Dixon had to go in in the ninth to retire the final man with the bases loaded.

VIRGINIA CITY, Nev. -- For a good many years now a local civic project, or what comes as close to being one as possible in a community where civic consciousness is practically an unknown quantity, has been the abatement of the belief that Jenny Lind once sang in Piper's Opera House here.
WATERTOWN -- The picturesque Thousand Islands section of northern New York, one of the state's traditional playgrounds, is greatly increasing its facilities this year.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Defense Department has completed its first omnibus revision of the Uniform Code of Military Justice and will soon submit its proposals to Congress.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 12 (AP) -- Illinois Republicans, at their state convention today, adopted a platform that praised President Eisenhower and took no stand on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, the Bricker Amendment or the Indochina situation.

LONDON, June 12 -- Spokesmen for the Government, spurred by the defeat of the French Government and the looming failure of the Geneva conference, warned tonight that the time of decision involving "hideous" risks was approaching.

LONDON, June 12 (UP) -- John Haines of Pennsylvania and MacAllister Booth of Cornell won two races each today to lead a combined track and field team from the two universities to a 9-6 victory over Oxford and Cambridge.

This year's college graduates will not have much difficulty getting jobs. Not only are jobs available in most fields, but the salaries are higher than they were a year ago, according to a survey made by this department.
