LONDON, June 12 (AP) -- Britain's National Council of Civil Liberties today sought "political asylum" here for a young American doctor and his doctor-wife who have been ordered to leave the country.
IT might be said that the month of June belongs to the rose. For across the land, the queen of the month is enthroned in gardens, festivals and flower shows everywhere.
Every day more than 1,000,000 Gothamites ride over a good part of their city in John E. McCarthy's buses.

PARIS, June 12 -- The Laniel Government is the first since World War II to receive an adverse vote based officially and perhaps mainly on foreign policy. The vote came in the midst of the greatest foreign crisis that has faced France since that war.
" The portable radio, within two years, is to be the size of a package of cigarettes. A few years more and the wrist radio will emerge from the laboratory and the comic strips to full-scale reality."

MONTICELLO -- Although many of Sullivan County's 40.000 residents spend their time ministering to 610,922 hens, non-paying guests at 600 of the world's largest chicken farms, more of them are concerned with the care and comfort of some 4,000,000 annual paying guests of the county's vast and energetic resort industry.

IN a world of spiders, even Man may act arachnid. Marguerite Cranleigh, time-traveler to an inconceivably distant future, finds herself in the body of Gleda, a captive girl. Her captor, Lemno, frees her and makes her his wife by killing his former mate; then the two eat her.

The finger foods of summertime should be quite as beguiling as summer itself -- pretty to the eye, pleasant on the palate and, all in all, a thoroughly appetizing accent to a long, cold drink. Those presented here are the inspiration of Miss Irma Rhode, the cookbook author ("Viennese Cooking Cook-book for Fridays and Lent").

THE International Rollei Jubilee Competition to commemorate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the introduction in 1929 of the Rolleiflex and Rolleicord cameras, the first of the twin-lens reflex cameras, is announced by the manufacturers, Franke Heidecke of Braunschweig, Germany.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 12 -- Armagh drowsed in the sun; on the Mall cricketers were at play. At Portadown, twenty miles away, half the policemen in the county stood on parade for the ceremonial visit of the Governor of Northern Ireland, Lord Wakehurst.

As a result of changes in the nation's medical and health needs, the nursing profession is faced with new responsibilities. The acute shortage of professional nurses is causing many hospitals, clinics and other agencies to reorganize their nursing service and to base training on improved concepts of patient care.

HARTFORD, June 12 -- Connecticut Republican leaders have made two efforts in the last few days to settle a party feud that has existed during the entire administration of Gov. John Davis Lodge, but the conflict still exists.

FEW other summer-flowering bulbs can equal the dramatic effects of gladiolus if they are planted with a little imagination. Too often gardeners plunk them in long stiff rows that look so much like a factory assembly line.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The United States is expected to issue a call next week for a special hemispheric conference of foreign ministers on the threat of Communist-infiltrated Guatemala.
SANTIAGO, Chile, June 12 -- According to a message from Chile's Minister to Turkey, the Cominform has instructed Communist leaders in Chile to stage activities against the Government.

OKLAHOMA CITY, June 12 -- Two of Oklahoma's most prominent political figures, whose backgrounds were almost identical, were locked this week in a bitter struggle to win the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate.

NEW HAVEN, June 12 -- Western scientists at the rededication of the Pulkovo Observatory outside Leningrad saw and heard little new, Dirk Brouwer, Professor of Natural Philosophy and Astronomy at Yale University, said today.

The American Society for Testing Materials reported yesterday that it expects 2,400 engineers and technical experts on materials to attend the fifty-seventh annual meeting of the society, opening today and continuing through Friday at Chicago.

IN her latest novel, "The Royal Box," Frances Parkinson Keyes turns her prolific pen to the "suspense story." Baldwin Castle, the American Ambassador to "Aristan," is, after a party in the royal box of a London theatre, suddenly murdered.

RICHMOND, June 12 -- Department store trade in the Fifth Reserve District continues to show a moderate decline compared with the same time last year although the cumulative volume for the year is off only 2 per cent. Business loans also continue to drop off moderately. Most Carolina textile mills will close for the annual vacation period for a week following the July 4 holiday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 12 -- Tension between Ecuador and Peru caused representatives of the United States, Argentina, Brazil and Chile to appeal today for both countries to try to calm their public opinion.

BONN, Germany, June 12 -- The West German Government announced tonight the establishment of a "coordinating committee" to centralize political information made available to the press and to control the disbursement of funds in this connection.

MOUNT POCONO, Pa. -- An old-timer who remembers the trainloads of ice that used to pull out of here every day in summer before the advent of electric refrigeration would probably be astonished were he to return today.

To criticize Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer for "lack of enthusiasm" for the hydrogen bomb is the kind of official attitude "customary in Russia" but regarded in the United States as "morally reprehensible," the American Physical Society declared yesterday.

IN Boston's Public Gardens countless visitors file through a series of big tents where are displayed some 350 examples of paintings, sculpture and graphic art by artists who work in the New England states. The walls of the tents are raised permitting of access as free as the admission and the comment of the visitors.

The New York Public Library's exhibition of letters, diaries and manuscripts of the poet Percy Bysshe Shelley, his wife, Mary, and their circle will be extended to June 23. The exhibit, in the Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street building, was scheduled to close in mid-month.

TRENTON -- Significant anniversaries are being observed this year by three of the fifty-five resort communities that dot the white sandy shore of New Jersey south of Sandy Hook. Atlantic City is celebrating its centennial, Long Branch its golden jubilee and Ocean City its seventy-fifth birthday.
Eight graduates of Columbia University's School of Architecture have received traveling fellowships that will enable them to continue their studies in Europe in the next academic year.

MONTICELLO -- One of the powers in the Sullivan County hotel business stood the other day in the monumental front entrance of his Queen Mary-style lobby. He gazed off into the middle distance, where workmen were pouring concrete for an extension of that lobby.

ONE hundred and seventy-seven years ago tomorrow the second Continental Congress assembled in Philadelphia's State House passed a routine resolution providing: "That the Flag of the thirteen united states be thirteen stripes, alternate red and white; that the Union be thirteen stars, white in a blue field, representing a new constellation.''

A critical study of the educational needs of the professional designer has been started at the Parsons School of Design, 136 East Fifty-seventh Street, New York City. The study is being conducted with the aid of a grant from the Fund for the Advancement of Education, a Ford Foundation unit.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 -- A decline in industrial activity in Pennsylvahia during April has been offset by an expansion in general business, says the Bureau of Business Research of Pennsylvania State University. The expansion was 5 per cent from March to April, and new records for April were noted for life insurance sales, postal receipts, building operations and telephones.

A total of 2,548 academic degrees and certificates will be awarded to graduating students at City College's 108th commencement on Wednesday night. The exercises, which will begin at 8 o'clock, will be held in the college's Lewishon Stadium, 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, and will be preceded by an academic procession along Convent Avenue.

HARRISON, N. Y., June 12 -- An imported wire-haired fox terrier turned back the strong challenge of an imported miniature poodle for best in show at the Greenwich Kennel Club event at the Blind Brook Polo Club today.

Rocky Marciano will defend his heavyweight championship of the world against Ezzard Charles, former titleholder from Cincinnati, in a 15-round bout at the Yankee Stadium on Thursday night, with the local area blacked out to television, the clash promises to attract a crowd of 30,000 fans and a gate of $500,000, according to Jim Norris, president of the International Boxing Club.
SPRINGFIELD, N. J., June 12 -- Ben Hogan, who next Thursday will begin the defense of his United States open golf title at the Baltusrol Golf Club, today set a competitive record for the layout.

PAR LAGERKVIST, who won the Nobel Prize in 1951 and is highly esteemed in Sweden as the author of over thirty-five books in nearly all the literary forms, is little known in this country, his work in translation until now having been limited to two short novels, "The Dwarf" (1945) and "Barrabas" (1951).
A vast expansion in the volume of United States foreign trade moving by air is believed to be in prospect.

FULL of the hot summertime sunshine of a small town in Kentucky thirty years ago, this episodic story conveys the wonderful feeling of affection and understanding between Mary Lizbeth and her best-friend-and-severest-critic, Lyssus.

RICHARD D. BUCKLEY, apparently is no trend follower. In a television age when broadcasting's major effort is placed on the sight-and-sound medium, he and four business associates recently put up $2,100,000 in cash to purchase WNEW, sometimes called New York City's 50,000 watt juke box.

VANCOUVER, B. C. -- This mountain-rimmed metropolis beside the Pacific Ocean expects at least 100,000 visitors when the quadrennial British Empire Games are held here during the midsummer period of July 30 to Aug. 7. It is the first time in history that this athletic event, second in scope only to the Olympic Games, has been scheduled for the western part of the North American continent.

PARIS -- This city can be one mass of problems. Hotel heating is often ineffective and taxis sometimes overcharge. Changing currency is always a worry and laundries work slowly. But the most delicious dilemma of all is the one that seems to arise every evening as you sit on your cafe terrasse with an aperitif: Where to eat?
Is it too late to plead for a better and more sober understanding of the deeper reasons of the present divergencies between American and British policies in Asia, and at the Geneva Conference ?

If one could rise to the Olympian heights of a Toynbee and view all recorded history, six thousand years of it, as contemporary history, then Cheops, his pyramid and his solar boats, might not seem so far "out of this world."

THE problem of unhappy children in conflict with society or with themselves, often characterized as juvenile delinquency, has grown alarmingly in the past year. In Manhattan the rate of teen-age crimes has been estimated at three times the average for all U. S. cities.

ONE of the oldest -- yet youngest -- nations of the Atlantic community celebrates its Independence Day this week. It was just ten years ago Thursday, when Allied troops so recently landed at Normandy were in the eleventh, day of their push to liberate Europe, that Iceland became for the second time in its history an independent republic.

United States High Commissioner Conant, Cabinet members of the Bonn Government and high officials of West Berlin will participate in dedicating the first central building of the Free University of West Berlin on June 19. The Free University has been functioning in fifty small scattered structures.

AUGUSTA, Me., -- Visitors to Maine will not lack for entertainment this season. More than 100 special events, ranging from food festivals to horse races, are scheduled between now and the end of September in communities all over the state.
NEWARK, June 12 -- A run-off election for nine Council seats in the new city government will be held here next Tuesday.
TORONTO, June 12 -- A United States professional golf team scored its third straight Hopkins Trophy victory over Canada today by 41 1/2 to 21 1/2 points.
MILWAUKEE, June 12 (UP) -- Mr. Michael said Senator McCarthy's record showed "neither honesty, integrity nor decency."

MOSCOW, Sunday, June 13 (AP) -- Two "American spies" have been sentenced to twenty - five years each in prison by the Supreme Court of the Soviet Union, Pravda announced today. The Communist party newspaper said the two men had been spirited into Murmansk with the aid of Norwegian officials.

STANTON, Del., June 12 (AP) -- The Wheatley Stable's Full Flight, second in last week's Kent, came back today with a popular victory in the seventeenth and richest Leonard Richards Stakes before 23,905 fans at Delaware Park.

NEW HAVEN, June 12 -- Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale University, is scheduled to speak on progress of the Yale Alumni Fund tomorrow noon at the annual alumni luncheon. More than 2,000 alumni are attending class reunions here.

IF vacationists in this country follow the pattern set in recent years the majority of them will once again make the national parks the most popular tourist attractions in the country. But in the Eastern states, where national parks are few and far between, tourists turn to other places for sight-seeing and recreation, with a noticeable emphasis on sites with historic associations.
VANCOUVER, B. C., June 5 -- Canada's 40,000 Chinese are wondering when they can bring their remaining relatives from China.

Anesthetic gases may explode when they are ignited by a spark, which is easily generated by the friction of shoe bottoms on a dry floor on a cold winter day. The architects who design hospitals and the administrators who run them know this and take precautions.

WASHINGTON THE distinguished board which has reviewed the charges against Dr. Oppenheimer has now reported, and the situation is therefore open to discussion. But this particular case is only part of the whole situation, and it marks a trend which is disheartening in this democracy of ours.

DAR ES. SALAAM, Tanganyika, June 8 -- When a United Nations investigating commission visits this trust territory, the Negro natives' representatives will call attention to the fact that their opportunities for education are limited.

AN interesting presentation of the history, development political problems of the Moslem world, "Moslems on the March" will open new vistas for most Americans. It is a book written for the laymen, not for the experts.

CHARLOTTETOWN, Prince Edward Island -- This is land tucked away in the Gulf of St. Lawrence lies only a short distance offshore from New Brunswick and Nova Scotia. Yet it is only in the last few years that any considerable number of tourists coming into Canada's Maritime Provinces have found their way to it across the Northumberland Strait.

A COUPLE of weeks before the close of this academic year there could be seen on the door of a small stationery shop near Columbia University a roughly lettered sign which read: THE LONELY CROWD IS IN. This referred to Mr. David Riesman's chief work, now a best seller in the paper-bound Anchor edition.
DES MOINES, June 12 (AP) -- Midwestern Democratic leaders decided at a strategy conference here today to make the farm issue the dominant theme of the fall Congressional campaign in this region.

FOR years after Ben Hecht's departure from Chicago there were legends about him. Before I was out of grammar school I had already read "1001 Afternoons in Chicago." and in high school I combed the secondhand bookstores for his other works, "Erik Dorn," "Humpty Dumpty," "Gargoyles." "Broken Necks" and "Count Bruga."

WHEN a Victorian chaise longue somehow takes on the magic properties of a time machine there is only one era to which it can logically return its occupant, to the age of lavender, bric-a-brac, sealed windows and serious family skeletons.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- Two new treaties were approved here last week which tourism experts promise will do much to smooth the traveler's' way through customs inspections and also make it easier and simpler for motorists to take their cars across frontiers.

PROVIDENCE, R. I. -- To cynical outlanders, Rhode Island may be little more than a fringe of land around Narragansett Bay. This slighting opinion, however, is of little concern to Rhode Islanders, who are for the most part quite happy to have such an excellent water playground right in their front yard, so to speak.

TO Communist leaders everywhere the mass rally is a traditional propaganda tool of tested value. It has the simple virtue of providing a built-in claque for a show organized with an eye to world-wide press notices.

HARTFORD, Conn. -- Connecticut's summer vacation resorts are looking forward to one of their best seasons, according to a survey of resort owners in various parts of the state. These report that advance reservations and inquiries are high.
GUATEMALA, June 12 -- A United Fruit Company official said today that an agreement had been reached with workers to end the strike that began May 20.

IN March, 1943, a message came to Peenemunde on the Pomeranian coast where V-2 rockets were being developed. "The Fuehrer has dreamed that no V-2 will ever reach England," it ran. There was consternation.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Leaders of both parties predicted today Senate approval of an extension of the 20-year-old reciprocal trade program, which expires at midnight.

YOU forget the chilling drizzle that lasted two days, but remember the music of rain pinging against taut canvas as you await sleep. The poison ivy rash heals and time dulls the memory of insecticide-resistant mosquitoes.

WESTFIELD, N. J., June 12 -- Edward Taylor of 603 Hillcrest Avenue, former president and now vice chairman of the board of Smith, Kirkpatrick Co. in New York, exporters and importers, will be honored Thursday as the dean of commuters of the Central Railroad of New Jersey.
With attention focused on problems of Southeast Asia, the American Press Institute of Columbia University opened yesterday a seminar for fourteen newspaper editors from that part of the world.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 1 -- In what must be one of the cleanest factory buildings in industrial America, the soft coal industry is trying these days to make something more of its product.

HONG KONG, June 12 -- The war in Indochina, where this reporter has spent the last six weeks, is clearly political as well as military. Although the fall of Dienbienphu on May 7 has been followed by a military lull, the war has gone on unabated in the political sphere, with the Communist-led Vietminh forces continuing to win psychological victories.

TRENTON -- The recent announcement that the Garden State Parkway will be open from Irvington to Atlantic City by Aug. 1 is welcome, if delayed, news for thousands of New Yorkers and New Jerseyites planning to vacation along the shore from Sandy Hook to Cape May.

An important mile of the eleven-mile-long Brooklyn-Queens Expressway will be opened to traffic June 22. The new section will enable mixed traffic to bypass congested downtown Brooklyn. It completes the direct route from the intersection of the Gowanus Parkway and the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel approach to the modernized Brooklyn Bridge.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13 -- Dr. Nathan M. Pusey today told Harvard College seniors that their generation had seen little public conduct that "deserved either admiration or respect."

PRESQUE ISLE, Me., June 11 -- The Air Force's newest heavy bombardment base within the United States, equipped with the largest kown intercontinental bombers, now is in full-scale training operations near here.

LONDON, June 13 -- The necessity of finding a new means of rearming West Germany is advanced by influential Government sources as a principal reason for arranging early United States-British discussions of basic policies in Europe and Asia.

Several persons with whom I have talked have received an incorrect inference from that recent Executive directive -- namely: "The Executive branch of the Government has the sole and fundamental responsibility under the Constitution for the enforcement of our laws and Presidential orders."
ROME, June 13 -- Florence began today its celebration of the 500th anniversary of the birth of Amerigo Vespucci, who gave America its name.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (UP) Watson Rogers, president of the National Food Brokers Association, said today the future never had been brighter for independent grocers who followed modern sales practices.

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 13 -- The "watch-minded" Swiss are worried about what President Eisenhower will do with the recommendations of the United States Tariff Commission that import duties on Swiss watches be raised 50 per cent.

OSSINING, N. Y., June 13 -- Fifty-three young Men of Maryknoll, fifty priests and three brothers, pledged themselves this afternoon to a lifetime of missionary work in Asia, Africa and Latin America. The occasion was the thirty-seventh annual departure ceremony at Maryknoll, major seminary of the Maryknoll Fathers under the Roman Catholic Foreign Misionary Society of America.
Retailers are not permitting talk of a business setback to dull their optimism.

CAIRO, June 13 -- Eric Johnston, President Eisenhower's special ambassador to the Middle East, began a series of meetings today with Arab experts on proposals for integrated development of the Jordan River valley's water resources.
The National Council of American Importers announced over the week-end that it was opposed to a proposed increase of duty-free allowances for Americans returning from abroad.
ROME, June 13 -- Pope Pius XII attended today the first mass in honor of the five new saints he canonized yesterday.

SINGAPORE, June 13 (AP) -- A thousand students, staging the second sit-down strike at the Chung Cheng Chinese High School here in less than a month to protest compulsory military service, defied their parents and advisers today.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Bob Porterfield of the Washington Senators held Baltimore to six hits in winning his seventh game, 4 -- 0, today after the Orioles collected fourteen hits to take the opener of a doubleheader, 6 -- 4.

PARIS, June 13 -- The cuts in wheat prices by the United States and Canada have had their effect here. The Ministry of Agriculture has announced that a decrease in the legally set price of wheat -- the first since the war -- must be made this year.
PHILADELPHIA, June 13 -- When a utility outboard can cover ninety-six river miles up and downstream in just over 2 hours 10 minutes, that's news in the speedboat regatta world.
The American Federation of Labor is cool to moves by one of its affiliates to take the left-wing International Fur and Leather Workers Union into the federation.

A ready source of information on foods and cookery, the new "Handbook of Food Preparation," could be as helpful to the practical homemaker as to the professional home economist for whom it is intended primarily.

Debt service was made in full last year on $3,277,168,303 of $4,479,918,914 of publicly offered foreign dollar bonds outstanding on Dec. 31, 1953, according to a study issued yesterday by the Institute of International Finance of New York University.

A rapid transit tunnel under the Hudson River to connect New Jersey railroads with the local subway system at Fourteenth Street was advocated yesterday by the Regional Plan Association. The plan has two basic purposes, the association said.
MADRID, June 13 -- Abundant rainfall and cool temperatures in most of Spain are expected to produce an "excellent cereal crop," according to reports published today.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said in his sermon yesterday: "One of the greatest weaknesses of democracy is that able and unscrupulous men who understand the psychology of the mass-mind can whip up the worst passions of men and women and then use them for their own selfish ends."
CINCINNATI, June 13 -- Belting four three-run homers in the two games, the Dodgers today swept a double-header with the Redlegs, 6 -- 5 and 14 -- 2, before a Crosley Field crowd of 29,764.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Washington's Board of Trade is out to find new businesses for the nation's capital city. Not any old business, but something that will employ a lot of people without using smokestacks or raising fumes that could damage the foliage in the tree-lined streets.

WALTHAM, Mass., June 13 (AP) -- Dr. Abram L. Sachar, president of Brandies University, described Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer today in a commencement speech "as surely one of the most uneducated educated men of our time."

There is no way to put a pleasant, favorable, or even reasonably hopeful, face on the present French Cabinet crisis. The acceptance of Premier Laniel's resignation by President Rene Coty comes precisely at a time when there is need for a strong French authority in Paris, in Saigon and in Geneva.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy has been informed by one of his ardent supporters that large numbers of Europeans believe that the United States is in the throes of a neo-Nazi movement headed by a potential Hitler, namely Senator McCarthy.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (UP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. was accused today of intensifying the "wetback" problem in his efforts to solve it.

Eight hundred persons attended yesterday the sixtieth commencement of the Jewish Theological Seminary at 3080 Broadway. Forty degrees -- two of them honorary -- were awarded at a ceremony held in the seminary quadrangle.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Federal Reserve System's independence is showing.
President Eisenhower pledged the United States yesterday to continue to do all it could to help the Baltic states of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania recover their independence.

According to recent press reports, a Chinese Communist spokesman has hinted at Geneva that his Government may be willing to exchange Americans imprisoned in China for Chinese students who wish to return to the Chinese mainland.

MEXICO CITY, June 13 -- The Guatemalan Embassy here released today the text a message of support and sympathy sent to the Guatemalan Government May 29 by Gen. Lazaro Cardenas, former President of Mexico.

Any doubt that the Liberal party will continue as a legal political party was ended yesterday when its officers issued a call for a meeting of its executive committee on June 28 to fix the time and place for its state convention.

LONDON, June 13 -- British Treasury officials will go to Paris tomorrow to make preparations for major talks on convertibility to be held here next month. The group will be led by Sir Leslie Rowan, second secretary in charge of overseas financial matters.

Pressure to rush the Coliseum spotlights a project of even greater need -- namely, a municipal stadium to cover a useful span of 100 years or more and to seat possibly 125,000. For successful precedent there are stadia of the kind needed here in Philadelphia, Chicago and Los Angeles.
Bellevue Hospital is a great city hospital dealing with the ills and problems of humans. But yesterday the talk there was of a grayish-white dog -- name and breed unknown.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- President Eisenhower returned tonight from a week-end in Maryland's Catoctin Mountains. He and Mrs. Eisenhower arrived at the White House at 7:40 P. M. after a two-hour drive.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 13 -- Princeton University's class of '54 was told today not to be intimidated by attacks upon intellectualism.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 13 -- A five-year plan providing minimum investments of $1,900,000,000 for the rehabilitation of the Republic of Korea was made public today.

Kilts tossed to the skirl of bagpipes at Fordham campus in the Bronx yesterday as contestants in the twenty-second annual Feis matched footwork and knowledge of Celtic lore. The cultural festival had been arranged by the United Irish Counties Association of New York.

PARIS, June 13 (AP) -- France has had nineteen Cabinets, headed by thirteen different men, since Gen. Charles de Gaulle established himself as head of the Government in September, 1944, after the liberation of Paris.

DOVER, N. J., June 13 -- The count of injured in the collapse of a section of the bleachers at the reopened Dover Speedway last night mounted to eighty-seven today. Eleven persons were still under hospital care.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- A possible showdown on President Eisenhower's public housing program looms this week on the floor of the House of Representatives.

Three young pianists and a violinist have won engagements to make orchestral appearances at young people's concerts next season as a result of their playing last season in the broadcast series, "Musical Talent in Our Schools," jointly sponsored by radio station WQXR and The New York Times.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 13 -- Soviet Nurse Sokolova Stanislawa Rapoles, who refused to return to the Soviet Union after having been treated for typhus at Thorshavn Hospital, arrived in Copenhagen today. The 23-year-old Lithuanian-born nurse served with the Soviet herring fleet at the Faeroe Islands.

RYE, N. Y., June 13 -- Light air and shifting winds tested the skill of the sailors today as the New York Yacht Club conducted the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta. The largest fleet of the season, 104 craft, took part. Included were three twelve-meters and twenty-one Internationals.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 13 -- Sir Laurence Olivier and Vivien Leigh, his wife, are considering an offer by Columbia to appear in "Joseph and His Brethren."
VIENNA, June 13 -- Czechoslovakia, like Hungary, is to have her nationalized economy more closely coordinated with that of the Soviet Union.
East Coast tramp shipping found ready customers last week in coal shippers looking for tonnage to pick up cargoes before the miners begin their annual holiday, which runs from June 25 until July 26.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 13 (AP) -- Guatemalan exiles, eager for their country to throw off its leftist Government, say 1954 is "the year of independence from Russian imperialism."
Brooklyn College conferred degrees on 2,160 graduates yesterday at its twenty-ninth commencement. Seven thousand guests attended the exercises on the campus quadrangle.

LONDON, June 13 -- The stock markets last week suffered a relapse -- moderate, it is true, but nevertheless quite a distinct setback. And, for this change in the pattern of the markets. Wall Street has been largely to blame, although what appears to be some deterioration in the international political situation has also had an adverse effect on sentiment and security prices.

In voices ranging from the treble of childhood to a rich baritone, five boys, 12 to 16 years old, preached brief sermons yesterday at the West End Collegiate Church, West End Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street.

LONDON, June 13 -- Aneurin Bevan, criticizing official Labor party policy over German rearmament, said today the controversy within the party was dangerous because it would seem to make people believe "that our safety against war depended on whether or not there was a German war machine." Mr. Bevan, left-wing party leader, spoke at Glascow.

HANOI, Vietnam, June 13 -- Rebel guerrillas ripped up 200 yards of the Hanoi-Haiphong rail line eleven miles east of Hanoi last night. They used the twisted steel of the rails to barricade the paralleling road and scrawled mud warnings on the road that they intended to "kill all French."

The first nation-wide civil defense test will subject the continental United States, Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands to theoretical nuclear attack this morning. Canada also will participate.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Laws that inflict automatic penalties on parents for the delinquency of their children are strongly opposed in a report issued today by the Federal Children's Bureau.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The stage was set tonight for the first public test of the effort to strip Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of his key Senate chairmanships unless he answers lorg-standing questions about his personal finances.
PALERMO, Sicily, June 12 -- The island of Sicily has life, vigor and high morale. This is new in its modern history, for it has been a depressed and oppressed area for many centuries.
HANOVER, N. H., June 13 -- Dartmouth College conferred degrees on 557 students at commencement exercises this morning that closed its 185th academic year.
MILWAUKEE, June 13 (UP) -- The Milwaukee Braves followed up Jim Wilson's no-hit triumph with a 9-5 victory today over the Philadelphia Phillies and a sweep of the three-game series.
NEW HAVEN, June 13 -- The Yale University Alumni Fund received contributions of $975,000 in the last year, Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, university president, said at the annual alumni luncheon today.
PITTSBURGH, June 13 -- A new series of peace conferences in the seven-month-old department store strike here was scheduled today by Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

The police seized 500 cases of fireworks here yesterday. The seizure capped a three-week investigation touched off when Bronx youth gangs began using illegal "cherry bombs" to divert attention from actual gunfire. The cherry-size bombs explode noisily when hurled to the ground.

The hot days are upon us. Once again families go down to the shore, to the wide white beaches, seeking coolness and relaxation. Some seem to like the throngs, the color and clamor of a crowded day at the beach. To others, the beaches are most enjoyable when they are least crowded, and he counts himself lucky who can take his family to the shore on a weekday when others are hard at work.
GENEVA, June 13 -- Talks here seeking a solution for Korea have reached a crucial stage. A final decision on whether they will be broken off is due by tomorrow.
Foreign exchanges idled through a quiet trading week. With transfers limited in volume price changes were minor in size. Absence of demand reflected the usual mid-month lack of interest.

Three out of the 852 Annapolis students who received their diplomas on Friday, June 4, had to wait a week before they also received their commissions in the Navy. The delay was due to the Navy's inability to make up its mind as to whether these three young men, who had passed every mental and moral test for admission to the Academy and during four years of study there, were good "security risks."

Slow but perceptible progress in 1953 toward greater equality for all Americans regardless of race, creed or origin was reported yesterday in a joint survey by the American Jewish Congress and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
Vagrancy charges were lodged by the police yesterday against a man who was shot Saturday night in front of Madison Square Garden. He was wounded by a sniper who fired a rifle from a hotel window.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $76,784,135,011. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Mural Properties, Inc., bought for investment the apartment house for twenty-four families at 1019 Trinity Avenue, the Bronx, from Edward J. Byrne, former architect, who altered the building about ten years ago. Peter A. Clancy was the broker.

May I be so bold as to suggest that the plan of Governor Dewey to rehabilitate the Long Island Rail Road is at best a temporary stopgap. The long, turbulent history of this railroad shows clearly that as long as the Pennsylvania Railroad is in the picture the riding public will continue to suffer.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 13 -- Although capital traffic within the Benelux countries probably will be liberalized next month, there will be safeguards regarding undue capital export outside Benelux and issues by public bodies.
The Rot-Weiss team of Germany and Olaria of Brazil played a 2-to-2 tie at Randalls Island yesterday in one of the best soccer performances of the season here. A crowd of 8,931 turned out.
Nine new films, including imports from England, France, Australia and Russia, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

CASEY STENGEL had been recounting with gusto and gestures the episode of the day before when Nellie Fox had slid hard into second base on a take-out play. It almost precipitated a fight involving Fox, Jerry Coleman and Phil Rizzuto.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UP) -- A nonprofit organization, headed by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, said that it would complain to the Federal Communications Commission that the Mutual Broadcasting System had given too much free time to friends of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
With the exception of the May delivery, cotton prices on the New York Cotton Exchange last week again closed slightly lower.

For years the essays of Arthur F. Burns in the annual reports of the National Bureau of Economic Research have been joyfully accepted by the world of economics. Dr. Burns took upon himself the labor of explaining that Keynes was not merely a nasty word -- a handy political symbol for a centrally managed economy.

SIOUX FALLS, S. D., June 13 (AP) -- Senator McCarthy told the Legionnaires that American dollars "are directly fashioning bullets which may well cause the death of some of the young men in this audience."

SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 13 (AP) -- Debate over the advisability of limiting world cotton production was predicted here yesterday at the thirteenth meeting of the International Cotton Advisory Committee.

A plot of vacant land at 539-47 West Fifty-first Street and 546-50 West Fifty-second Street has been sold by the Micmar Realty Company to the 402 East 101st Street Realty Corporation for improvement. It is 75 by 100 feet and was sold through the Cross Brown Company, broker.

SEOUL, June 13 (Reuters) -- President Syngman Rhee today ordered $17,000,000 in currency printed, as government officials charged that "slowness" of United States aid had stepped up circulation of the hwan.
Governor Dewey, a director of the New York Heart Association, notes progress in the fight against heart disease in the association's report for 1953, published today.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Attorney General, Herbert Brownell Jr., declared tonight that "our system of Government" could not survive if any person was "allowed to set himself above the laws of the land" or one branch of Government is able to "usurp powers of another branch."

The integrity of the International Labor Organization is involved in the fight being conducted by the United States and other democratic nations to prevent seating of the so-called "worker" and "employer" representatives from the Soviet nations at the I. L. O. conference in Geneva.

ST. LOUIS, June 13 (UP) -- Stan Musial's twenty-first home run in the eighth inning today gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 5-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates and a sweep of their double-header. The Redbirds took the first game, 5 -- 0.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- The Giants today concluded one of their most successful Western jaunts in recent years as they flattened the Cubs in both ends of a double-header that left 26,597 fans unhappy. It also left Leo Durocher's cast tied with the Dodgers for the National League leadership.

The Communist Party of the U. S. A. issued a call to its members yesterday to start a drive to arouse the same mass sentiment here that, it said, had caused the French and British Governments to "hesitate about going along with" United States foreign policy.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 (AP) -- Elmer Valo drove in four second-game runs with a bases loaded triple and a single and Vic Power lined a two-run pinch-hit single in the opener as the Philadelphia Athletics took a double-header from the Detroit Tigers today, 4 -- 3 and 6 -- 3.
FOR almost three years, now, Ervin Nussbaum, a Columbus, Ohio, man, has found sylvan tranquillity in Inwood Park at Manhattan's northern end. He does oil landscapes there.
Besides "Under the Sycamore Tree," written by himself, Sam Spewack will be represented by another comedy. Bearing the title of "Festival," it is a collaboration by Mr. Spewack and his wife, Bella.

BOSTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians increased their American League lead and extended their winning streak to four games by downing the Boston Red Sox, 4 -- 1 and 8 -- 1, in a double-header today before 26,750 fans in Fenway Park.
An attempt to get more college men to become newspaper space peddlers is being made by agency and newspaper advertising executives in Pennsylvania.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 13 -- Ch. Dortmund Delly's Colonel Jet, a Doberman pinscher that has come along rapidly recently, added a third best-in-show title to his record today in the twenty-second event of the Longshore-Southport Kennel Club.
Civilians with an intensive interest in flying who like to keep a hand in it by belonging to the Civil Air Patrol participated in a state-wide test yesterday to prove their worth to the Air Force.
NEW HAVEN, June 13 -- The centennial of the graduation of the first Chinese student from an American college was observed here tonight in a program sponsored by Yale University and Yale-in-China.

Of more than $115,000,000 of German dollar bonds submitted for validation, less than 1 per cent have been held invalid, according to Douglas W. Hartman, American member of the Validation Board for German Dollar Bonds.

A limited series of test runs on Seventh and Eighth Avenues showed that taxicabs moved faster and buses traveled slower after the routes became one-way, the West Side Association of Commerce said yesterday.
YAKUTSK, U. S. S. R., June 5 -- One way of describing Yakutsk is to call it a Klondike under strong Soviet Marxist direction.

On Flag Day we have been accustomed to honor those things for which "Old Glory" stands: the principles set forth in the Declaration, the Constitution, the Bill of Rights, the Gettysburg Address; the sacrifices offered in times gone by to make those principles good.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Testimony released today indicated that the United States hopes to make the army of Iraq a "stabilizing force" in the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- A large collection of art and historical objects here is looking for a museum.

Two gunmen robbed the RKO Franklin Theatre, at Prospect Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, of $2,500 last night while a movie was in progress. They handcuffed the manager and two employes to a water pipe, the police of the Morrisania station said.

Governor Dewey warned yesterday against listening to the critics of leaders in other free nations. These critics, he said, tear down the leadership of these free countries "just because their Governments are not like ours."

BEN HECHT is 60 years old, but he still writes like a young man excited by words and his own brash cleverness. Complicated, paradoxical, talented, prodigiously energetic, Ben Hecht is as joyful an egoist as the Pharaoh Cheops himself. His autobiography, "A Child of the Century,"* seems almost as excessively massive and solid as the Great Pyramid.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- The movement of new crop wheat in the Southwest is expanding steadily, with harvest operations now extending into southern Kansas, but there is no pressure on the growers to sell. They apparently are set to take out loans on the greater part of their wheat.
Arthur B. Bisguier won the United States chess championship yesterday at the Marshall Chess Club.

The Child Welfare League of America, national federation of child care agencies, announced yesterday that it had begun a survey to determine how many of the nation's 1,900 children's institutions were meeting the needs of the youngsters and communities they served.

There seems to be a considerable amount of confusion about the UNICEF appropriation which is due to be reported out of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. On the surface it would seem that Congress was about to authorize for the United Nations' Children's Fund $13,500,000 for eighteen months additional work, caring for millions of needy youngsters in the world's underdeveloped areas.

More than 650 members of the parish of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, comprised of the clergy, choirs and congregations of six chapels and the mother church, filled every seat in the historic edifice yesterday morning.

The famous Negro surgeon, Dr. Daniel Hale Williams, the first to operate successfully on the human heart, is the subject of a biography by Helen Buckler, entitled "Doctor Dan: Pioneer in American Surgery." The author, who spent ten years on the research, tells how Dr. Williams rose in his profession to become the first vice president of the National Medical Association. Atlantic-Little, Brown will publish the book Wednesday.

Every citizen acquainted with the accomplishments of the United Nations Children's Fund shares with The Times the concern expressed in a recent editorial that a reduction in the United States contribution to UNICEF will seriously curtail this organization's ability to assist sick and hungry children throughout the world.

Shipments of rayon and acetate yarn and staple in May totaled 92,000,000 pounds, a slight gain over the previous month but 16 per cent under those for May, 1953, according to the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.

A 14-year-old New England boy, a few women and a doctor who needed a hole-in-one were among the approximately 2,500 golfers who beat the 64 which the United States open champion, Ben Hogan, returned in his National Golf Day round at the Baltusrol Club, Springfield, N. J., The Associated Press reported yesterday.

There are so many traditions about the origins of Flag Day in this country that it is a little difficult to fix upon one of them without running serious risk of offending people whose patriotism and respect for the flag are every bit as strong as one's own.

LEWISTON, Me., June 13 (UP) -- Sherman Adams, Presidential assistant, declared today that the United States political system was sound despite the limelight seekers who were "elbowing" their way "across the American scene."
PASSAIC, N. J., June 13 -- Although juvenile delinquency is reported on the increase elsewhere in the country, it is not a major problem here.
HANOI, June 13 (UP)--French planes bombed today the trunk highway carrying supplies from China to Vietminh troops forty to fifty miles northwest of Hanoi.

FRANKFORT, Ky., June 13 -- A race for the United States Senate between Senator John Sherman Cooper and former Vice President Alben W. Barkley was assured today when no other state-wide aspirant filed for the primaries.

Play clothes in variety are an indispensable part of summer and vacation wardrobes. This season they are unusual, practical and fun. Obviously planned to be combined and coordinated, the two play suits and two jackets presented today by Patterns of The Times can be worn together or separately on the beach, in the garden or for active sports.

CAIRO, June 13 -- The Iraqi Ambassador, Najeeb el Rawi, said today the Egyptian Govern ment had been inspiring Arab hostility toward Iraq. He had requested an appointment with Foreign Minister Mahmoud Fawzi to protest allegedly inspired press attacks and against the Egyptian-Saudi Arabian military alliance announced Friday.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Americans for Democratic Action (A.D.A.) said today the United States should "undertake a large-scale economic program of loans and grants to help the Asians help themselves."
PARIS, June 13 -- President Rene Coty accepted the resignation of Premier Joseph Laniel tonight and asked Pierre Mendes-France, one of M. Laniel's principal opponents, to form a Cabinet.
The city had its hottest day of of the year yesterday, but a relatively low humidity and fresh breezes from the sea made it pleasantly bearable.
PITTSBURGH, June 13 -- The increase in steel output last week was counter-seasonal. Usually the month of June shows some leveling-off, but factors in the market last week were anything but normal.

Appointment of an impartial chairman to arbitrate grievances between the Transit Authority and its unionized employes was urged yesterday by Matthew Guinan, president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O.

SWAN LAKE, N. Y., June 13 -- The annual convention of the New York State branch of Jewish War Veterhans called today upon "every freedom - loving American" to oppose Senator Joseph R. McCarthy as a threat to "our democratic way of life."

AMHERST, Mass., June 13 (AP) The Secretary General of the United Nations, Dag Hammarskjold, said here today that "we hear so much about two worlds that we are in danger of coming to accept as part of our creed that the nations are to be forever divided into opposing camps."
The new luxury liner Cristoforo Colombo, another milestone on Italy's road back in the trans-Atlantic steamship business, will make her debut here late next month.

When the Chicago White Sox moved into the Stadium last Friday night for the start of a four-game set, the Yankees would have been happy to settle for three out of four from the then pace-setting Pale Hose. However, after Casey Stengel's men had taken yesterday's opener, 4 -- 2, before 60,070 fans, to make it three straight over the visitors, only a clean sweep would have satisfied the Yankees.

In an address delivered in Washington last May 24, Prof. Sumner Slichter of Harvard, after consulting and analyzing the current statistics on industrial production, new orders of manufacturers, personal income before taxes and retail sales, concluded:
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. called for an end yesterday to "inadequate quotas" in his department, in the interest of efficiency and morale.
GENEVA, June 13 -- Richard G. Casey, Australian Minister for External Affairs, advocated tonight that the United Nations deal with Vietminh aggression in the Indochinese states of Cambodia and Laos.
CAIRO, June 13 -- British-Egyptian negotiations on the dispute over sovereignty in the Suez Canal zone will be resumed within three weeks, a responsible British official said today.

When New York State adopted a new salary program in 1947, adding some millions of dollars to the school payrolls, a realistic approach to teachers' pay was taken for the first time. Substantial increases were assured, with higher minimum and maximum schedules.
The new luxury liner Cristoforo Colombo, another milestone on Italy's road back in the trans-Atlantic steamship business, will make her debut here late next month.

When the Chicago White Sox moved into the Stadium last Friday night for the start of a four-game set, the Yankees would have been happy to settle for three out of four from the then pace-setting Pale Hose. However, after Casey Stengel's men had taken yesterday's opener, 4 -- 2, before 60,070 fans, to make it three straight over the visitors, only a clean sweep would have satisfied the Yankees.
St. John's University conferred degrees on 1,209 graduates yesterday afternoon at its eighty-fourth commencement, held in the Second Corps Artillery Armory in Brooklyn.

LINDEN, N. J., June 13 -- Al Keller, 32-year-old mechanic from Bloomfield, driving an XK120 M Jaguar, owned by Paul Whiteman, the bandleader, won the 100-mile international automobile race before 23,000 persons at Linden Airport today. He was clocked in 1:17:20.40 for an average of 77.58 miles an hour.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Following are the votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll calls in Congress during the period June 5 through June 11.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Maj. Gen. Kenneth D. Nichols, general manager of the Atomic Energy Commission, has drafted his recommendation in the Oppenheimer security case. It supports the Gray board's finding that Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer is "loyal" but should not be retained as a consultant to the commission.

The Estate Securities Company, New York operators, bought the red brick apartment building for thirty-eight families at 147-03 Northern Boulevard, northeast corner of 147th Street, in Flushing, Queens, in a deal negotiated by George Brezel, vice president of Sydney M. Siegel Co., Kew Gardens brokers.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 13 -- More than 600 women representing twenty-seven nations from all parts of the world are now meeting in Helsinki for the third post-war congress of the International Council of Women. The first was staged in Philadelphia in 1947, the second in Athens in 1951.

CAIRO, June 13 -- A Government censor cut down last night local newspaper articles on the inspection during the day by Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser of the solar boats of Pharaoh Cheops, discovered May 26 by the Government architect and Egyptologist, Kamal el-Malakh.

As the son and grandson of self-employed physicians I want to record my protest on the reversal of the House Ways and Means Committee's previously announced decision to include such persons under the Social Security program.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 13 -- Wesleyan University held its 122d commencement today, conferring eight honorary degrees, thirty-one master's degrees and 162 Bachelor of Arts degrees.
A WEST COAST college professor is going to walk away with the television laurels in New York this summer. There need be no doubt about it.

JERUSALEM, June 9 -- Israel is approaching a moment of economic decision. Can she press some of the inflation out of her commercial life by canceling food subsidies? Or will such an action cause a new spurt of inflation by increasing the cost of living and thereby automatically lifting wages?

PARIS, June 13 (AP) -- Former Gen. Auguste Nogues, 78 years old, who had been in exile in Portugal since 1943, has returned to Paris to give himself up as a prisoner, the French Press Agency reported today.

AMMAN, Jordan, June 13 (AP) -- Demonstrators shouting against "Zionist America," Britain and the Jordanian Government halted traffic here today just after the arrival of King Saud of Saudi Arabia for an official visit.
CHICAGO, June 13 (AP) -- The president of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society asked members today to help find jobs and housing for immigrants who wanted to come to the United States.

SIOUX FALLS, S. D., June 13 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy predicted here today that the Army-McCarthy hearings would not produce a clear-cut decision and that the controversies it had raised would be carried into the 1954 election campaigns.

As a combination driver-pedestrian who enjoys seeing that all of our traffic regulations here in New York City are strongly enforced I regret to note that there is a marked increase in the number of motorists who have become itchy-accelerator-footed traffic-light jumpers.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 13 (AP) -- Rocky Marciano finished 183 rounds of boxing for Thursday's heavyweight title defense against the former champion, Ezzard Charles, with a brief two-round drill today.

Francis P. Carr, yesterday's witness in the Army-McCarthy hearings, was brought up in Newport, R. I., and studied political science at Brown University in the last college class before the start of World War II in Europe.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, said today he was "basically optimistic" about the success of the European Defense Community despite the change of Government in France.
WEST POINT, N. Y., June 14 (AP) -- Five of the six top seeded players advanced through the opening rounds of the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships today.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- President Eisenhower went underground today in the capital's simulated air raid.

DETROIT, June 14 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks told the Detroit Economic Club today business was on the upswing but that "our home-grown Communists, echoing their Moscow masters, are trying to start a depression."

PARIS, June 14 -- Pierre Mendes-France agreed today to appear before the National Assembly in quest of the premiership. He said he would propose a peace in Indochina that would be "the contrary of a capitulation."

On the strength of Duke Snider's home run in the fourth inning and Jim Gilliam's run-producing single in the eighth, the Dodgers turned back the Yankees, 2 -- 1, last night in the fourth Mayor's Trophy game between the teams for the benefit of sandlot baseball.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Both exports and imports increased sharply during April, the Bureau of Census said today, despite a decline in shipments abroad of military aid items.
Gian-Carlo Menotti is thinking in terms of Broadway once more. He has nurtured "The Saint of Bleecker Street" for several years, and the show is almost completed.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The new assault by Senator Ralph E. Flanders upon another Republican, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, appeared today to have caused more unhappiness in the Senate than most issues raised in recent years.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 14 -- Brazil, once the world's only producer of rubber, is closing down factories for lack of raw rubber.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Cornelius Edward Ryan, who has figured in the McCarthy-Army hearings as commander of Fort Dix, N. J., was nominated today by President Eisenhower to the permanent rank of major general. He holds the rank on a temporary basis.

SOUTH AMBOY, N. J., June 14 -- This small community, which had idolized the late Harold G. Hoffman, former Republican Governor of New Jersey, was stunned today by the disclosure that he had embezzled $300,000 from the South Amboy Trust Company.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 14 -- Peru has given assurance to the four guarantor powers of the Rio protocol that she will not disturb the peace pending the settlement of her frontier dispute with Ecuador. A similar reply from Ecuador to an appeal sent Friday night is expected but has not been received.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 14 -- Dr. Clarence Manion, former dean of the Notre Dame University Law School, said here today that the United States should sever diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union and its satellites.
William White, the defeated president of the New York Central Railroad, said yesterday the former management had no plans to file suit to regain control of the road.

Evil influences in the community are complicating the work of the schools, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday at a conference of magazine editors and educators at Columbia University.

After weighing the divided counsel of his advisers as to whether he should go or not, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that he would fly to Puerto Rico next Sunday. There he will attend the Second Migration Conference in San Juan to be held throughout the week.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UP) -- The Democratic Digest said today that T. Coleman Andrews, the Internal Revenue Commissioner, had entertained Senator Joseph R. McCarthy as a house guest and called him a "great American" while investigating "possible tax evasions" by the Wisconsin Republican.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Two favorable reports on the national economy were issued today by three Government agencies.

LONDON, June 14 -- The strains on United States-British cooperation in foreign policy, already great, increased today with the publication in one of this country's most respected newspapers of a charge that Secretary of State Dulles spoke with one voice for home consumption and another for circulation abroad.

On May 24 and 25 there were two separate articles referring to the aviation problem so far as it concerned the metropolitan area. The articles referred to the tremendous growth of passenger flights as well as the inadequate facilities of the present airfields.

Republican leaders of the Eighteenth Congressional District, meeting yesterday with Thomas J. Curran, Manhattan Republican leader, endorsed Representative James G. Donovan, a Democrat, for a third term.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 14 -- Many favorable factors combined to make 1953 the best economic year since World War II, the sixth world economic report of the United Nations indicates.
ITHACA, N, Y., June 14 -- John S. Knight, president of the Knight newspapers, was elected to the board of trustees of Cornell University today following the commencement program.

The race for Father's Day gift business this week is generating advertising worth many hundreds of thousands of dollars. Manufacturers and sellers of nearly every item worn or used by men are bidding hard for the money being spent for presents for the nation's dads, that will be given next Sunday.
ALBANY, June 14 -- New York City opened today before the Public Service Commission its case against a $68,500,000 rate increase sought by the New York Telephone Company.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Senators Joseph R. McCarthy and Stuart Symington waged a bitter overtime word battle tonight on whether the McCarthy investigating committee's own files were safe from potential spies.

THE trout fisherman who ties his flies concentrates on creating an artificial that is as closely a facsimile of the real insect as can be devised with fur, wool, tinsel and feathers. The angler who ties bass flies, however, seems to spend most of his time creating "new" insects.

MONTREAL, June 14 (Canadian Press) -- The first phase of a Latin-American attempt to move the headquarters of the International Civil Aviation Organization from Montreal fell one vote short of approval today.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 14 -- Chairman Edward F. Howrey of the Federal Trade Commission said here today "a sensible and consistent anti-trust policy depends upon the appraisal of relevant economic and marketing factors."

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The Defense Department today announced the conclusion of talks between Secretary Charles E. Wilson and Duncan Sandys, British Minister of Supply, covering "matters of mutual interest in connection with the development and production of weapons."

A husband who steals from his wife (or vice versa) is guilty of a crime, a state court held yesterday. This broader concept of the common law doctrine was voiced by the Supreme Court's Appellate Division, Second Department.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Find thrilled a crowd of 22,095 by winning the $30,350 Queens County Handicap, the mile and a sixteenth race that served as the feature of the opening day's card at Aqueduct yesterday.

"THE most effective pitch in baseball," Paul Richards was saying the other day, "is the change of pace. It's also the most difficult to master. The success that Eddie Lopat has enjoyed should be an object lesson to all pitchers. By using varying speeds he keeps the hitters off balance and I doubt that any pitcher ever has studied the operation more thoroughly than he.
MADISON, Wis., June 14 (AP) -- The University of Wisconsin and the State Department of Agriculture here reported a new step in manufacturing Swiss cheese that is square and rindless.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 14 -- Prime Minister Daniel Malan failed by nine votes tonight to get a two-thirds majority in Parliament to ratify the bill to remove 38,000 Cape coloreds (persons of mixed blood) from the white voters' register.

Three Government witnesses testified yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court that Joseph D. Nunan accepted a $25,000 legal fee from a corporation in St. Paul, Minn., to expedite "a closing agreement" with the Internal Revenue Bureau on a tax matter. It was brought out that the so-called agreement effected a savings of nearly $1,000,000 for the corporation.
MADRAS, India, June 14 (Reuters) -- The tiny settlement of Yanam [cross on map] has thrown off French rule and hoisted the Indian flag, according to an Indian news agency report.

An industrial plot on the north side of Jackson Avenue, about 100 feet east of Forty-fourth Drive, in the Queens Plaza sections of Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by Bream Builders, Inc., for improvement with a two-story warehouse and showroom building.

PITTSBURGH, June 14 (AP) -- Hank Sauer's twentieth homer in the eighth inning with Ralph Kiner on base gave the necessary runs to the Chicago Cubs tonight in a 6-5 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

Green beans, coming now from southern states in increasing quantities, decreased 4 cents to about 15 cents a pound -- last Friday. Even more attractive was the price in some chain and large independent stores, two pounds for 27 cents.

A nine-day "driver's clinic" at the State Bureau of Motor Vehicles, 80 Centre Street, has alerted several hundred persons to the fact that their eyesight or reaction times are below the acceptable standards for safe driving.
In an editorial of June 7 you mention that the immigration station at Ellis Island might be moved to another location and wonder how this island might be utilized in the future.

LONDON, June 14 -- Prices continued to slip in the stock markets here today under the influence of the Geneva conference deadlock and the French political crisis. All sections except Government funds closed dull, although one or two were a little steadier in late business.

MEXICO CITY, June 14 -- Representatives of industry, labor and Government met today in the first of a planned series of conferences to try to avert a general strike called for July 12 by the Confederation of Mexican Workers.

The Rev. Yonezo Doi, a representative of the Church of the New Jerusalem (Swedenborgian) in Japan and Korea, said yesterday that Communist influence was steadily decreasing in these two countries while interest in religion was growing apace.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 14 -- Mrs. Florence Vaccaro, 24 years old, surrendered here today on charges that she honored in the last three years overdrafts totaling $40,000 for a depositor at the private bank in Port Chester where she was employed as a bookkeeper.
GENEVA, June 14 -- The Allied got into a sharp wrangle today as they tried to find common ground for breaking off the Korean phase of the Far East conference.
BOSTON, June 14 (AP) -- American Woolen Company today disputed Federal Court jurisdiction in a suit brought by Textron, Inc., to prevent American from disclosing results of its April 23 election.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 14 -- The sixth Holland Festival reached back more than two millenia tonight to produce, for a gala opening here, a Dutch version of Sophocles' "Elektra" by the Nederlandse Comedie.
Two new films will arrive in first-run theatres today.
Flag Day, commemorating the 177th anniversary of the adoption of the flag by Congress, was celebrated yesterday in ceremonies throughout the nation.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned somewhat irregular yesterday and prices closed 1 point higher to 14 points lower than on last Friday.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 14 (AP) -- Rocky Marciano relaxed in the sunshine today, talking shop with the boxing writers before his Thursday night heavyweight title defense in the Yankee Stadium, New York, against the former champion, Ezzard Charles.

Americans from California to Maine and from Puget Sound to Miami Beach shared yesterday the first nation-wide civil defense test against atomic attack. Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands and the ten provinces of Canada also participated.
LONDON, June 14 -- Dame Sybil Thorndike, one of Britain's best loved actresses, celebrated her fiftieth year as an actress by appearing as usual at the Hay-market Theatre today in N. C.

It is unfortunate that in his recent letter to The New York Times Henry Epstein, the Deputy Mayor, has resorted to charges of McCarthyism in his discussion of a matter of as much concern to the people of the City of New York as the creation of an effective commission on intergroup relations.
The New York Central Railroad's new president and chief executive officer, Alfred Edward Perlman, 51, is a soft-spoken railroad man of progress.

The Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company has made a new leasehold first mortgage loan of $1,000,000 at 5 per cent on the thirty-story office building at 501 Madison Avenue, northeast corner of East Fifty-second Street. The financing was arranged by Feist Feist, the mortgagee's local correspondents, and the Clark Company, as broker.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 14 -- The former Israeli Army Chief of Staff warned today against the "dangerous assumption" that Iraqi military power could be made a stabilizing force in the Middle East.
Relatives of three policemen killed in line of duty and thirty other heroic policemen received medals yesterday in City Hall Plaza.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 14 -- A gift of $500,000 for remodeling and enlarging the library building at Wellesley College was announced today by Miss Margaret Clapp, the college president, at the seventy-sixth commencement exercises.
DETROIT, June 14 -- The mentally retarded children here are being accepted as part of the human race. They have responded as flowers to the sun.
The main charges in the Army - McCarthy controversy now before a Senate investigating subcommittee are:

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UP) The Senate approved a $1,140,851,280 money bill for the State, Commerce and Justice Departments today after Democrats had failed in an effort to impose a political gag on Scott McLeod, State Department security chief.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles has approved a major reorganization of the Department of State and the Foreign Service of the United States.
DUBLIN, June 14 (AP) -- The Cornell-Penn track team placed 1-2-3 in the 100-yard dash and the 440-yard run and won one of the four other events tonight in an international track meet.
GENEVA, June 14 -- The Government of Vietnam is to be reorganized, delegates to the Far Eastern conference said today.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Pledge of Allegiance to the flag hereafter will give recognition to God as well as country.

BONN, Germany, June 14 -- The United States announced today that six tons of anti-aircraft shells in transit from Switzerland to Guatemala had been intercepted in Hamburg. German port policemen, acting with United States and British authorities, prevented the loading of the 20-mm. shells aboard the Hamburg - American line freighter Coburg about May 20.
CHICAGO, June 14 -- Edwin G. Nourse, once head of former President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers, outlined bankers' responsibility under present business conditions here today.
YAKUTSK, U. S. S. R., June 5 -- There is a Yakut Burbank named Mikhail Yegorov who last year grew a watermelon not much more than 100 miles from Verkhoyansk, the former cold capital of the world.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The United States has cold-shouldered a Guatemalan proposal for a conference to study "all causes of tension" between the two countries.
A graduating class from New York City Community College passed its finals yesterday by serving luncheon to sixty guests in the Waldorf-Astoria's Perroquet Suite.
LONDON, June 14 (Reuters) -- Britain's export drive suffered a setback during May, according to Board of Trade figures.
Exhibitors at the fifth semi-annual Women's Sportswear Show at the New Yorker Hotel yesterday described business at the show as "fair."

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company plans to offer $39,950,000 in twenty-five-year first and refunding mortgage bonds, according to a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs had turned upward after a downward trend of more than a month.

Gov. J. Bracken Lee of Utah held yesterday that Robert Moses had threatened the Westinghouse Electric Corporation with loss of business because its president favored private -- instead of state -- power development at Niagara Falls.

Yesterday's nation-wide air-raid drill went as well as could be expected. Most people stopped what they were doing, obeyed the words of air-raid wardens and police and took shelter. This is good. It proves we can discipline ourselves against a danger hard to imagine.

LOS ANGELES, June 14 -- E. Roland Harriman, chairman of the American Red Cross, declared here today that the organization was tired of helping disaster-stricken communities that recognized no obligation in return.
MADISON, N. J., June 14 -- Mrs. Ada Hoffman Leonard, daughter of the late Gov. Harold G. Hoffman, said here tonight that any money her father had embezzled would be repaid.
Earnings of Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc., and its subsidiaries continued to decline from the corresponding period last year, the distiller reported yesterday.

WAUKEGAN, Ill., June 14 (AP) -- Patty Berg, with birdies on the last three holes bettered par by five strokes today with a 36, 34 -- 70 to smash the course record and win the medal in the women's Western open golf tournament.
MONTREAL, June 14 -- A firm appeal for more enterprise and less nationalization was sounded here today at the opening session of a Commonwealth trade conference.

Masked by the June wedding festivities are the changes taking place in families as the children leave them to marry. However, there are factors that influence a continuing close relationship between the young married person and his family, and these are discussed in an article by Marvin B. Sussman in the current issue of Marriage and Family Living. The article is based on a survey of 195 families.

Ezzard Charles, who hopes to become the first heavyweight to regain the world championship when he meets Rocky Marciano in the Yankee Stadium on Thursday night, is an ambitious man. He has always wanted the "big" things in life, and he learned years ago that if a fellow keeps working and plodding and improving, he can have them.

BONN, Germany, June 14 -- The decision of the West German Government to establish a special committee to coordinate the processing and distribution of political news has aroused the suspicion of leading newspapers that another attempt is being made to control the press.
SEATTLE, June 14 -- A former leading woman operative in the Communist party in the Pacific Northwest today began publicly identifying more than 400 persons she said she had known as party members.

BASLE, Switzerland, June 14 -- The Western world gets far nearer to stability under economic freedom than under government controls. This is the conclusion of the Bank for International Settlements in its review of 1953, published here today.
ACCRA, Gold Coast, June 14 -- Tomorrow's general election in the Gold Coast will bring into force a new Constitution of great consequence to all of Africa.

One need not have lived in Vienna to feel a nostalgia for it. Any one who has listened to a Strauss waltz has a friendly feeling for the Austrian capital that has seen happier days than it now is enduring. One has a natural interest in things Viennese, which extends to Viennese wine.
BERLIN, June 14 -- Four persons charged with playing leading roles in organizing the riots in East Germany last June 17 received sentences today ranging from five to fifteen years imprisonment.
SPRINGFIELD, N. J., June 14 (UP) -- The jinx that for seventeen years has hounded Sammy Snead in the United States Open golf championship struck again today.

LONDON, June 14 (UP) -- Art Larsen, Louise Brough and seven other United States players won singles matches today as the London grass court tennis championships began at the Queen's Club. Four other Americans were eliminated.

Sales of forty-four chain store and mail order companies in May were 4.1 per cent behind those of the like month a year ago, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times. Dollar sales last month were $1,047,168,000.
A new $5,000,000 Tele-Centre, said to be the most complete television production facility under one roof on the East Coast, was formally dedicated here yesterday by the Du Mont network.

GUATEMALA, June 14 -- Three political parties supporting President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman published today a manifesto pledging to assist this Government "in a moment in which external and internal forces are plotting to subvert the constitutional regime."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 14 -- Harvard evened its season record against Yale at one victory each by defeaating the Elis, 4 -- 2, before a disappointed reunion crowd today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 14 -- Mayor Robert F. Wagner and members of New York's new United Nations hospitality committee were guests today at a luncheon given here by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.
The ownership of the mongrel that on Sunday reportedly followed an ambulance carrying its injured master to Bellevue Hospital has become a mystery.

This is a nice month, this one called June, perhaps the nicest of the twelve. It is a month for the sun, and happy the bride upon whom that shines. It is a month for green trees, for visible growth in the garden, for meadows to look like meadows and for hills to look like hills.

HAMBURG, Germany, June 14 (AP) -- United States officials insisted today that the ammunition destined for Guatemala was live, although a port representative said it had been marked "dummy ammunition," meaning that the shells were without explosives.

The French Cabinet crisis, the stalemate at Geneva and the continuing deterioration in Indochina coincide this week with a newly formed desire on the part of the British Government to discuss an alternative to the European Defense Community.
POUGHKEEPSIE, June 14 -- Adlai E. Stevenson warned Vassar's graduating class today against the "corruption of conformity."
LONDON, June 14 (Reuters) -- Three scientists have successfully frozen warm-blooded animals to 23 degrees below zero and had them walking again within two hours.
HAMILTON, N. Y., June 14 -- Colgate University today granted 307 degrees of Bachelor of Arts degrees, twelve Master of Arts degrees and eight honorary degrees at its 133d annual commencement.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The blurs and gaps in the line that is supposed to demarcate the two major political parties in this country have again been illuminated by a series of mixed-up events. The words "Republican" and "Democrat" still stand out boldly on the labels, but the contents are scrambled.

Carmelo Costa, Brooklyn featherweight, ran his unbeaten string to 24 fights, last night by taking a split decision over Baby Ortiz of Mexico City in the ten-round feature bout before 1,310 at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn.
The Waterfront Commission will begin hearings this morning to decide whether 144 men accused of violence and other offenses in the recent longshore strike should be barred from pier employment.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 14 -- The United Nations will take one more step Wednesday toward action to try to prevent the spread of the Indochinese war.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Wheat had a weak tone today while corn and oats showed considerable strength. The feature of the session, however, was the sharp upturn in July soybeans, which rose 10 cents, the day's limit.
