The strength in July soybeans, in which there was active short covering, helped the deferred months but there was free selling of the latter on moderate bulges.

The Equitable Gas Company had gross operating revenues of $18,400,000 in the first five months of this year, a decline of $1,300,000 from expectations, A. W. Conover, president, told the stockholders at their annual meeting in Pittsburgh yesterday.
Teen-age boys no longer regard sewing as a task exclusively for "wimmin-folk," according to a survey reported on yesterday by the Youth Research Institute for the Necchi Sewing Machine Corporation.
Following is the text of the affidavit by Mrs. Ada Hoffman Leonard concerning a letter left by her father, former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey, as released by Gov. Robert B. Meyner.
CHICAGO, June 14 (UP) -- A report proposed today for issuance by the World Council of Churches as guidance for Protestants throughout the globe criticized both democracy and communism.

Carmine G. DeSapio, Democratic National Committeeman, accused the Eisenhower Administration last night of engaging in a calculated campaign of character assassination and vilification for the sole purpose of gathering votes.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Although the country's 1,000,000 non-operating railroad workers are legally free to go on strike as of Wednesday, no walkout appears imminent for several weeks at least, a survey disclosed today.

CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- Zenith Radio Corporation and Rauland Corporation, both of Chicago, today received Federal Court authority to proceed with their six-year-old anti-trust suit against the Radio Corporation of America and others.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 14 -- Faith in the patriotism and loyalty of teachers in the United States was expressed today in a resolution adopted unanimously by 1,000 delegates at the forty-eighth annual convention of Brith Sholom, national Jewish fraternal order.

An investing client of William Altman, attorney, bought the four-story apartment house for forty-two families on plot 138 by 167 feet at 5 South Sixteenth Avenue, Mount Vernon, in Westchester County, from Jerome Jakubovitz, operator, in a deal arranged by Langsam Schiffman, brokers.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 14 -- Princeton University's graduating class renewed a 200-year-old tradition today with the annual Class Day exercises.
BERLIN, June 14 -- Sir John Hunt arrived here from Moscow today and said he believed he had convinced the Russians that the expedition he led last year really had reached the summit of Mount Everest.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 14 (AP) -- The second track record in two days was set at Monmouth Park today when Mrs. Zelda Cohen's Bold Command, a 2-year-old running his first race, went five furlongs in 58 3/5 seconds.

Sergeants traditionally are not interested in the amenities. We don't expect them to pre sent bouquets, either verbal or written. But this note of appreciation from a staff sergeant is one of many received by the United Service Organizations.
The appointment of John R. Pickering as paymaster of the United States Lines was announced here yesterday by C. D. Gibbons, vice president and treasurer of the line.

Many sincere people are deeply upset that Senator McCarthy in attacking the sincerity of Army counsel Welch used a weapon that he must have known would incidentally irreparably damage a third person not involved.

INWOOD, L. I., June 14 -- Mrs. Maxon Berger of Glen Oaks, the former Roslyn (Cookie) Swift, was invited by the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association to defend the metropolitan title she had won last year. Thus, Mrs. Berger, who was married last March and moved to Buffalo, was eligible to play in the fifty-first annual championship.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Two Puerto Rican Nationalists on trial for the shooting in the House of Representatives on March 1 in which five representatives were wounded, defied the orders of a Federal Judge here today.

Trading was dull yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Prices closed irregular, with coffee, wool, hides, zinc, tin, lead and potatoes down; cocoa, soybean oil, silk, rubber and copper up and sugar, cottonseed oil and burlap mixed.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- June 14 -- The United States declared today that Somaliland would need foreign help -- both administrative and economic -- for some time after the territory got its promised independence in 1960.

Senator Knowland, who holds the title of majority leader, may or may not be right when he says that any move to deprive Senator McCarthy of his committee chairmanships "would be certain to precipitate a controversy that might completely block the Administration's legislative program."

The United States has transferred to the Philippine Government the historic naval base at Cavite. Thus changes, and passes, what has been quite a landmark in our naval history from the time of Dewey's victory in Manila Bay, during which the Spanish guns at Cavite were silenced.

PROF. CLEMENT DARRELHYDE, a zoologist, was contemplating Percy, an ape with a "sweet, clownish face" and a thoughtful expression. Pensively staring through the bars of Percy's cage, the professor thought: "When my species has destroyed itself, we may need yours to start it all again." This reflection shows that the professor is a mid-twentieth-century fictional character, for the idea of race suicide is a strictly modern one.

The most spectacular midday matinee in town yesterday was staged in Columbus Circle, with a huge ball of steel stealing the show. Its midair carryings-on thrilled and delighted an S. R. O. audience of about 1,000, on hand to witness the dying moments of a half-century-old building probably best known for its gigantic, 80-by-45-foot billboard.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 14 --Jane Russell will meet with United Artists executives in New York this week to discuss a proposal for her to co-star with Jeanne Crain in "Gentlemen Marry Brunettes." The property is owned by Richard Sale and Robert Bassler, the latter an independent producer associated with U. A.
Flint, Mich., borrowed $6,288,000 in the public market yesterday on issues of bonds to finance bridge, street, sewer and other improvements.

The sixteen Russian and American chess masters who will engage in the first of a series of international matches at the Roosevelt Hotel tomorrow night met for the first time yesterday. They mingled in friendly fashion at a cocktail party in the small ballroom of the Roosevelt.

LONDON, June 14 -- Dr. Joseph H. Cort, American lecturer at Birmingham University who is sought by United States authorities as an alleged draft dodger, said today he was prepared to perform any military training or duty required by the British Government if allowed to become a resident here.
TRENTON, June 14 (AP) -- The New Jersey Assembly today sent Gov. Robert B. Meyner a bill setting up a referendum on a $25,000,000 bond issue for a state medical-dental college.

Sharp and determined-looking out-of-towners seen in increasing numbers around town lately are not sightseers. They are women's ready-to-wear store buyers in their annual visit to New York and they are surging into the city in greater numbers than at this time last year.
After seven weeks of talk the Geneva conference is now approaching a showdown. Only some fundamental Communist concessions, evidencing a real desire for peace, can save the conference from collapse.

PARIS, June 14 -- Fireplaces, dividing dual purpose living rooms, and movable lighting fixtures are two ideas that make for comfortable living. Both are interpreted by modern interior decorators at the exhibit of model rooms recently opened at the Grand Palais.

Stocks went through one of their more non-committal sessions yesterday. There was virtually no change in The New York Times combined average, industrials rising gently and rails falling with the same lack of emphasis. Volume slipped to a mere 1,420,000 shares, against 1,630,000 Friday.

Atlantic and Gulf Coast ship operators and the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., were still deadlocked yesterday on three issues in negotiations over a contract to replace one that expires at midnight tonight.
The four-story tenement building also containing a store at 131 East Seventeenth Street has been sold by Nuemann Brothers to I. Feldman. Louis C. Dupuy Jr was the broker.

The first formal offer of a German corporate enterprise to settle its defaulted debt with American bondholders was announced here yesterday. Bosch-Germany (Robert Bosch GmbH.), a family-owned Stuttgart manufacturer of electrical automotive and diesel equipment, submitted the offer.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., June 14 -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, told the members of the Middlebury College graduating class to be true to one another and to humanity everywhere.

The New York Press Photographers Association opened a three-day exhibition of prize-winning pictures yesterday in the New Yorker Hotel. The free show will be open on the mezzanine from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M. through tomorrow.

SEWANEE, Tenn., June 14 -- Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, warned today that "the primitive know-nothings are again on the march" and were "determined to take us back into the Dark Ages."
Statistics that point up the carelessness of American families in protecting their children's lives in the home are included in a report in The Journal of Pediatrics.
BEACON, N. Y., June 14 -- Mrs. Margaret S. Lewisohn, nationally known education leader, was killed in an automobile accident near here today shortly after giving a lift to Adlai E. Stevenson.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington before the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in its thirty-third day of hearings on the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

The Pioneer Natural Gas Company, natural gas producer and distributor operating in Texas and New Mexico, has entered into agreements for the private sale of $13,500,000 in 20-year 3 3/8 per cent sinking fund debentures to the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, Aetna Life Insurance Company and Connecticut General Life Insurance Company.
TRENTON, June 14 -- Former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman confessed before his death ten days ago to having embezzled $300,000 from the South Amboy Trust Company, of which he was president.
GENEVA, June 14 -- The Soviet Union offered the Western powers today a minor concession on the machinery for observing an armistice in Indochina, if one is ever reached.
City automobile owners who fail to affix their auto use tax stickers to the right front vent windows of their cars by tonight's deadline will face prosecution for failure to pay the tax.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced yesterday that its Spingarn Medal had been awarded to Dr. Theodore K. Lawless of Chicago, dermatologist and member of the faculty of the Medical School of Northwestern University.
The New York Central Railroad, identified with the vast Vanderbilt-Morgan fortunes for more than three-quarters of a century, became a Robert R. Young operation yesterday.
ANKARA, Turkey, June 14 -- General Staff representatives of Turkey and Pakistan will meet "immediately" to begin drafting plans for military cooperation and defense in the Middle East.
Lieut. Edward Hamilton Morgan, U. S. N., died on Saturday when an F9F-6 Panther jet plane, which he was piloting crashed while taking off from El Paso, Tex. His age was 32.
BOSTON, June 14 -- Adverse publicity has stimulated Federal Housing Administration activity, the Acting Commissioner of that agency said today.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 14 (AP) -- The publication of radio and television program schedules was resumed by Nashville's two daily newspapers today for stations that agreed to pay a service charge. The rate was not disclosed.

There has long been good reason to believe that the ultimate Soviet goal in Eastern Europe is the complete conversion of the satellite countries into component "republics" of the U. S. S. R. The Kremlin can hardly desire that Poland, say, should have any more status or sovereignty than the Ukraine or Armenia.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The House Agriculture Committee ran contrary to the Administration's wishes again today by voting to raise the level of Federal supports on dairy products.
The credibility of Arnold Bernstein and the solvency of his shipping ventures were under attack yesterday in Federal Court as cross-examination of the former German shipowner began.

Now that the threat of a transit strike has abated I thought you might like to know that, in my opinion, the four editorials that appeared in The New York Times discussing the merits of the issues in dispute between the Transport Workers Union and the Transit Authority contributed as much as any other single influence to the settlement without a strike.
Panic gripped 1,400 passengers on a crowded I. R. T. subway train under Lexington Avenue near Eighty-sixth Street during yesterday morning's rush hour.

Frank Erickson, the gambler, testified yesterday that he had paid Joseph D. Nunan $1,800 in 1948 after the former Commissioner of Internal Revenue had won a bet on the election of President Harry S. Truman. The testimony was presented to Judge Walter Bruchhausen and a jury in Brooklyn Federal court.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- The Eisenhower Administration in its plan for national defense intends to rely chiefly on the country's ability to convert economic resources into military strength quickly in times of emergency, John Slezak, Under Secretary of the Army, told the Illinois Bankers Association convention in the Drake Hotel here today.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP) -- The Post Office Department estimated today that its annual sales to stamp collectors had passed $15,000,000. The business is getting better all the time, with the take nearly all profit.
Retailers were told yesterday to buy enough fall fabrics now to cover sales into August. Prices are low, they were assured.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Civil Defense and mobilization officials warned today that the nation's survival in war demanded a more rapid scattering of its industrial might.
PARIS, June 15 -- Pierre Mendes-France will go before the National Assembly Thursday afternoon to ask that he be approved as Premier of France.
ALBANY, June 15 (AP) -- A consulting engineer suggested today that the New York Telephone Company charge for local calls on a basis of time and distance, as it does for long distance calls.
ASCOT, England, June 15 -- The royal Ascot meeting opened today in a blaze of royal ceremonies that will continue through Friday.

ALBANY, June 15 -- Governor Dewey cleared the way today for a $58,739,000 rehabilitation program on the Long Island Rail Road that will raise commuter fares on the bankrupt carrier by about 20 per cent.
Members of the Transit Authority and officials of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., met in harmony for an hour and a half yesterday to discuss a new labor contract.

MOSCOW, June 15 (AP) -- Izvestia told the story today of two displaced Russians who, it said, had been parachuted into Soviet territory as American spies. The Government organ said that the men had repented and confessed and that "the Soviet people returned them to their ranks."

LOS ANGELES, June 15 -- Attempted influences of communism upon his organization were attacked today by James T. Nicholson, executive vice president of the American National Red Cross. He addressed delegates to the national convention here.

Reflecting an excess of funds available for short-term investment, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation yesterday reduced interest rates to investors on its commercial paper for the seventh time this year. Similar action was taken by the Associates Investment Company, automobile and commercial financing concern.
KANSAS CITY, June 15 -- A build-up in American military strength was urged here today by Alf Landon, former Kansas Governor and Republican Presidential nominee in 1936.

Since the end of World War II, packaging has become one of the nation's largest industries. It is in the multi-million-dollar class, and is still growing fast. For this reason, Michigan State College, in East Lansing established last year the country's first four-year packaging technology course, one of the most unusual on any campus.

MILWAUKEE, June 15 -- Harry S. Truman, on the piano, and James C. Petrillo, playing trumpet, beat out a duet version of "Hail, Hail, the Gang's All Here" twice today. The former President of the United States and the chief of the American Federation of Musicians, A. F. L., played their duet at the union's national convention.

BEACON, N. Y., June 15 -- The State Police theorized today that the driver of the other automobile in the collision that caused the death of Mrs. Margaret Seligman Lewisohn on the Taconic Parkway yesterday had dozed off at the wheel.

CHINHAE, Korea, June 15 (AP) -- President Syngman Rhee told an eight-nation unofficial Asian anti-Communist conference today that it would not "lack support" from the United States in trying to stop Red expansion in the Far East.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington before the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in its thirty-fourth day of hearings on the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

Senator Homer Ferguson, chairman of the Senate Republican Policy Committee, called last night for a "rational, clearly defined security program. This, he said, should protect the constitutional rights of the individual while at the same time protecting the nation against "the few rotten apples that exist in our midst."

HOUSTON, Texas, June 15 -- Lieut. Gen. Andrew Davis Bruce, commandant of the Armed Forces Staff College at Norfolk, Va., was named today president of the University of Houston, second largest in the state.
VENICE, Italy, June 15 -- The twenty-seventh Venice biennial art exhibition held its vernissage or private opening here today for critics.
WHITE PLAINS, June 15 -- John and Stewart Ledbetter of Scarsdale regained the Metropolitan Golf Association's father-and-son championships today.
TOPICAL satire with real sting is so extremely rare on television that last Sunday's presentation of the Television Playhouse (9 P. M. on N. B. C.) came as a refreshing surprise.

A Federal hearing found Congress of Industrial Organizations utility workers strongly opposing public electric power projects yesterday. At the same time two national C. I. O. spokesmen called for Government power competition to revive New England's economy and to obtain a low-rate yardstick for Niagara electricity.

Like all successful comedians, Menasha Skulnik, Second Avenue's popular farceur, long has aspired for the earnest or Hamlet-like role. Now for the first time in his career, he will be portraying "a serious role with humorous overtones" in Clifford Odets' latest play, "The Flowering Peach."
After advancing seven times since early March, the price of lead was reduced 1/4 cent a pound yesterday, to 14 cents, New York basis.

Governor Dewey's limited intervention in the city's tax plans, through an order initiating a state study of the proposed 5 per cent levy on amusements, constitutes an additional warning that Mayor Wagner might well heed before he signs the tax law. The Governor's action, taken in response to an appeal by theatre owners and employes, apparently signifies his own opinion that the amusement industry faces considerable damage from the tax.

The fifteenth of the nation's thirty-five new Mariner cargo ships to be declared surplus was ordered into lay-up yesterday. Eleven of the vessels, the largest and fastest class of cargo ships, are in service for the Military Sea Transportation Service, but three of these are expected to be sent into reserve in the next few weeks.
More than seven tons of New York's history went into storage yesterday in a vault beneath the Federal Hall Memorial Building at Wall and Nassau Streets.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 15 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, conferred degrees upon 873 students and honorary degrees upon eleven persons at the university's 207th annual commencement here today.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Senate Finance Committee approved today a one-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, which expired last Saturday.

GENEVA, June 15 -- The prospects that Americans imprisoned or otherwise detained in China would be freed improved today as a result of a meeting here between United States and Chinese Communist representatives.
A door to better health for elderly persons opened yesterday at the municipal Goldwater Memorial Hospital on Welfare Island.
The Waterfront Commission killed yesterday a move to turn its hearings on pier strike violence and intimidation into a televised counterpart of the Army-McCarthy hearings.
A BACK-ROAD safari, conducted yesterday by Bart Allen of New York, over an area within seventy-five miles of the city convinced us that the woodchuck population could be described as "flourishing.''

In your issue of June 5 Senator Hugh Butler, as chairman of the Senate Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs, presented his views concerning Senate Bill No. 3378, to revise the Organic Act of the Virgin Islands. He did not specify the way in which this bill provides more self-government for the Virgin Islands.
Mayor Wagner presented medals for outstanding acts of heroism to thirty-one uniformed members of the Fire Department, or their next of kin, at noon-hour ceremonies yesterday in City Hall Plaza.
ALBANY, June 15 -- Governor Dewey requested today a special investigation of the wisdom and practicality of the proposed New York City amusement tax.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Sen. Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, said today that "we are not going to permit anyone to sabotage the Export-Import Bank or interfere with its becoming a strong, aggressive institution."

LOS ANGELES, June 15 (AP) -- Dr. Oscar A. Benson, Lutheran leader, today criticized what he called the "arrogance" of Congressional investigating committees "in assuming that they are competent to determine for the rest of us what is and what is not American."
WEST POINT, N. Y., June 15 (AP) -- Dick Raskind of Yale turned in the only upset of the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships today as the tournament progressed into the quarter-final round.

The award of two fellowships providing for two years of study at Oxford and Cambridge Universities in England was announced yesterday at Columbia University. Established in 1930 as the Euretta J. Kellett Fellowships under the will of Euretta Jane Schlegel, they carry stipends of $2,000 a year each.

Some six years ago an American soil expert named Walter Eugene Packard of Berkeley, Calif., went to Greece to do a job of work in or near the town of Antheless. Before Mr. Packard went to Greece the country was importing about $5,000,000 worth of rice.

FLINT, Mich., June 15 -- Flint officials retorted irritably today to the American Red Cross, which cited this city as an example of a disaster-stricken community that had accepted its emergency funds but had failed to pay back.

Towers Warehouses, Inc., has purchased the six-story warehouse buliding at 511-25 West Twenty-second Street, in the Chelsea area, from Louis J. Glickman, who bought the property recently from Ludwig Baumann-Spear.
Rocky Marciano and Ezzard Charles will trade punches under a special ring canopy in their listed fifteen-round world heavyweight championship fight tomorrow night at Yankee Stadium.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Leo A. Rover, United States Attorney, asked a jury here today to find four Puerto Rican terrorists guilty in the March 1 shooting in the House of Representatives.

GENEVA, June 15 -- The deadlocked Korean negotiations were broken off tonight by the United Nations side. The debate will be resumed in the United Nations General Assembly when the 1954 session convenes in September.

CLEVELAND, June 15 (AP) -- Al Rosen, playing in his first game since June 4, hit a three-run pinch double for Cleveland during a six-run rally in the eighth inning tonight as the Indians beat the Washington Senators, 9 -- 3.

With two out in the ninth inning, Henry Thompson of the Giants crashed a three-run homer high into the right field stands to beat the Redlegs, 5 -- 3, last night and move the Polo Grounders into undisputed possession of first place in the National League standings.
ALBANY, June 15 (UP) -- The State Motor Vehicle Bureau today issued regulations and sample forms, paving the way for a state-wide uniform traffic ticket system, designed to prevent "ticket fixes."
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- President Eisenhower and Sir Winston Churchill will meet at the White House June 25 to review the tensions within the United States-British alliance.
NEWARK, June 16 -- Nine Council seats in the new city government that will become effective July 1 were filled today in a run-off election.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- John C. Caldwell, a former Voice of America official in China, said today most newspaper and magazine editors m this country "are so prejudiced against Chiang Kaishek and Syngman Rhee" that "honest coverage of free Asia is almost impossible."

Activity increased yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. The domestic sugar market had the largest number of daily sales since March 31 and coffee the heaviest trading since May 5. Prices closed irregularly lower.

A Foreign Operations Administration official declared yesterday that glowing Communist offers of increased trade with Western nations were "a lot of bunk." Ellsworth B. Buck, director of the agency's office of trade, investment and monetary affairs, asserted that the Soviet bloc's ability to export was insufficient to support greater imports "except by one-shot draw-down of its gold reserves."

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres today. "Mr. Hulot's Holiday," a French-made comedy starring Jacques Tati, who also directed and, with Henri Marquet, wrote the offering, is at the Fine Arts. Nathalie Pascaud, Michelle Rolla and Valentine Camax head the supporting cast of the Fred Orain Produc tion, which is being released by G-B-D International Films.

At City Hall yesterday Mayor Wagner swore in Gordon R. Clapp, former chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, as a deputy City Administrator. The post pays $20,000 a year. The appointee has come to New York from Norris, Tenn.

GUATEMALA, June 15 -- Two principal officers of the Revolutionary party have been expelled for "having abandoned their country in a moment of national emergency." The party is a chief supporter of the Government. Its leader is Augusto Charnaud MacDonald, Interior Minister.
PARIS, June 15 -- What is happening these days is not so much a decline of French power and prestige as the belated recognition of this decline.

New issues of corporate securities valued at more than $30,000,000 will be offered to investors today. They include public utility mortgage bonds, convertible debentures of a loan company and common stock of industrial companies.

Margaret S. Lewisohn once identified herself as "a citizen interested in education." How abundantly she fulfilled that modest claim and how richly this city -- and the nation as well -- benefited by her consuming, courageously spoken interest! She was a leader in and a respected spokesman for the Public Education Association, fighting for the good cause of sound principle and more adequate financial support of the schools.
GENEVA, June 15 -- The outlook for the Indochina phase of the Far East conference was uncertain tonight.
Tradition has it that Boy Scouts, scorning matches, rub two sticks together to start a fire.

BONN, Germany, June 15 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer told his Cabinet today that it would be intolerable for West Germany to wait indefinitely for its sovereignty after having fulfilled all commitments to the Western Allies and ratified the European Defense Community Treaty.

WAUKEGAN, Ill., June 15 (AP) -- Patty Berg, the medalist, and Louise Suggs, the defending champion, easily moved through the first round of the women's Western open today but such stars as Joyce Ziske, Marlene Bauer and Betty Mackinnon were upset.

SAUK CITY, Wis., June 15 (UP) -- Leroy Gore, refusing to back down under threat of jail, said today he would answer a subpoena tomorrow but would not produce the petitions he collected demanding the recall of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

DETROIT, June 15 (UP) -- Steve Gromek of the Detroit Tigers scored his eighth victory of the season and his first in nearly a month tonight with a seven-hit, 4-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox before 32,330 fans at Briggs Stadium.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved somewhat irregularly yesterday and the close was 9 points up to 6 points off.

Mr. Turf, competing in the silks of Jack J. Amiel, gained an easy victory in the Gravesend Handicap, the classified event that occupied the feature spot on the program at Aqueduct yesterday. Established the favorite by the crowd of 17,868, Mr. Turf responded to a competent ride by Eric Guerin to take the six-furlong event by more than three lengths in the spanking time of 1:10 4/5.

Events tonight: Choon Cba, pianist, and Chungsoon Kwak, violinist, Manhatan Towers Hotel 8 P. M.; "Two Centuries of American Song," New York Public Library Fifth Avenue Building, 8; Concert by students of Syracuse University School of Music Steinway Concert Hall, 8:30.

Dr. Norman Jolliffe, director of the Bureau of Nutrition of the Department of Health, said yesterday that 35 per cent of the calories in foods bought for American homes and restaurants were "empty calories."
TOKYO, June 15 -- The Japanese Diet [Parliament] broke up last night in a round of apologies for the rioting on the floor June 3, when fifty members were slightly injured.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, adopted as State Department policy today the major recommendations of his Public Committee on Personnel for a far-reaching reorganization of the Government's diplomatic corps.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Some military aid to Europe is already being cut off under the terms of the Richards amendment, Secretary of State John Foster Dulles disclosed today.

TRENTON, June 15 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner disclosed here today that $300,000 in state employment disability funds, which former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman swore he banked five years ago, had mysteriously disappeared.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Two airline presidents urged Congress today to withdraw the "special exemptions" under which the nonscheduled airlines operated.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Dr. Edward Teller, the "father of the H-bomb," testified that the United States might have developed the weapon at least four years earlier if Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer and others had given the project their "moral" support.
The forces that want to strip James A. Roe of his power as Queens Democratic leader were made powerless for a few minutes last night when they were locked out of party headquarters.

SEAFORD, L. I., June 15 -- Trudy, a setting duck who caused a work stoppage on a housing development here on May 24, gently helped five ducklings pack their way into the world today and hopefully stayed with the three remaining unhatched eggs in her nest.
On June 11 you published a letter from James P. Warburg setting forth anew his thesis in favor of a "disarmed, reunited Germany, neutralized under adequate safeguards."

Five radio stations here are planning to present "The American Story," a new series of programs designed to tell the story of the United States from the age of discovery to the age of the atom. The series was conceived by Broadcast Music, Inc., a music licensing agency, and prepared in association with the Society of American Historians.
City College will bestow 2,548 academic degrees and certificates at its 108th commencement tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The Western Union Telegraph Company today asked the Federal Communications Commission for rate increases, effective July 15, designed to yield $10,000,000 a year.

YONKERS, June 15 -- Builders of the New York State Thruway discovered this morning that a woman's determination was more powerful than the explosives they were using to blast through her property. The revelation came when Miss Lisa Hein of Fern Terrace called the police.

TRENTON, June 15 -- The following is a summary of the text of the misconduct charges involving the late Harold G. Hoffman, who was suspended March 18 as director of the Division of Employment Security in New Jersey:

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 15 -- The International Court of Justice ruled unanimously in favor of Italy today in her dispute with the United States, Britain and France over $2,600,000 worth of gold.
The low wholesale level of egg prices -- lowest for any June since 1942 -- has been reflected at retail, where large Grade A eggs average an economical 59 cents a dozen.
MOSCOW, June 15 (AP) -- The Soviet Writers Union has criticized Ilya Ehrenburg for his latest novel, "The Thaw."
A suspended Hunter College teacher said yesterday that he had labeled three former colleagues as Communists in a confidential chat last April 8 with Dr. George N. Shuster, president of the college.

For the better part of a half century Viscount Camrose, who died yesterday in England, had been a leading figure in British journalism. Born William Ewert Berry, his career led from a grim Welsh mining town to highly successful magazine and newspaper publishing in London, and eventually to the peerage.
ACCRA, Gold Coast, June 15 -- The voters of the Gold Coast went to the polls today to elect the first fully responsible Parliament in colonial Africa. First reports indicated a heavy vote.

The Pittston Company has transferred to its wholly owned subsidiary, the Sierra Ancha Mining Company, Grand Junction, Col., all its uranium ore properties, claims and acreage in Arizona, Colorado, Utah and Wyoming.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP) -- Representative Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio, snagged up a hearing on tax-exempt foundations today by accusing a special House committee of bringing in witnesses to "peddle tripe."
CHICAGO, June 15 -- The wheat market was weak today, with prices sagging more because of absence of any important demand, than because of any free selling.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP) -- The President's Atomic Labor Board today recommended a 6-cents-an-hour wage rise for 8,500 atomic energy workers at four Government plants at Oak Ridge, Tenn., and Paducah, Ky.
The police reported yesterday that they had found four pieces of pipe in underbrush near the spot where John Francis Roche said he had killed a sailor last Aug. 22.

ROME, June 15 -- The United States campaign in Europe to publicize peaceful uses of atomic energy was opened here tonight with a message from President Eisenhower calling atomic discoveries "the most far-reaching physical accomplishment of all this century."
PITTSBURGH, June 15 -- The United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., made it clear today that it hoped to have a contract agreement with the United States Steel Corporation by next Tuesday.

Following is the text of the main portion of the brief on behalf of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer filed with the United States Atomic Energy Commission. The sections omitted here cover data on previous clearances of the physicist, and previous testimony by several authorities in his behalf.

LOS ANGELES, June 15 (UP) -- E. Roland Harriman said tonight the American Red Cross, of which he is national chairman, never would refuse to help any disaster-stricken community but pleaded for a return to the "neighbor helping neighbor" tradition.

THE Hayden Planetarium people, a forward-looking group, have sent word to amateur astronomers and photographers that if they want to see what a total solar eclipse looks like they'd better be out before dawn on June 30 this year.
KANSAS CITY, June 15 (AP) -- Flour Mills of America, Inc., announced today election of M. F. Mulroy of Minneapolis as president, succeeding A. B. Ewing, who resigned.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Army-McCarthy drama moved today into its final act. The indications were that the curtain might fall before tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that the "Communist type of terrorism" in Guatemala was all that stood in the way of an anti-Communist house-cleaning by the Guatemalan people.

A left-wing Chinese newspaper and four of its officers were found guilty yesterday by Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan of inducing Chinese here to send large sums of money illegally to Communist China. Sentences will be imposed tomorrow.
For the third time this year the Milwaukee Braves beat the Dodgers at Ebbets Field last night. A two-run rally in the eighth inning gained a 7-6 victory for Charley Grimm's team.

GENEVA, June 15 (AP) -- Following is the text of a North Korean resolution and an Allied declaration at the Far East conference here, and excerpts from addresses by Chou En-lai, Chinese Communist Foreign Minister; Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister; Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, United States Under Secretary of State, and Gen. Nam Il, North Korean Foreign Minister:

The attack on the financial position of the Arnold Bernstein shipping enterprises continued yesterday in Federal Court as cross-examination of the former German shipowner was resumed by John A. Wilson, attorney for the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The House Post Office and Civil Service Committee reported out a bill today that would increase the pay of postal workers by $189,960,000 annually.

William V. Rosenberg, in a purchase for occupancy, has acquired the two-story business building at 48 Bergen Street, near Smith Street, in Brooklyn from the National Gauge Corporation. The buyer will alter the building and use it for his cotton fabrics business.

BALTIMORE, June 15 -- A .203 hitter when the contest started, Joe Collins provided the power that Allie Reynolds and the Yankees needed to defeat the Baltimore Orioles, 6 -- 4, before 29,840 fans tonight.

New York, "the richest city in the richest state of the richest country in the world," is far behind some less well-to-do communities in providing for the welfare of children, a panel of child specialists agreed yesterday.
LONDON, June 15 (AP) -- American players ripped through most of the opposition in early rounds of the London lawn tennis championships at the Queen's Club today.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 15 -- The men of Princeton took hold of a dead language here today and made it live Latin was the Lingua Princetoniensa for Donald Van Twisk Bear of Cinncinati, salutatorian, at today's commencement exercises. His oration was received with lavish enthusiasm.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (AP) -- Vic Raschi hit a third inning single and Rip Repulski followed with a homer as the St. Louis Cardinals whipped the Philadelphia Phillies, 3 -- 1, at Connie Mack Stadium tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The House Rules Committee voted today to let the full House of Representatives decide whether the Administration's public housing program should be accepted in whole or in part.
A late buying flurry in rails, accompanied by a show of moderate strength in some major chemicals, aircrafts and steels, sent the stock market ahead yesterday with the widest gains since April 29.

MADISON, N. J., June 15 -- A committee is being organized to handle contributions to a "Harold G. Hoffman fund," Mrs. Ada Hoffman Leonard, daughter of the late former Governor, said tonight at her home here.

Under the caption "Parking Tax Opposed" one of your contributors maintains that a levy of this type would be "discriminatory" because it "would fall on those car owners who cannot afford garage facilities."
CHICAGO, June 15 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics extended their winning streak to five games by battering three Chicago White Sox hurlers for fourteen hits and an 11-to-4 victory tonight.
MEXICO CITY, June 15 -- The Guatemalan Army was reported here today to have called on President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman to make a firm decision on governmental policy toward communism.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders' demand that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy be ousted from Congressional investigative leadership was taken out of his hands -- at least temporarily -- by the Senate today.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Attorneys for Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer made public tonight a brief to the Atomic Energy Commission in which they argued that the nuclear scientist's lack of enthusiastic support for the hydrogen bomb project did not make him a security risk.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 15 (AP) -- The University of Illinois produced five winners tonight to lead the Big Ten to a surprising 74-58 victory over the Pacific Coast in the annual track meet between the two conferences.

Ernest O. Thompson, "father of effective petroleum conservation," is the subject of a biography by James A. Clark. Random House will issue it June 25. Entitled "Three Stars for the Colonel," the story begins in the days of the East Texas oil discovery, when Mr. Thompson was the newest member of the Texas Railroad Commission, and comes up to the present.

INWOOD, L. I., June 15 -- Three extra-hole matches, one resulting in an upset, marked the first round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's fifty-first championship being played on the Inwood course.
MONTREAL, June 15 (Canadian Press) -- The National Industrial Advertisers Association was told today that the economic readjustment has had its run.

EL PASO, Tex., June 15 -- Border town merchants have seen a ready retail market almost completely disappear since Mexican customs officials began this week to enforce the levy of 100 per cent ad valorem tax on luxury goods imported from the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The House rejected today an amendment to the Administration's farm surplus disposal bill that would have curbed the nation's efforts to move surplus farm products into world markets. The vote was 74 to 37.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 15 -- Donald M. Hobart, vice-president and director of research for Curtis Publishing Company, and Wroe Alderson of Alderson Sessions, both of Philadelphia, received the Charles Coolidge Pardon Memorial Awards tonight for distinguished service in marketing.

LONDON, June 15 -- A better tone developed in the stock markets today in contrast to the weakness of the last week. Selling dried up and prices strengthened, although there was little increase in buying.

In a surprise announcement timed to coincide with what seems to be the closing days of the Geneva conference the White House reveals that Prime Minister Churchill and Secretary Eden are coming to Washington to hold informal conferences during the week-end of June 25 with President Eisenhower and Secretary Dulles on the multiple crisis confronting the free world.
On July 1 two priests of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will go to Puerto Rico for a year's work and study among the people of that Caribbean island.
DUBLIN, June 15 (AP) -- Andy Dadagian, who will captain Cornell's 1955 track team, equalled the Irish "All-comers" record tonight in the 440-yard hurdle race at Trinity College.
The main charges in the Army - McCarthy controversy now before a Senate investigating subcommittee are:

Joseph B. Cavallaro was reelected chairman of the Board of Higher Education last night. He defeated Dr. Harry J. Carman by a vote of 12 to 9 for the one-year term as the head of the board that directs the affairs of four municipal colleges.
The Ryan Aeronautical Company increased its net profit to $1,054,088 in the six months ended on April 30 from $792,833 in the corresponding period a year earlier, the report disclosed yesterday.
The Ohio Edison Company reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $19,595,506 for the twelve months ended May 31.

IN 1913, when Josephus Daniels went to Washington to become Secretary of the Navy in Woodrow Wilson's Cabinet, his son Jonathan was not quite 11 years old. For the next eight years the elder Daniels played a major role in Wilson's two Administrations and in this country's part in the First World War. His Assistant Secretary in the Navy Department was a tall, handsome, rich and charming young man named Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Our foreign relations no longer depend on diplomacy alone, or on the course of in ternational trade. A new and possibly decisive factor in this field is the American service man who is garrisoned in friendly lands across the seas.

Medical help and counseling for the young woman with heart disease who wants to have children should be sought well in advance of marriage, a heart specialist advises. He urges early guidance also for her family, since the success of the patient's pregnancy may depend on the help she receives from them.

SEATTLE, June 15 -- The Communist party in Washington state was pictured today as having had at least one member each in Congress and the Legislature and as having penetrated labor unions with considerable success. Its headway among clergymen was declared slight.

Profits of the Allied Stores Corporation in the first four months of this year were somewhat lower than those for the corresponding period last year, B. Earl Puckett, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

LONDON, June 15 -- Coventry, the city that was almost razed by the Nazi Luftwaffe during World War II, is going to invite war-battered Stalingrad to sign a special "ban the H-bomb" appeal to the United Nations Disarmament Commission.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. asked a Federal court today to dismiss a suit brought by the National Lawyers Guild.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 15 -- Gregory Peck, in Hollywood for a brief spell after two years of picture making abroad, reports having purchased in association with Robert Parrish screen rights to the Tom Lea book, "The Wonderful Country."

VIENNA, June 15 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, first secretary of the Soviet Communist party, addressing a mass meeting in Prague tonight, asserted that the Soviet Union "developed the hydrogen bomb before our enemies." His strongly worded speech was broadcast by the Prague radio.

A warning against "false prophets" who would undermine democracy in the guise of fighting subversion was voiced last night by Judge John M. Harlan of the United States Court of Appeals. He spoke at the annual commencement of the Brooklyn Law School in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
LONDON, June 15 -- Bonnie Prince Charlie of Britain and his curlytop sister Anne have already, at the tender ages of 5 and 3, far outdistanced their royal mother as style-setters in England.
Atlantic and Gulf Coast ship operators and the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., reached agreement on a new contract at 12:20 A. M. today, twenty minutes after the old one expired.

A young King and an old King are rulers of two little countries in Indochina whose names might never have appeared in the newspaper headlines were it not for the menacing shadow of war which has fallen over their peaceful rice paddies, fruitful valleys and pointed-roof palaces.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Public Housing Administration today received the best offers in close to ten years in marketing $82,923,000 worth of temporary loan notes by forty-four subsidized local housing authorities. The notes, which averaged six and seven-tenths months' maturity were purchased at an average bid of .669 per cent.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 15 -- Emanuel Kratter, 62 years old, of Port Chester, owner of Consumers Super Markets, Inc., Greenwich, Conn., pleaded not guilty today to charges that he had conspired with a bank bookkeeper to cover up $40,193 in overdrafts in his behalf at the private bank of Kavey Sons, 6 South Main Street, Port Chester.

THE Brooklyn Museum yesterday placed on view in its entrance hall two sets of tapestries presented by the Hearst Foundation in memory of William Randolph Hearst. One of these, illustrating five episodes in the life of the Roman hero Coriolanus, was executed in Paris and dates from about 1625.

THE one-two favorites for the United States open, which begins tomorrow at Baltusrol in near-by Springfield, N. J., undoubtedly will be Ben Hogan and Sam Snead. The choice of Blazin' Ben and Slammin' Sam is automatic, one of those force-of-habit things. Yet each is 42 years old. Gone is the resiliency of youth. Hogan still hasn't shaken off a virus attack.

Your editorial and Judge Samuel Hofstadter's letter published June 2 point to a question that millions of Americans ask: What can the Senate do about Senator McCarthy? Past history of Senate proceedings contains some interesting precedents.

A study over many years of the records of Maternity Hospital in Aberdeen, Scotland, has established that women of the lowest "social class" have more difficulties bearing healthy children than do women in more fortunate circumstances, it was reported here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today called upon the Eisenhower Administration to cancel at once all secrecy "blackout" orders, so his investigating subcommittee could hunt treason in high places.
The 57-year-old Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., is going to spread its activities throughout the state.

Earl B. Dickerson, president of the National Lawyers Guild, announced yesterday that he had written to Senator Karl E. Mundt, chairman of the Army-McCarthy hearings, asking him to read aloud into the record a statement by the guild.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Six railroads today urged the Interstate Commerce Commission to cancel its order delaying for seven months the railroads' plan to start hauling loaded trailer trucks on railroad flat cars.

One need not be a chess enthusiast to welcome the Soviet-American team match which opens here tonight at the Hotel Roosevelt. We in this country admire superlative ability in any field where it is shown, and the Soviet chess masters who are our guests have demonstrated their excellence time and again.
LONDON, June 15 -- Sir Winston Churchill and Anthony Eden plan to discuss bringing West Germany into the Atlantic alliance when they meet President Eisenhower in Washington.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 16 -- The existence of a puppet "Free Thailand" regime in Communist China was brought today to the attention of the United Nations Security Council.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 16 -- The Brazilian Chamber of Deputies rejected today by 136 to 37 a motion to impeach President Getulio D. Vargas.

Hunter College will confer 918 degrees in course today at its 106th commencement, which will be held on Bronx campus at Bedford Park Boulevard and Goulden Avenue. Dr. George N. Shuster, president of the college, will preside.

FOG pockets have cut off-shore fishing activity in many coastal areas, but they have not reduced in-shore trolling or the bay fishing. The resulting concentration in those waters has improved the catch reports.
Testimony released yesterday disclosed that the "weapon" about which Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer had doubts in 1949 was a hydrogen bomb in theory only.

Assured after the signing of a new agreement early yesterday that, for at least one year, their ships will be manned by unlicensed personnel, Atlantic and Gulf Coast operators opened intensive contract negotiations last night with two officer groups.
LONDON, June 16 -- The River Thames is to be a kind of "helicopter highway" along which passengers can reach the heart of London after arrival on international airliners.
A $50,000,000 slum clearance and housing program for the Rockaways was announced last night with a prediction that the area would become a resort rivaling Atlantic City.

The electric utility industry will spend $35,000,000,000 on new plant and equipment in the next decade, according to a joint estimate yesterday by General Electric Company and Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- The American Meat Institute reported today that sharp declines in the wholesale prices of bacon, ham and other pork cuts had resulted in hog prices reaching the lowest level in several months.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- An angry debate today over Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's asserted right to receive and divulge secret Government documents delayed conclusion of the Army-McCarthy hearings until tomorrow.
A good summer for newspaper advertising departments is in the offing.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, June 16 -Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah of the Gold Coast, whose party won a substantial victory at the polls yesterday, will call on the Governor, Sir Charles Noble Arden-Clarke, at Christiansborg Castle here tomorrow.

GUATEMALA CITY, June 16 -- Guatemala's chief export crop. coffee, this year will be about 50,000 quintals -- some 5,000,000 pounds -- above last year's crop. according to estimates by the Central Coffee Office carried in the newspaper Impacto. (A quintal is 101.43 pounds.)
EL CENTRO, Calif., June 16 -- Mexican border jumpers by the scores and hundreds, generally gaunt, ill-clad and penniless, were streaming out of the bushes and fields of southern California today.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization today moved to get the Government's stalled metals purchase program rolling by authorizing payment at the current market price.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, said in the McCarthy-Army hearings today that an attempt was made during the New Deal to "get" J. Edgar Hoover and replace him as Federal Bureau of Investigation director with a politician.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UP) -- A small band of Senate Democrats failed at least temporarily today in a surprise move to overrule the Administration and put a nineteen-division "floor" under Army strength in the 1955 fiscal year.

BOSTON, June 16 (AP) -- The nation's rising school population was spotlighted today when school building designs won twelve of the thirty-eight awards, including three of the six honor awards, voted at the American Institute of Architects' eighty-sixth annual convention.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 16 -- A 35-year-old man known to his neighbors in New Hyde Park, L. I., as David Grossman was arrested as he emerged from the Nassau County grand jury room yesterday after completing testimony against four teen-age boys accused of robbing his home.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today coupled an appeal for enactment of his legislative program with a bit of nostalgic recollection how he used to dip into the neighborhood grocer's pickle barrel.
GUATEMALA, June 16 -- Events of great potential political importance have been piling up here within the past twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended June 9:

More than $10,000,000,000 of assets and at least 4,000,000 investor accounts will be serviced by investment companies and mutual funds in this country by 1960, it was predicted yesterday. This amount is double the present asset figures and 1,000 per cent more than in 1940, when investment companies began their present period of growth.

LONDON, June 16 (AP) -- The International Wheat Council began a week-long behind-closed-doors conference today against the background of a wheat glut and the recent cuts in American and Canadian export prices.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Senator Robert C. Hendrickson, Republican of New Jersey, said today that three out of every four school and college students who took part in a recent New Jersey poll "brushed aside lying and cheating as acts which are not considered delinquent."
MIAMI, Fla., June 15 -- The landing of six paratroopers in the Pacific Coast section of Guatemala was reported to the police there last night.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Atomic Energy Commission, in seeking to determine whether Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer held back the development of the hydrogen bomb by his lack of enthusiasm, pondered today a conflict of testimony between the two scientists chiefly responsible for the bomb's success.

The Gourmet Society had a good idea when it asked the Newarker Restaurant to build a dinner around New Jersey foods. Ninety members and friends of this local society, to which anyone devoted to gastronomy may belong, dined earlier this week in the sightly eating establishment overlooking the Newark Airport on fish, fowl, vegetables and fruits of the Garden State.
Governor Dewey has informed several friends that he has reached a "definite and irrevocable" decision to retire from public office at the end of his present term.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Three Puerto Ricans were convicted here today of assault with intent to kill and assault with a dangerous weapon upon five members of Congress.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The transcript of the hearing before the Gray Board in the case of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer is so voluminous -- half a million words -- that many days and pages of newspaper space would be required for adequate appraisal by the most diligent and impartial of summarists.
CHELSEA, Mich., June 16 -The Chrysler Corporation dedicated its new 4,000-acre multimillion dollar proving ground sixty miles west of Detroit today.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and closed slightly irregular, 6 points higher to 5 points lower.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16 (AP) -- George F. Kennan, former Ambassador to Russia, said today that millions of Americans had been "stampeded into a panicky, ridiculous and even dangerous attitude" that see no solution to "our conflict with Soviet power" except in the horrors of atomic war.

LONDON, June 16 -- The Geneva conference has shown that the basic Communist policy of expansion is unchanged and that consequently Britain must do her utmost to "maintain the integrity of Southeast Asia," Earl Alexander declared today.

LOS ANGELES, June 16 (AP) -- I. Roland Harriman, National Red Cross chairman, today described supplemental aid given tornado victims last year in Flint, Mich.; Waco, Tex., and Worcester, Mass. -- after the Red Cross ad done its work -- as "frosting in the cake."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16 -- Harvard College seniors held Class Day ceremonies today as some 10,000 alumni and their families returned to the banks of the Charles River.

Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman of Stadium Concerts, asserted yesterday that every possible effort was being made to re-route planes away from Lewisohn Stadium during the concert season. She predicted confidently that at the opening concert Monday evening "there won't be a plane in the sky."

Defense counsel in Federal Court sought to show yesterday that the treatment of Arnold Bernstein during his imprisonment by the Nazis was not of a nature that would subject him to pressure or duress by the representatives of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.
Three hold-up men took the silver out of a Brooklyn couple's silver wedding anniversary early yesterday morning.

Frank Costello invoked the Fifth Amendment yesterday in refusing to answer seventeen of twenty-two questions about his assets. Federal Judge Edward A. conger scheduled a hearing for June 29 on a Government motion to cite the gambler for contempt.
Following are brief identification of witnesses who testified before the United States Atomic Energy Commission's Personnel Security Board hearing on Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer:

Commodity prices on the New York exchanges closed irregularly higher yesterday. Coffee, wool, rubber, cottonseed oil, burlap, lead and zinc were stronger; cocoa and hides ended lower, and sugar, soybean oil, potatoes, silk and tin closed mixed.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has been asked to decide whether Robert R. Young and associates have legally acquired control of the New York Central Railroad Company.

The proposal of Webb Knapp to build a $4,000,000 bus terminal in Flushing, Queens, received impetus yesterday when it was disclosed to have received the support of City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses.
The Naval War College at Newport, R. I., oldest of the service war colleges, ended another academic year yesterday with the graduation of more than 200 students.

I must take issue with your editorial of June 11 in which you describe the recently enacted program for rehabilitation of the Long Island Rail Road as a "good plan" for which there is "simply no acceptable alternative."

TRENTON, June 16 -- Former State Treasurer Walter T. Margetts Jr. was summoned here today to explain why he had ignored for five years the financial operations of the State Division of Employment Security. In that period the agency was headed by former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman.

The ends of beef rib bones, covered with layers of fat and lean, are known as the short ribs. Usually economical, they now may be had for 20 to 30 cents a portion. This recipe, in which the ribs are marinated before cooking, elaborates the usual method of braising them:

William Faulkner's new novel, "A Fable," will be issued Aug. 2 by Random House. The story's background is France during Passion week in 1918. The publisher says it is "a parable, an allegory, a morality" about soldiers and civilians during a mutiny in the trenches.

Charles Gaynor, who wrote the lyrics, music and all but one of the sketches in "Lend an Ear," the hit revue of 1948, has provided the framework for another Broadway-bound intimate musical called "Between Friends."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16 -- Fear still is widespread in American colleges and universities, but much of it is "self-generated.'' The Harvard Crimson said today in reporting on its annual survey of academic freedom.

New York's provincialism, differing little from that of any other American community, signifies the vigor of democracy, Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College, told its graduating class last night.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Eisenhower said today that the purpose of Sir Winston Churchill's forthcoming visit was to keep strong the bridge between the United States and Britain.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Eisenhower discussed these topics in his news conference:

A revised salary plan for 80,000 civil service employes of the city was made public yesterday at City Hall. It will be the subject of a public hearing before the Board of Estimate at 10:30 A. M. on June 25.

Legislative committees perform a vital function in spurring the national defense against Communist subversion, Municipal Court Justice Robert Morris declared yesterday. The former counsel of the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee spoke at a luncheon of the Twenty-third Street Association in the Gramercy Park Hotel.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., June 16 -- The Hudson River Conservation Society joined today in the fight to prevent "destruction" of Grand View and Piermont in Rockland County by a projected spur of the New York-Buffalo Thruway.

LONDON, June 16 (UP) -- Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif.; Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, and Mrs. Margaret Osborne du Pont of Wilmington, Del., gained the quarter-finals in their singles divisions in the London grass court tennis championships today.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse as required by White House rules:
ALBANY, June 16 (AP) -- A New York City spokesman described the New York Telephone Company's earnings today as higher than the Public Service Commission had judged adequate.
BERN, Switzerland, June 16 (Reuters) -- Six top-notch American chefs set out today to show the world there is more to cooking in the United States than opening tin cans.
The share of this country's foreign waterborne commerce moving in American-flag vessels continues to drop, the American Merchant Marine Institute said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- While President Eisenhower described recent developments in Guatemala as very disturbing, the State Department said today that the Communist-dominated government there had been trying to buy large quantities of military vehicles, aircraft and ammunition.

Today's new film is "The Student Prince," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer remake of the Sigmund Romberg operetta, in Cinema-Scope and Ansco Color, at the Radio City Music Hall. Ann Blyth, Edmund Purdom, John Ericson, Louis Calhern and Edmund Gwenn head the cast.
MEXICO CITY, June 16 -- The 16-year-old daughter of the President of Guatemala and the wife of a former Guatemalan foreign minister have arrived in Mexico.

HAWTHORNE, N. Y., June 16 -- State troopers said tonight they had captured the last member of a gang of "party bandits" that recently raided Westchester County homes. Identified as Dominick Tribote, he was arrested in Brooklyn this afternoon.
PARIS, June 16 -- The Tunisian Cabinet was endangered today by the resignation of one Minister and the threatened resignations of three other members.

Cantor Walter Davidson of Temple Beth Emeth, Brooklyn, was re-elected president of the American Conference of Certified Cantors at the Park Sheraton Hotel yesterday afternoon. The conference was organized last June. This was its first annual convention. An attendance of 150 delegates from this country and Canada was reported.

LONDON, June 16 -- The news that Sir Winston Churchill and Anthony Eden would visit Washington and yesterday's rise on Wall Street helped the stock markets here to recover today. Buying expanded moderately, especially for industrials, and prices advanced in nearly all fields.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The House of Representatives passed the Administration's $1,300,000,000 farm surplus disposal bill today without any curbs on East-West trade.

The Transit Authority agreed yesterday in negotiations with the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., to prepare for an election by its 44,000 employes of unions to represent them in grievance proceedings.

LONDON, June 16 -- The British Government is planning to propose the evacuation of all its 80,000 troops in the Suez Canal Zone. The proposal is to be made immediately after the Churchill-Eden visit to Washington late this month.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -President Eisenhower said today he had discussed political plans with Governor Dewey, but he believed it was up to the Governor to decide for himself what he would do.
GENEVA, June 16 -- South Korea's Foreign Minister said today failure of the Far Eastern conference here to unify his country had invalidated the Korean armistice.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 16 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner today held out an olive branch to top leaders of the New Jersey State Federation of Labor. He expressed the opinion that "misunderstandings'' between his office and the federation could be resolved at a personal meeting.
Russia's chess team gained a 5-1 lead over the American contingent early this morning as the international tournament between the two countries ended its first day.
In the published comments on the Oppenheimer case it seems to me that too little consideration has been given to what is encompassed in the term or concept of "national security."

BONN, Germany, June 16 -- The first anniversary of the uprising of the working class in East Berlin and East Germany against their Communist rulers was commemorated today throughout West Germany, with speeches, resolutions, and open-air meetings along the zonal border.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 16 -- Following is the text of a resolution submitted today to the United Nation Security Council by Thailand:

The spirits of quite a few members of the New York Public Library staff were at low ebb yesterday. The first of the 1954 summer concerts outdoors in Bryant Park was getting off to a halting start, after elaborate preparations.

BERLIN, June 16 -- The West began elaborate ceremonies tonight to mark the first anniversary of the uprising that threatened to unseat the East German Government last June 17. The Communists did their best to make the populace forget about it.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 16 (AP) -- Frederic W. Ecker, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, said here today thre were indications that the economic downtrend was ending and that an improvement would soon be evident.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 16 -- Gen. Paul Ely, French military and political chief in Indochina, is scheduled to leave tomorrow for consultations in Paris, amid a highly fluid political situation marked by Cabinet upheavals both in France and Vietnam.
The invitation was formal. It read: "The U. S. O. Opera Group, seven men from the Navy of the United States, request the pleasure of Mme. Leyla Gencer's company at dinner."
MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 16 -- A Dewey Administration commission is considering the possibility of putting the state's personal income tax on the same withholding basis used by the Federal Government.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 16 -- The State Board of Education today sold $26,692,000 in school building loans to a syndicate headed by Ira Haupt Co. and Glore, Forgan Co. for an average interest rate of 2.689 per cent.

DETROIT, June 16 (UP) -- Williard Nixon pitched a four-hitter today to snap the Boston Red Sox out of an eight-game losing streak, but he needed a couple of unearned runs for a 3-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

Joseph D. Nunan and his wife, Kathryn Murphy Nunan, had $170,000 in cash on deposit before the 1933 bank holiday, according to testimony yesterday at the trial of the former Commissioner of Internal Revenue for tax evasion in Brooklyn Federal Court.
FORT DEVENS, Mass., June 16 (UP) -- Alex Litman, a 34-yearold sergeant, captured the 220yard dash for the fifth consecutive year at the all-Army track and field championships today.
There is still no checking the blistering pace of our Giants, who at the moment seem to be New York's antidote to the cold snap.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- State Department officials cited yesterday's statement in Geneva by Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Under Secretary of State, to answer suggestions that South Korea was now free to take whatever action it chose.
The main charges in the Army - McCarthy controversy now before a Senate investigagating subcommittee are:
With volume topping 2,000,000 shares for the first time since last week's sell-off, stocks wiped out yesterday the last remnants of that decline and pushed forward to new highs for 1954.

BALTIMORE, June 16 -- Another sharp pitching performance by Ed (Whitey) Ford, who now owns a string of twenty consecutive scoreless innings, highlighted the Yankees' 2-0 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.

Directors of the Permanente Cement Company recommended a stock dividend of one share for each share held to effect a two-for-one stock split, and also increased the quarterly cash dividend to 40 cents.

BELFAST, Ireland, June 16 (AP) -- Victor Milligan, a Belfast civil engineer who will enter Purdue University in September, set an Irish record for the mile run tonight when he defeated Dave Pratt of Ithaca, N. Y., and Cornell University by 30 yards in an international track and field meet.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Office of Defense Mobilization today gave its sanction to a $170,000,000 pipeline capable of delivering 500,000 barrels of petroleum products daily to Newark, N. J.

CAIRO, June 16 -- Maj. Salah Salem, Minister of National Guidance, announced today that Kamal el-Malakh, the discoverer of the Cheops solar boats at Giza, and Dr. Zakaria Ghoneim, discoverer of a Third Dynasty unfinished pyramid and tomb at Sakkara, would be sent to New York for the opening of an Egyptian Tourist Bureau there.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Representative Carl Hinshaw, Republican of California, said today a semi-secret summary of the proceedings in the security case of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, and some secret Federal Bureau of Investigation documents, were lost or stolen last Friday night.

The heavyweight championship of the world will be at stake tonight when Rocky Marciano of Brockton, Mass., opposes Ezzard Charles, the challenger and former champion from Cincinnati. at the Yankee Stadium. The fight is scheduled for fifteen rounds and will start at 10:30.
The city's long-term plan for developing the Brooklyn Civic Center area came much closer to realization yesterday by a city sale of twenty acres of condemned slums in the Fort Greene area.

When the nation Voted Mr. Eisenhower into the White House in 1952 it did so, in part at least, because it saw in him a man who had not only a coherent economic philosophy but a philosophy that stressed traditional American values and traditional American institutions.

ALMOST everybody in the South writes novels these days, and Robert Tallant writes some of the funniest. His new book, "Mrs. Candy Strkies It Rich,"* is a cheerful comedy based on reliable plots that Mr. Tallant probably picked up while shopping in the antique stores on Royal Street in the French Quarter of New Orleans.

If someone told us that Tiffany's had aluminum ware on display in their Fifth Avenue show windows we would be justified in suspecting a hoax of some sort; perhaps a bizarre effect resulting from one of the television programs that specializes in zany stunts and fabulous prizes.
An 11-year-old Korean pianist arrived in New York last night as one of the good things to come out of the Korean war.
Clarence Henry, 27 - year - old heavyweight boxer, was indicted yesterday on a charge of offering a bribe to another fighter to lose a match in Madison Square Garden last Friday night.
Magistrate Paul Balsam in Lower Manhattan Court gave a suspended sentence yesterday and 15 cents carfare to a shipyard worker who made the mistake of asking a plainclothes policeman for a handout.
INWOOD, L. I., June 16 -- Mrs. Maxon Berger of Glen Oaks, the former Cookie Swift, gained the quarter-finals in the women's Metropolitan Golf Association's fifty-first annual championship today.

The Appellate Division rejected yesterday an employer's contention that workers discharged on the basis of an adverse Government security report were not entitled to seek reinstatement under the arbitration provisions of their union contract.
NEW DELHI, India, June 16 -- The Indian Government has demanded the withdrawal of the French troops who landed today in Pondicherry, the principal French settlement on India's east coast.
The city's basic real estate tax rate for 1954-55 will be fixed by the City Council next Tuesday at $3.68 for each $100 of assessed valuation.

In The Times of June 7, tucked away on page 29, is a statement by Premier Menderes of Turkey warning of a "Munich" at Geneva. This statement is so forthright, so pertinent to the present situation at Geneva, that I am of the opinion it deserved a more prominent position.

Though the legendary Lorelei may have emerged from the waves and combed her hair with devastating charm on the rocks, the average modern miss doesn't relish caring for her tresses during a summer vacation. With that in mind, hair stylists have created coiffures that a woman can manage easily despite frequent dips in the ocean.

TODAY, 3 to 5 P. M.: Costumed dolls from twenty lands are on view at the New York Public Library's Countee Cullen branch, 104 West 136th Street. Dolls from England, Scotland and European and South American countries are accompanied by illustrations and picture books of scenes in those countries.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, is not the only victim of the "chicken-luncheon" technique, according to a University of California scientist.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- President Eisenhower signed today legislation increasing benefits an average of $24 a month for about 36,000 pensioners covered by the Railroad Retirement Act. The increases are retroactive to Oct. 30, 1951.
WITH two highly contrasting one-man shows and a number of summer group exhibitions, the pulse of the art world continues to beat strongly.

The Dodgers blasted five home runs into Ebbets Field's left-field stands last night to the delight of 14,237 chilled fans. This distance-hitting exhibition produced an 8-4 victory over the Braves that squared the series at 1 -- 1 and kept the Brooks within one game of the league-leading Giants.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission deferred today a ruling on a motion by Otis Co. to dismiss the agency's action to revoke Otis' brokerage license.
SPRINGFIELD, N. J., June 16 "I'm ready," said Ben Hogan as he completed practice for the fifty-fourth United States Open golf championship at the Baltusrol Golf Club today.
WEST POINT, N. Y., June 16 (AP) -- Three seeded players reached the semi-final round of the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships today with straight-set victories.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 16 -- Harry A. Murray, merchandise manager at Lord Taylor, captured the Simon F. Rothschild Cup, chief prize at the twenty-fifth annual Retail Dry Goods Association and New York City newspaper publishers golf tournament at the Century Country Club today.
The Phillips Petroleum Company announced yesterday that it intended to appeal to Congress the recent decision against it by the United States Supreme Court.

Judge Peter T. Farrell of the Queens County Court in Long Island City dismissed yesterday an indictment charging two physicians with second-degree manslaughter in the death of a 10-year-old boy from India.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Irregular trends marked the trade in grain futures today, while in soybeans the July contract soared to a new high price for the present upturn. Wheat, after opening lower, had a good advance but met the usual increased selling on the hard spots.
SEATTLE, June 16 -- A witness chided members of the House Committee on Un-American activities and called the chairman "a phony" in a tumultuous session late today.
PARIS, June 16 -- The news of the forthcoming visit to Washington by Prime Minister Churchill and Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, provoked somewhat bitter comments in Paris today.

A syndicate headed by Putnam Co., Charles W. Scranton Co. and Estabrook Co., will place on the market today 200,000 shares of $2.06 dividend preferred stock of the Connecticut Light and Power Company at a price of $50 a share.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 16 -- A platform in space from which to make recordings of celestial activities was predicted here today as being only "decades" off.

CAN Ezzard Charles pitch a no-hitter? That would seem to be the key question as he prepares to enter the Yankee Stadium ring tonight against Rocky Marciano, the world heavyweight champion. The belief here is that the Brockton Blockbuster cannot help but land at least one home run clout during fifteen rounds

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A witness today accused the staff of the House's special committee investigating tax-free foundations of trying to "rewrite history" and of having put the inquiry on a false trail.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington before the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in its thirty-fifth day of hearings on the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
