CHICAGO, June 16 (UP) -- Four former champions today gained the quarter-finals in the twenty-fifth annual women's Western open golf tournament at the Glen Flora Country Club.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 -- Dr. Gaylord P. Harnwell, president of the University of Pennsylvania, conferred 1,981 degrees in course, 126 diplomas and seven honorary degrees at the university's 198th commencement here today.

CLEVELAND, June 16 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians broke loose tonight for three runs in the seventh inning after being blanked on two hits by Washington's Mickey McDermott. That rally provided the impetus for a 5-1 victory over the Senators and enabled the Tribe to keep its three-game hold on first place in the American League.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 16 -- "War and Peace," the monumental literary work by Leo Tolstoy, will be brought to the screen by David O. Selznick on a scale that is expected to surpass his epic film, "Gone With the Wind."

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 16 (AP) -- The Venezuelan Government will build a $60,000,000 steel mill on the Orinoco River near Puerto Ordaz, Col. Luis Felipe Flovera Paez, director of the Office of Special Studies, announced today.

The International Seamen's Recreation Council has taken over sponsorship of the International Lifeboat Race in New York Harbor, the group announced yesterday. The races had been arranged in the last two years by the American Seamen's Friend Society, which has decided to relinquish its role.
State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein moved yesterday against a "bishop" whom he accused of operating under a religious guise for personal profit.

William Haggin Perry's bay filly Trying, who made her debut by winning at Belmont Park last week, followed that success with a signal one at Aqueduct yesterday. Competing in an eight-horse field in the $13,550 Astoria Stakes for juvenile fillies, the Perry color-bearer registered a head triumph over Mrs. Wallace Gilroy's Fashion Page.
VIENNA, June 16 (AP) -- Vienna music critics today unanimously hailed Blanche Thebom's debut in the Austrian capital.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, served about 225 subpoenas today on all the regular participants at the Army-McCarthy hearings.

A. $1,270,000 contract to build a ventilating building for the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel was let yesterday by the Port of New York Authority. The 155-foot-high structure will be erected on West Thirty-eighth Street east of Twelfth Avenue. It has been designed to span the roadway, so that the traffic flow will not be impeded.
The copper industry's position brightened considerably last month, a Copper Institute report showed yesterday.

MONTREAL, June 16 -- C. D. Howe, Canada's Minister of Trade and Commerce, expressed tonight strong disappointment over United States trade policies that, he said, "are beclouding the international economic picture."

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Sears, Roebuck Co. today released its 1954 fall general catalogue. Edward Gudeman, Sears merchandising vice president, said that the publication, listing more than 100,000 items, offered the lowest prices since 1950.
The permanent financing of New York State's $962,000,000 Thruway passed the halfway mark yesterday with the sale of $300,000,000 of revenue bonds to a nation-wide syndicate of 475 investment houses.

A group headed by Hanns Ditisheim, investment banker, has bought 220,000 common shares of Butler Brothers, Chicago general merchandise house, and is planning a general reorganization of its operations, Mr. Ditisheim announced yesterday.

CALHOUN, Tenn., June 16 (AP) -- The Bowaters Southern Paper Corporation is testing machinery at its big multi-million-dollar newsprint plant near here preparatory to starting production within the next few weeks, officials said yesterday.

The Army's issuance of an "undesirable discharge," without hearing, to an enlisted radar instructor at Fort Monmouth, N. J., is being appealed to Secretary of the Army Robert T. Stevens. The action is being taken by Norman Thomas, former Socialist candidate for President, and the Workers Defense League, an 18-year-old legal aid group here.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 16 -- A highway authority predicted here today that residents of New York City in the future might be forced by heavy surface traffic to travel on underground conveyors.

MILWAUKEE, June 16 -- The American Federation of Musicians' rule that requires a theatre operator to hire a local stand-by orchestra when a traveling "big name" orchestra is playing was criticized here by James C. Petrillo, president of the A. F. L. union.
John Francis Roche was named yesterday in four first degree murder indictments.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 -- Dr. Edward Teller, Professor of Physics at the University of California, has won wide recognition in astrophysics, geophysics and physical chemistry as well as in nuclear physics.

Alfred E. Perlman, new president and chief executive officer of the New York Central Railroad, began his tour of inspection of the system's properties yesterday. Mr. Perlman, after his election on Monday, said he expected to live on the railroad in his business car for several months finding out "just what the system needs."
GENEVA, June 16 -- Conciliatory proposals from the Communists on the question of Cambodia and Laos gave the Far East conference here a new lease on life today.

Southbound vehicular traffic was barred from the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive between Fifty-third and Thirty-fourth Streets for more than an hour yesterday as the result of a fire at Thirty-eighth Street.

Following are excerpts from the testimony of leading witnesses in the hearings on Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer before the Personnel Security Board of the United States Atomic Energy Commission. The excerpts have been selected in the main to cover phases of the controversy not previously explored extensively in textual matter published in The New York Times.
BERLIN, June 16 -- Recent trends in Soviet policy have led some observers here to believe Moscow soon may sponsor a new Berlin conference at which the Russians would champion West German sovereignty.
Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, returned from Rome yesterday with a comment on a recent speech by Senator Ralph Flanders that accused Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of dividing the country.

CHICAGO, June 16 (UP) -- Ferris Fain slugged an inside-the-par grand slam home run in a seven-run seventh inning today to spark the Chicago White Sox to an 11 to 6 victory which broke a five-game Philadelphia Athletics' winning streak.

The marital difficulties between Jackie Gleason, television comedian, and his wife, Mrs. Genevieve Gleason, appeared to be nearing settlement yesterday, when Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht Jr. directed that the matter be placed on the calendar of Special Term Part III for hearing tomorrow morning.
The old International Longshoremen's Association informed a court-appointed receiver yesterday that it hoped to be able to get itself in the clear by tomorrow.
The nation's gasoline production and inventory was reduced last week by 1,226,000 and 2,401,000 barrels, respectively, the weekly report of the American Petroleum Institute disclosed yesterday.

MELBOURNE, June 16 -- Thomas Playford of South Austria announced today that experimental drilling since March had disclosed uranium over an area of 500 square miles, seventy-five miles northwest of Radium Hill, in the northeast part of the state, where uranium already is being mined. Mr. Playford said the new fields showed promise of many millions of tons of uranium ore.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UP) -- Robert T. Vogeler, United States business man who was imprisoned in Communist Hungary on "spy" charges, was introduced by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today as a "loyal American" and one of his unpaid consultants on communism.
One man was acquitted yesterday of charges of conspiracy to defraud the Government in connection with a Government contract. A Federal Court jury disagreed in the case of two other men.

Striking X-ray motion pictures of the first gasp for breath of a baby at the time of birth were shown here yesterday afternoon. The showing came at the close of the second annual conference on "Research in Congenital Malformations," arranged by the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children.
May I commend The New York Times for its eminently fair and objective reporting of the many incidents in the controversy over Facts Forum.

JERUSALEM, June 16 -- A bill dealing with crimes against the state passed the first reading in the Knesset (Parliament) today. It was approved by 39 to 16 and sent to committee for some amendments and changes in language.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, said today it was his '"understanding" that Defense Department security clearance had been denied two staff members of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's investigating subcommittee.

THIRTY long years have gone aglimmering since Sigmund Romberg's "The Student Prince" first made theatrical promotion for Old Heidelberg, beer and romance. And in that period a virtual revolution has occurred in the field of the operetta, which, of course, is what "The Student Prince" is.
The Long Island Rail Road will ask the Federal District Court in Brooklyn today to take it out of bankruptcy.

BONN, Germany, June 17 -- The State Government of Schleswig-Holstein has banned a meeting of European Fascists scheduled in Luebeck from June 24 to June 26, the newspaper Die Welt of Hamburg reported today.
The Book-of-the-Month Club, Inc., announced yesterday plans to purchase frequency modulation station WABF. At the beginning, at least, it may operate the radio outlet without advertising commercials.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Twenty-three Senators joined today in a move for approval this year of President Eisenhower's liberal foreign-trade program over Republican opposition.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Eisenhower touched off today another fight over public versus private power.
DETROIT, June 17 -- Adlai E. Stevenson expressed relief today that the "melancholy spectacle" of the McCarthy-Army hearings in Washington were nearing an end.

Refrigerated ready-to-bake sour milk or baking powder biscuits, popped into a hot oven for eight to ten minutes until golden-crusted, tender and begging for butter, are an ideal hot bread to serve with cold summer meals.

BALTIMORE, June 17 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, today accused Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of actions that "would substitute government by an individual for government by law." Mr. Brownell did not mention the Wisconsin Republican by name.

A selection of resplendent bridal gowns for fall and winter was shown last night at Russeks. Designed for the store by Henri Mulle, the dresses varied in style and fabric just enough to please the bride of 1954 who wants to blend the useful with the traditional.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 17 -- The decline of American power and prestige in the world was attributed by a speaker here today to the error of thinking that "evil fanatics" could be contained by reason and negotiation.

GENEVA, June 17 -- The democratic delegations to the Far Eastern conference here gave intense consideration today to new perspectives opened by seeming concessions on Indochina presented yesterday by the Communist spokesmen.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Following is the text of a letter by Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, to Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota and chairman of the Senate's Army-McCarthy investigation, explaining Mr. Stevens' contact with Clark Clifford, former special counsel to President Truman:

Five attorneys, including two former top assistants on the staff of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, were assigned yesterday to defend John Francis Roche, who was indicted Wednesday on four first degree murder charges.

Something new has been added at the United Nations. Along the esplanade that faces the East River benches have been installed. Composed of three heavy wooden planks resting on concrete supports, each is about eight feet long.

In the testimony before the House Committee on Foreign Affairs high officials of the United States Department of State asserted that "there is a new spirit in Iraq" and "a new feeling of friendship toward the United States," that members of the Iraq Government are making "open and effective" anti-Communist speeches and that the Iraqi Army indeed has become a "stabilizing force" in the Middle East.

Federal authorities picked up the passport of Hubert Fauntleroy Julian, once celebrated as the Black Eagle of Harlem and Ethiopian aviation, yesterday. They were also threatening him with prosecution if he failed to register as a foreign agent of Guatemala.

Active negotiation on plans for a large bleached-sulphate kraft pulp mill in Western Canada was announced yesterday by the St. Regis Paper Company, New York, and North Canadian Oils, Ltd., Calgary, Alberta.

The fact that most women's ready-to-wear shops have a monotonous sameness was criticized yesterday by Bernard G. Cohn, president of Independent Retailers Syndicate, Inc., resident buying office. He blamed a lack of daring in operations for this situation.

NEWARK, June 17 -- A license to operate three raffles June 21 to Aug. 16, issued to the volunteer Protection Fire Company 1 of Woodbridge, was ordered suspended today by the commission controlling legalized games of chance. This was its first license suspension.

DAPHNE DU MAURIER, one of the most regularly popular of living novelists, has not been bedazzled by her success. In a recent interview granted to a reporter for The London News Chronicle she said that her talent was "a flair for telling a story people enjoy reading, and that's about as far as it goes," and added: "There are people who can polish and people who can't polish.

A left-wing Chinese newspaper was fined $25,000 yesterday and three of its officers were given jail sentences by Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan for inducing Chinese here to send money illegally to Communist China. A fourth official received a one-year suspended sentence.
OTTAWA, June 17 -- Sir Winston Churchill will visit Ottawa after he talks with President Eisenhower in Washington this month.

SEATTLE, June 17 -- Testimony today by the chief witness at the hearings here of the House Un-American Activities Committee was disputed in part by a druggist named as a Communist and a contributor to Communist party funds.
CAMDEN, N. J., June 17 -- Sgt. Georg Haegle, Delaware River Port Authority Police Department, had a toss of a coin today to thank for his promotion to lieutenant.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 17 -- Four men who represented themselves as members of the Soviet Embassy staff at Washington spent a half-hour at the Birmingham Chamber of Commerce building today. They failed in efforts to be allowed to tour Birmingham's steel plants.
PARIS, June 17 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from a speech today by Premier - designate Pierre Mendes-France to the French National Assembly.
JERUSALEM, June 17 -- The United Jewish Appeal will conduct a four-month drive starting Sept. 1, to raise $50,000,000 in cash on its pledges for the year.
James J. McAleer wished yesterday that detectives of the West Fifty-fourth Street station had applied to him the advice Othello gave Iago: "Let him not know't and he's not robb'd at all."

CHICAGO, June 17 (UP) -- Lefty Jack Harshman lasted only six innings against the Philadelphia Athletics today, but gained his third victory of the season as the Chicago White Sox belted Alex Kellner and Ed Burtsohy for twelve hits and a 6-to-4 triumph before 12,807 ladies' day fans Kellner suffered his eighth defeat against three victories.
The oil industry is getting rid of its excess inventories in an efficient manner, according to P. C. Spencer, president of the Sinclair Oil Company.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Demetrius and the Gladiators," a Twentieth Century-Fox sequel to "The Robe," filmed in CinemaScope and Technicolor, with Victor Mature, Susan Hayward, Michael Rennie and Debra Paget, is at the Roxy.
Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop Rockefeller have agreed on terms of a separation and property settlement it was anounced yesterday by Ephraim London, one of Mrs. Rockefeller's lawyers.

MOSCOW, June 17 -- The United States formally protested to the Soviet Foreign Office today publication by the satirical Soviet journal Krokodil of a cartoon directed against the late James M. Forrestal, former United States Defense Secretary.

Two Alaskan cities borrowed $3,325,000 on bond issues yesterday to finance various public improvements at interest costs ranging from 3.847 per cent to 4.34 per cent. The money will be used to pave roads, expand telephone and other public utility services and to build an auditorium.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 -- The role of college-trained women in meeting the acute national shortage of scientific and technical personnel is the theme of a two-day conference that opened today on the campus of Bryn Mawr College.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee, with Administration backing, moved today to put new pressure on France and Italy for ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty.

At the meeting of the Hungarian Workers (Communist) party, held on May 30 in the presence of Marshal Klementi Voroshilov in Budapest, Prime Minister Imre Nagy announced the Hungarian Workers party's future collaboration with the peasants and with the intelligentsia.

As scientists we are particularly concerned about the implications of the majority finding in the Oppenheimer security hearing. We know Professor Oppenheimer as a brilliant physicist and teacher who has made a very important contribution to our country's military power.
BANGKOK, Thailand, June 17 -- A high official said today that any report that a "Free Thai" Communist regime in China was prepared to function in Thailand was "without foundation."

QUANTICO, Va., June 17 -- Coincident with the close of the Army - McCarthy hearings, the Eisenhower Administration's first team of national security planners opened a three-day conference here this evening on the state of the country's defenses.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Senate passed today the Administration's $29,000,000,000 "new Look" military budget for the 1955 fiscal year beginning July 1. Democratic efforts to block a planned reduction in Army strength were defeated.

Although the Geneva conference continues a desultory debate about Indochina it has already gone down in history as a failure in respect to the main purpose for which it was convened. That purpose, in the words of the Berlin communique, and in keeping with the Korean armistice agreement calling for such a conference, was to reach "a peaceful settlement of the Korean question."

The seventy-sixth annual commencement exercises and concert of the New York College of Music took place at Town Hall last evening. The graduation address and presentation of awards were made by Dr. Arved Kurtz, director of the school.
PARIS, June 17 -- The National Assembly's approval of Pierre Mendes-France as French Premier brings to power one of the most controversial figures of the post-war period.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- When President Eisenhower and Sir Winston Churchill reach the Southeast Asia question in their forthcoming talks they will be confronted by the military realties of the Indochina situation as focused in the recently ended five-power military staff talks.
Roland L. Stratford, director of the counseling and employment service of the Children's Aid Society, will retire July 1, the society announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- A recess to "cool off" was taken today by the special House committee investigating tax-free educational foundations.
A collection of wallpapers designed for various types of interiors was displayed yesterday by Wall Trends, Inc., in its showroom at 509 Madison Avenue. The papers are available through decorators.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 17 -- The Tennessee State Medical Association announced today the admission of two Negro physicians, first of their race to be admitted.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Department store sales last week were 1 per cent below those of the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

THE week-end fishing prospects seem brighter than at any other time this season, with a wide variety offered anglers on fresh and salt water. The opening of the bass season in some up-State counties should remove some of the pressure from the trout streams.

YELLOWKNIFE, Canada, June 16 -- With the meeting here of the "Little Parliament of the North" this gold mining community is witnessing another stage in the political evolution of the Northwest Territories toward eventual self-government.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- Roy M. Cohn said today he had been informed he would not take his annual summer training with the New York National Guard -- at least for the time being.

Output of Canadian and United States newsprint mills during May amounted to 593,891 tons, compared with 572,644 for the like month last year, the Newsprint Service Bureau reported yesterday. Shipments of 596,277 tons were well ahead of the 558,824-ton total for May, 1953.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 17 -- Drastic overhauling of the motion picture industry distribution system is necessary to eliminate "prohibitive costs" and "chaotic" procedures harmful to both the production and exhibition branches of the business, according to Walter Reade Jr., president of the Theatre Owners of America.

Two broad means of bringing cognac consumption in this country to record heights was offered the other day by Michel Martell, senior partner of Martell Co., Cognac, France. One method he suggested was an educational campaign aimed at taking cognac out of the special occasion class.

It is highly unlikely that any prompt action can and will be taken by the United Nations in response to the appeal from Thailand for the dispatch of a peace observation team to offset the Communist threat. When the Thai resolution comes to a vote in the Security Council it will almost certainly be vetoed by the Soviet Union.
Policemen and Customs agents seized more than twenty-five pounds of pure opium here early yesterday morning in one of the largest narcotic hauls of the last ten years.

By way of adding further luster to their recent exploits of resourcefulness, the Giants yesterday won a ball game in which they got only two hits. Even more remarkable, neither blow figured in the scoring as Leo Durocher's men tripped the Redlegs in the series finale at the Polo Grounds, 2 to 1.
Beginning next Monday, the slogan for city automobile owners will be: "Show your new tax stickers or get stuck."
Efforts to cement friendly relations between the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., struck a snag yesterday.

TRALEE, Ireland, June 17 (Reuters) -- Threatening gangs forced projectionists in two local motion-picture theatres tonight to flash slides on their screens urging men to join the illegal Irish Republican Army.

BALTIMORE, June 17 -- A 9-2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles today sent the Yankees on their way to Chicago tonight with a modest winning streak of three. However, the clean sweep over Jimmie Dykes' somewhat feeble outfit did not exhilarate the New Yorkers. Rather, they entrained for the West puzzled by their failure to gain ground on the league-leading Cleveland Indians.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee approved a bill today aimed at ending a practice under which minority groups sometimes can put a director on the board of a national bank.
A forty-five-piece band led by guest conductors will open an ambitious series of park concerts next week on the mall of Battery Park under auspices of the New York Summer Festival Season Committee.

On May 31 the average market price of stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange was $46.30, the highest month-end figure since the $47.99 of June 30, 1946. The price on April 30 was $45.37, so that the gain in May was 93 cents.

ASCOT, England, June 17 -- Queen Elizabeth of England saw a pair of French-owned horses run one, tow today in the two-and-a-half-mile. Ascot Gold Cup race -- the top prestige event on the British turf after the Epsom Derby.

With two brothers fighting side by side yesterday as members of the United States chess team in the adjourned games of the international series of matches at the Roosevelt Hotel, the first round went to the Soviet grand-masters by a score of 6 -- 2.
Grateful though the farmer may be to the wasp, which, according to the United States Department of Agriculture, destroys many harmful insects, most people may consider them nuisances.
The end of the McCarthy-Army hearings left the Pentagon, and particularly the Army, somewhat confused and divided, like the nation, about the results.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- The new group of stockholders that next week will take over operation of Butler Brothers, plans to retain its West Coast stores, it was revealed today. These include the large units acquired in the last two years in Los Angeles, San Francisco, Long Beach and Seattle.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 17 -- Plans have been discussed here for placing South Vietnam and part of Central Vietnam under the direct operational command of Gen. Nguyen Van Hinh, young Chief of Staff to the Vietnamese National Army.

CAIRO, June 17 -- The newly-discovered alabaster sarcophagus within a buried, unfinished step pyramid at Sakkara "definitely does not contain the remains of the Pharaoh Sanakht," the discoverer, Dr. Mohammed Zakaria Ghoneim, said today.

SCOTIA, N. Y., June 17 (AP) -- The Mohawk Association of Scientists and Engineers in a letter to President Eisenhower yesterday said that three of the four conclusions of the special personnel security board that investigated Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer were "inadequately supported and subjective."
The main charges in the Army-McCarthy controversy now under study of a Senate investigating subcommittee are:

The possibility isn't at all remote for Mary Martin to appear on Broadway in "Peter Pan" with musical trimmings. Should the anticipated treat become an actuality, Leland Hayward would bring the show here early in October.
Gilbert Yates, a vice president of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company at 165 Broadway, died yesterday under a Lexington Avenue subway train as it entered the Seventy-seventh Street station.

PHILADELPHIA June 17 -- Representative Walter H. Judd, a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, declared today that all the gains we had made on the European continent were being jeopardized by our losses to the Communists in Asia.

It was a butcher-boy job performed with a blunt axe. Rocky Marciano, who is supposed to be able to fell a bull with one mighty swish, hacked away at Ezzard Charles for fifteen full rounds in the Yankee Stadium last night. He never finished the task in the fashion expected of him.
EL CENTRO, Calif., June 17 -- A specially marshaled force of more than 700 Federal officers fanned out over California today in a widespread round-up of Mexican border jumpers.
LONDON, June 17 -- The recovery in the stock markets progressed today despite some late profit-taking.
SPRINGFIELD, N. J., June 17 -- A 69 by Billy Joe Patton, Morganton (N. C.) amateur, set the pace as the United States open golf championship began today.

Eleven persons, including three doctors, who had been indicted on abortion charges, were held in $1,000 bail each when arraigned yesterday in Bronx County Court. A fourth doctor will be arraigned on similar charges today.

An office and store building at 401-405 Park Avenue to cost $1,250,000 is among plans for new buildings and alterations filed with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The owner is 405 Park Avenue, Inc., of 342 Madison Avenue. Herbert Tannenbaum is the architect.
CLEVELAND, June 17 (UP) -- The Cleveland Indians stretched their winning streak to eight games today when they defeated the Washington Senators, 6 -- 4, for a sweep of the three-game series.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 17 -- The number of interracial congregations in the United States is on the increase, according to a report made public here today.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday, closing 8 points lower to 2 points higher than on Wednesday.

LONDON, June 17 -- Communist China has agreed to send a charge d'affaires to Britain to negotiate the establishment of full diplomatic relations. In addition, arrangements for the visit of a party of Chinese trade experts to Britain are almost complete.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board declared today that a merger of National Air Lines and Colonial Air Lines would be in the public interest.
The round-by-round description of the Rocky Marciano-Ezzard Charles fight at the Yankee Stadium last night follows:
DETROIT, June 17 (UP) -- George Zuverink scattered seven hits effectively today to pitch the Detroit Tigers to a 2-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox before 3,285 fans at Briggs Stadium.
John L. Lewis reached out yesterday for a foothold on the Great Lakes.
Members of the recently dissolved NBC Symphony Orchestra are taking steps to keep the orchestra alive.
Borrowing for tax purposes raised New York bank loans to business $161,000,000, in the week ended on Wednesday. It was the first such expansion since the week ended on May 5.

Decreased sales and earnings for the quarter and six months ended May 31, were reported yesterday by Rice-Stix, Inc., manufacturer and converter of textiles and a distributor through its store in St. Louis, of products and merchandise made by others.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Army-McCarthy hearings ended late today with a suggestion by Senator Charles E. Potter for perjury prosecutions and the dismissal of employes on both sides who played top roles in the controversy.

KIRENSK, U. S. S. R., June 5 -- This wooden town, situated largely on a triangular island at the confluence of the Lena and Kirenga rivers, demonstrates the hardships that human beings must overcome to survive in the climate of Siberia.

JERRY LESTER must be a comedian of nineteen lives. Away back in television's early days he was a funny guy on the "Broadway Open House" with Dagmar. Then he was the proverbial dud on a big nighttime show and more recently on an afternoon opus.
POUGHKEEPSIE, June 17 -- Vassar College will welcome 870 alumnae tomorrow for a reunion week-end scheduled this year as a separate event following graduation.

An eleven-story apartment house named Riverdale Towers at 3103 Fairfield Avenue in the Riverdale section of the Bronx has been sold by Aaron Shriro and others to a group of investors. The structure was built in 1949 by the Campagna interests and contains 108 apartments and a thirty-five-car garage.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The United States Overseas Information director said today his agency had set out to blunt the Soviet Union's propaganda campaign in Asia by exposing Communism as "Red Colonialism."

Thomas E. Dewey has been in public office nearly twenty-five years and is now rounding out his third term and twelfth year as Governor of New York. In view of this length of service and the fine accomplishment that attended it he is entitled to public acquiescence in his desire to retire to private life.
" It was my toughest fight," said Rocky Marciano.
BERLIN, June 17 -- The anti-Communist passions that erupted in East Germany last June 17 broke loose again at today's anniversary demonstration in West Berlin.

An Army promise of a hearing for an enlisted Fort Monmouth, N. J., radar instructor, who had been given an "undesirable discharge" without a hearing, was received here yesterday by Norman Thomas, former Socialist candidate for President.
The New York Shipbuilding Corporation has bought a controlling interest in the Devoe Raynolds Company, Inc., one of the nation's oldest paint manufactures.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- The wheat futures market was again under pressure today. Favorable crop reports increased the liquidation by longs, while no investment buying was indicated except on the extreme declines. September, December and March wheat deliveries all registered new lows for the season.
The Protestant Episcopal Church will hold its 1955 triennial general convention in the racially heterogeneous city of Honolulu, Hawaii.

Rocky Marciano successfully defended the heavyweight championship of the world against Ezzard Charles at the Yankee Stadium last night. The favored titleholder from Brockton, Mass., gained the unanimous decision over his Cincinnati opponent, who once was the ruler of the division.

A Republican movement to draft Governor Dewey for re-nomination got under way in earnest yesterday following a disclosure that he had decided to retire from public office at the end of his present term in December.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson urged the nation's grocers today to play a bigger part in food nutrition education "both for good health and good business."
BOSTON, June 17 (AP) -- George D. O'Brien, a gambler acquitted only two months ago of participating in the $681,700 looting of an armored truck, suffered a fatal gunshot wound in the head today.

NEW ORLEANS, June 17 -- All indications are that the mother and two children of President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman left Guatemala by military transport plane late Tuesday night, according to visitors reaching here today from Guatemala.

The four-story apartment house accommodating thirty-eight families at 147-03 Northern Boulevard in Flushing, Queens, has been resold by the Estate Securities Company, real estate operators, to clients of Sam Halpern, attorney. The Advance Realty Company, Harry Shapiro and Murray Handel were the brokers in the transaction.

INWOOD, L. I., June 17 -- Mrs. Maxon Berger of Glen Oaks will meet Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century in the semi-finals of the women's Metropolitan Golf Association's fifty-first annual championship over the Inwood course tomorrow.
Sinclair Oil Corporation invited bids yesterday for 769,721 common shares of Pioneer Natural Gas Company.

There were some vociferously unhappy horseplayers at the Aqueduct track yesterday. They bet on Christopher T. Chenery's Permian, Eddie Arcaro up, in the sixth race, and Permian refused to run. The colt walked out of the gate after the others had gone on their way.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The United States has asked for a complete embargo by the free world on arms sought by Guatemala. The right to search and seize Allied vessels suspected of violating it is included in the request.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 17 (AP) -- The International Cotton Advisory Committee has dropped, for the time being, plans to set up a world agreement to control cotton production and prices.

The annual meeting of the Holly Sugar Corporation was enlivened on Wednesday by the demands of some stockholders for a more liberal dividend policy. They asserted the company's financial position enabled it to increase the annual rate of $1 to $1.20 and a possible extra.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 17 -- Guatemalan exiles who oppose the regime of President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman are being flown to points in Honduras just on this side of the Guatemalan border.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington before the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in its thirty-sixth and last day of hearings on the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

The volume in zinc yesterday was the second highest since trading in that commodity reopened opened in June, 1952, but activity on the other items on the New York exchanges was light. Prices closed irregularly higher with cocoa, coffee, zinc, tin, lead, copper; hides and burlap registering gains; sugar, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, potatoes, silk and wool mixed, and rubber lower.

LONDON, June 17 (UP) -- Art Larsen, the last American remaining in the men's singles in the London grass court tennis championships, was upset by Rex Hartwig in the quarter-finals today, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, as the Australian stars captured all semi-final berths.

After thirty-six days of testimony the hearings in the dispute between Senator McCarthy and the United States Army have faded out to their unlamented end. They have provided the country and the world with an extraordinary spectacle, and yet, in the uninhibited way in which great issues are often decided in our democracy, they have served an important purpose.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 17 -- Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, today accused "real estate interests" of attempting to defeat Governor Dewey's proposed $200,000,000 housing bond issue by branding it socialistic.
The bill providing for the use of civilians as school-crossing guards was signed yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

With ceremonies in which all free men could join in spirit the German people observed a National Memorial Day yesterday to commemorate the revolt against Communist tyranny that swept East Germany a year ago. It was a day of mingled sorrow and hope, giving rise to a new dedication which the free world can welcome.
Supreme Court Justice L. J. Corcoran reserved decision yesterday in a suit seeking a court ruling that out-of-city telephone calls made by local subscribers are not subject to the city's sales tax.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The House of Representatives voted today, 360 to 19, to send the Administration's housing bill to conference without any strings attached.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Eisenhower urged 300 young persons today to get behind his proposal to give the vote to 18-year-olds.

KETCHIKAN, Alaska, June 17 (AP) -- Alaska's first pulp industry, a project that cost seven times what the United States paid Russia for the whole Territory ninety-seven years ago, has started opertaion in a modern plant built in two years in a coastal wilderness.

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 17 (AP) -- Herb Browne of North Carolina and Tim Coss of Swarthmore, seeded No. 1 and 2, respectively, advanced to the final of the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championship with decisive victories today. Browne and Coss will meet for the title tomorrow morning.
Graduating students of Hunter College were told yesterday that unless the educated young people "take responsibility in their communities the American way of life will be destroyed."

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 (AP) -- Del Ennis hit a fifteenth-inning single to score Robin Roberts with the winning run as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 3 -- 2, tonight in the longest game of the National League season.

The American National Theatre and Academy will bestow an unusual honor on T. Edward Hambleton and Norris Houghton, producing heads of the Phoenix Theatre, the off-Broadway venture that scored one of last season's major artistic successes.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- The Senate approved today the major elements of President Eisenhower's education program after a Democrat had assailed it as "inconsequential, not to say trifling."
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- During the week ended June 16, member bank reserves decreased $118,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, moved in the Senate today to strip Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, of his committee chairmanships.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday were 697,583 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
Two important textile trade associations plan to merge, according cording to an announcement yesterday by the National Federation of Textiles, Inc.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 17 (AP) -- Brazil may finish its coffee year on June 30 with 700,000 bags more of coffee than it had expected.

PARIS, Friday, June 18 -- Pierre Mendes-France, 47-year-old Radical intellectual, was chosen Premier early today, contrary to all expectations. He won by the extraordinary vote of 419 to 47 because of the appeal to nearly all parties of his proposal to negotiate a cease-fire in Indochina by July 20.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 17--The sale of beer in upstate drug stores was opposed today in a resolution adopted unanimously at the New York State Pharmaceutical Association's seventy-sixth annual convention here. About 500 pharmacists are attending.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Representative Sidney A. Fine, Democrat of the Bronx, abandoned today an eleven-month effort to stop publication of a report critical of George P. Monaghan, former New York City Police Commissioner.

GENEVA, June 17 -- George P. Delaney, United States worker delegate to the International Labor Organization, bitterly as-sailed the Soviet Union today but said that the Soviet bloc might well serve a useful purpose in the organization.

An agreement was reached last night in negotiations between Atlantic and Gulf Coast shippers and a deep-sea engineers' union. Talks were continuing early today in a parallel conference involving the companies and radio officers.

A syndicate of investors represented by Lorimer Denner has purchased the eighteen-story apartment house for seventy-eight families on plot 101 by 100 feet at 49 East Ninety-sixth Street, northeast corner of Madison Avenue, from the Manufacturers Trust Company, trustee.

DACCA, Pakistan, June 16 -- In this rice and jute area, the eastern part of Pakistan, 42,000,000 inhabitants are recovering from the aftermath of their first electionAfter routing the Moslem League party three months ago, th four-party United Front died May 30 in its second month of administration.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., June 17 -- It undoubtedly was the most talked about shot of today's opening round of the United States open golf championship over Baltusrol's lush, green pasture land. Naturally enough, Sam Snead made it. The Slammer didn't want to make it, despite his flair for the spectacular. He just had no choice in the matter.
Yesterday's stock market started firm and drifted downward all day on inconsequential volume, but it managed to establish new high marks for the movement.
Crying towels may not be in demand in Brooklyn yet but some small moisture absorbent may be needed after what happened to the National League champions yesterday at Ebbets Field.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- A proposed cut in railroad rates on shipment of export grain from Buffalo and Oswego, N. Y., to five Atlantic ports and Albany was turned down today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Five hold-up men robbed two payroll messengers of $8,500 in Brooklyn yesterday despite a smoking alarm-satchel and a faulty getaway car.
The North Atlantic Mediterranean Freight Conference has made a downward adjustment of freight rates on shipments to Marseille, one of France's main ports of entry.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Southern state officials who are deep in study of the local problems created by the recent unanimous decision of the Supreme Court outlawing racial segregation in the public schools have particularly been examining the proposal that private schools, continuing this segregation, be substituted.

A plan to exchange stock of the Penn-Texas Corporation for stock of the Industrial Brown-hoist Corporation on a share-for-share basis, was announced yesterday by L. D. Silberstein, chairman of both companies.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call 50 to 38 vote by which the Senate today defeated a Democratic amendment to add $350,000,000 to the defense bill to prevent a planned reduction of two army divisions:

The heads of all city departments and agencies were directed yesterday by Mayor Wagner to follow the prevailing labor practice in private industry in connection with delivery and installation of furniture for new city projects.
A wheel chair that will climb street curbs by the hand power of its occupant has been devoloped at the research division of New York University's College of Engineering.

The contract for the superstructure of the $10,000,000 buildings of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine was awarded yesterday to Cauldwell-Wingate Company, 101 Park Avenue, The medical college, associated with Yeshiva University, is now under construction on a sixteen-acre tract at Morris Park Avenue and Eastchester Road, the Bronx.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 17 - Dr. Grayson L. Kirk, president of Columbia University, called on all university alumni today to help dispel the "irrational fear" that the nation was on the brink of revolutionary chaos.

LONDON, June 17 -- Prime Minister Churchill declined today to compel Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery to turn over to the National Archives the original document of surrender of half a million German soldiers in May, 1945.

TOKYO, Friday, June 18 (AP) -- The United States Air Force placed all its heavy bombers in the Far East under the Strategic Air Command, the nation's atomic bomb carrier, today. It will base them on Guam [cross on map] rather than Japan.
TRENTON, June 17 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner took steps here today to effect a drastic and swift reorganization of the State Division of Employment Security.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Mrs. Lolita Lebron was acquitted by a jury in Federal court today of assault with intent to kill in the House of Representatives on March 1.
The advent of summer brings to local markets a wide variety and an abundance of fresh fruits. Each week more arrive.
LUXEMBOURG, June 17 -- The $100,000,000 the United States lent last April to the European Coal and Steel Community will be put to work soon.

The superliner United States has proved over a two-year operation that her record-breaking speed run in July 1952 was no accident. In that month she took from the Cunard liner Queen Mary two speed records, eastbound and westbound, crossing to England in 3 days 10 hours 40 minutes at an average speed of 35.59 knots, and coming home at 34.51 knots.

Mayor Wagner signed yesterday the local law imposing a 5 per cent amusement tax. The new levy will become effective July 1 and is expected to yield $16,700,000 in 1954-55. The tax will be administered under regulations now being drafted by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A House subcommittee investigating alleged waste of foreign-aid funds heard today that five cargoes of United States corn worth $2,900,000 had "disappeared" en route to Austria and might have entered profitable speculative markets in Germany, Greece, Switzerland and Italy.
Orlando Zulueta, Havana lightweight, outpointed Johnny Gonsalves of Oakland, Calif., in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption for the May period had averaged 32,294 bales for each working day. This compared with 37,402 bales for the corresponding period a year earlier and 33,564 for the April period this year.
NORFOLK, Va., June 18 -- The aircraft carrier Intrepid, which became known as the "most hit ship in the Navy" during World War II, rejoined the Navy this afternoon.

A 23-year-old unemployed truck driver was seized by detectives in St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street, yesterday afternoon after he allegedly attempted to extort $500 from Mike Wallace, radio and television actor.
OTTAWA, June 18 (AP) -- A group of Canadian officials will leave for London next week to seek further reductions in British import restrictions as a means of boosting lagging Canadian exports.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Wheat futures showed strength this afternoon after moving irregularly lower in the morning. Buying was attributed mostly to shorts, but there was some early buying on resting orders.

ASCOT, England, June 18 -- Queen Elizabeth II escaped injury today when, forewarned by the Duke of Edinburgh, she ducked under a sagging telephone wire while galloping her horse at the Ascot race track.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Moscow was denounced here today for its position on disarmament and international control of atomic energy. David McK. Key, Assistant Secretary of State for United Nations Affairs, told the convention of the United World Federalists that the Soviet Union had been intransigent while the United States had been flexible.

BONN, Germany, June 18 (AP) -- The chief United States prosecutor in Germany recommended today that the United States Department of Justice decide whether to extradite James M. Leech of Lima, Ohio, a former Army captain, to stand trial on charges of slaying three American Army offices in Bavaria in 1946.
QUANTICO, Va., June 18 -- The Defense Department made public today a plan to build a combat-ready reserve of 3,000,000 men through a modified form of universal military training.
Elmer Burke, a dangerous gangster wanted by the New York police for one killing and a suspect in five other unsolved murders, was arrested yesterday in Boston.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 (AP) -- The American College of Chest Physicians refused yesterday to single out cigarette smoking as a suspected cause of lung cancer.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Four Russian diplomats are now on a grand tour of the Southeastern United States, and their trip is stirring up worry among security-conscious citizens.
ROME, June 18 (AP) -- The Assembly of God, which has its center at Springfield, Mo., was advised today that it had won its appeal to Italy's highest magistracy for juridical recognition here.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A comprehensive "honest and objective inquiry into Federal housing program scandals is now under way by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, its chairman, Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, announced today.
QUANTICO, Va., June 18 -- Robert T. Stevens, looking back on the Army-McCarthy hearings, contended today that the Army's good name had been vindicated.
The second round of the international chess series between the United States and Russia will be played tonight in the grand ballroom of the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today authorized Pacific Northwest Pipeline Corporation to deliver natural gas to the Northwest, the only big area in the nation without such fuel.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 18 -- Five United States enlisted men disappeared Monday afternoon in the vicinity of the large French air base at Tourane, a seacoast town about 375 miles northeast of Saigon, the United States Embassy announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Senator Guy M. Gillette today won for the second time Senate approval of Government supervision of speculation and futures trading in coffee.
A second day's record for this month to date was set Thursday for the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program with 838 donors as compared with the 828 on Tuesday.
GENEVA, June 18 -- The confirmation of Pierre Mends-France as Premier of France, has given new life to the conference here on Far Eastern affairs.
The regional National Labor Relations Board came up yesterday with a formula for counting challenged ballots in last month's union waterfront election.

LONDON, June 18 (UP) -- Louise Brough and Shirley Fry reached the women's singles final in the London grass-court tennis championships today with straight-set victories and will meet for the title tomorrow.
The Long Island Rail Road Company filed yesterday in the Federal District Court in Brooklyn a petition to terminate its bankruptcy. A hearing on the action will be held June 28.

Whether or not President Eisenhower now regards the Tennessee Valley Authority as "creeping socialism" he is not eager to expand it any more than he can help. This is clearly shown in his directive to the Atomic Energy Commission to contract with a private utility group to replace the 600,000 kilowatts of power taken from T. V. A. by the A. E. C.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Administration's omnibus tax reform bill -- providing about $1,500,000,000 of reductions the first year and perhaps twice that much later -- was reported to the Senate today by its Finance Committee.
Webb Knapp, a $250,000,000 realty development organization, is going into the hotel business.
Ships, planes, guns and ammunition are vital to our service men on duty far from home. .m Morale is even more important. And the United Service Organizations deals in morale.
BOSTON, June 18 (UP) -- Ted Williams, hard luck Boston Red Sox slugger, "forced" himself to work out at Fenway Park today after being sidelined for two weeks with a virus infection.
Governor Dewey said yesterday that he was not yet ready to announce his plans formally but did not take advantage of an opportunity to deny he had decided to retire at the end of his present term.
CHITA, U. S. S. R., June 7 -- Chita is one of Russia's eastern "watchdogs." It is one of a series of great garrison points built up in Czarist times along the eastern reaches of Siberia.

SHERMAN, N. Y., June 18 -- America may be dotted with older and larger museums and restored historical landmarks, but few can boast of achieving national and international recognition within seven years of their founding.
DETROIT, June 18 -- The General Motors Corporation is refusing to give to The Wall Street Journal figures on weekly production that it heretofore furnished each Friday.

When a business man becomes bankrupt and cannot pay his debts his creditors normally have no choice but to sell the bankrupt's assets at a liquidation sale for whatever they will bring to help minimize the loss. This normal business practice must be borne in mind in evaluating the $1,300,000,000 farm surplus disposal bill passed by the House of Representatives.
A collection of 1,500 original letters by and to Gouverneur Morris, a statesman of the Revolutionary period, has just been acquired by Columbia University.

Smoke cookery, one of the newest of the popular do-it-yourself projects, also is one of the most ancient methods of preparing foods for the table. The current revival undoubtedly stems from the ready acceptance received by commercially smoked items, such as oysters, cheese, turkey, shrimp and even whale meat.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A bill increasing the lending authority of the Government's Export-Import Bank of Washington by $500,000,000 went to the Senate floor today with the unanimous approval of the Banking and Currency Committee.
BUENOS AIRES, June 18 (UP) -- Nearly 30,000 persons were homeless today after the worst floods in fifty years along the Paraguay and Parana Rivers.
LONDON, June 18 (Reuters) -- Correspondents sent these reports today of reactions in European capitals to the United States proposal for power to search ships on the high seas for Guatemalan arms:
Indications from Albany to the effect that New York may be forced to abandon its 5 per cent amusement tax lead me to offer a few observations.

Twenty-five Christian leaders in the United States and from abroad will join the Rev. Dr. E. Stanley Jones, for years a Methodist missionary to India, this summer in conducting religious assemblies in this country and Canada patterned after a Hindu example but devoted to Christian objectives.

More community participation in furthering the work of the All-Day Neighborhood School's program was urged and weighed yesterday in a workshop conference conducted by the group. The meeting was held at the McBurney branch of the Y. M. C. A., 215 West Twenty-third Street.

One of the "favorable developments" that has impelled the French to insist upon the continuation of the Geneva talks is the implied suggestion by the Communists, at this late date, that the cases of Laos and Cambodia could be considered separately from that of Vietnam.

Some "do's" and "don'ts" on how to behave in Europe as junior ambassadors from this country were detailed yesterday to 367 teen-agers who will embark today on the Seven Seas, a converted Navy transport.

CLEVELAND, June 18 (UP) -- Mike Garcia pitched his ninth victory of the season and the Cleveland Indians won their ninth straight tonight with a 2-0 triumph over the Boston Red Sox. The game drew the largest Cleveland night crowd of the year -- 23,706.
Continuing their recent devastating extra-base hitting, the Dodgers last night produced three home runs to beat the Cubs, 6 -- 3, before 14,379 fans at Ebbets Field.
William Howell, accomplice in the slaying of Thomas F. Lewis, Bronx labor leader, was found guilty last night of second degree murder.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- In New York it was 1 o'clock Saturday morning, when Gil McDougald scooped George Kell's grounder, fired accurately across the diamond to Joe Collins and sealed an important 7-6 victory for the Yankees over the Chicago White Sox tonight.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 18 -- Ray H. Jenkins predicted here today that such an event as the Army-McCarthy hearings would "never" occur again. He doubted that any future Congressional hearings would be televised.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 18 (AP) -- A Guatemalan representative at the United Nations said tonight his Government had protested to the Security Council against "criminal invasion of my country."
Following are editorial comments by some of the country's newspapers on the McCarthy-Army hearings that ended Thursday, as gathered by The New York Times and The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- A proposed new method of qualifying pilots to fly into airports into which they have never flown was demonstrated this week by Pan-American World Airways.
ASCOT, England, June 18 -- Today's racing at Ascot proved exciting and joyful for Queen Elizabeth II as the royal colors triumphed in two eevnts.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The State Department said this evening it had information of "serious uprisings" in Guatemala but had received no word about a bombing announced by the Guatemalan Foreign Minister.

TRENTON, June 18 -- Another New Jersey official was suspended today and charged with malfeasance as the investigation continued into the complex financial manipulations of former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Democrats of the Senate subcommittee investigating the Army-McCarthy dispute unanimously demanded today a thorough "housecleaning" of the permanent subcommittee's staff before Senator Joseph R. McCarthy starts any more investigations.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 18 -- Four kings tonight took part in the first night of the Old Vic Company's presentation of "Hamlet" at Kronborg Castle at Elsinore, the original setting of the drama.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The President sent to Congress today supplemental appropriation requests for $132,098,500 for the fiscal year beginning July 1, mainly to meet unemployment costs.

The first concert of the thirty-seventh season of Guggenheim Memorial Concerts opened last night in the Central Park Mall with a concert by the Goldman Band. Following the tradition established in recent years, Edwin Franko Goldman, who shared the podium with his son, Richard, and several composer-conductors, led the group through a program of original music for band.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- A "revolutionary" Talgo-type stream lined passenger train has been ordered by the Rock Island Railroad for delivery in December, 1955, J. D. Farrington, president of the road, announced today.
A golden wedding celebration has been arranged for a couple in their eighties, both patients at the Bird S. Coler Memorial Hospital and Home on Welfare Island.
H. T. Dodge has been named general manager of the foreign operations department of the Texas Company. C. W. Saville replaces Mr. Dodge as assistant to the vice president of the department.

INWOOD, L. I., June 18 -- A new champion will be crowned tomorrow after Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century has met Mrs. Bernard Freeman of Inwood in the thirty-six-hole final of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's fifty-first annual championship.
YONKERS, June 18 -- Two parkway improvements in southern and northern Westchester will help to speed traffic through the county.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., June 18 -- A museum of the art, culture and history of the Hudson River will be established by the Historical Society of Newburgh Bay and the Highlands. It will be situated in Crawford House, on the hills of Newburgh, overlooking the Hudson.

The Giants, who had been on a six-game winning streak, ran afoul of Harvey Haddix last night. The St. Louis Cardinals' southpaw had won eight straight games and hadn't allowed a run in twenty-three innings. It was the Giant string that snapped. Haddix beat the New Yorkers, 5 -- 0, with a masterly four-hitter.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 18 -- A former member of the Communist party central committee of Oregon today focused the attention of the House Un-American Activities Committee on alleged Communist infiltration at Reed College here.
The little truck crane that is the workhorse of the waterfront has been found not to be a motor vehicle that needs a license.

The shortest price of the young Aqueduct meeting seems in the offing for the $30,050 Gazelle Stakes today. The strong favorite is Mrs. George D. Widener's Evening Out, a 3-year-old filly that has never been beaten by one of her sex.

CAIRO, June 18 -- The Arab states bordering Israel are willing to accept an international body as the authority over the development and distribution of the water resources of the Jordan River Valley.
GUATEMALA, June 18 -- The battle for Guatemala is on, Foreign Minister Guillermo Toriello announced today.
More teen-agers are seeking summer jobs than in recent years, but fewer opportunities for them are listed at State Employment Service offices, according to the State Labor Department.
The rayon fabric industry must institute quality control that will insure washability and wearing satisfaction, according to Jack Altman, vice president of United Merchants Sales Corporation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 18 -- Six United States concerns are working with Brazil's petroleum monopoly, Petrobras, on development of the country's oil resources. They are doing so in spite of a nationalistic law that bars even naturalized Brazilians from a financial share in the oil business.

HANOVER, N. H., June 18 -- President John Sloan Dickey of Dartmouth College today announced the choice of Albert Bradley of New York, executive vice president of General Motors Corporation, as a member of the college board of trustees.

PARIS, June 18 -- The National Defense Committee of the French Assembly urged today rejection of the European Defense Community Treaty. The action was taken On a vote of 29 to 13, with one abstention.
MELBOURNE, Australia, June 18 -- Two divers will start tomorrow examining the hulks of 200 Japanese ships sunk in Rabaul Harbor, New Guinea, during World War II.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday and prices closed unchanged to 10 points net lower than on Thursday.

HARRISON, N. Y., June 18 -- While trying to reduce fatalities in the Hutchinson River Parkway's "death valley" here, motorcycle policemen are creating so much business for the town traffic court that judges are thinking of opening a drive-in office.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 18 -- The Brazilian Communist party's effort to get a camouflaged slate of candidates into this year's Congressional elections seems to have been defeated.
Housewives who buy new home furnishings a few months from now can expect to get good value for their money.

Concerned over the city's polluted air, the Kings County Medical Society's public health committee has recommended legislation to restrict atomic and hydrogen bomb experiments. Explosions thousands of miles away endanger New Yorkers, the committee reported yesterday, warning also that present air pollution here bore "potentialities of a serious disaster."

Today's new film is "Adventure in Odessa," a Soviet-made comedy-drama in Sovcolor featuring M. Kuznetsov and E. Samoilov. A. Kozir directed the Kiev Film Studios' offering which is being released here by Artkino.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Supreme Court Justice Robert H. Jackson today ordered that Frank Costello, New York gambler, be released on $50,000 bail pending decision by the high tribunal on an appeal his counsel plans to file.

DETROIT, June 18 -- An important meeting is scheduled tentatively for New York on Tuesday in connection with the recurring reports that the Studebaker Corporation and the Packard Motor Car Company are to be merged.

Mrs. Amalie Lang, who celebrated her seventy-ninth birthday on Wednesday at the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews of New York, yesterday was the oldest among this year's recipients of the Perry H. Schneider Medal awarded by the Board of Education.
PARIS, June 18 -- The rabbits of France had their day in court today.

With surprising speed, but somewhat problematical results, the French National Assembly has resolved its latest Cabinet crisis by bestowing the mantle of the Premiership on Pierre Mendes-France, a 47-year-old Left-Wing Radical and intellectual who has pledged himself to a program that may involve a change in French foreign policy.
SYRACUSE, June 18 -- Navy's record-breaking crew goes to the starting line for the last time tomorrow.

OCEAN CITY, Md., June 18 (AP) -- Commissioner Robert E. Lee of the Federal Communications Commission said tonight that at the rate educational television has grown in the last two years all the channels set aside for it will not be used for fifty years.
This story is about red paint, longshoremen and a steel mill originally destined for Czechoslovakia but later sold to Argentina. Confusing? Just wait.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (UP) -- Senator Wallace F. Bennett of Utah reported today that thirty-six other Senators had signed his resolution to ban commercial sponsorship of any future televised Senate hearings.
GENEVA, June 18 -- Communist China charged today that the United Nations side, in breaking off the Korean talks, had made statements that already proved to be "out-and-out lies."

GENEVA, June 18 -- The direct military talks here betwen the French-Vietnamese and the Vietminh commands in Indochina recessed today until Monday after three weeks of preliminary and inconclusive discussions.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The Army has ordered the prompt release from active duty of Lieut. Col. Melvin B. Voorhees, the Reserve officer who was tried and convicted by a court-martial after writing about his experiences as a censor during the war in Korea.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., June 18 -- Gene Littler, 23-year-old Californian, was close to the scoring record today as he posted a total of 139 to assume the lead after thirty-six holes in the United States open golf championship.

State Supreme Court Justice Thomas L. J. Corcoran upheld yesterday the right of the State Commission Against Discrimination to post placards in employment agencies. These placards state the object of the anti-discrimination laws and give the address of the commission's local office where aggrieved persons may obtain information as to their rights under the law.

Tomorrow may belong to the nation's papas but today has been set aside in honor of all expectant fathers, according to the United States Chamber of Commerce listing of special days, weeks and months. This tribute to fathers-to -be is little enough recognition, in the opinion of two maternity education specialists interviewed yesterday.
In three separate hold-ups in Brooklyn yesterday armed bandits, two in each case, stole $4,765 in cash and jewelry.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Self-heating footwear devised especially for sportsmen and soldiers was among the inventions patented this week. The inventor is Edward T. Behner of Cleveland, who received Patent No. 2,680,918.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 18 -- Resolutions on atomic energy were the main theme of the International Council of Women, which ended a ten-day congress today. The group went on record as wishing "to unite women to work against the destructive and aggressive use of these [atomic] energies, for their international control and for their pacific uses."

Paul Seligman, an elementary school teacher, charged with lying concerning Communist affiliations, submitted his resignation yesterday just one hour before his departmental trial was scheduled to open.
Col. Carlos Castillo Armas, leader of the resistance movement in the Guatemalan armed forces, has been massing forces in Honduras since early this year in preparation for an invasion.

The National Broadcasting Company said last night its correspondent in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, had telephoned that Puerto Barrios, Guatemala, had fallen to anti-Communist forces. N. B. C. said its correspondent added that defenders of the north coast Guatemalan port were fleeing.
LUXEMBOURG, June 18 -- The High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community began its first formal tariff negotiations today -- with Austria.
Cocoa prices were strong in active trading yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange, advancing the cent-a-pound limit in the near-by positions.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles charged today that the Communist forces in Southeast Asia were trying to keep their "deeds" secret.

A CRISP eighteen - minute compilation of highlights from the fifteen-round heavyweight championship fight of Rocky Marciano and Ezzard Charles, held on Thursday night in Yankee Stadium, was showing in several Broadway theatres by 6 o'clock last evening. The showcases included the Palace, the Embassy and the Forty-ninth Street Trans-Lux.

The reply by the State Department's former Director of German Affairs, Percy Laukhuff, to my proposal for revision of our German policy raises a number of points as to the past which could be argued at length. Whether the Acheson-Adenauer-Dulles policy has been wise or unwise has now become unimportant.
A. C. F. Industries, Inc., formerly known as the American Car and Foundry Company, declared a special dividend yesterday of $1 on the common stock out of surplus net profits on April 30.
WEST POINT, N. Y., June 18 (AP) -- Tim Coss of Swarthmore won the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championship today by defeating Herb Browne of North Carolina, 6 -- 2, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4.

Steels, motors and chemicals showed a few symptoms of underlying strength in yesterday's stock market but most of the other groups were mixed or lower in desultory trading. Volume slipped to 1,580,000 shares, from 1,810,000 on Thursday.

Aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange dropped 25,525 shares between May 14 and June 15, the Exchange reported yesterday. The total was 2,823,171 shares, smallest since March 15, against 2,848,696 shares on May 14.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 18 -- The Soviet Union used the veto power today to block -- for the time being, at least -- Thailand's appeal for a United Nations peace observer team.

PARIS, June 18 -- It was generally assumed tonight that the new Premier, Pierre Mendes-France, would be his own Foreign Minister, at least while negotiating for an armistice in Indochina. It was reported he intended to go to Geneva for those negotiations early next week.
NEW HAVEN, June 18 -- Joseph N. Welch headed home for Boston tonight hopeful of returning to the obscurity from which he told the closing session of the Army-McCarthy hearings he had emerged.

Normally I would refrain from criticizing a Moslem state like that of Afghanistan. But the letter of Azam Amini, the Public Relations Attache of the Embassy of Afghanistan in Washington, published in The Times of June 12, is so misleading that I am forced to clarify some of the points that he has raised.
A special meeting Monday of the Transit Authority was being planned yesterday to act on a deferred resolution to authorize a union representation election.

BALTIMORE, June 18 (AP) -- Bob Porterfield of the Washington Senators went the distance to defeat the Baltimore Orioles tonight, 7 -- 5, in thirteen innings, extending the Flock's losing streak to five games.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Setting its eighth consecutive record in this respect, Sears, Roebuck Co. invested $36,340,500 in newspaper advertising space in 1953, Edward Gudeman, merchandising vice president, disclosed today. This outlay topped by 6.4 per cent the previous high of $34,009,500, made in 1952.
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, June 18 -- Alan Watrous, manager of the Wichita (Kan.) Symphony, was re-elected president of the American Symphony Orchestra League at its convention here yesterday.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 18 -- The World Bank has approved a $19,110,000 loan toward development of Stage 2 of Ceylon's hydroelectric project, it was announced here today.

Robert Montgomery, whose chief duties these days are serving as President Eisenhower's television adviser and as actor-producer of his own program on the N. B. C. television - network, will stage the forthcoming Broadway production of "The Desperate Hours."
SAN SALVADOR, June 18 -- Guatemalans realized Wednesday night during their first blackout, how far the country had advanced toward war conditions, travelers from the city of Guatemala said today.
LONDON, June 18 -- The rise in stock prices and activity continued today, with industrial shares stimulated by a new batch of higher dividend statements.

Thomas Toomey, 45-year-old president of Local 2001, United Railroad Workers Union, C. I. O., was shot and killed at 1:30 A. M. yesterday by a Transit Authority employe in the High Street, Brooklyn, station of the IND subway.

DETROIT, June 18 (UP) -- Arnold Portocarrero pitched a four-hitter and Bill Renna, with a home run and double, supplied the batting punch to carry the Philadelphia Athletics to a 2-1 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight before 23,216 fans at Briggs Stadium.
DETROIT, June 18 (AP) -- Motor vehicle output this week will be up slightly, but the industry is about to level off its production volume.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 18 (UP) -- J. R. Wiggins, managing editor and vice president of The Washington Post and Times Herald, said today that a trend toward secrecy at all levels of Government threatened "erosion" of the people's right to know what their Government is doing.
BELIZE, British Honduras, June 18 (Reuters) -- The anti-colonial People's United party pledged today to do "nothing to forfeit the goodwill of Britain."

The report from the Jordan sector of Jerusalem (New York Times, May 26) makes it quite clear that doctrinal differences jeopardize the safety of Christendom's holy shrines. But the report of your correspondent that some churchmen in Jerusalem favor the internationalization of the city as a means of "straightening out the tangle" hardly meets the realities of the situation.
THE angling parade to the north is picking up more marchers every day, and reports from New Hampshire, Maine and New Brunswick indicate that the fishing is unusually productive in many areas.
The following is a round-up of household information and reports on new products for summer living:

PHILADELPHIA, June 18 (UP) -- Wally Post smashed four hits and drove in both Cincinnati runs tonight as the Redlegs snapped a five-game losing streak with a 2-1 victory over Philadelphia despite a bases-loaded Phillies' threat in the ninth.

ST. LOUIS, June 18 (AP) -- Curtis Stone of the New York Athletic Club, the defending champion, won the six-mile run at the National Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships tonight. It was the opening event on the program.
Despite a reduction in sales, the Kelsey-Hayes Wheel Company yesterday reported increased earnings for the latest quarter and nine months periods.

" WHAT would you do with a million dollars?" Frederick T. Gates, the financial adviser of the Rockefellers, once asked the noted American educator Abraham Flexner. That most widely popular of all fiduciary questions did not stump Flexner for a minute. "I should give it to Dr. Welch," he promptly said.

William H. Evans has been appointed a vice president of the Diamond Alkali Company, manufacturer of chemical products. Mr. Evans has been manager of silicate operations for six of the company's plants.

BUENOS AIRES, June 18 -- The plans of President Juan D. Peron for the formation of a six-man supercabinet appeared today to have been frustrated by the determined opposition of a majority in his present Cabinet instead, the plans have been supplanted by a milder revision of Government apparatus, cutting down the Cabinet from its present total of twenty-one ministers to sixteen.
NEWPORT, R. I., June 18 -- The waterfront just abeam Thames Street here was running knee deep in superlatives today.

An appeal from the Community Service Society reminds us that there are many city youngsters who will be bereft of their right to summer happiness unless New York citizens care enough about them. The society plans to provide vacations for some 1,400 boys and girls selected from families under the agency's care.

BONN, June 18 -- The value of West Germany's exports increased 22 per cent during the first four months of this year compared with the corresponding period in 1953, thus lending weight to the thesis that Europe's economy is becoming more independent and less susceptible to the economic fluctuations in the United States.

MILWAUKEE, June 18 (AP) -- The Phoenix Hosiery Company has announced it would shift its women's hosiery knitting operations to Southern subsidiaries. Frazier D. MacIver, company president, said this would be the last move in the firm's reorganization and shifting of manufacturing to Southern mills.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (UP) -- The Senate's majority leader, William F. Knowland of California announced today that the Senate would hold Saturday sessions, starting next week to avoid legislative congestion that would delay adjournment.
Thirty representatives of the World Parliament of Religions will spend a week in Moscow this summer as guests of Metropolitan Germogen, Exarch of the Russian Orthodox Church.

MADRID, June 18 -- Spain has sold to Poland about 300,000 metric tons of iron ore in exchange for 178,950 metric tons of coal in the last few weeks. This was revealed today in a list of export licenses granted by the Ministry of Commerce to Spanish companies.
The Mutual Network made no comment yesterday while the producer of two of its sustaining programs rebutted criticism by the National Issues Committee.

One of the best things about the warming weather is that much of the late spring's free time can be spent in shirtsleeves. This perhaps is next best only to spending all of the free time in and about a trout stream.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday was 0.8 per cent above that of the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were up 2.6 per cent and orders 9.3 per cent. Following are the weekly statistics in thousands of board feet.

Lagging business in the television receiver manufacturing industry adversely affected earnings of the General Instrument Corporation for the quarter ended May 31, Abraham Blumenkrantz. chairman, told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Elizabeth, N. J.

VICTORIA, B. C., June 18 (Canadian Press) -- Government and industrial leaders in British Columbia today started to figure out just how hard the Washington decision on natural gas would hit the province's industrial future.
