WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A proposal that regional offices of the Small Business Administration be authorized under certain conditions to grant loans up to $50,000 to small business enterprises in their area was placed before the Government today.

William Clark, who was dismissed last year as Chief Justice of the United States High Commission's Court of Appeals in Western Germany, filed suit yesterday to compel the State Department to let him return to Germany as a private citizen.
ROME, N. Y., June 18 (AP) -- Champions were crowned tonight in six divisions of the second annual Air Force world-wide track and field championships.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The General Accounting Office questioned today President Eisenhower's order to the Atomic Energy Commission to negotiate a contract with a private utility group. That group would supply power to the Tennessee Valley Authority.

LONDON, June 18 -- The British Government rejected today a United States request for authority to search British vessels on the high seas, but promised to detain any ships suspected of carrying arms to Guatemala.

BRUSSELS, June 18 (AP) -- The twenty-third International Wool Conference ended here today with a unanimous resolution attacking excessive subsidies and calling for the wool trade to be "free of all distorting restrictions."

Walter Cronkite, major domo for "The Morning Show" on C. B. S. television, will be absent for two weeks starting Monday when he enters New York Hospital for a minor operation. Jack Barry will take over the master of ceremonies role for the two-week period.

" The Story of Our Civilization," by Philip Lee Ralph, has been scheduled for Aug. 2 publication by Dutton. A history covering ten thousand years of Western man, the volume discusses the beginnings of civilization, the values it has established, the mistakes it has made and their relevance to contemporary hopes and fears.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 18 -- Guatemala has been invaded by land, air and probably by sea in a drive to unseat the Communist - infiltrated Government of President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman.
PITTSBURGH, June 18 (AP) -- Vernon Law gave only three hits to the Milwaukee Braves tonight, then singled with the bases loaded to snap a tie as the lowly Pittsburgh Pirates gained a 2-1 victory.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- President Eisenhower assured the new Government of France today that it could count on the United States as a real and spiritual ally.

PHENIX CITY, Ala., June 18 (AP) -- Albert L. Patterson, who won Alabama's Democratic nomination for Attorney General on a pledge to wipe out this city's organized crime, was slain in gangster style tonight.

It was agreed by everybody on the boxing beat yesterday that Ezzard Charles was a big winner in his fifteen-round fight with Rocky Marciano at the Yankee Stadium on Thursday night. Not that there was any taint to the unanimous victory gained by Marciano. Far from it.
In adjusting to our present machine age and quantity of automobiles the human machine has been shown no consideration.

Supreme Court Justice George A. Arkwright held yesterday that the reapportionment of the Brooklyn Assembly districts by the City Council violated the state constitution. He found that four of the twenty-two districts were not formed of "convenient and contiguous territory in as compact form as possible."
CRESTVIEW, Fla., June 18 (UP) -- The Air Force said today that six white civilian barbers would "undoubtedly" be dismissed for their refusal to cut the hair of Negro airmen at Eglin Air Force Base.

Numerous motorists and pedestrians on a busy Bronx street yesterday in broad daylight failed to deter two robbers from stealing $1,416 from a man and handcuffing him to his automobile. Apparently only the three men involved knew anything about the episode.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.5 per cent to 110 in the week ended on Tuesday. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics (The index is based on an average of 100 for 1947-49.)
BERLIN, June 18 -- Thanks to donations from the Ford Foundation that last week reached a total of $1,434,000, West Berlin's Free University will have its own home tomorrow.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 18 -- Semyon K. Tsarapkin, a blunt-jawed, blunt-spoken Soviet delegate, put his foot into a hamper full of trouble today at a meeting of the United Nations Security Council.

On June 7 you carried an editorial concerning "Two Sick Industries," wherein you urged the Administration to give thought to the "depressed state of the coal and textile industries," and "together with management and labor in these industries to seek answers to their basic problems," so that "remedial programs can get under way."

A speaker got up at the annual convention of the American Federation of Musicians held in Milwaukee this week to lecture his fellow harmonists. He said that he no longer approved of the union requirement that theatre operators hire a local "stand-by" orchestra when a traveling "big name" orchestra comes to town to play for them.
The 2,000-member American Radio Association, C. I. O., signed a new contract with Atlantic and Gulf Coast ship operators at 4:20 P. M. yesterday, ending a brief tie-up of four passenger vessels.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- President Eisenhower signed into law today a measure giving the armed services full authority to deny commissions to drafted doctors or dentists who were considered security risks.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 18 -- Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d ended today their silence about the casting of players for their film version of "Oklahoma!" and officially confirmed the selection of ten principals.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18 -- The American Friends Service Committee charged today that the "timidity" of United States officials had prevented two overseas experts from participating in the Quaker organization's summer Institutes on International Relations.

The Republic of Guatemala, which spans the Central American isthmus roughly 800 miles northwest of the Panama Canal, has in recent years become the vortex of mounting pressures in Central America and throughout the American continents.

SALEM, N. H., June 19 (AP) -- Jockeys Gene Martin, Vernon Bush and James Mayer were involved in a spectacular three-horse spill during the fourth race at Rockingham Park today but none was injured seriously.

IT is difficult to think of a garden flower that gives as much satisfaction as the rose, either indoors or out. From the time that it starts blooming in June, until the last blossoms fade in the fall, it gives continuous pleasure.

EL PASO, Tex., June 19 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, the Senate Democratic leader, has introduced a resolution to have Congress create a commission to try to settle an old dispute with Mexico over title to the Chamizal Zone in South El Paso.

RADIO Station WNYC will provide intensive coverage of major musical presentations scheduled for the summer months in New York City. In cooperation with Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, forty-two musical broadcasts from various points in the city will be put on the air.

WITH the present-day emphasis on the joys of outdoor living, a terrace seems to be almost as important to new home owners as the kitchen -- almost, but not quite. One chief drawback, unfortunately, is a general misunderstanding as to what a terrace really is.

THE babbling brook or clammed-up creek may have been an ideal "ole swimming hole" for Mom and Dad, but it's "old hat" to today's youngsters. They need venture no farther than their own back yards, thanks to the moderately priced plastic play pools.

AS the title suggests, this is a novel partly about a man cast away on a lonely isle. It differs from Defoe's classic, however, in a number of respects. For one thing, the author throws his hero into the arena of empyrean social thinking -- and into amorous involvement with a bevy of young women.

IN chapter one of Shirley Jackson's strange and provocative new novel, we find Elizabeth Richmond, an orphan now in her twenties, employed at a museum in a colorless town where she has led a colorless existence since early childhood.

IN the winter people expect to attend musical performances in proper concert halls and opera houses, but at this time of the year the unusual setting counts for almost as much as the quality of the presentation.

PORTLAND, Me., June 16 -- Victory for Senator Margaret Chase Smith in the Republican primary next Tuesday is taken for granted in Maine, and Democratic party strategists already are looking beyond that to the election in September.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Representatives Kenneth B. Keating and Harold R. Ostertag, New York Republicans, said today they were "urgently" seeking creation of "appropriate international machinery" to protect owners of Lake Ontario shore property from flood damages the St. Lawrence power project might cause.

BLANDING, Utah, June 19 -- Sheltered from the desert sun by a century-old cottonwood tree, and using a blanket-covered water barrel as a bench. United States District Judge Willis W. Ritter took testimony this week in a complex lawsuit involving 300 Navajos of the Montezuma Creek band, the Federal Bureau of Land Management, a score of white ranchers -- and lands and livestock worth millions of dollars.

MOSCOW, June 19 (Reuters) -- The Rev. Judicael Nicholas, a French Roman Catholic priest, left by train tonight en route to France after serving an eight-year sentence in Soviet labor camps for alleged espionage activities.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 19 -- Representative Pat Sutton, Democratic member of the House from the Sixth District, is on record that Senator Estes Kefauver "doesn't represent the views of the people."

I HAVE often revisited the old Studs Lonigan neighborhood. I did so recently on a warmish March Sunday afternoon. Spring was hovering over the leafless trees of Washington Park where I dreamed so much in my boyhood. The snow in front of the buildings and on the streets was dirty and melting.
INWOOD, L. I., June 19 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of the Century Club is the new champion of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.
MEXICO CITY, June 19 (UP) -- President Arbenz charged tonight that the United States encouraged the rebellion against his Government.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 19 (AP) -- Philip Scott, 6-year-old bay horse owned by the Gray Brothers of East Providence, R. I., won the featured Jericho pace by two lengths from Prince Adios in 2:02 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Chief Strong finished third.
" Summer '54," a New York Public Library publication free for the asking in all branches in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island, lists suggestions for vacation time.

Television has brought new life to many communities. For Bloomington, Ind., a city of 30,000, television has a special significance because it is the place where Sarkes Tarzian runs one of the nation's largest operations producing TV tuners and other video components.
LONDON, June 18 -- Britain is watching closely the steady rise of Yugoslav political influence in the Eastern Mediterranean, traditionally an area of special interest to the United Kingdom.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 19 -- Working together in beautiful style for the entire four-mile grind, Yale's varsity sweepswingers won their annual race with Harvard on the Thames today. It was an impressive victory as the Elis gained the lead early and stayed ahead far the rest of the trip.

BONN, Germany, June 19 -There are indications that the United States and British Governments have washed their hands of the controversy over the West German Government's decision to establish a Coordinating Committee for Press Affairs, which the newspapers in this country contend will be a thinly disguised Propaganda Ministry.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 19 (AP) -- President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman of Guatemala declared in a radio address tonight that invading forces had made penetrations of "some kilometers" into Guatemala but he predicted victory for his own army.

EXPOSURE suggestions for photographing the rare and beautiful spectacle of a total eclipse of the sun in the Eastern half of the United States Wednesday morning, June 30, are offered by Peter A. Leavens, a member of the photographic crew on the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium and American Airlines expedition to the scene of totality.

GENEVA, June 19 -- The Credentials Committee of the International Labor Organization recommended today that the employer and worker members of the countries of the Soviet bloc be seated at the organization's conference now in session here.

THE mysterious absence of Raphael's Sistine Madonna from the Gemalde Gallery in Dresden, which is in the Russian zone of Germany, is soon to be emphasized by the appearance of a somewhat trimmed version of the famous painting on a 10-franc stamp of the Saar.

This is the week scores of cruising and navigating yachtsmen have been awaiting with mixed feelings of dread and glee, for the succession of predicted log tests, which have been causing planning commotion all winter, will be launched.

While the big $60,000,000 Thruway bridge across the Hudson River between South Nyack and Tarrytown is the best known span on the route, there will be four other major bridges and hundreds of small spans to carry the expressway across the state.

ONE might say that the most important of all the functions of literature is to be a part of that whole Discourse whose function it is to prevent our understanding of the meaning of human life from degenerating into that "nothing but" to which all the sciences, because of the simplicity of their conceptions and the crudity of their instruments, tend to reduce it.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia suggested this week that figures indicating an early upturn in business should be interpreted cautiously, particularly in view of the psychological reaction that might occur if optimistic expectations do not materialize.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today a proposed order to bar World Scope Encyclopedia salesmen from saying, to get inside homes, that they were taking a radio or television poll and not making clear their connection with the encyclopedia.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 19 -- While the flags of both countries fluttered in the desert wind, the music of the Pakistani and United States national anthems lent emphasis today to the inaugural ceremony of the Pakistan Friends of America Society.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 19 -- Dr. Charles W. Mayo, president of the American Association for the United Nations, announced today that V. J. Skutt of Omaha, Neb., had been named national chairman for United Nations Week of 1954.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Eisenhower Administration on Monday will call for another drastic cutback in wheat production, this one of 11 per cent.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Democrats pressed today for early action on their demand for a staff shake-up by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, but an early decision seemed unlikely.

LOS ANGELES, June 19 -- For the first time in more than a decade, officers of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service this week-end believed they had brought under control a major portion of the tremendous illegal traffic of Mexicans across the southwestern border.

PIONEER Valley Laurel Week in Massachusetts, which opened Thursday, finds the highways and roads in the area brimming with lily white to deep rose mountain Laurel. Special guide markers for motorists have been placed along the most popular routes.

ALBANY -- A new detail of twenty - eight Thruway troopers -- the vanguard of an eventual force of eighty-six -- will take to the road next Thursday in a round-the-clock check on speeders and other law violators traveling the cross-state expressway.

For the stock market to act otherwise than most people anticipate, surprising many traders and investors is an old story in Wall Street. However, last week's performance showed such marked inconsistencies that it raised many questions among professionals.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 19 -There is a cultural unity of mankind, Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, told the American European Friendship Association, Inc., here tonight.

THE Little Miss Fixit who gives the title to this airy parable is 10 years old. "Gives" is hardly the word; she probably charged the author a right smart fee for it. For besides being a jill-of-all-trades, Dodie is the poor child's Hetty Green.

COLUMBUS, Ohio. IN farm homes of several states of the Middle West and also of the Eastern states of Vermont and Maryland, every month of the year miniature "town meetings" are held to discuss topics as wide-ranging as the market price for milk and the actions of Senator McCarthy, the value of the United Nations and the need for a stop sign at a local intersection.

ZANZIBAR, June 19 (AP) -- A British resident magistrate today banned the Arab newspaper Al Falaq for one year and gave the editor, Ahmed Mohammed Lemki, a choice of six months in jail or fines totaling nearly $2,800 for publishing pro-Communist articles.

Eispeth Huxley's article, "What Life Is Like For a Settler in Kenya" (June 6), fills this Christian minister with anger and dismay. The author suggests that the answer to the Mau Mau is Christianity. This would seem to take the form of prayers and "Christian doctrines" to fill the "empty" minds of Kenya nationals purged of Mau Mau teaching.

THERE is nothing more annoying to a family gathered on a terrace or in a picnic nook than to have a horde of flies descend on its food or to have ants crawling all over the place. Nightfall brings no relief either, fort as soon as dusk descends, everyone starts slapping mosquitoes. In some areas mosquitoes are so bad that people are driven indoors in self-defense.

THREE pastry-brown dachshunds, in a setting of bakeshop goodies, should prove a tempting combination for youngsters just beginning to read on their own. In their first year, Pumpkin, Ginger and Spice get their pictures in the paper for heroism in a fire, help locate a missing heirloom for their friend the carpenter, and manage to lose themselves completely by following the right smell to the wrong place.

IT has been clearly demonstrated in recent years that the conservation of our national recreational resources is the concern not only of the angler, hunter and outdoor enthusiast, but of those who directly or indirectly provide these hobbyists with goods and services.

SOWING seeds of annuals in June may have a somewhat "late" sound, but it is good practice for more than one reason. Now is the time to check on short-lived plants for additional sowings of them so that their place will assure a colorful display all season. Then for those "fussy" seeds, the soil is at last warm enough to plant them.

Solstice, we call it, the summer solstice, when the earth begins to swing back on its trunnions and the longest day of the year is at hand and daylight begins its creeping abbreviation once more. Solstice, and summer, and bee-drone in the clover field; first fledglings out of the nest, corn almost knee high, another spring complete.
BERLIN, June 19 -- A colorful assemblage of scholars from many parts of the Western world gathered today to dedicate the campus of West Berlin's Free University.

LONDON, June 19 -- Two important Cabinet Ministers proclaimed today that the Conservative Government had brought Britain economic strength and an end of scarcity for the consumer. Their speeches read like the opening of a campaign to convince voters that the Conservative version of the welfare state was just as good as if not better than Labor's.

ATLANTA, June 19 -- Farmers in the Southeastern states in the first four months this year received more than $750,000,000 in cash from their products, the regional Department of Commerce office reported in Atlanta this week. This was some $65,500,000 below cash receipts in the corresponding period of last year.
The Zenith Radio Corporation, which for years has maintained that prices charged by other manufacturers for hearing aids are far too high, will be heard from again this week.

LONDON, June 19 -- German rearmament might touch off a third world war, two Laborite speakers asserted today as the Labor party's debate on arms for the Federal Republic threatened to dominate British politics.

DURING the next few months, whether actively or vicariously, all but a fraction of the American population will live much of its time in the world of sport. Baseball, golf, tennis, fishing, sailing, swimming, mountain climbing, horse racing, boxing will be major interests in its life.
I am surprised to read in your paper of June 16 the comment by Lieut. Gen. Clarence Huebner on the coastto-coast civil defense exercise: "If I were a Russian I would be worried."

NEW YORK CITY will try for the next ten weeks to be what it has not been for well over 200 of its 300 years -- a country town with country storekeepers, with its village greens as places for nocturnal entertainment, its hotels like country inns, its theatres like barn playhouses.

AN agreement between Angel Records and the music publishing firm of G. Ricordi on terms for recording operas copyrighted by Ricordi has been signed by Franco Colombo, managing director of the publishing house, and Dario Soria for Angel.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 19 -- Following are the texts of a protest sent by Guatemala today to the United Nations, addressed to this month's President of the Security Council and of the parts of the United Nations Charter referred to:

PORTLAND, Ore., June 19 -- A subcommittee of the House of Representatives delved into Oregon's political history today. It drew testimony that members of the Communist party became nominees for the State Legislature on Democratic and Progressive party ballots.

PARIS, June 19 -- This week saw France get into and out of a political crisis with unexpected speed. The crisis was produced by fundamental divisions within the country and among its political representatives. It was settled, for a time at least, by that rare thing in French political life -- near unanimity on a major issue.
CLEVELAND, June 19 -- Great Lakes boat operators have placed four additional freighters in commission, but sixty carriers remain on the inactive list.

Good physicians come out of good medical schools. It is important, therefore, to maintain and even raise standards of medical education if general practitioners are to keep abreast of medical progress. Yet the seventy-nine medical schools of the country find it more and more difficult to meet their responsibilities.

GENEVA, June 19 -- The Geneva conference, which was thrown into confusion by the fall of the Laniel Government in Paris a week ago, has acquired a new lease on life as a result of the installation of Pierre Mendes-France as French Premier.

THE most confirmed optimist would find it hard to deny that relations between India and the United States are not in the healthiest state. However, in the world of movies Hollywood still ranks favorite, and the force of Hollywood depicting the American way of life is an old story tied up with the events of the day which sometimes can be amusing.
Starting tomorrow and continuing for two weeks, New York will be the educational center of the United States.

To most people the sway of a hammock is a soporific. To John H. Rawlins, a deeply tanned, red-headed citizen of Atlanta, Ga., the old hammock in his backyard was the jumping off point for thousands of miles of aerial hitch-hiking throughout this country.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Army and the Air Force are handing out recruiting booklets carrying the plea not to "join now" but "stay in school."
RENO, Nev., June 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Winthrop Rockefeller late today announced that she had reached a property settlement with her estranged husband.
SCHUYLERVILLE, N. Y., June 19 -- Schuyler House, an eighteenth -century manor house in this village and now a national monument, will be opened to the public with special exercises tomorrow.

AS in her earlier books, "Wonders of the Seashore" and "Wonders of Woodland Animals." Jacquelyn Berrill skillfully depicts an aspect of life about which children are perennially curious. In "Strange Nurseries" she shows how instinct and parental love guide certain members of the animal kingdom in care for their young.
HARTFORD, June 19 -- Certain conditions in Connecticut's nine county jails were described as "disgraceful" today in a survey submitted by the Connecticut Prison Association to Gov. John Davis Lodge.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- Former President Harry S. Truman will present an historic portrait of Benjamin Franklin to the National Park Service for exhibition in Independence Hall during a visit to this city on June 30.

In his interesting account, "Facts and Fancy About Mars" (May 30), J. Gordon Vaeth leaves open the question of what gives Mars' mantle of dust, ash or sand rich red, orange and yellow hues, but notes that some astronomers theorize that Mars is "a planet which has rusted away, its oxygen having been used up eons ago, by combining with elements of its sur face to form brightly colored oxides, particularly red-colored iron oxide."

WASHINGTON, June 19 -Robert Newton Denham joined the National Labor Relations Board here after working as a cowpuncher, investment authority, machinist and lawyer. He had just about decided to go to Florida and raise cattle in 1938 when he was asked to join the board as a trial examiner.

With Peter D. Whitney's vivid article describing the outlandish costume and behavior of Britain's problem-adolescents -- "Britain's Zoot Suiters -- The Edwardians" (June 6) -- you carried a boxed note, "Original Edwardians" which contained that hackneyed phrase "drab Victorian Age." May I file a dissent?

Advance buying for Father's Day this year slipped slightly under that of last year. But ideal shopping weather during the week and enticing promotions on furniture pushed department store sales in the city slightly above the same week a year ago.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 19 -- Having arranged a marriage of convenience between Turkey and Pakistan, the United States was gratified this week when the new partners announced plans to bring other nations into their household as rapidly as possible. Such neighbors as Iraq, Iran and Syria will be primary objects of this solicitude.
LONDON, June 19 (Reuters) -- The Cunard steamship company's new 22,000-ton liner, Saxonia, will make her maiden voyage from Liverpool to Quebec and Montreal Sept. 2, the company said today.

NEW YORKERS who like to watch boat races will have plenty of opportunity to do so this summer without going very far from the city. On Long Island Sound there will be the usual heavy quota of week-end, yachting programs.

OCEAN GROVE, N. J., June 19 -- Criticism of United States Government actions that sought "to create situations of strength by direct reormament of Japan and Germany" was voiced in a series of resolutions adopted today at the 168th annual conference of the Church of the Brethren.

The preliminary results of the first nation-wide Civil Defense first last week, under study and assessment at the week-end, demonstrated how little the United States has done to decrease the vulnerability of its cities and urban populations to atomic assault.
MOSCOW, June 19 -- The Soviet Air Force will demonstrate tomorrow a new type of jet "flying rhombus" with a speed faster than that of sound (about 750 miles an hour).

The expected has happened in Guatemala. Elements opposed to the slow Communist infiltration of the Government have taken up arms to end it. Censorship yesterday delayed or suppressed news from inside the country. News from outside indicated well-planned movements from Honduras and from Mexico and from the sea into Puerto Barrios on the Atlantic side and San Jose on the Pacific side.

WHEN the New York State Thruway is completed in 1955, motorists traveling it will be able to buy anything from a cup of coffee to a full-course dining-room dinner at the restaurants, lunch counters and snack bars along the route.

A SCANDAL in High Life is always an interesting subject, particularly when an attractive woman is involved. Early in 1809 the Duke of York, second son of George III, was accused of the corruption of his office as Commander-in-Chief of the Army by the sale of commissions at prices that undercut regulation rates.
JERUSALEM, June 19 -- A new flare-up of violence threatened the Israeli-Jordanian border tonight after three Israelis were killed.

CELEBRATED those many years as an acute (If slightly surrealist) observer of mankind's foibles, cartoonist Virgil Franklin (Vip) Partch has set up a special drawing board to record the perils and punishments of the average homo sapiens at play.
THERE are many motorists who object to paying tolls for the use of publicly built and owned highways and bridges.

Also in the whole neighborhood I did not find one For Rent sign in a window. In the old days, there were always some For Rent signs to be found. Some buildings have been turned into rooming houses and hotels. This is always a sign of neighborhood deterioration in Chicago.

DENVER -- Motorists fleeing up to Colorado this summer from file scorching heat of the Great Plains will find many roads improved as a result of the biggest construction program in Rocky Mountain history. In the past eighteen months, the Colorado Highway Department has spent nearly $27,000,000 on 226 projects covering 1,500 miles of roadway.

THIS is a time of strain and criticism between America and its allies -- a situation which lies behind the forthcoming visit of Winston Churchill and Anthony Eden to America. Every traveler returning to the United States from Britain or Europe brings back reports of an increase in anti-American feeling.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday the appointment of ten additional lay members of the New York City Youth Board and the reappointment of four others.
PHENIX CITY, Ala., June 19 (UP) -- National Guardsmen rushed here today to keep order after the gangland slaying of a vice crusader who had been chosen as Alabama's next Attorney General.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP) -- The National Federation of Post Office Clerks charged today that Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield was using pressure tactics to defeat a 7 per cent increase in postal pay.

FLINT, Mich., June 19 -- The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers have joined forces against some avowed anti-Communist union members who are trying to bar other members accused of Communist affiliation.

HARTFORD, June 19. -- The Democratic State Convention will be held here Friday and Saturday, with Abraham A. Rubicoff of Hartford, former Representative in Congress, assured of the nomination for Governor.
The public market for new debt capital is breathing easier after a spell of prolonged strain not uncommon to spring.

WQXR, the radio station of The New York Times, is scheduled to become the country's first 50,000-watt station devoted to programs of classical music and news. This will happen early in 1955, when the station increases its present power of 10,000 watts to the new output, the maximum granted to any commercial radio station in the country.

TODAY, when the first visitors remove their shoes and enter the Japanese house in the garden of the Museum of Modern Art, they will see a series of empty rectangular rooms. The rooms will be bathed in the soft, diffused, even light that filters through rice-paper panes.

Thirteen years ago tomorrow Prime Minister Churchill of the United Kingdom was in Washington conferring with President Roosevelt and others on the course and prognosis of the Second World War. One day the late Harry Hopkins told Mr. Churchill that he would like to bring in "a couple of American officers the President would like you to meet." One of the two officers was Dwight D. Eisenhower.

THIS IS the time of year when summer theatre managers are investing in barometers, studying meteorological charts and thumbing the pages of the Old Farmer's Almanac. The word, to date, has not been reassuring. The almanac indicates that it may be a rainy summer.

UNION CITY, N. J., June 19 -- A 55-year-old Union City scrap metal dealer has confessed, according to the police, to shooting three fellow patrons in a tavern here early today. He is being held in $10,000 bail.

Senator Lester C. Hunt went to Washington in 1948 after a political career in his home state that started with his election in 1932 as a member of the Wyoming Legislature and led to the Governor's chair.
" Royal jelly" has been in the news of late. And what is royal jelly? The food of queen bees.

Frank Costello was released yesterday in $50,000 bail by Federal Judge John F. X. McGohey. The gambler's release on bond had been ordered Friday by Justice Robert H. Jackson of the United States Supreme Court pending the outcome of Costello's appeal of an income tax evasion conviction.

Architects throughout the nation will be asked to contribute to a $1,000,000 drive to expand applied research in architecture and related fields, Douglas W. Orr, president of the American Architectural Foundation, announced yesterday.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York last week urged a Congressional committee to "give favorable consideration" to a bill that would provide a round-the-clock Quarantine Inspection Service.
NEWPORT, R. I., June 19 -- There were good starts and bad today when seventy-seven cruising craft began one of the year's great sailing events, the biennial ocean race to Bermuda, 635 sea miles away.

Sales of men's and women's apparel will increase sharply during the next two decades, according to a booklet released by the Wool Bureau, Inc. The brochure, which will be distribut ed to wool mills, clothing manufacturers and retailers, projects the 1950 census through 1960 and 1970 and analyzes the population changes with respect to the clothing industry.

A VERY shrewd observer here -- not an American -- once remarked back in the Occupation days: "Japan is nobody's ally." The phrase is not necessarily gospel. But it is useful to bear in mind in weighing the value of the new partner the United States has acquired in the Orient.

ONE of those "generations" novels, "The Beckoning Hill" starts back in the Eighteen Eighties, covers thirty years or so and presents close to a dozen principal characters. Its main scenes are in Ilium (which looks suspiciously like Troy, N. Y.) and in Brooklyn and Manhattan.

MODERN art is still very young -- a mere fifty years or so. So young, in fact, that many of its creative pioneers are still imaginatively active and many of its courageous crusaders still in there fighting.

BRITTEN: Four Sea Interludes and Passacaglia from Peter Grimes; Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra; Amsterdam Concertgebouw Orchestra, Eduard van Beinum, conductor (London). The "Interludes" are Britten at his best and the "Guide" shows that even when the composer is being playful he is musical and ingenious. Well recorded.

STANTON, Del., June 19 (AP) -- Wreck Master, a 7-to-10 favorite, drove to a hard-earned victory today in Delaware Park's $14,825 Christiana Stakes, a five-furlong dash for juvenile colts and geldings.

MAKING it easier for the 4,500,000 motor vehicles licensed in this state to get on and off the New York State Thruway has been a primary consideration in the planning of the toll road, which also will have spurs reaching out in a beckoning gesture to the millions of out-of-state motorists.

WASHINGTON -- The Passport Office of the State Department has just passed the peak of its work in issuing passports for the present fiscal year. During March, April and May, this task involved the production of more than 50,000 passports a month and their safe delivery to anxious travelers.

THREE aspects of the New York State Thruway have made it a mammoth construction job: it's long, it's level and it's straight. Because it is long -- 427 miles on the main New York to Buffalo route -- a staggering amount of material has to go into it.

CHITA, U. S. S. R., June 7 -One of the remarks most often heard by a visitor to Chita, and indeed other Siberian points, is "Of course, we are a very young city and things are not as well fixed up as they will be later on."

THE story about the working-class couple who come into a lot of money has always been a good one, and if Robert Tallant's material isn't exactly original, he has handled it well. In this novel, the third installment of the life and times of Mrs. Candy (of Cairo Street, New Orleans), the author proves that his pneumatic heroine and her second husband, Henry Petit, are certainly a more ingratiating couple than Jiggs and Maggie.

ONE wayward thought persists in intruding itself on post-bellum musings about the Rocky Marciano-Ezzard Charles blood-letting. If Ezzard had fought all his fights the way he did against the rock-ribbed, rock-jawed and rock-fisted Rocky, he would have been the heavyweight champion of the world for a much longer time.

LAKE GENEVA, Wis., June 19 (AP) -- John McCollow, Lake Geneva attorney, said today that opponents of a site near here for the Air Force Academy had him go to court because Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, refused to listen to their arguments.

Guillermo Toriello, the Foreign Minister of Guatemala, declared early today that the entire nation -- the Army, the workers and the peasants -- stood united behind the Guatemalan Government in the current crisis.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- An enterprise founded at a whistle stop seventeen miles southeast of Chicago reached retirement age this week. Nothing, however, is more remote from its plans than retirement. The enterprise is Standard Oil Company of Indiana, and its recent rate of development has been that of a robust youngster.

PARIS, June 19 -- In assuming the post of Foreign Minister, Premier Pierre Mendes-France ends the virtually uninterrupted tenure of two leaders of the Popular Republican party, Robert Schuman and Georges Bidault.
The American Legion of Kings County ended yesterday its two-day, thirty-sixth annual convention at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn with the election of officers and the adoption of resolutions.

FOR the first time in six years the New York Unit of the Herb Society of America will play host for the twenty-first annual meeting of the society, to be held Tuesday through Thursday. The York Club, 4 East Sixty-second Street, New York 21, N. Y., will be official headquarters for the group.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 19 -- Don MacKenzie, with his Black Arrow, took the twenty-boat International Class race today as the season's record fleet, 107 craft, turned out for the tenth Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association championship regatta, run by the Larchmont Yacht Club.

RESORT AIRLINES' "flying houseparty" trips, the airplane equivalent of an ocean cruise, will begin taking off next Sunday on a delayed summer season. Covering much of the Caribbean, these all-expense trips include transportation, hotel accommodations, meals and sight-seeing, with the whole operation nudged along by a cruise manager, who acts as "host."

IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON -- Throughout the length of this beautiful river valley, the pilgrimage of nature lovers, vacationists and treaders of historic ground is swelling toward new records. Growing also is the resentment among valley folk against the practice of some writers and tourists of calling the Hudson River "the American Rhine."
A rise in United States commercial exports -- although a modest one -- is under way, and some traders feel that it will continue sufficiently to produce a slight gain for this year over 1953.

The experts who reviewed the results of the theoretical atomic-bomb attacks on thirty-one cities concluded that if real A-bombs had been dropped, 7,276,000 (possibly as many as 13,000,000) would have been killed and 3,344,000 injured. In New York City 1,773,600 were theoretically dead, 1,176,000 injured and 1,000,000 homeless. On the whole the authorities were satisfied with the response of the country to the warnings, but there was evidence enough of unpreparedness.

A long and tortuous chapter in the story of East-West struggle seems to be coming to an end. It is a chapter that began more than a year ago when the two leading figures in the Western world addressed themselves to the new regime in the Kremlin. These were their words:
New York will welcome summer tomorrow seven hours and twenty-five minutes early.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- John Foster Dulles, the Secretary of State, seldom intervenes in the internal affairs of other countries, but his brother Allen is more enterprising.

In the hush throughout the upper floors of the Empire State Building yesterday, the tapping of a typewriter in Room 7705 sounded unusually loud. Behind the frosted glass panel of the door, the atmosphere was solemn and discussion non-stop.
BRUNSWICK, Me., June 19 -- Seven honorary degrees and 185 bachelor of arts degrees were conferred today by James S. Coles, the president, at the 149th commencement exercises of Bowdoin College.

ROME, N. Y., June 19 (AP) -- Track and field stars from the Far East Conference placed first in ten of twenty-one events and romped off with official team honors today in the U. S. Air Force world-wide championships.

TOKYO, June 19 -- Representatives of Japan's five major parties decided today on an extra parliamentary session next month to complete the legislative program. The program was held up by rioting on the floor of the Diet and a minority boycott of the lower house sessions.

It is common knowledge that bats avoid obstacles, even fine wires, on the radar principle. That is, they emit ultrasonic squeaks which are reflected by the obstacle. Bats hear the echos and avoid collisions.

On a home run streak since they returned to Ebbets Field last Tuesday night, the Dodgers walloped the ball out of their park three times yesterday to defeat the Cubs, 6 -- 2. All the Brooklyn runs -- and Chicago's pair -- were the product of homers.

Congratulations on your timely editorial of June 14 captioned "Honesty in the I. L. O.," pointing out that integrity of that body is involved as well as its future usefulness in the question of seating the so-called "employer" and "worker" representatives of the Soviet nations at the International Labor Organization conference now in session in Geneva.

DURING her recent rebellion against a role in the movie, "Pink Tights," Marilyn Monroe lisped -- with less languor than usual -- that she would not do another remake, so soon after "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," which was a remake, and "How to Marry a Millionaire," which was an amalgamated remake of two other stories.

Nearly half of the private liberal arts colleges in the United States are operating on a deficit, a recent report from the Council for Financial Aid to Education declared. The council, supported by leading business men and educators with the aim of promoting greater public interest in education, asserted that the financial plight of the colleges was growing serious.

AT LEAST twenty emergency repair trucks equipped as mobile garages will patrol the New York State Thruway around the clock to rescue motorists stalled by flat tires and breakdowns. There will be gasoline service stations every twenty miles along the highway, but breakdowns usually occur between stations.

A grant of $30,500 from the Fund for the Advancement of Education will support a teaching program at Wesleyan University (Middletown, Conn.). The program is designed to encourage and speed the development of college teachers. Seven young instructors with little or no teaching experience will start a year's internship this September.

LONDON, June 19 (UP) -- Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., warmed up for Wimbledon by beating Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, today for the women's singles crown in the London Grass-court tennis championships and Australia's Lewis Hoad retained the men's title with an 8-6, 6-4 victory over his countryman, Mervyn Rose.
The Russian chess team increased its lead last night over the American players to 8 -- 3 in the second eight-game match of the international tournament at the Roosevelt Hotel.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Senator Lester C. Hunt, Democrat of Wyoming, committed suicide today in apparent despondency over his health. He was 61 years of age.
The strategy of the anti-Communist Guatemalan rebels attacking Guatemala appeared to aim at the severing the nation's only coast-to-coast railroad and bottling up the Government in the capital.

Until the Senate Finance Committee has presented to the Congress the revised form of the Revenue Code of 1954 (H. R. 8300), which was passed by the House of Representatives on March 18, many business transactions will necessarily be held in abeyance.

The thirty-seventh summer session of Fordham University directed by William F. McAloon, will open Tuesday, July 6, with 238 graduate and undergraduate courses being offered. The six-week session will include courses in art, biology, chemistry, classics, education, English, history, social studies, mathematics, modern languages, philosophy, physics, psychology, science, speech and theology.

THE televised series of lectures on Shakespeare by Dr. Frank C. Baxter, Professor of English Literature at the University of Southern California, should hearten all those who firmly believe that TV has barely begun to lift its sights in the realm of education.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Thunder and lightning cooled off this heat-gripped city today, bringing relief to the local citizenry after nine consecutive days in which the temperature had been in the nineties. Also cooled off were the world champion Yankees, who had won four straight and nine out of ten before they were blanked, 3 -- 0, by the Chicago White Sox this afternoon.
Three writers and a newspaper will receive the 1953 awards of the Education Writers Association for rendering important contributions to educational journalism.

THE bulldozers, graders and power shovels that are carving out a course for the New York State Thruway are spinning a web of increased prosperity for the state's industries. Virtually every section of the New York economy will benefit from the faster, cheaper, more dependable transportation the new expressway makes possible.
It started thirty-nine years ago when a doughty Yankee out of Gloucester, Mass., while on a fur trapping cruise to Labrador, found that he relished frozen seal, whale and caribou.
Speculation in low-priced uranium mining stocks is showing signs of becoming America's newest gambling fad.

MONTEZUMA -- Since 1937, when the Montezuma Swamps became a national wildlife refuge, protected by the Fish and Wildlife Service of the Department of Interior, the snowy egret, blue heron, glossy ibis, American bittern, white pelican and many equally unusual birds have lived comfortably and peacefully in the nine square miles of swamp near the northern tip of Cayuga Lake.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 (UP) -- Cincinnati scored five unearned runs in the third inning for a 7-6 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today, but for the second game in a row Frank Smith had to take over the pitching assignment to stop a ninth-inning rally.

THE financing of the New York Thruway is passing the half-way mark just as it is becoming clear that the project, estimated four years ago to cost about a half-billion dollars, will instead cost nearly twice that amount.

CAIRO, June 19 -- The first anniversary of the proclamation that Egypt was a republic passed yesterday uncelebrated but not entirely unnoticed. In fact, most of the notice was drawn to the lack of celebration.

A TRIO of minor movie blessings were bestowed upon local screens last week, and the prospect of pleasant movie-going this blissful summer was enhanced that much thereby. Diligent picture selectors should carefully jot these in their books.

SOMETHING a bit off the beaten track will be attempted by Hope Sheridan and D. D. Livingston when they present their New York City Summer Dance Festival at the Ninety-second Street Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., July 6-11.

QUANTICO, Va., June 19 -President Eisenhower joined the Quantico conference this morning as his national security planners pondered a warning that Russia was narrowing the United States' lead in weapons technology.

THE Japanese iris has often been called the artist's flower for its exquisite form and colors in rainbow hues. Rare spectacular effects are possible with these larger-flowered beauties, too, which appear in June soon after the tall bearded iris fade.
WHERE in our century was there another like Finland's Field Marshal and President Carl Mannerheim? Where another life so fully, so resolutely lived? Here, indeed, was one of earth's giants.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- A movement has started in Congress for a modern museum to supplant the seventy-five-year-old Arts and Industries Building of the Smithsonian Institution.

CHICAGO, June 19 (UP) -- Betty Jameson of San Antonio, who last won the women's Western open golf title in 1942, played some of her greatest golf today and defeated Louise Suggs of Atlanta, Ga., the defender, 6 and 5, for the title.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP) -- Highway signs instructing the public not to use major roads in event of enemy air attack will be taken down soon. They are outmoded by the hydrogen bomb.

Is there a place for a psychiatrist in the college program? Schools across the country have given the answer. The psychiatrist is now a familiar figures on the campuses of a number of colleges. He has taken a place beside the guidance counselor and adviser on student problems.

YOU don't have to close your eyes to imagine yourself on an African safari. Open them to the pages of this exceptional book and the living panorama of the Dark Continent is spread out for your personal participation.

BALLET stories, like horse stories, have their impatient audiences, who are more often concerned with the frequency of new books on the subject than with the quality of the story. These eager readers are none the less entitled to full measure.

AN arm of Finnish territory juts out to the northwest, almost reaching the Atlantic Ocean. At its outer end three countries meet, and within it are spoken four languages: Finnish, Swedish, Norwegian and Lapp. Remote though this corner of Scandinavia may be when viewed from more temperate latitudes, it has played a strategic role in two world wars.
LA GRANGE, Ill., June 19 (UP) Earl D. Eisenhower, brother of President Eisenhower said today that he didn't know "there was so much work to putting out a newspaper."

FULTONVILLE -- This is the tiny village that has been literally bisected by the New York State Thruway. An overpass splits Main Street at right angles. The massive, red-leaded structure is a mere dot on the route of the superhighway, about halfway between Albany and Utica.

IN order to keep the roadbed of New York's great super-highway in prime condition, a Bureau of Maintenance has been organized, under which the route between New York and Buffalo has been divided into three maintenance divisions.
BERN, Switzerland, June 19 (AP) -- Uruguay, Austria, Brazil and Yugoslavia advanced to the quarter-finals in the world soccer championship today.

UP Rockland County way, where some mighty slick folk from Hollywood and Broadway have gone to escape the light and the fantastic, a Democrat is mighty hard to come by. But last Sunday, 1,000 of them (if you count non-voting children and a few Republican spies) made a quorum {or an old-fashioned country auction.

VICKSBURG, Miss., June 19 -- A Government installation whose staff of scientists, engineers and technicians claim to have saved the taxpayers at least $100,000,000 is celebrating its twenty-fifth anniversary here this week-end.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 19 (AP) -- The French High Command said tonight that a commercial airliner, now delayed in India, was scheduled to be the first plane in the homeward airlift of 1,000 Dienbienphu wounded.
Several hundred persons yesterday devoted their time here to discussing what has been done and what should be done to help the mentally retarded child to attain mental adulthood.
AN unusual and, perhaps, unique experiment in educational television is now under way in this state. Sponsored by WATV (Channel 13), its reaction upon the viewing public is already obvious.

GENEVA, June 19 -- With the United States reluctantly agreeing, the Far Eastern conference here decided tonight to start immediate military conversations on a cessation of hostilities in Cambodia and Laos.

PARIS, June 19 -- An aluminum congress, called to celebrate the hundredth anniversary of the discovery of an industrial technique for producing the metal, concluded its sessions here today with a visit to an industrial installation at Saint-Jeande-Maurienne.

THE vikings are on the move again, this time opening what they consider the first new important travel route in a thousand years. Negotiations between the United States State Department and the Governments of Sweden, Denmark and Norway are in progress now and the details of a new air service between California and Europe, via the Arctic, are being arranged.

As a part of its national defense function last year, the National Recreation Asso ciation assisted 220 communities and areas in establishing better recreation oppor tunities for defense and military personnel.
EARLIER this spring five producers and shippers of the wines of Bordeaux, which has been called the greatest wine district in the world, arrived in New York to explore the American market.

THE signs designating community names along the entire Thruway system will have upper and lower case letters. It was found that such signs provide better visibility than markers using only capital letters, until recently the usual pattern for road signs.

THE variety of contemporary juvenile literature -- in subject-matter, if not necessarily in treatment -- is well illustrated in the latest additions to the Signature Books. There could scarcely have been three more diverse temperaments than the dashing General Custer, the self-reliant, determined Clara Barton and that self-effacing genius, George Washington Carver.

Chicken, three varieties of salami, cold herb omelette, gorgonzola cheese and three loaves of hard-crusted bread had been laid atop a cotton towel as soon as we had pulled out of the station in Rome.

The men's neckwear industry has shaken-off the shackles of despondency and has begun to report improved sales volume. The entire soft goods field, and men's wear lines in particular, have finished a trying eight months. All segments of the apparel industry had lower sales volume than the previous year from last fall through the first quarter of this year.
MISSIE almost surely would have cried at being shut out of the new club on Woodland Hill, if carrot-topped Pete hadn't tossed it off with. "Pooh, we'll have one of our own."

HARVESTING the rich fields of modern Italian short fiction, Marc Slonim presents a collection of thirty-four stories from Verga to Vittorini that is little less than superb. The tales, most of them of high literary quality and human significance, throb with the unmatched variety and vitality that is Italy.
" Class Day" of an unusual university -- the old liner President Wilson -- will be observed this summer on two temporary "campuses" separated by the width of this continent.

THE June Festival has offered a fairly accurate reflection of the contemporary musical scene: concerts of traditional music well covered by the public and concerts of modern music well covered by the critics.

WHILE most of the publicity on the giant Thruway project has gone to its designers and builders, the unsung heroes of the cross-state expressway are the specialists who have accomplished one complex and indispensable job:

Alexis Lichine, author of "Wines of France" (Knopf, 1951), lists here a few common wine terms with brief definitions. Mr. Lichine stresses that one gets to know wine better through the bottle than through the printed word.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The United States rejected today Guatemala's assertion that she had been invaded.
TRENTON, June 19 -- The New Jersey Legislature will reconvene here Monday for a brief session after which it is expected to recess until September.

Thomas E. Dewey, 52, has been extremely successful at getting and keeping New York's Republican governorship for the past three terms. In 1942, 1946, and again in 1950 he won by well over a half-a-million votes. Governor Dewey is also a key figure in the National Republican Party. In 1952, it was largely through his influence that Eisenbower won out over the Taft forces at the Republican Convention.
PITTSBURGH, June 19 (UP) -- Andy Pafko and Joe Adcock pounded out a homer and double apiece today to drive in five runs and lead the Milwaukee Braves to an 11-2 rout of the Pittsburgh Pirates.

WILDWOOD, N. J., June 19 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner pledged his cooperation to members of the New Jersey Disabled American Veterans at a luncheon here today at the thirty-fourth annual convention of the state group.

PORTOFERRAIO, Elba -- The fact that Napoleon lingered less than a year on Elba did not mean he disliked the place. He enjoyed himself and entertained lavishly. Therefore, the natives ask, if the Little Corporal, who was notoriously hard to please, liked their island, why don't more Americans visit them ?
The Venezuelan Government has embarked on a $37,500,000 project to build a large drydock and navy yard in the Santa Lucia Valley near the port of Puerto Cabello.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 19 -- Several Vietminh units totaling about 1,000 men ambushed a French-Vietnamese road-opening company yesterday morning eight miles west of Haiduong at a mid-way point on the Hanoi-Haiphong highway in northern Indochina, it was announced here today.
MOSCOW, June 19 -- Tass, the Soviet news agency, charged today that the United States had opened an "assault on the freedom and independence of the people of Guatemala."

THE Opening of the first major section of the Thruway to toll traffic next Thursday will be marked by a big celebration which will last from early morning until well into the evening. It will consist of a series of six wayside ceremonies along the 115-mile route and will wind up with a reception and dinner in Rochester.
You can never trust this game of baseball, Eddie Stanky, the bustling skipper of the Cardinals, learned yesterday at the Polo Grounds.
SPRINGFIELD, N. J., June 19 -- Ed Furgol, who overcame a physical handicap in becoming a golfer, won the United States open championship at the Baltusrol Club today.
NORWALK, Conn., June 19 -- Construction of a $20,000,000 steam generating plant by the Connecticut Light and Power Company on Manresa Island has been deferred until about 1960.

The first births in the remodeled reptile house at the Bronx Zoo were announced yesterday. On May 25 a 15-foot Indian rock python arrived with thirty eggs she had laid on the way. The first slits appeared in the eggs yesterday morning, marking the start of hatching.

ACCORDING to Leslie Turner White, Russia in the reign of Ivan the Terrible (about 1576) was "notoriously a land of spies." The Tsar maintained his own secret police, a sixteenth-century M. V. D. called the Opritchnina.

For the moment Cheops' solar boats, discovered near his Great Pyramid, have taken the play away from the ships of the Suez Canal. The stubborn quarrel between the Egyptians and the British over the canal has quieted down while Egyptians, British and the rest of the world marvel at the strange relics of an almost incredible antiquity.

AFTER the lush days of May, when so many shrubs vie for attention with their floral displays, interest naturally shifts to the evergreen bloomers such as mountain laurel and rhododendron. A closer look, however, will reveal that nature has reserved certain choice deciduous shrubs and trees for enjoyment in mid-June.

THE longest way around will be the shortest way between New York and Buffalo in point of time, when the Thruway opens all the way across the state. Between the centers of the state's two biggest cities, travel via the toll road will cover 442 miles, as compared with 374 over the shortest free route.

The role of the nation's public schools in helping to strengthen American community life was outlined last week in a forty-two-page report issued by the Educational Policies Commission. The commission, sponsored by the National Education Association and the American Association of School Administrators, is composed of twenty of the nation's leading school spokesmen.

THE time is rapidly approaching when the West German problem as distinct from the whole German problem will have to be re-examined and reappraised in the light of the events which have occurred since the Berlin Conference of the four Foreign Ministers. Those events have stirred the nationalism which is latent in West Germany and which may challenge the "European Idea."

An important new step toward economic integration of Communist Eastern Europe with the Soviet Union has been announced by the top party leaders of Hungary and Czechoslovakia. Beginning with 1956, the five-year plans of the satellite states will be integrated with the corresponding Soviet blueprints, in the first place with the Sixth Five-Year Plan scheduled to run from 1956 through 1960.

Back in 1879 a workman at the Procter Gamble Cincinnati factory making Ivory soap left his mixing machine running when he went to lunch. The extended mixing beat a few tiny bubbles of air into the mixture. The result was a product that floated.

HAVERSTRAW, N. Y., June 19 -- Ten thousand marched in the sixty-ninth annual parade of the Hudson Valley Volunteer Firemen's Associations today as this village and its fire department celebrated their 100th anniversary.

THE partial opening of the New York State Thruway this year will find the traffic situation somewhat chaotic at both the Buffalo and New York City ends. Construction is lagging badly on expressways, parkways and other arteries needed to carry the vehicular load to and from the Thruway in both terminal areas.

THE typical bridge player, if he exists, tries to play the right card every time it is his turn to play. He would feel pardonably proud if he could always play the card that the "rules" call for. Furthermore, he would be a very superior bridge player.
OKMULGEE, Okla., June 18 -- Voters in Oklahoma are facing the problem of choosing gubernatorial candidates from one of the most crowded slates in the state's history.

NEWPORT HARBOR, Calif., June 19 (UP) -- Four Massachusetts Institute of Technology sailors only smiled today when asked if they used slide rules in figuring tacks that brought them top honors in the eighteenth national intercollegiate dinghy championships.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP) -- The political arm of the American Federation of Labor "blacklisted" today on the basis of their Congressional voting records sixty Republican Representatives in Congress and one Democratic Senator who are up for re-election this year.
A total of 3,385 "lost time" accidents occurred on the docks of the Port of New York in 1953, compared to the record of 3,832 in the previous year.

A NEW record for wide-angle lenses for 35mm miniature cameras was set recently with the introduction of the Biogon 21mm f/4.5 lens by Carl Zeiss, Inc., 485 Fifth Avenue, the importers. The $269 lens, which covers the extreme angle of 90 degrees, has been equipped with a bayonet mount to fit the Contax camera.

SAUK CITY, Wis., June 19 (UP) -- Supporters of a move to recall Senator McCarthy tried today with release of a financial report to refute a prosecutor's charge that the movement appeared to be a "wholesale financial racket."

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- For a number of reasons, the state of morale in the nation's diplomatic service -- an acute and alarming and much discussed problem, several months ago -- has been all but abandoned as a subject of conversation here.
Next Thursday the 90-year-old Union News Company will open a $150,000 restaurant in the midst of a thriving new shopping center in Syracuse.

BERLIN, June 19 (UP) -- Thousands of East German refugees who fled to the West to escape Soviet tyranny are returning to the Soviet zone because they are are unable to find work in West Germany, Western officials said today.

The Flammable Fabrics Act, which goes into effect on July 1, bars interstate shipment of flammable textile materials. To comply with the act, Dr. John D. Guthrie and Wilson A. Reeves of the Southern Regional Research Laboratory, New Orleans, La., have developed an agent that protects clothing from flash fires.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 19 -- The United Nations Security Council will meet tomorrow at 3 P. M. to look into a charge by Guatemala of open aggression against her territory.

BILLINGS, Mont., June 19 -- Plans for a referendum to legalize gambling in Montana are being pushed by a group known as the Open Montana Committee, which has conducted meetings in twenty-two of the state's fifty-six counties.
Mayor Wagner declared last night that his forthcoming trip to Puerto Rico was a matter of "serious business" involving the living standards of the city's residents of Puerto Rican birth or origin.
Ed Furgol captured the United Open championship at the Baltusrol Club yesterday by finishing with a 72 for a seventy-two-hole total of 284. His margin was one stroke over Gene Littler.

In the Nineteen Twenties and early Thirties, opportunity in the form of newly built express highways that reached into Upstate New York knocked on the door of White Plains. Business men there were quick to recognize the knock.

MOTORISTS will have a choice of nine brands of gasoline at twenty-seven service stations along the 427-mile Thruway route from Buffalo to New York. They will pay a premium for buying gasoline on the Thruway, the same 1 to 2 cent-higher price usually charged by gas stations on toll highways and turnpikes.

ALONG with the problem of where to go and what to wear, one of the basic questions facing any traveler abroad is how to divide his time effectively. The simple matter of using time wisely, of adjusting to the tempo and timetable of the places visited, helps determine the success of any trip.

The motorship Seven Seas chugged out of New York yesterday with 1,250 scholars thirsting for educational travel in Europe. It was also the start of a goodwill cash program that will let students from poorer countries study in hard-currency lands.

THERE seems to have been a vogue in England, lately, for novels which deal with the merry japes of fundamentally irresponsible young men. "Under the Net" is the third such to come before me, recently, of a trio which one could imagine having been written by the same hand. The other two are "Lucky Jim," by Kingsley Amis, and "Born in Captivity," by John Wain.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- "Think twice -- once for yourself and once for the other guy" is the advice the National Safety Council gave today to motorists for the July 4 holiday. The council asserted that one or both of the drivers were at fault in about 75 per cent of all fatal traffic accidents.

GUATEMALA, June 19 -- The agreement reached last Saturday between the United Fruit Company and union representatives to end a twenty-three-day strike has been ratified by the laborers in a general assembly, a company spokesman announced today.

THE pleasure traveler will be one of the principal beneficiaries of the New York State Thruway. The tolls he will pay will add to the direct cost of his holiday transportation but the sixty-mile-an-hour speedway will save time and driving effort for the man behind the wheel.

IN "Animals, Men and Myths" Richard Lewinsohn has written a book that is neither just a history of animals nor a discourse on animal mythology and men; rather it is a report' on how men and animals have got along together throughout human history.

DACCA, Pakistan, June 18 -A nation-wide industrial strike of 350,000 has been set for next month. The strike is scheduled to go on unless the Government begins immediate recognition of the six-and-a-half-year demand for extensive labor legislation.

The 38,000-deadweight ton tanker W. Alton Jones, flagship of the Cities Service Oil Company fleet and first of four supertankers being built for operation to the Persian Gulf, will make her initial appearance here Monday morning.

CLEVELAND, June 19 -- Ellis Kinder, making his first start since 1952, snapped the Cleveland Indians' nine-game winning streak today by pitching the Boston Red Sox to a 6-3 victory. The triumph was Boston's first over Cleveland after nine straight losses to the Tribe this season.

CLEMENS KRAUSS died of a heart attack a few hours after he had led a concert in Mexico City on May 16. Since the 61-year-old Viennese conductor was slated to conduct both "Ring" cycles, at the Bayreuth Festival, his sudden death caused dismay in the Festspielhaus.
THE growth of the Tappan Zee Bridge, which carries the Thruway over the Hudson River from South Nyack to Tarrytown, has been like that of the storied ugly duckling, but in reverse.
The appointment of Giuseppe Ali as general manager of the Italian Line's new organization in the United States was announced here yesterday by Carlo Linch, president of the company.

At Wagner College, Staten Island, last week, Bernard Haldane, a member of the faculty, demonstrated a method of letting bacteria digest city garbage and convert it into virgin topsoil or compost. The method was developed by George H. Earp-Thomas. It, or something very like it, is in successful use in Sydney, Australia; at East Lansing, Mich., and other places.
LUXEMBOURG, June 19 -- The lieutenants of the movement for a more united Europe are frightened about the future of their cause. But the generals have not given up the fight.

GUATEMALA, June 19 -- The Guatemalan Government has announced that the invading anti-Communist rebel forces have captured the town of El Florido and have advanced about nine miles into Guatemala from the Honduras border.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 19 -- Cinda's supremacy in the $20,000 added Regret Handicap at Monmouth Park came to an end before 24,278 when Mrs. S. M. Pistorio's Brazen Brat staged a stirring drive in the stretch run to win the filly-and-mare feature event by three-quarters of a length today.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Senator Walter F. George, Democrat of Georgia, said today that Democrats would fight in the Senate to write new income tax cuts into a general tax revision bill that already provided almost $1,500,000,000 in tax relief for corporations and individuals.
DETROIT, June 19 (AP) -- Gale V won the Maple Leaf regatta today when Miss U. S. flipped in the final heat and almost sank.
BALTIORE, June 19 (UP) -- The Washington Senators scored four unearned runs in the ninth inning to defeat Baltimore, 5 to 2, today, and hand the Orioles their sixth straight defeat.

THERE is something particularly democratic and of New York in the Stadium Concerts, which open their thirty-seventh season tomorrow night and bring it to an end on July 31 with five concerts a week containing music of both the "classic" and "popular" persuasion.

LOS ANGELES -- Practically everything from soaring in the air to spear-fishing under water awaits the million or more prospective visitors to Southern California this summer. What is more likely than any single attraction to arrest the attention of even perennial argonauts, however, is the array of new features that have burgeoned since a year ago and the welter of activity attendant on the completion of even more.

BERLIN, June 19 -- The Soviet Union has closed down all of its provincial High Commissioner's offices in East Germany and cut the staff by two-thirds, the East German news agency A. D. N. reported today.

HANOVER, N. H., June 19 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York, the Under Secretary for Health, Education and Welfare, was elected today to the presidency of the General Association of Dartmouth College Alumni at the organization's 100th anniversary meeting.

Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, said yesterday that he was studying plans to establish a new station in the Bronx or lower Westchester County to supplement Grand Central Terminal.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 19 (AP) -- Guatemalan officials said rebel planes had bombed oil tanks and military bases at San Jose and strafed military targets and Government buildings in the capital in other flights last night and yesterday afternoon.
MOTORISTS who use the New York state Thruway will be operating under a set of driving regulations formulated by the Authority and designed to prevent accidents on the new high-speed facility.

NEW YORK'S Thruway started life as a hedge against a post-World War II depression. Had it not been for the belief, amounting to a conviction, that the end of the war would be followed by widespread unemployment, it is doubtful that the original Thruway law could have been passed in 1942.

SEVEN earnest and single-minded young men, whose average age is 19, will make Australia's annual pilgrimage to the All-England lawn tennis championships at Wimbledon this July. From London, they will continue on what for most teen-age tourists would be a dream trip.

Parents were urged yesterday to be less concerned over providing for children those things they themselves went without and to be more solicitous over seeing that their children acquired a pioneering spirit.

This is a momentous week for the Empire State. We who live within its borders will have a first-hand look at history in the making as traffic starts rolling over the first substantial section of the New York State Thruway.

WALPOLE, Mass., June 19 -- Senator McCarthy's contention that he has the right to receive confidential documents from Government employes "is a grave thing and is bound to destroy the F. B. I.," Joseph N. Welch said today.

Patrolman Martin Corbett rounded out twenty-six years of service with the Police Department yesterday by apprehending an armed man wanted for an attempted shooting. The policeman made the capture a few hours before completing his final day of duty and retiring.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., June 19 (AP) -- The starting field of ninety was cut to less than half today in the opening rounds of the New Jersey State men's tennis championships at the East Orange Club.

NORTH up the Hudson River, west along the Mohawk and on past the narrow lakes of the Oneida Indians, the Onondagas, the Senecas and Cayugas, to the shores of the Great Lakes, lay the early course of America's empire.

At 10:35 A. M. on Thursday, April 22, Karl Mundt, Acting Chairman of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, rapped the McCarthy-Army hearings to order. He announced that the committee, in a determined effort "to reveal that which is true and that which is false" would "follow the evidence wherever it leads."

WITH Congressional activity moving from the side show into the main arena, the long awaited legislation for bolstering the economy may at long last be enacted. The omnibus tax bill, designed to remove inequities that tend to hamper business investment, should get quick attention; most business groups have been urging its enactment.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 19 -- Relations between the Government and the Republican People's party, principal Opposition group, have reached a crisis over Premier Adnan Menderes' proposals for changes in the electoral law and in civil service regulations.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Again this week the Central Intelligence Agency was attacked by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. He contended that the global cloak-and-dagger outfit was infiltrated by Communists, and threatened to drag its operations into the glare of Congressional hearings.

SEVERAL items of miscellaneous photographic literature on the practical level were published recently. Most of them deal with special fields. An exception is Godfrey Frankel's "Short Cut to Photography" (New York: Sterling Publishing Company, $2.50), a manual written for the teen-ager but eminently useful for all beginners of any age.

DIVIDED highways engineered for high-speed driving are completed or in the construction stage from Augusta, Me., to the Illinois line near Chicago. If no hitches develop, within three years one will be able to get behind the wheel of an automobile and drive a third of the way across the North American continent with virtually no interruptions for traffic lights or grade crossings.

IN November and December, 1953, Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer broadcast six radio lectures in England on the evolution of atomic physics and the philosophical implications of that evolution. The lectures are assembled in this small volume in permanent form, a richly deserved tribute to their quality. Though they bear no direct relation to the recent investigation of Dr. Oppenheimer as a security risk they do illuminate his character and his habit of thought.

D-DAY follows hard upon the summer shutdown of city schools. The first assault wave moves in between dawn and noon They travel in trucks, coming out from New York along the Boston Post Road, which has no ban on heavy vehicles. They carry furniture, bedding and cumbersome articles like play pens, perambulators and tricycles.

ONE of the pleasantest one-day or week-end motor trips out of the city at this time of year is across New Jersey to the Delaware River Valley. There, away from the frantic pace of superhighways, one can enjoy the beauties of green countryside at leisure and investigate some historic spots at the same time.

DINARD, France -- France's most westerly province, the rectangular Breton peninsula jutting out into the Atlantic, holds many attractions for the tourist. For one thing, it is within easy reach of Paris; its most accessible points -- Dinard on the northern coast and La Baule on the southern coast -- are each but a five-hour train journey from the capital.
May I crave your hospitality to express some thoughts of an American Egyptologist inspired by recent dispatches from Cairo on the sensational discoveries at the Great Pyramid and at Sakkara?

WHEN the Thruway gets into full swing next year it is estimated that it will take in close to $25,000,000 in tolls annually, or an average of nearly $70,000 a day. To handle the mechanics of this vast operation the Thruway Authority has invested $4,677,203 in the installation of a collection system which is as nearly foolproof as modern business technicians can devise.
Radio station WRUL announced last night that since the outbreak of the Guatemalan insurrection it had increased its nightly Spanish-language broadcasts to Central America.

Between the covers of an impressive volume of statistics recently published by the Society of Actuaries, in cooperation with the Association of Life Insurance Medical Directors, there is cheerful news for many groups of persons suffering from a variety of conditions.

There are moves and countermoves in the assault on Southeast Asia by the Communists and the attempt by the free world to defend the strategic area. They are taking place in New York, in Paris, in Geneva, in Saigon and in the Red River delta.
