At this moment there is a lull, both political and military, but the issue is still joined and the outcome has not been determined

On Your Own of the King Ranch ran as if there was something fast pursuing her in the $30,050 Gazelle Stakes at Aquaduct yesterday. She was absolutely right, for the filly that she feared was Mrs. George D. Widener's Evening Out, the 3-year-old that had never been beaten by one of her sex.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Eisenhower Administration's Federal employe security program came under new scrutiny this week with the release of testimony in the Oppenheimer hearings and the end of the thirty-six-day Army-McCarthy hearings.

IN the perspective of the years the Administrations of Woodrow Wilson will loom as among the most significant and dramatic in our history. The country then entered upon a new phase in national affairs. The two political parties, too long quarreling over nonessentials, began to think in terms of elemental principles.
KANSAS CITY, Sunday, June 20 -- Former President Truman was taken to surgery in Research Hospital at 12:30 o'clock this morning for an emergency operation.

Cool weather throughout the country has retarded sales of summer merchandise, resident buying offices report. As a result, stores expect good summer business through July, and many are planning to delay clearances to the end of the month, the offices say.
DETROIT, June 19 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics exploded for five runs in the eighth inning today to beat the Detroit Tigers, 5 -- 4, before 7,321 fans at Briggs Stadium.
PARIS, June 19 -- France's new Premier, Pierre Mendes-France, formed his Cabinet today.

WHEN in the midst of strife and distress we read that Archeology had untombed a perfumed ship that was to take the soul of Cheops to Paradise, we couldn't help experiencing the most delicious and tranquil sensations.

OUR Pittsburgh listening post, puffed with pardonable local pride, reports that one of the Smoky City's favorite daughters, Gladys Schmitt, with the aid of her husband, Simon Goldfield, is busily engaged in preparing what may be Julie Harris' next play on Broadway.
SYRACUSE, June 19 -- Three years of the most glorious success in Naval Academy rowing history reached a triumphant climax today.

ST. LOUIS, June 19 -- Mal Whitfield of the Los Angeles A. C., the world's greatest half-miler, won his specialty in meet record time of 1:50.8 in the National Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships tonight.

STANLEY KRAMER was prepared to explain when he announced the other day that he would direct "Not As a Stranger" in addition to producing the best-seller novel by the late Morton Thompson. Yet, one could not help but feel in talking with the still boyish- looking producer that he was himself a little surprised that the question actually should be raised. This was indicated in his reply:
BALTIMORE, June 19 (AP) -- The National Editorial Association attacked Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield today for what it called "flagrant exercise of bureaucratic power."

RARELY before have we seen so many stories emphasizing the maturity and responsibility of our young people. Paradoxically, though, supporters of teen-age enfranchisement point with pride to the accomplishments of adolescents at the same time that specialists in other fields view with alarm the growing crime rates among the young.

Brown University will institute this fall an undergraduate curriculum leading to the Bachelor of Science degree in applied mathematics, it was announced last week. The program is designed to train students to translate scientific problems into mathematical form that can be handled by electronic computing devices.

TAX lawyer, tax writer, tax adviser to President Roosevelt and former Secretary Morgenthau, Randolph Paul has written a distinguished book on the history, the law and the economics of taxation. The author writes not only for lawyers but also for historians and economists, and in his thorough survey of more than 100 years of taxation his appeal is both to scholars and the lay public.

PARIS, June 19 -- The most urgent problem of the Eisenhower -Churchill talks is how to draw a line against further aggression in Asia. It is a question of how to draw a line, where to draw a line, and what type of aggression shall be prevented.

THE face of New York State has been -- and will be -- changed in many ways by the coming of the Thruway. But so far as is generally known Syracuse is the only place to which the superhighway has brought parks.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP) -- German state documents of the Hitler regime, published today, disclose that mutual distrust and self-seeking marked Nazi-Soviet relations almost from the moment the Soviet-German non-aggression pact was signed in August, 1939.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Whatever else may come out of the thirty-six days of hearings on the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, one inescapable conclusion is that the Wisconsin Senator has suffered a measurable dampening of his political voltage.

THE fifteen years from 1763 to 1778 possess some measure of unity from the standpoint of British-American relations. The period opened with an earnest, if not a wise, attempt by the British Government under the leadership of George Grenville, then First Minister of the Crown under George III, to reconstruct and reform the old British colonial system.

DESPITE the imminence of summer heat and the cares of family life, birds continue their symphony of song in woodlands, fields and gardens. An intriguing variety of calls, whistles, notes and songs still emanates from trees and shrubbery, and even the most conscientious gardener takes time out from mulching and spraying to listen and identify the voice.
ACCORDING to the present prospects, it appears likely that the New York Thruway will be financed at a bonded debt cost of around $1,650,000 a mile.
TOLEDO, June 19 (UP) -- Pat (Spunky) Lowry, 148, Toledo, outpointed Joe Miceli, 150, New York, tonight in a hard-fought ten-round nationally televised welterweight bout.

THE strangest and most interesting news in the art world last week was the announcement from Paris that the Russian Government had lent for exhibition thirty-seven of the pre-World War I paintings by Picasso which were part of the fabulous collection of the Museum of Modern Western Art in Moscow.

THERE have been LP disks about birds and locomotives, about the birth of a baby and how to mix a cocktail, about how to sleep and how to relieve your neuroses, about how to train your dog or how to teach a budgie to speak. Nearly everything, in short. But the American-Russian chess match, which opened last Wednesday at the Hotel Roosevelt, reminds us that as yet there is no LP disk devoted to chess.

THE over-all $962,000,000 cost of the 564 miles of Thruway network will include Federal grants of $58,000,000. Although the Federal highway law bars aid for toll roads, the Thruway Authority -- like other state toll road agencies -- has been able to obtain grants for sections that are to be toll-free.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 19 -- There are growing indications in Wisconsin that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy is losing some of his political popularity in his home state.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -Following is the text of a statement on Guatemala, issued today by the State Department:

WITH this eighth volume Lawrence Henry Gipson's history of the old British empire reaches its climax at the Peace of Paris in 1763. The climax of action, at least for American readers, had come in the previous volume, with the victory of Wolfe over Montcalm at Quebec in 1759.

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 20 -- The twenty-fourth annual report of the Bank for International Settlements, at Basle, is regarded here as by far the most authoritative compact diagnosis of economic and financial conditions and trends in Europe available to practical bankers and business men.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 20 -- A "war front" has shaped up across Guatemala from Puerto Barrios to the Salvadorean border, according to the Guatemalan rebels here today. But the war itself was vague.

Hope is the dominant note of the Christian religion, the Rev. Bjorn Johannson said yesterday at the Swedenborgian Church of the New Jerusalem, 112 East Thirty-fifth Street. The church is host to the 131st General Convention of the New Jerusalem.

PARIS, June 20 -- Maj. Gen. Marie-Antoine d'Hauteville, military commander of Marrakesh in French Morocco, was seriously wounded this morning by pistol fire. His assailant, presumed to be a Moroccan terrorist, escaped on a bicycle.

QUANTICO, Va., June 20 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, voiced the belief today that the United States still had an over-all lead of two to three years over the Soviet Union in weapons technology.

Walter S. Franklin, who retired last month as president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, has agreed to continue as president of the Long Island Rail Road Company when it becomes a railroad redevelopment corporation under a new state law, the Pennsylvania announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP) -- Herman Wehmeier, ex-Redleg, retired only one of his former team-mates today as Cincinnati tallied nine times in the first inning of the nightcap of a double-header to trample Philadelphia, 15 -- 6.
Thirty youths went on a destructive spree early last night in the last car of a Brooklyn subway train, and in twenty-one minutes they took this toll:
LONDON, June 20 -- The Duke of Kent, 18-year-old first cousin of Queen Elizabeth II, received a severe concussion and other head injuries and abrasions this morning while driving to London.

During the year that began last June with the crowning of Elizabeth II, Cleopatra and Lucrezia Borgia have each been in the news. A few weeks ago Dr. Lillian M. Gilbreth became the first woman ever to receive the Washington Award for leadership in engineering.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- President Eisenhower, surrounded by Indians (Menominee Tribe), members of Congress and Interior Department officials, signed a bill to give the Menominees control of their own assets in a few years.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 20 -- Negotiators for the Western oil consortium and their technical, legal and financial experts arrived in Teheran by air today. They were met by the United States and British Ambassadors, Herbert Hoover Jr., oil consultant for the United States State Department and Nury es Fandiari, senior member of the Iranian delegation.

PITTSBURGH, June 20 -- The steel market continues to improve slowly but steadily. How much of this improvement is influenced by wage contract bargaining is debatable. But there are few who doubt that real demand -- after all hedging has been discounted -- is stronger than it has been at any other time this year.

The Fire Department's current building inspection in the city's resort areas has uncovered 369 violations in 1,584 structures. The drive has centered on hotels and lodging and boarding houses, but it also has included schools and other public buildings.

Sir Adrian Boult, the very British conductor of the London Philharmonic and former head of the B. B. C. Symphony Orchestra, will raise his baton tonight over the Stadium Symphony in Lewisohn Stadium and thus begin the thirty-seventh season of concerts there.

LONDON, June 20 -- In the biggest grab bag in tennis, 128 players from all six continents and some of the islands in between open play here tomorrow for what are unofficially recognized as the world championships on the grass courts of the All-England Club.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, declared today that "statement or no statement," Governor Dewey remained his candidate in New York's Gubernatorial race this fall.
Increased relaxation of licensing controls over dollar imports is under consideration by the Italian Government, according to information reaching trade sources here.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- C. M. Stanley of Muscatine, Iowa, manufacturer and consulting engineer, was elected today president of the United World Federalists. Norman Cousins, editor of The Saturday Review, was elected honorary president.
This winning of ball games continues to be an elusive piece of business for Eddie Stanky.
FLORENCE, Italy, June 20 -- The third International Convention for Peace and Christian Civilization was opened tonight by Mayor Georgio La Pira in an atmosphere of religious fervor.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 20 -- Former President Truman underwent an emergency operation for removal of his gall bladder and appendix early today, and his physician said he was in "excellent condition." Six hours after the 70-year-old Mr. Truman came out of the anesthetic his nurses said he seemed to be his usual cheerful self.
ANKARA, Turkey, June 20 -- Turkey has told the United States, Britain and France that she wishes to be associated with any new pledge by the Western Big Three to oppose aggression in the Middle East.

Two questions have been brought up by the crisis in Guatemala. The first, which was put before the Security Council yesterday, was as to the nature of the present uprising and the responsibility therein of two designated Governments: Honduras and Nicaragua.
The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman said yesterday that the world was too high-powered for people to just live and learn. They must, therefore, learn and live, he added.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 20 -Universal - International has made a multiple picture agreement with Jane Wyman, who recently starred for the studio in its remake of "Magnificent Obsession.'' The arrangement calls for Miss Wyman to appear in a minimum of three pictures.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Ray H. Jenkins said tonight that if he ran for the Senate he believed he would accept the help of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

The National Book Committee, a citizens' group, has been formed to help keep books free and to encourage people to read them. Creation of the committee was announced yesterday by Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College and chairman of the organizing group. It includes publishers, lawyers, business men, educators and authors.
SANTIAGO, Chile, June 20 -- Chilean Leftists, with Communists in the front row, are allowing a popular movement of sympathy for Guatemala to take on the appearance of an attack on the United States.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 20 -- Col. Carlos Castillo Armas' program includes drastic revision of the Guatemalan agrarian reform law. The statute has been considered the heart of the program of President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman.

The announcement that the Japanese Diet will shortly be reconvened to complete its legislative work and, even more importantly, to entertain a broadly nonpartisan move to revise the election and Diet laws is good news. The Japanese political scene has been confused to the point of chaos for several weeks. It is now possible to find the way to clean up the disorder and to prevent its recurrence.
The election of James S. Nelson as president of the New York and New Jersey Dry Dock Association for the coming year was announced yesterday by Watters Donovan of New York, counsel to the group.

The National Broadcasting Company and the British Broadcasting Corporation announced yesterday an agreement for exchanging television news film and co-operating on coverage of stories in remote parts of the world where one or the other may have camera men.
Three major faith groups at Clark Air Force Base in the Philippines regularly schedule activities at the United Service Organizations' Center in near-by Angeles.

LONDON, June 20 -- Those who were scared by the break in the stock markets into hastily predicting that the bull market was ended and that a slump might not be far away have been proved wrong in no uncertain manner.
GUATEMALA, June 20 -- The United States asked permission today for Americans in Guatemala to leave the country overland, but the Government said it could not guarantee their safety.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The public kept a cautious hand on its purse in the first four months of this year. It cut its annual rate of purchases of goods by almost five and a quarter billion dollars, or 3 per cent, from the rate in the first half of 1953.
LANSING, Kan., June 20 (AP) -- Six long-term convicts, wielding three home-made pistols and several knives, killed a guard in an unsuccessful attempt to escape from the Kansas State Prison today.

Holy Communion, the sacrament of the Lord's Supper, is "the most powerful weapon in the arsenal of heaven, given to man to aid him in working out his eternal salvation," the Rev. John M. Crotty declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Following are the votes of the legislators from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the period June 12 through June 18:

In the Nineteen Thirties some of our highest Army and Navy officials fought Col. William Mitchel's attempt to increase and modernize our air power, and they court-martialed and punished him for his efforts. Gen. Douglas MacArthur was one of his judges. The attitude of our top-ranking officials seriously delayed the development of our air power.

Ten days ago the House Committee on Agriculture, headed by Clifford R. Hope, voted in favor of extending for still another year the effective date for the introduction of flexible price supports for the six basic farm commodities -- wheat, cotton, corn, tobacco, rice and peanuts.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Aside from adding to the already growing suspicion that the Cleveland Indians are the team to beat, the Yankees and the Chicago White Sox proved nothing after six hours sixteen minutes of diamond warfare at Comiskey Park today.

ATLANTA, June 20 (AP) -- Tom Brown, San Francisco lawyer and former Davis Cup player, defeated Eddie Moylan of Trenton, N. J., 2 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 1, today in the men's singles final of the Southern tennis tournament.
The Museum of Modern Art, now 25 years old, will begin official observance of its birthday in the early fall.
Roy M. Cohn, chief counsel for the Subcommittee on Investigations, said last night that he ex pected some members of the subcommittee staff to resign.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- The mid-June crop outlook is extremely promising, and thus there has been plenty of selling this past week, especially in wheat. However, bearish sentiment seems to have been a little too unanimous and the market gets oversold rather easily, which would indicate that prices appeal to investors in a moderate way at least.

Prices of the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange last week were under pressure because of the uncertainty of the Federal Government's price support program with respect to the staple. Final quotations on the Exchange ranged from $1.45 a bale lower for the distant October delivery to 10 cents a bale higher for the near-by July delivery.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 20 -- Latin America's fast-growing markets are the object of covetous attention from all parts of the world. Even Iron Curtain countries have been cutting in recently.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20 -- Waldemar Kaempffert, science editor of The New York Times since 1927, has been chosen to receive the 1954 Kalinga Prize, awarded annually by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. Previous winners were Prof. Louis de Broglie of Paris and Dr. Julian Huxley of London, who was first director general of UNESCO.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $75,543,227,011. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
A report from the U. S. S. Harveson, the Navy escort vessel placed Bolera 240 miles southsoutheast of Brenton Reef Lightship, the starting point, at 7:40 P. M.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 11 -- When the sea is all around you, but you can't see a bit of it because you're shut up snugly in a submarine, little things mean a lot.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Continued improvement of the national economy, at least to the end of the year, was forecast this week by a group of economists for the nation's largest corporations.
A record school building and modernization program, involving an outlay of $108,425,000, has been recommended for 1955 by the Board of Education's committee on buildings and sites.

BIROBIDZHAN, U. S. S. R., June 11 -- Headlines about Birobidzhan have been rare indeed in recent years, but not quite so rare as foreign visitors to this area, which is officially designated as the Jewish Autonomous Oblast (Province).

Assistant Secretary of Defense Donald A. Quarles gave this nation a major warning Saturday when he said, "We must conclude that on balance our technical position vis-a-vis the Soviets is less favorable than it was a year ago. Our margin of advantage has been narrowed, and we must face the sober inferences to be drawn from these facts."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20 -- Four times during the emergency meeting of the Security Council this afternoon, minor demonstrations broke out among the spectators, three of them on behalf of Guatemala. Each was dealt with summarily and lasted but a few moments.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- A survey of the effect of six months of operation of the President's order on security of information indicates an increasing use of the label "for official use only."

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Following is the text of a letter, made public today at Quantico, Va., by Assistant Secretary of Defense H. Struve Hensel, to Senator Karl E. Mundt enclosing an affidavit in connection with the Army-McCarthy hearings:
MONTREAL, June 20 -- Canada is seeking anxiously to dispose of the biggest wheat surplus in its history in an effort to stave off what may be an economic crisis.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (UP) -- Retail sales in April and May after seasonal adjustments were "slightly higher" than in the first quarter of the year and only 1 per cent below those of last year, the Commerce Department said.
Insurance rates for collision and other physical damage to automobiles will drop substantially today.

As an alumnus of Marquette University I was both shocked and disgusted to read the recent letter to The Times on behalf of Senator Joseph McCarthy written by the new chairman of the Political Science Department at that great university.

ROBERT E. LEE, the newest member of the Federal Communications Commission, touched off over the week-end a new controversy on educational television and, more particularly, its disappointing progress.

House painting is usually reserved for the summer months when home owners have more leisure and daylight. Weather can play an important role in a satisfactory paint job, advises Douglas C. Arnold, president of the Keystone Paint and Varnish Corporation.

LANGHORNE, Pa., June 20 (AP) -- Jimmy Bryan, who finished second in the 500-mile Indianapolis race, won the 100-mile American Automobile Association national championship race today in a record time of 61 minutes 30.6 seconds.
Memo to bargain hunters generally and to residents of the Bronx, White Plains, Stamford and Connecticut communities to the northeast:

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- A Senate floor fight appeared almost certain today as the Republican leadership prepared to press a bill on Tuesday for a year's extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20 -- The United Nations Security Council unanimously called today for an immediate end of the bloodshed in Guatemala.

SAN JUAN, P. R., June 20 -- Mayor Wagner found Puerto Rico openly hot in temperature and a bit warm under the collar for the sake of its peaceful name when he led a party of thirty-seven persons here today.

The six-story apartment building housing forty families and occupying a plot 100 by 155 feet at 145 Franklin Avenue, New Rochelle, in Westchester County, has been resold by Phillip P. Zipes, New York operator, to an investing client of Nathan Rosenberg, attorney.

The statue of the Rev. Francis P. Duffy, Chaplain of the old Fighting Sixty-ninth Regiment in the First World War, now looks upon a flaghole dedicated yesterday on Duffy Square to the memory of soldiers who served in World War II and the Koeran conflict.

It was a quiet and uneventful week in the foreign exchanges. Business was light, bringing minor price changes. British sterling remained firm around its upper levels on a normal supply and demand and no official intervention.

GENEVA, June 20 -- The efforts here to establish the basis for a cessation of hostilities in Indochina appeared today to face an indefinite period of discussion at a secondary official level. Since major decisions seemed unlikely at this level, the Far Eastern conference had an uncertain future.

Philippine President Magsaysay has just signed a bill that proposes to restrict retail trade in the archipelago to Philippine citizens. Americans will be exempt, for the time being, under the "parity" provisions of the Trade Act that is now under review. This exemption does not justify the harm that this measure can do in international relations.
The chairman of a motion picture company that beat competition from black and white television is not afraid of color video.

LONDON, June 20 -- Aneurin Bevan, Left-Wing contender for leadership of the British Labor party, said today that the United States "sulks" instead of seeking to relieve the current tension with Communist China.
Christ never intended that religion should become "an insurance policy with premiums of spurious piety," the Rev. Dr. Leslie D. Weatherhead declared yesterday morning at Riverside Church.

PARIS, June 20 -- It was said on high authority tonight that the new French Premier, Pierre Mendes-France, would not go to Geneva this week to negotiate on Indochina, as had been expected. It was said he would go only if the principal foreign ministers, who have just left there, returned to the conference on Far Eastern affairs.
MOSCOW, June 20 -- The Soviet Air Force put on today one of the most stunning exhibitions of close-order jet flying that foreign military attaches have yet seen in the Soviet Union.

The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, one of the nation's largest distributors of natural gas from the fields in Texas, Oklahoma and Kansas, has requested the Federal Power Commission for permission to proceed with a $66,750,000 expansion program in order to supply additional quantities of the fuel to users in Michigan.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20 -- Hybrid corn from the United States and Canada, grown experimentally in twenty-four European and Mediterranean countries, contributed to the 1953 crop nearly 500,000 extra tons of grain, valued at $40,000,000.

The Charter of the United Nations opens with the words, "We the peoples of the United Nations." For most New Yorkers "the peoples of the United Nations" become manifest through United Nations representatives and personnel working and living here.

Japanese shipyards have been successful in obtaining contracts to build four big tankers aggregating more than 130,000 deadweight tons. But this was at the sacrifice of bargain prices, installment buying and what amounts almost to barter, it was learned yesterday.

I have read with great interest your editorial on teachers' salaries. You are undoubtedly aware of the low morale that now exists among teachers in our high schools. Improvement in this area of education, it seems to me, should be the first and the supreme concern of our present Board of Education.

Back from a triumphal journey to London, where he duplicated his staging of "The Teahouse of the August Moon," Robert Lewis was wondering yesterday which of three entertainments will be ready for him to direct.
Baby pythons peeping through their shells and considering whether to hatch exerted the legendary serpent's fascination on visitors to the Bronx Zoo yesterday.
CARLSTADT, N. J., June 20 -- New Jersey's Hackensack River, off the Majestic Boat Club, has for years been the "proving ground" of racing outboard hydroplanes.
SOMETIMES the dice come up seven. Destiny's darling throughout the United States open golf championship at Baltusrol last week-end was Ed Furgol, the winner with 284.

QUANTICO, Va., June 20 -- H. Struve Hensel, Assistant Secretary of Defense, asserted today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had offered to withdraw charges against Mr. Hensel if he could do so without appearing to be a "damn fool."
A 6-year-old boy playing with matches set a $100,000 fire yesterday afternoon in a West Side lumberyard.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Guatemala is by no means the only Latin-American country in which communism is a cause for concern to the United States, State Department officials said today.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (UP) -- A Defense Department official has declared that $2,000,000,000 in "fat" was left in the Army budget to allay public fears that the ground forces were being cut too hard.
Russia's chess team led the American players last night by a score of 10 1/2 to 4 1/2 and was within six points of victory in the international tournament being played at the Roosevelt Hotel.

CLEVELAND, June 20 (UP) -- Bob Feller and Art Houtteman, who seem to be making a specialty of Sunday pitching this season, hurled the Cleveland Indians to a double-header sweep over the Boston Red Sox today, 3 -- 1 and 9 -- 2, before a crowd of 36,751.
BALTIMORE, June 20 (AP) -- The Washington Senators, taking advantage of Baltimore's poor pitching and fielding, swept a double-header today, 7 -- 1 and 7 -- 2, before 17,149 fans.

Henry Seidel Canby, the Book-of-the-Month Club has announced, will retire as member and chairman of its editorial board on July 1. Mr. Canby, who has occupied that post since the club was formed in 1926, will be succeeded by Gilbert Highet, Anthon Professor of the Latin Language and Literature at Columbia University, author of "The Classical Tradition" and other works, book critic of Harper's Magazine and weekly book commentator on the WQXR radio network.
New Yorkers took advantage of a sunny Father's Day yesterday to get a one-day jump on summer and filled some of the city's beaches and parks with the largest crowds of the season.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 20 (AP) -- Five United States airmen who were captured by the Communist-led Vietminh rebels six days ago near Tourane are on a Vietminh ship heading southward, authorized French military sources said tonight.
BERN, Switzerland, June 20 (AP) -- Hungary, the favorite, swept into the quarter-finals of the world soccer championship today with an 8-3 victory over West Germany.
CALCUTTA, India, June 20 (AP) -- Two French planes left for Indochina today after a check-up by Indian officials to make sure no military personnel were aboard.

The Rot-Weiss soccer team of Essen, Germany, won from Olaria of Rio de Janeiro by 1 -- 0 at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday. August Gottschaulk, center forward, booted the goal in the thirty-seventh minute of the first half before 2,344 fans.

Suppose that an investor, at the average price of the week of Sept. 6, 1929 -- and wasn't he the lucky one to buy at that time? -- bought $1,000 each of the ten most active New York Stock Exchange stocks.

A new and financially powerful group has entered the rapidly growing trade and business publishing field. It comprises the principal owners of Telenews Productions, Inc., which has acquired the Industrial Publishing Company of Cleveland with eight trade publications.

The union welfare fund plundered by Thomas E. Lewis, slain labor boss of the Yonkers Raceway, has been restored to financial health by the trustees who took over after Lewis' murder less than ten months ago.
TOKYO, Monday, June 21 (AP) -- Communist China is further centralizing her government "to suit the country's planned economic construction," the Peiping radio reported today.
PHENIX CITY, Ala., June 20 (UP) -- Three persons have been arrested and questioned in connection with the slaying of the Democratic, candidate for State Attorney General.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 20 -- The Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta attracted 123 craft, the season's record, at the Port Washington Yacht Club today. The previous record was established at Larchmont yesterday, when 107 yachts competed.
MOSCOW, June 20 (UP) -- The Moscow radio described the appearance of the glider as follows:

OCEAN GROVE, N. J., June 20 (AP) -- A mission organizer for the Church of the Brethren said tonight that man must pay the price of his freedom in order to learn whether communism can fulfill its promises.

Harry S. Truman has seemed to have a good time being an ex-President. He has worked on his memoirs, traveled about the country, made a speech now and then, eaten quite a number of dinners in public and, when urged, has played the piano. He has been political when he felt like it, but he has not felt like it all the time.

TRENTON, June 20 -- Federal and state auditors continued over the week-end their examination of the records of the South Amboy Trust Company and the Trenton Trust Company in connection with the transfer of $3,427,000 in unemployment insurance funds to noninterest-bearing accounts in these banks.

The outpouring of emotions against the Iraqi Army by General Yadin, former Israeli Chief of Staff, which appeared in your issue of June 15, should be considered a compliment to Iraq and its army, considering from what prejudiced source it has come. An Israeli official engaged in a propaganda tour to persuade Americans to give more money to Israel is not a good judge in such a matter.
Five new films, including importations from England and Italy, are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

I WASHINGTON, June 20---In [twenty-one years on the Washington staff of The Times, Mr. Michael gained a wide reputation as an aggressive but fair-minded reporter on politics and politicians. He was feared by the few, but respected by all who practiced the big business of politics, of which his knowledge was intimate and complete.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 20 - Richard David Mann, who weighed one pound when a doctor whacked him gently and popped him into an incubator at New Rochelle Hospital almost eight years ago, re-entered that hospital briefly today to have his forehead stitched.

PITTSBURGH, June 20 (UP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates swept, a double-header with the Milwaukee Braves today, scoring all their runs in the seventh inning for a 5-3 second game victory after taking the opener by 2 -- 1 in ten innings.

PROBABLY the best free show in the city today will be the efforts of crews of workmen trying to put an entire aluminum front on the new twenty-two-story office building at the northwest corner of Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street.

BOSTON, June 20 -- The title of "Advertising Woman of the Year" was conferred today upon Mrs. Charlotte Montgomery of Westfield, N. J., as some 1,000 delegates gathered for the fiftieth annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America.

The congregation of the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Virgin Mary, Help of Christians, at Seventieth Street and Forty-seventh Avenue, Winfield, Queens, celebrated its 100th anniversary yesterday morning.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., June 20 -- Alumnae gifts amounting to $475,321 for 1953-54 were reported today at the annual Vassar College alumnae meeting.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 20 -- The study of atomic energy will become more and more a part of engineering education, the International Congress of Nuclear Engineering was told here today.

PORTLAND, Me., June 20 (AP) -- On the eve of Maine's primary, Senator Margaret Chase Smith said that her opponent in her campaign for the Republican re-nomination appeared to have been planted in the race by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
PARIS, June 20 -- France will turn over $70,000,000 to the United States at the end of the month as its regular semi-annual reimbursement for loans contracted from the United States in 1945 and 1950.
The vacation months have arrived, and clothes for the young now call for coolness in the summer heat as well as freedom for activity.
JERUSALEM, June 20 -- The United States and Britain proposed for Israel's consideration today a series of procedural measures designed to check violence along the border with Jordan.
Not too impressively, but still emphatically, the Dodgers yesterday beat the Cubs, 6 -- 4 and 16 -- 3, at Ebbets Field to move within half a game of the league-leading Giants.

This is the first day of summer and the opening day of New York Summer Festival 1954 which, with many and varied attractions lasting through Labor Day, hopes to bring to New York more seasonal visitors than have come here in any year since the World's Fair.
The ship charter market was at "stand-by" last week. Volume showed little change from that of the week before, and rates showed signs of weariness in the fight to keep at earlier high levels.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., June 20 -- Forty top golf professionals, many of whom declined to take a day's rest following the United States open championship, took part in the $7,500 tourney at the Briar Hall Country Club today.

TEGUCIGALPA, June 20 (AP) -- The anti-Communist invaders trying to topple President Arbenz' regime said today their invading forces were well into Guatemala and striking toward the Pan American Highway near the Salvadorean border.
Supermarkets have successfully overcome the competition of discount houses, drug stores and department and appliance stores, according to a survey by the Standard Factors Corporation.
GRANVILLE, Ohio, June 20 -- Leading Protestant educators heard here today that irresponsible learning was producing disastrous results to Western culture.

Food fadists and quacks, successors to old-time medicine men who peddled spurious elixirs, today influence, it is reported, some 10,000,000 Americans, endangering the health of a significant proportion of this group.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 20 -- No matter how the Guatemalan uprising ends, the United States is bound to be blamed by elements throughout Latin America, diplomatic observers agree.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 20 -- Shareholders of Royal Dutch Petroleum adopted here last week the changes in the articles of association required for listing on the New York Stock Exchange.

Plans for altering the six-story dwelling on lot 36.8 by 102.2 feet at 120-22 East Eightieth Street into apartments have been announced in connection with the sale of the property by George Whitney, of J. P. Morgan Co., to a client of Harry Berger, attorney. Douglas L. Elliman Co. were the brokers in the sale of the realty, which is assessed at $190,000. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

SINCE that epochal day lost forever in the dark mists of prehistory when man ceased to be a promising primate and became an intelligent hunter and food gatherer there have been only three major developments in his history. This truly basic outline of history is the idea of William Howells and it may be found in his able and informative book, "Back of His tory: The Story of Our Own Origins."

HARTSDALE, N. Y., June 20 -A Westchester Academy of Medicine will be established in a forty-room mansion here at an estimated cost of $500,000, if a campaign by the Medical Society of Westchester succeeds.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- A growing need exists in the United States for women trained in chemistry, mathematics and physics, a committee representing industry and education reported at Bryn Mawr College yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20 -- Following are the texts of the French resolution adopted by the Security Council today and the Brazilian-Colombian-French resolution vetoed by the Soviet delegation:

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., June 20 -- A nine-room "House of Ideas" sponsored by House and Garden magazine opened here for public inspection yesterday. The house is built on three levels and is completely air conditioned.

Alfredo Salmaggi opened his seventh post-war season of opera at the Triborough Stadium on Saturday night. The opera was "Carmen," and all seats were $1, which is the lowest top the impresario has yet set for his outdoor summer performances.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20 -- Guatemala told the United Nations today that two United States airmen had crash-landed in Mexico after having bombed a Guatemalan town.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- Counsel for customers of Northern Natural Gas Company argued in a Federal Power Commission hearing today over whether Northern should have a uniform or zone system of rates. Northern now has uniform rates for its whole system, which delivers gas to companies serving more than 200 cities in Kansas, Nebraska, Oowa, South Dakota and Minnesota.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, June 21 (UP) -- The Royal Air Force prepared today to parachute two cats to a mouse-plagued British fort in the Malayan jungle.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 21 -- This country is confronted by increasing competition between the aged population and children for public funds, John W. Tramburg, United States Commissioner of Social Security, said here today.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (UP) -- Thomas Marino, described as a Brooklyn racketeer and onetime associate of Charles (Lucky) Luciano, has been ordered deported to Italy, the Justice Department said today.
CATSKILL, N. Y., June 21 (AP) More than 350 employes of two North American Cement Corporation plants voted today to accept a pay increase of 5 cents an hour and to end their month-old strike.
QUEBEC, June 21 -- The largest ocean-going dry-cargo ship ever built in Canada was launched here this morning.

The almost opera-bouffe quality of the Guatemalan "war" -- a war that so far is primarily without battles but is punctuated by pronouncements and rumors -- should not conceal the global importance of the struggle.

IF the British foot-racing authorities had not sprinted with the zealous burst of a 4-minute miler to get Roger Bannister's historic 3:59.4 accepted as a world record for the mile, the first penetration of the 4-minute barrier never would have made the formal list. That would have been the supreme irony -- "the most unkindest cut of all," to quote another English-man.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 21 -- This nation's self-interest demands that every source of knowledge within it be strengthened and every means of communicating the truth about it be explored, President Eisenhower declared today.

In a sworn statement Assistant Secretary of Defense Hensel has again characterized the charges recently made against him by Senator McCarthy as "untrue and false." He had previously described them as "barefaced lies." In any case, there is no doubt what he thinks about them.
A medal for heroism in the capture of a criminal was presented yesterday to Boot, a mixed bull terrier-Labrador retriever, which served with the Marines in the Pacific in World War II.
PORTLAND, Me., June 21 -The Republican voters of Maine gave Senator Margaret Chase Smith a ringing vote of confidence today by nominating her for a second term by an overwhelming margin.
Russia's chess team last night was within 3 1/2 points of winning its matches against the American team. The score was Russia 13, the United States 6.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Government of Nationalist China obtained a judgment for $6,368,503 in Federal Court today against Lieut. Gen. P. T. Mow, former head of the Chinese Air Force office in the United States.

City water reserves in the Catskill and Croton watersheds totaled 225,590,000,000 gallons, or 89.1 per cent of capacity, at 8 A. M. yesterday. The figures represented a loss of 780,000,000 gallons from the preceding day. A year ago the reservoirs held 238,364,000,000 gallons, or 94.2 per cent.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On May 30 The Times carried an article headed "White Girl to Get Degree from Fisk." That article stated: "It is also believed that she is the first white person to win an earned degree from a Southern Negro college in fifty years or more."
A uniformed fireman has been suspended in connection with department refrigeration inspections, Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. announced last night.
PORTLAND, Ore., June 21 (AP) -- Members of two big lumber unions went on strike in much of Oregon, Washington and California today.
Eddie Stanky was still doing some furious masterminding at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but to no avail. Leo Durocher again held most of the trumps.
Summer arrived in New York yesterday on the longest, and so far the hottest, day of the year.

New York and the sun beamed at each other yesterday as the city gave a tuneful and colorful welcome to the first day of summer. Times Square was the scene of the event, which opened the New York Summer Festival.

GRANVILLE, Ohio, June 21 -- Educators from more than 450 of the nation's church-related colleges and universities were warned here today that "it is a mistake to think of a college made up entirely of Christians."

TRENTON, June 21 -- A handwriting expert has characterized as forgeries the signatures on five documents that had been filed with the State Treasurer from 1949 to 1953 by the South Amboy Trust Company to certify that state money had been deposited with the bank.

Mrs. Margaret S. Lewisohn, who was killed in an upstate automobile accident on June 14 shortly after giving a lift to Adlai E. Stevenson, left various, works of art to institutions. Most of her estate will be held in trust for her four daughters.
Agreements have been concluded under which New Jersey Zinc Company may take over majority control of four dormat Canadian companies with uranium claims in the Blind River district.
PITTSBURGH, June 21 -- Negotiations for a new steel wage agreement broke down here tonight.

An investment syndicate represented by Jerome Dansker, president of the Investors Funding Corporation of New York, has purchased the two four-story buildings containing thirty-nine apartments at 29 and 35 East Seventh Street in Brooklyn from the Caton Realty, Inc. Title was insured by the Security Title and Guaranty Company.
James S. Campbell, in 120 E. 87th St; Mrs. H. Banks, James G. Bright Jr, in 135 E 54th St; Leonard Formosa, in 455 E 51st St; Edward G. Burke, in 655 Park Ave -- Douglas L. Elliman Co. brokers.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

New issues of public utility securities totaling $54,000,000 will be placed on the market today by investment bankers. The money raised will be used mostly to finance new construction and pay off bank loans. Some of it will go to retire higher-cost debt.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short term borrowing costs had taken a slight rise for the second consecutive week.
GUATEMALA, June 21 (AP) -- The text of today's communique:
Commodity prices moved irregularly lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was very light with most items registering fewer sales than in Friday's inactive market.

The formation of an inter-industry committee for the coordination of style and color trends in the clothing, shirt and neckwear industries was suggested yesterday by a panel discussion sponsored by the National Association of Shirt, Pajama and Sportswear Manufacturers at the Astor Hotel.
The Transit Authority had a change of heart yesterday and agreed to a union representation election on Friday among its 37,000 hourly rated employes.

MELBOURNE, June 21 -- The aggregate amount received for Australian wool in the year ending on June 30 is expected to be 400,000,000 Australian pounds ($900,000,000), or nearly half Australia's income from exports. Growers will get an average return of nearly 4,000 Australian pounds ($9,000) each.

MOUNTAINHOME, Pa., June 21 (AP) -- Margaret Truman made her dramatic debut in the Pocono Playhouse tonight playing the role of a young American school teacher who finds love briefly and unhappily on a European vacation.

Father's Day business this year fell short of expectations, according to New York City retailers. While slightly ahead of last year, generally, sales were disappointing in the light of the growing custom of giving a gift to father each year.

Although trading was sluggish and almost as many stocks fell as rose, enough leaders performed well in yesterday's stock market to send The New York Times combined average to its best levels since June 11, 1930.
Frankie Ryff, unbeaten Bronx lightweight, gained a unanimous ten-round decision over Brian Kelly of Niagara Falls, Ont., at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.
The ocean race to Bermuda, which had been a light air test from the start at Newport last Saturday, became an almost windless drift for the seventy-seven cruising yachts in it yesterday.
ANKARA, Turkey, June 21 -- Premier Mustafa Halls of Libya arrived here today, on an official visit designed to strengthen his country's ties with Turkey and perhaps even more with the United States.
Customs inspectors will be out in force today to cope with the heaviest influx of arriving ship travelers to date this year.
Beginning next month, hundreds of theatre patrons face the prospect of being stopped at playhouse portals and being required to pay an additional 5 per cent on their ticket costs before entering.
KLAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 21 -- Because of the limited capacity of our medical schools, the United States faces a shortage of 30,000 doctors, Dr. Abraham White said today.
An idea of the competition in the cosmetics industry and the need for extensive advertising was supplied yesterday by Hazel Bishop, Inc., maker of lipstick, rouge and nail polish.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 21 -Five hundred Vietminh war prisoners escaped early Saturday when several companies of insurgent regional troops attacked the camp where they were held. The camp is on the outskirts of Mytho, thirty miles southwest of Saigon.

DETROIT, June 21 -- It never has been a sound practice to write off the Yankees at this stage of a pennant race. At least, not during the reign of Casey Stengel, a pilot who has captured five straight flags and as many world series.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Eisenhower Administration set up the most rigorous farm controls in the history of Federal price supports today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 -- Cigarette smokers from 50 to 70 years of age have a death rate, from all diseases, as much as 75 per cent higher than that of nonsmokers, the American Cancer Society reported today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were more active yesterday than for many weeks. Prices eased 2 to 16 points.
The temperature on the streets was in the high 80's and their asphalt surfacing was soft. But in the New Yorker Hotel yesterday there was a white Christmas.

Immersed in Hollywood work for a good many years, Allan Scott, remembered on Broadway chiefly as co-author of "Goodbye Again," has written a new play, "The Second Monkey." Robert Bassler and Myron McCormick have scheduled it for presentation here in December.
BANGKOK, Thailand, June 21 -- Thailand would welcome free world troops if they were needed to fight Communist aggression here, Premier Pibul Songgram said today.

Members of the former N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra at a meeting yesterday afternoon at Local 802 of the musicians union, 261 West Fifty-second Street, extended a formal invitation to Arturo Toscanini to return to this country next season as conductor of the orchestra.
LONDON, June 21 (UP) -- The International Wheat Council warned tonight that the present surplus wheat supply must be adjusted to world demand.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 21 -- England's famous music hall, the Palladium, will be the subject of a motion picture to be produced by Henry Ginsberg in association with the Moss Theatre Enterprises, operators of the showhouse, and Val Parnell, its managing director.

Operations of the steel industry for this week are estimated at 72.6 per cent of rated capacity, the American Iron Steel Institute reported yesterday. Production is scheduled at 1,731,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings.

LONDON, June 21 (Reuters) -- While Russian and Communist papers screamed "Yankee Imperialism," the non-Communist press of Europe appealed to the United States today to avoid giving the Communists propaganda material concerning Guatemala.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The fact published in The Times of June 10 that an associate research director of a Congressional investigating committee said that certain quotations, which he afterward found were from papal encyclicals, "paralleled very closely communistic ideals," points up an error often made by some of those whose justified indignation against communism at times overrides their common sense.
UNDETERRED by the official opening of summer, local galleries continue to function with an occasional group exhibition or one-man show.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 21 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of the Cherry Valley Club shot 36, 38 -- 74, three strokes over par, to win the medal during the qualifying round of the twenty-fifth Women's Long Island Golf Association match-play championship at the Meadow Brook Club today.

A 55-year-old house painter was killed yesterday morning and his 26-year-old co-worker miraculously escaped death when the scaffolding on which they were working collapsed six stories aloft. The victim was Ted Shapiro of 88 West 169th Street, the Bronx.

The prediction last week that coffee prices at retail would decline because of the larger-than-anticipated carryover in Brazil is premature, Horacio Cintra Leite, United States representative of the Brazilian Coffee Institute said yesterday.
About 1,500 persons got their first close-up view yesterday of one of the giant oil carriers that shuttle a continuous stream of petroleum from the Persian Gulf to the industries of the nation.

GENEVA, June 21 -- United States delegation circles conceded tonight that their strong efforts to persuade the International Labor Organization session to refuse to seat Soviet worker and employer delegates had failed.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 21 (AP) -- Former President Truman was in "very satisfactory" condition tonight following emergency removal of his appendix and gall bladder, but his physician said he still "is not out of danger."
The State Civil Defense Commission said yesterday it would continue its policy of restricting the use of highways to essential and military vehicles in time of atomic or hydrogen bomb attack.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 21 -- A millinery salesman from Johannesburg, a virtual unknown who was not even ranked among South Africa's first ten tennis stars a year ago, had the vaunted Ken Rosewall, No. 3 seeded players hanging on the ropes before the Springbok's fine game disintegrated under lobbing pressure as the All-England lawn tennis championships began today. Rosewall won by 7 -- 5, 4 -- 6, 8 -- 6, 8 -- 6.
LONDON, June 21 (AP) -- Roger Bannister heard tonight that John Landy had shattered his "miracle mile" record and immediately sent congratulations to the Australian.

GENEVA, June 21 -- Chou En-lai, Chinese Communist Premier and Foreign Minister, took his overtures to Cambodia and Laos a stage further here tonight by having the chief Geneva representatives of the two countries as dinner guests with Pham Van Dong, head of the Vietminh delegation.
The nation's educators were taken to task yesterday for generally failing to recognize the dangers of communism.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Senator Jackson on June 11 in his discussion of the Schine "plan" to combat communism raised an interesting point which merits further consideration. He asked Senator McCarthy if there was an Elks Lodge in Pakistan, for instance, or in Africa through which communism could be fought.

RYE, N. Y., June 21 -- Johnny Palmer of Charlotte, N. C., the recent winner of the Colonial invitational, teamed with Sammy Kaye to take the first pro-amateur golf tournament at the Apawamis Club today.

A special, hour-long film compilation of footage from various forthcoming Twentieth Century-Fox features designed to illustrate advances in the company's CinemaScope and stereophonic photographic and sound systems, will be shown to an invited audience this morning at the Roxy Theatre.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., June 21 (UP) -- Joseph B. Rendon, unsuccessful candidate for the Republican nomination for Representative last month, has joined the anti-Communist rebel forces in Guatemala.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The tenure of Ray H. Jenkins as special counsel to the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations in the Army-McCarthy row was threatened seriously today by Democratic members.

The appointment of Dr. Lyle C. Fitch as management consultant in the city Division of Administration was announced yesterday by Dr. Luther H. Gulick, City Administrator. Dr. Fitch, who will be paid at the rate of $13,000 a year, will direct major economic and fiscal studies.

THE car-top boat may have a rather low safety factor for some salt water situations, but it provided all the comfort and safety of a forty-foot cruiser on Peconic Bay yesterday. There the weakfish were hungry and responsive.
GENEVA, June 21 -- Peiping's representatives handed over details today on the fate of a number of Americans in Communist China.
The Appellate Division directed the Fire Department yesterday to discontinue the practice of assigning captains as battalion chiefs without giving them the title or the higher salary.

CAIRO, June 21 -- The name of a hitherto unknown Pharaoh in the dimly known Egyptian succession forty-six centuries ago may be revealed in a royal cartouche found in the solar ship's chamber beside the Great Pyramid of Cheops at Giza.

WOODS HOLE, Mass., June 21 -- Man's unending battle against the sea took on a new recruit today with the dedication of a laboratory for the study of the ocean's secrets as they relate to war and national defense.

Plans are being made at frequent tea meetings in private homes for the annual fashion show and card party for the benefit of St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases. The forthcoming event will be held on Sept. 28 at the Pierre under the auspices of the beneficiary's Women's Auxiliary Board and Hospital Unit Associates with the assistance of Philip Hulitar.

THE Stadium Concerts opened their thirty-seventh season last night in the Lewisohn Stadium. Sir Adrian Boult conducted there for the first time in a Beethoven program, with Rudolf Firkusny as soloist in the C minor piano concerto.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Federal Reserve Board ordered a gradual lowering of reserve requirements of member banks today to meet expected heavy demands for credit later this year. The reduction becomes effective over the next six weeks.

More Eyes on News of Finance The recent activity in the coffee market has had one interesting side effect: more housewives have begun to read the financial pages of newspapers to keep up with the fluctuations in the price of the bean. For this, it may be assumed, the corner grocer is duly grateful.
A prediction was made yesterday that the value of national production by 1977 would approximate three-quarters of a trillion dollars. This would be more than twice the current gross national product.

CINCINNATI, June 21, (AP) -- Foreign delegates to the thirty-second convention of Zonta International expressed themselves today as being impressed by the United States' "fantastically practical kitchens" and "inspiring church attendance."
Want to be an angel? On Broadway an "angel" is the financial backer of a show. You can invest in the greatest theatrical enterprise in this coun try -- U. S. O.-Camp Shows.
WASHINGTON June 21 -- The operators of thirty-eight major airports in the United States told Congress today that they would prefer Federal to local regulation of air navigation.

" CURIOUSER and curiouser!" cried Alice. She was exclaiming at the marvels of Wonderland. Nevertheless, her comments could well be inspired by the literary career of Shirley Jackson. Miss Jackson is gifted, original and unpredictable. Her "The Lottery" is one of the most celebrated of modern short stories, an enigmatic and shocking parable that can still start an argument in any literary group.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 (AP) -- Here are some of the main statistics presented in the Cancer Society report:

In a city as rich with history as New York street names should not be changed without overwhelmingly good reason, long consideration and ample public debate. Such changes are confusing to the public, they make maps obsolete, they break the traditions of the past.
PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- Under a star-studded sky, Robin Hood Dell opened its twenty-fifth season and its second year of free concerts tonight in its natural amphitheatre in Fairmount Park.

GUATEMALA, June 21 -- The Guatemalan Army announced today that its first contact with rebel forces took place last night at Gualan, in Zacapa Department. Gualan is about sixteen miles from the Honduran border and about seventeen miles from the garrison town of Zacapa, apparently the first major objective of the invading force.
SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., June 21 -- The medical profession was urged today to set up average fee schedules on an area basis instead of charging for services on such bases as a patient's income.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Appliance manufacturers can cover the field with a lot fewer models than in their present lines, Judson S. Sayre, president of Norge division of Borg-Warner Corporation, said today.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Furniture design is in for a rosy future, judging from wholesale offerings at the Summer Home Furnishings Market, which opened here today. Carpets, linoleum, sofas, daybeds, table tops, bedroom chests, dinette sets, lamps and lamp shades all appear in varying shades of pastel pink.
PORTLAND, Ore., June 21 (AP) -- Montgomery Ward Co., which sued for $2,900,000 twelve years ago charging damage from a picket line, won a $153,050 verdict today.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 21 -- A glimpse into the future when atomic power is harnessed for peaceful use is afforded here in a display for the first International Congress of Nuclear Engineering.
Italo Scortichini of Italy won a ten-round split decision from Pedro Gonzales of Rankin, Pa., last night at the St. Nicholas Arena. Scortichini weighed 154 pounds to Gonzales' 158 1/4.

" To me, fashion is za complete woman," Lilly Dache said in an interview yesterday. Mme. Dache, who was recently named president of the General Beauty Corporation (a combination of Marie Earle products and Lucien Lelong perfumes) feels that she is rounding out a lifetime devoted to beautifying women.
BUENOS AIRES, June 21 -Attracted by the terms of an investment law passed almost a year ago, foreign capital is once again trickling into Argentina.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20 -- The oil-rich countries in the Middle East plowed back less than one-fifth of their $500,000,000 oil revenues last year into regional development, the United Nations reported today.

NATROBI, Kenya, June 21 (Reuters) -- European electors of the Thika District Association, mainly coffee and sisal farmers, have adopted a resolution of no confidence in the British Commander in Chief in East Africa, Gen. Sir George Erskine, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Inter-American Peace Commission took official note this afternoon of Guatemala's charge that she was a victim of aggression, but at Guatemala's request it deferred action.

BOSTON, June 21 -- The driving energy of West Germany -where top executives devote ten hours a day to their Jobs, six days a week, every week -- was credited here today for a major part of that country's "amazing postwar recovery."
NUEVA OCOTEPEQUE, Honduras, June 21 -- The insurgent forces under Colonel Castillo Armas have captured the pilgrimage town of Esquipulas in Guatemala, just across a mountain ridge from here.

Pigeons, as well as persons, have been uprooted by the demolition of several buildings situated in Columbus Circle, the site of the city's new Coliseum. In the last week alone, construction workers, preparing to raze the six-story office building at 5 Columbus Circle, have taken down dozens and dozens of nests on the roof, the upshot being that dozens and dozens of pigeons have been left nestless.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 21 -- Guatemalan diplomats said today they probably would bring the case of the rebel invasion back to the United Nations Security Council if the fighting continued.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -The Department of Commerce reported today that Europe's economy kept on improving during the first three months of this year, despite the downturn in this country.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Senate rules of procedure are such that the majority leader, Senator Knowland, may find himself in a dilemma over the current moves to discipline Senator McCarthy that will persuade him to call up, for action at this session, the committee "reform" code offered by Senator Bush of Connecticut.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- The wheat market had good support on early declines today and scored fair gains later, but buying was not enthusiastic. Hedge sales are extremely light for this time of year. On the other hand, there appears to be investment buying on the dips.

SAN JUAN, P. R., June 21 -- Puerto Rican migrants to the United States mainland this year seem to have been largely wives and children of workers who had migrated earlier, the second annual Migration Conference heard today.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 21 (UP) -- Col. Carlos Castillo Armas set up an anti-Communist Government inside Guatemala today and called for the unconditional surrender of President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman and his Communist-supported regime.

Pedestrians near the intersection of Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street gawked yesterday as the framework of a twenty-two-story office building on the northwest corner was swiftly enclosed by prefabricated aluminum panels over the two main facades.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Under Secretary of State Walter Bedell Smith returned from Geneva today to report on seven weeks of unsuccessful negotiations on Korea and Indochina.

The City Department of Commerce and the Mayor's Reception Committee were merged into a single unit yesterday. Richard C. Patterson Jr., chairman since Jan. 1 of the Mayor's Committee, was named to head the merged agency.

ALBANY, June 21 -- Governor Dewey agreed today to postpone temporarily any announcement of his decision as to whether he would be willing to head the Republican state ticket for the fourth time next fall

LONDON, June 21 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden firmly supported in Parliament today the efforts made in the United Nations Security Council meeting yesterday to transfer the Guatemala dispute to the Organization of American States.

The City Department of Commerce and the Mayor's Reception Committee were merged into a single unit yesterday. Richard C. Patterson Jr., chairman since Jan. 1 of the Mayor's Committee, was named to head the merged agency.

ALBANY, June 21 -- Governor Dewey agreed today to postpone temporarily any announcement of his decision as to whether he would be willing to head the Republican state ticket for the fourth time next fall

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- Glenn Cunningham, the famous Kansas "miler" of twenty years ago, testified before a Senate Commerce subcommittee today that the extractiveness of alcoholic beverage advertising is a major influence in causing young people to drink.
The first American chinchilla fur auction in twenty-five years, held yesterday, was a real success.

" Savage Papua: A Missionary Among Cannibals," by the Rev. Andre Dupeyrat, will be published Aug. 23 by Dutton. It is a record of a Roman Catholic missionary's twenty-one years with a barbaric race in New Guinea. The story tells of dangerous journeys, cannibal feasts and blood baths, the challenge of witch doctors and of healing the bodies as well as the souls of the savages.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I call to your attention a series of statements culled from reports in The New York Times of June 13 indicating that the Administration's foreign policy is now bankrupt.

BONN, Germany, June 21 -- The speech of Dr. Heinrich Bruening, former Reichschancellor, advocating neutrality between the East and the West, has angered Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, whose policy is for European integration.
A record net income of $2,813,848 was reported yesterday by the Cosden Petroleum Corporation for the fiscal year ended April 30.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Republican Congressional leaders assured President Eisenhower today that the "essential parts" of his program could be enacted in time for adjournment on July 31 as scheduled.

BIROBIDZHAN, U. S. S. R., June 11 -- While Birobidzhan has grown and expanded since World War II, it must be emphasized that its importance as an area primarily dedicated to the settlement of persons of Jewish nationality has tended steadily to decline.

TURKU, Finland, June 21 -John Landy of Australia ran the mile in 3 minutes .and 58 seconds today, clipping 1.4 seconds off Roger Bannister's world record and becoming the second man to crash the 4-minute barrier.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 21 (AP) -- The Fourth Army said today that Cpl. Claude Batchelor of Kermit, Tex., who first stayed with the North Korean Communists, then changed his mind, would be court-martialed.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UP) -- The Federal Communications Commission's Common Carrier Bureau said today the F. C. C. should order Western Union Telegraph Company to dispose of its $12,000,000-a-year cable business within six months.

Conrad Nagel, the actor, is an amateur chef. He has had an interest in gastronomy since the days when he became a star of the silent flicker. In an interview the older day he spoke in the modulated voice of the stage professional on such household matters as baked grapefruit, chef's salad and iced tea.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had denied an appeal from Jess M. Ritchie of Oakland, Calif., for dismissal of a complaint charging false advertising of the battery additive AD-X2.
Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons is pretty tough on his home grounds The 79-year-old trainer is a dangerous man with a horse anywhere, but at Aqueduct he's a regular Rocky Marciano.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 21 -- Following are texts of messages from Guillermo Toriello, Guatemalan Foreign Minister, and Jose Edgardo Valenzuela, Honduran Foreign Minister, to the President of the Security Council. The messages were received too late for yesterday's Council meeting and were made public today:

BETHLEHEM, Pa., June 21 (AP) -- Progress in the field of human relationships can quell many of the conflicts and uncertainties in the world today, Monroe J. Rathbone, president of the Standard Oil Company (N. J.) said today
WASHINGTON, June 21 (UP) -- The G. I. Bill of Rights, ten years old tomorrow, has produced the most educated generation in the nation's history, the Veterans Administration said today.

CHICAGO, June 21 (UP) -- A group fo 214 atomic scientists at the Argonne National Laboratories charged today that the labeling of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer as a security risk "adopts the worst features of totalitarianism."

The shadow boxing in the Security Council on Sunday and the meeting of the Inter-American Peace Commission in Washington yesterday could not penetrate to the deep causes of the present upheaval in Guatemala. Of the two agencies the Peace Commission is the more suitable to deal with a hemispheric issue, and there is no good reason why the whole dispute should not have been referred in the beginning to the twenty-one-member Organization of American States.

AN exciting sense of the magnitude and significance of the round-the-world trip of Britain's Queen Elizabeth and her husband Philip is richly conveyed in the ninety-six-minute color picture, spanning the entire six-month tour, which British Movietonews has put together and which was delivered yesterday to the Globe.

" It's like looking at the original painting instead of the reproduction." This was one youngster's comparison of the workshop method, carried on experimentally for a week this month in Junior High School 65, with the usual classroom method of teaching.

Having pledged himself to the task of arranging for an "honorable peace" in Indochina within thirty days, Premier Mendes-France has run into difficulties which have caused him to postpone his scheduled appearance in Geneva. Except for Chou Enlai all the major Foreign Ministers have left and Mr. Chou's departure is reported imminent. The remaining talks are for the moment mainly technical and military.

PARIS, June 21 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France made his first great effort yesterday to remove misconceptions about his policies that exist in the United States. He did so in a long talk with Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, United States Under Secretary of State, who was on his way home from the Geneva conference on Far Eastern affairs.
TRENTON, June 21 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner won a partial victory tonight in his long fight to block distribution of $28,500.000 in additional school aid until July 1, 1955.

LONDON, June 21 -- Industrial shares reached a new peak in an active and rising stock market today. The Financial Times Industrial ordinary share index rose 1.6 points to 153.7, thus passing the previous peak reached just before last week's set-back.

Donations of blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program totaled 610 pints Friday. Included were 196 pints given by employes of the City Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity at the Municipal Building and 121 by employes of Piel Brothers, brewers, at 1632 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn.
A period of firm to rising prices in the bond market was predicted before the New York Society of Security Analysts here yesterday by Edward L. Holsten, partner in Salomon Bros. Hutzler, bankers.
DES MOINES, June 21 (AP) -- A series of floods that continued to grow as they rolled downstream left more than a thousand families homeless in Iowa tonight.

MADRID, June 21 -- The Spanish armed forces are being rapidly and intensively trained by United States military experts with the ultimate objective of enabling them "to assist in the defense of the Iberian peninsula."

The present system of high farm price supports, when it is justified at all, is usually justified by pointing out that the system is "a two-way street." Price supports and crop controls go hand in hand, say the defenders of the present arrangement, and you can't discuss the one without discussing the other.
With so much emphasis placed on learning to live with others, young people today are in danger of losing the ability to live with themselves, Mrs. Lillian Ashe declared last night.
Don Hollenbeck, television news commentator, ended his life yesterday morning by inhaling gas in his apartment at 148 East Forty-eight Street.

As measured by The New York Times composite average of fifty stocks, the stock market yesterday reached its best level since early June, 1930. Final price yesterday, however, were well below the session's highs, with seven of every eleven issues traded finishing lower or unchanged on the day.
Economic initiative in this country may have been dampened a bit by the recent recession, but it still is strong.

For years now we have been watching superbly conditioned athletes run their hearts out trying to lower the record for the mile run. And with each failure we have heard the arguments grow as to whether the much-sought four-minute mile was within the province of human accomplishment.

A syndicate will offer to the public today a $35,000,000 issue of 3 1/8 per cent debentures, due in 1974, of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company. The underwriting group is managed jointly by Kidder, Peabody Co., Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane and Carl M. Loeb, Rhoades Co. The debentures are priced are 99.625 per cent, to yield 3.15 per cent.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 22 -- If war comes to this country, none of New York State's rural areas is sufficiently organized to cope with the problems that will arise through the influx of refugees from the cities.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (UP) -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today for $380,000.000 to stockpile strategic metals and minerals that would be difficult or impossible to get in event of war.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- The Airline Pilots' Association, representing crews for the major air carriers of the United States, sent strike ballots today to 2,400 United Air Lines and Trans World Airlines pilots.
Yeshiva University will hold its twenty-third annual commencement exercises tomorrow at which it will confer 176 graduate degrees and three honorary degrees.

The four-story loft building at 320-322 Butler Street in Brooklyn has been sold by the Hansart Realty Corporation to a client of Arthur Gordon, attorney. The Brevoort Management Company was the broker. The building contains 25,000 square feet of space and is on a plot 240 by 100 feet.

SAN JUAN, P. R., June 22 -- An intensive law - enforcement program will "clean up virtually every slum in New York" by March, 1956, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh predicted today. The forecast was made at a conference on Puerto Rican migration to the mainland.
Russia virtually clinched the chess tournament with the United States in yesterday's play at the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Pakistan agreed today to take part in an engineering study of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development's proposals for solution of Pakistan's dispute with India over the waters of the Indus River basin.

LEO DUROCHER'S enthusiasms never are restrained. He goes all out, full tilt. This is particularly noticeable during spring training when he raves about rookies as if each one is a step from immortality, on his way to baseball's Hall of Fame. However, the Dandy Little Manager normally calms down slightly once the official season gets under way.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Democrats accused the Eisenhower Administration today of pursuing "do-nothing foreign trade policies" while Red China and Soviet satellites captured United States foreign markets.
Progressive education in this country is as "dead as a dodo," a leading American public school educator asserted yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 22 -- This process-conscious film capital was treated today to demonstrations of the long-talked-about Todd-A. O. big-screen system and the latest innovations in the development of anamorphic, or squeeze, lenses used in the photography and exhibition of CinemaScope.

Commission house buying, dealer purchasing and short covering pushed most cocoa options up the 1-cent a pound daily limit yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The London market was sharply higher and spot supplies were tight.

Dr. Gerhard Bucerius, a publisher in West Germany and a member of its Bundestag, testified yesterday in Federal Court that in the Sondergericht, a special court of the Nazi regime for handling Jewish cases, "Jews had no chance to escape."

Joseph D. Nunan told a Brooklyn Federal grand jury that he was not a tax expert even though he was the United States Commissioner of Internal Revenue, it was brought out yesterday at his income tax evasion trial in Brooklyn Federal court.
