HOUSTON, June 22 (AP) -- Don Albert of Purdue used a 67 today to fashion a record 8-under-par 136 qualifying score as Southern Methodist University captured the team title while setting another mark in the fifty-seventh National Collegiate golf championships.
Eddie Cantor will be the star and producer of a new television program to be made on film and sold to sponsors on individual stations rather than on a national network basis.
Sales and earnings of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company for the six months ended on April 30 dropped from the corresponding period last year.

TRENTON, June 22 -- A company charged with entering into collusive and unlawful purchase agreements with aides of former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman was blacklisted by the state today. State Treasurer Archibald S. Alexander took the action against George F. Fish Associates, stationery jobbers, under a law signed by Gov. Robert B. Meyner last Friday.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 22 -- Two Class A yawls, Bolero and Good News, were slugging it out late this afternoon in the 635-mile yacht race from Newport. Bolero, owned by John Nicholas Brown, commodore of the New York Yacht Club, was two miles ahead about 220 miles northwest of Bermuda.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 -- Doctors were advised tonight by the new president of the American Medical Association to "reach back further than the disease" in treating their patients.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board strongly supported today a bill to fix airline mail rates on a divisional basis. The Post Office Department strongly opposed it.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 -While many doctors puffed on cigarettes in meeting rooms and hotel lobbies, the retiring president of the American Medical Association today voiced the belief that the case linking cigarettes and cancer had "not been proven."

MADRID, June 22 -- A communique issued today indicated that Don Juan of Bourbon, generally acknowledged as pretender to the Spanish throne, must never return to Spain as long as Generalissimo Francisco Franco is in power.

The years come and go at the Lewisohn Stadium and generations of New Yorkers grow up on the music made there. Fine music is welcome at any time, and is especially refreshing on a warm summer evening -- a leading reason why our annual Stadium Concerts have become one of the consolations of a summer in the city.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 22 (AP) -- Roger Le Blanc, an apprentice who was sidelined nine months after a spill last summer at Atlantic City, was injured again today. He was thrown from his mount at the starting gate in the second race at Monmouth Park.

ST. LOUIS, June 22 (UP) -- Beer drinkers waited hopefully today for news of a full-scale price war, but the brewers of four local beers said they had no intention of following the lead of Anheuser-Busch, Inc.

A cancer expert cited yesterday the need for more extensive research to determine the causes of cancer and heart disease, particularly as related to a reported higher death rate for cigarette smokers.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The National Grange is not interested in promoting sales of liquor and beer even though it might help solve the farm-surplus problem, a spokesman said today.

JERSEY CITY, June 22 -- A formal bid for leasing a part of the Medical Center for use as a medical and dental college was submitted to the city administration today by Seton Hall University of South Orange.
TORONTO, June 22 -- The Canadian fine-paper industry was fined $242,000 today for price fixing and restraint of trade over the last twenty years.

KHABAROVSK, U. S. S. R., June 12 -- For a thousand miles southward from the Bering Sea runs the fief of Russia's great far eastern capital, Khabarovsk. The city is the administrative center of a sprawling empire far vaster than those over which reigned the early Czars in European Russia.

PARIS, June 22 -- The United States Government is investigating an agreement between Saudi Arabia and Aristotle Socrates Onassis, millionaire shipowner, establishing a new tanker fleet under the Saudi Arabian flag. Opponents of the contract, which was concluded at Jidda Jan. 20, last, say it establishes an unfair monopoly in violation of normal trade procedures.

LIDO BEACH, L. I., June 22 -- The Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation will raise prices on most of its television models 10 to 20 per cent within sixty days, Benjamin Abrams, president, disclosed here today.

International Packers, Ltd., has selected three new directors, at the same time increasing the board from seven to nine members, A. Thomas Taylor, board chairman, announced yesterday. Leroy G. Denman Jr. fills the vacancy created by the retirement of Alfred T. Carton, associated with the company and its predecessor as legal counsel thirty-six years.

Donald Couper, according to his letter in your issue of June 14, would like the biggest stadium in the country in the southwest corner of Central Park, and asks for "public reaction." This is to oblige.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Attempts were made to define good design both visually and verbally today at the summer home furnishings market now in progress. The conclusion would seem to be that it was as difficult to define this illusive term as it was to find objects worthy of the title.

EARLY summer art attractions have been pleasurably increased with the two new exhibitions in third-floor galleries at the Museum of Modern Art. One of these is a retrospective exhibition of paintings by the late Niles Spencer; the other, a showing of examples of abstract calligraphy as developed by Japanese artists during the last decade.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Wednesday, June 23 -- Guatemala has called for further United Nations action to stop rebel attacks and has received a sharp scolding from the United States.
CRESTWOOD, N. Y., June 22 -- Dorothy Lowenstein of Fenway captured low gross honors in a Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class A one-day tournament at the Leewood Club today.

MEVO BEITER, Israel, June 22 -- This hill settlement from which three men went to their deaths along the border with Jordan Saturday is for the time being the focus of the whole Israeli-Arab bitterness. On this side of the line the emotion is flowing over into distrust and even animosity toward the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization.

The League of New York Theatres, Inc., declared yesterday that it would be physically impossible to collect the 5 per cent city admissions tax on tickets sold prior to the signing of the new tax law last Friday.

Sir Adrian Boult last night led the Stadium Symphony Orchestra in its second concert of the season at Lewisohn Stadium, with Michael Rosenker, concertmaster of the orchestra, as soloist in the Sibelius Violin Concerto.
Dr. Karl T. Compton, one of the country's top scientists and a leading figure in the development of the atomic bomb, died yesterday in New York Hospital of Cornell Medical Center.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 22 (UP) -- Former President Truman "had his best day yet" since undergoing emergency surgery, his physician said tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Senate Democratic leader, Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, asked Congress today to warn that the Western Hemisphere would tolerate no further Soviet interference in its affairs.

Eleven air - pollution experts from seven foreign countries arrived here aboard the America yesterday for a six-week inspection tour of industrial plants in the United States. The tour will end on Aug. 6.

Fifty musicians went out in the noonday sun yesterday to give the first of fourteen weekly New York Summer Festival band concerts. Their audience, spread over Battery Park, numbered thousands, who enjoyed the music, the sunshine and cooling breezes.

Judge Harold R. Medina of the United States Court of Appeals here urged yesterday a "sound bold program" to reform the courts of New York State. He also called on the Temporary State Commission on the Courts to fight for broad reforms.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- President Eisenhower, an Army man himself, jokingly remarked today that the Army was always doing something for the Marines. He made the observation at a White House ceremony when he signed an order establishing the first official seal for the Marine Corps in its 178 years of existence.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- President Eisenhower transferred from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to other agencies today functions dealing with the production and disposition of rubber, tin and abaca fiber.
PORTLAND, Me., June 22 -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith looked forward today to the Maine general election in September with a solid Republican endorsement for a second term.

The manufacture of apparel and accessories is the lifeblood of the American economy, according to Thomas J. Carroll, executive vice president and general manager of Frederick Atkins, Inc., New York resident buyers.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- President Eisenhower said tonight that either we help Japan get on her feet or the Communists would use her to turn the Pacific into a Communist sea.
The Public Service Commission yesterday rejected for the second time an appeal by two southern Westchester bus companies for higher fares.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Bills to bar Alger Hiss from receiving a Government pension were opposed at the highest Administration levels today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 22 -- Most United Nations delegates do not have the faintest idea whether the Guatemalan Government will be able to hold on or whether an anti-Communist regime will take power.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's speech tonight to the National Editorial Association:
WOODS HOLE, Mass., June 22 -- The ocean's movement, one of the biggest riddles of oceanography, may be yielding some secrets.

More imports are being shown at the fall Main Floor Accessories Show at the McAlpin Hotel than at the spring and summer show and they have attracted large numbers of buyers from quality stores, exhibitors reported yesterday.

A contingent of foreign Girl Scouts, a group of Massachusetts industrialists and a former United States Maritime Commission chairman arrived yesterday aboard the United States Lines passenger vessel United States.

PARIS, June 22 -- Pierre Mendes-France, new head of the French government, will discuss a cease-fire in Indochina tomorrow with Chou En-lai, Premier and Foreign Minister of Communist China, in Bern, Switzerland.

The background of the revol. now raging in Guatemala is discussed in a book by Daniel James former managing editor of The New Leader. Mr. James has made two recent trips to Latin America. His book, entitled "Red Beachhead in America," is planned for publication early in the fall by John Day.
CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Depart- ment of Agriculture follows:

PARIS, June 22 -- While history may seem to be a succession of kings and wars, it is really a record of bread and soup, Lucien Febvre, historian and professor at the College de France, said today at the official opening of an international seminar on education and problems of daily life.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Congressional conferees today broke a long deadlock and reached agreement on a lease-purchase bill expected to set off a multi-billion dollar Government building program.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Consumer prices went up last month, reversing a three-month trend. Ewan Clague, Federal Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said that he still regarded the price situation as "stable."
The law firm of Proskauer. Rose, Goetz Mendelsohn, in 300 Park Ave---Cross Brown Co, agents.

THE daily bag limits on all species of game fish, including trout, are liberal in this country and in Canada, but the average angler visiting a resort should be guided by his needs rather than the maximum number of fish he may legally take.

On the afternoon of June 1, 1950, a trim, gray-haired woman stood on the floor of the United States Senate and told her colleagues, including Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, who was sitting hardly three feet away from her:

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Southern Democrats searched today for a feasible method of blocking President Eisenhower's order that the Atomic Energy Commission make a contract with private power companies to supply power to the Tennessee Valley Authority.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 22 -- Favored Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley, seeking her sixth title in the twenty-fifth women's Long Island Golf Association match-play championship, led the way through the first round in impressive fashion at the Meadow Brook Club today.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- The announcement of another drastic slash in wheat acreage next year, and somewhat less favorable yield reports from western Kansas and northern Texas, were responsible for a stronger tone in wheat. Prices moved up 1 cent or more before meeting much resistance.

ELLIOTT MURPHY'S "Aquashow," the outdoor entertainment combining swimming, singing, dancing, ice-skating and now log-rollong (not the political kind), returned last night to the Amphitheatre in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens.
The lonely white dog that ten days ago chased a returning Bellevue Hospital ambulance for twenty-four blocks found a home yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 22 -- Following is a telegram dated June 21, 1954, from Foreign Minister Guillermo Toriello of Guatemala to the President of the Security Council of the United Nations:
LONDON, June 22 -- Commercial television will probably be on the air in Britain next year.

S. M. Hirsch has relinquished his affiliation with the management of the textile building at 1407 Broadway and has established a real estate consulting business, principally for textile and apparel firms, with temporary headquarters at 1407 Broadway.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- There is great activity here in preparation for this week-end's meeting between President Eisenhower and British Prime Minister Churchill.

Held to two hits by Bud Podbielan while Cincinnati hammered three of their four pitchers for seventeen assorted safeties, the Dodgers were routed by the Redlegs, 13 -- 1, at Ebbets Field yesterday. It was the worst defeat for the Brooks this season.

Prime Minister Churchill and Secretary Eden plan to leave London tomorrow for Washington for a weekend conference with President Eisenhower and Secretary Dulles which is certain to be of importance to the whole free world. The discussions in prospect will doubtless range over the whole gamut of problems confronting our two nations and all free nations in this atomic age, including Indochina and the European Defense Community, now in the focus of world attention.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., June 22 -- Katharine F. Lenroot, former chief of the United States Children's Bureau, urged citizens tonight to recognize that they, singly and collectively, formed the "society" on which the welfare of many youngsters depended.
New Britain, Conn., yesterday sold $1,165,000 of bonds due from 1955 to 1974 to Salomon Bros. Hutzler and associates at a bid of 100.33 for obligations bearing interest of 1.8 per cent.

" All Summer Long" isn't going into the Morosco as had been assumed. Instead, the drama by Robert Woodruff Anderson, author of the successful "Tea and Sympathy," will open Sept. 23 at the Coronet, where it can remain for eight weeks only.
Chess spectators are like Dodger fans with laryngitis -- men with rampant emotions but muted voices.
GUATEMALA, June 22 -- The Army announced late last night that it had forced the rebels to retreat at Gualan, rail town fifteen miles inside the border, after heavy fighting.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UP) -- The American Legion is not angry with President Eisenhower personally, but it complained bitterly today about a White House request for funds to "maintain public order" at the Legion's forthcoming convention here.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 391 pints of blood on Monday, including 108 at M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., 43 Leonard Street, and ninety-nine in a community collection at Monticello, N. Y.

PIKE, N. H., June 22 -- The chief spokesman for the Reform Jewish rabbinate in this country called tonight on his fellow clergymen to ask Congress to adopt "clear and equitable" Congressional investigating committees.

The danger of a strike in East Coast shipyards was removed yesterday afternoon for at least one month. The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., agreed to give at least fifteen days' notice of a walkout and not to take any strike step before July 23. The present agreement was to have expired at midnight tonight.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 22 -- An unidentified plane of the DC-6 type flew over here early today and scattered leaflets denouncing President Jose Figueres and Dr. Romulo Betancourt, ousted Venezuelan President, who lives in exile here.

No question that a pun is a low form of wit and perhaps can be better left unsaid, yet it has a pungency that has its due. One is tempted, thus, to see in the name of the new Premier of France an omen for good. Permit a bit of Anglicization and Mendes-France becomes "mend France." Would that he will, for that land is sore stricken and needs the balsam of a magic touch.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 22 -- Jane Wyman and Charlton Heston will be starred by Paramount in the romantic drama, "Lucy Gallant" if all goes well with current negotiations for the two stars. The deal is expected to be closed shortly.
The two top prizes in the twenty-seventh biennial international art show in Venice, Italy, which opened on June 16, went to New Yorkers -- Max Ernst and Ben Shahn.

Higher food costs, especially of fruits and vegetables, were a major factor in the increase for the second successive month in the city's consumer price index. Compiled by the regional office of the United States Department of Labor, the statistics showed that from April to May average retail food prices advanced 0.7 per cent. They had risen 1.0 per cent between March and April.

Local authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration borrowed $119,210,000 yesterday for the permanent financing of low-rent projects at an average interest cost of 2.2727 per cent, the lowest since January, 1952.

The American Heart Association and its affiliates have made 169 awards totaling $954,370 to scientists who will do research in the field of heart and blood vessel diseases in the year beginning July 1.
MOST New Yorkers have retreated so far from nature that they seem blind to the astonishing amount of wildlife that swoops through the town's canyons during migration, if at no other season.

Events tonight: Stadium Symphony Orchestra, Sir Adrian Boult conducting, Henri Deering, pianist, Lewisohn Stadium, 8:30 P. M.; Goldman Band, Central Park, 8:30; "La Boheme," La Puma Opera Workshop, 250 West Ninety-first Street, 7:45.

The Federal Reserve Board has just taken a fresh step to implement its stated policy of maintaining a condition of "active ease" in the money market. It has announced a general reduction in the percentages of reserves that member banks of the system must maintain against their demand and time deposits.

ROME, June 22 -- A wave of strikes to last twenty-four to forty-eight hours hit Italy today in a number of important industries. A million metallurgical workers were called out as were workers in the food, electrical, cement and mining industries.
Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. was promised yesterday the support of ten more delegates for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

Pity the car owner who leaves his automobile in a public garage or parking lot. The cars are stored so close together that it is almost impossible to move them or open the doors without collision. When the owner calls for his car he may find with dismay, crumpled fenders, smashed headlights, dented doors scratches, marks or nicks decorating his once proud possession.

Coming up with another of their electrifying finishes, the Giants jammed two runs across the plate in the last half of the ninth at the Polo Grounds last night to defeat the Braves, 3 to 2, before a roaring crowd of 29,136.

An unusually designed section of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway that bypasses congested downtown Brooklyn by way of a one-mile link between Atlantic Avenue and the Fulton Street approach to the Brooklyn Bridge was opened to the public yesterday.
Cotton futures were active on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Closing prices for ac- tive months were somewhat irreg- ular, 11 points off to 5 points up.

Crash Dive, owned by Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, had little trouble justifying the odds in his favor at Aqueduct yesterday. A crowd of 16,716 liked the 4-year-old son of Devil Diver so much that he was installed an 11-20 favorite and he responded by winning just as he pleased over the course of a mile and a sixteenth.

CLEVELAND, June 22 (UP) -- Although he failed to finish, Al Sima pitched fine ball in his first start of the season tonight to lead the Philadelphia Athletics to a 4-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians before a crowd of 12,964.

SOMETHING ought to be done about Pamela Frankau, something that would multiply her pleasantly loyal body of readers by ten and win her her rightful share of the critical attention often wasted on writers decidedly her artistic inferiors. Miss Frankau is a deft technician who achieves any effect she wishes with glittering skill.

It was a perfect kind of day, a dandy, just exactly right for the last day of spring. The sun was warm hut not too hot, the air was soft but not too humid. It was a day meant for a picnic, a canoe trip, for an afternoon lying on the sands of a beach, for a slow, aimless meandering along country lanes.

TELEVISION'S, propensity for biting off more than it can chew asserted itself once again in the earnest if ill-advised attempt of the Robert Montgomery program to condense the Charles Dickens work, "Great Expectations." The novel was lost without the compensating reward of a good play.

Today's new film is "Side Street Story," an Italian-made picture co-starring Toto and Eduardo De Filippo, at the Art Theatre. Signor De Filippo also directed the adaptation of his own stage play, which he wrote with P. Tellini and A. Majuri, and co-produced with Dino De Laurentiis.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Farmers would get a chance next year to decide for themselves whether they prefer flexible or rigid corn price supports under a provision approved today by the House Agriculture Committee.
CHICAGO, June 22 (UP) -- The second-place Chicago White Sox beat the Washington Senators, 7 to 5, before 23,016 fans tonight to cut the Cleveland Indians' league lead to three games.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (UP) -- The Senate approved today a bill to provide $182,000,000 in Federal aid for hospital construction, including new facilities for victims of long illnesses.

" Actions speak louder than words" -- an old and homely adage, but to us Americans living in Japan the truth of this adage cuts more keenly as the spirit of McCarthyism colors more luridly day by day the news from the United States.
Two of the nation's oldest automobile concerns, now merging into what is to be known as the Studebaker-Packard Corporation, had humble beginnings.
PARIS, June 21 -- French silks, rayons and velvets for the 1954-55 winter are a riot of patterns, as the prevailing passion for prints is interpreted in winter media.
PITTSBURGH, June 22 -- Representatives of 600,000 unionized steel workers rejected a company wage offer today and empowered their leaders to call a strike if no accord was reached by next week.

In your report on the Gold Coast elections carried in your issue of June 17 you state that "the party's (that is, the Convention People's party) most significant defeat occurred in British Togoland, a Trust Territory administered as part of the Gold Coast." This statement is incorrect.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 22 -- A move to restore and maintain historic graveyards in this town, now bramble-ridden jungles where eighteenth-century slate and sandstone markers lie forgotten, was made this afternoon.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 -- California's Indians, dispossessed of their lands during the Gold Rush of 1849-52, finally took their claims for recompense into court today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP) -- Robin Roberts fanned eleven men and spaced six Chicago hits for his ninth victory as the Phillies beat the Chicago Cubs, 4 -- 1, tonight. The Chicago run was Hank Sauer's twenty-first homer of the season.

BUENOS AIRES, June 22 -- Alianza, newspaper published by the Alliance of National Liberators, attacked the Peronista press and labor leaders today for allowing Red agents to foment violence during the recent strikes.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Senate subcommittee investigating the Army-McCarthy dispute agreed informally today to seek a final report before Congress adjourns around Aug. 1.
LONDON, Jan. 22 -- The five-nation subcommittee of the United Nations Disarmament Commission has failed to find a solution to the problem of disarmament.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., notified the Transit Authority yesterday that it would be a candidate as exclusive representative of the agency's employes in eight of ten units established for a union representation election Friday.
By this time next week, the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad will be out of debt to the Federal Government for the first time in a generation.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A Congressional group moved today to require at least partial repayment from beneficiaries of the foreign aid program.
YONKERS, June 22 -- The two-family frame house at 8 Fern Terrace here still stands tonight as a monument, albeit a temporary one, to a woman's determination.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- A bill to create a national defense reserve of tank ships and modernize the present tanker fleet was approved by the House Merchant Marine Committee today.
The five-story apartment house on lot 25 by 100 feet at 141 East Ninety - seventh Street has been sold by George Willi to an investor in a deal negotiated by the Haggstrom - Callen Company, broker.

The directors of the nation's last two independent automobile manufacturers, the Studebaker Corporation and the Packard Motor Car Company, agreed yesterday on a merger under the name of the Studebaker-Packard Corporation.

BALTIMORE, June 22 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox pushed across two runs in the twelfth inning to score a 3-1 victory over the cellar-dwelling Orioles tonight as a crowd of 13,093 watched Baltimore go down to its ninth straight setback.

The progress being made toward putting atomic power and related uses of nuclear energy to peaceful uses is being graphically displayed these days at the first International Congress of Nuclear Engineering at Ann Arbor, Mich. For the scientist and engineer concerned with these developments, of course, the atomic future is one filled with new materials needed to cope with the special hazards of this field.
The Department of Health expects to save more than $50,000 a year with a simplified system of issuing and renewing routine business permits beginning July 1.

SALEM, Ill., June 22 (AP) -- Stephen A. Mitchell, the Democratic National Chairman, said today the televised McCarthy-Army hearings had highlighted "inefficiency" and "disunity" in the Eisenhower Administration.

The use of flexible plastic packaging films has tripled during the last eight years and it now seems possible that the trend toward clerkless retail establishments may double last year's $240,000,000 volume in these products. Consumer acceptance and increasing demand for visual-package merchandise, says Chemical Week Magazine, may well carry film sales over the 400,000,000-pound mark by the end of the year.

A trick to shorten cooking time for broiled chicken is suggested by Mrs. Marian Tracy in "Complete Chicken Cookery" (1953, Bobbs-Merrill, 234 pp.). The pieces of poultry are dropped into boiling water and allowed to remain in the pan, which has been removed from the flame, for about five minutes. When this method is followed, the poultry requires only twenty-five to thirty- three minutes under the broiler instead of the usual fifty minutes.
Fresh sea breezes made the summer sun a shade more bearable for New Yorkers yesterday.
New York City has offered to construct a new pier and terminal for the Italian Line along "luxury liner" row in the West Fifties.

Henry Rombey, a 63-year-old foundry worker of 30 Briggs Street, Hicksville, L. I., was released in $500 bail yesterday when he was arraigned before United States Commissioner Martin C. Epstein in Brooklyn on a charge of sending Irish sweepstakes tickets through the mails.

The one - story taxpayer building containing six stores and occupying a plot of 8,100 square feet on the west side of 163d Street, between Jamaica Avenue and Eighty-eighth Road, in Jamaica, Queens, has been sold by Max Brezel of Long Beach, L. I., to an investing client of Martin B. Nadle, attorney.
GENEVA, June 22 -- Soviet and and satellite worker and employer delegates won the right today to sit and vote in the International Labor Conference.

LONDON, June 22 -- Prime Minister Churchill and Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, will start their discussions with President Eisenhower this weekend convinced that hope still exists for a settlement of the war in Laos and Cambodia. They base their convictions on the Chinese Communists' concessions at the Geneva conference on Far Eastern Affairs.
Acquisition by the Penn-Texas Corporation of the Industrial Brownhoist Corporation was voted yesterday by directors of both concerns on a share-for-share exchange of stock.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (UP) -- A House Judiciary subcommittee today approved an Administration bill authorizing the death penalty for peacetime spying.

Benjamin Fine's excellent discussion of the increase in college enrollments anticipated in the next sixteen years, published on June 6, indicates that additional members for college faculties will be needed in proportion to the increase in the number of undergraduates enrolled.
BOSTON, June 22 -- A broad picture of vast gains yet to be made by advertising was painted today at the convention of the Advertising Federation of America.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 (UP) -- A committee of the American Medical Association today considered an amendment to the association's code of ethics aimed at barring doctors from participaing in so-called "closed-panel" medical care plans.
MILAN, Italy, June 22 (AP) -- A bronze bust of Arturo Toscanini was unveiled here today, with both the Maestro and the widow of the Iowa-born sculptor attending.

PASADENA, Calif., June 22 (AP) -- Thirteen physicists of the California Institute of Technology, including Carl D. Anderson, winner of a Nobel award in physics, urged today that the Atomic Energy Commission reinstate the security clearance of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, atomic scientist.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 22 -- The Government announced tonight that unidentified planes had bombed a Honduran town near the border of rebel-invaded Guatemala. The Foreign Ministry announced the bombing of Santa Rosa, an important road junction about twenty-one miles from the Guatemalan frontier. The town had not previously figured in the invasion of Guatemala by anti-Communist "liberation" forces.
The City Council softened the 1954-55 realty tax blow for city property owners yesterday by approving lower borough assessment rates than those in effect in 1953-54.

Volunteers, trained and closely teamed with professional workers, have a "unique and invaluable role" to play in social service activities, Mrs. Bernice Wolf Frechtman said yesterday. Mrs. Frechtman, who is executive director of the New York section, National Council of Jewish Women, spoke at an open house at her group's new headquarters, 9 East Sixty-ninth Street.
DES MOINES, June 22 (AP) -- This city of 178,000, faced with its biggest flood, was in an official state of emergency tonight.

The New York City Transit Authority has taken a constructive and realistic position in agreeing to an election Friday among hourly rated employes to determine union representation in grievance matters. The cause of stability in labor relations will be furthered rather than hindered by policy that encourages union responsibility.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Foreign Operations Administration began today a new approach to Technical Cooperation (Point IV) by signing a three-year contract with the University of Maryland for work in British Guiana.

DETROIT, June 22 -- Although they dropped a 4-1 decision to the Detroit Tigers today, the third-place Yankees remained five games behind the American League's pace-setting Cleveland Indians, who obliged by losing tonight.

CAIRO, June 22 -- Nine Army officers were sentenced today to prison terms of up to fifteen years by the ruling Junta's Revolution Tribunal after conviction on charges of mutinous conspiracy against the regime. Three other officers were acquitted, two received suspended sentences and two were cashiered from service.

Net income of the Southern Railway in the first five months of this year amounted to $9,267,539, equal to $3.09 a common share, compared with $13,797,652 or $4.83 a share for the five months to May 31, 1953.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 22 -- Industrial and Government interests in Belgium reported here today at the first International Congress on Nuclear Engineering that they were well on the way toward making a power-producing nuclear reactor.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 22 -- Some gambling in the clutch brought the defending titleholders, Lew Hoad and Ken Rosewall of Australia, home somewhat shakily today in the first round of the all-England men's doubles against the Belgian combination of Jacques Brichant and Phillipe Washer.
Columbia University's bicentennial theme was extolled yesterday as a fine bridge between the university and the high schools of the metropolitan area.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 21 -- Outnumbered two to one, about 1,000 troops of the Vietnamese National Army turned back a heavy Vietminh assault early yesterday on the coastal town of Tuyhoa, the French High Command announced here tonight.

LONDON, June 22 -- Prices for industrial shares continued to rise today, stimulated by the overseas trade returns for May and a shortage of offerings. Gains were both bigger and more widespread than on recent days. Store shares were particularly strong, putting on as much as 3s. 6d. (52 1/2 cents).
GRANVILLE, Ohio, June 22 -- Christian educators who are meeting here to assess their strengths and weaknesses were given chapter and verse today on their shortcomings.
WESTBURY, L. I., June 22 (AP) -- Miss Handy, who led almost all the way, was driven to victory by Jimmy Jordan tonight at Roosevelt Raceway in the $3,500 New Hyde Park pace in 2:04 3/5.

It was broiling hot yesterday on the unshaded, stone-paved animal enclosures in the Central Park Zoo. So when a keeper carelessly left a gate open for a moment in the European red deer cage about 10:15 A. M. a two-year-old doe near the exit did just what comes naturally.
Low prices cannot take the place of sound merchandising in shoring up lagging sales, P. B. Wishart, president of Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company, warned yesterday.
Willie Mays hit another home run at the Polo Grounds yesterday, his twenty-second of the year. But it wasn't enough.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- United States Air Force planes of the Caribbean Command are ready to aid in evacuating United States citizens from Guatemala should that become necessary, the State Department said today.

For the first time since 1949, holders of the common stock of the Pennsylvania Railroad won't have a dividend check to spend on their summer vacations. Directors of the road met yesterday, but took no action on a dividend payment. And the board is not scheduled to meet again until Sept. 22.
NEW HAVEN, June 23 -- Dr. Albert Buckner Coe of Boston was elected moderator of the general council of Congregational Christian Churches at the biennial meeting here today.
LONDON, June 23 (AP) -- The London Symphony Orchestra Orchestra disclosed tonight that Austrian-born Prof. Josef Krips had resigned as its conductor in chief.
The cost of atomic energy will soon be brought to a level competitive with conventional power sources, an American Management Association conference was told yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Army has turned down British bids to supply hydroelectric generators for dams in the Pacific Northwest at $225,000 less than the lowest domestic price.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Edward Lamb, Toledo, Ohio, publisher and broadcaster, accused Federal Communications Commissioner John C. Doerfer today of a smear attack intended to strangle him economically.

The great super-tanker W. Alton Jones will be off ere now toward the morning sun and the long sea lanes that she was designed to cleave with her proud, swift bow. She came into New York in last Monday's early heat haze and berthed for the day at Pier 88, where those who love ships paid her the kind of tribute New York has held out in the past for the liners.
Kansas City, Mo., announced yesterday that it would offer for sale on July 7 an issue of $18,700,000 of airport revenue bonds. Dated July 1, 1954, the bonds will mature from 1963 to 1971.
A newly redecorated model apartment will be opened to the public today by the management of Stuyvesant Town, the 8,755-apartment housing project.

ESQUIPULAS, Guatemala, June 23 -- The military limitations and the political aspirations of the insurgent Guatemalan movement under Col. Carlos Castillo Armas can be observed here in much sharper focus than in Tegucigalpa, Honduras.

Physical work on a $20,000,000 program of bringing into production the asbestos ore bodies underlying Black Lake, Quebec, has begun, the United Asbestos Corporation, Ltd., informed stockholders yesterday.
TRENTON, June 23 -- An auditor's report explaining how a state deposit of $300,000 in the South Amboy Trust Company was accounted for on the books of the bank will be made public here tomorrow.

ROME, June 23 -- The Italian Senate gave the Government of Premier Mario Scelba a vote of confidence tonight that showed good majority in the upper house for ratification of the European Defense Community pact.
Russia's chess team clinched the series with the American players in the fourth and last round of the tournament at the Roosevelt Hotel last night.
CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- Hog receipts fell far below expectations today and the market responded with gains ranging from 25 cents to $1 on both butchers and sows.

A Geriatric Rehabilitation Service for men and women over 60 years of age has been opened at the municipal Goldwater Memorial Hospital on Welfare Island. Dr. Howard A. Rusk, a supervisor of the joint project of the Department of Hospitals and NYU-Bellevue Medical Center, has termed the undertaking "the first comprehensive geriatric service any place in the country."

The regional Red Cross blood program received 684 pints of blood Tuesday. Employes of concerns at the Empire State Building gave 217 pints on the first day of a two-day donation at the McAlpin Hotel At the Central Queens Chapter, 92-32 Union Hall Street, Jamaica, 190 pints were contributed.
ALBANY, June 23 -- The Public Service Commission considered today whether speed-recording devices should be made mandatory equipment on all buses that travel routes of more than twenty-five miles.
A four-block area on the lower East Side, just above Manhattan Bridge, will be the center tomorrow night of the third annual Civil Defense training exercise in this city.
A mixture of minced food, salad dressing and summer heat magnifies the danger of bacterial growth that may cause food poisoning, the Department of Health warned yesterday.

MONTAUK yesterday began to redeem its reputation as an area inhabited by Roccus saxatilis, otherwise and more familiarly known as striped bass, for several boats returned before noon with fish scaling up to sixty pounds.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's special message to Congress today urging authorization of a $3,500,000,000 foreign-aid program:

PARIS, June 23 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France returned to Paris tonight by air in a professedly optimistic mood. He told reporters at the Villacoublay airport that he had talked with Chou En-lai for two and one-half hours exclusively about Indochina and that the two had made a survey of that question that had been "as complete and detailed as possible."

HOUSTON, June 23 (AP) -- Stewart Carrell of Southern Methodist beat the defending champion, Earl Moeller of Oklahoma A. and M., as Don Albert, the top favorite from Purdue, was forced into overtime in today's opening round of the fifty-seventh National Collegiate golf championship.

Foreign Secretary Eden laid before an appreciative House of Commons yesterday a good part of the program which Prime Minister Churchill and he will bring to Washington for their forthcoming week-end conference with President Eisenhower and Secretary Dulles.

New Yorkers and their visitors will have an opportunity again this summer to hear good music while enjoying the benefits of fresh air in Bryant, Central and Prospect Parks. From Monday to Friday of each week the New York Public Library in cooperation with the Union Dime Savings Bank will present its seventh annual season of musical programs on records on the Bryant Square Park side of the library.
Rain and lightning storms -- with brief hail storm assists -- struck noisily yesterday, driving the mercury here into spasmodic up-and-down spurts and cutting off power in several communities.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (UP) -- The National Editorial Association said today that a proposed restriction on liquor advertising would violate "the right to advertise" and constituted a possible step toward press censorship.

Underwriting syndicates will place on the market today new issues of public utility securities of bonds and preferred stock, the offerings are designed to raise funds to finance expansion and to refund outstanding securities with issues costing less to service.
The Briggs Manufacturing Company, manufacturer of automotive equipment, showed a 56 per cent drop in first-quarter earnings from those of a year earlier.
Brooklyn's delight at thumping Cincinnati, 6 -- 3, behind an encouraging pitching job by Don Newcombe, was tempered by disturbing news from off the field last night.
GUATEMALA, June 23 -- The Guatemalan Army continued yesterday and last night its pressure on the invading forces in three fighting sectors, according to a High Command communique issued here today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (AP) -- A pair of costly Chicago errors and a two-run double by Willie Jones gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 5-3 victory over the Cubs tonight. One of the seven Chicago hits off Curt Simmons was Randy Jackson's twelfth homer of the year.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- President Eisenhower said today he was opposed to a Federal pension for Alger Hiss. The White House reacted sharply to news stories reporting that the Administration was opposed to bills offered in Congress to bar the pension payments.
Cardinal Spellman gave diplomas to 113 graduates of the School of Nursing of St. Vincent's Hospital at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., June 23 -- Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells posted a 2-over-par 38, 37 -- 75 today to take a one-stroke lead as the thirty-first annual Women's New Jersey Golf Association fifty-four-hole medal play tournament started at the Forest Hill Field Club.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 23 -- Plans for a new atomic reactor to generate electric power have been presented at the first International Congress on Nuclear Engineering.
The maze of glass, chemical and paper devices used by New York City to measure how much of what pollutes air here was inspected yesterday by eleven experts from seven foreign countries.
Commodity prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was normal but coffee trading was the largest since Jan. 13 and hides had the best volume in more than a month.

Your editorial of June 21 on "The Issues in Guatemala" justifies the failure of the United Nations Security Council to respond to the appeal of Guatemala because the question whether there was an invasion "could not be answered on the spur of the moment."

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- John Foster Dulles suggested today that the granting of sovereignty to West Germany should be considered promptly if the European Defense Community Treaty was not fully ratified soon.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 23 -- Twentieth Century-Fox will raise its production output for the next twelve months to twenty-four CinemaScope features. The first picture in the $55,000,000 program will be Darryl Zanuck's production of "The Egyptian," which has been completed and is awaiting release, it was announced.
The first ordination of a former city fireman to the Roman Catholic priesthood was disclosed last night by Fire Department orders.

After a day of indeterminate moves in both directions, yesterday's stock market rallied near the close under the leadership of Chrysler, the tobaccos, rails and electric equipment shares. The New York Times combined average gained 0.81 point on the day and ended at 212.58, the highest close since June 10, 1930.

PIKE, N. H., June 23 -- The Central Conference of American Rabbis was asked today to shun tradition by embarking on a program of conversion. The conference represents 600 rabbis affiliated with the Reform branch of Judaism in this country.

GREENSBORO, N. C., June 23 (AP) -- Marlene Gesell, the medal-winner from Minnesota, and Pat Lesser, Seattle's defending champion, scored easy first-round victories today in the women's national collegiate golf tournament.

vy Properties, Inc., has purchased for investment the' Exchange Court Building, a telvestory office - structure at 52 Broadway, from Max Orda and others in a deal negotiated by: L. J. Phillips , brokers. Sold subject to fmortgages amounting to $3,100,000, the property fronts 124 feet on Broadway, 135 feet: on Exchange Place and 130 feet on New Street.

It was testified in Federal Court here yesterday that Arnold Bernstein, former German shipowner, agreed to repeat the transfer of his Red Star Line stock to a trustee to please the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.

GENEVA, June 23 -- The International Labor Organization was urged by its director general today to keep its eye on the ball in spite of the political tensions that have lately threatened to pull it apart.

Newmont Mining Corp, floor, in S00 Park Ave through Villiam A. Vhite Sons; Avery-Knodel Ine, radio and television station representatives/ floor in 720 5th Ave through Huberth Huberth-- Cross Brown Co, agents.

LONDON, June 23 -- The boom in industrial shares slackened today. Prices rose at the start and business expanded but many of the gains were reduced or eliminated in the afternoon. Nevertheless, the undertone was described as strong at the close.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Senate Democrats maintained today that President Eisenhower would need a three-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act to carry out his ideas for strengthening a free Japan.
ALBANY, June 23 -- Senator Irving M. Ives left the door ajar tonight on the possibility of accepting the Republican nomination for Governor next fall.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Eisenhower Administration is thinking largely of salvage, or a policy of limited loss, in the military crisis in Indochina.
ALBANY, June 23 -- The first toll section of New York State's $962,000,000 Thruway system will open tomorrow.
The University of the Ryukyus at Shuri, Okinawa, has participated in Columbia University's bicentennial celebration.

Guy Lombardo's summertime musical extravaganza "Arabian Nights," starring Lauritz Melchior, opens tonight at 8:30 o'clock at the Jones Beach (L. I.) Marine Amphitheatre, the New York State playhouse on the shore of Zachs Bay.

Today's new film is "The Caine Mutiny," Stanley Kramer's Technicolor production of the novel by Herman Wouk, starring Humphrey Bogart, Jose Ferrer, Van Johnson and Fred MacMurray, at the Capitol. Stanley Roberts wrote the screen play and Edward Dmytryk directed. Robert Francis, May Wynn, Tom Tully, E. G. Marshall and Arthur Franz are among the supporting players.

The corporate seal of the Herb Society of America contains the phrase "For use and for delight." Because cooking is not least among the uses for the little plants, it seemed likely that members attending the society's annual meeting here might have good ideas about herbs in the kitchen.

ST. LOUIS, June 23 -- Integration of white and Negro students in the city's public high schools will be instituted Feb. 1, and racial segregation will be eliminated in the elementary schools by September, 1955, the Board of Education announced last night.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Federal Judge Edward A. Tamm dismissed today a suit that had sought to invalidate the title of the Northern Pacific Railway Company to its railroad system, valued at $820,000,000.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Philip Ray Rodgers, a member of the National Labor Relations Board, may become its general counsel.

DETROIT, June 23 -- Six of the ten walks issued to the Yankees were turned into runs today and the champions, rebounding from yesterday's setback, downed the Detroit Tigers, 9 -- 4. Jim McDonald and Whitey Ford, who hurled for the winners, also issued ten passes between them, but five double plays minimized the Detroit threats.

LONDON, June 23 -- Sir Winston Churchill and Lady Churchill, together with leading figures in journalism, politics, commerce and industry, attended a memorial service in St. Paul's Cathedral today for Viscount Camrose, owner and editor in chief of The Daily Telegraph, who died on June 15.
PHILADELPHIA, June. 23 -- The railroads' essential contribution to national defense will be lost unless they receive a better break from the Government a railroad official asserted tonight.

BUFFALO, N. Y., June 23 (AP) -- An Ohio motion picture theatre owner filed a $450,000 suit in United States District Court here today against five corporations of the Schine theatre interests and seven major film distributing companies.
MEJIT, Marshall Islands, June 9 (Delayed) (AP) -- The "poisoned people" have a new home.
KANSAS CITY, June 23 (UP) -- Former President Truman walked around his hospital room and ate today for the first time since he underwent surgery Sunday.

Freakish reception conditions, apparently resulting from changes in the weather, played tricks with television reception in some parts of the metropolitan area Tuesday evening and early yesterday morning.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., June 23 -- Young mothers interested in community work were advised here today to take part in organization activities if they wished to learn to say a pleasant, firm and guilt-free "no" to groups that made too many demands on their time.
Directors of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company yesterday increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock by 5 cents and voted to call in the preferred stock.

BONN, Germany, June 23 -- A Swiss correspondent said today that he had been threatened by a cabinet minister for having reported a speech by the minister advocating the recovery of territories lost to Czechoslovakia and Poland.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 23 -- Mrs. Luise Meyer Schulte, wife of Arthur D. Schulte of Stamford and 3 East Seventy-first Street, New York, died this afternoon at her home here. She had been under treatment recently for a nervous disorder. Her death was attributed to an overdose of barbiturates.
To a 2-year-old named Right Down, a gelded son of Knockdown, went first money of $9,920 in the sixty-second running of the Tremont Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 23 (UP) -- The Chicago White Sox broke Bob Porterfield's pitching string of twelve consecutive complete games today with a five-run first inning that led to an 8-to-6 victory over the Washington Senators before 7,234 fans.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Affidavits contradicting statements by Paul Crouch, former Communist and ex-convict now employed by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service, have been filed with the Department of Justice.

Two hundred and two employes of Lord Taylor stores, all of whom have served with the company for twenty-five years or more, were honored at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night. Collectively, the group represented 6,000 years of continuous service.

"American Ways of Life," a new work by George R. Stewart, will be issued by Doubleday on July 15. It is a discussion of American folkways and customs and how they developed. Among the subjects considered are language, religion, food, drink, personal names and holidays.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board declined today to reconsider its new temporary regulation permitting airlines to keep the same plane crews at work up to ten hours on uninterrupted flights.
Detailed instructions for the election of union representatives tomorrow by 37,000 Transit Authority employes were issued yesterday by the American Arbitration Association.

Title to the Aramco BuilHing, 'a ;'wentsLone-story office structure at.the northeast comer of Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth' Street, has been- taken by the Penn Lifei. Insurance Company of Philadelphis. The Will/am Val.d0rf 'Astor Estate, original owner Of the property, tcok'a lease-back ,%0 the property, for uorty-twc !years on a net basis.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 23 (AP) -- Diamond Hal, 3-year-old bay colt owned by the S. A. Camp Farms of Shafter, Calif., and driven by Joe O'Brien, won Roosevelt Raceway's Glen Cove pace in 2:05 tonight. He finished a half-length in front of Mighty Grattan, with Greentree Express third.

ALBANY, June 23 -- Officials of Great Britain, Canada and seven states gathered here today to help celebrate the 200th anniversary of the Albany congress that produced the first plan of union for the American colonies.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 23 -- Although pressed by Mrs. Watson K. Blair of the home club, Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley gained the semi-final round in the twenty-fifth Women's Long Island Golf Association's match-play championship with a 1-up victory today over the Meadow Brook course.
The possibility of a split in the anti-Communist vote among 18,000 employes of the General Electric plant at Schenectady, N. Y., was eliminated yesterday.

This is an important day of progress in the Empire State. A series of ceremonies will open 115 miles of the New York State Thruway between the environs of Rochester and Utica. In the late summer a seventy-mile section west to Buffalo will be ready, and in December 212 miles east and south to Suffern, near the Hudson River, are to be finished.

The appointment of Dr. Harold A. Zintel as attending surgeon and directory of surgery at St. Luke's Hospital, effective next Thursday, was announced yesterday by J. Stewart Baker, president of the hospital.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The House Agriculture Committee rejected today an effort to limit Ezra Taft Benson's broad authority to clamp the tightest controls in farm history on farmers in 1955. The vote was 12 to 9.
CLEVELAND, June 23 (AP) -- Home runs by Al Rosen, Larry Doby and Bob Lemon accounted for all of Cleveland's runs today as the league-leading Indians trimmed the Philadelphia Athletics, 5 -- 2.

The relationship between the science of acoustics and the performance and reproduction of music will be discussed tonight at Columbia University's McMillin Theatre, 116th Street and Broadway. The program has been arranged by the Acoustical Society of America and members of the university's acoustics laboratory.

WHEN the time comes to give out the lit'ry laurels for 1954 the judges who wear the silks of the Bollingen, the Pulitzer and the National Book Awards are going to have the devil's own time deciding between the works of Leonie Adams and Louise Bogan. We have their distinguished new volumes on our table this morning.

Unjust criticism of the nation's public schools may cause the country itself considerable harm, Dr. John P. Myers, chancellor of the New York State Board of Regents, warned yesterday. The use of the term "egghead" to deride the scholar and scientist, he said, is part of the hostile atmosphere against education found today.

BALDWIN, L. I., June 23 -- A Long Island Rail Road train killed a pedestrian here this afternoon, touching off a bizarre series of accidents in which two police cars, two trucks and a police ambulance were involved within a few minutes.

The "ivory tower" attitudes of some schools and colleges have made them "pushovers" for attacks by critics of education, Mrs. Agnes E. Meyer declared yesterday. She spoke before the thirty-eight annual convention of the American College Public Relations Association at the Roosevelt Hotel.

MOSCOW, June 21 -- To report that there has been no improvement in conditions of life in Siberia, the Soviet sub-Arctic and the Far East under Communist rule would be untrue. It would be equally untrue to say that Soviet rule has brought a millennium to this vast area.
The Federal Government kept hands off the steel wage dispute yesterday.

Included among the several reasonable proposals by Senator Bush for reforming Congressional inquiries, as outlined by Arthur Krock in The Times of June 22, is the following: "If a witness objects, his appearance shall not be televised or circulated through any 'entertainment media'."
LONDON, June 23 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the speech in the House of Commons today by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden:

MINNEAPOLIS, June 23 -- More than a hundred instances of "pressure against reading of books and * * * school and libary collections" were brought to the attention of the American Library Association's Intellectual Freedom Committee last year, the association was told today at its seventy-third annual conference.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., June 23 -- Hoyt Wilhelm of Hastings, a pitcher for the New York Giants, paid $60 in Police Court here today for speeding sixty miles an hour last Saturday night, driving with a North Carolina operator's license and disorderly conduct.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- A nation-wide campaign to induce states and communities to sponsor local improvements was started here today.

BERN, Switzerland, June 23 -- France and Communist China agreed today on the basic terms of a political settlement for Indochina. The settlement will apply if an armistice can be reached at the Geneva conference.
ALBUQUERQUE, June 23 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee chairman said today that President Eisenhower "absolutely" would be a candidate for re-election in 1956.
The Electric Bond and Share Company is working on the application of atomic energy for both defense and civilian use.
Miss Liberty, newest of New York's excursion boats, will make her maiden voyage from the Battery to the Statue of Liberty today.

A vacant plot 75 .by 200 feet on the west side of Forty-nhith Street and 650 feet north of Twentieth Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by the Thomas 'Crimrdins Con-' tracting Company from Homesites Estates, Inc.
Residents expressing a desire to preserve historic street names opened a campaign yesterday to restore the name of Livingston Place to a two-block street in the Stuyvesant Square area.

That old argument in flush families, whether to buy the latest model motor car or a mink wrap, has been neatly solved in the Bronx by a car dealer's legerdemain: he is offering both items for the price of one in a de luxe penny-sale proposition.
GENEVA, June 23 -- Chou En-lai returned here this evening with his entourage from Bern. He drove immediately to his suburban villa.

A spokesman for Aristotle S. Onassis in New York said yesterday that the royalty tax accruing to Saudi Arabia as a result of a tanker transportation agreement between the country and the millionaire shipowner had been erroneously computed in The New York Times.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 23 -- New York State's local public welfare organizations are confronted by serious shortages of career personnel, and the situation is "especially disturbing" in New York City, a state welfare official warned today.
Kenneth C. Brownell, industrialist; Eli Whitney Debevoise, lawyer, and Dr. Robert F. Loeb, physician, have been added to the board of trustees of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- Dr. Raymond S. Hall, director of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, proposed here today the creation of an international organization for seamen's welfare.

Roy M. Cohn, chief counsel to the Senate Permanent Investigations subcommittee, testified voluntarily in Federal Court yesterday in the case of a convicted narcotics peddler. In 1951, as an assistant United States Attorney, Mr. Cohn prosecuted the man.

The Nation's gasoline stocks declined 2,117,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 169,186,000 barrels, compared with 171,303,000 a week earlier and 148,144,000 a year earlier.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., June 23 (AP) -- A life insurance execuUve tonight told New York realtors they must prepare for a change from a seller's to a buyefs market within the next ten years that would "separate the men from the boys."
ROME, June 23 -- The Communist-dominated Italian General Confederation of Labor called today for a general strike July 2 in the province of Rome.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Absence of any important hedge pressure brought in more buying support in the wheat futures trade today. This resulted in quick recoveries from depressed spots, with local sentiment apparently veering to the bull side.

PITTSBURGH, June 23 (AP) -- Halwey Haddix allowed the Pittsburgh Pirates five hits tonight in hurling the St. Louis Cardinals to a 7-1 triumph over the National League s cellar dwellers. The victory, his tenth in a row, gave Haddix 12-2 record for h season--the best of any pitcher in the majors.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (UP) -- The House Democratic Whip, Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts, accused President Eisenhower today of "dictating" the power policies of the Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy has assigned a man who has not received a Federal security clearance to a preliminary investigation of the Central Intelligence Agency, well-informed sources said today.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active yesterday, and there was a large volume of evening up in old July. Closing prices were 2 points lower to 7 points higher than on Tuesday. The opening was active, 1 to 7 points higher, and the market was steady all day. The trading included large transactions by spot firms.

"THE one shot any golfer is best equipped to make," said Walter Hagen, "is the first shot off the first tee in any tournament. His shoes are clean; his shirt is fresh; his clothes are pressed and his hands feel thin. He's brimful of confidence and is serene, untroubled. If he could maintain that mental attitude for the entire round, he'd score well.
ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., June 23 -- A Georgetown University golfer, Charles Slicklen Jr., captured the medal today in the Metropolitan Golf Association's thirty-seventh junior championship.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 23 -- Budge Patty, the master tactician, found his incomparable volleying touch in the fourth set to defeat Hugh Stewart, the former intercollegiate champion from Southern California, 10-8, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, on the famed center court of Wimbledon today.

I admit that I am confused as to what the United States should do in the Guatemala incident. While my regard for your editorials is high, your editorial of June 22, "Shadow and Substance," has done nothing to dispel my confusion.

DETROIT, June 23 (AP) -- The board of directors of the Detroit and Cleveland Navigation Company adjourned a board meeting yesterday until July 6 without making an expected announcement that the company would be liquidated.

TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., June 23 (AP) -- Carloadings on American railroads declined 13.7 per cent in the first five and a half months of 1954 compared with the same period of 1953, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, June 23 AP) -- Deletion from a Government press release recently of a friendly reference to the late President Roosevelt brought angry charges by Democratic Senators today of "political censorship."

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Senate Rules Committee gave one of its subcommittees today two assignments that might block or delay action on efforts to expel Senator Joseph R. McCarthy from his investigative committee chairmanships.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- President Eisenhower won a quick and favorable response tonight to his plea to Congress against major change in the Administration's $3,500,000,000 foreign aid program.

LOS ANGELES, June 23 -- Accusations of fraudulent management over a fifteen-year period were made today against Wilshire Oil Compny, Inc., in a $15,000,000 suit filed in Superior Court by Bandini Petroleum Company.

BALTIMORE, Thursday, June 24 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles broke a nine-game losing streak by pushing across a run in the seventeenth inning to down the Boston Red Sox, 8 -- 7, early today. The game lasted 4 hours and 58 minutes, an American League record.
One of the most important functions of the retailer is to discover consumer desires and pass the information on to the producer, according to Norman Tarnoff, vice president of Robbins Mills, Inc.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 23 -- The Netherlands, after having consulted with Belgium and Luxembourg, announced today that all three Governments had rejected the idea of circumventing the stalemated European Defense Community by a military grouping with West Germany.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Two panels of leading home furnishings retails agreed today that fall business would be good, but cautioned that consumers would not stand for the price increases a few manufacturers have forecast.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The most optimistic report on business conditions it has drafted since spring of last year will be handed to Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks this week by his Business Advisory Council.

LIDO BEACH, L. I., June 23 -- Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation made its bid here today to bring high fidelity to music-loving millions. The company introduced at its convention of national distributors in the Lido Hotel a high fidelity, three-speed, dual-speaker portable phonograph to sell in stores for $49.95.

SAN JUAN, P. R., June 23 -- Edward Corsi, New York State Industrial Commissioner, urged Puerto Ricans today to "be part and parcel of the organized labor movement, not segregated in Puerto Rican unions."

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- President Eisenhower will give a luncheon for Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden on Saturday with Congressional leaders of both parties attending. The White House said fourteen members from each chamber would be present.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Inter-American Peace Committee proposed tonight that a fact finding commission be sent to investigate Guatemalan charges of agression by Honduras and Nicaragua.
Yesterday noon, the Fashion Group raised the curtain on fall fashions. The presentation was an exciting one. It was an all-American show, in which top native talent scored.
The American Association of Advertising Agencies has stepped up its fight against objectionable advertising, which, it says, undermines all advertising.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 23 -- The United States and its Latin-American allies again will urge the United Nations Security Council to allow the American republics to handle an inquiry into the Guatemalan case.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 -- A showdown battle in the field of medical ethics was averted today in the legislative assembly of the American Medical Association.
The 73-year-old treasurer of an economic educational foundation was found murdered last night in his Greenwich Village apartment off lower Fifth Avenue.

JERUSALEM, June 23 -- Israel was strongly condemned today by the Mixed Armistice Commission for the border incident last Saturday in which three Israelis lost their lives seven miles southwest of Jerusalem.
Rabbi Irving Miller, president of the Zionist Organization of America, sharply criticized last night the State Department's policy of "coddling the Arabs under the slogan of impartiality."

LONDON, June 23 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden proclaimed today the prospect of a settlement in Indochina if the Communists ceased active military operations. In a definitive speech before the House of Commons, Mr. Eden suggested two methods for checking Communist aggression in Southeast Asia and emphasized that "real security" in the area was impossible without the goodwill of India and other free nations.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 16, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Anglo-American talks that are about to begin in Washington will have a world-wide range because there is no corner of the planet without some importance to the United States and Great Britain in their joint effort to find a wider measure of agreement on the means of achieving a durable peace.

BONN, Germany, June 23 -- In an interview that will be published tomorrow in the Hamburger newspaper Die Welt, Fritz Berg, president of the Federation of German Industries, says that industry supports the foreign policy of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and opposes any new orientation.

Members of the board of directors of the Thirty-fourth Street-Midtown Association paid tribute yesterday to Henry Wolf, president of the Hotel Garage Company, Inc., at a luncheon in the New Yorker Hotel.
BOSTON, June 23 -- The Ford Motor Company is discussing the longest range expansion and modernization program in its history, Benson Ford, vice president, said today.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, June 21 -- Political leaders here were astounded to learn today that the British Government had decided to relinquish its responsibilities as administering authority in the British Togoland trust territory as soon as the Gold Coast attained full independence within the Commonwealth a year or two hence.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 23 -- The first rail-down wind since the Newport to Bermuda yacht race began last Saturday kept John Nicholas Brown's seventy-three-foot yawl Bolero ahead today.

TEGUCIGALPA, June 23 (AP) -- The invaders of Guatemala said tonight they were moving on the city of Guatemala from three directions. The Guatemalan Government radio countered the rebel broadcast statement with the announcement that the rebels had been repulsed and were fleeing toward Honduras.
Martin B. Grossman, 44-year-old wholesale jeweler, wanted as a scofflaw, came a cropper early yesterday. Grossman had been sought by the police for six months to answer a batch of traffic summonses.

Because her husband had concealed his belief in communism from his wife, Supreme Court Referee Earle S. Warner yesterday recommended, on ground of fraud, the annulment of a thirteen-year marriage for a 30-year- old mother, giving her the custody of her two daughters and the right to assume her maiden name.

Two world wars have had a profound effect on federal science. Though it had a host of laboratories and scientific agencies, the Government found it necessary in both wars to draw on the universities for research scientists to aid its military departments.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 23 -- The Honduran Government has protested to the United Nations against the bombing of a town about 1 P. M. yesterday.

JESUP, Ga., June 23 -- A new and impressive unit was added to Georgia's growing list of industries here today. Despite rain, 5,000 persons turned out for the formal opening of the Jesup plant of Rayonier, Inc., which manufactures chemical cellulose from pulpwood.

GEORGETOWN, Del., June 23 -- Mrs. Anne M. Barczewski, Newark, Del., housewife and mother of three children, was crowned national chicken cooking queen in the Delmarva Chicken Festival here today. She won out of 100 contestants from all over the nation.

WILTON, Conn., June 23 -- No one here seems to know the exact number but everyone agrees there are probably many more antique shops in Wilton (population 5,000) than in other towns several times its size. Wilton's preoccupation with artifacts of the past, however, is a growing interest that seems to be just hitting its stride.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Secretary of State Dulles has produced a catalogue of differences to be discussed in the Eisenhower-Churchill meetings here this week-end.
