It sits dark and silent now, quiet at last, mercifully quiet. To be sure, there were indications in recent days that it might grow dark before its official time, as the picture faded a little, the sound grew slightly indistinct.
BUENOS AIRES, June 24 -- Tar was hurled last night at a United States Information Services cultural exhibit in Rosario.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 24 -- Britain and France, supported by the United States, have proposed a ban on the use of nuclear weapons except in defense against aggression.
GUATEMALA, June 24 -- This capital city, after a week in which it and a sizable section of the country had been under attack, appeared almost normal today.
Back on June 24, 1929, Walter Watson, then a veteran Wall Streeter aged 65, had an idea that the stock market was getting "a little high."

WASHINGTON, June 24 (UP) -- The Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee voted tentatively today to grant President Eisenhower's request for authority to join a world atomic pool for peaceful purposes.

LONDON, June 24 -- Sir David Maxwell Fyfe, Home Secretary, told the House of Commons today that he would not grant an extension of the work and residence permit of Dr. Joseph H. Cort, American lecturer at Birmingham University.
PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- The Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company decided late today to abandon its Panther Creek Valley anthracite mine operations.

ATLANTA, June 24 -- Because of the part he played in the Supreme Court segregation case, Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. will not be invited to address the National Association of Attorneys General in their next convention, Georgia's Attorney General Eugene Cook declared today.

CHICAGO, June 24 (UP) -- Billy Pierce worked two and two-thirds hitless innings in relief today to preserve Sandy Corsuegra's ninth victory of the year as the Chicago White Sox beat the Washington Senators, 5 to 2. It was Pierce's second appearance since May 25 when the lefthander went to the sidelines with a sore arm.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 24 -- Following is the text of a message from the Foreign Minister, Guillermo Toriello, of Guatemala yesterday to the Secretary General of the United Nations, Dag Hammarskjold:

A permanent injunction restraining Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, A. F. L., from picketing Stations WOR and WOR-TV was issued yesterday by Justice Carroll G. Walter in Supreme Court. The pickets asserted sought to force the stations to hire instrumentalists.
GUATEMALA, June 24 (AP) -- Harold Von Broekhoven, evangelist who was born in Pasaic, N. J., said his radio station was knocked off the air when strafed by a fighter plane.

A ten-year campaign begun last year to clear away the remaining racial barriers by Jan. 1, 1963 -- the centennial of Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation -- is described in the 1953 annual report of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

President Eisenhower was criticized yesterday for having failed to choose engineers for appointment to the St. Lawrence River Joint Board of Engineers. The criticism came from the Engineers Joint Council and was coupled with a request that the President name at least one engineer to a five-member group that will serve in the development of the St. Lawrence River.

The high cost of polio prevention and an incidence of new cases greater this year than at any previous time have caused the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis to schedule an emergency appeal for funds.
The fair trade principle, which permits manufacturers to fix retail prices on their products in most of the country, has just won two smashing court victories.
BONN, Germany, June 24 -- A conference of the six countries that signed the European Defense Community Treaty has been called in Brussels to try to prevent the project from dying.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Profit-taking, headed off small rallies in wheat in the early trade today, and prices receded quite sharply from the initial tops. On a reaction of about 1 cent there was fair commission support however, and the market steadied.

LONDON, June 24 -- The stock markets here today continued yesterday's irregularity. Business contracted and some of the industrial shares that have made the biggest gains recently slipped back during the morning under profit-taking. However, many of the losses were wiped out later and nearly all groups closed firm, although price movements were still irregular.
LONDON, June 24 (Reuters) -- A campaign has begun to stop the sandy advances of the Sahara [shaded area on map].

PARIS, June 24 -- Aristotle Socrates Onassis denied today that any aspects of his agreement with Saudi Arabia were monopolistic or discriminatory, or that fuel prices would be increased because of it.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 24 -- The National Liberation movement of Col. Carlos Castillo Armas announced tonight that a bloody battle was raging for Chiquimula, railway town in eastern Guatemala. It said Government troops were being reinforced by artillery, mortars and machine guns.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 24 -- Malay, a 39 1/2-foot yawl belonging to D. D. Strohmeier of South Dartmouth, Mass., was the winner of the Bermuda Trophy on corrected time as the biennial race from Newport ended tonight.

ALBANY, June 24 -- Dr. G. Orville Johnson has been named to head the State Mental Health Commission's new pilot study to determine the extent to which severely mentally retarded children can be educated and trained.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Following is the 45-to-32 roll-call vote by which the Senate today rejected an amendment to substitute a liberalized three-year trade act for the Administration's one-year extension bill:
A new Reserve program for the armed forces, which would require for the first time in our history conscription for the Reserves as well as for active duty, was officially launched last week.
The ballroom of the Governor Clinton Hotel was set a-ringing yesterday with the tintinnabulation of many bells.

FOUR more group exhibitions in galleries have been added to the local summer art attractions. Four painters and two sculptors are represented in the exhibition at Kraushaar's, each by both early and late work. The surprise here is in the painting of Andree Ruellan whose style has undergone a striking development.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., June 24 -- Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells today added a one-over-par 74 to her first-round 75 for a total of 149 in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's 54-hole medal play championship.
A lake community in Orange County is to be formally opened this week-end with the display of three model houses. The development is off Route 17-A in the Village of Warwick, N.
This is the story of a shepherd, wearer of Police Shield 6330, and how much he will be missed at the teeming intersection of Twenty-first Street and Tenth Avenue.

The Long Island Rail Road will be able to buy new air-conditioned cars for its commuter service faster than was planned when the Legislature approved its rehabilitation program, Walter S. Franklin, the line's president, announced yesterday.
Social, civic and religious organizations were urged yesterday to take action against the increase of inter-cultural and inter-religious tensions in the Washington Heights section of upper Manhattan.
Operations of the Seeger Refrigerator Company in the nine months ended on May 31 resulted in a net income of $4,498,852, according to the report issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- State Department officials said tonight that nothing in the Soviet note substantiated the charge against this Government. They indicated Washington would reject the charge as being without foundation.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 4 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The Nassau Hotel, a 15-room building on plot ?5 by 100 feet at 56 to 60 East Fifty-ninth Street has been acquired by a syndicate represented by Louis Schesinger, attorney. faurice Renard and William lV[. Cooper were the brokers and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Percy Bassett of Philadelphia and Lulu Perez of Brooklyn will meet in the feature bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. The fight is scheduled for twelve rounds and the winner will be recognized by the New York State Athletic Commission as the logical contender for Sandy Saddler's world featherweight championship.
The Transit Authority approved yesterday the expenditure of $1,069,000 for improvements this year to the subway system.
HOUSTON, June 24 (AP) -- Eddie Merrins of Louisiana State burned up the Brae Burn course today as the National Collegiate golf tournament field was cut to eight players.
The Board of Education asked yesterday for a record $108,425,000 to construct twenty-seven new schools and modernize ten existing structures.

Last night's concert at Lewisohn Stadium by Sir Adrian Boult and the Stadium Symphony Orchestra presented not one but two soloists -- Michael Rabin, violinist, who had been scheduled to appear originally, and Henri Deering, pianist, whose appearance Wednesday evening was postponed on account of rain.

A GREAT thirst came upon David Bronstein, one of the Russian chess masters, during the match at the Roosevelt Hotel the other day. He asked for a drink: "A glass of lemon juice." One of the Americans tried to correct him and said: "You mean a glass of lemonade -- lemons, water and sugar."

ANKARA, Turkey, June 23 -- Inflation is threatening Turkey. A housewife finds it reflected in the high prices and empty shelves at grocery and butcher shops. The Government of Premier Adnan Menderes sees it in Turkey's dwindling foreign exchange reserves and soaring indices.

LONDON, June 24 -- Jaunty and smiling, Sir Winston Churchill and Anthony Eden left tonight by plane for the Washington discussions with President Eisenhower. The British Government regards these talks as the most important British-United States exchanges since the end of World War II.

The moves within the Senate to protect itself and the nation from further abuses of Mr. McCarthy's power are serious moves, seriously intended. Before the end of this session the McCarthy issue in some form or another ought to come to a vote, no matter what Messrs. Knowland and Lyndon Johnson, respectively, may think is "smart politics" at the moment.

It is a commentary on the state of the world today that the most remarkable fact about the 12,000-mile trip through much of Siberia recently made by this newspaper's Moscow correspondent, Harrison E. Salisbury, is that it happened. No one here is surprised when a foreigner visits Chicago, Minneapolis, Denver and Salt Lake City.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Churchill-Eisenhower talks begin at the White House tomorrow in an atmosphere of pessimism and doubt that the free world can agree on a program of united action in Southeast Asia.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 24 (Reuters) -- Britain re-entered the Iranian market today with a $14,000,000 contract for 100,000 tons of rails and other rail equipment.

An effective veto of a Queens zoning change in the Board of Estimate by Bronx Borough President James J. Lyons yesterday brought a charge by James A. Lundy, Borough President of Queens, that Mr. Lyons was not voting "in good faith."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 24 --- Malayan mine production of tin in concentrates during April was 5,024 long tons, the International Tin Study Group reported here today. The totals for Indonesia and the Belgian Congo were 2,684 and 1,321 tons, respectively.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (UP) -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, said today that the Internal Revenue Service had collected only $1,669,132 of $44,626,822 owed by 180 delinquent taxpayers in New York City.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 -- Organized medicine today reaffirmed its opposition to "fee splitting," but voted it ethical for two or more doctors in a case to submit a joint itemized bill if the patient requests it.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Government has been swindled out of millions of dollars through false parental dependency claims by servicemen, the House of Representatives was informed today.

LONDON, June 24 -- Morehead Patterson, United States representative on the subcommittee of the United Nations Disarmament Commission, said today that the ending of the talks here did not mean a final breakdown in disarmament discussion.
The winning streak of Extra Points, the excellent jumper owned by Col. Lafayette Henry Nelles of Toronto, reached an inglorious end yesterday.

In a three-to-two decision, the Brooklyn Appellate Division yesterday reversed a ruling by Supreme Court Justice George A. Arkwright that the new Kings County Assembly District lines as set up by the City Council were unconstitutional.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 23 -- Japan is shifting her foreign trade from the United States and Europe to Asia as a result of the increasingly unfavorable balance of trade with the West.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 24 -- New oil traces have been found by West Australian Petroleum Proprietary, Ltd., in its well at Rough Range on the coast of Western Australia where the first strike was made last December.

SAN JUAN, P. R., June 24 -- The annual organized migration of Puerto Rican seasonal farm workers to the mainland is just about at its midpoint. Today the major contracting agency forecast a 20 per cent drop in the movement that earned $6,000,000 for Puerto Ricans last year, or a loss of $1,000,000 in income.
Herbert L. Brickman, $9,100-a-year director of veterans activities, was ousted yesterday by Mayor Wagner. The dismissal is effective next Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- President Eisenhower invited Arthur H. Vandenberg Jr. and sixteen other guests to a White House stag dinner tonight.

A fear of ideas, books and Communist hunters has created anxiety and confusion among the American people, Dr. Alvin C. Eurich, vice president of the Ford Foundation's Fund for the Advancement of Education, warned yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Competition will close 50 per cent of the country's retail furniture stores within ten years and 30 per cent of upholstered furniture manufacturers within two or three years, a Chicago manufacturer said today.
Now that the Army-McCarthy hearings are ended, it may be appropriate to comment on the conduct of those Republicans who constituted the responsible majority of the special subcommittee.

NEW DELHI, India, June 24 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and Chou En-lai, Premier of Communist China, are expected to discuss an Asian consultative committee and extension of a "peace area" in this part of the world.

CLEVELAND, June 24 (UP) -- Arnold Portocarrero held the league-leading Indians to five singles today and the Philadelphia Athletics won the rubber game of their series, 5 -- 1, for their ninth victory in twelve games. As a result, Cleveland's lead over the second-place White Sox was cut to two games.

LONDON, June 24 -- Prime Minister Churchill was bitterly cirticized in the House of Commons today when he announced that his Government did not feel justified in the present circumstances in increasing the salaries of members from 1,000 ($2,800) a year to 1,500.

BANFF, Alberta, June 24 (AP) -- Although the Pacific Northwest Pipe Line Corporation of Houston, Tex., received a permit to ship natural gas to the northwestern United States, the decision of West Coast Tranmission Company to appeal the ruling will probably postpone work on the project for a year or more. This was the opinion of a number of gas executives attending the Canadian Gas Association convention at Banff yesterday.

Amazing Willie Mays once again hit a home run at the Polo Grounds yesterday and this one really paid off. For, unlike the one that had gone to waste on Wednesday, Willie the Wonder's No. 23 was struck with a runner on base into the upper left tier and lifted the Giants to a 2-1 victory over the Braves' Warren Spahn.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 24 -- Burt Lancaster and Harold Hecht, his partner in independent film production, have disclosed that they are thinking big in terms of casting their projected picturization of "The Way West," Pulitzer Prize novel by A. B. Guthrie Jr.

PARIS, June 24 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France told the National Assembly today that agreement on the terms of an armistice in Indochina might come before agreement on the political future of the country.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active yesterday with heavy trading in old July, which declined 30 points on the day. Other months closed 6 points higher to 6 points lower than on Wednesday.

GEORGETOWN, Conn., June 24 -- This is a village with its own post office and fire department. But despite the pride of its 1,800 residents, Georgetown does not exist legally. It has no land. It is all part of the towns of Redding, Weston, Wilton and Ridgefield.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Former President Hoover counseled the American people tonight to cherish nationalism as a "great spiritual force." He declared that love of country was a source of strength that would help keep Americans free.
The Pennsylvania General State Authority announced yesterday that it plans to offer for public sale on July 15 an issue of $30,000,000 of serial revenue bonds to finance general improvements.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 24 (AP) -- Bolero finished spectacularly after being struck by a squall on approaching the finish line. The squall left her windless. With her big sail slapping about limp, she turned a complete slow circle, which gave the race committee reason to believe she did not intend to finish.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Colorado Springs was selected today as the site for the new Air Force Academy.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 24 (AP) -- The Chilean Foreign Ministry announced today that a two - engine Chilean civilian plane had been shot down while being ferried over Guatemala from Tapachula, Mexico, to San Salvador.

MENLO PARK, Calif., June 24 (AP) -- The Exchange Club here has disbanded by a 30-1 vote rather than oust a Chinese member. A National Exchange Club spokesman denied that any racial discrimination was involved.
Pork prices are down this week. The New York City Department of Markets reports declines of 2 to 6 cents a pound on a variety of cuts.

The Greater New York Fund announced yesterday that contributions in the 1954 campaign to raise $9,000,000 have passed the halfway mark. The city's business community has donated thus far $5,338,872, it was reported.
The new tax bill will be of great aid to the small business man, a government official said yesterday.

Industrial stocks represented in The New York Times average jumped 2.97 points yesterday to 355.18, the best closing level since Oct. 26, 1929. The high point of the day was 356.00, still below the 1930 top of 358.16, set on April 10 of that year.

Stockholders of the Pittsburgh Metallurgical Company, Inc., at a meeting in Buffalo yesterday approved an increase in the authorized shares from 300,000 to 1,000,000. This paves the way for a split of the outstanding stock on a two-for-one basis. The par value of the common stock was also reduced from $5 to $2.50.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Oveta Culp Hobby, today urged the Senate to reverse the House and put 150,000 medical doctors under Social Security.

DETROIT, June 24 -- Tom Morgan never has lost to the Detroit Tigers. Ned Garver rarely beats the Yankees. It was, therefore, hardly a surprise that the Yankees walloped the Tigers, 11 -- 2, today and an hour later the champions were riding the rails to Cleveland still in third place but only four lengths behind the pace-setting Indians.

By the sale of a new issue of first mortgage bonds the Consumers Power Company arranged yesterday to replace $25,000,000 of 3 3/4 per cent bonds with a new issue of like amount bearing an interest rate of only 3 per cent.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., June 24 (UP) -- E. D. (Ted) Crippa, a business man and veteran Republican party worker, was appointed by Gov. C. J. Rogers today to complete the unexpired term of the late Senator Lester C. Hunt, a Democrat.
Richard H. Balch, Democratic State Chairman, declared yesterday that the opening of a 115-mile section of the State Thruway by Governor Dewey was "nothing more than an election year publicity stunt."

BOSTON, June 24 -- Any three-way merger of the American Woolen Company, the Bachmann Uxbridge Worsted Corporation and Textron, Inc., is "probably off," Joseph B. Ely, president of American Woolen, said today.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Senate approved a straight one-year extension of the reciprocal Trade Agreements Act tonight.
The clamorous screeching of a parrot named Polly sent three stick-up men in pell-mell retreat from a home in Queens last night.

The Ford Motor Company and the Radio Corporation of America each will sponsor forty-five minutes of the hour and a half program in the N. B. C.-TV network series of Monday night color shows scheduled to start Oct. 18. The thirteen-program series will be seen every fourth Monday beginning at 8 o'clock.

Last fall the Russians, through their Minister in Bern, put in for membership in the I. L. O. They were turned down, largely because they attached conditions to their membership. They refused to admit the jurisdiction of the World Court in disputes arising from I. L. O. membership.

Discussions that are taking place between the National Federation of Textiles, Inc., and the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute have nothing to do with the promotion or merchandising of textile fibers, according to a joint statement issued yesterday.
New York bank loans to business resumed their prolonged decline during the week ended on Wednesday, dropping $33,000,000.

Your editorial in the issue of The Times for June 20 entitled "Help for Medical Schools" is indeed pertinent to the present crisis in medical education. It brings forth the fact that whereas private enterprise has totaled $2,500,000 of new money during the past year, what actually is needed is $10,000,000.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, said today he had asked the Pentagon to explain its failure to grant two members of the Senate Investigations subcommittee staff security clearance to examine classified documents.

MOSCOW, Friday, June 25 -- The Soviet Union has charged that a United States destroyer intercepted the Soviet tanker Tuapse off Formosa and compelled the ship to change course. The Tuapse's fate was unknown to Moscow, the Government said.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 24 -- A special committee of the State Bar Association recommended tonight that lawyers who continued membership in officially designated subversive organizations be denied the right to practice.
TAIPEI, Formosa, June 24 (AP) -- Top jobs in Nationalist China's Army, Air Force and Navy were shuffled today and President Chiang Kai-shek's elder son was left without a job.

Management of the Union Pacific Railroad this year has put a tight check rein on operating expenses. While the road's revenues declined again last month, the traffic loss was more than offset by reductions in the cost of running the system.
CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows.
The strikebound carpet factory of Alexander Smith, Inc., Yonkers' chief industry since Civil War days, will be shut down permanently, the company announced yesterday.

Another attempt to break the deadlook on disarmament ended in failure yesterday when the subcommittee of the United Nations Disarmament Commission, which had been meeting in London, announced its inability to solve the problem and referred it back to the parent body.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 707,208 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (UP) -- Earl Torgeson's bases-loaded single off the glove of Steve Bilko drove home Del Ennis from third in the eleventh inning to give the Phillies a 3-2 victory over the Cubs tonight. It was Chicago's seventh straight loss.

CAIRO, June 23 -- Growing Israeli hostility toward United Nations personnel along the Jordanian frontier is evident in United Nations truce observers' reports. These reports state that Israeli soldiers had threatened to shoot them in Israeli territory and an Arab Legion surgeon in Jordanian territory during the investigation on June 19 of a border clash in the Wadi Fukeen-Husan area southwest of Jerusalem.
There were no takers yesterday when the city offered to sell its ninety-one-year-old Yorkville Magistrates Court Building at 153 East Fifty-seventh Street for a minimum of $500,000.
A 61-year-old man routed two bandits in his Brooklyn grocery store last night but suffered a bullet wound in the neck while grappling with the assailants.
LONDON, June 24 (Reuters) -- Communist China offered, in an official statement today, to "commute" the sentences of Americans held in Chinese jails provided they "behave properly in prison."

IT IS not often that a television drama may achieve some success on theatrical grounds and at the same time be challenged on the larger question of sound public policy. Such is the case, however, with Tuesday night's presentation of "Fearful Decision" on the Theatre Guild-United States Steel drama hour over the A. B. C. network.

Blueberry pickers in southern New Jersey are harvesting the first of the big, blue cultivated varieties that will predominate in local markets from now through middle August. Supplies will reach their peak next month, and prices undoubtedly will drop from present levels.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- When Secretary of State Dulles today read the published excerpts from Foreign Secretary Eden's speech in Commons yesterday he was "upset." That description trickled out of the huddle in the State Department that was called to talk over the speech, which apparently couldn't have been more of a surprise to the huddlers.

THINKING about war and peace and the various sinister probabilities that the immediate future holds (as who of us is not daily?) Sir John Slessor, Marshal of the Royal Air Force, has reached several positive conclusions. These may be divided roughly into a series of comments on the grim necessities of life in a brutal age and some specific proposals.

THIS is it. That intrepid pioneer, Daniel Boone Stengel, has guided his valiant little band through the wilderness to the shores of Lake Erie. Tonight his men will come to grips with a tribe of marauding Indians, who are led by a merciless chief, Pennant-in-the-Eye Lopez. The depredations of the not so noble redmen have been alarming this year.
GUATEMALA, June 24 (AP) -- A Guatemalan Army spokesman said tonight the main resistance of the invading forces had been broken.
LONDON, Friday, June 25 (UP) -- A "significant and steadily rising" lung cancer death rate among doctors, who smoked was reported today by the British Medical Journal.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges generally eased yesterday. Coffee, cocoa, sugar, soybean oil, silk, burlap, zinc and copper were off; hides, rubber, tin and cottonseed oil ended mixed, and wool, potatoes and lead rose. Hides had the largest volume of sales since April 27.
MOSCOW, June 24 (AP) -- The text of the Soviet note regarding the tanker Tuapse follows:...

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Northern Natural Gas Company of Omaha, Neb., asked authority of the Securities and Exchange Commission today to sell $25,000,000 of sinking fund debentures through an underwriting group headed by Blyth Co.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Net income of Illinois Bell Telephone Company in the quarter ending June 30 is expected to about equal the $8,207,000. earned in the corresponding period a year ago, W. W. Kahler, president, reported today.

Eight hundred apartments especially designed for older persons will be available by the end of next year in city and state housing projects now under construction in New York, George W. Biro, assistant secretary of the New York City Housing Authority, announced yesterday.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 24 -- Volunteer workers, struggling to protect the center of this city from the overflowing Des Moines River were encouraged today as the flood's crest reached emergency levees and was kept within bounds.

One of these days Frank Loesser and Garson Kanin will get together to write an original musical comedy. Mr. Loesser wrote the songs for such popular entertainments as "Where's Charley?" and "Guys and Dolls," while Mr. Kanin, a topflight playwright-director, hasn't been connected previously with the musical stage.
Louis B. Saperstein, an insurance broker suspected of complicity in union welfare rackets, was disclosed yesterday to have told a grand jury that he collected $500,000 in commissions last year.

C. S. Forester, creator of Horatio Hornblower, has written a series of short stories based on "sworn evidence presented at the Nuremberg and Belsen trials." In an introductory note the author says that during the Nazi regime "crimes were committed -- usually quite legally, according to the letter of the law of the land -- which make those of Jack the Ripper and Landru appear quite insignificant."

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 24 -- Secrecy in technical matters is a poison that can destroy us, Dr. Lloyd V. Berkner warned today at hte first International Congress on Nuclear Engineering. The congress, sponsored by the American Institute of Chemical Engineers is being held at the University of Michigan.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Guatemala has turned aside "on principle" a proposal by the Inter-American Peace Committee for a fact-finding investigation of charges by Guatemala that she is the victim of aggression.
TRENTON, June 24 -- Evidence was mounting tonight that the defalcations of former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman may have far exceeded the $300,000 embezzlement to which he confessed.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 24 -- The United Nations Security Council will meet tomorrow afternoon to take up the Guatemalan case again. Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States delegate and Council President for June, late today summoned the eleven-member Council to meet here at 3 P. M.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 24 -- Frank K. Stevens of Wykagyl shot a four-over-par 38, 38 -- 76 to win the Westchester Seniors Golf Association spring tournament over the east course of the Winged Foot Club today.

GRANVILLE, Ohio, June 24 -- Representatives of more than 450 church-related colleges and universities, "in repentence and humility," today called on the Christian colleges of the nation to clean house.

THE water as well as the fishing pressure has been reduced on most of the popular Catskill trout streams, and a glance at the reports yesterday indicated clearly that the Esopus undoubtedly would be the best bet for the week-end.
A rubber waterproofing that "breathes" was introduced yesterday at the Statler Hotel by the Aldan Rubber Company of Philadelphia.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 24 -- The General Council of the Congregational Christian Churches adopted here today, with some grave misgivings, a resolution paving the way toward a constitution for the denomination.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Senate Agriculture Committee rejected today the Administration's request for a flexible Federal price support system on farm products.

Sir Winston Churchill, due to arrive in the United States today by air, would not be coming if there were a perfect agreement and understanding between our two countries. At 79 one does not make such journeys for the fun of it. Sir Winston and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden are coming because they judge it necessary to do so.

The United States chess players, after losing three rounds to their Russian opponents in the international series at the Roosevelt Hotel, finished the fourth and last round yesterday with a 4 -- 4 score as the tournament ended with a 20-12 victory for the visitors.
The Board of Estimate handed out generous pay rises to city employes yesterday and created several new jobs.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 24 (AP) -- Representative W. Sterling Cole, Republican of upstate New York and chairman of the Joint Congressional Atomic Committee, today urged immediate American initiative toward creating an international peacetime atomic agency based on President Eisenhower's atomic pool proposal -- even without Russia's participation.
Forty detectives sought yesterday a motive for the slaying Wednesday in Greenwich Village of Edwin B. Whitmarsh, 73-year-old secretary - treasurer of the American Economic Foundation.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 24 -- There were indications here tonight that Honduras intended to declare Guatemalan Ambassador Amadeo Chinchilla persona non grata tomorrow as a result of the bombing incident at San Pedro.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The long-awaited House Judiciary Subcommittee report on civil rights investigations in New York City, soon to be released, taxes George P. Monaghan, former Police Commissioner, with "lack of forthrightness."
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Significant support emerged in Congress today for a move to block use of the United States foreign aid funds to support a "Locarno Pact" for Southeast Asia.

PARIS, June 18 -- Flattened tweeds are one of the excitements of French woolens for next winter. Paris calls them "smashed" tweeds. They look as if a steam roller had been in action until nubs are like flecking on a broadcloth surface.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- During the week ended June 23, member bank reserves decreased $89,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Capt. George Clancy of the trim new excursion boat Miss Liberty kept his record clear yesterday. He had made 60,000 visits to Bedloes Island as skipper of the older excursion vessel Liberty, and had never set foot inside the famous statue, which a million sightseers are expected to visit this year.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 24 -- Philippe Washer of Belgium switched on the full power of his big game today and blasted sixth-seeded Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., out of the all-England lawn tennis championships before a crowd of 28,000.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Eisenhower - Churchill meeting, starting tomorrow, is being discussed, as usual, in terms of personalities and political differences, but the common dangers and common interests of the principal Allies transcend all differences and all personalities.

Robert D. Murphy, Deputy Under Secretary of State, asserted last night that the Near East could not become a "vigorous partner" of the free world until stronger progress had been made toward creating peaceful relations between Israel and the Arab states.

Twelve-year-old Frances Cwibeker is making good in her adopted land. Yesterday, four years after she had come to this country with her family from Poland, she received the Children's Aid Society's sixteenth annual ward as "The Most Dependable Teen of 1954."

GUY LOMBARDO, who has managed to satisfy countless numbers as an impresario of dance music, now has turned his hand to producing theatrical entertainment. With the assistance of his brothers, Carmen and Lebert, he made his debut last night with "Arabian Nights" at the Jones Beach Marine Theatre.
For the past year I have been an exchange professor in France, living among my students and my colleagues, traveling extensively through the provinces, getting to know people in all walks of life.

Expenditures for newspaper advertising set a record last year, according to a study by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association. They were estimated at $2,655,500,000, or 8 per cent more than in 1952.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The United States Government has protested to Saudi Arabia against an agreement granting Aristotle Socrates Onassis oil transportation concessions.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 24 -- The perennial titleholder, Mrs. Reinert G. Torgerson of Cherry Valley, defeated Mrs. Mortimer May, Middle Bay, 2 up, in the semi-finals of the Women's Long Island Golf Association match play championship at the Meadow Brook Club today.

Martin T. Lacey, leader of 100,000 unionized teamsters in this city, ended his two-year-old feud with Dave Beck, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L. The rift between the two union chiefs had been a major factor in the failure of the American Federation of Labor to defeat the old International Longshoremen's Association on the New York docks.

A judgment of $819,299 was awarded to the owners of the Liberty-type vessel Armar by Justice Benjamin J. Rabin in State Supreme Court yesterday in an unusual suit involving Lloyd's of London and thousands of defendants.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., June 24 (AP) -- Dr. Cary Middlecoff of Memphis Tenn., one of the nation's top pros, fired a six-under-par 65 today to set the pace in the opening round of the four-day, seventy-two-hole $15,000 Insurance City open golf tournament.
CHICAGO, June 24 -- "A wholesome new style" was the description given to contemporary furniture design in a speech here today by William E. S. Griswold Jr., president of W. J. Sloane of New York.

Nikita S. Khrushchev, first secretary of the Central Committee of the Soviet Union's Communist party, apparently deviated from the party line in a Prague speech June 15, but the Soviet press published a version of the speech that differed significantly from what Mr. Khrushchev actually had said.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The nation's cartoonists today praised President Eisenhower for "a sense of decency." He in turn said they helped keep America "straight and true and strong."

The Great Northern Paper company, one of the nation's largest manufacturers of newsprint, is planning to raise about $10,000,000 through the sale of preferred stock to finance additional funds for its program of expansion and new facilities.
ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., June 24 -- Charles Slicklen Jr., the medalist from Georgetown University, moved into the semi-final round of the Metropolitan Golf Association's junior championship today.
With home runs accounting for the bulk of the scoring by both sides, the Dodgers defeated the Redlegs, 9 -- 6, at Ebbets Field yesterday to remain one game behind the league-leading Giants.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., June 24 -- Along the trail blazed by pioneers two hundred years ago, Governor Dewey today dedicated its twentieth century projection -- the New York State Thruway. Throughout the long ceremonial day as he traveled over the 115-mile segment being opened to toll traffic, the Governor stressed one theme.

There is nothing surprising in the special message President Eisenhower sent to Congress in support of the new $3.5-billion foreign-aid program. Nor was there anything surprising in the favorable response in the House of Representatives to this year's proposals.

Today more than 1,000,000 American servicemen are garrisoned overseas, in almost every corner of the world. For most of these young men serving in strange lands the cold-war vigil is a lonely task. The touch of home they find through United Serice Organizations centers means more than ever before.
SEPT ILES, Que, June 24 -- The three-year struggle to wrest Labrador's rich iron ore deposits from the northern wilderness was completed today.

GENEVA, June 24 -- A concrete study of the military aspects of a peace settlement in Laos got under way here today between Communist and non-Communist representatives. Delegates of the French-Laotian high command and the Vietminh command met for the first time to consider ways to achieve a cease-fire and the withdrawal of foreign troops in the territory of Laos.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- A Government attorney today agreed to suspension of deportation proceedings against Jacob Burck, Chicago newspaper cartoonist, but left up to the Board of Immigration Appeals a request that they be canceled.

HONG KONG, June 24 (AP) -- The Hong Kong Supreme Court today ordered a Belgian Bank to pay the China Mutual Trading Company 2,590,171 Hong Kong dollars ($455,870) in return for funds the United States Government blocked in New York to keep them out of Chinese Communist hands.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 25 -- Sir Philip McBride, acting Minister of External Affairs, conferred today with the High Commissioner for India, Gen. K. M. Cariappa, who was reported to have said in Brisbane this week that the white Australia policy was driving the people of India and Pakistan away from the British Commonwealth into the arms of communism.

NEW HAVEN, June 25 -- Tension within the Congregational Christian Churches, anxious to preserve their traditional parish independence, became increasingly evident here on the third day of the General Council's biennial meeting.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 25 -- New York State's Juvenile Delinquency Law is branding a generation of youthful offenders as "junior criminals," a leading Children's Court expert told the State Bar Association today.

During the closing months of the Second World War and for some years following high-level diplomatic conferences almost invariably inspired optimism and seemed to hold out hopes for agreement. More recently we have seen other conferences fall short of their advance publicity.

In your issue of June 22 there appeared an editorial entitled "Changing Street Names" criticizing the New York City Council for changing Livingston Place into Nathan D. Perlman Place and encouraging a movement to change the name back again.

DENVER, June 25 (UP) -- The Colorado University Board of Regents voted unanimously today to bring all professional and honorary fraternities under its 1947 ban against religious and racial discrimination.

TRENTON, June 25 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner charged today that a number of former associates of the late Harold G. Hoffman had sought to coerce him into calling off the investigation of Mr. Hoffman's administration of a state agency.

A salute is due to the Soviet chess masters for their brilliant team victory over this nation's best players at the meet just concluded. The merit of their performance is increased when it is realized, that they were playing in a strange country, after a long and tiring journey from their homeland.

The appeal for "friendship" between Soviet and American trade unions recently issued by the boss of the Soviet unions, N. A. Shvernik, will undoubtedly be answered properly by those in this country to whom it is addressed. The leaders of our great unions can scarcely have forgotten the long years during which they and their organizations have been assailed from Moscow as "betrayers of the working 'class" and "agents of capitalism."

OMAHA, June 25 (AP) - Col. C. J. Sanders, State Safety Patrol Chief, said late tonight that reports to him indicated sixteen to eighteen persons had been injured seriously tonight when the Rock Island Rocky Mountain Rocket, eastbound to Chicago, was derailed.
NEW DELHI, India, June 25 -- The prime ministers of India and Communist China began today a conference that is expected to influence decisively the policies of the Southeast Asian countries.

The regional Red Cross blood program received 718 pints of blood on Thursday. Included were 197 donated at the Fort Instrument Company, Dutch Kills Road and Jackson Avenue, Long Island City, Queens; 140 given by employes of the New York Public Library and the Mutual Broadcasting System, at the library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, and 137 at the New York Telephone Company, 230 West Thirty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Two organizations that the Attorney General has called Communist fronts were active today in opposing Government proposals designed to curb subversive activities.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 25 -- William Powell will join the cast of "Mr. Roberts" in the role of "Doc," played on the stage by Robert Keith.
A scorching sun beat down over the New York area yesterday, sending temperatures to a record high for the year and raising the specter of drought over Long Island and New Jersey.

To maintain the party coalition that brought about the defeat of former Representative Vito Marcantonio, members of the Tammany executive committee of the Eighteenth Congressional District yesterday designated Representative James G. Donovan for renomination.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Average primary market prices declined one-tenth of a point to 109.9 (1947-49=100) during the week ended Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

BOSTON, June 25 -- Joseph B. Ely, president of the American Woolen Company, said today that the proposed acquisition of the Bachmann Uxbridge Worsted Corporation had been cancelled by mutual agreement.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Two high State Department officials met with Aristotle Socrates Onassis in Washington on May 26 to hear the shipping magnate's case for his oil transport agreement with Saudi Arabia.

HANOI, Vietnam, June 25 (UP) -- Communist commandos have raided the Doson air base outside Haiphong, where more than 100 United States Air Force men service French warplanes, the High Command announced today.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 25 (AP) -- Only one of the seventyseven starters in the Newport-toBermuda ocean race had not been spotted today when the committee on the finish line pulled up anchor.

BERLIN, June 25 (Reuters) -- The Austro-Yugoslav film "Die Letzte Bruecke" (The Last Bridge) today won the David O. Selznick Golden Laurel Award for 1954. The prize was presented at the International Film Festival.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 25 (AP) -- William A. Rowan of 520 East Twentieth Street, Manhattan was awarded first prize of $300 in an essay contest on the American Constitution sponsored by the bar association.
LONDON, June 25 (Reuters) -- The head of the British Treasury gave a confident all-clear signal today to British industrialists worried about a possible recession in the United States.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Senate gave final Congressional approval today to President Eisenhower's "new look" defense budget.
CHICAGO, June 25 -- A sharp warning against indiscriminate building of shoppings centers was sounded today by Arthur Rubloff, chairman of Arthur Rubloff Co., Chicago real estate developer.
More than 1,500 perspiring workers last night staged what civil defense officials called a model air-raid test in a four-block area of the lower East Side.
SAN PEDRO, Calif., June 25 (UP) -- One of the largest fires in Los Angeles Harbor history raged out of control at the Tide-water Association Oil Company docks tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 25 -- An oil painting by the late Howard Chandler Christy, placed on view today in the Carnegie Endowment Building at 345 East Forty-Sixth Street, was revealed later as an embarrassment to its owner, the United Nations.
Alexander Smith, Inc., Yonkers carpet factory, clung fast yesterday to its decision to shut down.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 25 -- Guatemalan insurgent headquarters announced tonight that the provisional government of Col. Carlos Castillo Armas had been established at Chiquimula, between Esquipulas and Zacapa, and that a cabinet might be announced tomorrow.

A hold-up man who was arrested in Queens Thursday night when a parrot's screeching sounded the alarm was arraigned Yesterday on charges of robbery, felonious assault and violation of the Sullivan Law.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Senate warned "the international Communist movement" today to stay out of the Western Hemisphere. By a vote of 69 to 1 it adopted a manifesto that, in addition to warning communism, sought:

BALTIMORE, June 25 (UP) -- The combination of a four-run first inning and Dee Pillette's six-hit pitching carried the Baltimore Orioles to a 5-to-1 victory over the Philadelphia Athletics tonight. Dick Kryhoski of the Orioles ran his hitting streak to fifteen consecutive games.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Food and Drug Administration announced today the seizure of ten consignments of adulterated coffee from three New York companies and a Philadelphia concern.
Another boxing upset occurred last night when Percy Bassett, the Philadelphia featherweight, knocked out Lulu Perez of Brooklyn at Madison Square Garden.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 -- Stockholders of the San Francisco Bank today approved the purchase of the Central Bank of Oakland and the sale of 300,000 new shares in their bank to Transamerica Corporation.
Nathaniel L. Goldstein, the Attorney General of New York, yesterday went to the defense of Herbert Brownell Jr.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 25 -- Following is the text of a speech made before the United Nations Security Council today by Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., delegate of the United States:
Stan (The Man) Musial hit his twenty-third home run of the campaign at Ebbets Field last night but that was the only blow to damage Carl Erskine and the Dodgers.
BLOOMFIELD, N. J., June 25 -- Overcoming a four-stroke deficit, Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair retained the Women's New Jersey Golf Association championship at the Forest Hill Field Club today.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 7 to 17 points yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy has killed a proposal that some of its members say might have jeopardized newspaper men who reported public statements on atomic affairs.

Dr. Harry Soderman, former chief director of Sweden's National Institute of Technical Police and author of "Modern Criminal Investigation," has a new book on Funk Wagnall's list. It will be the story of his life as a criminologist and a study of a wide variety of crimes and criminals. As yet untitled, the book is planned for November publication.
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 25 -- Flood waters of the Des Moines River were moving slowly out of the heart of this city today after having reached the highest level on record.

ITHACA, N. Y., June 25 (AP) -- The seventy-five pilots of the Mohawk Airlines have voted unanimously for "a peaceful withdrawal of their services," Robert W. Jenkins, chairman of the Association, A. F. L., said today.

Lawsuits to prevent the city from Collecting the 5 per cent amusement tax on theatre tickets sold before July 1 for performances to be given on and after that date were begun yesterday in the Supreme Court.

JOHANNESBURG, June 22 -- South African government, business and gold mining leaders have been vying in enthusiasm over predictions of a South African boom. If the forecasts are realized, South Africa will again become one of the United States' best customers -- a role she held until import control was imposed in 1948 to offset the dwindling of dollar reserves.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The first day of the United States-British conversations produced little hope that any definitive agreement could be reached here this week-end on a security system for Southeast Asia.

From the land where women are called Noi Tuong ("minister of the interior") come the many objects of art and handicrafts that will be exhibited this evening at the Carnegie Endowment International Center, 345 East Forty-sixth Street.
John Golden, one of the main ingredients of the American theatre, will be 80 years old tomorrow.

City Council President Abe Stark said yesterday that lack of parking space in this city was shunting business into suburban areas. He urged that off-street facilities be provided by private enterprise to induce shoppers to remain here.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The House Merchant Marine Committee today ended public hearings on a bill to put at least 50 per cent of Federal-financed cargoes on privately owned American ships.
The importance of freedom of inquiry was stressed yesterday by the National Council of Chief State School Officers, meeting this week at its annual convention at the Biltmore Hotel.
ARDSLEY - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., June 25 -- The new Metropolitan amateur junior golf champion is Charles Slicklen Jr., a Georgetown University student.
ALBANY, June 25 (AP) -- The editor of a teachers' publication said tonight youth must be taught the force of ideas and ideals -- a force he called "more powerful than the atomic bomb."
CHICAGO, June 25 -- Deferred deliveries of corn and all oats futures were especially strong today, while wheat was under pressure. Some operators sold wheat and bought the coarse grains.
" It is the apparent position of the General Motors management and of the union that a man is not guilty until proven so." -- From a Detroit dispatch to this newspaper of June 20.

The city's director of veterans' activities, 31-year-old Herbert L. Brickman, announced yesterday that he would move in Supreme Court to prevent Mayor Wagner from dismissing him from his $7,850-a-year post. The Mayor disclosed on Thursday that he had informed Mr. Brickman that his tenure would end next Wednesday.

CAIRO, June 25 -- Eric Johnston said today "we have reached the ten-yard line" in negotiations with the Arabs looking to a unified plan for the development of the Jordan Valley water resources for Israel and the bordering Arab states.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, tore into the Agriculture Department today for making poultry loans to "poor little farmers," one of them "down to his last Cadillac" and another involved in a housing venture "to the extent of more than one million dollars."
MINNEAPOLIS, June 25 -- The importance of books in the battle against communism for men's minds was stressed here today at a round-table session of the American Library Association.
ANKARA, Turkey, June 25 -- Libya is now under serious consideration as a third member of the Turkish-Pakistani pact.
WESTBURY, L. I., June 25 -- One world record and two other track marks were set tonight on the Grand Circuit program at Roosevelt Raceway.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., June 25 (AP) -- Private enterprise is essential to the solution of the housing problems of European countries, according to Ronald J. Chinnock of Chicago, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- An invention patented this week permits its owner to throw a switch merely by expanding the muscles of his stomach.

Broad, uncluttered surfaces, strong silhouettes and unusual color combinations characterize the clothes created by Rudi Gernreich, young California designer, who is making his mark in the fashion world. When his patterns are placed on a cutting table, they look like a bold; abstract drawing.

Another vicious blow has been struck against the cause of music in America. Three unidentified thieves calmly drove into Lewisohn Stadium last Wednesday morning, loaded their truck with five tables built especially this year for the sole use of the music critics and drove off.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 25 (UP) -- The world's top amateur tennis players fretted in the dressing rooms of Wimbledon today while rain washed out the day's program of the All-England championships. The postponed matches will be crammed into tomorrow's schedule.
TORONTO, June 25 (Canadian Press) -- A 43-year-old record toppled tonight as foreign entries dominated the Canadian open track and field championships.
Industrial stocks yesterday rose to the highest level since Oct. 28, 1929.

PORI, Finland, June 25 (UP) -- John Landy, Australian miler, who on Monday set a world mile record of 3:58, fell 2 seconds short of equaling the world mark for two miles today, when he ran the distance in 8:42.4.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Patent Office issued this week to the Atomic Energy Commission Patent No. 2,681,883 for a method of recovering heavy water (deuterium oxide) from solution after it has been used in an atomic reactor.

LONDON, June 25 -- A fight to a finish over Aneurin Bevan's bid for leadership of British socialism became inevitable today when, for the third time, the Welsh leftwing radical was nominated for treasurer of the National Labor party.
The proposed new salary plan prepared by experts in Mayor Wagner's Administration for the benefit of 80,000 of the city's civil service employes ran into serious roadblocks yesterday.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Saturday, June 26 -- Nationalist China announced yesterday it had seized a Russian tanker because the ship was bound for "Communist bandit" Shanghai in defiance of the Nationalist blockade.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 25 -- The Guatemalan delegation reported today that the city of Guatemala was bombed at 5:30 P. M., New York time, by three planes, Dr. Eduardo Castillo-Arriola, Guatemalan representative, said he had been talking by telephone with Foreign Minister Guillermo Toriello during the attack.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., June 25 -- Three tied for medal honors today in the metropolitan district qualifying round for the New York State amateur golf championship. Joe Marra, former metropolitan titleholder; Bob Sweeny, ex-British amateur champion, and Tommy Goodwin, current state champion, returned 69's at the Leewood course to lead a field of seventy.

The address of Dr. Joseph L. Fink to the opening session of the Central Conference of American Rabbis as reported in The Times on June 23 presents a number of points which require clarification for the benefit not only of American Jews, but for Americans generally.

Impulsivo showed a liking for the distance in taking the Fort Hamilton, the classified handicap that served as the feature event at Aqueduct yesterday. Engaging nine others in the test of a mile and a sixteenth, Impulsivo scored by three-quarters of a length over Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin's Bradley.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 25 -- Brazil is facing strike trouble because the Supreme Court has suspended operation of the Presidential decree doubling minimum wages all over the country as of July 1.

VIENNA, June 25 (UP) -- A stray pigeon that detoured across the Iron Curtain into Czechoslovakia has returned with a message from "unbowed Pilsen" pleading with the West to continue its work against communism, Radio Free Europe said today.

About a month ago the Hon. David W. Peck, Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division First Department, delivered a very interesting address before the Bar Association of the City of New York. His remarks were directed toward the simplification of litigation procedures, and he addressed himself in particular to the problem of speeding up the disposition of litigated matters in the City of New York.
Efforts to reach Dr. Hiskey yesterday at his last-known address, 2 Grace Court, Brooklyn, were unsuccessful.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 25 -- The United Nations Security Council refused tonight to discuss the case of Guatemala again until the American republics had made their own investigation.

ATLANTA, June 25 (AP) -- An Amendment to the United States Constitution and elimination of the Supreme Court were suggested today as means of nullifying the decision striking down public school segregation.

PIKE, N. H. June 25 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, was labeled here today by the Conference of American Rabbis the "most flagrant and immoral symbol of the hysteria commonly known as McCarthyism."
NEW DELHI, India, June 25 -- India and the Union of South Africa will break off diplomatic relations effective July 1, the foreign office announced today.

LONDON, June 25 -- Stock market prices continued today their irregular course of the preceding two days. Although the undertone remained satisfactory, some of the industrial shares that had led the recent advance eased under profit taking.
The "New Look" for the Reserves, outlined in tentative form by Assistant Secretary of Defense John A. Hannah recently, has some grave disadvantages as well as some advantages.

Romeo Salta, formerly of the Chianti restaurant in Hollywood and the Mercurio in New York, recently started a new eating establishment under his own name at 39 West Fifty-sixth Street. It is unusually well decorated.
Another chapter in the colorful history of Willie Mays was written at the Polo Grounds last night as the Giants defeated the Cubs, 6 -- 2, to stay one game in front of the second-place Dodgers.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today announced the sale of $64,585,000 worth of Baltimore and Ohio Railroad bonds at an average price of 95 3/8.

KANSAS CITY, June 25 (UP) -- Dr. Wallace Graham went to Research Hospital tonight to take X-rays of former President Harry S. Truman's chest, but decided not to when he found Mr. Truman "resting well."

CLEVELAND, June 25 -- The Yankees, adhering to an old Yankee custom, tonight strolled boldly into Municipal Stadium, the home of the league-leading Cleveland Indians, and hammered a lot of enthusiasm out of the team they figured they must beat for a sixth straight pennant.

MOSCOW, June 25 -- Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov pledged to Guatemala today that the Soviet Union would take "all possible measures" to obtain enforcement of the United Nations Security Council cease-fire resolution.
An improved twelve-acre Arthur von Briesen Park on Staten Island, overlooking the Narrows, has been reopened to the public.

IN the lexicon of the fly fisherman the word Beaverkill takes up a greater space that might seem justified by the physical proportion of this winding ribbon of water, for many anglers judge the quality of the trout season on the basis of the fishing provided by this pleasant stream.
SEOUL, Korea, June 25 -- President Syngman Rhee gave assurance to the world today that his armies would not, for the time being at least, resort to warfare in an attempt to unify Korea.
James Wilson, 31-year-old Department of Sanitation engineer, was fatally wounded last night in the back yard of his home at 1122 University Avenue., the Bronx.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 -- The prospect of a nation with numerically 40 per cent more juvenile delinquents in 1960 than it had in 1952 was laid before the American Medical Asociation's convention today.
The police reported four payroll hold-ups yesterday, two in the Bronx, one in Brooklyn and another in Queens. The robbers escaped with a total of $12,617.
Wall Street analysts like positive statements. Patrick B. McGinnis, who was recently elected president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, is a man who speaks positively.

HONG KONG, June 25 -- Gen. Li Hsien-nien, vice chairman of the Central South China Administrative Committee, has been named to succeed Teng Hsiaoping as Finance Minister in the Peiping Government, the Peiping radio said tonight.
Net income of the Seaboard Air Line Railroad for the first five months this year declined $1,031,692 from that of the corresponding period last year. At the same time, the gross fell $5,656,250.

PARIS, June 25 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France told Belgian Ambassador Baron Guillaume today that he was against a proposed meeting in Brussels of the six nations comprising the projected European Defense Community.

The Very Rev. John B. Janssens of Rome, general of the Society of Jesus, has announced the appointment of the Very Rev. Thomas E. Henneberry, president of Bellarmine College, Plattsburg, N. Y., as provincial of the New York Province of the society.
PITTSBURGH, June 25 (UP) -- Ted Kluszewski drove in four runs with his eighteenth and nineteenth homers to pace the Cincinnati Redlegs to an 8-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.

New capital financing pending in the public market reflects a shrinkage in the issues of debt by state and local governments. However, in the corporate field a period of considerable activity lies ahead, with underwriters' commitments likely to be divided among debt issues and new blocks of preferred and common stock.
RICHMOND, Va., June 25 (UP) -- Gov. Thomas B. Stanley declared today that "I shall use every legal means at my command to continue segregated schools in Virginia."
The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., led by Michael J. Quill, won overwhelming support yesterday in a union representation election among the Transit Authority's 37,000 operating employes.

Men who make their living grappling with the noise problem sat down together yesterday and brooded about it. At least one thing is certain, according to speakers at the twenty-fifth anniversary celebration of the American Acoustical Society -- no one likes noise.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 25 -- Foreign Minister Jose Edgardo Valenzuela of Honduras declared tonight that authorities in border provinces had a standing order to round up Guatemalan insurgents who were violating the neutrality of Honduras.

The Russian Orthodox Church of North America last week rejected the latest effort of the Moscow Patriarch Alexei to reestablish his authority over 300,000 dissident Orthodox Church communicants on this continent, it became known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Federal Housing Administration suspended two more veteran officials today while charges of "serious irregularities" Were being investigated.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 -- A shipload of relief items for Korea, sent here by rail from all parts of the country, was "dedicated today at the motor vessel Korea, tied up beside fishermen's wharf. The ship is scheduled to sail next week.

DETROIT, June 25 (AP) -- Pete Runnels drove in two runs with a double and triple as Washington edged Detroit, 4 -- 3, tonight. The victory halted a three-game losing streak and moved the Senators to within one game of the fourth-place Tigers.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Sir Winston Churchill began secret talks with President Eisenhower today after having appealed for British-United States unity and an end to "misunderstandings."
WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) -Unemployment insurance claims dropped earlier this month to the lowest weekly levels so far this year except during holiday weeks.

CHICAGO, June 25 (UP) -- Bob Keegan tonight became the first American League pitcher to win eleven games. He held the Boston Red Sox to eight hits as the Chicago White Sox won, 6 -- 4, to pull within a game of the leading Cleveland Indians.

GENEVA, June 25 -- The negotiators on the organization and functioning of armistice control machinery for Indochina met for three and one-half hours today and decided to hold private discussions until Tuesday when another general conference will be held.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 25 -Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley gained her sixth title in the Women's Long Island Golf Association match play tournament today by defeating Mrs. Allan A. Ryan, The Creek, 9 and 8, in the thirty-six-hole final at the Meadow Brook Club.

Cocoa prices soared yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange to close at the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit higher in all months except the spot month. This contract has no limit and was up 110 points. Volume was 251 contracts. There was dealer and commission house buying, influenced by the sharply higher London market.

" About Mrs. Leslie," a Paramount romantic drama co-starring Shirley Booth and Robert Ryan and produced by Hal Wallis, will open Sunday evening at the Victoria Theatre. Daniel Mann directed from a screen play that Ketti Frings and Hal Kanter adapted from the Vina Delmar novel of the same name. Marjie Millar, Alex Nicol and Sammy White are among the supporting players.

Plans to establish a council of young people's organizations in the Eastern Orthodox Church have been announced here. The proposal was discussed last week at a conference at the headquarters of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America at 10 East Seventy-ninth Street.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., June 25 -- Mr. and Mrs. L. D. Cohen of Glen Oaks scored a 38, 41 -- 79 to win the Women's Cross-County Golf Association's first husband-and-wife championship and the Charles Stillman Memorial Trophy at the Glen Head Golf Club today.

When Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company, closed down abruptly for several weeks in 1897, among the thousands of employes thrown out of work was John Masefield, now Poet Laureate of England. The company took its present name on April 16, 1951.

Arthur Oppenheimer Jr. has purchased operating control of Oliver Kaufman, 40-year-old drapery converting firm here, of which he becomes president and general manager. The announcement was made yesterday by Mr. Oppenheimer and the firm's former partners, Samuel U. Oliver and Samuel S. Kaufman. The latter will remain in an active capacity as vice president. Mr. Oliver plans to retire.

What on earth is so wrong about ridding this country of Communists ? What has Senator McCarthy or his committee done except follow the rules and try to do, despite many obstacles, what every, Senator, big brass, Government employe and just plain citizen should be helping to do ?

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Concern over a possible Presidential veto caused the Agriculture Committee of the House of Representatives to strike from its "single package" farm bill today two major provisions on high price supports.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 25 -- Newly appointed Premier Ngo Dinh Diem arrived today and received an enthusiastic welcome from his Roman Catholic supporters. However, the great mass of the Saigon population stayed home.
The Sheffield Steel Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Armco Steel Corporation, will be consolidated with Armco on Wednesday.

Yesterday started out to be a bad day for Louis Magid, who runs a small fruit store at 250 West Eighty-sixth Street. The rent was due, some urgent bills had to be paid and he was missing $300 he had obtained the day before by cashing in some defense bonds.
Three attorneys and an accountant, all tax experts, were indicted yesterday on charges of giving $160,000 in bribes to avert criminal prosecution of clients in two tax evasion cases.

Next Thursday Robert L. Joseph, who owns the English rights to "La Guerre de Troie N'Aura Pas Lieu" ("The Trojan War Will Not Be Fought"), will be winging his way to London to conclude arrangements for its presentation there.

A consolidated net income of $2,827,894, equal to 30 cents a common share, was made by the Avco Manufacturing Corporation in the six months ended May 31. In the similar period of the previous year the net was $3,315,897, or 35 cents a share.

SAN JUAN, P. R., June 25 -- A proposal to stretch the Federal housing program by giving special consideration to Puerto Rican conditions won the endorsement today of Philip J. Cruise, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.

There is an element of unconscious irony in the timing of the ceremonial visit of the Chinese Communist Premier, Chou En-lai, to India. It happens to fall on the fourth anniversary of the Communist invasion of the Republic of Korea, aided and abetted by the regime that Premier Chou presents to the Indians as the hope of peace in Asia.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The National Association of Real Estate Boards called on Senate-House conferees today to discard President Eisenhower's public housing proposals. The association said private enterprise could take care of the nation's low-cost housing needs.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 25 -- Surrendering to public demand, the New York Telephone Company agreed at a hearing today to revert in November to one directory for Westchester and Putnam Counties and Greenwich, Conn.

OTTAWA, June 25 (Canadian Press) -- Talk of recession has left investors unshaken. A mid-year survey, made public today, shows they are determined to pour a record $5,826,000,000 into expansion of the Canadian economy this year.

CAMP LEJEUNE, N. C., June 25 (AP) -- Athletes representing the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Air Force gave three record breaking performances to mark the opening of the inter-service track and field championships on Liversedge Field today.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 25 -Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts charged at the opening session of the Democratic State convention here tonight that the Eisenhower Administration had "broken" many of the promises it made in the national campaign of 1952.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (UP) -- The Milwaukee Braves, backing Lew Burdette's five-hit pitching with a fifteen-hit attack moved into third place tonight by blanking the Phillies, 7-0. The victory put the Braves one-half game ahead of the Phillies.

PEAPACK, N. J., June 25 -Mr. and Mrs. Sigfrid Irl Lonegren and Mr. and Mrs. Wfiliam Fowler Van Deven.ter of Far Hfils gave jointly a dance tonight at the Essex Hunt Club here for their respective debutante daughters, Miss Sally Pleasants Lonegren and Miss Adelaide Chapman Yah Deventer.

Drastic revision of the world Zionist structure is necessary to effect "a solid and indivisible partnership between Jewish communities everywhere and Israel," the fifty-seventh annual convention of the Zionist Organization of America was told yesterday.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., June 25 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt of Houston shot a spectacular eleven-under-par 60 today to equal the Professional Golfers Association competitive record. He gained the lead with a two-round total of 131 as the $15,000 Insurance City Open reached the halfway mark.
Plans for a merger between the Bachmann Uxbridge Worsted Corporation and the American Woolen Company have been formally canceled.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Following is the text of a resolution, adopted by the Senate today, on Communist interference in the Western Hemisphere:

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 25 -- With Yehudi Menuhin as soloist and Antal Dorati, conductor of the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra, the first Pacific Coast Festival at Santa Barbara began auspiciously this afternoon with a Bach and Mozart concert presented at the Coral Casino of the Biltmore Hotel.

Yesterday this newspaper carried a Page One story on the action of the Senate Agriculture Committee in voting 8 to 7 for another year's extension of 90 per cent of parity price supports for basic farm commodities. The headline on the story read: "Senate Farm Unit Snubs Eisenhower."

Moscow's protest against the supposed seizure of a Soviet tanker by an American destroyer in the East China Sea appears to have been somewhat premature. It was, quite likely, an American-built destroyer, but it happened to be operating as a unit of the Chinese Nationalist Navy.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- One of the most defiant witnesses the House of Representative Committee on Un-American activities has encountered has asked to be heard again.
Recognizing that no one can be more discouraged than a newly recruited G. I. with a
FERRARA, Italy, June 25 -- It was estimated here today that nearly one-third of the 60,000 head of cattle affected by Ferrara's strike of dairymen will have to be destroyed because of starvation.

LONDON, June 26 -- Despite the freshet of commentary from Washington during the last week on the sins of British colonialism and the advisability of dividing United States-British relations into spheres of agreement and disagreement, it is safe to say that from the standpoint of Sir Winston Churchill, Anthony Eden and the rest of the Conservative Government, the central issue dividing the trans-Atlantic partners remains that of an approach to Communist China.

LONDON, June 26 -- Britain's foreign policy won emphatic national endorsement today and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, its molder and chief advocate at the current talks in Washington, was hailed as Prime Minister Churchill's political heir by another Conservative Cabinet minister.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 26 -- This started as a serene day at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club. The club burgee hung listlessly on its pole. The committee boat chugged out of the harbor right on schedule and only a moderately sized fleet was waiting at the rendezvous for a start.
The White-Young battle for control of the New York Central and other corporate dissensions illustrate the importance of directing the affairs of a corporation.

Zionism and its relationship to Israel as well as to Jewish communities throughout the world was discussed last night at the fifty-seventh annual convention of the Zionist Organization of America in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Dr. J. S. Weiner of Oxford University and Dr. K. P. Oakley of the British Museum report to the American Association of Physical Anthropologists that whoever "planted" the skull of the Piltdown Man made the mistake of doctoring a canine tooth so that it appeared to be worn.

The attempted revolution in Guatemala, of which we find it very hard to get news, was obviously designed to remove Communist influence. There are other and less violent ways of promoting the same object. One of them is the maintenance by other American republics of a firm position against foreign intrusion into American affairs.

GENEVA, June 26 -- Western sources at the Far Eastern conference here believe that the Communist-led Vietminh is going along unwillingly with the program for settling the Indochina war. This plan was set in motion last week as a result mainly of proposals from Chou En-lai.

IT is difficult to realize that barely nine months have passed since the movie projection process known as CinemaScope was formally presented to the public with the premiere of "The Robe." So intense has been the exploitation of this spectacular wide-screen device and so swift has been its road-testing with a considerable number and variety of films that both exhibitors and public have developed an almost casual familiarity toward it.

Contrary to popular belief, foreign language study is on the increase in the nation's college, a survey by the Modern Language Association of America has disclosed. The much advertised and greatly exaggerated trend away from foreign languages has been halted and reversed, according to a report issued recently by Dr. William R. Parker, executive secretary of the Modern Language Association.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., June 26 (UP) -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, made a bid tonight for union support with an attack on the labor policies of both the Republican national and State Administrations.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Sir Winston Churchill said at a White House luncheon today that patience as well as vigilance was necessary to cope with the problems of Communist imperialism.

OUR firmest convictions are apt to be the most suspect, they mark our limitations and our bounds. Life is a petty thing unless it is moved by the indomitable urge to extend its boundaries, Only in proportion as we are desirous of living more do we really live.
