And if he thinks of himself as the sum of all intelligence he should take a particularly long and thoughtful look at the stalks of corn growing there. That corn is a plant developed by men whose name and origin are lost in the misty past.
CAMP LEJEUNE, N. C., June 26 (AP) -- Five records fell today before a mass attack by track and field champions of the Army, Air Force, Marine Corps and Navy in the inter-service track meet here.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., June 26 -- "Citizen-soldiers" from New York City's metropolitan area began arriving today at Camp Drum, the 107,000-acre field training center near here.

DAZZLINGLY readable, Pamela Frankau's new novel presents a group of characters facing the Problem of Values with which all of us, in today's traditionless society, must grapple. Miss Frankau's skill has enabled her to clothe this serious theme with an entertaining story.
STANTON, Del., June 26 (AP) -- Parlo, a long shot from William du Pont's Foxcatcher Farms, easily won the $47,625 Delaware Oaks for 3-year-old fillies at Delaware Park today.

TO this day there remain several areas of mystery in the life of John Paul Jones. (For one thing, just when and just why did he add Jones to his original Scottish name of John Paul?) In spite of his own voluminous and often heated correspondence; in spite of official records of the time, which, to be sure, were often poorly preserved, no one can say for sure exactly what kind of man he was.

Biggest news for the more than 11,000 physicians attending the 103d annual meeting of the American Medical Association here last week and for their patients back home was the report of the American Cancer Society on death rates among cigarette smokers.

A further attempt to make real political progress in Vietnam is marked in the appointment and return to Saigon of a new Premier. He is Ngo Dinh Diem, leader of a substantial Roman Catholic group, a strong-minded nationalist and a strong anti-Communist. He is pledged to work for national unity and for fully implemented independence.

EACH book in The True Adventure Library -- a new series -- is a collection of stories based on facts about individuals or groups of people, each story complete in itself. The reader may skip about, reading first whatever strikes his fancy, as he might with most volumes of short stories.

BONN, Germany, June 25 -- The first major test of popular feeling toward the policies of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer since the Bundestag election of last September will take place Sunday. More than one-quarter of the West German electorate will be entitled to cast its ballots for the provincial legislature of North Rhine-Westphalia.
BONN, Germany, June 26 -- Henry Ford II, president of the Ford Motor Company, warned West German industry today not to become tied up again in cartels and monopolies.

SOMEONE recently defined an anthropologist as an apologist for man. William Howells, who is Professor of Anthropology at the University of Wisconsin, and the author of two widely read books, "Mankind So Far," and "The Heathens," doesn't feel that man requires to be apologized for.

New Yorkers will be able to see three-quarters of a total eclipse of the sun next Wednesday if they are willing to get up at sunrise and if the heavens are clear. Or they can just turn on the television set and see the whole celestial display from Minneapolis.

THIS novel dramatizes the hazardous journey of a missionary couple, Laura and Jimmy Woodbury, as they cross the Hungry Country in Africa to the Land of the People of the Fan, who are in need of help, both spiritually and physically.
ADVENTURE fiction heads the borrowing and buying lists of American soldiers in Korea. And comic books don't do quite as well as one might expect.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, June 26 -- President Paul Magloire of Haiti endorsed the United States warnings to international communism to stay out of the Western Hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -- A top United States diplomat warned in 1937 that Western influence would be forced out of China if the major powers allowed Japan to march through China unchecked, according to State Department documents revealed today.
SCHROON LAKE, N. Y., June 26 (AP) -- Thirteen persons were injured, two critically, when a Greyhound bus and a truck crashed today on Route 9, about six miles north of this Adirondack resort village.
Bruno-New York, Inc., did a land-office business last week.

THE spidery workings of the overwrought, overtaut mind are intriguing to contemplate. Perhaps because we are on slippery ground here, as dilettante observers and even specialists in this labyrinthine field of study, the novelist who introduces us to a character completely withdrawn into himself immediately clamps a hammerlock on our attention.

IT is very likely that William Bradford Huie's "The Execution of Private Slovik" will long survive the official histories of World War II. It is a big book and Mr. Huie deserves some sort of rich reward for this unburying of an incident of the war which must disturb us all.

NEW DELHI, India, June 26 -- India served notice on Portugal today that the consequences that might follow continuation of repressive policy in three tiny Portuguese settlements on India's west coast would rest with the Lisbon Government.

HARTFORD, June 26 -- Abraham A. Ribicoff of Hartford, a former United States Representative, was nominated for Governor by Connecticut Democrats today. He immediately called for a campaign free of vilification.
A signed contract with the Transit Authority within two weeks became the goal yesterday of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., after the heavy vote for it Friday by authority employes.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of the note by the United States and nine other American nations proposing an Inter-American meeting of Foreign Ministers July 7 to agree upon measures for dealing with Communist "intervention" in Guatemala.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The prospect is dim that the Senate will have a direct showdown at this session of Congress on the issue of its responsibility for the investigatory activities of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin. In substance, of course, such a showdown would pose the broader political issue incarnated by McCarthy's entire public record.

RECENT remarks in this column on the vanishing borderline between the mystery story and the straight novel are nicely illustrated by the publication, by the same house on the same day, of two novels markedly similar in content yet wholly different in effect: Marc Brandel's THE TIME OF THE FIRE (Random, $3) and David Alexander's TERROR ON BROADWAY (Random, $2.75).

The recent decline in wholesale prices of oil products has reduced materially the profit margin of the refining branch of the industry. The companies that purchase all their crude oil in the open market are having some difficulty in making ends meet and several already have had to reduce operations.
Summer vacation advantages of the city's 27,000-acre park and playground system were detailed for visitors and residents yesterday by the Parks Department.

Out Wisconsin way in the famed Fox River Valley the country's largest outboard marathon will be held today. This ninety-two-mile novelty is unique in starting and finishing at the same point in Neenah, Wis., and taking the fleet to Oshkosh on Lake Winnebago and then up Wolf River past Winneconne to Fremont and return. A purchase order for cotton undershirts ordinarily would have little significance in the annals of the Quartermaster Corps. But the one placed last week for 293,275 cotton T-shirts for $100,807 makes history because it was the last official procurement by the Quartermaster Purchasing Agency at 111 East Sixteenth Street.
BALTIMORE, June 26 -- Maryland voters will go to the polls Monday in one of the most listless state primaries in local recollection.

APPARENTLY the dancers are taking quite earnestly the city's idea of selling itself as a summer resort. The City Summer Dance Festival up at the Ninety-second Street "Y" has already been noted for next week.

The National Multiple Sclerosis Society is conducting a national search for identical twins, male or female, one or both of whom suffer from the crippling disease. The twins are sought to take part in research into the disease's possible hereditary and environmental causes. Neither cause nor cure is known.

SUMMER, arriving on schedule with sunny skies and favorable shopping weather, has instilled new life into retail sales. Merchants have reason to be optimistic. In the week ended on June 19 the country as a whole showed a 4 per cent gain in department store volume.

LEGENDRY is a tricky and elusive business. There's something about a legend that calls for not only its own language of statement but its own terms of belief. It makes slanting references to and oblique contacts with reality, but the exciting thing about a memorable legend is its summation -- the keen, clear light it throws upon human strength or frailty.
PIKE, N. H., June 26 -- The Rev. Dr. Barnett R. Brickner, rabbi of the Euclid Avenue Temple in Cleveland, was unanimously elected president of the Central Conference of American Rabbis here today.

United States officials professed not to know what it was that M. Mendes-France had in mind, but they were certain, nevertheless, that the French Government would press for a European army that minimized the loss of France's "sovereignty" or her national identity in the six-nation defense alignment and raised safeguards on German rearmament.
The outlook for bank earnings brightened considerably last week when the Federal Reserve Board announced a reduction in reserve requirements.

FLORENCE, Italy, June 26 (AP) -- The District Attorney in Florence has ordered "confiscation" of a Fifteenth-Century masterpiece from the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York. But there was a question whether the Italian Government would relay the demand.
SALT LAKE CITY, June 26 -- A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a restraining order against further harassment of 350 Navajo Indians by whites would remain effective throughout this summer.

THIS new book by C. Day Lewis, "An Italian Visit," is an attempt at a nouvelle in verse. The attraction of the poem, though, is that of a travel diary, not of a nouvelle. Mr. Day Lewis is an admirable diarist. He is as well an easy conversationalist, a fine observer, and he can spell out the moods of ecstasy and regret.

IN a border, spires of bloom rise above rounded masses of annuals and perennials somewhat like church spires piercing the treetops. Delphinium, foxglove, lupine and some others contribute this distinctive effect in June.
GENEVA, June 26 -- Western Germany, which has surprised the world by the vigor of its economy, has presented Europe a new and rather odd economic problem.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, June 26 -- Someone once said you could see a human habitation from almost every point on this rugged green isle from which 450,000 New Yorkers of Puerto Rican birth or parentage stem. Rural though the island remains, the observation does have considerable truth.

The first year of the ten-year Loomis-Chaffee Development Fund, inaugurated last fall for the expansion of the Loomis and Chaffee schools in Windsor, Conn., has brought in $300,000. This represents gifts from 256 different sources -- parents, alumni and friends of both schools. The drive was launched last October by a gift of $100,000 from Winthrop Rockefeller, Loomis class of '31, and a trustee.

SAN JUAN, P. R., June 26 -- New York City and Puerto Rican officials joined today in urging Congress and the Federal Government to "re-evaluate the social welfare, housing and other Federal benefit programs" available so as to increase services to Puerto Rico.

DESPITE the fact that all his relatively small output was acquired for public or private collections, the late Niles Spencer did not in life have the wider recognition he merited. The artist whose work does not demand partisan recognition for strict adherence to tradition nor through impact of violent novelty is very likely to find himself in this situation.

NEW DELHI, India, June 26 -- Pakistan's reported rejection of the proposal suggested by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development for solution of the water dispute has been described by India as a failure of "one of the noteworthy cooperative efforts in settling disputes between nations under the auspices of an international agency."

PARIS -- To satisfy a popular urge to get off a track that this summer will be beaten by some million American feet, one may make a delightful detour between London and Paris via the Channel Islands as my wife, two children and I did.
The week-end visit to Washington of Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill can only confirm the imminence of a major Communist victory in Indochina.
A Navy jet dove 22,000 feet into a Long Island sand bar yesterday, killing the pilot, one of the nation's top oarsmen.
Philip R. Lochner has been appointed Eastern regional sales manager of the Union Asbestos and Rubber Company, effective July 1.
CHICAGO, June 26 -- At least four persons drowned today when a phenomenal wave struck nearly twenty-five miles of Chicago's Lake Michigan shoreline.
The first step toward production of a paper shipping sack that will not be used until some time after 1970 was taken a few months ago in a Florida pine woods.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- United States diplomatic officials predicted today that the new French Government would move soon for talks such as are going on here now with British leaders.

ROBERT STACK, heretofore identified as the teen-agers' delight, would have it known that he has come of age professionally. The handsome juvenile star of pre-war films has blossomed forth of late into a rough-riding hero of Westerns, adventure dramas and swashbuckling entertainments.
BUENOS AIRES, June 26 -- The late Senora Eva Peron's fortune was incorporated into a new and tax-free organization to be known as the Fundacion Evita by the Argentine Congress yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, June 26 (UP) -- Bob Friend, working on a no-hitter until rain cooled him off in the sixth inning, survived Ted Kluszewski's two-run homer in the eighth today and pitched the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 4-3 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs.

With the Percy Bassett-Lulu Perez bout last Friday night having brought the spring Madison Square Garden boxing season to a close, interest this week will be centered on matches arranged for the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn and the St. Nicholas Arena in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Disagreement over tactics and at least three outright defections crippled Senate Democrats today in their drive for a general reduction in individual income taxes.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, who presided over the Army-McCarthy hearings, predicted tonight that the Senate permanent subcommittee on investigations would not authorize an investigation of the highly secret Central Intelligence Agency.
SEATTLE, Wash., June 26 (UP) -- Ham Richardson defeated Bob Perry of U. C. L. A. to retain the National Collegiate tennis singles championship today in straight sets, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3.

LONDON, June 26 (UP) -- Russia's national rowing eight, heavy favorite to take the Grand Challenge Cup at the Henley Royal Regatta next week, drew a tough first-round opponent today in the Danish national crew.

THE pleasant days of June are a reminder that seeds of biennials need to be sown soon. Groups of foxgloves seen in a friend's garden last summer and memories of campanulas in an old garden have made this family resolve never to be without these biennials again.

WAREHAM, Mass., June 26 -- A 1,000,000-barrel national cranberry harvest this year is estimated by Dr. Chester E. Cross, director of the East Wareham Cranberry Experimental Station. The crop last year was 1,230,000 barrels, a record.
KANSAS CITY, June 26 (AP) -- Dr. Graham said that intravenous feeding was being continued and that no other food was given to Mr. Truman today.

HALLAM, Neb., June 26 (AP) -- The Rock Island Railroad's Rocky Mountain Rocket left the tracks near Hallam last night, strewing cars along its right-of-way and injuring at least seventy-five of its 225 passengers. Only two remained in serious condition today.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 26 -- The insurgent radio appealed today to the Guatemalan Army to form a military junta, seize President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman and consult with the rebels about a cease-fire.

A move to coordinate the four New York City municipal colleges under one chancellor has been pressed by Joseph B. Cavallaro, chairman of the Board of Higher Education. Dr. Cavallaro was recently re-elected as chairman of the board.

PANAMA CITY -- Delegates from twenty countries of North and South America appropriately concluded the Fifth Inter-American Travel Congress here last week-end by embarking on a sight-seeing trip through the Panama Canal.

TORONTO, June 26 -- Art Bragg, 21-year-old Baltimore runner who holds the National Amateur Athletic Union 100-yard and 220-yard titles, took the 220 -- yard dash at the Canadian open track and field championships today in the meet-record time of 0:22.1. The previous mark was 0:22.3.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Ted Williams, starting for the first time since June 5, drove in a run, set up another with a first-inning single, and scored a third as the Boston Red Sox ended a five-game Chicago White Sox winning streak with a 3-1 victory before 10,127 fans today.
BISMARK, N. D., June 26 -- North Dakota's primary election Tuesday again pits two rival factions of the State's Republican party.

IF General Two-Gun Cohen had never lived, Bernard Shaw might very easily have invented him. For he is an extraordinary instance of a Shavian archetype, the genial roughneck who becomes a dedicated server in a mighty cause, the wanderer who finally finds himself in a great adventure.

THE regular sale of fine single photographic prints on the same level as paintings and other artistic work is being inaugurated this week at Brentano's bookstore on Fifth Avenue. There is a persuasive body of evidence that the stock market advance since the end of 1948 may have been due at least partly to a shortage of new issues.

BILL CULLEN, the slim, alert man with the big horn-rimmed glasses, the large eyes, and the elfin grin which splits his face wide and lights it like a ball park at night, is currently seen on three coast-to-coast television shows and two network radio programs.

For the principle is merely the starting of another vegetable or flower crop as soon as space is vacated by an earlier maturing one.

The Giants retained a one-game lead in the National League by defeating the Cubs, 6 to 4, at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Wes Westrum's four-run homer highlighted the New York attack. The second-place Dodgers rallied to beat the Cardinals, 7 -- 6, in eleven innings at Ebbets Field. The Yankees turned back the Indians, 11--9, and moved within two games of the pace-setting Cleveland club.

I wish to thank and congratulate The Times and Gertrude Samuels for the article, "Where Troubled Children Are Reborn" (June 13), on the wonderful work being done by the Kenneth Clarks in their center and clinic in rescuing children from the blight of under-privilege and lack of opportunity in New York.

GREENBORO, N. C., June 26 (AP) -- Nancy Reed of George Peabody College, Nashville, Tenn., scored her third straight upset today to win the tenth women's National Collegiate golf championship. She beat the defending champion, Pat Lesser of Seattle University, on the nineteenth hole in the final.

DON CAMILLO, Peppone, and the crew of rabid individualists who inhabit Guareschi's Po Valley world, are back! For the first time in the history of the floor-covering industry, a 100 per cent wool tufted carpet is being introduced. Its manufacturer is A. M. Karagheusian, Inc., maker of Gulistan carpets.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 26 -- Agreement within two weeks on a plan to end the dispute that has kept Iranian oil off world markets for three years was predicted today.

America's chess players in the international match with Russia that ended at the Hotel Roosevelt last Thursday, suffered a seemingly one-sided defeat 20 -- 12, but demonstrated in the fourth and final round that the visitors were not invincible.

IT may be that Charles Ives, who died a few weeks ago at the age of 79, is the only true musical nationalist that this country has produced. Much has been made of his daring experiments, his tinkering with polytonality and polyrhythms be- before 1900.

PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., June 26 -- Against a fleet of champions and former champions with years of experience in predicted-log races, a Long Island radiator engineer with no records to brag about won the Huckins event today.
NEW DELHI, June 26 (Reuters) -- Premier Chou En-lai said tonight he hoped China and India would work more closely in the future "for the noble aim of safeguarding peace in Asia."

LONDON, June 26 (AP) -- The Moscow radio declared today that Britain would not share in United States attempts "to keep the Chinese People's Republic from taking part in a settlement" of the Korean war.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 26 -- New Yorkers had an unusual opportunity tonight to discover what Vietnam and the people of that Asian land were like in peacetime, and took advantage of it in numbers that crowded the International Center at the Carnegie Endowment Building, 345 East Forty-sixth Street.

DES MOINES, June 26 (AP) -- The flooding Des Moines River rolled southward toward Ottumwa tonight. That city of 34,000 in southeast Iowa is expected to handle without major damage the arrival of the crest there tomorrow night.
Last month the United States again announced its refusal to participate in a proposed $250 million United Nations fund for economic assistance to underdeveloped areas.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -- New York State Democratic leaders will meet here Monday with national party officials to discuss plans for this fall's election campaign. Pennsylvania Democratic leaders will come here Wednesday for a similar strategy session.

HIGHWAY laws have not kept pace with technical advances in road engineering and management. The result has been a hodgepodge of statutes that is hard on motorists and highway officials, according to the National Highway Research Board.
MADISON, Wis., June 26 (UP) -- The private papers of Robert M. La Follette Sr., founder of the Progressive dynasty in Wisconsin, were opened to public view today for the first time.

Business in New York City's department stores was good during the week. Retailers felt the New York Summer Festival, a promotion started Monday and aimed at publicizing the city as a vacation spot, may have caused the upturn.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 26 -- Dr. Irving Stoddard Kull, Voorhees Professor of History at Rutgers University since 1932 and a member of the faculty for thirty-six years, will retire next Wednesday.

Billings Wilson, who will retire July 31 as director of operations of the Port of New York Authority, was honored last week.

JAPAN'S burgeoning film industry, which is rarely represented in local theatres, may have two prize-winning features unveiled here in coming months, it was reported last week by Masaichi Nagata, president of Daiei, one of Nippon's five major production companies.

RICHMOND, June 26 -- Improvement in department store trade last week in the Fifth Reserve District was encouraging to retailers. Industrial developments of the week were mixed, but with good news predominating.

AN exciting new approach to yearbook photography, in the style of the picture magazines and with imaginative use of layout, characterizes the 1954 yearbook of Drake University, Des Moines, Iowa. Editor and principal photographer is Joseph K. Brown, who took most of the pictures reproduced.

A BACKWARD glance at the past season reveals it somewhat shockingly as the most barren season New York has had in many a long year, creatively speaking. In what is generally considered to be the professional district, as distinguished from the outlying neighborhoods where the younger and more experimental dancers hold forth, there have been only four new works presented by our native companies, and not one of them first class.

Emperor Haile Selassie arrived at 7:27 o'clock last night at the Marine Terminal, La Guardia Airport, on a chartered T. W. A. Constellation from Fort Benning, Ga. He was accompanied by his son, Prince Sahle Selassie, and two granddaughters, Princess Sebla Desta. 23 years old, and Princess Sofia Desta, 20.

THIS story of Tony LeVier's career as a pilot begins with his youthful struggles to log enough hours in the air to qualify for a private pilot's license back in the early Nineteen Thirties. It ends with some predictions about military and commercial flying of the future.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 26 -- Construction activity in the Ninth Federal Reserve District stepped up last month, compared with the previous May, but still is below 1953 figures for the first five months of the year. Building permits valued at $28,693,550 were issued during May in eighty-three cities of the district, compared with $25,789,700 in May a year ago.

IT is exciting, heartening news that the members of the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra, which the National Broadcasting Company decided to disband after Arturo Toscanini's retirement, are going to fight for their organization's life.

BACK in the days when bridge writers were first confronted with the newfangled idea of "bidding" -- until about 1907, the dealer always played the hand, and his partner was always the dummy -- their advice used to be: "Count the number of tricks you can win, and add one trick for the advantage of being declarer."

Under an excellent ride by Eric Guerin, the Saxon Stables' Invigorator won the $29,000 Edgemere Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. He was the solid choice in the nine-furlong run, and the cashiers paid off on him at the rate of $4.50 for each $2.

THIS is the time of year when new radio and television receivers come on the market, and it is now evident that the manufacturing boys have missed the boat. They're still thinking of such old-fashioned things as AM radio, FM radio and television.

About 2,000,000 pairs of eyes on this continent alone will be directed at the sun on June 30 over a path that will stretch from Nebraska into Canada and beyond. The occasion will be a total eclipse of the sun; the 2,000,000 pairs of eyes lie in the path of totality.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -- The armed forces can't get together on a single, money-saving equipment catalogue, but they've done something almost as difficult. They have agreed on a standard field ration for the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marines.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 26 (AP) -- Philip Scott, 6-year-old bay horse owned by the Gray brothers of East Providence, R. I., and driven by Frank Safford, remained undefeated during his 1954 campaign as he won the Merrick free-for-all pace from Prince Adios by a length and one-quarter in 2:01 1-5 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. MOSCOW, June 26 (AP) -- The Russians would like to send a picked track and field team to the United States next year, and probably have some American trackmen come here too, if arrangements can be made in time.

THIS is an Irish folk tale with a story as light and airy as the lovely line drawings that illustrate it. The scene is County Cork where Mr. Brogan woke up one fine morning with a great determination to do certain chores that day.

HACKENSACK, N. J., June 26 -- Dr. Reginald Weir of New York led the way into the third round of the twenty-seventh annual Eastern men's clay court tennis championship at the Oritani Field Club today. The tournament attracted 103 entries.

LONG ago George Bernard Shaw said his oculist had discovered with much amazement that Shaw had absolutely normal vision, which hardly anybody had. Shaw remarked that it was then clear to him why he saw the world about him so much more accurately than most other people saw it.

The Manufacturing Chemists' Association has announced the publication of a new manual, entitled "Guide for Safety in the Chemical Laboratory." The 228-page book, illustrated with charts, tables and photographs, was described as a cooperative venture of the chemical industry.
ANKARA, Turkey, June 21 -- The United States has been joined by Canada as a large-scale contributor to the build-up of Turkey's armed forces under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

SIGMUND ROMBERG'S operetta, The Student Prince, may not be the greatest of musical compositions, but no one could deny that it is one of the most indestructible. Its sentimental tale of the love of a prince for a commoner, set to music no less charming for reminding you of various other things, has survived Broadway, the movies and generations of touring road companies.

EVEN though the vegetable garden by now has probably yielded a bountiful harvest of radishes, peas or lettuce, that by no means is the signal to sit back and relax. For now more than ever the plot will need attention to keep it producing all those luscious crops that were dreamed of in the seed catalogue days of last spring.

SEATTLE, Wash., June 26 -- A new "partnership" approach to the electric power problems of northwest and north central Washington is intriguing onlookers, chiefly because of the identities of the "partners."
ON Wednesday this week the United States Air Force will draft the sun and the moon for a few precious hours to help measure the width of the North Atlantic and the size and shape of the earth.

ARTISTS, one and all, will be busy this afternoon in the Queens Botanical Garden, Flushing Meadow Park. For it is Art Festival time and contestants will be gathered on the grounds to interpret garden scenes in oils, water colors and pastels.

Following a policy of making its judging slate public months in advance, the Westminster Kennel Club issued the names of those who will rate the candidates for high dog show honors at its event yesterday. Westminster will be held in Madison Square Garden Feb. 14 and 15.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- India said today that Pakistan had rejected the proposal of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development for solution of the Indus River basin dispute. India is therefore free, she said, to proceed unilaterally with water development in her own part of the basin.

TELEVISIOIN will bring views of Wednesday's total eclipse of the sun into living rooms across the country. The solar phenomenon will be covered by both C. B. S.'s Morning Show and N. B. C.'s "Today" from points of vantage in the path of totality.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Churchill have already covered a lot of those "family matters" to which the Prime Minister referred yesterday when he arrived, but there are certain other "matters" of personality and principle which are not likely to be discussed at all.

STARTING today, Cape Cod will have a new tourist service -- free coffee for tired drivers. The project is the joint inspiration of Yarmouth's Police Chief, Nelson Cressy, and Ed Downs, vice president of the Aborn Coffee Company, an old New England concern. Together they are sponsoring a free coffee bar in Yarmouth's Police Headquarters.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 26 -- The State Bar Association abandoned today its controversial effort to prohibit by law the release to the press of any pretrial information about a criminal case except the formal charges.

THE rugged virtues of the modern Spaniard, and the bitter intransigeance that will always isolate him from his fellow-Europeans, is stated rather than explained in this awkward, sincere, and wholly unconvincing novel by Maurice Solignac, the free-wheeling French journalist who writes under the nom de guerre of Saint-Paulien.

LEO MENDES, a Portuguese Jew, grew up in New York City. When he was 28 years old, and the possessor of a weak lung, a bad cough and three hundred dollars, he traveled to the enchanting land of New Mexico to regain his health.
DETROIT, June 26 (AP) -- Frank House and Bob Nieman hammered home runs today to help the Tigers nip the Washington Senators, 5 -- 4, as Detroit retained its slim hold on fourth place.

CHICAGO -- Visitors here, whether voluntary or suffering from the enforced wait between cross-country trains, soon find out what Chicagoans know very well: when the weather gets really hot there is relief on the breeze-swept beaches along the Lake Michigan shoreline.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 26 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority, now in its twenty-second year of operation, is the world's largest integrated power grid system, with twenty-five hydroelectric dams and eight giant steam plants.

New Is Old "We are a new country," Russians in Siberian towns told Harrison Salisbury, The New York Times correspondent, when explaining the lack of many of the urban facilities and amenities of European cities. By recalling a few dates, the correspondent with an American background could not agree that Siberia was exactly a new country.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, today released figures proving what he has contended all along: Housewives will buy more butter if the price is cut.
Ireland's policy in the last thirty-two years has been to halt "the national hemorrhage of emigration" wherever possible, John J. Hearne, Irish Ambassador to this country, asserted yesterday.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 26 -- United States prestige with the Latin Americans has suffered a severe blow through the Guatemalan fighting whether the North Americans have any direct responsibility or not.

PARIS, June 26 -- In a letter to President Eisenhower published today, the French President, Rene Coty, said he desired to "reopen" high-level talks with the United States in the near future. M. Coty was replying to a note June 18 from President Eisenhower expressing a similar desire.
GENEVA, June 26 -- The Geneva conference, which started its third month today, has given up Korea as a bad job, but is now apparently on the way to some kind of settlement in Indo-china.

The relation of cancer of the lung to the smoking of cigarettes has been a familiar story for months. Nevertheless, Drs. E. Cuyler Hammond and Daniel Horn, statisticians of the American Cancer Society, startled the American Medical Association, assembled at San Francisco, and made front pages by presenting the preliminary findings of a survey which called for the services of 22,000 trained volunteers and covered the smoking habits of 187,766 men.

GARDENS are well under way for the summer and once again comes the army of unwelcomed invaders -- insects and diseases. To many home owners the battle may seem an unending one, but with the modern equipment and sprays, alert eyes and regular attention, the foes can easily be vanquished.
ALBANY, June 26 -- A joint legislative committee took the first exploratory steps this week toward shaping a revised policy on the state's giant forest preserve.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin predicted today that the House of Representatives would override its Agriculture Committee and approve President Eisenhower's plea for flexible farm price supports on five basic crops.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 26 (AP) -- Richard McCreary of Houston, who had held the Texas and Indiana amateur championships, and John Hare Jr. of Indianapolis, chopped eleven strokes off par to win medal honors today in 36-hole qualifications for the Western Golf Association's first international four-ball tournament.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies presented Robin Roberts with four runs in the first inning today as the big righthander easily defeated Milwaukee, 10 -- 3, for his tenth victory.

LONDON, June 26 -- Jim Peters, the British distance runner who was forced to drop out as Emil Zatopek won the 1952 Olympic marathon, today set a record of 2 hours 17 minutes 39.4 seconds for the 26-mile 385-yard grind.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Booming construction activity, continued declines in business inventories and the rise of industrial stocks give assurance of a full upturn in business, Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, said today.

AT a time when writers on Indo - American relations are likely to be somber and "significant" it is refreshing to read a relaxed account of life in both worlds by a young Indian woman, who not only is charming and beautiful but intelligent as well.
NOW -- while you are busy fishing the lakes, streams or coastal waters -- is the time to give some thought to definite plans for fall hunting.

IT is always pleasant to visit a neat and clean garden. And the general appearance of flower beds speaks eloquently of gardening abilities. Often the mere presence of fading and withered flowers can ruin the whole picture.
OCEANPORT, N. J., June 26 -- Shady Tune of the Carolyn K. Stable won the Molly Pitcher Handicap, the $28,950 event that served as the feature of the card at Monmouth Park today.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 26 -- South Africa's 8,600,000 Negroes are on the road to freedom and are resolved not to turn back, A. J. Luthuli, president of the African National Congress said at the provincial congress of the organization in Uitenhage today.
" HERE they come, down the highways, down the roads, down the street you live on, into this book!"
WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee urged today $3,470,608,000 foreign aid next year to counter new threats of Communist aggression.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: In areas where rainfall has been scant recently, soak the soil deeply under all newly planted trees and shrubs. Water window boxes, daily if necessary, and house plants now summering outdoors. Since drought halts growth, water the annuals thoroughly once a week if possible.

The Dodgers pulled one out of the fire at Ebbets Field yesterday. In the ninth inning, with two out and two strikes on Duke Snider, the Duke belted a two-run homer to tie the score. Then in the eleventh inning with one out, Jackie Robinson dropped a pop-fly single into left field to score Junior Gilliam from second base and give the Brooks a 7-6 victory over the Cardinals.
The United States Golf Association's second women's open championship will be held Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the Salem Country Club, Peabody, Mass.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 26 -- Count W. F. L. van Bylandt, Netherlands High Commissioner in Indonesia, urged Indonesia today not to accept the "Communist recipe" by labeling foreign investment capital in Indonesia "colonial."

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission approved a settlement yesterday under which Southern Tier Gas Corporation, Watertown, N. Y., is to refund all revenues collected under bond since last Aug. 24 under a proposed natural gas rate increase of $9,800 annually on sales to the village of Bath, N. Y.

HOUSTON, June 26 (AP) -- Nearly everything went wrong for Hillman Robbins on the first six holes today before the Southern intercollegiate champion from Memphis State settled down to defeat Cecil Calhoun of Louisiana State for the National Collegiate golf championship.

Seven months ago at Bermuda Dwight D. Eisenhower and Sir Winston Churchill met for the first time as heads of Government. With France they set in motion the machinery for a meeting in Berlin with Russia. Afterward the President said:

Sosthenes Behn entered business when the world operated on the basis of free enterprise and the gold standard. Free enterprise has since been suppressed in many areas by the hand of the dictator and the extension of Communist domination.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- The number of jobless workers in Illinois unemployment polls has continued to decline, while the number of additions has also slipped from week to week, the Department of Labor reported. For the week ended June 19, 13,598 newly laid-off workers were added to the list, compared with 14,941 the week before.

CLEVELAND, June 26 -- The average hourly rate of factory workers in Cleveland is $1.96, exclusive of fringe benefits of approximately 31 cents an hour, according to a survey made by the Associated Industries of Cleveland.

SYRACUSE, June 26 -- Carmen Basilio, top-ranking welterweight contender, beat Al Andrews at his own flurrying game tonight, floored him twice and won a unanimous ten-round decision at War Memorial Auditorium.

LIMA, Peru, June 21 -- More than a mile of road through the jungle of the Amazon Basin of Peru has now been carved in the first stages of the Robert G. LeTourneau road-building and colonization project on the Pachitea River, 300 miles from the Ucayali River port of Pucallpa.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The successful Communist infiltration of the Government of Guatemala has raised an anxious question in Washington: Is this an isolated case, or are similar things brewing in other parts of Latin America?

CLEVELAND, June 26 -- The Yankees and the Indians battered each other all over Municipal Stadium before they reached a decision tonight. The verdict, for the second straight night, was in favor of Casey Stengel's champions.
NEW DELHI, India, June 26 (AP) -- Textual excerpts from toasts exchanged tonight by Premier Chou En-lai and Prime Minister Nehru follow:

Something in the nature of a showdown in the A.P.B.A.-N.O.A. battle will happen Friday night at Detroit. President Merlyn Culver of Dayton, Ohio, head of the American Power Boat Association, is taking advantage of the concentration of speed-boat moguls in Detroit over the coming week-end for a meeting of the national council. It will be held at the Windmill Pointe Y. C. Friday at eight o'clock.

RECENTLY there have been indications that the stock-librarians of fiction -- those ladies of the screwed-up hair and the awesome per sonalities -- are retiring in favor of more personable members of the profession.

The economic status of Negro workers in the South has improved in the last fifteen years but the vast majority of them still are restricted to poorly paying, unskilled jobs. This is a finding of an extensive study of Negro employment in the South conducted by the Urban League.

PHYSICIAN, naval officer and Arctic explorer, Elisha Kent Kane (1820-57) led an unusually active and useful, though short, life. He explored and charted Greenland during his last seven years and contributed more to our knowledge of that country than anyone before him.
The City of Yonkers refused yesterday to give up the struggle to keep Alexander Smith, Inc., carpet factory, from leaving town as planned.

PERHAPS, in these days, only an Englishman could have written this lively little book. It has those qualities one has come to associate with the best features of the British character -- calmness in danger, sturdiness in crisis and the kind of hard common sense that derives from the ability to look a nasty situation unflinchingly in the face.

The problem of too much U. S. farm production, now plaguing the Eisenhower Administration, has its source in a U. S. wartime decision to increase output of the six basic crops (wheat, corn, cotton, rice, peanuts, tobacco) to meet U. S. military needs and to help feed our Allies.

SEOUL, Korea, June 26 -- Since the Geneva Conference ended its consideration of Korean affairs about two weeks ago, the Republic of Korea Government has been silent -- surprisingly so in view of its record of staging mass demonstrations at the drop of a hat and issuing threats and protests over almost any issue connected with the Korean peninsula.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- Employment in Pennsylvania manufacturing industries dropped 27,000 to 1,026,000 in May. In reporting the 3 per cent decline this week, the Federal Reserve Bank noted that it was the largest in any month since the downturn started last fall.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Twelve members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee have advised President Eisenhower to reject the British plan for a non-aggression pact in Asia -- or face a complete review of foreign aid.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -- The American Chemical Society charged today that Selective Service was violating the law on occupational deferment of young scientists and engineers and thereby jeopardizing national security.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, June 23 -- The new Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland is eagerly awaiting the arrival of an international bank mission which is expected soon.
Former President Harry S. Truman was reported in "serious condition" early today by his physician, Dr. Wallace Graham.
Wes Westrum provided the chief heroics yesterday as the sizzling Giants defeated the Cubs, 6 -- 4, to maintain their one-game advantage over the hotly pursuing Dodgers.

There are no indications that the Monthly Investment Plan of the New York Stock Exchange is adversely affecting the growth of mutual funds and other types of investment companies, as was feared in some quarters when it was started.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 26 -- Midwestern farmers received the news of additional cuts in wheat acreage this week like men with aching teeth who were about to go to a dentist. They knew the reaction was inevitable and that it was going to hurt, but this knowledge didn't make the situation any easier.

CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals had three players in top National League spots today as the All-Star game voting turned into its final week. The Yankees dominate the American League with four leading candidates.

THERE seems to be a sort of durability about "Ballet Ballads," that John Latouche-Jerome Moross creation seen in the local sector back in 1948. You can still get into an argument over it with partisans who remember it fondly, California hailed it in revival not too long ago, and now word comes that it will be one of the American representations at the Berlin Festival, beginning Sept. 15.

In "Any Schoolboy Knows That" (June 13), methinks that Leonard Buder or someone else erred in giving the answer to "Divided 16 by 3/5" as 26 2/3. To arrive at such a figure one must add 17 1/15 to the correct answer of 9.60 or 9 3/5.
MOSCOW, June 26 -- The United States Government has flatly rejected Soviet charges that United States naval forces intercepted the Soviet tanker Tuapse off Formosa.

The Third Annual Institute of Religious Vacation Centers and Summer Day Camps will be held at Fordham University tomorrow. The purpose of the institute, conducted under the auspices of the Catholic Youth Organization and the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine of the Archdiocese of New York, is to demonstrate useful methods of operating a parochial summer leisure-time program.

Prime Minister Churchill's gift for the right phrase was illustrated on Friday when he stepped from his plane in Washington and announced: "I have come with Anthony Eden to talk over a few family matters and try to make sure that there are no misunderstandings."
BERN, Switzerland, June 26 -- Uruguay and Austria swept into the semi-final round of the world soccer championship today after two of the most thrilling matches the sport ever has seen.
Some of the freshness peeled off the "new look" in the steel industry's labor-management relations last week.

Not an atomic power plant is in commercial operation. Yet engineers are already worrying about the "hot ashes" or radioactive wastes with which they must deal in a not very remote future. If the wastes were turned into rivers, fish caught in the water would probably be as radioactive as those contaminated by "fall out" in Japanese smacks during the recent Eniwetok experiments, and if buried they would contaminate the soil.

THE helicopter, that ungainly, silly-looking, wonderful flight freak that has captivated the heart and imagination of our admirals and generals (and every man of war in bell-bottom pants and battle-fetid fatigues) has had the red carpet, double thick and gold-bordered, rolled out by Lynn Montross in its honor.

PIERRE, S. D., June 26 -- South Dakota, after whittling away at a staggering $60,000,000 of rural credits-farm loan debt since 1917, will be one of the few states without general obligation bonded debt by Aug. 1.
CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- Hasty Road stumbled out of the gate but recovered quickly and raced to a one-length victory today in the $28,625 Warren Wright Memorial at Arlington Park.

SOMEHOW the words "summer" and "discipline" don't seem to mix. To our ears, at least, they sound about as unpalatable a combination as the proverbial pickles and ice cream. Mothers and dads whose youngsters are away at camp will have neatly passed the discipline question on to counselors.
YOUR article last Sunday happens to be on my latest enthusiasm, Dr. Baxter's lectures. Luckily, I read about the series in advance and, luckier still, I remembered to tune it in.

Baseball fans, who have been lending an ear to various proposals urging midsummer inter-league competition between the various clubs of the two major circuits, are about to have something of the sort served to them.

The "pork chops" era for American merchant seamen that has lasted fifteen years appears to have ended, although there are some indications that this may be only a temporary respite for the shipowners.

EARLY in 1861 the editors of The London Times did something that has caused historians to bless them ever since. Concluding that the brawling Americans were about to engage in civil war they sent their ace correspondent, William Howard Russell, to cover the fight.

DALLAS, June 26 -- The Texas Employment Commission reported that the state's working force increased 20,800 in May, bringing to 2,673,200 the number of employed. There were 133,500 unemployed in the state, the Commission estimated.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 26 (UP) -- High Scud. one of a three-horse entry in the $27,200 Inglewood Handicap at Hollywood Park today, flashed to a nose victory over the Irish-bred Curragh King.

BACK in July, 1919, the late Prof. Morris Raphael Cohen, a gentle, medium - otherworldly philosopher, wrote an essay which he called "Baseball as a National Religion," and which was published in The Dial, a very self-consciously worldly little magazine of the day.

COL. ORESTE PINTO is a Dutch counter-intelligence officer who during World War II served as Chief Examiner of the Royal Victoria Patriotic School at Wandsworth, England. There he screened men who had escaped from the occupied Continent.

OTTAWA, June 26 -- The second longest sitting in Canadian parliamentary history ended today. Major issues decided during the 139 sitting days that began last Nov. 12 were agreed to be comparatively negligible by both the Liberal government, with 172 seats, and the Opposition, with ninety-one.

In the volatile Republics of Latin America, revolution is as familiar a means of changing governments as balloting in the United States. Accordingly, the coups and caudillos that flash up and down the continent do not generally engage the world's attention.

It is often said that one man's misfortune is another man's gain. And Dr. William M. Scholl, founder and president of the Scholl Manufacturing Company, Inc., Chicago, maker of remedies and appliances for sore feet, is an exemplification of the truism.

PARIS, June 26 -- The balance of power in free Europe has now begun to change. France's Continental leadership west of the Elbe River is waning. And, commensurately, the influence of Western Germany makes itself felt.

READERS of "When God Says 'No'" by Margaret Blair Johnstone are in for some surprises. This probing resume of Mrs. Johnstone's nineteen years as a Protestant minister contains three essential elements: answers for those who have lost their faith, questions for apathetic churchgoers, jolts for ministers stuck in comfortable ruts of conventionality.

OGDENSBURG, N. Y., June 26 (AP) -- Continuing his tour of northern New York, Mr. Roosevelt argued today that his proposal for distribution of Niagara power should be applied to the St. Lawrence power project.

IF a passenger flying in any commercial plane now in service in this country tries to balance a coin on its edge on a seat armrest, he will find that his dime is far too thin to remain upright. If the trick is attempted in an airliner with turboprop power plants, however, the coin will actually stand on edge.

ATLANTA, June 26 -- Retail trade in the Southeast showed improvement last week. Special sales and demands for vacation goods spurred business in most large centers of the district. The Georgia State Chamber of Commerce reported this week that retail sales in Atlanta in April totaled $93,980,663, an increase of $7,100,000 over the preceding month and more than $2,700,000 above the April, 1953, volume.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -- The Reconstruction Finance Corp. ends its independent existence at midnight next Wednesday -- twenty-two years and almost $50,000,000,000 from the day it was set up by President Hoover to help banks and businesses maimed by the depression.
GENEVA, June 26 -- Britain has come forward with a plan for bringing Western Europe into a closer and more durable economic relationship with the rest of the non-Communist world.

To determine to what extent a taxpayer may exercise legal means to obtain the benefit of a tax advantage or to save himself from a tax penalty is a burden that must be borne by the courts. Frequently these cases must be judged by the intent of the taxpayer as indicated by all the circumstances of the case.

AMONG musicologists it is generally agreed that Samuel Scheidt's Tablatura Nova, published in Hamburg in 1624, is one of the epoch-making works in the development of organ literature. The layman, though, has been more or less obliged to take this on faith.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- President Eisenhower at his latest news conference said it would be "news" if a Potomac River bridge collapsed. A standing bridge, he added, creates no news.

ROME -- The Colosseum, Roman landmark and tourist attraction since the pilgrimages of the Middle Ages, is sick. Treatment will be long and costly, and surgery may to a certain extent become necessary. But everything will be done to keep the monument at all times open to sight-seers and to spoil as little as possible of its celebrated silhouette.
The New York Historical Society announced yesterday that it had the original doctor's bill for the treatment of Alexander Hamilton after his fatal duel with Aaron Burr.
BERLIN, June 22 -- Forgery has become a thriving business in Berlin. It is a weapon little publicized but much used in the era of "psychological warfare."

IF SHAKESPEARE were collecting royalties this summer, his income would be many times greater than that of any other playwright living or dead. Information on hand indicates that close to two-score productions of his plays will be performed from Zurich in Switzerland to San Diego in southern California.
NEW HAVEN, June 26 -- The General Council of the Congregational Christian Churches, acting as a committee, strongly endorsed today its Council for Social Action.

WHEN rawboned Pelican Cavanaugh came from a Wyoming ranch to a private school in New Jersey, he found the going tough at first. One group even tried to run him out of school. But a level head, loyal friends, and a growing interest in ham radio helped Pelican over the rough spots.

MILWAUKEE, June 26 (AP) -- More than 3,000 Wisconsin Republican party members shouted their approval tonight as Vice President Richard M. Nixon told them the G. O. P. "must be united on fundamental principles which transcend the differences we have."
CHICAGO, June 26 -- New York City has been advised to reconsider its claim that the projected Columbus Circle Coliseum will hold "the largest exhibition area under one roof."

Wall Street's rising young investment specialists are a lot more certain of the career they have chosen than they were a few years ago. Fewer young men are leaving the business. There is less hopping from one investment house to another.

Retail sales have risen with the temperature, resident buying offices report. At the same time, visiting buyers who are shopping the markets here for fall goods indicate satisfaction at the emphasis by manufacturers on style and value.

LOS ANGELES, June 26 -- The Government's campaign to purge the Southwest of Mexican border-jumpers bore definite promise this week of eventual permanent solution of a problem that has beset this country for a decade.

Three weeks ago retail buyers flocked into New York to shop the women's apparel market amid rumors that they would be more careful than ever before in early buying. Despite warn ings by manufacturers and resident buying offices that failure to order enough merchandise on this first trip would mean difficulty in obtaining goods later in the season, the merchants proved these early rumors to be true.
Trustees of the Publishers-Paper Handlers Welfare Fund reported yesterday that in the first seventeen months of operation the fund amassed a surplus of $39.371.

Formation of a new nursery school which will inherit the staff and educational concepts of the Harriet Johnson Nursery School, 69 Bank Street, New York City, has been announced. The new educational center will cooperate with the New York School of Social Work, on whose grounds it will be situated.

ZIKHRON YAACOV, Israel. THE twenty-eighth International Society for Contemporary Music Festival came to an end in Zikhron Yaacov, Mount Carmel's idyllic wine village, when delegates and guests met with the musicians and composers of Israel and heard two characteristic concerts: an evening of Israeli folklore and a concert of chamber music of the oriental-minded Israeli composers, Partos, Boscovich and Seter.

DETROIT, June 26 -- Reports from new and used-car dealer sources this week indicated that the automobile business might soon be able to get out of its iron lung and start breathing normally again. The partial paralysis that set in last year seems to be receding.

MOZART: Symphony No. 40 in G Minor; SCHUBERT: Symphony No. 8 in B Minor (Unfinished); Felix Prohaska conducting the Vienna State Opera Orchestra (Vanguard). Polished, fluent performance of two orchestral favorites.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 26 -- The dominance of the Australian-American axis again was etched clearly across the face of world tennis as a brilliant quartet from Down Under, a trio from the United States and the nomadic Jaroslav Drobny reached the quarter-finals of the all-England lawn tennis championships today.

Readers of The Times owe you gratitude for publishing the stirring article by Dr. Vannevar Bush. As true and loyal citizens, we must bestir ourselves, more than ever, in protecting our institutions as prescribed in our Constitution.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (AP) -- Donna Floyd, first-seeded player from Arlington, Va., today won the Middle States grass court tennis singles championship for girls aged 15 and under. She defeated Andrea Berger of Bethesda, Md., 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2.

The recent case of a Japanese fishing boat whose hull and cargo of tuna fish were damaged by "fall out" from atomic test explosions at Bikini has raised the question in American insurance circles of insurance coverage on such hazards.

AT the age of 80, which he reaches today, John Golden is the patriarch of New York's show business. On the basis of pure longevity he has put more into the theatre, taken more out, given more away, had more influence on it than any man living.
TORONTO, June 26 (UP) -- Rudy Horvath, Windsor, Ont., won the 1954 Ontario open golf tournament today, scoring a 208 for $500 first prize money.

LUXEMBOURG, June 18 -- There is a saying in this part of the world, which has seen a lot of political ideas come and go, that one can begin really to have confidence in the "building of Europe" when they start digging the canal of the Moselle.

PROPER Bostonians on their way to work these past few weeks have taken an almost jaded attitude toward a seemingly endless cops-and-robbers chase up and down Beacon Hill, in front of court houses, city jails and other civic and historical landmarks.
KEOKUK, Iowa, June 26 (AP) -- Three members of the Peoria, Ill., Three-I League club were jailed tonight after an altercation with an umpire in a baseball game with the Keokuk Kernels.

AMERICANS who spend their vacations in Canada think of the Hudson's Bay Company as a symbol of our northern neighbors. Yet there was a time when The Company figured mightily in the destiny of a great region belonging to the United States.

WHEN 9-year-old Hannah Adams and her grandmother moved from Washington Square to Washington Heights, in New York City, she was ignored by the children in P. S. 181. Then she found a Star of David locket that opened the door to friendship with the 4 B's, most of whom were Jewish.

BALTIMORE, June 26 (UP) -- Ed Burtschy wild-pitched the winning run home in the tenth inning today to give the Baltimore Orioles a 5-4 victory over the Philadelphia Athletics before 7,418. It was the smallest crowd of the season at Memorial Stadium.

ONLY recently has the immense, rich, complex and seemingly remote area of sub-Sahara Africa assumed its proper position in the thoughts and interests of the United States. Until not long ago this vast land was regarded as unreal and distant in terms both of time and space, more near to the tales of H. Rider Haggard or the memoirs of audacious explorers than to the twentieth century and its problems of politics, ideology and economics.
GUATEMALA, June 26 -- The border between El Salvador and Guatemala has been closed, according to travelers who had intended going overland to San Salvador this morning.

THE wisest and most interesting book about reading that I know is Holbrook Jackson's "The Reading of Books."
