The forthcoming resurfacing of the West Side Highway from Twenty-second to Seventy-second Street will be done entirely during light-traffic hours. The contract for the job will require that the work be performed between 9 o'clock at night and 6 o'clock in the morning.

THE Eighth Annual Open Photography Exhibition, which opened last week at the Village Art Center, 42-44 West Eleventh Street, is notable principally for an over-all quality of mature expression rarely seen in shows of this type.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The United States and nine Latin American Governments called today for a meeting of the inter-American foreign ministers to consider the threat of international communism to the American Hemisphere.

In an unexpected diplomatic turnabout, Guatemala agreed yesterday to allow the Inter-American Peace Committee to conduct an on-the-spot investigation of the nine-day-old invasion of her her soil by anti-Communist rebels.

Eighteen outstanding tuberculosis experts will form an advisory committee to help carry forward a vigorous city-wide attack on the disease, Dr. Leona Baumgartner, Commissioner of Health and chairman of the Interdepartmental Health Council, announced yesterday.

As never before, the American college and university campus has taken on an international look. Hundreds of institutions now train foreign students. Even the smaller college has a fairly large representation of students from other lands.

PARIS, June 26 -- The French have grown accustomed to observe from afar such British-American discussions as that which began in Washington yesterday between President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill and their advisers.

THE review by Edward de Grazia of Gregory Zilboorg's "The Psychology of the Criminal Act and Punishment" begins with a reference to Li'l Abner, who was asked whether he was going to shoot his pappy. He answered, "Better me than someone who doesn't love him."

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., June 26 -- Tommy Bolt posted a 2-under-par 69 today to retain the lead at the end of the third round in the $15,000 Insurance City open golf tournament with a 54-hole score of 200.
NAPLES, Italy, June 26 -- The fifth national congress of the Christian Democratic party opened here this evening in a harmony that promises political stability in Italy for some time to come.
NEW DELHI, India, June 26 -- India and Communist China pledged today to follow a good-neighbor policy.
JERUSALEM, June 26 -- Evidence that the Wilderness of Zin was settled when Abraham moved through it from Canaan to Egypt about 4,000 years ago was reported today.

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., June 26 (UP) -- Eighty-year-old Donald B. MacMillan was promoted to rear admiral in a special Navy ceremony today and then sailed out of Boothbay Harbor on his thirtieth voyage to the Arctic.

AT one point in his late middle age Samuel F. B. Morse wished everything he had painted, aside from a few portraits that he valued as family records, might be destroyed. He considered himself a failure as an artist, and he did not care to be remembered as one.

Despite expressions to the contrary, the nation's schools are doing a good job in teaching the three R's (reading, writing and arithmetic), Dr. Herbert G. Espy, Maine Commissioner of Education, said yesterday.

Arginase is an enzyme -- that is, a catalyst -- which plays an important part in the utilization of nitrogen by the body. Dr. David M. Greenberg, chairman of the University of California's department of physiological chemistry, and his Egyptian associate, Mostafa S. Mohammed, thought of studying the effect of arginase on cancer tissue.
The October, 1952, Kings County Grand Jury handed up a presentment last week urging that the present Brooklyn Adolescents Court at 31 Snyder Avenue be moved to a more modern structure.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -- A Senate Rules subcommittee starts digging Monday into the ethics of Congressional investigating committees. It will hear an imposing list of witnesses. Vice President Richard M. Nixon will testify Wednesday.

I DETECT signs of a struggle. Quite possibly, Hawthorne Daniel, the romantic generalist, devoutly believed that the sea is an inexhaustible source that could offset the failing bounty of the land; but Francis Minot, the scientist, cautiously questioned and whittled away at his collaborator's will-to-believe.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dulles told Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden today that he had a "bad habit" -- doodling. The two were posing for photographers. They were sitting side by side behind a big table and trying rather self-consciously to look relaxed and cordial.
The first half of 1954 is coming to a close with business showing signs of improvement, and the stock market at a new high point since 1929.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 27 (AP) -- Two youngsters from Memphis blasted through the first round of the Western Golf Association's international four-ball tournament today and headed for the showdown match tomorrow with Don Cherry, Garden City, L. I., and Dale Morey, Martinsville, Ind., the tournament favorites.
CAIRO, June 27 -- The newly discovered sarcophagus of an ancient Pharaoh at Sakkara was opened secretly yesterday and found to be empty.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that an uptrend in exports of United States farm products that began last year continued through April of this year. April exports, valued at $244,000,000, were nearly 6 per cent larger in value than March shipments.

The large residence at 4643 Waldo Avenue, in the Fieldston section of the West Bronx, has been purchased by Dr. and Mrs. Lazarus Orkin from Paul Landau through Robert E. Hill, Inc., broker. It was once the home of the late John N. Willys, auto manufacturer.

Siberia is a vast region, about 5,000,000 square miles in area, rich in natural resources -- timber, nonferrous metals, furs and coal. These resources, for the most part, are still unexploited because of poor transportation, a population deficit -- and weather.
SEOUL, Korea, June 27 -- Four hundred youths of the Student Corps to Preserve the Nation gathered here this afternoon at Bai Jai High School to pay tribute to the bicentennial of Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Ever since his remarkably successful tour of non-Communist Asia last autumn, Vice President Richard M. Nixon has steadily squandered what seemed to be the most promising political reputation in the Republican party.

We welcome reports that the chances have improved for heading off a national steel strike when the present contract expires at midnight Wednesday. If a strike does occur in this period of relatively low steel production and high unemployment it will be hard to put aside the conviction that union politics is more responsible than economic considerations.
MOSCOW, June 27 -- The Communist party's Central Committee has reviewed the spring planting and plans for the fall harvest.
Col. Carlos Enrique Diaz, head of the Military Junta that took power in Guatemala last night, has been chief of that country's armed forces since March, 1951.
Land has been acquired for a new Harlem Children's Center to occupy the block between 117th and 118th Streets and Fifth and Lenox Avenues, it was annouced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (UP) -- Gran Hamner's two-run triple in the ninth inning gave the Phillies a 2-1 victory over the Milwaukee Braves today after Philadelphia took the opener from the visitors, 4 -- 3.
The Zionist Organization of America closed its fifty-seventh annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday with the election of Mortimer May of Nashville as president.

The Dodgers swept the series against the Cardinals with an 8-6 victory for their fifth straight at Ebbets Field yesterday. The Brooks had played .800 ball in their last thirty games -- but they still were one game out of first place.
MARKLEEVILLE, Calif., June 27 (AP) -- One of 500 searchers and his mongrel dog found 5-year-old Kathy Paxton today after she had been lost for two cold nights in the High Sierra.

The American Chemical Society's charge that the Selective Service authorities are violating the law and jeopardizing national security by giving inadequate occupational deferments to young scientists and engineers brings up an important problem.

BALTIMORE, June 27 (AP) -- Dick Kryhoski singled home winning runs in the eleventh and ninth innings today to extend his hitting streak to eighteen games and bring 4-3 and 3-2 victories to the Baltimore Orioles over the Philadelphia Athletics.

DETROIT, June 27 (AP) -- Eddie Yost, Mickey Vernon and Pete Runnels of the Washington Senators hammered home runs in Briggs Stadium today as Bob Porterfield coasted to an 8-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

GENEVA, June 27 -- Prince Wan Waithayakon, Foreign Minister of Thailand, left for New York by plane today to discuss arrangements for convoking the General Assembly to discuss Thailand's appeal to the United Nations.
A cooling breeze from Canada wafted over the northeastern part of the United States yesterday, bringing a sharp drop in the humidity and a brief hiatus in the sweltering summer weather.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Everybody talks about the high price of coffee -- and the Foreign Operations Administration is doing something about it.

" Sour-faced" Christians who are continually anguished about their own spiritual health and that of "those whom they annoy" tend to belittle God's love and God's forgiveness, Canon Darby W. Betts, precentor of the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine) declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Guatemalan Government has charged that rebel planes bombed and sank the British steamer Springfjord today at San Jose, fifty miles south of the city of Guatemala.

The Administration of President Eisenhower has been in office now for a little less than a year and a half. A year and a half is not a very long span of time; yet in this brief period the Administration has already proved that it possesses one very important attribute.

By its refusal to charge the owners of homeless cars for the publicly owned street space pre-empted, the city is not only now losing desperately needed revenue, but is also forfeiting what may be its last politically practical opportunity to control these mechanical vagrants.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- A United States-British agreement was reported tonight on a method for British withdrawal from the Suez Canal Zone.
MOSCOW, June 27 (AP) -- Izvestia today accused the United States of "intrigue" and of attempting to bind all Scandinavia in a North European military bloc directed against Russia.

MARCH AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 27 (AP) -- Fourteen men of the United States Air Force were killed early today when their big refueling plane, groping through the dark and heavy overcast, crashed and burned on Box Springs Mountain near this base.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- An early start toward formation of a Southeast Asian defensive alliance, with the concurrence of both Britain and the United States, was forecast tonight.

LONDON, June 27 -- The bull movement in the stock markets, which after a momentary pause was resumed ten days ago, continued throughout the last week with only a slight pause for breath toward the close.

PITTSBURGH, June 27 (AP) -- The Redlegs split a double-header with the Pirates today. Frank Thomas belted a tie-breaking single in the ninth inning of the second game to give Pittsburgh a 4-3 victory. Corky Valentine hurled a 9-0 shutout for Cincinnati in the opener.
A new industry wage offer was expected last night to ease the threat of a national steel strike.
ANKARA, Turkey, June 27 -- Turkey has privately urged Greece not to bring the question of the status of Cyprus before the United Nations.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 27 -- The total solar eclipse that will occur Wednesday along a 100-mile wide path through North America, Europe and Asia has drawn scientists from five nations to free Asia's most modern observatory at Quetta.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Light hedge pressure continued in the wheat trade last week, reflecting the intentions of growers to take government support loans at current price levels rather than sell on the open market. As a result there has been more active accumulation and prices edged up substantially only to react later.

BUFFALO, June 27 (AP) -- Parry O'Brien, Southern California's shot-put star, lived up to his reputation today and set three Niagara A. A. U. records at the Buffalo Fire-Fighters Association track and field meet.

TORONTO, June 27 -- Disaster could come to the security and freedom of the Western nations if they should ignore the need for economic improvements in underdeveloped areas, Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Minister for External Affairs, warned tonight.

SEATTLE, June 27 (AP) -- Bob Perry and Ron Livingston won the National Collegiate tennis doubles championship today, whipping Jacque Grigry and Allen Cleveland of Southern California, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 0, 3 -- 6, 8 -- 6. Their victory clinched the Penick Bowl for U. C. L. A.

MADRID, June 27 -- Jose Felix de Lequerica y Erquiza has resigned as Spanish Ambassador to the United States. He is expected to leave Washington before the end of the summer, well-informed Spaniards said today.
PITTSBURGH, June 27 -- Even aside from the impact of forward buying in the steel market because of wage and price factors, business has been on the upgrade for several weeks.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 27 -- President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman of Guatemala resigned tonight. He turned command of Guatemala over to Col. Carlos Enrique Diaz, chief of the armed forces.

TAMAQUA, Pa., June 27 (AP) -- Hard coal miners in Panther Creek Valley urged the Lehigh Navigation Coal Company today to cancel plans to abandon its operations in the area and offered to give up twenty days' pay to help the company in case of new losses.
Shakespeare enthusiasts will be flocking to the Stratford (Ont.) Shakespearean Festival, which embarks upon its second season tonight.
FOREST, Miss., June 27 (UP) -- Senator James O. Eastland took the spotlight in the South's anti-segregation fight today with a proposal for a national States Rights movement.

The fur industry will enjoy a 25 per cent increase in volume this year to pull it out of its depressed state, New York manufacturers predict. They base this forecast on greater enthusiasm shown by retail fur buyers who have been in the market in the last three weeks.

The ship charter market showed virtually no change for the better and very little change for the worse last week. The usual factors -- unstable international politics, small demand for coal and grain, the continuing slump in ore imports -- all contributed to keep volume and rates down.
KANSAS CITY, June 27 -- Some of the nation's top medical specialists have been summoned here for consultation on the unfavorable condition of former President Truman.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Several legal experts agreed today that witnesses before Congressional committees should enjoy greater protection against abuse.
Seven new films, including imports from England, Germany and Russia, will arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
National Guard trainees at Camp Drum, near Watertown, N. Y., got special leave yesterday to drop their training gear and fly back here to pick up their high school diplomas.
Undercover religious activities in Siberian slave-labor camps were described yesterday by the superior of the Russian Center at Fordham University.

BERN, Switzerland, June 27 (AP) -- A fight broke out between the Hungarian and Brazilian soccer teams in Bern's Wankdorf Stadium tonight after Hungary defeated Brazil, 4 -- 2, to enter the semi-final round of the world soccer championship.
CENTRAL CITY, Colo., June 27 -- Stars from the Metropolitan and the New York City Opera Companies opened the 1954 Central City Festival here last night with a presentation of Gounod's "Faust."

DARTMOUTH, Mass., June 27 (AP) -- The body of Theodore A. Morde, 43 years old, of New York, a television news producer, was found hanging yesterday in a shower stall in the bathroom of the home of his parents. William Rosen, medical examiner, of New Bedford ruled the death a suicide.
TO the right, inside the doorway at 1880 Broadway, last Thursday morning, seventeen children from 3 to 6 years old, all blind, were having their last day of school before summer holiday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 27 (AP) -- An American Airlines plane with thirty-four persons aboard landed safely here tonight on one engine, after a spectacular collision with a Navy plane that exploded and crashed in flames killing two crewmen.

It has become increasingly apparent that Red China's adroit Premier, Chou En-lai, is a formidable antagonist. In ten days of manipulation at Geneva and Berne, and now in the course of his triumphal processional through South Asia, he has made it more difficult than ever for the free world to unite in its defense against Communist aggression.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 27 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations said today the Eisenhower Administration's "piecemeal" approach toward development of water power resources was causing "growing anarchy" in the economy of the Pacific Northwest.
WASHINGTON, June 27 --A Senate subcommittee on irrigation and reclamation is scheduled to begin hearings tomorrow on an Administration measure that, for some Republicans, poses a political dilemma.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Republican leadership of Congress braced today for showdown votes in the week ahead on the Administration's tax, foreign aid and farm price support programs.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 27 -- A new factor has entered the United Fruit Company strike. A labor organizer for an anti-Communist group that has been backed by United States labor unions has applied for a visa in Mexico and is due here soon.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., June 27 -- Yesterday there was barely enough wind to make a pennant flutter for the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association's regatta at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club. Today it was a different story as the Riverside Yacht Club played host to the Y. R. A. fleet.
I read with dismay Gabriel R. Mason's letter advocating a salary differential, for New York City high school teachers.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 27 -- A carnival spirit spread over this resort today as a vanguard of 50,000 visitors -- Shriners and their families -- arrived for the week-long eightieth Imperial Council session of the Ancient Arabic Order of Nobles of the Mystic Shrine.
HANOI, Vietnam, Monday, June 28 -- The French High Command announced today that the opening of the Indochinese truce talks had been postponed until tomorrow.

NAPLES, June 27 -- The fifth national congress of the Christian Democratic party was set to work this morning with a keynote speech by former Premier Alcide De Gasperi, political secretary of the party. It was a two-hour address essentially directed at achieving party unity and strength.

The dog show successes of an imported 3 1/2-year-old hound-marked wire-haired foxterrier continued in the event of the Staten Island Kennel Club yesterday. Ch. Travella Superman of Harham, belonging to Mrs. Harold M. Florsheim of Chicago and handled by Tom Gately, was made best in show by Mrs. Rudolph A. Engle, the club president, at Cromwell Center, which also is called Pier 6.

The letter of Prof. Robert G. Mead Jr. in The Times of June 22 was very interesting to the writer -- but for a reason not mentioned by Professor Mead, nor, so far as has come to my attention, in any comment elsewhere in the press.
NEW HAVEN, June 27 (AP) -- The convention of the Congregational Christian Churches was told today that more than $4,500,000 dollars had been raised for the building of new churches.

In another of those spine-tingling finishes that have become standard Polo Grounds procedure, the Giants, after being two runs behind with two out in the ninth, defeated the Cubs, 3 -- 2, in ten innings yesterday. The victory kept the league-leading New Yorkers one game in front of the Dodgers.
WASHINGTON, Monday, June 28 -- The turnover in the Government of Guatemala has caused the Inter-American Peace Committee to postpone its scheduled flight to investigate the war there.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- A call for immediate recruiting of a civilian reserve of 5,000 executives, trained and willing to fill top jobs in war agencies in an emergency, was issued today by the National Planning Association.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 27 (UP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson charged today that the Republican Administration had permitted what "begins to look like a breakdown of effective government in the United States at this most critical time."

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- A clever maneuver by Senate Democrats did much to create an impression that President Eisenhower, despite strong Democratic support, lost a battle last week to high-tariff Republicans.

Department stores are still losing ground in the race for the consumer dollar. Two reports on 1953 business highlight the fact that their sales failed to keep pace with total retail sales or with the rise in consumer income.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- For years automobile companies have supplied cars to the White House on a lend-lease $500 a year basis, although that doesn't begin to cover the cost.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., June 27 -- The Seventy-seventh Army Reserve Infantry Division, at its initial 1954 summer training formation at near-by Camp Drum, heard tonight that the fundamental concept of leadership was for "each one of us to be able first to lead ourselves."

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, predicted today that "political indictments" of prominent Democrats would be an "important factor" in the 1954 Congressional campaign.

Of the 6,900 Stray animals picked up from New York streets during the past year, 2,600 were collected during the four summer months. The abandonment of animals by owners leaving on vacations is a serious and cruel offense to all sensitive citizens.

Available the year round, thanks to winter shipments from Florida, snap beans have an extra crisp "snap" of freshness now when they come from near-by gardens. The United States Department of Agriculture reports large supplies of top quality green beans, both the round and the flat types. It also notes that there are other kinds of beans in local markets, including favas, yellow wax and cranberry beans.

BONN, Germany, June 27 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democratic Union led the field in today's elections in North Rhine-Westphalia but lost ground to opponents of the Chancellor's pro-Western foreign policy.

NEW DELHI, India, June 27 -- Chou En-lai said today that Communist China was prepared to cooperate with other Asian nations. The Premier and Foreign Minister of Red China declared that "revolution cannot be exported," but he added that "outside interference with the common will expressed by the people of any nation should not be permitted."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 27 -- Dr. Eduardo Castillo-Arriola, permanent representative of Guatemala at the United Nations, said tonight that he believed and hoped that the change in government there "will be a very good one."
Construction of Private homes in this city declined 21 per cent last month, compared with May, 1953.
TOKYO, June 27 -- The Socialist Opposition will use the new Diet session next month for an attack on United States "domination" of the conservative Japanese Government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida.
Defying the season, Emy St. Just presented a dance program last night at the Alvin Theatre. It was the only modern dance performance in the Broadway district all season.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 27 -- Writing in the current issue of De Zankenwerld, Prof. Gerard M. Verryn, until recently senior manager of the Amsterdamsche Bank, says: "Even if convertibility were restored, a high European monetary authority still would be necessary."

William H. Davis, former chairman of the War Labor Board, called yesterday on leaders of organized labor to support Caspar H. Citron for the Democratic nomination for Representative in the Eighteenth Congressional District at the primary election on Sept. 14.

CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists called today for a speed-up in a program to disperse basic industries and civilian populations vulnerable to enemy hydrogen bomb threats.
Prices of near-by cotton futures contracts weakened last week on the New York Cotton Exchange, while those of the two most distant months improved moderately.

TUNIS, Tunisia, June 27 (AP) -- Members of the Cabinet of Mohammed Salah M'Zali, who resigned June 16 but have not been replaced, refused to attend to any more business today.

Men and women who were like brothers and sisters to each other as children in the old Sheltering Arms home met again yesterday at their annual reunion in the new Sheltering Arms Children's Service, 122 East Twenty- ninth Street.
PARIS, June 27 -- A further increase in the French industrial production and improvement in exports in May have just been announced by the Ministry of Finance and Economic Affairs.
JERUSALEM, June 27 -- An Israeli farmer who carried a United States passport was shot dead just after midnight at the door of his home in the orange-growing village of Raanana.
Net income of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway for the first five months of this year dropped to $20,058,121 from $31,002,844 for the same period last year.
WOLFEBORO, N. H., June 27 -- One of those vague international goodwill ideas that usually never amount to much beyond the thought amounted considerable in central New Hampshire this week-end.

" Call to Greatness," by Adlai Stevenson, a survey of the main problems and perils that the United States faces in this century, will be published by Harper Aug. 25. The former Presidential nominee finds "heartening evidence" of democracy's will to survive and of its ability to compete with totalitarianism.

The Rev. Dr. John Paul Jones, minister for more than twenty-two years of Union Church (Presbyterian), Eightieth Street and Ridge Boulevard, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, announced his resignation yesterday. It is effective Oct. 3. He announced no immediate plans.

A cricket match between the sexes, staged by the Staten Island Cricket Club was contested yesterday at Walker Park in Livingston. The Gentlemen of New York, batting left-handed, won by a margin of 21 runs from the Ladies of New York.

Three members of the Atlantic and Gulf District of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., and the son of a member of that union are the four winners of the second annual S. I. U. college scholarship awards.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UP) -- Joseph M. Swing, the Immigration Commissioner, said today the flow of illegal Mexican "wetbacks" across the Rio Grande was "drying up" as the result of a new crackdown by the Border Patrol.

The perennial attraction of "look-alike" fashions is probably shared equally by mother and daughter. Designs for these combinations are always thoughtfully planned to appeal to the mother's predilection for youthful lines and to the daughter's wish to look older.

Although man is able to fly at supersonic speeds, the air is not legally free as a medium of international travel. "Free as the air," it has been pointed out, "is a phrase which dates back to days when only birds flew."
HACKENSACK, N. J., June 27 -- Seeded players set the pace in the twenty-seventh annual Eastern clay court tennis championships at the Oritani Field Club today.

GENEVA, June 27 -- In two months of quarreling and negotiating, delegates to the Far Eastern conference here have at least succeeded in arriving at the main outlines of a possible settlement of the Indochinese war.
ST. LOUIS, June 27 -- The National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs took steps here today to strengthen its support of qualified women for elective and appointive Federal office.

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 27 -- The June Economic Bulletin of the Swiss Bank Corporation, issued today, explains why the Geneva conference on East-West trade, summoned at the wish of the countries of East Europe, ended on May 3 without any concrete achievement to its credit.

COLOR television took another major forward stride over the week-end with the first showing on the air of a 35-mm. film in natural hues. The quality of reproduction was by far the best yet seen and obviously is going to be ready for commercial acceptance within a short time.

A group of about seventy-five students and some twenty-five other persons in a Variety of walks of life have founded, in Karachi, Pakistan, "The Pakistan Friends of America Society." The purpose of the organization is to promote student exchange between this country and Pakistan, and through that to aid in building up closer cultural and social relations.
Health Commissioner Leona Baumgartner, a non-smoker, had some terse advice yesterday for cigarette smokers.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Army's world-wide stocks of combat equipment and ammunition are only one-third larger today than they were four years ago this month, at the start of the Korean war.
Communist China has set as her major 1959 target the heavy-industry level attained by the Soviet Union in 1932, according to Pravda, Soviet Communist party newspaper.
Advertising officials seem to be addicted to long vacations, according to Tide magazine.

CALCUTTA, India, June 27 (Reuters) -- Ten weary United States mountaineers arrived in Calcutta today after being beaten back from the summit of the world's fifth highest mountain by a wave of avalanches.
CHICAGO, June 27 (UP) -- The Red Sox committed five errors in the second game today and the White Sox scored four unearned runs in a 9 -- 1 victory to split a twin-bill before 29,684 fans.

A welcome wrinkle-resistance has been imparted to many new cottons by the use of resin finishes. These finishes, according to a recent bulletin of the United States Department of Agriculture, do not take well to chlorine bleaches.

BEFORE taking the cover off the typewriter I walked out into the garden to admire the roses and petunias and to listen to an invisible bird whose insistent cheep I could not recognize. It seemed not only an appropriate but also a necessary preparation for writing about Nan Fairbrother's "An English Year,"* for few books are so concerned with flowers and birds as this is.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Hearings in a test case that affects 20,000 refugees from behind the Iron Curtain will open here tomorrow. Affected are persons who concealed their true national origins when they entered the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Senator George W. Malone said today there was evidence that the late Harry Dexter White and other former Government officials deliberately "planted" a policy of buying critical raw materials overseas, making the United States dangerously dependent on "possible fickle allies or timid neutrals."

The proposed code of the Department of Hospitals raising standards for private nursing homes to be established after July 1 should be amended to provide for uniform regulation of all private nursing homes within three years, the Welfare and Health Council of New York City urged yesterday.
Business men need a clear picture of how to operate under the anti-trust laws, the National Association of Manufacturers asserts.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 27 -- The D. H. Lawrence novel, "Sons and Lovers," published in 1913 and rated as one of the best of the prolific English writer's controversial studies of emotional conflicts, will be put on film next year by Columbia Pictures.

Jacobo Arbenz Guzman, the former infantry lieutenant who became President of Guatemala on March 15, 1951, seemingly walked a tight-rope between his anti-Communist Army and his Communist political allies during his term of office.

The All-America halfback from Minnesota has been a member of the New York Giants baseball team a little more than a fortnight and he's seen more dramatic finishes, more heroics and more spectacular baseball than any newcomer to the big leagues has any right to witness.
A hot sun and merciful breezes greeted fifty Chicagoans yesterday morning at the roof-top auditorium of the Presbyterian Labor Temple, 242 East Fourteenth Street.
Four American independent oil companies are preparing to drill test wells in an 80,000-square-mile area of the western Egyptian desert under an agreement with the Egyptian Government.

The teachers of America are afraid to discuss controversial issues in the classroom, Dr. Martin Essex, chairman of the Committee on Tenure and Academic Freedom of the National Education Association, declared yesterday.

LONDON, June 27 (AP) -- British cruisers steamed out into the North Sea tonight for an early morning meeting with the Swedish cruiser Tre Kronor (Three Crowns), on which Sweden's King Gustaf and Queen Louise are traveling to Britain for a state visit.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- The Army has acted under the new Defense Department directive authorizing secrecy for information stamped "For official use only."
A five-alarm fire in Harlem early yesterday resulted in injuries to five firemen and considerable damage to two tenements.

John Golden, a dynamic pillar of the American theatre, made his debut yesterday as an octogenarian. He was a smash hit.
GUATEMALA, June 27 -- The regime of President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman came to an end tonight. He agreed to step down in favor of a military junta.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 27 -- By new efforts they have made to dodge a showdown, both the Government and labor in Brazil have shown the importance they attach to the current dispute over a nation-wide increase in minimum wages.

Franchot Tone is quitting "Oh, Men! Oh, Women!," of which he is the star and a backer. Beyond admitting that he was leaving Edward Chodorov's hit comedy, Mr. Tone declined to volunteer any details. Elsewhere, it was learned that he was making preparations to relinquish his role on July 10 or thereabout, depending upon when his successor can join the Cheryl Crawford-Anderson Lawler attraction.

Rose L. Halprin's letter published in The Times of June 18 treats us to some fanciful feats of reasoning. It seems that because there has been a change of regime in one or two Arab states the United States Government ought to abandon any effort to win back the friendship and the mutual confidence which characterized Arab-American relations prior to the Palestine debacle.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., June 27 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt missed a 9-footer for a birdie on the final hole today and ended in a tie for first place with Earl Stewart in the seventy-two-hole, $15,000 Insurance City open golf tournament. Each posted 271.

Fred Eckhoff, a national junior champion of Norway, running for the New York Athletic Club, broke a 40-year-old meet record in the three-mile run yesterday at the junior track and field championships of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union at Randalls Island.
CLEVELAND, June 27 -- This is not a fish story, but the Yankees, who had reeled in two big ones the first two nights here, let the biggest one get away from them today.

Only a few years ago the economic future of the strategic little island republic of Iceland looked as bleak as most of her landscape.
Michael J. Quill called on the Transit Authority yesterday to resume contract talks immediately with his Transport Workers Union, C. I. O.

The Rev. Dr. C. Ivar Hellstrom, in a sermon at Riverside Church, yesterday linked a "disturbing" stress on conformity in American political life with a form of "conventional religion." This religious form, he said, seeks to "domesticate God."
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 27 -- Yehudi Menuhin and Jascha Veissi shared soloist honors this afternoon at the fourth concert of the Pacific Coast Festival of Music.

The men's clothing industry operated at 76 per cent of capacity during the first five months of this year, as compared with 88 per cent in the corresponding period of 1953 and 70 per cent in 1952, the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. reported yesterday.
SEOUL, Korea, June 27 -- South Korea was reported today to have asked Gen. James A. Van Fleet, President Eisenhower's fact-finder in the Far East, for $300,000,000 a year in military aid.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (UP) -- The Administration apparently has reversed itself and decided to put off any drastic overhaul of the military reserve program until next year.

In Christ, "the first priest of the Church," is the key to peace in the world, Msgr. Francis X. Shea, pastor of the Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New Rochelle, declared yesterday in a sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 28 -- Gus Salerno, Hampshire Country Club professional who will celebrate his forty-third birthday on Saturday, scored his first major golf victory today. Salerno won the Westchester Professional Golfers Association championship at the Fenway Golf Club with a 36-hole score of 143.

A 54-year-old doorman at the apartment building at 785 Park Avenue, at Seventy-third Street, was shot yesterday as he attempted to hold a gunman who was escaping after a $30 robbery in a near-by candy store.

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -- Butchers and sows fell 25 to 50 cents on the livestock market today as salable hog receipts totaled 9,000 head. Top of $25.45 was sparingly paid for choice offerings weighing around 215 pounds and less. Spring lambs, old crop lambs and sheep sold steady in the sheeep section. Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today:
Overheard at Grand Central Terminal at 5 P. M yesterday at the entrance to Track 23:
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The new Guatemalan regime of Col. Carlos Enrique Diaz pledged full cooperation today with the Inter-American Peace Committee's investigation of the fighting in Guatemala.
LONDON, June 28 (AP) -- Five more tin-consuming nations signed the International Tin Agreement today in a last-minute rush that officials said ensured ratification.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 28 -- The African National Congress, which has been lying low since the failure of its "defiance" campaign two years ago, is mobilizing 50,000 volunteers for a new nonviolent attack on Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's apartheid (segregation) policy.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Sir Winston Churchill, full of mighty hopes, appealed today for another "patient, cool, friendly examination of what the Russian intentions are." In what must have been the largest news conference in the history of this capital, the British Prime Minister told more than 1,000 reporters that he was still for talking to the Russians in the hope of avoidinga war that would "leave us victorious on a heap of ruins."

Paul Giel, the All-America football player from Minnesota who signed with the Giants for a reported $60,000 bonus a couple of weeks ago, pitched five strong innings against the Red Sox last night. Then he was tagged for a grand-slam homer by Grady Hatton.
The city is preparing to bring order out of what Dr. Leona Baumgartner described last year as "the chaos of mental health services."

When Virgil Burford landed in Alaska in 1938, he was penniless. Not long afterward he received $100 for ten minutes work -- going underwater in a diving suit and cutting a killer whale out of a salmon trap with wire-nippers. In "North to Danger," he tells about his fifteen years of adventure around Prince William Sound, doing deep-sea diving, fish - pirating, treasure - seeking and bear-hunting.
Du Pont rose a spectacular 15 1/2 points yesterday and, almost unaided, pushed The New York Times industrial and combined stock averages to new high marks for the year and for the movement.
The factional division among Queens Democrats widened last night when leaders of the two groups held separate meetings in the same building at 60-19 Roosevelt Avenue, Wodside.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Joseph F. Elward, Chicago attorney, won today his fight for election as a director of Peabody Coal Company. Shareholders also approved by a wide margin a management-proposed stock option plan for Otto Gressens, executive vice-president.

TRENTON, June 28 (AP) -- The conviction of Michael Orecchio, former Bergen County Chief of Detectives for misconduct in office was set aside today by the New Jersey Supreme Court. A new trial was ordered.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 28 (UP) -- Mrs. Andrea Luckenbach Hammer, 33-year-old heiress to a shipping fortune, was shot four times by her estranged husband in a paddock at the Delaware Park Race Track today.

The Hundred Year Association of New York, Inc., announced yesterday that its gold medal in recognition of outstanding achievement for the advancement of New York had been awarded this year to Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president and publisher of The New York Times.

After four days of "friendly and fruitful" discussions, ranging over the whole gamut of problems confronting them, President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Churchill have reached agreement on the most essential steps to be taken in Europe and in Asia to safeguard the free world against Communist aggression.

An article published in The New York Times on June 12 erroneously identified a sightseeing vessel involved in a harbor accident as the property of the Circle Line, 30 Rockefeller Plaza. The boat, the Gotham, is not owned by the Circle Line.

ST. LOUIS; June 28 -- A panel discussion of women in business and the professions reached the view here tonight that women workers, by inclination or error, often hindered their own progress toward top careers.

Siberia has been surrounded for so long with an aura of mystery that the pictures of Siberian cities published in this newspaper yesterday may well have surprised many by their commonplace features. The pictures showed that Siberia has ordinary people who go to market or to the movies; it has children who like to play like youngsters everywhere; and it even has a beauty parlor for ladies in search of permanent waves.
William L. Patterson, executive secretary of the Civil Rights Congress, was adjudged guilty of contempt of court yesterday by Federal Judge John F. X. McGohey and sentenced to ninety days in jail.
Following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's interview with the press in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The United States was advised today "to resort to some type of governmental export pricing program" to get a fair share of world markets for farm products.

The resolution of the New Jersey Legislature to cooperate with New York and assist in the study of a new railroad tunnel under the Hudson to connect with the existing Fourteenth Street B. M. T. subway is a commendable step.

Thanks for your round-up on June 19 of editorial opinion on the Army-McCarthy hearings. Many are asking me my opinion about them. Yes, McCarthy is on the long road down. But none of your quotations, from twenty-seven newspapers, touched on what may prove to be their lasting consequences -- on what students of politics ten or twenty years from now may see as important about them.
The resurfacing of part of the West Side Highway and other Manhattan improvements will cost the city less than expected.

PITTSBURGH, Tuesday, June 29 -- The danger of a national steel strike was virtually eliminated here early this morning as union and industry negotiators reached tentative agreement on terms of a new contract.

PARIS, June 28 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France said tonight that in their joint statement today President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Churchill had provided "valuable support" for France in her negotiations for a cease-fire in Indochina.
Charles J. McCarthy has been elected chairman of Chance Vought Aircraft, Inc., effective July 1. Mr. McCarthy formerly was a vice president of United Aircraft Corporation.

ANN ARBOR, Mich, June 28 -- Aging persons must shake off a "guilt feeling" about not working if they are going to be happy in retirement, Clark Tibbitts, chairman of the Committee on Aging and Geriatrics of the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare, said today.
" Complete confusion" is in the making for the cigarette market unless "aggressive measures'' are undertaken. The United States Tobacco Journal asserts in its current issue.

TRENTON, June 28 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, won a major victory today over the Republican-controlled Legislature when that body submitted to his terms on the controversial-state school aid program.
Play in the women's Eastern clay court tennis championships started yesterday at the Bayside Tennis and Racquets Club with thirty contestants.

A current vogue in wine-drinking puts that table beverage right "in the pink." Popular choices in shops today are those rosy wines the French call vins roses. They are neither red nor white but in between. In the best specimens they are light, lively, fresh and fruity.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Democratic party leaders of New York State, two former high Truman Administration officials among them, today assailed the Eisenhower foreign policy.

BUFFALO, June 28 (UP) -- Aid and understanding must come from the Interstate Commerce Commission and state commissions if the railroad industry is to compete with subsidized transportation, the new president of the New York Central said yesterday.

New Yorkers up at sunrise tomorrow will be able to see -- weather permitting -- three-quarters of an eclipse of the sun. If they watch a television screen instead of the sky they may be able to see a complete eclipse.

CAIRO, June 28 -- The Egyptian Government is expecting information tomorrow on proposals to settle the Anglo-Egyptian dispute over sovereignty in the Suez Canal area reported to have been formulated at the Eisenhower-Churchill talks in Washington.
The Nicaraguan merchant marine, a post-war addition to world shipping, is expanding rapidly in an effort to insure prompt, direct trade with the United States and Europe.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- The Marine Corps is organizing its own anti-aircraft guided missile units to protect its airfields and beachheads in amphibious operations.

Retirement plans cannot begin too early. That is the view found among women who took part recently in a survey by the appointment oureau of Radcliffe College. Seventy-one women, retired or approaching the age for it, answered a questionnaire that dealt with retirement problems. The results have been reported by Mary Islay Tucker Murgatroyd in the current issue of The Radcliffe Quarterly.

Contributions of blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program on Friday totaled 399 pints. Included were 104 pints given at the Western Electric Company, 395 Hudson Street; ninety-four at the Department of Public Works, Municipal Building, and ninety-one at the Singer Sewing Machine Company, 149 Broadway.

HANOI, Vietnam, June 28 (Reuters) -- Efforts to arrange an Indochina ceasefire ran into a series of snags today as scheduled truce talks between the opposing high commands were postponed for the second time.

BERN, Switzerland, June 28 (AP) -- International soccer officials today severely censured the Hungarian and Brazilian teams for their fist fighting yesterday. But they carefully avoided taking any action that might have hurt Hungary's chances against Uruguay on Wednesday in the semi-finals of the World Cup championship at Lausanne.

CONCORD, N. H., June 28. (AP) -- Attorneys for two educators argued in Merrimack County Seuperior Court today that State Attorney General Louis C. Wyman had no constitutional right to compel their clients to give details of a University of New Hampshire lecture.
TRENTON, June 28 -- Former State Treasurer Walter T. Margetts Jr. accused former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman today of "deceiving" both the State Auditor and himself.

LONDON, June 28 -- Politicians and diplomats expressed the opinion tonight that the British policy of delaying formal international negotiations on the formation of a Southeast Asian defense pact till the outcome of the Geneva conference is known had prevailed in the Washington talks.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 28 (AP) -- Midway Queen captured the Floral Park Grand Circuit, pacing feature tonight at Roosevelt Raceway in 2:12 2-5 over the mile and one-sixteenth route. Hal Adam was second, two lengths back. Chief McKlyo was third.
Reflecting a rise in sales, net profit of the Champion Paper and Fibre Company for the year ended March 31 increased to $9,546,312 from $8,873,918 in the preceding fiscal year.
Temporary financing for a prompt start on the St. Lawrence River power project has been arranged by the Power Authority of the State of New York, it was announced yesterday by Robert Moses, chairman.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- In diplomatic quarters equipped with what are believed to be excellent channels of intelligence in Guatemala an opinion expressed today was that, while the situation is more favorable from the standpoint of the anti-Communist interest, the claims of several Guatemalans who played a part in deposing President Arbenz must be resolved before anyone can be sure how much damage has been inflicted on the Moscow-directed Communist conspiracy in that country.
Seven high school students left here by bus yesterday to spend two months' living and working with Navajo Indians in the community of Ramah, south of Gallup, N. M.
HACKENSACK, N. J., June 28 -- Ronnie Holmberg, 16-year-old Brooklyn player, advanced to the fourth round of the Eastern clay court tennis championships at the Oritani Field Club today.

Commodity prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges in generally dull trading. Potatoes, rubber, cottonseed oil, hides, burlap and tin closed higher than Friday; coffee, wool, silk, zinc, lead and copper lower, and cocoa, sugar and soybean oil ended unevenly.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Eisenhower Administration made clear tonight it was ready to take on the bipartisan Congressional farm bloc in the increasingly bitter battle over farm policy.

DALLAS, June 28 -- The leading official of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People declared today that the coming challenge of de-segregation was "not a Negro problem, but an American problem."
A trend of recent years toward a shorter work week and higher wages and salaries in New York City Continued last year, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

JERUSALEM, June 28 -- Prime Minister Moshe Sharett said today that recent talks with Eric Johnston, President Eisenhower's special envoy, had "evidenced a common desire to arrive at a coordinated development" of the Jordan River basin.
MOSCOW, June 28 -- Special prayers will be said tomorrow night in Moscow's Baptist Church for the recovery of Mr. Truman.
The money market was easier yesterday, reflecting the initial impact of the recent reduction in reserve requirements.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce wants the nation's industries to draw up their own individually tailored plans for getting back into production after a bombing assault and is not working out any master industrial defense plan, it was announced today.

ON the cover of the New York Giant yearbook for 1952 there appeared one of Willard Mullin's cleverest cartoons. It portrayed Leo Durocher sitting on the bench in uniform and reading a book. The title of the book was "The Little Miracle of Coogan's Bluff," the fantastic tale of the unbelievable homestretch run of the Polo Grounds tenants to the pennant, a surge which was capped by Bobby Thomson's historic home run.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 28 -- It was brains over brawn as those wandering veterans of the tennis wars, Jaroslav Drobny and Budge Patty, threw the seedings into confusion and the packed house into pandemonium with smashing triumphs over Lew Hoad of Australia and the defending champion, Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, in the all-England lawn tennis championships this bitterly cold afternoon.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- The text of the statement issued today by President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Churchill follows:

This is my first attempt to break into print, but the Summer Festival just inaugurated has set me off. The merchants' efforts to bring more visitors to New York -- and also more business -- are commendable. But it would be wise for them also to get together with the so-called City Fathers to make the city safe and pleasant for those visitors.

If the city's business men want to make certain that no more nuisance taxes will be imposed, they were told yesterday that they should get solidly behind future fiscal programs sent to Albany by City Hall.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 28 -- About 4,000 B. C., the Chaldeans and Assyrians had calendars, as did the Egyptians. The Greeks and Romans later devised improved versions, following which, in 1582, Pope Gregory XIII worked out the calendar that is used in most countries today.
GENEVA, June 28 -- The United Nations program for the rehabilitation of South Korea finally is getting into high gear. However, it is in danger of running out of money.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UP) -- Senate investigators were told today that Robert R. Young, railroad magnate, and members of the du Pont family had interests in concerns that reaped "windfall" profits in recently exposed housing scandals.
The week-long Puerto Rican migration conference just ended in San Juan resulted yesterday in plans for the migration of one Puerto Rican -- to Puerto Rico.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- For the third consecutive week the Treasury has reported a slight raise in its short-term borrowing costs.
At the urging of Governor Dewey the State Commerce Department yesterday asked Alexander Smith, Inc., Yonkers rug plant, to reconsider closing its factory.

NIANTIC, Conn., June 28 -- The striped bass that feed in the Niantic are not as large as those that cruise the waters near Jamestown and Narragansett on the Rhode Island shore. However, they provide really interesting light-tackle fishing.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The most effective cures for Juvenile delinquency are the strengthening of family life and fighting adult crime rings, Senator Robert C. Hendrickson asserted today.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Senate Democrats, drastically lowering their sights, came forward today with a proposal for a $100 increase in personal income tax exemptions, effective next year.
MOBILE, Ala., June 28 (UP) -- A blind Korean War veteran swam to the rescue of two teen-age girls and a 22-year-old man yesterday.

Seventeen plots 100 by 150 feet on Summit Avenue and Shady Lane in Mountainside, N. J., have been purchased by Louis Simon and Ralph Dietz for improvement with split-level dwellings in the $19,000 price bracket. The Boyle Company, broker in the transaction, will act as sales agent for the houses.

TORONTO, June 28 -- Full-scale application of welfare state principles may undermine the foundations of Western society, one of Britain's leading authorities on child health told the seventh International Conference Social Work today.
Walter Cartier, 164 1/2, Greenwich Village, gained a ten-round verdict over Tuzo Portuguez, 161, Costa Rica, last night before 1,002 persons at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn.
Business has started to climb in New York City's department stores and retailers do not know exactly why.

Time was when paint could be roughly classified in interior and exterior categories. But, more and more, efforts are being made by manufacturers to engineer paints to specific needs and end uses -- the latest being fire-retardant and non-slip finishes and coatings for exterior woods that retain the wood grain.

BALTIMORE, June 28 (AP) -- Dr. H. C. Byrd, former University of Maryland president making his first bid for public office, held a narrow edge over George P. Mahoney, paving contractor, tonight in the Demrcratic primary for Governor.

LONDON, June 28 -- King Gustaf Adolf and Queen Louise of Sweden sailed up the Thames today in a full state ceremonial. They were greeted at the river's edge by Queen Elizabeth II on behalf of the people of Britain.
NEW DEHLI, India, June 28 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the communique issued today on the talks between Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India and Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China:

The net income of thirty-five leading United States oil companies last year amounted to $2,258,000,000 after taxes, an increase of 8.8 per cent over the $2,075,000,000 cleared in 1952, the Chase National Bank reported yesterday.

Bernard R. Sobel, counsel for the Long Island Rail Road Company, told Federal Judge Mortimer W. Byers in Brooklyn yesterday that the bankrupt railroad had been caught in a controversy between the city and State of New York "which had political overtones."
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active and irregular yesterday, closing 22 points lower to 8 points higher on active months.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 28 -- Plans are shaping up for a motion-picture version of the operetta "Porgy and Bess," first produced on Broadway in 1935 and revived there last year with great success.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 28 -- The Pacific Coast Music Festival began its institute phase today at the Lobero Theatre with an exploration of current major questions in the social, scientific and esthetic fields.

Hyman's New York and Long Island Express, Inc., in a plan for expansion, has purchased an adjoining plot of 15,000 square feet on the north side of Ninety-fourth Street, between Sutphin Boulevard and 150th Street, in Jamaica, Queens, from the Julian Freirich Company. Louis J. Unger was the broker.
KANSAS CITY, June 28 -- Former President Truman showed virtually no progress today in his fight against enteritis -- an intestinal inflammation.
The National Maritime Union, C. I. O., announced yesterday that it had signed a new contract with the Collier Owners Association covering 550 to 650 seamen employed on twenty-six coal ships.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 28 -- The Guatemalan insurgents declared tonight that the banning of the Communist party by the new junta was a "maneuver inspired by desperation."
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Senators set out today to revive public confidence in their investigations.

The first performances of new operas by Stanley Hollingsworth and Lukas Foss are planned as highlights of the 1954-55 season of the N. B. C. Television Opera Theatre, it was announced yesterday by Samuel Chotzinoff, producer.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., June 28 (AP) -- Mickey Mantle's seventh-inning home run with a man on base was the only display of Yankee power today as the world champions bowed to their Binghamton Eastern League farm club, 5 -- 2, in an exhibition.

It is with satisfaction that we note a moderate and realistic tone in the statements coming from President Rhee and his Government in Korea. They give an assurance that there will not be, at this time, any unilateral Korean action that might forfeit United Nations support and jeopardize the chance of a future settlement.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 28 -- Headquarters of Col. Carlos Castillo Armas here declared today that the resignation of President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman of Guatemala was unconstitutional and that his successor, Col. Carlos Enrique Diaz, was a "usurper."

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., June 28 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt won the Insurance City open golf tournament 18-hole play-off today when Earl Stewart, conceded on the final green in a heavy shower. They had tied with 271 at the end of 72 holes yesterday.

United States Attorney Leonard P. Moore charged yesterday that Joseph D. Nunan was doubly guilty of willful evasion of his income taxes because, he said, Nunan was familiar with "the rules and regulations" when he was the United States Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

When Johnny comes marching home, it's a big day in the lives of his family and friends. Johnny comes marching home to thousands of American families each month, but thousands of other boys are being regularly inducted into our ormed forces.
The Liberal party announced yesterday that it had decided to oppose the re-election of Representative James G. Donovan in the Eighteenth - Congressional District.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The United States and Britain agreed today to move forward at once to form plans for the defense of Southeast Asia based on the alternatives of peace or continuing war in Indochina.
LONDON, June 28 -- The stock markets today pursued their hesitant course of the last few days. Industrial shares, in particular, weakened in late business and closed showing both gains and losses.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 28 -- After a crippling automobile accident, Wilfred Schwab has twice learned how to paint -- first with his right hand, until it became paralyzed, and now with his left hand.

GENEVA, June 28 -- French sources here expressed satisfaction tonight with the paragraph in the Eisenhower-Churchill statement warning of the dangers that would follow if France were faced by unacceptable demands from the Communists.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Senator William Langer said today that the Senate anti-monopoly subcommittee would open hearings Thursday on the contract President Eisenhower directed the Atomic Energy Commission to sign with a private utility combine to supply power to the Tennessee Valley Authority.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., June 28 -- What often is referred to as the "stepchild" of the military -- the Intelligence section -- got a small but significant boost today at near-by Camp Drum.
FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan., June 28 (AP) -- The Secretary of the Army, Robert T. Stevens, said today he would serve as Secretary as long as President Eisenhower felt he was doing his job right.

A tugboat capsized yesterday in Jamaica Bay while helping to pull an excursion steamer free of the Rockaway Beach Playland dock at Beach Ninety-eighth Street. The two crew members of the fifty-foot tugboat were rescued.
The Giants and the Dodgers, virtually shoulder to shoulder in the National League pennant race, will clash tonight at the Polo Grounds in the opener of a three-game series.

Canadian Pacific Railway's business plummeted in the first five months this year. The railroad announced last night that gross revenues fell to $170,445,714 from $190,755,636 in the like period of 1953. The decline was the sharpest ever recorded for the corresponding period in the company's history.

The Distaff Handicap had its inaugural running at Aqueduct yesterday, and the result was one of no little surprise to most of the 20,727 fans in attendance. There were twelve fillies and mares in the seven-furlong sprint, and one of these, Robert Howard's Mab's Choice, hadn't won a race in thirty starts over a two-year period.
DEL RIO, Tex., June 28 -- History's greatest flood on the Rio Grande sent thousands fleeing to the hills tonight as rain-swollen tributaries to the north claimed a mounting toll of dead and missing.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 28 (UP) -- Night Baker, with Joe Culmone aboard, accounted for his second straight victory of the Monmouth Park meeting today by leading home a field of 3-year-olds in the featured Audacious Purse.
Vacation schedules and preparations for the July 4 holiday were expected to trim the nation's steel-making operations this week to the lowest level since Christmas.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- National banks had assets of $107,000,000,000 on April 15, Ray M. Gidney, Controller of the Currency, reported today.

The Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks announced yesterday that he would retire on Oct. 1 after twenty-eight years as rector of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty third Street. He will become rector emeritus.

BANFF, Alberta, June 28 -- Women of North America are not living up to their leadership responsibilities, Dr. Kenneth Dale Wells declared at a meeting in the Banff Springs Hotel here today. President of Freedom's Foundation, Valley Forge, Pa., Dr. Wells spoke at a meeting of the biennial convention of the American Federation of Soroptimist Clubs.

After more than a year of negotiation and some changes in its articles of incorporation, the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company, one of the two largest international oil enterprises in the world, has applied to list 24,327,321 of its new capital shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Foreign Operations Administration allotted $8,000,000 to Jordan today. The action was taken under the first economic aid agreement between the United States and an Arab state.
Critics of modern education have built a straw man that they are now trying to knock down, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, June 28 -- the historic wage differential between Northern and Southern steel workers will be eliminated Thursday in plants of the major steel producers.
I would like to call your attention to a ridiculous and discriminatory tariff regulation which was conceived in ignorance and carried on the books due to the same ignorance that fashioned it.
A Federal court jury decided early today that Westbrook Pegler, columnist, and two Hearst corporations must pay $175,001 in damages for libeling Quentin Reynolds, author and former war correspondent.

Pierre Monteux returned to Lewisohn Stadium last night for the ninth successive summer. His soloist was Claudio Arrau, Chilean pianist, who also has been appearing regularly at the Stadium since 1946. The two distinguished musicians collaborated in a program devoted wholly to Beethoven.

WQXR will celebrate Dominion Day, Canada's national holiday, on Thursday with a program of works by Canadian composers during "Symphony Hall," from 8:05 to 9 P. M. The feature work of the musical salute will be the "Coronation" Suite by Healy Willan.

A veteran of both World Wars, Maj. Gen. Charles W. Christenberry, will retire from the Army at a ceremony on Governors Island tomorrow. A parade will be given in his honor at First Army Head-quarters. An Oak Leaf Cluster for his Korean services will be presented to him by Lieut. Gen. Withers A. Burress, First Army Commander.

The success of the New York State programs to aid the migrant worker's child depends on the communities through which the programs operate. This community responsibility, a "matter of public education," was emphasized in interviews recently with spokesmen of state departments that deal with these children.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 28 -- A United States Air Force C-47 flying over the area where Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador converge was shot at this morning by an unidentified F-47, Whiting Willauer, United States Ambassador, said today.

This is wonderful weather for weeds, and it is obvious that they fully appreciate it. Standing straight and tall, they seem to be giving thanks to the sun which warms them or to the rain which offers nourishment.

NEW DELHI, India, June 28 -- India and Communist China have come to an agreement that the political settlement for Indochina should aim at the creation of "free, democratic, unified and independent states." It specifies that the states, Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia, should not be used for aggressive purposes or be subject to "foreign intervention."

The man who commanded the Soviet Air Force in World War II, Chief Aviation Marshal Alexander A. Novikov, has been returned to power and rank after a period of post-war disgrace during which he worked as a slave laborer in the Vorkuta coal mines.
Short-term loan notes totaling $55,000,000 will be sold by the New York City Housing Authority on July 13, according to Philip J. Cruise, chairman.

The National Football League's 1954 season of seventy-two games will open on Sunday, Sept. 26, with all twelve teams in operation. The campaign will end with another full slate on Sunday, Dec. 12, and the championship game will be played two weeks later in the home park of the Eastern Conference victor.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 28 -- Guatemala's delegation chief said today he had received no new instructions from the new government at home. Dr. Eduardo Castillo-Arriola said the only information he had had from the Foreign Ministry was a cablegram confirming the resignation of President Jacob Arbenz Guzman.
GUATEMALA, June 28 -- The Communist party was outlawed in Guatemala today by the administration of Col. Carlos Enrique Diaz, Provisional President.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UP) -- The Navy Department announced today it would cost $85,000,000 to convert the Boston Navy Yard to handle Forrestal class carriers and that it could not justify such an outlay at this time.

Four men lost their right to deal in securities in the state yesterday for defrauding their employer, B. G. Phillips Co., a brokerage concern at 44 Wall Street that was put out of business two months ago, according to State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.

New York plays host to many conventions, but it takes more than the usual pleasure in welcoming the nation's public school teachers, represented to a strength of perhaps 20,000, at the National Education Association's first meeting here in many years.

Securities totaling $33,870,000 have been called for redemption or conversion by the Union Oil Company of California and the Haloid Company, it was announced yesterday. Both companies have made arrangements with investment bankers to offer to purchase all securities tendered in the exchange period.
MINEOLA, L. I., June 28 -- The Nassau County Health Department, in an initial 1954 report on county bathing beaches, today listed fifty-nine beach permits and denial of four applicants.
ROME, June 28 -- The Roman Catholic Church is prepared to collaborate with the United Nations for a reform of the calendar. It would even consider establishing a fixed date for Easter.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Administration leaders in the House of Representatives asked passage of the $3,470,608,000 foreign-aid bill today to support President Eisenhower's hand in world affairs.

Twentieth Century-Fox announced yesterday that it would release "Martin Luther," Louis de Rochemont's film biography of the religious leader in thirty-eight countries, including Argentina, France, Italy, Israel, Japan and Spain.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Francis X. P. Crowley, one of nine persons cited for contempt for refusing to testify about alleged Communist party connections, today reversed his stand and testified freely before the House Un-American Activities Committee.
Robert Whitehead has engaged Sam Jaffe to portray the important role of the Inquisitor in "Saint Joan," starring Jean Arthur.

The American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday that net income in the twelve months ended May 31 rose to $30,331,013, from the $29,560,320 earned in the preceding fiscal year.

Word came through yesterday afternoon that the new Government of Guatemala, after taking power away from President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman, had outlawed the Communist party. Guatemala now has a Government, legal or otherwise under the Guatemalan Constitution, which came into power without any fighting in the capital city itself.

BONN, Germany, June 28 -- The statement issued in Washington by Prime Minister Churchill and President Eisenhower was greeted by the West German Government with a silence that bespoke obvious disappointment.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- The American Federation of Labor today urged that Social Security benefits be increased considerably more than provided in the Eisenhower Administration's bill.

In his State of the Union message last January President Eisenhower declared: "We should now remove the more glaring tax inequities, particularly on small taxpayers; reduce restraints on the growth of business and make other changes that will encourage initiative, enterprise and production."

MUNICH, Germany, June 28 (UP) -- A former Soviet secret police officer said today the Soviet people and the Soviet Army would support the West in a "shooting war" aimed at overthrowing the Communists and freeing the Soviet Union.
NEW HAVEN, June 28 (AP) -- Representatives of the nation's Congregational Christian churches today gave an emphatic -- but steadying -- "go ahead" to their Social Action Council.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 28 -- Henri Hoppenot, chief French delegate to the United Nations, said here today that the world organization should not be used to further any one ideology or the interests of any one nation.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- All grain futures declined in the forepart of the session today, wheat leading the downturn. The lowest prices were registered early in the session and good support was encountered in all pits.
ALBANY, June 28 -- The Court of Appeals up held tonight the constitutionality of four new Brooklyn Assembly Districts that had been attacked as examples of gerrymandering.

Greater support of education is essential if this country is to retain its world prestige and leadership, Harold C. McClellan, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, declared yesterday.
As thousands of New Yorkers prepare for another carefree three-day holiday on Friday, the oldest mutual savings bank in the state will quietly observe its 135th birthday.
The nation's largest steel company announced plans yesterday to sell $300,000,000 in debentures to bolster its working capital.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 29 -- Mrs. Pandia Ralli of Apawamis gained a one-stroke victory in the Women's Tri-County Golf Association tourney today by carding a 43, 38 -- 81 at Westchester Hills.

A "fresh" approach to the study of America's history is offered by Edward N. Saveth's "Understanding the American Past" The author, a former teacher at the New School for Social Research, has brought together the writings of thirty-two American historians to explain the dominant issues and developments in our history.

Trans World Airlines and two foreign air carriers announced yesterday that the purchase of tickets on the installment plan was now available to their passengers. Pan American Airways first introduced this method of air travel on May 1.

Recently the Interstate Commerce Commission suspended for a period of seven months the effective date of tariffs published by six Eastern railroads which sought to put into effect rate covering so-called "piggy-back" service, the transportation of loaded highway trailer by rail.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, June 30 -- The Soviet Union charged today that United States warplanes were inspecting Soviet merchant ships in Far Eastern waters "in rude violation of freedom of navigation in the open seas."
BALTIMORE, June 29 (AP) -- Stockholders of Olin Industries, Inc., and Mathieson Chemical Corporation have voted approval of a merger, presidents of the two companies announced today.
The bagel has surrended to the tin can. That sturdy bread of Broadway, which has been described as the dougnut with rigor mortis, is newly available in a vacuum pack that keeps it fresh a year.

Two critics of public school education clashed yesterday with 500 angry parents and teachers and came off second-best. The spirited tussle between the critics and defenders of the public schools, with no holds barred, was held in the grand ballroom of the Astor Hotel.
The greatest record of success in a century of intercollegiate rowing has been marred.
BALTIMORE, June 29 (UP) -- Art Houtteman snapped the Baltimore Orioles' five-game winning streak in pitching the pace-setting Cleveland Indians to a 5-1 victory tonight.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 29 -- By virtue of runaway victories, the defender and two former Wimbledon tennis champions paraded to the semi-finals of the Women's singles before a chilled crowd of 20,000 this afternoon.
GUATEMALA, June 29 -- Col Carlos Castillo Armas, insurgent leader, has agreed to meet in El Salvador with Col. Elfego Monzon, head of the new governing junta, to discuss truce terms.
ST. LOUIS, June 29 -- A report that 30,000 members leave the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs yearly spurred the members today to take action to revitalize its program.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Senate was urged by one of its members today to prevent investigations that might bring it discredit and loss of public confidence.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 29 -- Led by Mrs. R. M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley, the newly crowned Long Island champion, a Long Island team of ten players retained the Golf Illustrated Trophy over the Creek course today.

NAPLES, Italy, June 29 -- The fifth national congress of the Christian Democratic party ended here tonight with the figure of Amintore Fanfani firmly planted as heir apparent. His current political faction known as the Democratic Initiative clearly dominated the congress in alliance with the center group of former Premier Alcide De Gasperi.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Following are the texts released by the Atomic Energy Commission today, in ruling that Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer should not be allowed access to secret data:
ROME, June 29 (AP) -- Soviet Russia tonight won the women's world artistic gymnastic championship and other teams from Communist East Europe took the next four places.

LONDON, June 29 -- The drastic concentration of power in the hands of Mao Tse-tung and a new Communist party officials at the expense of the local authority of miltary commanders impresses officials here as one of the most important developments in Communist China.
LOS ALAMOS, N. M., June 29 -- The first reaction from atomic scientists here to the A. E. C. decision on Dr. Oppenheimer reflected disappointment and anger.
Modifications favored by Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams to the stock car taxicab law were approved yesterday by the City Council. The vote was 21 to 3.
Now that vacation days are here, parents who like to share activities with their children may welcome some suggestions for outdoor fun.

Subversive activities and Communist infiltration by Americans employed at the United Nations have been reduced drastically by the Administration's anti-subversive program, a special Federal grand jury reported yesterday after an eighteen-month investigation.

LONDON, June 29 (UP) -- Britain announced tonight she was extending the borders of her colonies on the island of Borneo to include part of the oil-rich continental shelf around the world's third largest island.

Monday's donations of blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program totaled 300 pints. Included were seventy-eight pints taken at the Karp Metal Products Company, 211 Sixty-third Street, Brooklyn, and sixty-nine from members of the 244th Infantry Regiment, New York National Guard, at its armory at 125 West Fourteenth Street.

The Committee on Government and Art proposed yesterday that five advisory commissions be established, representing leading schools of thought in the art world, with veto power over Federal art projects. It urged that Federal agencies be compelled to consult the commissions on artistic matters, and that the commissions be provided with adequate staffs and funds.

ELIZABETH, N. J., June 29 (AP) -- Stockholders of Daystrom, Inc., manufacturers of electronics products, furniture and printing equipment, authorized yesterday a $950,000 increase in the company's capital stock to facilitate the purchase of .an interest in the Weston Electrical Instrument Corporation of Newark.
PITTSBURGH, June 29 (UP) -- Richie Ashburn's inside-the-park homer for the Phillies with two out and two aboard in the eighth helped Herman Wehmeier beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4 -- 0 tonight.
