The first radar control traffic device in the city is scheduled to be installed at Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive and Ninety-sixth Street early in the fall. Some of the equipment already has been delivered to the Traffic Department, according to Eugene D. Stirlen, president of Eastern Industries, Inc., of New Haven, Conn., manufacturer of the appliance.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The statement of principles signed by the Indian and Chinese Communist Prime Ministers brought sharply different reactions from diplomatic authorities here today.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and closing prices were 2 points higher to 5 points lower than Monday's.

AS far as international competition is concerned, this one is much too new to have any great significance. But because it involves Gene Sarazen, it has an appeal it would not otherwise have. It's the International Seniors' championship at Southport-Ainsdale in England today and tomorrow between Sarazen, the American titleholder, and Percy Alliss, the top man among the British graybeards.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Frederick Stueck of St. Louis, 48-year-old Republican attorney, to a five-year term on the Federal Power Commission. Mr. Stueck once was executive secretary to former Gov. Forest Donnelly of Missouri.

DALLAS, Tex., June 29 -- President Eisenhower declared today that the recent Supreme Court decision banning public school racial segregation constituted "a milestone of social advance in the United States."

Further coordination of the educational program offered by leaders of the apparel industry for students entering this field was assured yesterday. This developed at a meeting of the Needelcraft Educational Commission in the Central High School of Needle Trades, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The House of Representatives voted the Eisenhower Administration a free hand and funds today to meet the crisis in Southeast Asia.

The post of Director of Cancer Control was established yesterday in the Health Department. Dr. Abraham Oppenheim, assistant visiting surgeon at Harlem and Montefiore Hospitals, assumed the task of finding new cases early enough to prevent long-term suffering and death.
Bids will be received by eleven Massachusetts housing authorities on fourteen temporary loan note issues totaling $37,031,000 on July 7, it was announced yesterday.

Trading was dull in the New York commodity futures markets yesterday. Prices moved irregularly with cocoa, coffee, cottonseed oil, burlap, tin, lead and copper higher; wool, potatoes, sugar, silk and soybean oil lower, and zinc, hides and rubber mixed.
LONDON, June 29 -- The stock markets showed signs of recovery today from the weakness of the past week. Buying remained selective and price movements, though generally upward, were narrow.

The financial position of Arnold Bernstein prior to his trial and conviction by a Nazi court on charges of illegal foreign exchange operations was discussed again yesterday in Federal Court as cross-examination of the former German shipowner reached its fifth day.
William A. Prendergast died just a week ago, at the age of 87, having been active in business virtually up to the time of his death.

About 800 landlords, including a public school teacher who looked awfully familiar to Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh, were advised yesterday in Upper Manhattan Court to study the Multiple Dwelling Law and thereby save themselves a lot of reading, writing and arithmetic.

The production of crude oil in Saudi Arabia last year amounted to 308,294,245 barrels, an average of 844,642 barrels a day, according to a report of the Arabian American Oil Company to the Saudi Arabian Government. In 1952, output amounted to 301,860,885 barrels, or 824,756 a day.
A former deputy United States delegate to the United Nations, Ernest A. Gross, will become tomorrow a partner in the law firm of Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt Mosle.
Cuba will have to restrict its sugar production further in 1955 to to fulfill its commitments under the International Sugar Agreement, according to Lamborn Co., Inc., sugar broker.

As one of the three surviving members of the United States delegation that signed the United Nations Charter in 1945 I am shocked by the information given in your issue of June 26 about Howard Chandler Christy's painting of the delegation. For years I have thought the picture was hanging peacefully in our Capitol at Washington, with the paintings of other significant events in the history of our country.

Today's new film is "The High and the Mighty." a Warner Brothers presentation in Cinema-Scope and Warner Color at the Paramount. The principal roles are portrayed by John Wayne, Claire Trevor, Laraine Day, Robert Stack, Jan Sterling, Phil Harris, Robert Newton and David Brian.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Churchill set forth today their joint policies for world peace. They called for a reduction in armaments and the use of nuclear power to enrich, not destroy, mankind.
The milk market administrator of the New York metropolitan area forecast yesterday a drop in prices and increased production of milk for the last half of 1954.

Mayor Wagner's choice of a Director to head the newly created City Department of Personnel and be chairman of the reorganized City Civil Service Commission had been awaited, especially in employe circles, with great interest. Yesterday the appointment of Joseph Schechter, since 1940 counsel of the State Department of Civil Service, was announced.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (UP) -- The Senate completed Congressional action today on legislation providing for a simple one-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 29 -- The suggestion that the United Nations "guarantee" a peace settlement for the Indo-chinese states of Laos and Cambodia was put forward today by Prince Wan Waithayakon, Thailand's Foreign Minister.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Reports of a cease-fire in Guatemala were received "hopefully" in diplomatic circles here tonight. However, lacking confirmation that hostilities had actually ended, one prominent official urged caution against any immediate conclusion that the latest Communist threat in this hemisphere was over.

MR. and Mrs. William Breau, down from Abbott Street in Gardner, Mass., and on a holiday, stood a little while at Broadway and Forty-second Street yesterday to test the legend that because that spot is called the Crossroads of the World you're bound to meet a neighbor there sooner or later. The Breaus returned to their hotel an hour later, breathless with confirmation.

NEW DELHI, India, June 29 (Reuters) -- A quarter of a million Indian pilgrims are massed on the banks of Lake Kurushetra north of here, waiting to dive into its sacred waters when the demon god Rahu swallows the sun in tomorrow's eclipse.
The General Motors Acceptance Corporation announced a $150,000,000 refunding program yesterday.
Earnings of the Bulova Watch Company increased 6.8 per cent in the fiscal year ended in March, the annual report to stockholders disclosed yesterday.
Because of threatening weather, only a small audience of music-lovers turned up at Lewisohn Stadium for last night's concert by Pierre Monteux and the Stadium Symphony Orchestra.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 29 -- Twentieth Century-Fox moved today to complete deals pending for the purchase of two novels, "Good Morning Miss Dove" and "A Many Splendored Thing."

BOSTON, June 29 -- Mickey Mantle feasted on Boston Red Sox pitching at Fenway Park, where the "fattening up" period for the Yankees began tonight. Mantle's four hits, including a triple, paced the champions in a 14-5 rout of the Bosox before 24,828 Hub fans.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., June 29 -- The world, in these troubled times, needs a sense of justice instead of a sense of might, Chief Justice Earl Warren asserted here today.

Among the important public issues obscured by the Republican TV circus is the powerful movement afoot to return German private property seized during the Second World War. Since approximately thirteen billion United States dollars have already been spent in the reconstruction of Germany, the American taxpayers ought to be informed, at least, that the Congress is considering legislation to return such property.
Reesburg, Wis., gambled in a risky market and won.
Elaborate scientific rehearsals were held yesterday in various parts of the world to survey the heavens during the solar eclipse today.

LONDON, June 29 -- The set of principles published at the conclusion of the Eisenhower- Churchill conferences was a little disappointing here because there had been some expectation that the statement would be more, not less, precise than that issued yesterday by the White House.

QUANTICO, Va., June 29, (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Clifton B. Cates will retire from the Marines tomorrow in special ceremonies that will mark his end of tenure as commandant of the Marine Corps schools here.

The United States isn't represented in the current international theatre festival in Paris. The omission has caused visiting Americans there to wonder why. One inquisitive tourist obtaincd an explanation from the cultural attache at the American Embassy.
A defense motion to set aside as excessive a $175,001 libel award to Quentin Reynolds, author and former war correspondent, will be argued in Federal Court on Friday.
OTTAWA, June 29 -- Prime Minister Churchill arrived in Ottawa this afternoon to visit what he called "the master link of Anglo- American unity."
The New York Central Railroad, including leased lines, reported yesterday that its gross operating revenues dropped to $57,528,677 in May from $69,765,847 in the same month last year.
The Arthur Lehman Counseling Service, a new agency for the advancement of personal and family adjustment and well-being, will open today at 1382 Lexington Avenue, at Ninety-first Street.

Promulgation of Regulation 33 for the reporting and allocation of income and expenses by life insurance companies in New York State, effective next Jan. 1, was announced yesterday by Adelbert G. Straub Jr., deputy superintendent of the State Insurance Department.

MILWAUKEE, June 29 (UP) -Jim Wilson limited the Chicago Cubs to five hits tonight to win his third shutout of the year, 7 -- 0, for the Milwaukee Braves. The Cubs suffered their eleventh straight defeat.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Wheat traders today became more conscious of the surprising lack of hedge selling pressure and bought future steadily through most of the session. Prices advanced substantially, with evidence of investment based on the conviction that growers intend to take out loans on all the wheat they can find storage room for.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics scored two runs in the seventh inning tonight to defeat Washington, 3 -- 2, but Arnold Portocarrero had to stifle a ninth-inning threat by the Senators.
BALTIMORE, June 29 -- In almost complete returns today, Dr. H. C. (Curly) Byrd, former president of the University of Maryland, was the winner of yesterday's state Democratic gubernatorial primary.

ITHACA, N. Y., June 29 (AP) -- Young persons with the training and experience provided by 4-H Clubs are the "emotional and mental safety pins" of the nation, delegates to the twenty-eighth annual State 4-H Club Conference were told tonight.

JERUSALEM, June 29 -- The first congress of the Agudath Israel World Organization to be held in this country opened here tonight amid signs that the breach between this orthodox association and Israel's Government might soon be healed.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (UP) -- Labor leaders declared tonight that the American people "have nothing to fear" from a United labor movement.

SHAVIANS who may have felt neglected this recent season by the lack of attention given to the erstwhile master of Ayot St. Lawrence can buck up. The wit and incisive comment of the mischievous idol can be heard again, this time at the Greenwich Mews Theatre on Thirteenth Street, where "Major Barbara" is being offered by art ambitious troupe of players.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 29 -- The Brazilian Government is buying coffee at 87 cents a pound to keep the price up to that level. As of July 1, by decree, the Government must buy all coffee at that price if it cannot be sold for as much elsewhere.

HANOI, June 29 -- The High Command announced tonight it had ordered the evacuation of Namdinh Province south of Hanoi. This move will give the Communists Namdinh, the third biggest city in the Red River delta, without a shot being fired.
TRENTON, June 29 -- State funds deposited by former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman in a South Amboy bank, but now missing, stood tonight at $300,000 after an additional $100,000 had been accounted for.

Joseph D. Nunan was found guilty of income tax evasion yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court. The former United States Commissioner of Internal Revenue had been indicted on a charge of cheating the Government of $91,086 in taxes for a five-year period.

Mrs. Nellie Sheer Kagan, top favorite in the women's Eastern clay court tennis championship, overcame stubborn opposition to gain the quarter finals yesterday at the Bayside Tennis and Racquets Club in Queens.

To mark fifty years in the shoe-repairing industry, the Shoe Service Institute of America and various suppliers and manufacturers are making plans for a year-long jubilee campaign that will include a spate of newspaper advertising.

United States textile exporters are losing ground in Latin America despite the growth of population and purchasing power in that area, according to Matthew J. Cuffe, president of the Textile Export Association of the United States.

The Police Department was criticized by Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg, yesterday for raising a Communist issue against a 26-year-old veteran who had sought to join the force. The court directed the Police Commissioner to appoint the candidate.

BAY SHORE, L. I., June 29 -- Joe Ennis, a 22-year-old unheralded professional golfer from Lawrence, L. I., took the lead today at the Southward Ho Country Club in the first round of the Long Island open championship with a record-equaling 6g.
LAREDO, Tex., June 29 (UP) -- The rampaging Rio Grande, which has driven 40,000 persons from their homes, gathered new momentum tonight and hurled a record sixty-foot crest at the twin Laredos.
Thirteen innings of a nerve-tingling baseball came to a dramatic close at the Polo Grounds last night just a couple of minutes before midnight.
NEW HAVEN, June 29 (AP) -Congregational Christians, in a new action upholding the national organization unity of their denomination, rejected today a separated group's bid for recognition.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Construction of sixty ocean-going merchant ships each year is needed "if national defense requirements are to be fully met," Under Secretary of Commerce Robert B. Murray Jr. told the House Merchant Marine Committee today.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UP) -- Jack A. Lucas, 29-year-old refugee from the Nazis, who said he had fallen under the Communist spell for a year, declared today that Congressional Red hunts did democracy more harm than good.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 28 -- Less than five years after setting up a union for "friendly cooperation," the Netherlands and Indonesia met here today to dissolve it.
The Philadelphia Electric Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income of $30,646,009 for the twelve months ended April 30.

Radio station WNBC and television station WNBT will present an eight-week series of lectures on arts and sciences to be given in capsule form by faculty members of City College and Columbia, Fordham, New York and Rutgers Universities.
District Attorney T. Vincent Quinn of Queens, said yesterday that he would not oppose a new trial for Paul A. Pfeffer.
Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer voiced the hope last night that "honestly and freely" given advice of American scientists would be heard by the country.
KAPUSKASING, Ont., June 29 -- Six squads of Canadian and American scientists completed final preparations today at various sites near this northern mill town to observe the total eclipse of the sun.

Differences over how militantly the forty-four-year-old National Urban League should battle discrimination against Negroes have led to the resignation of two directors and failure to re-elect a third.
GENEVA, June 29 -- The eighteenth session of the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations opened here today.

Marble, now enjoying a revival as a furniture material, presents two problems -- staining and etching. Explaining the difference between the two, the Marble Institute reports that beer will stain, while champagne or any other wine with an acid content will etch the surface of marble.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Following is the text of the final communique from the meeting between President Eisenhower and Sir Winston Churchill:

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 29 -- The estate of a late Westchester County resident who left $14,111,160 must pay a state tax of $1,906,670, while the estate of a county neighbor who left $55,605,290 must pay only $61,171, appraisers announced today. This means, in the second case, a tax figure thirty-one times smaller for an estate almost four times larger.
CHICAGO. June 29 (AP) -- Today's report by the Department of Agriculture on the live stock markets here follow:

Teddy Atkinson was the difference between success and failure for Mrs. Philip Bieber's Bicarb in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. Bicarb gained the victory in the mile and a sixteenth Amsterdam purse, but only because of Atkinson's persistence and proficiency.

FOLLOWING another mild winter, and a spring survey showing excellent population trends in upland game birds and animals, the State Conservation Department has announced that seasons and bag limits for the fall will be as liberal as last year.

NEWARK, June 29 -- About 2,000 honeybees, half of the live bee exhibit at the Newark Junior Museum, were retrieved today after they had been on a three-day house-hunting escapade. Led by the queen, the bees had deserted an overcrowded window-box hive that has an opening to the street.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee struck at Iron Curtain embassies and consulates in this country today in a new move to ward off Communist propaganda. It was told that propaganda was flooding the United States from abroad "literally by shiploads."

A syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer today $16,000,000 of 3 1/3 per cent first mortgage AAA-rated bonds of the Duquesne Light Company. The bonds, maturing in 1984, are being offered at 102.461 to yield an interest return of 3 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 (AP) -- Trucking interests moved today for reargument of a court ruling that legislative activities by railroads were not in themselves a basis for charges of violating the anti-trust laws.
The stock market yesterday sagged under a flood of order that clogged the tickers, but soon rallied to close fairly firm. New of the steel wage settlement was a major factor in the recovery.
Bonds on the New York Stock Exchange lost $1 in average market value in May, that institution reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 29 Both exports and imports declined in May, compared with April, according to preliminary estimates released today by the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 29 -- George T. Weymouth, a director and former president of Clifton Park Manor Apartments Corporation, today denied that Government money was used to finance construction of the 920-unit project in the Edgemoor area.
Higher benefit payments that go into effect tomorrow will mark the fortieth anniversary of the State Workmen's Compensation Law.

Fifteen hundred members of the Fire Department attended a solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday celebrated by a newly ordained priest of the Franciscan Order of Friars Minor Capuchin, who for seven years was a city fireman. The firemen marched up Fifth Avenue from Forty-third Street to the cathedral and later marched to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for a breakfast and reception.

PARIS, June 29 -- The United States Ambassador told France today she must choose "for herself and before history" between the controlled rearmament of West Germany within a European Defense Community and the re-creation of an independent German national army.

To adult eyes accustomed to the conventional recreational equipment afforded by playgrounds to young visitors, a newly designed collection of play sculptures on view at the Museum of Modern Art, both in full size and in model form, may easily appear startling.

The conference in Washington between President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Churchill has come to an end with a Declaration of Basio Principles which reaffirms above all temporary differences the enduring and intimate comradeship between the United States and Britain and proclaims in effect a new Atlantic Charter for the guidance of the free world.

SITE OF FIFTEENTH AIR FORCE SOLAR ECLIPSE EXPEDITION, Kafshgiri, Iran, June 29 -- The painstaking preparations were completed here today for using the shadow of tomorrow's solar eclipse as a terrestrial tape.
OCEANPORT, N. J., June 29 (AP) -- Darby Dan Farm's Skipper Bill, turning back two challengers in the stretch, won the Kingston Purse by a neck before a crowd of 12,650 at Monmouth Park today.

NEW HAVEN, June 29 -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad took a step yesterday toward cutting the run between New York and Boston to two and one-half hours -- but much depends on other Eastern railroads.

" THIS is a delightful book. I could not put it down," says Lord Vansittart in his foreword to "Sudan Days and Ways" by his friend, H. C. Jackson, former Governor of the Provinces of Berber and Halfa in the Sudan. It is not necessary to share such generous enthusiasm in order to enjoy Mr. Jackson's volume of rather dignified, impersonal and scrappy reminiscences.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- President Eisenhower today ordered a special Government committee set up to try to help the ailing soft coal industry.
GENEVA, June 29 -- The French Government is holding up a decision on how much of Vietnam to hand over to the Communists until the United States indicates what it intends to do about Indochina.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Dr. Henry DeWolf Smyth, the only scientist on the Atomic Energy Commission, stood alone today against the finding of his four colleagues that Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer was a poor security risk.
The Parks Department Marionette Theatre will tour park playgrounds in Queens from tomorrow through July 21, giving eighteen performances of its pup- pet show, "The Shoemaker and the Elves."

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations called today for a "positive and consistent" United States policy in Latin America, based on the economic and social needs of the people.
Airmail is a boon to mothers of boys in the armed forces. Dated Monday, this cheery letter reached New York in time to brighten the family weekend. It said:

STRATFORD, Ont., June 29 -- Even before the Stratford Shakespeare Festival opened under the inviting big top last evening, "Measure for Measure" seemed like an unpromising choice of play. There is little reason for revising that impression this morning.

CINCINNATI, June 29 (AP) -The Cincinnati Redlegs tonight crushed the St. Louis Cardinals, 11 -- 4, in a battle for fifth place before 15,018 fans. Gus Bell, one of three Redlegs struck by Card pitchers, paced the hitting barrage with two singles and a home run.
PARIS, June 29 -- It was reported here tonight that the French populace in Hanoi had been advised to leave.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -Following are sketches of the five members of the Atomic Energy Commission who decided 4 to 1 today not to lift the suspension of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer from access to secret data:
CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox dropped back a half game in the American League race tonight when the Detroit Tigers forced them to split a twilight-night double-header.

On June 24 a report was printed that a man was fined $1,270 for forty-four traffic summonses. It was alleged in the newspaper article that the man had an arrangement with the traffic authorities to pay his parking summonses once a year. This article points up two attitudes toward the parking situation in New York.
BOSTON, June 29 -- The Rev. Dr. Anson Phelps Stokes Jr., rector of St. Bartholomew's Church in New York, today was elected Bishop-Coadjutor of the Massachusetts Episcopal Diocese.

New York's public schools are out today. The 3 P. M. bell will signal the transfer of 921,824 dilemmas from school to the home domain. Teachers will relax, mothers will face new nerve strain and fathers will be called upon for most of the answers.

Two members of a three-man fact-finding panel recommended yesterday that there be no reduction in hours and no further wage increase beyond a $3.75 "package" offered by ten New York newspapers to 425 members of the Paper Handlers and Straighteners Union No. 1, A. F. L.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, the man who directed the making of the first atomic bomb, today lost his long fight for reinstatement as an adviser to the Government.

It is good news indeed that agreement on a new contract has been reached between the United Steel-workers of America and the United States Steel Corporation, a contract which will presumably form the pattern for the industry as a whole. Already all the major steel producers are reported ready to accept its terms.

Directors of R. K. O. Pictures Corporation have offered to buy all or any part of the 1,262,120 shares of common stock held by Howard Hughes, the chairman, at $6 a share J. R. Grainger, the company's president, announced yesterday. At the same time the board extended to July 31 a similar offer that has been in effect for all stockholders

MINEOLA, L. I., June 29 -- A five-year boom in the baby crop and an expected continuation of the upward trend of births has caused the Nassau County Department of Health to intensify its program of education of prospective mothers and fathers.

WILMINGTON, Del., June (AP) -- A project to expand facilities for the manufacture of Teflon, tetrafluoroethylene resin, one of the newer plastics, was announced today by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.

Governors Dewey of New York and Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey reported yesterday that they were pleased with the progress made by the bi-state Waterfront Commission in eliminating unscrupulous elements from New York harbor.

Varied divertissements will be features of the annual Summer Day Fair for the benefit of the Society of St. Johnland to be held today on the grounds of the home in Kings Park, L. I. Mrs. Gertrude H. T. Le Boutillier of Oyster Bay, L. I., and Mrs. Arthur B. Lawrence of Smithtown, L. I., are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Clyde L. Powell, ousted top official of the Federal Housing Agency, had a record of eight arrests ranging up to larceny, the Senate Banking Committee was told today.
PARIS, June 29 -- French small business men are in a state of revolt against the Government's efforts to prevent tax-dodging.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 29 (UP) -- Remington Rand, Inc., said today it would appeal to the United States Supreme Court a lower court decision ordering the company to pay $1,220,000 to the estate of a West Hartford, Conn., inventor.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A resolution urging that police dealing with juveniles be regarded as professional men and women and not as members of "The Diaper Squad" was adopted today at the Police Services Section of the Juvenile Delinquency Conference.

" THE Saturday Night Revue," currently filling the old Imogene Coca-Sid Caesar spot between 9 and 10:30 o'clock on Saturday nights over N. B. C. television, is another reason why motion picture theatres report better business during the warm weather.

GLASGOW, Scotland, June 29 (UP) -- Bob Kelly, president of the Glasgow Celtics and of the Scottish Soccer League, said today the world cup tournament was "a washout" and that he would never allow Players from his club to compete in it again.
ALBANY, June 29 -- The plan of the Temporary State Commission on the Courts for judicial reorganization ran into strong opposition from local Supreme Court justices today.

GUATEMALA, June 29 -- Guatemala's new military regime reached a cease-fire agreement with the insurgents today and started formal peace negotiations in San Salvador, capital of neighboring El Salvador.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 29 -- Former President Truman today appeared to have won his fight against an intestinal infection that slowed his recovery from an operation nine days ago.
CAIRO, June 29 -- The Egyptian Government is preparing for a resumption of negotiations with Britain within a week on their dispute over the Suez Canal Zone.
PITTSBURGH, June 29 -- The United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., and the United States Steel Corporation signed a new no-strike agreement today.
Catapult mechanisms on all except the most modern American aircraft carriers will be altered as a result of the fatal explosion last month aboard the carrier Bennington.
Herbert L. Brickman, whom Mayor Wagner has discharged as city director of veterans services, effective today, appealed yesterday to Governor Dewey to help him keep the job.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Mrs. Katie Louchheim, director of Women's Activities of the Democratic National Committee, today predicted a very heavy vote in elections this fall.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 29 -- The Guatemalan insurgents indicated tonight that acceptance of an armistice would depend on their original conditions. A communique said:

The National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. announced yesterday that the Rev. R. Norris Wilson has been named executive director of Church World Service, the international relief agency of the council.
A weary diplomat who had the world's attention ten days ago sat by his telephone all day yesterday waiting to find out if he was an Ambassador, a former Ambassador or an exile.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Administration leaders in the House of Representatives appeared ready today to put forth what might prove a face-saver for all parties in the deepening clash over farm policy.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, June 29 -- The Government of the new Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland presented to Parliament today a $210,000,000, three-year development plan. The Federation's first full budget also was presented.
ANSEDONIA, Italy, June 17 -- A Roman Senate house has been found here on the site of the old Roman settlement of Cosa, which is being excavated by the American Academy of Rome.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 29 -- A colorful four-hour pageant was presented before 100,000 onlookers today in a parade of 10,000 members of the Ancient Arabic Order, Nobles of the Mystic Shrine.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 28 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali told Parliament today that the "present Government is determined to crack down on all Communists."
OSLO, June 29 (AP) -- Ernie Shelton of Los Angeles and Sverre Strandli of Norway were the standouts tonight in an international track and field meet in the Bislett Olympic Stadium.
The City Administration indicated strongly last night that some relief would be provided to theatres and baseball clubs in collecting the new 5 per cent amusement tax on advance sales of tickets.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Individuals saved nearly $1,000,000,000 more in the first three months of this year than in the corresponding period in 1953.
MOSCOW, June 29 -- A prayer for the recovery of Harry Truman, a fellow Baptist, was offered tonight by nearly 2,000 persons in Moscow's Baptist meeting house.
HACKENSACK, N. J., June 29 -- William Lurie of Brooklyn defeated the eighth-seeded player, William Tully of New York, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, in the Eastern clay court tennis championships today.

Cumulative preferred stock of the Public Service Company of Indiana, Inc., amounting to $15,000,000, and $6,300,000 of common and preferred stock of the O. A. Sutton Corporation, Inc., will be placed on the market today by two underwriting groups.
BISMARCK, N, D., June 30 -- Gov. Norman Brunsdale of North Dakota won renomination today to a third two-year term.
MONTREAL, June 30 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian Industries, Ltd., Canadian chemical concern, became two separate companies at the close of business today.
The nation's railroads are being "taxed to death, bargained to death and regulated to death," Benjamin F. Fairless, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, declared yesterday.

How the first gay days are squandered -- as if there were an infinity of them, to be filled forever with swims or ball games or hours just lounging in the green shade of a cool tree. The last week of June was agonizing, we know. What was to be learned was learned or not and nothing to do for it then.

The State Education Commissioner, the city Superintendent of Schools and the presidents of the four city colleges will be among twenty educators who will receive honorary degrees from Columbia University today at a special bicentennial convocation on the Morningside Heights campus.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse as required by conference rules, except portions authorized for direct quotation by the White House:

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 30 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority is ahead of schedule in repayments to the United States Treasury as well as in bond retirement, John Oliver, general manager, revealed today.

The spectacular sky waltz that is a total eclipse of the sun by the moon was danced along an 8,000-mile arc yesterday, across a third of the globe from Nebraska to India. In an age of potential intercontinental warfare, it aroused more concentrated scientific study than ever.

A decline last week of 862,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were 168,034,000 barrels, compared with 168,869,000 a week earlier and 145,651,000 a year ago.

Inductions into the armed forces will increase considerably in the fiscal year begin ning today. Some 209,000 men were drafted this year. Next year the total will be 420,000, according to Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of Selective Service. Molding these young Americans into soldiers is up to the military.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Eisenhower said today the hope of the world lay in peaceful coexistence with the Communists. He added, however, that he would not appease them or recognize their enslavement of peoples.
GUATEMALA, June 30 (AP) -- United States Ambassador John Peurifoy played a major part in the negotiations that led to formation of a second governing junta in Guatemala and ceasefire negotiations.
Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer said yesterday that he planned to continue as director of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, N. J., and "do some physics."
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 30 -- Pacific Coast Music Festival participants assembled tonight at Santa Barbara Mission for a concert in Latin for a capella group of sixteen voices.

Your Moscow correspondent, Harrison E. Salisbury, has recently been doing a greatly needed bit of reporting on conditions and attitudes of the Russian people in eastern Siberia. This is objective, unemotional reporting, at its very best, on a "hostile" people.
After negotiations lasting more than two years, a new contract was signed yesterday, by the A. F. L. Local No. 1, Theatrical Protective Union (the stagehands' union) and the Metropolitan Opera.

Alexander Schneider, violinist-conductor, and the Washington Square Association have announced a fund-raising program for a series of chamber music concerts to be given in Washington Square in the summer.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 30 -- Physicians attending former President Truman said tonight with unguarded enthusiasm that he was making "substantial progress" and that "continued progress" was expected. The official evening bulletin of Research Hospital said that Mr. Truman's general condition showed great improvement.
GENEVA, June 30 -- The World Veterans Federation asked the United Nations today to take urgent action on behalf of disabled Korean veterans of the Korean war.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) -- The Administration today endorsed sweeping legislation to deny a Government pension to anyone, including Alger Hiss, who commits a crime or seeks refuge in the Fifth Amendment.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 30 -- For more than a minute today the sun hung over central Minnesota like a twinkling, slate-blue Christmas ornament as the moon moved between it and the earth.

The stock market rose in June for the sixth consecutive month. The volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange was somewhat greater than in May, and was the largest for any June in four years. The volume for the first half of this year rose to 238,806,601 shares, the largest since 1951.
" The Circle of Chalk," the thirteenth century Chinese play, will be one of the five or six plays that The Ensemble, new producing company, will present at the Bijou Theatre this season.

PARIS, June 30 (AP) -- Daniel Mayer, president of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the French National Assembly, was deprived today of all rights to Assembly committee assignments by his Socialist party's executive.

The city's farmers would be assured of the protection of the zoning law in their right -- subject to some restrictions -- to sell their own produce at roadside stands in residence districts under a zoning amendment approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled unanimously today that an employer may refuse to bargain with a labor union that is operating a competing business.

ELIZABETH, N. J., June 30 -- Punishment of parents found guilty of neglect of their children is among the six recommendations for the solution of juvenile crime problems included in a presentment handed up yesterday by a holdover Union County grand jury.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 30 -- Gen. Silvio Raulino de Oliveiro, president of Brazil's National Siderurgical Company, left for the United States today to seek a $35,000,000 loan with which to raise the capacity of the Volta Redonda steel plant to 1,000,000 tons a year.

HENLEY, England, June 30 -- Powerful, fast-stroking Soviet oarsmen, the first seen on the River Thames since Czarist times, swept to a victory today on the opening day of the annual Henley royal regatta.

The blockfront apartment property comprising five four-story buildings at 47-06 Eighty-eighth Street and 86-30 to 86-42 St. James Avenue in Elmhurst, Queens, was purchased by the Estate Securities Company, real estate operators, from the St. James Properties, Inc., and was immediately resold to the Eighty- eighth Street Queens Investors Corporation.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Eisenhower appealed to correspondents today to do all they could through newspapers, television and radio to reduce the Fourth of July traffic deaths 50 per cent below last year's.
The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday a net income of $2,528,588 in the first five months of this year, after provision of $2,728,000 for Federal income taxes.

LEUCHARS, Scotland, June 30 (Reuters) -- Britain's leading astronomer landed here tonight after having chased the moon's shadow from Iceland to Scotland in a Royal Air Force bomber to gain twenty precious seconds of darkness.

The division of preventive medicine of the Sloan-Kettering Institute, research unit of Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases, will be opened today. Dr. Emerson Day, director of the center's Strang Cancer Prevention Clinic, has been appointed chief of the new division and Professor of Preventive Medicine at the Sloan-Kettering division of Cornell University Medical College.
MELBOURNE, Australia, June 30 -- A former Soviet diplomat and secret agent described today to a Royal Commission on Soviet Espionage in Australia how the Soviet secret police operated.

BOSTON, June 30 -- Tom Morgan tied a major league record when he hit three Boston Red Sox with pitched balls in the third inning at Fenway Park today. Hurling of this caliber didn't injure the Bosox as much as it hurt the flag hopes of the Yankees, who dropped a 6 -- 1 decision to Willard Nixon.

PARIS, June 30 -- An extension of the European Payments Union for another year as from tomorrow was decided today by its members. Its rules will be changed to facilitate its operations pending some degree of convertibility of currencies.
BAY SHORE, L. I., June 30 -- Jay Hebert, Woodmere Club professional, today captured the Long Island Open golf championship with a fifty-four-hole aggregate of 213. He shot 72, 71 today.

FIFTEENTH U. S. AIR FORCE ECLIPSE EXPEDITION, Kafshgiri, Iran, June 30 -- Heavy clouds -- the first seen here for several days -- blotted but visual observation of the solar eclipse today at this final station along the shadow's 8,000-mile path.

MILWAUKEE, June 30 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs went wild in the seventh and eighth innings today, scoring nine runs against an assortment of pitchers to snap an eleven-game losing streak and beat the Milwaukee Braves, 9 -- 7, before a ladies' day crowd of 34,226.

PARIS, June 30 -- Father Emmanuel Hernandez Suarez, world head of the Order of Dominicans since September, 1946, was killed this morning in an automobile accident near Perpignan in southern France. He was 59 years of age.
" The Salad Book," by Marye Dahnke (Pocket Books, 307 pp., 35 cents), is a new cook book reflecting American tastes. Much of its appeal depends on whether one shares those tastes.
LONDON, June 30 -- President Eisenhower's ability to speak for the United States and the wisdom of the policy that bars Communist China from the United Nations were questioned here today.

Chemicals, oils and electrical equipments took a hammering in yesterday's stock market. Despite spotty gains for such issues as Johns-Manville, Montgomery Ward, United Fruit, Procter Gamble, International Paper and Vanadium, the list suffered fairly wide recession.
Visitors to Aqueduct yesterday saw a 2-year-old colt of much promise score a front-running victory in the sixty-fourth Great American Stakes.

The Quaker State Metals Company, Lancaster, Pa., announced yesterday it was producing corrugated aluminum roofing and siding in rolls for use primarily on industrial and farm buildings. The material "can be laid like a rug, can be easily cut into required lengths by dealer or user, and reduces installation costs by an estimated 50 per cent," according to Raymond Buckwalter, president of the company.

PITTSBURGH, June 30 (AP) Robin Roberts of the Philadelphia Philies pitched a six-hit shutout for his eleventh victory of the season while his teammates collected fifteen safeties to defeat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 8 -- 0, tonight.

NEW HAVEN, June 30 (AP) -- Congregational Christians denounced atomic bomb production today as "a prostitution of scientific skill" -- but they rejected a proposed demand that it be halted immediately.

An unusual cargo - handling contract -- only six weeks' work a year -- has been taken on by Atlantic and Gulf Stevedores, Inc., at the Canadian town of Churchill, Man. The reason for the brief work period is that little Churchill, 2,500 miles north of here on the western side of Hudson Bay, is ice-free only for that length of time in midsummer.

A $15,000,000 office building will rise on land adjoining the New York Stock Exchange, which plans to use space in the proposed skyscraper for expansion of its auxiliary facilities and possible enlargement of its trading floor at some future date.

Radio station WOR will return to a twenty-four-hour-a-day schedule with the debut on Sunday morning, July 11, of "Meet Mr. Midnight," a recorded music and chatter program featuring Lee Donahue. The program will be heard seven mornings a week from 1 to 5:30 o'clock.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 30 -- Ending a six-month investigation of Yonkers traffic ticket fixing, a Westchester County grand jury today indicted two former Yonkers City Court aides on sixty-nine charges and declared the court guilty of "definite laxity in administration."

American marine insurance underwriters are faced with paying an estimated $1,500,000 in claims -- one of the largest totals in recent years -- resulting from cargo lost in the aerial bombing and sinking of the British freighter Springfjord at San Jose, Guatemala, last Sunday.

THE first live televising of an eclipse was at a decided disadvantage yesterday. Many viewers had had only six hours or so of sleep because of Roy Campanella. And not even the moon's passage in front of the sun could compare with the previous night's exhausting drama of watching the Giants beat the Dodgers twice in the same game.

YONKERS, June 30 -- The president of Alexander Smith, Inc., carpet company here, gave assurances today that the concern would make its land and buildings available as quickly as possible for new industries.
Observers from New York had a perfect view of the total eclipse of the sun yesterday, thanks to an 832-mile airlift to a grandstand seat 13,000 feet above Hudson Bay.

Higher steel prices and more cooperative labor - management relations in the steel industry were forecast yesterday as all major producers followed the United States Steel Corporation in signing new wage agreements.
PARIS, June 30 -- Dr. Emile Eyraud, publisher of La Vigie Marocaine, a French newspaper in Morocco, was assassinated today in Casablanca. His assailants, two young Moroccan terrorists, were captured.

The City Planning Commission moved yesterday to speed up work on eight large slum clearance projects, several of which have been held back by delays of private sponsors in meeting financial commitments.

The New Democratic Club of the Eighth Manhattan Assembly District announced yesterday that it had designated Mrs. Mary de Groat Reed as its candidate for the Democratic nomination for member of the Assembly. The district is now represented by Archibald Douglas Jr., a Republican.

The amount of corporate bonds on the legal list increased by more than $2,100,000,000 in the fiscal year just ended to reach a total of more than $26,000,000,000, the highest on record, it was announced yesterday by William A. Lyon, Superintendent of Banks of New York State.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, announced today how his agency would apportion Federal highway funds to the states next year.
An ebony jewel chest with an unusual history, and a collection of jewels that filled it, came as a recent gift to the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Senate rejected today two rival proposals for a general reduction in individual income taxes. It thus apparently settled the issue for the present session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Eisenhower said today that he had directed the Atomic Energy Commission to seek power from a private utility to gain time in a study of the future of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

Thirty-two medical schools, universities, hospitals and other institutions and organizations will receive $2,486,244 in grants and appropriations today for research and education in poliomyelitis and related fields.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 30 -- Teachers in United States communities were called upon today to defend the United Nations from attacks by small but influential groups.

KAPUSKASING, Ont., June 30 -- While clouds and heavy ground haze completely obscured the skies, a team of Canadian scientists went through the motions of recording this morning's total eclipse of the sun.

MOSCOW, Thursday, July 1 (Reuters) -- Pravda, in the first Soviet comment on last weekend's Washington meetings, charged United States diplomacy today with a "continued policy for the intensification of international tension in Asia and all over the world."
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that prices of farm products dropped 4 per cent between mid-May and mid-June, the sharpest monthly decline in several years.

It can be called the summer now, and outside the Motor Vehicle Bureau is a long line of those seeking learners' permits. The summer is a nice time in which to learn to drive a car, and 16 is a nice age for the summer. This is not too young, obviously, and those who occasionally question the wisdom of entrusting to 16 some two tons of juggernaut can be only spoilsports.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) -- Senate housing scandal investigators were told today how apartment builders used Government loan guarantees to parlay stock originally worth only $5 into $1,737 a share.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Eisenhower Administration today asked Congress for a billion and a half dollars more to support farm prices.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) -- Defense Secretary Charles E. Wilson said today he had thirty-three vice presidents as head of General Motors and needed a few more such helpers in his present post than Congress had allowed him.

DALLAS, Tex., June 30 -- The legal staff of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People made public today its plan of strategy for implementing at the community level the recent Supreme Court decision banning public school racial segregation.
As a New York City subway rider I have borne uncomplainingly the rise in fare from 5 cents to 15 cents with no commensurate increase in service, However, I think the time is ripe to lodge a protest.
George Gregory Jr., a Democrat who lives at 596 Edgecombe Avenue, was named yesterday by Mayor Wagner to the newly reorganized Civil Service Commission.
One-way operation has made a motorists' paradise of Seventh and Eighth Avenues, compared with the two-way pattern that was abolished three weeks ago.

The appointment of Dr. Paul Weiss, biologist, as a member of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, was announced yesterday, Membership corresponds to a senior professorship in leading universities.
EAGLE PASS, Tex., June 30 (AP) -- The bodies of thirty-eight victims of the rampaging Rio Grande were taken today from the floodswept ruins of the border city of Piedras Negras, Mexico.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower made an early and very gay start tonight on the celebration of their thirty-eighth wedding anniversary tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Eisenhower accepted personal responsibility today for the initial Government decision last December that resulted in the suspension of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer's security clearance.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 (AP) -- Bill Wilson hit two home runs over the left-field roof, the second with two out in the ninth inning, as the Philadelphia Athletics scored over the Washington Senators in a seesaw duel tonight, 18 -- 7, for a sweep of the two-game series.

Your correspondent Jack Molin, in his letter published June 28, takes Dr. Gabriel Mason, principal of Abraham Lincoln High School, and the High School Teachers Association to task for advocating a salary differential for high school teachers.

Cross-examination of Arnold Bernstein continued yesterday in his $11,000,000 Federal Court suit against the Holland-America Line. Letters and documents were introduced by John A. Wilson, counsel for the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.

" My Name Is Tom Connally," by former Senator Tom Connally as told to Alfred Steinberg, will be published Sept. 13 by Crowell. In the book, the Senator looks back over his long career, which included both World Wars, the depression, the New Deal and the Korean conflict.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the House of Representatives passed today a $3,368,608,000 foreign aid bill:

The traditional Three R's -- reading, writing and arithmetic -- are not enough in the world crisis, Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, said yesterday. He urged the adoption of the modern Three R's -- resources, resolution and responsibility.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Eisenhower said today that Vice President Richard M. Nixon normally might be assumed to be speaking for the Administration. However, he avoided any specific endorsement or repudiation of the Vice President's latest foreign policy speech, which irritated Democrats.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller said today that the 2 per cent of United States children who were juvenile delinquents were in "desperate" need of help.
ROME, June 30 -- A month-old Communist-inspired farm strike in Ferrara Province in north-central Italy was called off today.

THE year reaches its midway point, or thereabouts, today. It is time for the semiannual casting up of lit'ry accounts, with grace notes on summer reading. On balance, the first six months of 1954 in books present a far more reassuring landscape than some of the other, less civilized, public endeavors of man at this moment in history.

Giving no quarter to a foe who wouldn't ask for it in any event, Leo Durocher's high flying Giants flattened a riddled band Dodgers at the Polo Grounds yesterday, 5 to 2, before a gathering of 29,693.
GENEVA, June 30 -- The United States delegation at the Indochina negotiations, which has already been reduced to skeleton size, may soon be cut down to vanishing point.
RICHMOND, Va., June 30 -- The Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company of Virginia received an increase in rates today.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 30 (AP) -- Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Peter Lane surprised in the first division of the Select Handicap by outclassing a strong field of 3-year-olds before a crowd of 14,505 at Monmouth Park today.
Mrs. Nellie Sheer Kagan was the first player to reach the semi-final round of the Women's Eastern clay court tennis championships yesterday.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 30 -- Racial segregation in all parochial schools in Nashville and Davidson County will be ended next fall.

TRENTON, June 30 -- The more than 14,000 horse racing fans who placed bets at Monmouth Park today became, perhaps unwittingly, the first persons to contribute to the new school aid program that was signed into law this morning by Gov. Robert B. Meyner.

The Murray Corporation of America, manufacturer of automotive equipment, home appliances and plumbing fixtures, had a net profit of $3,601,895 in the nine months ended May 31, compared with $2,233,359 earned in the similar period of the previous year.
OTTAWA, June 30 (Canadian Press) -- Two Russian chess masters, Igor Bondarevsky and Alex Kotov, disposed of twenty-eight Canadian players in four hours last night.
AS amusing light summer fare the Metropolitan Museum and the Public Library have opened in their print departments colorful displays from their collections, which should appeal to many visitors.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane and Kidder, Peabody Co. jointly headed two syndicates which were successful bidders on 245,000 shares of common stock and 50,000 shares of 4.32 per cent cumulative preferred stock, series D, of the Florida Power and Light Company.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 30 -- Two bright spots in the Hollywood employment situation came to light today. George Sidney, president of the Screen Directors Guild, reported that 78 per cent of the organization's 750 members were employed by motion-picture studios and by companies engaged in making movies for television.
CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- There was a good demand for lightweight butcher hogs today but otherwise trading was slow. Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- In upholding the 2-to-1 conclusion of the board headed by Dr. Gordon Gray, that Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer is a security risk, the Atomic Energy Commission accepted, 4 to 1, the board's basis of his "trustworthiness" as the governing criterion.

JERUSALEM, June 30 -- The United Nations Truce Supervision organization told Israel today that United Nations observers were entitled to "take quick action irrespective of the provisions of the armistice agreements."

The three-story building at 425-29 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Thirty-eighth Street, has been sold by C. A. Brenninkmeyer, Inc., to Louis Schleifer, a realty investor, and will be vacated within about two weeks by the Women's apparel store.

NOW that the bass season is open, avenues of opportunity have broadened for the fresh as well as salt water anglers, and the holiday weekend offers a really wide range of angling activity, provided the weather man will cooperate.

James A. (for Andrew) Hagerty retired last night from active newspaper work. Now nearing his seventy-eighth birthday, he has been a respected reporter for the last fifty-five years, the last thirty-four of which were spent in the employ of The New York Times.
The election of Cassius C. Mallory as chairman of the Committee of American Steamship Lines for 1954-55 was announced yesterday by Rudolph S. Hecht, who is retiring from the post.

The 5 per cent amusement tax law, in effect since 12:01 A. M. today, will be amended this afternoon to exempt tickets sold prior to today for baseball games and theatrical performances to be given after July 10.
A former Deputy Chief of Staff of the Eighth Army in Korea, Maj. Gen. Charles W. Christenberry, has been appointed chief executive officer of the American-Korean Foundation.
Co-existence with the Communists -- Good faith on both sides was required. It must not mean appeasement, for he "will not be a party to any treaty that makes anybody a slave."
HANOI, Vietnam, June 30 -- According to Gov. Nguyen Huu Tri, 50,000 to 60,000 Vietnamese civilians have pulled up stakes and evacuated four towns in the lower Red River delta.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., June 30 (AP) -- The International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., tonight was declared the winner of a National Labor Relations Board election at General Electric's main plant here.

PARIS, June 30 -- France's Premier said tonight that any proposal by his Government to break the deadlock over the European army treaty would be discussed with the five other signatory states before being submitted to Parliament. He predicted the issue would be put up to Parliament in the first half of August.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) -- Bobby Dykes of Miami provided a major upset tonight by holding Holly Mims of Washington, the world's second-ranking middleweight contender, to a ten-round draw.

In its 4-to-1 vote to withhold clearance from Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer the Atomic Energy Commission dismisses entirely as a factor in reaching its decision any alleged lack of "enthusiastic support" by Dr. Oppenheimer regarding the making of the so-called H-bomb.

ALBANY, N. Y., June 30 (AP) -- The State Commerce Department said today that business was "very good" in New York State during the first six months of 1954 and promises to stay that way for the rest of the year.

An intensified drive to build support for enactment next year of President Eisenhower's liberal tariff-trade program was pledged yesterday by Charles P. Taft, president of the Committee for a National Trade Policy.

Thompson - Starrett Company, Inc., international builder and contractor, will acquire the Roberts Schaefer Co., fifty-year-old Chicago engineering construction and manufacturing company, subject to approval of the stockholders of both companies at special meetings on July 26.

The Moscow announcement that the Soviet Union opened its first industrial atomic power station last Sunday is clear evidence that the race for atomic power is in full swing. No doubt Communist propaganda will hail this as a major, historic achievement.

ZURICH, June 30 (UP) -- Favored Hungary had to go into overtime to beat the defending champion, Uruguay, 4 to 2, and Germany crushed Austria, 6 to 1, in semi-final games in the World Cup Soccer football championships today.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The National Labor Relations Board announced today it would accept fewer small and local cases from now on.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) -- Senator Charles E. Potter Republican of Michigan, today criticized the use of unpaid consultants such as G. David Schine, former member of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's staff.

City Civil Defense planning to meet possible hydrogen bomb attacks does not differ basically from the preparedness to meet atom bomb attacks, Herbert R. O'Brien, Director of Civil Defense, said yesterday in his annual report to Mayor Wagner.
BOTH the Giants and Dodgers were a mite sleepy-eyed when they reached the Polo Grounds yesterday, not so much more than ten hours after they'd left the place in the small hours of the morning.
For the third successive month, new bonds marketed publicly here have exceeded a billion dollars.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Laurence B. Robbins, Administrator of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, delivered today a check for $100,000.000 to the Treasury as one of the final acts of the twenty-two-year-old Government lending and business agency.

CHICAGO, June 30 (UP) -- Bill Tuttle, rookie centerfielder, hammered his fifth nomer of the season in the ninth inning today to give the Detroit Tigers a 4-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox before 17,775 ladies' day fans.

Bargaining continued early today as negotiators for the Western Electric Company and 17,000 of its telephone equipment installers throughout most of the country sought to avert a strike scheduled for 6 A. M.

MOSCOW, June 30 -- Another big new canal project has been launched in the Ukraine -- an eighty-mile channel [cross on map] designed to double or triple the water supply of the important coal and steel region of the Donets Basin (Donbas) by tapping the Northern Donets River.

OTTAWA, June 30 -- Sir Winston Churchill urged again today the "peaceful coexistence" of the Western and the Communist worlds. Again and again during a press conference here he came back to this idea.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., June 30 -- The Forty-second Infantry Division of the New York National Guard was host today to nine business officials, who came to near-by Camp Drum to watch the Forty-second undergo military training exercises.
GUATEMALA, June 30 -- Guatemala's new military govern-pressing agrarian uprisings in at least two areas. It was probable that more were in the making.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The House of Representatives approved today a continuation of the Mutual Security Program and authorized $3,368,608,000 to do the job in the fiscal year opening tomorrow. The vote was 260 to 125.

A plastic dome may be home in 1964 if a prediction announced by the General Electric Company yesterday comes to pass. A model, which incorporates this dome and other unusual features, designed by Eliot Noyes, architect of New Canaan, Conn., will, according to the company, be built full size in ten years.

SAN SALVADOR, June 30 -- The first meetings on a Guatemalan truce took place here today between Col. Elfego Monzon, chief of the new junta, and Col. Carlos Castillo Armas, insurgent leader, in the presence of a third colonel, Oscar Osorio, the Salvadoran President.

By the end of next week New Yorkers may be seeing something new on the streets, the stock-car taxicab. The City Council has approved, by a vote of 21 to 3, the legal modifications suggested by Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams, and Mayor Wagner is expected to sign the amendments after a five-day statutory period.
VALLEY STREAM, L. I., June 30 -- Long Island motorists will pay their first parkway tolls here tomorrow with the opening to traffic of the first five miles of the improved Southern State Parkway.
The effect of the Oppenheimer verdict on national security will be felt in the scientific community and in military technology.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 30 (AP) -- Arch Ferrell, Circuit Solicitor of Phenix City; the Jefferson County (Birmingham), Democratic Chairman, Lamar Reid and a "widely known Alabama public official" were indicted on vote fraud charges today.
Contract negotiations between the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., were resumed yesterday after a two-week suspension.

There can be little quarrel with the general idea of the City Planning Commission that henceforth new nonresidential construction should provide some space for off-street garaging and parking of cars. If something like this is not done, the continued construction of new offices and other commercial buildings, particularly in the congested midtown areas, will merely mean intensification of the traffic suffocation that the city for years has been experiencing.
SOUTHPORT, England, June 30 (AP) -- Gene Sarazen gained a four-bole lead over Percy Alliss of Britain today in the first international senior professional championship golf match.
LONDON, June 30 -- Scientific investigators reported tonight that uranium, the stuff of the atomic bomb, had given clinching evidence of the hoax of the Piltdown man.
MOSCOW, June 30 -- Diplomats here think the principle of collective leadership in the Communist party has been strengthened by the recent plenary session of the Central Committee.

MOSCOW, June 30 -- Only spotty glimpses of the solar eclipse were possible in Moscow today because of clouds, but in the North Caucasus, where the main Soviet astronomical observation was centered, fine weather was reported.

LONDON, June 30 -- The improvement in the stock markets here extended today from selected industrials to Government funds. The revival of interest in funds brought gains of up to two shillings sixpence (35 cents).

BALTIMORE, June 30 (AP) -- Mike Garcia shut out the Baltimore Orioles tonight, 2 -- 0, yielding four singles, and the Cleveland Indians extended their American League lead to three games over the Chicago White Sox.

The first formidable and nearly successful attempt of Kremlin-directed Communists to seize a whole state in the Americas has apparently been crushed. In what looks like the first successful anti-Communist revolt since the last war, the Communist-dominated regime in Guatemala has been overthrown and the new provisional regime, headed by a military junta, has taken immediate steps to rid the country of the Communist menace.

CINCINNATI, June 30 (AP) -- Joe Cunningham, playing in his first major league game after being brought up from Rochester of the International League, drove in five runs tonight with a home run and a single as the St. Louis Cardinals drubbed the Cincinnati Redlegs, 11 -- 3.

TOKYO, June 30 -- The new Japanese Army, Navy and Air Force officially come into existence tomorrow. The rush of enlistments among young men of military age is much greater than the recruiting stations can handle.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange developed irregularity yesterday, but trading was more active and closing prices were 14 points higher to 11 lower than Tuesday, on active months.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 30 -- Alfred Rowe of East Orange, Grand Master of Masons for New Jersey, today urged the 700,000 members of the Ancient Arabic Order, Nobles of the Mystic Shrine for North America, to participate more actively in political, civil and social activities in their communities.
FAIRFIELD, Calif., June 30 -- Forty-seven French soldiers wounded in the defense of Dienbienphu landed at near-by Travis Air Force Base today and called for wine and haircuts.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- Furniture manufacturers and retailers in 1954 will clear their lowest profits in more than ten years despite near-record sales, Walter S. Marder of Portville, N. Y., president of the National Association of Furniture Manufacturers, predicted today.

Forty or so members of the staff of Lennen Newell gathered late yesterday in the conference room of their spanking-new offices at 380 Madison Avenue. Philip W. Lennen, director and chairman of the board, had been planning to retire -- and never quite getting around to it.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The United States, New Zealand and Australia called today for "immediate action" toward the creation of an anti-Communist security pact for Southeast Asia.

Large refundings by public utility corporations lifted the total of bonds called in June for redemption before maturity to $147,258,000, the largest for any month since March, 1952. The total compared with $92,365,000 last May and $83,158,000 in June, 1953.

NEW DELHI, India, June 30 -- While astronomers and scientists in India anxiously scanned the sky with their costly instruments for valuable data on India's first solar eclipse in fifty-six years, millions of devout Hindus throughout the country rushed to seashores and rivers for a bath to ward off the "evil effects" of the heavenly phenomenon today.

Yesterday was V (for vacation) Day, and the city's youngsters made sure their elders knew about it. In time-honored and earsplitting fashion, more than 920,000 public school pupils unceremoniously greeted the end of the school year and the start of the summer vacation with laughter and shouts.

All stock exchanges in Canada, the Winnipeg Grain Exchange and virtually all banks and business houses north of the border will be closed today in observance of Dominion Day. Exchanges will be open tomorrow but many businesses will take an extra-long week-end.

HACKENSACK, N. J., June 30 (AP) -- Edward Moylan of Trenton, New Jersey state tennis singles champion, today defeated Dr. Jack Geller of Port Chester, N. Y., 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, to reach the Eastern clay court tennis tournament quarter-finals.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 30 (AP) -- Adios Boy, Philip Scott and seven other speedy pacers will hook up tomorrow night in the $25,000 National Pacing Derby on the Grand Circuit program at Roosevelt Raceway.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) -- Paul Crouch, a former Communist, suggested to J. Edgar Hoover today that he check on the loyalty of the office aides of Attorney General Herbert Brownell.

" We offer not just braces to the handicapped child but counsel to his family," a staff member of the new Diagnostic and Evaluation Clinic at Queens General Hospital explained on an inspection tour of the clinic the other day.
An all-Tchaikovsky program was conducted last night by Pierre Monteux at Lewisohn Stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended June 23:
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- John Foster Dulles declared tonight that the overthrow of the Guatemalan Government had removed "at least one grave danger" to the American hemisphere.

A full appraisal of the situation in Guatemala would seem to suggest that the measure you propose in your editorial of June 22 "Shadow and Substance" would fall far short of its goal Tyranny and poverty -- I have inverted your phrase -- in Central America cannot be reduced merely by grants and loans.
MOSCOW, June 30 -- The Soviet Council of Ministers announced tonight that a 5,000-kilowatt electric power station using atomic energy was being operated somewhere in Russia.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Federal Tariff Commission, by a 4-to-2 vote, has urged President Eisenhower to raise tariffs on Swiss watches and watch movements by at least 50 per cent.

Cocoa futures reached new highs yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Commission-house buying and trade short-covering moved most options up the cent-a-pound daily limit. Trading was influenced by a tight supply of actual cocoa and a sharply higher London market.
Following is the text of a speech last night by Secretary of State Dulles on Guatemala, as recorded by The New York Times:

CHICAGO, June 30 -- Wheat futures registered further substantial gains in the early trade today, but receded substantially from the top as general demand faded. Local longs were inclined to cash in on profits.

ST. LOUIS, June 30 -- The National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, after twenty-five years of contemplation, voted today to move its national headquarters in New York to Washington.

ALBANY, June 30 (AP) -- The New York Telephone Company asserted today that a New York City engineer had made a $10,000,000 error and thus had given "grossly misleading" testimony against the company's request for a rate increase.

A letter from Warren W. McSpadden, general manager of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, points out that many pets are abandoned by owners going on vacation. Mr. McSpadden indicates that if the animals are turned over to the public animal shelters efforts will be made to find them good homes.

MASTUNG, Pakistan, June 30 -- The first total eclipse of the sun in fifty-six years in the Indo-Pakistan subcontinent today sparked the hope of scientists that long-range weather forecasts -- possibly as long as four weeks -- might be made as a result of atmospheric data gathered in the seventy-two seconds of the solar phenomenon.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 -- It will be young Ken Rosewall of Australia against Jaroslav Drobny of Egypt Friday in the men's singles final of the all-England lawn tennis championships.
Mississippi borrowed $13,000,000 in the public market yesterday at a net interest cost of 2.5344 per cent.

The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad announced yesterday that it had asked for bids on construction of 500 to 1,000 fifty-ton boxcars. Prices on the equipment are to be on an alternative basis of company specifications and those of prospective builders.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Defense Department has refused, with apparent finality, to give security clearance to two staff employes of the McCarthy investigations subcommittee.

LONDON, June 30 -- King Gustav Adolf of Sweden, in a speech at Guildhall here today, paid special tribute to those qualities of "reliability" he said "have justly made the city of London admired and respected."
CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., June 30 -- An anthropologist and social biologist said here today that he "hoped to see the day when all mothers would have their babies at home."
The General Cable Corporation announced plans yesterday to install the nation's first press for extruding aluminum sheathing directly on to an insulated cable core.

ROME, June 30 (AP) -- Soviet Russia completed a sweep of the world gymnastic championships tonight by winning the men's team title, five individual crowns and sharing in a sixth. Japan finished second in the team race.
BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., June 30 -- James Galgano of Rockland tied with two others for low gross honors in a one-day Metropolitan Golf Association tournament over the Briar Hall course today.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 30 (AP) -- Admiral Charles Turner Joy tomorrow steps out of a forty-year Navy career that once thrust him into the role of chief negotiator with the Communists in Korea.
Nearly 150 drivers and tank-linen who service all the aircraft at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, walked out early today in a dispute over wages and other benefits.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet and irregular most of yesterday, prices closing 5 points higher to 13 lower than Wednesday.
ALBANY, July 1 -- The State Commissioner of Social Welfare promised today that his department would not publish a list of "approved" charitable organizations.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 30 -The National Assembly approved tonight Government sponsored election law changes that virtually mixed party voting lists in Turkey. Written votes also were banned. The Assembly vote was 337 to 33, with one abstention.

The vacant plot 75 by 150 feet at the northwest corner of West 235th Street and Oxford Avenue in the Bronx, which was bought about ten days ago by Robert Zeilter, has been resold to Riverdale Properties, Inc., headed by Albert Phelps Jr. The property was held at $60,000.
Once a Thanksgiving specialty only, turkeys are high on the list of "specials" that are being offered for this festive Fourth of July week-end.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that price support rates for 1954 crop wheat would average $2.24 a bushel nationally instead of the $2.20 minimum average announced at planting time last fall.
Sir Winston Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden sailed for home yesterday aboard the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth from West Fiftieth Street.
PEABODY, Mass., July 1 -After a two-year absence because of illness, Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias came back today to try again for the women's United States open golf crown.

With a million or more automobiles expected to move in and out of the city over the Fourth of July week-end, suggestions for safety dominated pre-holiday announcements. At the same time, airlines, bus companies and railroads prepared to make space available for the extra thousands who will travel by those means on the holiday.

The turbulent situation in Guatemala has brought Political the practice of granting political asylum in foreign embassies back into the news. Because the United States has for so long been identified as a haven for the oppressed of the world, it may surprise some readers to learn that had such refuge been sought within American diplomatic premises, in all probability it would have been denied.
CAIRO, July 1 -- Archaeologists have evolved five theories about the fact that the sarcophagus at Sakkara is empty.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UP) -- Saudi Arabia has assured the United States that the oil-shipping deal King Saud has made with the Greek-born shipper, Aristotle Socrates Onassis, will not bar United States tankers from Saudi Arabian oil. United States officials said today the assurance was given during recent talks in which Ambassador George Wadsworth protested the shipping concessions granted Mr. Onassis.

Arnold Bernstein, former German shipowner, testified yesterday in Federal Court that he paid $30,000 to Nazi authorities in July, 1939, for his release from German prison, after serving a two-and-a-half year term for foreign exchange violations.

DETROIT, July 1 (AP) -- Shrugging off a two-stroke penalty, Dave Douglas, son of a Scottish professional, fired a 3-under-par 68 at the Meadowbrook Country Club today to take the first round lead in the Motor City open golf tournament.

The Boston and Maine Railroad apparently is not waiting for any new revolutionary trains to come off the drawing boards before it modernizes its passenger service. Directors of the road decided yesterday to take advantage of what is available now. The board approved the purchase of fifty-five Budd self-propelled Diesel rail cars and twelve Diesel locomotives.
OTTAWA, July 1 -- Major changes in the Canadian Cabinet were announced by Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent today.
The Colorado Interstate Gas Company has filed a registration statement covering the sale of securities amounting to $41,000,000. This will be the first public financing by the company.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt announced yesterday that she had canceled her proposed trip to Russia because Soviet visas had not been granted to the journalist or to the Russian-speaking writer she had planned to take with her.
