ST. MARY'S, Scilly Isles, July 1 (UP) -- Two would-be rescuers failed today in an attempt to catch a seal so they could remove an old airplane tire stuck around its neck. The seal, nicknamed Sammy by local residents, aroused their sympathy when they noticed he could not dive for food because the tire gave him too much buoyancy.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 1 -- Prince Adios, with a closing burst of speed under the whip of Clint Hodgins, beat Adios Boy by a head to win the $25,000 National Pacing Derby on the Grand Circuit program at Roosevelt Race way tonight.
PARIS, July 1 -- The withdrawal of French forces from the southern part of the Tonkin delta does not mean abandonment of Hanoi, according to officials here.

Charles Burlingham was re-eletced yesterday to his eighth term as president of the Civil Service Reform Association. He is a member of the law firm of Burlingham, Hupper Kennedy and a trustee of the Community Service Society.
JERUSALEM, July 1 -- Israeli and Jordanian representatives agreed upon an unconditional cease-fire to take effect at 6:30 o'clock tonight.
Exiled leaders of countries that have fallen under Soviet domination joined with Americans at the Statue of Liberty yesterday to observe the first Freedom Day, dedicated to freedom for all peoples.

Rubber prices were strong yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange in the most active market since rubber trading resumed on March 3, 1952, after Government restrictions were removed. The spot price of rubber rose 5/8 cent a pound to 23 7/8 cents for No. 1 standard rib, smoked sheets, to establish a new high for the year. Futures prices rose 72 to 94 points on 3,700 long tons traded.

HENLEY, England, July 1 (UP) -- A lightweight crew from Massachusetts Institute of Technology remained in the running for the Thames Challenge Cup in the annual Henley regatta today by winning its second heat.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UP) -- The Department of Commerce today took fourtten additional commodities, ranging from pill-making machinery to railway cars, from its list of strategic or short supply items which may be exported only by special permit.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 1 -- Walter Hendl, young American conductor of the Dallas Symphony Orchestra directed the Pacific Coast Festival Orchestra this afternoon in the last of four concerts of a series at the Santa Barbara High School auditorium. A capacity audience of 1,800 attended.

LACHAUX-DE-FONDS, Switzerland, July 1 (Reuters) -- Swiss watchmakers today renewed their protests over attempts of the United States watch-making industry to persuade President Ei senhower to boost import duties on foreign timepieces by 50 per cent.
Mrs. Alice Toby's motor trip to Jackson, N. H., was delayed three hours yesterday after it was discovered that her little bag containing $18,000 worth of jewelry was missing.

The Royal Bank of Canada, the largest bank in Canada and the fifth largest in the Western Hemisphere, plans to raise $21,000,000 through the sale of capital stock to its stockholders, James Muir, its president, has announced.

Dr. William F. Russell, president of Columbia's Teachers College, said yesterday that modern teachers in modern schools, colleges and universities must be encouraged. Otherwise, he warned, mankind will be unable to make the best possible use of available knowledge.

Pressing relentlessly on, the Giants gave the reeling Dodgers a farewell buffeting at the Polo Grounds yesterday and if there was any joy in Flatbush last night, the matter must have been kept a dark secret.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Senate trimmed the Administration's plan for tax reductions on income from corporation dividends today to a point where a single relatively minor feature remained.
LONDON, July 1 -- The British Government is planning major shifts in its overseas armed forces if, as it expects, it can reach an agreement with Egypt soon on the future of the Suez Canal base.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, July 1 (Reuters) -- Mrs. Janet Jagan today was sentenced to pay a fine of $85 or serve three months imprisonment for the unlawful possession of a top-secret police riot manual. A notice of appeal was given.
Shishkebabs, which have become a favorite in America, will be the featured item of many cooked-in-the-open meals this holiday week-end.
TORONTO, July 1 -- A Scottish clergyman denied today a British physician's contention that the British welfare state was hurting individual initiative.
The general committee of Lloyd's Register of Shipping elected officers for the year in London yesterday, the society's New York office announced here.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- A bill for the preservation of five of the Navy's historic ships, including the Constellation and the Constitution, was approved today by the Senate Armed Services Committee. The others are the Hartford, the Oregon and the Olympia.
Concerned over what was described as an acute teacher shortage, the National Education Association moved yesterday to ask for Federal aid to finance an adequate salary scale for teachers.

TRENTON, July 1 -- The posthumous confession of Harold G. Hoffman named the late United States Senator Hamilton F. Kean as the man partly responsible for Mr. Hoffman's becoming an embezzler. It blamed the Senator's failure to keep what the former Governor said was a promise of financial aid.

The recent action of the Federal Reserve Board in reducing legal reserve requirements represents an extension of the policy of "active ease" designed to help turn the tide of business recession, the National City Bank of New York reported in its July letter.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Senate Republican Policy Committee proposed today its own code of conduct in Congressional investigations to "assure the rights of witnesses" and protect people from "smears."

New York City's four municipal colleges -- City, Hunter, Brooklyn and Queens -- are not only excellent educational institutions, they are also big business. The four schools have an annual operating budget of $25,000,000. Thus Dr. Joseph B. Cavallaro, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, is sound in pressing for implementation of a recommendation by the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey that a chancellor be appointed to coordinate their administrative and financial activities.

The original report of a New York coroner's jury that Aaron Burr "willfully, feloniously" and with "malice aforethought" did "kill and murder" Alexander Hamilton in their famous duel on July 11, 1804, has just been put on public display.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 1 -- The Soviet Union has agreed to turn over to Iran eleven tons of gold and goods worth $8,000,000 in settlement of claims arising from wartime occupation of the country by the Russian Army.

The restless, changing sea is the subject of an anthology that A. C. Spectorsky has edited for Appleton-Century-Crofts. The selections have been culled from the works of eighty writers. They range from the beginning of recorded time to the present and are primarily nonfiction, but nonnarrative passages from fiction are included.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 -- The reigning queen of tennis, 19-year-old Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., will face that fine champion of yesteryear, Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., in the women's singles final of the all-England lawn tennis championships on Saturday.

WESTOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Mass., July 1 (AP) -- Forty-seven wounded French soldiers, the first of 500 being flown home, drank French Bordeaux wine tonight as they rested before taking off for Paris tomorrow on the final leg of their trip from Indochina.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) -- The owners of the Philadelphia Athletics have told Mayor Joseph S. Clark Jr. that unless the American League club can draw 400,000 fans in its remaining 1954 home games, the franchise would be moved or sold.

The selection of a site last week for the Air Force Academy, the future "West Point of the Air," represents an important milestone in rounding out what is perhaps the world's most extensive system of military education.
The city's new Department of Personnel, incorporating the revised Civil Service Commission, went into operation yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Board of Education of the District of Columbia voted today to eliminate the color line in the school census.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 3 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Reflecting the accelerated pace in Congress, President Eisenhower put in one of his busiest days today. He and Mrs. Eisenhower topped it off with a party for their staffs celebrating their thirty-eighth wedding anniversary.
The name Mitsubishi Shoji Kaisha was something to be reckoned with in Japanese business before Pearl Harbor and it is rising again on the international commercial scene.

Having worked together in their respective capacities as author and director on the forthcoming film "On the Waterfront," Budd Schulberg and Ella Kazan are likely to continue their association for the stage.

A rally by steels, motors, chemicals and aircrafts just before the close yesterday changed the tone of what had been a dull and generally downward market. As a result, the price average showed a small plus sign.

Plans for modernizing the store and second floor of the five-story store, office and apartment building on lot 25 by 100 feet at 10 East Fifty-third Street were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the property by the City Investing Company to Jack Brause for investment. James Felt Co. were the brokers.

GENEVA, July 1 -- One of Switzerland's leading newspapers warned today that raising of United States tariffs on watches would "mean the injection of a serious element of insecurity into the economic relations of the United States with foreign countries."
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee today approved a House bill extending the free trade arrangement between the United States and the Philippine Islands until Jan. 1, 1956.

At his press conference this week President Eisenhower refused to rebuke Vice President Nixon for a recent speech in which the Democrats were condemned for "the loss of China," the war in Korea and "the difficulty in Indochina." The President seemed to believe that the young Californian, like the rest of us, was entitled to free speech.

All segments of the American maritime industry were jubilant yesterday at the easy passage of an amendment to the Mutual Security Act that would require 50 per cent of all aid cargoes to go in American bottoms.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- A suspended Federal Housing Agency official refused today to answer questions about parties and fishing trips to Mexico asked by Senators investigating scandals in the Government's housing programs
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Lawyers at the forthcoming meeting of the American Bar Association will hear a churchman discuss the family court movement.
GUATEMALA, July 1 -Guate-{ mala's three day-old military] junta is facing increasingly seri-] ous trouble from incipient upris-] ings across the country.
PARIS, July 1--More than 4,000 recently drafted French troops will be sent to Morocco.

Following, as gathered by The New York Times and The Associated Press, are editorial comments by some of the country's newspapers on the Atomic Energy Commission's refusal to give Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer access to secret atomic data:
I note your editorial of recent date protesting against the change of the name of the street in front of Beth Israel Hospital from Livingston Place to Nathan D. Perlman Place.

LIVERPOOL, England, July 1 (Reuters) -- After lying crippled for seventeen months on the muddy bottom of Gladstone dock here, the burned-out liner Empress of Canada sailed again today, but only into drydock.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that it would purchase this month about $62,000,000 worth of cotton price support certificates sold to private lending agencies to help finance price support loans to farmers on the 1953 cotton crop.

TOWNSFOLK who scatter to the hills and down to the sea on Independence Day in the mid-twentieth century ought to know that when the nation and the holiday were new New Yorkers celebrated the Fourth, broadly speaking, in soberer ways.

MADRID, July 1 -- Enrique Cardinal Pla y Deniel has told the Spanish people that the Roman Catholic Church in Spain acts independently of the state. Therefore, it is the Government that must be credited with the "glory for its successes and the responsibility for its possible errors," he added.

A 50-year-old woman, despondent since the death of her husband three months ago, spent ninety frantic minutes on a narrow fifth-floor window ledge of a West Side hotel last night. Policemen combined cunning, agility and force to drag her to safety after she had threatened to jump.
MELBOURNE, Australia, July 1 -- The former chief of Soviet espionage in Australia told a Royal Commission today of severe punishment given captains of ships who mingled too freely with foreigners.

Three new films open at first run theatres today. At the Globe is an Italian import "Hell Raiders of the Deep," a drama of undersea warfare during World War II. Heading the cast are Pierre Cressoy and Eleonora Rossi Drago, with Paul Muller, Riccardo Gallone, Girolamo Manisco and Luidi Ferraro in featured roles.

The plan of the World Calendar Association to standardize the calendar seems to overlook one important thing -- that a great merit of our present calendar lies in the very fluctuation which the reformers would eliminate.

A moderate and guarded approval of advertising as a means for disposing of the mounting surplus emerged yesterday from a meeting of the butter committee of the New York Mercantile Exchange, trading center.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Powerful Senate Republicans warned the Administration today to remain firm against Communist China's entry into the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Thirty - two Western Senators urged President Eisenhower today to increase tariffs on lead and zinc.

The forward landing gear of a National Airlines DC-6 collapsed on landing early yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. The airliner stopped abruptly, remaining on the runway with its nose on the concrete and its tail high in the air.
OTTAWA, July 1 (Canadian Press) -- The new Canadian Cabinet is as follows:

WEST ORANGE, N. J., July 1 -- Chester Sanok, New Jersey State amateur champion, and Jerry Volpe of Forsgate shot a seven-under-par 31, 34 -- 65 to win the state pro-amateur best-ball championship today at the Essex County course.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 1 -- Business and professional women set their sights anew today against legislation they termed discriminatory to women. Their principal targets were alleged Civil Service bias, tax inequities and legislation aimed at weakening the proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution of the United States.

HANOI, Vietnam, June 30 -- The French High Command acknowledged today that French Union troops were evacuating the entire southern zone of Tonkin's Red River delta. The withdrawal leaves about 1,600 more square miles to the Vietminh rebels.

Spring shopping was a little late this year but not too late to make June the best month of 1954 for New York City's department stores; according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.

LONDON, July 1 -- Five men were found guilty today of smuggling or attempting to smuggle nearly $1,500,000 worth of copper and brass behind the Iron Curtain. Three other men were acquitted, and two companies were found guilty and one was acquitted.
New York bank loans to business dropped $26,000,000 last week, bringing the decline since the start of the year to $882,000,000. In the similar period of 1953 the reduction was $481,000,000.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Manufacturers' inventories shrank an additional $400,000,000 in May, compared with April.

It was heartening to read the statement of Dr. David L. Hill in The Times concerning the Oppenheimer case. It is wonderful to know that men of such caliber have the courage to express disapproval in such certain terms.
Assets and deposits of the Manufacturers Trust Company reached the highest totals in its history on June 30, according to the semi-annual condition statement issued for publication today.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled 4 to 1 today that an employer must furnish a union with complete payroll data for collective bargaining without requiring the union to prove it needs the information.

MILWAUKEE, July 1 (UP) -- Joe Cunningham hit his third major league homer in his second game today, Stan Musial took over the big league home run lead with two and Harvey Haddix was felled by a line drive as St. Louis defeated Milwaukee, 9 -- 2.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 -- Net current earnings of the Bank of America for the first six months of the year were reported today as $37,698,476, or $1.57 a share. This compares with $34,876,726, or $1.45 a share, for the first half of 1953.
A New York County grand[ jury has been investigating sinceI last autumn alleged racketeering] in public loading operations atI the Washington 1VIarket.

ALBANY, July 1 -- The State Police Superintendent, Albin S. Johnson, announced today that the thirty-seven-year-old "Boots and Saddles" uniforms for troopers were to be replaced this month by a lighter, looser and more efficient garb.
SOUTHPORT, England, July 1 (UP) -- Playing in a half gale today, Gene Sarazen defeated Percy Alliss of England, 4 and 3, to become the first international senior golf champion.

DUBLIN, July 1 (UP) -- A retired British general, who served with the British Eighth Army in North Africa, won a legal battle with Prime Minister Churchill today over a reference to him in Sir Winston's volume of war memoirs, "The Hinge of Fate."
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 713,160 cars, the Association of American Railroads reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Maj. Gen. K. D. Nichols, general manager of the Atomic Energy Commission, denied today that the agency had given a private power combine the go-ahead signal on construction of a $107,250,000 plant to supply energy to the Tennessee Valley Authority.
The United States Steel Corporation is raising base steel prices $3 a ton because of increased production costs resulting from the new labor contract settlement with the steelworkers.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Council of the Organization of American States will hold a special meeting tomorrow to "consider postponement" of the inter-American foreign ministers' conference, which was scheduled next Wednesday to discuss the Communist threat from Guatemala.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 1 -- Former President Truman continued today to make steady and encouraging progress in recovering from complications that followed an operation June 20.
A newspaper wire service would have "just and sufficient cause" for discharging a reporter whom its customers considered "biased," a labor arbitrator ruled yesterday.
LONDON, July 1 -- The Government named today eight members of the new civilian-oriented Atomic Energy Authority.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Administration was reported ready today to offer more defense orders to United States watch and clock makers to relieve distressed conditions in their industry. This would take the place of the increase in import duties the industry is demanding.

GOTHENBURG, Sweden, July 1 (AP) -- John Landy, Australia's "Miracle miler," failed in a new attempt to break his world 1,500-meter record tonight, but won the race with a clocking of 3:43.2 before 20,000 fans.

TOLEDO, July 1 -- Europeans acquire some strange ideas about the United States, and especially the midlands, it seems. Eight of them were disabused of at least some of their misconceptions -- to their evident pleasure -- and were confirmed in some of their ideas in a two-day visit to this "typical industrial city" on Lake Erie.
SAN SALVADOR, July 1 -- A settlement was reached here tonight ending the two-week conflict in Guatemala.

Isidor Stern has purchased the sixteen-family apartment house at 1917 Cropsey Avenue in Brooklyn from the 1917 Realty Corporation. Broadview Homes, Inc., was the broker in the transaction and title was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company. The property was held at $47,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 1 -- Frank S. Land, past Potentate of Ararat Temple, Kansas City, and founder and Secretary general of the Order of Demolay, was inaugurated Imperial Potentate of the Ancient Arabic Order Nobles of the Mystic Shrine this evening in Convention Hall.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 1 -Wrecking crews are swarming over the eighty-three-acre R. K. O. ranch in the San Fernando valley, tearing down and carting away buildings and sections of towns that for years have figured prominently in motion pictures.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, criticized Vice President Richard M. Nixon today as "an inept, naive Piltdown statesman." During debate on the farm bill he said Mr. Nixon had predicted that if Democrats regained control of Congress it would be "left wing."

While sales of the Wesson Oil and Snowdrift Company, Inc., and its subsidiaries declined in the nine months ended May 29 from those in the same period of the previous year, net profit increased to $4,406,756 from $2,641,503.

Hyvania and Neji, competing as the entry trained by George H. (Pete) Bostwick, finished one, two in the $11,400 Forget Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The Forget, a hurdle event of about two miles, had its seventeenth running.
LONDON, July 1 -- Prices continued to rise steadily on the stock exchanges here despite the weakness of Wall Street and the French retreat in Indochina.

WHEN Larry MacPhail, a man with ideas, first suggested night baseball for the major leagues, his proposal was greeted with shocked silence. The most articulate opponent of the plan, once he'd caught his breath, was Clark Griffith of the Washington Senators. But no team in the American League now plays more night games than Griff's hired hands.

A miniature wireless microphone that can be concealed on a performer's person was shown yesterday by the National Broadcasting Company. In television the device will give a dancer or artist the same freedom of movement as on the legitimate stage and end the so-called "tyranny" of the microphone boom.
LONDON, July 1 -- The case of Dr. Joseph H. Cort, the American former Communist who has been refused asylum in Britain, erupted in Parliament today.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Following is the text of the statement to the Senate by its majority leader, Senator William F. Knowland of California, regarding the possible admission of Communist China to the United Nations:

With all the grave problems that crowd in on the President of the United States, what was uppermost in his mind as he faced the assembled reporters at the start of his news conference on Wednesday? It was this:
HARTFORD, Conn., July 1 -- Connecticut Republicans nominated today candidates for the House of Representatives from the state's five Congressional Districts.
Telephone equipment installers employed by the Western Electric Company throughout the nation went on strike yesterday in a dispute over a new union contract.

DALLAS, Tex., July 1 -- Racial integration in the public schools in the South can be achieved if Negro and white community leaders emphasize to local officials "the real and influential shifting of public opinion throughout the region."

THE fresh water angler is not the only sportsman who is intrigued by the possibilities on the "other side of the fence," as was demonstrated yesterday when Chuck Meyer of New York returned from a three-day sortie to the Gulf Stream, 125 miles off Montauk.
Mechanical signs to "unbalance" traffic flow and help speed eastbound vehicles off the George Washington Bridge were installed yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.
Two French girls who are children's nurses for two United Nations families in Great Neck, L. I., started out yesterday for California on a motor scooter.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Mill buying of wheat futures was responsible for an early bulge today, but when this demand subsided prices reacted sharply from early highs. An easier tone at Kansas City, where buyers were less aggressive and country offers somewhat larger, checked the demand here.

The election of Bethuel M. Webster, retiring president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, as chairman of the board of the Public Education Association was announced yesterday. He succeeds Mrs. Samuel A. Lewisohn, who died June 14 in an automobile accident.
Herman E. Krawitz has been engaged as administrator of stage departments at the Metropolitan Opera, it was announced by the management yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Eisenhower Administration split the bipartisan farm bloc today to win tentative House approval of a compromise version of flexible farm price supports. The teller (unrecorded) vote was 179 to 164.

BOSTON, July 1 -- The Yankees, who left New York on June 15 in third place, three and a half lengths behind the league-leading Cleveland Indians, concluded their longest road trip of the season with an 8-7 victory over the Boston Red Sox today.

Since it would be considered nothing short of abominable for any person or group of persons to take away the locomotive power of other human beings I feel it is high time that some one pointed out the very serious thing that is being contemplated by the City of New York.

Japan's new defense forces came into official existence yesterday. An interesting and significant aspect of the situation is that enlistments have far outrun expectations. Actually, by no means all of the volunteers can begin to he accepted.

Now that all the evidence on the Oppenheimer case is in and the official opinions have been voiced, all but two dissenters seem to agree that the evidence against Dr. Oppenheimer, to quote the words of Eugene M. Zuckert, results in a "risk to security [which] passes acceptable bounds."

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Representatives of insurance organizations today attacked a proposed increase in payroll deductions for Social Security, contending that expanding benefits would some day ruin their business.
GENEVA, June 30 -- The Vatican has informed the United Nations Secretariat that it does not support the project for calendar reform now before the Economic and Social Council.
Soft, feminine lines in smooth, textured fabrics were featured in Gimbels' preview showing of autumn bridal gowns yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 1 -- V. K. Krishna Menon of India declared today that at the Geneva parley Eastern and Western powers, for the first time since the end of World War II, had made a real attempt at conciliation.
Memphis, Tenn., will receive bids on two bond issues totaling $6,000,000 on July 20, it was announced.
HOLLYWOOD, July 1 (AP) -Vince Martinez, 146 pounds, of Paterson, N. J., gained a unanimous ten-round decision tonight over Art Aragon, 145 1/2, Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -A Senate subcommittee was told today that secrets developed by the General Aniline and Film Corporation would be passed behind the Iron Curtain within thirty days if foreign control of the company were restored -even temporarily.

ALBANY, July 1 -- The State University filed a breach of contract suit today against Syracuse University in an effort to resolve a dispute involving $1,250,000 in endowment funds. The case centers on the College of Medicine, which the State University acquired from Syracuse in 1950.

The international educational exchange program is one State Department activity that has been receiving virtually unanimous approval ever since it was first undertaken after the war. It involves travel and study on the part of selected Americans abroad and on the part of selected foreigners in the United States, with the aid of a relatively small amount of Government funds.

Production of the country's paper industry during the first half of the year ran only slightly below record levels of 1953, it was reported yesterday by the American Paper and Pulp Association. Output of paper and board was about 13,100,000 tons.

A quick-thinking patrolman saved the life of a 41-year-old mother of three children yesterday by applying first aid after she had been slashed with a knife by a youthful burglar. A suspect was arrested several minutes after the attack.
MEXICO CITY, July 1 (UP) -- Jules Dubois, The Chicago Tribune correspondent for Latin America, is under police surveillance in the city of Guatemala, the Inter-American Press Association said today.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Except for the fact that reporters in Washington last week-end were free to write, and their publishers to publish, any news they could get of the Anglo-American conversations, the American press was in the position of the staff of Pravda.

LONDON, July 1 (Reuters) -Gen. Wilfred Kitching, taking over the leadership of the Salvation Army, called all members "to their knees" today and appealed for at least 5,000 more young men and women officers.
The Federal Flammable Fabrics Act, which went into effect yesterday, brings to mind other consumer protection laws that often pass unnoticed by consumers.
Holders of baseball and theatre tickets purchased before yesterday will not have to pay the city's 5 per cent amusement tax when the pasteboards are presented at ticket windows and box offices.

IN the year 1737 George II, by the Grace of God King of Great Britain and Ireland and Elector of Hanover, had been safely installed on the English throne for ten years. He had succeeded a father who hated him. In his turn he hated and despised his own heir, Frederick Louis, Prince of Wales. Queen Caroline also regarded the Prince as her enemy.
EAGLE PASS, Tax., July 1 (AP) -- The south Texas borderland where fifty-five are known dead and ninety are missing in the great Rio Grande flood today was declared a major disaster area.

The decision of the Alexander Smith Carpet Company to close its Yonkers plant threatens 2,200 residents of that city with a loss of their jobs and its merchants with a drop of almost $2 millions a year in their customers' purchasing power, except in so far as the displaced workers can get other jobs.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- During the week ended June 30, member bank reserves decreased $814,000,000 the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
MONT-LOUIS, France, July 2 -- French scientists are using the sun's energy here to produce and study a class of minerals called high refractories.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 2 -- Jaroslav Drobny of Egypt defeated Ken Rosewall of Australia, 13 -- 11, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 9 -- 7, today for the men's singles title in the all-England lawn tennis championships. And the thunderous applause that rang down the crowded center court at Wimbledon must have echoed wherever tennis is played.
Frederick C. Esser, purchasing agent for the Westinghouse lamp division, Bloomfield, N. J., has been elected second vice president of the Purchasing Agents' Association of New York.

Amid all the sound and fury about farm surpluses and price supports there is something new and hopeful in the Congressional scene that deserves the attention of consumers. It is the Dairy Stabilization Act of 1954, introduced by Senator Karl D. Mundt of South Dakota as S. 3152 and by Congressman Jack Westland of Washington State as H. R. 8493.

The $50,000 added Dwyer will have its thirty-seventh running at Aqueduct today, with a half-dozen 3-year-olds scheduled to compete. If they all go in the mile and a quarter fixture, it will be worth $57,900, with $39,800 going to the winner.
CHICAGO, July 2 (UP) -- The Chicago Cubs, losers of eleven of their last twelve games, scored five runs in the third inning today and held off a late St. Louis rally to edge the Cardinals, 7 -- 6.

Last Tuesday, Morris and Maria Xenos locked up their two infant children in their apartment at 58 West 104th Street. The parents have not been seen since, and yesterday one of the infants was found dead and the other suffering from hunger and thirst.
MADRID, July 22 -- Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Forces, arrived here today by special plane for an inspection of United States naval and air bases the United States will build in Spain.
PARIS, July 2 -- Gen. Paul Ely, French commander and High Commissioner in Indochina, said tonight before he left by plane for the Far East, that he had responsibility for defending the Tonkin delta.
GENEVA, July 2 -- The Secretary General has urged the United Nations to stop burdening the overworked secretariat with trivial tasks.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 2 -- The first West Coast presentation of Bohuslav Martinu's Rhapsody Concerto was the feature of today's concert at the Pacific Coast Festival.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 2 -- In spite of Communist pressure Brazilian workers have decided to hold off the threatened general strike until they see whether the Supreme Court throws out a new wage rise decreed by President Getulio Vargas.

Of discussions I have read on the disclosure of security-classified information by Government employes none seems to approach the one by Philip H. Phenix in his letter in The New York Times for June 18 for recognition and understanding of the problem and for a sound approach to it.
BENNINGTON, Vt., July 2 (UP) -- Bennington Selectmen were up in arms today over the closing of the 306-foot high Bennington battle monument, the world's tallest battle monolith.
KANSAS CITY, July 2 (AP) -- Former President Truman's condition was reported generally improved today. His temperature, pulse and respiration were normal.

GENEVA, July 2 -- The conference on peace in Indochina met again today. Deputies of the foreign ministers were the chief delegates for another discussion of the control machinery for an Indochina armistice.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- In a new step to prepare for any hydrogen bomb attack on the United States, the Federal Civil Defense Administration announced today it would move its headquarters to Battle Creek, Mich. The transfer will be completed within sixty days.

BERLIN, July 2 (AP) -- Friedrich Paulus, field marshal general in the Nazi army, urged today that West Germany sever what he called "nationally undignified ties" with the United States and establish good relations with the Soviet Union and France.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 2 -- United States military equipment for Pakistan will begin to arrive in October, according to Ambassador Horace A. Hildreth, who returned today from Washington. He left here May 16.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Council of the Organization of American States overwhelmingly approved tonight a United States proposal to postpone indefinitely the scheduled meeting next Wednesday of the Inter-American foreign ministers.

The Empire Trust Company reported as of June 30 total deposits, including official and certified checks outstanding, of $146,642,665 and total assets of $161,527,415, compared with $140,263,845 and $154,602,690, respectively, on March 31.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Eastern Air Lines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to change its mind about approving a possible merger between Colonial and National Airlines. Eastern is seeking a merger with Colonial.
PARIS, July 2 -- How France can become independent of United States aid is discussed in a report by the Commission on the National Economy issued here today.

BOSTON, July 2 (AP) -- Grady Hatton drove in three runs with an eighth inning bases loaded triple tonight as the Boston Red Sex pinned an 8-4 setback on the Philadelphia Athletics and their rookie pitcher Bob Trice.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 2 (AP) -- E. P. Bixer's Count Flame, with a stirring drive in the stretch, broke the track record for the mile and a sixteenth at Monmouth Park today while winning the Cavalcade Purse.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Secretary of States John Foster Dulles said today there was "no objection from the foreign policy viewpoint" to returning German and Japanese property in this country seized during World War II.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 -- The Dodgers are finding the road back from the Polo Grounds debacle rough, indeed. Tonight they first blew a 4-1 lead, then a 5-4 lead and the Phils beat them, 7 -- 6, before a cheering crowd of 21,929.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- A plastic valve to be inserted in the human heart was patented this week by Harry A. Lord of Pottstown, Pa.

The new general pay classification plan for 80,000 of the city's civil service employes will be established by resolution of the Board of Estimate and not by local law as first contemplated. It will be implemented by a resolution to be adopted by the newly-created City Civil Service Commission.

Reflecting a drop in sales, net profits of the Continental Motors Corporation and its consolidated subsidiaries declined to $2,293,541 in the six months ended on April 30 from the $3,343,658 earned in the corresponding period a year ago.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 2 -- William H. Baumgartner Jr. of 611 Radnor Avenue, Haddonfield, today was elected governor of New Jersey Boys State at Rutgers University.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, July 2 (Reuters) -- Francis Lacoste, resident general of Morocco, appealed today to the people of the French protectorate to remain calm despite increasing Arab terrorism. He urged the people to avoid retaliating with "blind violence."
The first project of the newly revitalized city Department of Commerce will be to stop the flight of industry from the city and to attract new business to New York.

UTICA, N. Y., July 2 (AP) -- A silvery, balloon-like object floating high over the Utica area tonight sent residents rushing to their telephones to make inquiries of newspapers, police and radio stations.
For the last six years director and co-producer with Ann Lee of the successful Sombrero Theatre in Phoenix, Ariz., Richard Charlton now has trained his sights on Broadway.

FRANKFORT, Ky., July 2 -- The Citizens Telephone Company, serving about 60,000 subscribers in Northern Kentucky, voluntarily reduced its rates today by $231,880 a year. The Kentucky Public Service Commission immediately approved the company's action, said here to be the first of its kind on record.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Small Business Administration today gave its fourteen regional offices authority to approve loans up to $50,000 without prior reference to Washington.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 2 -- The right to charge a 10-cent toll on Southern State Parkway was challenged today less than twenty-four hours after motorists started handing over dimes at the tollgate in Valley Stream. The collection began at 4 P. M. yesterday.
LONDON, July 2 -- Britain's meat trade was back private hands today for the first time in fourteen and a half years, as the nation prepared for the end to food rationing tomorrow midnight.

A divorce suit charging incompatibility has been filed in Mexico by John Jacob Astor against his second wife. Mr. Astor is the son of the late Col. John Jacob Astor, who lost his life in the sinking of the Titantic in 1912.

The Halliburton Oil Well Cementing Company earned $5,776,000 in the first five months this year, an increase of $2,000,000 over the similar period last year, Erle P. Halliburton, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting in Duncan, Okla., yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 2 -- Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, questioned today the Soviet Union's motives in having suddenly joined the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
MEXICO CITY, July 2 (AP) -- The Interior Ministry granted political asylum today to two former police officials in the Communist-backed former Guatemalan Government of Jacobo Arbenz Guzman.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 -- A suit charging fraud and demanding nearly $8,000,000 in damages was filed in near-by San Rafael today against Stewart B. Hopps, a San Francisco and New York financier.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Mill buying of wheat developed on early price recessions, absorbing pit offerings and starting a wave of stop- loss buying that resulted in the most outstanding price gains in a long time.
The rarity of psychosomatic ailments among women in Indonesia may be owing to the fact that, in that country, the woman's place is still in the home, according to a recent report by Dr. Mohamed Toha.
The United States Steel Corporation issued a revised list of steel prices yesterday and announced that the new prices, averaging $3 a ton higher, would become effecitve as of 12:01 A. M. today.

TORONTO, July 2 -- The Seventh International Conference of Social Work ended today with a plea by its president for greater understanding in Western countries of social and cultural conditions in the world's underdeveloped areas.
The city's post-war boom in babies is continuing this year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 2 -- Dan Dailey and Twentieth Century-Fox have reached agreement on terms of a new seven-year contract. It will go into effect Sept. 14, continuing an association begun in 1946 after the actor was discharged from the Army.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady all day yesterday, and closing prices were 15 points up to 2 off on active months.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Wholesalers sold $8,500,000,000 worth of goods in May, an amount slightly below the April total. Seasonally adjusted, the May sales were about $1,000,000,000 below the level of May 1953.

THE wisest and funniest book about Topic B (Russia) that I have seen this year is Eddy Gilmore's "Me and My Russian Wife," the shrewd and circular Associated Press correspondent's casual memoir of nearly a dozen years in baffling Muscovy. Topic A, of course, is either the hydrogen bomb, sex, where-shall-I-go-for-my-vacation or Willie Mays.

Three of the four gunmen who held up the Rutgers Check Cashing Service, 26 Canal Street, yesterday escaped, but the fourth was arrested on a rooftop after the police had chased the bandits by car and on foot.
SAN SALVADOR, July 2 -- A traditional embrace between two colonels with tears in their eyes symbolized at dawn today the end of the civil war in Guatemala.

Two five-story buildings containing forty-one apartments at 1232-36 Webster Avenue in the Bronx have been sold by Nathan Kaminsky to the Debray Realty Corporation an investor, for cash above mortgages of $109,000. Allan S. Feldman Co. and Joseph Panman were the brokers.

CLEVELAND, July 2 (UP) -- Bob Feller scored his fifth victory and Early Wynn gained his ninth triumph tonight as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Chicago White Sex, 3 -- 2 and 5---4, and increased their American League lead to four and one-half games over the second-place Yankees.
UTICA, N. Y., July 2 -- A jet fighter plane returning from a quick "scramble" to investigate an unidentified plane, later reported to be "friendly," crashed in flames in a crossroads hamlet today.
BALTIMORE, July 2 (UP) -- Joe Coleman pitched a three-hitter for his second shutout and ninth victory of the season tonight to give the Baltimore Orioles a 2-0 triumph over the Detroit Tigers.

HANOI, Vietnam, July 2 -- Vietnam's Premier has "protested energetically" against French abandonment of the lower area of the Red River delta to the Vietminh, Ngo Dinh Diem made his protest before the French Union troops were pulled out.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- An agreement for joint action to grant West Germany sovereignty was reached during the visit of Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden to Washington last week-end. But just how to go about it was not determined.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Sir Winston Churchill and Anthony Eden took the position during their recent talks here that the admission of Communist China to the United Nations was inevitable.
MILWAUKEE, July 2 (AP) -- Four home runs in the opener and another in the second game gave Milwaukee 11-4 and 2-1 victories over Cincinnati tonight in a twilight-night double-header.

NAMDINH, Vietnam, July 1 -- With half of its 80,000 population already gone, abandoned Namdinh, once the defense keystone for the lower Red River delta, is in a state of disarray, confusion and bewilderment.
NEW PALTZ, N. Y., July 2 -- Specialists in family relations should help mobile families put down roots easily and quickly in new settings, participants in a family life conference agreed here today.

" Skanderbeg," a Russian-made film biography in Sovcolor of the fifteenth-century Balkan warrior, opens today at the Stanley. Akski Khrava is featured in the title role of the Mosfilm-New Albania Production, which was written by Mikhail Papava, produced by Sergei Yutkevich and directed by Mary Antjaparidze, Mikhail Gomorov and Victor Stratoberdha.
The General Electric Company announced yesterday it would assume a greater share of the risks on orders of big turbine-generating power equipment.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 2 (UP) -- The Massachuetts Institute of Technology eight, the only remaining American crew in the Henley Royal Regatta, reached the Thames Challenge Cup semi-finals today, while Britain and Russia headed for a showdown in the Grand Challenge Cup.
The wife of Venezuela's President, speaking from Caracas yesterday, launched the latest addition to her nation's merchant fleet in Holland.

PARIS, July 2 -- The statement by the West German Chancellor demanding sovereignty came as a shock to those Frenchmen who had hoped the advent of Premier Mendes-France would open the way to a reconsideration of the European Defense Community Treaty offering opportunities to amend it.
The American Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., said yesterday it would seek the reinstatement of Theodore S. Polumbaum, who was dismissed in April, 1953, by the United Press Association.
PITTSBURGH, July 2 -- Under Leo Durocher's magic touch the Giants, it seems. have arrived at that stage in their gay pennant dash where most anything they try turns out right.

DENVER, Colo., July 2 -- "Ironically our nation under the Republican Administration has attained the lowest farm prices and the highest cost of living in the history of the United States," Adlai E. Stevenson said here today.
GUATEMALA, July 2 -- This capital city, in a wildly exuberant mood, turned out today to welcome home the heroes of peace. The only hitch was that the heroes did not arrive.
Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld reserved decision yesterday on a motion to reduce a jury's libel award of $175,000 in punitive damages to Quentin Reynolds.

LONDON, July 2 -- The United States and Britain will begin talks here Monday on alternative means of granting sovereignty to West Germany should France fail to ratify the European Defense Community treaty.
The views of leaders in several faiths on the question "Religion in a Distraught World" will be given at a conference beginning next Friday at Chillon Montreux Switzerland.
BONN, Germany, July 2 -- With new force and directness, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer demanded today that the West German Government receive full sovereignty.

MOSCOW, July 2 -- Pravda placed its support behind Einsteinian physics today. The Communist party paper sharply rebuked Soviet scientists who sought to differentiate between the great physicists's scientific contributions and what it called his "confused" philosophy.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Vice President Richard Nixon charged today that the Truman Administration left behind a "policy of weakness, a policy of surrender of principle at the conference table" in foreign affairs. Mr. Nixon said that Democratic planners "didn't understand . . . what the Communist threat really was" and "failed to recognize that it was a world trap."

Pyrotechny is the art of making fireworks It was developed first in China, where on festive occasions fireworks were used with great color ingenuity, beauty and brilliance. Fireworks were imported into Europe from the Far East and then brought into the United States in colonial times.
HARTFORD, July 2 -- Harold Strauch, Unemployment Compensation Commissioner, awarded compensation today to a cleaning woman who was discharged for using profanity.

LONDON, July 2 -- Peter Thorneycroft, President of the Board of Trade, left here tonight by air for Washington. He will confer with Harold E. Stassen, Foreign Operations Administration, and other United States officials on East-West trade security controls.
Capital financing now scheduled to enter the public market shows a sharp increase in the volume of corporate offerings, but a shrinkage in borrowings by state and local governments.

In planning meals, housewives should bear in mind the influence of family nutrition on dental health. Food is one factor affecting teeth, according to a recent bulletin from the National Research Council, a cooperative organization of American scientists.

Summer is here and the season of the salad is upon us. Not the little lettuce-and - tomato salad with French dressing that gives a fillip to a man-sized steak. Not the modest green salad with oil and vinegar that adds zest to a thick slice of rare roast beef.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Following is the 228-170 vote by which the House of Representatives today approved the Administration's compromise sliding-scale farm support program:

Detectives took into custody yesterday a prizefighter whom they described as "a prime suspect" in the killing of Edwin Whitmarsh early last month. Mr. Whitmarsh, 73 years old, was found slain in his apartment at 25 East Tenth Street.
East Baton Rouge Parish, La., will receive bids on July 29 on $2,625,000 of Recreation and Park Commission bonds due from 1956 to 1974.

The net result of the Congressional debates and the voting of the past forty-eight hours on the two most important economic reform measures to come up at this session -- the omnibus tax bill and the farm bill -- would indicate at this point a decisive, if by no means total, victory for the Administration.
PEABODY, Mass., July 2 -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias moved a step closer today to her goal of recapturing the women's United States open golf championship.

The long Fourth of July weekend started at the close of business yesterday with a rush for cooler places. In the city the weather was hot but not humid. The temperature reached a high for the day of 88.4 degrees at 4:05 P. M.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- Eugene M. Zuckert, recently retired Atomic Energy Commissioner, today opposed an all-out "crash" program to develop a peacetime atomic-power program. He said the nation needed more atomic weapons.

TOKYO, July 2 -- United States spending in Japanhas been halved since the end of the Korean war, according to official figures published here today. The reduction is seriously pinching the Japanese pocketbook.

ALBANY, July 2 (AP) -- Traffic over a 115-mile stretch of the State Thruway was heavier than expected in the first week of toll operation -- and there were no accidents, the Thruway Authority reported today.

TRENTON, July 2 -- One of four state officials suspended as a result of the investigation into the juggling of public and bank funds by Harold G. Hoffman has challenged the right of Gov. Robert B. Meyner to remove him from office.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 2 (AP) -- Casanova captured the featured $4,000 Oceanside Pace on the Grand Circuit card at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, scoring by a neck over Stanton Hal. The winner's time for the mile and one-sixteenth was 2:11 4-5. Mighty Boy was third.
The slacks, jacket and silk scarf pictured below look and feel much like other such garments.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 2 -- A sizzling battle in the United States Senate race between Robert S. Kerr, incumbent, and Roy J. Turner, former Governor, holds the spotlight in Oklahoma's Democratic primary.

CINCINNATI, July 2 (AP) -- Billy Talbert of New York, a former national doubles champion, was eliminated today from the Tri-State tennis tournament by E. Rubinoff, 19, of Miami Beach. Talbert lost in the third round, 6 -- 3, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 1.
Striking telephone equipment installers and the Western Electric Company settled their contract dispute early today.

ASHBY-DE-LA-ZOUCH, England, July 2 (Reuters) -- Coal mining threatens this market town's famous ancient tournament field, where armored knights jousted for a fair maiden's hand in the days of King Richard the Lion-hearted seven and a half centuries ago.
DETROIT, July 2 (AP) -- Firing six birdies apiece today, Dick Mayer of St. Petersburg, Fla., and Fred Haas of New Orleans, shared the lead at the halfway point in the Motor City open golf tournament.

Potato prices registered their sharpest rise of the year yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The increase was 13 to 16 points, or 13 to 16 cents a hundredweight. Volume was 996 car lots, the third most active day of the year.
LONDON, July 2 (Reuters) -- Communist China, denying United States accusations in the United Nations, protested today that it had nothing to do with international narcotics traffic.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 2 (UP) -- Nebraska's voters, represented by five Senators in the last three years, will elect three Senators in the same election in November for the first time in the state's history.

Two things have been happening to firm up the relations between the United States and the Philippines. They are important because the Philippines is one of our committed fronts in the long struggle against aggression. The Philippines forms also a unique bridge between East and West, since it is an Asian country with a fully accepted concept of society that complements the occidental outlook.
American Indian progress in agriculture is endangered by proposed Federal legislation, Oliver La Farge, president of the Association on American Affairs, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- President Eisenhower today rejected a Tariff Commission recommendation that he increase the duty on imported ground-fish fillets and set an annual quota on imports.
Nicholas H. Maarschalk retired last week from the least retiring business in the world. He managed the freight traffic department in New York for the Holland-America Line.
CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- Directors of the American Farm Bureau Federation urged President Eisenhower today to turn down proposals to increase the tariff on Swiss watches.
Sarsaparilla, a two-year-old Brooklyn monkey, succumbed yesterday to the universal Independence Day urge to go places, and thereby gave his neighbors and the police a busy morning.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Representative Shepard J. Crumpacker Jr., Republican of Indiana, introduced legislation yesterday to help automobile manufacturers combat new car "bootlegging."
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Government brought an antitrust suit today against the United Fruit Company.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, President of the Republic of Korea, is understood to be considering a trip to the United States for talks on the political and economic future of his country.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Eisenhower Administration overcame the "invincibility" of the farm bloc today as the House of Representatives adopted a flexible system of support ing farm prices. A roll-call vote of 228 to 170 gave President Eisenhower one of his most sweeping legislative victories.

French Union forces in the Red River Delta of Tonkin have withdrawn from their southern defense positions to shorten the "perimeter" and thus tighten the defense of Hanoi and Haiphong. This means turning over to undisputed Communist control an area somewhat larger than that of the state of Rhode Island.
LONDON, July 2 -- The Yorkshire Post celebrated its 200th aniversary today with a commemorative issue marked by messages of congratulation from Queen Elizabeth, Prime Minister Churchill and others.
After reading your editorial "Curtailing T. V. A." and the news stories concerning this vital public power installation, several questions present themselves.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 -- A proposal for a $5,000,000 bond issue to finance a major league baseball park in San Francisco led today to an unofficial move to bring the Philadelphia Athletic's American League franchise to this city.
ST. LOUIS, July 2 -- Six years' active support of the United Nations Genocide Convention by the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs was withdrawn today.

If the Yankees expect to make any progress in this pennant race, they are going to have to end their habit of dividing double-headers. Especially the double-headers they play against second-division rivals while the Indians and White Sox are battling each other.
Your editorial "Satellite Integration" states correctly that "The Kremlin can hardly desire that Poland, say, should have any more status or sovereignty than the Ukraine or Armenia."

LONDON, July 2 -- The stock markets ended the week with prices still rising. Industrials strengthened further on selective buying. Stores were especially strong, with gains generally of one shilling sixpence (21 cents). Up to one shilling (14 cents) was added by engineering, shipping, tobacco and paper-making shares.

In a match lasting three and a quarter hours, Isabel Troccole of New York defeated Jane Breed of New Caanan, Conn., in the women's Eastern clay court tennis championship yesterday at the Bayside Tennis and Racquets Club. The score was 2 -- 6, 6 -- 4 10 -- 8.

The sharp rise in the price of cocoa beans in the last six months has reduced the import demand, Bache Co., broker, reported yesterday. In the first six months of the year cocoa imports were 1,977,461 bags, about 25 per cent below the figure for the corresponding 1953 period.
Father Knickerbocker is trying to collect $416,985 in real estate taxes from twelve foreign countries, but so far has made scant headway.
LINCOLN, July 2 -- A hot fight between the ultraconservative and the more liberal elements of the Nebraska Republican party was fast developing in the wake of the death of Senator Butler.

The Academy Players, a select group of vastly appreciated actors, are performing in a loft building at 7 Hubert Street. Everyone in the audience wears a pistol, and the players' weapons are close at hand, for the "Academy" involved is the Police Academy, and the participants all are members of the Police Department.

At last the Senate heads of the Republican party have responded to the insistent public demand that the Senate recognize responsibility for the procedure of its own committees. They have recommended a code which, if adopted by the Senate, would be mandatory, would curb the present power of committee chairmen and would establish uniform rules for all committees.

Robert K. Christenberry and Livingston Osborne, chairmen of the New York and Illinois State Athletic Commissions, respectively, met in the New York Commission's office yesterday for three hours to discuss national and international boxing problems.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- An early report on the essentiality of the watch industry to national security was promised by a subcommittee of the Senate Armed Services Committee today as it concluded three days of hearings on the subject.
The Certain-teed Products Corporation has offered to purchase at $6.50 a share up to 75,000 shares of the common stock of the Valspar Corporation from holders of record as of Thursday.

MOSCOW, July 2 -- The Soviet Union today rejected United States disclaimers in connection with the seizure of the Soviet tanker Tuapse off Formosa and charged Americans with responsibility for it regardless of "whatever flag" the intercepting destroyer carried.

LONDON, July 2 (Reuters) -- Denis Compton, in a brilliant batting display, today registered 278 in four hours 50 minutes on the second day of the second test cricket match between England and Pakistan at Nottingham.

A syndicate of investors represented by Emil Leepson, attorney, has purchased the six-story apartment house for forty-eight families on plot 100 by 100 feet at 854 West 180th Street, corner of Cabrini Boulevard, in a deal negotiated by Abbott Adams Inc., brokers.

NEWARK, July 2 -- Federal labor mediators said today they had arranged a meeting for Tuesday in an effort to find a quick settlement of a work stoppage by American Federation of Labor ironworkers in eleven North Jersey counties.

MANILA, Saturday, July 3 (AP) -- An earthquake of great violence spread terror and destruction through the central Philippines yesterday and left possibly twenty-two dead in the ruins of homes and buildings. Scores were injured. Light tremors continued today.
Yesterday evening's program at Lewisohn Stadium was devoted entirely to Strauss "Die Fledermaus," and a good number of holiday stay-at-homers turned out for a relaxing evening.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Maj. Gen. Herbert B. Loper (Ret.) of Oxford, Neb., to be chairman of the Military Liaison Committee to the Atomic Energy Commission.
Louis B. Saperstein, a Newark insurance broker, was convicted last night in General Sessions of five counts of criminal contempt.

Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia made a surprise visit to the Bronx Zoo for an hour yesterday afternoon. It was his own idea. The usually stern-visaged little monarch, who seldom is seen to laugh in public, did for once and appeared to enjoy himself hugely.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 2 -- Chile's shortage of not only dollars but also pesos was brought sharply to public notice today.
EAGLE PASS, Tex., July 2 (AP) -- Authority was given today for aid from sympathetic Americans to cross the Rio Grande to Piedras Negras, Mexico, devastated by flood.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs had increased for the fourth week.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent to 110 in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

JERUSALEM, July 2 -- Gunfire from the Old City walls killed a soldier and wounded four other persons in the Israeli sector of this city this morning. But after noon the guns fell silent and in the evening the familiar Sabbath hush prevailed.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday was 38.4 per cent below that of the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were down 23.7 per cent and orders were up 2.4 per cent.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 2 -- Jim Podoley, Central Michigan College sophomore, gained the jump over the twenty-three-man field in the thirty-sixth annual national decathlon championship tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- The Senate approved a proposal today to deny tax exemption to any foundation or organization that tried to influence or intervene in any political campaign.

It was very good indeed to read your editorial entitled "Jim Hagerty Retires"; your superlatives were no exaggerations and your handsome tribute expressed what a multitude feel about him. You omitted to include among those he has known members of our State Legislature, many of whom, like myself, were fortunate to win his wise counsel.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The long-quarreling special committee of the House of Representatives investigating educational philanthropic foundations voted 3 to 2 today to hold no more hearings.
DALLAS, July 2 -- Basic legal studies have been completed for a broad campaign to end racial discrimination in privately owned multiple-unit housing developments having "governmental involvement."

The C. B. S. television network's decision to realign its Tuesday night schedule will remove "Suspense" from its usual 9:30 time period after the program of Aug. 17. C. S. B. says it has offered Electric Auto-Lite Company, the sponsor, an alternate time period or an alternate program but the company has decided to exercise its option to withdraw sponsorship.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Justice Department announced the United Fruit Company suit a scant forty-eight hours after Secretary of State Dulles had declared the Communists were trying to "obscure the real issue" of Communist imperialism in Central America, by charging that the United States was only interested in protecting United States business.

Flouting both the weapon of his attacker (a kitchen knife) and the burden of his years (78), an Avenue of the Americas jeweler displayed the heroics of a Musketeer yesterday. William Jacques, the gray-haired manager of the Jewelers Surplus Trading Company at Fifty-second Street, was alone in his store at 6 P. M. having pleasant thoughts about his Fourth of July week-end.

" A. Treasury of the World's Great Speeches," selected and edited by Houston Peterson, has been scheduled for Aug. 9 publication by Simon Schuster. The anthology begins with Moses proclaiming the Ten Commandments and ends with President Eisenhower's Inaugural Address.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Senate passed the Administration's omnibus tax reform bill today, 63 to 9.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- Charles H. Glueck, an Indiana mortgage broker, testified today he had made up to 9-for-1 profits on Federal housing deals while the state Federal Housing Agency commissioner was his close friend and penthouse neighbor.
CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- The report of the Department of Agriculture on today's livestock markets follows:

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 2 (UP) -- Gov. Johnston Murray today ordered martial Law during the Democratic primary next Tuesday in five eastern Oklahoma counties. He said troops would be stationed at polling places.

Leaders among the steels, motors, oils, aircrafts, chemicals, farm equipments, papers and radios made good gains yesterday and enabled the market to close with a net advance for the third successive week.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 2 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold called on Israel and Jordan today for immediate and "complete observance" of the cease-fire ordered in Jerusalem by the United Nations.
With all but two Southern states voting for it, the National Education Association adopted yesterday a resolution asking that segregation end in the nation's public schools.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Senate anti-monopoly subcommittee demanded today that the Atomic Energy Commission halt negotiations on a $107,250,000 contract to supply the Tennessee Valley Authority with power privately generated.

Admiring our parks as I do and seeing their beauty being destroyed I think the time has come to eliminate the pigeons. Just look what they are doing to our new Battery Park and what they have done to our lovely Bryant Park.

THE New York hunters who like to "rough it," and enjoy scoffing at the Sybarites who scour the farm-fringe jungles for their deer, have an opportunity to get in some wilderness hunting and two deer by packing in to some sections of the Adirondack Park this fall.
Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association will conduct an eight-week summer program for children and adults at its headquarters, 331 East Seventieth Street, starting Tuesday.

ZURICH, Switzerland, July 3 (Reuters) -- Austria defeated Uruguay, 1950 world champion, 3 -- 1, at Hardtum Stadium today for an unexpected victory in a match to decide third and fourth places in the 1954 world football soccer tournament.

LIMESTONE AIR FORCE BASE, Me., June 30 -- The world's smallest known television station was declared today to have proved its worth as an integral part of this remote air base from which the men of the United States Strategic Air Command fly inter-continental bombers capable of reaching half of the critical targets on earth.

LONDON, July 3 -- Continuation of the basic difference between the United States and Britain on an approach to Communist China and the Soviet Union was bared today by Selwyn Lloyd, Minister of State in the Foreign Office.

IN 1938 Vanguard Press brought out Theodore McClintock's "The Underwater Zoo," a diary account of the creatures that flourished in a bowl of water brought for observation from the Fenway in Boston to the author's apartment.

CLEVELAND, Sunday, July 4 -- Hank Majeski pinch singled two runs home in the fifteenth inning early today to give the Cleveland Indians a 5-4 victory over the Chicago White Sox and safeguard the Tribe's four and a half game lead over the second-place New York Yankees.

The question of academic freedom was the dominant theme of the National Education Association's ninety-second annual convention here last week. In various sessions and panel discussions, as well as through reports and resolutions, the nation's educational leaders strongly urged that the public school teachers be accorded rights of "first-class citizens."

MYRTLE BEACH, S. C. To the New Yorker seeking the sun, the near South offers two seashore resorts of real merit, Virginia Beach in the Old Dominion and Myrtle Beach in South Carolina. Geographically they are easily accessible to the metropolitan motorist.
MEXICO CITY, July 3 -- The United Fruit Company is a business empire with total assets of $579,342,000 -- one of the largest American companies in foreign operations.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 3 -- The Marine Corps League, Department of New Jersey, today urged the United States to withdraw from the United Nations if Red China is admitted.

A couple whose infant son was found dead and whose 18-month-old daughter was found suffering from hunger and thirst in their apartment on Friday were arrested yesterday. On the order of the District Attorney's office, the mother was booked early today on a charge of homicide.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- The rising trend of unemployment in Philadelphia continues. Data collected by the Pennsylvania State Employment Service in mid-May showed employment at an estimated 1,600,600, representing a drop of 10,000 from the level of two months ago.

A STRANGE and wonderful world of color and shapes is suggested in the exhibition of playground sculpture which has opened at the Museum of Modern Art, consisting of some of the results of a competition sponsored by the Museum of Modern Art, Parents Magazine and Creative Playthings Inc.

PORTSMOUTH, N. H., July 3 -- Following a luncheon at the Wentworth by - the - Sea, New Castle, the formal ceremony took place at the site of the new $46,000,000 base. State Representative John E. Holden of Newington presided and invocation was by the Rev. John N. Feaster, DD., of the North Congregational Church.

The information desk and main reading room at the Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street building of the New York Public Library will be open as usual today and tomorrow. Central circulation will be open from 2 to 6 P. M. today but will be closed tomorrow, together with all divisions and neighborhood branches in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 3 -- The Suspension of Prof. Lloyd Reynolds from the summer session staff at Reed College has provided a focus for the fight between the faculty and the college's president, Dr. Duncan S. Ballantine.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 3 -- Ambassador James Scott Kemper, in a speech today, urged on United States residents here the importance of defending the freedoms set forth as "self-evident" truths in the Declaration of Independence.

" ROUTINE fear" on the part of major studios to tackle "unconventional" and/or "controversial" stories, especially when they have not previously demonstrated acceptability in other media, is a contributing factor to the production slowdown in Hollywood.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 3 (UP) -- Ray H. Jenkins, who gained national prominence as the counsel of the Senate subcommittee that investigated the Army-McCarthy dispute, announced today that he would not run for the Senate.

The soft coal industry faces a drastic readjustment if it is to operate profitably. According to executives in the industry, this would involve the elimination of hundreds of higher-cost operating units and mergers of the lowercost companies into a very few organizations.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 3 -- Ken Welles Pudge surprised with its first victory of the Yacht Racing Association championship season at Indian Harbor Yacht Club today, leading Mills Husted's Rumour II and nine other Luders-16's in the seventh race of the title term. Husted was nearly a full seven minutes astern.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Investments in industrial development projects in the Chicago area totaled $133,264,000 in the first half of 1954, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. This included investment in new plants, expansion of existing facilities and acquisition of land and buildings for industrial purposes.

LYONS, France, Sunday, July 4 (Reuters) -- Twenty bodies were removed by early today from the wreckage of a four-car Diesel train that collided head-on with a shunting locomotive at Chateaubourg [cross on map] last night.

A new paint for the latest jet fighters and bombers which will not peel off in flight near the speed of sound has been developed by a British company. The paint, already tested on the tail of the latest R. A. F. operational aircraft, will soon be used full-scale on a jet plane.

THE great tomb hewn for Ramesses VI in the cliffs of western Thebes has had a long and eventful history. Originally constructed for Ramesses V around the middle of the twelfth century B. C., it was usurped by Ramesses VI under circumstances we can only suspect.

DETROIT, July 3 (UP) -- Dick Mayer of St. Petersburgh, Fla., shot a par 71 over the rain-drenched Meadowbrook Country Club course today to take a one-stroke lead at the three-quarter mark of the 72-hole Motor City open golf tournament.

HANOI, Vietnam, July 3 -- Phuly, formerly a key point on Hanoi's main line of communications with the lower Red River delta, was evacuated by French Union forces today. The withdrawal was preceded by two sharp encounters with the Communist-led Vietminh insurgents.

In connection with John D. Hillaby's "Cheops, a 'God on Earth,' Lived to Die" (June 6), it may be of interest to point out that funerary ships like those of Cheops, or at least their pictorial representations, appear also in ancient Palestinian tombs.

THERE is one place in Washington, perhaps above all others, that is good to come to in a time of stress and doubt. It is not the Capitol, nor the public rooms of the White House, nor even the Lincoln Memorial, though it comes closer to inspiring the reverence that the Memorial enforces upon all of us.

GENEVA, July 3 -- Authoritative French sources said today that in the event of a partition of Vietnam the Mendes-France Government would insist on the Eighteenth Parallel, north of Hue, as the dividing line.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 3 -- The Rev. Bob Richards, Olympic champion from the Los Angeles Athletic Club, brought his two-day stand in the National A.A.U. decathlon championship to a rousing finish this afternoon when he accounted for a decathlon world record of 15 feet in the pole vault.

UNITED NATIONS -- Workshop The fourth annual United Nations Institute and Workshop, sponsored by Montclair (N. J.) State Teachers College, will take place July 12-24. All aspects of the United Nations will be covered by leading U. N. staff members. Several field trips to U. N. headquarters are planned as part of the program.
The North Atlantic's passenger-carrying greyhounds are churning to another banner travel year.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 3 -- Iranian and international oil company negotiators were reported today to be within three words of agreement on a new pattern of management for the long stalled Iranian oil industry.

The Department of Correction is interested in taking over the detention station on Ellis Island, it was learned yesterday. The station is now operated by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which may abandon it.

DALLAS, July 3 -- Southwestern department store business maintained a steady pace through May and the first half of June, about 6 per cent behind the same period last year, and inventories were about 8 per cent behind, the Federal Reserve Bank reported in its monthly business summary.

NOW that summer is here the animals and humans are flocking to the shore. For some, as it is for Little Teddy Bear, this will be a first experience. Wisely, Mr. Bear gives Teddy a proper introduction to the force and pleasure that the sea can offer.

ABRAHAM CRONBACH grapples in this book with a number of basic questions asked by Jewish youth about religion in general and Judaism in particular. For those who are both scientifically and spiritually motivated, he tries to meet these questions by drawing on the religious philosophy of Judaism and on other sources such as humanism, ethics and the teachings of psychoanalysis.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 3 (AP) -- In one sense, Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer is returning to the ivory tower from which he was shaken loose twelve years ago to direct the making of history's first atomic bomb.

A SIZZLING summer day holds few finer refreshments than a great chunk of cold watermelon, spilling with juice from the crisp, red flesh. A giant watermelon of fifty pounds or so, deliciously ripe, is something to bury in ice, perhaps in an old-fashioned wash tub, and then forget till it has acquired a chill.
PORTSMOUTH, N. H., July 3 (UP) -- Senator Styles Bridges said today that the nation's strategic air arm was "fully capable" of delivering atomic age destruction on enemy targets.
COLORADO SPRINGS, July 3 -- The National Council of Juvenile Court Judges today urged legislation at local, state and national levels to outlaw "horror comics."

THE average gardener usually thinks of wild flowers solely as residents of the woodlands or fields or of so-called "wild gardens." But today's cultivated gardens actually owe a sizable debt to the wild flowers and native shrubs of the Eastern woods.
Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Army Chief of Staff, said here yesterday that the danger of war was not "immediately upon us," and that peace with honor was possible.

Kenneth H. Redmond, president of the United Fruit Company, charged yesterday that the Government was seeking to penalize his concern for complying with the Government's own appeal to aid underdeveloped countries.

EVERY time a trans-Atlantic liner pulls away from the pier these busy peak-season days, it means that in addition to the passengers some 4,000 to 8,000 pieces of luggage have been safely stowed aboard.

The announcement by the Soviet Council of Ministers that Russia is operating an atomic power plant with an output of 5,000 kilowatts of electricity means much less than many have inferred from the dispatches. A station of 5,000-kilowatt electric output is uneconomical.
The grip of communism appeared to be closing fast on Indochina last week. After eight years of bloody fighting, the war seemed to be drawing to a close in victory for the Communists.
Deaths from highway accidents, drownings and miscellaneous mishaps yesterday started the three-day Independence Day holiday on a somber note.

WHAT part has tourist-class travel played in maintaining the uninterrupted growth of passenger traffic carried by the world's airlines ? Apparently its effect has been substantial, although a report by the International Civil Aviation Organization points out that the exact extent is uncertain.

JUDGING by "The Caine Mutiny," and Van Johnson himself, Hollywood's perennial lad next door is ready for sterner stuff. At any rate, his highly acclaimed performance as Lieut. Maryk marks the turning point of a career launched and generally dogged ever since by freckle-faced boyishness.
