KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 3 (UP) -- Former President Truman was given permission to leave his hospital bed today and he promptly pushed a chair up to a table, sat down and ate a hearty lunch.
The guaranteed annual wage, most publicized of labor's unrealized goals, is virtually dead for 1954.
PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- Bob Milliken, the almost forgotten man of the Brooklyn bullpen, today pitched four and two-third innings of hitless relief ball to preserve a one-run lead.

FROM Paul Revere's ride in 1775 to the comeback of a down-and-out jockey on Derby Day in 1951, Louis Wolfe recalls many exciting stories of the part men on horseback have played in the American past. Here are John Phillips' epic ride to save a garrison from the Sioux; General Washington at the Battle of Princeton, and the race of 100,000 homesteaders to claim free land in the Oklahoma Territory.
Diamond sales have been slow this year. The industry puts the decline from last year at 10 per cent and blames generally slow business conditions during the first five months of the year.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 -- Three faculty members at the University of California Medical Center, two of them world figures in medical science, retired this week.
This is the season of job-hunting for most college graduates, or, for those in the upper fractions of their classes, the season of having jobs handed to them.

" THE reading of the 'Divine Comedy' has no end," Francis Fergusson reminds us on the threshold of his book. The late Michele Barbi, who was Italy's foremost Dante scholar, devoted a lifetime to this task. In 1921, on the sixth centenary of the poet's death, he published a critical edition of the "Commedia."
MEXICO CITY, June 30 -- A continuing crisis of confidence stemming from the devaluation of the peso two-and-a-half months ago is causing the Mexican Government considerable concern.

GUATEMALA, July 3 -- Two strong men in the new Guatemalan military junta, and the two who undoubtedly will have an eventual struggle for supreme power, are Colonels Carlos Castillo Armas and Elfego Monzon.

The effects of the Independence Day holiday week-end were felt by retailers toward the close of the week as shopping fell off from last year. This decline was attributed to the fact that more people are planning to leave the city on this year's three-day week-end than last year, when July 4 fell on a Saturday.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 3 -- Fault Free, a colt that had never von a stakes, scored one of the major upsets of the year today in capturing the $55,900 Westerner at Hollywood Park in which Determine, winner of the Kentucky Derby, finished third.

HAMLET, that actor's Everest, is luring the redoubtable talents of Judith Anderson. Our properly awed coastal courier reports, following a visit to the lady's hilltop home outside of Santa Barbara, that Miss Anderson is industriously orating the Dane's unhappy lines, hoping that the winter will see her Broadway-bound.

Manhattan is becoming "one vast slum with oases of luxury apartments for the very wealthy" partly because of Robert Moses' opposition to master planning, according to Prof. Talbot F. Hamlin of Columbia University.

GENEVA, July 3 -- Despite the failure of the Geneva conference to reach an agreement on Korea, it is now obvious that the question of seating Communist China's representatives in the United Nations can no longer be postponed. This is certain to be one of the most hotly debated issues when the 1954 session of the General Assembly meets in September.

SOME time before the end of summer, the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania expects to open a new bypass around one of its most aggravating highway bottlenecks. The bottleneck is the section of U. S. 22 that runs through Easton, Bethlehem and Allentown.

SEVEN HUNDRED FIFTY years ago, about the time England's Richard the Lion-Hearted was slaying Saracens, another and far more successful royal butcher was scourging Central Asia. To his fierce Mongol followers he was known as Temujine, Khan of the Northern Steppes.

EDWARD MACDOWELL, who on account of the immense popularity of one work appears destined to a place in musical history somewhere between Mrs. Crosby Adams and Carrie Jacobs Bond, wrote a number of things worthy of a different fate.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 3 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower viewed with admiration today a century-old fireplace given to them as a thirty-eighth wedding anniversary present.

HARTFORD, July 3 -- Connecticut Republicans will open their two-day state convention here Thursday night. Gov. John Davis Lodge is the apparent unanimous choice of the 630 delegates for renomination to a second four-year term.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UP) -- Representative Daniel A. Reed, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today there would be no tax revision bill this year unless a House provision for liberal treatment of dividend income was adopted.

PITTSBURGH, July 3 -- The Giants committed one of baseball's cardinal sins today. They paid more attention to the scoreboard than to what was going on about them on the ball field. As a consequence they lost out all around.
The Garden City Hotel had a dining room full of leading bankers on the night of Jude 17. They were gathered to honor Adam Schneider Jr. with a testimonial dinner.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee plans to broaden its inquiry into nation-wide housing scandals. Senator Homer E. Capehart, committee chairman, said today that the group would open a broad attack on "smelly, rotten deals" in several major cities.
KANSAS CITY, July 3 -- An avalanche of letters and telegrams descended this week upon this city to remind a man that a nation had not forgotten him.
THE most discussed novelty of the spring festival season has been the revival here of Leos Janacek's opera, "Aus einem Totenhaus."

The man considered the chief architect of the hydrogen bomb has made clear that Russia not only came closer than was realized to outdistancing the United States in developing the super-weapon, but still could push ahead in improving it.
THE tempestuous film which Stanley Kramer has produced from Herman Wouk's "The Caine Mutiny" will probably prove one of the most favored and most debated motion pictures of the year.

PUBLICATION of "A History of the Southern Confederacy" marks the debut of a distinguished newcomer among historians of the "Lost Cause." Clement Eaton, Professor of History at the University of Kentucky, is author of "Freedom of Thought in the Old South" and "A History of the Old South."
HACKENSACK, N. J., July 3 -- Eddie Moylan of Trenton and Jerry DeWitts of Oakland, Calif., reached the final round of the Eastern clay court tennis championship at the Oritani Field Club today.

BACK in 1884, there appeared in The New York Times an editorial on the comparatively new fad of cigarette smoking that concluded: "The decadence of Spain began when the Spaniards adopted cigarettes, and if this pernicious practice obtains among adult Americans, the ruin of the Republic is close at hand."
A NEW 4c airmail stamp will be issued at Philadelphia on Sept. 3 during the thirty-first annual convention and exhibition of the American Air Mail Society.

BONN, Germany, July 3 -- With the signature of the European Defense Community treaty more than two years old and no prospect of French ratification yet in sight, West Germany is going through its own "agonizing reappraisal."
BOSTON, July 3 (UP) -- Alex Kellner pitched a seven-hitter against the Boston Red Sox today to pace the Philadelphia Athletics to a 7-3 triumph before a ladies' day crowd of 7,859 at Fenway Park.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 3 -- Scenes of jubilation surrounded the Russians after each victory in the Henley Royal Regatta today.

ONE seldom reads a story about people in a faraway land so appealing as "Tosie of the Far North." Little Tosie-apik (small boy) is real and understandable in his need to prove himself a man and worthy of his real name of Davidee.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- They have met before -- the President and the British Prime Minister -- and they have differed before, as importantly as they differed last week-end. On both occasions Dwight D. Eisenhower has prevailed: In 1945 as Supreme Commander in Chief of the Allied Forces in Europe. In 1954 as the Chief Executive of the United States.

Electrically speaking, the United States moved forward to the point where it now turns out nearly 45 per cent of all electricity generated throughout the world. This is based on estimates for the twelve months ended June 30.

IT was the fashion a generation ago to learn to play some musical instrument, usually the piano. Today lessons in painting have taken the place of lessons in music. Muted are those endless scales that at certain hours made life for all but the performer, and sometimes for him as well, unbearable.
SOMERSET, Pa., July 3 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that the American people could be sure the Government would oppose the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

A DISTINCTIVE style is rare in photography. The lack of it is particularly noticeable among the younger photographers today, many of whom appear to be more concerned with kinds of material -- which incidentally are treated with little variation in approach -- than in developing an individual manner.
SAN SALVADOR, July 3 -- An important political incident went unnoticed to all but a few persons at the airport here today when Colonels Castillo Armas and Monzon left for Guatemala.

DALLAS, Tex., July 3 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People called on the Federal Administration today to support nationalist movements among colonial peoples "because independence is the best answer to Communist intrigue."
The French retirement last week to a shorter defense line in the Red River delta area of Indochina merely represents confirmation of decisions previously made.
One hot Sunday morning last month, this writer, then in a Southern city for a medical school commencement, took a short cut to a meeting room through the back door of the local hospital.

DR. FRANK C. BAXTER, Professor of English Literature at the University of Southern California, whose "Shakespeare on TV" program is now seen by kinescope recording on Saturday afternoon over WCBS-TV, will undertake a new discussion series described as "an exploration of the world's literary heritage."

THE United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) is an international agency dedicated to serving needy children everywhere in the world. Danny Kaye is an international institution who loves children and is, in turn, loved by them. He is now traveling at his own expense to help UNICEF make a documentary film of its activities in Africa and Asia.
SEOUL, Korea, July 3 -- A serious setback for President Syngman Rhee and his Liberal party was seen here in the National Assembly's denial of a vote of confidence for the new Cabinet.
From its humble beginnings in a New England blacksmith shop more than a century ago, the industrial fastener industry in the United States has grown into a $500,000,000-a-year business.

TURKEY'S first good-will ship to the United States is scheduled to arrive in New York on July 19 for a six-day visit. En route it will stop at other American ports: Miami, July 7-9; Charleston, July 11-12; Baltimore, July 14-18.
BONN, Germany, July 3 -- The threat of unlimited German rearmament suggested yesterday by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has put a heavy strain on French-German relations.

HACKENSACK, N. J., July 3 -- After more than three years of supervision and investigation, in which racketeers like Joe Adonis, Frank Erickson, and Sollie Moretti were sent to jail, the State of New Jersey has turned the job of law enforcement in Bergen County back to the local authorities.

AS wars become more intricate, the job of recording their details becomes more exacting. Capt. Russell A. Gugeler, in this account of the Korean War, has been most painstaking -- and his book achieves the subtle, cumulative impact of a powerful documentary.

AS an epigraph for his latest novel John Bingham has chosen a quatrain by Hilaire Belloc: "Weigh human actions carefully. Explain/The worst of them with charity. Mayhap/There were two sides to that affair of Cain -- /And Judas was a tolerable chap."

A sad and romantic eight-line farewell that may well have been the last written words of Thomas Jefferson before he died July 4, 1826, has just been purchased from a Virginia owner by John Fleming, a rare book dealer of 322 East Fifty-seventh Street.

In the passing on June 22 of Karl Taylor Compton, chairman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the world lost one of its greatest scientists, educators and public servants. It is tragic that he was taken at such a relatively early age, just at a time when his wise and kindly counsel is so sorely needed.

PARIS, July 3 -- The three greatest powers have all pledged themselves to peaceful coexistence, but the world, from Vietnam to Guatemala, remains as nervous as ever and the most costly arms race in history continues.

The pace of a Congressional session follows a traditional rhythm. The Congress convenes on Jan. 3 and proceeds slowly and leisurely through the early stages. Presidential messages are sent up and read. Legislation is introduced and referred to committees. The lawmakers' hopper is full but very few new laws come out.

IN the wonderful world of books our friend and neighbor. England, seems to be a bit of a laggard. Recently we reported the archaic struggle raging between publishers and authors over subsidiary rights. Now, with pending trials of publishers charged with carrying obscene books, the press has gotten flooded with letters over the question of obscenity, or to put it in Elizabethan, whether "to ban or not to ban."
A young man who gave spurious checks to tradesmen along with the traditional gift of a new father -- cigars -- was captured after a chase in Brooklyn early yesterday.

Vassar College opened its annual Summer Institute for Family and Community Living last week. Family groups, teachers, professional specialists and volunteer community workers will spend the next four weeks in seminars, workshops and play on the 950-acre campus on the Hudson River.

SOUTHPORT, England, July 3 (AP) -- Jimmy Demaret and Jim Turnesa, a pair of United States Ryder Cup team players, head a nine-man invasion from the United States in the five-day British open golf tournament which begins Monday.

FOUR more additions to the museum without walls -- or, as Malraux might have called it, the museum between covers -- have recently made their appearance. One of these is a particularly outstanding addition, the volume on Japanese color prints by J. Hillier who is both critic and collector.
The ice cream cone, a traditional part of the Fourth of July celebration, is having its fiftieth birthday this summer.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 3 -- High Voltage of the Wheatley Stable gave a sparkling performance to speed to victory in the $28,950 Colleen Stakes at Monmouth Park today. With the competent Eddie Arcaro guiding her, the daughter of Ambrosia closed fast to gain the victory by a neck in the test of five furlongs and a half.

May I, as I'm sure others have done, call your attention to a conspicuous error in your picture feature "The 'Old Friend' Visits Again" (June 20), concerning Sir Winston Churchill's trip to Washington. The caption on the photograph contains the date March, 1946, and shows Mr. Churchill with President Truman at Fulton, Mo. Further on is another picture of the two in January, 1952, at Washington.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 22 -- Iraq has everything she needs to recreate the Garden of Eden and she is trying to do that on a tremendous scale, guided by Western technology and financed by oil royalties.

ROME, July 3 -- Italy this week turned a page of her political history. It is the same book, telling much the same story, but new characters are coming into the plot and future developments are going to be complicated and perhaps hazardous.

GENEVA, July 3 -- Viewed in the light of the Geneva conference developments, the Churchill-Eden visit to Washington does not appear to have altered materially the outlook for Indochina and Southeast Asia established after the conference opened.

HOBOKEN, July 3 -- A 14-inch-high bronze eagle sailed today aboard the Holland-America Line's motor vessel Westerdam in the custody of Maj. Benjamin H. Namm. It is the gift of the Society of Old Brooklynites to the Dutch town of Breukelen, for which the New York City borough was named.
TOKYO, July 3 -- Considerable anxiety was expressed here today over the French defeat in Indochina's Red River delta.

HAMBURG, Germany, July 3 (AP) -- West Germany's line shipping service, wiped out by World War II bombs and postwar reparations, is now back on the high seas with regular service to seventy-four countries in all parts of the world.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 3 -- Thirty-one political parties and organizations, including the leading governmental Nationalist party and its Communist supporters, urged the Indonesian Government today to declare the presence of the Dutch High Commissioner, Count van Bylandt, undesirable for his recent remarks on Indonesia.
Two cygnets, only four days old, were stolen from the nest, under the beaks of their father and mother, on Friday evening at the Bronx Zoo, it was reported yesterday.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 3 (UP) -- Maureen Connolly said today she expected to be married long before next year's Wimbledon tournament.
To Harold Callender's excellent "French Premier With a Deadline" (June 27) may I add the following facts about Mendes-France:

Nobody said it would be easy to apply in the schools of the South the principles of the recent decision of the Supreme Court of the United States rejecting racial segregation in the schools. Southern schools have been progressing toward the separate but equal system of education, but there are admittedly all sorts of practical and psychological difficulties in ending separation altogether.

From the time of American Military Government until the present many American and United Nations officials have publicly stated that the free world, as well as the United States, must make South Korea a prosperous "show-window of democracy." And we Koreans are grateful both to the U. N. and the United States for what we have received from them so far.

Ernest Charlton, chief steward of the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth, is nearing home and the end of a forty-six-year career at sea, entrusted with the care of a valuable "cargo" that has become a routine matter with him.

AWARE of the great stream of casual summer visitors, two institutions last week opened amusing shows of prints with basic popular appeal of themes the first consideration rather than purely esthetic considerations.

IF you want to hear jazz performances that have an intimacy and subtlety worthy of chamber music, listen to Oscar Peterson at the piano with the electric guitarist and bass player who make up his trio. This is jazz playing that does not overwhelm with its animal vigor or clamorous outbursts; it depends on lightness of manner, contrasts in harmony and color and a kind of lively good taste.

VINCENT BARBI may not be handsome, but his face is his fortune all the same. The ex-pug, who had appeared on almost 400 TV programs at a recent counting, is sick and tired of brushing off well-meant suggestions to undergo plastic surgery on his battered face.
DENVER, July 3 (AP) -- James G. Patton, president of the National Farmers Union, said today that Ezra Taft Benson should resign as Secretary of Agriculture.

THE Guatemalan crisis is an event of prime importance. It foreshadows for the first time Asiatic-type operations conducted by Communists in the New World. Also it brings up forcibly the neglected duties of the United States toward Latin America.

The basswood will soon be in blossom; it is in fat bud now. And the bees will be gathering, so that the clumps of basswood will be loud as well as sweet, and the honeycomb will be full of some of the sweetest honey ever made.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The official "silly season" in Washington runs from the Fourth of July until Labor Day, but it's a little ahead of time this year.

The King Ranch's High Gun ran off with first money of $39,300 in the Dwyer Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. It was a thumping good horse race. There were five 3-year-olds in the mile-and-a-quarter run. High Gun, winner of the Peter Pan Handicap and Belmont Stakes in his last two starts, was the 11-to-20 favorite. He had 126 in the saddle, and he was spotting each of his opponents a dozen pounds.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The full impact of the Oppenheimer verdict on the essential teamwork between science and government cannot yet be gauged with any accuracy. Whether the United States will be safer and stronger by reason of the "blank wall" between one physicist and the official secrets he carried in his head for eleven years remains to be seen.

The outcome of the steel wage negotiations, the debate on taxes and the meetings in Washington on foreign affairs overshadowed the stock market much of last week. Wide fluctuations in a few stocks added to the confused shifts in trading, as the market started the new month on an easier note, and then quickly resumed its advance.

THANKS to their charm and versatility, herbs are winning new popularity among gardeners throughout the nation. Whether they are tucked in a tiny bed near the terrace, combined in borders, planted in old-fashioned or formal gardens with geometrical lines or kept in pots in a sunny kitchen window herbs are always a center of attention. And harvest time is here, or near, for many varieties.

IN recent years four well-known writers for young people have chosen the fabulous life of Captain John Smith as the subject of novelized biographies. Ronald Syme's portrait differs from its predecessors in being a more straightforward telling of Smith's adventures, with little attempt to manipulate material for dramatic effect.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The Eighty-third Congress, in which Republican control has been more nominal than real, is approaching the end, and when it has gone it will be hard to characterize precisely what it has done in political terms.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- This country needs to step up its production of goods and services by at least $25,000,000,000 over the next twelve months to keep the economy healthy, the National Planning Association asserted today.
Arturo Toscanini has declined the invitation of the former N. B. C. Symphony to conduct its concerts next season.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Senator Capehart has called a recess in public hearings this week, but he planned four private sessions with unidentified builders who were expected to testify publicly later.
DETROIT, July 3 (AP) -- Small auto companies with big problems have turned to mergers in their fight against the most devastating competition they have known.

Even though the President got a great deal less in the one-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act than he had originally asked for, he at least now has authority to undertake the pressing trade negotiation with Japan.

FARMINGTON, Pa., July 3 -- Greetings from President Eisenhower touched off this afternoon an Independence week-end celebration of the 200th anniversary of the Battle of Fort Necessity, now restored by the National Park Service.
Thus far the business recession has been a mild affair.

MR. FROST is an honest writer, writing from himself from his own knowledge and emotion; not simply picking up the manner which magazines are accepting at the moment, and applying it to topics in vogue. He is quite consciously and definitely putting New England rural life into verse.

BUENOS AIRES, July 3 -- The Peronista Government issued a warning order today against the striking cigarette workers. The Ministry of Labor and Social Security told the union, which has been on a slow-down strike for almost two months, that if the workers did not return Monday morning, the union would be dissolved.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- President Eisenhower, who likes to describe himself as a Kansas farm boy, put the Republican party on a political farm fire this week. He divided and conquered what had been considered the invincible bi-partisan farm bloc in Congress and, in doing so, established the November Congressional elections as the final answering ground for his farm policy.
CHIQUIMULA, Guatemala, July 3 (AP) -- An affable young rebel pilot is credited with waging a one-man air war that helped blast Guatemalan President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman out of power.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 3 -- Russian crews, slicing into the wind and rain-buffeted Thames River with red-tipped oars, rowed away with most of the honors at the Henley Royal Regatta today, but a spunky crew from Massachusetts Institute of Technology won the only final in which a United States crew was involved.
The nation-wide strike of telephone equipment installers ended yesterday when their union signed a new one-year contract with the Western Electric Company.

IN 1878 William H. Welch, a young New Englander from a doctoring family, returned to New York from Germany where he had gone to train himself for a career in medical science. He soon discovered that the opportunities for academic medicine in America were "simply horrible."

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The sudden withdrawal of French Union troops in the Red River delta region of Indochina has heightened official concern here over future relations between France and Communist China.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 3 -- Kurt Grandpierre, with the Luders-16 Pierrette, and Fred Hibberd Jr., with the Lightning, Flash, kept their perfect records in Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound sailing intact today.

ON July 15 James Mason will appear in Yeats' version of Sophocles' "Oedipus Rex" at the Stratford Shakespeare festival. The performance will be directed by Tyrone Guthrie, the artistic leader of this summer enterprise.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 3 (AP) -- Poplar Perry, a 7-year-old bay gelding owned by A. J. Schrader of Scranton, Pa., and driven by George Phalen, won the $6,500 Wantagh free-for-all trot on the Grand Circuit card at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. A half length back was the odds-on favorite, Katie Key.

The nation's first county-wide overnight check-clearing bureau celebrated its first birthday last week. Swamped by a mounting flood of checks, arising from the area's vast population growth and increased industrial activity, Long Island's Nassau County banks on July 1, 1953, set up the new system.
JERUSALEM, Jordanian Sector, July 3 -- Jordan's Arab Legion braced itself tonight against the possibility of an Israeli attempt to seize the Arab part of Jerusalem.

The first Communist-infiltrated Government in the Western Hemisphere was ousted last week. In the wake of a twelve-day revolution, an anti-Communist junta took over the reins in Guatemala, clamped down on the extreme Leftists and forced the man who had encouraged them -- former President Jacobo Arbenz -- into hiding.

NORTH BAY, Ont. -- Magnificent fishing and hunting grounds lie readily accessible along the 700-odd miles of Highway 11 between North Bay, less than a day's run along the Queen Elizabeth Highway from Niagara Falls, and Fort William at the northern head of Lake Superior.
GUATEMALA, July 3 -- Col. Carlos Castillo Armas came home today.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- A new investigation of alleged Communist infiltration of the Army, this time dealing with efforts to indoctrinate G. I.'s in World War II, was announced today by the Senate Internal Security subcommittee.
The annual award of three graduate scholarships in marine engineering and naval architecture was announced here last week by the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers.

BLOWING soap bubbles and watching the family fights that take place between and within the transparent globules has become a respectably scientific method of obtaining data that will eventually build sturdier motor vehicles.

The great question that ran through the Big Two conversations in Washington last week -- Sir Winston said it "goes really to the heart of the matter in current public political life" -- was this: Can the free and the Communist worlds peacefully coexist?
The permanent shutdown of the Yonkers, N. Y., mill of Alexander Smith, Inc. does not spell doom either for the company or for the carpet industry.

A research team at Oberlin College (Ohio) has begun a study of preparation for medical education in a liberal arts college, aided by a grant from the Commonwealth Fund of New York. While medical schools are encouraging prospective students to gain a liberal educational background, little is known about the progress in medical schools of students with such backgrounds as compared with students whose undergraduate programs have been heavily weighted with premedical courses.

Nicolo Rizzi, president of the Swiss-owned Arosa Line, said here last week that the company, a relative newcomer to trans-Atlantic passenger shipping, now has expansion plans including the acquisition of a third passenger liner next year.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 3 (AP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson said here today that statements such as that of Senator William F. Knowland, Republican of California, on taking the United States out of the United Nations if Communist China gets in are "foolish and dangerous."

IT has been a matter of convenience and safety for nearly everyone to adopt the "strong" no trump. That is what it is called now, though twenty-odd years ago, when the "powerhouse" no trump had a vogue, it would not have seemed so strong.

STANTON, Del., July 3 (AP) Ogden Phipps' homebred colt, Bassanio, found the mile and a quarter distance of Delaware Park's $29,550 Sussex Handicap to his liking today and raced to a surprise victory over Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney's Cold Command, the favorite.

THE United States marched into the arena of this year's Berlin Festival with twelve motion pictures, five of them in CinemaScope. When the many honors were passed around this week, Hollywood only walked off with one of them.
Mars is now about 40,000,000 miles away, a close approach as astronomical distances go, yet not the closest possible. Next year Mars will be only 35,000,000 miles distant.

It is somewhat surprising to learn from Commissioner Lee of the Federal Communications Commission that after two years there have been no applications filed for 81.8 per cent of the television channels set aside for educational use. At this rate these channels will not be fully utilized for fifty years.

AT the age of 59, which he reached ten days ago in a state of at least comparative grace, the highly definable aura of the champion still curls about William Harrison (Jack) Dempsey like a sort of shimmering effluvium, attracting middle-aged hero worshipers ostensibly seeking autographs for their small nephews and young people who have been told to go and look upon a monument.

LONDON, July 3 -- "Tomorrow is American Independence Day," Gerald Nabarro, a Conservative Member of Parliament, said at a political rally in Worcestershire today. "Today is British independence day -- food freedom day."
Re: "Some Fathers Not to Envy" (June 20):

IF the depression hadn't forced young Gus Turner to quit school he might never have questioned the caste system of his home country, the Mississippi Delta. As long as he could remember, people in the Delta were sharply set aside from one another.

THEY ran the Dwyer Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday and that automatically started a bell tinkling down Memory Lane. It was the recollection of another and far more famous Dwyer Stakes, the one that produced the finest competitive effort that Man o' War ever made. It was the race in which Big Red "broke the heart of John P. Grier."
Never in my life have I written to a newspaper, but I cannot help but address this to you.

The Catholic Youth Organization of the Archdiocese of New York, 122 East Twenty-second Street, has appealed to former benefactors for funds to send poor boys and girls to its two summer camps. The camps, one for boys and one for girls, are in Putnam County, seven miles from Peekskill, N. Y.

A GRADUALLY increasing store of Indian relics, in a cave in the Alabama Appalachians, was the secret shared by 10-year-old Davy Cobb and his grandfather. But when heavy rains unearthed a mysterious skeleton, Davy's mother made him promise not to visit the cave alone.

ALTHOUGH the last three decades have been called the Age of Criticism, the memorable essay in literary criticism is extremely rare. A few good essays may be found in critical anthologies, but these books are usually composed for college students and not for the mature minds of intelligent readers.

THE 1954 Berkshire Festiva given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Charles Munch conductor, at Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass., will also be the twentieth anniversary of the founding of the Berkshire Symphonic Festival in 1934.

" We hold these truths to be self-evident. . . ." So said the Declaration of Independence, but the truths proclaimed in these words were by no means self-evident when they were written. They merely signaled the determination of the brave men who wrote them to make them ring clear in a new land dedicated to freedom -- a determination that spelt six years of war, anxiety, misery and near-defeat.
Showmanship and the old-time medicine man have long been identified with American business. Today, however, its development is as spectacular as the growth of American industry itself.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UP) -- Senator J. William Fulbright asserted today that Vice President Richard M. Nixon's current attacks on the Democrats are an attempt to cover up "bankruptcy of leadership" in the Republican party." The Arkansas Democrat said they also showed the Republican party's "complete bankruptcy of ideas" on foreign policy.

In a year when fiftieth anniversaries are breaking out like a rash, the New York Athletic Club has joined the parade. Its Block Island Race this week is a "Fiftieth Anniversary" event, like the American Power Boat Association's first half-century observance this year, and like the fiftieth anniversary of the Gold Cup Race and the golden jubilee of the National Motor Boat Show last winter.

Sandy Saddler of New York, world featherweight champion who suffered a reverse by Hocine Khalfi in his last appearance in the arena, hopes to return to the victory column when he meets Libby Manzo of Elmhurst, L. I., at the St. Nicholas Arena tomorrow night.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 3 -- President Eisenhower has endorsed the objectives of the Rockefeller public service awards, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, announced today with the opening of the third year's competition.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- Two similar triumphs were scored in Arlington Park's feature races today as Blue Violin defeated Roman Warbler in the $27,650 Cleopatra Handicap and Duc de Fer won the $22,225 Myrtlewood Handicap at 7 -- 1.

SALEM, N. H., July 3 (UP) -- The Palatine Stable's Royal Indian, with Keith Stuart up, sped to a length triumph over H. W. Patrick's Day's Duke in the $5,000 Juvenile Handicap at Rockingham Park today before a crowd of 15,290.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 3 -- Retail trade showed a marked improvement in the closing week of June and in the first few days of July as the rush for summer goods continued. A heat wave over the entire district produced urgent buying of air-conditioning units, fans and lightweight clothing.

PARIS, July 3 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France declared in a nation-wide broadcast tonight that French evacuation of the southern Tonkin delta had been undertaken to strengthen France's military and diplomatic position in the Indochina war.

THE National Broadcasting Company, which of late years has not been exactly noted for the vigor of its commentary on the air, seems bent on making amends with two new television programs well worth a viewer's attention.

VERY likely one of the most comforting aspects of this novel by Will Oursler, a mystery-story writer, co-author with his father (the late Fulton Oursler) of a biography of Father Flanagan of Boys Town and, with Laurence Dwight Smith, of a narcotics expose, is that it deals uncompromisingly with the completely expected.

YOU might call this intense and disturbing story a Martha's Vineyard version of "Rain." Snows driven by screaming sea winds engulf the Vineyard folk, imprisoning them in dark thoughts and shadowy desires as impassable as the drifts on moor and hill.

PEABODY, Mass., July 3 -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias completed her comeback bid by winning the United States women's open golf championship today. Over the Salem Country Club course the famed woman all-around athlete, who underwent an operation for cancer in the spring of 1953, regained the title she held in 1948 and 1950 with a seventy-two-hole score of 291.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 3 (AP) -- The evacuation of Phuly was preceded by withdrawals yesterday from two small posts six miles southeast. They were Binhyen and Point 73, each normally manned by between 100 and 150 men.
One of America's most unusual industrial processes in generating electric power has just been placed in operation at Holtwood, Pa., on the Susquehanna River.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., July 3 -- The 7,000 members of the Forty-second (Rainbow) Infantry Division of the National Guard marched in review at near-by Camp Drum today.

READERS of "Adirondack Country" who are not aware that the author lives close to the friendly, low, tree-covered mountains he describes will nevertheless have the secure feeling that this man knows what he is talking about. "Talking," moreover, is what these chapters seem to be.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- A review of differences between the United States and Britain on control of strategic exports to the Soviet bloc began here this afternoon.

ALTHOUGH "The High and the Mighty" has gotten off the ground, so to speak, Robert Fellows, co-producer with John Wayne of that flying number, still has things aeronautical on his mind. Mr. Fellows, here last week in conjunction with the premiere of the picture, revealed that "the company expects to conclude a deal to do the biography of the late Brig. Gen. Billy Mitchell."

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- The annual poll for the All-Star baseball game, at Cleveland July 13, neared its end tonight. The final results, which determine American and National League starting line-ups, except for the pitchers, will be announced tomorrow night.
DETROIT, July 3 (AP) -- Lee Schoenith and his new boat, Gale V, won the eighth Detroit Memorial Regatta on the Detroit River today.

CONFIDENCE, a quality rare in the modern world, flourishes in these islands. There is an elemental, long-term optimism in the British outlook which has no counterpart among the other great peoples of the West. Like the rest of us, the British are perplexed and worried by the urgent, strident issues of our time.

Wolfgang Unzicker of West Germany won the International Chess Federation's European zone tournament held in Munich recently. He took eleven games and drew eight for a score of 15 -- 4, without losing once. Unzicker qualified for a place in next year's inter-zonal tournament along with three others, J. H. Donner, the champion of the Netherlands, and Braslav Rabar of Yugoslavia, who tied for second place, and Andrija Fuderer of Yugoslavia, who was fourth.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 3 -- The case of Guatemala has touched off one of the most searching examinations of the meaning, structure and purpose of the United Nations in its history.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 3 -- Let it be placed on the record that Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., won her third Wimbledon singles title today. In a swirling wind that raised eddies on the famous center court she defeated Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., 6 -- 2, 7 -- 5, and the manner in which she did it put her closer to her rightful niche among the tennis immortals.

Bob Wiesler, a stop-gap selection by Casey Stengel, impressively outpitched the formidable Bob Porterfield to give the Bombers a 3-2 triumph over the Senators before 20,011 spectators at the Stadium last night.

THE once-famous Gen. Joseph Orville Shelby, C. S. A., has been passed over in the great amount of recent writing about the Civil War. Yet Shelby, as Daniel O'Flaherty quickly demonstrates, was a man of unconventional zest, of flaming spirit and of considerable importance in his day.

EVERY spring thousands of flower lovers travel along the Pacific Coast to view one of the world's richest floral tapestries -- hundreds of millions of wild flowers in full bloom. This exciting scene, contributed by nature, who happens to be a full-time landscape architect, is big even in terms of global strategy. It stretches from San Diego in the south to British Columbia in the north, a distance of 1,500 miles.
There have been few net changes in the news censorship business in the last six months. Small gains have been offset by losses.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 3 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold left today for Geneva, where he will attend the sessions of the United Nations Economic and Social Council.

IT is as a story-teller of whaling that A. B. C. Whipple, one of the associate editors of Life magazine, presents himself in this book. His appeal is to the newcomer or non-expert who would like to engage upon terms of straightforward readability with some of the annals of the great pursuit without being exposed to specialized lingo and technical minutiae.

A FORMER sports writer who became a noted foreign correspondent, Eddy Gilmore has written a very personal account of his eleven years in Russia. Mr. Gilmore is a good reporter and a shrewd and folksy individual.

WITH the opening of Senate hearings on the Upper Colorado River storage project last week, Congress moved a little closer toward the critical decision on authorization of Echo Park Dam within the Dinosaur National Monument.

WALTER GIESEKING seems to be on his way toward a series of recordings for Angel that will encompass all of Debussy's piano music. One of the recent disks surveys early works; the others are devoted to a group of masterpieces.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican of Michigan, said today the early recognition of the new regime in Guatemala by the United States and other North and South American republics should be forthcoming.

THERE was a great hullabaloo in American railroad circles last week over an experimental, low - slung, streamlined train that clocked 102.8 miles an hour on the New Haven Railroad's main line between Boston and New Haven.

Matson of Pennsylvania State University uncovered near Modoc, Ill., at a depth of twenty-six feet, near the base of limestone bluffs, ancient hearths and other evidence of early man's occupation of the area.
UTRECHT, the Netherlands, July 3 -- Premier Willem Drees attacked today a Roman Catholic anti-Socialist directive that has posed the nation's foremost political issue.

MANUFACTURERS have trimmed nearly a billion dollars from their inventories in the last twelve months, but apparently the period of inventory adjustments is not yet over. The continuing contraction in stocks is one factor that will delay an upturn in business, particularly in the summer months when industrial activity normally declines.

Yet both these documents come within the normal limits of what the Declaration calls "the course of human events."

THE description on these pages last week of a portable receiver that picked up the sound channels of television stations -- but no pictures -- appears to have aroused widespread interest. The advent of "TV radio" may not be far off, it seems.

CLEVELAND, July 3 -- Monthly consumption of iron ore by furnaces in the United States and Canada is approximately 3,000,000 tons below last year's figures, but stocks are piling up in furnace yards and on Great Lakes docks. The surplus makes it virtually certain that sixty ore carriers now on the inactive list will not be pressed into service this season.

Several valuable books and pamphlets dedicated to LP and hi-fi have recently hit the market. Most ambitious is Frederic Ramsey's book, "A Guide to Longplay Jazz Records," published by Long Player Publications ($4.50). Mr. Ramsey has done a thorough, critical job.

Most workers in advertising agencies would insist they live in no ivory tower. They are people and they live, act, think and work like people. In addition, many have moved from the ranks of salesmen, production workers or other lines to the agency field.

The National Multiple Sclerosis Society, 270 Park Avenue, New York City, is looking for identical twins, male or female, in which either or both members suffer from multiple sclerosis. Object: To aid in determining the possible hereditary and environmental causes of multiple sclerosis.
Isabel Troccole of the Bronx won the Women's Eastern clay court championship yesterday for the second successive year.

Preparations were made in Washington last week for public hearings to examine the steepest section of the nation's "tariff wall" in which are nearly 440 import duty rates ranging from 50 to as high as 416 per cent.
Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and his supporters have established a timetable which they hope will clinch the Democratic nomination for Governor for him by Aug. 15.

LOS ALAMOS, N. M., July 3 -- The Los Alamos branch, Federation of American Scientists, expressed deep concern today over the possible effects of the present personnel security system on the morale of the scientific community. The group, in considering the case of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, who has been refused access to atomic secrets, recommended that three factors be recognized in a wise security policy. They provide that:

THE background of this well-written and exceedingly topical novel is Red China today. It is effective on several levels: an exciting adventure tale, a fascinating character study of people we need badly to understand in these troubled times, plus a tender and moving love story of two people in the constant shadow of death.

LILIES are easily grown, readily available from a number of reliable sources and, considering the care lavished on them by the producers, reasonably priced, yet they are still among the rarer flowers to be seen in gardens.

PARENT participation in children's summer camp activities is largely limited to an occasional Visitors' Day when mom and dad are honored guests and campsite and campers more or less "on parade." Quite a different situation existed recently at Rifton, N. Y., when parents, prospective campers and their brothers and sisters as well joined forces with Pioneer Youth Camp staff to get buildings and grounds ready for summer use.
NOTTINGHAM, England, July 3 (Reuters) -- Only the intervention of bad weather or a miracle batting feat can save Pakistan from defeat at the hands of England in the second cricket test match.

MILWAUKEE, July 3 (UP) -- Jim Greengrass, after driving in three runs with a homer, doubled and scored on a scratch single by Johnny Temple, a pinch-hitter, to give the Cincinnati Redlegs a 5-to-4 victory over the Milwaukee Braves tonight.
BALTIMORE, July 3 (UP) -- Bob Turley walked eleven Detroit batters but gave only five hits as he pitched the Baltimore Orioles to a 5-to-3 victory over the Tigers tonight.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, June 3 -- People began to move normally today about streets here that had been under gunfire for two days. No breach of the new Israeli-Jordanian ceasefire agreement has been reported since shortly after 11:30 P. M. yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, July 3 -- Small pleasure boats plying New Haven harbor and three rivers emptying into it are daily adding to highway congestion during rush hours by forcing the opening of five drawbridges, Mayor Richard C. Lee today protested to Secretary of the Army Robert T. Stevens.

IN spite of the fact that this is July, when things usually find themselves on the inert side in the local dance world, this will be a full week. The New York City Summer Dance Festival will be held in the air-conditioned auditorium of the Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., at Ninety-second Street and Lexington Avenue, nightly (except Friday) and with a matinee next Sunday.
THE off-shore big-game angling season now can be considered officially open.

AS your correspondent told you they would a year ago, dial telephones have come to this village in the Green Mountains. Mildred Perry, our Central for over thirty-one years, took the change gracefully, albeit a bit sadly.

A 36-year-old woman lawyer survived late yesterday a 130-foot leap from the pedestrian walk of the Manhattan Bridge into the waters of the East River. It appeared to be her third suicidal attempt of the day.

FROM 1932 to 1952 the Julliard Summer School was a regular feature of the city's musical life. Its annual enrollments went into the hundreds and most of its students were teachers coming to New York to take refresher courses during their vacations.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Wind and rain make staking advisable. It will be less conspicuous if done before plants are full grown. Supports of wood or metal in various styles and lengths are chosen to suit the spirelike delphinium, a clump of platycodon or a row of cosmos or gladiolus. Use raffia for tying.

ROCHESTER -- Preparations are well under way in this photography-conscious city for the celebration on July 12 of George Eastman Day, honoring the 100th anniversary of the birth of George Eastman. To mark the birthday centennial of the "father of modern photography," special events and exhibits have been planned by a variety of civic and business institutions in the city.

Special-priced promotions are planned by many retailers after this holiday week-end, resident buying offices report. Most stores, looking at June sales figures, have grown more optimistic about the possibilities for both summer and fall business.

ON the Fourth of July every year, Americans do more than celebrate the beginnings of their Republic; they honor a charter, the Declaration of Independence, which has come to be invested with the sanctity that once hedged about a king. But this sacred charter was originally a human document, prepared and adopted by living men.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Senator Milton R. Young said today that the 228 to 170 vote in the House of Representatives for a flexible farm price support program "is bound to hurt the Republicans in farm states."

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 3 -- Precautions to prevent incidents at the Burmese frontier resulting from the fighting between Chinese Nationalist guerrillas and the Burmese Army at Monghang have been ordered, a Government spokesman said today.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 3 -- Gov. Robert Crosby appointed today Sam W. Reynolds of Omaha, a coal company executive, to fill until November the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Hugh Butler, Republican, on Thursday.

CHICAGO, July 3 (UP) -- The Chicago Cubs, who can't seem to beat any team except the St. Louis Cardinals, walloped their "cousins" again today, 4 -- 1, making it eight victories in ten games this season against the St. Louisans.

Department store executives must have a mighty accurate crystal ball. Their predictions on 1954's business pattern, made at the beginning of the year, are proving almost perfect. That's why they have a large audience when they look ahead to the last half of the year.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The United States is rushing medical supplies to Guatemala as a gesture of friendship.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Defense Department officials said tonight that they were considering halting shipments of United States military equipment to French Union forces within the Tonkin delta perimeter of northern Indochina.

PITTSBURGH, July 4 -- The decline in the steel operating rate last week (and the same trend for this week) was not considered significant here. The drop last week was due to an outlaw strike in the Detroit area and also to plant shutdowns among steel consumers.
MOSCOW, July 4 -- Pravda called on the Communist party and social organizations today to organize "a real struggle" against drunkenness.
Grain dragged the lagging charter market's over-all level down last week. The West Coast situation stood where it was "when we came in" earlier in the year.
ZURICH, Switzerland, July 4 -- Interhandel common stock changed hands here yesterday at 1780, up from 1530 the Saturday before. Brokers expect the advance to continue.
ANKARA, Turkey, July 3 -- Faced with an increasingly serious trade and payments deficit, the Turkish Government has decided to embark on a limited anti-inflationary program.

PANAMA CITY, Fla., July 4 (AP) -- Second Lieut. Stephen G. Brown was killed today when his jet training plane crashed near Green Hills, thirty-five miles north of here. He was on a training flight from the Tyndall Air Force Base. He was the son of B. Osmond Brown of Hastings on Hudson, N. Y.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 4 -- A new international pact, which seeks to advance women's political rights, will come into force on Wednesday.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals tallied five runs in the fifth inning in blanking Chicago, 7 -- 0, in the second game of a double-header today. The Cubs won the opener, 4 -- 2. The Redbirds' victory snapped a string of six losses to the Chicagoans.

DETROIT, July 4 -- This highly competitive year in the automobile industry is witnessing the upsurge of a 23-year-old business that, before December, is expected to give a 1,000 to 2,000 mile paid ride in a brand new automobile to 40,000 to 50,000 Americans.

LONDON, July 4 -- The forces of British diplomacy, past and present, are being discreetly mobilized to explain to the world, and especially to the United States, precisely what the British are talking about when they advocate increased negotiation with the Communist powers.

The maritime industry, which, since the days of Noah, has relied on the calluses of master mariners as the best way to forecast weather, has the chance to save thousands of dollars by taking a scientific approach to the matter.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., July 4 (UP) -- Douglas McKay said today that the nation's "legacy of freedom" was its bastion in an age when "bitter and partisan recrimination is the stock in trade" of those attacking American institutions and ideals.

In a report on the Mafia, in Sicily, an American correspondent writes: "The Mafia works somewhat like certain political machines in the United States." Then are given instances such as the blowing off a man's head, "justice" by private courts, revenge and vengeance of the cruelest type.

One step toward world peace "is to work as hard for mutual understanding as we do now for military defense," declared the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman in his sermon yesterday morning at Christ Church (Methodist), Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.
Prices of cotton futures moved irregularly last week. Closing prices on the New York Cotton Exchange ranged from $1 a bale higher to $1.05 lower.

The news the other day carried a story that the Navy had outfitted the U. S. S. Bergall, a veteran submarine of the Second World War, with if not all the comforts of home at least some of the attractions of the local clubhouse.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 4 -- A few isolated shots last night and this morning threatened to shatter the peace of this divided city again.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (UP) -- The National Boxing Association declined today to recognize Ezzard Charles as a "logical contender" for Rocky Marciano's heavyweight crown, although it did designate Charles the "leading challenger."
AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, July 4 (UP) -- A middle-aged San Diego (Calif.) widow collected $12,724.80 -- the biggest daily double pay-off in racing history -- today at the Agua Caliente race-track.
PARIS, July 4 -- The Congress of the Socialist party reaffirmed its opposition today to sending conscripts to Indochina.

The League for Industrial Democracy asserted yesterday that John T. Flynn's radio broadcasts presented "an utterly unbalanced picture of current problems." It requested the Federal Communications Commission to ask the Mutual Broadcasting System to allot equal time to the league or a similar group.

ARLES, France, July 4 -- Two school teachers representing the city of York, Pa., spent the 178th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence today celebrating the 2,000th anniversary of the founding of Arles.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 4 -- The men and women of the First Presbyterian Church will meet tomorrow night in their parish hall to vote upon this proposition: "When a church has the opportunity to build something great, it is not enough to settle upon a merely good design."
Has the dynamism of our economy outdated the monopolies?

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 4 (AP) -- Mrs. Doris Thorkildsen, mother of two from Newport Beach, Calif., was first to arrive here today at the end of the "powder puff" aviation derby -- an hour and forty-five minutes ahead of the second plane.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 4 -- Two University of Michigan economists took a midyear statistical look at the United States economy and found it reassuring.
Incorporation of the Spanish Institute here by a group of Americans who are admirers of Spanish culture was announced yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, July 4 -- The strike at five of this city's biggest department stores went into its eighth month last week with neither side showing any sign of capitulation.
PITTSBURGH, July 4 -- A figure out of the past rose today to smite the Giants an unexpected blow.

The Naumburg Orchestra gave the second of its four free summer concerts last night in the shell in Central Park that Elkan Naumburg presented to the city. Like the Decoration Day concert and the two still to come, the concert was the gift of Walter W. and George W. Naumburg, sons of the shell's donor.
Europeans generally are uneasy over whether the United States will come to their aid if they are attacked, Maj. Gen. James M. Gavin, Army Assistant Chief of Staff, said last night.

RHEIMS, France, July 4 (AP) -- Three British Jaguars swept the first three places today in the cold and windy twelve-hour Rheims international sports car race. An American-entered Ferrari finished fourth, followed by two American Cunninghams.

TRUNGGIA, Vietnam, July 4 -- Representatives of the French Union and Vietminh high commands began technical talks today on various military problems related to the execution of an Indochinese armistice.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- A Chinese military officer, under arrest by the United States Navy, was en route from here tonight to Formosa to face charges as a "deserter," it was announced by Lieut. Comdr. Robert R. Dennes, public relations officer for the Great Lakes Naval Training Center here.

GENEVA, July 4 -- Members of the Vietnamese Government delegation here are resigned to the prospect that an armistice may soon be concluded under which the Vietminh forces would occupy large areas of Vietnam. It is assumed that virtually all the northern half of the country may go to the Communist-led rebels.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- One of the big complaints against Congressional investigations has been "too many one-man hearings." A subcommittee headed by Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, is now holding hearings on the investigative problem.

MILWAUKEE, July 4 (AP) -- Jim Greengrass' bases-loaded single highlighted a four-run sixth inning today as the Cincinnati Redlegs chased Lew Burdette to beat the Milwaukee Braves, 4-3. The victory brought the Redlegs to within a half a game of the National League's first division.
GUATEMALA, July 4 -- Evidence is piling up that the number of persons executed in Guatemala for political reasons exceeded the number of battle fatalities in the fourteen-day revolution.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., July 4 -- A University of Illinois farm machinery expert predicts that a machine being tested here would revolutionize methods of harvesting corn, the nation's Number 1 grain crop, in the next few years.
Three Hollywood entries and an importation from France are among the feature films slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 4 -- The major issue in the current session of the Central African Federation's Parliament will be a measure to control white immigration.

BALTIMORE, July 4 (UP) -- The Baltimore Orioles completed a three-game sweep of their series with Detroit today. They defeated the Tigers, 3 to 1, behind the five-hit pitching of Lou Kretlow, a right-hander.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., July 4 (AP) -- With the sun shining and the temperature about 80 degrees, Arthur Tokle of the Norge Ski Club, Chicago, soared 112 and 109 feet in two leaps today to win the Fourth of July ski jump.

At Basle, Switzerland, on "14 June," 1954, Roger Auboin, general manager of the Bank for International Settlements, submitted his annual report to the meeting of the bank's board of thirteen directors.

LAREDO, Tex., July 4 (UP) -- Typhoid fever, dread aftermath of major floods, has broken out in the Rio Grande Valley and 300 bottles of vaccine will be flown to the area, authorities asserted tonight.
A study of possible sources of additional city revenue to meet larger budget requirements in 1955-56 will be undertaken soon by Dr. Luther H. Gulick, City Administrator, and his staff.

TOKYO, Monday, July 5 (AP) -- Japanese scientists sent by their Government to check any effects of the recent hydrogen bomb tests reported yesterday that they had safely eaten raw fish caught in Bikini waters. This is the area where the United States staged the tests.

DALLAS CITY, Ill., July 4 (AP) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas said today that provisions in the pending tax bill granting write-offs for the expense of building farm ponds and grain storage bins "will be a great aid to the farmer."
The line distinguishing between the sacred and the secular has been too sharply drawn, said the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken in his sermon yesterday morning at Riverside Church.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Following are the votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll calls in Congress during the period June 26 through July 3:
LOS ANGELES, July 4 -- The Government is about to start the second phase of its campaign to rid the nation of Mexican border jumpers.

HACKENSACK, N. J., July 4 -- Edward Moylan of Trenton took the Eastern clay court tennis championship today with a straight-set victory over Jerry DeWitts of Berkeley, Calif. Moylan, seeded No. 1, won, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, at the Oritani Field Club.

The other day it was my misfortune to have to venture into the subway. It was hot on the street, but even hotter in the subway, where the air was so dead you felt you could slice it with a knife. Again I was forced to consider how little the I. R. T. division of the Transit Authority has done for the riding public.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 4 -- Long before the Declaration of Independence, Thomas Walker, Daniel Boone and others blazed trails through the Cumberland Gap area.
For a manager whose Yankees had just recorded a 3-0 victory over the Washington Senators, Casey Stengel was a forlorn figure in his private office at the Stadium yesterday.

PARIS, July 4 -- Now that an effort has been made, in the Eisenhower - Churchill talks, to reconcile the United States and British policies, an effort is to be made to reconcile United States and French policies.

BRISTOL, Pa., July 4 -- Rain that varied from a light drizzle to a teaming downpour reduced the number of contestants in some of the events of the Bristol Yacht Club regatta for inboard and outboard motorboats today. But in the popular Class B utility category two elimination heats were necessary.

" THE ART OF ERNEST HEMINGWAY,"* by John Atkins, is a critical tribute to that celebrated novelist, presented from an English point of view, complete with a chapter on "Hemingway and the English." This opens awesome possibilities of many future books with chapters on "Hem ingway and the French," "Hemingway and the Africans," "Hemingway and the Gulf Stream," and so on, to illustrate the worldwide field of his writing. Why not?

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., July 4 (UP) -- Chautauqua Institution, long a summertime cultural center, was opened today as Samuel M. Hazlett, Pittsburgh attorney, rapped his gavel three times to signify the inception of the eighty-first season.
MEXICO CITY, July 4 -- The Mexican Government is about to enter the movie distributing business.

The motion picture distributing company formed thirty-five years ago by Mary Pickford, Charles Chaplin, Douglas Fairbanks and David Wark Griffith has beaten the Hollywood depression and is running at a tidy profit.

The New Haven Clock and Watch Company, in its annual report for 1953, issued over the week-end, showed a net profit of $152,337, equal to 37 cents a common share, after providing $150,000 for inventory write-downs. This is in contrast to a loss of $141,806 suffered in 1952.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 4 (AP) -- Vice President Richard Nixon has praised volunteer firemen in a message to W. Earl Hopper, chairman of tomorrow's salute here to the volunteer firemen of the world's free nations.

Courage and good sense are qualities we have come to associate with David Dubinsky. The president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union has demonstrated both of these virtues in the advice he has just given his colleagues in organized labor on legislation to control abuses in the administration of union welfare funds.

A friend who is recovering from an injury says she cannot cross Second Avenue because the red light does not allow time enough for pedestrians to cross unless they can walk rapidly. War veterans who have been wounded say they have a similar fear of crossing a broad one-way avenue.

OMAHA, July 4 (AP) -- Jack McAfee, Manhattan Beach, Calif., gunned his maroon Ferrari into the lead in the fiftyninth lap and stayed in front to the finish to win the 200-mile feature at the national sports car races of Offutt Air Force Base today.

DETROIT, July 4 (AP) -- Cary Middlecoff of Memphis, who almost quit in the first round, ended a one-year slump today when he carded a three-under-par 68 to win the Motor City open golf tournament with a seventy-two-hole total of 278.

About 860 naval reserve officers with long and honorable active service are now receiving "Dear John" letters precedent to their separation from active duty. This is a polite way of informing individual reservists that their past services have been appreciated but they are no longer needed because of budget cuts and the consequent reduction in the size of the Navy's officer corps.

David Dubinsky, for thirty years a leader in the fight against union racketeering, called on organized labor yesterday to support legislative measures designed to curb abuses in the conduct of union welfare funds.
PHILADELPHIA, July 4 -- The Dodgers were a trifle dilatory in declaring their independence today. They waited until the tenth inning, then their bats began booming like cannon crackers.

BOSTON, July 4 (AP) -- Sammy White drove in three runs with a homer and a single today as the Boston Red Sox blanked the Philadelphia Athletics, 8 -- 0, behind the eight-hit pitching of Leo Kiely, a southpaw.

The June 23 issue of The Times reports Senator Homer Ferguson, chairman of the Republican Policy Committee, as saying that "high priority" was being given at this session of Congress to Administration-sponsored anti-Communist legislation.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 4 -- A letter written to Thomas Jefferson in 1781 by the Marquis de Lafayette has been presented to the Princeton University Library in honor of Dr. Julian P. Boyd, editor of "The Papers of Thomas Jefferson."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 4 -- Skippers accustomed to being at or near the top week after week dominated the classes in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta conducted by the Larchmont Yacht Club today.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 4 -- The Dutch Foundation of Labor, a body on which all employers' organizations and trade unions are represented, has completed a report advocating early drastic relaxation of rigid wage controls by allowing greater freedom within each branch of industry.

The Estate Securities Company, New York operators, bought the four-story apartment house for thirty-nine families at 37-76 Sixty-second Street, in Woodside, Queens, from a client of Murray Selby, attorney. The sale was negotiated by George Brezel, vice president of Sydney M. Siegel Co., Kew Gardens brokers, who also arranged the purchase by the seller about a month ago.

It seems to me there is a lack of coordination on the part of the Health, Sanitation and Education Departments in the matter of public health education regarding the cause and prevention of the ragweed pollen chronic disease, hay fever. The public should be more extensively enlightened as to what ragweed is and what it looks like, especially since it is the chief cause of hay fever.

On the two sides of the South China Sea, the Fourth of July this year has meant two vastly different things. On one side, in Manila, 100,000 persons gathered and paraded to celebrate the eighth anniversary of the independence of the Philippines. On the other, in Tonkin, many times that number were fleeing in terror from the Communist occupation of the abandoned delta area.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., July 4 -- The Connecticut River Game Fish Association believes it may know the results of its effort to return salmon to the Connecticut River late this year or early next.
BOSTON, July 4 -- In a day when highway engineers are beginning to realize the dreams of super expressways, Massachusetts is being forced to seek a cure for a turnpike nightmare.

There never would have been a need for alarm at Communist penetration in Latin America, and the present events in Guatemala would never have taken place, if Washington had not, the moment the war was over, turned its back on Latin America.
Two Brooklyn youths were seized yesterday while unloading merchandise the Federal Bureau of Investigation charged they had hijacked in Newark six days ago.

LONDON, July 4 -- Some slackening of stock market activity has occurred in the last week as the result of preoccupation with affairs connected with the turn of the half-year. But less business has not affected security values and the markets as a whole have remained as robust as ever, with the industrial share index reaching another high record.
BERLIN, July 4 (Reuters) -- West Berlin went wild tonight as radio and television newscasters announced Germany's "miracle of the century" upset of Hungary in the world cup soccer final by 3 -- 2.
As the mighty United States commemorates the anniversary of her independence today, a tiny island in the West Indies offers congratulations.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (UP) -- Senate Republican aides have seized on a Democrat's statement to supply G. O. P. Senators with some political ammunition.

THE boxers are now about to muscle into the act. Baseball has its Hall of Fame and so has football. Now the Busted Beak Industry wants one of its own. And when brawny citizens brandish fists while making demands, it takes brave men to refuse. If the pugilists want a pantheon for their immortals, they can have it. No questions asked, either.
Averell Harriman, who frequently has been mentioned as a possible Democratic choice for Governor, predicted yesterday that the nominee of the Democratic convention would be the next Governor.

I was most interested in Lillian Smith's letter which you printed June 6. Miss Smith drew an interesting parallel between segregation of Negro students and another type of segregation not subject to the judicial process. She pointed out that more than forty states have laws which forbid an epileptic child to attend public school in spite of the fact that the epileptic convulsion can be controlled in many cases.

CHICAGO, July 4 (UP) -- The New York Yankees and the Brooklyn Dodgers each placed three players on the 1954 all-star teams in the balloting for the annual inter-league game, final vote tabulation showed today.
Howard Greet has been called the friend of many of the smartest women in the country. His friendships are deep and loyal, his ability to enhance the feminine figure renowned.
The bath is one of the few remaining methods of individual relaxation in our society. It still seems to hold its own in New York City against the encroachment of modern amusements such as television.
PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (AP) -- The Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia took eight first places to dominate the annual People's Regatta on the Schuylkill River in Fairmount Park today.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Monday, July 5 (Reuters) -- Kenya's reconstituted Government announced today a policy of sweeping racial, economic and administrative reforms to rebuild the British colony from the disasters of Mau Mau terrorism.

MOSCOW, July 4 -- The bodies of Lenin and Stalin will be removed from the famous mausoleum in Red Square in the center of Moscow and placed in a new Pantheon to be erected in open fields on the city's southern outskirts.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 4 -- "New Heaven, New Birth," a novel by Arthemise Goertz set in Louisiana in 1909, has been bought for filming by Universal. The book, published last year, deals with the problems that confront a young physician when his fashionable family objects to the girl he wants to marry and also attempts to dissuade him from practicing his profession among poor people.

A major addition to the thirty- vessel fleet of Flota Mercante Grancolombiana will be made next year with the delivery of four new cargo vessels being built at the yards of H. C. Stuelcken Sohn, Hamburg, Germany.
It was an extremely quiet week in the foreign exchanges, with only a minimum of business transferred at nominal price changes.

LAREDO, Tex., July 4 -- The Falcon Dam, about 75 miles down the Rio Grande, more than paid for itself in last week's flood up river, officials of the International Boundary and Water Commission believe.
Rain, the source of bitterness for the city's pleasure-seekers, made philosophers yesterday of many who worked on the holiday.
THERE'S a small boy's paradise inside the six-story gray building at 427 East Ninetieth Street, though you'd never guess it from just passing the place.

The "greatest blood donation on record" was given on the hill of Calvary for the spiritual redemption of all mankind, the Rev. Harry J. Wolf of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral declared yesterday.
" The Remarkable Mr. Pennypacker" is nearing the end of its successful run at the Coronet Theatre.

PITTSBURGH, July 4 (AP) -- From now on if a ball strikes the clock on top of the scoreboard at Forbes Field, the batter will have to make as many bases as he can. No longer will it be an automatic home run.
Objects made of glass help to give a cool look to a room in summer. New collections of glassware, including functional and decorative pieces, recently arrived in the shops.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- Wheat futures prices showed considerable strength here last week. Support came from mills, reflecting a moderate expansion in the flour demand, and from traders, who were fairly well convinced that there would be no free selling of wheat from the farms at this price level.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The Federal Government is about to spend $175,000 to find out what kind of air is breathed by dwellers in industrialized urban areas.
Americans around the world observed the Fourth of July yesterday in activities ranging from solemn wreath-laying ceremonies to fireworks displays and beach picnics.

NEW HAVEN, July 4 -- Archaeologists have discovered a 100-mile canal that irrigated an arid waste in ancient Mesopotamia and aided in the development of one of the world's earliest civilizations. It ran parallel to the Euphrates River.

JACKSON, Mich., July 4 -- Two members of President Eisenhower's official family will fly from Washington to help this Central Michigan city of 55,000 celebrate the disputed 100th birthday of the Republican party this week.

BERN, Switzerland, July 4 (UP) -- Germany spotted "unbeatable" Hungary two goals in eight minutes and then roared from behind to capture the world soccer championship, 3 to 2, today before 65,000 rain-drenched fans in Wankdorf Stadium.

Senator William F. Knowland's proposal that the United States quit the United Nations if Communist China is admitted represents "an air of moral superiority" inconsistent with Christian patriotism, the Rev. Dr. John M. Krumm, chaplain of Columbia University, declared yesterday.

ELMSFORD, N. Y., July 4 -- Fifteen hundred Philippine-born residents of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut celebrated their eighth "Fourth of July" today on the twenty-three-acre estate of their acting Consul General here.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Congress faced a new hurdle tonight as it turned into the homestretch in its drive toward adjournment by July 31.
AUSTIN, Tex., July 4 (UP) -- An anti-Communist school to teach city and state police that "all red rashes are not measles" will open here Tuesday.

DALLAS, Tex., July 4 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche declared here today that the American Negro's history of patriotism at home and on battlefields abroad was assurance to this country that "in the very hour of its sternest challenge" there would be no disunity.
WASHINGTON, July (AP) -- Lawmakers opposed to the Eisenhower program of flexible farm supports outlined a strategy today they hoped might reverse the setback they suffered in the House last week.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 14 -- Five leading gardens here will be opened for a special garden tour on July 14 under the auspices of the Southampton Garden Club. Mrs. Fenton Taylor of Southampton and New York will direct the tour.
The customers will write the advertising in a campaign being planned by the Standard Oil Company (Indiana).

Plans for altering the five-story brick dwelling at 54 Garden Place in the Brooklyn Heights section of Brooklyn have been announced in connection with the sale of the house by Frieda Weiss to David Tucker. The house is on a lot 19 by 95 feet and will be made into a ten-family building.

Under the conditions laid down by Chairman Reece the suspension of public hearings by the special House of Representatives committee to investigate foundations is inexcusable. Twelve witnesses have so far been heard in public session. Nine of these have attacked the foundations -- on grounds fantastic almost beyond belief, as we have pointed out before. The committee thus far has called only one witness for the defense.
Maj. Charles E. Yeager of the Air Force and Jacqueline Cochran, noted woman flier, were chosen yesterday as this year's winners of the Harmon Awards for outstanding achievements in aeronautics.

The conclusion of the Wimbledon tennis championships and the United States Women's Open Golf tournament brought sports victories that were popular both in Britain and here. In his eleventh attempt Jaroslav Drobny won the singles title at Wimbledon. "Mighty Little Mo" Connolly won the women's championship.
