Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $74,042,195,011. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

CLEVELAND, July 4 (AP) -- Three Cleveland hurlers kept the Chicago White Sox hitless for nearly nine innings today as the Indians posted a 2-1 victory for a sweep of a four-game series and their seventh victory in a row.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- This nation's first fission fleet sailors are polishing off -- by land and by sea -- the training they need to operate the world's first atomic submarine.

We certainly do not wish to see the plans for the new Columbus Circle slum clearance project, including the construction of a new convention hall and coliseum, delayed any more than can possibly be helped. For this reason we think the City Planning Commission has acted wisely in recommending the setting up of a $20,000,000 revolving fund to assist and speed up the work.

WOODSTOCK, Vt., July 4 (UP) -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders said today that "foolish and shortsighted citizens" who thought only of fighting communism at home would make the United States and Canada "islands of besieged freedom in an enslaved world."
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 4 (UP) -- Former President Truman was pronounced out of danger today for the first time since his gall bladder and appendix were removed two weeks ago.

SOUTHPORT, England, July 4 (AP) -Bobby Locke of South Africa was favored today to win his fourth British open golf championship in the competition opening tomorrow over the Royal Birkdale and Hillside courses.

PARIS, July 4 -- The single, freely competitive market instituted by the six-nation coal and steel community is putting the nationalized French coal industry in a difficult position, according to officials here.
The spirt of Independence Day, reflected in the Declaration of Independence, was noted with symbolic music yesterday in a special program over Station WQXR.

Hosteling, a notably inexpensive form of outdoor recreation, has taken more of a hold on teen-agers and young adults in the New York area this year than at any other time since the idea was imported from Europe twenty years ago.

WITH Jackie Gleason off on vacation, an item called "Stage Show" has been inserted in the 8-to-9 period on Saturday evenings over C. B. S. television. The program is another warm-weather puzzlement: Is there so little pride of craft in summer TV that now anything goes?

The religion of Americans "can and must be a strong force for God," the Rev. Joseph D. Huntley declared yesterday morning in a sermon in the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church, at Fifty-sixth Street.

Peter Greig, a wine authority associated with a local importing company, called recently to say he had just heard that Larue's had closed. He was referring to a Paris restaurant known for nearly seventy-five years as "a temple of gastronomy."
Representative James I. Dolliver, Republican of Iowa, called yesterday in a sermon for a rededication to the ideals of the first American Independence Day.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 4 (UP) -- Ray Jenkins' backers said today that they would renew their "draft Jenkins" move despite the attorney's statement that he would not run for the Senate.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (UP) -- The United States announced today a new drive to fight Red lies about this country by tightening cultural ties with people all over the world.
THURMONT, Md., July 4 (UP) -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower spent a quiet Fourth of July today with a few friends at their Catoctin Mountain retreat.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Former President Hoover announced today that his Government Organization Commission would study the "structure and administration" of the top-secret Central Intelligence Agency.

Brian Harrison, Professor of History at Hong Kong University, has written a one-volume history of southeast Asia which St. Martin's Press will issue July 27. The book begins with the earliest traces of man in Java and moves through the successive waves of conquerors and traders over the centuries.

Lily Pons was the soloist and Andre Kostelanetz the conductor at Saturday night's concert by the Stadium Symphony at Lewisohn Stadium. The famous husband-and-wife team offered a program consisting of items with which they have long been identified.
NORWALK, Conn., July 4 -- A law forbidding any resident of this city to harbor "horse, cattle, swine, goats or fowls" in his home is to be removed from the statute book.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- A deadlocked wage dispute between the Federal Government and 500,000 postal workers threatened today to kill prospective pay increases this year for 1,500,000 Federal employes.

DETROIT, July 5 (AP) -- Improvement in used-car sales is reported from most of the nation's larger centers. This is accepted by most industry analysts as supporting the conviction that there will be no major slump in the new-car market during the latter half of 1954.

OTTAWA, July 5 -- The Canadian Government has signed a contract to buy uranium from the Pronto Uranium Mines in the new Algoma field on the north shore of Lake Huron and is negotiating for similar agreements with other uranium companies in the area, it was learned today.

NARRAGANSETT, R. I., July 5 -- The striped bass may have been late in arriving along this stretch of coast, but surf casters and trollers now are taking fish up to forty pounds, with an occasional bull bass crowding the fifty-pound mark.

I have been spraying poison ivy. It is a subversive force among the rocks and cedars of the abandoned farm where we have lived for the last thirty-five years. A few plants of this three-leaved vine are not dangerous, but if allowed to become a majority of the woodland growth it brings pain to many and seriously limits our freedom to enjoy our acres.

Traditionally the Fourth of July means festivities -- picnics, ice cream, tinkling iced drinks and candle-lit meals. But along with these pleasures comes the inevitable worm in the apple -- stains on table linens and dishes that can give a Tobacco Road atmosphere to the best run household.

MOSCOW, June 5 -- The Soviet note that requested the recall of Colonel Felchlin and Major McKinney of the United States military attache's office simply stated that the two were persona non grata as a result of activities that were said to be incompatible with their continued stay in Moscow.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Three Soviet attaches have been expelled from the United States for spying, and the Kremlin has retaliated by forcing the recall of two United States officers under similar charges.
PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 5 -- Charles S. Thomas, Secretary of the Navy, said today that the nation's best defense against the Communist threat was military and spiritual strength.

A young descendant of an old Mediterranean shipping family, Nicos Vernicos, 34 years old, has been chosen to succeed the late Eugen Eugenides as president of Home Lines, it was announced here yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- Heavy favorites scored easily today in Arlington Park's two feature races.

A famous collection of stories, which probably has left a deeper impression on the young than any other, came to these shores in its original manuscript form a little more than a year ago and has now departed.

The truth of the axiom about half a loaf being better than none is being questioned by several port business associations -- at least, in so far as it pertains to a reduction of certain lighterage charges in New York Harbor.

IS the Administration's foreign policy sword, "agonizing reappraisal," hanging over the heads of our recalcitrant allies -- or is it in reality pointed at our own throats? Does not this official warning resemble more the attitude of a patriarch who threatens to disinherit his whole family, or perhaps the adolescent who pouts in a corner?
PHILADELPHIA, July 5 -- A train stops, an elevator stops. Even a television commercial comes to an end.

JERUSALEM, July 5 -- Defense Minister Pinhas Lavon declared today that the shooting outbreak last week in Jerusalem represented a brutal attack organized by the Jordanian Government and carried out under orders of responsible officers of the Arab Legion.
Nathaniel Hawthorne tried to destroy all copies of his early novel "Fanshawe" after it was published in 1828, but a handful of copies survived the attempt and it has become a collector s
A fire lieutenant who objected to having a firecracker explode in his face charged yesterday that he had been severely beaten by four youths in Elmhurst, Queens wlth Whom he had remonstrated.

There is fully as much need for automatic manufacturing in the small job shop as in the sprawling plant that needs a single part reproduced by the millions, week after week and year after year, according to John Diebold.

After a considerable number of charges and counter-charges, some of them irresponsible, the correct approach to some of the problems of our Central Intelligence Agency has been announced. A task force of the Hoover Commission will "study" the agency's "structure and administration."

A meeting today between union and management representatives may decide whether the Alexander Smith, Inc., carpet factory in Yonkers, due to be shut down, will open temporarily to complete work still on the looms.

C. W. Pennington has been appointed general sales manager of consumers' products and F. A. Sawyer general sales manager of manufacturers' products in the footwear and general products division of the United States Rubber Company.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 5 -- The Brazilian Supreme Court voted today, 6 to 1, to uphold President Getulio D. Vargas on a decree doubling the minimum legal wage.
OTTAWA, July 5 (Canadian Press) -- Canadians with a yen for travel have become big spenders abroad, and indications are they will continue to spend heavily in 1954.

WHEN I was a boy "Moby Dick" was generally considered to be a book about whaling. In recent years the collegiate critics have been changing that simple idea. They swarm over Melville's masterpiece -- harpooning its symbolism, cutting up its myths, boiling out the folklore and selling their bottled Moby Dickery as an awesome allegory of good and evil.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (UP) -- Senator George D. Aiken, chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, said today it was "entirely possible" that Congress would approve a plan to dispose of milk surpluses to low income groups at cut prices.

THERE are many who insist that the greatest day in track history was May 25, 1935. It's difficult to argue against them. Within the space of seventy minutes at Ann Arbor, Mich., the incomparable Jesse Owens of Ohio State shattered three world records and equaled another. And in the light of recent developments it appears that the Buckeye Bullet shot over the cinders at even higher velocity than the record books indicate.
GENEVA, July 5 -- Participants in the Indochinese peace conference looked forward today to one of the most important weeks of the two-months-old gathering here.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 5 -- The Communist party was banned in East Pakistan today as a danger to the public peace. The Government's action was the climax to a charge last Monday by Prime Minister Mohammed Ali that the Communists had been the "master-minds" behind the labor riot in East Pakistan last month that left a death toll of 600.
HAMBURG, Germany, July 5 (Reuters) -- The West German oil industry, prostrate at the end of World War II, now ranks among Europe's most important.

ELLSWORTH, Me., July 5 (AP) -- An ultramodern million-dollar woolen mill was opened here today, and Gov. Burton M. Cross said it represented a challenge to the southward drift of New England's hard-pressed textile industry.

OTTAWA, July 5 (AP) -- Canada's cost of living jumped by three-fifths of a point in May, the biggest rise in thirty months. The Federal Government reported that a jump in food prices combined with higher rents boosted the consumer price index in May to 116.1 from 115.5.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 5 -- There are signs of alarm in official Iranian circles today on the course of the negotiations to resume operations on the nation's oil industry. However, these are believed to reflect internal political conditions rather than any serious disagreement over the terms offered by the international oil consortium.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (UP) -- Ted Lepcio and Roy Sievers each hit a grand-slam home run as the Red Sox and Senators split a double-header today. Boston won the opener, 14 -- 0, and Washington took the nightcap, 7 -- 1, before 14,514 fans.
In your June 27 issue appears another drive against the forest preserve, under the heading "State Opens Study of Forest Preserve Lands."
A slowdown by dock workers in me port of Rio de Janeiro has congested its piers. As a result, several steamship concerns serving Brazil from New York have reshuffled their schedules.
PITTSBURGH, July 5 -- The dungeon-dwelling Pirates, referred to this morning by a local sports editor as the Dodgers' "special patsies," proved to be just that today at Forbes Field.
In contrast to other major metals still plagued by oversupply and slow demand, copper has made a strong recovery from its recession early this year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 5 -- Sterling Hayden will complete his commitments with Allied Artists by appearing in a Western story titled "Walk Tall." The cameras won't turn on this one until next year, however. The studio has one of Mr. Hayden's pictures, "Arrow in the Dust," now in release.

PARIS, July 5 -- Scientists heard today that there was a possibility of effecting photosynthesis independently of whole green plant cells. It is in such cells that nature normally carries on this process of converting light energy into chemical energy.
WINNIPEG, July 5 (Canadian Press) -- Barley and flax showed the best activity today as all grain prices held to a narrow range, then closed generally lower on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange.

CINCINNATI, July 5 (AP) -- Straight Clark, 29-year-old Philadelphian, today won the men's singles championship in the fifty-fifth tri-state tennis tournament with an 8-6, 6-1, 6-1 victory over young Sam Giammalva of Houston.

What is essentially a "6 R" policy in public education was urged by Dr. Grayson Kirk, the president of Columbia University, in an address before the National Education Association. To "readin', 'ritin', and 'rithmetic" he would add emphasis on resources, resolution and responsibility.
OTTAWA, July 5 -- Preliminary discussions began here today on United States participation in building the St. Lawrence Seaway to open a twenty-seven-foot waterway to the Great Lakes.

LONDON, July 5 -- Lord Ismay, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said here today that the proposed European Defense Community remained an "essential" feature of Atlantic alliance policy militarily and politically.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (UP) -- The Government this week makes its first official survey of 1954 farm production -- expected to indicate a near-record harvest and swelling surpluses despite Federal controls on major crops.

CINCINNATI, July 5 (UP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs downed the Chicago Cubs twice today, 6 -- 5 in ten innings and 8 -- 7. Bobby Adams singled home the winning run in the opener and a Chicago ninth-inning rally fell short in the second game.

When the doctor prescribes a diet -- diabetic, low-sodium or low-calorie -- it often is left to the patient or a member of his family to devise menus that are attractive enough to stimulate the appetite.

SALEM, N. H., July 5 (AP) -- Vernon Smith, 19-year-old jockey from Conway Springs, Kan., died as the result of a fall today during the morning section of a horse racing double-header at Rockingham Park.

DETROIT, July 5 (UP) -- Harvey Kuenn's eleventh-inning homer gave the Detroit Tigers a 1-to-0 victory over the Cleveland Indians in the second game of a double-header today after Bill Glynn powered the Indians to a 13-to-6 triumph in the opener by driving in eight runs with three successive homers and a sacrifice fly.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (UP) -- The Army virtually has completed its program of ending segregation of its white and Negro soldiers, a spokesman for the service said today.
OKLAHOMA CITY, July 5 (UP) -- Two oil millionaires will fight it out for the Democratic Senatorial nomination tomorrow while 200 National Guardsmen, operating under martial law, keep watch.
DARLINGTON, S. C., July 5 (AP) -- Death marred the annual Independence Day big car race today

The disclosure that twelve foreign Governments are charged by the city with owing $416,985 in municipal real estate taxes shows that we have a problem somewhat akin to that of Nassau County. Our neighbor county has been having its troubles trying to prove to the Russians that they owe for realty taxes due there. The problem with us, however, involves more countries and hence is much greater.
PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (AP) -- Senator James H. Duff, Republican of Pennsylvania, said today the time was "overripe" for drawing a line beyond which communism must not be allowed to advance.

The one-story taxpayer building at 43-04 Broadway, Astoria, Queens, which is entirely occupied as a branch post office under a twenty-year lease, has been purchased for investment by Mrs. Sandra Antonini in a deal negotiated by Jerry Lieberthal, vice president of Sydney M. Siegel Co., brokers.

Plans for converting the three five-story apartment houses on a plot 75 by 100 feet at 15, 17 and 19 East 101st Street into residences for nurses have been announced by J. E. Mautner, broker, who arranged the sale of the property for Dr. Murray Siegel to the Haroer Realty Corporation.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 5 -- What happens today to the home in the West is likely to happen to homes all over the country tomorrow, three speakers agreed here yesterday.

LONDON, July 5 -- The British housewife, protected from the world rise in meat prices for fourteen years, faced the economic facts of life today. Meat prices took a sudden jolting leap with the end of rationing.

Jose Greco and his company of Spanish dancers drew some 14,000 persons, quite the largest crowd of the season, to Lewisohn Stadium last night. Mr. Greco is not only a good dancer but also a good showman, and that makes all the difference in the world in a dance performance at the stadium.
Sandy Saddler, world featherweight champion, knocked out Libby Manzo of Elmhurst, L. I., in 2:35 of the final round of a scheduled ten-round non-title bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night.
The combined assets and deposits of the National City Bank of New York and of its affiliate, City Bank Farmers Trust Company, showed substantial increases over those of three and twelve months ago.

MADISON, Wis., July 5 -- Construction of a $1,500,000 athletic field house for the University of Wisconsin will be begun this fall. The site is at Camp Randall which includes about two acres of a six-acre park dedicated in 1912 as a memorial to Wisconsin's Civil War soldiers.

Bill McNeece, 163 1/2 pounds, Central Islip, L. I., scored a technical knockout over Jackie LaBua, 162 1/2, East Meadow, L. I., in the feature bout scheduled for ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.

Henry A. Hoffman, president of the National Alfalfa Dehydrating and Milling Company, expects that his company's volume will "about double" in the fiscal year to April 30, 1955. The company's annual report for fiscal 1954, being issued today, shows a decline in sales to $7,975,633, from $9,054,448 in the previous twelve months.
GENEVA, July 5 -- The United States supported the United Nations Secretary General today in his efforts to improve the functioning of the Secretariat and reduce unimportant tasks.

HANOI, Vietnam, July 5 -- French Union and Vietminh officers announced tonight that they had agreed on means of effecting the release of sick and wounded prisoners of war. The first exchange was set for July 14, which as Bastille Day is France's national holiday.
A B-47 bomber of the Air Force Strategic Air Command has flown the equivalent of fifteen times around the world without having any of its six jet engines overhauled.

The N.B.C.-TV network will televise the National Basketball Association games throughout the 1954-55 season on Saturdays, beginning Oct. 30. WNBT, Channel 4, will carry the contests for local audiences. The basketball pick-ups will follow the Canadian professional football contests on the network through Saturday, Nov. 27, but thereafter will begin at 3 P. M. Telecasts will be from each of the cities in the nine-team league.

On June 23 the Senate considered a bill, S. 2862, sponsored by Senator McCarran of Nevada, providing for admission on a non-quota basis of 385 Basque sheepherders. This special legislation was expected to pass unnoticed and in a routine manner, as had happened in the previous two sessions of Congress.

STANTON, Del., July 5 (AP) -- Gainsboro Girl, a 4-year-old owned by the Shawmut Stable of Richard A. Jenks of Providence, scrambled racing's filly and mare championship picture today by flashing to a four-length victory in the $138,400 New Castle Handicap on the closing program at Delaware Park.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 5 -- Two Westchester youths, Eddie Dooley Jr. and Fred Hibberd Jr., and a fireman from the Bronx, Kurt Grandpierre, completed perfect holiday week-ends afloat today. They were unbeaten in the three days of Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound sailing competition.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- A showdown is near in the Hell's Canyon case, one of the biggest power fights in the country and a major political issue in the Pacific Northwest.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., July 5 -- The New York State men's tennis tournament, suspended since Bill Talbert won his third Empire State title in 1952, was revived at the County Tennis Club of Westchester today with ninety-eight singles entries.
MEXICO CITY, July 5 -- An invitation for President Eisenhower to visit Mexico is en route to the White House by airmail today.

ST. LOUIS, July 5 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves swept a double-header from the St. Louis Cardinals today, winning a duel of home runs in the opener with four circuit drives, 8 -- 6, and backing Warren Spahn's pitching with a seventeen-hit attack to take the nightcap, 10 -- 4.

By July only the true New Yorkers are left to the town. The fair-weather friends, those who condescend to visit in the fall to see the Broadway offerings, those who think of the city in terms of a perfect May afternoon on Central Park South, they are all gone now.

CHICAGO, July 5 (UP) -- Ron Jackson, 6-foot 7-inch rookie, blasted his first major league home run in the seventh inning today to pace the Chicago White Sox to a 2 -- 1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles after the Sox had taken the first game of a double-header, 3 to 0.

Commendation of Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh and Mrs. Bernice P. Rogers, Deputy Housing Commissioner, for their zealous enforcement of the State Multiple Dwelling Law against "irresponsible landlords" has been voted by the city affairs committee of the New York chapter of Americans for Democratic Action.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 5 (UP) -- King Ranch's Rejected, whose last previous victory had been in the Santa Anita Handicap last winter, raced to a powerful half-length victory today in the $55,150 American Handicap before a record crowd of 59,178 at Hollywood Park.

The one-story factiry building at 3902 Seventh Avenue in Brokklyn has been sold by the New comb Spring Corporation to a client of Sidney Snyderman for ocsquere feet and is assesed at $52,500. The Brevoort Management Company was the broker.

LONDON, July 5 -- A four power treaty granting sovereignty to West Germany by autumn was discussed today by United States and British diplomats. They met in the first of a series of talks seeking means to break the stalemate arising out of France's delay in ratifying the European Defense Community Treaty.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (UP) -- Senator George A. Smathers disclosed today that he planned to offer a constitutional amendment to stiffen the requirements governing admission of states to the Union.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 5 -- The David Levitt Trophy, named after the founder of the Victory fleet in Manhasset Bay, was won by Stormy today as Gil Schwartz guided his Victory class craft to its second triumph in two days.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 5 -- Pipers practiced today in the parking area of Round Hill, the Henry S. Moore estate here. Others piped around the meadow before competing in the annual games held by the Round Hill Highland Games Association.

LONDON, July 5 -- Industrials, particularly store, aircraft and papermaking groups, rose on the stock markets here today. Most other sections were fairly firm too, and gains of one shilling (14 cents) were common.
GUATEMALA, July 5 -- The new Guatemalan Government has arrested 2,000 Communists. It promises to proceed swiftly to decide whether to release them or try them for common crimes.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 5 (AP) -- Mrs. Ella K. Bryson's Kinda Smart, second each time in three previous stakes races this season, found a field he could beat at Monmouth Park today and took the $22,750 Tyro Stakes before 34,071, largest crowd of the meeting.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- President Eisenhower has won or is on the way to winning in five of eleven major legislative areas as the Eighty-third Congress presses toward adjournment by the end of this month.

Problems of school financing and the recruiting of teachers will be up for discussion today at the opening of the thirteenth annual work conference for school superintendents at Teachers College, Columbia University.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- President Eisenhower today forecast the eventual stoppage of what he called the Communist "conspiracies" against the world march of freedom.

The best news from Mr. Truman's bedside is that he isn't in bed any more most of the time, that no more regular bulletins about his condition will be issued and that it is his work on his memoirs and not his temperature that is described as "serious." In short, our junior ex-President is officially out of danger and feeling chipper and sassy again.

Determined to lose no more ground before their next big clash with the pursuing Dodgers, the Giants swept the double-header with the Phillies at the Polo Grounds yesterday before a roaring crowd of 36,547.

As the year of 1954 enters its second half it becomes evident that it will be a year of decision on what is undoubtedly one of the supreme issues confronting the Western World. This issue, which will determine the shape and course of Europe's history, is the problem of Germany.

Samuel F. Chalfin has been named vice president for the Latin-American division of American Machine and Foundry Company's international group. Mr. Chalfin has been associated with the company's foreign activities since 1926.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 5 -- Over the bitter protests of the Opposition, the Grand National Assembly enacted tonight a measure giving the Government sweeping discretionary power to discharge civil servants without the right of appeal. The vote was 309 to 25.

An increasing portion of the consumer dollar is being spent on housing, utilities, medical care, transportation and other services, according to the July review of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, published today.

John Mills, previously reported under consideration for "End of the Affair," now is definite to join Olivia de Haviland in the picturization of the Graham Greene novel. It is being made in London for Columbia Pictures.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 4 -- The Ministery of Justice here is alarmed by evidence of a new passive resistance campaign to racial segregation, being organized this time under actual Communist leadership.
BUENOS AIRES, July 5 -- President Juan D. Peron forcefully re-emphasized tonight his decision to refrain from intervening in labor-management disputes over collective agreements.

LOS ANGELES, July 5 -- Color, the return of the look of casual elegance, and a great versatility of fabric provided the staccato notes of the new fall showings of the Affiliated Fashionists presented here this morning.

The American Jewish Tercentenary, commemorating the 300th anniversary of Jewish settlement in this country, was formally proclaimed yesterday at a special ceremony at Congregation Shearith Israel, Central Park West at Seventieth Street.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, July 5 (AP) -- Six United States soldiers and a captain on leave were reported today to have been seized by the Communist Czechoslovak border police when they strolled too close to the Iron Curtain.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 5 -- The New York Air National Guard is to start Saturday its use of the state's new $4,000,000 permanent air training site at Hancock Field here.
Venezuelans of disparate political views observed their country's 145th independence day yesterday by honoring its liberator, Simon Bolivar.

A plainclothes policeman's attempt to track down dealers in illegal firecrackers led yesterday to a furious ten-minute gun battle in front of 525 Macon Street in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

The only book published today is Robert St. John's new work, entitled "Through Malan's Africa." It is a firsthand report on the various warring factions in the Union of South Africa. Published by Doubleday, it sells for $3.95.
The United States Rubber Company has announced the development of a product which the concern said "may break the bottleneck that has prevented the widespread use of rubber roads."
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Prominent members of both major parties are embroiled in an angry argument over foreign policy, but in point of fact the two parties are not nearly as divided as they sound.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Following are tables listing the votes of the Representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut and of all Senators up for re-election, apart from those so newly in office as to have little record, on the major issues of the session of Congress:
WESTBURY, L. I., July 5 (AP) -- Adio Abe, 5-year-old bay owned by J. U. Sto. Marie of Quebec, and driven by Jimmy Jordan, won the Independence Day Mile Pace in 2:02 2/5 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

If the teen-agers emulate their elders it is safe to assume that they are interested in diets, or at least are curious about them. This assumption has led the Formfit Company of Chicago, a large manufacturer of foundation garments, to publish a twelve-page pamphlet called "Calorie Counters."
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- The Bureau of Land Management said today it would offer a ten-acre tract in Kern County, Calif., for sodium leasing through competitive bidding here July 21.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 5 (AP) -- Stenographer, highly regarded candidate for the Hambletonian, owned by Max Hempt of Mechanicsburg, Pa., won the $17,900 Coaching Club Trotting Oaks in straight heats today as Historic Track opened its 100th anniversary meeting.

Never again. The same as the last time, never again. It is all very well to get away for a while, and travel is broadening. But not on a long week-end; never again. Too many of those who clearly should have remained at home are out being broadened.
CHICAGO, July 5 -- Today's holiday receipts of 21,000 head of cattle were the biggest for any July session since 1946.
SAN SALVADOR, July 5 -- President Oscar Osorio of El Salvador hailed today the Guatemalan accord he helped to forge last week. He said it was of greatest importance to Central America.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 5 -- The American Civil Liberties Union charged today that William Wadman, University of California security officer, was playing the role of "a 'thought policeman', in that he checks on the opinions and associations of faculty members."

Assemblyman Julius J. Gans, dean of the Bronx Democratic delegation in the State Legislature, has been designated to run for City Court justice in the Bronx this fall. His designation is subject to approval in the Democratic primary on Sept. 14.
Livable rooms planned for limited space make up the theme of a series of settings on view at Gimbels. Six decorators have arranged them, each taking a different approach to the problem.

KEYPORT, N. J., July 5 -- Seasoned campaigners of the outboard world of old-time hydroplanes, the original racing flotilla long before the newer upstarts of stock and modified utilities were created, had a gala reunion and regatta this afternoon in one of North Jersey's busiest seaports.

LONDON, July 5 -- The British Government will deal with the new junta that is ruling Guatemala on a de facto basis until its constitutional position becomes clear, Selwyn Lloyd, Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, told the House of Commons today.

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York lifted its assets and deposits on June 30 from comparative figures three months and a year ago, according to the midyear condition statement issued for publication today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 5 -- Synthetic textile fibers are giving natural fibers ever-increasing competition in world markets, according to a report issued by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations.

Tax reductions on investment income were pictured in a report yesterday as giving greater stimulus to long-term economic growth and employment than would result from tax cuts on consumer income. The study, entitled "Tax Reduction as a Stimulus to Employment and Economic Growth," was released by the National Association of Manufacturers.
White Skies once again demonstrated his top class as a sprinter by winning the $62,300 Carter Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The Federation of American Scientists called upon President Eisenhower today to name a special board to study the Government's program for safeguarding secrets.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- An intensified Communist offensive for men's minds is indicated in the vast amounts of political propaganda dispatched from behind the Iron Curtain for delivery in the United States.

City firemen ran into an Iron Curtain last night at the north-west corner of Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street. The corner is the site of a five-story mansion that houses the Soviet delegates to the United Nations.
Fourth of July travelers streamed back home yesterday after a three-day holiday in which they kept the traffic death toll well below expectations.
LONDON, July 5 -- Britain, acutely conscious of her vulnerability to atomic attack, will designate a commander in chief for civil defense to make plans in peace time, Parliament was told today.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Senator William F. Knowland announced today that a bipartisan Senate bloc was studying three possible courses of action to prevent admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

MOSCOW, July 5 -- Trofim D. Lysenko's theory of species formation by environmental means is characterized as "unsubstantiated and essentially mistaken" by the Journal of General Biology, an organ of the Soviet Academy of Sciences.
A bill of three one-act plays by Paul Green, entitled "Salvation on a String," will open at 8 o'clock tonight at the Theatre de Lys, 121 Christopher Street.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 5 (UP) -- Former President Truman, who hopes to leave the hospital in ten days, spent two hours away from his bed today and gave himself a manicure to while away the time.
The election of eleven new directors of the Ctiizens Housing and Planning Council of New York, Inc., was announced yesterday.

SOUTHPORT, England, July 5 -- As the wind blew cold, then warm, off the Irish Sea, more than 300 competitors -- the largest field ever -- teed off today in the first of two qualifying rounds for the British golf open championship on the Royal Birkdale and Hillside courses.

LITCHFIELD, Conn., July 5 -- One of the favorite topics here-abouts is Litchfield. This subject, which seems to have turned every Litchfieldian into a local historian, receives added interest at this time of year when some of the fine old houses are opened to the public.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy returned to the Capitol today after a seventeen-day vacation and promised to cooperate in the Hoover Commission's study of the Central Intelligence Agency.
OKLAHOMA CITY, July 6 (AP) -- Senator Robert S. Kerr took a 13,000-vote lead over former Gov. Roy J. Turner tonight in Oklahoma's Democratic primary election for the Senate.

SOUTHPORT, England, July 6 -- Norman Von Nida, 37-year-old Australian open champion, toured the Hillside course in 67 strokes today and took the lead with 137 in qualifying for the British open golf tournament.

HONG KONG, July 6 -- A projected railway bridge over the Yangtze at Wuhan [cross on map] will have a main span 3,760 feet long. The total length of the approach spans and connecting lines will be more than eight miles.

Chih Ku Chang, a Chinese resident of Los Angeles, was held in $25,000 bail here yesterday on a charge of grand larceny. The case is linked with the activities of Lieut. Gen. P. T. Mow, former Washington representative of the Chinese Nationalist Air Force, who was ousted when he failed to account for $6,368,503 of the funds entrusted to him.
CHICAGO, July 6 -- The country's air line industry soon will be free of Government subsidies and within twenty-five years will have paid back all the grants given in the last quarter century.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., July 6 -- This pleasant island has become established as the "light tackle" striped bass center through the efforts of Leo Garceau and his ten-pound-test line. However, surfcasters from a half dozen states have been trying to steal his laurels.

Thus we slam the door after our cousins, or crack the whip over their backs. House members said, according to a July 1 Associated Press story, that the answer of Congress to Eden's proposal was that not one penny of an 800-million-dollar fund should be used on behalf of Governments which accept his suggestion of non-aggression pacts with Red China.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 6 -- Dr. Lewis Webster Jones, president of Rutgers University, announced today the appointment of Wherry E. Zingg as registrar of the university and of Dr. Ralph R. Shaw as Professor of Library Service in the university's Graduate School of Library Service.
Alfredo Antonini led the Stadium Symphony Orchestra at Lewisohn Stadium last evening in a concert that featured the first performance there of a Symphony in C major by Muzio Clementi.
HARTSDALE, N. Y., July 6 -- The top favorites in the men's New York State championship moved ahead today on the courts of the County Tennis Club of Westchester.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that its investment in surplus farm commodities under price Support programs totaled $6,109,295,000 on May 31, a decline of $79,443,000 since April 30.

Tallying of the 25,000 votes cast in the election of officers of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., began yesterday afternoon in the Straubenmuller Textile High School, 351 West Eighteenth Street.
TORONTO, July 6 (Canadian Press) -- A Canadian has beaten a Russian grand master of chess.
MADRID, July 6 (AP) -- A strong Spanish financial group may take over the copper mines of Rio Tinto, southern Spain, from the British Rio Tinto Mining Company, Ltd., it was announced last night.
Life scarcely was worth living in Brooklyn last night.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Foreign Operations Administration announced today that it had sold $6,000,000 worth of surplus butter to Great Britain and called it the biggest such overseas sale ever made.
The reduction in the luxury excise tax from 20 to 10 per cent and the cool weather played major parts in shaping business in May for department stores in the Second Federal Reserve District.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., July 6 (AP) -- Frank Hull, president of the International Brotherhood of Operative Potters, A. F. L., said today "foreign made pottery is gradually exterminating the American dinnerware industry."
A report yesterday by the regional Red Cross blood program shows that 161,614 pints of blood were contributed in the fiscal year ended June 30. The quota was 160,000 pints.
ALBANY, July 6 (AP) -- Members of the Cement, Lime and Gypsum Workers Union, A. F. L., trooped back to work at eight plants today after settlement of a two-month strike.

Round-the-clock inspection of inbound vessels and planes in the Port of New York moved a step nearer realization yesterday with the passage by the House of Representatives of a measure providing overtime payments for the Quarantine Inspection Service of the United States Public Health Service.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Wheat prices showed surprising strength today in view of the large receipts at primary points, and the rapid piling up of visible stocks. The upturn attracted profit taking, causing temporary recession from the tops, but late buying was active.

A MAN from Mars or from across the seas could probably never quite understand the deep feeling that runs among partisans in this city when the Giants and Dodgers face each other in a ball park. Even professional men with yards of college degrees are subject to it.

Potato futures continue to move into new high ground on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Yesterday, the fourth most active day of the year, prices rose 3 to 7 points on 949 car lots. There was short covering and new buying induced by reports of decreased acreage and poor weather.

In a letter printed in The Times on July 1 from Owen B. Hunt, president of the American Anti-Vivisection Society, it is stated that "pet owners should be informed, therefore, that in giving animals to the A. S. P. C. A. shelters they may be surrendering the pets not to good homes but for experiment and all it implies."
WASHINGTON, July 6 (UP) -- Senate and House Democrats today attacked President Eisenhower for directing the Atomic Energy Commission to sign a power contract with a private company.
Managements of representative first-run theatres in the midtown area reported generally excellent attendance over the holiday week-end, with new house records established in some cases.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 6 -- The chairman of the Native Labor Board, S. D. Mentz, ordered 7,000 Negro dock workers today to get out of their living quarters in Durban. The Negroes had struck for a rise of $1.47 daily or 18 cents an hour.

The National Urban League said yesterday that it had received no response to a letter sent June 18 to President Eisenhower requesting a "White House Conference" on racial discrimination in the housing field.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 -- Two rolling earthquakes, eleven hours apart with a series of minor tremors between, shook northern California and Nevada today.

NO matter how many exhibitions one has seen of work by Paul Klee, comes another and one is pretty sure to discover something new and remark, "I didn't know he did anything like this!" That is likely to happen to anyone except the most confirmed Kleeophile at the show of thirty prints, chiefly early, which opens today in a third-floor gallery at the Museum of Modern Art.
Mayor Wagner expressed hope yesterday that band concerts in Battery Park and elsewhere in the city would stimulate interest in "live" music.

The Russian chess players, who gained a 20-12 victory over the United States recently, clinched the initial honors against a British team in the first of two matches at Caxton Hall, Westminster, according to a report received yesterday from London.

Bicarb made it two in a row by taking the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The humorously named 4-year-old colt. a son of Half Crown and Brides Biscuit, scored by a length over William Noble's South Point in the mile-and-a-sixteenth event, called the Brighton Beach Purse.

PARIS, July 6 -- Plans to set up an international institute charged with taking education out of its "ivory tower" and adapting it to modern living were among the major accomplishments of an international seminar on education, which closed today.

HANOI, Vietnam, July 6 -- Losing little time in exploiting their new control over the lower Red River delta, the Communist-led Vietminh insurgents already have started moves to filter their regular troops into the contracted French perimeter from the southern zone recently abandoned by the French High Command.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives released today, eleven months after they were submitted, eight reports by a subcommittee appointed to investigate the Justice Department.
BERKELEY, Calif., July 6 (UP) -- Three hundred forest and brush fires will be set deliberately in Southern California in the next three months.

DETROIT, July 6 (AP) -- Virgil Trucks, a burly 35-year-old Alabamian, allowed just one hit -- a third-inning single by Harvey Kuenn -- as he pitched the injury-riddled Chicago White Sox to a 4-to-0 victory over the Detroit Tigers today.
The Chase National Bank improved its asset and deposit position on June 30 from the corresponding figures three months and a year ago.

June was the biggest month on record for long-term financing by state and local governments. According to The Daily Bond Buyer, bond issues totaling $805,089,791 were sold by state and municipal governments last month.

High school freshmen, so often the picture of brash self-confidence, share many of the fears of the nursery school child, according to a study reported by the National Association for Mental Health in the current issue of its quarterly publication, Understanding the Child.
Maceo A. Thomas, 57-year-old salesman and real estate broker, was sworn in yesterday as foreman of the July Bronx grand jury. He is the first Negro to be named to such a post in the county's history.

TOKYO, July 6 (Reuters) -- Political disturbances, increasing bankruptcies and general unrest are attributed here partly to violent fluctuations in the Japanese economy in the last three or four years.
Whitey Ford is a fellow who operates on the principle that one good turn deserves another.
CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves scored eleven runs in the first three innings, and breezed to a 14-to-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.
STAMFORD, Conn., July 6 -- Proposals for an ultramodern million dollar edifice were approved today by the congregation of the First Presbyterian Church.
Upsurges in aircraft, steel, chemical and radio - television stocks yesterday brought the rest of the market up with them and resulted in a broad general advance to new high ground.

LONDON, July 6 -- The British Government fought off a Labor Opposition attack in Parliament tonight on the allegedly dilatory and ineffective handling of its overseas information program. The Government won the debate 280 to 264.
Vacation schedule in steel mills and the Independence Day holiday were expected to cut the nation's steel production sharply this week.

MADRID, July 6 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco called upon the Western world today to launch a complete economic boycott of the Soviet Union and other Communist-dominated nations. This, he said, is a sure way to thwart Moscow's warlike preparations and "aggressive plans."
Gazpacho. (1) Disk made of bread, oil, vinegar, onions, salt and red pepper, mixed together in water. (2) Crumbs of bread fried in a pan.

MOSCOW, July 6 -- The Communist youth newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda criticized plays, movies, popular songs, radio performers and advertisements that concentrate the attention of young people on drinking.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The cult of the paid informer is growing in the Federal Government.
CAIRO, July 6 -- The discoverer of a solar ship of Cheops believes two more lie sealed on the north side of the Great Pyramid in the Giza plateau.

It is certainly a mark of the times when a simple act of justice, such as the return of private property seized during the war, is spoken of as though it were a conspiracy. Belle M. Zeck, in a letter to you published June 30, speaks critically of the proposal for return as a "powerful movement afoot * * * about which the American taxpayers ought to be informed."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 6 -- Otto Preminger, the director-producer, and F. Hugh Herbert, the writer, expect to be represented on Broadway again next season with a new play, "Filumena Marturano." It is described as a comedy and was written by Eduardo De Filippo. Mr. Herbert has begun work on the translation of the play from the Italian. It has been seen in Italy, France and Germany.
Six South African farmers -- three men and three women -- left for England yesterday after a twenty-two-day, cross-country tour of American agricultural facilities.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Eisenhower Administration apparently is attempting to slow down a Republican movement for withdrawal from the United Nations if Communist China is admitted.
SEOUL, Korea, June 22 -- South Korea's policemen are probably the young republic's most unpopular public servants. There are obvious reasons for this widespread sentiment among the Korean people.
ALBANY, July 6 -- James R. Macduff, state motor vehicle commissioner, predicted today that registrations would reach a record high of more than 4,500,000 before the end of 1954.

GUATEMALA, July 6 -- All property belonging to the most prominent figures of the overthrown regime of Jacobo Arbenz Guzman was frozen today by official decree. The order included cash, stocks and bonds.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., July 7 -- Mrs. Bernard Freeman of Inwood and Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood today won the qualifying medal in the eighth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's four-ball best-ball championship.

OTPAWA, July 6 -- United States officials who had discussed their country's participation in the St. Lawrence Seaway returned to Washington tonight fully apprised of the difficulties that lay in the way of the proposed partnership with Canada.

ST. LOUIS, July 6 (UP) -- Gerry Staley pitched a nine-hit game and Stan Musial batted in two runs with a pair of singles tonight to pace the St. Louis Cardinals to a 6-to-0 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., July 6 -- Troops from the New York City area today continued their field training under battle conditions at near-by Camp Drum.

CINCINNATI, July 6 (AP) -- The rosters for the 1954 major league All-Star game were completed today as Walter Alston of Brooklyn, the only "freshman" manager to pilot a team in this competition, filled out the National League squad by selecting seven pitchers, two catchers, four outfielders and four infielders.

I was pleased to read a review of the census of foreign students in the United States in Benjamin Fine's June 27 column. This booklet, Education for One World, is published by the Institute of International Education. It may be obtained from the institute's offices at 1 East Sixty-seventh Street, New York City.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., July 6 (UP) -- Congress of Industrial Organization officials tonight called a strike for 9 A. M. tomorrow at Atomic Energy Commission plants here and in Paducah, Ky.

Community Opera, Inc., a group that has presented free operatic performances at the New York Historical Society and the Brooklyn Museum, canceled last night its projected six-week season of summer "dinner opera" at the Town Hall Club.
GENEVA, July 3 -- Italy may be about to get some economic breaks.

LONDON, July 6 -- Sir Winston Churchill returned from the United States today and sent a warm message to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer expressing pleasure that British and United States policy had "earned" the approval of the Western German Government.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The public went to bat today for fairer play in Congressional investigations.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- A former Information and Education officer told the committee today that he was a former Communist.

A wife's "inside story" of life with one of the world's great physicists will be issued in November by the University of Chicago Press under the title "Atoms in the Family: My Life With Enrico Fermi." The book has been written by Mrs. Laura Fermi, who describes their early years under the Fascists in Italy, her husband's winning of the Nobel Prize and their subsequent escape to the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Government announced plans today to buy 200,000 flasks of domestic and Mexican mercury at $225 a flask during the next three and one-half years. A flask contains seventy-six pounds of mercury.

In anticipation of a more powerful drive from abroad than ever before to seat Communist China in the United Nations a bipartisan bloc in Congress has begun a counter-drive to defeat such a move at any cost -- even at the cost of American withdrawal from the world organization and the risk of wrecking it.
OTTAWA, July 6 -- Charles E. Wilson, United States Secretary for Defense, arrived today for a series of informal talks with Canadian officials on common defense problems.
PARIS, July 6 -- Government circles reported tonight that Premier Pierre Mendes-France would tell the National Assembly tomorrow what he intended to do should he fail to get a cease-fire in Inochina.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 6 (AP) -- Brazil finished its 1953-54 coffee season with an unexpectedly high carry-over of nearly 3,100,000 bags, according to figures released today by the Brazilian Coffee Institute.

The United Electrical Workers, independent, accepted yesterday a pay increase averaging 5 cents an hour for its members in thirty-two plants of the General Electric Company. The union estimated that 30,000 workers were involved. The company put the number at 21,000.

Drawing again upon his extensive knowledge of the ancient Greek drama, Robinson Jeffers has fashioned "The Cretan Woman." It will be presented at 8:30 tonight for a limited engagement in the 182-seat air-cooled and refurbished Provincetown Playhouse in Greenwich Village.

A CRITIC once wrote of a new score, "It was not so bad as it sounded." Of Erik Chisholm's "Murder in Three Keys," which was unveiled by Punch Opera at the Cherry Lane Theatre last night, it may be said: It was better than it sounded.

Members of the newspaper paper handlers' union voted last night to reject the recommendations of a fact-finding panel but to accept a $3.75 package offer made by the publishers before the panel was created.

" SALVATION ON A STRING" is the collective title of the three short plays by Paul Green that opened last night at the Theatre de Lys in Greenwich Village. Mr. Green is a playwright of eminence, having enriched the Broadway stage with several interesting dramas, including his 1927 Pulitzer Prize winner, "In Abraham's Bosom."

The International Shoe Company of St. Louis, the world's largest shoe manufacturer, shows in its semi-annual report to May 31 a decline in sales from a year before but a 5 per cent increase in earnings, largely as a result of lower taxes.
The 1955 fiscal year, just starting, will witness the refinement and expansion of a new program for industrial mobilization planning, part of the military "New Look."
YONKERS, N. Y., July 6 -- Hope for a temporary reopening of the closed Alexander Smith carpet mill grew after a cordial union-management meeting here today.
The lean days seem to be over for a while for Gotham's department stores.

Discontinuation of rayon staple manufacturing at the Buffalo plant will not necessarily take the du Pont company out of staple production, according to a company spokesman. Experimental production will continue on the company's new rayon staple called No. 109, and larger output is possible in the event the product proves successful.
The potential for increased sales in drug stores in the years ahead is excellent, according to a report by A. C. Nielsen Company.

Russian child-care experts are making new demands for tightened parental discipline over preschool and first-grade youngsters. Excessive tolerance leads to selfishness, stubbornness and indolence, Soviet pedagogues warn. They advise stricter regulation of the child's daily life and earlier assignment of responsibilities.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 6 (AP) -- Pocahontas Boy, 4-year-old bay gelding owned by the Bergstrom stable of Westbury and driven by Dick Thomas, scored a nose victory over Prince Eton in 2:04 3/5 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

JACKSON, Mich., July 6 -- The birth of the Republican party in a grove of oak trees here 100 years ago was hailed today by Vice President Richard M. Nixon as an earnest to the world that Americans believed in the equality of man and would fight to preserve it.

The city began publication yesterday of a notice to the "heirs at law and next of kin" of Charles Morgan Sr. to remove his grave and those of his descendants from the Charles Morgan Sr. cemetery on Staten Island.

The mental state of Arnold Bernstein while in a Nazi prison in 1937 was again the subject of questioning in Federal Court yesterday in his $11,000,000 suit against the Holland-America Line. Mr. Bernstein completed seven and a half days of cross-examination at the morning session.

CHARLES DILLON STENGEL has a remarkable record as a world series manager, five consecutive victories and never a defeat. The Ol' Perfessor also has a remarkable record as an All-Star manager, four consecutive defeats and never a victory.
The Kings County District Attorney's office pressed yesterday its drive against illegal rates charged by auto repair servicemen and arrested the owner and foreman of a Brooklyn concern.
Two Philadelphia men were questioned yesterday about the disappearance of a Brooklyn man believed to have been murdered and robbed of $1 Monday night while he was surf fishing at Manhattan Beach.

BUFFALO, N. Y., July 6 (AP) -- Charles Fichtner, executive vice president of the Buffalo Chamber of Commerce, said tonight that the closing of du Pont rayon production here would result in an increase of about one-third of 1 per cent in factory unemployment in the Niagara Frontier.

CLEVELAND, July 6 (UP) -- The Cleveland Indians exploded for eleven runs in the first inning and Early Wynn pitched no-hit ball for the first seven innings tonight in an 11-to-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 -- World peace and good-will start not at the council table but in the home.
GENEVA, July 6 -- The early return of Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov here seemed to he presaged today by the arrival of four aircraft bringing subordinate Soviet personnel.
MOSCOW, July 6 -- Anton Chekhov's "The Sea Gull" has returned to the regular repertoire of the Moscow stage for the first time in many, many years.
The International Committee of Bankers on Mexico is about to dissolve after thirty-five years of negotiation and other activity related to the restoration of Mexican dollar bonds to a paying basis.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- George P. Monaghan, former New York Police Commissioner, was praised for fighting for his men but criticized for his zeal by a House Judiciary subcommittee in a report released today. Mr. Monaghan, the subcommittee said, "pressed hard -- in perfectly good faith -- to get something for his department to which it was not entitled."

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 6 (AP) -- Frank Ervin drove Child's Hanover, owned by K. D. Owen of Houston, to a track record for 2-year-old trotters today as the bay colt won the $8,000 E. H. Harriman Challenge Trophy race at Historic Track's Grand Circuit meeting.

July Fourth has passed, and though the accident toll did not reach the predicted figure it was unnecessarily and wastefully high. Most of the unfortunate New Yorkers who were killed or injured were given at one time a copy of a booklet which might have spared them had they remembered its contents.

BATON ROUGE, La., July 6 (AP) -- The Louisiana Legislature, first in the South to meet since the United States Supreme Court ruled against segregation, voted today to continue separate white and Negro schools by use of the state's inherent police power.
PARIS, July 6 (AP) -- The International Lawn Tennis Association decided today to modify the foot-fault rule which has been a source of dispute between the American and Australian Davis Cup teams.

BIRMINGHAM, England, July 6 (UP) -- Jaroslav Drobny, Lew Hoad of Australia and four Americans scored straight-set victories over British opponents today in the midland counties lawn tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Mrs. Theodore S. Chapman, new president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, said today that the average clubwoman's fear of isolationism was stronger even than her fear of the admission of Red China into the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (UP) -- Johnny Schmitz checked the Philadelphia Athletics on six hits tonight while the Washington Senators put together four hits for three runs in the sixth inning and a 5-2 victory.
The Rev. William Howard Melish described yesterday the role he played in the formation of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship.
SULAIMANIYA, Iraq, June 20 -- Kurdish nationalism, which has boiled over in violent rebellion four times in the last thirty-five years, has made an ominous swing to the left since World War II.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 6 -- The only important obstacle between Communist China and a seat in the United Nations is the wall of the United States' opposition.

From now until the middle of the month the outlook in this section of the country is for a substantial dose of heat and little rain. This isn't an unusual recipe for this time of year, of course, but the situation, according to a recent weather prognosis chart, is blacker -- or, rather, hotter -- than it would normally be expected to be.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, July 6 -- New Zealand has gone over the side of those supporting the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- President Eisenhower, back from a long week-end holiday, divided his time today between some pressing international problems and receiving visitors who brought invitations, greetings and gifts.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 6 -- The Soviet Union charged today that the United States was violating the agreement under which it holds the Marshall Islands as a trust by using the islands as proving grounds for hydrogen and atomic weapons.
Lions are in the streets. Here to see and be seen, they walk up and down, awaiting the opening of their annual convention today in Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Six North Atlantic Treaty nations will join forces this month in a major air-sea maneuver, called Exercise Haul, in the English Channel.
The swing is to larger families in New York City. The over-all birth rate last year was 42 per cent above 1940, but this does not tell the whole story.
On behalf of The Fifth Avenue Association, Inc., we wish to comment on your editorial of July 1 on the subject of compulsory off-street parking for new non-residential construction.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today that total business inventories decreased in May for the eighth straight month, but at the lowest rate of decline for the period.

The evangelist Billy Graham returned on the Queen Mary yesterday after a five-month tour of Great Britain and Western Europe. He said he had preached "old time religion" to 2,000,000 persons at 300 meetings and believed there was a spiritual reawakening in Britain and Europe that might prevent a third world war.

An inquiry into Fire Department building inspection methods has found "carelessness, negligence and a disregard of required duties on the part of chief officers, company officers and company building inspectors."
Democratic leaders have decided to take a state-wide poll of enrolled Democrats to help them select a candidate for Governor this fall. The poll is scheduled to start next week.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (UP) -- The House voted unanimously today to authorize honorary promotions to the rank of full general for eleven retired or deceased general officers of World War II.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, with prices unchanged to 18 points net lower than Friday.

With a month, more or less, to go, Congress still has time to complete a modest legislative record despite all the delays and digressions that this session has produced. The regular appropriation bills were out of the way by the beginning of the new fiscal year, which, in view of the history of the last few Congresses, is itself no mean achievement.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today to give the Federal Government authority to penalize "Communist - infiltrated" labor unions but not to outlaw them as proposed by the Eisenhower Administration.
Yma Sumac, Peruvian coloratura, was directed yesterday to appear at Ellis Island on Monday at 1 P. M. for a hearing before officials of the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (UP) -- The Government ended the 1954 fiscal year on June 30 with a deficit close to the Administration's advance estimate of $3,300,000,000.

Nearly sixteen years ago the Astronomical Division of the Soviet Academy of Sciences adopted scathing resolutions in condemnation of Einstein's theory of relativity. Though Trotzky had been banished, fear of him and his adherents was still rife. The resolutions declared that the theory of relativity was a glaring example of counter-revolutionary propaganda conceived by scoundrels.

PARIS, July 6 (Reuters) -- An exhibition of early paintings by Pablo Picasso, brought here from the Leningrad and Moscow Museums, was closed hurriedly today after a White Russian woman began legal action contending that she was their rightful owner.
PHILADELPHIA, July 6 (UP) -- Curt Simmons pitched the Phillies to a 3-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight. Philadelphia tallied only three times on seventeen hits.

LONDON, July 6 -- Prime Minister Churchill came home tonight with a cautious warning that he had not "entirely" ironed out his foreign policy disputes with President Eisenhower. But he emphasized "nothing comes before the true and lasting friendship between Britain and the United States."

YONKERS, July 6 -- Doug Turnesa, the Briar Hall pro, and William Griffin of Hudson River had the winning best-ball card of 29, 32 -- 61 in the proamateur competition staged by the Westchester Professional Golfers' Association at the Hudson River today.

The city of Schenectady announced plans yesterday for the sale of $1,900,000 of school bonds on July 15. Dated Aug. 1, 1954, the bonds will come due in annual installments on Aug. 1 from 1955 to 1959.

AS one deeply interested in Latin-American affairs I should like to express my warm appreciation of the way The Times has handled the Guatemala situation over the past weeks. Its articles and editorials have not only been objective and well-informed; they have penetrated beyond the mere face of the news and contributed to an understanding of the causes of the disturbance and the motivations of the personalities involved.

TRENTON, July 6 -- A general revision of New Jersey's method of investing state funds is expected shortly as an outgrowth of the continuing investigation into the financial manipulations of former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman.
The Sloan-Kettering Institute reported yesterday the development of a chemical compound that produced permanent cure of one type of transplanted cancer in 100 per cent of its trials on rats.

DUBLIN, July 6 (AP) -- Maureen Connolly, 19-yearold Wimbledon tennis champion, flew into Dublin at noon today and a few hours later gained the third round of the Irish lawn tennis championships with a 6-0, 6-2 victory over Ireland's E. Kirkpatrick.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (UP) -- The Senate approved today legislation creating two new assistant secretary posts in the Army, Navy and Air Force in an effort to improve civilian management of the military.

The Customs Service is moving to put eleven more translators on the job of examining increasing amounts of foreign Communist propaganda. The present staff of five now working in New York is inundated.
Two citations are on their way through diplomatic channels to Mrs. Gerda Freudmann, matron of the Jerusalem Animal Hospital, who stood by her charges during the recent Israeli-Jordanian hostilities.

Final figures on the federal budget for the fiscal year ended last Wednesday should be available within the next two weeks. But there is little reason to believe they will differ substantially from the last-minute approximation offered on June 30 by Secretary of the Treasury Humphrey in the course of a radio interview.

A Board of Higher Education trial committee was told yesterday that a Brooklyn College faculty member was promoted to a full professorship after he had admitted lying in 1941 about membership in the Communist party.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Doctor witnesses on Social Security disagreed sharply today on whether physicians should be taken into the Social Security system.

CLEVELAND, July 6 (UP) -- A 15-year-old boy who weighed nearly 300 pounds and stood six feet tall forced his way aboard a Mexico-bound American Airlines DC-6 here today and was shot and killed by the pilot when he ordered the crew at gunpoint to "take off for Mexico City."
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- If the present-day stocking doesn't wear as long, maybe it's because it's only half as strong.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (UP) -- Senate investigators were told today that the Army's Information and Education Service sent out material in 1945 praising the Chinese Communists as friends of the United States.

THIS morning's books are two Western, or, rather, Southwestern, novels written with a competence fairly unusual in the antique and somewhat battered tradition. One is "The Conquest of Don Pedro,"* by Harvey Fergusson, a New Mexican whose grandfather was a freighter on the Sante Fe Trail. The other is "Bigamy Jones," by Frank X. Tolbert, a fifth-generation Texan, which is just about as Texan as you can be, all things considered, isn't it?
WILMINGTON, Del., July 6 (AP) -- E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced today it planned to discontinue all rayon operations at its Buffalo, N. Y., plant.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 6 -- President Jose Figueres urged the establishment of an international body to control cocoa prices stabilize markets in a speech inaugurating the fifth Inter-American Cocoa Conference yesterday.
Advertising on the theme that its beer has more proteins and fewer calories has paid off for the G. Krueger Brewing Company.

KANSAS CITY, July 6 (AP) -- The peak of the 1954 wheat harvest was reflected in thousands of cars of grain jamming Kansas City rail terminals today. Receipts over the three-day holiday week-end totaled 2,420 cars -- 4,370,000 bushels. Earlier estimates had been that receipts might reach 3,000 to 3,500 cars for the period.
In the last five years newly developed lending techniques have channeled some $650,000,000 in bank and insurance company credit into the construction of foreign and domestic shipping.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Eric Johnston reported to President Eisenhower and Secretary of State John Foster Dulles today that Israel and Syria, Lebanon and Jordan had accepted the principle of international sharing of the water of the Jordan River in a unified development project.

A wide-open Democratic primary battle in Queens was assured yesterday. James A. Roe, the nominal county leader, met with a group of leaders still loyal to him and named a slate of candidates for party nominations to oppose the ticket set up last week by the faction seeking his ouster.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Air Force disclosed today that the XF-104, a lightweight jet fighter for which it held high hopes, had made its first flight last February over the Mojave Desert in California.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 6 -- Mario Puchez, 36-year-old member of the Italian team climbing Mount Godwin Austen, highest unconquered peak in the world, died of pneumonia June 21, according to a message brought to the base camp in Skardu today.
Historic Van Cortlandt Manor House at Croton - on - Hudson, called by historians one of the most important landmarks in the nation, will be restored to its eighteenth-century appearance.

IF Western pictures in black and white have proved a television fascination for youngsters, wait until they see them in color. With heroes and villains decked out in spectacular shirts and the ranges and hills shown in natural tints, the horse operas should be enjoying still another lease on life.

TOKYO, July 6 -- Japan has announced that the waters around the United States atomic testing ground near Bikini Atoll are safe for navigation. Little danger exists from radioactivity in fish and marine life there, the Government reported today.
MEXICO CITY, July 6 -- Mexico is determined to abide by established principles of political asylum in the case of the hundreds Guatemalans sheltered in her embassy in Guatemala.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Former President Hoover set up a task force today to study "all phases of overseas economic operations" by United States Government agencies.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 7 -- Atomic production workers ignored President Eisenhower's request for them to stay on the job at Oak Ridge and Paducah, while a fact-finding board looked into the dispute.

Among the greater glories of our two-party political system are certain apparent paradoxes in the nomenclature and traditions of both parties. In 1792, for example, the term Republican was interchangeable with Democratic-Republican; moreover, it was introduced by none other than Thomas Jefferson, now held in hallowed memory by the Democrats, who wanted to oppose the conservative measures of the Federalists under Washington, Adams and Hamilton.
The Sinclair Oil Corporation announced yesterday that it had received three bids from investment banking groups for its block of 765,721 shares of Pioneer Natural Gas Company.
Arthur P. Hassell has been appointed a director of the Citizens Trust Company of Summit, N. J. Mr. Hassell is merchandise manager of the home furnishings division of B. Altman Co.

Fifteen hundred visas for immigrants under the Refugee Relief Act of 1953 were issued last week, Scott McLeod, State Department administrator of security and consular affairs, announced here yesterday.

The signing of a long-term lease on a branch store to be built in Levittown Shopping Center in Levittown, L. I., was announced yesterday by Mays Department Stores of Brooklyn. Space also has been taken by shoe and apparel firms in other store centers in the area.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower invited sixteen industrialists, Government officials and others to a stag dinner at the White House tonight.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 7 (AP) -- A repeat battle of the millionaires was in prospect for Oklahoma voters July 27 as today's tabulations of Tuesday's primary balloting showed Roy J. Turner had forced Senator Robert S. Kerr into a runoff for the Democratic nomination for Senator.

The three-masted schooner Vema, Columbia University's geological research vessel, sailed yesterday from Piermont, N. Y. A two-and-a-half-month voyage across the Atlantic will cake the vessel to the Azores Islands, French Morocco and Lisbon, Portugal.

PARIS, July 7 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France told the National Assembly today that if a ceasefire in Indochina was not obtained by July 20 he would urge reinforcing the French Army there with conscripts from France.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 (UP) -- Joey Giardello, Philadelphia middleweight, fought through the blood of a cut left cheekbone tonight to win a one-sided decision over Billy Kilgore of Miami in a ten-round bout that saw Giardello vainly trying to knock out a tiring opponent in the final minute.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today increased its buying prices 1 cent a pound for surplus cheese and nonfat dry milk, effective Monday. Buying prices for surplus butter were not changed.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 7 (UP) -- Top-seeded Pat Stewart of Indianapolis was upset by Mrs. Juliana Copeland in the Western tennis tournament today as the favorites in the men's singles advanced against tough competition from juniors.
The recent sales of another modern Norwegian freighter and two British cargo ships, one of them launched this year, to the Soviet Union were reported here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The United States protested "in the strongest terms" today against Communist Czechoslovakia's "abduction" of seven American soldiers and demanded their immediate return.
CINCINNATI, July 7 (AP) -- Members of the Rubber Workers Union, C. I. O., walked off the job at two Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company plants tonight and planned to quit work at others in eight cities.
GENEVA, July 7 -- The decisive phase of the Indochina negotiations is expected to begin the middle of next week.
After a day of wild swings that virtually canceled each other, the stock market lost support in the closing half-hour yesterday and ended with a moderate net loss.
Amid pageantry, a parade and a reminder that they were free men, delegates to the thirty- seventh annual convention of Lions International become honorary New Yorkers yesterday.

The Federation Bank and Trust Company reported as of June 30 total deposits of $64,062,956 and total assets of $69,768,692, compared, respectively, with $61,051,680 and $66,598,962 on March 31. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $13,467,128 against $14,248,697 holdings of United States Government securities to $22,600,685, against $17,610,540, and loans and discounts to $24,918,442, against $25,388,858.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Samuel Cardinal Stritch, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, today forbade Catholic clergy and laity to participate in the World Council of Churches meeting which opens in Evanston, Ill. Aug. 15.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 7 -- Thailand served formal notice today that she intends to recall the United Nations. General Assembly to consider the danger of the spread of the war in Indochina.

LONDON, July 7 -- Sir Winston Churchill declared today that the United States and Britain were "so firmly based on fundamental principles" that there was no chance of their differing on the identity of the sovereign states now in bondage.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Eisenhower believes his legislative fortunes have taken such a turn for the better that he will be glad to make his program a campaign issue this fall.

DANVERS, Mass., July 7 -- Mass production of color television picture tubes providing images virtually as large as those seen on present black-and-white receivers was demonstrated here today by the tube manufacturing subsidiary of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

A heavenly display was staged yesterday for the special benefit of Emperor Haile - Selassie of Ethiopia after he completed a tour of the American Museum of Natural History. He was accompanied by his son and two granddaughters.

WAYLAND, Mass., July 7 (AP) -- The School Committee tonight dismissed Miss Anne Hale Jr., second grade teacher, a self-admitted former Communist who says she is descended from John Alden, the Pilgrim.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., July 7 -- A four-way tie for first place marked the first round of the thirty-fourth annual New Jersey State open golf championship over the Essex County course today. The lead was shared by two amateurs and two professionals at 73.
