Mays Department Store, Inc., Brooklyn, has leased a partially completed building in the Levittown Shopping Center and plans to open there about Aug. 1, 1955. The building, formerly leased by another New York City specialty store, will have 180,000 square feet when completed.
TRENTON, July 7 -- State Treasurer Archibald S. Alexander and Banking Commissioner Warren N. Gaffney met here today to discuss how banking and auditing procedures may be strengthened in the state.
As a result of governmental and private financing in this country after World War II, more ship tonnage was acquired by private operators than in any other comparable time in maritime history.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Federal Trade Commission ordered the Harley-Davidson Motor Company today to discontinue practices which it said tended to stifle competition and create a monopoly in the sale of motorcycles and related equipment.

JERUSALEM, July 7 -- A fourth Israeli sector victim of last week's shooting died in Jerusalem last night. He was Rabbi Moshe Goldberg; a delegate from France to the Agudath Israel World Congress, which is meeting here.

A monthly dividend of 15 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Aug. 20, has been authorized by directors of the Winn Lovett Grocery Company, it was announced yesterday. The company previously paid a dividend of 11 cents a share at monthly intervals.

The majority and minority leaders in the United States Senate have declared that if Red China is admitted to the United Nations they will advocate withdrawal from that organization. The issue thus raised is nonpartisan.

Philip J. Cruise, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, announced yesterday that applications for 469 low-rent apartments in the first section of Jefferson Houses would be distributed starting at 9 A. M. today.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 7 (AP) -- The historic Dickerson Cup, first major preview for trotting's $115,000 Hambletonian Stake on Aug. 4, went to the weatherman today as rain halted racing at the Historic Track after Lord Pick had won the opening heat and Cronus had equaled a record in taking the second.

The new warehouse and office building of the J. L. Hammett Company in Union, N. J., has been purchased by the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company which has leased the property back to the seller. The transaction was negotiated by Stevens Perkins as brokers.

THE picture had become a standard part of his traveling equipment. Whenever John Blanks Campbell moved from one track to another, the picture went with him to hang on the wall behind his desk. It was the reproduction of the photo finish in the Carter Handicap of 1944. For Campbell it was better than a diploma.
The Eagle-Picher Company has offered to buy all of the capital stock of Fabricon Products, Inc., for $9,900,000, it was announced yesterday.

Stockholders of Industrial Brownhoist Corporation of Bay City, Mich., at a meeting here yesterday, approved merging the company into the Penn-Texas Corporation, formerly the Pennsylvania Coal and Coke Company. Under the merger terms, approved by directors of both companies on June 22, one share of Industrial Brownhoist will be exchanged for one share of Penn-Texas Corporation.

SOUTHPORT, England, July 7 -- A pair of middle-aged professionals from the English county of Kent, Sam King, 43, and Bill Spence, 42, posted 69's to lead the first round of the eighty-third British open golf tournament by a stroke today.

The letters you have published suggesting ways in which to bring our court calendars up to date are quite interesting, but I believe that members of the bar and the bench have deluded themselves into concluding that our courts are primarily for the purpose of "settling cases."

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Eisenhower Administration has set next Feb. 1 as a target date for starting negotiations on a multilateral trade agreement that eventually could bring Japan into full trading partnership with the rest of the free world.
The police continued their search yesterday for a Brooklyn man believed to have been murdered, robbed and thrown in the Atlantic Ocean as he was fishing Monday night at Manhattan Beach.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 7 (AP) Ngo Dinh Diem, the Vietnamese Premier, said today he could not accept the French withdrawal from the southern Red River delta as final. He said he would demand that the area be returned to his Government's control.

Hardy is the word for the Lions. Fifteen thousand members of Lions International proved the point yesterday when they paraded down Fifth Avenue for four hours in a pelting rain. Less sturdy citizens took for shelter. came down Fifth Avenue with rhythmic step undaunted by the weather. There were sixty floats, thirty-nine bands and twenty drum and bugle corps.

Kansas City, Mo., sold yesterday $18,700,000 of airport revenue bonds to finance construction of an overhaul base at the ity's Mid-Continent International Airport. The facilities are to be used by Trans World Airlines, Inc.
GENEVA, July 7 -- The United Nations Secretary General warned today that the world was "skating on thin economic ice."
HARTFORD, July 7 -- The two-day Republican State Convention will open here tomorrow night with Gov. John Davis Lodge assured of renomination to a second four-year term.

The closed Alexander Smith carpet factory in Yonkers will reopen Monday for at least three months. The stay of execution for the doomed mill may be lengthened to six months if it takes that long to complete work already on the looms and to dismantle the plant equipment.
LONDON, July 7 -- The first "flying saucer" of the season fascinated Londoners during their lunch hour today. Thousands craned their necks on sidewalks and from windows and rooftops.

The law provides that pedestrians always have the right of way on the highways of New York State. This, of course, is little consolation to anyone hit by a car. The recent changeover of several north-south avenues to one-way thoroughfares prescribes extra caution to pedestrians who are not satisfied to rest on their rights.

Criminal informations were filed yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court by United States Attorney Leonard P. Moore against twenty-seven alleged bookmakers and lottery operators. They were accused of failing to register with the Government as licensed gamblers and to pay the $50 fee.

A five-horse sprint was the feature at Aqueduct yesterday, and in it the 4-year-old gelding Haviland scored for the third straight time. He was the $9.30-for-$2 second choice and he clicked off the six furlongs in a brisk 1:12.

ST. LOUIS, July 7 (UP) -- Peanuts Lowrey's two-out pinch single in the eleventh inning scored Rip Repulski with the winning run tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals downed the Cincinnati Redlegs, 5 -- 4.

The sale of 14,600,000 pounds of butter to Great Britain earlier this week will have no effect on domestic butter prices, dealers said yesterday. This transaction and recent sales of about 160,000 pounds of butter to other countries will not relieve for long the heavy surplus in the United States, industry spokesmen said.
Shelley Winters will be starred in William Marchant's dramatic comedy, "Faster! Faster!," which is scheduled for production here this season by Jay Julien.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today an order barring five companies from combining to fix prices and restrict competition in the coin lock field.

A new split-level dwelling at 239 Mayflower Avenue in New Rochelle, N. Y., has been purchased by Walter R. Schmidt through the Thomas B. Sutton Corporation, broker. The house has five rooms, two baths and a built-in garage. It is one of fourteen ranch and split-level models being built there by Danfield Homes, Inc.

Mrs. Conrad W. Thibault and Mrs. John C. Wood gave a luncheon yesterday in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Mrs. Elizabeth N. Graham, honorary chairman of the executive committee for the autumn benefit in behalf of the Travelers Aid Society of New York.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 7 -- A Chinese Nationalist Marine captain asked today for a "fair hearing" by the State or Justice Department to bar his return to Formosa and what he viewed as certain death.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Employment rose 989,000 from May to June, most of it on farms. The rise in unemployment was negligible -- not more than 42,000. After allowance for seasonal factors, the downtrend in nonfarm employment appeared almost completely halted in June.
The Rev. William Howard Melish denied emphatically yesterday that he was or even had been a member of the Communist party.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Eisenhower denounced Red China today and said he would fight to the last minute to keep it out of the United Nations.

Cocoa futures rallied yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange, closing the cent-a-pound limit higher in all positions. Volume was 265 contracts. Short covering following the limit decline on Tuesday helped raise prices.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- A hard election-year struggle over the old question of Communist China is engaging the Senate and may characterize the whole final phase of this Congress.

HANOI, Vietnam, July 7 -- Fifty French B-26 planes bombed Vietminh-infested villages north of Hungyen yesterday. The attack, it was announced today, was made to protect French Union engineers repairing the broken north-south road leading to that isolated Red River town.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., July 7 -- There are several things worse than being isolated on an island during bad weather while on vacation. One of them is being on the same island, during the same weather conditions, with a fishing column to write.

NEWARK, July 7 -- Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate for United States Senator from New Jersey, declared in a statement today that Congressional investigations under Senator Joseph R. McCarthy were "reckless and unfair."
Elegance, for those who want a simple or a lavish wedding, was stressed in the collection of fall bridal gowns shown at Macy's yesterday morning.
In a rain-splashed contest that saw the hitters on both sides and the grounds crew comport themselves with distinction, the Yankees swamped the Red Sox, 17 -- 9, at the Stadium yesterday.
Operators and investors figured in several deals involving multi-family buildings reported yesterday in the Bronx.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 7 -- The Communist China issue pinched the British today in a diplomatic nutcracker.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The case of Captain Hsuan has posed a delicate problem of diplomacy between the United States and the Formosa Government.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 7 -- Diet rather than weight was declared today to be the probable cause of degenerative diseases, such as high blood pressure, which afflict the old.
VIENNA, July 7 (AP) -- Austria told world Jewish leaders today that she was unable to make any new proposals before autumn for a settlement of Jewish claims.
DETROIT, July 7 -- Barring unforeseen eventualities, the automobile industry is looking forward at midyear to one of its best twelve months of export business since World War II.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 7 -- A proposal that four apparel unions in the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations pool their organizing resources was made here today.
OTTAWA, July 7 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian grain crops are showing sharp variations in development and rust now is emerging as a danger.
Design inspiration for fall millinery collections shown here yesterday devised from fashions of two decades and several millenniums ago.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce urged the Senate Finance Committee today to blanket all aged persons under the Social Security system regardless of whether they had contributed to it.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., July 7 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood and Mrs. Bernard Freeman of Inwood, continued their fine golf as the first round of the eighth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association four-ball best-ball tournament was completed today.
WESTBURY, L. I., July 7 (AP) -- Patrick Primrose, 7-year-old brown gelding making his first start at Roosevelt Raceway, won the Glen Head Pace in 2:05 4/5 tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (UP) -- The Harry S. Truman Library will be built on a 13 1/2-acre site in the northern section of Independence, Mo., home town of the former President, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Eisenhower said today that he viewed acceptance of the principle of flexible farm price supports by the House of Representatives as "a great and sweeping victory."

DUBLIN, July 7 (AP) -- Maureen Connolly, the Wimbledon champion from San Diego, Calif., moved into the semi-finals of the Irish lawn tennis championship today with a 6-3, 6-3 victory over Miss E. F. Lombard of Ireland.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Wheat prices soared again today, largely on heavy buying by mills, which were reported to have sold up to 10,000,000 sacks of flour during the last two days. This is the heaviest flour business in more than two years.

LONDON, July 7 -- Aneurin Bevan's bid for a greater share in the direction of the Labor party received a serious setback today. Britain's second and third largest unions chose Hugh Gaitskell as their nominee for treasurer over the leader of Labor's radical left wing.
The Russian chess team clinched the honors in the two-match series with the British by gaining an unsurmountable lead in the second round, according to a report from London yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- The report by the Department of Agriculture on today's livestock markets follows:

NEW DELHI, India, July 7 -- If powerful nations pursuing different economic and ideological systems refuse to recognize the principle of "peaceful coexistence," the only alternative is war, according to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru.

A national real estate and brokerage concern lost its license in this state yesterday on charges that it collected advance fees from property owners but made no real effort to sell the properties listed.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The United States and Britain began today drafting plans for a Southeast Asian defense alliance, asked ten days ago by President Eisenhower and British Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Senate-House conferees agreed today to liberalize money limits on Government-insured loans in home sales.

DALLAS, July 7 (AP) -- E. E. (Buddy) Fogelson, Dallas oil man who is the husband of Greer Garson, the screen actress, was revealed today as one of a group of wealthy men backing a drive to bring a major league franchise to Dallas.
MIAMI, July 7 -- The Turkish goodwill ship Tarsus, a 10,000-ton "floating exposition" of Turkish products made with United States aid, received a gay and noisy welcome here today.

An important hat trend was illustrated yesterday at the Fashion Group Fall Millinery Meeting held at the Astor Hotel. Hats that snugly covered the head were seen in casual slough versions, berets, deep turbans, and profiles tilted far over the ear.
OTTAWA, July 7 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's trade with the world dropped to a four-year low in the first four months of 1954.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization today lifted its goal for expansion of the country's aluminum forging capacity by 108,250,000 pounds of forgings annually.

CREDIT the newly formed Players Theatre with courage, enterprise and the good sense to give New York its first public hearing of Robinson Jeffers' "The Cretan Woman.'' For, as a reviewer for this newspaper remarked after seeing a production of the play by Washington's Arena Stage back in May, this is a script worth doing by an off-Broadway group.
LONDON, July 7 -- Stock market prices continued to advance today. Government funds strengthened and industrials followed suit, making extensive gains despite some late profit taking.

WASHINGTON, July 7 - President Eisenhower said today it would be most embarrassing and serious for the United States if a strike of atomic workers at Oak Ridge, Tenn., and Paducah, Ky., was long continued.

CHICAGO, July 7 (UP) -- Jim Pendleton slugged a seventh-inning double today to drive in Danny O'Connell as Lefty Chet Nichols of the Miuwakee Braves pitched a 1 -- 0 victory over the Chicago Cubs before 4,883 fans.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended June 30:
Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz was designated yesterday for renomination to the Kings County Court bench for another fourteen-year term by the members of the county's Democratic Executive Committee.
The Hospital Council of Greater New York issued yesterday the results of a survey on available hospital facilities in Bay Ridge and adjacent communities in Brooklyn.

LONDON, July 7 -- The Electrical Trades Union protested today against the American boycott of television films made in Britain. In a letter, it ras requested that the president of the Board of Trade, Peter Thorneycroft, be asked to "take every action possible" to have the boycott removed

New York Airways began carrying passengers by helicopter on scheduled inter-airport flights a year ago today, in which time it has transported 4,000 persons with its fleet of five Sikorsky rotorcraft.

It is difficult to understand how the Senate committee vote to retain price supports for farm commodities at 90 per cent of parity is to be considered a "snub" either to Eisenhower or to the American people.
Recent naval exercises have demonstrated that, for the first time since the introduction of the snorkel - high - speed submarine, defensive measures probably now have an advantage over the submarine.
MIAMI, Fla., July 7 (AP) -- Judith Ann Roberts, 7-year-old daughter of a Baltimore lawyer and labor leader, was kidnapped from her bed early today and slain.
DETROIT, July 7 (UP) -- Don Johnson, a White Sox right-hander, shackled Detroit, 9 to 0, on four hits today as Chicago made it seven in row over the Tigers at Briggs Stadium this season.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Eisenhower had a critical word today for some of his biographers.

Former Representative Vito Marcantonio announced yesterday that he would run as an independent in November. He will fight to regain the Eighteenth Congressional District seat he lost in 1950 to a Democratic-Republican-Liberal coalition candidate, James G. Donovan. Mr. Marcantonio did not run in 1952.

PARIS, July 7 -- The Court of Appeal of Paris decided today not to rewrite French history but to stick to the conventional but disputed thesis that the uncrowned King Louis XVII died in prison in 1795 at the age of 10.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 7 -- The United States said today that there would be more tests of nuclear weapons in the Pacific Islands trust territory.

GUATEMALA, July 7 -- Former President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman was formally charged today with implication in the assassination of Col. Francisco Javier Arana in June, 1949. The charge was made by a private individual in a justice of the peace court.
Foremost Dairies, Inc., reported yesterday a net income of $1,857,236, equal to 98 cents a share, for the quarter ended May 31. Earnings before taxes were $3,005,637.
The coffee-imbibing citizens of Toledo, Ohio, were deprived of 36,000 pounds of precious beans yesterday afternoon because of a felony at the Bush Terminal in Brooklyn.
ELMSFORD, N. Y., July 7 -- Tommy Goodwin, the defending titleholder, gained a 1-up triumph in the opening round of the New York State amateur golf championship today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 7 -- Dizzy Dean, one of baseball's most colorful personalities, will try his hand as an actor in motion pictures and television. He has entered into a partnership agreement with William Grady Sr., former casting director for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, and William Grady Jr., the producer, to co-star in a series of character-type comedies.
A dental drill -- virtually painless and almost noiseless -- was demonstrated yesterday at the Columbia - Presbyterian Medical Center.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UP) -- The House of Representatives passed without dissent today an Administration Communist-control bill to stiffen penalties against persons convicted of harboring fugitives from justice.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. The White House permitted direct quotation of indicated portions of the President's remarks. The rest are in indirect discourse as required by conference rules:

CLEVELAND, July 7 (UP) -- Mike Garcia pitched his eleventh victory tonight, although an irritation on his finger kept him from finishing the Indians' 6 -- 1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles. The triumhp kept Cleveland three and one-half games in front of the second-place Yankees in the American League race.

One feature of the recent agreement between the United States Steel Corporation and the United Steel-workers deserves more attention than it has received: the decision of both parties to hold quarterly meetings to discuss both company and employe problems other than those settled in the contract.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points in his news conference today:

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Eisenhower asserted today that he had the utmost confidence in Allen W. Dulles, the head of the Central Intelligence Agency, which is under threat of investigation by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Congress must clean up its investigations or lose the public's respect for it laws, a Senate Rules subcommittee was told today.

Federal Judge Mortimer W. Byers cleared the way yesterday for the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road to become solvent again through its operation by a redevelopment corporation set up at a recent special session of the Legislature.
BERLIN, July 7 (AP) -- More than 60,000 Protestants from East and West Germany assembled in Leipzig today for their sixth annual rally since the war, the first to be held in the Soviet zone.
The authority and functions of the Surveyor of Customs here, an office that traditionally has enjoyed virtual independence, have now been placed within the purview of the Collector of the Port.

Seven new members of the board of the New York Central Railroad, upon arriving at that status recently, were required for the first time to report their holdings of company stock to the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The cotton futures market closed steady here yesterday, 1 to 8 points higher than Tuesday.
PARIS, July 7 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the speech of Premier Pierre Mendes-France before the French National Assembly today:

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Several Navy ships caught in the radioactive "fall-out" from the March 1 hydrogen bomb test escaped contamination by using exterior sprinkling systems which washed them down with clear water as they passed through the atomic rain belt.

One of the recurrent themes of Soviet propaganda is that the United States is populated by materialistic barbarians who, lacking all cultural attainment, are unworthy of political leadership. It is good to learn that this particular type of Russian mendacity is to be met head-on by a new cultural offensive planned by the United States Information Agency.

According to estimates by the Post Office Department this will be a profitable year for sales to philatelists. With more than 12,000,000 collectors keeping the stamp windows busy in this country alone sales have already passed the fifteen-million-dollar mark. The Government realizes that there is a tremendous profit and advantage in selling to collectors.
New issues of corporate securities valued at more than $43,000,000 will be offered to investors today.

When a Republican candidate for the United States Senate in so doubtful a state as New Jersey goes squarely on record against Senator McCarthy as "a deeply divisive force" in our country, we think the event is worth both notice and applause.

Spokesmen for exporters and importers active in the Port of New York called yesterday for elimination of railroad lighterage charges on less than carload lot shipments to and from steamship piers. One of them also advocated elimination of lighterage charges on full carload shipments.

On the first page of this newspaper yesterday a dispatch from Washington began: "The cult of the paid informer is growing in the Federal Government." The process of informing is -- as Justice Holmes once said of the not-unrelated art of wiretapping -- a "dirty business."
TORONTO, July 7 (Canadian Press) -- The resignation of Harry G. Ferguson as chairman and director of Massey-Harris-Ferguson, Ltd., was announced today by the company.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 7 -- Iran made a "friendly complaint" to the Soviet Embassy today concerning Moscow's press attack on current oil negotiations with the West and its warnings against Iranian participation in Western-sponsored military alliances.
Everything went black in Brooklyn last night.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Business reports in recent months showed increasing evidence of a turn from decline to stability, or even moderate improvement in production and trade, the Northern Trust Company said today in its monthly publication, Business Comment.
PRINCETON, N. J., July 7 -- Eight men have won fellowships from the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation for advanced study at Princeton University's Guggenheim Jet Propulsion Center.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Dr. Julius Schreiber, a psychiatrist who helped run the World War II program of teaching G. I.'s what they were fighting for, swore today he was not a Communist at the time but refused to say whether he ever had been.

Identical exhibits keyed to the sober theme of family food reserves in the event of a war-caused emergency are being set up today in the twenty-six health centers and stations of the New York City Department of Health. Maintenance of household reserves for such a disaster is "the most important segment of civil defense," it was said yesterday.
ALBANY, July 7 -- The State Civil Service Commission today added seven groups to its official list of subversive organizations.

MALVERNE, L. I., July 7 -- A regulation providing for an official flag ceremony at municipal functions has caused this culturally inclined community to become the first incorporated village in the state to adopt a municipal flag, complete with coat-of-arms.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Marine Corps, two months after ruling that Col. Frank H. Schwable's military usefulness was "seiously impaired" by his false germ warfare confession to the Korean Communists, has awarded him the Legion of Merit.
GENEVA, July 7 -- A safe haven is in sight for the last of the 250,000 Jewish refugees who were uprooted during World War II and are still living in Europe.

"The Road to Mecca," by Muhammad Asad, will be issued Aug. 12 by Simon Schuster. It is an account of the author's desert journey from the interior of Arabia to the Holy City of Mecca in the late summer of 1932. It also concerns the author's conversion to Islam.

More than $7,000,000 will be spent by Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation in the year just ahead to advance the cause of its television receivers, radios, phonographs, air-conditioning apparatus and other products.
The second annual Institute of Mission Studies opened yesterday at Fordham University in the Bronx with 100 Roman Catholic missioners in attendance. It will continue until Aug. 23.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., July 7 -- An Air Force jet plane crashed today and cut a fiery swath through a residential district after missing a downtown skyscraper. Four persons were killed, and several others had narrow escapes.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 7 -- Southern politicians openly or covertly trying to circumvent the recent Supreme Court decision outlawing public school racial segregation were cautioned today to "remember that freedom-loving Americans can still debate the issue."

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 7 -- Edgard Rego Santos was installed today as Minister of Education and Culture. This completes the series of changes to make a virtually non-political Cabinet until after the Oct. 3 elections.

THE end came in a recreation hall where young Frenchmen had played chess and table tennis. When it was over, the defeated and the victorious representatives of the warring powers had moved a few steps closer to their places in history. The air was not yet peaceful, but it was better than it had been for a long interval

Five city officials and a group of engineers and lesser municipal officials took a tugboat ride down the Harlem River yesterday to view progress on the Harlem River Drive. On the trip, one Commissioner gave away a bridge.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- A Department of the Interior official testified today that although the Government had lent or guaranteed loans totaling $3,000,000 to the United States Tin Corporation since 1951 to develop a mine in Alaska, little or no tin had been produced.

JOHN BLANKS CAMPBELL, the New York Jockey Club handicapper who died Wednesday, confined his wagering in twenty years as a Jockey Club official to $2 bets. He bet only on vacations and always at tracks outside his jurisdiction.

The vestry of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, has called to be its rector the Very Rev. Dr. Frederick Myers Morris, dean of St. Mark's Cathedral, Minneapolis.
PHILADELPHIA, July 8 (AP) -The Sun Oil Company and the Atlantic Refining Company today cut gasoline prices in Pennsylvania to meet competition.

Emil H. Ronay, managing director and treasurer of the Salisbury Hotel, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, was killed early yesterday when he jumped or fell from his seventeenth-floor suite. He was 67 years old and had been in ill health for some time.

Charges against Jerome Binder, 29-year-old vocational high school teacher who had been accused of trying to induce two pupils to steal an automobile for him, were dismissed yesterday in Felony Court. Magistrate J. Irwin Shapiro threw out the case after he had been informed that a grand jury had heard it and failed to return a true bill.
Operators of a group of movie theatres sued yesterday in Supreme Court, Queens, to kill the city's 5 per cent tax on theatre admissions, which took effect July 1.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The House of Representatives passed a bill today adding about 4,000,000 employes of the Federal Government and small business firms to the unemployment insurance system.
Your editorial "After Active Duty" in The Times brings to mind the pioneering effort along these lines, which deserves attention.

The National Cash Register Company has eliminated the human element in computing change for the retail-store customer. It unveiled yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel a cash register that performs this chore.

Arrangements were completed here yesterday to finance construction of a $24,500,000 oil refinery in Puerto Rico, with capital put up by American banks and investing institutions and by Puerto Rican banks.
ENGLEWOOD, N. J., July 8 -- It will be a repetition of last year's match when the eighth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's four-ball best-ball final is played tomorrow.
One of the country's leading investment banking houses has agreed to pay the New York City Housing Authority $2,797.88 for the privilege of lending it $10,000.000 for seven months.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., July 8 -- The annual service commemorating the death of Capt. Emilio Carranza, a Mexican goodwill flier, on his way home from Washington in 1928, will be held at 4 P. M. Saturday at the spot where his plane crashed into the Burlington County pine belt.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Federal Court of Appeals sustained today dismissal of the key count of the perjury indictment against Owen Lattimore. The vote was 8 to 1.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Ralph A. Tudor, Under Secretary of the Interior, said tonight that he planned to leave his post and return to private business "some time near the end of Congress."

It is appropriate that one of the first tasks of the new Department of Commerce and Public Events under Commissioner Patterson is to take stock of what New York City's trade situation actually is. We know that for a variety of reasons some business and factories have moved away, but it is not clear whether they have been replaced by an equal or even greater number of new enterprises.

A combined investigation by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, the Department of Markets and the Better Business Bureau resulted yesterday in grand larceny indictments against four operators of a Fifth Avenue linen and rug shop.

Two off-duty patrolmen were attacked early yesterday morning by hoodlums. One patrolman shot and killed a man who tried to stab him and the other suffered an arm injury but captured one of his assailants.
With a rip-roaring sixteen-hit attack that included four home runs and four doubles, the Giants rubbed more salt yesterday into the wounds they have been inflicting on the Dodgers recently.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- A quickly assembled Taft-Hartley Law emergency board began work today on an urgent schedule to find the facts in the Oak Ridge, Tenn., and Paducah, Ky., atomic plant strikes. Production is continuing with a skeleton force on duty at the struck plants.

The judgment of the French Premier, M. Mendes-France, on the prospect of a just and honorable peace in Indochina may be right or wrong. But there can be no gainsaying his political courage. He put his Administration flatly on the line in the first place by setting a time limit for the accomplishment of that peace.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (UP) -- Two Democratic Senators said today they would propose cuts of 50 per cent or more in the Administration's new $3,338,000,000 foreign aid program for the 1955 fiscal year.
Manager Walter Alston snapped the whip on the Dodgers as it seldom has been snapped before following their sixth straight loss to the Giants yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 8 -- A complete program for Communist action in Brazil and a list of proposed Communist candidates for office are in the hands of authorities. These were seized in the capture Tuesday night of a long-hunted party leader.

The two-story taxpayer at 2533 Glen Cove Avenue in Glen Cove, L. I., has been purchased by Irving Fishman and David Lieberman in a transaction negotiated by John J. Reynolds, Inc., as broker. Abraham Weinberg was attorney for the buyers and William Cohn of Guggenheim Untermeyer acted for the sellers.

LONDON, July 8 -- Sir Winston Churchill announced in the House of Commons today that a "sessional allowance" of 2 ($5.60) would be granted to each member of Parliament for every day -- excluding Fridays -- that the House of Commons sat. Each member will be free to accept or decline it.

LONDON, July 8 -- Sir David Maxwell Fyfe, Home Secretary, today stood on his refusal to permit Dr. Joseph H. Cort to remain in Britain but said he would consider an application from his wife, Dr. Ruth Cort, to remain here alone.

Uncle Sam, an unwilling landlord, was selling yesterday a forty-eight-family housing project in Greenport, L. I., and a 100-family development in Upper Penn's Neck Township, N. J. The sales were part of a Federal effort in which 21,000 permanent housing units have been disposed of in the last year.

PARIS, July 8 -- The apparent intention of the top United States delegates to be absent from Geneva next week, when France's effort for an Indochinese truce will reach its final stage, came as a blow to French hopes today.

Governors of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday authorized for listing 24,327,312 shares of capital stock of N. V. Koninklijke Nederlandsche Petroleum Maatschappij -- the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company. The shares will be admitted to dealings following registration under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The Senate Agriculture Committee took another slap at the Eisenhower farm program late today by ordering mandatory Government price supports on oats, barley, rye and grain sorghums, all important livestock feed crops.

Foundations, already unnecessarily bedeviled by Congressional investigations, are now faced with the threat of equally unnecessary legislation which would hamstring their operations. Last week the Senate passed, by merely a voice vote, an amendment by Senator McCarran to the omnibus tax bill -- worthy and innocuous at first sight -- which would deny tax-free status to any foundation contributing to a "subversive" individual or organization or to any members of such an organization.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (UP) -- Len De Caux, Congress of Industrial Organizations former public relations director, was threatened with deportation to New Zealand today after refusing to answer more than fifty questions by the investigators of the House of Representatives.
LONDON, July 8 (Reuters) -The British pound today made one of its longest strides toward convertibility when it became fully convertible in terms of raw sugar.

GENEVA, July 8 -- International trade was by the end of 1953 "far better balanced than at any time during the post-war period." This conclusion was reached by the secretariat of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) in a report published here today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 8 -- Judge George W. Smyth of the Westchester Children's Court rejected today a plea by Rita Hayworth to relinquish immediately jurisdiction over her two daughters. The children had been taken into court custody on neglect charges in April and now are with the actress and her present husband, Dick Haymes, in Nevada.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- A bill to protect consumers from poisonous spray residues on fruits and vegetables was sent to the White House today.

Negotiations to settle the two-weeks-old longshoremen's strike in Puerto Rico continued yesterday, but according to informed sources management and labor were still "wide apart" on the question of wages and working conditions.

LONDON, July 8 -- Dr. Cyril F. Garbett, Archbishop of York, called on Britain today to abandon her attitude of "resentful acceptance" of United States leadership and to recognize that the United States now was the "senior partner."
New York's official back fence -- Radio Station WNYC -- capsuled its thirty-year public service history, from classics to comics, in an eighty-five-minute birthday greeting to itself last night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 8 -- One of the most complex play purchase agreements in Hollywood history was completed today after four months of negotiation. Samuel Goldwyn and the owners of the hit show "Guys and Dolls," which ended a three-year Broadway run last November, were the principals.

LOS ALAMOS, N. M., July 8 -- The decision of the Atomic Energy Commission against restoring the security clearance of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer was defended by Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss in a letter made public here tonight.

Even though the Budd Schulberg-Harvey Breit dramatization of the former's novel, "The Disenchanted," isn't completed, many bids have been received to put it on the boards. On the inside track are William Darrid and Ann Noyes. Their signatures aren't on the dotted line yet, according to Ad Schulberg, Mr. Schulberg's mother and favorite agent.

The County Trust Company, White Plains, N. Y., reported, as of June 30, total deposits of $250,163,208 and total assets of $268,573,195, compared, respectively, with $229,070,221 and $247,596,717 on March 31. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $39,637,263, against $31,657,305; holdings of United States Government securities to $72,600,323, against $60,229,396, and loans and discounts to $62,044,239, against $57,325,907.
Big, red Bing cherries from Northwestern orchards are among the most tempting "specials" in the city's markets this week-end.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., July 8 -- The week-end should provide considerable activity for the angler in these waters. Mackerel are plentiful, the bluefish have made an appearance, large school tuna are within two hours' run from the harbor, and striped bass are a possibility for the surfcaster.

CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- A surprisingly large turn-out of hogs broke prices of both] butchers and sows today. Producers unloaded [ 12.000 salable head m the market, which was 4.50 more than had been expected. It was also the largest day's receipts since[ Jan. 7. Department of Agriculture reports[ on the day's trading:
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Treatment of the Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, N. Y., on a par with the military, naval and air academies was urged today before a Senate Commerce subcommittee.
DARIEN, Conn., July 8 -- The weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association held today at the Wee Burn Country Club ended in a three-way tie.

A pop-up toaster that toasts any kind of bread--white, whole wheat, frozen, or what have you -- to the same degree of brownness was itroduced yesterday by the Proctor Electric Company at the Pierre Hotel.

AKRON, Ohio, July 8 (AP) -- About 23,000 members of the United Rubber Workers Union, C. I. O., were on strike today at the ten plants of Goodyear Tire Rubber Company, demanding pay increases of more than 5 cents an hour.

DETROIT, July 8 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers' Steve Gromek struck a blow against Chicago's pennant hopes today when he scattered seven hits to post his tenth victory of the season, 2 -- 0, over the White Sox.

One of the most priceless and important of our privileges under the Constitution is a citizen's right to vote. Our parties, movements, laws, codes and Government are the reflection of the American people's wisdom produced by voting through the years.

Larry Knohl, a target as a tax fixer in several Congressional inquiries, was indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn Federal grand jury on a charge of evading payment of taxes totaling $210,796. He will be arraigned July 27 in Brooklyn Federal Court.

SAVANNAH, Ga., July 8 -- Three years of immunity from union organization were promised today to Southern garment manufacturers who committed themselves to keep their wage rates at least 15 cents above the Federal minimum.

LONDON, July 8 -- The British Government is not pressing the United States to accept Communist China as a member of the United Nations and, in the present world situation, it has no intention of doing so.

Two prominent educators disagreed yesterday on the place of religion in the public schools. They debated before 500 teachers and administrators attending the summer session program at Teachers College, Columbia University, in the Horace Mann Auditorium.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Senator Homer Capehart, Republican of Indiana, announced today he will ask the Secretary of State to "rescind" the passport of Norman K. Winston of New York, described by Mr. Capehart as "one key witness" in the housing scandal.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- Wheat futures reacted today from this week's sharp advances. A halt in the demand for flour from bakers and the elimination of a lot of shorts in the past two days created a temporarily overbought situation.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Secretary of State Dulles assured the world today that the United States had no intention of leaving the United Nations. There is no reason to contemplate such a withdrawal, he added.

OAKLAND, Calif., July 8 -- If proponents of the punitive "woodshed" treatment for juvenile delinquency have their way, all our acquired knowledge on child development will be scrapped, a noted expert on family relations said here.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Four leading national farm organizations split 3 to 1 today in favor of extending Social Security coverage to farm operators and additional large groups of farm workers.
A fairly accurate cross-section of the melange of new styles that home-furnishings manufacturers are offering is on exhibit on the new ninth floor at Gimbels.
MEXICO CITY, July 8 -- According to Guatemalan Army officers, some of the arms shipped recently from behind the Iron Curtain to Guatemala were duds, worn out or entirely wrong for use there.

GENEVA, July 8 -- An Australian economist, Sir Douglas Copeland, warned Western Governments today that spending billions on armaments would not provide effective defense if poverty continued to dominate large areas of the world.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- The Air Line Pilots' Association announced today that all flight crews of American Airlines would "withdraw from service" at midnight on July 15. This is a move by the pilots' labor organization to prevent scheduling of crews for longer than eight hours continuous flight duty in any twenty-four-hour period.

Nineteen hunting rifles and 100 rounds of ammunition as well as binoculars, cameras, watches, stock certificates and $500 in cash were stolen last night by two armed thugs from the apartment of a building superintendent who is a hunting enthusiast.

Former Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind and Arleigh B. Williamson, an educator, were appointed yesterday by Mayor Wagner to the Board of Higher Education, governing body of the four municipal colleges. Both appointments are for full nine-year terms.
iobfie, Ala., borrowed $6,000000 for water service in the publie market yesterday at a net interest cost of 3.2473 per cent.
NEW DELHI, India, July 8 -- The Ministry of Food and Agriculture announced today the abolition of all controls over price, procurement and the movement of rice throughout the country.

Department store business in the Second Federal Reserve District is developing a reputation for stability. In the early part of 1953, when the remainder of the country was registering sharp advances, the gains in this district were relatively moderate.
The first line of "big screen" color television sets to be offered at retail prices below $1,000 was introduced yesterday by Motorola, Inc.
Since no twelve-day tercentenary celebration should lack a "spectacular-gigantic" parade, Mystic, Conn., is arranging one for the afternoon of Saturday, July 17.

The men's wear retailer is in a period of profitless prosperity which must be corrected by more realistic gross margins, Louis Rothschild, executive director of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers, said yesterday.

BONN, July 8 -- West Germany has "reason to hope" that sovereignty, including the "right to make her own decisions regarding her relations with the East-bloc states," will be restored by the end of this year, the official Government bulletin said today.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -The House of Representatives voted today to make peacetime spying punishable by death as it passed and sent to the Senate a bill drastically stiffening the espionage and sabotage laws.

There are many things a President can't learn until after he takes the oath of office. One of them is how to conduct a news conference. Mr. Eisenhower was not at his best in his early White House meetings with the press. He was, if one may say this of a General and a President, a little embarrassed.

A drop last week of 3,601,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 164,546,000 barrels, compared with 168,147,000 a week earlier and 143,077,000 a year ago.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The Senate passed and today sent to the President a lease- purchase bill that its sponsors say will touch off a multi-billion dollar government building program.
The Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., settled their major differences yesterday and agreed on a two-year contract.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., July 8 -- Dave Baldwin of Baltusrol, a left-handed amateur, led the field after thirty-six holes had been completed in the thirty-fourth annual New Jersey State open golf championship.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 1 to 20 points net higher than Wednesday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 8 -- The United Nations will find itself in a major constitutional controversy if the United States uses the veto to keep Communist China out of the Security Council.

A 35-year-old bank clerk and his wife spent several hours yesterday at the New York Association for the Blind, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street. Both have perfect eyesight and their visit had humane and specific meaning.

TRENTON, July 8 -- State investigators seeking to examine Harold G. Hoffman's safe deposit box found today that the inner metal container was unaccountably missing. This added a new mystery to the case involving the late former Governor's financial manipulations of New Jersey funds.

LONDON, July 8 -- The stock market rise continued today, although not so exuberantly as yesterday. Profit taking brought losses for a few industrial shares, but the selling was well absorbed and the close generally was firm, with gains greatly outnumbering losses.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 8 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren urged the nation's lawyers today to interest themselves "tremendously" in the cause of free legal aid for the penniless. Otherwise, they would face an alternative "that won't be as good," he said.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 8 (AP) -- Dynamic Hal, 7-year-old bay owned by the Happy Valley Stock Farm of Suffolk, Va., and driven by William Haughton, won the Green Vale Mile Pace in 2:06 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (UP) -- Herbert Brownell, Jr., Attorney General, declared tonight that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had put himself "above the law" in urging Federal employes to furnish secret information despite a Presidential ban.
PARIS, July 8 -- The French Army has begun organizing a new light infantry division, containing conscript troops, as a prospective reinforcement for the Indochinese War.
Stocks made moderate gains through most of yesterday's session but sold off at the close. As a result, The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks was virtually unchanged on the day.

" The Fifth Freedom -- Freedom from Taxation," by Butler Sheldon Jr., economic consultant and industrial engineer, has been scheduled for summer publication by the Library Publishers. Mr. Sheldon presents a plan for "the drastic reduction" of Federal taxes and the prevention of inflations and depressions.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., July 8 -- A committee of fifty junior riders of the Long Island colonies is working on plans for the Huntington Horse Show, which will be held on July 18 at Rice Farms, Lawrence Hill. Proceeds will aid the local branch of the Young Men's Christian Association.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- White House approval for a 5 per cent increase in postal workers' pay today signaled a drive to pass it in the bill for higher postal rates asked by the Administration.
Indians outnumbered cowboys, an old American custom, at the Independence Week celebration held yesterday at the Police Athletic League playstreet project in Henry Street.
The man who strolled with a live lion into, the Statler Hotel lobby yesterday is a salesman of optical goods back home in Illinois. He calls on the retail trade without the lion.

ST. LOUIS, July 8 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals bunched four singles in the second inning tonight to defeat Cincinnati, 2 -- 1, and gain a tie with the Redlegs for fifth place in the National League as Harvey Haddix notched his thirteenth victory.

One of the season's largest audiences turned up at Lewisohn Stadium last evening drawn by the combination of Mischa Elman and the Mendelssohn Violin concerto; and the combination turned out to be a highly rewarding one.

Directors of National Airlines, Inc. have elected two vice presidents, Charles E. Banks, in charge of production, and Charles F. Sharp, in charge of customer relations, G. T. Baker, president and board chairman, announced yesterday.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 8 (AP) -- Lord Pick, a bay colt by Eva's Boy and owned by A. L. Baxter of Davison, Mich., won the third and deciding heat of the $5,200 Dickerson Cup Trot for 3-year-olds at Historic Track today.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 8 -- Doug Bruce sailed home first today with an Indian Harbor Arrow Class boat, Cherokee, as a record fleet of 118 began competition for the Clinton M. Bell Trophy in the ninth annual Junior Yacht Racing Association regatta conducted by the New York Yacht Club.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 618,597 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
CANBERRA, Australia, July 8 (AP) -- Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies said today there had been no change in Australia's opposition to the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.
Although the automobile industry generally is having some trouble with indigestion growing out of heavy production and unsold cars, at least one dealer has no complaint to make.
ELMSFORD, N. Y., July 8 -- Playing sub-par golf, the defending titleholder, Tommy Goodwin, gained the fourth round of the New York State amateur golf championship today.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (UP) -- Congressional investigators said today that Oscar Chapman, former Secretary of the Interior, had approved the "feasibility" of an unproductive Alaskan tin mine that the Government backed with $3,000,000 in loans.

HANOI, July 8 (AP) -- General Ely said today he had ordered an all-out defense of Hanoi and Haiphong, and the route connecting them. He denied emphatically to newsmen rumors that Hanoi would be abandoned to the Communist-led Vietminh without a fight.

The Federal Maritime Board has determined that conditions warrant the continued chartering of fifteen Government-owned surplus vessels to private shipping lines. Under the law the maritime agency is required to review bareboat charters of war-built craft to make sure their employment does not impair private interests in the industry and does not inhibit the ordering of new ships for private account.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 18 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 8 -- The strikes of atomic production workers will not end until the Government gets an injunction under the Taft-Hartley Law, it was indicated today.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- During the week ended July 7 member bank reserves increased $395,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LONDON, July 7 -- Those in the Eisenhower Administration, and there are several, who think that Communist propaganda with respect to the overturn of Governments in Guatemala was superior to that of the United States could final rueful satisfaction in the British press these days.

Some industrial strikes are contests between employers and employes, in which the public has only a casual interest. One can't say this of strikes which cut down essential services: without transportation a community sickens; without water or electric power it begins to die. But what of a strike that hits at the sources of our national defense?
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- A group of Senate Democrats agreed today to press for amendment of the atomic law to prohibit the Atomic Energy Commission from contracting for private electric power.
John R. Cabey, a 65-year-old former building superintendent who looked forward eagerly to the purchase of a house on Long Island for his retirement, saw his dream shattered yesterday.

Bank clearings of the twenty-five leading cities of the nation for the holiday week ended on Wednesday amounted to $16,604,926,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This was 2.1 per cent below the $16,958,721,000 of the corresponding period of 1953 and 14.8 per cent below the $19,499,082,000 of the previous full week. Transactions in the 1953 week were not affected by the Independence Day holiday as it fell on a Saturday.

HARTFORD, July 8 -- Gov. Dan Thornton of Colorado told the opening session of the Republican State Convention tonight that the main "task" of Republicans everywhere "is the election of a loyal Republican Congress to give President Eisenhower the support to make his program a reality."
Ship construction in this country's private yards has reached its lowest point of the last three years, the Shipbuilders Council of America aid yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by Secretary of State Dulles today at his news conference:

MINEOLA, L. I., July 8 -- The Nassau Red Cross issued a public challenge to the Nassau County Medical Society today for its approval of a civilian blood program in the county, culminating several years of negotiations.
Sweeping editorial and administrative changes were put into effect yesterday by the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Four Puerto Rican terrorists were sentenced to maximum prison terms today for the shooting March 1 in the House of Representatives, in which five members of the House were wounded.
GENEVA, July 8 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, returned here by air today for the final stages of the Indo-china negotiations.

Sixteen prowl cars, carrying thirty-two policemen, converged last night on a Brooklyn street corner when a 17-year-old loiterer successfully dared a patrolman to arrest him and then got his gang to help resist the arrest. All thirteen of the youths were soon on their way to tell it to the judge.

ATLANTA, July 8 -- Federal Judge Boyd Sloan ordered the City of Atlanta today to admit Negroes to its seven public golf courses but ruled that the city may do so on a seggregated basis in accordance with municipal laws.

Cool green in hue, refreshing in flavor, limes are a natural for summer foods and drinks. Fortunately it is during the hot months that Florida, principal producer of this citrus fruit, sends them here in greatest quantity. This year the crop in that state is expected to total 420,000 boxes.

Eleven months ago President Eisenhower signed the emergency Refugee Relief Act providing for admission to this country of 214,000 aliens outside the regular quotas over a three-and-a-half-year period. At the time he signed the bill the President hopefully declared that the measure was "an important contribution toward greater understanding and cooperation among the free nations of the world."
CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- Randy Jackson's single with two out in the fourteenth inning scored Gene Baker as the Chicago Cubs snapped a five-game losing streak with an 9-8 victory over Milwaukee today.

Three new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Garden of Evil," a Twentieth Century-Fox in Cinema Scope and Technicolor, with Gary Cooper, Susan Hayward and Richard Widmark, is at the Roxy. Charles Brackett produced and Henry Hathaway directed from a screen play by Frank Fenton and a story by Fred Freiberger and William Tunberg. Hugh Marlowe, Cameron Mitchell and Rita Moreno head the supporting cast.
The outstanding business loans of the New York City banks do not yet reflect the seasonal rise in borrowing that generally gets under way at this time of the year.

HANOI, Vietnam, July 8 -- Gov. Nguyen Huu Tri of North Vietnam disclosed today that he had resigned. He said he would continue performing his Gubernatorial functions pending appointment of a successor by Premier Ngo Dinh Diem.

OMAHA, July 8 -- The Omaha Housing Authority, which administers 1,778 units of Federal low-cost housing, voted today to investigate whether the electrical wiring of the units was in danger of being overloaded by air conditioners installed by low-income tenants.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (UP) -- The Defense Department has pigeonholed a study of military pay rates that calls for "substantial'' salary increases for generals and admirals.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- An order for fifty-one Diesel-electric locomotives for the Consolidated Railroads of Cuba was received today at the General Motors Corporation Electro-Motive Division plant near La Grange, Ill.

SEATTLE, July 8 (AP) -- An atomic particle apparently from outer space, capable of annihilating ordinary matter, has been captured at the top of the earth's atmosphere, a cosmic ray scientist reported today.
Agreements have been completed with thirty-one movie theatres throughout the country to carry the opening-night program of the Metropolitan Opera on Nov. 6 by large-screen, closed-circuit television.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 8 (UP) -- Vic Seixas, Art Larsen, Hamilton Richardson and Bernard Bartzen, stroked their way into the semi-finals of the sixty-fifth annual Western tennis championship today.

This appears to be a season highly favorable to the losing of briefcases. An unusually large number, as regular readers of the lost-and-found column know already, seem lately to have been mislaid, left on buses or in taxicabs, and this suggests that someone in need of a research project might do a little thoughtful inquiry on why, or how, persons "lose" briefcases.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 (AP) -- Mayor Joseph S. Clark Jr. today asked Philadelphia area business men to "pick up the ball" and help keep the Athletics in Philadelphia through a "community-chest kind of drive."
GUATEMALA, July 8 -- Col. Carlos Castillo Armas has been elected president of the governing junta. The junta itself has been reduced from five to three, members.

Proposals for a schedule of mandatory service charges on brokerage customers have been filed with the governors of the American Stock Exchange by a special committee appointed on March 17 to consider the matter.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 8 -- The Brazilian official petroleum monopoly, Petrobras, has signed a $200,000,000 contract for the purchase of crude oil from two United States companies. This is the largest oil deal Brazil has ever made.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 8 -- The effectiveness of anti-discrimination laws cannot be measured by the degree of visible integration attained under such laws, Henry Spitz, general counsel to the New York State Commission Against Discrimination, declared today.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (UP) -The Department of Agriculture said today there were 19,961,000 acres of cotton under cultivation on July 1, 21 per cent less than a year ago.

NEW DELHI, India, July 8 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru opened the flood gates of the Nangal dam in East Punjab today and waters of the Sutlej River surged into what officials regard as one of the world's longest irrigation networks.
A good Christian can be a Communist "under certain qualified circumstances," the Rev. William Howard Melish asserted yesterday.

ALTHOUGH the times are large, the themes are small. That remark was made by the drama critic of this newspaper last season about plays. The same thought -- that novelists are overlooking the major stories of our time and concentrating on private matters and small subjects -- is pertinent to fiction today. That includes run-of-the-mill and stylized fiction as well as fiction by talented writers, such as "Happy New Year, Kamerades!",* by Robert Lowry.
Centuries and countries mean nothing to Sally Victor when she's searching for inspiration. She dips into one and then another, combining the results with perfect aplomb.
Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., and subsidiaries increased net profits in the nine months ended last May to $15,121,490 from $14,503,844 earned in the similar period of the prior year.
Sponsors of the annual spring International Flower Show have decided to postpone the exhibition here for a year.
Representative Walter H. Judd of Minnesota declared yesterday that admission of Communist China to the United Nations would give the Kremlin its "greatest possible diplomatic victory."

SOUTHPORT, England, July 8 -- A gloomy little man from the North Country, 40-year-old Sydney Simeon Scott, had the day of his life and a record round for the Royal Birkdale course -- a 67 -- but at sundown Bill Spence of Kent was still clinging tenaciously to the lead midway through the British open golf championship.

ROME, July 8 -- Pope Plus XII can now be considered entirely recovered from the desperate illness that struck him in February, a person in close daily contact with the Pontiff said today. The Pope's recovery has been remarkable and far beyond the most sanguine hopes of his physicians.
TOKYO, Friday, July 9 (AP) -- Gen. John E. Hull, the Far East commander, announced today that United States troops will be withdrawn from Hokkaido -- Japan's Soviet frontiers -- later this year.

The feature event at Aqueduct yesterday was the Sheepshead Bay, a classified handicap of a mile and an eighth. It was only fitting therefore, that the race be won by a horse trained by Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, the Sheepshead Bay native who makes Aqueduct his home grounds, occupation-wise.

Your editorial attacking New York City for its opposition to the Long Island Rail Road Rehabilitation Plan is unwarranted. The plan does nothing to stop the "milking" of the L. I. R. R. by the Pennsylvania Railroad as charged by the Nassau County Transit Commission.
LONDON, July 8 -- A Labor member in the House of Commons twitted Sir Winston Churchill today about a report that, while in the United States, he had referred to Anthony Eden as his "successor."
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Secretary of State Dulles foresaw today early United States recognition of the new anti-Communist regime in Guatemala.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 8 -- Indonesia and the Netherlands have agreed in principle to dissolve their five-year-old union, it was learned here today.
An Air Force flight surgeon is planning to "break" the sound barrier without leaving the ground.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Paul Crouch, former Communist and long a Government witness in anti-Communist cases, has turned against his employers. He has demanded formally a Congressional investigation of Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. and his deputy, William P. Rogers.

Coffee futures registered losses up to the 2-cents-a-pound daily limit yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The close was 95 to 200 points lower on 71,750 bags with the distant options weakest.

DETROIT, July 8 -- Interpretations of the figures on unemployment released yesterday by the Labor and Commerce Departments were sharply challenged today by Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

" THE WORLD OF MR. SWEENEY," the Charles Ruggles vehicle that was part Kate Smith's show, now is a television program in its own right and the odds would seem to favor its survival beyond a summer replacement run.
Although Sidney Kingsley has not yet selected a name for his first comedy, he is busy with plans for its presentation here next fall.

Aided by a change of heart on the part of Bronx Borough President James J. Lyons, the Board of Estimate approved unanimously yesterday a rezoning of the East Cunningham Park area in Queens to bar apartment houses.

STARLIGHT, Pa., July 9 (AP) -- B'nai B'rith, through its administrative committee, today voted full support of the ruling by the United States Supreme Court outlawing racial segregation in public schools.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 -- Housing and equipment, like most of the home economics fields, were criticized today at the close of the forty-fifth annual meeting of the American Home Economics Association.
TRENTON, July 9 -- New evidence in the state's investigation into the financial manipulations of former Gov. Harld G. Hoffman was brought to light here today.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 9 (AP) -- The Tippler, owned by K. D. Owen of Houston, won the $5,200 Orange County Board of Supervisors Pace today at Historic Track in track record time of 2:01 2-5 as the Grand Circuit meeting ended.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The General Services Administration today announced the signing of a contract with the Dow Chemical Company to increase the nation's productive capacity of titanium sponge by 1,800 tons to 15,000 tons a year.

THE first thing about Red Smith is that he writes English. Sports have an accepted, almost a desired, language of their own which is most admired when farthest removed from Messrs. Webster Fowler. In sports is the home of the sentimentalist spewing ridiculous gush over -- as John Dryden put it hundreds of years ago -- "the athletic brutes whom undeservedly we call heroes."

The daughter of a New York hotel waitress has been awarded a scholarship of $1,000 a year for a four-year college course. The award was made by her mother's union, representing 27,000 hotel and club workers in this city. At least a dozen other unions are making similar scholarship grants to the children of their members.

PELHAM, N. Y., July 9 -- The Winged Foot Sinbads of the New York Athletic Club's Yachting Department started their sail to Block Island tonight to launch the club's biggest yachting weekend of the season.
ENGLEWOOD, N. J., July 9 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood and Mrs. Bernard Freeman of Inwood won the eighth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association four-ball best-ball championship today.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., July 9 (UP) -- Former President Truman walked out of a Kansas City hospital and came home looking fit and chipper today, just nineteen days after doctors removed his gall bladder and appendix.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, July 9 (Reuters) -- Three plump Princess flying boats are sitting by the seashore here waiting to be carried off by atomic engines -- if someone will only build them.

The Monsanto Chemical Company, one of the first big corporations to announce results for the first six months this year, yesterday reported declines in sales and earnings from the first half of last year.

On July 1 you published a letter in which Messrs. Ostrover and Leavitt of the High School Teachers Association chided another correspondent for presuming to uphold the single-salary principle in teachers' salaries. May I, a former teacher in both the junior and senior high schools and now an assistant principal in one of the New York junior high schools, enter the discussion?

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- A study outlining a possible project for development of the Litani River in Lebanon at a cost of $97,800,000 over twenty-five years has been submitted to the Lebanese Government by the Foreign Operations Administration.

The National Maritime Union, C. I. O., and five companies operating twenty-six colliers have signed a supplementary contract covering vacations and pension and welfare fund payments, the union announced yesterday.

The United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, 47 West Fifty-seventh Street, has reason to view with satisfaction the progress made in treating cerebral palsy, a neuromuscular affliction that follows injury to the motor centers of the brain. Of the 550,000 persons in this country with cerebral palsy nearly half are children or adolescents.
NAIROBI, Kenya, July 9 (Reuters) -- A new white political party whose program is the uniting of all races by backing a multi-racial government was launched in Kenya today.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Secretary Oveta Culp Hobby tonight urged support for President Eisenhower's health re-insurance plan.
MANILA, July 9 (AP) -- A Philippine official today charged that Cuba was trying to corner Japan's sugar import market.

There was an increase in distress conveyances of Manhattan real estate during May as compared with the previous month, according to a survey by the Real Estate Board of New York. There were nine distress conveyances in May involving liens of $2,121,403 on properties assessed at $2,080,500.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 9 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan and his Nationalist party have reopened their attack on South Africa's Constitution in connection with the provincial elections five weeks ahead.
Willie Mays did not hit a homer yesterday at the Polo Grounds but Alvin Dark, Monty Irvin, Wes Westrum and Johnny Antonelli did and the streaking Giants turned back the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6 -- 3.

DUBLIN, July 9 (AP) -- Gil Shea of Chicago, down two sets, compelled Mervyn Rose of Australia to go thirty games before yielding the third set in their semifinal match in the Irish tennis championship today.

ELMSFORD, N. Y., July 9 -- Bob Monk, a 27-year-old White Plains, N. Y., golfer, eliminated the defending champion, Tommy Goodwin, in the quarter-finals of the New York State amateur golf championship today.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The United States Court of Military Appeals ordered today a new court-martial of Lieut. Col. Melvin B. Voorhees on charges of evading Army censorship.

A ten-story apartment house is to replace the famous Studio Building at 45 West Tenth Street. The property has been purchased by Joseph Chinich Son, builders, from S. Tarlow and Julius Vinik in a transaction negotiated by William Alfred White as broker.

Steve Allen, television comedian who appears nightly on his own show on the National Broadcasting Company network, and Miss Jayne Meadows, also a television performer, will be married on July 31, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -The United States Tin Company, already owing the Cvernment $3,000,000 but not producing tin, has applied for $403,000 more of Government-insured credit, Congressional investigators were told today.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it will hold a hearing on July 27 to decide whether the Alleghany Corporation, headed by Robert P. Young, who recently gained control of the New York Central Railroad, is an investment company subject to S. E. C. regulations.
LOS ANGELES, July 9 -- The easy-to-wear, casual look has predominated in the fashions shown here this week during the California fashion creators' annual Fall Press Week.

Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Speaker of the House, questioned yesterday the possibility of peaceful coexistence between the Soviet Union and non-Communist nations. His address was heard by 6,000 members of the Lions here.

CHICAGO, July 9 (UP) -- The Chicago White Sox pounded four Cleveland hurlers for four runs in the seventh inning tonight to beat the Indians, 8 to 3, and end a four-game losing streak to the league leaders before 43,740 fans.

LEIPZIG, Germany, July 9 (Reuters) -- Speakers from East and West lashed communism and capitalism with equal vigor here today at the all-German Evangelical church rally for which the Iron Curtain has been opened wide.
Firemen have been assigned to a twenty-four-hour guard of two East Side apartment houses that are without fire escapes and have been without them for two weeks.
GENEVA, July 9 -- Substantial, but so far little noticed, shifts have recently occurred in the composition of the trade of the United States and Canada with other parts of the world.
The Board of Estimate adopted unanimously yesterday a revised pay classification plan affecting 80,000 of the city's civil service employes.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange Friday was very quiet, and prices at the close were somewhat irregular -- 13 points lower to 11 points higher than on Thursday. The far months were strong, and old July was the chief loser.

Bargain hunters and sentimentalists rub shoulders at the Opportunity Shop, a New York institution of twenty-nine years. At 46 West Forty-seventh Street, the shop, which has been called "The Tiffany of Thrift Shops," will hold a special sale Monday in conjunction with the New York Summer Festival.

Six turtles and two alligators are ready to leave tomorrow on a one-way, goodwill trip to Jerusalem. They will not travel under their own steam, however, as they will be escorted in a plane leaving from New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
HARTFORD, July 9 -- Gov. John Davis Lodge was renominated by acclamation today by the Republican State Convention for a second four-year term.

Why is it necessary to schedule parades on Fifth Avenue during the hours when New York working people are returning home and are so very anxious to get there? Wednesday night it took one hour to get from Fifty-second Street to Eighty-sixth Street by bus.

RABAT, French Morocco, July 8 -- Francis Lacoste, French Resident General in Morocco, has returned to his post after discussions in Paris about the problem of restoring confidence and security in this troubled protectorate.

Through the purchase of stock of the Lion Realty Corporation, Max Bregman has acquired control of the five-story apartment house at 20 East Sixty-sixth Street. The building, on lot 50 by 100 feet, contains suites of one to three rooms.
SOUTHPORT, England, July 9 (AP) -- Cards of Australia's Peter Thomson, winner of the British open golf tournament today, and the American players:
HARTFORD, July 9 (AP) -A. passenger's complaint today broughtI a reprimand to the New York,I New Haven Hartford Railroad] for overcrowding an excursion train.
The widening inquiry into Fire Department rackets has disclosed evidence of kickbacks and pay-splitting in inspection of refrigeration equipment.

Commodity prices drifted yesterday on the New York exchanges in the usual pre-weekend lull. Cocoa, rubber, hides, wool, burlap and zinc were lower; potatoes, silk and tin ended higher and coffee, sugar, cottonseed oil and soybean oil closed mixed.

CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- A Commodity Exchange Authority official testified today that the Chicago egg market was pushed to "an artificial level" in December, 1952, "by a group of traders doing business under some form of control."

Readers of this newspaper have doubtless noted, in the financial pages on Saturdays, Stacy Jones' dry and often witty weekly report from Washington of the latest inventions on which patents have been granted.
ST. LOUIS, July 9 (UP) -- Gene Baker drove in four runs, including the winning tally in the eleventh inning tonight, as the Chicago Cubs beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 6 -- 4.

The proudest boast of democracy is that under such a system persons are free to criticize even the President. On major public issues such criticism has been expressed traditionally through picketing of the White House.
The seventeenth general council meeting of the World Presbyterian Alliance will be held at the Princeton Theological Seminary July 27 to Aug. 5.
The address by Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts at the Lions International convention here yesterday follows:
DETROIT, July 9 (UP) -- The Baltimore Orioles pushed across five runs in the sixth inning today and moved to a 7 -- 5 triumph over the Detroit Tigers before 3,240 fans at Briggs Stadium.
LONDON, July 9 -- Britain hopes to begin building "advanced" types of atomic power stations within five and a half years, Parliament was told today.

WASHINGTON, July 9- -William F. Tompkins of Maplewood, N. J., was sworn in today as an Assistant Attorney General. He will have charge of the new Internal Security Division of the Department of Justice.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Yankees bore something of a charmed life to win tonight.

Dorothy Bennett, author of "The Golden Encyclopedia" and "Sold to the Ladies," received recently the Outstanding Achievement Medal of the University of Minnesota. The presentation was made at the twenty-fifth anniversary Library School Alumni dinner in Minneapolis.

HANOI, Vietnam, July 9 -- The Vietminh has intensified its infiltration harassment of the French Union positions within a twenty-five mile radius of Hanoi. The Communist-led insurgents are striking on the northeast, northwest, southeast and south, it was disclosed here today.
