WASHINGTON, July 9 -Rail passengers commuting between points in Northern New Jersey for distances over four miles will have to pay more if the Interstate Commerce Commission adopts the recommendations proposed today by one of its examiners.

KOHLER, Wis., July 9 (AP) -- Herbert V. Kohler, president of the strike-bound Kohler Company, today rejected a proposal by Gov. Walter Kohler Jr. of Wisconsin, who is his nephew, that the long and bitter dispute be submitted to arbitration.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 9 -- Nassau County, which boasts four Long Island state parks, will have a swank new $1,700,000 clubhouse of its own at the county park at Salisbury. Building plans are expected to be approved at a meeting of the Board of Supervisors on Monday.

The Brooklyn Handicap will be the big attraction at the Aqueduct race track today. Recognized as the third part of the handicap triple crown, the Brooklyn has always been a popular event, and its sixty-sixth running is expected to attract a crowd of more than 30,000.

The Royal State Bank of New York has leased banking space on the ground floor of 245 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of East Twenty-eighth Street, and will move its main office there from 1134 Broadway about Dec. 1.

Shoppers increased their spending in the week ended on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Spurred by traditional post-Independence Day sales, volume was found to be ahead of that of the week before and also ahead of that of the same week a year ago.

Larry Jansen, a front-line pitcher for the Giants since he joined the club in 1947, was removed from the active list and made a coach yesterday. The 33-year-old right-hander said he hopes to make a comeback next season. In the meantime, Al Corwin has been recalled from Minneapolis to fill the gap.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 9 -- An angry anti-Indian mood fanned by seven years of frustration in efforts to settle canal waters dispute with India developed throughout Pakistan today. It came as a climax to the opening in India yesterday of the 677-mile Bhakra Canal.

The proposal by the North Atlantic United Kingdom Freight Conference of a minimum rate of $25 a ton on all cargo moved on "express" liners has aroused a storm of protest among shippers here. The new rate was to become effective Sept. 1.

LONDON, July 9 -- A British trade delegation of a dozen manufacturers and importers will visit Peiping in November, Sir Harry Pilkington, president of the Federation of British Industries, announced today.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, United States Ambassador to Italy, said today she was optimistic about a settlement of the Trieste problem "in the not too distant future."

VIENNA, July 9 -- The Danube River flooded thousands of homes today in 100 or more villages in Austria and southern Germany Thirteen persons were known to have died in the floods. Many others were marooned.
The interesting letters published in your columns recently from James P. Warburg and Perry Laukhuff on German rearming cover many of the issues involved.

The George Comfort Company, Inc., broker, has arranged mortgage financing for a large plant built in Egg Harbor, near Atlantic City, N. J., for Lenox, Inc., maker of chinaware, and for a new cooperative apartment group in Bronxville, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Senate Republicans redoubled today their efforts to fix the blame for present Asian crises largely on past Democratic Administrations. The foreign policy issue was progressively sharpening for this Congressional election year as the Democrats renewed their counter-charge that the Eisenhower Administration was failing in the Far East.

NEWARK, July 9 -- The Legalized Games of Chance Control Commission of New Jersey invoked its punitive powers for the first time today. It revoked three licenses for bingo games and raffles issued to Volunteer Protec Fire Company 1 of Woodbridge Township, Middlesex County, and declared the company ineligible to apply for another license for a year.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., July 9 -- Phil Steckler of Scarsdale sprung the big surprise today as quarter-final brackets of the New York State men's tennis championship were filled at the County Tennis Club of Westchester.
The Health Department expects every property owner to do his duty in the ninth annual campaign against ragweed.

Col. Carlos Castillo Armas, who has just become president of the governing junta of Guatemala, did not owe the success of his revolution entirely to chicanery and corruption behind the Iron Curtain, but he certainly profited by them. Colonel Castillo Armas was able to travel from the border of Honduras to Guatemala City with comparatively little bloodshed partly because the Government army did not have any adequate weapons with which to fight him.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Senator William J. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, made a sweeping denial in the Senate today of all charges leveled against President Eisenhower's proposal to have a private plant supple power to the Tennessee Valley Authority.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- Wheat prices weakened under free selling in the early trade on reports of more liberal country sales in the Southwest and a continued lull in flour demand. Mill buying in the pit was of moderate volume. There was some commission absorption on resting orders on the declines, but rallies were not specially convincing.
WASHINGTON, Saturday, July 10 -- Government and union officials agreed yesterday on terms to end walkouts in two atomic plants.

Thomas Scherman will make his debut at Lewisohn Stadium Monday evening, conducting the Stadium Symphony Orchestra in a program of dance music featuring the first performance of Morton Gould's "Concerto for Tap Dancer and Orchestra." Danny Daniels will be the soloist.

Roman Hilewetz, 64-year-old Brooklyn handyman, for years carried with him a .38 cartridge, a memento of World War I, in which he served. Then he decided to turn gunsmith and fashion a revolver from which the pellet could be fired.

About 14,000 holders of Commonwealth Edison Company preferred stand to lose stock conversion privileges worth about $1,300,000 if they don't exchange their shares for common stock by July 22. Thereafter, unconverted shares now worth $40.375 each will be redeemed by the company at call prices of $32 and $32.50.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, July 9 (AP) -- The United Fruit Company of Boston and leaders of 23,500 strikers tonight signed an agreement settling a two-month walkout that had paralyzed the company's banana operations on the North Coast here.

SOUTHPORT, England, July 9 -- Twenty-four-year-old Peter William Thomson of Australia is the new British open golf champion. He shot rounds of 72, 71, 69, 71 for a total of 283 to defeat Bobby Locke of South Africa, Dai Rees of Wales and Sydney Simeon Scott of England by one stroke and become the youngest champion since the immortal Bob Jones.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 (UP) -- Two home runs by Joe DeMaestri and one each by Bill Renna and Bill Wilson paced the Athletics to a 9-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight to end a four-game Philadelphia losing streak.
UNITED NATIONS, July 9 -- Guatemala ousted today the diplomat who pleaded the case of the deposed Arbenz Government before the United Nations.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, July 9 (UP) -- The regional director of the National Labor Relations Board asked for a Federal court injunction today to keep the waterfront strike from further paralyzing local industry.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- A special Presidential committee of Governors urged today the construction at any cost of a great warning system in the Pacific and Far East to guarantee against "future Pearl Harbors."

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee today completed hearings on the Administration's Social Security bill with testimony from State welfare directors strongly supporting the legislation.

Out from under the oppressive shadow of the Giants, the Dodgers resumed being the Dodgers again last night, rallying from three runs behind in the ninth to defeat the Phillies, 7 -- 5, in ten innings at Ebbets Field.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- President Eisenhower suffered another loss today in his fight for flexible farm price supports.

On top of a few other worries, the Dodgers are faced with the possible loss, perhaps for good, of Roy Campanella, their all-star catcher and the National League's most valuable player of 1953, it was learned last night.
ALBANY, July 9 (AP) -- A ten-member temporary commission was appointed today to study financial relations and duplication of Government functions between villages and towns.

Dr. Samuel M. Brownell, United States Commissioner of Education, said yesterday that the problems of crowded classrooms and teacher shortages would be solved only when the public became concerned and did not leave the job entirely to educators.

Dr. Charles W. Hughes, suspended associate Professor of Music at Hunter College, refused again yesterday to identify other faculty members who were fellow members of a Communist cell at the college from 1938 to 1941.
GUATEMALA, July 9 -- Safe conduct assurances for Jacobo Arbenz Guzman, deposed President, his wife and two youngest children were asked today by Mexico.
OTTAWA, July 9 -- The Ontario Hydroelectric Commission called today for the first bids for work on the power part of the St. Lawrence Seaway project.

ST. LOUIS, July 9 (AP) -- Harvey Haddix, the St. Louis Cardinal southpaw, aggravated a knee injury last night in becoming the major leagues' first thirteen-game winner and will not play in the All-Star game at Cleveland next Tuesday.

ELKIN, N. C., July 9 (UP)The Textile Workers Union, C. I. O., filed unfair labor practices charges today against the blanket manufacturing concern headed by RepresentativeThurmond D. Chatham of that state. He and other company officials denied union charges of "coercion and intimidation."

GENEVA, July 9 (AP) -- Steel production in Communist Europe took a great leap forward last year, while that of Western Europe declined slightly, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today.

The four-story apartment house accommodating thirty families at 87-74 150th Street in Jamaica, Queens, has been sold by Ralph R. Janis, as liquidating trustee of the Morral Realty Corporation, to an investing customer of the Advance Realty Company, broker in the transaction.
The public market for new capital is getting a crowded look again, as far as new corporate bond issues are concerned.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 9 (AP) -- Katie Key, 7-year-old bay mare owned by Pat Tuccio of Riverhead, L. I., and driven by Clint Hodgins, led all the way tonight to score a half-length victory over Royal Pastime in 2:02 3/5 at Roosevelt Raceway in the featured Malvern free-for-all trot. Torch Key was third.

PARIS, July 9 -- The French Government has told Washington that any armistice line or political boundary dividing Indochina after a cease-fire would require a United States guarantee to have any great security or permanence.

I have recently seen some discussion in the press concerning the desirability of employing prisoners on farms and public works for the mutual benefit of the state and the prisoners. In none of these discussions have I seen it pointed out that this has been the practice in the State of New Jersey for many years.
GENEVA, July 9 -- The Soviet Union has submitted a resolution to the Economic and Social Council calling upon the Secretary General of the United Nations to convoke a world conference on trade.

Stocks ended their fourth successive week with a net gain yesterday, closing with a sprint that carried The New York Times combined average to 221.94 for a gain of 1.36 points. This was the highest close since June 5, 1930.
The porgies, sea bass, flounders and their cousins in the waters off Staten Island went on a "lost week-end" yesterday on 14,000 fifths of imitation Scotch.

LONDON, July 9 -- The stock markets here ended a boom week with prices still rising, despite profit-taking. Industrial shares resumed their advance after absorbing this selling. The week's volume was the highest in six months.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., July 9 -- Dave Baldwin, a left-handed amateur from Baltusrol, put the finishing touches to one of the biggest golf surprises in the East this season as he captured the thirty-fourth New Jersey open championship today.

BARABOO, Wis., July 9 (UP) -- District Attorney Harlan Kelley filed a twenty-one-count warrant in Circuit Court here today, charging that the "Joe Must Go" club had broken a state law that made illegal the donation of money by Wisconsin corporations for political purposes.
LONDON, July 9 -- The British Government has decided to reject French proposals for an extensive revision of the European Defense Community Treaty.

LENOX, Mass., July 9 -- Twenty-eight hundred people somehow managed to pack themselves into and about the theatre-concert hall this evening at Tanglewood for the first concert of the Bach-Mozart series of the Berkshire Festival of 1954.
PHENIX CITY, Ala., July 9 (AP) -- Reformers seeking to dislodge criminal leaders who have held the town under control for many years were armed today with some 200 recordings.

CLINTON, Conn., July 9 -- A check of fishing possibilities from the Cape Cod Canal to the mouth of the Hammonasset indicates that the angler not only has variety, but an assurance of abundance in many coastal resorts.
ANKARA, Turkey, July 9 -- A serious disagreement has arisen over the extent of Yugoslavia's obligations to aid Greece and Turkey under the proposed alliance being negotiated by the three governments.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted tentatively today to cut $238,208,000 from the $3,338,000,000 in foreign aid funds that had been approved by the House of Representatives June 30.

The parents of Iraq are as concerned about crime and horror "comic" books as are those in this country, according to Mrs. Sarah Jamali, mother of three sons and wife of Mohammed Fadhil Jamali, Iraq's Minister of Foreign Affairs.
Burlington Mills Corporation announced yesterday the purchase of a large block of Pacific Mills stock and offered to buy additional shares in the open market.

The Rev. William B. Spofford Sr. of Tunkahannock, Pa., a Protestant Episcopal minister and a director of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship, Inc., testified yesterday that the council was not dominated by Communists.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- A measure calling for a 5 per cent pay rise for 500,000 postal workers, with a minimum increase of $200 a year, was approved by the House of Representatives' Post Office Committee today. This opened the way for a possible pay increase for a million other Government employes and a general increase in postal rates.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today withdrew its orber prohibiting six Eastern railroads from transporting highway trailers on flat cars.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today forecast this year's corn crop at 3,311,493,000 bushels and the wheat crop at 988,321,000 bushels.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 point to 110.0 over the week ended Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Higher average prices for processed foods, principally meats, and for some industrial commodities more than offset a decrease in the index of farm products.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 9 (Reuters) -- The Belgian Foreign Ministry announced here tonight that the Soviet Union had "rejected all responsibility" for shooting up a Belgian transport plane near the Hungarian-Yugoslav border on June 3.
The Transit Authority asked the city yesterday for $172,062,000 in capital funds for improvements next year on the publicly owned subway and elevated lines.
TOKYO, July 9 -- Withdrawal of all United States ground forces from Japan may begin by the end of next year, Japanese sources said today.
LONDON, July 9 (AP) -- The Soviet Union disclosed today that it had asked Iran for explanations of alleged Teheran defense talks with the West.

Neutral observers in Ankara are said to be disturbed by the trend of recent legislation and to have expressed the fear that it may threaten the future of Turkish democracy. The Government, powerfully supported in the last election, has pushed through several measures that the Opposition feels to be unreasonable.
MANILA, July 9 (AP) -- The Philippines' new law -- Filipino retail trade for Filipinos -- has touched off jitters among foreign businessmen here and a storm of protest from abroad.
Frank E. (Jimmy) Kilroe was appointed yesterday to the post of racing secretary and handicapper for The Jockey Club, to take over the duties of John B. Campbell, who died on Wednesday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 9 -- India demanded today that the United States stop all nuclear tests in the Pacific islands until the International Court of Justice ruled that it had a right to conduct such experiments.

CINCINNATI, July 9 (UP) -- Jim Greengrass drove in four runs tonight with a first-inning three-run homer and an eighth-inning single to give the Redlegs a 5-3 victory over the Milwaukee Braves before 20,410 fans and end Cincinnati's three-game losing streak.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Capt. Hsuan Wei, Chinese Nationalist Marine Corps officer who refused to return to Formosa with his unit last month, has been turned over to the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service, it was announced tonight.

The Foreign Ministers of the major Powers (except one) are again gathering in Geneva for what looks like the final round of the conference on Indochina. Mr. Molotov has already arrived, M. Mendes-France arrives today, Mr. Chou En-lai is on the way and Mr. Eden is due on Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UP) -- The Soviet Union has cracked down on nine writers and musicians in an apparent reversal of trends started after Stalin's death last year, the United States Information Agency reported today.

Summer, we all agree, is here. But it's still young and like the spikes of corn has yet to grow its beard of age. The youthful season is sweet and gentle with little hint of what will come when it finds strength and maturity.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 9 -- A special military court has unanimously acquitted forty-four persons accused of subversive activities among the military. The judges ruled yesterday that the prosecution had not produced satisfactory evidence.

By the end of this month two foods, Bartlett pears and turkeys, are expected to be so plentiful that the United States Department of Agriculture and producers have designated the period from July 29 to Aug. 7 as both Midsummer Turkey Time and National Vegetable Week.
LONDON, July 9 (Reuters) -- British newspapers again criticized today President Eisenhower's refusal to consider Chinese Communist membership in the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- A German received a patent this week for a method of stabilizing building foundations with a liquid that has at least one attribute of mayonnaise.

LOS ANGELES, July 9 -- KTHE, one of the nation's pioneer educational television stations, is being forced by financial problems to reduce its activities to what may be little more than a token operation.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday it had accepted a tariff amendment filed by Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., designed to increase rates for steam service by five cents on each 1,000 pounds under all service classifications.

GENEVA, July 9 -- The final phase of the Indochina truce negotiations will start tomorrow with the arrival of Pierre Mendes-France. He took over three weeks ago as French Premier and Foreign Minister with the promise that he would get an armistice by July 20 or resign.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., July 9 -- Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, Commanding General of the Seventy-seventh Infantry Division of the Army Reserve and a leading advocate of Universal Military Training, will retire from the Army next Dec. 31.

BEDFORD, Ind., July 9 (AP) -- Senator William E. Jenner called "absurd" tonight the request of a former Communist turned Government witness that his Internal Security subcommittee investigate Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. and his deputy, William P. Rogers.

FORT DIX, N. J., July 9 -- The Army has relieved from duty the commanding officer and the administrative first sergeant of a company whose 225 enlisted trainees were made to stand at attention in 90-degree heat for an hour in an alleged unauthorized mass disciplinary action.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 9 -- The Superior Court in Los Angeles has been asked to adjudicate a dispute concerning ownership rights to the ballet numbers created by Jerome Robbins for "High Button Shoes," a hit Broadway attraction in 1947.
A motorist allegedly grabbed a policeman's nightstick and attacked him with it yesterday afternoon after receiving a traffic ticket for making an illegal turn in the Bronx.

MANILA, July 10 -- In the face of Communist gains in Indochina President Ramon Magsaysay is pushing implementation of the American-Philippine mutual defense pact. Conferring with President Eisenhower's special envoy, Gen. James A. Van Fleet, President Magsaysay reaffirmed all-out support of American leadership in the fight on communism.

UP to now there have been two complete recordings of the sixteen Beethoven String Quartets -- the Pascal Quartet (Concert Hall) and Budapest Quartet (Columbia) -and goodness knows how many recordings of individual ones.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, said tonight that Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, the Democratic leader, was not speaking for the Democratic party in suggesting the United States should quit the United Nations if Red China was admitted.

AN original novel, by de Camp, and a reprint, by Simak, are presented in this two-books-in-one volume, but if only Simak's fascinating account of alternate (if not quite parallel) earths were offered this book would still be a tremendous bargain.
DALLAS, July 10 (AP) -- Dallas carded a 220 today and easily won the team championship of the national public links golf tournament.
PRINCETON, N. J., July 10 -The Princeton Institute of Theology, which attracted representatives of thirty-two denominations last year, will convene Monday at the Princeton Theological Seminary.
RABAT, French Morocco, July 10 -- The French authorities in Morocco report slow progress in their efforts to deal with Nationalist terrorism.
ALBANY, July 10 (AP) -- Governor Dewey today appointed Charles S. Hamilton Jr. of Pleasantville as a Moreland Act Commissioner to continue an inquiry into workmen's compensation costs.

LONDON, July 10 -- The British Government would like to have United States Secretary of State John Foster Dulles present at the closing phase of the Geneva conference on Far Eastern affairs. The Government believes no peace settlement for Indochina will be worth while without the United States approval.

CLEVELAND, July 10 -- The major league all-star game returns to Municipal Stadium after a nineteen-year absense Tuesday and officials predicted today that attendance and receipts records would be established.
TRENTON, July 10 -- A seventeen-mile stretch of the Garden State Parkway between Toms River and Route 72, Manahawkin, in Ocean County, will be opened Thursday.

THIS is the story of a love that was deep enough to defy conventions and withstand the ostracism and censure of a small community. It was a love strong enough to give comfort to children even after they learned why they were so cruelly set apart.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -- Two years ago next Wednesday began a continent-wide undertaking vital to United States defense.
The Saxon Stables' Invigorator, with the distinguished George Edward Arcaro in the saddle, won at a non-Arcaran price in the $58,600 Brooklyn Handicap as Aqueduct's four-week meeting ended yesterday.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 10 -- Artismo got off in front and remained in front all the way to win the $25,800 Lamplighter Handicap at Monmouth Park today. The colt, owned by James Cox Brady, was ridden by Dave Gorman and his chances were considered so light that he returned $32 in the straight mutuels.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Eisenhower Administration denied today that its proposal for a private combine to supply power to the Tennessee Valley Authority was part of a plan to "dismember" the twenty-one-year-old natural resource development project.

At the Eisenhower-Churchill meeting in Washington two weeks ago major public interest centered on the problems of the Far East on which the U. S. and Britain are divided. But the two leaders devoted most of their talk to an old problem on which they are in virtually complete agreement.
RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 10 -- Thirty-nine craft started tonight in the Riverside Yacht Clubs twenty-third over-night race to Stratford Shoal and return.
CLEVELAND, July 10 (AP) -- Timely Tip, the second choice, won the Ohio Derby at Thistle Down Park today at 7 -- 2.

MUNSAN, Korea, July 10 (AP) -The United Nations Command warned the Communists today that it had ordered the civil police "to protect themselves by all available means that may be brought to bear" in the event of future attacks by Communist soldiers.
ALBANY, July 10 -- The Temporary State Commission on the Courts has a plan with which it hopes to reduce the high cost to the individual of pursuing a case through the courts.
WHEN D. D. Livingston and Hope Sheridan thought up the idea of a summer dance festival in New York, to compete with the choreographic strawhat circuit, they had to take their courage in their hands.

IN the past ten years or so, the word "character," meaning a person, usually of considerable eccentricity, has been run ragged. Talkers laboriously seeking to give flavor to their speech have been saying "I met this character," and so on and so on, instead of saying "I met this man," which is the simple way of talking, and also the more endurable way.

FOR those who, like me, hold to the belief that the perceptive reporting of a factual criminal case can cast more light upon human character and psychology than all but the greatest novels, the Nineteen Fifties have offered a succession of bright searchlights.

The University of Pennsylvania has added new curricula in its program of education for adults, leading to the degrees of Associate in Arts and Associate in Business Administration. The degrees will provide a goal for part-time students who lack the time or resources to work for a bachelor's degree.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The suddenly breaking storm in Congress over Communist China's long effort to enter the United Nations involves perhaps the most complicated series of factors to rise here since World War II.

THE collecting of old stereoscopic photographs, the popular pictorial medium of entertainment and information of the second half of the last century, is discussed exhaustively in the current issue of Eye to Eye, quarterly bulletin of the Graphic History Society of America.

ABOUT this time of year the preliminary sounds of music festivals, getting organized for the summer season, begin to be heard in the land. All over the country, in Colorado, North Carolina, Michigan, California and Virginia, these festivals have created a new "season" for music, which used to hibernate during the summer.

ALBANY, July 10 (UP) -- Garth A. Shoemaker, president of the Citizens Public Expenditure Survey, said today that a proposal that "federal assistance" be given states to raise teachers' salaries was "foolish."

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The emphasis in Washington for the time being is on the negative. There are, of course, many exceptions, but in general the Government seems to be acting as if more progress can be made by stopping bad things than by doing good things.

SMITHTOWN, L. I., July 10 -- Ralph Marcano, 30 years old, a commercial artist, was held today on a first-degree manslaughter charge in connection with the death of his 18-month-old girl baby, Thaubet.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- Business volume during June in the Chicago area slipped from the May levels, but second quarter volume maintained a slight edge over first quarter business, according to the monthly survey of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago.

RANGOON, July 10 -- The Burmese display grave concern and show great interest in happenings in Indochina. Because of religious affinity they look with greater sympathy on Buddhist Laos and Cambodia than on Vietnam.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10 -- During the first five months of 1954 industrial activity in Pennsylvania was 14 per cent below that of 1953, according to figures compiled by the Bureau of Business Research at the Pennsylvania State University.
GUATEMALA, July 10 -- The Guatemalan Government plans to take stringent health measures in all embassies harboring political refugees.
GENEVA, July 10 -- Pierre Mendes-France, French Premier and Foreign Minister, arrived this evening from Paris for the critical closing days of the negotiations on Indochina.

CINCINNATI, July 10 (UP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs routed Warren Spahn during a five-run rally in the sixth inning today and went on to beat the Milwaukee Braves, 7 -- 3, with the help of homers by Chuck Harmon, Jim Greengrass and Wally Post.

WEST SAYVILLLE, L. I., July 10 -- The once prosperous oyster industry in Great South Bay received an optimistic report today from Dr. George H. Vanderborgh of G. Vanderborgh Sons, a shellfish concern, who said the bay was more pollution-free than it had been for the last nine years.
JERUSALEM, June 27 -- Israelis will continue to enjoy their bread, confections and edible oils at subsidized low prices. But they will pay a new tax to cover what the Government spends for subsidies.

Your editorial on educational television in the July 4 issue of The Times quotes Commissioner Lee of the F. C. C. on the number of applications which have been filed for permits to build educational television stations on reserve channels.

THOUGH the old home of the Armstrongs on the Hudson, near Newburgh, was pulled down many years ago to make way for a brickyard, there is no danger that the family will be forgotten. Too many members have been heard from.

VIENNA, July 10 (AP) -- Central Europe's worst floods in fifty years carried their destruction today into the Czechoslovak capital of Prague. In Austria and Germany up to 50,000 persons were believed homeless.

IN North Africa, the land of veiled women, dwell the veiled men. These are the Tuareg: nomads of the Sahara, fierce warriors, and certainly among the world's most menacing-looking inhabitants, with slitted eyes showing above their dark blue or white face-coverings (called the litham), the rest of their bodies sheathed in cloaks.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- Dr. Alice Masaryk, daughter and sister of leaders of the former Republic of Czechoslovakia, would be given permanent residence in this country under a bill passed by the Senate today and sent to the House.

The neighborhood hand laundry, a handy aid to the harried housewife, is out to make a comeback. Almost driven into extinction in the late Nineteen Thirties by the development of efficient laundering machines, and further inhibited in the post-war period by the popularity of the home washing machine, the hand laundry has gotten another chance because synthetic fabrics have made home laundering complicated.
HOUSTON, Tex., July 10 -- The inclusion of Administration-backed flexible price supports in the farm bill passed by the House has received general approval throughout Texas.

A GROUP of Oxford scholars is gathering today at a quiet Welsh graveyard to celebrate the two-hundredth birthday of an eighteenth-century prude who considered Shakespeare in the raw "unfit to be perused by the eye of delicacy." and published a ten-volume cleaned-up "Family Shakespeare."
TWO men who dreamed of and worked toward the present state of Israel, but did not live to see it founded, are to be honored by that country on separate commemorative stamps this month and next.

NO plant is more striking than yucca -- in its own setting. That may be clinging to the side of a canyon in southern California or near a sandy dune in South Carolina. Yucca also is seen in northern gardens.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 (UP) -- Five amateur sailors on a raft they hope will take them to Hawaii asked for help today after drifting twenty-two miles and ending up four miles closer to shore than when they had been set adrift.

WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind., July 10 (UP) -- Herbert Brownell Jr. said today the Administration's campaign against domestic Communists had been "vigorous and successful" and had proceeded "with a careful regard for individual dignity and rights."
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 10 -- A breakfast of coffee and a sweet roll is bad for the breadwinner, a two-year survey by a team of Rutgers University scientists indicates.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles has withheld any decision for or against returning for the final phase of the Geneva Far Eastern conference pending a fuller understanding here of the terms of a possible Indochinese settlement.

Dr. Arthur Smithies, chairman of the Harvard University economics department, has been named chairman of the annual summer seminar in advanced studies of the Institute of World Affairs, 522 Fifth Avenue. The seminar will start and continue to Aug. 30 at the institute's 600-acre campus at Twin Lakes, Conn.

JAKARTA, July 10 -- Chou En-lai's South Asian tour, accompanied by French military withdrawals in Indochina and continued indecision on Southeast Asia in the Anglo - American camp, has contributed to a general feeling in Indonesia that communism may be the winning side in Asia.

The scoreboard's report on the Giants provided the chief excitement for 18.998 spectators at Ebbets Field yesterday. The Dodgers took all the suspense out of their own game with the Phillies by putting across five runs in the fourth inning. From there, they breezed to a 10-5 victory behind Billy Loes.

A B. GUTHRIE Jr., author of the Pulitzer Prize novel "The Way West" and "The Big Sky," is forthright in his admiration of the finer things Hollywood people frequently accomplish, and tolerant of their mistakes, which also are frequent and inevitable, in the course of making close to 300 pictures a year.

URANIUM CITY, Sask., July 5 -- The inhabitants of this self-styled city are beginning to think in terms of atomic power, although Uranium City has as yet no municipal status, sewers, sidewalks, hospital or even a permanent water supply.

GRAND VIEW, N. Y., July 10 -Four road signs went up today in this little residential village, where no road signs have ever been permitted before. What is more, Elmer Hader, village zoning commissioner for the last thirty years, erected the signs himself and with the full approval of the villagers.

For the second week retail sales figures were affected by the fact that Independence Day was celebrated this year on a Monday and last year on a Saturday. This year the majority of stores were open four days against five last ear and stores that are open on Saturday did business five days this year against six last year.

TO a small boys' parochial school in a coastal town in western Ireland comes a new appointee for the first grade, young Nora Byrne. Nora's colleagues are three males: Peter Lynch, the principal, mild and 40, who lives with his waspish sister Helen; Brennan, a morbid, defeated soul; and young Murphy, harshly cynical.

THOSE shopping the wholesale home furnishings markets held here late last month were given a formidable review of furniture fashions for fall. The merchandise on view, which will become generally available in the stores this fall, was the fanciest, fussiest, most decorated that has been around for many a year.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 10 -- Theophilus E. Donges, Minister of Interior, has announced a campaign to ferret out Communists in administration and more particularly in schools and universities on lines similar to the investigations in the United States and Australia.

DETROIT, July 10 (AP) -- Spur On, a stretch-running son of Whirlaway, took advantage of a "lucky break" today and sped his way through a field of sixteen starters to win the $50,000 added Michigan Mile -- Michigan's richest horse race.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission said today that Sunshine Biscuits, Inc., had consented to an order prohibiting exclusive-dealing practices in the sale of packaged bakery products.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 10 (UP) -- Anti-revolutionary measures decreed here two days ago were suspended today, and officials indicated their belief that the threat of attack had passed.

American methods of social work should be recast to fit conditions in undeveloped countries, in the opinion of Michel P. Goutos, Secretary General of the Greek Ministry of Social Welfare. He has just wound up a fortnight's visit to the United States and Canada.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 10 -- Dr. T. F. Tsiang, Nationalist China's delegate, warned today that if the prestige of United Nations membership was given to Communist China, it would be used by Peiping to promote "imperialist expansion in Asia."

NEWARK, July 10 -- William Howe Davis, director of the New Jersey Division of Alcoholic Beverage Control, laid down a ruling today that forbade the sale of alcoholic drinks from coin slot machines.

BEETHOVEN: Violin Concerto; Yehudi Menuhin and Philharmonia Orchestra conducted by Wilhelm Furtwaengler (H. M. V.). Exceptionally fine recorded sound here, and a broad, large-scale performance with that indefinable authority that comes when major artists are in good form.

Faced with a need for additional classroom facilities -- a need that will become dangerously acute within a decade -- communities throughout the country have begun to plan for the future. They have mapped out building programs designed to meet the tremendous growth in enrollment that is on the way.

To provide students with new and enriched opportunities for cultural studies and to extend its courses preparatory to professional services in various art fields, Boston University has organized a School of Fine and Applied Arts.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted tentatively today to halt military and other aid to France and Italy Dec. 31 unless by that time they had ratified the treaty for the European Defense Community or an acceptable alternative.
MONTREAL, July 10 (UP) -The du Pont Company of Canada has announced plans to build a $1,500,000 laboratory at Kingston, Ont.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -Key members of the Senate Finance Committee today predicted approval of the Social Security bill by that group just about as President Eisenhower wanted it, except possibly for some changes in the coverage provisions.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The United States Consul in Hanoi has advised a few remaining "non-official" Americans to leave the area because of the "deteriorating security conditions" in the Red River delta.

LOS ALAMOS, N. M., July 10 -- When Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, arrives in Los Alamos next week, he is bound to hear about what is commonly referred to as "the open gate controversy."

TEHERAN, Iran, July 10 -- Through press and diplomatic channels Moscow is trying hard to pry out of the government of Premier Fazlollah Zahedi a public commitment that it will not join with Turkey and Pakistan in a Middle East defense alliance.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 10 (AP) -- Ray Billows, Poughkeepsie, N. Y., and Jay C. Jerome, the defending champion, of Bennington, gained the final of the twenty-sixth Robert Todd Lincoln amateur golf tournament today.
LONDON, July 10 -- Britain's aircraft industry, which pioneered jet propulsion, will mark Monday the tenth anniversary of the delivery of the first jet fighter to the Royal Air Force.
ALBANY, July 10 -- The State Commerce Department has concluded that New York State is "the mecca of ambitious men and women from every state in the Union and from every foreign land as well."
DETROIT, July 10 (UP) -- Ned Garver scattered seven hits today to pitch the Detroit Tigers to a 2-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles before 6,729 fans at Briggs Stadium.

PRENTISS, Miss., July 10 (AP) -- Prentiss, once the seat of Bolivar County and the eastern landing of the only ferry crossing the Mississippi between Vicksburg and Memphis, is no longer on the map.
HANOI, Vietnam, July 10 -- Four posts within twenty-five miles of Hanoi were overrun by Vietminh troops last night.

DALLAS, July 10 -- A long Fourth of July week-end cut into department store sales last week, but business indicators generally were good. A midsummer bank call found the area's banks in most instances with substantial gains in deposits and resources,

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday his approval of a five-point program for making the city's port "the greatest in the world." He plans to do this by restoring its prestige, improving its business and expanding its facilities.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., July 10 (UP) -- A pleasure boat carrying eleven men on a Hudson River moonlight cruise crashed into a barge early today ten miles north of here. One man was reported drowned and two were injured.

NEW DELHI, July 10 -- The present situation in Indochina has provided Indians with a means of testing Chinese Premier Chou En-lai's assurances to Prime Minister Nehru of efforts to put an early end to the fighting.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, who was Secretary of Agriculture in the Truman Administration, today denounced the Senate's new farm bill as "impossible and miserable" and predicted its defeat unless it was modified.

Earnings of leading New York City banks were higher in the first half of 1954, despite a decline in money rates and business loans. Higher income and profits on securities more than offset a decline in returns from commercial borrowing, condition statements for June 30 indicated. Second quarter profits, too, were mostly higher than a year ago.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- There is now a good chance that Congress, before it adjourns, will take up a security problem that has been worrying many of its members for a long time. NORTH BAY, Ont., July 10 (UP) -- Two Royal Canadian Air Force Vampire jet fighters collided and crashed in flames near here today in the second fatal accident in less than twenty-four hours since the beginning of "Operation Checkpoint," largest air defense test in North American history.

ROSE bloom in gardens in the New York suburbs this past June was far better than average, evidently helped along by a mild winter, sufficient rain in May and relatively cool weather at the height of flowering.

GUATEAMALA, July 10 (AP) -The junta announced today it was starting an investigation to find out how the Arbenz Government bought the arms that arrived in May from Stettin, Poland, and whether it ever paid the bill.
CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- Driving stretch runs paid off today for Our Prince and Sickle's Image as they won the two $20,000 added co-features at Arlington Park.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 10 -- Althea Gibson, New York, and Isabel Troccole, the Bronx, favorites to reach the final of the New York State women's tennis championship, will meet for the title at the Pelham Country Club tomorrow.

The stock market started strong last week and soared to new twenty-four-year highs, but its momentum was not sustained. A mild reaction set in at mid-week as the trading pace slackened and prices receded moderately.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 10 -- Betts Nashem's Honeybrook from Greenwich, Conn., had a good start in the working hunter division today at the opening of the annual two-day New Brunswick horse show. The 5-year-old mare won two events, was second twice and fourth once for a 5 1/2-point advantage over the next contender, Mr. and Mrs. F. W. Janssen's G. Junior.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- Senators investigating multi-million-dollar post-war housing irregularities will take testimony Monday from one of the backers of a Brooklyn, N. Y., apartment project built with a Government-insured loan alleged to have exceeded construction cost by $3,500,000.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- The American Bar Association will be represented at the fifth International Conference of the Legal Profession at Monte Carlo, Monaco, July 19 to 24. The conference will be sponsored by the International Bar Association and will consider various aspects of international law.

ST. LOUIS, July 10 (AP) -- Joe Frazier blasted a pinch hit two-run homer in the ninth inning tonight to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 2-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs. Red Schoendienst's hitting streak was stopped at twenty-eight consecutive games by Bob Rush of the Cubs.

Since the end of World War II, group insurance protection for American families has tripled. In its various forms, group insurance now covers about 34,000,000 persons, primarily for benefits in the hospital and surgical fields.

PORTLAND, ORE., July 10 (UP) -- to end a twenty-day lumber strike by 100,000 United States workers will be renewed Monday as the result of a "package" contract settlement with 32,000 Canadian woodmen.

FOR many years now, considerable lip service has been paid to the concept of a National Theatre. What is meant by a National Theatre? What effect might it have on the economy of our country and the lives of our citizens?

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 10 -- Israel has complained to the United Nations that Jordan has desecrated the ancient Jewish cemetery on the Mount of Olives in Jerusalem. The cemetery, considered among the oldest in the Western world, is situated in an area that has been under Arab control since 1947.

The constant backdrop against which Kristina Czaykowska's day-to-day problems are met is the world of the Paris haute couture, where authoress Orme herself worked for over a year.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- A back-to-work vote at Paducah, Ky., ended the Government's atomic strike crisis tonight, for the time being at least. The vote was reported as 329 to 96. About 1,000 workers were involved in the strike there, but all did not vote.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 10 -- Opinion among Kansas farmers, and editors on the Administration's agricultural program is split, in general, along geographic lines.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Bucking a midterm election trend that historically has meant gains in Congress for the party out of power, President Eisenhower reaffirmed this week his belief that the Republican party will merit and receive public support only if a substantial part of his legislative program is enacted into law this year.

HIS recent flying accidents in Africa have had the effect of revitalizing for the Fifties the public legend which Ernest Hemingway has re-created around himself in each decade of his literary career. They have served as the equivalent in our day of his early expatriate experiences in the Twenties, his big-game hunting and Spanish War activities in the Thirties, and his spectacularly unofficial combat adventures in World War II.

LIMA, Peru, July 7 -- The fourth archeological team to be sent to Peru by the University of California since 1899 will begin work next week around Ica in the south of this country. Dr. John H. Rowe, Associate Professor of Anthropolgy at the university and assistant curator of South American archeology in that institution's Museum of Anthropology, heads the group.

WILLIE HOWARD MAYS JR., the 23-year-old center fielder for the New York Giants and a baseball property of incalculable if ephemeral value, represents, in all likelihood, the most special case of special pleading in the history of organized baseball or, for that matter, any other sport, organized or merely disheveled.

LONDON, July 10 (Reuters) -- A public controversy exploded today over an order requiring the plumed, red-coated sentries of Britain's crack Horse Guards to salute all men passers-by wearing bowler hats and carrying umbrellas.

AN intensive course in photographic training, consisting of twenty-four three-hour sessions to be given in July and August, is offered by Joseph Breitenbach. The course is open to a limited group and will emphasize the development of a personal style in photography.

Now about midseason, as the yachting and speed-boat year can be measured, the coming weekend is one of the busiest of all. On metropolitan waterways, Long Branch's Golden Jubilee two-day inboard and outboard regatta on Pleasure Bay, an arm of the Shrewsbury River, will be a mecca for the pilots.

A CHILD'S eye view of the great Flood and life aboard the Ark is what Miss Fanchiotti has attempted here, and very successfully. Taking as her framework the brief biblical account, she fills in the human interest gaps: What did people say about Noah while he was building the Ark ? How did the animals behave ? What stages of hope and despair did the passengers pass through while the endless waters swirled ?

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 10 -- There is a general inclination among Missouri Basin corn growers to keep silent until they are sure they are going to be hurt by the House's adoption of flexible farm price supports.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -- J. Edgar Hoover said today that "the long-range view" of Federal Bureau of Investigation counterespionage activities was to identify and control foreign spy rings -- not to arrest, perhaps prematurely, individual spies.

THE country's major airlines with coast-to-coast services are now making twelve daily non-stop flights between New York and California, with well over 500 seats available every day. The number of fast, long-range domestic flights was increased recently when Trans World Airlines joined American Airlines and United Air Lines in offering two-way non-stop trips.

ONE of the phenomena which most amazed the directors of foreign museums, when they visited the United States last winter, was the American museums' sense of responsibility to their communities and, in particular, their emphasis on educational activities.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 10 -- Vonian Chief, a 5-year-old bay horse owned by the ABC Freight Forwarding Corporation of New York, won the $5,000 Lynbrook, a one-mile Class AA pace, at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

PARIS, July 10 -- The latest cablegrams from Washington received by Premier Pierre Mendes-France before his departure today for Geneva said that John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, would consider further whether he would go to Geneva in the nine days that M. Mendes-France has left for his negotiation or an "honorable" agreement for a truce in Indochina by midnight July 20.
Do you get a sudden rush of letters now and then, letters you hadn't expected, letters from strangers or near-strangers?

As the Congressional Directory correctly states, Senator J. W. Fulbright is a Democrat and comes from Fayetteville, Ark. He has long been a friend and defender of the Tennessee Valley Authority, although, as he explained in the Senate on Friday, he believes private enterprise and the Authority can work "side by side in harmony" -- a sort of co-existence. Many among us accept this as possible and desirable.

WITH twenty-one countries ready to discuss far - reaching highway problems, the sixth annual Pan-American Road Congress will open today in Caracas, Venezuela, continuing through July 21. Delegates seeking ways and means to improve motor transportation in South, Central and North America will consider projects that involve billions of dollars for vast highway development in mountains, plains and swamps.
The resignation of Max E. Halpern as assistant general counsel to the Federal Maritime Board and the Maritime Administration was announced yesterday by Louis S. Rothschild, Maritime Administrator.

Last winter an unmanned balloon floated up from Texas. It carried a package of photographic film. At an altitude of about twenty-five miles, which is about as high as such balloons can rise before bursting, a particle from outer space tore through the package. When the film was developed Dr. Marcel Schein of the University of Chicago, saw straight tracks that startled him.
Q.: Mr. President, do you believe that the compromise flexible system passed by the House [on July 2] gives you enough flexbility to deal with the present farm situation?

WASHINGTON. Massachusetts Avenue, NW, from Sheridan Circle to Wisconsin Avenue, is known to all Washingtonians as Ambassadors' Row. Here, in the capital of the most powerful country of the free world, are many of the homes and chanceries of the representatives of great nations. From their extrater ritorial islands -- the embassies -- some of these distinguished and privileged men play the role of friends of the United States, vital elements in the Western alliance.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 -- A project in preventive medicine in which a medical society and an insurance company are cooperating with a dock workers' union and a management group got under way this week on the Stockton waterfront.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Now that Japanese beetles have emerged, spray or dust with DDT to protect grapes, roses and other ornamentals. Control aphids on these and on all other plants with nicotine sulfate. As soon as corn is ten to fourteen inches in height at the whorl, spray or dust regularly with DDT against European corn borer.

NEWPORT, R. I. -- Newport's reputation as a tattered resort of bygone days is completely fictitious, as every visitor here remarks with surprise. For there is more to see than the millionaires' old mansions that built the legend of Newport.

The vanguard of 10,000 furniture store owners and buyers will stream into the New York Furniture Exchange, 206 Lexington Avenue, tomorrow at the opening of the sixty-third annual local summer furniture market.

GREAT celebration is under way this year at Mystic, Conn., for the town is marking its tercentenary. To honor this occasion the Mystic Garden Club (which observes its thirtieth anniversary this year) has planned a house and garden tour for Wednesday.
STAMFORD, Conn., July 10 -- A dispute born in the wilderness ten miles north of here 300 years ago is still alive.

IT is hard to lay down general principles for defensive play. The most effective procedure is to figure out what everyone has and then analyze the hand as a double-dummy problem. All this requires is a combination of intuition and an aptitude for problem analysis.
LONDON, July 10 -- The Admiralty announced today that the Royal Navy officer and eight ratings, held by the Chinese Communists since June 1, crossed the border into Hong Kong today.

HOLLYWOOD. M-G-M is spending more than $250,000 on a wardrobe for its current multi-million-dollar production, "The Prodigal." This is the biggest wardrobe expenditure on this lot in twenty years. Some 2,600 costumes are being created.

ON many a stroll through the great outdoors in June or July, the blossoms of the wild rose paint a long-remembered picture. Sometimes they are found in an out-of-the-way pasture or along a rarely traveled lane.
Joseph J. Gannon has been named personnel manager of the sales division of General Foods.

KARACHI, July 10 -- From Prime Minister Mohammed Ali down though the hangers-on in the crowded bazaars, coffee shops and tea stalls, Pakistanis are worried about the unrelieved crisis in Indochina. Their newspapers carry as many as five front-page stories in a single issue telling of the military crisis less than a thousand miles away.

AMONG recent operatic releases, an outstanding item is the new Elisir d'Amore recorded for His Master's Voice in Rome under the direction of Gabriele Santini (two disks). The Donizetti work already is available in a Cetra set, but a new version so well-performed as the H. M. V. recording is always welcome.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 10 -- Bitterness in Wisconsin's dairy districts over the Eisenhower farm program, particularly the cut in dairy-product price supports, has given the state's Democrats high hopes of winning a larger share of Wisconsin's ten Congressional seats in the fall elections.

Another of the twenty-four winners of the national essay contest of the Propeller Club of the United States -- Stephan Robert Cavior of Brookline, Mass. -- is now at sea enjoying the fruits of his literary efforts.

Referring to Ted Szulc's "Mapping the Eclipse" (June 27), it was surprising to find the Times Magazine keeping alive the error that medieval geographers or other learned men believed the earth to be flat -- either disk or rectangle.
DENVER, July 10 (UP) -- Governor Meyner said today that President Eisenhower was "a disheartened and disillusioned man, who would like to be relieved of his burdens."
GENEVA, July 10 -- Military representatives of the opposing forces have reached an agreement in principle on most of the military problems connected with a cease-fire in Laos.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10 (UP) -- The Boston Red Sox scored two runs in the eleventh inning today to defeat the Philadelphia Athletics, 5 -- 3, and snap a four-game losing streak before 3,047 fans at Connie Mack Stadium.

THE tradition of the jazz instrumentalist who is also a singer, a tradition soundly established by such dual virtuosi as Jelly Roll Morton, Louis Armstrong and Fats Waller, has been carried on most notably in recent years by Nat "King" Cole.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., July 10 -- Those who have been yearning to take a broadbill on rod and reel, an angling feat which few anglers have accomplished in East Coast waters, have an opportunity now in Block Island Sound.

KINGSTON, N. Y., July 10 -- State Senator Arthur H. Wicks, former Senate Republican majority Leader, was endorsed today for a fifteenth two-year term at an unofficial convention of the Ulster County Republican organization.

LONDON, July 10 -- Only a few moments after Queen Elizabeth wished him good luck. Sir Gordon Richards, England's champion jockey, suffered his second serious spill in less than two months today and was rushed to a hospital with back and pelvic injuries.

The neighborhood branches of the New York Public Library, as well as the Central Building on Fifth Avenue, periodically become showcases for a varied assortment of materials. Some are strictly literary, others go far afield.

LAST year, Somerset Maugham wrote an introduction to a volume of Rudyard Kipling's stories; more recently A. J. Liebling gave both editor and author a monumental panning in the columns of The New Yorker. Messrs. Maugham and Liebling do not see exactly eye to eye.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- When the State Department announced this week that three Soviet attaches had been expelled from the United States, and that the Kremlin had retaliated by expelling from the Soviet Union two United States officers, it made headlines across the country.

THE title story of this collection was Richard Matheson's first, and it was published in 1950. People are still raving about that grisly little masterpiece. Matheson's talent was no flash in the pan; it has stood up nobly and most of these seventeen stories prove that he is an established producer of the violently disturbing.

NEW YORK STATE plays host, today through Wednesday, to the forty-sixth annual Governors' Conference, and has let the distinguished visitors know it wants them to take a look around the Empire State while they are here.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -The long fight over whether private or Federal enterprise should develop the Snake River and its Hell's Canyon stood at an important roadmark today but substantial litigation undoubtedly lay ahead.

RADIO STATION WNYC will provide on-the-scene coverage of the sixth annual Conference on American Foreign Policy beginning today and continuing through Thursday. The conference is to be held at Colgate University, Hamilton, N. Y., and will have for its theme "American Foreign Policy: Economic and Political Stability in the Free World." Both the afternoon and evening meetings will be broadcast.

As was generally expected following the settlement in San Salvador at dawn of July 2, Lieut. Col. Carlos Castillo Armas has been chosen head of the anti-Communist junta in Guatemala. Seldom in recent Latin-American history has a revolutionary leader come to power with greater opportunity -- and with graver problems.

It struck Dr. Raymond Villers that in courses in industrial management it is not organization but reorganization that is taught. Prof. Arthur Lesser, chairman of the department of industrial engineering at Stevens Institute of Technology, was impressed by the argument when he heard Villers present it two years ago at the annual conference of the American Society for Engineering Education.

THE other day we were getting a briefing on some of the upcoming paperbacks and the fellow with the briefcase mentioned a Bantam book called "Troubling of a Star." He then told us that the author. Walt Sheldon, had definitely made Japan his home, and then he went on briefing us about other books.
Virtually unknown at the turn of the century, American china has become the standby in most homes in this country and continues its steady rise in popularity.

In the Red River delta in northern Indochina last week the French continued their withdrawal to a narrow corridor connecting the delta's port, Haiphong, with its main city, Hanoi. During the week two fairly large towns were abandoned to the Communist Vietminh.

JOHNNY JACK lived on a farm and when he was 5 he became curious about the surprise arrival of puppies, kittens, chickens and other baby animals. One day there weren't any puppies and on the next there were.

LONDON, July 10 -- Freddie Green of Britain, a 28-year-old wartime parachutist, set a world three-mile record of 13 minutes 32.2 seconds today. In a desperate neck-and-neck finish, he just beat another British international runner, Chris Chataway, who recorded the same time as Green.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The growing power of hydrogen bombs makes evacuation of cities an "urgent necessity," Val Peterson, Civil Defense Administrator, said today.

AN exhibition of press photographs with an attempt at a historical perspective is on display through July and August in the main lobby of the Union Square Saving Bank's Stuyvesant Town office, 245 First Avenue.
IT was at the All-Star baseball game in Cincinnati last year. An American League fan turned to a National Leaguer and sighed deeply.

The Grantland Rice Fellowship in Journalism for 1954-55 has been awarded to John Thomas Clary 3d of Atlantic City, 21 years old, a graduate this year of Fordham University, where he edited The Fordham Ram. In 1949-50 he was a sports writer on The Atlantic City Press and from 1950 to 1953 worked there on a part-time basis.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 10 A fleet of 123 craft turned out today for the seventeenth regatta of the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association. All but a few finished, and that was more or less a miracle.
THE New York Philharmonic-Symphony is taking a leaf from the Metropolitan Opera. It is planning to televise its opening night program on Oct. 7. But the program will not be available to home-viewers.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Two Army divisions -- one infantry, the other armored -- are to be torn down and rebuilt next autumn in the hope of perfecting a new battlefield organization for atomic warfare.

DUBLIN, July 10 -- Hugh Stewart of Pasadena, Calif., upset favored Mervyn Rose of Australia in the final of the Irish open lawn tennis championship today and Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., won the women's title from Mme. Ginette Bucaille of France.
HAVANA, July 10 (AP) -- President Fulgencio Batista announced today his willingness to be a candidate for President in the election Nov. 1.
ALBANY, July 10 (AP) -- From the approximately 12,000 inmates of New York State correctional institutions blood is being contributed to help the wounded, ill and burned in civilian hospitals.

MILWAUKEE, July 10 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey came to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's home state today and characterized him as "an unprincipled demagogue who has capitalized and distorted a popular issue for his own aggrandizement.''

THOUGH home-freezing may be done at any season, this is the time of year when interest in it is strongest in many households. Home gardens and orchards, at least in this area, yield their harvests. Providing for weekend guests raises the question of what products may be frozen ahead in quantity, then brought out for quick service.

AT the turn of the century the "metropolis" became a new center of interest for American novelists. Both Walt Whitman and William Dean Howells had been fascinated by New York; a new group of writers, including Henry B. Fuller and Robert Herrick, began to study the cliff-dwellers of Chicago.

TWO of Benito Mussolini's more casual remarks have been my favorites for many years. The first is a personal statement, curiously bordering on the metaphysical: "I never exclude anything." The second, of a more practical nature, is an exhortation to his fascist followers, who were then marching into power: "Let us utilize the coming months before our party convention to create a philosophy of fascism."

THIS fifth edition of the semi-annual "New World Writing" (with Arabel J. Porter as editorial coordinator and Richard Eberhart as guest poetry editor) continues a tradition of hospitality to "the eminent, the aspiring and the young in the world of letters."

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- It could be that the Yankees finally have gotten around to setting up their long awaited drive toward the top in the American League flag race, with the big push to get under way directly after the All-Star interruption.

HANOI, July 10 -- The perspiring little man in the shabby shirt stamped another travel form in the hot, sticky and crowded passport office. It was the 323d he had handled in one day. Still lying before him was a stack of additional applications submitted by Vietnamese seeking permission to leave Hanoi for Saigon and the comparatively safe south.
BANGKOK, July 10 -- Although no imminent peril is sensed here, the Thai Government sees the deteriorating Indochina situation as posing an increasingly grave threat to this country's freedom.

Nino Valdes, heavyweight champion of Cuba, who is rated second among world contenders for Rocky Marciano's title, and Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson of Far Rockaway, ranked fifth, will meet in the main bout scheduled for ten rounds at Madison Square Garden Wednesday night.

LONDON, July 10 -- The continued preoccupation of Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, the two most powerful figures in the Government, with foreign affairs has delayed the Cabinet's domestic program.

DULUTH, Minn. -- So natural a vacation land is the North Country of Minnesota that an Easterner finds it hard to believe that scarcely more than one generation has passed since the first resorts were built and roads hard-surfaced, and a trickle of cars from out of state began arriving.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Congress has been given evidence that the public wants reform of Congressional investigating committee procedures. Pressure for new rules of conduct has been building up, especially since the Army-McCarthy hearings, and has been reflected in testimony by representatives of civic, civil rights, religious and other groups, as well as legislators, in hearings conducted by Senate and House Rules subcommittees.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 10 (AP) -- Rhode Island potato growers have asked John L. Rego, State Director of Agriculture, to embargo Long Island potato shipments into this state because of fear of spreading a root disease.

CALTANISSETTA, Sicily, July 10 -- The Sicilian sulphur industry, largest in Europe, is passing through a crisis for which the United States is largely blamed.

HAVERSTRAW, N. Y. -During the week of July 25, this Rockland County village on the west shore of the Hudson will celebrate the first hundred years of its incorporated existence. Major items on the schedule of activities for Centennial Week are a big parade to be held on July 28 and an outdoor pageant with a cast of more than 500 performers.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 10 -- The eighth summer session of Santa Barbara's Music Academy of the West is under way with a larger registration of senior musicians than ever before.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 10 -- Richard H. Balch, chairman of the Democratic State Committee, said today that in November we are going to retire Tom Dewey or his stand-in, if he prefers not to risk political defeat himself."

MONTICELLO, N. Y., July 10 -- The Women's Swimming Association 300-meter medley relay team automatically created a senior metropolitan amateur athletic union record of 5 minutes 54 seconds in a meet at Kutsher's Country Club today.

GREEN BAY, Wis., July 10 (UP) -All five striking employes of the tiny Ahnapee and Western Railroad have been discharged, the company announced today.

GANDER, Vfld., July 10 -- A hesitant and uncertain cooperation (or lack of it) between international airlines immobilized a big Douglas airliner of the Italian Airlines here today. Arriving just before 1 A. M. this morning the liner, carrying forty-four passengers, had a blow-out in the tire of the nose wheel and the plane's officers spent more than half a day trying to get a new landing assembly and tire.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -- The Department of Justice investigation of "collusive" gasoline price increases, begun thirteen months ago, has bogged down, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- A year and three days ago a Federal Power Commission hearing opened in Washington. It closed Friday, little noticed and its importance almost forgotten in the welter of words that has flowed since in the fight over public versus private power.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 10 (AP) -- Hamilton Richardson, playing a hard-smashing overhand game, upset second-seeded Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., today in the Western tennis semi-finals, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 10 -- Representative Stuyvesant Wainwright, who has the support of the Suffolk County Republican organization for re-election to his First Congressional District seat, is being challenged in the fall primary by a Lake Ronkonkoma lawyer who is an avowed supporter of Senator Joseph McCarthy.

The issue of Red China's possible admission to the United Nations as part of a "settlement" in the Far East has been in the forefront of the political scene this past week. We have now had that issue approached with sound reasoning by both President Eisenhower and Secretary Dulles.

A GREAT vehicular tunnel is to be built under the St. Lawrence River from Quebec City to the south shore. Construction is scheduled to begin before the end of the summer and the tunnel should be ready for use early in 1957, thus bringing to realization an idea that engineers have alternately considered and discarded over a period of many years.
JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, July 10 (Reuters) -- German technicians are arriving here to take up long-term engineering and contracting jobs with the Saudi Arabian Government.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 10 -- The recent Supreme Court decision outlawing public school segregation must be understood as the logical development of a major shift in national philosophy rather than "an isolated act of sudden inspiration."

From the Sloan-Kettering Institute, which is the research unit of Memorial Hospital, New York City, comes the news that after six years of research a high percentage of cures for several types of cancer in rats has been achieved. In one type of cancer complete cures were recorded.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 10 -- Department store business continued to rise, and on a day-to-day comparison easily surpassed the like 1953 period. For the week, however, the volume slipped a little from a year ago on account of the holiday.

THE European headquarters of the United Nations at Geneva will be pictured in an architectural drawing on the 3c deep purple and 8c dark carmine stamps which the United Nations Postal Administration will issue on Oct. 25 to commemorate United Nations Day.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- For the second consecutive year Congress faces a session-end wrangle over the national debt. With the outcome again in doubt, this is the one issue above any other now in sight that might well upset plans for a July 31 adjournment.

EUGENE, Ore., July 10 -- Adlai E. Stevenson called on the voters today to send more Democrats to Congress this year to arrest what he termed a "menacing disintegration in our Government" and help the Eisenhower Administration to succeed.

Aluminum - coated fire - fighting clothing, which gives greater protection against heat and weighs less than present Army standard firemen's garments, has been developed by the Quartermaster Corps and will be submitted to rigorous field testing during the coming summer.

FOR the past four or five weeks London has been absolutely humming with music. RIDGEFIELD, Conn., July 10 -- Once a battleground, this town has become a symbol of security for more exposed communities anxious, in the face of atomic warfare threats, to protect priceless records.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 10 -- It is understood that the Turks appealed today for help from Washington, London and Paris in persuading the smaller members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to give whole-hearted support to the Balkan alliance. Under this arrangement Greece and Turkey bind themselves to aid Yugoslavia in case she is attacked.

The controversial subject of smoking, discussed in John Willig's "Why People Smoke" (July 4) was evidently of sufficient importance in the days of early Elizabethan comedy to be included in the plays of the day. For example, in Francis Beaumont's lusty farce. "The Knight of the Burning Pestle." * * *

CHICAGO, July 10 -- The Chicago White Sox scored three runs in the second inning and defeated the first-place Cleveland Indians, 3 -- 0, behind the pitching of Jack Harshman and Sandy Consuegra today.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The Senate took an unsual step today to force the Navy and the House of Representatives to approve promotions of two naval officers who, Senators contend, were unjustly retired.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., July 10 -- Dr. Alien B. Du Mont, television scientist, tonight became a two-time winner of the New York A. C. predicted-log race to Block Island, the banner event each summer for power cruiser men and navigators.

THE South African people are becoming increasingly sensitive to the attention they are receiving from abroad, especially from America. Until about ten years ago an American correspondent was a comparative rarity in South Africa. Now they pass through in a steady stream with pencils in their hands and books on their minds.

EVEN a reviewer must occasionally pause for breath, while he looks around and surveys his experiences during the last few months or years. So far 1954 and the latter half of 1953 have made a passable literary show. But, whereas the novel seems to have remained static -- most modern novelists are hard at work consolidating their previously prepared positions -- biography goes briskly ahead and continues to cover fresh territory.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., July 10 (AP) -- Top-seeded John McLean of Buffalo today captured the state junior tennis championship with a three-set victory over Lloyd Moglen of Mount Vernon.

HAVING Cotton Mather level an accusing finger at you and cry "witchcraft" in Salem, Mass., of 1692 would be an unenviable prospect. But that's what happened to two twentieth-century boys, Doug Kennan and Rich McClain.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., July 10 -- Dr. Alien B. Du Mont, television scientist, tonight became a two-time winner of the New York A. C. predicted-log race to Block Island, the banner event each summer for power cruiser men and navigators.

THE South African people are becoming increasingly sensitive to the attention they are receiving from abroad, especially from America. Until about ten years ago an American correspondent was a comparative rarity in South Africa. Now they pass through in a steady stream with pencils in their hands and books on their minds.

EVEN a reviewer must occasionally pause for breath, while he looks around and surveys his experiences during the last few months or years. So far 1954 and the latter half of 1953 have made a passable literary show. But, whereas the novel seems to have remained static -- most modern novelists are hard at work consolidating their previously prepared positions -- biography goes briskly ahead and continues to cover fresh territory.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 10 -- The opening this week of the Bhakra-Nangal Canal in India has reduced the flow of water into Pakistan's canal system from a minimum requirement of 22,000 cubic feet a second to 9,800, according to a Government spokesman.

HUGH HERBERT'S latest probe into the psyche of a young girl, "I'd Rather Be Kissed," is, for all its super-slickness, gay, interesting and even touching. Dolores Keith is 15 years old. She has a pleasant home, a pretty mother, a nice father and -- this is what makes the book somewhat unusual -- she is a happy, good, affectionate child without a shadow of a neurosis.

THE Cherry Lane Theatre stands near the end of short Commerce Street down in the Village. Traffic is light in the evenings, and the old buildings are quaint. During intermissions of Punch Opera's current production of "Murder in Three Keys" it is pleasant to take the air -- and a glass of lemonade offered by courtesy of the management -- on the sidewalk and in the street.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- The Chicago White Sox scored three runs in the second inning and defeated the first-place Cleveland Indians, 3 -- 0, behind the pitching of Jack Harshman and Sandy Consuegra today.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The Senate took an unsual step today to force the Navy and the House of Representatives to approve promotions of two naval officers who, Senators contend, were unjustly retired.

HALF the contributors to this volume are science fiction editors, who demonstrate that they can write as well as, if not better than, the authors whose stories they publish. One of the best entries is H. L. Gold's "Man of Parts," an odd tale of a wrecked spaceman who finds himself reconstituted in an alien body.

ANYONE familiar with David Duncan's novels on such diverse matters as American labor or life in an artists' colony knows that he is a skilled story-teller. Science fiction aficionados, encountering Mr. Duncan for the first time, may be somewhat disappointed to find that he has devoted his very considerable talents to a shopworn theme: the building of the first space platform.

INCREDIBLE as it may seem, a somewhat different quiz show has turned up on television, this one on the DuMont network at 8:30 o'clock on Wednesday evenings. Even more surprising, the show is an import from the British Broadcasting Corporation, not normally a major source of programming ideas for American video.

Coup: By dangling tempting bids, Roger L. Stevens, one of the owners of the Empire State Building, who is affiliated with the Playwrights Company as well as the Producers Theatre, has entered into a tacit alliance with Hugh Beaumont, probably the most active of London producers.
The writer of this letter has been a consistent supporter of the United Nations since its earliest days. The letter refers to your editorial of July 7 entitled: "Red China and the U. N."
