The city will begin today an intensive campaign against the operation of refuse incinerators after 5 P. M. The only legal hours for such operation are from A. M. to 5 P. M.

PITTSBURGH, July 11 -- The decline in steel output last week was the result, in a large measure, of the Fourth of July holiday. Part of the decline might have been caused by a combination of less order volume, because of mass plant vacations, and the ending of some wage-price hedge buying.

LATILA, Finland, July 11 (UP) -- John Landy of Australia, the world's No. 7, miler, ended his European tour tonight by running 1,000 meters in 2 minutes 20.9 seconds. He missed by a tenth of a second the world record of 2:20.8 set last year by America's Mal Whitfield.
LONDON, July 11 -- A Dominican diplomat died today as a result of gunfire at the Dominican Consulate last night. Another diplomat is seriously wounded.

LENOX, Mass., July 11 -- The programs of the 1954 Berkshire Festival make special observation of the sesquicentennial of Hector Berlioz, born in the last month of the year 1803. At least one or more of Berlioz' major works will figure in each of the Boston Symphony programs of the six weeks of the festival.
Sunny skies, warm temperatures and comfortably low humidity combined yesterday to lure peak crowds to the beaches and parks in the New York area.
Civil Defense officials will test New York's 679 fixed air raid warning sirens at 11 A. M. today.
ST. LOUIS, July 11 (UP) -- Joe Cunningham's fifth home run since joining the Cardinals on June 30 gave St. Louis a 4-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

VIRGIL TRUCKS of the White Sox pitched his second one-hitter of the season the other day and that focuses attention on the fact that an inordinate number of one-hitters have been tossed this year, including a most peculiar one. Since the statisticians never have bothered to make a chronological breakdown of this phase of the sport, no one knows whether a record is in the making.

A grant of $850,000 to the University of Michigan to study effectiveness of the anti-poliomyelitis vaccine being tested this summer through the country was announced yesterday by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 11 (UP) -- Vic Seixas, 29, of Philadelphia was pressed to the limit today by Hamilton Richardson before winning his first Western singles tennis championship, 7 -- 5, 3 -- 6, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., July 11 (UP) -- Gov. Walter J. Kohler of Wisconsin identified himself today as the person who had talked General Eisenhower out of lauding General of the Army George C. Marshall in a Wisconsin speech in 1952 to avoid any possible affront to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Republican leaders in Congress said tonight that they had the votes to enact the balance of the Eisenhower program substantially as presented and still adjourn by July 31.

DETROIT, July 11 -- A hint of a possible further merger of independent auto companies was given today in a call to Studebaker and Packard stockholders to meet on Aug. 17. At that time they will vote on uniting their companies.

Charles Dollard, president of the Carnegie Corporation, declared yesterday that charges against five specific projects financed by the corporation had been characterized by "errors of fact and interpretation."

Last week's labor crisis at the atomic plants at Oak Ridge and Paducah had what seems at the moment a happy ending. The A. F. L. unions did not strike and the C. I. O. unions came back after two days. The output of that lethal but essential substance known as U-235 was not seriously interfered with.
ROME, July 11 (UP) -- Pope Pius said today in a message that every attack against the church "is doomed to be broken against the invincible shield of God."
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The wonders of electronics have been turned loose on the evasive elements of weather.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., July 11 -- President Eisenhower's cancellation of his plan to address the Governors' Conference brought deep disappointment today to four Bronx boys. They had been chosen to caddy tomorrow for the President and his party at the Sagamore Hotel golf course.
Within a mile of the densely populated upper East Side the wide-open spaces of one of the city's big but little-known parks remain wide and open these days.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., July 11 -- James Francis Byrnes, the 75-year-old outgoing Governor of South Carolina, was the center of attraction today at this forty-sixth annual Governors Conference, of which he is the undisputed "elder statesman."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 11 -- Columbia Pictures will be well represented at next month's Venice Film Festival with two of the four Hollywood films selected to represent the United States.

Investors Funding Corporation of New York has purchased, on behalf of an investing syndicate, the four-story building with twenty-eight apartments and six stores at 156 South First Avenue in Mount Vernon, N. Y.

VIENNA, July 11 -- Flood waters of the Danube have forced the evacuation of 24,000 persons from the Austrian city of Linz. Thousands of others have been left homeless in four countries. The flood disaster the worst some areas of Central Europe have experienced in hundreds of years, has caused at least fifteen deaths.

Since taxes may in some cases be escaped, but death never, persons should implement the realistic Christian attitude toward death in their lives, Bishop Herbert Welch declared yesterday. He spoke at Broadway Temple-Washington Heights Methodist Church, at 174th Street.

The recent moves of Congress and the Administration toward withdrawal of federal responsibility for the American Indian have aroused apprehension on the part of many Indian tribes and close students of Indian affairs.
Work has begun on the replacement of twelve plain clerestory windows, which have lighted the nave of St. Patrick's Cathedral for seventy-five years, with stained glass windows.

OAKLAND, Calif., July 11 -- "Through family life education we hope to cure the most serious disease in our culture -- the neurotic pattern in families," an educator told the annual meeting of the National Council of Family Relations at Mills College here last week.
White, Weld Co. is offering 100,000 shares of common stock of the Inter-Canadian Corporation, a non-diversified management investment company of the closed-end type, at $25 a share today.

ELMSFORD, N. Y., July 11 -- Bob Monk of Knollwood, unheralded as the tourney got under way, won the New York State amateur golf championship today at the Fairview Country Club. He captured the title by defeating the favorite, Bob Sweeny, former British amateur champion, 2 and 1, in the thirty-six-hole final.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., July 11 -- William Tully of Yonkers captured the New York State singles championship with a straight-set victory over Calvin MacCracken of Tenafly, N. J., at the County Tennis Club of Westchester today.

British sterling was given quite a fillip in value last Friday in response to the announcement of its use for sugar purchases through London. The plan envisages any non-dollar, non-sterling country can now buy dollar sugar in sterling or in any local currency acceptable to the Bank of England.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Federal agencies spend billions of dollars yearly doing a lot of things, like roasting coffee and building battleships. Now the Eisenhower Administration is planning to turn many of these enterprises over to private industry.
HUNTINGTON, L. I., July 11 -- Two barefoot farmers brought two suspected thieves to bay today after a wild hour-and-a-half truck chase through Suffolk and Nassau Counties.

DETROIT, July 11 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 2 -- 1 today, as Al Aber retired the first seventeen batters. The left-hander yielded only four hits, but needed the help of Billy Hoeft and Steve Gromek to protect the victory in the last one and two-thirds innings after Jim Fridley had hit a 410-foot home run.

Despite healthy gains in financial and automotive linage, the seven New York daily newspapers showed a loss of 0.13 per cent in their totals for the first six months this year as compared with a year ago. The total was 77,784,199 lines.
Parisian couturiers have bestowed their approval on synthetic fabrics and blends of synthetics with natural fibers.

The United Nations has been requested by the World Veterans Federation to take action to alleviate the plight of the Korean veterans of the Korean struggle. The South Korean armed forces have discharged 132,000 men as disabled, including 35,000 seriously and permanently maimed.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. Y., July 11 -- The horses of Mr. and Mrs. Leon S. Haymond of Armonk, N. Y., were the heavy winners of the New Brunswick horse show that ended today. They won eight first places through the two days of competition. Two were championships.
A device that rings bells to alert off-duty marine radio operators to emergency calls as well as ordinary messages was demonstrated for the first time last week.

CAIRO, July 11 -- Egyptian military forces charged today that Israeli forces pounded an Egyptian military position with mortar fire and overrun it last night in a bayonet charge, killing six troops and wounding two.
SEOUL, Korea, July 11 -- Vice Admiral Sohn Won Il, South Korean Defense Minister, disclosed today that his country had asked the United States' support to maintain 1,000,000 reserve troops.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $77,779,093,652. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Union workers in New York hotels will receive retirement pensions of about $40 a month under an arrangement announced jointly yesterday by the Hotel Association of New York City, Inc., and the New York Hotel Trades Council, A. F. L.

The body of Howard Englander, the 29-year-old father reported to have been killed near Coney Island last Monday in a $1 mugging by a Philadelphia youth, was found by a fishing boat yesterday off eastern Long Island.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Officials will begin drafting a Congressional resolution this week to give President Eisenhower wide powers for restoring sovereignty and a national army to West Germany if France rejects the European Defense Community.

CHICAGO, July 11 (UP) -- Billy Pierce twirled a two-hitter and Virgil Trucks a five-hitter today as the Chicago White Sox beat the Cleveland Indians, 3 to 0 and 8 to 2, to sweep a four-game series with the league leaders.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 (AP) -- Five hungry and thirsty men aboard the small raft Lehi battled heavy seas and a rising wind tonight as a rescue ship returned to port after failing to locate the craft.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 11 -- South Africa is developing a Midas touch. Her gold and foreign exchange reserve increased substantially this year despite the publicly announced policy of the Government and the Reserve Bank to reduce it.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., July 11 -- Republican Governors, arriving for the forty-sixth annual Conference of Governors, reported today that a major economic upswing was in progress throughout the country.

LONDON, July 6 -- The eleven middle-aged men and one elderly woman who rule Britain's fashion world as the "Top Twelve" have been put on their mettle by an unknown group of designers, all in their early twenties.
BERLIN, July 11 -- The first Evangelical Church congress to be held in the Soviet Zone of Germany ended today after several startling displays of anticommunism.

If imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, to a struggling inventor it also is the surest sign that he has hit upon something on which other men think it worth their while to risk time and money.

The Manufacturers National Bank of Detroit reported as of June 30 total deposits of $570,854,352 and total assets of $601,055,602, compared, respectively, with $578,755,417 and $607,386,537 on Dec. 31, 1953. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $138,565,928, against $143,881,385; holdings of United States Government securities to $273,301,848, against $230,324,498, and loans and discounts to $164,633,036, against $169,337,753.

For some time there has been a steadily mounting tension over Far Eastern questions. There is the feeling that we are approaching some sort of decision. With the arrival of Premier Mendes-France in Geneva, the return of Molotov and the expected return of Chou En-lai, there is the feeling that this week may be the decisive one.

RADIO CITY MUSIC HALL'S most curious customer is a white-haired, white-mustached gentleman with conservative old-style spectacles and quiet suiting who always takes a front row extreme left seat at early evening performances. He turns up at least three times a week, frequently four or five times.
PARIS, July 11 -- The National Committee of the Popular Republican party warned tonight against a worsening of relations between France and her major Western allies, the United States and Britain.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved within a narrow trading range last week and closed 2 points, or 10 cents a bale, lower to 20 points higher. Only the current July delivery ended with a net loss for the week.
The sting of a split with the eighth - place Pittsburgh Pirates at the Polo Grounds yesterday did not pain the Giants too much.
LONDON, July 11 -- The British-American study group formally submitted today its report on reinstating Germany as a Sovereign nation.

The Rochester Civic Music Association of Rochester, N. Y., has received a gift of $100,000 from the Eastman Kodak Company as a memorial to George Eastman, photography pioneer, who was born 100 years ago today.

Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and president of the New York City C. I. O. Council, declared yesterday that he would support the Democratic candidate for Governor only if he were an outstanding liberal.

CINCINNATI, July 11 (AP) -- Gus Bell, Cincinnati's slugging outfielder banged out a homer, triple and two singles in five trips to the plate in the second game of a double-header today, but the Milwaukee Braves won the game, 6 -- 5.
Administration of mental health services is still archaic and inadequate in most states, but there is more of a trend toward improvement, the National Association for Mental Health says.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- A Senate Rules subcommittee, studying how to give Congress better control over investigations, has determined to go deeply into the past.
No ground was gained and no ground was lost by the Dodgers yesterday. However, they missed a fine opportunity to move up a trifle on the league-leading Giants.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Communist China is being obliged to export food to the Soviet Union and its European satellites in spite of serious food shortages in China, the United States Information Agency has reported.

As part of an environment sanitation program, the Federal Government has allocated $175,000 to analyze the contents of the air in industrialized urban centers. A spokesman for the Public Health Service has stated that vapors, gases, droplets, spores, pollen grains, bacteria and radioactive particles would all receive close examination and study.

CAIRO, Monday, July 12 -- A new attempt to settle the long, bitter dispute between Britain and Egypt over control of the strategic Suez Canal zone began here last night, with brighter prospects than at any time in the past.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization is setting up a dozen industry committees to help work out details of a plan for cracking potential bottlenecks in machine tools and other critical defense items, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) -- Allie Reynolds, ace right-hander of the New York Yankees, has been scratched from the American League roster for Tuesday's All-Star game and replaced by Yankee Outfielder Irv Noren.
The blockfront at 322-34 Third Avenue, between Twenty-fourth and Twenty-fifth Streets, figured in a quick sale and resale announced yesterday.

BATON ROUGE, La., July 11 (AP) -- A three-way Senate race led by Senator Allen J. Ellender and the Democratic National Committeeman, Frank Ellis, is sending political salvos across Louisiana and into Texas.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., July 11 -- Bob Bavier Jr. of the Noroton Yacht Club, a seasoned big-boat and blue-water sailor but new to the Lightning Class, won the Pequot Y. C.'s fourth annual Lightning Regatta today.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UP) -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, has warned Congress that the Soviet Union has greatly increased the striking power of its armed forces -- particularly airpower -- and steadily is improving Red satellite armies.
Apartment properties figured in most of the realty deals reported in the Bronx over the week-end.

" Journey With Loshay," an account of a Tibetan adventure by George N. Patterson, will be published Aug. 9 by Norton. The author is a Scottish medical missionary who went to Tibet via China in 1947. The journey about which he writes took place in 1950, a 300-mile trek through southeastern Tibet to northern Assam.
CHICAGO, July 11 -- A rush by the big baking chains to cover flour needs, coupled with active absorption of this product by the family flour trade, started a wave of wheat buying last week by mills.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Small Business Administration reported today that 515 business loans totaling $30,145,262 had been approved in the last nine months to aid small concerns.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 -- Reopening of scores of California quicksilver mines, idle since World War II, is being weighed here because of the newly announced buying program of the Federal Government.

Frank Hague, former Mayor of Jersey City, arrived yesterday by plane from Paris at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, to attend the funeral of his nephew and political protege, Frank Hague Eggers. It was the first time Mr. Hague had ever flown.

Two Brooklyn teen-agers were arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court, charged with the fatal beating of a father of four children early Saturday a few blocks from his home in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.
LOS ANGELES, July 11 -- Arthur B. Bisguier, the United States champion, was among the winners in the first round of the second Pan-American open invitation chess tournament last night.

BASTAD, Sweden, July 11 (UP) -- Budge Patty of Los Angeles and Paris won the men's singles title at the Bastad international tennis tournament for the third straight year today. He defeated Australia's Rex Hartwig, 7 -- 5, 2 -- 6, 3 -- 6, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 4, in the final.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics lost the services of their slugging outfielder, Gus Zernial, for the rest of the season today when he was injured while attempting to field a line drive against the Boston Red Sox in the ninth inning of the opener of a double-header.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 11 -- A 1927 all-white Rolls-Royce touring car, owned by Stanley S. Tarnopol of Philadelphia, was named Eastern Grand Classic winner today at the Classic Car Club's second annual show in the University Heights section of Rutgers University.
The loose, airy Indian squaw fashion and its association with wide open spaces and comfortable living has attained extensive popularity for summer wear.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation recovered early yesterday $30,000 worth of coffee beans stolen from a truck in Brooklyn last Wednesday. Five of seven suspects were arrested soon afterward in Coney Island.

The Rev. Dr. Marcel Pradervand, General Secretary of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches, declared yesterday there was a need for "the witness of Christ in our professional lives as well as our family lives."

The good ship Pendragon out of Stamford, Conn., Comdr. John O'Shea, United States Navy (retired), in command, sailed merrily down Long Island Sound yesterday. She headed into New York Harbor and got as far as off Orchard Beach in the Bronx. She stopped suddenly.

WOKING, England, July 11 (AP) -- Sir Gordon Richards, the world's winningest jockey, was resting "fairly comfortably" in a hospital today after being seriously injured when he was thrown by a horse yesterday.

BARTHOLOMEW ADAMS is back! Everybody knows young Bart, of course, the dashing and debonair television hero played by Barry Nelson in "The Hunter," which resumed over Channel 4 last Saturday from 7 to 7:30 P. M.
The Carnegie Corporation denounced the Reece Congressional committee yesterday for ending public hearings in its investigation of tax exempt foundations. The corporation as-...
The charter market was bucking a wild wind last week. The full fury of the economic gale was felt on the West Coast, where the rate barometer dipped sharply.
Ex-Justice McNulty's proposal to clean up court congestion by "penalizing" a party in negligence actions who refused a reasonable adjustment has much merit.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UP) -- The staff of the Federal Trade Commission accused today nearly 200 paint and wallpaper dealers in Metropolitan New York of conspiring to use unfair trade practices and unfair methods of competition in violation of the law.

It is good to know that the thousands of persons whose livelihood keeps them in lower Manhattan during the day are not being forgotten in the musical treats that have been made available to New Yorkers this summer. A forty-five-piece band led by guest conductors has opened a series of park concerts on the mall of Battery Park under the auspices of the New York Summer Festival Season Committee.

Unless Christianity can attack the causes of spiritual sickness, people will not listen to the Gospel, the Rev. Dr. William Lloyd Imes, director of field service for the New York State Council of Churches, said yesterday.

The customs report for June reflects the beginning of the annual summer travel season in increased ship sailings, larger internal revenue collections and greater activity at the New York area airports.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 11 -- A protocol providing liberalization of capital traffic within the Benelux countries was ratified last Thursday and becomes operative next Friday. Although it sets this traffic completely free, there are safeguards against undue increase of credit positions in the European Payment Union.
As a very pro-American Britisher who believes that Anglo-American coordination is the best investment for peace I do deplore the all-too-common direct comparison of the dollar and the pound.
ROME, July 11 -- Agreement for a solution of the Trieste problem has been reached in principle between Italy and Yugoslavia in negotiations involving Rome, Belgrade, Washington and London.

LONDON, July 11 -- The boom in the stock markets goes steadily on. After something of a pause at the turn of the half-year, business has re-expanded in the last week to make it one of the most active so far this year.

The annual report of the Bank for International Settlements, as noted here last week, is only incidentally a bank report in the customary sense. Thus, of the 230 pages that make up the twenty-fourth edition, submitted on June 14, only twenty-five deal with the internal affairs of the bank itself.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UP) -- Herbert Brownell Jr. said today that the Justice Department was studying the question of whether Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had broken the law by receiving a document of two and a half pages containing secret Federal Bureau of Investigation information.

TETERBORO, N. J., July 11 (AP) -- Mrs. Marion Hart set her single-engine airplane down at Teterboro Airport this afternoon, completing a 35,000-mile trip that took her through twenty-five countries of Europe, Asia and Africa.

The program of music devoted to excerpts from musical comedies by Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein, at Lewisohn Stadium Saturday evening, attracted one of the season's largest audiences. The official count was 13,500.

Sam Shulsky knows too much about the stock market to be much of a salesman. As a result, his "Stock Buying Guide"* is flavored pleasantly with the juice of the raspberry and has more than a drop squeezed over it from the resources of a man to whom many a lemon has been handed.
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 11 -- Demands are rising in the Pakistan press for "immediate and direct action" against India in the seven-year-old dispute over canal waters.
Four new films are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 11 -- R. L. Wagner's Oriole, a 43-footer from Port Washington, L. I., won the Commodore Sprague Trophy test today in the Riverside Yacht Club's twenty-third annual overnight race to Stratford Shoal and return.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 11 -- Thruston B. Morton, Assistant Secretary of State, warned tonight that the United States would not become a party to any French settlement in Indochina "which smacks of appeasement."
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Army and the nation's textile industry are looking to the Senate this week for a go-ahead signal that may bring new jobs to the depressed mill towns of New England.

OAKHURST, N. J., July 11 -- A specially designed floating aluminum wheel chair to transport orthopedically handicapped children down ramps into a new $50,000 outdoor swimming pool at Camp Oakhurst here will be demonstrated at the dedication of the pool on Wednesday.
A crowd of about 200 persons strolling along Madison Avenue yesterday afternoon applauded and praised two patrolmen who subdued and arrested a burglary suspect.
A warning against the "misuse of anger" was sounded yesterday by the Rev. John M. Crotty in a sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Cardinal Spellman presided at the mass.

JERUSALEM, July 11 -- Maj. Gen. Vagn Bennike, Chief of Staff of the United Nations truce supervision group, said today it was hopeless to try to prove who began the firing in Jerusalem June 30, in which nine persons were killed.

A man may steal to help his loved ones and then such a crime might be pardonable. A man might even, in a moment of passion, or to protect his family, commit murder, and his neighbors will see fit to forgive his act of violence.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Yankees bowled over the Senators in the series final today, 7 to 3. Thus, after a half-season of considerable trial and tribulation, Casey Stengel and his Bombers move up to the mid-summer All-Star breathing spell confident and cocky as of old.

At the end of 1953 international trade was "far better balanced than at any time during the post-war period." This is the conclusion reached by the secretariat of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) in a report just released at Geneva.

Early returns in the election of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., give every indication of a smashing victory for the slate backed by Joseph Curran, president, and another personal triumph for the only man to head the union in its seventeen-year history.

ALBANY, July 11 (AP) -- Governor Dewey today appointed fifteen state officials to a committee for economic progress. The group was directed to pull together for "dynamic" expansion of business and employment in the state.
ZURICH, Switzerland. July 11 -- Last week witnessed the long-awaited arrival from New York of the first batch of validated German bonds belonging to owners in Switzerland.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Government officials are privately and urgently explaining to key members of Congress this weekend that by subsidizing the Royal Air Force they can make an addition to free world defenses out of all proportion to the cost.
BONN, Germany, July 11 (AP) -- The Association of German Industries said today it had asked the West German Government to conclude a trade agreement with Communist China.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 (UP) -- The Boston Red Sox vacated the American League cellar and advanced to sixth place today with an 11-1 second-game beating of the Philadelphia Athletics after they had romped to an 18-0 victory in the opener.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 11 -- Hollywood television writers drew picketing assignments today as members of the Television Writers of America prepared to strike the three major TV networks.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 11 -- Huge profits being made by the Brazilian Government through a system of auctioning foreign exchange have aroused bitter criticism on several grounds. It is even charged that they can be used as a vast slush fund in this election year.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 11 -- a quarrel within the Western Alliance about a Mediterranean military base is headed for the United Nations. Nobody is happy at the idea.

PARIS, July 11 -- In 1953 the trade deficit of the franc zone with the rest of the world diminished $439,000,000 compared with 1952, according to a report just published by the French Ministry of Finance.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Following are the votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on major roll-calls in Congress during the period July 3 through July 9:
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The State Department, which is unhappy about the Southeast Asia situation, also is unhappy about the press emphasis on that situation.

Sales and earnings of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation and subsidiaries for the year ended on April 30 were 17.8 per cent and 22.6 per cent, respectively, greater than the results posted in the preceding fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- President Eisenhower's signature on the bill to extend the Hill-Burton hospital construction system will start nation-wide gearing up for better medical care to this country's neediest cases.

HANOI, Vietnam, July 11 -- French B-26 bombers flying night reconnaissance in northeast Vietnam have been spotting the lights of long columns of trucks bringing supplies from Communist China to the Vietminh insurgents.
GENEVA, July 11 -- The United States told France today that it awaited more concrete manifestations of Communist goodwill in the negotiations on Indochina before it would participate in them.

LONDON, July 11 -- British scientists think they may be on the trail of the cause of three disastrous crashes that have resulted in the grounding of the De Havilland Comet, pioneer jet airliner, it was reported today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 11 -- The spectacle of a tiny Lightning, Donald McNair's Mooncusser, tangling with a tug towing a big, steel barge in mid-Sound furnished the chief excitement today as the Knickerbocker Yacht Club staged its Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta.

In his defense of the Carnegie Corporation, made public yesterday, Charles Dollard, president, denied its trustees were mere "figureheads" with "no real knowledge of what the paid officers are doing."

ROME, July 5 -- When in Rome you must eat as the Romans. In fact, wherever you are in Italy you eat Italian food -- or you don't eat. New Yorkers or Parisians or Londoners can pick what nationality of food they want and find it, but the Italians have always been exclusive.

Should a marketer of several products split his account among several agencies? Yes, if the products compete, say most of 3,400 advertising executives questioned on the leadership panel conducted by Tide, which that fortnightly magazine of sales and advertising trends will publish in its next issue.

TUNIS, Tunisia, July 12 -- Counter-terrorists, thought to be Europeans, fired on Moorish cafes in two Tunisian villages last night, killing four Tunisians and wounding six. The murderers escaped in cars.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- The fifty-third annual Music Industry Trade Show and convention opened today in the Palmer House. Russell B. Wells, president of the National Association of Music Merchants, sponsor of the four-day show, said musical instrument sales may equal and certainly will not be more than 3 per cent below the record $325,000,000 volume in 1953.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 12 -- Silas Garrett, Alabama Attorney General, surrendered today on a Jefferson County grand jury warrant accusing him of changing the county's vote totals in the June 1 Democratic primary run-off for state Attorney General.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved late today a $3,100,000,000 foreign aid bill shorn of a controversial provision that might have shut off all assistance to France and Italy by Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- Australia's foreign minister, Richard G. Casey, said today there was a good chance of an "acceptable" end to the Indochina fighting because Red China needed to turn its full attention to internal economic problems.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., July 12 -- The Metropolis team of Harry Cooper, professional, and Dave Scope, amateur, here for a few weeks from Kane, Pa., topped a field of eighty-eight pairs to win today's pro-amateur competition of the Westchester Professional Golfers' Association.

The six-story apartment house accommodating forty-eight families at 39-25 Sixty-fifth Street, corner of Thirty-ninth Avenue, in Woodside, Queens, was purchased from Julius Perlbinder and others by the Estate Securities Company which immediately resold it to Jack M. Cohen.

Roy Campanella, Dodgers catcher, received the go-ahead signal yesterday. Campy, regarded as the backbone of the National League champions, was assured by Dr. Herbert Fett and Dr. Eugene Zorn, that he had no cause for concern regarding numbness in his left hand.
HANOI, Vietnam, July 12 -- Three thousand Vietminh troops launched a series of violent attacks yesterday morning against French Union positions north of Hungyen, twenty-five miles southeast of Hanoi.

COEUR D'ALENE, Idaho, July 12 (UP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson said today that Republican leadership was "drifting at home and disintegrating abroad." He called on all Democrats to help the Administration succeed "to keep civilization from suffering."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 12 -- The American Association for the United Nations said today the United States position on admission of Communist China to the world organization should be reviewed "from time to time with full consideration of all points of view."
OKLAHOMA CITY, July 12 (UP) -- Former Gov. Roy J. Turner withdrew tonight from the Democratic run-off race for United States Senator, giving the incumbent, Senator Robert S. Kerr, the nomination.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 209 pints of blood on Friday. Included were eighty-one taken at the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L. I.

The women who rattle charity boxes in the theatre district, keeping a large cut of the collections for themselves, were described yesterday as a "disgrace" that can't be eliminated under any existing law.

GENEVA, July 12 -- World Jewish organizations, in a statement issued in Zurich today, expressed the "most profound dissatisfaction" with the Austrian Government's failure to settle their claims on behalf of Austrian Jewish victims of Nazi persecution.

A week-end hardening of conditions in the New York money market was still visible yesterday, with the likelihood that there will be no material change until next week, when return flows of currency to the banks will not be offset by large draw-downs on Treasury balances, as they are this week.

LONDON, July 12 -- Britain opposes reconsideration now of Communist China's admission to the United Nations, Sir Winston Churchill declared today. He added that Britain would push the organization of a defense system for Southeast Asia, whatever the outcome of the Geneva conference.

PARIS, July 12 -- The meeting here tomorrow of the foreign ministers of the United States, France and Britain is considered an interruption of the Geneva conference in the interest of greater Western unity.

NORWALK, Conn., July 12 -- On the theory that only a poor cracksman complains of his tools, burglars who broke into a grocery store safe here over the week-end used soda from the store's stock to confine the flames from an acetylene torch and cooked some of the store's steak and spaghetti on a basement burner to replenish their energy.

On behalf of the Carnegie Corporation, its president, Charles Dollard, has made an able answer to the attacks of the Reece committee, which was charged with investigating the un-American activities of tax-exempt foundations. His reply gives further evidence of the extremes of absurdity to which a Congressional committee can aspire.

In response to urgent appeals by France and Britain to join them in Geneva for the expected showdown on Indochina, Secretary Dulles has embarked on a surprise trip to Paris to confer with Premier Mendes-France and Secretary Eden. Whether he will proceed from there to Geneva is still uncertain, but will presumably depend on the results of the Paris conferences.

Floyd Patterson rose from the first knockdown of his career to score a technical knockout over Jacques Royer of France at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Patterson was floored for a count of six in the first round.

GENEVA, July 12 -- The first direct talks between the chiefs of the Vietnamese and Vietminh delegations at the Geneva conference are scheduled for tomorrow. Dr. Tran Van Do, new Vietnamese Foreign Minister, will meet Pham Van Dong, the Vietminh rebels' acting Foreign Minister, for the talks.

The Lehman Corporation ended its first quarter-century of operation with a record net asset value of $158,409,024 as of June 30. The twenty-fifth annual report to stockholders issued yesterday by Robert Lehman, president, and Monroe C. Gutman, chairman of the executive committee, put the asset value of a share of capital stock at $38.14.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 12 -- Production of paper other than newsprint in Pakistan will reach the export level by the end of the year and save more than $14,000,000 a year in foreign exchange, a spokesman for the Pakistan Industrial Development Corporation said today.

A group of women headed by Mrs. George J. Leness is holding frequent meetings this summer to further plans for the annual Grosvenor Ball, which will take place Nov. 27 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Twelve young women will be presented at the forthcoming fete, which will serve also to raise funds for the Grosvenor Neighborhood House.
Gertrude Macy and Walter Starcke have acquired a new script entitled, "The Duchess and the Smugs," which they plan to present this season.

Today's new film is 'Victory At Sea," a feature-length documentary of World War II Naval ac tivities, at the Trans-Lux Sixtieth Street Theatre. The compilation of combat footage was made by the N. B. C. Film Division. United Artists is the distributor.
Testimony that James A. Lynch has been seeking to reestablish himself as a union representative at the Yonkers Raceway was given yesterday at a State Labor Board hearing.
LONDON, July 12 -- United States and British diplomats, meeting here with Italian delegates, were reported today to be "on the verge" of a final agreement on the future of Trieste.
PARIS, July 12 -- The chief of the Paris police was acquitted of "stealing" 213,000 copies of the French Communist newspaper L'Humanite.
Because chicks will grow up, some into roosters, their owner was in court and they were on the menu yesterday.

A big distilling concern will follow the lead of a soap maker and erect a monumental building on Park Avenue. The move is a pledge of faith in the growing prosperity of the American economy, Frank R. Schwengel, president of Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc., said yesterday.
In an attack on the Administration's foreign policy, Senator Wayne Morse, independent of Oregon, declared yesterday that the United States should be sitting at the conference table in Geneva.

LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- A Superior Court judge held today that the motion picture industry had a right to blacklist from employment workers who had refused to testify before the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- KP duty -- the most universally cursed aspect of military service -- may become a thing of the past.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The State Department announced today that it had made "other arrangements" to check the loyalty of United States employes of international organizations in Switzerland.
LONDON, July 12 -- The Coventry City Council reaffired tonight its decision to wash its hands of all civilian defense activities, thus rejecting the Government's advice.
Men and women who wish to become school crossing guards may make application beginning today at any of the Bronx police stations, Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams announced yesterday.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., July 12 -- A multi-billion dollar modernization of the nation's highway system, to be undertaken jointly by the Federal and state governments, was proposed tonight by President Eisenhower.

GUATEMALA, July 12 -- The defeat of communism in Guatemala will be completed with greatly improved social and economic conditions, Lieut. Col. Carlos Castillo Armas told several thousand cheering countrymen today.

GLEN COVE, L. I., July 12 -- Charles F. Slicklen Jr. of North Hempstead, the recent winner of the Metropolitan junior championship, led the Long Island qualifiers for the metropolitan amateur championship with a 1-over-par 34, 37 -- 71 at the Nassau Country Club today.

Relative to the rebuff given to critics of our current American educational system at the N. E. A. convention, let me state that there are many teachers, myself as one, who fully agree with this criticism leveled at our public schools.
GENEVA, July 12 (AP) -- The Western powers lost today the first round of a battle to keep Communist-run Rumania out of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

JERSEY CITY, July 12 -- Frank Hague, who once proclaimed "I am the law," found the law waiting for him today in the form of process servers. The papers were served on him at the funeral of his nephew and political protege, City Commissioner Frank Hague Eggers.

LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- Arthur B. Bisguier, United States champion, and Larry Evans, both of New York, defeated their respective opponents in the second round of the Pan American Chess Tournament today at the Hollywood Athletic Club.
A sports and vacation show will be held at Kingsbridge Armory, Kingsbridge Road and Jerome Avenue, the Bronx, from March 5 through March 13 of next year, it was announced yesterday.

THE waterfowl prospects are much brighter than they were early this spring. The late reports from the Canadian prairie provinces, where most of the continental waterfowl are produced, indicate that water levels are excellent and waterfowl broods running better than average.

CLEVELAND, July 12 -- A strange game is the All-Star game. It provides a reminder of the fellow who caught the tiger by the tail. He did not dare let go. It began as a promotion for the Chicago World's Fair in 1933 but captivated the imaginations of the fans in such overwhelming fashion that it has been continued with some reluctance but a great deal of success.

An enlightened approach characterizes a series of vignettes just installed on the modern furniture floor at Abraham Straus. Not only are the lines of most of the furnishings pleasantly light, but the illumination of them has been carefully considered.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., July 12 -- Typographical Union No. 6, the "Big Six" of New York City, broke ground today for the home it is building for Carmine Fanelli of 57 Kenmore Street, New York. He is linotype operator who became a paraplegic after being wounded in a burst of shrapnel fire in World War II.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- Holders of twenty-one contracts in egg futures defaulted on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in December, 1952, an official testified today.

CLEVELAND, July 12 -- A brief armistice having been declared in baseball's torrid pennant races, battle lines were sharply drawn tonight as the picked performers of the National and American Leagues stood poised for the twenty-first annual All-Star game tomorrow in Cleveland's huge Municipal Stadium.

WEST POINT, N. Y., July 12 -- Effective next July, all candidates seeking admission to the United States Military Academy will be required to take college entrance board tests to establish mental qualifications for enrollment.

BOMBAY, July 12 -- The United States tanker Caltex Wellington and the Indian coastal vessel Kalavati braved choppy seas to rescue eight officers and thirty-four crewmen of the 7,346-gross-ton Panamanian freighter San Mardeno shortly after she grounded and sank off Jaffrabad on the Saurashtra coast early today.
VIENNA, July 12 (AP) -- Many of Austria's and Germany's 70,000 homeless began to return today to their flooded hearths.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 12 -- Leaders of the nation's two-billion-dollar housewares industry expressed considerable optimism here today over business for the rest of the year. They predicted that some lines would even top the record-breaking figures of last year.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- A heat and drought scare hit the corn and soybean markets today. Prices for both these products soared under active buying, with the weather news offsetting the effect of the bearish July official crop estimates.

It is commonly believed that we Americans are deeply impressed by titles. Perhaps we are, but when it comes to choosing our friends we look behind the title to the man. In the case of the Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, who yesterday ended a visit of over a month in this country, we would respect the man even without the title.

Our attention has been called to a letter to the editor of The Times by R. J. Kornstein in which he refers to a driver's clinic conducted recently by the Greater New York Safety Council in cooperation with the State Bureau of Motor Vehicles.
The brilliant tones of precious and semi-precious stones characterized Delman's fall shoe collection at the Sherry Netherlands Hotel yesterday morning.
PARIS, July 12 (AP) -- A French court refused today to impound thirty-seven Soviet-loaned Picasso paintings despite a plea they were stolen from a fleeing Russian collector in 1918.
The next time you go to Ebbets Field, watch Walter Alston, the Dodger manager. He's the tall, substantial citizen wearing No. 24 on his back who coaches at third base when the Brooks are at bat.
LONDON, July 12 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's address in the House of Commons today:

James Shepley, head of the Washington Bureau of Time and Life, and Clay Blair Jr., of the same bureau are preparing a book on the hydrogen bomb. Mr. Blair is author of "The Atomic Submarine and Admiral Richover."
BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., July 12 -- Governors of nine coal-producing states united today in a demand for Federal action to restrict imports of residual oil and natural gas.
A sick man was taken off a fishing vessel yesterday through the combined efforts of a Coast Guard plane, a helicopter and a Navy submarine.

Gay Grecque came back to action with a winning performance in the $17,800 Champlain Handicap yesterday. The six-furlong sprint, the feature event on the opening day's card of the Saratoga-at-Jamaica meeting, attracted fourteen fillies and mares, but Gay Grecque, out of competition since February, was one of those given little chance by the crowd of 22,467.
The Board of Health gave its blessing yesterday to "half and half," a mixture of milk and cream that can be marketed below the price of cream.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, fresh from winning the Western tennis championship at Indianapolis, today breezed through the first round of the national clay courts tournament.
Two international honors have been awarded to Prof. Edward J. Squire, head of the Civil Engineering Department of the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- The Hasty House Farm's Argentine star, Mister Black, today won the $28,200 Laurance Armour Memorial Handicap at Arlington Park by a head over Iceberg II, Chilean-bred.
Tri Arts Press, Inc, in 311 E 38th St; Morris Zimmerman Dress Co, in 307 W 36th St; Friedman Handbags, in 17 W 20th St; Tuberculosis Preventorium for Children, in 80 5th Ave -- Spear Co, brokers.

GENEVA, July 12 -- The Swiss Government has informed the United States that it cannot agree to the hearing of loyalty cases in Geneva by a United States board established to screen United States citizens employed by international organizations.
PARIS, July 12 -- The Ministry of the Interior forbade today a demonstration that the Communist party had planned for Wednesday, Bastille Day, France's national holiday.

China's "agrarian reformers" are having some agrarian difficulties, it seems. Some of the troubles, floods and crop failures, are not to be attributed to the sins of the Communist regime. For those who suffer, as so many Chinese have suffered for so long, we have nothing but compassion.

CAIRO, July 12 -- Britain's offer to settle the Suez Canal zone dispute with Egypt on terms more liberal than those offered before has thus far failed to evoke any notable enthusiasm from the Egyptian Government.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., July 12 (AP) -- Eight thousand American Federation of Labor construction workers refused today to cross wildcat picket lines, causing a shutdown on two huge atomic plant building jobs here, the second major stoppage in two weeks.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Special House of Representatives Committee to Investigate Tax-Exempt Foundations reacted quickly today to the Carnegie Corporation's protest.

A 17-year-old youth who read and tried to write hard-boiled detective fiction and fancied himself a lawyer was one of three teen-age boys taken into Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday. They were charged with wantonly beating a 40-year-old man to death early Saturday morning.
Yma Sumac, Peruvian coloratura, was questioned yesterday on Ellis Island by immigration authorities and then released because "there was no cause for her exclusion."

A thrifty adaptation of the Near Eastern dish, dolma, for which vine leaves are stuffed with varied meats and vegetables, is today's suggestion for cabbage leaves stuffed with ground beef. Cabbage now is one of the most reasonably priced vegetables.
MEXICO CITY, July 12 -- President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines has ordered the establishment of a national production council, in which private enterprise is to play the leading role.

Thomas Scherman, founder-conductor of the Little Orchestra Society, made his debut at Lewisohn Stadium last evening, conducting the Stadium Symphony Orchestra in Morton Gould's "Concerto for Tap Dancer and Orchestra."

Plans for the ocooperative ownership of the twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 25 West Fifty-fourth Street are being arranged by Douglas Gibbons Co. and Riker Co., agents. The structure contains suites of two, three and four rooms which are being offered to buyers subject to existing occupancies.
Willie Troy, 161 pounds, from Washington, knocked out Tony Anthony, 157 1/2, Harlem, in the fourth round of the scheduled ten-round contest at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., July 12 (AP) -- The Army announced here today the clearing and reinstatement of Bernard Martin, a technical writer who was suspended last year from the electronic warfare center as an alleged security risk.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The House Public Works Committee approved today legislation to authorize 140 navigation, flood control and beach erosion projects for future construction.

Potato futures moved into new high ground yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Prices closed 3 to 7 points higher on 944 car lots. Buying was influenced by a lower-than-expected crop report released late Friday by the Department of Agriculture.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and closing prices were steady, 4 to 22 points net higher than last Friday on the active months.
The world's fastest passenger liner, the United States of the United States Lines, will take time out next week to enter one of the world's largest drydocks for a four-day overhaul.
HAMILTON, N. Y., July 12 -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. undertook a broad attack tonight on the Administration's conduct of foreign policy.
Seeded players swept into the third round of the Eastern junior and boys' tennis championships yesterday at the West Side Club, Forest Hills.

Many foreign exchange experts have contended for months that sterling could not remain inconvertible if the Dutch and the West Germans freed their currencies. These observers now believe an action last week by the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxemburg may bring early developments elsewhere -- such as a move by West Germany, which has been willing to close out the European Payments Union in the interests of convertibility.
CLEVELAND, July 12 (AP) -- Big league baseball players today organized formally into a group known as the Major League Baseball Players Association. They also adopted by-laws and a constitution.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 12 -- Hugh Skelley Jr. of the home club and Phil Santora, Westchester Hills, fired par 71's at the Tamarack Country Club today to tie for the medal in the Westchester district qualifying for the Metropolitan amateur golf championship.
COPENHAGEN, July 12 (AP) -- Robert Haillet and Paul Remy of France brought about the biggest upset of the 1954 European zone Davis Cup tennis competition today.
Only seventeen of the city's 679 fixed sirens were inoperative in the city's air-raid warning siren test yesterday. Twenty-one had failed to work in the last previous test on June 14.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 12 -- Double-purpose appliances are the most notable feature of the annual week-long exhibit of the National Housewares Manufacturers Association, which opened here today.

A nineteen-story office building for 3-11 East Fifty-fourth Street was among plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The Knickerbocker Construction Corporation of 600 Fifth Avenue is the owner and Richard and Emery Roth are the architects.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 12 (UP) -- Determine, the little grey colt that won the Kentucky Derby, has a giant-sized toothache and as a result his scheduled trip to Chicago has been canceled, Andy Crevolin, his owner, announced today.

The Commercial State Bank and Trust Company of New York reported as of June 30, 1954, total deposits of $65,946,732 and total assets of $73,558,039, compared, respectively, with $60,410,797 and $67,832,184 on Dec. 31, 1953. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $14,345,626 against $14,310,506 holdings of United States Government securities to $16,326,594 against $13,853,277 and loans and discounts to $41,321,908 against $38,945,029.

In your editorial of June 29 "An Epochal Measure" you regard as distortion the designation of the omnibus revenue bill as "tax relief legislation." Such a designation, you contend, ignores its "primary and most fundamental feature." That feature is the fact that there are over 3,000 changes which in the aggregate add up to a basic modernization of the tax laws.

James J. Nance, president of the Packard Motor Car Company, reported yesterday that reaction to the proposed consolidation of Packard and the Studebaker Corporation has been overwhelmingly favorable -- from the public, from dealers, and from stockholders in both companies."
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Senate housing scandal investigators voted today to ask the Justice Department whether criminal action should be brought against two New Jersey builders.

DALLAS, July 12 (AP) -- Hal McCommas of Southern Methodist University defeated F. M. Wiggins of Louisville, Ky., 5 and 3, in the first round of the twenty-ninth national public links golf tournament today.

New York City has borrowed $20,000,000 on short-term tax anticipation notes from banks here at an interest rate of 1 1/8 per cent, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday. The borrowing cost is 1/4 of 1 per cent less than that incurred by the city earlier this year.

One of the most exclusive bits of suburbia in the metropolitan area nestles inside the breastworks of a historic old fort that dominates New York Harbor. Fort Jay, on Governors Island, where the shouts of children at play have replaced the roll of drums, is now the headquarters of the First Army -- the administrative center for all Army affairs in New England, New York and New Jersey.

Phillip P. Zipes, operator, resold the sixty-five-family house at 3110 Kingsbridge Terrace, the Bronx, to a client of James Liebman, lawyer. It is assessed at $190,000. The Taylor Company was the broker and Fred S. Weitzner, lawyer, acted for the seller.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The first test of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's power and influence since the hearings on his dispute with the Army ended will come up on Thursday.

A new one-story building 200 by 100 feet at 345 Butler Street in Brooklyn has been leased from Richard Zirinsky, builder, by the Chock Full O'Nuts Coffee Company which will use it for the roasting and packing of coffee. The lessee plans to occupy the building next week.

FRANKLIN SQUARE, L. I., July 12 -- The powerful Nassau County Republican organization called upon Governor Dewey tonight to declare himself a candidate for re-election notwithstanding any personal inclinations he may have to step out of public office.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- A charge of "highly questionable" commercialism in Marine and Navy band tours was made today by Senator John J. Williams.
DUBLIN, July 12 (Reuters) A Government commission called on the Irish today to increase their marriage rate and to marry younger.
To the Coney Island beachcomber, there is nothing like a little sand to reveal the economic state of the nation.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, left by plane tonight for talks in Paris with Pierre Mendes- France, French Premier and Foreign Minister, and Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary.

FORT LEE, N. J., July 12 -- Eight thousand orphans and crippled children from New York had the time of their lives today at Palisades Amusement Park here. They were guests at the eighteenth annual Anchor Club outing of the New York City Police Department.

Interest in straw hats, which had been on the wane for several years, has picked up sharply according to James B. Lee, president of the Frank H. Lee Com- pany of Danbury, Conn. Speaking at the company's 1955 straw hat convention at the Commodore Hotel yesterday, he said the present summer season was the best the industry had had in twenty years.

One of the by-products of baseball is the extreme partisanship it creates. Note how frayed the tempers become and how loud the voices grow when the respective merits of the Dodgers and the Giants are compared or the chances of Cleveland or Chicago against the Yankees are weighed.
The women's hat trade is losing its market and it had better begin to do something about it, executives in the millinery trade were told yesterday.
Some manufacturers said business at the opening of the annual summer furniture market here yesterday was good and some store executives labeled it bad.

Four eastern railroads put "piggy-back" service -- the hauling of trailers on flat cars -- into operation yesterday. Those starting the service were the Pennsylvania, Erie, Delaware, Lackawanna and Western and the New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate).

Nine new members and three reappointed members of the New York City Youth Board were sworn in yesterday at City Hall. Mayor Wagner, administering the oath, hailed the expanded Youth Board as "the core of the city's long-range delinquency program."

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Prime Minister Churchill's statement in the House of Commons today that "this is not the moment" to consider Communist China's admission tto the United Nations got an enthusiastic welcome in Washington today.
LONDON, July 12 -- Britain's visible adverse balance of trade in the first six months of 1954 was reduced more than one hundred million pounds ($280,000,000), the Board of Trade reported today.
NEW HAVEN, July 12 -- The Yale Alumni Fund received $1,083,123 in the fiscal year ending June 30. This was a record, topping the previous year by $61,291.

GENEVA, July 12 -- The conference on Indochina showed signs of getting back to business today, but the announcement that Secretary of State Dulles was flying to Paris for discussions tomorrow set it to marking time again.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., July 12 -- Gov. William G. Stratton of Illinois laid claim today to one of the strongest Republican state organizations in the country, but bowed his head modestly when somebody suggested he might be a contender for the Presidency some day.

An underwriting group headed by Hornblower Weeks today will offer to the public 100,000 common shares of $10 par value of Sangamo Electric Company, Springfield, Ill., at $25 a share. Of the proceeds $2,000,000 will be used to reduce bank loans.
An apparent attempt to extort $10,000 from a wealthy New York family through a kidnapping hoax fell through yesterday after the intended victim promptly notified the police and Federal authorities.

Walter Florell repeated several themes in his budget-priced "Mr. Walter" hats and his regular collection in yesterday's joint showing of fall designs at 29 East Fifty-third Street. He featured berets, clothes and head-enveloping sleek caps that rose steeply to peaked or high crowns, developing them in both groups, but in different ways.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (UP) -- President Eisenhower today set up a special Cabinet committee on transport policy, calling for a comprehensive review of Federal transportation problems by Dec. 1.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- President Eisenhower's chief economic adviser asserted today that Government statistics were not good enough.

A first issue of Dutch guilder bonds of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is scheduled to be publicly offered in the Netherlands today in the amount of 40,000,000 florins, equal to about $10,500,000.
Harry W. Pierce, president of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, told last week how his company moved out of the red into the black between 1952 and 1953.

BONN, Germany, July 12 -- Princess Margaret charmed thousands of Bonn citizens today when she kept a date with them despite a change in plans. She arrived in the West German capital to start a three-day visit to West Germany.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The United States took another step today toward development of low-cost electric power from the atom.

Legislation to permit American exporters to buy Government insurance on their export sales for the first time was advocated here last night by Senator Homer E. Capehart. The Indiana Republican is chairman of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

Jerome Alexander in his letter of June 22 says "that so-called 'communism' is nothing more or less than a mask for 'Russian imperialism' under which, for centuries, Russia has extended her territories." In my opinion such identification of communism with Russian imperialism is a fallacy, since historical evidence shows that the Communist policies are in constant contradiction with the interests of the Russian people.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UP) -- President Eisenhower signed a bill today authorizing a three-year $180,000,000 Federal program to encourage construction of hospitals and other medical facilities for the aged, chronically ill and physically disabled.
ROME, July 12 -- The Italian Government ordered the Army today to be ready to take over Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste within a few hours of an agreement between Italy and Yugoslavia.

BALTIMORE, July 12 -- With both candidates for the Democratic nomination for Governor pressing demands for a recount of the votes in the June 28 primary, the winner was still in doubt today. The fight is expected to delay the state nominating convention, scheduled for July 28.

KARACHI, July 12 -- A Foreign Office spokesmen said today an announcement would be made "probably later this week" restricting members of the Soviet Embassy staff to Karachi's civic area. The Russians also will be prohibited from visiting defense establishments, the spokesman added.

LONDON, July 12 -- The stock markets began the week buoyantly today and rises of 1 shilling (14 cents) or more were recorded in a wide range of domestic issues. Profit-taking sales took the edge off some groups.

It is something of a rarity these days to find a public park languishing from the lack of use. But that is what is happening on the eighty-seven-acre Wards Island Park, located a short distance from the densely populated upper East Side. Things are so bad that the neat brick refreshment stand is closed for lack of business. On Sunday the beauties and facilities of this park were used by fewer than 1,000 persons.
LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- Two Texas multimillionaires are planning to acquire half a dozen of the nation's big horse-racing tracks and operate them for the benefit of underprivileged boys.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 12 -- Jeff Chandler will realize late next year a long-time ambition to play Moses. He will appear in a film based on the early exploits of the great leader.

BALTIMORE, July 12 -- Mayor Thomas D'Alesandro left a hospital bed today and returned to City Hall to enforce an order dismissing Arthur B. Price, City Council President, as Acting Mayor. Mr. D'Alesandro had been in the hospital four months.

The Wall Street Journal printed an exchange of letters yesterday between Harlow H. Curtice, president of General Motors Corporation, and Bernard Kilgore, president of Dow Jones Co., publisher of The Journal, which were aimed at clearing up the differences between the two.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 12 (AP) -- Sir Joseph, 6-year-old bay gelding owned by Harry Roughsedge of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., scored a length victory over Bluett Hanover in 2:03 4/5 tonight in the Grand Circuit pacing feature at Roosevelt Raceway. Chief McKlyo was third. Sir Joseph, driven by Bob Walker, returned $16.60 for $2.

A new navigational instrument for use in the Arctic regions, where conventional compasses are almost useless because of the proximity of the magnetic pole, has been developed by a Long Island company.

BERLIN, July 12 -- Twelve United States Air Force transports left Tempelhof Airfield today with capacity cargoes of children. It was the start of what the Air Force calls its "Kinderlift," in which 1,440 children are to be flown across the Soviet Zone to West Germany to meet a new "cold war" challenge.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 12 (UP) -- R. C. Hanna's favored Candle Wood just lasted to score a neck victory over Roman Fair today in the $6,000 Kerry Patch allowance purse at Monmouth Park. Candle Wood timed in 1:10 3-5 for the six furlongs, paid $5.20 for $2 before 20,031 fans.

A dispatch in the July 2 Times about problems involved in obtaining agreement on the proposal before the United Nation's Economic and Social Council for calendar reform raises one nasty question. If nations and groups within them cannot agree on an apparently simple matter like a uniform world calendar system, how can these same nations and groups possibly expect to agree on the obvious problems of war and peace?

The season for fresh currants, probably the briefest of that for any fruit, now is at its height. The tart berries, red or white, are available only this month and next with the bulk of the supply arriving between July 4 and 24. Home cooks who wish to make jelly or to use currants in a more unusual way, such as in a chiffon pie, should do so without delay.

Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia left by air yesterday on his way home in a chartered plane with sixteen others, including a son and two daughters. On the way he plans to stay for a few days in France, Yugoslavia and Greece.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 12 -- Soviet and Indian resolutions to prevent further United States nuclear tests in the Marshall Islands were turned down today by the Petitions Committee of the United Nations Trusteeship Council.

OTTAWA, July 12 (AP) -- Canada has decided to postpone plans for an investigation of coastal shipping until the conclusion of coming negotiations between the Commonwealth and the United States on the St. Lawrence Seaway.

THE day's books offer two splendidly contrasted vicarious holidays. They are both to be spent largely in the open air, far from the beguilements of summertime Manhattan and awash with episodes of courage, resourcefulness and discovery.
Rails moved higher in yesterday's stock trading, finally pushing through the 1953 high and closing at the best level since December, 1952.

LONG BEACH, L. I., July 12 -- A boy born with a partly formed Siamese twin attached to his breastbone died early this morning, twenty-nine hours after birth, at Long Beach Memorial Hospital after a rare emergency operation Sunday.
JERUSALEM, July 12 -- Israel and Jordan blamed each other today for the shooting in Jerusalem two weeks ago in which nine lives were lost.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 13 -- Blackmarketers breathed easier today. The Government's year-old policy of restricted imports on such items as food, toilet articles, liquor and cigarettes will continue for at least six months.

ARDSLEY, N. Y., July 13 -- Robert A. Arone of 13 Lincoln Avenue, this village, died of infantile paralysis at 3 A. M. today aboard the Queen Elizabeth as she approached New York. It would have been his first visit at home in two years.

BOLOGNA, Italy, July 12 -- Italy's chief school for communism teaches pupils to remain good Roman Catholics if they wish and not to work for a revolution or even for the conversion of farm laborers to communism.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 13 -- Denmark's foreign currency "till" is nearly empty, so a special session of Parliament is envisaged to deal with the crisis.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 13 -- Consumer goods being offered to department store buyers here at the annual summer exhibit of the National Housewares Manufacturers Association support the often-expressed opinion that the kitchen is becoming the best decorated room in many homes.

Counsel for the union representing employes at Yonkers Raceway said yesterday that he would ask the State Labor Board to subpoena James Lynch to testify about his relationship to a new union of raceway workers.
ELMSFORD, N. Y., July 13 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century, the metropolitan champion, won the low gross honors in a Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament today.

Cardinal Spellman yesterday announced the appointment of the Very Rev. Msgr. Francis F. Reh, vice chancellor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, as vice rector of the North American College in Rome.

The Citizens Budget Commission, in an attack yesterday on the assertion of City Administrator Luther H. Gulick that substantial management economies had been effected in the city's 1954-55 budget, challenged the accuracy of Mr. Gulick's figures.

GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 13 (UP) -- The international tennis championships of Switzerland opened with an upset today when Gene Garrett of New York was eliminated by Antonio Maggi of Italy in a second-round match.

In his article in your issue of July 3 Charles G. Bennett has explained in detail the point of view of the city of New York with respect to real estate taxes allegedly owed by foreign countries. My law firm represents several countries which are interested in this question.

Thomas M. Goodfellow, newly designated general manager of the Long Island Rail Road, said yesterday that $15,000,000 of the $58,000,000 to be made available under the road's rehabilitation program would be applied toward the purchase of 100 or more new cars.

Nino Valdes, the heavyweight champion of Cuba, and rated second among contenders for Rocky Marciano's world title, and Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson of Rockaway Beach, L. I., will meet tonight in the main event booked for ten rounds at Madison Square Garden.
ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 13 (AP) -- Britain took the lead today in a triangular golf match among senior amateurs from Britain, the United States and Canada.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- A program to make Thailand a base for defense against Communist aggression in Southeast Asia was announced today.
The election of Robert F. Six as chairman of the Swan Finch Oil Corporation was announced yesterday. John W. Meyer was elected vice president.
The world price of sugar dipped yesterday to 3.05 cents a pound, the lowest point this year.

Two views of what is wrong with the services, one from an Air Force officer and the other from a recently retired Navy captain, stress the "vital need for truly professional armed forces" commanded by "combat line officers" rather than specialists.

Two years ago today, the United States Lines' superliner, the United States, steamed into New York Harbor, bringing to this country the first Atlantic passenger-ship speed record to be held by an American vessel in almost 100 years.

New York's City Council is not easily discouraged. Last year the Councilmen failed to whip up enough interest to go through with a projected softball game with the Chicago City Council. Last week the Councilmen lost their annual baseball game with City Hall reporters, 9 to 5.
BERLIN, July 13 -- East German authorities massed trains, trucks and buses in Dessau today for possible evacuation of the entire city in the face of floods from two rivers.

C. S. FORESTER has written ten stories of monstrous psychology and called the collection "The Nightmare."* He brings to these macabre tales the outstanding skill he showed as a storyteller in creating the seaborne Hornblower saga. Yet the aim in view is far different from that saga's celebration of the navy that carried the meteor flag of England.
Hedley Woodhouse really showed 'em how to ride at Jamaica yesterday. The 34-year-old jockey had three winners, including a victory in the feature event of a mile and a sixteenth.
A carpet manufacturer and a vacuum cleaner maker are discussing a possible merger.
ROME, July 13 -- Italy is taking decisive action to enhance the future of her growing merchant marine and to attract foreign orders for her declining shipbuilding industry.
One hundred and forty-nine students who went to school the hard way were graduated informally last night by the evening division of New York University's College of Engineering.

When a business man finds that he is making more of a product than the public will buy he lowers his production. This fact could be related about any enterprise in the United States -- except one vast industry -- farm products which are getting Government supports. Here the tables are turned.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 13 -- Indonesia's Moslem party, which leads the opposition to the Communist - supported Government of Nationalist Premier Ali Sastroamidjojo, and is the largest political party in the country, has launched a grass roots campaign for a united Islamic front against continued Communist infiltration and encroachment here.
CHICAGO, July 13 (UP) -- The C. I. O. National Association of Broadcast Engineers and Technicians today threatened a $6,000,000 suit over telecast arrangements for the All-Star baseball game.

Marianna von Allesch was modeling a mermaid in her Greenwich Village workshop, 50 West Thirteenth Street, when we visited there this week. The form of the figure was strong, the texture rough, the color a cold gray, a design, all told, an interesting contrast to the sparkling, delicate glass objects on the shelves behind her -- work of her younger days.
" Rear Window" Alfred Hitchcock's suspense drama in Technicolor starring James Stewart and Grace Kelly, will reopen the Rivoli Theatre on Wednesday, Aug. 4, it was announced yesterday by Paramount.

RICHMOND, Va., July 13 (AP) -- Virginia Democrats picked two young state legislators in primary elections today to try to recapture Congressional districts captured by Republicans in the 1952 Eisenhower landslide.

In a conference in Paris which has now taken precedence over Geneva the Western Big Three represented by Secretaries Dulles and Eden and Premier Mendes-France are engaged in a new effort to compose the differences in their respective policies in Asia and in Europe in order to strengthen their common front.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The House of Representatives rejected President Eisenhower's health reinsurance plan today, 238 to 134, in one of the most stunning defeats for the Administration in this session of Congress.

CLEVELAND, July 13 (AP) -- The silence finally broke in the National League All-Stars' dressing room, and there were two main topics -- a bloop single that won for the American Leaguers and an attempted steal of home that fizzled.

If the country is successful in getting even a reasonably sound farm bill out of this session of Congress it will be because of the determination of the Administration, backed by a handful of leaders who have had the courage to place the good of the nation above selfish local interests.

OSLO, Norway, July 13 (AP) -- The Norwegian Government protested today "most firmly against espionage activities undertaken by officials of the Soviet Embassy." It demanded that steps be taken to prevent violations of Norwegian law and diplomatic rules.
Sharply contrasting interpretations of a famous historical character, St. Joan, are expected to be compared here late in the season.

The word "cure" is virtually tabu in popular discussions of cancer. Yet the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research of Memorial Hospital uses it boldly in its last progress report. To be sure, only rats and mice have been cured. Even this result is of historic importance because the cures were brought about entirely by chemical means.
PARIS, July 13 -- The Government is expected to announce soon a plan whose stated aim is to harmonize French and native interests in the North African protectorates.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 13 -- Robert Westbrook, president of the National Retail Hardware Association, told the fifty-fifth congress of the organization here today that the nation's hardware merchants have conquered their recession.
Donations to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program on Monday totaled 373 pints of blood, of which 129 pints were given at 44 Beaver Street by employes of the Foster Wheeler Corporation.

One of the unusual events being planned for the forthcoming season is the International Ball for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund. Mrs. Lytle Hull is chairman of the executive committee for the fete, which will be held on the night of Nov. 2 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, and among her aides is Mrs. John R. Drexel 3d.

CLEVELAND, July 13 -- In a slugfest that had a crowd of 68,751 fans roaring for more than three hours, the American League today brought to an end the National League's four-year reign in baseball's mid-summer classic.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The formation of the Robert A. Taft Memorial Foundation, Inc., with former President Hoover as chairman and President Eisenhower as honorary chairman, was announced today.

Stock prices closed mixed yesterday. Industrial shares appeared to be taking a much overdue rest while rail shares continued their recent buoyancy, and at one time pushed to their best levels since 1931.
