WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The United States granted formal diplomatic recognition today to the new anti-Communist Government in Guatemala.
NORTH PLAINFIELD, N. J. -- The Rev. Walter Propheta, 42-year-old pastor of St. Mary's Ukrainian Orthodox Church here, has organized a group that is called "Crusade Against Communism."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 13 -- The United States said today it was limiting economic aid for inhabitants of the Marshall Islands for fear that they might consider themselves its wards.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 13 -- Margaret (Peggy) Mackie of the Inwood Club shot 39, 39 -- 78 to win the low gross prize during the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day medal play tournament at the Garden City Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders said today that the Senate's Republican leadership would permit a showdown vote next week on his resolution to strip Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of his committee chairmanships.

Are you driving to the West or flying to Europe, swimming on Long Island or fishing in the Adirondacks? Sight-seeing in Mexico or taking a cruise to Nova Scotia? Whatever your choice, you are looking forward to a change of scene and air, to weeks or days of escape from city heat, a break in the day-to-day routine.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee, which sent to the Justice Department a transcript of what it said was conflicting secret testimony by two New Jersey builders, found tonight that the witnesses might not have been sworn.

CLEVELAND, July 13 -- At least it wasn't a pitchers' battle. From a purely technical standpoint today's All-Star game in the sprawling stadium on the shore of Lake Erie was a rather horrendous affair, one which must have left Abner Doubleday spinning frantically in his grave. But the so-called "dream game" is primarily the property of the fans.
The Philip Murray Memorial Foundation announced yesterday a grant of $200,000 to the National Council of Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.

I Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz was designated yesterday for another fourteen-year term on the Kings County bench by the Brooklyn Republican executive committee. The district leaders met at county headquarters, 16 Court Street.
The Police Department will start a city-wide drive against drunken drivers Friday with motorized squads equipped with chemical test apparatus.
SARANAC INN, N. Y., July 13 (AP) -- Mrs. Richard Hellmann of Scarsdale, N. Y., today captured the senior division championship of the New York State women's amateur golf tournament.

Dealer buying and shore covering in a dull market pushed cocoa prices up the cent-a-pound daily limit on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday. As the London market stiffened, buying developed here following three days of declines.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- A group of non-Government experts had some praise for the Government's statistics today, but in most cases they asked Congress to grant funds to improve them.

The importance of finding, through research, new uses for by-products was emphasized by O. Parker McComas, president of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., at the annual stockholders meeting yesterday in Richmond, Va.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Senator William F. Knowland, Senate Republican leader, announced today his intention to continue the fight to shut off all aid to France and Italy if they had not joined the European Defense Community by Dec. 31.
CHICAGO, July 13 -- A good deal of profit taking by longs unsettled the grain markets today, especially as the demand from shorts was less active than yesterday.

PARIS, July 13 -- Harold E. Stassen, United States Foreign Operations Administrator, said today that he had made "encouraging progress" in talks with French representatives on revision of the agreement for control of strategic East-West trade.

Battalions, rather than "bodies," may be the unit of replacement for the Army beginning next year if present tentative plans are finally approved. The projected "unit replacement system" will prove to be, if it is administered properly, one of the most effective remedial measures for Army morale.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 13 -- A commission representing Iran and international oil companies started drafting an agreement today for the management of Iran's nationalized oil industry.

The New York Central Railroad's new board of directors held a somewhat secretive meeting yesterday. It was as "hush-hush" as a meeting could be that is held aboard a private train clearly visible from thousands of motor vehicles along the highway routes that parallel the tracks of the West Shore Railroad in New Jersey.
A cheeky theft suspect demonstrated beyond doubt yesterday his prowess as a lock picker when he walked out of a locked cell at the East Sixty-seventh Street police station.

The Very Rev. Terence S. McDermott, vicar general of the Order of Preachers, took leave of his associates among the Dominican Fathers yesterday prior to his departure for Rome, where he is to become interim superior general of the order.

LONDON, July 13 -- Communist East Germany now has an army of more than 80,000 men equipped with 1,300 tanks and self-propelled guns and is training 7,500 fliers in Soviet aircraft, a Government White Paper asserted today.

An acceptable means of close- up showing of live models wearing brassieres on television apparently has been devised by Exquisite Form Brassieres, Inc., manufacturers. The immediate result is that the concern will sponsor a half-hour evening network television show beginning on Sept. 7, backed by network radio and cooperative newspaper advertising to cost more than $1,000,000.

Stockholders of the Western Maryland Railway will vote Sept. 21 on a proposal to issue $16,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, it was announced yesterday. The sale is subject to approval by the Interstate Commerce Commission. Directors also declared a dividend of $2.50 a share on the 7 per cent first preferred stock for the March quarter, payable on July 30, to holders of record on July 23.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy said today that the United States' "preponderance" of atomic weapons "foredoomed to failure" any Communist thrust into Europe or elsewhere in the free world.
PRINCETON, N. J., July 13 -- The East Coast's first electronic "answer machine" center for use by private industry opens here tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- This city's plan for "orderly" integration of Negro and white school pupils as a "model" for other parts of the country was threatened today by the local branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Public Housing Commissioner Charles E. Slusser announced the sale today of $155,514,000 in short-term notes by thirty-nine local housing authorities. The average interest rate for all the notes was 0.585 per cent.

LONDON, July 13 -- The rise in the stock markets continued today, under the lead of Government funds, which advanced as much as 1 ($2.80). Industrials finished higher after a slow start, although profit-taking again caused prices to be slightly irregular.

Lieut. Col. Carlos Castillo Armas, speaking publicly for the first time as provisional President of Guatemala, has outlined a program deserving encouragement. If the erstwhile insurgent leader can implement his words with democratic action, no one will be worse off in Guatemala save the Communists.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., July 13 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower attended today the funeral of Mrs. Milton S. Eisenhower, wife of the president of Pennsylvania State University.
A Kings County grand jury is expected to begin hearing evidence tomorrow in the case of two men involved in the $1-robbery-slaying of a fisherman on a Manhattan Beach pier.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active and prices rose 8 to 27 points.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 13 -- Harry Walker Canfield, 55 years old, a bank teller of 94-A Duncan Hill, Westfield, N. J., was held without bail here today after admitting, the police said, that he had embezzled nearly $25,000 while holding a part-time accounting job in this city.

Directors of the Household Finance Corporation yesterday voted a two-for-one split of the common stock, subject to approval of stockholders at a special meeting about Oct. 7. The board also declared a 10 per cent stock dividend payable to common stockholders on Nov. 5.

SALISBURY, England, July 13 -- British armored forces clanked and rumbled over Salisbury Plain today, breasting smoke-screens, dodging artificial artillery bursts and fending off mock strafing by low-level Royal Navy jets.
LONDON, July 13 -- The United States and Britain have agreed on a shorter embargo list for trade with the Soviet Union and its satellites.
A severe heat wave, which has enveloped virtually the entire nation, sent the temperature in this city up to 92.1 degrees at 6:15 P.M. yesterday, for a new high for the year.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., July 13 -- Sharp opposition to financing President Eisenhower's multi-billion-dollar "grand plan" of highway modernization through the Federal grant-in-aid system was voiced today at the forty-sixth annual Governors Conference.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 13 -- Ethel Barrymore, occupied of late with her own television film series, has accepted a top role in "Young at Heart," which goes into production next week at Warner Brothers.

LOS ANGELES, July 13 -- Isaac I. Kashdan of Los Angeles, national co-champion with Samuel Reshevsky in 1942, lost to Arthur B. Bisguier of New York, present United States champion, today in the third round of the Pan American chess tournament at the Hollywood Athletic Club.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 13 -- Officers and members of more than twenty-five Exchange Clubs from Northern California will meet in Oakland Sunday to discuss a mass withdrawal from the national organization because of its racial policies.

The Sanitation Department has a new way of getting rid of derelict cars so worthless that even junk dealers will not bid for them. Since May 21 it has given 672 of these jalopies burial in landfills along with the rest of the city's refuse.
A local law permitting stock model automobiles as taxicabs in competition with "jumbo" cabs was signed yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
GUATEMALA, July 13 -- The new Guatemalan administration's first real political bid is an extraordinarily powerful one, in the opinion of observers here.

" Listener's Digest," an album of ten 45 r.p.m. "extended-play" disks, was introduced yesterday by R. C. A. Victor Records at a press preview at the Plaza Hotel. The album, according to George R. Marek, director of artists and repertoire for the company, was planned as a musical counterpart of book condensations and magazine digests.

FORT LEE, N. J., July 13 -- The builder who refused to testify at a public session yesterday in the Senate housing scandal investigation talked freely for two hours about his business at his office here today.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today the nation produced nearly $365,000,000,000 worth of goods and services last year, a new high. This averaged about a billion dollars a day and for the fourth year the nation's production reached a new peak.

Arthur Krock suggests in his dispatch from London published July 9 that "a fault of reporting the facts to the British press by its correspondents abroad" has resulted in a failure on the part of people in Britain to realize that "'foreign invasion' or intervention was no part of the process" which resulted in a change of government in Guatemala.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- The Senate passed, 78 to 3, an unemployment compensation financing bill tonight that would provide for increased Federal grants to the states. It earlier rejected an amendment to raise the jobless aid benefits to individuals.

WITH three-score-and-ten behind him, a city dweller looking backward finds a lot of once-familiar detail gone from the urban tapestry. Dr. L. Hubert Costigan, for example, misses one-horse cars, two-horse cars, cable cars, slot-trolley cars, hobble-skirt cars, high-step cars, low-step cars, pay-as-you-enter trolleys, pay-as-you-leave types, straw-on-the-floor cars--among other kinds.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 13 -- A development company and three residents of near-by Greenburgh objected today to the state-approved public housing plan of the Greenburgh Housing Authority.

TOKYO, July 13 (AP) -- Japan said today in an Economic White Paper that the island nation consumed 9 per cent more imported and domestic goods last year than in the peak pre-war year. The result is a sharp decline in its cash reserve.
GENEVA, July 13 -- The three Communist delegations in the Indochinese negotiations here are annoyed over the Western Big Three talks in Paris.

THE big bluefins apparently have by-passed the New Jersey and Long Island waters on their early run, and have moved in on the Nova Scotia coast to gorge on the herring there, for several fish in the 500-pound class have been boated at Wedgeport.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Maj. Gen. John H. Stokes Jr., commanding general of the Military District of Washington, approved today the sentence of ten years at hard labor imposed upon Cpl. Edward S. Dickenson for collaborating with the enemy while a prisoner of war in Korea.
Have you ever weighed a hippopotamus? Or even a baby hippopotamus? If you have, the Bronx Zoo would like to know your formula. If you haven't -- well, don't try.

The victory of King's First, a 6-year-old bay gelding, at Saratoga Raceway on June 18 was legitimatized yesterday even though a routine test had indicated the presence of a drug in the trotter's saliva.

GENEVA, July 13 -- Representatives of the two rival governments in Vietnam discussed peace today. Principals in the talks, which were private, were Tran Van Do, new Foreign Minister of the Vietnam government, of which Bao Dai is Chief of State, and Pham Van Dong, Deputy Premier and Foreign Minister of the Vietminh government.

The Greyhound Corporation has called a special meeting of stockholders for Aug. 17 to vote on the proposed merger with Pacific Greyhound Lines, a California corporation. Recently Greyhound Corporation increased its holdings in Pacific to 97.49 per cent through purchase of a minority interest held by the Southern Pacific Company.

The General American Oil Company of Texas has concluded an agreement for the purchase of virtually all the properties of the Deep Rock Oil Corporation, Tulsa, Okla. Under the proposal Deep Rock will receive $22,000,000 in cash after financing arrangements are completed and 100,000 common shares of General American valued at $5,000,000.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 13 -- Brazil has put out feelers for a new loan from the United States to tide her over a critical dollar shortage, the newspaper O Globo reported today. American Embassy sources declined to comment.
HANOI, Vietnam, July 13 (AP) -- The Vietminh built up pressure today on French Union outposts shielding Hanoi on three sides. The French slammed back with air and tank attacks.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- Representative Ralph A. Gamble proposed today that the Government "foreclose" on the United States Tin Corporation's operations at Lone River, Alaska, and "get what money out of it we can."

Eugene Scott of St. James, L. I., 16-year-old unseeded player, scored his second straight impressive victory in the junior division of the Eastern junior and boys' tennis championships when he defeated Dick Katz of Baltimore, seeded seventh, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 0, yesterday to reach the quarter-final round.

When "The Halls of Ivy," the comedy drama series co-starring Ronald Colman and Benita Hume, makes its television debut in October, it will be sponsored by the International Harvester Company. No decision has been made as to whether the film program will be televised by a network or distributed to individual stations.
JERSEY CITY, July 13 -- Former Mayor Frank Hague remained in seclusion in a New York hotel suite today as his lawyers studied the legal problems of the 78-year-old former Democratic boss.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (UP) -- The Air Force plans 485 new radar posts to help guard the North American continent from a possible sneak atomic air attack.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 13 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey declared tonight that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had "done more than any individual of our time to damage America in the eyes of the world."

WESTBURY, L. I., July 13 (AP) Ferman Hanover, a 7-year-old bay gelding owned by Cleo A. Young of Timmonsville, S. C., scored a length victory over Freeman Hanover in the feature pace on the Grand Circuit program at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

The city's Board of Education has asked the Public Education Association to investigate charges of "Jim Crow" practices here. The charges, raised anew by a speaker at a recent symposium conducted by the National Urban League, hold that Negro students generally attend predominantly Negro schools, where they receive inferior teaching and inadequate guidance and counseling.

" Flying Saucers on the Attack," by Harold T. Wilkins, will be issued Monday by Citadel Press. Mr. Wilkins, who has spent nine years studying this subject, presents "reports" kept secret till now of actual encounters with flying saucers.

LONDON, July 13 -- A group of Conservative members of Parliament announced tonight it would vote against any treaty with Egypt that involved the removal of all the British fighting troops from the Suez Canal area.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 13 -- An appeal by American Federation of Labor union leaders today managed to get nearly 2,000 striking workers, mostly craftsmen, back on two Oak Ridge construction projects costing half a billion dollars.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation reported yesterday for the quarter ended May 31 -- the final three months of its fiscal year -- a net profit of $4,289,000, against $4,515,000 earned a year before.

Occasionally, about this time of year, people who have lived in the city all of their lives (and like it), after listening for weeks to talk by their more rural friends of annuals, perennials, fertilizers, rose sprays and the like may be moved to inquire concerning what life in Suburbia really is like.
Memo to New Yorkers on a hot day:

The Rev. William Howard Melish told yesterday of activities ranging from signing a clemency plea for eleven convicted Communists to participation in a "trial" of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Wisconsin Republican. The hearing was at 70 Columbia Avenue.

PARIS, July 13 -- The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France met here tonight for five hours. After their discussion, it appeared that an understanding might be reached regarding the kind of armistice in Indochina the United States would agree to guarantee.
CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -- Today's reports of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The Port of New York held on to its share of the nation's waterborne foreign trade last year. It would have done better had it not been for unsettled labor conditions that diverted an estimated 250,000 long tons of general cargoes to its major competitors.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- United States District Judge J. W. Morris today ordered acquittal of Robert E. Bowen, 36 years old, formerly of Spokane, charged with violating the Federal conflict-of-interest law.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Administration's anti - subversive program both gained and lost ground in Congress today.

The New York Times on July 9 published a letter from Nathan M. Klein relating to the Long Island Transit Authority's plan for the prompt rehabilitation of the Long Island Rail Road. Mr. Klein objects to the plan for various reasons and praises New York City for opposing it.

PARIS, July 13 -- Following Switzerland's refusal to permit loyalty hearings in that country, a United States loyalty board here was considering alternative means of hearing "about fourteen" Americans working in Geneva, it was learned last night from an official source.

MONTREAL, July 13 (Canadian Press) -- Twelve children were believed to have drowned today when a group of youngsters suddenly became panic-stricken and capsized a pleasure boat in Lake of Two Mountains, about twenty miles northwest of Montreal.

The busy housewife who must stay at home, perhaps to attend to a new baby, sends her older child off to school every morning with careful admonitions to look both ways before crossing streets. But even though the child forever assures his mother that he will, there is always apprehension when he leaves and relief when he returns.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 13 -- Eight feminine crews set out in Lightning sloops from the Riverside Yacht Club today in quest of the Syce Cup, which represents the women's sailing championship of Long Island.
Danny Gawronski of Brooklyn has discovered that a boy's fondest dream sometimes comes true.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 13 -- The International Court of Justice ruled today that indemnities awarded to dismissed United Nations employes could not be refused by the General Assembly. The vote was 9 to 3.
CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -- The top-seeded Tony Trabert of Cincinnati needed only 36 minutes today to reach the third round of the national clay courts tennis tournament.

WAYNESBURG, Pa., July 13 -- Token picket lines forced the closing today of eight big coal mines, including the largest bituminous pit in the world, the Robena mine of the United States Steel Corporation.

THE television drama based wholly on a theme of mental disorder, particularly where a female character is so afflicted, is beginning to wear thin. "Studio One Summer Theatre" contributed to this threadbare trend last Monday night (C. B. S., 10 to 11) with a play entitled "A Guest at the Embassy."

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Senate-House conferees looked ahead today to a final compromise on the Administration's housing program within twenty-four hours as they knocked out a proposal for Government-insured mortgage loans on trailer housing.

Opposite the Port Authority Building, at 626 Eighth Avenue, a Chinese restaurant opened recently. Unpretentious in appearance, Foo Chow's has something far more important to connoisseurs of food -- an excellent chef.
MEXICO CITY, July 13 -- Mexican natural gas may soon be flowing north to serve a large area of the northeastern United States.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., July 13 -- Mrs. Caroline K. Simon, State Commissioner Against Discrimination, said today that the final battle for tolerance would take place in the home.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- The Eisenhower Administration -- in a surprise move -- threw its support today behind a proposal to revive Federal aid for schools affected by defense activities.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Senator Homer E. Ferguson, Michigan Republican, after conceding he had conducted perhaps more one-man investigative hearings than any other Senator, urged Congress today to put a stop to them.

Decision was reserved yesterday in Queens County Court on a motion for a new trial for Paul A. Pfeffer. He is now serving a sentence of twenty years to life for the slaying last August of Edward S. Bates, a seaman, in Rockaway Beach, Queens, a murder to which John Francis Roche, alleged rapist-killer, has confessed.
A resolution introduced yesterday in the City Council would have the city seek a Federal subsidy for metropolitan transit to keep fares down.
Financing for the filming of the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical stage play Oklahoma! has just been completed with the aid of the Wall Street investment banking firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co.
Five hundred and ninety-seven persons applied at Bronx police stations yesterday for jobs as school crossing guards.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (UP) Senators Styles Bridges and Harry F. Byrd proposed today a Constitutional amendment to forbid the Federal Government to operate by deficit in peacetime.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Benjamin Franklin once suggested that a good recipe for Parmesan cheese might interest more people in the wonders of Italy than all the accounts of historic landmarks and the inscriptions thereon.

LONDON, July 13 -- The United States and Britain are in general agreement on the conditions they will accept as a basis for settlement of the war in Indochina. These conditions were agreed upon, reluctantly, by President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Churchill in their recent discussions in Washington.

New issues of public utility securities totaling $50,000,000 will be placed on the market today by investment banking syndicates. Among the offerings are $17,500,000 of first mortgage bonds, $25,000,000 of sinking fund debentures, and $7,500,000 of preferred stock. The new issues are as follows:

CAIRO, July 13 -- The Egyptian Cabinet tonight considered British offers for settlement of the dispute over control of the Suez Canal zone. Acceptance of the plan in principle and early formal negotiations on details are foreseen.

Several executive promotions were announced yesterday by the Procter Gamble Company in a realignment of its management structure. Howard J. Morgens was elected executive vice president in charge of all operations in the United States except the cellulose and oil mill divisions.

Featured among the many hat colors shown yesterday by the Millinery Stabilization Commission at the Astor Hotel, was "palette pink," a pink-mauve hue chosen by the commission as the color of the season. This flattering, versatile shade, which compliments skin tones, was combined effectively with ensembles of black, brown, gray and navy.

Beatrice Martin, champion of the small hat, presented yesterday at the Plaza Hotel a collection of berets, cloches, turbans and fezzes. Interesting fabrics and unusual combinations of fabric and trim added charm.

The program was all-Tchaikovsky at Lewisohn Stadium last night. Thomas Scherman conducted and the soloist was Mary Henderson, Canadian soprano who has appeared with Mr. Scherman at his Little Orchestra Society concerts, but previously had not sung at the amphitheatre.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture expects to add 60,000,000 bushels to the nation's grain storage capacity to take care of a gigantic outpouring of corn and other feed grains this fall.

TULSA, Okla., July 13 -- The bitter fight for the Democratic nomination to Oklahoma's United States Senate seat came to an abrupt end late last night when former Gov. Roy J. Turner withdrew from the July 27 run-off primary.
CHICAGO, July 13 -- So-called discount houses were assailed today at the fifty-third annual Music Industry Trade Show and Convention.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Labor Department said today the Government drive against Mexican "wetback" farm workers was resulting in a sharply increased demand in Texas and California for legal Mexican workers.

BONN, Germany, July 14 -- The West German Government appeared to be satisfied tonight with the United States-British decision to grant West Germany sovereignty at an early date should the French National Assembly adjourn next month without having ratified the defense community treaty.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., July 14 (AP) -- Mrs. Thomas Cantwell of Saranac Lake, a mother of five, today topped the field with a 79 in the opening round of the women's New York State amateur golf championship.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 14 (AP) -- Katie Key, sleek 7-year-old mare, is the 4-5 favorite in tomorrow night's $35,000 Roosevelt Trot, a Grand Circuit race in which Pronto Don has a chance to become the richest of all standardbreeds.
A reduction of 8 per cent in Suez Canal tolls becomes effective today for merchant shipping. The lowered rates are expected to save canal users more than $6,000,000 a year.

An American edition of "I Survived," an account of ten years' captivity in Soviet Russia, will be issued in the fall by John Day. The story is about an Austrian known as Pepi. It is told by Godfrey Lias, a correspondent of The Times of London and The Christian Science Monitor.
Sudden storms, with wind gusts racing 72 miles an hour and tearing down trees and power lines throughout the New York area, sent the year's highest temperature toppling quickly last night.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 14 -- "Global Mission," the autobiography of the late Gen. H. H. (Hap) Arnold, will be brought to the screen by Hal Wallis for Paramount.
PARIS, July 14 (AP) -- Following is the text of the communique issued today by Secretary of State Dulles, Foreign Secretary Eden and Premier Mendes-France:

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, July 14 (UP) -- Hamilton Richardson and Straight Clark swept to straight-set victories today to send the United States to a 2-0 lead over the British West Indies in their first-round series in the American Zone Davis Cup tennis eliminations.
ROME, July 14 -- Ratification of the European Defense Community was approved today by the Finance and Treasury Committee of the Italian Chamber of Deputies. The vote was 26 to 16.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- A New Jersey investigator testified today that two concerns dealing in Federally insured home improvement loans operated a school to teach salesmen how to defraud home owners.
LONDON, July 14 -- One of the fastest bombers in the world, the Handley Page Victor, crashed today, killing four persons.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The defeat of the health reinsurance bill is a defeat for the American people, President Eisenhower said today. He spoke with uncommon indignation when the question came up at his news conference.
CHICAGO, July 14 -- A replacement for steel in making military weapons has been developed by the Armour Research Foundation of the Illinois Institute Technology, it was announced today.
LOS ANGELES, July 14 -- Television is offering children four times as many filmed programs based on crime and violence as it was three years ago.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UP) -- Representative Samuel K. McConnell, chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, moved today to rescue part of President Eisenhower's program for amending the Taft-Hartley Law.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 -- A sound time-payment purchase plan as a stimulant for the retail hardware business was urged upon the fifty-fifth annual congress of the National Retail Hardware Association here today.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today: ...
Companies and brands under the control of Seagram-Distillers Corporation have spent $100,000,000 in advertising since Repeal, it was reported yesterday.

Two varieties of summer squash -- the straight-necked yellow and the long green -- are now plentiful in city vegetable stalls. The New York Office of Extension Service in Food Marketing estimates a serving of this mild-flavored vegetable costs only 3 to 6 cents.
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 14 -- The Central Government announced today it had approved a grant of $70,000,000 to avert the "complete collapse" of East Pakistan.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 14 -- A former champion, Mrs. James Mertz, representing the American Yacht Club, held a 3 1/2-point lead over the defender, Judy Webb of Riverside, in the chase for the Syce Cup at the completion of three more races today at Riverside Yacht Club.

RIVER FOREST, Ill., July 14 (UP) -- Maureen Connolly began the defense of her national clay courts title today, defeating Mary Lou Vash of Chicago without trouble although the little star from San Diego had spent a sleepless night aboard an airplane.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended July 7:
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The State Department said today it hoped for the early return of seven United States soldiers seized by Communist Czechoslovakia July 4 on charges of espionage.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Eisenhower is putting the United States back into the Geneva conference on the Far East.

What is probably the most improbable juke box in the city of New York blares forth from a colony of slot machines in the Eighth Avenue subway's station at Times Square. Of course all juke boxes are improbable contrivances -- marvelous mausoleums in which are interred the Top Ten records of the week (Twenty Selections), the week's Hit Parade favorites, or simply Old Favorites.
The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad has purchased an additional $5,000,000 of its 4 per cent collateral trust bonds, due 1965, formerly held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
A new aid-to-education program, designed to help relieve the financial plight of liberal arts colleges, was announced yesterday by the United States Steel Foundation, Inc.

Acting Deputy Inspector Michael P. Quinn of the Twenty-third Division in East Harlem will be promoted to deputy inspector at a ceremony in Police Headquarters today. Thirty-four other members of the force also will be raised in rank.

The American ideal of "equal justice under law" becomes more difficult to attain as the cost of litigation increases. This fact gives importance to the plan suggested by the Temporary State Commission on Courts to reduce by about $300 the cost of seeing a case through our appellate courts. The commission proposes that the now required expensive printed briefs and records give way to the less costly mimeographed or multilithed form.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 14 -- Oswaldo Aranha, Minister of Finance, issued a formal denial today of reports that Brazil was trying to negotiate a loan from the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse as required by conference rules, except portions authorized for direct quotation by the White House:

A 5-year-old Indian boy who visited here two years ago missed his New York playmates so much that he decided to send them a tiger. The tiger, a thriving 8-month-old cub named Vijay (the Hindustani word for "victory"), was flown in this week, a gift to the Central Park Zoo and the children of New York from Vijay Srivastava, the lad who lives in Kanpur.
The oil industry is getting really serious about cutting refinery output.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 14 -- Construction of two atomic energy projects in Oak Ridge was brought to a standstill today by a laborers' strike that American Federation of Labor leaders said was illegal.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 14 -- China's chief delegate today denounced British talk of United Nations' custody of Formosa as a "fantastic" insult that ignored all political and military realities.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Eisenhower is not challenging his friend, Gov. Walter J. Kohler of Wisconsin, but he does not remember a conversation with him that led to withdrawal of a reference to General of the Army George C. Marshall from the text of a 1952 campaign speech.

New lows were registered yesterday by half the hide contracts on the New York Commodity Exchange. Trading was influenced by a 1/2 cent decline in the price of spot hides in Chicago. There was dealer hedging, stop-loss selling and long liquidation. Short covering and speculator buying supplied the contracts. The market closed 29 to 41 points lower on 155 lots, the third largest daily volume of the year.

A decline last week of 834,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Total supplies on last Friday were 163,712,000 barrels, compared with 164,546,000 a week earlier and 142,527,000 a year ago.
CHICAGO, July 14 -- Wheat futures had an early decline today, but met active support on the recession and recovered to above the close of yesterday.
Nino Valdes scored a knockout over Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson of Far Rockaway in the main bout at Madison Square Garden last night.

I read with a great deal of interest the dispatch of your Warren Weaver Jr. on July 11 relative to the proposals by the Temporary State Commission on the Courts to reduce the expense of appeals by eliminating the requirement that records and briefs must be printed. It is patent that the present high expense of an appeal discriminates against the litigant of modest means in favor of his wealthy adversary.
The House Judiciary Committee has acted with courage and wisdom in a field where both have been singularly lacking of late: how to deal with the internal threat of communism in the United States.
The Burlington Mills Corporation, which has just purchased a majority interest in Pacific Mills, moved yesterday to obtain control of Goodall-Sanford, Inc.

TORONTO, July 14 -- The Hart House Orchestra, a chamber group of twenty-five players, has been organized by Dr. Boyd Neel, founder of the famed Boyd Neel Orchestra in England and Dean of the Royal Conservatory of Music of Toronto.

These are the days when ice cream is especially appetizing. Ice cream toppings, delicious to eat, quick to prepare and easy to make ahead and store, present the busy modern homemaker with an endless variety of desserts for summer meals or social gatherings.
LONDON, July 14 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the speech in the House of Commons today by the British Prime Minister, Sir Winston Churchill:
HEWLETT, L. I., July 14 -- The "missing link" of Peninsula Boulevard, covering a half-mile gap caused by fifteen years of controversy, was supplied officially today.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Eisenhower declared emphatically today that he was not going to let his peacetime international atomic pool plan die if he could help it.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 14 -- Within a week, Dwight Heine, a mild-mannered school teacher from the Marshall Islands, will go home to the Pacific to tell his people how the United Nations has listened to their troubles.
ATLANTA, July 14 (AP) -- A Federal court ruling that Negroes can use Atlanta's municipal golf courses on a segregated basis will be appealed.
PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP) -- Villanova University today named Francis X. (Frank) Reagan as head football coach to succeed Art Raimo, who resigned last month.

PITTSBURGH, July 14 (UP) -- Fifteen coal mines, thirteen of them operated by the nation's biggest steel makers, were shut down today by rebellious pickets who acted in defiance of United Mine Workers union orders.
Senate and House conferees have begun the task of reconciling two versions of the Administration's omnibus tax bill. It is hoped to have the joint bill finished by the end of this week.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Earl Campbell of Washington, D. C., today was elected president of the National Association of Music Merchants, meeting for its fifty-third annual convention at the Palmer House, Chicago. He succeeds Russell B. Wells of Denver, who becomes chairman of the board of directors. Mr. Campbell heads the Campbell Music Company in the nation's capital.

RICHMOND, Va., July 14 (AP) -- Two young members of the Virginia General Assembly -- Ernest Robertson, 39 years old, and John C. Webb, 38, have been nominated by the Democrats to bid for Congressional seats now held by Republicans.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- As a joint Congressional conference committee started work today on the final draft of the Administration's omnibus tax reform bill, the measure got a push from President Eisenhower.

It was cooler in the subway yesterday, if you took a thermometer's word for it. But the reading was lower if you were just waiting on the platform than if you caught a train. And the hottest places in the city transit system were the cars on the elevated tracks.

Offerings of new corporate securities totaling more than $50,000,000 will be made today through the public market for new capital. Among the new issues are mortgage bonds of a Chicago public utility, preferred stock of a Maine paper company and common stock of a Pennsylvania cement company. The offerings are as follows:
RIDGEWOOD, N. J., July 14 -- Carl W. Timpson of the Rockaway Hunting Club won the twenty-seventh annual Metropolitan Golf Association's senior championship over the Ridgewood course today.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today that United States exports and imports both declined in May.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 14 -- Failure to build the proposed $2,200,000 public housing in Greenburgh would "relegate minority groups to second-class citizenship" and undermine health and morals, the Urban League of Westchester and the White Plains branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said today.

LONDON, July 14 -- Sir Winston Churchill told the House of Commons today of a drastic alteration of United States and British policy in Europe expediting West Germany's sovereignty and deferring its rearmament.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission said today it would permit Western Union Telegraph Company to put into effect an average 11 per cent rate increase for interstate services at midnight tonight.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 14 -- The chief Iranian negotiator in the current oil talks said today his country would require further emergency United States assistance to tide it over until the end of the year.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The United States and Britain have agreed to seek France's approval for granting West Germany sovereignty if the French Assembly refuses to ratify the European Defense Community treaty. Under this plan the arming of West Germany would be deferred.
Cotton futures were moderately active yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and closing prices were 8 points higher to 2 points lower than on Tuesday.

LOS ANGELES, July 14 -- The fourth round of the Pan American chess tournament at the Hollywood Athletic Club today failed to produce a break in the ranks of the four players tied for the lead -- Arthur B. Bisguier and Larry Evans of New York, Herman Steiner of Los Angeles and Nicolas Rossolimo, former French champion.

CAIRO, July 14 -- The Soviet Union has been rebuffed in a diplomatic attempt to discourage Egypt from granting Britain reentry rights in the Suez Canal Zone in case of a future war in the Middle East.

Stock prices closed higher yesterday after drifting irregularly lower for much of the session. Railroad issues again were credited with renewing interest in the general list. Some of the best prices of the day were reached in the final thirty minutes of trading for selected television, steel, textile and paper issues.
Representatives of the city's volunteer child care agencies were told yesterday that the Department of Welfare "expects to go into the adoption business soon."

The fate of the European Defense Community, and with it the whole European Idea, hangs in the balance and may be decided before the end of this summer if the projected talks between French and American leaders materialize. The pressure for E. D. C. from Washington and the resistance in Paris have presented to the world a long-drawn-out struggle of frustration and frequent bad temper damaging to Western unity and giving comfort only to Moscow.

The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) announced yesterday that declaration of a dividend for the third quarter was being deferred temporarily. It said that, as a result of the merger agreement with Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company, the declaration would be withheld until the new tax legislation was passed by Congress.

BERLIN, July 14 -- Karl Hamann, former East German Supply Minister, has been sentenced to ten years' hard labor on charges of having "sabotaged" food deliveries. Four of his colleagues drew terms ranging from three to six years.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Auditors tracing the financial operations of the Government-aided United States Tin Corporation's mining venture in northern Alaska said the concern had failed to report full liabilities on applications for Government loans.
The new Fire Department inquiry into kickbacks and other improper practices in inspections resulted yesterday in the filing of charges against five firemen.

LONDON, July 14 -- The revolt of forty Conservative backbenchers in protest against the Government's resuming talks with Egypt on the evacuation of British troops from the Suez Canal base reached a new stage today.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Clint W. Murchison and Sid W. Richardson, the Texas oil men who are friends of Robert R. Young, have sold to the Alleghany Corporation 600,000 of the 800,000 shares they owned of New York Central Railroad stock.

LONDON, July 15 -- Government bonds continued to lead the stock markets here today, although shares of companies expected to benefit from the lifting of installment-buying restrictions also provided some sharp rises.

VIENNA, July 14 (AP) -- Communist Hungary and Czechoslovakia, alarmed by disastrous floods that have caused damage estimated at $1,000,000,000 in Germany and Austria, warned their people today to expect severe losses in food stocks.
LONDON, July 14 (Reuters) -- Following are excerpts from the speech in the House of Commons today by Clement R. Attlee, leader of the Labor Opposition:

Completion yesterday afternoon of the New York District count in the elections of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., bore out early estimates of an overwhelming victory for the slate headed by Joseph Curran, the president.

There are those who dislike the majority of designs being offered buyers at the semi-annual wholesale showing of lamps at the New Yorker Hotel. It is obvious that there are some simple porcelain vases and brass bullets that could satisfactorily be used to light a room, but most of the merchandise is fantastic rather than ingenious.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, asked Congress today to bar all former Federal employes from ever representing private interests in any matter in which they had participated while in Government service.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 14 -- The Americanism commission of the Westehester County American Legion renewed today its criticism of Dr. Goodwill Watson of Rye for his alleged activities with pro-Communist organizations.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 14 (AP) -- Fergan O'Sullivan, former press secretary to Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Opposition leader, acknowledged to a Royal Commission on espionage today that he had furnished the Russians with a detailed report on Australian news men.
TOKYO, July 14 -- Japan, it is indicated here, will tighten her policy of retrenchment and deflation and seek further loans abroad.

"Ring of Fear," a circus melodrama in WarnerColor and CinemaScope has been scheduled to open on Wednesday, July 28, at the Paramount Theatre, the management announced yesterday. Clyde Beatty, Pat O'Brien, Mickey Spillane and Sean McClory head the cast.
LONDON, July 14 -- Ten thousands of Britain's bobbies marched in spanking review order across Hyde Park today before Queen Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh.
PARIS, July 14 -- The war in Indochina and the negotiations to finish it provided a somber background today for the celebration of France's national holiday, Bastille Day.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Senate-House conferees agreed today on compromises to make it easier to buy older homes.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Eisenhower said today he thought the Senate Agriculture Committee had made a grave error in voting to raise Federal dairy price supports.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 14 -- A recent Government decision to double export rates for cocoa has resulted in Ceylon cocoa shippers being hard hit on stocks already sold to overseas buyers and now awaiting shipment.
OTTAWA, July 12 -- Under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization Canada shares responsibility with her allies in the defense of West Europe and North America.

Twenty-five of the New York Public Library's most precious possessions have been taken out of their vaults for a summer-long exhibition. The display opens today in the main lobby of the building at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
GENEVA, July 14 -- Chou Enlai, Communist Chinese Premier, continued to display a conciliatory attitude toward Cambodia and Laos in visits to their delegations today.
KETCHIKAN, Alaska, July 14 -- Alaska took a long-deferred stride today toward industrial expansion that many of its citizens considered a powerful impetus along the path of statehood.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Daniel B. Maher, a Washington lawyer, filed with Congress today a "petition for redress of grievances.'' He also asked the expulsion of all members of the Senate and House of Representatives who had violated their oath to protect and defend the Constitution.

Sales of toys, which have climbed each year for fifteen years, will decline for 1954, according to Melvin Freud, president of the Toy Guidance Council, Inc. Speaking yesterday at the council's annual press preview of Christmas playthings, Mr. Freud said late and cautious buying by retailers would cause a dip in the sales volume.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Senate subcommittee seeking stringent rules that would improve Congressional investigations received today its briefest recommendation. It was this:
Gregory Ratoff has signed to direct A. B. Shiffrin's comedy, "Black-Eyed Susan," which is due on Broadway late in November.

MILWAUKEE, July 14 -- In the first inning of tonight's game between the Dodgers and Braves Duke Snider sent Junior Gilliam home with a sacrifice fly to left field. In the twelfth inning the Duke did the same thing, completing the Brooks' run total for the 3-hour 21-minute affair.

Skill in marketing new products is vital in realization of the profits of research and development. While the introduction of new products provides an opportunity for company growth and increased earnings, experience shows that many new products put on the market are doomed.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 (UP) -- Five men on a raft they hoped to float to Hawaii on ocean currents sent a weak radio S. O. S. tonight saying "bow open, talking on water, need tow."

NEWARK, July 14 -- An explosion in a subterranean vault housing a Public Service Electric and Gas Company electrical transformer injured five persons at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon. The explosion blew a manhole cover and two iron gratings, weighing more than a ton, ten feet in the air.
BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., July 14 -- An economic adviser to President Eisenhower asserted today that a business upswing was about to start.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Committee for A National Trade Policy appealed to President Eisenhower today not to increase the present duties on imported watches and lead and zinc.

CHICAGO, July 14 (UP) -- The Claiborne Farm's Delta, a 14-1 shot, beat the highly favored Lea Lane in a photo finish today for a surprise victory in the nation's richest 2-year-old filly race, the $101,920 Lassie Stakes at Arlington Park.
BOSTON, July 14 (UP) -- Clarence (Woody) Dumart, top goal-getter of the Boston Bruins' Sauerkraut Line, was made a free agent by the Bruins today at his own request.
SEOUL, Korea, July 14 -- United States Ambassador Ellis O. Briggs will leave here Saturday to fly to Washington at the request of Secretary of State Dulles.
In a season of almost uniformly good fall millinery collections, Gustavo of 59 West Fifty-sixth Street presented the most radically different designs seen so far this season.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UP) -- Dr. Irving W. Winik, who has a Washington medical practice, refused to tell House investigators today whether he was a Communist or had engaged in Communist party activities.

Just as Pierre Monteux was conducting the slow movement of Debussy's Iberia last night at Lewisohn Stadium, a windstorm kicked up at the south and of the field. This was after the intermission, at about 10:20 P. M. Not much more than five minutes later, the windstorm became a gale.
ST. LOUIS, July 14 -- As interest returned today to the two major league pennant races baseball men from both camps were still buzzing over yesterday's All-Star thriller in Cleveland.

DURING the unhappy years of the bluefish depression, a two-pounder often managed to win the pool, but proof that these scrappy fish are making a real comeback may be found in the fishboxes of the boats now docking at Brielle, Belmar and the Highlands, for six and eight pound fish are common.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Republican Congressional leaders said after a conference with President Eisenhower today that if pending postal pay increase legislation was passed a postal rate rise must accompany it "in view of the nation's fiscal condition."

The conference of the Western Big Three, which in President Eisenhower's words took Secretary Dulles to Paris to demonstrate this country's eagerness for a united front with its allies, has come to an end with what looks like a limited compromise, leaving major questions still to be settled.

Mrs. Mary Stillman Harkness, who died in 1950, left $4,217,697 in public bequests, it was shown yesterday by an estate tax appraisal. Her net estate was $18,117,995. She was the widow of Edward S. Harkness, financier and philanthropist.
FORT DIX, N. J., July 14 -- Col. Earl L. Ringler, commanding the 272d Infantry Regiment ordered court martial proceedings today against Lieut. Robert S. Morgan and Sgt. 1/C Richard J. Witbeck.

LOS ANGELES, July 14 (AP) -- George and Ira Gershwin's famed operetta, "Porgy and Bess," is described as "too sexy and lewd" for this city's Philharmonic Auditorium, which is owned by a Baptist church. The operetta is based on the play "Porgy," by Dorothy and Du Bose Heyward.
The regional office here of the National Labor Relations Board has obtained extensions of restraining orders aimed at keeping peace on the waterfront.
HANOI, Vietnam, July 14 (AP) -- The French paraded their military strength in Hanoi today as the Communist-led Vietminh stepped up its pounding of the Red River delta's northern defenses.

The second anniversary of Operation Skywatch coincided yesterday with the announcement from Washington that the Air Force planned 485 new radar posts to help guard the North American continent against devastation from the skies.
A temporary little corner of France in New York, the French Line freighter Saint Malo, observed Bastille Day yesterday in Gallic spirit, if not in Gallic leisure.
CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

OSLO, Norway, July 10 -- From the window of a Scandinavian Air Lines plane the land of Norway, rising swiftly from the shores of the North Sea, justifies with its rugged beauty every claim that could be made by a travel agent. As represented, there duly are the mountains, the fiords and the thick expanses of northern timber, shining under the sun -- at least on this occasion.

HARRISON, N. Y., July 14 -- For the second consecutive year, Lloyd Ribner and J. Henry Attas of Dellwood teamed to win the British Victory tournament. With a best-ball score of 66, five under par, at the Harrison Country Club, they led a field of thirty-four teams today.
The leaning tower of Pisa and the five-story brick building at 881 East 178th Street in the East Bronx have something in common. They both lean.

The National Association of Wool Manufacturers informed the Tariff Commission yesterday that there are no grounds for lowering duties on certain low-value wool textile items. The stand was taken in a letter by Edwin Wilkinson, executive vice president of the group, in connection with a commission investigation of tariffs having an average equivalent rate of 50 per cent or higher.
A proposed zoning amendment to require off-street parking or garage facilities for all future non-residential buildings was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Senator William F. Knowland said today that he would lead the fight against the resolution to remove Senator Joseph R. McCarthy from his committee chairmanships.

For Stanley Small, race-riding son of a Philadelphia truck driver, and for the holders of eighty-eight winning daily double tickets, yesterday's program at the Jamaica track was one for the memory book.
New high records in sales and earnings were achieved by the Continental Can Company in the first half of 1954, General Lucius D. Clay, board chairman, reported yesterday.
CLIFTON, N. J., July 14 (AP) -- Thirty-three Clifton school teachers ignored the heat today to get on with renovating the city's fourteen elementary schools.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- All American Airlines planes on scheduled flights will be grounded at midnight tomorrow unless the National Mediation Board in Washington steps into the dispute between the company and its 1,206 pilot members of the Air Line Pilots' Association, A. F. L.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- A bill calling on the Postmaster General to investigate the extent of "hate propaganda and anti-religious" literature being sent through the mails was introduced today by Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican of Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Representative Herbert C. Bonner, Democrat of North Carolina, criticized today a Senate-passed bill to authorize $45,000,000 for repair and modernization of vessels in the defense reserve fleet.

Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, whose charges that Negro pupils were receiving an inferior education in the city's public schools touched off a Board of Education request for an investigation, said yesterday he welcomed an objective and impartial study.

NEWARK, July 14 -- Former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman, who in a posthumous letter confessed the embezzlement of $300,000, left a will designating his widow, Mrs. Lillie Moss Hoffman, sole beneficiary and executrix.
The Greater New York Fund has received $5,747,993 in cash and pledges thus far in its 1954 fund-raising campaign.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 14 (AP) -- Yugoslavia announced tonight postponement of a "Little Three" foreign ministers' meeting to sign a pro-Western Balkan military alliance.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Senators from five states today urged President Eisenhower to withdraw tariff concessions on watches and watch movements granted to Switzerland under the Reciprocal Trade Agreement of 1936.
HAMILTON, N. Y., July 14 -- Leading Republican and Democratic spokesmen tonight presented sharply different estimates of this country's international economic policy.
Joseph D. Nunan, who was found guilty on June 29 of cheating the Government of $91,086 in income taxes, applied yesterday to Federal Judge Walter Bruchhausen for a new trial.
ALBANY, July 14 (AP) -- The constitutionally of the Stokes Law, which forbids construction of a dam on Panther Mountain in the Adirondacks, was upheld today by the Court of Appeals.

Fairfax County, Va., announced yesterday plans for the sale of $10,000,000 of sewer bonds at competitive bidding on July 28. Dated July 1, 1954, the bonds will come due annually on July 1 from 1958 to 1989.

One of the nation's largest investment companies of the closed-end type, the Tri-Continental Corporation, reported yesterday that net assets showed a substantial gain in the first half of this year, exceeding $200,000,000 for the first time.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, Apostolic Delegate to the United States, announced today that Pope Pius XII had conferred the title of archbishop 'ad personam' on Bishop Thomas J. Toolen.
Mrs. Suburbia, whose fashion consciousness may be based upon infrequent "sprees in the city," has been served by Mr. Arnold in fall hat designs.

GENEVA, July. 14 -- An air of optimism pervaded the Far Eastern conference here tonight as France's Premier and Britain's Foreign Secretary returned from their Paris meeting with John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State.
The Rev. William Howard Melish admitted yesterday, after having "refreshed my memory," that he had been a vice president of the Civil Rights Congress of New York in 1947.
I have been an admirer of The New York Times for a great many years, but I certainly cannot go along with your editorial on "Agreement in Steel," published July 2.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Eisenhower was asked at his news conference today about his ideas of financing his $50,000,000,000 ten - year highway building program.

One of the most exciting millinery collections for the fall has been produced by Fred Frederics of John Frederics. Shown yesterday at 711 Fifth Avenue, his relaxed and easy silhouettes caught the spirit of the new autumn fashions.
VANCOUVER, B. C., July 14 (UP) -- Bob Rosburg, 27, of San Francisco, shot an eight-under-par 63 today to lead a field of 137 in the first round of the Canadian open golf tournament.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 14 (AP) -- E. P. Bixer's Bunny's Babe outraced the odds-on favorite, Sorceress, before 20,324 fans at Monmouth Park today and notched his first stakes victory in the $23,670 New Jersey Futurity.
Delays in inspection and license transfers will probably keep the new stock model small taxicabs off New York streets until tomorrow, according to the police.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The labor relations of thousands of small business concerns were exempted from Federal control today.

CHATSWORTH, N. J., July 14 -- This little community in the center of a wooded area of Burlington County was saved from probable destruction by fire this evening by the untiring efforts of 1,000 volunteer firemen.

The University of Illinois air charter service in eight years has flown the equivalent of fifty-three trips around the world. Yesterday the university's Institute of Aviation reported that this flying had been done without a passenger injury or death.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 14 -- Work began in earnest today on the Hadassah-Hebrew University medical center in Ein Karem. This long-awaited development followed a diplomatic visit by Hadassah leaders last night to the picturesque band of oriental settlers who are farming next to the hospital site.

DENVILLE, N. J., July 14 -- (AP) The Odenwald Bird Company, quarantined last April by the State Board of Health after some of its parakeets were found to have psittacosis or "parrot fever," has sent all of its remaining parakeets to a laboratory for use in studies of the rare disease.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 -- The handling of all dry cargo in the Philadelphia port area, extending from Wilmington, Del., to Trenton, N. J., was halted today by a dispute over three hours of pay for about 100 dock workers.

Working on a nine-game winning streak, the Yankees will begin a thirteen-game home stand tonight when they face the Baltimore Orioles in the opener of a three-game set at the Stadium. The major league pennant races will be back on a full-scale basis today following the All-Star game schedule break.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 -- Some of the problems, as well as the practices, of the homemaker in feeding her family were discussed by nutrition experts at the annual meeting of the American Home Economics Association here last week.

President Eisenhower has signed a proclamation making effective, as of July 4, an eighteen-month extension of our reciprocal free trade with the Philippines. Congress had authorized this step and a similar measure has been approved by the Philippine Legislature. The purpose of the extension is to provide a period in which further study can be made of Philippine-American trade relationships, looking to possible revision of the basic Trade Act.

MILWAUKEE, July 15 -- Shut out in the first game by Bob Buhl, a first-time winner, the Dodgers tonight blew an 8-3 lead in the ninth of the second game and lost a twilight-night double-header to the Braves, 2 -- 0 and 9 -- 8.

ST. LOUIS, July 15 -- A superbly pitched game by little Don Liddle and some effective swatting by his burley receiver, Wes Westrum, combined to send the Giants off winging tonight as they opened their third Western jaunt of the year.

Seven men were indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn Federal Grand Jury for allegedly being members of a $1,000,000 interstate automobile theft ring. They were specifically charged with the theft and transportation of eighteen automobiles between New York and New Jersey.

Contract negotiations between shipyard workers and the Bethlehem Steel Company were resumed yesterday after a lapse of almost three weeks. No progress was reported after a three-hour meeting in the company's offices at 25 Broadway, and no date for another session was set.
GENEVA, July 15 -- France, backed by the United States, is determined not to fix a date for holding elections in Vietnam, even if the Communists make this the price for agreeing to an armistice.
A state-wide postcard poll to determine the predominant sentiment among enrolled Democrats on candidates for Governor was begun yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Sears, Roebuck Co. has bought a stock interest in -- but not control of -- one of its suppliers, Crescent Industries, Inc., the latter company reported today.

The Secretary of the Army, Robert T. Stevens, has handed down the first four decisions in the cases of twenty-two Fort Monmouth, N. J., Signal Corps civilians who had been suspended on charges under the Eisenhower security risk program. Two men have been ordered reinstated, and two dismissed.

JERUSALEM, July 15 -- Maj. Gen. Vagn Bennike withheld his decisive vote today on resolutions blaming Israel and Jordan for a shooting affray in Jerusalem two weeks ago. Then he announced that he would report on the case to the United Nations Security Council.

A protest against the procedures of the Special House Committee to Investigate Tax-Exempt Foundations and an answer to charges lodged against the League for Industrial Democracy were made public yesterday by the league.

TRENTON, July 15 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today that New Jersey might seek a means of imposing tighter controls on the campaign expenditures of its political candidates as an outgrowth of the State's investigation into the activities of former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman.

Frequent meetings at the Plaza are being held during the summer months to advance the plans for the annual dinner dance for the benefit of the New York Chapter of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation. The event will take place on Oct. 13 in the main ballroom of the hotel.

It was inevitable that a deteriorating military situation in Indochina should speed up the plans for the strengthening of Thailand. The staff talks that have just been concluded in Washington were devoted, therefore, to details of a new military assistance program whose need had been recognized both in Bangkok and here.
ALBANY, July 15 -- The State Water Power and Control Commission helped clear the way today for construction of the proposed Mianus Reservoir northwest of Stamford, Conn.

Resplendent fabrics and designs of the Middle and Far East, reminiscent of styles and moods of exotic ancient headdresses, highlighted Laddie Northridge's fall hat collection shown yesterday at the Pierre Hotel.
Thomas F. Morrow has been named general manager of defense operations for Chrysler Corporations Detroit.

LONDON, July 15 -- Representatives of the United States, Canada and twelve European countries met here today to discuss when and how European currencies could again be made freely convertible and what trade problems might arise as a consequence.

THE program that may well hold the record for being the noisiest on television is "Summer in the Park," presented by the Du Mont network on Wednesdays from 9 to 10 P. M. The words "Summer in the Park" might ordinarily conjure up thoughts of fresh green grass, restful shade, cool waters and tranquillity, but things are different on Channel 5.
Mr. John has again proved himself a master of millinery. In his fall collection shown yesterday at 53 East Fifty-seventh Street, he delved into the culture of ancient Egypt as a source of inspiration

The president of Schering Corporation, former German-owned pharmaceutical company in Bloomfield, N. J., condemned a pending Senate bill yesterday which would compensate German and Japanese companies for property seized by this country during the war.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Senator John Sherman Cooper, one of President Eisenhower's early supporters, charged today that the Administration sought to usurp the powers of Congress over the Tennessee Valley Authority.

CINCINNATI, July 15 (AP) -- Terry Moore, a "gentleman" player with the tough St. Louis Cardinals of the old Gas House Gang days, today was named manager of the Philadelphia Phillies. He replaces Steve O'Neill.

CINCINNATI, July 15 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs got Terry Moore's National League managerial Career off to a dismal start tonight as they swept a twilight-night doubleheader from the Philadelphia Phils, 2 -- 1 and 4 -- 3.

WAYNESBORO, Miss., July 15 (UP) -- Alabama Attorney General Si Garrett, recently indicted for vote fraud, was critically hurt when his car plunged off a road near here last night, the Mississippi Highway Patrol reported.

Deliveries of refined copper to fabricators outside this country soared to a record high last month. And despite rising world production, combined stocks of copper in the hands of domestic and foreign producers dropped sharply to an eleven-month low.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (UP) -- The State Department was thrust into a diplomatic squeeze today by a lot of Russian children splashing in Chesapeake Bay.

HANOI, July 15 (AP) -- The rains came to the Red River delta in torrential force today. But the Vietminh rebel forces kept boring in toward Hanoi and plucked off two more of the dwindling French Union outposts.

I feel that your July 11 editorial "End of an Experiment," on the impending dissolution of the Indonesian-Netherlands Union now under discussion at The Hague, requires added comment to clarify Indonesia's point of view.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A seven-member minority of the Senate Agriculture Committee denounced mandatory rigid farm price supports tonight as injurious to farmers and consumers alike.

Archie Moore of St. Louis, 37-year-old world light heavyweight champion, signed yesterday to defend his title against Harold Johnson of Philadelphia in Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, Aug. 11.
LOS ANGELES, July 15 -- Nicolas Rossolimo, Franco-Greek international chess master, today broke the four-way tie for first place in the Pan American tournament at the Hollywood Athletic Club.
GENOA, Italy, July 15 -- At noon today the sea-loving people of this port gave a noisy, affectionate send-off to the new trans-Atlantic liner bearing the name of a famous Genoese, Cristoforo Colombo.
The big news in the cigarette industry -- charges of a link between cigarette smoking and lung cancer -- has affected the advertising fully as much as it has hit sales.
Every break in the game went to the Yankees and they clicked for their tenth straight victory with a 3-1 decision over the Baltimore Orioles last night at the Stadium.

Confronted with the possibility that the French National Assembly may reject or fail to ratify the European Defense Community before adjourning next month, the United States and Britain have agreed on a new procedure to restore German sovereignty and to prepare for German rearmament.
The moon pulled free of a deep cloud line and a heavy pall of smoke from a five-alarm fire in Brooklyn last night in time to give most New Yorkers a good look at its partial eclipse.

The final commas and periods were incorporated yesterday into a two-year contract between the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. Ratification awaits only a vote of the subway and surface line employes today.
Big, rich-fleshed swordfish are coming in from the cold waters off Nova Scotia. They usually are at their most plentiful in July and August, the Fishery Council says.
Here for a brief stopover between Boston and Billings, Mont., Thomas Donald Campbell expressed strong support yesterday for the Eisenhower Administration's farm program.

" Festival" is on its way. Accompanied by such performers as Melvyn Douglas, Vanessa Brown and Kurt Kasznar, the Sam and Belle Spewack comedy is to be brought to the stage by Walter Fried, co-producer of "Death of A Salesman" and "The Time of the Cuckoo" among others.

DETROIT, July 15 -- Coincident with dedication of the Army's new tank-automotive engineering laboratories here, the decision was announced to continue tank and armored vehicle production beyond next June. Contracts to be let for the twelve-month period total $266,000,000.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Friday, July 16 -- The Town Council of near-by Greenburgh early today blocked a proposed state-financed $2,200,000 housing project that had touched off a racial controversy.

When the Bishop of Leeds was about to ordain William J. Hayward as a priest of the Roman Catholic Church, back in 1927, he did not know just how to go about it. The young candidate for holy orders was wholly deaf.

The Rev. William Howard Melish, acting minister of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, claimed "ministerial privilege" yesterday in refusing to name persons who admitted to him membership in the Communist party.
Business loans of New York banks declined by $54,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday. Most of the decrease occurred in borrowings of food, liquor and sales finance companies.

OCEAN GROVE, N. J., July 15 -- The combined conference of the New York and New Jersey Women's Christian Temperance Unions voted today to intensify efforts against alcohol, tobacco, narcotics and legalized gambling.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A Joint Congressional Conference Committee today agreed to exempt companies earning less than $100,000 a year from President Eisenhower's plan for expediting the collection of corporation taxes.

I have followed with a great deal of interest the splendid coverage you have given the recent hearings on the defense situation affecting the American watch industry. I was particularly impressed by Charles Egan's excellent story on July 1, in which he disclosed for the first time the detailed recommendations of the Tariff Commission to the President on watch tariffs.

RIVER FOREST, Ill., July 15 (UP) -- Top-seeded Tony Trabert of Cincinnati today won a place in the semi-finals of the national clay courts tennis tournament with an easy victory over Chicago's Seymour Greenberg.

Commodity prices closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading was fairly active with coffee and the domestic sugar contract registering sizable volume. Coffee, cocoa, sugar, wool, soybean oil, lead and zinc ended stronger; rubber, silk and burlap eased, and cottonseed oil, potatoes and hides were mixed.

LONDON, July 15 -- The boom in British Government bonds continued today. Turnover again was high and prices closed at the day's best, advances of rises ranging up to as much as 13 shillings 9 pence ($1.92 1/2).
No action was taken yesterday by directors of Sidney Blumenthal Co., Inc., on a dividend on the common stock due at this time. A dividend of 25 cents a share was paid in March.

HARRY WILLIAMS, a New Orleans lumberman, sent a 16-year old baseball player to John McGraw with a letter of introduction and recommendation. The boy was Mel Ott, That's the way the New York Giants obtained most of their talent in the old days. McGraw had thousands of friends the country over.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -The Board of Immigration Appeals disclosed today that it had upheld a Brooklyn alien's contention that he could not be deported because of alleged "loan shark" operations.

OTTAWA, July 15 -- More United States capital flowed into Canada in 1953 than ever before but in its international transactions Canada suffered a severe deficit, according to the annual report on the Canadian balance of payments released today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.
GRANDVIEW, N. Y., July 15 -- Poetically speaking, there are brooks that go on forever. But that does not apply to the two that had adorned and gladdened the estate of Roland A. Wood here.

If New Yorkers have a municipal whipping boy, it is the subway. Both in talk and print the subway lends itself to the most wonderfully varied abuse. All its negative aspects -- its stuffiness, tardiness, noisiness, crowdedness -- can be dealt with at any time and in any mood. According to one's last subway ride, one can be flippant about the subway, ponderously critical, amazedly put out.

With the approval of the police, three of the new, smaller taxicabs moved out yesterday onto the streets of New York. They will begin cruising for fares today. Within a year the trade expects 1,500 of the stock model four-passenger hacks to be competing with the 10,000 familiar five-seat "jumbo," cabs.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UP) -- Six more Washington area residents refused to answer Communist questions today, and House of Representatives investigators concluded that a "hard core" of Communist party members was at work in the nation's capital.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Wheat futures took on new life today with substantial gains registered on fairly general accumulation by commission houses and local operators and by short covering. The main factor appeared to be the absence of any pressure either of local selling or of a hedge character.
A will under which the widow of Gustav Wurzweiler, stock broker, would receive $250,000 of his $2,000,000 estate was admitted to probate yesterday by Surrogate George Frankenthaler.

The axiom about locking the stable after the horse has been stolen had an application yesterday in the elections of the National Maritime Union -- somebody tried to "mess up" the votes after they already had been counted.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was back in business today as the operating chairman of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, July 15 (UP) -- The United States clinched a first-round series with the British West Indies in the American Zone eliminations of Davis Cup tennis play as Straight Clark and Hal Burrows scored a straight-set doubles victory for a 3-0 lead in the best-of-five event today.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 15 -Mrs. James M. Mertz, representing the American Yacht Club, regained the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound today in the wind-up of the seventeenth series for the Syce Cup.

BOSTON, July 15 (AP) -- Bill Tuttle's two-run double in the ninth inning, his third hit of the game, brought the Detroit Tigers a 4-2 victory over the Boston Red Sex tonight and a split in their day-night program.
DALLAS, Tex., July 15 -- The Round-up Theatre, Negro amateur group, gave the first performance tonight of a full-length script written in 1950 by William Saroyan called "A Lost Child's Fireflies."
Last night's audience -- a large one -- at Lewisohn Stadium heard the Stadium Symphony Orchestra conducted by Pierre Monteux and Yehudi Menuhin as violin soloist.

It is disturbing to read in The New York Times that the two Texas multimillionaires Messrs. Murchison and Richardson are planning to acquire half a dozen of the nation's big horse-racing tracks and operate them for the benefit of underprivileged boys and that they have approached J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to become head of the corporation which it is proposed to organize to carry out this plan.
TOKYO, July 15 -- Efforts to weaken extreme Leftist control over Japan's biggest labor federation failed today.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A Senate-House conference agreed today to hold building profits to 10 per cent on multi-family projects built with Government-insured mortgages.
