WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The State Department has recommended the admission of a group of Christians from Soviet Union satellites to the United States to attend a meeting of the World Council of Churches in Evanston, Ill., next month.
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 15 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali said today that the opening of the Bhakra-Nangal canal in India last Thursday was a "potential threat to peace in the subcontinent."

NEXT Monday 1,500 men and women will come from the nation's farthest corners and from Canada to convene in New York, the City of Utter Silence. They will wander through its traffic-snarled avenues and cluttered side-streets, cruise in its harbor amid hoarsely bellowing liners and wailing tugs, ride its thunderous subways -- but hear no sound.

NUREMBERG, Germany, July 15 (AP) -- Seven United States soldiers returned to freedom today after twelve days' imprisonment in Communist Czechoslovakia. They were seized by a Czechoslovak border patrol July 4.
Joseph T. Sharkey, Brooklyn's new Democratic leader, solved several major political problems yesterday at a meeting of the Kings County Democratic Executive Committee.

BONN, Germany, July 15 -- Three hundred thousand metal workers in the State of Wuerttemberg-Baden have received a 6 per cent wage increase in the first important labor - management showdown in West Germany in more than two years.

The president of the Old International Longshoremen's Association said yesterday that its leaders were working on a plan aimed at eliminating wildcat strikes, which have long bedeviled New York's waterfront.

The State Attorney General, Nathaniel L. Goldstein, noted yesterday that the storm-window companies he has had under investigation had sought to work a "racket" with the Federal Housing Administration.

AGAINST the modern souped-up vehicles of detective fiction -- a concatenation of clues sparked by a succession of blondes -- a writer of Wilkie Collins' speed soon would be forced to the side of the road. Collins is sometimes considered to be the first English author of the mystery story because of "The Moonstone" and "The Woman in White," novels he wrote a little less than a hundred years ago.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Department store sales last week were 16 per cent below those of the corresponding period last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
LONDON, July 15 -- Andrzej Panufnik, a leading Polish composer and conductor, has fled to Britain to seek asylum.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- During the week ended July 14, member bank reserves decreased $354,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
A national income of $600,000,000,000 a year with jobs available for 100,000,000 persons within the next twenty-five years was described as probable here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- William J. Levitt, one of the builders of Levittown, L. I., told Senate housing investigators today that a profit of more than $5,000,000 had been made on the sale of 4,028 homes in the development.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 15 -- Carol Haney, who earned praise and fame for her role in "The Pajama Game" on Broadway, has received a co-starring role from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.
SARANAC INN, N., Y., July 15 (AP) -- Two former champions and a mother of five moved into a three-way tie for the lead today in the second round of the women's New York State amateur golf tournament.
A union official was charged last night with trying to extort $4,000 from the head of a Manhattan garment concern.
CLEVELAND, July 15 (AP) -- Denny Shute, Akron (Ohio) pro, made one of his rare tournament appearances today and gave the youngsters a golf lesson in the first round of the $25,000 Manakiki open.
The Pennsylvania General State Authority borrowed $30,000,000 in the public market yesterday on serial revenue bonds maturing over twenty-seven years at an interest cost of 2.249 per cent.

GENEVA, July 15 -- A sudden spurt of economic cooperation among Britain, the United States and Canada has greatly accelerated the changes taking place in the framework within which economic life in Western Europe goes on.

LONDON, July 15 -- Sir Winston Churchill told the House of Commons today he would welcome any more detailed information about atomic defense that the United States Congress might make available by its pending revision of the McMahon Act.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (UP) -- Industrial production showed a slight seasonal increase last month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -The Government is planning a device that could sound an advance warning within each home in a target area in the event of an atomic or hydrogen bomb attack.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 15 -- The right of the United States to conduct nuclear tests in its Pacific trust territories was tacitly upheld today by a 9-3 vote in the United Nations Trusteeship Council.

The Container Corporation of America increased its half-year earnings by 65 per cent, despite a 2.2 per cent decline in sales from the initial six months of 1953, the semi-annual statement disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Former Judge William Clark was today denied an immediate court order allowing him to visit Germany, where he was ousted last year as Chief Justice of the United States Court. Mr. Clark for many years served on the United States Court of Appeals in New Jersey. Mr. Clark contends the State Department refused him a passport unless he abandon the idea of speaking out in Germany about his dismissal.

Inclusion of a series of band concerts on the Battery in the program of entertainment for New York's current Summer Festival, which seeks to recapture some of the color of the days when our big city was Little Old New York, seems a happy idea.

Running like a ghost through the bays, the browns and the chestnuts, C. V. Whitney's Ming Yellow, a 4-year-old gray filly, next-to-the-longest bet in the race at 19 -- 1, won the mile and a sixteenth Chickasaw Handicap at the Jamaica track yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on last Saturday was 569,562 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
New Yorkers settled down yesterday to enjoy what the Weather Bureau said would be three days of pleasant weather, after a violent thunder squall had broken the back of the year's worst heat wave.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Senator Price Daniel, Democrat of Texas, said at the White House today that President Eisenhower had assured him he still held to the position that Texas owned submerged lands extending three leagues, rather than three miles, into the Gulf of Mexico. Three leagues is about 10.5 miles.
Buyers of securities on the installment plan have put up almost $4,000,000 so far under the monthly investment plans of the New York Stock Exchange and its member firms.
This is the time for enjoying ripe, juicy cherries out of the hand or in desserts and salads. It also is the time to freeze or can them before their short season ends.
A five-alarm fire that touched off three chemical explosions destroyed a five-story, block-long combination brick warehouse and factory yesterday in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

Merger of the Irving Savings Bank and the American Savings Bank into the American Irving Savings Bank, effective Aug. 2, was announced yesterday by Robert A. Barnet and Henry R. Sutphen Jr., presidents of Irving and American, respectively.
PARIS, July 15 (UP) -- France gave up the tiny settlement of Mahe [cross on map] on the West coast of India today.
MEXICO CITY, July 15 -- Government officials defended today the Mexican Ambassador's grant of asylum to more than 300 Guatemalans.

Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, charged last night that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had abused his access to Federal income tax returns to collect information with which it would be possible to blackmail political enemies.

Chairman McCarthy has finally held a meeting of his Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations four weeks after the Army hearings stumbled to their dismal close. During this interval in which Mr. McCarthy has stayed out of the limelight it is reasonable to believe that he has been stalling in order to avoid the badly needed "housecleaning" of his own committee that its three Democratic members and Senator Potter have insisted upon.

Three new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Malta Story," a British-made drama of World War II, with Alec Guinness, Jack Hawkins, Anthony Steel, Muriel Pavlow and Flora Robson heading the cast, opens at the Guild Theatre.

There isn't an enlisted man alive who hasn't objected to some of the enforced differences between commissioned and non-commissioned personnel. The astute E. M. doesn't take these matters too seriously, since he understands that considerably more responsibility goes along with the officer's privileges and pay and that this responsibility must be rewarded if able men are to be induced to assume it.

" Struggle for Tomorrow: Modern Political Ideologies of the Jewish People," will be published by Arts, Inc., on Aug. 15. Edited by Basil Vlavianos and Feliks Gross, faculty members of New York University, it is a symposium of the political beliefs and parties commanding the allegiance of the Jewish people in the last sixty years.

President Eisenhower said one thing especially at his Wednesday press conference that ought not to be overlooked. Answering a question, he said that he did not intend to let his atomic pool plan die "if he could possibly help it." This may not mean that he has much confidence in Russia's willingness to accept his plan for an international atomic energy agency.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives approved and sent to the House today a bill to strip citizenship rights from persons convicted of conspiring to advocate the overthrow the Government by force or violence.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and closing prices were 2 points higher to 6 points lower than on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board and the State Department jointly announced today recommendations for a Spanish air route to New York City.

An indictment charging a Brooklyn patrolman with second-degree assault was handed up yesterday by a Kings County grand jury. The charges stem from the beating last June 30 of a gasoline station owner.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, today urged changes in Senate investigations to eliminate what he described as the "hit-and-run" technique.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 15 -- Katie Key, owned by Pat Tuccio of Riverhead, L. I., and driven by Clint Hodgins, scored a one and one-half length victory over Lord Steward in the eighth annual $35,000 Roosevelt mile and one-half trot before a crowd of 23,946 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
PARIS, July 15 -- In the face of continuing violence, Pierre Voizard, French Resident General in Tunisia, issued a proclamation today declaring that he was determined to enforce order at all costs.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 (AP) -- Five men who went to sea on a raft in an attempt to drift 2,400 miles to Hawaii were plucked from the Pacific Ocean today -- six days later, but only sixty-two miles out.

Supreme Court Justice Benjamin Rabin issued an injunction yesterday restraining Martin Fass, sports broadcaster, from "pirating" authorized broadcasts of baseball games played by the New York Giants. It also restrained him from providing information to Western radio stations for almost immediate re-broadcast of the game in progress.

BERLIN, July 15 (AP) -- Dr. James B. Conant, United States High Commissioner, said today the Soviet Union would not consent to reunification of Germany unless the West European nations "prove their readiness for ever closer economic, political and military cooperation."
HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., July 15 -- Bert Kohlman of Inwood, the only lefthander in the tourney, led the qualifiers in the Long Island amateur golf championship today at the Seawane Harbor Club.

SEATTLE. July 15 (AP) -America's first jet transporttanker, its four 10,000-pound jet engines screaming its power, leaped into the air today in an initial test flight that represented a $15,000,000 business gamble for the Boeing Company.

THOSE interested in competing for the honor of taking the first giant tuna of the season in nearby waters might reach their goal by chumming in the waters off Newport or Narragansett, R. I., where bluefins up to 600 pounds have been taken in the fish traps.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Secretary of State Dulles returned from Paris today hopeful that the danger of a deep fissure between the Western allies had been averted. He hoped also that France's Premier, Pierre Mendes-France, would not accept a "peace at any price" in the Indochinese war.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., will acquire the United Railroad Workers, C. I. O., under a merger plan announced today. The merger is subject to a referendum vote of the railroad workers.
J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., the big textile producer, has offered to purchase for cash the common and preferred stock of John P. Maguire Co., Inc., factoring concern, it was disclosed yesterday.
These dog days shouldn't happen to a dog. Especially a fat dog, and there are a lot of those.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Eighty members of the armed forces have been discharged as security risks in the last four months and 392 cases are pending, the Senate Armed Services Committee was informed today.
I have read with great interest your editorial of July 11 "End of an Experiment."
A 3,000,000-share day returned to the New York Stock Exchange yesterday for the first time since April, 1953. What it proved, however, was difficult for the technicians to determine.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Hog prices dropped today, butchers selling 28 cents to $1 down and sows 25 to 50 cents or more. The top of $24.35 was the lowest since June 18. However, two small lots went at $24.50 to $24.75.
CAIRO, July 15 -- The British and Egyptian negotiators seeking agreement on terms for the British withdrawal from the Suez Canal Zone solved some questions today and referred others to London.
Among the thirty-five policemen promoted yesterday at exercises at Police Headquarters was Capt. Conrad S. Jensen, 43 years old, who has been a lay minister for twelve years.

LONDON, July 15 -- When Sir Winston Churchill arose in the House of Commons today to announce the dissolution of the Ministry of Materials. Labor members complained that the story had "leaked" to the afternoon papers.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (Up) -- Tom Umphlett drove in all three runs for Washington with a sin and a triple tonight as the Senators gained a 3-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox.
CHICAGO, July 15 -- A threatened strike of the Air Line Pilots Association, A. F. L., against American Airlines was postponed tonight.
HAITHUON, Vietnam, July 14 -- The agony for the French Union defenders of Dienbienphu did not end with the fall of that fortress to the Communist-led rebels May 7.

The nation-wide Bell System continued to set new records in the communications field in the year ended May 31, according to its financial statements issued yesterday. On a consolidated basis, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its principal subsidiaries, which constitute the system, reported a net income of $492,897,154 in the twelve-month period.

A program to "break up ghetto living" in New York by encouraging interracial tenancy in three large-scale housing projects has been started by a Bronx community center with the support of the Wagner Administration.

The Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday the election of G. W. Trichel as executive vice president and general manager of its Amplex division, and Thomas F. Morrow as general manager of defense operations for the corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Eisenhower may call the Senate into special session in the fall to aid in granting sovereignty to West Germany at the earliest possible date. Senators to whom this prospect has been pointed out are reluctant to act but will be prepared to do so if called upon, even though this is a Congressional election year and much campaigning would be interrupted by a return to Washington.

BONN, Germany, July 15 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has prevailed upon Karl Arnold, Christian Democratic Premier of the state of North Rhine-Westphalia, to exclude the Opposition Social Democratic party from the new state government.
CHURCHILL, Man., June 16 -- This town of 1,000 persons is a center of British, United States and Canadian research into all aspects of Arctic warfare.

BUENOS AIRES, July 15 -- The French Embassy found it impossible to celebrate Bastille Day yesterday in the way it had planned. Argentine student politics frustrated the embassy's attempt to put on a special performance in the famed Teatro Colon of Paul Claudel's dramatic poem "The Book of Christopher Columbus," with music by Darius Milhaud, for the benefit of students of all political colors.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, July 15 -- The Soviet Union and Hungary have refused to accept the jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice in suits for damages resulting when a Soviet fighter forced a United States Air Force C-47 to land in Hungary Nov. 19, 1951.
PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (UP) -- Early Wynn blanked the Philadelphia Athletics with three hits tonight as the league-leading Cleveland Indians snapped a four-game losing streak with a 4-0 victory.

ROME, July 15 -- On the fashion surface all is quiet in Rome. Beneath there is seething activity. The collections will open Monday morning with a bang. Already buyers and newspaper folk are arriving, prepared to give the Roman couture the onceover.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 15 -- Authority granted by New York State for the Mianus River Reservoir to sprawl a mile up a scenic gorge of Westchester County was tagged today as a "complete victory" for drought-threatened Greenwich, Conn., and Rye and Port Chester, N. Y.

A syndicate of London banking houses headed by Baring Brothers Co., Ltd., is preparing for the public offering of a new issue of twenty-year sterling bonds of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

Your correspondent E. F. W. Wildermuth criticizes the bench and bar for "concluding that our courts are primarily for the purpose of 'settling cases'" and maintains, instead, that "the function of our courts is to hear evidence." He deprecates the fact "that courts * * * lend themselves to aiding the parties to consummate settlements * * *."

PARIS, July 15 -- While in Paris this week Secretary of State Dulles surprised Europeans by displaying a degree of suppleness and realism that they had failed to perceive in his speeches and had therefore not attributed to him.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 15 -- There is a growing apprehension in some circles here that the Government's policy of propping up the price of coffee may backfire and Brazil may be left with a surplus on her hands.

CHICAGO, July 15 (UP) -- The Chicago Cubs took their first double-header in thirteen attempts today, beating the Pittsburgh Pirates, 9 to 2 and 3 to 0, as Hank Sauer and Ernie Banks each hit two home runs.
A rich assortment of jewels, ornaments and trinkets formerly belonging to the Egyptian royal family and confiscated from ex-King Farouk, will go on sale here on Monday.

PARIS, July 16 -- Pierre J. Gerety, head of the executive board assigned to determine the loyalty of United States citizens working for international organizations, announced today that Americans employed in Geneva "who desire hearings" had been invited to come to Paris, where the board has been sitting.
City transit employes voted four to one yesterday to approve a two-year contract between the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., providing for a retroactive wage rise.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- President Eisenhower signed a bill today that increases substantially the size of re-enlistment bonuses available to members of the armed forces.
A new program to cover cargoes with war-risk insurance has been announced by Louis S. Rothschild, Maritime Administrator.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- President Eisenhower lent his photographic support today to eleven more Republican members of the House of Representatives facing election contests.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Some advocates of flexible farm price supports "really seek to embrace ruthless price competition among farmers" to bring about smaller farm output and less Federal control, a majority of the Senate Agriculture Committee stated today.
The collection of traffic fines in the first six months of this year is almost $1,000,000 above the figure for the same period last year, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh said yesterday.

It appeared that the Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles would have to go into extra innings yesterday at the Stadium until Irv Noren concluded a perfect afternoon with a screaming homer. The wallop, with two out in the ninth, none aboard and the score tied, gave the Yankees a 3-2 victory, their eleventh in a row.

HANOI, Vietnam, July 16 -- Ten thousand French and Vietnamese troops, with planes, tanks and artillery, went into action early yesterday northeast and west of Hanoi. The drive is aimed to clear away infiltrating Vietminh units.

COLUMBIA, Mo., July 16 (AP) -- The University of Missouri has ended its policy of racial segregation in line with the recent United States Supreme Court decision outlawing segregation in public schools.

For blind or seriously handicapped and aged women who cannot pay for vacations the coming of hot weather multiplies their year-round cares. Shelter Island Camp for many years has provided a summer haven for the sightless and lame of all races and creeds, through the generosity of people who understand their problem. The camp is a service of the Brooklyn Bureau of Social Service and Children's Aid Society.

Emotional disturbance often takes boys to the Berkshire Industrial Farm at Canaan, N. Y. But there hard work, sound education and sympathetic understanding return these same boys to society as good citizens. As one small boy resident has written in describing the farm, it has no "walls, gates, bars or guards."

Harold Riegelman, counsel for the Citizens Budget Commission, was challenged yesterday by City Administrator Luther Gulick to submit "by line and verse" specific recommendations for economies in the city's 1954-55 budget of $1,639,438,325.
The calamity 42-year-old Andy Klein dreaded and managed to avoid for eight years overtook him yesterday.
CINCINNATI, July 16 (AP) -- Gus Bell hit two home runs tonight to lead the Redlegs to a 9-4 triumph over the Philadelphia Phillies after Cincinnati took the twilight game, 7 -- 6, in ten innings.

The thirty-one-family garden-type apartment house at 130 Theodore Frend Avenue in Rye, N. Y., completed last year by the Fedrose Building Corporation, has been sold by the builders to an investing client of Robert Gallant, lawyer. The selling group, headed by Irving Feder, took back a long-term lease on the property.
CHICAGO, July 16 -- United Air Lines is about to sell its fleet of six Boeing 377 Stratocruisers to British Overseas Airways Corporation, it was reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The twelve New England Senators today asked asked an investigation of the "discriminatory effect" of national transportation policies on their six-state region.
LONDON, July 16 -- Germany's future is developing into an issue that can damage United States-British relations as seriously as the present difference in attitude toward Communist China is doing.
Recent news stories in The Times suggest an increasingly wide belief that the entire population of the United States opposes the admission of China to the United Nations Organization.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Treasury announced today that it would borrow another $3,500,000,000 iin cash to meet Federal operating expenses. This will bring the national debt to just $1,000,000,000 below the debt limit of $275,000,000,000
A collection of antique motor vehicles went on display yesterday as the Carnival of Cars Auto Museum opened at 1539 Broadway near West Forty-fifth Street.
GENEVA, July 16 -- The Vietnamese Government's delegation is reserving judgment on whether it can accept the peace settlement being negotiated here, a spokesman said today.

PORTLAND, Me., July 16 (AP) -- James C. Oliver, a Democratic candidate for Congress, today proposed that Maine banks and citizens try to keep Goodall-Sanford, Inc., from passing into control of the Burlington Mills Corporation.

LONDON, July 16 -- The United States indicated today it might agree to the use of the $271,000,000 in the reserves of the European Payments Union to help tide over Western European nations when they decide to make their currencies freely convertible.
LOS ANGELES, July 16 -- Larry Evans lost today in the sixth round of the Pan-American chess tournament at the Hollywood Athletic Club to Nicolas Rossolimo, the leader.

Dr. Samuel Johnson -- not Boswell's -- was no less impressive yesterday as, attired in peruke, black coat and breeches, white stockings and buckled shoes, he started eight young gentlemen on a career of learning at King's College. One of them was late to class.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- An apartment house builder questioned about his "windfall" profits blasted back at Senate investigators today with a statement that it was "unfair" to criticize those who had responded to urgent appeals for housing.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 16 -- A diminutive, dark-eyed young woman, born in a royal household, is working at the United Nations.
CAIRO, July 16 -- Israel was condemned today for a "warlike act" by "Israeli regular armed forces" who killed five soldiers in an invasion of Egyptian-controlled territory last Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Senator William F. Knowland, Senate Republican leader, lost two attempts today to force an early Senate vote on revisions of the Atomic Energy Law. The revisions would lay the foundation for President Eisenhower's international atomic pool plan.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon's uncovered head is giving the domestic hat industry gray hairs.

CLEVELAND, July 16 (AP) -- Fred Haas, 38, of New Orleans added 69 to his opening 67 for a 136 total today to take the lead in the $25,000 Manakiki open golf tournament at the halfway point in the seventy-two-hole medal-play event.
Federal mediators moved yesterday to head off a "possible" strike of East Coast shipyard workers when the present one-month contract extension ends Friday midnight.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 16 (AP) -- Red Sails, 6-year-old chestnut horse owned by H. T. King of Lynn, Ind., and driven by Gene Sears, won the Seaford Pace by a head in 2:01 3/5 tonight on the Grand Circuit card at Roosevelt Raceway. Adio Abe was second, with Irish Hal third. Red Sails paid $14.80 for $2.

In a dispatch to this newspaper Henry R. Lieberman has described the Bastille Day exchange of prisoners in Vietnam. The French Union troops, survivors of a "Death March" from Dienbienphu, were, he says "a ghastly contingent of emaciated, sallow-faced men, living sacks of bones with festering sores, swollen feet and haunting, glazed eyeballs."
TOKYO, July 16 (AP) -- Japan announced today it would push the merger of its strongest trading concerns into giant corporations to meet international competition.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Blocked by the Republican leadership on his projected investigation of defense plants in Boston tomorrow, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy immediately transferred the inquiry to Washington. He will begin it at 9 A. M. Monday.
A bill that would require shipment of half of all Government cargoes on American-flag ships passed an important stage in Congress yesterday.

The six-story twenty-family apartment building with six stores at 57-67 Kenmare Street has been sold by Cleveland Associates and others to the Gaetano Realty Corporation. Phillip Yaccao was the broker and the City Title Insurance Company insured title. The property occupies a plot 48 by 102 feet.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 16 -- Anne Bancroft, a native daughter of the Bronx, will have the feminine lead in "New York Confidential."
I have read with considerable interest your editorial of July 14 entitled "Where Leadership Counts." In this editorial you have vigorously supported President Eisenhower's farm program.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Representative Joel T. Broyhill has reported to the Department of Justice that a bribe was offered to a member of the Post Office Committee of the House of Representatives while a postal pay rise bill was under consideration.

Amateur fishermen who pursue their favorite sport with success this week-end may be interested in some tips on the home freezing of fish. The Home Economics Department of Deepfreeze Home Appliances recently issued such information for the benefit of those who wish to keep for later use at least part of their catch.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 16 -- Charitable bequests exceeding $135,000 were left by Miss Georgine Iselin of New Rochelle, member of an old New York banking family, who died June 30. Her will was filed here today. Cash bequests to fifty-eight relatives and friends exceeded $350,000, with eight servants getting $1,000 to $15,000 each.

PURCHASE, N. Y., July 16 -- Gus Salerno of Hampshire, the Westchester Professional Golfers Association champion, and Mrs. Edward Wolinsky, women's club titleholder, topped seventy-five rival teams in the Westchester P. G. A.'s second pro-lady tournament of the season today at Old Oaks.

" The World's Great Bridges," a history by H. Shirley Smith, a british bridge builder, will be published by Harper July 28. Yhe story in words and pictures traces the development of bridges form the days of the Romans, Perisan and Chinese to today's gigantic suspension spans.

ROME, July 16-----The European Defense Community treaty advanced today to the second stage in its progress toward ratification by the Chamber of Deputies when it was approved by the Defense Committee.
LONDON, Saturday, July 17 (Reuters) -- Vladimir S. Semyenov, Soviet Ambassador in East Germany, has been relieved of his post, Tass, the Soviet official news agency, reported early today.
Your editorial "After Active Duty" in the July 5 edition was read with great interest.
RIVER FOREST, Ill., July 16 (UP) -- Bernard Bartzen, wiry Texas southpaw, today eliminated the defending champion, Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, from the national clay court tennis tournament.
GENEVA, July 16 -- With four days left to meet his deadline for an Indochinese truce, Pierre Mendes -France, Premier of France, failed to make progress today.
The Army has backtracked on one of the undesirable discharges it has handed to alleged security risks, and has agreed to replace the discharge with one under honorable conditions.
VANCOUVER, B. C., July 16 (UP) -- Gordon Brydson, a Toronto professional, gained a two-stroke lead in the Canadian open golf tournament today with a fifty-four-hole total of 207.

For mid-July, the public market for new capital is experiencing a period of uncommon activity. Although the requisitions of local governments on the bond market are visibly tapering off, there is no measurable let-up in the flow of new corporate bond issues.

LONDON, July 16 -- British Government securities were the only really firm group in the stock markets today. Increased profit-taking among industrials found prices sensitive after their sustained rise, though losses were small, as a rule.

The usual week-end lull set in on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday. Trading in most items was dull and featureless, with dealers evening their holdings. Cocoa, coffee, wool and silk eased; suger, cottonseed oil, potatoes, hides, rubber, burlap and tin rose, and zinc and soybean oil ended mixed.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 16 -- The Brazilian Senate refused tonight to ratify a cultural agreement with Spain that included a clause requiring history textbooks used in Brazil's schools to have the approval of the Spanish Government. The vote was 18 to 14, despite the backing of the Brazilian Government for the measure.

BUENOS AIRES, July 16 -- President Juan D. Peron denied today that there was anything the matter with his health and predicted he would outlive rumormongers who had spread reports he was seriously ill. At the same time the President announced that his plans for the reorganization of the government would become effective at the end of this month.

LOS ALAMOS, N. M., July 16 (UP) -- A group of scientists at the scientific laboratories here where the atom and hydrogen bombs were developed today called for a "reconsideration of the personnel security program" of the nation.
SAN JUAN, P. R., July 16 (AP) -- A strike by this island's 6,000 dock workers went into its fourth week today as a commercial airlift poured in critically needed meat and fresh produce.
BOSTON, July 16 (UP) -- Lanky Frank Sullivan of the Boston Red Sox pitched one of the finest games of his major league career today -- a three-hit, 3-0 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

Workers in the wholesale liquor industry will take a wholesale two-week vacation, beginning on Monday, and the retailers with whom they deal don't like the idea. The retailers would prefer, they say, that the wholesalers take a retail vacation, a little at a time, instead of all at once.
ORADELL, N. J., July 16 -- Fred Grieve Jr. teamed with Dr. Milton Weller of Glen Head to tie for low gross honors in a Metropolitan Golf Association four-ball, best-ball tournament today.

It would be nice, the lady of the house had said, if there were a bird bath in the garden. The man of the house, stooping over some undernourished petunias, heard this suggestion but said nothing for the excellent reason that he could think of nothing to say.

An attorney for the old International Longshoremen's Association charged last night that the National Labor Relations Board was attempting "to steal" the May 26 longshoremen's election here from the union.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Testimony at the Senate Banking Committee's investigation of huge profits made by some builders of Government - backed apartment projects indicates it did not take a financial genius to make a "windfall" profit. It was easy for those who had a certain amount of know-how.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (UP) -- Saudi Arabia has told the United States she does not want any new technical aid funds because those offered are too small, informed sources reported tonight.

LONDON, July 16 (UP) -- The Government solemnly acknowledged today that it had financed the replacement of three jazz records allegedly broken by the noise of a Royal Air Force plane as it exceeded the speed of sound.

DETROIT, July 16 (AP) -- The nation's auto plants will build 125,210 vehicles this week, about 24 per cent fewer than were produced in the same week of last year, Ward's automotive reports said today.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A device patented this week foils the miscreant who has been emptying vending machines by dangling a quarter on a thread.
Alexander H. Cohen has set Oct. 27 as the opening date in New York for "The Champagne Complex." This is the comedy by Leslie Stevens that Mr. Cohen will present in association with Gayle Stine.

ST. LOUIS, July 16 -- The Giants spent almost three hours tonight striving to avert defeat. They even rushed three runs over the plate in the eighth to deadlock their struggle with the Cardinals at 4-all.
LONDON, July 16 (UP) -- The House of Commons had a tussle with the word filibuster today, and the Speaker ruled that if it meant what he thought it meant it could be used in the House.

Possibly the recent Guatemalan imbroglio has brought us to a point in time when it is advisable that the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs or an official responsible for such matters be represented in the President's Cabinet or at least be empowered to sit in at Cabinet meetings so that he might be available for consultation by other Cabinet members when legislative policies and programs affecting other countries in this hemisphere are of public concern.

The troublesome question of bomb tests in the Marshall Islands trust territory has been wisely handled by the United States and in the United Nations. A school superintendent from the Marshalls was flown here to present a petition that he had helped to draft urging that greater precautions be taken to prevent danger and hardship.

HEWLETT, L. I., July 16 -- Jack Lyons, the Garden City Golf Club star, turned back the defending champion, W. G. Holloway of Meadow Brook, in the second round of the Long Island amateur championship today.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UP) -- The Navy rejected a plea for more repair and conversion work at the Boston naval shipyards today, but promised to give "careful consideration" to the possibility of assigning some new construction work there.

The Hospitals Department has completed its first full year in which it had a surplus of space for tuberculosis patients instead of a shortage. The city turned the corner in this phase of the campaign against the disease on July 14, 1953.
CHICAGO, July 16 -- This year's richest race for 3-year-olds will be run at Arlington Park tomorrow. The event will be the $100,000 added Arlington Classic.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee voted unanimously today to report the $3,100,000,000 foreign aid bill to the Senate without change.
Two six-story buildings containing forty-four apartments and five stores at 184-86 Lincoln Avenue in the Bronx have been purchased by Dr. Maurice R. Goodman for cash over mortgages totaling $85,000.
A detail of specially trained policemen equipped with mobile Drunkometers to test the breath of suspected drivers went into action yesterday on a city-wide basis.

CHESTERTOWN, Md., July 16 -- Explosions blasted through the Kent Manufacturing Company, a fireworks and munitions plant on the west edge of Chestertown, for ninety minutes today, leaving ten workers dead. One more could not be accounted for hours later.
Playtime is pay time for resort operators, as vacation spending continues heavy.

TORONTO, July 16 (UP) -- Luis Ayala and Andres Hammersley kept Chile's hopes alive in the North American Davis Cup tennis tie today with an upset doubles victory over Lorne Main and Paul Willey of Canada. The score was 13 -- 11, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 16 -- The clouds that have appeared on the horizon of Yugoslav expectations for an early conclusion of the military Alliance with Greece and Turkey, and an agreement with Italy, over the future of Trieste were discussed with some seriousness by the spokesman of the Yugoslav Foreign Ministry today.

Apartment house owners certainly have a civic duty to perform in cooperating with the Department of Air Pollution Control in its drive to curb the illegal use of incinerators. As Commissioner Greenburg says, most apartment house fuel-burning equipment is idle for the summer, except perhaps for heating water.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.2 per cent to 110.2 in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Higher average prices for farm products were largely responsible for the increase.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 16 -- The Swedish capital resounded to the booming salute of Russian guns today when a Soviet naval squadron, led by the 12,000-ton Admiral Ushakov, a modern heavy cruiser of the Sverdlov class, anchored off the Royal palace here on a six-day courtesy visit. It was the first time Sweden had received the Soviet Navy, and forty years since Czarist warships last called here.
NEW DELHI, India, July 16 -- An official Indian delegation has returned from China impressed with the Communist regime's methods of flood control.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today froze, as of June 7, the wellhead price of natural gas sold by independent producers for interstate distribution.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 -- Corduroy has graduated from the realm of children's practical clothes to the "high-style" fashion and home furnishings class.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Tax deductions for the child-care expenses of more than 2,000,000 parents who work were approved today by a conference committee of the Senate and House of Representatives.
Rum supplies here are dwindling as the result of a dock strike in Puerto Rico, which supplies nine-tenths of the mainland's imports of bottled rums.

The House of Representatives has again gone on record in opposition to the admission of Red China to the United Nations. Its vote was again unanimous, a roll-call of 381 -- 0. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, meanwhile, has put a rider on the foreign aid bill expressing the same sentiment once more on behalf of the Senate.
ALBANY, July 16 (AP) -- Dr. Harold Lenz has lost his court fight against removal as dean of students at Queens College, the State Education Department said today.
MOSCOW, Saturday, July 17 (AP) -- The Soviet Union has established scientific stations on two floating ice islands near the North Pole [stars on map], Tass news agency said today.
The proposed Second Avenue subway and innumerable other contemplated and necessary city improvements must be held off because of the limited city debt and other financial stringencies.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The State Department declared today that the refusal of the Soviet Union and Hungary to answer United States charges before the International Court of Justice did not absolve the two of the "wrongs they have committed."
ST. LOUIS, July 16 (AP) -- Twenty- six railroads filed suit yesterday to enjoin C. R. Trans., Inc. of Des Moines, Iowa, from purchasing the bankrupt Keeshin Freight Lines of Chicago.

STRATFORD, Ont., July 16 -- To follow a dark, rich production of "Measure for Measure" and a "Taming of the Shrew," which is filled with Keystone Kops, the Shakespearean Festival moves back to Sophocles' "Oedipus Rex" and finds its most impressive offering of its second season.
The following books of a religious and an inspirational nature have been issued recently:

Representatives of the United States, Canada and twelve European countries yesterday concluded meetings in London that dealt with currency problems that have now become a more or less continuing feature of post-war economic planning. The leading figure of the gathering was R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the British Exchequer and Chairman of the Council of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

ROME, July 15 -- On the top floor of Casa Fontana, 38 Via Liguria, Mamma Fontana reigns supreme. The 75-year-old Amabile (Christian name meaning amiable) wears a long coral necklace. From it is suspended a fan that is in perpetual motion.
MILAN, July 16 -- The Communist domination of the General Confederation of Italian Labor is so powerfully entrenched it would take long, hard and skillful work to break its grip.

Business volume of the nation's chain store and mail order companies continued in June to lag behind 1953, but there were signs of increasing strength, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 16 -- For the first time, a major Western delegation has declared bluntly that the United Nations' majority plan for atomic control is unworkable and dead.

It is interesting that no one as yet has been able to answer Martin Abel's disconcerting question asking how it is possible to reconcile the insertion of the words "under God" in the new oath with the last part of the pledge, "with liberty and justice for all." The only replies given are diversions, having nothing to do with the point Mr. Abel brought up.

STORRS, Conn., July 16 -- Application of time and motion principles in business and industry to the everyday tasks of the housewife is being carried on here at the School of Home Economics, University of Connecticut.

Sales of the Diamond Alkali Company for the first half of this year reached $47,059190, the highest for any six months in its forty-four-year history, John A. Sargent, president, reported yesterday. The previous peak was $43,439,558 set in the initial half of 1953.

President Eisenhower's health reinsurance bill was killed in the House of Representatives by a formidable combination of both the friends and enemies of Government aid for voluntary health insurance. The opposition of the latter can readily be understood.

When Larry Denny, 8 years old, of 347 East Tenth Street, put on his New York Yankee uniform (child-size) yesterday morning, he thought the biggest event of his day would be seeing his favorite team play the Baltimore Orioles at the Yankee Stadium.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UP) -- Sandy Consuegra, a Washington cast-off, gained his eleventh victory of the season tonight in relief of Virgil Trucks when the Chicago White Sox rallied for three runs in the eighth to down the Senators, 4 -- 2.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- President Eisenhower honored Irving Berlin today for his song writing.

A record daily double for the New York racing season of $1,898.50, an impressive victory by a half-brother of the great Native Dancer and a stirring ride by Eddie Arcaro in winning the featured sixth race kept a crowd of 20,831 on its toes at the Jamaica track yesterday.
Pan American World Airways yesterday urged the Civil Aeronautics Board to set a policy with regard to earnings that would help reestablish confidence in airline securities.

GENEVA, July 16 -- Pierre Mendes-France found a brief calm in his whirlwind of activity today to address the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations here. Expecting a formal statement without much content, the council found itself listening to a serious lecture on world economic problems.
CHICAGO, July 16 (UP) -- Gene Baker tripled with one out in the ninth today to send Bob Talbot home from first base and enable the Chicago Cubs to score a 3-to-2 victory over Pittsburgh.
A municipal civil service worker has been dismissed because he has been unable to provide immediate proof that he is an American citizen.

ONE day on the Italian front in the summer of 1944 a white captain commanding a Negro company of the Ninety-second Division was asked what he thought of his soldiers. It was a few hours before they went into the line. He replied that they could drill beautifully because "they had jungle rhythm" but that as riflemen "they were yellow."
CRANBURY, N. J., July 16 (AP) -- New Jersey potato farmers, hit by plunging wholesale prices, have started a drive to get minimum price agreements among themselves, a spokesman revealed today.

An outdoor celebration of the Holy Eucharist under the auspices of the Urban Mission Priests Group of New York will be conducted at noon today in the amphitheatre on Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, near Grand Street, on the lower East Side.

LENOX, Mass., July 16 -- A sylvan concert-hall open to three of the four winds is a decidedly pleasant place to hear chamber music, especially as performed tonight by Charles Munch and members of the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

PARIS, July 16 -- The French infant mortality rate reached a record low in 1953, the National Institute of Statistics reported today. For every 1,000 births thirty-six children died before one year of age.

PASSAIC, N. J., July 16 -- When a parakeet speaks, people are prone to listen. Taffy, a blue parakeet of these parts, speaks constantly and sometimes clearly and thanks to this he is back home today. Taffy is the cage-hating, beer-drinking pet of Charles, Elizabeth, Nancy, Patricia, Beverly and Rip Van Winkle of 461 Broadway here.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Profit taking by longs caused recessions of as much as 2 cents in wheat prices from the early tops. But there was little evidence of hedge pressure and prices had a strong tone again later in the session.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Three men were killed and a fourth was burned seriously at 11 A. M. today when a series of explosions destroyed the Melrose Fireworks Company plant in Leyden Township, northwest of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson and Representative Thor C. Tollefson of Washington were in disagreement today -- just like the House and Senate -- on the best means of building twenty tankers needed by the Military Sea Transportation Service.

The fifty-sixth annual Race Week of the Larchmont Yacht Club will begin today and continue without interruption through next Saturday. It is the foremost sailing event of Long Island Sound, usually drawing 250 to 300 boats a day.

A last-minute rally wiped out most of the earlier losses in the stock market yesterday and final prices were only irregularly lower in slightly slower trading. Aircraft issues again were in demand and finished near their best levels. Almost all other major divisions lost ground.

THERE is considerable speculation by anglers as well as boatmen concerning the white marlin migration in Long Island waters. Although a few fish have been sighted by tuna trollers, the angling results have been disappointing in the extreme.

MEXICO CITY, July 16 -- Dr. Andres Iduarte has been dismissed as director of the National Institute of Fine Arts for permitting the coffin of a painter to be draped in the Soviet Union's flag while lying in state in the institute.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Republican National Committee demanded and received from the Foreign Operations Administration today a statement that it was not considering the appointment of Miss Frieda Miller to be a labor consultant to the Government of Iran.

When the children at Riverdale Play School were swapping tall tales about what their fathers could do, some of them were skeptical when their Indian school chum said his could lick lions and tigers. They were more credulous yesterday when they went to Central Park and personally met a young tigress that the lad, now back in India, had sent them from Kanpur.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (UP) -- The United States Court of appeals today reversed a lower court decision that Federal workers might be dismissed at any time without cause.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization today ordered the stockpiling of titanium, vital in jet aircraft production.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Senate, or perhaps the whole of Congress, will be summoned into special session in the fall if necessary to help grant sovereignty to West Germany. This was made known officially today.

John C. Wendes, in a purchase for investment, has acquired the three-story apartment house at 63 Washington Place and 35 Try on Avenue in Teaneck, N. J., from the New Jersey Realty Company. The building contains sixteen apartments of three and four rooms. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

MILWAUKEE, July 16 -- Walter (Smokey) Alston, a long-suffering manager who may have felt he had suffered enough, was tossed out of tonight's ball game, which the Braves won, 6 -- 1, for their third straight over the Brooks.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 13 -- The Public Administration Institute for Turkey and the Middle East has successfully completed its first year under United Nations auspices; but it has been prevented from becoming a truly regional center by the Arab-Israeli conflict of views.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians pounded out eighteen hits, nine of them for extra bases, to whip the Philadelphia Athletics, 9 -- 3, tonight and hold their half-game margin in the American League over the second-place New York Yankees.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Thei Long Island Rail Road Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to issue $67,585,983 in securities as part of an effort to wrest the railroad from bankruptcy by Aug. 1.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., July 16 (UP) -- Striking laborers today refused to remove pickets from two atomic construction projects despite a warning that they might face contempt of court charges.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Senate and House conferees split sharply today on public housing as they reached final agreement on the Administration's housing program.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 16 --At 2 A. 1VL today the controversial $2,200,000 public housing program for Greenburgh was declared defeated by the Town Board's vote of 3 to 2. This after-i noon proponents called the deci-i I sion an error, with a reversal m the offing.

LONDON, July 15 -- The British Government is surprised and annoyed at the reception that the Egyptian leaders have given to Britain's newest proposals for evacuating the Suez Canal area. The Egyptians' reaction is described as cool.

Air Force recruiting sergeants, who were freed from the Army's supervision two weeks ago, are offering free automobile transportation and airplane rides to boost enlistments in their branch of the military services.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The House Appropriations Committee recommended a 39 per cent cut today in nearly $2,000,000,000 of supplemental funds requested by the Administration.

A vacant plot of 36,000 square feet at the southeast corner of Montauk Highway and Flying Point Road in Water Mill, L. I., has been sold by Roger White to the All States Realty Corporation. The buyer will improve the parcel with a gasoline service station which has been leased by the Esso Standard Oil Company.
TOKYO, July 16 -- The new Japanese Air Force was expected here today to put its first squadron of jet fighters in the air next spring.

IN his review of my book "Break Down the Walls" (Book Review, May 30), Croswell Bowen charges my publisher with misrepresentation and me with "anti-intellectualism." Mr. Bowen apparently has misread my book.

MARCO POLO, the thirteenth-century Venetian traveler who served as an agent at the court of Kublai Khan for many years, has been honored by Italy with two engraved stamps issued on July 8 to commemorate the 700th anniversary of his birth.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Senator William F. Knowland, the Republican Leader, called upon the Senate today "not to make the farm program a political issue now at the expense of a sound agricultural economic policy."

ARTHUR MILLER, a host of serious-minded theatregoers should be pleased to note, is making satisfactory progress on his new play. A late dispatch from the Miller workshop up in Roxbury, Conn., states that he is two-thirds of the way along in the script and that he is hopeful August's end will see its completion.

SHOULD plans move accordingly, Philip Dunne will have Twentieth Century-Fox cameras turning in August on his scheduled adaptation of Eleanor Ruggles' biography of Edwin Booth, "The Prince of Players."

THE Sibelius Festivals are here to stay. Held each June in this far northern capital of Finland during the period of "white nights" just before midsummer, they have been gaining steadily from year to year in musical prestige and international recognition.

CONSUMER attitude is the unknown factor in the economic picture. The attention paid to it in recent weeks would indicate that many leaders in Government and business believe that expressions of confidence will definitely turn the tide toward an increase in consumer spending and start sales volume on an upward cycle once again.

BELGRADE. Yugoslavia, Sunday, July 18 (Reuters) -- Yugoslav President Tito added his regrets today to those of Greek Premier Alexander Papagos over postponement of a meeting intended to mark the signing of a Balkan alliance among Yugoslavia, Turkey and Greece.

THERE is always something fascinating about a man of genius who wastes his gifts in reckless profligacy. And this may explain the irresistible attraction of the Restoration rakes. Witty and talented, they seemed obsessed with the urge to self-destruction.

PROBABLY the most frequent motivation for the exploitation of photography as an art medium, especially by painters turned photographers, is the convincing quality of the images it records. The camera shows the thing as it is.

Experts of the United States and Canada left here yesterday for Europe, where they will exchange information with specialists from all over the world on the problems posed by the ever-increasing number of elderly persons.

A significant experiment in adult education is now ending its third year. It is the "Test Cities Project," centered in thirteen widely separated communities in the United States. It is designed to emphasize liberal education and responsible citizenship for adults.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, July 17 (AP) -- Hope for quick settlement of Puerto Rico's crippling dock strike diminished today as members of the A. F. L. Maritime Workers Union approved a resolution insisting on a 25-cent hourly wage increase immediately. The resolution also called for the twenty-three-day-old strike to continue indefinitely.

CLEVELAND, July 17 -- Business indicators for the first six months of this year are with few exceptions substantially below the 1953 levels, but second quarter gains were made in steel production, automobile sales and in the construction industry.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's stable had a three-for-three afternoon at the Jamaica track yesterday. After Runner-Up had won a $3,500 purse and Hot Stove had finished first in a $4,000 number, First Glance ran off with the largest share of the swag in the $23,300 Wilson Handicap.

RIVER FOREST, Ill., July 17 -- Tony Trabert and Maureen (Little Mo) Connolly, the nation's top-ranking tennis stars, scored victories today to complete the cast for tomorrow's finals in the national clay court championships. Trabert will face Bernard Bartzen of San Angelo, Tex., for the men's singles title, while Miss Connolly will defend the women's crown against Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Senator William F. Knowland, Senate majority leader, challenged the Communists today to accept United Nations-supervised elections in Germany, Korea and Vietnam.

GENEVA, July 17 -- One of Peiping's main preoccupations over an Indochinese settlement seems to be United States military power in Indochina. Chou En-lai, Chinese Communist Premier and Foreign Minister, apparently wants to bring about a settlement incorporating assurances that the United States will establish no bases nor engage in any other military activity in any of the three Indochinese states.

NOW is the time for all young men and women to come to the aid of their morale by way of the annual masquerade called a vacation, which gives millions of Americans a chance to shed their winter personalities and for a brief time pretend they are the personality they wish they were, and maybe were really intended to be, and maybe could become if only the vacation lasted long enough.

WITH mounting frequency in recent months the headlines have shrilled disquieting news about youngsters in trouble with the law. The statistics make rough reading. Rates of delinquency are rising; the violence of juvenile crimes is increasing; the youngsters judged delinquent come more and more often from "better homes" and "better neighborhoods."

NORWALK, Conn., July 17 -- The Norwalk Historical Society and "similar" organizations may soon be allowed to use the historic Norwalk Town House on Mill Hill as a result of a compromise ending a five-year dispute.

Alaska got into the news last week with the dedication of a $52,500,000 pulp mill at Ketchikan, a not too encouraging reference to statehood in President Eisenhower's press conference and the announcement that a citizen well known to the President and to many other Americans, Adlai E. Stevenson, was arriving for a two-week vacation visit to the territory.

Business in New York City's department stores last week approximated that of the same week a year ago. Weather during the week ranged from very hot to cool and the average temperature was close to that of 1953's week.
LIMA, Peru, July 14 -- Members of a scientific fishing expedition, sponsored by the University of Miami, have arrived in Lima from Chile and will undertake studies off the coast of Peru shortly.

A few years ago a small retailer, selling men's and women's clothing to a low-income group, faced the problem of steadily falling business. His larger competitors charged higher prices -- but offered the inducement of time payments.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 17 -- A Miami airlines man, Frank C. Moon, passed up many other scheduled regattas today between Biscayne Bay and Jersey to come north for a fifth annual race meet here on Pleasure Bay, an arm of the Shrewsbury River. It was a good decision. He was the only double winner of the day.
NEWARK, July 17 -- The Essex County Park Commission's facilities will become richer by 1,878 acres if a new development project now under consideration is adopted.

JERUSALEM, July 17 -- The bright summer days follow one another here in an endless procession. Conflicts like the gun battle which a fortnight ago took nine lives and wounded fifty-two persons are soon submerged in the flow of serenity.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 17 -- The first conference of Turkish diplomatic representatives in the Middle East was held this week in Ankara and Istanbul with President Djelal Bayar and Premier Adnan Menderes participating.
MIAMI, July 17 (AP) -- Chico Varona, Cuban welterweight, held on against a last-round comeback by Jimmy Martinez tonight to gain a unanimous ten-round decision over the Phoenix, Ariz., battler.

Last month Representative Gordon Canfield of New Jersey wrote President Eisenhower about textile unemployment in his area and suggested that the Administration get together with management and labor to see what could be done to decrease it. Secretary of Commerce Weeks has now called a conference of woolen and worsted manufacturers for July 28 to discuss industry problems.
A considerable expansion in the use of background music in offices, factories and places of public assembly is in the offing.

FIVE years ago, a strange, thirty- minute short subject detailing the life and loves of the Alaskan seal came out of the Walt Disney Studios in Burbank to fatigue and alarm the entire industry. "Mating habits of seals yet!" groaned one distributor. "And thirty minutes of it," corroborated another.

In 1917 a well-known song writer found himself in the Army as a private soldier. This gave a gifted newspaper headline writer a chance to slug his story "U. S. Takes Berlin." Subsequently Irving Berlin, the hero of this episode, rose to be a sergeant and in two wars proved himself one of the most useful soldiers and ex-soldiers the entertainment world has ever produced.

BETHEL, Conn., July 17 -- The spirit of 1759, when the men of this community first fought for and won a measure of independence, still smoulders hot and smoky in the colonial town. Though the spirit is laudable, it has brought about an unusual and sometimes embarassing situation.

ANYONE whose commitment to Christianity is based on text of the canonical Gospels must dismiss this huge book as ludicrous or blasphemous. Militant atheists, on the other hand, will scorn its essentially reverent tone.
BERLIN, July 17 -- Dr. Theodor Heuss was elected today to a second five-year term as President of West Germany by an overwhelming majority of the Federal Assembly.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) -- The Washington Senators, with Bob Porterfield pitching an eight-hitter, beat the Chicago White Sox, 3 to 1, today. The setback dropped Chicago five games behind the league-leading Cleveland Indians.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 17 -- Jaime Cardinal de Barros Camara, Archbishop of Rio de Janeiro, has issued a pastoral letter calling for a moral reform drive in the coming eucharistic year.
This is not likely to be a poliomyelitis epidemic year in the city, Dr. Morris Greenberg, director of the Health Department's bureau of preventable diseases, predicted yesterday.
Another retreat of the thin red line of Empire was forecast last week as the British resumed discussions with Egypt about the future of the Suez Canal military bases.

Although there may be some few "sleepers" who take until the closing date of July 28 to file their papers, the fact that thirteen speed boats have already entered this year's Gold Cup regatta on Aug. 7 at Seattle stamps it as one of the potentially biggest races of its long history.

WASHINGTON -- Thirty-five years ago this month, the Secretary of War initiated a transcontinental truck convoy to prove that the gas engine had displaced the mule, even on the country's relatively primitive roads.

PARIS, July 17 -- After having surveyed the sad Indochina scene, Pierre Mendes-France warned the French National Assembly on June 9, shortly before he became Premier, that North Africa "will be the next act of the drama we are living through."

A STOLID, rather humorless work, this autobiography of Fred Lewis Pattee, American teacher and literary historian, is instructive. He was born in 1863, a New Englander five generations removed from the Revolution, reared in a rural, primitive, stern and Puritanical world. In one man's long lifetime our consciousness has been radically altered, from simplicity to complexity, from Puritanism to indecision.

"FUTURE INDEFINITE" is Noel Coward's second volume of autobiography. "Present Indicative" took him from zero to the age of 31, which neatly enough happened to coincide with the year 1931. This one goes from 1939 to 1945, from a trip he took about Europe before the war to Victory Day in London.

A MANHATTAN huckster sits in Central Park playing Hamlet with himself. The huckster's name is Johnny Drake, His problem: whether to take the new job at the agency, which means giving the axe to "a good guy," or to reject it out of some vague impulse of virtue and honor.

THIS has been a trivial period in which the most ambitious offering has been "After the Ball," a musical fabricated by Noel Coward out of Oscar Wilde's "Lady Windermere's Fan" and, though this has served to show that a Coward opening still is regarded as an important social event by London's first-nighters, it falls a long way short of being an artistic triumph.

Aided by a $15,000,000 bond issue, the six New Jersey state teachers' colleges are now engaged in a vast expansion program that will increase their facilities by 50 per cent. Prompted by the acute teacher shortage in the state -- and elsewhere -- the expanded program is designed to increase the output of trained teachers, particularly on the elementary level.

THE time for Beauty is over. Mankind may return to it, but it has no use for it at present. The more Art develops, the more scientific it will be, just as science will become artistic. Separated in their early stages, the two will become one again when both reach their culmination.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 17 -- Jaclyn Stable's Closed Door, part of a three-horse entry saddled by Sid Jacobs, captured the featured $15,000 added Salvator mile at the Monmouth Park race track today.
IN talking with Igor Gouzenko one is first of all struck with his intensity, and the restless energy which impels him to keep moving, even if only within the confines of a living room.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L. I., July 17 -- A night of dining and dancing ended in death at dawn today for Jack Glickman, 28 years old, of 219 Brightwaters Court, Brooklyn. He died of a severed jugular vein at 3:45 A. M. at St. Joseph's Hospital, Far Rockaway, a half hour after plunging through a plate glass panel in the entrance to the Surf Club here.
LEAVENWORTH, Kan., July 17 (AP) -- George (Machine Gun) Kelly, so nicknamed because he could write his name on a wall with machine gun bullets, died in prison today.

THE name of George Villiers, second Duke of Buckingam, is familiar to every reader of Pepys, de Gramont and the other gossips of Restoration England. They know him as Dryden's Zimri, "everything by turns and nothing long"; they know him as author of a rowdy burlesque, "The Rehearsal"; they know him, above all, as the center of various gaudy, and bawdy, anecdotes.

THE chief problem facing the author who writes what one may be allowed by this time to call the "missionary novel" is that of credibility, of presenting his characters in such a way that his readers will be convinced of both their earthly reality and their spiritual biases without producing on the one hand a caricature, on the other a piece of saccharine piety.

ATTEMPTS to get more than the indicated number of exposures from a roll of 35mm color film often mean the loss of valuable shots, Eastman Kodak warns in one of its color bulletins. "A roll of Kodachrome Film," the company notes, "contains enough usable length to take the number of exposures specified on the carton, provided the camera is properly loaded.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Unemployment continues to be one of the economic and political realities nagging the Eisenhower Administration. It is not critical enough to set off an emergency work program, but it is too evident to forget.

This being the poison-ivy season, campers, picnickers and woodsmen ought to know more about the plant than some of them do. The term "poison ivy" is applied loosely to several species of sumacs. What we call "poison ivy" in the East is a vine that climbs to considerable heights, but often appears in the form of a three-foot shrub.

FRANCE'S losses in seven and a half years of fighting in Indochina have been severe. But perhaps most serious have been the casualties in her officercorps. In this war, 9,000 miles from France, some 1,800 officers have been killed. Of these, nearly 800 were graduates of the old and hallowed Special Military School of St. Cyr, the French West Point and training ground of France's marshals and generals.

Stores are now in their yearly between-season lull in ready-to-wear selling. Summer goods are being cleaned out by promotions and fall goods are not yet being offered, generally. However, certain trends are already discernible on the basis of early selling of late summer and fall goods, according to resident buying offices.
Your leading editorial in The Times of July 8 was excellent, but I do not believe it goes to the heart of the matter.

THROUGH the courtesy of Norman Dello Joio, the composer, we have been privileged to scan the facsimile manuscript, which he possesses, of the sketch of Verdi's opera, "Rigoletto." It is an astonishing document, and one of exceptional significance in its testimony to the workings of a great creative mind.

THE review by Samuel Flagg Bemis of Admiral Robert A. Theobald s 'The Final Secret of Pearl Harbor" is colored by his prejudices, prejudices such as he has shown in other reviews of works of the so-called "revisionist'' school of historians (Morgenstern, Flynn, Beard, Tansill).

PARIS, July 17 -- A quite unique political gamble that began exactly a month ago will be won or lost within about three days. Nobody yet can be sure of the outcome, at least nobody west of the Iron Curtain, not even Pierre Mendes-France, who became French Premier by proposing the gamble and might remain to change the French political scene if he won it.

SAN LUIS POTOSI, Mexico, July 17 (UP) -- Three persons were reported killed and at least thirty injured when the south-bound luxury train, the Aztec Eagle, was derailed today ninety-five miles north of here.

THIS little book by Thomas Merton is an introduction to an Encyclical of Pope Pius XII (included at the end of the volume) which was written last year on the occasion of the eighth centenary of Saint Bernard of Clairvaux, the great Trappist, who, if not the founder, is at least the spiritual father of his order.

IT is probably too much to expect a gallant and honest general like Gen. L. K. Truscott to recognize in his review the self-serving and propagandistic character of the memoirs of war criminal Kesselring ("A Soldier's Record"), but the following inaccuracies should be corrected: Kesselring was not sentenced to death for his treatment of Italian partisans but for his treatment of nonpartisan hostages whom he butchered in Rome.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Controversy over proposed tax relief for corporation stockholders threatened today to delay final action on the Administration's omnibus tax bill. The possibility of a session-end fight arose as Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat of Colorado, served notice that he would oppose any compromise "with every ounce of energy I have."

A SHORT and stimulating excursion into the history of photography before 1920 was put on exhibition last week at the Kodak Information Center in Grand Central Terminal, where it will hang through Aug. 2. The center is open 10 A. M. to 10 P. M. daily.

HEWLETT, L. I., July 17 -- Over the wind-blown Seawane Harbor Club course, Frank Strafaci, five-time titleholder, gained the final of the Long Island amateur golf championship by playing brilliantly this afternoon.

THE air age appears to have had some curious effects on film-makers on both sides of the Atlantic in the recent past. There was a time when the combination of strong and/or weak men, interesting women and the roar of powerful motors against a cerulean background generally was a guarantee of high adventure and, sometimes, genuine drama in the cinema.

IT is due to the efforts of the Arts Council of Great Britain that London owes its outstanding current art exhibitions. First among these is that of nearly eighty paintings on loan for the summer to the Tate Gallery, from the world's youngest important museum, that of Sao Paulo in Brazil which already can rival, in some respects, the most established treasure houses elsewhere.

SOME men have this problem: there is a nightmare that is very difficult to dream, but they must dream it before they can sleep in peace. The British army, regulars as well as draftees, has been suffering from this in Malaya -- courtesy of Communist guerrilla bands.

FOR many years Kilton Stewart, at one time a Mormon missionary and later an anthropologist, entertained a theory "that all men develop from a single mental pattern, and that this pattern can be discovered by a psychological study of successive levels of humans, ranging from the primitive to the sophisticate."

IN his column in the Sunday Times, Bosley Crowther states that the many readers of "The Caine Mutiny" will go to see the motion picture version to see how closely it follows the author's original story. The same thing, of course, can be said of "From Here to Eternity," "The Robe," "The High and the Mighty," and other recent bestsellers that have been filmed.

ALTHOUGH July is one of the two months of the year when most Easterners take a vacation, it is for a considerable number of ladies the time for the annual kitchen maneuvers in preparation for several hundred county fairs in the northeastern states during the next few months.

THIS first novel has all the virtues and defects of its class. The writing is bravely unedited, and plausibility is freely sacrificed in the interest of high feeling. A reckless use of melodrama saves the day in critical spots where the narrative must march or perish, and one minor character is fully realized.

Few teams in baseball would accomplish less with fourteen hits than the Baltimore Orioles did against the Yankees yesterday at the Stadium. While Jimmy Dykes' cellar-occupants were going through the motions, most of them wasted, the champions streaked to their twelfth straight triumph, a 9-3 victory that gave them the longest string in the majors this season.
TORONTO, July 17 -- Five Mennonite families completed this week a trek by truck from Chihuahua, Mexico, ending a thirty-year self-imposed exile from Canada.
BALBOA, C. Z., July 17 -- The removal of earth and rock from the top and face of Contractors' Hill to prevent a big slide into the Panama Canal will start tomorrow.

CAIRO, July 17 -- Great hopes flourished in Cairo and Teheran this week. Diplomats held their breath and -- more unusual -- politicians held their tongues. Even the normally brassy press of the two capitals appeared on the streets with, figuratively speaking, eyes discreetly downcast.

How can some measure of industrial democracy be provided for workers whose jobs are so vital to the public welfare that they must be deprived of the right to strike? Answers to that vexing question are likely to come out of the labor strife that has boiled up in recent weeks in the New York subway system and the big atomic energy plants at Oak Ridge, Tenn., and Paducah, Ky.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Congress this session has made noticeable progress on its programs to "free" the Indians from Federal supervision.

ST. LOUIS, July 17--The Giants defeated the Cardinals, 10--9, in the eleventh inning today. The victory of Leo Durocher's Polo Grounders over Eddie Stanky's St. Louis squad was achieved in 100-degree temperatures and was witnessed by a Ladies' and Children's Day crowd of 31,033.

RELATED in the first person by its lyrical heroine, Agnes, Phyllis Hastings' "Rapture in My Rags" concerns an English back-country girl's creation of a scarecrow, the seeming miracle of its coming to life and its catalytic effect on her character and her drab, painful existence.

One of the worst droughts on record in the metropolitan area is burning up lawns, killing shade trees and ruining commercial fruit and vegetable crops, reports from many parts of this city and its suburbs indicated yesterday.

NORWALK, Conn., July 17 -- A Red Bank dentist, Dr. Anson G. Hoyt, who a year ago won the New York Athletic Club's predicted log race to Block Island, today took the first cruiser contest of navigation sponsored by the Greenwich Power Squadron.
CHESTERTOWN, Md., July 17 (AP) -- The toll of the dead in a fireworks plant explosion here was placed at eleven today after it was decided that five persons listed as missing had been killed.

Henry Adams believed tact and persuasion were wasted on a Congressman. He wrote: "You must take a stick and hit him on the snout." This, however, was a literary and not a practical opinion, for Henry was not one of the Adamses who became President.

The Atomic Energy Commission announces that in collaboration with North American Aviation, Inc., it will design, build and operate an experimental reactor to generate heat which could be utilized to drive turboelectric machinery but which will be studied by itself by engineers who need information to develop efficient atomic power plants.

COUNT ALBERT DE DION can be said to be the world's first automobile racing driver, for he entered a steam-powered quadricycle in a "race" in 1887. Since there was no competition, naturally he had to win.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 17 -- Fashion shows, art exhibitions and festivals for the benefit of philanthropic and civic projects have been arranged for the midsummer season in resorts at this end of Long Island.
CHICAGO, July 17 (UP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates won the second game of a double-header today from the Chicago Cubs, 6 to 2, after losing four straight to the team they are chasing for seventh place.

SILVERSTONE, England, July 17 (UP) -- Froilan Gonzales of Argentina won the British Grand Prix auto race over 270 miles of the twisting, rain-drenched Silverstone circuit today at an average speed of 89.69 miles an hour.

ONCE again the radio listener is being treated as a wayward child. After reading that the very excellent radio program of a few seasons ago, "The Halls of Ivy," is going on television this coming fall, I am about ready to throw in the sponge.
