WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) -- -- The Government is getting tougher with chiselers and sharpers who try to do business with Federal agencies. It now keeps them on a blacklist, and they number about 500.
HANOI, Vietnam, July 17 -- On what may be the last week-end of the war in Indochina, two French Union forces continued today to mop up Vietminh infiltrators within thirty miles of Hanoi.

OF ALL the blights that may take their toll of fine shade trees each year, the most damaging -- at least in many rapidly expanding suburban communities -- is inflicted by the bulldozer. Lack of protection from this ruthless, earth - churning monster can strike even the sturdiest tree a mortal wound, as fatal as the scourge of an army of bark beetles or any one of the other tree pests.

Berlioz' "Requiem" will be heard in its entirety on Thursday in the recorded concert given by the New York Public Library from noon to 2 P. M. in Bryant Park. The presentation will take up the entire program.
FURTH, Germany, July 17 (AP) -- Czechoslovak Communists tried to pry military information from seven United States soldiers imprisoned twelve days in the Soviet satellite, the soldiers said today.
HARTFORD, July 17 -- Connecticut Democrats are hoping they may be able to pick up at least three additional Congressional seats in this state in the November election.

NEWARK, July 17 -- Preparations for a $10,000,000 operations improvement program for the Passaic Sewerage Commission will be completed within two months, Herman Blank, chairman of the commission, said today.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Errard King, owned by Joseph Gavegnano and ridden by Sammy Boulmetis, won the $161,300 Arlington Classic today. The colt had an easy time of it, being in front most of the way to win the mile test by two and a half lengths.
On a warm summer's day in 1927 a Michigan housewife suddenly rebelled. Making the special foods the doctor had ordered for 7-month-old Sally was just too much work. And was it ever hot!
A spokesman for importers challenged what he termed "misconceptions" about tariffs last week.

Dolores Dwyer of the Catholic Youth Organization scored three firsts, but a strong Equitable Life Assurance Society squad took six events to capture the Metropolitan senior women's track and field championships at Van Cortland Park yesterday.

Regarding the words of Ethan Allen when he demanded the surrender of Fort Ticonderoga "In the name of the great Jehovah and the Continental Congress," as quoted in your picture display, "We Hold These Truths . . ." (July 4), there is an interesting footnote which appears in Volume I of the "Official Reference Library of United States History."

COOLING and refreshing milk sherbets, prepared from summer's abundant fruits, are an ideal hot weather dessert. Easy to make at home in the freezer or freezing unit of the refrigerator, they have the fresh-from-the-garden flavor of the family's favorite seasonal fruits.

TRAFFIC violations are involved in eight out of ten highway accidents, with exceeding posted speed limits the most frequent violation, according to "Highway Safety and Driver Education," a book edited by Dr. Herbert J. Stack, director for safety education, and Dr. Leon Brody, director of research and publications, both of the Center for Safety Education of New York University.
GENEVA, July 17 -- France was told by her Premier tonight that none of the differences with communism over an Indochina settlement was insurmountable.

A special series of lectures on "The Development of the Concept of God in Indian Thought" will be given at Fordham University during the last two weeks of July and the first two weeks of August by the Rev. Gioacchino Patti. Dr. Patti is Professor of Sanskrit and Comparative Philology in the Pontifical Biblical Institute at Rome.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 -- Bob Feller pitched a two-hitter today to gain his sixth straight victory and score his first shutout of the season as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Philadelphia Athletics, 6 -- 0, to remain atop the American League ladder.

MACHADO de Assis (1839-1908) is generally considered Brazil's greatest novelist. Although his works have been translated into four European languages, "Philosopher or Dog?" (1892) is but the third of his novels to appear in English.

VIENNA, July 17 (UP) -- The United States rushed 300 bottles of typhoid vaccine today to the Linz region of Upper Austria, where officials warned that receding flood waters left a typhoid epidemic threat.
PRINCETON, N. J., July, 17 -- A Princeton University geophysicist will circle the world several times this summer, but he may not get to see much of the territory he covers.

RICHMOND, July 17 -- Further evidence of the strong economy of the Fifth Federal Reserve District is shown in the amount of new building authorized in the first half of 1954. The total for the 1954 period was $168,752,587, compared with $196,050,249 in the same 1953 months, the decline being only 13.9 per cent.
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 17 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali said today, "Islam and only Islam, not secularism, can save Pakistan and the world."

TOLEDO, July 17 (UP) -- The smooth-swinging team of Betty MacKinnon of Savannah, Ga., and Betsy Rawls of Spartanburg, N. C., today led a field of twenty in the first round of the $15,999 Inverness women's invitation golf tournament.
True or false: Massachusetts municipal housing authorities borrowed $27,000,000 for one year in the public market without cost?

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 17 -- An old fur trading post where one of the original researches in stomach medicine was begun by a United States Army surgeon more than 125 years ago today was dedicated as a memorial to the pioneers of American medicine and surgery.
ALFRED WALLENSTEIN, being justifiably proud of the sound of his Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra, exhibits the orchestra's tone on a new Decca disk in a second volume of Showpieces for Orchestra.

NEW HAVEN, July 17 -- The New Haven Railroad has placed into operation here the first section of what railroad officials say will be one of the largest installation of consolidated interlocking signals in the world.

July is running true to form, what with hot weather and higher prices in Wall Street. But, while stocks vied last week with the thermometer in advancing, the movement of prices was more selective than it had been in recent weeks.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 17 -- In the two months since the Supreme Court's decision outlawing racial segregation in public schools, the outstanding development is the disclosure that there is neither a uniform plan among the states involved to meet the problem nor a common reaction committing public sentiment to any one course.

DALLAS, Texas, July 17 -- Abnormally high temperatures that have been setting heat records over the Southwest have cut into department store sales volume and have caused a nosedive in summer range and pasture feed prospects for the region's farmers and ranchers.

THIS is the season of the year when the leading bridge players all over the United States are practicing for the biggest annual national tournament, the American Contract Bridge League's summer championships, which are always played during the first week of August.

AUTHOR of sixteen spy-adventure novels, many among the best in their genre. Manning Coles dedicates this story "To E. M. S., who detests spy-thrillers." For the sake of E. M. S. and others who may have overlooked the insouciance of Coles' story-telling, he here spins a fantasy of three ghosts -- a dashing Virginian, a staid Englishman, and a pet monkey.

IN the language of protocol, every ambassador is extraordinary and plenipotentiary. Once in a while you find one, like John Emil Peurifoy, United States Ambassador to Guatemala, whom the title fits in fact. Yet it is jarringly wrong to call John Peurifoy a diplomat.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 17 -- Well-informed sources said Indonesia's reluctance to place rubber and oil on her export list to Communist China, pending United Nations action in lifting its embargo on strategic shipments to the Peiping regime, was the reason for the suspension of trade talks here last week.

Rarely does one find the traits of thoroughbred racer and work horse united in a single object. Yet the impressive statistics compiled by the superliner United States since she broke the Atlantic speed record on her maiden voyage two years ago give evidence that she embodies that unique combination.

DURING the first six weeks the Pan American World Airways "pay later" plan was in effect, more than $1,000,000 worth of tickets was sold under the installment payment system. More than 90 per cent of the reservations sold on credit terms represented new business and it appears that the traveling public has given a hearty welcome to the new ticket-purchasing plan.

MILWAUKEE, July 17 -- A high bounding single by Gil Hodges for the sixth Brooklyn hit of the game today gave the battling Dodgers a 2-1 triumph over the Braves, who were able to score only one run on twice as many blows.

GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 17 (UP) -- Lewis Hoad and Neale Fraser won their singles semifinal matches in straight sets today to set up an all-Australian championship match in the Swiss international tennis tournament.

ONE of the "Whiteheadisms" quoted along with the review of "Dialogues of Alfred North Whitehead" was: "There are no whole truths; all truths are half truths. It is trying to treat them as whole truths that plays the devil."

A remark in last Sunday's Times, attributed by Thomas M. Pryor to PulitzerPrize-winner A. B. Guthrie Jr. whom he had interviewed, interested me considerably. "To write a good film script," according to the author, "is just as difficult to do, and it is just as much of a creative effort as a good novel."

TO those who know nothing of Sidi Barrani or the other milestones in his fighting career, Field Marshal Earl Wavell (1883-1950) must ever remain something of a puzzle. The secret of his exalted reputation as a master of war cannot be found in his writings on that subject.

RED BUTTONS was doing his "strange - things - are happening" comedy routine long before he took his talents before the television cameras. But if he had tried long and hard to develop a perfect description of his career in video he could not have found a better way to express it.
This past week French Union prisoners of war held by the Communist Vietminh since the fall of Dienbienphu were returned in an exchange of the sick and wounded.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., July 17 -- The prevailing view among the forty-two Governors who attended the forty-sixth annual Governors' Conference here this week was that relations between the Federal Government and the states have shown marked improvement in the eighteen months President Eisenhower has been in office.

One of the country's largest millinery manufacturers completed arrangements yesterday for a union loan of $250,000 to keep his hat plants operating and to preserve the jobs of his 1,050 unionized employes.
Most persons try to leave their business problems behind when away from the job. But that is not so for a group of graduate students at Teachers College of Columbia University.

CINCINNATI, July 17 (AP) -- Granny Hamners ninth-inning home run with Stan Lopata on base gave the Philadelphia Phils a 5-3 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs today and their first triumph under their new manager, Terry Moore.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 17 -- Correspondent, ridden by Johnny Longden, staged a wire to wire victory in the $137,100 Hollywood Gold Cup today.

The weakness in the market for refined oil products, caused in part by heavy inventories, may be corrected with no important change in the crude oil price structure. This seems to be the consensus of leading oil executives, who however feel the crude oil market is in for a severe test.

Heroin has been used by Asian Communists to spread drug addiction to a substantial number of American troops in Korea and Japan, Harry J. Anslinger, United States Commissioner of Narcotics, said yesterday.

IN view of the great popularity of Jack Webb's "Dragnet," and of the fact that it has three times received The Mystery Writer's Edgar award for outstanding quality in radio and TV, I've been surprised at the relative absence of any influence on the modern detective story of "Dragnet's" underplayed documentary approach.

IN spite of 90 degree heat and insects, there is always some garden work to be done all summer long. However, it is not necessary to gamble on heat prostration. Chores can be tackled in such a way as to beat the heat.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The directives Gen. Walter Bedell Smith carried with him to Geneva deal with the terms of an Indochina cease-fire "the United States could respect." State Department officials said today that the important thing to understand at this point about the phrase "the United States could respect" was what it did not mean.

The Turkish liner Tarsus, carrying 500 Turkish visitors and an exhibition of the country's products, will arrive here tomorrow morning on the final leg of a goodwill cruise to United States East Coast ports.
ATLANTA, July 17 (AP) -- Sometime this fall the Federal Supreme Court and Gov. Herman Eugene Talmadge of Georgia, "white supremacy" advocate may clash head-on.

CLARENCE STREIT'S central theme is, or ought to be, well known by now for he has expounded it before in "Union Now" and "Union Now With Britain." He holds that the peoples of the Atlantic, especially North Atlantic, area share a common heritage and a common civilization, characterized by the practice of democracy, anchored in the idea of freedom.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation saved $375,000 last week.
MEMPHIS, TENN, July 17 (UP) -- Newly-chartered American University here is inviting both Negroes and whites to attend.

BIG SEA DAY will be celebrated Aug. 14 at Point Pleasant, N. J., with band contests, dancing and a two-mile-long parade, all dedicated to the seafood of the Jersey coast. The ceremonies, sponsored by the Chamber of Commerce and the state's seafood industry, will lead to the selection of a State Seafood Princess.

LAST March Rudolf Bing announced the operas he would present next season at the Metropolitan Opera. The list included "Orfeo ed Euridice," which has not been given there in twelve seasons. It has now been learned that Pierre Monteux will conduct the Gluck revival and that two of its leading parts will be sung by singers new to the company, Giulietta Simionato and Laurel Hurley.

IN 1939, at the Belmont Pleasure Grounds in Exeter, England, the first public garden for the blind was established. Today there are about ten such gardens in the United States, and others abroad, where the blind can come to sniff and examine plants at close range.

SO far as museum plans may be taken into account, next season should provide the New York art world with a year of reappraisal. For most of the exhibitions thus far scheduled are group exhibitions with a sober retrospective cast.

ON my desk at this moment lies a manuscript, scrawled in childish writing over the torn pages of a school exercise book and posted in a remote seaport on the Persian Gulf. "This is my first literary work." says the covering note. It can hardly be called that.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Senator Wayne Morse, Independent of Oregon said this week that a report that he planned to enroll as a Democrat this fall was "a lie being spread by my enemies."

A MEET-THE-PRESS party given here by Columbia recently for two Hollywood arrivals apparently achieved its objective in an atmosphere of mutual good will but it did not -- indeed could not -- answer the intriguing question of how a popular movie is to be made out of Graham Greene's novel, "The End of the Affair."

CLEVELAND, July 17 -- Jerry Barber of La Canada, Calif., and Ted Kroll of New Hartford, N. Y., tied at 208, eight under par, today for the third-round lead in the seventy-two-hole, $25,000 Manakiki open golf tournament.

MASTER of Queen's College, University of Melbourne, Raynor C. Johnson is a physicist. Though he is not the only physicist who believes in what Main Street calls "hunches" and psychologists "intuition," he is a rare specimen; for he is convinced that we must reckon with something more than pure reason in evaluating the powers of the mind.

High tariffs and quotas have long been the chief means by which countries contrive to restrict imports. A lesser -- yet bedeviling -- device is the requirement of special markings or labels to indicate origin, nature or other peculiarities.
Top management in the aluminum industry is wrestling with an unusually knotty problem this year.

IT is easy, today, to make out case for despair. Events, as they unfold themselves, look more and more like portents of disaster. Reason, which has seldom, if ever, been really ascendant in human affairs, seems powerless to arrest the trend.
DETROIT, July 17 (AP) -- The best news the auto industry has heard in many months is the indicated drop in field stocks.

THE great legion of shooters whose interest in rifles and pistols concerns the punching of small holes in black paper rather than providing game for the table, will settle the 1954 shooting laurels Aug. 16-Sept. 5, at the national matches in Camp Perry, Ohio.
IN FOUR localities in the Southeast are four outdoor dramas which open each summer in late June and play six nights a week until Labor Day.
NEW HAVEN, July 17 -- Bassett Junior High School where children and teachers use fire escapes to get in and out of the building, is going to be completed, twenty-eight years after it was opened.
KANSAS CITY, July 17 -- The heat wave throughout the Southwest kept shoppers from the stores and volume slipped from the levels of the previous week and a year ago.
UTRECHT, the Netherlands, July 17 -- The close post-war cooperation among Dutch trade unions ended today. It was an important factor in the maintenance of industrial peace.

THIS short novel attempts to reconstruct the impact upon various individuals and groups, mostly living in or near Jerusalem, of the Crucifixion of Christ and of the mysterious events of the subsequent days. The author, the late Evan John, an Anglican clergyman who has written previous novels and historical works, does not employ here the direct narrative form.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 17 (AP) -- The Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia held the lead at the halfway point of the eightieth regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen today in defense of its Julius H. Barnes team trophy.
TWO of the more famous European pre-war labels were L'Oiseau-Lyre and Anthologie Sonore. Both specialized in out-of-the-way items, with Anthologie Sonore concentrating on pro-Mozart music.
A Chicago woman was booked here last night on charges of kidnapping on June 1 a 6-year-old girl whose mother allegedly had written an adoption consent to a truck driver on a tavern menu.
R. Buckminster Fuller, inventor and designer of ultra-modern houses and automobiles, envisions a military application for his invention, the "geodesic dome."

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 17 -- Representative Pat Sutton of Lawrenceburg appears to be gaining so much ground in his race for the Senate as to cause speculation here that he may upset Senator Estes Kefauver in the Aug. 5 Democratic primary.

INWOOD, L. I., July 17 -- Dr. Robert E. Lake, a Professor of Physics at Pratt Institute, today began the quest for his third straight Eastern senior tennis championship and reached the third round at the Inwood Country Club.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A fourth investigation into education in this country by the present Congress was under preparation this week.
The textile industry is playing a major role in the nation's air defense through that segment that manufactures woven glass fabrics used as a base for plastic impregnation.
LONDON, July 17 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union announced tonight a series of steps designed to improve relations with her non-Communist northern neighbor, Finland.

The New York Times and The Associated Press have been informed by their correspondents in Hanoi that censorship in Indochina has progressed to the point where the French Army admits double censorship exists and that censors are editing and changing copy without informing correspondents.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 17 -- The fifty-sixth Larchmont Race Week began today with 324 starting yachts and an almost complete absence of sharp competition.
PARIS, July 16 -- Shipping flying the French flag has increased by more than 800,000 tons since the outbreak of World War II, the Ministry of Public Works and Communications announced here today.

Mid-July brings days when a man can lie in the shade or sit in the sun and let the simplicities of the world surround him, and when he does that he wonders about a good many things. Why, for instance, anybody ever thought up a philosophy of scarcity when there is so much evidence, all around him, of abundance.

AT the sumptuous show staged here last month by the American Institute of Decorators, eighteen elaborate room settings represented as many different points of view. Examination of these settings (arranged by local chapters of the organization) made it evident that the differences were regional -- dictated in each case by the climate, pace of life, customs and traditions indigenous to specific areas of our country.
BOSTON, July 17 (UP) -- Ellis Kinder cut off a ninth-inning Detroit rally after four runs had scored today to enable the Boston Red Sox to score a 7-6 victory before 8,796 fans.
MOSCOW, July 17 (Reuters) -- The writer, Ilya Ehrenburg, was in hot water again today, this time charged with "preaching wrong ideas" about the development of Soviet art.

HAVANA, July 15 -- Internal strife broke out in all Cuban political parties this week with the opening of the nomination period for the Presidential elections in November. However, the public continued to regard the electoral contest with apathy.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The United States has ruled that eleven churchmen from Communist Czechoslovakia and Hungary may attend Protestant church conferences in this country beginning late this month.

George Meany president of the American Federation of Labor, is scheduled to address the opening session tomorrow of the annual convention of the New York State Federation of Labor at the Commodore Hotel.

CHORE FOE THE WEEK: Start seeds of pansies, foxglove and hollyhock, columbine, candytuft and other biennials and perennials. Sow in rows in a coldframe or each variety in a pot of sand and soil. Shade and keep constantly moist until germination. When the second pair of leaves appears, transplant to about two inches apart in richer soil.

Derivatives of the plant Rauwolfia Serpentina are now widely used with good results in the treatment of high blood pressure. They have a rival in an old Indian snakeroot remedy. According to Drs. William R. Livesay, John H. Moyer and Samuel L. Miller, three physicians of Houston, Tex., who write about it the Journal of the American Medical Association, the active drug in the snakeroot remedy is alseroxylon.

THE trouble with translation begins with the very nature of words. Words not only "mean" something; in the process of meaning it, they release all sorts of suggestions. "Daisy," for example, points to a common flower and lightly conceals the root-picture "day's eye."

ROME, July 17 -- If the Trieste problem is solved soon -- and, despite some eleventh-hour hitches in negotiations, the betting in Rome is that it will be -- credit for Italy's acceptance will be due largely to three persons. They are former Premier Giuseppe Pella, United States Ambassador Clare Boothe Luce and Premier Mario Scelba.

PONTIAC, Mich. -- On the sunburnt concrete infield of the GMC Truck and Coach Division plant here they held a fashion show last week to unveil and christen with a bottle of domestic champagne the newest Greyhound Corporation bus, the Scenicruiser.

Operating a trust department profitably in a commercial bank in New York and New Jersey is not only difficult but exceptional, a survey of a group of banks indicated. Fifty-six of 107 bank trust departments examined suffered a loss in 1953; only fifty- one showed a profit.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Senate was urged today to carry out President Eisenhower's plea for a freer flow of atomic knowledge to the Allies as a national security measure but to hold up the "more complex" problem of peacetime development of the atom.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) -- Bernard M. Baruch warned today that if Congress failed to enact stand-by economic controls this session, "it may cost us dearly.''

HAVING noted that a group of critics has recently designated ten American writers "who are considered to have rendered the greatest service to the world of books in the quarter century from 1929 to 1954," I was pleased to find on the list the name of Van Wyck Brooks. In my opinion, Mr. Brooks is our foremost living writer.

SAMUEL R. ROSENBAUM has more money to spend on music than anyone else in the country. There are other people and groups with more reserves of the green stuff, but Mr. Rosenbaum is obliged to spend the money at his disposal for music.

DURING July and August, two major problems are encountered with fruit trees, and, in fact, with most plants around the house and garden. One is to keep them supplied with adequate water and the other is to keep the foliage and fruit covered with spray material for bugs and diseases.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., July 17 -- Two automobiles collided head-on early this morning near here, killing the six occupants of one car and the driver of the other. Two of the victims were children and another was an expectant mother.

VICTORIA, B. C., July 17 (Canadian Press) -- A party of seven Canadian and ten United States scientists left here today for Kodiak, Alaska, the last stop before penetrating to uncharted areas around the entrance to the Northwest Passage in the Canadian Arctic islands.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, predicted today that the Senate, with the support of more than a dozen Republican Senators, would approve his motion to censure Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

IN a prefatory note to this heady mixture of fictional lilac and old rose leaves, the author points out that little is known of the Nahuatlan Indians, who once dominated the great plateau valley now occupied by the modern capital of Mexico.

JERUSALEM, July 17 -- The Israeli Government has informed Maj. Gen. Vagn Bennike, chief of staff of the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization, of its deep regret that responsibility was not fixed for the shooting in Jerusalem two weeks ago.

LONDON, July 17 (AP) -- A foursome of Britain's best milers ran the 6,000-meter relay (approximately four miles) today in 15 minutes 29 seconds, but failed to better the 15:21.5 clocking made by a Hungarian team on Wednesday. The listed world record is 15:27.2, set by another British team.

LOS ANGELES, July 17 -- A Sicilian defense, adopted by Nicolas Rossolimo, former champion of France, against Arthur B. Bisguier of New York, United States champion, as drawn after eighteen moves in the seventh round of the Pan-American Chess tournament at the Hollywood Athletic Club today.
NEW PROVIDENCE, N. J., July 17 (AP) -- Seven girls qualified today for the finals of the fifth annual National Amateur Athletic Union junior outdoor synchronized swimming competition.

In a report urging Congress to vote for a $3,100,000,000 foreign aid program for the current year the Senate Foreign Relations Committee rightly declares that American assistance to war-torn nation has paid off well in terms of our own security. The Senate Armed Services Committee, in a unanimous vote on Friday, sustained this position.

The Women's Tri-County Golf Association's tenth annual tournament will start tomorrow on the Leewood Golf Club course in Tuckahoe, N. Y. Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis will be seeking her third successive title.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Eisenhower Administration's foreign policy is at the point of crisis nearly all the world around.
CHICAGO, July 17--Two former school teachers have opened what appears to be one of the most vigorous political campaigns seen here in many years.

THE National Broadcasting Company has gone rural. Each Sunday afternoon (5 to 6 o'clock) it takes television viewers on a trip to a modern 160-acre farm near Cloverdale, Ill., about thirty miles from Chicago.

CLEVELAND, July 17 (AP) -- Smoke Screen of the Reverie Knoll Farm won the $30,100 Thistle Down Cup today with a neck to spare over Euclid. Rock Cottage was two lengths behind as he nosed out Marked Game for third place.

DALLAS, July 17 (AP) -- Gene Andrews of Pacific Palisades, Calif., was the stronger in the stretch today to win a 36-hole contest, 1 up, from Jack Zimmerman of Dayton, Ohio, and take the national public links championship.

ST. LOUIS, July 17 -- Trade in the St. Louis area was dominated in the week ended today by hot weather, with a new high established for temperature readings at 112.3 on Wednesday, following a near-record high on Monday. Stores reported unparalleled sales of room coolers and electric fans, although the volume failed to offset the slack in other goods.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 17 -- The United Nations' eight-year-old atomic energy debate will be reopened here on Tuesday.

Fifty-six years ago yesterday the Spanish surrendered to United States forces at Santiago, Cuba, ending the first phase of the Spanish American War. An unpublished letter, bought recently by the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, adds an eyewitness account of the ceremonies attending the capitulation.
A clause calling for a fifteen-day strike notice in all maritime union contracts affecting the Port of New York has been proposed by Robert W. Dill, Collector of Customs in this district.

IN the twenty-first century, Man has discovered how to defeat death. Through a process of Restoration, immortality has become a reality. By recording the cellular memories and personalities of carefully selected men, they can be revived -- if necessary, in new bodies.

FOR this anthology August Derleth has collected twelve hitherto unpublished stories of science and fantasy. They concern themselves with the world of tomorrow and, frankly, if the general caliber of their concepts and writing is any criterion, that world will be a dull one indeed.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 -- The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia noted this week that the major theme of mid-year forecasts is that "business will he better," but not much. The optimists are influenced, the Bank said, by underlying forces of considerable strength, while the views of the pessimists reflect skepticism as to the significance of recent favorable tendencies.

Before July 20 [my Government] will endeavor to obtain settlement of the Indochina conflict. * * * If no satisfactory result can be reached by that date my Government will hand its resignation to the President of the Republic.

COLUMBIA, S. C., July 17 -- Gov. James F. Byrnes' temporary ban on new school construction was lifted yesterday after a number of districts re- studied proposed locations and moved Negro schools closer to Negro residential areas.

The recent Eisenhower-Churchill conference has resulted in merely narrowing our differences and the measure of agreement is exceeded by the degree of divergence. Britain continues to believe that the East-West conflict may be resolved -- hence it is better to "jaw than war"; we, that our adversary is unappeasable.

WHILE the brightest minds of the industry decry Hollywood's present timidity in the choice of outspoken subject matter, Century Productions, a small independent company, is going ahead on the greatest and most delicate story in the annals of Christendom.
"RAY, as soon as you finish putting Miss America's head in that celastic, would you get rid of Clooney? She's finished as a girl. She'll be a frog next week."

LEE GRISSOM was a talented pitcher for Cincinnati but a mite on the unpredictable side. He was left-handed all the way. One day at the end of the 1937 season he was chatting with Warren Giles, now president of the National League but then the general manager of the Reds.

BAASTAD, Sweden, July 17 (AP) -- Philippe Washer, Belgium's No. 1 player, defeated Sweden's Lennart Bergelin, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4, in a drizzling rain today to give Belgium a tie with Sweden in the semi-finals of the European Zone Davis Cup tennis competition.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) -- The Civil Defense Administration said today that wartime blackouts could be eliminated in big city target areas under a new plan for controlling lights to foil enemy bombers.
WHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory, June 13 -- Yukon is only a little more than 1,200 miles from Siberia. It is 5,000 miles to St. John's, Nfld., and about 4,000 miles to New York.

THE East Side Airlines Terminal, an efficient block-long machine for dispatching buses filled with passengers to airports, has been in operation for more than half a year now, with results that are gratifying to nearly everyone concerned.

IGOR GOUZENKO, hitherto known simply as the man responsible for a crucial exposure of Soviet espionage, has written a novel of substantial merit. This would be less astonishing, perhaps, if the novel were autobiographical, for many a gifted amateur has been able to make acceptable fiction out of personal experience.

COLLECTIONS of reproductions of photographs for the picture's sake alone, without accompanying text as in American annuals and other picture books, apparently have a better public reception abroad than in this country, judging from the frequency of their appearance.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 17 -- The last major obstacle barring the return of Iranian oil to world markets after a three-year stoppage appeared to have been removed today.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 7 -- A new study of literature in the Afrikaans language by the official bibliographer, Prof. P. J. Nienaber of Witwatersrand University, says there are now about 10,000 books in Afrikaans.

A Huzzah! for Mrs. Helen Gross for her letter which you published recently, and a resounding boo for all those who scream with delight over that "uncluttered" Japanese house at the Museum of Modern Art. I haven't been to see that house but I have seen similar ones in Japan and spent an uncomfortable time last winter dining and sleeping in a Japanese inn that was just as uncluttered and unlivable.

As an Australian resident in Canada I was most interested to read Drew Middleton's "Troubled Britain -- And Confident Britain" (July 4). How ever, I feel that the author gave a somewhat incorrect impression when he wrote: "Victoria's empire is gone. India is a republic. * * *"
AUSTIN, Tex., July 17 -- Texans will vote next Saturrday for the first time since the state supported General Eisenhower in 1952 and the result will be of nation-wide interest.

ASCOT, England, July 17 (AP) -- Queen Elizabeth watched joyously through binoculars today as her horse Aureole made up for a disappointing 1953 season by winning England's richest turf prize -- the 27,650 ($77,420) King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Stakes.

LET there be no minimizing of Capt. Horatio Horn-blower! That bellowing belligerent has won an everlasting place in the minds and hearts of all who love tales of naval heroism and high adventure. Notwithstanding, the Hornblower renown has so overborne Mr. Forester's other writings that the reader of "The Nightmare" may be in danger of a number of things.

Disagreement, said Prime Minister Churchill, speaking in the House of Commons last week, is "often much more exciting to the reader than agreement." He went on to say that "the highest common factor of public opinion is not a fertile ground for lively epigrams and sharp antitheses."
In your picture display, "On a Sunday in the Park" (July 4) you represent Central Park as an idyllic summer retreat for city dwellers. From recent experience things are different.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., July 17 (AP) -- Thirty-one striking American Federation of Labor laborers tonight were cited to court next Tuesday to show cause why they should not be held in contempt of court for violating an anti-picketing injunction.

Adolf A. Berle Jr. in his "Communist Thunder to the South" (July 4) did well to call attention to the need for giving support to men like President Figueres of Costa Rica who defeated the Communists through liberal economic and social reforms.
LANCASTER, Pa., July 17 -- A 130-year-old Conestoga wagon is being put into shape at the blacksmith shop of M. H. Eby in Blue Ball for a westward overland journey reminiscent of pioneer days.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- A drive was under way today to restore $71,500,000 in maritime funds from the Appropriations Committee of the House of Representatives slashed from an emergency appropriations bill yesterday.

A program to introduce new members of the faculty to the college and to the profession of teaching will begin at Hunter College this September. This is to be the first of its kind in the metropolitan area and one of the first in the country.

Sensational news came from Seattle, Wash., last week, where the American Physical Society was meeting. Dr. Marcel Schein, Professor of Physics in the University of Chicago's Institute for Nuclear Studies, reported that he had detected on photographic emulsions what he considered evidence of a nuclear explosion of the order of ten million billion volts.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 17 (AP) -- W. P. Kennedy of Cleveland, president of the 215,000-member Brotherhood of Railroad Train-men, called today for "broad Government action to head off a threatened business depression."

FOR the last six months the index of industrial production in the United States has scarcely moved upward or downward. Other signs reinforce the view that the recession which began a year ago has been flattening out. All of this evidence prompts the question: Has the danger of a severe recession passed?

IT was in 1922, when Ruth St. Denis and I were dancing for a month at the Coliseum in London, that I first met Margaret Morris, and visited her school and theatre in Chelsea. Her fame had reached America years before, as the pioneer in England of what was to be known much later as modern dance.

ATLANTA, July 17 -- Completion of defense contracts, poor markets and seasonal cutbacks were the principal factors in the decline of manufacturing employment in eight Southeastern states during May, when the level reached 1,889,000, according to Brunswick A. Bagdon, regional director of the U. S. Department of Labor's. Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WHATEVER the problems of the reprint houses and reprint subsidiaries of the trade publishers, and whatever the villainies they perpetrate and perpetuate (the counterfeit), it has become increasingly apparent that at one end of the spectrum they have been doing an excellent job.
BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., July 17 -- The Bridgehampton Child Care and Recreational Center, supported by this community for the children of migrant farm workers, will reopen in a new location Aug. 8.

In a recent issue there appeared an informative account of the duel between Aaron Burr and Alexander Hamilton. The following additional information, taken from the History of The Saint Andrew's Society of New York, may be of interest.
BERLIN, July 17 -- The Russians have decided to remove from the United States sector of Berlin a Soviet Army tank memorial that long has been a focal point of anti-Communist demonstrations.

One thousand five hundred men, women and children of several Protestant Episcopal parishes attended a field mass celebrated yesterday noon in the amphitheatre on Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive near Grand Street.

LANSING, Mich., July 17 -- A four-candidate contest for the Republican nomination for Governor and an inter-union fight for power within the Democratic party have featured the campaigns that will be decided in the Michigan primaries Aug. 3.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 17 (UP)--Senator Theodore F. Green, Democrat of Rhode Island, said today the United States was pursuing a "get tough" policy with its allies.

CLEVELAND, July 17 -- With the chance of an accelerated ore and coal movement becoming more remote each week, some operators are chartering idle vessels to hold grain at ports in which elevators are jammed to capacity, it was reported today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 17 -- Moorehead Patterson, a large man (about 6-1) with a large business (about $140,000,000 a year) is back in the United States after spending a few months abroad finding that State Department persons earn their keep.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- The labor force in Illinois was all estimated 4,173,000 persons last March, the Department of Labor reported. Of these 2,478,000 are in Cook and Du Page Counties, including Chicago and a large suburban area. The department said that of the state total 3,949,000 were employed at the end of March with 223,000 unemployed and 1,000 engaged in labor-management disputes.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 17 (AP) -- Royal Mist, a 5-year-old bay mare owned by Franklin S. Hastings of Berlin, Md., and driven by Mack Hayman, won the $5,000 Rockville Centre Pace over the mile and one-sixteenth distance in 2:12 1-5 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

Henry G. Riter 3d entered Wall Street the day after his sixteenth birthday in 1908 because "the only relative who ever made or had any money was a stock broker." He left the field, forty years and several thousand deals later, when he found an industrial company that needed an investment banking mind to put its affairs in order.

A plan to stop price cutting on toys has been formulated by the Toy Guidance Council, Inc., and will be put into effect next year if the toy industry cooperates, according to Melvin Freud, president of the council.

THIS prolegomenon, or "reconnaissance map," as the author calls it, to American culture originated, happily, in a series of lectures at the University of Athens, where George R. Stewart was Fulbright Professor of American Literature and Civilization in the winter of 1952-53.

AT 27, Kenneth Tynan is the bad boy of English dramatic criticism. What George Jean Nathan was to the Broadway of the Twenties, Master Tynan is to the West End of the Fifties. Cecil Beaton, whose "Glass of Fashion" was recently published, needs no program note. Some time back the old master and the young man got together.

SYRACUSE, July 17 -- Forty-four chiefs of the Six-Nation Confederacy gathered today at the Onondaga reservation long house near here to decide whether they would accept President Eisenhower's invitation to meet with him in Washington Tuesday. A spokesman said they probably would accept.

LONDON, July 17 -- Socialist pressure for the inclusion of Communist China in the United Nations increased today. Aneurin Bevan, leader of the Labor Party's left wing, demanded sympathy and understanding between Britain and the Peiping Government.

A NEW Messiah conducted by Sir Adrian Boult and two versions of Belshazzar are the big items among recent Handel releases. The Boult "Messiah" is much the best of three albums, but since this is the sixth LP "Messiah" it is not so newsworthy as the rival versions of "Belshazzar," a work virtually unknown in this country and never recorded before.

WE have listened to so many conflicting opinions on Ben Hecht's book. "A Child of the Century," that we talked to a Simon Schuster fellow who we figured would have a line on the conflict. He knew what he liked, he said, but he didn't know about the critics.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission charged today that the Warren Petroleum Corporation of Tulsa, Okla., had engaged in unlawful pricing practices. The F. T. C. described Warren as one of the largest marketers in the United States of liquefied petroleum gas.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The Foreign Operations Administrator, Harold Stassen, flew back from Europe today, presumably with new light on the touchy problem of trade between the Free World and the Communists.
CHICAGO, July 18 -- The Pure Oil Company of Chicago has acquired the large refining plant of the Globe Oil and Refining Company at Lemont, Ill.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UP) -- Senator George W. Malone, Republican of Nevada, said today the United Nations is trying to set up international controls over the world's raw materials despite State Department objections.
CHICAGO, July 18 -- Russ Meyer registered his fourteenth straight triumph over the Cubs today as the Dodgers pounded out a dozen hits off three pitchers for a 12-6 margin.
Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. said yesterday that admission of Communist China to the United Nations would transform the United Nations into "a cynical, sordid cockpit of power politics."

The Right Rev. Lucian Charles Usher-Wilson, Anglican Bishop on the Upper Nile in East Africa, described yesterday the growth of Christianity in his diocese. He was guest preacher at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street.
LONDON, July 17 (Reuters) -- Rapidly growing West German competition in the shipbuilding industry is threatening British supremacy and bringing fears of a slump to the shipyards.
SLOATSBURG, N. Y., July 18 -- More than 2,000 persons attended today the largest camp meeting ever held by the Seventh-Day Adventists in the New York area.
TUNIS, July 18 -- French settlers in Tunisia and many moderate Tunisians are growing more apprehensive as the time approaches when the French Government must define its North African policy.

More New Yorkers give more to more charitable causes than the people of any other city; an estimated $500,000,000 out of a national total of $4,500,000,000 in 1953. Last winter the Tompkins-Rabin Joint Committee of the New York Legislature spread on the record some outrageous abuses of the public's willingness to be kind.

QUEBEC, July 18 (UP) -- Marie Dionne, the shy, frail quintuplet who entered a convent nearly nine months ago to become a nun, has given up a life of prayer and silence for "health reasons." She has gone into seclusion in Montreal with one of her sisters.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Secret decisions by a joint Congressional conference committee on the Administration's tax reform bill have given insiders excellent opportunities for quick profits in the stock market.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 18 -- The ideology of moral re-armament as the best answer to communism in Asia, Africa and other disturbed regions was the theme most stressed today by speakers at the North American assembly of the Moral Re-Armament Movement.

The importance of the frequent reception of the holy eucharist to the life of the soul was stressed yesterday by the Rev. James Kenney of the New York Apostolate. He preached at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

GENEVA, July 18 -- French experts estimate that 1,000,000 tons of shipping will be required for a year to evacuate the military and civilian personnel and military equipment from the Red River delta if an Indochina settlement is reached here.

An erratic movement in the Canadian dollar in the closing session of the week, was the only incident of otherwise quiet trading in the foreign exchanges. British sterling and the Continental Europeans were firm on light dealings.

TEHERAN, July 18 -- Iran announced tonight that she had successfully concluded general discussions with the consortium of eight international oil companies on renewed production and marketing of Iranian oil.
Your recent editorial on the rapid growth of stamp collecting in this country was deeply appreciated by those of us who live and work in the world of stamps.

Optometrists have been following with interest the reports on the drivers' clinic conducted by the Greater New York Safety Council, and the exchange of views between such individuals as R. J. Kornstein and Paul F. Stricker. This letter is principally concerned with Mr. Stricker's comments, as reported in The Times of July 13.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders of Vermont today called on his Republican colleagues in the Senate to support his motion on Tuesday to censure Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

Retailers intend to increase sharply their purchases of worsted and mohair blended suits and wool and Dacron blends for next spring, according to the Clothing Manufacturers As sociation of the U. S. A. The group's survey of the buying intentions of 384 mens' wear retailers throughout the country gives the percentage of suits to be purchased in each style, color and fabric.
WILLOUGHBY, Ohio, July 18 (UP) -- Julius Boros beat George Fazio on the first hole of a sudden-death play-off today to take the $5,000 top money in the $25,000 Carling's Open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (UP) -- The House Labor Committee today named a special seven-man subcommittee "to work out a realistic plan" of Federal grants for school construction.

LONDON, July 18 -- Variations in gravity in different parts of the world may have an "appreciable effect" on international athletic records such as jumping, pole vaulting and weight throwing, British scientists declare.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 18 (AP) -- The Television Writers of America, bargaining agent for TV writers, announced today that picket lines would be established Wednesday in front of buildings of the three major networks here.

Although production of lumber products by Powell River Company, Ltd., declined in the first half of this year, newsprint output increased from 163,515 tons to 184,628 tons and sales rose from 163,172 tons to 179,410.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 18 -- There were splintered masts and capsized boats all over Long Island Sound today when a south-southwest wind of about twenty knots velocity gave the smaller of 301 competitors in the second regatta of Larchmont Race Week a severe dusting. As far as could be learned, all hands were picked up unharmed. Fifty-six boats did not finish.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Senator J. William Fulbright asserted tonight that he believed the United States could accomplish more by quiet diplomacy than by public threats to its Allies.

People who live in magnificent splendor upon estates where homes are surrounded by acres of carefully tended lawns and woodlands miss a homely pastime familiar to apartment dwellers and many residents of suburbia, especially in summer.
LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 18 -- Gusty squalls hit the land-locked pleasure bay every few minutes here this afternoon during the second day of the city's Golden Jubilee Speedboad Regatta.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The long-delayed air base agreement between the United States and Libya may finally be nearing completion.

On the face of it, what is ostensibly under negotiation at Geneva is simple. Two groups that have already agreed that they want to stop shooting at each other or they wouldn't be at the conference, are there to agree to stop shooting at each other. In a rational world the formal agreement ought to be reached in twenty minutes. But this isn't exactly a rational world.

Gypsy Rose Lee is thinking of Broadway again. Not seen here since "The Naked Genius" (1943), Miss Lee in intrigued by the potentialities of "Darling, Darling." Freely adapted by Anita Loos from the 1950 Parisian hit of Pierre Barillet and Jean-Pierre Gredy, the farce has been listed for production on this side since 1951.
JERUSALEM, July 13 -- Israel and the World Zionist Organization have worked out an agreement covering their joint operations.
SEOUL, Korea, July 18 -- President Syngman Rhee yesterday approved four proposed major constitutional amendments.

BALDWIN, L. I., July 18 -- A home-made bomb, exploding in a crotch of a maple tree in front of 9 Newton Avenue here at 2 A. M. today, wrecked the tree and broke twenty windows in four near-by homes. No one was injured.
AMSTERDAM, July 18 -- Last week the Stock Exchange here displayed exceptional strength and activity, with an average turnover of about 5,000,000 guilders a day in shares alone.

THE McAlpin Hotel intends to do something pretty soon by way of official recognition for Miss Flora Livingston, who entered its employ in 1912 as the first woman cashier in a major New York hospice. She has stayed at the job ever since.

Despite commendable efforts by many people to stand up against the attacks on nonconforming thought which have become popular in some quarters, there is a disturbing tendency often to be noted in the tactics of the defense. Rather than being met directly, the attack is evaded through the argument that the thinking in question is not really nonconformist.
Having recently read a letter in this column concerning noise and dirt in New York, I would like to join the discussion.

WEST SAYVILLE, L. I., July 18 -- The West Sayville Baymen's Association, the first such cooperative on, Long Island, announced today that it had leased 14,000 acres of valuable Great South Bay bottom for clamming.

In his letter to Mayor Wagner, released today, submitting the 1953 report of the Fire Department, Commissioner Cavanagh -- far less colorfully than the occasion deserves -- hints at a development of great interest to all New Yorkers: one that should show striking results in his 1954 report.

SOMETHING new and different and delightful has come along in the field of domestic situation comedy. Entitled "The Marriage" and co-starring Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy, the newcomer is televised by the N. B. C. network on Thursdays from 10 to 10:30 P. M.
GENEVA, July 18 -- France and the Communists have reached a tentative agreement under which an Indochina armistice would be supervised by a commission composed of Canada, India and Poland.

Transit Authority plans for early demolition of the Third Avenue elevated line south of 149th Street have inspired realty activity that promises to bring a structural rebirth to that blighted area of Manhattan.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 18 -- Iran rejected a Soviet protest today and stoutly reasserted her readiness to join regional military pacts if they served to safeguard her "independence and territorial integrity."
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The present search by Congress for codes of procedures that might stop criticism of its investigations has developed a new problem.
NEWPORT, R. I., July 18 -- This town, which has been described as one of "the last resorts," gave itself a shot in the arm this weekend with an infusion of one of the liveliest arts.
One experiment in "permanent" traffic-line marking was written off yesterday as a failure and a test of another product was initiated in Times Square.

Columbia University will honor the nation's teachers in an outdoor academic ceremony at 10:30 A. M. tomorrow. Dr. John A. Krout, vice president and provost of the university, will present citations to six men and women for their "distinguished services to American education."
Forty canvas money bags containing $12,000 in coins were stolen Saturday night from a Brooklyn bank by thieves who broke through an iron gate and iron door and into a vault.

In the debate on China and the United Nations the American public and our statesmen seem to have skipped a whole chapter. The debate is on the question whether we ought to leave the United Nations if China be admitted. Even the opposition concedes that Communist China ought not be admitted until it prove itself to be "peace-loving."

The New York Stock Exchange has become a better drawing-card for sightseers than the National Archives Building in Washington, where the Constitution and the Declaration of Independence are on display. This is noted by Keith Funston, president of the Exchange, in his report for the first half of 1954 to be issued today.

McCALLEN, Tex., July 18 (UP) -- The Border Patrol confirmed today that Mexican aliens arrested in the "wetback" round-up in South Texas were forced to pay their fares to El Paso, Tex., 600 miles away.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 18 (AP) -- John B. Kelly, successfully defending his national singles sculls title, helped the Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia take team honors in the eightieth regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen today on Lake Quinsigamond.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- A new study showed today that foreign earnings in trade with this country from 1950 to 1953 were higher than during the entire period between the first and second World Wars. This was one of the findings the Department of Commerce reported in a special study of the balance of international payments between the United States and other countries from 1919 through 1953.

GENEVA, July 18 -- Vietnam's Foreign Minister today voiced his Government's objections to peace plans under consideration by the Geneva conference. These plans provide for an armistice based on the regrouping of rival forces on either side of a truce line.

The National Interchurch Foundation, a nonprofit organization with offices at 700 Marcy Avenue, Brooklyn, has started a self-help movement to build, equip and endow new hospitals in communities of more than 10,000. Though better medical care for Negroes is a primary object, the hospitals will be opened to all, regardless of race or religion.

MOSCOW, July 18 (Reuters) -- Premier Georgi Malenkov, Nikita S. Khrushchev, First Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, and other top Soviet leaders sat with a crowd estimated at 80,000 in the grandstand of Moscow's Dynamo Stadium today as Russia's picked athletes and sportsmen filed past.

An autobiographical story of life in the South Pacific by Tom and Lydia Davis will be issued Aug. 9 by Atlantic-Little, Brown, entitled "Doctor to the Islands." It tells of Tom Davis, who is part Polynesian and part Welsh, who left his home in Rarotonga in the Cook Islands to study medicine in New Zealand.

TOKYO, Monday, July 19 (AP) -- Communist China professed fear today that the Tokyo Government's plan to increase Japanese defense forces from 110,000 to 150,000 by April "poses a grave threat to Asian peace."

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 18 -- Jan van der Berg, chairman of the Parliamentary special committee on a new code of labor legislation being prepared for the next session, said in an address this week-end that all strikes should be made illegal in South Africa. Parliament closed in June and the draft labor code was returned to committee to be worked over again.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., July 18 -- The Volco Stable's Riviera Mann captured the jumper championship at the Huntington Y. M. C. A. horse show today at Rice Farms. The one-day event had 816 entries. The program required more than nine and one-half hours to complete.
Three Brooklyn residents and a Long Island man were killed in auto accidents on Long Island early yesterday.
DANBURY, Conn., July 18 -- The din originating at a firing range cut into the base of Wooster Mountain has left a group of residents up in arms -- legal arms, that is.
Self-determination for the island of Cyprus and its union with Greece were urged yesterday at the third annual convention of the Cyprus Federation of America.

TOKYO, Monday, July 19 (AP) -- Top military sources said today that the action of the United States Air Force in eliminating Japan as a possible base for atom or hydrogen bombers, had been taken as a direct result from pressure of the Japanese Government. Japan did not want atomic weapons or H-bomb carrying planes based here.
The charter market steamed through sluggish, quiet seas last week toward a fog-shrouded, uncertain future.

A Queens motorist, whose alleged driving in a wrong lane resulted in a four-car collision injuring seven persons yesterday morning, was arrested on charges of drunken driving, dangerous driving and driving without a license.

LONDON, July 18 -- The depth and vehemence of the opposition within the Labor party to rearming Germany and establishing a defense system for Southeast Asia are emphasized by resolutions prepared for the fifty-third annual party conference.
An estimated $500,000,000 was donated in New York to bring contributions to philanthropy in the United States last year to the record sum of $4,500,000,000.
The two five-story apartment houses at 1064-68 Woodycrest Avenue, in the Bronx, have been sold by the AEFS Realty Company, headed by Sol Lewis, to an investing client of Sidney Rodwin, lawyer.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Several major price moves developed on the Board of Trade last week. Early in the week there were rapid advances in corn and soybean prices. Buying was based on record high temperatures for several days over much of the corn and soybean area, there was fear that drought conditions in a large area would result in serious crop deterioration.

LENOX, Mass., July 18 -- The second week of Berkshire Festival concerts was completed this afternoon with a performance by Charles Munch and the Boston Symphony Orchestra. Leo Smit was featured as soloist in the Aaron Copland Piano Concerto.
Attending church for self-satisfaction was criticized in two sermons here yesterday morning.
Six new films, including entries from France and Mexico, are due to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

BOSTON, July 18 (AP) -- Russ Kemmerer, a 22-year-old rookie up from Louisville, pitched a one-hitter today in his first major league start for a 4-0 victory as his Boston Red Sox teammates split a double-header with Baltimore. The Orioles won the second game, 4 -- 1.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- If the President calls a special session this fall to act on sovereignty for West Germany, it would be the twenty-seventh in the 165 years since the first Congress met.
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 18 -- Income tax evasion in this country of 75,000,000 persons is the rule, and there are only 21,000 exceptions.

The dismantling of the stern section of the Cornhusker Mariner, ordered last week by Maritime Administrator Louis S. Rothschild, may not end the controversy that has surrounded the vessel for almost a year.
Concerned over the city's budget needs for 1955-56, Mayor Wagner has called upon his unsalaried advisory council for help in drafting a fiscal program for presentation to the 1955 Legislature.
CUTTACK, India, July 18 (Reuters) -- Indian monks charged into an advancing police posse today, hacked one policeman to death with swords and seriously wounded six others.
STAMFORD, Conn., July 18 -- Five firemen were injured in a spectacular blaze here this afternoon that destroyed a two-story warehouse.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (UP) -- Penal institutions in the United States -- both Federal and state -- held 172,729 inmates at the end of 1953, the Federal Bureau of Prisons reported today.

At 4:24 yesterday afternoon the Yankees, for the first time this season, owned exclusive rights to first place in the American League. Also in their possession was a thirteen-game winning streak, the longest in the majors this year.

STORRS, Conn., July 17 -- The housewife can make her job much easier by application of motion economy rules developed in industry, according to Prof. Mary Rokahr, coordinator of a home management workshop of the School of Home Economics of the University or Connecticut.
The American Civil Liberties Union asked the Federal Communications Commission yesterday not to adopt a rule requiring loyalty oaths from amateur and commercial radio operators.

LONGUE POINTE, Que., June 24 -- Besides maintaining substantial air, ground and naval forces in Europe and Korea, Canada is giving generous and effective material aid to her allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 18 (UP) -- The National Committee of the Young Democratic Clubs of America today refused to recognize a Texas delegation that bolted to vote for President Eisenhower in 1952.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Following are the votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll calls in Congress during the period July 11 through July 17.
BONN, West Germany, July 18 -- The number of fully employed workers - in West Germany reached the record of 16,500,000 on June 30.
PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (UP) -- The Chicago White Sox swept both ends of a double-header today from Philadelphia, 10-2, and 14-3, to extend the Athletics losing streak to eight.

BILBAO, Spain, July 18 -- Spanish arms manufacturers were reported today to have signed contracts with the Egyptian Government calling for the delivery of light weapons and munitions estimated to be worth $3,500,000.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were firm to strong last week and closed up 18 points, or 90 cents a bale, to 37 points, or $1.85 a bale. All active months from December onward made new highs, in the week, while the nearby October contracts equaled their previous high.

PITTSBURGH, July 18 -- The recent price increase caused hardly a ripple in the steel trade. Many users were loud in their denunciation of the yearly wage rise, but they felt that steel companies had been forced to pass on most of the increased costs. They also were cognizant that they themselves would soon be facing higher wage costs.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Organized labor is back in the foreign operations program in full strength.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 18 -- The Schenck brothers, Joseph M. and Nicholas M., have been named as recipients of the Screen Producers Guild Annual Milestone Award for their contribution to the industry. This was announced today by Arthur Freed, president of the Guild.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (UP) -- The Cleveland Indians, defeated the Washington Senators, 7 -- 4, after dropping the first game of a double-header, 8 -- 3, today.
DUBLIN, July 17 -- International fashion experts were enthusiastic over what they saw here last night and today at the fall and winter collections shown by Sybil Connolly and Irene Gilbert.

The drive by the dry forces in Washington to bar liquor advertising from interstate media, print and air, has apparently backfired. Licensed Beverage Industries, public relations organ for the industry, reports that in the last twelve months fifteen newspapers "of substantial influence and circulation" have changed their policy to accept liquor advertising.

DENVER, July 18 (UP) -- Jimmy Jackson, 31-year-old three-time Missouri amateur champion, overcame a six-hole deficit today to beat Rex Baxter, 4 and 3, and win the fifty-first Trans-Mississippi golf tournament.

LOS ANGELES, July 18 -- Competition in the eighth round of the Pan-American chess tournament at the Hollywood Athletic Club today brought about no pronounced change in the relative positions of the leaders. Victories for Nicolas Rossolimo, Arthur B. Bisguier and Larry Evans left these players in first, second and third places, respectively.
LONDON, July 18 (Reuters) -- Russia will reintroduce coeducation in Moscow, Leningrad and other cities in September, the Soviet news agency Tass reported today.
The development of a 21-inch color television tube with a picture area of 250 square inches was announced yesterday by the Radio Corporation of America. The tube will be demonstrated on Sept. 15.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 18 -- Edward H. Luckett and Arthur J. Horton, both of the New York metropolitan area, have accepted posts with the Princeton University fund. This was announced today by the executive director, George J. Cooke Jr.

CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- Bernard Bartzen of San Angelo, Tex., defeated Tony Trabert of Cincinnati, 6 -- 2, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2, today to win the national clay courts singles tennis championship at the River Forest Tennis Club.
NEWARK, July 18 (AP) -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said tonight there was no slackening in state efforts to get the full story of the financial operations of the late Gov. Harold G. Hoffman.

The dress and jacket ensemble and its numerous practical features and attractive effects has become an established staple in every woman's wardrobe. It is a seasonless style, used as frequently in winter as in summer.

LONDON, July 18 -- One very definite fact that emerges from the two-day convertibility conference just ended is that free convertibility of funds among nations is steadily becoming more likely but is still a distant goal.

At last, after years of obstruction and delay, the stock-car taxicab is cruising New York City's streets. During a trial period ending March 31, 1956, these new, shorter taxis will be permitted to compete with the familiar "jumbo" cabs that long have been the only type sanctioned by municipal law.

HANOI, Vietnam, July 18 -- A Vietminh unit, one of twelve insurgent battalions believed to be in the Hungyen area of the Red River delta, launched an attack at 4 A. M. today against part of a French-Vietnamese motorized infantry group. It was intercepted by the main body of this tank-supported group.
Two marine unions and two shipowner groups laid the ground-work here last week for an industry-wide approach to the problem of adequate pensions for ship officers.
VENICE, July 18 (Reuters) -- Australia won tonight the Grand Prix of the annual International Documentary Film Festival here with the movie "Beyond the Horizon."

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UP) -- A Government reorganization "task force" headed by Gen. Mark W. Clark may study the "security" machinery of the Central Intelligence Agency as part of its survey of the agency, an official said today.

STRATFORD, Ont., July 18 -- Tom Patterson, founder and planning director of the Stratford Shakespeare Summer Festival, confirmed a report today that he and Douglas Campbell, one of the stars here, have organized the Canadian Players, Ltd.

It took a sandhog with the bends nearly five hours to reach the relief of a recompression chamber early yesterday. He rode in a taxi, three ambulances and a police launch before he got there -- and on the way he traveled through two boroughs, across two and a half rivers and into a second state.

NEW HAVEN, July 19 -- Granger Costikyan of Purdys, N. Y., has been elected chairman of the board of directors of the Yale Alumni Fund and five new board members have been selected. This was announced today by Charles Watson 3d, managing director of the fund.
Hugh K. McGovern and David Kamerman have bought the Mills Hotel at 4817 Seventh Avenue, corner of Thirty-sixth Street, through E. M. Simon Co. and Douglas Gibbons Co., brokers.

The saying that one cannot teach an old dog new tricks is true, but it is a mistake to apply it to people, the Rev. Ernest H. Sommerfeld, guest preacher at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue and Eighteenth Street, said yesterday.

ZURICH, July 18 -- For the first time since World War II, an American loan has just been successfully issued in Switzerland. A Swiss banking consortium including all five great commercial and several private banking groups sponsored a loan for 75,000,000 francs ($17,162,500) for the International Standard Electric Corporation.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 18 -- The Indonesian economy has taken a sudden turn for the worse. Financial authorities ascribe the present situation to mismanagement, corruption and low productivity amid vanishing foreign exchange reserves.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 18 -- Inflation has hit the Asian counterpart of American chewing gum, and its effect is threatening to weaken public support of the Government. Pan leaf, indispensable wrapper for the betel nut and katha, a blood-red paste, is selling on the black market at $25 for two pounds. The controlled price is $2.25.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Senate leaders of the Administration's fight for a flexible farm price support system asserted today that they had the votes to put across President Eisenhower's program.
HEWLETT, L. I., July 18 -- Tim Holland of the Rockville Country Club won the Long Island amateur golf crown today for the first time.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $77,778,074,652. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
The country is going to the dogs and cats and this means big business for the pet care and accessories industries, according to a manufacturer of pet supplies.
Bids will be invited in the fall for the long-discussed passenger conveyor belt to link Times Square with Grand Central Terminal in place of the thirty-six-year-old subway shuttle trains.
CINCINNATI, July 18 -- Something new has been added to the National League pennant race and today the Giants ran right smack into it.

Directors of Ebasco Services, Inc., engineering, construction and business consulting subsidiary of the Electric Bond and Share Company, have elected Frederick C. Gardner as president and chief executive officer, and T. C. Wescott as vice chairman of the board. Mr. Gardner has been with Ebasco or its associated companies since college graduation in 1917, when he became a draftsman on investigation of hydro-electric power sites in North Carolina.

NEW DELHI, India, July 18 -- The All-India Congress Committee, highest policy-making body of the ruling Congress party, will hold a three-day session in the city of Ajmer, 215 miles southwest of New Delhi, starting Friday. The committee will review the progress of economic reforms in the country and also take stock of the international situation.
The plan to rehabilitate the Long Island Rail Road was hailed yesterday as a constructive development that will benefit the public.

MILWAUKEE, July 18 (UP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates made a six-run second inning stand up for a 7-5 victory over the Milwaukee Braves in the second game of a double-header today. The Braves took the first game, 4 -- 1, on thee three-hit, pitching of Warren Spahn.

This is the third and final article of a series of three dealing with world economic trends between April, 1953, and March, 1954, as seen and interpreted by the economic staff of the Bank for International Settlements. It will confine itself to the high-lights of the bank's observations in the field of foreign exchange.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Republican leadership of the Senate decided today not to back down in its fight to pass the Administration's atomic energy bill.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 -- Hawaii is as typical of the "American way" of eating as are any of the forty-eight states.

The distinctive mark of a Christian marriage, said Dean James A. Pike in a sermon yesterday morning at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine), "is not simply that the marriage was performed in a Christian church."
The Brazilian Senate has rejected a cultural pact with Spain that would have required history textbooks used in Brazil to have the approval of the Franco Government.
Geared to the dormitory needs of the Greek key aspirant is a new group of ready-made ensembles called "Perfect Room Mates," which is offered today at Macy's.

ST. LOUIS, July 18 (AP) -- Incensed by delaying tactics of the St. Louis Cardinals in the fifth inning, the umpires forfeited the second game of a double-header to the Philadelphia Phillies, 9 -- 0, today. The Phils had rallied three times and captured the opener, 11 -- 10, on Bobby Morgan's single in the tenth inning.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UP) -- Representative Lester Holtzman, Democrat of New York, complained today that "political assassins" were trying to "smear" him out of his seat in Congress because of his part in the so-called "Peress case."

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- More than 524 business loans totaling $30,896,262 have been approved by the Small Business Administration since the agency began receiving applications last October, it was announced today.

THIS is the season for center fielders. It's the most talked about position in the business. Willie Mays started it and arguments have grown intense as to whether he's the best of the current crop or whether that distinction more properly belongs to Duke Snider or Mickey Mantle. And from outlying precincts have come vehement claims for Gus Bell, Larry Doby and Jim Busby.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 (UP) -- A truck driver was arrested today as a suspect in the theft of a "priceless" miniature painting which the director of the De Young Museum said was the work of the Flemish master Peter Paul Rubens.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The Government has been making about $50,000,000 a year turning out syntheic rubber for automobile tires, Congress was told today.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 18 -- The five-year trade agreement, beginning in 1956, that was signed Saturday in Moscow by Finland's Foreign Minister Urho K. Kekkonen and Sergei A. Borisov, Soviet Deputy Minister for Foreign Trade, signifies a slow but continuous increase in Finnish trade with the Soviet Union.
A scarcity of the type of hard lumber needed for the construction of fire truck ladders has compelled the Fire Department to switch over to reliance in part on metal ladders.

It will never be quite as much fun to ride through the tunnel from Times Square to Grand Central or from Grand Central to Times Square as it might be to go for a sleigh ride in Vermont. Even though the shuttle trains had bells that really jingled the pleasures of the journey would be mild indeed.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 (AP) -- A 350-year-old Rubens painting, stolen Saturday from a museum, was recovered undamaged today from the home of an unemployed teamster who had been arrested on suspicion of the theft.

TWO handsome athletes enter the ring at Madison Square Garden. The one in this corner with the crew haircut and the pink trunks is Mortimer J. Hammersmith of the Southampton Hammersmiths. He smiles pleasantly at his rival, Percy K. Sockdolager, the white silk-trunked Vassar Professor of Home Economics for whom the manly art of self-defense, begun as a hobby, has become a necessity.

PITTSBURGH, July 19 (AP) -Hubbard Co., a 111-year-old Pittsburgh hardware company, today announced sale of all its outstanding stock to Charles H. Dyson, a former textile executive of New York, and associates.
PHILADELPHIA, July 19 -- Efforts to end the six-day shutdown in the Port of Philadelphia area were stymied today by a new dispute.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 19 -- A United Nations safari, heavily armed with pencils and pads, will take off tomorrow for East Africa.
Sunbury is a community of fewer than 16,000 persons in eastcentral Pennsylvania, on the Susquehanna River, thirty miles southwest of Williamsport.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 19 -- Dr. Ali Amini, Finance Minister, said tonight that the amount of compensation to be paid by Iran to the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company as a result of the nationalization of its properties would be determined in "four more negotiating sessions."
WASHINGTON, July 19 (UP) -- Premier Pierre MendesFrance thanked the United States today for airlifting 500 wounded French Union forces from Indochina to France.

Commodity prices closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cottonseed and soybean oils reached new seasonal highs. Wool, cocoa, potatoes, hides and tin also rose; coffee and rubber declined, and sugar and zinc closed mixed.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Senator John L. McClellan of Arkansas has given two proxies to his Democratic colleagues on the to McCarthy subcommittee for tomorrow's session of a staff clean-up.
DETROIT, July 19 (AP) -- The Michigan Consolidated Gas Company said today it had returned to Panhandle Eastern a check for $2,238,000 sent as a partial refund.
LONDON, July 19 -- The care of the aged is a major social problem, Iain Macleod, British Minister of Health, said today.
