HAVERFORD, Pa., July 19 (AP) -- Louise Brough, top-seeded, and Mrs. Margaret Osborne du Pont, ranked second, overpowered their first two opponents today to gain the third round of the fiftyfourth annual Pennsylvania and Eastern States women's grass court tennis championship at the Merion Cricket Club.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., the nation's largest manufacturers of chemicals, lifted earnings 33 per cent in the first six months of this year. The company cleared $3.22 a common share, compared with $2.41 a share in the initial half of last year, despite an 8 per cent decline in sales.

A busload of gaily chattering sightseers had an advantage here yesterday other touring visitors lack. Their talk did not disturb the bus driver, and they could communicate at considerable distance despite the thundering of a Coney Island calliope.
A $14,000,000 underwater telephone cable from Washington State to Ketchikan, Alaska, is proposed.

Newport News, Va., borrowed $2,500,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of water bonds maturing serially from 1955 to 1974 at an interest cost of 2.15 per cent. The bonds were sold at public sealed bidding to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc, The bid was 100.24 for obligations bearing interest of 2.15 per cent.

The vogue for bouffant petticoats "has been a lifesaver to large segments of our industry," Louis Stulberg, vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, says in Justice, the union publication.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Joe Jones made an auspicious return to the races at Monmouth Park today by sprinting to an easy victory in the Balko Purse.
RANGOON, Burma, July 19 -- Premier U Nu declared today the British-United States and Chinese-Soviet power blocs were heading for a catastrophic war.

RICHWOOD, W. Va., July 19 (UP) -- Flash floods caused by a fourteen - hour downpour sent rivers and streams on the rampage in central West Virginia today, driving some 500 families from their homes, causing at least one death and flooding two hospitals.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Export-Import Bank of Washington said today that it would help finance the sale of a thermal electric unit to a Spanish power company.

JUNEAU, Alaska, July 17 -Salmon canneries, scattered along 15,000 miles of Alaska coastline, are turning out their 1954 product. Leaders of the traditionally greatest industry in the territory scanned their reports anxiously as they recalled the most disastrous season on record -- one year ago.

Said the President of the United States to the Governor of South Dakota: "I refuse to use anything but dry flies. I want fishing to be a challenge." This challenging statement, which baited fishermen from the bass lakes of Maine to the trout streams of California, is an example of the Great Debate that is now overheating the fresh waters of the country.
THE surfcasting improved considerably over the weekend and yesterday on eastern Long Island, with the beach and jetty fishermen picking up plenty of big blues and an unusual number of stripers.

GENEVA, July 19 -- Midnight tomorrow is the hour of decision for Pierre Mendes-France, who took office as French Premier June 18 with the promise that he would get an armistice in Indochina by July 20 or resign.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- President Eisenhower signed today a bill authorizing him to appoint to the grade of full general eleven Army officers who attained the rank of lieutenant general in World War II. Three of the officers are dead, and the others are retired.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that the United States would not sign an Indochinese peace settlement. But he said the United States would not do anything to upset a reasonable settlement sought by France.
Twenty-six persons, including eighteen Manhattan and Brooklyn lawyers, face arrest within the next two weeks as a result of a grand jury investigation into ambulance chasing.
LOS ANGELES, July 19 -Nicolas Rossolimo and Arthur B. Bisguier were defeated for the first time today in the ninth round of the Pan American chess tournament at the Hollywood Athletic Club.

The growing shortage of teachers is a topic for grave consideration among our top educational administrators. These officials may have overlooked one important source of highly qualified teachers. I am told there is a rule which prevents the reinstatement of a regularly appointed teacher if she or he resigned more than ten years ago.
Four dairy organizations in the New York milkshed have been qualified to receive monthly service payments from the New York Milk Pool.

BERLIN, July 19 -- In his first official act since his re-election as President of West Germany, Dr. Theodor Heuss paid tribute today to those who ten years ago sought to assassinate Hitler and stop World War II.

Richard H. Balch, Democratic state chairman, announced yesterday the appointment of Thomas K. Finletter of New York as chairman of the platform committee for the Democratic state convention to be held here Sept. 21 and 22. Mr. Finletter, a lawyer, was Secretary of Air under former President Harry S. Truman.

BERLIN, July 19 -- The possibilities of a solution of the Indochina crisis in Geneva tomorrow can open the way for the proposed talks among the signatories of the European Defense Community treaty, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said tonight.
HALIFAX, N. S., June .26 -- In any future war the Royal Canadian Navy would have an important part to play in the protection of convoys and the defense of the coasts of Canada and the United States.
ST. LOUIS, July 19 (UP) -- Red Schoendienst and Stan Musial drove in two runs apiece tonight to lead the St. Louis Cardinals to a 5-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.
Roy M. Cohn has resigned as the chief counsel of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

Pep, spelled with capital letters and periods, thus: P. E. P., will be the theme of an intensive commercial cooking sales campaign being planned by the American Gas Association for September, October and November.
One teen-ager was killed and four injured yesterday as nine youths in two stolen cars led an off-duty patrolman in a seventymile-an-hour chase on the Harlem River Speedway, the police reported.

Today's new film is "Mexican Bus Ride," ("Subida Al Cielo") a Mexican import at the Fifth Avenue Cinema. The comedy's cast is headed by Lilia Prado, Estaban Marquez, Carmen Gonzalez and Leonor Gomez. Luis Castaneda and Manuel Donde head the supporting cast.
GUATEMALA, July 19 -- A national committee met last night to reorganize Guatemala's labor movement, which had been under Communist leadership. Fourteen unions were represented on the committee.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -Senate investigators heard today that four builders of an Ohio military housing project had cleared nearly a million dollars, but had delayed a distribution of their profit to await tax decisions by the Internal Revenue Service.

The American-Korean Foundation will be the beneficiary of the premiere showing of the motion picture, "Rear Window," on the night of Aug. 4 at the Rivoli Theatre. Mrs. Wendell L. Willkie, Mrs. Henry C. Alexander and Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel head the benefit committee.

There may have been a few raised eyebrows yesterday afternoon when Staten Island ferryboat riders saw the superliner United States make a right turn near Robbins Reef, in the upper bay. However, the queen of the American merchant marine, was not off her course; she was merely headed for Bayonne, N. J., and a date at the "beauty parlor."

Today is the day which is supposed to decide whether the one remaining armed conflict resulting from the upheavals of the Second World War is to end in an armistice in Indochina or whether that conflict must continue at the risk of spreading beyond its present confines and raising new perils to world peace.

Allie Reynolds, ace right-hander, spun a three-hitter for his tenth straight victory of the season yesterday as the Yankees clubbed the Detroit Tigers, 8 -- 0, at the Stadium. Since the Cleveland Indians halted the Washington Senators, the Yanks remained a half-game back of the pace-setting Tribe.
LONDON, July 19 -- The first prototype of the Comet III, first jet airliner with a capacity to fly the London-New York route commercially, made its maiden flight today.
Representative Herbert B. Warburton, Republican candidate in Delaware for the United States Senate, proposed yesterday that foreign aid be used to bolster American industries in need of orders.
Dates were set yesterday for tryouts of two plays scheduled for Broadway this season under the sponsorship of Morton Gottlieb and Albert Selden.
Conn McCreary gave an excellent exhibition of his noted comefrom-behind style of riding to guide Lavender Hill to victory at the Jamaica Race Track yesterday.

A young business executive, transferred from Akron to his concern's New York office, put his name down for a $300 donation when the cards were passed around in the annual campaign of the Greater New York Fund.
WASHINGTON, July, 19 (AP) -The Air Force announced today that Lowry Field at Denver, Colo., would be the temporary location of the new Air Academy.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 19 -- The press hailed today the Government's rejection of a Soviet note asking Iran to promise not to enter Western-arranged regional security pacts.

Famous for summer resorts, the Catskills also are the source of some of the finest cauliflower that comes to town. As shipments from that area are increasing, the price of the vegetable is expected to decline. But even now cauliflower is a good buy.
CHICAGO, July 19 -- It may have been the Russian version of "beisbol" the Dodgers were playing against the Cubs at Wrigley Field today. Certainly it bore scant resemblance to a major league game.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy conducted a public hearing on Communist infiltration of defense plants today.

The Kimberly-Clark Corporation and its subsidiaries attained the highest sales in its eightyone-year history in the fiscal year ended April 30, and increased earnings 18.8 per cent over the previous fiscal year.

STANFORD UNIVERSITY, Calif., July 19 (AP) -- Americans might just as well get used to innovation and social readjustment, as they are "likely to characterize the American society for the foreseeable future."

Commercial exports by the United States this year -- exclusive of military aid -- should approximate $12,500,000,000, the National Foreign Trade Council estimated yesterday. This would mark a "slight gain" of about $100,000,000 over last year, it was noted.

GENEVA, July 19 -- Communist demands that indigenous Communist-led guerrillas in Laos and Cambodia be allowed to occupy zones in the two states represented a major last-minute obstacle tonight to an Indochina settlement.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., July 19 -- Tony Kaczenski, Westhampton Country Club professional, held two parts of a three-way tie in the amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island Professional Golfers Association today.
CHICAGO, July 19 -- Prices for all futures except wheat soared on the Board of Trade today, as a result of three days more of searing heat over much of the corn and soybean areas.

A news article and a letter to the editor have recently dealt with the problem of real estate taxes imposed by New York City on property owned by foreign Governments and used primarily for their delegations to the United Nations and their staffs.

A $502,530 budgetary load of fifty-one new non-Civil Service jobs created since Jan. 1 is complicating Mayor Wagner's quest for a satisfactory fiscal program to present to the 1955 session of the Legislature.
Your editorial in the issue of June 28 "Scientific Manpower" is in complete agreement with the basic policy of the National Association of Manufacturers on this question.
Birch beer, which the Amish and Mennonites in Pennsylvania Dutch country savored long before the more popular soft drinks existed, now is available here in commercially bottled form.

MEXICO CITY, July 19 -- A clean-up of all Communists holding public office has been demanded of the Government in the wake of its dismissal of Dr. Andres Iduarte as director of the National Institute of Fine Arts.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short term borrowing costs are continuing an upward trend begun six weeks ago.

MILWAUKEE, July 19 (UP) -Jim Wilson limited the Pittsburgh Pirates to three hits tonight for his seventh victory of the year without a loss and the Milwaukee Braves won, 4 -- 1, before a crowd of 23,281.

BERLIN, July 19 -- With republication of news in the Communist press that the two top East German leaders were in Moscow, there was renewed speculations today that the Soviet Union might soon make a new move in Germany.

LONDON, July 19 -- Industrials were again dull on the stock markets here today. Losses of one shilling sixpence (21 1/2 cents) or more were common among the leaders. Profit taking laid to the end of the bookkeeping account was held to be a cause of the decline.

BOSTON, July 19 (AP) -- Mickey Owen capped a six-run, ninth inning Boston rally with a grand-slam homer in the first game today as the Red Sox employed a home run barrage to sweep a doubleheader from the Baltimore Orioles, 9 -- 7 and 8 -- 5.

A single unusual color has been used in each of the refurbished model rooms now on view on the fifth floor at Bloomingdale's. The decorator, Henriette Granville, has added emphasis with contrasting bright pillows and out-of-the-ordinary accessories.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- Easing of United States regulations to enable Japanese war criminals serving terms of more than thirty years to become eligible for parole after ten years became effective July 12 with the approval of President Eisenhower.

New York department store business continues to show strength. Last week's sales were 5 per cent ahead of those of a year earlier, according to the "flash" report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the four weeks ended on Saturday, sales were 1 per cent heavier than in the same period of 1953.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -Strong anti-Semitism still exists beneath the surface among the German people, even though the West German Government has made democratic strides, according to the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (UP) -The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today a bill to authorize return of millions of dollars worth of alien property seized in World War II to former owners.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -Democratic Senators, rallying behind a proposal to censure Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, caused a postponement of a vote until July 30 when the chances for success were deemed better. The vote had been scheduled for tomorrow.
Al Andrews of Superior, Wis., gained a unanimous decision over Sauveur Chiocca of France in the ten-round feature bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 -- A musical version of "Peter Pan" - co-starring Mary Martin and Cyril Ritchard -- had its world premiere at the Curran Theatre here tonight. The performance was given under the auspices of the San Francisco Civic Light Opera Association.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., July 19 -Barbara Bruning of White Plains, the New York State champion, became a strong favorite in the Women's Tri-County Golf Association Championship by carding a one-over-men's-par 73 in the qualifying round today at the Leewood Country Club. Sixty players competed for sixteen places.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The State Department said today it had made "inquiries" in Madrid about Spanish exports of arms to Egypt and other countries. It expressed "concern" that these exports might be contrary to the provisions of the United States-Spanish military aid agreement.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 19 -- The patterns that will lead to Larchmont race week class championships and the trinkets that go with them began to emerge more clearly today at the end of the third regatta.

Trimly tailored Bermuda shorts, neat blazers, smooth flannels and bulky tweeds all contrived to give an "Ivy League" menswear look to the fashions shown yesterday at the opening of Abraham Straus' college shop.
Showers pelted New York last night, causing flash floods in parts of the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. At the same time, blistering heat continued to sear much of the rest of the country.

Anthony A. Klein, the blind newsdealer whose stand at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street was burned out last Friday, was back in business yesterday. He was not only selling newspapers, but also directing sighted persons to places in the neighborhood in the manner of newsdealers everywhere.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Ezra Taft Benson, the Secretary of Agriculture, indicated today that price supports on the 1955 wheat crop would not be set at less than 80 per cent of parity, whatever Congress did about the farm bill.

Fear that the Eisenhower Administration was substituting "massive appeasement" for its old doctrine of "massive retaliation" was expressed yesterday by George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UP) -- President Eisenhower called today for a floor fight in the House of Representatives to restore part of the 40 per cent cut the Appropriations Committee made in his $2,000,000,000 supplemental money request last week.

ST. LOUIS, July 19 (AP) -- Manager Eddie Stanky of St. Louis was suspended today pending a hearing here tomorrow on a free-for-all between his Cardinals and the Philadelphia Phils last night in a game which was forfeited to the Phils.

The Iranian Government of General Zahedi, ably assisted by Foreign Minister Entezam, is doing some straight thinking and straight talking. A Soviet note that protested against even the possibility that Iran might become associated with the TurkishPakistani entente has been rejected in firm terms.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Senate Finance Committee today voted to liberalize old-age benefits under the Social Security law and extend its coverage to more than 6,000,000 additional persons.
CLEVELAND, July 19 -- A committee of churchmen late today recommended New York as the headquarters city for the National Council of Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.

CALLANDER, Ont., July 19 (AP) -- Poor health, loss of appetite and extreme homesickness were the reasons Marie Dionne, one of Canada's quintuplets, left the Quebec convent she entered only last fall, she said today.

Observers of the Latin-American scene find it difficult to reconcile the United States people's obvious preference for constitutional democratic government with the readiness of their State Department to grant diplomatic recognition to new revolutionary dictatorships in the Western Hemisphere.
Two appointments to West Coast positions were announced yesterday by Emmet J. McCormack, chairman of the board of the Moore-McCormack Lines.

The total blackouts which shrouded large cities during the Second World War are, apparently, to be no more. The Civil Defense Administration and the Defense Department have evolved a "sky glow control" plan which will permit persons living in our cities to have almost normal lighting even in emergency conditions.
A strike set for midnight by 35,000 unionized employes at nineteen plants of the United States Rubber Company was postponed last night two hours before its deadline.
The director of one of television's most widely acclaimed summer programs -- by critics and lay viewers alike -- has resigned after two performances.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Miss Waurine Walker, newly elected president of the National Education Association, was in Washington today to press for approval of bills for a two-year, $250,000,000 - a - year emergency school building program.
An audience of 11,000, by refusing to be routed by the menace of a thunderstorm, saved the annual Gershwin concert last night at Lewisohn Stadium.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 19 (AP) -- An awkward situation involving the national open champion, Ed Furgol, and Cary Middlecoff arose today as leading links teachers and tourists gathered for the thirty-sixth Professional Golfers Association championship.
The active ocean-going United States merchant fleet lost nine ships last month and, as of July 1, consisted of 1,359 vessels of 1,000 gross tons and over, the Federal Maritime Board has reported.

Mayor Wagner called upon the Public Service Commission yesterday to deny the application of the New York Telephone Company for increases in subscribers' rates. He said the increase would net the company $68,850,000 a year.

PARIS, July 19 -- Starting the autumn hat parade today, Janette reversed the forward trend of summer by berets, cloches and snugly draped turbans uncovering the hairline but moving down onto the nape.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -President Eisenhower is not ready to decide whether lead and zinc tariffs should be raised.
Redeployment of, and major reductions in, Army strength in the Far East are planned as part of the present fiscal year's streamlining of the armed forces to accord with a reduced defense budget.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 19 -- Robert Anderson's drama "Tea and Sympathy," now playing its tenth month on Broadway, will be brought to the screen next year by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

Vincent Cronin, son of the novelist A. J. Cronin, will have his first work published by Dutton on Aug. 5. Entitled "The Golden Honeycomb," it is an account of the author's search of Sicily for the legendary Golden Honeycomb fashioned by Daedalus.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The House of Representatives passed and sent to the White House today a bill to force subversive organizations to provide the Government with a list of their printing machinery.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -Harold E. Stassen defended the Foreign Operations Administration, which he heads, as faithful to the letter and spirit of the law, during a long questioning session with Senators today. But he was quoted as conceding that "mistakes had been made."
Chris Christensen of Copenhagen outboxed Billy Graham of New York's East Side last night in the feature bout of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn.

Prices of cotton futures yesterday opened 2 points higher to 2 points lower than last Friday's close on the New York Cotton Exchange. They turned strong, closing at about the best levels of the day, with gains of 8 to 24 points net.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 -Marriner S. Eccles, former Chairman of the Federal Reserve System, asked today for reduction of taxes to increase consumer purchasing power. He urged a debt-management program to increase commercial bank holdings of Government securities, and continuation of an "easy money" policy by the Reserve to supplement these programs.

OSLO, July 14 -- The Oslo-Bergen State Railway and the post-Neanderthal groups of statuary in Frogner Park in this capital are as representative of Norway as are the tumbling mountain masses, the deep valleys and the mighty fiords. For this is a powerful land, inhabited by a powerful breed, and its massive monuments are fitting in tone and proportion.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 18 -- The answer to a question diplomats have been asking each other at the United Nations is at No. 2 Luquer Road here.
A Fire Department inspector of refrigeration and air conditioning equipment admitted yesterday that he split fees with a fellow-fireman whom he had placed in private jobs as a licensed supervisor.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -A pinch single by Dale Mitchell drove home the run that gave the Cleveland Indians a 4-3 victory over the Washington Senators today, preserving the Indians' half-game lead over the New York Yankees in the American League pennant chase.

MACKINAW CITY, Mich., July 19 -- A rectangular steel box resembling an oversized furnace boiler, with twenty-one openings and weighing several hundred tons, was towed up Lake Huron last Friday by two tugs.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Austria got its first loan today from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

As they had done on Friday, aircrafts dominated yesterday's stock market, Douglas and Boeing pushing ahead to new 1954 highs. The rest of the market did not follow their lead, however, and the close was lower. Steels, oils and chemicals were particularly weak.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The "top would have blown off the Capitol" if President Truman had proposed what President Eisenhower has directed the Atomic Energy Commission to do in the field of private power, a Democratic Senator asserted today.

HANOI, Vietnam, July 19 -- A tank-supported French Union force of About 5,000 men started another mopping-up operation yesterday against Vietminh infiltrators less than twenty-five miles northwest of Hanoi.
Pan American World Airways has ordered a fleet of fifteen high-speed, intercontinental airliners capable of flying nonstop well over 5,000 miles.

CINCINNATI, July 19 -- Harry Perkowski, a long and lean Cincinnati left-hander with a record this year of only one victory against seven defeats, shut out the Giants with three hits through twelve innings tonight.

ITHACA, N. Y., July 19 -- College dormitory directors from all over the United States were urged today to prepare for a large rush of students expected between 1960 and 1970. This would be the result of high World War II birth rates.

A new issue of $40,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds of Consolidated Gas Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore will be placed on the market today by a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a price to yield 2.97 per cent.

Week - end influences making for easier conditions in the New York money market were intensified yesterday with the result that the lending rate on free balances in the Federal Reserve Bank declined to a range of one-quarter of 1 per cent to fiveeighths of 1 per cent, compared with a range of from threefourths of 1 per cent to 1 1/2 per cent.

Victory by the entire administration ticket in the election of officers of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., was announced here last night by George J. Abrams, executive director of the Honest Ballot Association, after counting of the votes had been completed.
In the Indian summer of a sixty-nine-year career in racing, James (Sunny Jim) Fitzsimmons still begins his labors at sun-up. They end near nightfall.

TRENTON, July 19 -- The specific rules of civil courts will not govern the quasi-judicial public hearings to be held here next month for the four state officials suspended in the investigation into the activities of former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman. The hearings will open on Aug. 16.
SEOUL, Korea, July 19 -- Since the return of Premier Y. T. Pyun from the Geneva conference the Korean press has become increasingly critical of the Korean armistice agreement.

The Rev. William Howard Melish, acting minister of the Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church of Brooklyn, testified yesterday that he had not known during the Nineteen-Forties that Alexander Trachtenberg, later to be convicted as a secondary Communist leader, was a member of the Communist party.
ROME, July 19 -- The Roman collections got under way this morning on a high note. Ferdinandi was the first house to show.
Some automobile producers appear to be emerging from their time of travail.

OTTAWA, July 19 -- Canada indicated today her willingness to serve with India and Poland on an Indochinese armistice commission. She is not prepared, however, to enforce any armistice settlement, because present commitments under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the United Nations have stretched the country's resources to the limit.

Because soil conditions in California are similar to those in the Canary Islands, Enrique Fernandez Caldas is happy that he is going to spend a year studying soil science at the University of California.

As a long-time worker with youth I would normally go along with the attitude expressed by Chester A. Smith in a letter published in your issue of July 16, criticizing the Texas millionaires, Messrs. Richardson and Murchison, for their plan to operate race tracks and utilize their profits to finance youth work.

Until the spring of 1954 the authority of the Commodity Credit Corporation to purchase and lend upon surplus farm commodities was limited to a total of $6,750 millions. With surpluses backing up on the Government at a record rate, however, it was necessary to increase that ceiling to $8,500 millions.

A MAN of selective candor Called Walter Savage Landor Said: "Nature I loved, and, next to Nature, Art." (All the more tidily, no doubt, by keeping them apart.) If such distinctions do not trouble you, I think you will enjoy reading a fine new book called "Nature Parade,"* By Lane, Frank W. It's a sort of animal who's who And a true Zoo.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -A Panhandle Eastern Pipeline Company official said today the concern had made partial refunds of about $14,500,000 to gas utility companies in six states.
GENEVA, Tuesday, July 20 -Communist China suddenly put forward last night a demand that the United States join in guaranteeing the proposed Indochina armistice and political settlement.
CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
People and wares from Afyonkarahisar and Mus, from Ankara and Urfa, from Istanbul and Zonguldak, arrived here yesterday on the Turkish liner Tarsus.

J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., announced yesterday plans to realign its manufacturing and sales organizations. Effective Aug. 1, the textile manufacturing company will form four separate operating divisions, each under the direction of a divisional head, with co-ordinated manufacturing and selling organizations.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Proofs of growing strength in the economy is apparent in reports from nearly all branches of industry and commerce this year, Walter Willims, Under Secretary of Commerce, said today.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- An injunction preventing the National Labor Relations Board from decertifying the Fur and Leather Workers International Union as a collective bargaining agency entitled to use its facilities was issued today.

The only valid explanation of Roy Cohn's resignation as chief counsel of the McCarthy committee is that he wished to beat the gun to avoid a certain dismissal. Mr. Cohn liked the job well enough. Senator McCarthy wanted him to keep it. If he has re-signed it is because, with Senator Potter swinging over to the Democrats on this issue, a majority of the committee was prepared to fire him.

The Greeks have a name for Walter E. Packard, the lively, 70-year-old American who has just returned from six years of helping Greece to develop her agricultural capacities. The name is Indoxi Pami, and it means, roughly translated, "O. K., let's go !"
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- After the loss of northern Vietnam, the non-Communist world's next line of defense in Southeast Asia is Thailand.
GENEVA, Wednesday, July 21 -- Armistice agreements bringing the fighting in Vietnam and Laos to a halt were signed this morning by representatives of the French and Communist Vietminh forces.
PHILADELPHIA, July 20 -- The shutdown of the Port of Philadelphia ended its first week tonight with the union and employers further apart than ever.

CLEVELAND, July 20 (AP) -- Huge stockpiles of iron ore had Cleveland shipping concerns -- which control about 80 per cent of the Great Lakes fleet -- talking today about tieing up ships by mid-November, a month earlier than usual.
The Rev. William Howard Melish expanded yesterday on testimony he gave last week that "under certain qualified circumstances" Christian could be a Communist.
CHICAGO, July 20 (UP) -- A man-killing heat wave threatened a farm disaster in the Midwest today.
HOPEWELL JUNCTION, N. Y., July 20 (AP) -- A 13-year-old boy trapped waist deep in a well cave-in for more than seven hours was rescued unhurt today.
Louis A. Wehle has resigned as state chairman of the March of Dimes after a disagreement with the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis over fund-raising, it was learned yesterday.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 20 (AP) -- Hal Adam, a 4-year-old bay gelding owned by Dayton Benham of Scottsboro, Ala., and driven by Sanders Russell, won the featured mile pace in 2:06 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The House of Representatives voted tentatively today to restore $93,569,449 of the $765,770,188 its Appropriations Committee had cut from $1,959,958,267 of supplemental funds asked by the Administration.
LONDON, July 20 (Reuters) -- Marshal Enver Hoxha, Communist leader of Albania, has relinguished the post of Premier that he has held for ten years, the official Albanian news agency reported tonight.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 20 (UP) -- Alfred Roberts' Piping Arms, with Willie Hartack up, scampered to a one-and-one-half-length victory over T. F. Corcoran's Stepper Upper today in the $6,000 Five Boroughs Purse at Monmouth Park.

LONDON, July 20 -- Italy has approved the major points in the United States - British proposals for a settlement of the Trieste dispute, competent sources here say. Only minor issues are said to remain between Italy and Yugoslavia.

An exhibition at the New York Historical Society of water-colors of New York City churches does not merely give us a new look at some of the houses of worship most familiar in their monotone of brown stone or gray.

CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- Butcher hogs dropped 25 to fully 50 cents on the livestock market today, the top at $23.50 equaling the low for the year set on June 17. Sows were steady to 25 cents down. Lower prices were posted despite the fact salable receipts at 7,500 head were 1,500 below the advance estimate.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20 (UP) -- The seventh-seeded Jack Frost was an early casualty in the Pennsylvania state grass court tournament today as the defending champion, Vic Seixas, and the second-favored Art Larsen moved into the third round.
The first unit of the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center, closely related to the budding Albert Einstein College of Medicine, will open late this summer or by early fall.

The American Heart Association announced yesterday the winners of its $500 Howard W. Blakeslee awards. Dr. H. M. Marvin, chairman of the awards committee, listed the following: Cathy Covert, medical writer, and Arthur Cornelius, chief photographer of The Syracuse Herald- Journal, for a series on heart diseases.
Plans were filed yesterday for the thirty-one-story office building project announced recently by Joseph E. Seagram Son, distillers, at 375 Park Avenue. The cost was estimated at $10,000,000.

Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams presented certificates and excellent police duty citations yesterday to those members of the force who had suggested methods of increasing efficiency under the Commissioner's "Operation Efficiency" program.

Since the beginning of July 800 members of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., have instructed the Transit Authority to stop checking off their union dues while 300 other transit omployes have authorized checkoffs.
The action of Mr. Stassen, Director of the Foreign Operations Administration, in re-establishing the F. O. A. Office of Labor Affairs is most welcome -- for several reasons.

The National Academy of Design, one of twelve leading art organizations comprising the Committee of Government and Art, declined yesterday to approve a report submitted by the committee to President Eisenhower proposing drastic revisions in Government art policy and practice.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- A labor subcommittee of the House of Representatives asserted today that business ventures operated by rich unions or union leaders might turn collective bargaining with employers into "an empty farce."
The Communists have scored another major victory in the struggle for the world with a cease-fire attained in the Indo-chinese war.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 20 -- The Bowaters Southern Paper Corporation's new mill at near-by Calhoun delivered its first newsprint manufactured from Southern pine to customers in this area today.

The nation's biggest cigarette manufacturer, the American Tobacco Company, Inc., achieved a slight gain in net income in the second quarter this year. But earnings of the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company, which vies with the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company for second place, dipped slightly.

About 800,000 men are in the battle lines in Indochina -- 300,000 in the Communist ranks. The number who gave their lives -- Frenchmen, others in the Foreign Legion, Vietnamese non-Communists, Vietminh Communists -- must be close to 300,000, more than two-thirds of them on the Communist side.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A modified version of the Administration's bill for expanding and liberalizing the Social Security System was approved today by the Senate Finance Committee.

HANOI, Vietnam, July 20 -- Two kinds of preparations were being made here to cope with problems related to the surrender of North Vietnam to the Vietminh under a cease-fire. Hanoi will eventually be taken over by the Vietminh under a truce agreement.

The Bulova Watch Company, Inc., has completed arrangements for long-term financing aggregating $8,000,000. The money will be used to carry out expansion and diversification of consumer goods production.

LONDON, July 20 -- The difficult lives and often miserable deaths of the world's aged persons were analyzed and reassessed by 600 relatively youthful delegates at today's session of the International Congress of Gerontology here.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- President Eisenhower's evolving formula for dealing with bedrock politics -- the individual candidate and his problems -- took a new turn today.
Detective Margaret M. Leonard, cited three times for police work in combating narcotics rings, applied for retirement yesterday. She said she wanted to devote her time to her three grandchildren.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The State Department confirmed today reports that one of the eleven church men from Czechoslovakia and Hungary to be admitted to this country to attend Protestant meetings within the next few weeks would be much more sharply restricted than the other visitors.
Negotiations between the shipyard workers' union and the Bethlehem Steel Company resumed yesterday, under the auspices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.
The head of the Fund for the Republic, Inc., accused the chairman of a Congressional committee yesterday of slander for implying the Fund was subversive.

THE men who nurse the city's 2,820,000 trees are in a sweat over the second year of drought in New York. Trees are dying in greater numbers than they have ever known, and there is not too much they can do about it.
CHICAGO, July 20 -- Reflecting unfavorable crop news, corn and soybean futures again registered big gains today.

PARIS, July 20 -- The terms of agreement for the truce in Indochina were regarded here as presaging a peace without victory. Some called it a peace that would confirm a defeat for the West in Asia and would mark the most notable loss in battle of French territories since Louis XV lost Canada in the eighteenth century.

LONDON, July 20 -- A late rally on news from the Geneva conference steadied the stock markets today after prices had drifted downward all day. The net result was that small losses pre-dominated in nearly all groups, including Government funds.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -A New York builder testified today that Clyde L. Powell was facing the political axe even before his connection with alleged irregularities in the Federal Housing Administration was made public.

JERSEY CITY, July 20 -- There was no sign of a rift in the city administration here today as Mayor Bernard F. Berry and the three other City Commissioners elected Hudson County Freeholder Joseph Soriero to succeed the late Commissioner Frank Hague Eggers as Director of Public Works.
A meeting between wool fabric manufacturers and Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks, scheduled for July 28, has been postponed. It will be held in late September, but no definite date has been set.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The plans of Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, for a careful study of the Food and Drug Administration appear to have been killed for this year.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- President Eisenhower received today a portrait of himself painted by the late Sir Oswald Birley, British artist.

Three new awards have been offered by the National Federation of Music Clubs for its twenty-first biennial Young Artist Auditions, which will take place next spring. One award, offered in conjunction with Inter-Allied Artists Corporation, is open to an American-born lyric tenor between the ages of 23 and 28.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 20 (UP) -- Sam Snead and Cary Middlecoff rated slight favorites today to win the Professional Golfers Association tournament opening tomorrow, although Snead was reported suffering from a stiff neck.

The police cracked down yesterday on a gambling ring that has been using Dick Tracy techniques, complete with purse-size transmitters and skin-shock radio receivers, to flash race results far in advance of official returns.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. The close was 5 points higher to 11 points lower than on Monday, with the far months relatively easier than near months.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20 (UP) -- The Army was authorized today to negotiate for the purchase of the big Scranton, Pa., ordnance plant now operated by the United States Hoffman Machinery Corporation. The plant is owned by the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad.
The nation's teachers took the academic spotlight yesterday as Columbia University honored six outstanding representatives for distinguished service to American education.

Prices closed irregularly lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Rubber, zinc, lead, potatoes and wool declined; soybean oil, cocoa, coffee, sugar, hides, burlap and silk were mixed, and only cottonseed oil was higher in all positions.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A band of Senate Democrats agreed tonight to a showdown vote tomorrow afternoon in their fight against President Eisenhower's order to the Atomic Energy Commission to carry out a private power contract.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -The House Veterans Committee approved today a compromise measure to increase compensation payments for veterans and their dependents. House leaders scheduled the bill for a vote tomorrow.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 20 -Nassau County hospitals do not give the best quality of care to patients because medical staffs fail to exercise sufficient control, according to the findings of a year-long survey.

Discussions are in progress for Gabriel Katzka to produce a musical version of "Boy Meets Girl" during the 1955-56 season. Mr. Katzka is a young man who has invested in many attractions and now aims to join the managerial ranks.

Many women in the Berkshires, Albany and adjacent communities are active in planning the fifth annual outdoor square dance for the benefit of the Berkshire Industrial Farm, a training school for boys in Canaan, N. Y. The fete will be held on Friday night on the grounds of the beneficiary in Canaan.

LONDON, July 20 -- In a dramatic scene in the House of Commons, Sir Thomas Dugdale, Minister of Agriculture, announced his resignation from the Conservative Cabinet today. He had made a persuasive defense of his handling of the so-called Crichel Down affair.

KINGSTON, N. Y., July 20 -- Is there enough traffic crossing the Hudson River Valley to justify more bridges? The answer will be sought starting Thursday when Madigan-Hyland, consulting engineers, start a traffic study for the New York State Bridge Authority.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 20 -- Prince Wan Waithayakon, permanent United Nations delegate of Thailand, said here today that the Geneva negotiations apparently did not provide for guarantees against Communist subversion in Indochina and that he was "uneasy" about the situation on his country's frontier.

Colonial America is the back-ground of two novels scheduled for fall. Crowell will issue on Sept. 20 Howard Breslin's new book "The Silver Oar." It is a story of romance and adventure in Long Island and Connecticut and in Boston in 1689.
PHILADELPHIA, July 20 (UP) -- The Detroit Tigers took both ends of a double-header from Philadelphia tonight, 12 -- 0 and 4 -- 3, to extend the Athletics' losing streak to ten games.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Senator John J. Williams charged today that laxity in the Truman Administration had helped the underworld, put two men in key contacts with defense mobilization.

" Valley of the Kings," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer adventure in color, partly made in Egypt, will open tonight at 8:30 at the Plaza Theatre. This is a benefit opening, with proceeds going to the School of Archaelogy of the University of Cairo.

ST. LOUIS, July 20 (AP) -- Scoring all four runs in the first inning -- two of them on Ray Jablonski's triple -- the St. Louis Cardinals backed Harvey Haddix' hurling for a 4 -- 2 victory tonight over the Phillies. Gerry Staley had to put down a ninthinning Philadelphia threat, however, to protect Haddix' fourteenth triumph.

I think that the defeat of the re-insurance bill by the House Democrats and a few short-sighted Republicans July 13 was disgraceful. I believe that a bil that gives people social benefits without socialism and fosters capitalism deserves strong support.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (UP) -- The first hearing held by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations after its staff housecleaning today was presided over by Democrats.

DETROIT, July 20 (UP) -- The Rabbinical Council of America protested today against Communist enslavement of Jews behind the Iron Curtain and said that the Soviet Union had tried to use Israel as a pawn in Middle Eastern diplomacy.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Miss Bertha S. Adkins, assistant to the chairman of the Republican National Committee, today ended a report to President Eisenhower on a Western tour with a request that he make a foreign policy address to the country fairly soon.

LOS ANGELES, July 20 -- Arthur B. Bisguier of New York, the chess champion of the United States, today was back in first place in the Pan-American tournament at the Hollywood Athletic Club as a result of winning in the tenth round from Herman Steiner, Los Angeles, national titleholder in 1948.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 20 -- The only good sailing in the fourth regatta of Larchmont Race Week was squeezed into an hour's time today when a southerly mooring breeze filled in just after 6 P. M. and whistled miscellaneous small craft over the line.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 20 -- Syria complained to the United Nations Security Council that Israel was planning to resume canal-digging work in a demilitarized zone.
GENEVA, July 20 -- In statistical terms, a balanced settlement on Indochina seems to have been reached.

When the Yankees sprinted from the Stadium diamond last night, 4-1 victors over the Chicago White Sox, the champions did not know which place they held in the American League standings. That depended on the outcome of the Cleveland Indians' overtime game with the Red Sox at Boston.

NOW that a lot of hay has been piled in barns, many of the fields that provided a covering jungle of alfalfa, timothy or clover for the woodchucks are sufficiently open to provide easy spotting conditions for varmint hunters.
TUCKAHOE, N. Y., July 20 -- Several upsets today marked the first round of match play in the Women's Tri-County Golf Association's tenth annual championship being contested over the Leewood course.

A large-scale advertising campaign on the virtues of rayon is being planned by the American Rayon Institute, a group formed last fall by eight leading producers to promote the fiber. The institute has begun operations with a first-year budget of $750,000, of which $400,000 will go into a fall advertising schedule, chiefly in fashion and service magazines.
Two state labor officials asserted yesterday that employment and industrial production in New York State were on the verge of great expansion.
The convalescent leave of Maj. Gen. Kirke B. Lawton, commanding officer at Fort Monmouth, N. J., was extended "indefinitely" by the Army yesterday.

CINCINNATI, July 20 -- The Giants battled through thirteen broiling innings today, but in the end the effort paid off handsomely. For the Polo Grounders, behind an extraordinary display of mound stamina by Johnny Antonelli, brought down the Redlegs, 2 to 1.

Investment banking syndicates are marketing today $196,000,000 of new securities. Among the offerings are debentures of an automobile sales finance company, bonds and preferred stock of a natural gas transmission company, and equipment trust certificates of a western railroad.

BOSTON, Wednesday, July 21 (UP) -- Bobby Avila's two-run homer with two out in the ninth enabled Cleveland to gain a sixten-inning, 5-5 tie with the Boston Red Sox early today. The deadlock kept the Indians atop the American League by 4 percentage points.

A 25-year-old Army lieutenant filed suit yesterday in Federal Court for an injunction to restrain the commander of the First Army here from issuing the lieutenant a discharge from the service other than honorable. No date has been set for hearing on the suit.

Mrs. Philip Bieber's Bicarb and Mrs. Herbert C. Boorse's G. R. Petersen engaged in an exciting duel yesterday, with the former scoring decisively. The occasion was the Severance Handicap, the classified race that occupied the feature spot on the program at Jamaica.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Following is the letter of resignation from Roy M. Cohn as chief counsel of Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's appended statement:

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UP) -- The House Un-American Activities Committee voted today to seek contempt of Congress citations against seventeen persons who refused to cooperate with its search for communists.

World-wide ship construction decreased more than twice as fast in the last three months as in the first quarter of 1954. As a result, total tonnage under construction or on order on June 30 was 445,985 gross tons below the post-war high of 6,294,876 tons on Dec. 31, 1953.
The New York and Brooklyn blood donor centers of the American Red Cross received 103 pints of blood on Monday.
JERUSALEM, July 20 -- Thousands of Israelis honored tonight the memory of Theodor Herzl by gathering at dusk on the mountain on the western border of Jerusalem named in his honor.

BERLIN, July 20 -- The Social Democratic party convened here today to determine its future course. The party is opposed to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's coalition government and the Washington-London-Bonn policy of raising a European army through the proposed European Defense Community.
CINCINNATI, July 20 -- This is usually the time of season when the experts start taking inventory of the managerial field in the major leagues and calculating heads not likely to survive.
The Good Neighbor Federation gave a check for $15,000 yesterday to the New York School of Social Work of Columbia University for fellowships to second-year students.

The one question which I have not seen asked in all the controversy over the admission of Red China into the United Nations Organization is: Were it not for Soviet Russian backing, would Red China have been able to be the aggressor nation she has been; would she have been able to do what she did in Korea, would the French have suffered the reverses they have in Indochina?

NAPLES, Italy, July 20 -- Though European defenses against possible attack still need be strengthened, Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther feels "soberly optimistic" that the main goal of discouraging a would-be aggressor will be achieved.

In its first change of ownership in more than fifty years, the property at 416-22 West 126th Street, near Morningside Avenue, has been purchased by an investing client of Jay Winston, attorney, in a deal negotiated by Kennedy Young and Darling McDonald, brokers.

CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- Johnny Podres, Brooklyn southpaw who underwent an appendicitis operation June 23, will rejoin the Dodgers Thursday in Cincinnati. He will be removed from the disabled list the fallowing day in St. Louis but it is unlikely that he will do any pitching for at least another week, Manager Walter Alston said today.

A banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., submitted the best bid from the New York financial center yesterday for bond issues of Memphis, Tenn., totaling $6,000,000. For $4,200,000 of general improvement bonds due from 1955 to 1984 the Halsey, Stuart bid represented an interest cost of slightly more than 1.9 per cent.

CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- The Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad announced today that it had decided not to take over a 105-mile stretch of the financially ailing Wichita Falls and Southern Railroad in Texas.

Like a bit of an Arabian Nights fantasy against a background of Turkish music and coffee, Turkish fashions from the goodwill liner Tarsus, which is visiting New York for one week, were presented yesterday afternoon by the Fashion Group at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
CHICAGO, July 20 -- Jim Hughes, Brooklyn's ace relief pitcher, dropped a throw at first base from Gil Hodges in the tenth inning today -- and the Dodgers found another way to lose a ball game.
TOKYO, July 20 -- The Japanese Government has decided it will have to reduce its program for strengthening the nation's defenses in the coming year.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday a consolidated net income for the year to June 30 of $48,671,756. This was equal to $2.86 a share on the company's outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $49,856,424 or $2.97 a share in the preceding comparable period.

The letter of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey in your July 17 issue is typical of the logic used by farm-bloc Senators and Congressmen in defending the "right" of farmers to enjoy a privileged status bearing small relation to the market demand for their product.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- An Army spokesman said to-i night that the grant of "top se-I cret" clearance had been strictlyj an accident, and it had been in-I tended that Tele-King should have had access to nothing higher than "secret.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., July 20 -- Maureen Connolly, the tennis queen, was so seriously injured when she was crushed against a big cement truck while riding her horse here today that she will be unable to defend her national title next month at Forest Hills, Queens.

The Air Force has ordered an undisclosed number of "flying laboratories" from the Convair Division of the General Dynamics Corporation. Similar in appearance to the twin-engined Convairs flown by the airlines, the laboratories will be used to test air-borne electronic equipment.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July, 20 -- "Magic Fire," a film biography of Richard Wagner, the composer, is taking shape under William Dieterle's direction.

Australia soon will be able to boast about having the "biggest permanent refrigerator in the world" if plans succeed for containing water in a valley with a well of ice as part of the Snowy Mountains Hydro Electric Project.
Jack Paar, the comedian, will replace Walter Cronkite as master of ceermonies for "The Morning Show" over the C. B. S. television network, beginning Aug. 16.
Our discussion the other day of gazpacho nowhere nearly exhausted the subject of cold soups, which seem to increase in number as American interest in them continues to grow.
An organization of major Italian industries yesterday announced here a drive to obtain the use of American-developed patents and processes.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The House of Representatives killed the last real hope today to enact President Eisenhower's public housing program at this session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy yielded today to the insistent demand for a staff housecleaning from a majority of the members of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

Stocks were caught in a sharp reaction yesterday, rallied near the end of trading and closed with a moderate loss. Airlines led the recovery, aided by such individual issues as Douglas Aircraft, Youngstown Sheet and Tube, Mack Trucks and International Telephone and Telegraph.

We can frighten the people into paying taxes for war but not for peace. It appears that unless we can successfully do the latter we may falter economically, which could well mean catastrophe for the Western World. All sorts of officials -- labor, business, government -- are peering hopefully at business-activity curves.
It takes 85,000 gallons of water to lead a child to one cake of soap.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Members of the Senate Interior Committee praised Clarence A. Davis of Lincoln, Neb., today before approving unanimously his nomination by President Eisenhower to be Under Secretary of the Interior.

One of the apprehensive notes sounded about a year ago when the fighting stopped in Korea came from the Red Cross. There was fear the public might conclude that blood donations were no longer needed. This of course was not so, and the Red Cross saw to it that all of us were informed of the fact.

WITH summer at the midway point, television programs in general have slipped into a dreadful state of mediocrity. An appalling number of shows brought in as hot-weather replacements are trite, trivial and dull.

Secretary of Agriculture Benson has reassured the country's wheat growers that price supports on the 1955 crop will not be reduced below 80 per cent of parity, regardless of what kind of farm bill the Congress passes.

Castleton Park in St. George, S. I., a residential colony consisting of apartments and dwellings on a six-acre site overlooking New York Harbor, has been purchased by Nathan Wilson, operator. The seller was the estate of Bernard T. Kearns, who bought the property in 1905 and developed it.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The House of Representatives was urged today to investigate one of its investigations.
Earnings of the General Electric Company in the first six months this year rose 24 per cent to a record $93,856,000, despite a 7 per cent decline in sales.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UP) -Clint W. Murchison Jr., son of the Texas oil millionaire, told the Senate Banking Committee today that he had made $1,550,000 in profits by building two military housing projects for less than the Government-insured mortgages.

Gross revenues of the New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad, dipped to $70,292,000 in the first half this year and net income slipped to $5,794,744, or $2.32 a share, the company announced yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, July 20 -- Hollister Noble, novelist and screen writer who had been missing for five days, was found dead of a gunshot wound in the cellar of his home in suburban Sherman Oaks today. The police called the death a suicide.

The two apartment houses at the southwest and northwest corners of Ocean Parkway and Ditmas Avenue in Brooklyn have been sold by the Cammledge Realty Company to an investing customer of Daniel D. Cantor, broker in the transaction.
ROME, July 20 -- Pope Pius XII warned France today against the "temptation of weakness" that might force her Government to "surrender under the joint pressure of men and events."

LONDON, July 20 -- Concern over United States-British differences on timing and methods for a defense system in Southeast Asia modified the mild satisfaction in Government circles here today over the outcome of the Geneva conference.

SAN JUAN, P. R., July 20 (UP) -- Government officials said today the strike that has paralyzed the insular waterfront for three weeks had cost 71,930 Puerto Ricans their jobs and reduced stocks of essential foods nearly to the vanishing point.

ROME, July 20 -- Sports fashions are among the most pleasing of those made by the Italians. They were outstanding in the collection of Giovannelli-Sciarra, which opened the last day of the Roman showings this morning.

CAIRO, July 20 -- Continuation of informal negotiations for settlement of the British-Egyptian dispute over control of the Suez Canal Zone awaited today a response from London to Egyptian demands for speedier evacuation of British troops and a shorter term for the agreement.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -Roy Sievers blasted his fifteenth home run and Eddie Yost slammed a bases-loaded triple as the Washington Senators routed Joe Coleman and breezed to a 9-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.

LONDON, July 20 -- The Soviet Foreign Minister, Vyacheslav M. Molotov, has suggested to Pierre Mendes-France, the French Premier, that new four-power talks about the future of Germany might be held sometime this autumn.

In connection with the recent report on tenant relocation and the housing program, submitted to the Board of Estimate by Luther H. Gulick, our organization has requested a public hearing so that a discussion may be had of the problem of relocation of tenants and its connection with the housing program of the city of New York.

Largely because of stock splits, the aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange on July 15 was the highest reported figure since April 6, 1932. The total was 3,047,494 shares, against 2,823,171 shares on June 15 last and 3,063,927 shares on the 1932 date.

Higher sales and lower taxes enabled the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company to lift its net earnings for the first half of this year to $13,082,796 from $8,594,593 earned in the corresponding six months of 1953, John D. Biggers, chairman, reported yesterday.

A fireman changed his plea to guilty of fee splitting at his departmental trial yesterday. He had taken a civil service examination to qualify as a refrigeration engineer and then got a departmental inspector to extract fees from two midtown business concerns.
PARIS, July 20 -- The dominant instrument in the Paris Symphony, the automobile horn, will be muted after Aug. 1.

THE Abominable Snowmen of Mount Everest are still legendary creatures. Their enormous, puzzling tracks have been seen and photographed by sober, dedicated mountaineers. The natives in those parts say the beasts are somewhere between five and ten feet tall, that they are liberally thatched with hair, and that their toes point backward, to help them in their hilly travels.
The virtues of hard work were expounded to retailers yesterday as the best way to overcome what promises to be a difficult fall-winter season for the dress departments of retail stores.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UP) -The Civil Service Committee of the House of Representatives unanimously approved a bill today which would deny pensions to Federal workers who are convicted, of felonies or who take refuge in the Fifth Amendment.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 20 (AP) -- Ray H. Jenkins, said today he would not permit his name to go on the November general elcetion ballot for Senator regardless of whether he was nominated in the Republican primary next month.

Having given long and careful consideration to the traffic problem as a whole, and off-street parking particularly, the Commerce and Industry Association is compelled to dispute the opening statement in your recent editorial: "There can be little quarrel with the general idea of the City Planning Commission that henceforth new non-residential construction should provide for off-street, garaging and parking of cars."

The one-story garage-type building at 79-26 Seventy-first Avenue in Glendale Queens, has been leased by Talbert G. Nelson from the Formulette Company. The building, containing 5,000 square feet of space, will be used by the lessee for the manufacture and distribution of automatic orange juice machines.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 20 -- The United States said today it had reached the conclusion that Moscow had no "serious desire" to negotiate on disarmament.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Powerful Senate Republicans will advise the Eisenhower Administration that West German rearmament and sovereignty should be pushed this year.
ALBANY, July 20 -- Governor Dewey asked a joint legislative committee today to investigate summer camps in the State to determine whether any of them were operating under "subversive" management.
A return to elegance in the traditional Elizabethan and Victorian styles was emphasized yesterday in B. Altman's fall bridal collection.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 20 -- After playing host to thousands, the Soviet cruiser Admiral Ushakov and four accompanying destroyers prepared tonight to return to their Kronstadt base. The squadron is scheduled to leave tomorrow after a five-day good-will visit.
Shares of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company returned yesterday to the New York Stock Exchange after an absence of seventeen and a half years.

The last martial echoes of the Second World War began to die down when the Geneva conference reached agreement last night on an armistice ending more than seven years of armed conflict in Indochina. The armistice will not end the struggle for Indochina as such, and the firmness of the anti-Communist dike erected by it must still be tested.

WESTFIELD, N. J., July 20 -Alleviation of low water pressure, which has plagued many communities in western Union County, is expected this week. Completion of a pipe line between South Plainfield and Westfield will give the Plainfield-Union Water Company an additional 3,000,000 gallons daily from the Elizabethtown Water Company Consolidated.

ST. LOUIS, July 20 (AP) -- Eddie Stanky, fiery manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, today drew a five-day suspension for his stalling tactics in a game against the Philadelphia Phils that erupted into a general free-for-all Sunday.

The last martial echoes of the Second World War began to die down when the Geneva conference reached agreement last night on an armistice ending more than seven years of armed conflict in Indochina. The armistice will not end the struggle for Indochina as such, and the firmness of the anti-Communist dike erected by it must still be tested.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The United States Government will issue a unilateral statement tomorrow accepting in principle the terms of the Indochina cease-fire accord. It also will acknowledge its "ability to respect" such terms under the United Nations Charter, diplomatic officials disclosed tonight.
The field of philanthropy has become a battleground on which several national health organizations are competing with unitedappeal campaigns for the donor's dollar.

TRENTON, July 20 -- The preliminary report of a handwriting expert released here today said that former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman apparently concealed his $300,000 defalcations by forging thirty-eight bank certifications in six years.

Ania Dorfmann finally got her chance to play the Grieg Piano Concerto with the Stadium Symphony at Lewisohn Stadium. The happy event took place last night. Twice before had Miss Dorfmann's appearance been postponed; once earlier in the season because of rain, and once more last Tuesday evening, when Monday's all-Gershwin concert was repeated.
CHICAGO, July 21 (UP) -- Rain and cooler weather brought relief to parched farmlands in the north central area today, but the South and Southwest remained in the grip of drought and heat.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UP) -- The House of Representatives unanimously approved sharply reduced increases in veterans' benefits today.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 21 -- Production of concentrated superphosphate will be discontinued in 1955 by the Tennessee Valley Authority.

The nation's railroads are nearing full dieselization of their motive power. The Association of American Railroads announced yesterday that Class 1 carriers, those with operating revenues of more than $1,000,000 a year, installed 788 new locomotives units in the first six months this year.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The American Council of Learned Societies struck back today at a Congressional committee for aspersions cast on scholars and teachers.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Eisenhower made it clear today that the United States accepted the settlement in Indochina in the spirit of making the best of a bad bargain.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The United States and Spain signed today an agreement authorizing a Spanish airline to fly between Madrid and New York.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Administration and Congressional sources said today they expected the early resignation of John G. Adams, Army counselor. Mr. Adams was a principal in the recent Army-McCarthy controversy.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 21 (Canadian Press) -- Bobby Houston, a 16-year-old student at Blessed Sacrament in New Rochelle, N. Y., today captured the high school singles event, first final of the four-day seventy-second Royal Canadian Henley Regatta.

Two 19-year-old girls who tried to kill themselves in New Jersey Tuesday afternoon taxied to New York and tried again late Tuesday night. They were found yesterday morning in a gas-filled combination art gallery and apartment at 6 East Sixty-fifth Street -- one dead, the other unconscious from gas poisoning.

PARIS, July 21 -- Before the National Assembly tomorrow Pierre Mendes-France, Premier and Foreign Minister, will explain and defend the agreements he signed in Geneva early today for a truce in Indochina.

GENEVA, July 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of the final declaration of the conference on Indochina as well as texts of statements by Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary; Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, United States Under Secretary of State, and Chou En-lai, Premier and Foreign Minister of Communist China, and excerpts from a speech by Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister:

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- A Congressional subcommittee said today an "untested model" radio set that the Air Force had ordered in quantity had so far proved "so unreliable as to be of no practical use."

Steels and oils took stock market leadership yesterday in a session that saw general gains. Chemicals and telephone issues were also strong but aircrafts, after making new highs, lost momentum and ended pronouncedly lower.

Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan completed yesterday the appointment of his cabinet by swearing in Assemblyman Louis A. Cioffi as $15,000 Commissioner of Borough Works and Mrs. Blossom G. Saxe as $9,500 executive manager of Mr. Jack's office.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Senator John Marshall Butler, Republican of Maryland, said today that President Eisenhower had "pledged his full support to the ship repair bill" now before Congress.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, July 22 -- The Senate rejected last night a move to impose a Senatorial veto on President Eisenhower's order to the Atomic Energy Commission to supply the Tennessee Valley Authority with power through a private contract.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 -- The eight-day shutdown of dry-cargo handling in the Port of Philadelphia, which has cost shippers and longshoremen hundreds of thousands of dollars, is scheduled to end at 8 o'clock tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Without debate or call for explanation of details, the House of Representatives passed by voice vote today a bill to strip United States citizenship from any person who wanted the Government overthrown by violence. This included citizens by birth.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The House of Representatives defeated today an Administration-sponsored proposal to increase postal rates by $233,280,000 a year.

Some of the charity racketeers and wastrels who have been taking $12,000,000 to $15,000,000 a year out of New Yorkers' philanthropic contributions are on the run because of public exposure and new legislation. Many others continue to abort the good intentions of this city's givers.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (UP) -- Sonny Dixon, making his first pitching start since June, 1953, brought the Philadelphia Athletics' ten-game losing streak to an end tonight when he set down the Detroit Tigers, 4 -- 1, on six hits.
The Tompkins-Rabin Joint Legislative Committee will meet here Tuesday to start an investigation into "summer session subversion" in vacation camps that get any part of their funds from philanthropy.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 21 -- Twentieth Century-Fox today signed Guy Madison to a long-term contract.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UP) -- Representative Sam Rayburn of Texas said today, "There isn't any more chance of this Congress adjourning July 31 than there is for a one-legged man to win a foot race without his crutches."

A decline of 1,926,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks during the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 161,786,000 barrels, compared with 163,712,000 a week earlier and 142,190,000 a year ago.

A Greenwich Village property has passed to new control with the sale by Phillip P. Zipes, operator, of the six-story apartment house for eightyfive families on plot 100 by 100 feet at 30 Charlton Street. The buyer, an investing client of Max Orda, attorney paid cash over mortgage amounting to $255,000 for the property, which is assessed at $325,000. L. J. Phillips Co. and Joseph Cooper were the brokers.
CHICAGO, July 21 -- The Giants, by way of demonstrating their versatility, won without Willie Mays today, beating Stan Hack's seventh-place Cubs before a gathering of 12,190.
LOS ANGELES, July 21 -- After ten rounds of the Pan American chess tournament at the Hollywood Athletic Club, four players were tied today for the first prize of $1,000.

Cocoa prices rose the cent-a-pound limit in most positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Profit taking eased prices from the highs, the market closing 61 to 91 points up on 247 lots. The near-by options were strongest.

The series of four articles by Charles Grutzner on philanthropy which are concluded in this issue raise a question of first importance both to those who give to charitable causes in New York City -- a total of $500,000,000 last year -- and to the agencies which solicit their gifts.

GENEVA, July 21 -- The Geneva conference ended this afternoon after formally "taking note" of the three Indochina armistice agreements concluded earlier in the day. Representa tives of eight of the nine participants in the conference included in their final declaration a paragraph pledging that they would consult each other on any violation of the agreements serious enough to be reported to them by the three-nation international supervisory commissions.
LONDON, July 21 -- Britain reaffirmed today her guarantee of the frontiers of Israel against aggression, irrespective of any British-Egyptian agreement on the Suez Canal base.
A letter written by Reinhold Niebuhr of Union Theological Seminary appeared in the July 19 issue of The Times. I wish to present an argument against his position and his conclusions.

Representative Javits is to be congratulated on his introduction of a House resolution to set up a special committee to investigate the Reece committee, which in turn has been investigating foundations and other tax-exempt agencies. If members of Congress realized every time they propose an investigating committee that its own activities might some day be subject to Congressional investigation, the public might be spared much boredom, irritation and unnecessary expenditures of taxpayers' money.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UP) -- The House gave final Congressional approval today to two bills to increase the size of blocks of public land that can be leased for oil drilling and generally modernizing oil leasing laws.
When an advertiser calls attention in his copy to "unbelievable price reductions," the public is apt just that: It doesn't to do believe.

The final chapter in the tale of the house that Frank Lloyd Wright has been trying to build here is about to unfold, it seems. The villain of the piece -- New York's building regulations -- has been appeased, and the happy ending is in sight.
GENEVA, July 21 -- Communist China has promised to free six detained Americans, including four Roman Catholic priests, the United States delegation to the Geneva conference announced today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 21 (AP) -- A plan for the hydroelectric development of Lebanon's Litani River to ultimately produce more than 600,000,000 kilowatt hours was completed and handed to the Lebanese Government by American Point Four officials today.

The National Planning Association has called for imposing responsibility upon the Office of Defense Mobilization to organize "a civilian reserve of 5,000 executives, trained and willing to fill top jobs in war agencies in an emergency." A special report by the association, an independent organization of leaders in industry, labor and agriculture, suggests that a talent pool of executives "five and ten deep" be created for essential positions required by emergency control and administrative activities.

HANOI, Vietnam, July 21 -- After seven and a half years of bitter and dirty fighting in mountains, jungles and rice paddies, the Indochinese war drew to a close today amid scenes of spiritual debilitation, lassitude and general fatigue.

Net income of American Airlines, Inc., dipped to $5,014,000, or 66 cents a share, in the first half this year, the company announced yesterday. In the six months to June 30, 1953, the net was $6,658,000, or 92 cents a share.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The country's tax-free foundations won their fight today against a proposal by Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, that spokesmen said might have crippled or even destroyed some of them.

LYMAN BRYSON has done about as much as any living man in these parts to give others a chance to express their ideas -- if any. In a thoughtful and humane new book, "The Drive Toward Reason,"* he expresses some of his own. The volume isn't very long, but then neither is "Candide." And it isn't particularly Voltairean, except in its lucidity and candor.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Eisenhower at his news conference today made the following points:
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Presdent Eisenhower announced today that, following the Indochina agreements, the United States was seeking rapid organization of collective defense in Southeast Asia.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Eisenhower still is confident that his legislative program, on balance, is coming out all right. Admittedly, he said at his news conference today, some features he is very deeply interested in are not going to be enacted.

SAN JUAN, P. R., July 21 -- Gov. Luis Munoz Marin warned his people today that they faced a "grave crisis" and possibly "tragic" psychological effects on their industrialization hopes if a twenty-seven-day harbor shutdown continued.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 21 (AP) -- Vicki Hanover, 3-year-old black filly owned by Stanley Cooper of Port Jervis, N. Y., and driven by Jimmy Wingfield, won the Baldwin Trot in 2:08 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. She returned $20.60 for $2.
ST. Paul, July 21 -- Ed (Porky) Oliver took the lead in the opening qualifying round of the Professional Golfers Association championship with a 5-under-par 66 today.

Today's new offering is "Seven Brides for Seven Brothers," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Ansco color musical at the Radio City Music Hall. The cast is headed by Howard Keel, Jane Powell, Jeff Richards, Russ Tamblyn, Tommy Rall, Marc Platt, Matt Mattox and Jacques d'Amboise.
