WASHINGTON, July 21 -- A labor leader who called on President Eisenhower today spoke critically of union colleagues who were less friendly to the Administration.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 21 -- Political and scientific leaders from sixteen Southern and border states opened a four-day meeting today to formulate a regional action program to alleviate the area's mental health problem.

A 15-year-old boy, working as plumber's helper for the first time, drowned yesterday in a Queens cesspool as neighbors and the police tried in vain to rescue him. He was Boris Suravleff of 62-42 Eighty-first Street, Elmhurst, Queens, only child of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Suravleff.
FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., July 21 -- A Cyclopean Peeping Tom that can spot a jeep thirty miles away was described by the Army Signal Corps here today.
The closing of books on several oversubscribed new issues of securities was announced by banking syndicates yesterday.

BOSTON, July 21 (UP) -- The Cleveland Indians and the Boston Red Sox battled to a 7-7 tie today before the contest -- the second stand-off in two days between the clubs -- was called in the top of the ninth because of rain.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was slightly easier yesterday and prices closed 16 to 22 points net lower on active months.

Aggregate draft indebtedness of Latin American countries to United States exporters increased during June for the third consecutive month, it was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The total outstanding June 30 was $122,600,000, an increase of $6,100,000 for the month.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., July 21 -- Former Mayor Frank Hague was ordered today to show cause on July 30 why he should not be held in contempt of court for failure to answer a subpoena.
The offices of the Toilet Goods Association has moved to the Americas Building, Rockefeller Center, 1270 Avenue of the Americas.
LONDON, July 21 -- The West succeeded at the Geneva conference on Far Eastern affairs in averting the danger of a third world war, Anthony Eden declared tonight on his return to Britain.

The stinging range of the Air Force's F-89D Scorpion interceptor is being increased. Northrop Aircraft. Inc., manufacturer of the twin-jet, king-sized, fighter-type warplane, announced yesterday that the planes now coming off its assembly lines were equipped with external fuel tanks almost fifteen feet long and weighing more than a ton each when filled.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Jim Brideweser permitted Jim Busby's easy grounder to roll past him at second with the bases loaded and one out in the ninth inning, enabling Eddie Yost to score the tie-breaking run as the Washington Senators defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 6 -- 5, tonight.
A new Traffic Safety Night School for Problem Drivers will get under way Oct. 1 in the Criminal Courts Building, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh announced yesterday.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 22 -- United States tinplate production in May was 541,794 long tons, the highest monthly figure ever recorded, the International Tin Study Group reported here today. Of the total, 411,630 tons was electrolytic tinplate and 130,164 hot-dipped.
An executive order establishing an interim labor relations policy guaranteeing to city employes the right of self-organization was issued yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 21 -- There was a pause in the regular operations of the fifty-sixth Larchmont Race Week today. The elder statesmen of the Sound remained ashore and youth took over for this twenty-sixth annual Mid-Race Week variation.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Two new major grants of $5,000 were announced today by the American Library Association's American heritage project in its nationwide program of adult discussion in public libraries.

Lorraine Schneider of Fort Pierce, Fla., reached the semi-final round of the girls' division in the Long Island junior and girls tennis championships yesterday, but Bermuda's first two ranked players were eliminated.

Long after Casey Stengel had conceded the victory to the opposition, the Chicago White Sox continued to pound New York pitching yesterday at the Stadium. At the finish, the Pale Hose had a 15 -- 3 triumph over the Yankees, but it was difficult to determine which club was nearer exhaustion.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., July 21 (UP) -- Maureen Connolly, three-time national women's tennis champion, smiled from her hospital bed today despite the news she would not be able to try for her fourth national crown at Forest Hills, Queens, next month.
Under the heading of Topics of The Times on July 15 I read with interest the article on the improbable juke box at Eighth Avenue and Times Square.

Contract negotiations between the Bethlehem Steel Company and the shipyard workers' union turned to wage matters yesterday. The union restated its demand for a 21-cent hourly increase and outlined the "economic plight" of yard workers.

Electric power production last week rose to 8,951,000,000 kilowatt hours from 8,185,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended July 18, 1953, was 8,209,000,000. Comparative percentages of the past two weeks with the like weeks of 1953 are:

The Southern Production Company, Inc., oil and gas producer, announced yesterday the consummation of a refinancing program involving the sale of a new issue of $52,000,000 in one-to-fifteen-year notes.

FLORENCE, Italy, July 21 -- Crowds poured into the Pitti Palace this afternoon to witness the beginning of the Florence fashion showings. Every visitor was registered, every one had a specially assigned seat. While registration was going on chilled soft drinks were served from a huge bar set up in one of the handsome salles with murals and glinting crystal chandeliers.
Despite March's crippling longshore strike, mid-year statistics compiled by the Maritime Association of the Port of New York showed that more ships called here than at any other port in the nation.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 21 -- The deadline for raising funds to preserve Mettler's Woods as a primeval forest has been extended.
One of the most demanding roles of the forthcoming stage season has been assigned to an actress with only one Broadway appearance to her credit.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 21 -- Nationalist China entered a sharp protest today after the French delegation had used a United Nations meeting as a forum to praise the Indochina agreement.

The justices of the City Court and the Appellate Term of the Brooklyn Supreme Court filed actions in the Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday to compel the city to grant $108,525 in salary increases to more than 200 court clerks, attendants and other employes of these courts.
GENEVA, July 21 (UP) -- The Russians rolled out a lavish array of delicacies and liquors tonight at a marathon celebration to mark the end of the Geneva conference.

In the Republic of Korea President Syngman Rhee has given his approval to four proposed constitutional amendments and they will go to the Assembly for a final vote next month. Their adoption seems likely, since they reflect popular wishes. They are designed to strengthen the framework of democratic government in Korea and therefore they should be welcomed by all friends of the Korean people.

JERUSALEM, July 21 -- The United Nations Truce Supervision Organization would like to abandon the procedure within the Israeli-Jordanian Mixed Armistice Commission of condemning one nation or the other for each serious incident.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 21 -- American industry is saving an estimated $100,000,000 a year, and ten years hence may save $1,000,000,000 a year through the use of radioisotopes, Joseph Campbell, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, said here tonight.
Life in the great outdoors plays as much havoc with summer furnishings as it does with the human epidermis unless proper precautions are observed.
A watched plant never blooms.

Richard H. Balch, Democratic state chairman, yesterday repudiated the Queens County leadership of James A. Roe. He gave formal recognition to the anti-Roe forces headed by Daniel A. Haggerty, vice chairman of the Queens County Democratic Committee.

GUATEMALA, July 21 -- A national Committee to stop Red infiltration throughout the country has been organized by a junta decree. This action complies with the international agreements to curb communism signed in Rio de Janeira, Bogota and Caracas.

STOCKHOLM, July 16 -- It is always lively on the Saltsjon, the finger of the Baltic that leads past Skansen and Skeppsholmen into the docks at the foot of the Grand Hotel in Stockholm. But this morning, in a sunlight forgiven for its month-long tardiness because of unusual generosity in these latitudes, the Saltsjon is the scene of a real traffic jam differing from that in Fifth Avenue only because it is aquatic.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UP) -- The House Commerce Committee approved today a bill to impose $1,000 in fines for any bus, train or other public transport concern that segregated passengers in interstate travel. The unexpected action was taken by a 19-to-7 vote at a secret session.
The city's theatrical bill was enlivened yesterday by a production not scheduled in advance.
ROME, July 21 -- During the S. I. A. M. (Syndicate of Italian High Fashion) showings, an exhibition of Roman-produced accessories has been taking place in the Excelsior Hotel.
LONDON, July 21 -- Britons consumed nearly 3 per cent more goods in the first quarter of 1954 than the same period last year, the Treasury announced today.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today invited bids for still more bins in which to store grain acquired by the Government under price suport programs.

MILWAUKEE, July 21 (UP) -- Robin Roberts limited the Milwaukee Braves to four hits tonight but lost his bid for his sixth shutout of the year in the ninth inning when Eddie Mathews hit a homer, as the Phillies won, 6 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, July 22 -- The Senate, often described as the world's greatest deliberative body, heard a lot about veterans' pensions, the Republican party and even President Eisenhower's voting record as it debated the atomic energy bill early today.
The land of claymores and tartans is benefitting the world by shipping out record quantities of what many people believe is its best export.

ST. LOUIS, July 21 (UP) -- St. Louis outlasted Pittsburgh, 13 -- 12, at Busch Stadium tonight as Harvey Haddix, the eighth pitcher used by the Cardinals, fanned two Pirates to halt a ninth-inning rally.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (UP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, the defending champion, was carried to three sets today by unranked John Lesch as most of the favorites moved ahead easily in the Pennsylvania and Eastern States tennis championships.
Records of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship were subpoenaed yesterday in a Government effort to show "inconsistencies" in testimony before the Subversive Activities Control Board.

FEW fly fishermen could find greater solitude on an obscure and isolated feeder of the Snake than is presently available on the historic Beaverkill. Its low, warm and gin-clear waters have discouraged all but a few determined "regulars."

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 21 -- Federal defense installations in the Tennessee Valley are using more power. And in the Tennessee Valley Authority system the output of big steam generating plants has overtaken that of the hydro generators.

DETROIT, July 21 -- The first reaction of most political observers in Michigan to the death yesterday of former Senator Blair Moody was that is assured the re-election in November of Senator Homer Ferguson, the Republican incumbent.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Democratic Women's Day will this year run in a different way.

When it comes to establishing athletic world records enormous precautions are taken before the challenging times and spaces are validated. But even after disinterested experts have given the nod to the up-and-coming over the done-and-gone, the quibbling and hypothesizing go on for decades.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The Bureau of Census reported today that cotton consumption averaged 31,909 bales for each working day in June.

An account of the struggle just ended for Indochina and its meaning for the free world will be published Aug. 5 by Praeger. Titled "Report on Indochina," it has been written by Bernard Newman, who is the author of sixty books on politics and travel as well as novels.

James Fitzsimmons, the twinkly-eyed dean of the horse-trainers, had a big afternoon at Jamaica yesterday. He won a $6,000 added overnight handicap with Wheatley Stable's Hilarious and he won the $12,175 Albany Stakes with Wheatley's Laugh.
TUCKAHOE, N. Y., July 21 -- Three holders of major titles and a newcomer reached the semifinal round of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association's tenth championship over the Leewood course today.

BERLIN, July 21 -- Social Democratic leaders said today they favored the postponement of any form of West German rearmament until all possibilities of negotiating German reunification with the Soviet Union had been exhausted.

ST. PAUL,. July 21 -- One of golf's oldest championships is slated to get under way tomorrow. It is the fifty-second amateur tournament of the Metropolitan Golf Association to be played at the Garden City Country Club, Garden City, L. I.
NEWARK, July 21 -- Mayor Leo P. Carlin today directed Chief Frederick R. Lacey to reorganize the Police Department to "return as many policemen to foot duty at night as is possible."

Burlington Mills Corporation has obtained control of Goodall-Sanford, Inc., one of the largest textile producers in the country, J. Spencer Love, chairman of the board of Burlington, announced yesterday.
The state of Louisiana borrowed $8,900,000 in the public market yesterday on highway revenue bonds maturing serially from 1955 to 1984.

LONDON, July 21 -- The stock markets here responded to the Indochina pact with moderate advances at the start of business. Some of the gains among industrials were reduced later or replaced by small losses, but most markets were described as firm at the close.

TORONTO, July 21 -- Financing of Canada's first privately-owned uranium project has been completed and $19,560,000 in sinking fund debentures will be issued soon, Gunnar Mines and an investment syndicate headed by Nesbitt, Thomson Co. announced today.

DANBURY, Conn., July 21 -- The feuding in Sugar Hollow has come to a temporary truce. From now until Labor Day nothing larger than .22 caliber rifles or pistols will be used on a shooting range there.
A move to promote a "war atmosphere" in all parts of the state government was begun yesterday by the State Civil Defense Commission.
Percival Jackson's letter of July 16 evidences present-day thinking among many members of the bar that our courts are for purpose of effecting settlement of lawsuits.
CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 14, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

Keun-ho Lee's letter in The New York Times on July 4 argues that Korea "does not wish to buy consumers' goods from Japan, preferring to buy productive machinery from the United States, to solve its economic problem at the root."

PALMER, Alaska, July 18 -- Successors to the Middle West "farmers" on the lands settled in one of the Roosevelt Administration's most publicized depression-era experiments today were packing fancy cabbages, lettuce and radishes for delivery to the Alaska markets.

CLEVELAND, July 21 (AP) -- The board of directors of Republic Steel Corporation has approved the spending of nearly $10,000,000 for expansion and improvement, with more than $5,000,000 to go for new equipment in the Warren and Youngstown, Ohio, plants.

C. J. Blanford, market administrator of the New York Metropolitan Milk Marketing Area, forecast yesterday a uniform farm price of $3.69 a hundredweight (46.5 quarts) for July milk deliveries to approved plants.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse, as required by White House rules:

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Eisenhower Administration advised the House Appropriations Committee today that, despite the terms of the Indochina truce, it still was seeking $1,133,100,000 in aid for Southeast Asia.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 20 -- The United States was reported tonight to have averted an economic crisis in Pakistan. This was said to have been done by changing the present form of aid from technical to commodity assistance and by allowing the purchase in Pakistani rupees (worth about 30 cents) of surplus United States farm products.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, July 21 (AP) -- Two world harness racing records were established in consecutive Grand Circuit events at Saratoga Raceway tonight.

CAMDEN, N. J., July 21 -- Deepening of the Delaware River shipping channel between Philadelphia and Trenton will not damage the quality of underground water supplies of communities bordering the river, it was reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Its hands freed by the Indochina settlement and tensions eased throughout Southeast Asia, the Soviet Union is expected here to focus Communist diplomacy and propaganda on a defeat of Western aims in Europe.

LONDON, July 21 (UP) -- Canadian riders continued to fare poorly in the White City horse show, with a Canadian team of three being eliminated in the first round of the Country Life and Riding Cup today.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's statement today on the Indochina cease-fire:

CHICAGO, July 21 (UP) -- The Reverie Knoll Farm's Smoke Screen, victor only twice in seven previous starts this year, won the fourteenth running of the Equipoise Mile and $36,000 at Arlington Park today.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UP) -- Senator Burnet R. Maybank said today Federal housing irregularities were getting "worse and worse" and the Administration was doing nothing to stop it.

The Navy's share of the 1955 fiscal year military budget -- $9,712,000,000 -- will support a fleet of about 1,080 operating ships, more than 13,000 combat and support aircraft, three Marine divisions and their air support, and a shipbuilding and conversion program totaling almost $1,000,000,000.

Demand never ceases for unusual party menus to pique the appetite of guests and enhance the culinary reputation of the hostess -- without too much wear and tear on her. Nor does there seem to be an end to the publication of cookbooks designed to meet this need.

CINCINNATI, July 21 -- A superb pitching performance by Carl Erskine and some consistent hitting by his mates gave the Dodgers a 5 -- 1 triumph over the Redlegs before 14,831 fans at Crosley Field tonight.

HELENA, Mont., July 21 (AP) -- James E. Murray of Montana, who has been in the Senate longer than all but five of his colleagues, set his sights today on his fourth consecutive full term in the November election.
Sales and earnings of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation in the first six months this year declined sharply from those of a year earlier.
SUFFERN, N. Y., July 21 -- The New York State Thruway will do great things for motorists when it is completed, but right now it is creating trouble.
NEW DELHI, India, July 21 -- The signing of the Indochina cease-fire agreement was welcomed by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today as "one of the outstanding achievements of the post-war era."
Operating revenues of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad dipped more than $42,000,000 in the first half of this year, but the company has maintained operations in the black.
LONDON, July 21 -- Thirteen American women who are paying $1,200 each for a fashion tour of Europe are finally getting their money's worth in London after a slow start.

Samuel Edelman, real estate investor, has purchased the one-story taxpayer at 35-71 South Ocean Avenue in Patchoque, L. I., from the 35 South Ocean Avenue Company. J. George Langfelder and Willard M. Bick were attorneys for the buyer and Joseph G. Abramson acted for the seller. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
GENEVA, July 21 -- Cambodia's delegates to the Indochina conference dug in their heels last night and gained an important success for the free world in negotiations with the Communist-led Vietminh.

ALGIERS, Algeria, July 21 -- Agents of Communist and anti- Communist trade unionism are vying in pursuit of the same political objective in Tunisia. That objective is described in both camps as "Tunisian independence," in other words, the destruction of the French protectorate.
General Foods Corporation yesterday reported the largest earnings for any June quarter in its history, more than double those of the 1953 quarter.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Rains over much of the Midwest took the edge off the demand for all grains as well as soybeans today, and much of the recent gain was erased by heavy profit taking by longs. With this the last day for trading in July, 1954, futures, there were naturally wide price swings in all pits, with erratic price moves.

What does one say to a gangling lad who fancies himself in love with the most wonderful girl in the world? Since one has not yet seen this most wonderful girl in the world it may be best to say nothing.
CHICAGO, July 21 -- A new type "swing around" X-ray machine that permits physicians to hang a patient by the heels while examining him has been put in operation in Wesley Memorial Hospital.

GENEVA, July 21 -- Even before completing the formalities of the Indochina ceasefire settlement, Pierre Mendes-France began working on ways and means of getting over the second big hurdle he has set for his Government -- a settlement of the French position on the European Defense Community treaty.
TOKYO, July 21 -- The agreement on a cease-fire in Indochina, reached at Geneva early today, was regarded here as a development of major significance for all of Asia.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Twenty educational and other groups joined today in a telegram to President Eisenhower asking Administration backing of emergency school construction bills.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- A Congressional conference committee agreed today on a compromise tax reform bill that would reduce revenues an estimated $1,363,000,000 next year. The bill also would give corporation stockholders considerably less tax relief than President Eisenhower had proposed.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- A House armed services subcommittee that investigated alleged "coddling" of athletes by the Army reported today "a glaring abuse of pass privileges" and too much granting of "compassionate leave."
MOSCOW, Thursday, July 22 -- Pravda acclaimed the results of the Geneva conference today as a triumph for the Soviet Union and the "democratic camp" and a smashing defeat for the United States.

Sales and earnings of the Douglas Aircraft Company climbed to new peacetime highs in the six months ended on May 31, last, while the second quarter earnings were the highest for any three-month period in the company's history.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Following is the 55-to-36 roll-call vote by which the Senate tonight defeated an amendment by Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, to ban President Eisenhower's plan for a new private power plant in the Tennessee Valley area:
The New York State Federation of Labor pledged itself yesterday to cooperate with "all liberal forces" to help carry out the recent Supreme Court decision banning segregation in schools.

Directors of the American Bosch Arma Corporation, in their first meeting following the merger of American Bosch Corporation and its wholly-owned subsidiary, Arma Corporation, which became effective yesterday, promoted four key executives, Charles W. Perelle president and chief executive officer, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- In the week ended July 21, member bank reserves increased $89,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

PHENIX CITY, Ala., July 22 (UP) -- Gov. Gordon Persons proclaimed martial rule in this crime-ridden area today. Armed National Guardsmen immediately surrounded the Russell County courthouse and police headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Friday, July 23 -- The Republican move early today to invoke closure to end the debate on the atomic bill relaxed the tension that had accumulated through two days and two nights in the Senate chamber.

JERSEY CITY, July 22 -- Word that the American Export Lines plans to give up Piers D and F here and move to a Port of New York Authority pier in Hoboken spread like wildfire today along the waterfront. Spokesmen for the line and the authority would neither confirm nor deny the report.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday. Prices closed with gains of 2 to 15 points.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 22 -- Defending Dr. Goodwin Watson as a "loyal American," the Guidance Center of New Rochelle accused the Westchester County American Legion today of "ill-tempered, ill-advised and hasty attacks with an utter disregard of facts."

Plans and specifications for a new passenger liner pier on the Hudson River were announced yesterday by Vincent A. G. O'Connor, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation. The pier would be built-by the city and leased to the Italian Line.

HANOI, July 22 -- Casualties suffered by the French-Vietnamese forces in Indochina from 1945 to May 31, 1954, included 34,242 killed. The data show 10,725 others died, 48,370 were missing and 71,560 wounded. The total is 164,897.

Complaints that Burlington Mills Corporation, in its recent tenders for shares of Pacific Mills and Goodall-Sanford, Inc., overlooked the interests of rank-and-file stockholders of the two companies, brought action yesterday.
The complaint sent by the Government of Israel to the Secretary General of the United Nations, Dag Hammarskjold, reported in your issue of July 11, did not overstate the damage done to this cemetery.

Foundations traditionally have been set up by individuals of great wealth to advance in various ways the welfare of mankind. Recent news items show that labor unions as well as corporations now follow suit.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- Fractional declines were registered in wheat and corn in the early Board of Trade transactions today, but wheat found buying resistance picking up and corn futures developed outstanding strength.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Senate and House conferees today compromised differences between their chambers' versions of a $150,000,000 tanker construction program.
following the slaying of Mr. Patterson.

CINCINNATI, July 22 -- A little progress for the Dodgers can be reported today. They completed a sweep of the two-game series here by beating the Redlegs, 8 -- 5, and cut the Giants' first-place lead to six games -- thanks to the timely cooperation of the Chicago Cubs.

IT is a pleasure to find a television program that hasn't lowered its standards for the summer. The "United States Steel Hour" presented a tasteful drama last Tuesday (A. B. C.-TV, 9:30 to 10:30 P. M.) that stood out like a flower in a barren land.

Helene Jacobs, 19 - year - old college student who, according to the police of two cities, attempted suicide twice this week in a pact with a college mate, remained in critical condition at Roosevelt Hospital last night.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Mickey Vernon's single with the bases loaded and one out in the ninth inning scored Maury McDermott from third base to give the Washington Senators a 3-2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight. Gus Keriazakos, who pitched the ninth inning after Bob Porterfield had pulled a back muscle, gained his first major league victory.

LOS ANGELES, July 22--In the Pan American chess tournament at the Hollywood Athletic Club, the four leaders, having completed the round-robin series among themselves, began taking on opponents in the lower groups.

The Conference Committee of the Senate and House has served the public well by throwing out of the omnibus tax bill the McCarran amendment which would have denied tax exemption to any foundation and other tax-free agency which made a contribution to a "subversive" organization or individual.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 22 -- Errol Flynn, Joanne Dru and Peter Finch will head the cast at Allied Artists' CinemaScope production, "The Black Prince."

THE terrifying prolificity of Georges Simenon, who has written something like 350 novels in the last thirty-four years or so, one of them in twenty-five hours but most in eight to eleven days at a recent rate of slightly more than six a year, is probably equaled only by his astonishing felicity, his ability to reproduce accurately whatever milieu he chooses and his insight, which he displays laconically but without ellipsis.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Following is the 45-to-41 roll-call vote by which the Senate upset the Administration by adding an amendment to the atomic bill sponsored by Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat of Colorado, which would authorize Federal construction of atomic plants to provide commercial power:

Heavy short covering yesterday pushed coffee prices 49 to 133 points higher on 79,250 bags on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The spot price of Santos 4's however, was unchanged and quoted at 86 1/2 cents a pound, ex-dock.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- The Giants' pennant flight suddenly ran into some bumpy going today, the skipper got just a little bit panicky and the result was a rather jarring crack-up.
Your recent editorial on parking and the letter from Michael Grosso of the Fifth Avenue Association prompt my protest.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, July 22 -- About 900 doctors from fifty-four countries assembled here today for the sixth International Cancer Congress, which begins formal sessions tomorrow.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel M. Gold granted yesterday a motion by the Board of Justices of the City Court for an order directing the city to pay $104,275 in salary increases to City Court employes. The board had approved the rises.

LONDON, July 22 -- Dated British Government securities again led a rally in the stock markets today. Demand, though still selective, was described as a little stronger than yesterday. Dated funds gained five shillings (70 cents) or more. The undated stocks again weakened, falling two shillings six pence (35 cents).

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., July 22 -- Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis, the defending champion, and Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century, will meet in the thirty-six-hole final of tenth annual Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, the Democratic leader, and Senator George D. Aiken, Vermont Republican, clashed head-on today over a delay in the farm bill.
A remedy for dishpan hands, short of going out to dinner, may be in sight.
North American newsprint mills set new records in production and shipments last month, it was reported yesterday by the Newsprint Service Bureau.

Cottage cheese salads, quick to prepare, nutritious and low in cost, are refreshing and satisfying main dishes for luncheons and suppers. To round out the menus only a hot or cold drink and hot bread or sandwiches are needed.

PARIS, July 22 -- The elegance of a medium size hat for cocktail and restaurant wear, instead of a calot, is one of the excitements of Mme. Legroux's collection. She calls them Rembrandts, and they do recall those in portraits by this artist.

ST. LOUIS, July 22 (UP) -- Red Schoendienst's two-out single in the fourteenth inning scored Wally Moon with the winning run tonight to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 3 -- 2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
The playing of the duo-pianists Arthur Gold and Robert Fizdale was a pleasant feature of the concert that Alexander Smallens conducted at Lewisohn Stadium last evening.
The underground water level in parts of Brooklyn is rising at the rate of three feet a year.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Living It Up," a Paramount musical comedy with Dean Martin, Jerry Lewis, Janet Leigh and Edward Arnold, is at the Criterion. Paul Jones produced and Norman Taurog directed, from a screen play that Jack Rose and Melville Shavelson based on the Broadway musical, 'Hazel Flagg."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 22 -- Bus Mosbacher's International Susan, Henry Boschen's S boat Sirius and Skip Etchells' Star Shannon won in the fifth point-scoring regatta of Larchmont Race Week today to strengthen already strong positions for championships in their divisions.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Government's effort to deport to Communist China ten anti-Communist Chinese was blocked, temporarily, by the Federal Court of Appeals here today.

Shipments from steel warehousing concerns, which serve thousands of small manufacturers across the nation, have turned upward after declining steadily since last summer, an industry spokesman reported yesterday.

BONN, Germany, July 22 -- The disappearance of Dr. Otto John, the West German Government's chief of intelligence, into the East sector of Berlin has aroused acute alarm in the Allied High Commission because Dr. John was familiar with the organization and operational plans of several Western intelligence agencies.

LONDON, July 22 (AP) -- Four labor unions, representing all sections of British film making, threatened today to retaliate if Hollywood unionists stopped American companies from producing United States television programs in Britain.
Jesse W. Tapp has been named vice chairman of the board of directors of the Bank of America.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A Federal grand jury indicted Henry W. Grunewald today for perjury. The alleged influence peddler was accused on ten counts of lying to a Congressional committee and to a grand jury about tax fixing activities.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The scheduled August visit of eleven Protestant clergy from Iron Curtain countries to the World Council of Churches Conference in Evanston, Ill., was made a springboard today for another Congressional inquiry into communism.

Stocks on the New York Stock Exchange stood, on June 30, at the lowest month-end average price since April, the Exchange reported yesterday. The figure was $45.68, against $46.30 at the close of May and $45.37 on April 30.
A world shortage of cocoa beans is making itself felt in market baskets.

The peace that has been established between Mayor Wagner and the Brooklyn Democratic organization was cemented last night, when the mayor swore in at City Hall two new jurists recommended by the Brooklyn group.

THE coastal fishing prospects from Barnegat Bay in New Jersey to Cape Cod in Massachusetts seem to be approaching something of a seasonal peak, and the week-end should provide a varied opportunity for both surfcaster and off-shore angler.
Earnings of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company in the first half climbed to $13,490,505 from $19,453,368 cleared in the initial six months of 1953.

HANOI, Vietnam, July 22 (AP) -- A French official announced today preliminary plans for evacuations from the surrendered Red River delta, as sporadic fighting continued. The Geneva cease-fire is not yet officially in effect.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The House of Representatives passed and sent to the Senate today a big appropriation bill that had been cut $656,603,000, or more deeply than any other of the present Administration.
CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- Heaviest run of hogs since January dropped prices to a new low for the year today. Prices fell 75 cents to $1.25 on both butchers and sows.

Case Goods "delivered" most satisfactorily for her backers in the feature race at Jamaica yesterday. The event was the Molly Brant purse, with 3-year-old fillies competing, and Case Goods, running in the silks of William Goadby Loew, easily beat eight others in the six-furlong sprint.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, July 22 (AP) -- A bold new operation removes 80 per cent of the human liver to cure cancer, and the liver soon grows back again.

This is the picnic season, no doubt of that. Travel along any highway to find the proof. In each meadow to right and left picnickers share the shade of trees, if not the hard boiled eggs, with the resident cows.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 22 (Canadian Press) -- The New York A. C. was the runner-up in three finals of the Royal Canadian Henley Regatta today as the Buffalo West Side Club took three events for a commanding lead.
Two cards, punched here and there in ways meaningful only to other such cards and the machines that shuffle them, traded punches the other day over the transocean radio.

A union demand for a 21-cent hourly increase for shipyard workers was again the sole topic of negotiations as the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., and the Bethlehem Steel Company met yesterday for more than eight hours under the auspices of Federal mediators.

LONDON, July 22 -- The settlement on Indochina at the Geneva conference represents a solid gain for peace, banishing the prospect of misery and suffering and the "certainty" of greater sacrifices, Anthony Eden told an enthusiastic House of Commons today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 22 -- Prince Wan Waithayakon of Thailand announced today that he was a candidate for election to the presidency of the United Nations General Assembly session opening Sept. 21.
The National Council of American-Soviet Friendship refused yesterday to produce records subpoenaed by the Subversive Activities Control Board.
ST. PAUL, July 22 -- Shooting his second sub-par round in two days, Ed (Porky) Oliver emerged as the leader of the qualifiers in the Professional Golfers Association championship today.
OTTAWA, July 22 -- Before agreeing to help supervise the truce in Indochina, Canada wants assurances that the international commissions will have a reasonable chance to perform their functions.

The criticism of Nikita Roodkowsky in The Times of July 13 is pointless, because it identifies the splendid and peace-loving Russian people with the de facto Russian rulers, the Czars and the Communists.
Stocks advanced yesterday to almost the best levels of the upward movement, with steels providing the main impetus.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Eisenhower Administration closed its first full fiscal year June 30 with a deficit of $3,029,000,000. This means that the Administration has come more than two-thirds of the way toward balancing the budget while putting into effect a tax reduction program.
Parks Commissioner Robert Moses disclosed yesterday that he was responsible for a ban against speeding "mercy errands" by Long Island park police.

NEW DELHI, July 22 -- The Indian Government said today that so far as it was concerned negotiations with the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development on sharing canal waters of the Indus system had ended.

FLORENCE, Italy, July 22 -- Outstanding in the Florentine pageant held in the Pitti Palace are the formal gowns by Roberto Capucci of Rome. This 22-year-old designer is one of the rising stars of Italian couture. His styles represent everything from coats to ball gowns.
BERLIN, July 22 -- The head of the West German equivalent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation vanished into the Soviet sector of Berlin Tuesday night.

GORKI, U. S. S. R., July 13 -- This city, Russia's ancient market town of Nizhni Novgorod, has been turned into a Soviet Detroit. It has one of Europe's largest auto plants and a population that has topped the million mark. It is growing like Los Angeles in its palmiest days.
SANFORD, Me., July 22 (AP) -- Business men here took an optimistic view but labor union officials differed among themselves today on probable effects of the purchase of Sanford's principal industry.
BANGKOK, Thailand, July 22 -- An outward show of relief with an undertone of apprehension marked Bangkok's reaction today to the Indochina armistice.

Simon H. Rifkind, former United States District Court Judge, and Arleigh Boyd Williamson, professor-emeritus at New York University, were sworn in yesterday by Mayor Wagner as members of the unsalaried Board of Higher Education.

According to your recent dispatches from Karachi leading Pakistan "Government and public figures," as well as most Pakistan newspapers, have been assailing India for opening up her sorely needed Bhakra-Nangal canal system in northern India. Moreover, Pakistan's Prime Minister, Mohammed Ali, even is quoted as having called this event a "potential threat to peace in the sub-continent."

LONDON, July 22 -- The British Government announced today that Spain had given assurances that she would ban the export of arms to Egypt and to other countries that were not members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

LONDON, July 22 -- Research among centenarians in the United States has shown that persons who survive the "dangerous retiring age" of 60 to 70 rarely succumb to the diseases of old age. They are able to support themselves thereafter "emotionally as well as financially."

PARIS, July 22 -- Pierre Mendes-France, told the National Assembly today he had sought a truce in Indochina within thirty days of his confirmation as Premier because otherwise the French force in the north of that country would have been in "grave danger" in about that period.

HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., July 22 -- Two men, and possibly a third, were killed in the terrific explosion of 200,000 defective hand-grenade fuses in Cranbury, two miles from here, just before 10 A. M. today.

BOSTON, July 22 (UP) -- Bob Feller and Bob Lemon won an important double-header for Cleveland from the Boston Red Sox, 6 -- 3 and 5 -- 2, today to keep the Indians in the American League lead by one-half game over the runner-up New York Yankees.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 (UP) -- Home runs by Harvy Kuenn, Wayne Belardi, Frank Bolling and Jim Delsing lifted the Detroit Tigers to a 9-4 victory over the Philadelphia Athletics tonight before only 1,675 fans, smallest night crowd of the season at Connie Mack Stadium.

HONG KONG, Friday, July 23 (AP) -- A British Skymaster carrying seventeen persons ditched in the South China Sea near Red China's Hainan Island today and rescue efforts were hampered by the proximity to Communist waters.

Bank loans to business in the New York area are still declining. Commercial, industrial and agricultural loans outstanding on Wednesday totaled $7,486,000,000, a decline of $55,000,000 from the week before.
With a reform tax bill under consideration, Congress has the opportunity to correct double taxation of corporate dividends by going to the source of the problem, the taxation of corporate earnings.
TRENTON, July 22 -- The complex manipulations of the late Harold G. Hoffman in embezzling $300,000 have been traced to the early Thirties, a state official said today.
FORT DIX, N. J., July 22 -- An Army lieutenant, decorated in World War II, went on trial here today for allowing his men to be forced to stand at attention for an hour in 92-degree heat.

ATLANTA, July 22 (UP) -- State Attorney General Eugene Cook, president of the National Association of Attorneys General, said today he had refused to invite Herbert Brownell Jr., United States Attorney General, to the association's 1954 convention because of Mr. Brownell's "ruthless political" attacks on segregation, former President Truman and the late Senator Robert A. Taft.
MADRID, July 22 -- Instructions were understood today to have been issued by the Spanish Foreign Ministry to the customs authorities in Bilbao to halt all shipments of arms from that city.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 22 -- Gene Jester, 4-year-old brown gelding owned by Paul Wixom and George W. Lutz of Chicago, set a world pacing record of 1:38 2/5 over the six and one-half furlong route at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

NEW YORK art galleries that remain open during the early summer make a practice of putting on informal group shows. Some of the gallery regulars are represented by several examples each. A larger number of the artists may be represented by one example each. Some of the work is recent; some has been seen in one-man shows during the preceding season.

LAST Saturday at Monmouth Park in New Jersey some new racing silks appeared in the winner's circle. They were the sea blue and white of Arthur Godfrey, radio and television salesman, worn by Augie Catalano astride the 2-year-old Case Ace colt, Lord Willin'.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP) -- Free world cotton production in the 1954-55 season may be down about 10 per cent from this season, chiefly because of big cutbacks in the United States, the International Cotton Advisory Committee said today.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Association on American Indian Affairs has opened a Washington office headed by William Zimmerman, who was Assistant Commissioner of the Indian Bureau from 1933 to 1950.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Wheat growers will vote tomorrow in a nation-wide referendum on next year's marketing quota. It is generally predicted they will approve rigid controls designed to lop 7,000,000 acres of wheat from the nation's overloaded grain supplies.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 17 aggregated 694,545 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 (UP) -- Eddie Moylan, eighth-seeded Trenton stylist, upset Straight Clark as the other matches followed form in the men's state and women's Pennsylvania and Eastern States grass court tennis tournaments today at the Merion Cricket Club.

WASHINGTON, Friday, July 23 -- The Senate Republican leadership early today invoked closure, a maneuver to limit debate, in an effort to cut off the speechmaking that has stalled legislative deliberation for ten days.

Two new Kitchen Aid dishwashers and five new Maytag gas ranges were. presented to the press and the trade yesterday at the Statler Hotel. They are expected to be available at retail within thirty days.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Twenty-three prominent citizens today urged all Senators, regardless of party to vote for the Flanders resolution to censure Senator Joseph R. McCarthy for abuse of his position.

A Wall Street secret that has kept for eighteen years came out yesterday over talk about the new skyscraper that is to go up at 20-24 Broad Street. Its lower floors will be used as an addition to the New York Stock Exchange building next door.

GENEVA, July 22 -- The French will be required to abandon the air base of Xiengkhouang under the Laotian peace agreement. This detail of the Laos settlement, overlooked in yesterday's splurge of Indochina conference news, was revealed here today by a Laotian source.
A proposal to require garage spaces in all new nonresidential buildings was disapproved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
ATLANTA, July 22 -- A twenty-four member council to guide the political and scientific leadership of a sixteen-state region in a cooperative campaign to combat mental illness was proposed here today.
A record net income of $63,435,549 was achieved by the Shell Oil Company in the first six months this year. In the corresponding period a year ago the net was $50,744,359.
The Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday an appropriation of $661,610 to enlarge the probationary and psychiatric services of three city courts.

The National Cash Register Company made a slight improvement in earnings in the first six months, despite a second-quarter decrease in defense shipments to about $4,000,000 from $9,000,000 in the same quarter last year. Stanley C. Allyn, president, said yesterday the shipments were expected to be even lower in the last half of the year.
CAIRO, July 22 -- Egypt's Premier in a speech marking the second anniversary of the revolutionary regime charged tonight that Israeli aggressions threatened to cause an explosion in the Middle East.

The Senators who started to filibuster -- for that was what Senator Morse of Oregon admitted he and the others were doing -- against the amendments to the Atomic Energy Act had a legitimate criticism of President Eisenhower's power policy. They disapproved of his order to the Atomic Energy Commission to supply the Tennessee Valley Authority with privately produced power to take the place of power used by the A. E. C. itself.

GLEN COVE, L. I., July 22 -- The Glen Cove High School will start this fall an adult course in "beginner's Russian" to provide a linguistic bridge between local shopkeepers and members of the Soviet Union colony.

VIENNA, July 22 (AP) -- A Czech grocery clerk has escaped from Communist Czechoslovakia by swimming three miles under water in a submarine suit fashioned after that of a United States Navy frogman, United States officials here said today.
Windows so large that electric motors are needed to draw the blinds were installed yesterday at the Manufacturers Trust Company branch being built at Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street.

Like a champion who engages in a couple of tune-up bouts before making the big defense of his title, the Yankees took on and took over the Chicago White Sox twice yesterday at the Staduim. After a 4-3 victory in the opener, clinched by Mickey Mantle's tenth-inning homer, the Bombers romped to an 11-1 decision behind Harry Byrd's five-hit pitching.

GENEVA, July 21 -- The United States has dashed the hopes of some of the poorer countries that it might support the establishment of an international finance corporation to make loans to them on easy terms.
Standard Brands, Inc., had a consolidated first half net income of $6,014,101, compared with $5,142,733 for the 1953 first half.

DETROIT, July 22, (AP) -- The Chrysler Corporation's production came to a virtual standstill today as the number made idle by a strike at its main Dodge plant rose to 44,850. Its work force of hourly rated workers totals 66,000, but all assembly lines have been shut down.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Prospects of a session-end tie-up over the Administration's omnibus tax reform bill were on the wane today.
SAN JUAN, P. R., July 22 -- The twenty-eight-day-old Puerto Rican dock strike has labor amifications far beyond this tied-up island.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP) -- The Joint Committee on Defense Production said today it had exposed "gross irregularities" in the Government's extension of $3,000,000 in loans to a nonproductive tin mine in northern Alaska.

It was to be expected that the official Moscow line, as trumpeted by Pravda, would be that the United States has suffered a smashing diplomatic and political defeat at Geneva. It is interesting to observe, however, that a part of the first reaction in this line is the demand that talks on Korea be resumed.

" Out Without My Rubbers," the memoirs of John Murray Anderson, as told to his brother, Hugh Abercrombie Anderson, has been scheduled for fall publication by Library Publishers. The story of "Uncle Broadway" and the revue, the type of show he helped make popular, has many anecdotes about famous personalities of the theatre.
Net income of the Erie Railroad dipped more than 50 per cent in the first half of this year on a 16.3 per cent decline in gross revenues.
MOSCOW, Friday, July 23 (AP) -- The Soviet Government called officially today for a new international conference on reunification of Korea.
The forty-seven top executives of the New York City Transit Authority received salary increases of $80,000 yesterday.
The New York County Republican organization designated yesterday a slate of thirty-four candidates for the Legislature, Congress and local courts.

The wheels of American industry may not be quite so well oiled as usual this week, for at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel 2,000 secretaries of business executives are holding what a speaker called "one of the most beautiful conventions ever held in New York."
The Military Air Transport Service, which has a large fleet of transport aircraft in extensive international operations, has completed eighteen months with a perfect passenger safety record.

GENEVA, July 22 -- Under the Indochina settlement, the three armistice supervisory commissions, each composed of representatives of Canada, India and Poland, will operate as a general rule by majority vote.
Three large new groups of furniture, two of them arranged in settings distinguished by imaginative decorating will go on view to the public at Macy's on Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- A Government housing official said today the Justice Department had been asked to take criminal action in connection with "one of the nation's largest" Government-insured apartment developments -- a $22,000,000 project in near-by Arlington, Va.

MILWAUKEE, July 22 (UP) -- Eddie Mathews hit a two-run homer in the first inning and Joe Adcock provided the winning marker in the sixth with his second double for a 3-2 Milwaukee victory over the Phfilies today.
FLINT, Mich., July 22 -- The controversy between the Red Cross and the Flint Red Feather agency over disaster relief for 1953 tornado victims was settled today.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Heavy pressure is being put on the Eisenhower Administration to grant West Germany sovereignty. This campaign, from within the Senate, also is designed to permit West German rearmament with or without the consent of France.
The ninety-first annual convention of the New York State Federation of Labor ended yesterday at the Commodore Hotel. All officers were re-elected except one.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 22 -- The Indonesia-Netherlands conference on political and economic relations between the two countries is to end Saturday with the signature of a protocol formalizing a complete agreement.
Two of the fastest trips on record arranged by the Metropolitan Museum of Art, took forty travelers yesterday and Wednesday to the mysterious Egypt of thousands of years ago.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Iberia Airlines of Spain announced today it would apply immediately to the Civil Aeronautics Board for an operating certificate. The line hopes to start a thrice-weekly Madrid-New York service on Aug. 9.
BOMBAY, India, July 22 -- One Portuguese policeman was killed and five other persons were injured when Indian nationalists took over the Portuguese village of Dadra on India's west coast today.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Eisenhower has endorsed a proposal for a conference of United States and Latin-American business men to be held in New Orleans later this year.
PHILADELPHIA, July 22 -- The port of Philadelphia bustled with activity today as longshoremen returned to work.
GENEVA, July 22 -- The economic implications for France of the Indochina settlement are at least as mixed as the political ones.
PARIS, July 22 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from an address by French Premier Pierre Mendes-France today to the National Assembly:

LONDON, July 22 -- A very important time of year is drawing near again for the very important people in Britain's fashion world. The time is the semi-annual showing of fashion collections starting Monday; the people, the Incorporated Society of London Fashion Designers, otherwise known as the "Big Twelve."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 22 -- For the first time a major television network plans to produce its own motion pictures for TV showing.
, What's cooking in steel shares ?
The National Urban League devised strategy yesterday to cope with problems expected to arise from the recent Supreme Court decision against segregation in schools.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The State Department announced tentative plans today for a conference of Western and Asian nations on the formation of a Southeast Asian defense alliance. The meeting is to be held late next month or in early September.

The Salt Lake City Suburban Sanitary District, Utah, announced plans yesterday for borrowing $8,100,000 on serial bonds. Of the total, $6,000,000 will be revenue bonds. The remaining $2,100,000 will be general obligations.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., July 22 (UP) -- Thirty-seven of the forty-three members of the executive committee of the Monroe County Democratic Committee today were reported to favor Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., as the party's candidate for Governor this fall.
A decision that, if upheld on appeal, would materially reduce the estimated annual yield of $16,700,000 from the city's 5 per cent amusement tax was handed down yesterday in the Queens Supreme Court.

After extensive hearings a House Armed Services subcommittee has brought in a finding of some coddling of athletes in the Army, especially through "a glaring abuse of pass privileges" and too much granting of "compassionate leave." The committee, however, does not place blame on the athletes.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 22 -- Wilson F. Barnes Jr. of Mount Kisco, the defender, was eliminated but other top shotmakers remained in the running as the fifty-second Metropolitan Golf Association amateur championship tournament began today at the Garden City Country Club.
The marketing of spirits made news yesterday.

The appointment of the Rev. Robert R. Spears Jr. as vicar of the Protestant Episcopal Chapel of the Intercession, Trinity Parish, Broadway and 155th Street, was announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. John Heuss, rector of Trinity Church. The appointment will become effective on Oct.
Robert Moses has resigned as a trustee of the National Safety Council as the upshot of a five-week debate by mail over the relationship of speed to fatalities in auto crashes.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 23 -- Wind conditions described by all hands afterward as "awful" in the sixth point regatta of Larchmont Race Week nevertheless left some skippers in unassailable positions for series championships today.
DALLAS, Tex., July 23 -- A million or more Texans will vote tomorrow in their first election since they kicked over the Democratic traces and helped put General Eisenhower in the White House in 1952.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -Senator Harry F. Byrd said today that housing investigations had uncovered an "unsavory concoction of malfeasance, greed, collusion and graft," and he demanded that Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, start prosecutions promptly.
PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., July 23 (AP) -- As part of a Suffolk County civil defense drill, a fifty-two-inch make-believe bomb was set off last night with these results:

HOBOKEN, N. J., July 23 -- Sailing today for a three-and-one-half-month tour of Europe, 80-year-old Dr. Lee DeForest, widely known as the "father of radio," said that he had perfected a low-cost picture tube for color television.

A delegation of clergymen from Hungary and Czechoslovakia, who have received visas to attend the convention next month of the World Council of Churches in Evanston, Ill., came under attack here yesterday as "simple instruments, tools and slaves of the Communists."

POUND RIDGE, N. Y., July 23 -- Nature lovers sought today to raise $50,000 to buy segments of northeastern Westchester and western Connecticut estates "to protect one of the few truly primitive forest land remaining in this part of the country" -- the Mianus Gorge.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) -- Two errors in the first inning helped the Washington Senators to five runs tonight and Chuck Stobbs carried on from there to pitch an eight-hit 8-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

A near-record volume of traffic moving from New Jersey into New York over the George Washington Bridge last evening caused a two-hour tie-up, with automobiles backed up for a mile on the bridge approaches.

Thousands of persons bound for Manhattan aboard forty-two trains of the New York Central And the New York, New Haven and Hartford railroads were delayed yesterday morning for period ranging from a few minutes to an hour and forty-eight minutes.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- President Eisenhower made another try today at getting action on his health reinsurance bill, but Senator William F. Knowland of California, the Republican leader, was not hopeful. The Majority Leader said he would explore the situation.
ABOARD THE LINER CRISTOFORO COLOMBO, at sea, July 23 -- The newest Italian entry in trans-Atlantic service will arrive at her West Forty-fourth Street pier between 8 and 9 o'clock tomorrow morning.
Paul A. Pfeffer, who was convicted of fatally beating a seaman in Rockaway Beach, Queens, last August 22, won a new trial yesterday as the result of another man's confession.
Remington Rand, Inc., had an estimated net income of $7,048,132 in the six months ended on June 30 as compared with earnings of $5,858,546 in the similar period of 1953.

ROME, July 23 -- The bill to ratify the European Defense Community treaty was approved today by the Justice Committee of the Chamber of Deputies. This nearly completed the committee stage of its progress through the Chamber. The vote was 77 to 18, with three abstentions.

Probably no sum of money spent by the city government during the coming year will do more good than the $661,610 voted unanimously by the Board of Estimate on Thursday to expand the probational, and psychiatric services of three courts: the Court of Special Sessions, the Court of Domestic Relations and the Magistrate's Court.
Although the closing of the musical "The Golden Apple" at the Alvin Theatre has been announced for Aug. 7, the attraction may return to the playhouse after an out-of-town engagement.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., July 23 (AP) -- Fay Crocker was six under women's par today as she won the qualifying medal in the $3,500 Fort Wayne women's open golf tournament with a 34, 35 -- 69.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Three of America's most famous fighting ships are assured of snug harbors and perpetual care under a bill signed by President Eisenhower today.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 23 (AP) -- The French high command today called a halt to offensive action throughout Indochina. It announced the Geneva cease-fire would go into effect in north Vietnam at 7 A. M. Tuesday, July 27 [8 P. M. Eastern daylight time].
MIAMI, Fla., July 23 (AP) -A "skin diver," Ed Fisher, set a world endurance record today by camping on the ocean floor for twenty-four hours:

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (UP) -- Art Larsen, Louise Brough, the defending champion, and Mrs. Beverly Baker Fleitz today gained the finals of the state men's and Pennsylvania and Eastern States women's grass court tennis championship at the Merion Cricket Club.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 23 -- The Government ordered precautionary mobilization of the country's tiny armed forces and reserves today following reports of armed attacks on the villages of Vara Blanca and La Cinchona, barely twenty miles from the capital.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., July 23 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century added the Women's Tri-County Golf Association's championship to her list of titles today as she defeated the defender, Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis in the thirty-six-hole final.

Along with such romantic durables as the cowboy, inventor, reporter, the movies have done well by the American secretary. She has and does serve as the dea ex machina, the love interest, the comic relief and once in a great while as the villain. She not only marries the boss on occasion but also saves the firm from failure and discloses the murderer.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, July 23 -The sixth International Cancer Congress opened here today.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) A Negro youngster has been named a page boy to the United States Supreme Court. He is the first of his race to be so honored.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Atomic Energy Bill, now before Congress, has three broad objectives:
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Many diners-out who like a quiet atmosphere will be indignant to learn that an exporter has been punished for grinding juke-box records into powder.
The following is a round-up of "do-it-yourself" products now on the market that may be of interest to homemakers:
PARIS, July 23 -- All of the United States citizens in Geneva who received invitations to come to Paris for loyalty hearings have come here and have been heard, it was disclosed officially today.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 23 -- Mal Galletta of North Hills and Gordon Stott of Nassau stole the show by engaging in a twenty-four-hole quarter-final-round match as play in the fifty-second Metropolitan Golf Association amateur championship reached the semi-finals today at the Garden City Country Club.
NEW DELHI, India, July 23 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today that India would "sympathetically" consider an invitation to participate in Indochina's armistice supervisory commissions.
HONG KONG, Saturday, July 24 -- The pilot of a British airliner that crashed off the Chinese Communist island of Hainan yesterday said here today the plane was shot down by two MIG jet fighters.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, today charged a York, Pa., man with an attempt to bribe his way into an appointment as postmaster at York. He named the man as George D. Shirey, a cost accountant.

The feature at the Saratoga-at-Jamaica meeting today will be the Saranac Handicap for 3-year-olds. Fifteen have been named to race in the forty-seventh running of the mile and a sixteenth event and if all face the starter the swag will total $31,250, a record for the stakes.
Charles P. Taft's letter published on July 16, opposing American manufacturers in the watch tariff case, does not do justice to the facts.

Commodity prices moved generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was limited in many markets by the usual week-end evening of holdings. Potatoes, coffee, cotton-seed oil, soybean oil, wool, silk and tin ended stronger; cocoa, rubber and hides closed lower, and sugar, burlap and zinc were mixed.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., July 23 -- A supercommunications channel that greatly out-performs the coaxial cable for multiple television network operations has reached a high degree of efficiency here. Army engineers and scientists say it now transmits easily thirty or more complete television programs and that the "limit Still seems far away." in transmitting programs about the country and in receiving them in homes.

One of the major conclusions drawn from a three-week "education workshop" on family life at Teachers College, Columbia University, was that courses in marriage, family living and boy-girl relations must extend downward through the secondary school level.
One of the good things about vacation is that it gives an opportunity to see what lies on the other side of the hill. It is a common failing of man to wish to know what is there.
ALBANY, July 23 -- Robert Moses has threatened to resign as chairman of the State Power Authority in the face of an open rebellion against his policies by a majority of the five-member agency.
A 22-year-old woman held up a Broadway dress shop with a toy pistol last night because, she told the police, her husband was unemployed and their 2-year-old son had to be fed.

PHENIX CITY, Ala., July 23 (AP) -- Armed National Guardsmen kept a tightening grip of law and order on troubled Phenix City today in a military occupation perhaps unparalleled in the Nation's history.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Consumers Price Index for the United States went up one-tenth of one per cent between mid-May and mid-June. Ewan Clague, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said today that the change was "so near stability it's insignificant."

The Royal McBee Corporation announced yesterday the election of Philip M. Zenner as president and Allan A. Ryan as board chairman, effective July 31. The corporation is the result of the merger of the Royal Typewriter Company, Inc., and the McBee Company, approved recently by shareholders of both concerns.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- Ferris Fain, first baseman for the Chicago White Sox, will have his injured right knee operated on next week and may be out of action the remainder of the season.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -The House of Representatives today cited two women and fifteen men for contempt in refusing to answer questions or produce documents at hearings before the House Committee on Un-American Activities relative to Communist activities.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (UP) -- The Baltimore Orioles pushed the Philadelphia Athletics into the American League cellar tonight by pounding out thirteen hits in a 7-5 victory. The Orioles rose to seventh place.

Both the Senate and the House have enacted by unanimous vote that portion of the President's legislative program which gives "new hope for the handicapped." The new legislation will increase the present federal-state vocational rehabilitation program from the 60,000 disabled now aided annually to 200,000 by 1959.

FLORENCE, Italy, July 23 -- Masterful handling of materials gives its exceptional character to the collection of Carosa of Rome, whether they are of cottons combining checks and stripes, or of lustrous silks. It shows a profound knowledge of the art of dressmaking.

SALMON fishermen and surfcasters have many things in common, including persistence that defies disappontment, and a sport that is influenced, to a greater extent than most forms of angling, by weather and water conditions.
ST. PAUL, July 23 -- The highlight of the opening day of match play in the Professional Golfers Association championship was supplied by 39-year-old Jim Browning of Weston, Mass.

W. R. Grace Co., the big international trading, shipping, and industrial company, plans to add to its chemical manfacturing interests. The company disclosed last night that it was negotiating a merger with the Dewey and Almy Chemical company of Cambridge, Mass.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has formally adopted the new Form S-9, providing simplified registration for high grade corporate debt securities. The simplified form was first proposed by the agency in May.
The dismissal of three associate professors of Hunter College who admitted past membership in the Communist party was urged yesterday.
PARIS, July 23 -- Tiny lumps of anthracite coal, grains of rice, artichoke leaves and shells of pink shrimp are media used by Achille, a young modist who has Paris talking.
Haverford Township School District Authority, Pa., sold yesterday $3,525,000 of revenue bonds to Drexel Co., and associates at an interest cost of 2.3396 per cent.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Under Secretary of State, returned today from the Geneva conference and ejected the charge that the Indochina settlement was "another Munich."

In this season when fabrics are uppermost in many fashion discussions, none has caused more interest than the sixteen-ounce pure silk coating called Set-a-Cascia. Presented in the showing of Monte-Sano Pruzan's collection, it is magnificent in texture and design.
A $6,910,000 reconstruction of the Manhattan plaza of the Brooklyn Bridge was officially initiated yesterday by Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack.

The New York Telephone Company announced yesterday that faster service to many New Jersey points would begin at 12:01 A. M. tomorrow. The improvement will affect the users of 630,000 instruments in midtown Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- John Foster Dulles called today for a declaration of intentions by the Allies and the free nations of Southeast Asia to deter Communist aggression there until a treaty organization could take shape.

PARIS, July 23 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France won the approval of the French National Assembly today for the truce in Indochina. The vote was 462 to 13. Most of the members of the Popular Republican party, which has hitherto conducted foreign policy, abstained from the balloting.
DETROIT, July 23 (AP) -- The nation's automobile plants will build only 120,363 vehicles this week, Ward's Reports said today.

Zuhtu Eren, a 58-year-old chef who apprenticed in the kitchens of the sultan's palace in Istanbul, prepared a Turkish lunch yesterday for a small group of Americans on board the Tarsus. Mr. Eren is ahciligi -- that is, head cook -- on beard Turkey's goodwill vessel of floating exhibits, which will leave tomorrow for Istanbul after a six-day stop here.
WASHINGTON, Saturday, July 24 -- The nation's wheat growers voted today by a narrow margin to fix marketing quota controls for the 1955 crop.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Saturday, July 24 -- The Communist party will be banned in West Pakistan today as a "danger to public peace."
GENEVA, July 22 -- Political names in Indochina may become a bit simpler as a result of the peace settlement just concluded in Geneva.

British woolen mills are actively engaged in development of wool-and-synthetic blends, but do not plan to export any quantities of these goods, according to Robert M. Campbell, vice president of the Rogers Peet Company, men's wear retailers.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- All Communists and other political prisoners of Vietnam are to be released under the truce agreement, the text of which, previously undisclosed, became available to The New York Times today.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- The House Merchant Marine Committee today approved a bill to authorize the spending of $25,000,000 to modernize ships in the Government's laid-up merchant fleet.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Treasury reported today that its offering of $3,500,000,000 in tax anticipation certificates had been oversubscribed by at least 3 to 1.
The successful marketing of $150,000,000 of General Motors Acceptance Corporation debentures has removed the recent uncertainties in the market for new corporate securities.

LENOX, Mass., July 23 -- The tenth program of the Berkshire Festival, given tonight in the concert-theatre hall, began with a Handel Concerto Grosso and the so-called "Military" Symphony of Haydn, conducted very effectively by Charles Munch.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) -The Defense Department has ordered its "big team" of twenty-four civilian and military leaders to refrain from writing signed articles for magazines and newspapers.
The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals is threatened with a strike because of its refusal to recognize an American Federation of Labor union as bargaining agent.

HANOI, Vietnam, July 23 -- French officials here are preparing for the greatest civilian flight from communism since the mass exodus of North Koreans from Hungnam in December, 1950. That was the culmination of the first Chinese Red offensive in the Korean war.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 23 (AP) -- Katie Key, the 2-5 favorite, added another victory to her ever-growing string tonight at Roosevelt Raceway when the 7-year-old bay mare raced a 2:02 1-5 mile for a length and a half triumph over Faber Hanover in the Bellmore Trot.

Marriner S. Eccles, former Chairman of the Federal Reserve System, spoke in San Francisco this week before the International Consumers Credit Conference. The prescription he had to offer in the present economic situation was no doubt a palatable one for this particular audience, but it seemed to us to be a little out of character for the forthright Mr. Eccles.

GENEVA, July 23 -- Important parts of the framework within which trade is carried on among the non-Communist nations are being rebuilt, or at least repainted. In various international organizations, in different capitals and in a multitude of negotiations among officials of central banks and governments the work goes forward.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 23 -- India is taking the initiative to try to start new United Nations consideration of two of the biggest problems before the organization: Korea and atomic energy.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- Unbeaten Royal Note, to be ridden by Eddie Arcaro is the 5-2 favorite in a field of sixteen 2-year-olds named for tomorrow's six-furlongs Arlington Futurity.

Edgar F. Kaiser, president of Willys Motors, Inc., issued a statement yesterday answering a wide range of rumors regarding the company's future. However, Mr. Kaiser did not deny that the company's automobile division producing Kaiser and Willys passenger cars is for sale.

CHICAGO, July 23 (UP) -- Danny Schell's bases-full single in the thirteenth inning provided the Philadelphia Phillies with a 5-to-3 victory and a doubleheader split with the Chicago Cubs today, after the Cubs had taken the opener, 5 to 2.

LONDON July 23 -- Delegates to the International Congress of Gerontology here have come to the almost unanimous conclusion that unsolved problems of the aging process lie in sections of living cell beyond magnification powers of the latest microscopes.

This morning one of our city's official doormen -- a Sandy Hook pilot -- will welcome a new addition to the mighty fleet of passenger vessels serving the Port of New York. The newcomer, the Cristoforo Colombo, flies the house flag of the Italian Line, an old member of the New York shipping fraternity.

LOS ALAMOS, N. Mex., July 23 -- Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said there had been no significant change in commission security regulations under the Eisenhower Administration.

In an interesting letter published in The Times of July 19 it was suggested that decorative sculpture be saved from buildings about to be demolished and that the statues and other ornaments so obtained be placed in our squares and our parks. The cost, the writers suggested, would be nominal and a foundation should be created to finance the undertaking.

The Department of Christian Social Relations of the Protestant Council of the City of New York, reorganized two years ago under the chairmanship of Robert McCurdy Marsh, former State Supreme Court Justice, will institute bimonthly meetings starting in September.
TRENTON, July 23 -- Former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman misappropriated $265,000 of State Motor Vehicle funds between 1930 and 1936, Attorney General Grover C. Richman revealed today.

MILWAUKEE, July 23 -- The "big deal" of last winter that sent Johnny Antonelli, among other chattels, to New York for Bobby Thomson, a transaction that to now had brought sadness to this city, paid a dividend to Milwaukee tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Thomas W. La Venia, a McCarthy subcommittee investigator, asserted tonight that security clearance had been denied him partly as a result of a convincing Secret Service "playboy" role he had used to break a 1943 plot against President Roosevelt.

DETROIT, July 23 (AP) -- The United Auto Workers International, C. I. O., ordered Chrysler Corporation strikers back to work tonight on a finding that their walkout was unauthorized and a contract violation.

Warnings against the inroads of communism in the Latin-American Republics were issued yesterday at a ceremony commemorating the 171st anniversary of the birthday of Simon Bolivar, South American military leader and statesman.

BONN, Germany, July 23 -- The Federal Cabinet met today in secret session to examine the politican and diplomatic consequences of the defection or abduction, as the case may be, of Dr. Otto John, chief of the West German intelligence service.

BERLIN, July 23 -- A voice purportedly that of Dr. Otto John, West Germany's counterpart of J. Edgar Hoover, was broadcast repeatedly over the East German radio tonight stating he had defected to the East.
KAZAN, U. S. S. R., July 14 -- Gone are the "Burlaki" and their mournful chant from the banks of the River Volga.

Lumber production in the week ended July 17 continued low owing to labor troubles in the Northwest. Production was 42.8 per cent below the comparable week last year, shipments 40.6 per cent and orders 43.2 per cent. Following are the weekly statistics in thousands of board feet:
