LONDON, July 23 -- The limelight in the stock markets shifted today from Government funds to industrial shares. The rise on Wall Street and some favorable company statements helped states to recover further during the morning, but some slipped nightly later.

Motion picture houses and other amusement places were warned yesterday that the city expected them to comply strictly with the 5 per cent amusement tax, despite the ruling made by Supreme Court Justice Nicholas M. Pette on Thursday.

The one-story industrial building at 154-56 South Van Brunt Street in Englewood, N. J., has been sold by the New Jersey Realty Company to the Fifty Associates, a Boston investment concern which has realty holdings throughout the country.

LONDON, July 23 -- The British Government announced tonight it was sending Antony H. Head, War Secretary, to Cairo tomorrow for top-level talks with Egyptian Government leaders over the proposed British withdrawal from the Suez Canal base.
The National Labor Relations Board in Washington yesterday directed that 657 of the challenged ballots cast in the May 26 waterfront election here be opened and counted.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- The wheat market showed considerable strength at times today. But after registering good gains there was a reaction on reports of local rains in Texas, Oklahoma and Kansas, which took the edge off the demand.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- President Eisenhower today nominated Raymond L. Rhodes of Hawthorne, N. J., to be Controller of Customs for the Port of New York. He succeeds Margaret Daley Campbell of New Jersey, whose recess appointment had expired.
KENNETT, Mo., July 23 (AP) -- A dozen Negro children today chose integration an decided to pass up the cotton vacation that always means spending-money in the fall.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 23 (Canadian Press) -- The New York A. C. moved into third place today as the Buffalo West Side Club increased its lead in the seventy-second Royal Canadian Henley, Regatta.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 23 -- Abuzz with expectation, fifty United Nations employes kept a rendezvous late this afternoon in the lobby of the Secretariat Building. Within an hour they were on their way from Grand Central Station to Pittsfield, Mass., to sample in a forty-eight-hour interlude American culture and hospitality.

Merger rumors continued to dominate stock market activity yesterday. After a strong opening, which carried The New York Times combined average back to the highest mark since June 5, 1930, prices sagged, only to recover near the close and end the day and week with a plus sign.
" Press Perspective," an examination of American journalism, will be presented by WNYC in a series of broadcasts next week as the sixth of ten "festivals" scheduled for 1954.

CINCINNATI, July 23 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates picked up their first Crosley Field victory of the year tonight, downing the Cincinnati Redlegs, 7 -- 4. Sid Gordon hit a pinch homer with one aboard in the seventh inning to break a 4-4 tie and the Pirates added an insurance run in the ninth on a double, sacrifice and single.

A group of artists, writers and teachers has purchased the five-story dwelling at 20 West Sixteenth Street from Roy Estates Inc. The buyers, headed by Dorothy Koppleman, will use the first floor of the house for an art gallery and lecture hall and will occupy apartments on the upper floors.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The retirement of Charles W. Crawford, commissioner since 1951 of the Food and Drug Administration, after thirty-seven years in that Federal service, was announced today by the Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, Oveta Culp Hobby.

SAN JUAN, P. R., July 23 -- Puerto Rico's Economic Development Administration -- Fomento -- drew a bitter picture today of long-range effects on this island's self-help program from the twenty-nine-day-old longshoremen's strike.
The cotton futures market moved yesterday 2 points higher to 5 points lower than on Thursday. Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was light.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The index of primary market prices declined 0.1 point to 110.1 over the week ended Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. A fractional dip in average prices for farm products and processed foods was responsible for the decrease, as average prices of industrial materials were unchanged again.
Many of the World War II Liberty ships in the "mothball fleet" have been drafted for useful peacetime work.
Dr. Russell W. Peterson has been named research director for Dacron polyester fiber by the textile fibers department of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., Wilmington, Del.
LONDON, July 23 -- With Left-Wing spokesmen in the lead, the clamor for reopening of negotiations with the Soviet Union for a united and neutral Germany is mounting in Britain.

A little over a year has passed since the coffee freeze occurred in Brazil and the coffee freeze-out began in the United States. The passing year has demonstrated that the will to raise coffee prices has been more influential pricewise than coffee supply factors.

Another phase of the reorganization of the Police Department was completed yesterday when Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams swore in his six deputy commissioners. There were seven formerly, plus the secretary of the department, who handled public relations.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A system for the safe removal of those troublesome and sometimes hazardous pins that come in new shirts was patented this week by Bernard V. Sturz of Mountain Lakes, N. J.

All the thrills, the drama, the excitement and the tenseness of a world series were crowded into one game at the Stadium last night when the Cleveland Indians met and passed the test put to them by the runner-up Yankees.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Following is the text of the agreement on cessation of hostilities in Vietnam signed in Geneva Wednesday by the commander in chief of the French Union forces in Indochina and the commander in chief of the People's Army of Vietnam (other agreements were signed with Cambodia and Laos ) :

BOSTON, July 23 (AP) -- Virgil Trucks pitched airtight ball in relief of Harry Dorish and Chico Carrasquel led an eleven-hit Chicago attack with three singles tonight as the White Sox defeated Boston, 7 -- 1. The game was delayed ninety minutes at the start by heavy rain.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- Following is the 46-to-41 roll-call vote by which the Senate today adopted a motion of Senator William F. Knowland of California, Republican leader, to table, and and thus kill without further debate, an amendment of Senator John O. Pastore, Democrat of Rhode Island, to the Atomic Energy Bill.

WASHINGTON, Saturday, July 24 -- The Democratic filibustering vise remained clamped on the Senate early today. As the third straight around-the-clock session rolled on the Republican leadership planned new moves to force an end to the legislative deadlock.

ST. LOUIS, July 23 -- Russ Meyer didn't have it tonight and the Cardinals beat him and the Dodgers, 6 -- 4, for the Redbirds' fifth straight victory at Busch Stadium -- all achieved during the suspension of their manager, Eddie Stanky.

To encourage the development of new creative writers, J. B. Lippincott is sponsoring a new $2,500 prize contest for young novelists. It is open to residents of the United States and Canada who are 35 years old or younger. Half the award will be an outright prize and the rest an advance against royalties.

HANOI, Vietnam, July 23 -- With their continued harassing of the French Union garrisons in the upper Red River Delta, the Communist-led Vietminh forces seemed intent on driving home the propaganda line that the Geneva settlement was brought about by their military strength.
FORT DIX, N .J., July 23 -- A special court martial today acquitted an Army lieutenant charged with allowing his men to be held at attention for an hour in 92-degree heat.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 23 -- Guy Madison will get a chance to don modern clothes for his role in "Five Against the House."
The ideal secretary, chosen yesterday from among 2,000 possible candidates, earns $80 a week, is 30 years old and is happy to do personal errands and work overtime for her boss.

Thirty-six hundred matchsticks dropped into the pocket of a dishonest employe cost a retail store $3,600. These matchsticks were his record of the money that he had placed in the cash drawer but had failed to ring up on the register.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -Senate Republicans and Democrats accused each other today of responsibility for the Housing scandals that had given many contractors multi-million dollar "windfall" profits.

NOW we can get a definition as to when a character in a book is real: it is real when the novelist knows everything about it. He may not choose to tell us all he knows -- many of the facts, even of the kind we call obvious, may be hidden.

The Cleveland Indians extended their American League lead to two and a half games yesterday by defeating the Yankees, 5 to 4, at the Stadium. Larry Doby's two-run homer in the tenth inning provided the winning margin. Meanwhile, the Giants lost for the second straight time to the Milwaukee Braves, 5 to 4.
ITHACA, N. Y., July 24 (AP) -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. called today for social and economic aid to win the promised Indochina election for the West.

This is not the time for acrimony or recrimination over the terms of the Indochina truce. It is the time to think clearly and to move swiftly if freedom in Southeast Asia is to be preserved. If the Communists live up to the agreements reached there will be a free and supervised election in Vietnam two years hence.
SAN JUAN, P. R., July 24 -- Both the Puerto Rican House of Representatives and the Senate tonight approved bills to authorize Government seizure of the docks so that maritime operations might resume.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Ford Foundation charged today that it had been publicly maligned by witnesses at Congressional hearings.

Tufts College has announced a new cooperative program with the General Electric Company of Lynn, Mass. Under the plan, which goes into effect this fall, the company will send a group of selected young men to the Tufts Engineering School to study mechanical engineering in a four-year apprentice-training program, leading to an associate degree in science. President Nils Y. Wessell of Tufts explained that the program will offer students practical as well as academic work.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Senator McCarthy said today he no longer would ask the Pentagon to give clearance to any of his aides for access to secret information.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, called today for "an outraged public" to cooperate with police agencies in helping "to stem the rising tide" of bank robberies, burglaries and larcencies.

MILWAUKEE, July 24 -- Although Leo Durocher, the skipper, still hasn't flashed the "fasten seat belts' signal," there is no denying the Giants' pennant flight has suddenly encountered some rough jouncing.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A Senate subcommittee declared today that a domestic watch and clock industry maintained "alive and vital" was essential to national defense.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 24 -- The Larchmont Yacht Club's vice commodore, S. G. Rodgers, left his own Race Week today to compete in the Stamford Y. C.'s second annual predicted-log contest for power cruisers and emerged a winner with an astounding accuracy in navigation.
LONDON, July 24 -- Expectation in official London tonight was that, after discussion in the Cabinet and with Britain's allies, the Soviet offer would be rejected.
The dean of the horse-trainers had another big winner at the Jamaica track yesterday.

DALLAS, July 24 -- Hot, dry weather continued to act as a brake on most Southwestern business factors last week. Agriculturally, the weather was pleasing only to some of the region's cotton farmers. Other crops and pasture lands suffered.
WASHINGTON, Sunday, July 25 -- The Senate temporarily ended one of the longest filibusters in its history at 11:48 o'clock last night.
HARTFORD, July 24 -- Control of the State Senate in the 1955 session of the Connecticut General Assembly may return to the Democrats even though a Republican Governor is elected.

THE first jet transport built in the United States -- a big, beautifully designed, swept-wing superliner of the air with extensively tested power plants -- has made its first flight, but nevertheless airline passengers need not start forming lines to buy tickets for their first jet rides.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 24 -- Withdrawal of United States support from the United Nations program of technical as sistance to underdeveloped countries would mean the collapse of the entire global effort, a representative of the world organization acknowledged today.

PARIS, July 24 -- A lawyer-economist wrested a diplomatic victory this week from a military and political defeat. Such was the achievement of Premier Mendes-France at Geneva when he negotiated a truce in the Indochinese war on better terms than anyone in the West had expected.
In more ways than one, this is a booming boating season for outboards. Once the "putt-putts" were derided as a nuisance. Now they are almost the tail that wags the dog.
MOSCOW, July 24 (AP) -- The Soviet press launched a major drive against religion today. Editorials in Pravda and the Literary Gazette called for intensified anti-religious activity.

SOME cheerful people up in Vermont are advancing the appealing notion of do-nothing vacations. The plan seems to be to invite visitors to spend their holidays in that state serenely avoiding conscientious sociableness and all those maniacal forms of organized violence that lie under the deceptive rubric of sport.

Last year, in the week corresponding to that ended on Friday, heavy rain on Thursday washed out much of the week's retail sales gains. This year the weather was generally favorable. The result, according to estimates by merchants, was sales about 10 per cent ahead of the same week in 1953.

POUND RIDGE, N. Y., July 24 -- A brand-new historical document, fresh as a daisy, lies in the hands of this township's proud officials. It bears witness to a promise that the Legislative Manual will henceforth and forever more (they hope) spell the place name as two words, abandoning the unpopular mouthful "Poundridge."

GLADIOLUS growers and hobbyists across the land are eagerly watching the progress of their favorite flower nowadays. For the annual show schedule is on the horizon and prizes and awards await those who enter the finest spikes of named varieties and new seedlings.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 24 -To most residents of the Great Plains the summers of 1934 and 1936 have a special and very unhappy significance. For these were the years of the great droughts. These were the years when thousands of acres of crop and range lands were ruined, when hordes of grasshoppers ate every shred of vegetation, when cattle and sheep were driven from the ranges and sold at calamity prices.
Seven months ago Francis W. H. Adams stepped into the city's second highest and toughest job -- that of Police Commissioner.

Caribbean baseball, a proposal for inter-league games between American and National League clubs and changes in the baseball draft law will be discussed here tomorrow when the major leagues hold their annual mid-summer meetings, normally held at the time of the All-Star game.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., July 24 (AP) -- Marilynn Smith, a rabbit's foot bobbing from her belt, collected three straight birdies and a 7-under-par 68 today to gain the lead in the Fort Wayne women's open golf tournament with a 141 total.

ST. LOUIS, July 24 -- The Dodgers beat the Cardinals tonight after the home side virtually refused to accept a victory as a gift. The Brooks wound up winning, 7 -- 6, following almost three hours of play before 30,700 fans at Busch Stadium.

JIM DAIGRE had been coming to Big Creek every summer since he was 9. He and his family came to escape the heat of town. Beyond the Daigre house was the swamp, and beyond the swamp was Big Creek itself, which ran into Blake's Hole, where the bones of young Fitz Blake were said to spin to this day, caught in an endless whirlpool.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 24 -- The prospect of an early infusion of oil revenues sent new vigor coursing through the Iranian body politic this week, enabling the once debilitated patient to move confidently at home and abroad.

In the speech that won him approval as Premier, M. Mendes-France promised the Assembly he would "submit * * * a coherent and detailed program for economic recovery and ask the necessary powers to realize it." It was a promise in a field dear to his heart.

DALLAS, Tex, Sunday, July 25--Texas' "Loyalist" Democrats, who were left in the lurch when a majority of their party swung to support of Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1952, made a spectacular comeback in the State's primary election yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- President Eisenhower told Congress today the Federal Government had provided $66,683,033 for flood, drought and other disaster relief to the states since the program was authorized in 1951.

Stars may twinkle to the delight of youngsters who wonder what they, are, according to the nursery rhyme, but to astronomers twinkling is a nuisance. The atmosphere "boils" at night when the earth is radiating heat accumulated during the day, just as it visibly "boils" over a steam radiator on a wintry day. Stars dance in the telescope. Photographs are blurred. There is always uncertainty about the exact brightness and position of a particular star.

THE Government of India has invited children under 16 from all countries to enter a stamp-designing competition for which a gold medal and fifty other prizes will be awarded. The theme of each design is to be "India as I see it."

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 24 -- Senator John L. McClellan, the conservative Arkansan whose righteous indignation and stern tones impressed a national television audience during the Army-McCarthy hearings, is at grips with another Mac. The scene of battle, far from the hearing room and the television cameras in Washington, is the hot, dusty campaign trail through this state, and the opponent this time is former Gov. Sid McMath.

THAT newly formed firm of Bruce Becker and Robert Ellis Miller could cause more than a casual ripple on Broadway this season. Not too long ago the gentlemen delighted the admirers of Eva Gabor with the news that they had signed her to appear here in November in Lorenzo Semple Jr.'s adaptation of Jacques Deval's "Tonight in Samarcand."

In the series of photographs entitled "Eight Key Ambassadors" (July 11) you pictured the Ambassador from India standing before a statuette which your caption described as "Nataraj, the Indian Goddess of the Dance who is supposed to bring good luck."

I DON'T see how it is possible to look at the exhibition, "Early Works by Modern Masters" (which was arranged by that excellent and too-little-sung department at the Museum of Modern Art -- the Department of Circulating Exhibitions) without being nudged by some disturbing thoughts.

AMONG the more persistent production legends to emanate from Hollywood is the one to the effect that when in doubt, the idea is to make either a musical or a Western. And, naturally, a happy combination of both is a consummation devoutly to be wished.

CHICAGO, July 24 (UP) -- Ralph Kiner, the Cubs' strong-armed outfielder who had driven in only four runs in the last twenty-nine games, smashed a triple off the centerfield wall with two men on to spark the Cubs to a 4-to-0 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today.

BAR HARBOR, Me. -- Sidewalk superintendents on vacation in Maine this year will have an opportunity to watch the construction of a new international terminal for the Bar Harbor-Yarmouth ferry, which is expected to begin operation next year.

EACH generation begins its career by a rupture with the past, as if thus only it could conquer its predecessors and find its own way. Yet only in mature civilizations does the unhappiness of the inheritors produce literary and artistic revolutions every twenty or thirty years.

TUCSON, Ariz. -- A horse, according to Webster's New International Dictionary, is "a large, solidhoofed, herbivorous mammal (Equus caballus) domesticated by man since a prehistoric period and used as a beast of burden, or draft animal, or for riding."

RED SKELTON is still having his television troubles. He returned last week in a new format, a one-hour revue, which turned out to be the same familiar Skelton characterizations dissipated among an odd assortment of guest attractions. Put into a disjointed, unwieldy production that never showed signs of where it was headed, both Mr. Skelton and his guests suffered accordingly.

A STRANGE, exciting, and an anxious time, too, it was in Newfoundland that summer for Angus and his townspeople in Ship Cove Silent, heavy fogs blanketed the fish ing outport most of the time. And father was away in St. Johns where he could find enough work for a carpenter. Of course the big thing that made it seem most like a dream was the treasure hunt.

MUNI LIEBLEIN, who took the picture reproduced on this page, begs to differ with those who think that child photography is easy. The fact that a good deal of it is being done does not prove it is easy, since only rarely do photographers come through with anything that captures the distinctive quality of true childhood.
ULYANOVSK, U. S. S. R., July 15 -- To anyone interested in the life of late Nineteenth Century Russia a visit to this Volga River city formerly called Simbirsk is recommended.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 24 (AP) -- Serbian Orthodox church sources said here tonight that Arsenije Bradvarevic, Metropolitan of Montenegro, has been arrested for alleged anti-state activities.
BARNAUL, U. S. S. R., June 13 -- Horse racing is general throughout the Soviet Union. Most large cities and many small ones have tracks.

BERLIN commemorated the re-election of President Theodor Heuss of Western Germany on July 17 by issuing on that day an overprint on the 20pf bright red Freedom Bell stamp of 1953. The black four-line overprint reads: "Wahl des Bundespraesidenten in Berlin. 17. Juli 1954."

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A 13 per cent slash in funds requested by President Eisenhower for the Mutual Security program was recommended to the House of Representatives today by its Appropriations Committee.

" Good morning, who owns you today?" This might be the standard greeting among wool textile manufacturers, as an expression of their reaction to the recent mergers in the industry. The mergers, incidentally, are speeding elimination of fiber lines of demarcation among producers of wool, cotton and synthetic fabrics.
That small cog in the distribution machine, the retail salesperson, is coming in for a lot of attention.

I wish to protest that the picture display "On a Sunday in the Park" (July 4 contains a serious iolation of the canonical law governing pictures of Central Park Lake rowers, and I would not be surprised if you were keelhauled by the United States Navy as a result.

THERE are few Americans not familiar with pictures of the giant cactus or Saguaro. Beloved by cartoonists and commercial artists as a symbol, it means "Scene: The Far West" just as much as the Public Library lions mean "New York."

BOISE, Idaho, July 24 -- Chief interest in Idaho's Aug. 10 primary centers on the Democratic Senatorial contest in which former Senator Glen H. Taylor, the erstwhile "Singing Cowboy," is running against two rivals. On the Republican side, the incumbent Senator Henry C. Dworshak is regarded as virtually certain of renomination.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 24 -- Red Sails, 6-year-old chestnut horse owned by Henry T. King of Lynn, Ind., came on from the backstretch to win the $6,500 Levittown, a free-for-all mile pace at Roosevelt Raceway, tonight.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. (UP) -- Youth prevailed in the men's and women's finals of the Mason-Dixon tennis tournament today as 17-year-old Mike Green of Miami Beach and 14-year-old Bonnie Loving of Charlottesville, Va., scored surprise victories.

GUATEMALA, July 24 -- Col. Luis Cruz Salazar has been named Guatemalan Ambassador to the United States. The 34-year-old Colonel Salazar, a former student at the United States Army Information Center in Carlisle, Pa., is a well known anti Communist and friend of the United States.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, July 24 -- A meeting of cancer specialists here heard pleas today for international agreements to bar the use in foodstuffs of dyes and other ingredients known to cause cancer or suspected of causing it.

FOUR French film projects of the eighteen now before the cameras are likely to reach New York screens and attract attention there. "Madame du Barry," with Martine Carol in the title role in Eastman color is perhaps the best bet.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -Pete Runnels, a pinch hitter, slammed Ned Garver's first pitch for a two-run single in the ninth inning as the Washington Senators defeated the Detroit Tigers, 2 -- 1, tonight and moved into fourth place in the American League.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Finish pruning the spring-blooming shrubs and vines as soon as possible to avoid destroying next year's flower buds. Prune climbing roses, too. Cut off at ground level all canes that blossomed on the ramblers. Shorten long canes of large-flowered climbers by as much as one-third their length. Cut off dead flower clusters.

A TOURIST traveling around Italy this year and considering what is happening that he does not actually see may reflect, these people have no right to be cheerful, yet in many ways, in many places, at many times, they actually are cheerful.
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 24 -- A round-up of Communists began today as Pakistan completed the outlawing of their party.

UNDER a drastically revised programming concept, C. B. S. television's "The Morning Show" will abandon the news and information format under which it was originally launched, and blossom out as a straight musical-variety show with news periods two minutes after the hour and half-hour.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 24 -- Ogden Phipps' Bassanio won the $58,800 Monmouth Handicap today. The 4-year-old colt, a son of Bimelech, was kept in a challenging position through most of the mile and a quarter test by Sid Cole, and in the stretch he turned on the speed enough to finish first by more than two lengths.

CINCINNATI, July 24 (UP) -Ted Kluszewski hit his twenty-seventh home run of the season and Ed Bailey blasted his seventh today enabling the Cincinnati Redlegs to snap a four-game losing streak with a 5-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
Business in the men's clothing industry since the beginning of the year has been neither very good nor exceptionally poor.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 18 -- A proposal to revoke the Seventeenth century excommunication of the philosopher Baruch de Spinoza has been rejected by the leaders of the Portuguese Jewish community here, descendants of those who originally banned the eminent scholar.

SWEET corn, one of summer's pleasures, is at its peak not only in quantity but also in flavor this month and next. Now that Florida supplies corn during the winter, the vegetable may be eaten fresh practically the year 'round.

IRVINGTON, N. J., July 24 -- The two-year hope of Mrs. Vickey K. Siegal of 18 Marshall Street here that she would present in person to President Eisenhower a portrait she painted of him will be fulfilled on Tuesday in Washington.

GENEVA, July 24 -- Gen. Joe Stilwell explained, back in 1942, after he had walked his men all the way from Burma into India to escape the Japanese advance, that "we took a helluva beating." He had the words for the Geneva conference.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -- The Defense Department, after a new appraisal of the Communist menace in the Orient, has abandoned plans to withdraw nearly all Army units from the Far East by 1957, an authoritative source said today.

NEWEST book sent forth by Jerome Weidman, author of "I Can Get It for You Wholesale" and a sheaf of other volumes, is a collection of nineteen travel reports. These range from St. Luke's account of a certain trip from Nazareth to Bethlehem, to John Barrymore's diary of a cruise down the coast of Lower California.

THE quiet, gentle music of Gabriel Faure has never been widely popular, but at the same time has never been without followers. Faure is one of the most delicate and subtle of composers. Chopin, Schumann and Mendelssohn were alive when he was born, in 1845.
A former soldier met his 2 1/2-year-old adopted son at New York International Airport, Idle-wild, Queens, yesterday when the boy arrived by plane from Stuttgart, Germany.

The army cots were back in the Senate cloakrooms last week. Red-rimmed eyes, bearded cliches and rumpled clothes were the fashion, and coffee consumption at the Senate restaurant rose to new records. For it was the season of the filibuster in the nation's capital

MISS PRISM -- the ineffable governess in "The Importance of Being Earnest" -- declares to her pupil: "The good ended happily and the bad unhappily. That is the meaning of Fiction." Clement Richer is an undeviating but cheerful exponent of the diametrically opposite credo.
Three more Japanese lines are planning to put their ships in service to West Africa.

LIBERTY, N. Y., July 24 -- A fifteen-ton milk tank trailer-truck hurtled down a hill here out of control this afternoon, rammed a smaller truck from behind, and caused a spectacular multiple crash in which three persons died and ten were injured.

BOSTON, July 24 -- Leo Kiely, Red Sox left-hander, retired the last nineteen batters in order in defeating the White Sox, 5 -- 2 today while his Boston team-mates. Jackie Jensen, Ted Williams and Del Wilber, cracked home runs. Kiely gave up only four safeties.
LONDON, July 24 (Reuters) -- Poland is suffering from a shortage of food, particularly meat, and Poles in general are drinking far too much.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- President Rhee's demand for more military aid and the problem of what to do with the existing Indochina aid program were considered this morning at a meeting at the State Department. It was called by Secretary of State Dulles and Harold E. Stassen, Foreign Operations Administrator.

HANOI, July 24 -- Outwardly the city of Hanoi, political and military capital of North Vietnam, appeared strangely calm as news arrived from Geneva that all of North Vietnam would be turned over to the Communistled Vietminh regime under the agreement ending the seven-and-a-half-year-old Indochina war.

RESPONDING to the growing interest in motion-picture photography by magazine photographers, a film division to distribute their work has been inaugurated by Photo-Library, Inc., 19 East Fifty-seventh Street, a picture agency.

The $3,247,000,000 United States Steel Corporation is about to go into debt -- a little, and for only a little while. installments over ten years. By the end of 1964, then, Big Steel -- barring contingencies -- should be even less in debt than on the eve of this week's borrowing.

I HAVE on my desk a pile of books published in Moscow after World War II: Lieut. Gen. P. K. Ponomarenko's "Behind the Front Line," Maj. Gen. Kovpak's "Our Partisan Course," A. Fedorov's "The Underground Party Committee Carries On," P. Ignatov's "The Krasnodar Underground," V. Andreev's "The Partisan War in Leningrad Region."

A management-conscious patient in one of the nation's first-rate hospitals recently noted that twenty-seven persons made more than 100 calls to her room in a single day. Like many other patients, she longed for the day when she could go home to rest.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., July (AP) -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood today won the Garden State women's golf assocation championship. She routed Jane Goss of Somerset Hills, 11 and 9.
CAMP DRUM, July 24 -- Ten thousand National Guardsmen and Reservists from New Jersey began arriving at this Army post today for two weeks of intensive field training and maneuvers.
This country's tramp cargo fleet now handles a larger share of world-wide dry cargoes in bulk than is commonly believed, according to a report just issued in London by W. G. Weston, Ltd.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The restless graph of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's political influence has, by every visible sign, fallen to its lowest point in two years and perhaps in four. It is equally clear, however, that in some areas and in some circumstances in this Congressional election year, Mr. McCarthy is still a formidable force.

The heat wave that seared the Midwest for most of last week spurred demand for lightweight apparel, according to resident buying offices. In some cases the suddenness and strength of the demand caught retailers by surprise and they found themselves short of stock.

DETROIT, July 24 (AP) -- Roaring from Los Angeles to Detroit in 3 hours 27 minutes 13 seconds, Lieut. Charles J. Young of the New Jersey Air National Guard today won the feature race of the seventh International Aviation Exposition.
PHILADELPHIA, July 24 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics checked a ninth-inning rally by the Baltimore Orioles today to preserve a 6-5 decision for rookie Johnny Gray's first major-league victory.

THE lack of any immediate adverse business reaction in the nation to news of peace in Indochina augurs well for the economy. Merchants took the news in stride, saw no reason to change any plans and appeared to be more concerned about Congressional activity on long-pending legislation than about events in far corners of the earth.
PARIS, July 24 (AP) -- Sven Davidson and Lennart Bergelin, Swedish tennis stars, got Sweden off to a 2-0 lead in the European zone Davis Cup final today with clear-cut victories over French players.

BONN, Germany, July 24 -- West Berlin Police Headquarters made public today evidence indicating that Dr. Otto John, who had been head of the West German Government's intelligence service, had entered East Germany voluntarily. He crossed the border Tuesday night at the Sandkrug Bridge.

WE are all aware that we are living through a great revolution, and, the more closely we look at it, the greater it proves to be. This revolution is attacking two things that have been characteristic of civilization all through the first five or six thousand years of civilization's history.
TRENTON, July 24 (AP) -- Thirteen convicts in the State Prison's "death house" went back to eating meals today after refusing prison food part of Thursday and all day yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio -- About fifty miles north of Marietta; on Ohio Route 7, is a small wayside park of half an acre. It has parking space for a dozen or more cars. Back under the trees are several tables, three fireplaces, a drinking fountain and a small building that houses toilet facilities and equipment for keeping the park in shape.
A writ of habeas corpus for a man convicted of a murder since confessed by another was signed yesterday in Queens in a 293-year-old house dedicated to the principles of freedom.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The atomic - power issue will not fade with the conclusion of the Senate filibuster aimed at forestalling the admittance of private power interests into the atomic energy field.

Like T. H. Chilton, whose letter on deferring specialists you published July 11, I was pleased to read your editorial on June 28 on "Scientific Manpower." Mr. Chilton has covered the thinking of those of us who are charged with meeting the technological security needs of the nation so well that there is only a little more to add in support of your commendable stand.

CANADIAN television will be two years old in September and the fruits of the Government policy to utilize Canadian talent as much as possible are beginning to show. Canadian television programs are becoming easier to look at and show a professional touch.

CRAFTWORK from more than twenty-five counties will be on display and for sale at the York State Craft Fair to be held Aug. 19-21 in Ithaca, N. Y. Ithaca College has provided space for the fair, which is sponsored by the New York State Craftsmen, a nonprofit, incorporated organization with headquarters in Ithaca at 210 North Aurora Street.

ROME, July 24 -- A magistrate has found that Wilma Montesi was not the victim or an accident but of homicide committed by one or more persons, according to reports published by the Italian press. All newspapers publish approximately the same version of the magistrate's findings.

THOUGHTFUL visitors newly arrived in Maine from the westward, who, after crossing the Piscataqua, eschew the monotonous convenience of the Maine Turnpike in order to explore the coastal roads, soon find themselves in Kittery Point.

THIS is a rather thin tale of the confusion, fear and loneliness of a small boy in wartime England. Eight-year-old Joseph Robert Redfern is living in a shabby London flat instead of the pretty house on the Yorkshire moors he remembers as his own.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 24 -- Mitchel Air Force Base is saving thousands of dollars through an experimental program designed to encourage management initiative in its noncommissioned officers.

THE comic performer in Hollywood has his work prescribed for him. He can play himself over and over until it is too late and the public bestows its favor on someone else. Not so Bob Hope. The comedian apparently realizes that a lengthy succession of pictures in which Mr. Hope invariably is been as Bob Hope can be too much for even the most ardent fan.

BRITTEN: A Ceremony of Carols; The Copenhagen Boys Mogens Woeldike, choirmaster; Benjamin Britten, conductor; Enid Simon, harpist (London, ten-inch). The Danish boys sing the English text with great sensitivity. It is an attractive work.

The gerontologists have been meeting in London. It cannot be said that they have produced a formula that will enable us to stave off old age. But Dr. Flanders Dunbar of New York, well known for her work in psychosomatic medicine, showed how wrong are some of our notions about superannuation.

FOR the amateur gardener-carpenter, a homemade window box offers a triple value. It is not only useful and showy but easy to construct. Although ready-made, metal boxes may be purchased at almost any garden shop at a moderate price, still the homemade, wooden type is less expensive and more durable.

CANCER is now responsible for two of every fifteen deaths in the United States, with a current toll of more than 225,000 victims a year. It far outweighs any other disease as a cause of death, except diseases of the heart and circulatory system.
The 18,000-ton liner La Guardia is about to return to the sea after twenty months in "moth balls."
INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 24 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Fleet Bird captured the $109,300 Sunset Handicap today, nosing out the favored Rejected in one of the closest finishes in the history of the race.
THIS short novel re-explores a theme that for centuries has tantalized man's imagination: how would we act if Christ were again to appear in our midst?

TORONTO, July 24 (UP) -- Karol Fageros of the University of Miami rallied after dropping the first set today to win the Canadian Women's tennis championship by defeating Ethel Norton, San Antonio school teacher, 3 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4.

BUENOS AIRES, July 24 (AP) -- Yoshio Shirai, world flyweight champion from Japan, and Pascual Perez, the Argentine champion, fought a ten-round draw tonight in a non-title bought before a sell-out crowd of 27,000 at Luna Park Stadium.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- All the activities supported by the Ford Foundation "adhere strictly to basic American traditions and principles," its president, H. Rowan Gaither Jr., told a Congressional committee today.

LESS a novel than a Joycean close-up of a self-contained family, "Johannesburg Friday" opens windows on the City of Gold and its explosive race tensions. For his odyssey through the hearts of the Leventhals, the author has chosen the Friday before the Day of Atonement.
MOSCOW, July 24 -- The Soviet Union delivered notes tonight to the United States, Britain and France proposing a new conference on European security problems.

The American-Korean Foundation has enlisted the aid of many persons of prominence as sponsors for their Aug. 4 benefit, the premiere of Alfred Hitchcock's motion-picture suspense drama, "Rear Window," starring James Stewart and Grace Kelly, at the Rivoli Theatre at 8:30 P. M. Tickets may be obtained in the theatre lobby, Broadway and Forty-ninth Street.
Vincent Madsen has been appointed deputy managing director of the plantation division of the United States Rubber Company.

JOSEPH SEVERN, the young artist who took care of the dying Keats, is one of the most engaging figures in literary history. As a painter, he had only talent, but he had a genius for friendship. After Keats' death, the tale of Severn's devotion to him spread through the British colony in Rome, and the painter was rewarded in story-book fashion.

A slow beginning and then renewal of major strength characterized stock trading last week. Selected issues again held the spotlight, with interest rotating from one group of stocks to another. It was not until midweek that prices displayed a firmer tone.
A simplified type of money order, the "Register Check," has moved out of the experimental stage here and is now a popular and easy method of handling personal banking transactions.

The National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. is senidng 300 teachers, ministers, college students and seminarians to camps for an estimated two million migrant farm workers in twenty-five states this summer.

LOS ANGELES, July 24 -- An eleventh-hour change in the leadership, as a result of play in the thirteenth and semi-final round of the Pan-American chess tournament at the Hollywood Athletic Club, found Arthur E. Bisguier of New York, United States champion, back at the top of the list today with a score of 10 1/2 -- 2 1/2.

IT being midsummer and not an active time in the book publishing world, we thought it a sound idea to look up a publisher we know and ask him a few questions with an eye to summing up. Could publisher say it had been a poor and ailing year? Publisher could not.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 24 -- Some of the civic leaders who fought for thirty years for construction of the New England Thruway here are now demanding of state officials that the road not add a hazard to New Rochelle.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 24 (UP) -- Senator John L. McClellan faces his first vote-getting test in twelve years Tuesday against the combined opposition of a former Governor, Arkansas' Democratic committeeman and a garage owner.
TUNIS, Tunisia, July 24 (UP) -A Tunisian Nationalist terrorist shot and killed the chief of the Bey of Tunis' palace guard today.

LONDON, July 24 -- Britain accused Communist China today of shooting down an airliner over the South China Sea and instructed Humphrey Trevelyan, charge d'affaires in Peiping, to protest to the Government of the People's Republic.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Senator Charles E. Potter went to the White House today to press his demand for the early resignation of John G. Adams as Army Counselor. Mr. Adams was a principal, along with Secretary of the Army Robert T. Stevens, in the recent Army controversy with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

On Sunday, after reading the interesting article by Kingsley Davis, "Small Families Are Still the Fashion" (July 11) my wife and I hastily pulled down the window blinds. We desired to be alone and re-examine our family situation.

SALT LAKE CITY -- Time has come full circle here in the West. There was an era -- if the canvases of Frederick Remington are to be believed -- when any dude, arriving in any self-respecting burg from Butte, Mont., to Kanab, Utah, could expect to trip the light fantastic on the handiest board sidewalk, while bullets threw splinters about his boots and gun-toting wranglers just in from the range shouted "dance, pard, dance."
I read ith great interest Sidney Hook's article "The Problem of the ex-Communist" (July 11 ).
HAMPTON BAYS, L. I., July 24 (AP) -- Lightning struck an aviation supply company building here tonight and set off a blaze that virtually destroyed the block-long structure.
DETROIT, July 24 (AP) -- Gulfstream, winner of only one of his previous seventeen starts, today won Michigan's oldest horse race -- the $15,000 Frontier Handicap -- at the Detroit track.

WHO remembers the old controversy over the relative merits of absolute and program music and the way some absolutists dismissed program music as inevitably third rate? How dead that issue seems now is illustrated by recent recordings of two works whose special charm lies in the fact that they contain so much program music.

" Carmen Jones," one of Broadway's major delights a decade ago, is currently being brought to life again for Twentieth Century-Fox as a big CinemaScope musical show. Otto Preminger, the director and producer, has planned his "Carmen" to keep the same form as the Oscar Hammerstein II-Billy Rose extravaganza.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., July 24 (UP) -- Three accidents marred the Brynfan Tyddyn sports car road races today and two events were shortened because the overturned cars made the roadway hazardous.

SEOUL, Korea, July 24 -- President Syngman Rhee leaves tomorrow for Washington to play for his big stake: He will make a personal plea for the United States' support to drive communism out of North Korea by force.

IN a unique laboratory maintained by the Columbia Broadcasting System on the western outskirts of Fifty-seventh Street, a trio of video wizards are poking around in the electronic unknown in search of TV magic.

MILWAUKEE, July 24 -- In this seething metropolis, where major league baseball is followed with a fierce fanaticism that beggars description, it is well not to mention the name of Johnny Antonelli within earshot of a native. Youngsters are spanked and sent to bed without their supper for considerably less.
EBENSBURG, Pa., July 24 (UP) -- A dispute over a cancer treatment brought dismissal today of a hospital administrator, his sixteen-man medical staff and fifteen dentists and technicians.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- H. Rowan Gaither Jr., president of the Ford Foundation, gave a detailed picture of the foundation's origin, organization and operations in a statement filed today with the House's Special Committee to Investigate Tax Exempt Foundations.

May I take issue with Irving Glassman's stand that motion-picture versions of novels must adhere closely to the author's original story. Why? * * * The fact remains that most novels are written to produce mental images via the written word, while a screenplay represents an entirely different medium, wholly visual, and may require a different story handling.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Royal Note, the fast-running son of Spy Song owned by Tilford L. Wilson and Carl T. Houston, remained undefeated today with a romping triumph in the $149,785 Arlington Futurity to earn $93,345.

IN the wildflower garden or in gardens where shady areas present a planting problem, the various hardy ferns are valuable landscaping adjuncts. Most species are easy to grow if their soil and moisture requirements are met and. an added boon, they require practically no maintenance.
DETROIT, July 24 (AP) -- Unless all signs are wrong, the "big discount" era will have vanished from the auto market by the time 1955 models appear.

PHENIX CITY, Ala., July 24 -A team of about 150 Alabama National Guardsmen this week skillfully meshed a limited martial law assignment with this community's governmental machinery to strengthen state and local anti-crime forces.
LONDON, July 24 -- A report on the most comprehensive study of atomic warfare yet made in the Western World has been given to the British Joint Chiefs of Staff.

BATON ROUGE, La., July 24 -- Louisiana's voters will go to the polls Tuesday in a Democratic primary for a Senator, Congressmen and lesser elective officers, including a new justice of the Supreme Court and a member of the Louisiana Public Service Commission.

BALTIMORE, July 24 -- The Maryland state Democratic convention, meeting Monday to formalize the nomination of Dr. H. C. Byrd, organization candidate for Governor, and others in the party primary June 28, is facing an embarrassing and highly unusual situation.

WATCHING children wherever they gather for summer fun -- on sandy beaches or the pebbly shores of lakes, in open fields or on the blacktop of public playgrounds -- one gets an impression of robust physical well-being that says much for American parents, American medical science and American food.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 24 (AP) -- Eight spills sent three riders to the hospital today and forced a halt in the national bicycle championships when the competitors refused to continue on the soft track.

THE recent report in your paper of the indignation of American tourists at the Paris International Theatre Festival raises a subject that deserves wide discussion. No American troupe is performing at the Paris Festival this month and no American troupe will perform at the Berlin Festival in September -- and it looks as if the coming season will set a low mark in U. S. performing arts representation abroad.

RECOGNIZABLY real children have almost never appeared in leading roles in detective stories. The outstanding previous use of children in a suspense story was in Michael Blankfort's "The Widow Makers''; now in THE GINGERBREAD MAN (Scribner's, $2.75), Richard Parker tops even Blankfort in creating a family of children as real and realistic as those of E. Nesbit or even Richard Hughes.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -- Representative J. Arthur Younger, Republican of California, said today it was time the Government concentrated on problems of the city folks.

RIGHT now, smack in the age of supersonic jets and rocket planes -- when, for all we know, atom-powered aircraft may be just below the horizon -- the most steadily exciting kind of flying is done at a leisurely fifty miles an hour, without any sort of motor whatever.

GENEVA, July 24 -- The change-over in Western Europe from a system of tightly controlled foreign exchange to a comparatively free one affects only specialists at first. But before long it affects everybody in the countries involved.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Soviet proposal today for a new European security system is not a new one. It was broached at the Berlin conference earlier this year and again in a Soviet note March 31. The United States has rejected it as a transparent effort to destroy Western security arrangements, such as the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the European Defense Community.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson promised today to carry out "constructively and equitably" the tough Federal wheat production controls voted by the nation's farmers yesterday.
Wall Street is beginning to show interest in low - priced stocks, those selling under $30 a share. So far there has been no stampede, merely a slight shift of emphasis.

IN 1938, when he was 33, Clarence R. Decker became president of the University of Kansas City. After fourteen years of successful administration (and a year's leave to serve as Assistant Director of the Mutual Security Agency), he resigned in 1953.

SINCE his return to "Desiree" after his flight from "The Egyptian" (and on the eve of the release of his newest picture "On the Waterfront") the publicity legend of Marlon Brando has been revised. Hollywood columnists in charge of such matters now state that, thanks to their vigilance, an exemplary new domesticated Marlon Brando has replaced the surly old savage one.

AS you price that doggie, kitty, guppie or budgie in the window or walk Bowser around the block some rainy night before retiring, you might be pleased to know that science is doing its best to insure that your pet reaches a healthy age of maturity.

AFTER the opening of his latest production, "On the Waterfront," at the Astor this week, producer Sam Spiegel will embark for Europe with plans for three new ventures, one of which, he disclosed, took shape during the "Waterfront" filming.

TWELVE - YEAR - OLD Jeb lives with hi Granny and his Uncle Raff in the Kentucky mountains. Thanks to Uncle Raft's teaching, Jeb is an expert shot and hunter. He wants a dog, and Tessie. renamed Jubilant, a golden retriever, is a natural.

" Forged Stamps of Two World Wars." By L. N. and M. Williams. An illustrated, forty-two-page study of the German, Austrian and Bavarian forgeries of World War I, and the French, German, British, Italian and Dutch forgeries of World War II.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Reporters attending the President's news conference this week were treated to one of those small but rewarding insights into the Eisenhower character that have come along so fortuituously to dispel some of the occupational cynicism with which they come inevitably to regard a President.

A THOROUGH countrywide study seeking remedies for traffic difficulties that beset our cities is being made under direction of the National Committee on Urban Transportation. The immediate objective is to develop manuals which will help communities collect data necessary to plan adequate transportation systems.

For one thing, it brings out sharply the close parallel between life on the Brazilian frontier in the E.ghteen Eighties and Eighteen Nineties and our own wild and woolly West of about 1860.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The Government forecast today that on the basis of a new jump in the already booming home-building industry 1954 production would be the largest since the 1950 record year.

SALEM, N. H., July 24 (AP) -- The River Divide Farm's Queensware, a 2-year-old filly that had equaled the track record for five furlongs earlier in the meeting, captured the $5,000 Monroe Memorial Handicap at Rockingham Park today.

DETROIT, July 24 (AP) -- Friends that Blair Moody made on his long road from City Hall reporter to United States Senator paid final tribute to him today.

To us they seem young and fresh in their unfamiliarity.

DARTMOUTH, England, July 24 (AP) -- Gen. Alfred Gruenther, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, told a group of naval cadets today that world conditions had deteriorated in the last few months and the tension probably would exist throughout their careers.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 24 -- Bobby Houston, 16-year-old high school student from New Rochelle, N. Y., retained the senior 145-pound singles title for the New York Athletic Club at the seventy-second Royal Canadian Henley regatta today.

The smiling 14-year-old lad whose photograph was published in this newspaper yesterday with the Supreme Court building in the background ought not to have been a historic figure. It ought to have been taken for granted that an American of any ancestry who could qualify to be one of the four page boys for the United States Supreme Court should have the chance to compete.

VANCOUVER, July 24 (AP) -- Nearly four-and-a-half years work will have gone into the fifth British Empire and Commonwealth Games, world's second largest athletic event, when they open here Friday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 24 -- The United Nations began another dejected round of disarmament talk this week, and the question that must have been in a great many minds was: What's the use ?

Nearly 1,000,000 students are attending summer-session classes at 1,250 American colleges and universities this month. This represents a substantial increase over last summer, and is just about double the number that attended in an average pro-World War II year.

The Interstate Oil Pipe Line Company, an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (N. J.), has announced the sale of its 1,050-mile crude oil gathering and trunk line facilities in Oklahoma to the Cherokee Pipe Line Company, effective Sept. 1.

NEW daylilies in ever lengthening lists are welcomed eagerly each year by increasing numbers of enthusiastic amateurs. It might seem, with hundreds of good varieties already catalogued, that there would be scant room for more improvements.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., July 24 -- A merging of municipal and railroad interests gave promise today of producing an abundance of automobile parking spaces in the old-fashioned downtown area of this city of 75,000. A new street for swift traffic also seemed likely.
ATLANTA, Ga., July 24 -- The establishment of a Southern regional council on mental health training and research was proposed today at the meeting of the Southern Regional Education Board here.

THE third edition of "Photographic Enlarging" (London: Iliffe Sons; Bronxville: Variety Books. $1.95) by Charles David, is a chatty 107-page book of guidance and counsel on the subject for beginners. In addition to being a clearly prepared introduction to enlarging, the book contains a miscellany of helpful hints on meeting the various problems that beset the darkroom worker.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 24 -- The race between Senator Estes Kefauver of Chattanooga and Representative Pat Sutton of Lawrenceburg for the Senate that now held by Mr. Kefauver turning into a heated contest. With less than two weeks to go before the Aug. 5 Democratic primary, which, for all practical purposes, will determine who gets the job, the two candidates are using every campaign tactic at their disposal.

DURING the past five years Copenhagen has become a sort of Mecca for balletomanes from all over the world. The shrine which draws them is the Royal Theatre and its splendid ballet company, which since 1950 has presented annual summer festivals.

CONCORD, N. H., July 24 -- The major attraction in the Granite State's Sept. 14 primaries is a three-cornered Republican contest to fill the remaining two-year United States Senate term of the late Charles W. Tobey. This promises to be one of the closest races in the state's primary history, with the issue very much in doubt. Nomination is considered tantamount to election in predominantly Republican New Hampshire.

As editor of "L.a Hacienda, a magazine dedicated for fifty years to exporting United States agricultural and industrial know-how to Latin America. I have had to follow closely the events culminating in the recent overthrow of the Arbenz regime in Ouatemala.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 24 -- A dry northeast squall whacked the tail-enders of 300 starting boats today to end the fifty-sixth Larchmont Peace Week with a flourish. The other white-capped flourishes were provided by those who took championships over seven days of point competition.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 24 -- Fifty-four items already are listed for consideration by the General Assembly on the provisional agenda for the ninth session, scheduled to open Sept. 21. THE tenor voice of Gianni Poggi, already known to those who collect European-made operatic recordings, may be heard in a varied repertory on three new ten-inch disks from London Records.

ALTHOUGH St. Swithin's Day brought thunderstorms and scattered showers throughout the East from Albany to Miami, it did not inaugurate the recurrent rains which gardens need so badly. The forty days of rain that supposedly follow a wet July 15 would certainly be tolerated, if not welcomed, by most farmers and gardeners.

Six years ago the nation's independent freight car builders broke a twenty-two-year record with an output of 83,196 cars. MOST of us today live in houses that are composed of rectangular cubes of enclosed space in varying proportions and sizes. These are placed, as the current issue of Progressive Architecture points out, "either beside each other or piled atop one another in endless monotony."

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 24--Frank Strafaci of the home club, seeking the crown for the seventh time, and Joe Gagliardi of Winged Foot, the winner in 1951, gained the final round of the fifty-second Metropolitan Golf Association amateur championship tournament today at the Garden City Country Club.

ST. PAUL, July 24 -- Showing no effects of the crick in his neck that bothered him earlier in the tournament, Sam Snead gained the quarter-final round of the Professional Golfers Association championship today.
Plans for the erection of a beacon in Flushing Meadow Park to guide airliners away from the densely populated sections of Queens were announced yesterday by the Civil Aeronautics Administration.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The annual all-Army golf tournament will get under way at the Woodmont Country Club in nearby Maryland on Tuesday, with Cpl. Billy Maxwell, former national amateur champion, a heavy favorite to win the open division.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Steel production in the Chicago metropolitan area for the first half of the year totaled 8,934,900 net tons, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. Output was down 1,586,400 tons from the 10,581,300 figure for the corresponding period last year.

THE battle of styles reenacted at this year's Biennale in Venice is a thoroughly confused one, with no quarter being given anywhere and no clear-cut victory on any one side. Initially, Surrealism was intended to predominate and for that reason Max Ernst and Arp, as representing Surrealism's two faces, the literary and the formal, are particularly honored.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 24 -- Three weeks ago a Federal-state statistician predicted that Illinois would produce its third largest corn crop in history this year. This week he was forecasting a less than average crop and possibly worse, unless rains came.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Soviet Union is expected here to sign at least twenty bilateral trade agreements with free nations this year, eight more than it was able to arrange in 1953.

HARTFORD, July 24. -- The Connecticut Supreme Court has ordered the city of Norwich, in the eastern part of the state, to build a sewage plant and thus prevent further pollution of three rivers in the area -- the Thames, Shetucket and the Yentic.

M. Tuesday (8 P. M. Monday Eastern daylight time).

Bearing the name of the great Genovese seafarer who sailed his caravels westward across the Atlantic 462 years ago, the 29,100-ton liner Cristoforo Colombo docked at West Forty-fourth Street after an eight-day crossing from the Mediterranean.

THIS season the Cincinnati "Zoo" opera has had a lopsided auditorium. On the left-hand side there has been a long, narrow strip of bleachers unmatched by a balancing strip on the right. HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 25 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has chosen James Cagney to co-star with Doris Day in the biography of Ruth Etting. The studio is calling the story "Love Me or Leave Me."

TOMS RIVER, N. J., July 26 -- Motorists using the new seventeen-mile stretch of the Garden State Parkway between here and Manahawkin were praised here today by State Police Lieut. Howard Lamberson, directing parkway patrols in the Ocean County area.

With the wartime and postwar impediments to general currency convertibility disappearing one by one, the arena has been cleared, in a manner of speaking, for a revival of debate on one of the most persistent of all recurring foreign exchange controversies. That is the controversy over fixed versus fluctuating currency rates.
The Spanish liner Magallanes is being rebuilt into an almost entirely new ship from the keel up, Jose Maria Ramon, director of the Spanish Line, declared here yesterday.

Winners of the eleventh annual national play competition sponsored by the Seattle Junior Programs, Inc., a non-profit group, were announced yesterday. The object of the contest is to encourage the writing of scripts to be performed by adult actors for children.

Net income of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., of Minneapolis, and undistributed earnings of its wholly-owned subsidiaries, the vast investment company group controlled by Robert R. Young's Alleghany Corporation, climbed to $3,779,828 or $2.60 a share in the first six months of 1954. In the like period last year the company earned $3,462,939, or $2.38 a share.

The Right Rev. Cuthbert K. N. Bardsley, the Lord Bishop Suffragan of Croydon, England, challenged the leadership of the United States yesterday to be God-inspired and not man-energized -- God-controlled and not fear-ridden.
AJMER, India, July 25 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru announced today India's agreement to serve on the three-nation Truce Supervisory Commission in Indochina.

ROOSEVELT, L. I., July 25 -- Free labor for the construction of a new $300,000 wing to the Cerebral Palsy Diagnostic and Treatment Center, pledged by member unions of the Nassau-Suffolk Building and Construction Trades Council, is scheduled to begin here Tuesday after ground-breaking ceremonies.

LIBERTY, N. Y., July 25 -- Mayor Hyman Heller has called a special session of the Liberty Board of Trustees for tomorrow to determine what to do to prevent a recurrence of yesterday's milk truck accident in which three persons were killed and ten were hurt.

TOKYO, Monday, July 26 -- Communist China admitted today that its patrol planes downed a British airliner near Hainan on Friday. Peiping said the airliner was mistaken for a Nationalist Chinese plane.

TORONTO, July 25 (AP) -- Bernard Bartzen, United States national clay court titleholder from San Angelo, Text., won the men's singles crown in the Canadian tennis championship today by defeating Kosei Kamo of Japan, 6 -- 4 6 -- 0, 6 -- 3.
PARIS, July 25 -- France and the three associated states of Indochina will soon meet in a conference to settle various economic problems that will arise after the peace.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- With Democratic ranks split, the outlook brightened today for a final showdown in the Senate, possibly by midweek, on the Administration's atomic energy bill.
PARIS, July 25 -- More hat, ear-enveloping hats with considerable depth, worn backward off the hairline sums up the new silhouette confirmed as opening follows opening.

The Texas Company had a record net income of $97,480,845 in the first half after all charges and taxes, J. S. Leach, chairman, reported over the week-end. This is equivalent to $3.55 a share on the outstanding stock.

IRONTON, Mo., July 25 (AP) -- Rescue workers today found the bodies of four Michigan soldiers and a civilian pilot killed in a plane that exploded and crashed in rugged hill country southwest of this Ozark community.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 25 -- Alvin Cadiz sailed Zephyr to victory in the long-distance event of the Larchmont Yacht Club's special program today. The sloop covered the sixteen-and-three-quarter-mile course over Long Island Sound in 4 hours 16 minutes.

ZURICH, July 25 -- Statements of account and annual reports for 1953 were represented last week at the general meetings of all four main successor concerns into which the vast German chemical trust I. G. Farbenindustrie was split by decartelization after World War II. These are the Badische Anilinen und Soda Fabrik, Casella Farbwerke, Farbenfabriken Bayer and Farbwerke Hoechst.

On July 22 the Mayor and his associate members on the Board of Estimate voted unanimously an appropriation to enlarge the probation and psychiatric services of the Court of Special Sessions, Court of Domestic Relations, and the Magistrates Court.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- United States, British and French officials will begin consultations tomorrow on the expected rejection of the Soviet proposal for a conference on a new European collective security system.

When young children reel off nonsense syllables or meaningless chants, it may seem silly to average adults, a childhood educator observed recently. But, Claudia Lewis maintains, "verbal doodling" is an important learning process, not only enjoyable to children but a valuable part of their language development.
LONDON, Monday, July 26 -- Britain has protested strongly to Communist China over the shooting down of a British civil airliner off Hainan Island Friday, the Foreign Office said today.

ST. PAUL, July 25 -- Tommy Bolt, after threatening to quit the tournament this morning, went on to defeat Sam Snead and gain the semi-final round of the Professional Golfers Association championship today.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Secretary Oveta Culp Hobby has asked the Senate to salvage a large portion of the Eisenhower health, education and welfare program.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 25 -- Playing a brand of golf that he described as his "best ever," Frank Strafaci of the home club won the Metropolitan Golf Association amateur championship for the seventh time today at the Garden City Country Club.
The Rev. Dr. John Paul Jones yesterday withdrew his resignation from his Presbyterian pastorate in Brooklyn.

MEXICO CITY, July 25 -- The National Union of Sinarquistas, a political organization of the extreme right, named 142 Federal employes today as Communist militants or sympathizers. It asked the Government to strip them of citizenship.
MILWAUKEE, July 25 -- The Giants' third western trip of the year, a jaunt that was expected to tear the National League flag race practically apart, wound up on a painful note for Leo Durocher today.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Eisenhower Administration is busy trying to line up some organized labor votes for the Republican party this fall and James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, is spearheading the drive.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 25 -- Denunciations of press, film, radio and television programs as demoralizing for the young remain to be proved, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization reported today.

PARIS, July 25 -- The European adventures of the United States executive board charged with determining the loyalty of American employes of international organizations ended happily here this week-end after a difficult month.

LOS ANGELES, July 25 -- Arthur B. Bisguier of New York, United States chess champion, gained his third consecutive victory to win the Pan American tournament today at the Hollywood Athletic Club. The victor's score was 11 1/2 -- 2 1/2, comprising ten games won, three drawn and one lost.

The defense of the Ford Foundation to attacks upon it by the Reece committee investigating tax-exempt agencies completely disproves the committee's criticism and illuminates the whole sorry record of the committee's activities to date. This is the fourth answer which the defendant organizations have made.

Although Christianity's influence in the "poorhouse" of East Asia "far outweighs its numerical stength," divisions within the Christian church and nationalism are detriments to its growth, the Rev. Rajah B. Manikam of Madras, India, declared yesterday.

News of the political settlement in Indochina last week and word that the French would need a million tons of shipping to move people and materiel out of the Hanoi area within the next year did not give the local charter market as much of a boost as might have been expected.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The nature and origin of radio waves that come from outer space and the existence of and location of stars that cannot be seen through even the largest telescopes will be explored by Australian scientists.

THE air in town these days is as warm as the atmosphere in a New York living room on a January evening when someone has decided to make a blazing fire on the metallic hearth. Well, not quite, perhaps. But warm enough, anyway, to talk about light summer reading -- the kind that is just as entertaining, as a matter of fact, when the window thermometer is down and the thermostat is soaring.

BOSTON, July 25 (UP) -- The White Sox needed three pitchers to subdue Boston, 4 -- 2, in the nightcap of a double-header today, after Jack Harshman had fanned sixteen Red Sox batters in a 5-2 first-game victory.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 25 -- The long negotiations to put Iran back among the world's major oil-producing countries entered today what qualified observers thought would be their final week.

Winter baseball, the draft system, inter-league competition and the opening dates of spring training and the regular season are among the topics to be discussed today at the major leagues mid-summer meetings at the Hotel Commodore.

Cotton futures prices moved over a narrowly irregular course last week, although new seasonal high were established at the outset. At the close of trading Friday, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances of 9 points to a decline of 7 points.

Three baseball fans got into a fracas yesterday when the strain of the game at Yankee Stadium became unbearable. The police promptly stepped in and escorted the Stadium battlers to the Highbridge police station.

BERKELEY, Calif., July 25 -- Herold M. Harter of Toledo, Ohio, Secretary of the National Exchange Club, defended at a statewide meeting here today the organization's all-white membership policy as nondiscriminatory.

In a recent issue of your paper I read the speech of the leader of the British Labor Opposition, Clement Attlee, who stated about the Chinese Nationalist Army at Formosa: "I think it is time that the leaders were pensioned off, and I believe the mass of the rank and file would be glad to return to China."

Plans for a $30,000,000 shopping center at Valley Stream, L. I., close to the New York City line, were announced over the week-end. A branch of Gimbels New York will be one of two focal stores of the development, which will rise on a seventy-acre tract of the former Curtiss-Wright Airport.
HANOI, Vietnam, July 24 -- All French Union forces north, west and south of Hanoi are scheduled to be pulled back by Aug. 11 into an assembly zone defined by the Geneva agreement.
The English, with their proud tradition as the homeland of the Mother of Parliaments, have always assumed an understandably cautious attitude toward political innovations from abroad.
CHICAGO, July 25 -- Weather played a major part in influencing grain prices last week.

ST. LOUIS, July 25 -- Roy Campanella's worry about his left hand has increased greatly during the past ten days. He said today that he would be examined by three nerve specialists on his return to Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- A group of atomic scientists, declaring "there is a need for a new approach" to security, proposed today a six-point revision of Government standards.

PIERMONT, N. Y., July 25 -- Legal action will be taken by the local school board to prevent the building through school property here of a connecting link between the New York State Thruway bridge at South Nyack and the New Jersey Turnpike.

Sight-seers of all ages from all walks of life turned out yesterday afternoon to stroll through the new queen of the Italian merchant marine, the 29,100-ton liner Cristoforo Colombo. The 700-foot vessel, her colorful signal flags from bow to stern whipping in the summer breeze and her black hull and white superstructure gleaming, was the objective of 8,600 visitors at her berth at West Forty-fourth Street.
DALLAS, Tex., July 25 -- Texas, historically one of the most disputed territories in the country once again is a political battleground.

CHICAGO July 25 (UP) -- Bob Talbot smashed a single with the bases loaded in the last half of the ninth inning today to give the Chicago Cubs a 2-to-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies after the Cubs had downed the Phillies, 6 to 1, in the first game before 23,353 fans.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (UP) -- Lester Granger, special consultant to the Navy on racial problems, has submitted his resignation on the ground the Navy was not doing enough to wipe out remaining race discrimination, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (UP) -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People asked President Eisenhower today to make a "clear and certain call" for passage of legislation to end racial segregation in interstate travel.

A big new open-pit copper mine will officially go into production next week in a historic mining district discovered seventy-seven years ago by a cavalryman in pursuit of Indians. The mine is the $25,000,000 Lavender Pit project of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, gouged into a valley of the sun-baked and barren Mule Mountains near Bisbee, Ariz., only a few miles from the Mexican border.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission said today it has broadened a complaint issued last Jan. 26 charging restraint of trade practices between two steel scrap brokers and sixteen iron and steel producers.

As a Canadian enjoying a vacation on your excellent New England beaches T have had the opportunity to study, through personal contact and press items, the United States viewpoint in many fields. In most respects it would seem that we both arrive at our conclusions through logical reasoning.

The police yesterday picked up three boys, ranging from 8 to 11 years old, who they said had spent two days systematically wrecking the interior of Public School 45 at 126-28 150th Street, Jamaica, Queens.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Navy will begin one of its largest exercises since the end of World War II tomorrow when it rehearses tactics designed to safeguard a convoy against submarine attack.

CINCINNATI, July 25 (UP) -- Howie Judson's two-run single in the seventh inning helped the Cincinnati Redlegs to a 3-2 victory in the second game of a double-header today after Paul LaPalme pitched his first complete game of the season in pacing the Pirates to a 4-2 triumph in the opener.

Members of the bar must have enjoyed the exchange of opinions in the published letters of Messrs. Jackson and Wildermuth relating to the aid of judges in settling cases. Unlike Mr. Wildermuth, I would hate to see the Day -- to quote his own words -- "when litigants and lawyers learn that the judiciary will no longer be available to effect compromises."

During the first half of this year only six members were tried for infraction of rules and only two cases were appealed, Paul Hall, secretary-treasurer of the Atlantic and Gulf District of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., said yesterday.

The peculiar things that can happen in Congress toward the close of a session in an election year were illustrated on Saturday when Representative John Taber's Appropriations Committee turned in its version of a foreign aid program. When the House recently voted an authorization bill for this program it allowed $3,338,000,000 in new money.

On Thursday at 3 P. M. Mayor Wagner will swear in Joseph P. McMurray, former chief of staff for the United States Senate Banking and Currency Committee, as executive director of the New York City Housing Authority.
AMSTERDAM, July 25 -- Dutch foreign exchange reserves showed further improvement in the second quarter of 1954.
HANOI, Vietnam, July 26 -- Despite the approaching ceasefire set for Tuesday morning in North Vietnam, Vietminh units are continuing to attack all posts defended by Vietnamese in this area.

Employe security programs run by private industry were criticized yesterday by the American Civil Liberties Union. The union urged that such programs be handled instead by appropriate Government security authorities.

CAIRO, July 25 -- The Patriarch Anba Yusab II, 76-year-old spiritual leader of 10,000,000 Orthodox Coptic Christians, was kidnapped and forced to sign his resignation at gun point by a group of young Coptic extremists early today.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The American Bar Association will be asked to approve the teaching of the theory and practice of communism in all United States schools.
