WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Following are the votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the period July 18 through July 24:
SALZBURG, Austria, July 25 (UP) -- A fanfare of trumpets from Salzburg's castled hills opened Europe's biggest music festival in brilliant sunshine today.
Four steamship companies are involved in two projected mergers, according to reports in shipping circles over the week-end.

COLOGNE, Germany, July 25 (UP) -- Jaroslav Drobny, the 32-year-old Egyptian citizen who has been unbeatable since he captured the Wimbledon championship on July 2, won the men's singles title at Cologne's international tennis tournament today by defeating Ernst Bucholz of Germany, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2.

PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., July 25 -- The American Yacht Club's annual cruise, a 23-year-old tradition on Long Island Sound, began today with a shortened course and two of the four divisions producng no finishers within the time limit, all because of an insufficient wind for the first of five squadron runs.

SAO PAULO, July 25 -- Sao Paulo is losing ground in the struggle to develop electric power at a rate to keep pace with the growth of the city, according to experts here. The rapid growth of industry is being stunted for lack of energy to factories.
It will be man against tide and current next Thursday morning when the 420-foot center-lift span of the new Welfare Island Bridge will be floated into position and set upon its piers.

New Yorkers, who habitually walk quickly, have discovered that they must move even more briskly to cross one-way avenues safely. When the signal light shows green the infirm have to depend on the patience of drivers.

ROME, July 25 -- In the opinion of Raffaele Scarpitti, recently elected President of the S. I. A. M. (Sindicato Italiano Alta Moda), Rome, not Florence, is the logical fashion center for Italy. The organization, which just completed its third seasonal showings, represents the designers of high style in Rome.
Summer's expectant mothers have an especially strong desire to feel cool and fresh in styles that are at once flattering and comfortable.

The Perth Amboy National Bank has sold the ten-story office building bearing its name at Smith and State Streets in Perth Amboy, N. J., to an investing client of Herman M. Glassner of Carb, Reichman Luria, attorneys.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States will begin a four-month special advertising campaign next Monday to introduce a new type of low-cost life insurance policy. The company, which is marking its ninety-fifth anniversary, will use daily newspapers, business magazines, farm journals and spot radio in the drive.

SEOUL, Korea, July 25 (UP) -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, South Korean President, took off for Washington today in a United States Air Force Constellation to confer with President Eisenhower on the future of divided Korea. He is due in Washington tomorrow.
Eight new films, including imports from Russia and Hungary, are slated to arive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

WASHINGTON, July 25 (UP) -- Frank Shea, who had lost eight in a row, finally won his first game of the year today and helped the Washington Senators strengthen their hold on fourth place by whipping the Detroit Tigers, 11 -- 3.

TOKYO, July 25 -- Ho Chi Minh, the Vietminh leader, has pledged to "liberate" the southern part of Vietnam, the Peiping radio said today in a Chinese-language broadcast. The broadcast said the following statement was made by Ho Chi Minh on July 22:
It is very gratifying to read the articles by Charles Grutzner which are appearing in your paper.

How the problem of juvenile delinquency is being dealt with today by an intelligent police force is the subject of "Juvenile Officer," which Crowell will issue Aug. 2. Written by Capt. Harold Stallings of the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department in collaboration with David Dressler, the book presents a series of case histories and outlines the progessive methods used by the county force.

TOKYO, Monday, July 26 (AP) -- Emphasizing tighter air defense along the southeastern coast of China, a Communist Peiping broadcast said last night that the Reds would shoot down any Nationalist Chinese planes flying in "violation of territorial rights."

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics, taking advantage of a big scoring inning in each game, downed Baltimore, 9 -- 4 and 6 -- 4, today for their first double-header triumph since June 13.

CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., July 25 (AP) -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. declared today that the "G.O.P. is the party of forgetfulness" and that Republicans had forgotten the people, the unemployed and their own campaign promises.

LONDON, July 25 -- Britain's largest post-war air defense maneuvers, known as Exercise Dividend, ended today after seven days in which four air officers and airmen were killed and six aircraft lost in accidents.
Dunlop Tire and Rubber Corporation plans to make an all-out bid for a major share of the passenger car, truck and bus tire market in the United States.
The Civil War is being fought with new intensity on the industrial front these days.
Lieut. Genevieve de Galard-Terraube, French nurse known as the "Angel of Dienbienphu," will arrive in New York today to be the guest of the United States, at the invitation of Congress.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., July 25 (AP) -- Marilynn Smith of Wichita, Kan., matched par 75 to win the $700 first prize in the Fort Wayne women's open golf tournament with a 216 total today.
NEW DELHI, India, July 25 (AP) -- India's commission of inquiry into the press recommended today extensive Government control of newspapers and establishment of a press council.

BOLOGNA, Italy, July 14 -- The Italian cuisine is relatively simple and limited in scope -- but you would not think so in Bologna. Culinarily speaking this is the heart of Italy, a beautiful old colonnaded city that richly serves the eye and the appetite.

HANOI, Monday, July 26 (UP) -- The French High Command said today fighting has flared up in the Red River delta and along the Annam (Central Vietnam) coast, despite tomorrow's cease-fire deadline for North Vietnam.

Five or six bungling safecrackers tied up a watchman shortly after midnight yesterday and went on a ransacking spree in the fifteen-story Elizabeth Arden Building at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street.

LONDON, July 25 -- Britain's biggest fashion week will open tomorrow with the showing of autumn collections by the "top twelve," the dozen members of the Incorporated Society of London Fashion Designers who represent British haute couture.

LONDON, July 25 (AP) -- Following is the text, as broadcast from Moscow, of a Soviet note to France proposing a new East-West conference on European collective security (similar notes have been sent to the United States and Britain):

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (AP) -- Vic Seixas won the Pennsylvania State men's grass court tennis tournament for the sixth time and fourth year in a row today, scoring a difficult 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4 victory over Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., at the Merion Cricket Club.
LONDON, July 25 -- The stock markets here have experienced their first substantial setback since the bull movement got into its stride several weeks ago.
The drought here had become so severe yesterday that corn was just about roasting on the stalk and the birds were racing the farmers for ripe ears.

KUIBYSHEV, U.S.S.R., July 16 -- Upstream from this wartime Soviet diplomatic capital an army of thousands of workers are rushing day and night to complete the world's largest hydroelectric installation.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., July 25 -- A few months ago a contractor at Iron Mountain, Mich., advertised for skilled workers. A defense contract depended on his ability to show that such manpower was available. He needed 200 men -- he received 2,000 applicants.
PITTSBURGH, July 25 -- The steel industry is looking forward to September, confident that order books then will reflect a much stronger volume.

Canada's eleven chartered banks are broadening their services. This has been made possible by a revised Bank Act, effective July 1, under which bank charters were renewed and the ground rules set until 1964.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 21 -- Huge military expenditures and a concept of planning based on the defense of selected vital areas have given Alaska a "reasonably good" defense system, according to the top military comander in the territory.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., July 25 -- Hope was rising here this weekend for a patchwork settlement of the wage dispute that culminated July 7 in short-lived atomic energy strikes at Oak Ridge and Paducah, Ky.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- President Eisenhower will decide by Tuesday whether import duties on Swiss watches and watch movements are to remain as they are or be increased by an average of 50 per cent.
Thurman Andrew has written a book that can be recommended as a kind of gym class for business men. It should tone up the flabby intellectual muscles and improve the wind for economic arguments.

In his article of July 18 on the Suez Canal Hanson Baldwin characterizes the impending British evacuation of the Suez Canal Zone as another retreat of the thin red line of empire. Suez and Egypt, he argued, have been for many a decade a military and political cornerstone of the British Empire tradition.

President Syngman Rhee is scheduled to arrive in Washington this afternoon for a few days of consultative talks about his country and its relation to ours. He will be here at the express invitation of President Eisenhower, which has been several times extended.

SAN JUAN, P. R., July 25 -- Gov. Luis Munoz Marin signed a bill today empowering him to seize the Puerto Rican docks in what the Legislature declared was a "grave public emergency" because of a thirty-one-day-strike.

BONN, Germany, July 25 -- The Federal Minister of the Interior, Dr. Gerhard Schroeder, is scheduled to make a public statement in the next few days on the case of Dr. Otto John, the West German Intelligence Chief who defected to the East Zone Communist authorities last Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- President Eisenhower urged today that peoples everywhere unite at least spiritually in a "great moral crusade" to meet an opposition united by force and terror.

The Beekman-Downtown Hospital provided 35,329 days of care for patients last year, Howard S. Cullman, president, said in the annual report yesterday. It was the first year of the hospital's operation in its new $5,500,000 building at 170 William Street.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 25 (AP) -- The French High Command announced tonight that the Vietminh had launched an assault on Nhatrang, on the south China Sea 180 miles northeast of Saigon. This is in Central Vietnam south of the partition line set by the ceasefire agreements signed at Geneva.

Ten innings of top-flight, nerve- racking baseball at the Stadium yesterday failed to settle the issue between the league-leading Cleveland Indians and the pursuing Yankees. In the eleventh, though, Andy Carey came up with one out and the bases loaded and punched Art Houtteman's first pitch through the middle to deliver the run that gave the Champions a 4-3 victory.

While one-way avenues have demonstrated their worth in moving more traffic more quickly, there still is a suspicion that the gain might be at the expense of pedestrian safety. Traffic experts contend that the pedestrian is as safe as or safer than when he crossed under the old two-way operation even though the time allotted is six seconds shorter.

A warm welcome is extended to Lieut. Genevieve de Galard-Terraube, the "Angel of Dienbienphu" who nursed the wounded until the French stronghold in Indochina fell to the Vietminh Communists. Mlle. de Galard arrives on our shores today as a heroine of the noblest order, a woman who has taken up the lamp borne just a hundred years ago by Florence Nightingale as she walked among the ill and wounded soldiers of the Crimean War.

As late as last week it had been assumed that the Theatre Guild and Fred Coe, producers of Horton Foote's "The Trip to Bountiful" last season, would team up again to put on Mr. Foote's next play, "The Traveling Lady." Such is not the case.
LIKE Helen Wills, as in so many other respects, Maureen Connolly has been the victim of a sudden crippling blow, ending her hopes of winning the national tennis championship a fourth successive time.
PHENIX CITY, Ala., July 25 -- Thirty-seven days ago the Democratic nominee for State Attorney General, the top law enforcement office in Alabama, was shot to death on a parking lot in this city.
Averell Harriman, former Director for Mutual Security, announced yesterday his availability for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

Christian hope proclaims to every man that he is unique and that his life has an eternal purpose, the Rev. Dr. Cecil Northcott of London, editor-secretary of the United Society for Christian Literature, said yesterday.

The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation reported for the six months ended on June 30 a consolidated net income of $15,664,362, or $1.22 each on the 11,556,036 common shares outstanding. This compared with $15,428,459 or $1.21 a common share in the similar period of 1953. Total revenues were $109,968,124, compared with $106,338,507.

NEWARK, July 25 -- Seventy employes without Civil Service status were dropped from the city payroll yesterday, Mayor Leo P. Carlin announced today. The dismissals, which Mayor Carlin said would save the taxpayers $238,100 a year, are part of an economy move under the strong Mayor-Council form of government that went into effect July 1.
PARIS, July 25 (AP) -- Sweden clinched the European zone Davis Cup tennis final today, defeating France in the doubles, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, 3 -- 6, 9 -- 7.
A solemn mass for "the common welfare of Italy and the United States and their continued great friendship" was offered yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Cardinal Spellman presided.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- "Satisfying progress" toward worldwide relaxation of exchange restrictions and toward universal convertibility was reported today by the International Monetary Fund.

ST. LOUIS, July 25 -- Jim Hughes came into the game for the seventh time on this Western trip today and made three pitches with the bases filled to save a 2-1 victory for the Dodgers over the Cardinals at Busch Stadium.

A few minutes before midnight last night, an energetic manhunt got under way in Brooklyn. They were looking for the fellow who only a few weeks ago rather incautiously remarked, "The Dodgers is dead."
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Mrs. Charles P. Howard, bidding farewell this week to her job of Deputy Federal Civil Defense Administrator, said it with statistics today.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Following are the texts of statements on the Hainan shooting by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and the Defense Department:

Directors of the Whitehead Metal Products Company, Inc., yesterday elected Clayton D. Grover as president to succeed Thomas M. Bohen. Mr. Bohen was elected chairman and chief officer of the company, which is a subsidiary of the International Nickel Company, Inc.

The regional blood program of the Red Cross announced yesterday that its bloodmobiles would be at Federal Hall at Wall and Nassau Streets tomorrow and Thursday from 10 A. M. to 4 P. M. No appointments to donate blood need be made.

PARIS, July 26 -- Several top Paris modistes carefully guarded the secret of their new lines for a combined opening at Maxim's Restaurant this afternoon. Fashion experts, just arrived for the couture openings tomorrow, got a quick over-all picture of brilliant new hats.

FLORENCE, Italy, July 24 -- Highly dramatic and swiftly paced, the Veneziani collection was among the last of the showings that have been going on here this week. This Milanese designer has long been connected with the theatre, a fact that was obvious from the moment she sent her first manikins out in groups of brilliantly colored coats, which she called winter, rain, frost and snow.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- George Meany today promised the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., continued support in its fight on the New York waterfront against the independent International Longshoremen's Association.

PITTSBURGH, July 26 (AP) -- Gene Conley yielded only four hits tonight in hurling the Milwaukee Braves to a 3-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates, the fifth triumph in a row for the third-place Braves.
The Spanish Embassy said yesterday it was "absurd" to assume that its press attache in Washington had reflected Spain's attitude when he attacked critics of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

Memories of an unusual 'academic year" in 1928-29 were recalled yesterday by forty men and women who twenty-five years ago were students of the "Floating University." They were guests of the American President Lines aboard the President Monroe at Erie Pier 9 in Jersey City.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UP) -- The Senate Finance Committee voted today to exempt farmers and ranchers in drought disaster areas from the tax on the sale of their livestock if the animals were replaced within twelve months.
SAN JUAN, P. R., July 26 -- The first break in the employers' ranks in the thirty-two-day-old Puerto Rican longshoremen's strike occurred today.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges closed generally higher yesterday. New highs were reached in potatoes, cottonseed oil and soybean oil. Hides, however, fell to new lows. Incidents in the Far East resulted in firmer prices in most markets.
MELBOURNE, Australia, July 26 -- Richard G. Casey, Minister of External Affairs, appealed to South and Southeast Asian nations tonight to join in defensive organization against Communist aggression.

YOU lie abed in Bryan Clark's Hawthorne Lodge on the southern edge of Louisville and listen to the song of the night. Katydids and crickets beat the time; whippoorwills whistle an obbligato for the frog chorus.

Though food prices nationally edged up last month, they fell off a bit in New York City, according to a welcome bulletin from the local regional office of the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics.
William Prentice, in his letter regarding the "No Dogs Allowed" signs at our beaches, has pointed up one facet of a widespread problem.
Money market rates stiffened a little last week, because of a moderate outflow of funds from New York to the rest of the country and to the Treasury.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UP) -- Congressional investigators tried to learn today why a 100-ton a day mill was installed at the Lost River Mine of the United States Tin Corporation when only a twenty-five ton mill had been authorized.
PARIS, July 26 -- Officials here said today the French Government would join with Washington and London in making a three-power reply to the Soviet note proposing a European conference.

CLINTON, Conn., July 26 -- De Coursey Fales' Staysail schooner, Nina, won the second day's race in the big cruising division and Arthur P. Davis with his forty-foot sloop Patricia, was victorious again in Division II as the American Yacht Club's twenty-third annual cruise advanced to Duck Island Roads tonight.
During its initial testing flights, the first jet transport produced in the United States nudged the sound barrier at altitudes of eight miles and more.

Word came from Washington yesterday that the Senate Finance Committee would penalize distillers who advertised that their whisky was nine to twelve years old, even if that is the fact. A previous effort linked to the Prohibitionist forces, which came to naught, sought to bar advertising of alcoholic beverages moving in interstate commerce.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Representative Carroll D. Kearns, Republican of Michigan, today introduced a bill seeking $5,000,000,000 in Federal aid for school construction in the next three years as a "realistic" approach to this problem.

BONN, Germany, July 26 -- In a preliminary statement today on the case of Dr. Otto John, the West German Government said that on the basis of available evidence it must be assumed he had been lured into the East sector of Berlin by the Communists.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Administration hopes for final action before Congressional adjournment on legislation to force balky witnesses to testify were brightened today. Chances for passage of a bill to admit wire tapped evidence to Federal courts, another key Administration objective, became dimmer.

JOHNSON CITY, N. Y., July 26 (AP) -- Research workers at the Ozalid division of the General Aniline Film Corporation said today that the Justice Department had reiterated its opposition to returning Aniline units to their former German owners.
The week-end clash in the skies off Hainan Island emphasized the increasing strategic importance of the South China Sea in the continuing struggle for Asia.

LONDON, July 26 -- The United States, Britain and other countries that subscribe to an embargo on the sale of strategic goods to the Soviet Union and its satellites have agreed to cut the list substantially Aug. 16.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee today voted special tax treatment for ultra high frequency television sets and moved to wipe out the 10 per cent excise rate on all commercial TV, radio and phonograph machines, except on tubes and cabinets.

TRENTON, July 26 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner asked legislative leaders today to sanction an emergency $200,000 appropriation to cover the cost of the state's investigation into the complex financial manipulations of former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman.

LONDON, July 26 -- The British Government welcomed today Communist China's offer to make amends for what Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden called the "savage and inexcusable" attack on a British airliner over the China Sea.
There is a possibility that Rocky Graziano may find himself involved with the Stone of Scone on the New York stage this season.

The hotels of this city are seeking to reduce some of the confusion of multiple charity appeals through a management-labor united fund drive by which their 36,000 employes would consolidate their giving.
The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation moved yesterday to reconvert the Little Inch pipeline, from Baytown, Tex., to Moundsville, W. Va., to an oil products carrier.

In 1950 Margueritte Harmon Bro accompanied her husband to Indonesia, where he had been appointed cultural attache to the United States Embassy in Jakarta. After learning the language, Mrs. Bro visited many parts of the Malay archipelago, talking both to the natives and to the Dutch business men.

Virgil Thomson was the conductor of the "All-American Gala" performed by the Stadium Symphony Orchestra at Lewisohn Stadium last night. Mr. Thomson led the orchestra in his own "Louisiana Story" Suite, excerpts from "Four Saints in Three Acts," his opera to a text by Gertrude Stein; Samuel Barber's Overture to "The School for Scandal" and Aaron Copland's "Appalachian Spring" Suite.

MOSCOW, July 26 -- A group of ten or twelve editors of Soviet university newspapers has applied for visas to visit the United States in return for visits to the Soviet Union in recent months by two groups of United States college editors.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Burton C. Bovard, ousted general counsel of the Federal Housing Administration, announced tonight he would summon Sherman Adams, Presidential adviser, and other high officials as witnesses at a hearing on his discharge.

The latest Soviet note, proposing in effect the establishment of Soviet domination over Europe by "peaceful" means, provides swift confirmation that the termination of the "hot" war in Indochina does not mean the end of the "cold" war elsewhere. The Soviet note will doubtless be rejected, but in view of the drift of European opinion a merely negative reply is not enough.

The plant and equipment of the Flushing Storage Warehouse Company at 135-28 Thirty-ninth Avenue in Flushing, Queens, has been sold through a transfer of stock to Stanley and Jerry Cirker, who operate the Gramercy and Hayes storage warehouses in Manhattan.

In a deal in the heart of the downtown insurance district, the five-story store and loft building on lot 25 by 83 feet at 112 Fulton Street, southwest corner of Dutch Street, has been sold by the 112 Fulton Street Corporation to an investing client of Walter J. Smith of Raymond E. Ryan, Inc., brokers.

Two of the most important of our look-out posts, so far as keeping us informed on world developments in trade and foreign exchange is concerned, are the Bank for International Settlements, at Basle, Switzerland, and the International Monetary Fund, which has its headquarters in Washington, D. C.

PHENIX CITY, Ala., July 26 (UP) -- National Guardsmen sent here by Gov. Gordon Persons to enforce the law in this gambling town have turned up evidence warranting a full-scale investigation into possible narcotics activity, their commanding officer said today.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UP) -- A Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee approved a compromise proposal today to require that all Executive agreements except treaties be disclosed to the Senate unless it would hurt national security to make them public.
LISBON, Portugal, July 26 -- Accusations of two further violations of Portuguese terrtiory in India by Indian "volunteers" have been made by the Portuguese Foreign Ministry.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- President Eisenhower sent to the Senate today his nominations for representatives of the United States to the ninth session of the United Nations General Assembly, which opens Sept. 21.

OTTAWA, July 26 (Canadian Press) -- The Federal Board of Transport Commissioners today granted Trans-Canada Pipe Lines, Ltd., a conditional permit to build a $300,000,000 natural gas line from Alberta to eastern Canada.
MEXICO CITY, July 28 -- President Rodolfo Ruiz Cortines gave a vote of confidence tonight to three members of his Cabinet and two Ambassadors charged with being Communists.

Atlanta, Ga., announced yesterday that it expected to offer $10,000,000 of new securities on Aug. 30. While it did not specify the purpose of the offering, it said that it expected to sell serial bonds, dated Sept. 1, which will mature from 1961 to 1979.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., July 26 (AP) -- Lloyd Moglen of Mount Vernon, N. Y., an unseeded player, staged the only upset today in the opening rounds of the thirty-ninth national junior and boys tennis championships.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 26 -- The United States said today that the "depredations" of Chinese Communist fliers provided another proof that Peiping did not belong in the United Nations.

Although organized parents' groups have been helpful in spearheading many educational and training programs for mentally retarded children, they often attempt to work out curriculums too much on their own; Dr. Samuel A. Kirk declared last night.

Net income of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company for the first six months of this year was $2,178,419. This was 5.8 per cent more than the $2,059,547 cleared in the same period of 1953, Frank McLaughlin, president, reported yesterday. Share earnings were $1 for the 1954 period, against 95 cents a year ago.
Five banking groups competed yesterday for the Boston Edison Company's offering of $18,000,000 first mortgage Series E bonds, due on Aug. 1, 1984.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Following are the major roll-call votes in Congress today involving the Atomic Energy Act:

The General Electric Company announced yesterday that a $500,000 fund had been established in honor of Owen D. Young, chairman of the board from 1922 through World War II. Another $500,000 fund has been set up in honor of Edwin W. Rice Jr., second president of the company, who served from 1913 to 1922.
JERUSALEM, July 28 -- The tasks, powers and privileges in Israel of the World Zionist Organization were embodied in a charter signed today by Premier Moshe Sharett.
In the current episode in the South China Sea the Chinese Communist fighter planes would appear to have undertaken to deny to American ships and planes the "freedom of rescue."
The House defeat of the President's reinsurance health plan makes timely review of both the objective and the method of the proposed legislation.
LONE ROCK, Wis., July 26 (UP) -- Wisconsin began an investigation today of Kenneth Crook s "uranium tunnel," which many ailing persons have visited in the hope of finding cures.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The House of Representatives passed today a bill to authorize future construction of about 145 flood control, navigation and beach erosion projects at a cost of $890,271,514.

New York's biggest union is giving a reverse twist to one of the key devices used by Southern communities to induce Northern manufacturers to abandon unionized plants here and operate under nonunion conditions in the South.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Advocates of statehood for Hawaii and Alaska gave up hope today for action this year to admit either to the Union.

Five dress manufacturers and two union accountants were indicted yesterday on the basis of a complaint filed by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L. They were accused of conspiring to cheat the union welfare fund of $18,000 in employer payments for health, vacation and pension benefits.
Joseph Solman is a man with double perspective -- he sees life from behind an easel and through a mutuel window at New York race tracks.

Dr. John Adams Kingsbury, chairman of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship, Inc., told a hearing of the Subversive Activities Control Board yesterday that the blame for starting the Korean War was "an unsettled question."
Two painters were killed at 2:10 P. M. yesterday when a rope securing one end of their scaffold gave way and they plunged three floors to the pavement outside a Roman Catholic school in Queens.

A new first mortgage of $1,150,000 for fifteen years has been placed by Dwight-Helmsley, Inc., brokers, on the new four-level parking garage at 218-30 West Thirty-first Street, running through to 225-37 West Thirtieth Street.
CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

STALINGRAD, U. S. S. R., July 18 -- A little more than ten years from the date of Field Marshal Friedrich von Paulus' surrender, a new, beautiful and industrially potent metropolis has arisen on the ruins that was Stalingrad.
Count Flame, a 9-2 shot, was able to maintain a strong pace all the way to win the Kingsbury Handicap, the classified event that served as the feature race at the Jamaica Race Track yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 26 -- Leslie Keith Munro of New Zealand told the United Nations Disarmament Commission here today that the "attitude of stony immobility" displayed by the Soviet Union had created an "unbridgeable gap" on the road toward disarmament and the control of nuclear weapons.
JERSEY CITY, July 26 -- Mrs. Carolyn Reidy, a ward leader here for the Democratic party, testified today before Samuel E. Larner, court-appointed examiner of the city's municipal financies.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations urged President Eisenhower today to ban the use of Federal funds in all private or public housing projects that did not completely prohibit racial segregation.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad scored a 116 per cent increase in net income last month over the same month a year ago. Patrick B. McGinnis, president, who acquired control of the road at the annual meeting last April 21, announced yesterday that earnings in June after all charges and taxes, but before sinking funds, amounted to $1,021,951.
Two officials of Local 1688, Retail Clerks International Association, A. F. L., were indicted yesterday by a Kings County grand jury on a charge of attempted extortion.
ALBANY, July 26 (AP) -- Special firecrackers are legal when used by farmers to scare birds out of orchards and cornfields, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein said today.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 26 (AP) -- A yearling, chestnut brother of Your Host, who four years ago captured the Santa Anita Derby, sold today for $60,000 as the summer auctions at Keeneland opened at a record level.
Mlle. Genevieve de Galard-Terraube, a young Parisienne with dimples in her smile, a fleeting shyness about showing them, and the emphatically low heels of a nurse, came to America yesterday.
LONDON, July 26 -- Stock market prices moved narrowly and irregularly today with changes generally limited to a few pence.
HONOLULU, July 26 -- Leaders of Hawaii's statehood drive expressed varying degrees of disappointment here today over the development in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Tuesday, July 27 -- The Senate headed into another all-night session early today as efforts to break the twelve-day tie-up collapsed.
MINEOLA, L. I., July 26 -- Action on another phase in the long struggle for Nassau County's first complete north-south arterial highway was started here this morning by the Board of Supervisors.

WESTHAMPTON, L. I., July 26 -- An Australian model plane enthusiast, Alan King of Victoria, today won the Wakefield Cup for rubber-powered models at the World Model Air Olympics at Suffolk County Air Force Base.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- President Syngman Rhee of South Korea arrived today for a state visit and immediately restated his ultimate goal -- the expulsion of Communists from North Korea and the unification of his homeland.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Treasury reported tonight that the interest rate on its ninety-one-day bills had gone up for the seventh consecutive week.

ST. PAUL, July 26 -- Walter Burkemo, the defending titleholder from the Franklin Hills Country Club, Birmingham, Mich., moved into the final of the Professional Golfers Association championship today.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., July 26 -- "It will be a damned long way from Times Square to safety if a hydrogen or atomic bomb is dropped on New York," Lieut. Gen. C. R. Huebner, director of the New York State Civil Defense Commission said today.
LONDON, July 26 -- The London autumn fashion shows opened this morning with Hardy Amies' "shoulder arms" collection, a sequel to the "battle of the bust," which Amies fought and won last season.

The National Collegiate A. A. has accepted for registration twenty-eight swimming records achieved under its supervision during the 1953-54 season, it was revealed yesterday by Philip S. Harburger, chairman of the committee in charge.

Alexander P. Maran, 57-year-old accountant who pleaded guilty on June 3 to stealing funds from the Manhattan State Hospital where he was employed, was sentenced yesterday to two consecutive terms of five to ten years in state prison.

TOKYO, July 26 (AP) -- Nathan Mallow of 857 Schenck Avenue, Brooklyn, N. Y., was sentenced to five years in prison and fined $5,000 for illegal commercial activities while working here as an Army employe, the Army said today.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, July 26 -- The man who frightened smokers last month with figures on higher death rates from cancer and heart disease among users of cigarettes gave them a word of cheer today. He believes harmless tobacco can be grown.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Atomic Energy Bill, now before Congress, has three broad objectives:
PARIS, July 24 -- United States architects have donated a modern stained-glass window to the Cathedral of Chartres as a tribute to the workmen and builders of the Middle Ages.
CAIRO, July 26 -- The Egyptian Government broke the insurgent movement among young Orthodox Coptic Christians today and restored to office the aged Patriarch kidnapped Sunday by the rebels.

Not so long ago, if United States business sneezed, the rest of the world shuddered in fear of economic pneumonia. That is no longer so today, according to the Chase National Bank. In its quarterly economic bulletin, Business in Brief, the bank contends that the dollar trade gap -- the amount by which ordinary commercial exports exceed ordinary commercial imports -- is disappearing.

AJMER, India, July 26 -- An important factor contributing to the conclusion of the truce agreements in Indochina was the Western nations' recognition of Communist China as a permanent major power, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today. He added that this had been achieved largely by the courageous leadership of Pierre Mendes-France, Premier of France.
HARTFORD CITY, Ind., July 26 (UP) -- A rural church group went out of the stray cat business today after protests that the project was "inhumane."
HICKORY, N. C., July 26 (AP) -- The Grace Evangelical and Reformed Church at near-by Newton voted yesterday to accept a conditional offer of $24 a share for its 5,200 shares of Dan River Mills stock.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 21 -- Alaska has passed the peak of a vast military construction program that boomed the territorial economy. It turned frontier towns such as Anchorage and Fairbanks into thriving cities.

Your editorial in the issue of July 20 "Straight Thinking in Iran" is another sign of the courageous and forthright support of fundamental principles consistently adopted by your esteemed paper. But I wonder whether one would be branded a Communist or accused of harboring subversive intentions if one questioned the correctness of your line of argument?
The children at Bellevue Hospital will be the beneficiaries of a dinner dance on Oct. 14 in the St. Regis Roof, an annual event given by the Recreation Service for the Children of Bellevue.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- A $12,500,000-a-year rate increase proposed by the Cities Service Gas Company was opposed today by several cities at a Federal Power Commission hearing.

Range riders, sheriff's posses hot in pursuit of cattle rustlers and the sound of gunfire echoing across the purple sage have fallen into comparative disfavor with a large segment of the seagoing reading public, the working seamen.

RYE, N. Y., July 26 -- Hot weather and recent currents in Long Island Sound have brought an unseasonally early infestation of jellyfish to some beaches. The free-swimming pests usually are not bothersome until mid-August.

The Armco Steel Corporation increased its earnings in the first half of this year by 18.2 per cent despite a drop of 8.5 per cent in sales, compared with a year ago. A sharp drop in taxes was a large factor in the higher profits.
ST. PAUL, July 26 -- Unfortunately, golf courses are not like Topsy. They just do not grow.
VANCOUVER, July 26 (AP) --It was "Hello, John" and "Hello, Roger" when the world's two fastest milers met today in Athletes' Village of the British Empire games.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Members of Congress applauded today the action of United States Navy fliers in shooting down two Chinese Communist fighter planes that had attacked them.
Domestic steel-making operations picked up slightly last week but were expected to fall back again this week.

A proposal to erect a Jack Frost Sugar sign in Long Island City more or less across the East River from the United Nations met with opposition yesterday from United Nations and city officials. Robert Moses was among the critics of the suggestion.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- For the second time in a week, President Eisenhower gave a political blessing today to a first-term candidate for Congress.
Prices of active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 10 to 27 points yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, July 20 -- Twice in this century Sweden has managed to keep out of war which has engulfed most of Europe, including her closest neighbors, but if there is to be a third conflict of that magnitude Swedish neutrality will be much more difficult to maintain.
ROME, July 26 -- Pope Pius XII, who has excelled all his life as a linguist, added another today to the long list of languages he speaks.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UP) -- The Justice Department announced today that two Belleville, N. J., corporations and six individuals had agreed to refrain from practices that the department contended amounted to an attempt to monopolize trade in chlorinating equipment.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 26 -- Senator John L. McClellan and former Governor Sidney McMath, who are rivals for the Democratic nomination to Mr. McClellan's seat, ended their campaigns tonight with television and state-wide radio appearances here.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 26 -- Thirty pickets in the recent Oak Ridge A. F. L. Laborers' Local 818 wildcat strike were fined for contempt by Knoxville Circuit Judge W. C. Burton today.
A list of college football games to be televised this autumn was jointly announced yesterday by the American Broadcasting Company and the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

Carmelo Costa, Brooklyn, featherweight, ran his unbeaten string to twenty-five last night when he gained a unanimous decision over Vic Toweel, former world bantamweight champion from Benoni, South Africa, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- United States carrier-based aircraft have shot down two Chinese Communist fighter planes that attacked them as they searched the South China Sea for survivors of the British airliner downed by the Chinese last Friday.

The parliamentary deadlock which has produced an atomic filibuster in the Senate ought not to obscure certain facts in the present position of our atomic program. One of these facts is that the proposed amendments to the Atomic Energy Act were convincing enough to be unanimously endorsed by the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy and, yesterday, to win House approval by a vote of 229 to 154.

Save for the aircraft group, which seemed to be affected by the shooting down by United States planes of two Red Chinese pursuit ships, the stock market was weak yesterday. Toward the end, however, a modest rally brought the day to a close with virtually no net change on the average.

Even in the neighborhood of New York City this has been a dry year. This newspaper yesterday published on its front page a sad picture of a cornfield at Congers, N. Y., with stunted, drooping plants and no prospect of much corn on the cob. Similar situations can be found on Long Island and in New Jersey.

The purchase by Louis J. Glickman, realty investor, of the twin business buildings at 680-84 Fifth Avenue, southwest corner of Fifty-fourth Street, from Georg Jensen. Inc., silversmiths; was announced yesterday. The property adjoins St. Thomas Church and is assessed for tax purposes at $2,490,000.
ALBANY, July 26 (AP) -- Radar, a war veteran with a fine service record, gradually is taking an important civilian role in New York State -- that of nemesis to speed- happy motorists.
A woman was handcuffed to her maid in her duplex apartment at 59 East Eighty-second Street last evening while a thief leisurely ransacked bureau drawers and escaped with $6,600 in jewelry and cash.

BOGOTA, Colombia, July 13 (UP) -- Architects and workmen are within sight of completion of the salt cathedral of Zipaquira, a triumph of man, nature and religious faith that is destined to become one of the modern wonders of the world.

Operations of the Phillips Petroleum Company and its subsidiaries in the first half of this year resulted in a net profit of $37,918,723, equal, to $2.59 each on 14,636,099 shares outstanding. This represented a rise of 11 per cent over the 1953 half-year net of $34,224,846, or $2.34 each on 14,595,341 shares.

LOS ANGELES, July 26 -- Five screen writers and producers appeared before the State Senate Fact-Finding Committee on Un-American Activities here today to clear their names of possible pro-Communist tinges.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Dr. John A. Hannah, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Manpower and Personnel, is leaving the Pentagon Saturday to rsume the presidency of Michigan State College. He will remain United States Chairman of the Permanent Joint Board on Defense with Canada.

GENEVA, July 25 -- The direction in which Western Europe is moving today in reorganizing its machinery for carrying on international trade and monetary relationships is clearly favorable to the United States. But there is plenty of time left for the movement to get sidetracked and rather badly out of line with traditional American interests in these fields.
CHICAGO, July 26 -- The disquieting news from the Far East and the worsening drought drove all grains upward today.
A lot of hot air was dispensed in air-conditioned meeting rooms by major league representatives at the Commodore Hotel yesterday, but for all of that the following positive decisions were reached:
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 26 -- Pakistan is restricting Soviet diplomats and their families to a radius of thirty-five miles from the center of Karachi.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 26 (AP) -- Pat Lesser, who plays on the Seattle University men's golf team, lowered the qualifying record for the 54-year-old women's Western amateur golf tournament today with a 3-under-par 72.

On the morning of July 27, 1953, the negotiators in Korea signed the terms of a cease-fire. This morning, just one year later, the President of Korea will be discussing the problems of his country with the President of the United States and with other high American officials.
HANOI, Vietnam, Tuesday, July 27 -- The cease-fire for North Vietnam went into effect at 8 A. M. today (8 P. M. Monday in New York).
CHICAGO, July 26 -- A formal announcement of the purchase of the Shamrock Hotel in Houston by the Hilton Hotels Corporation is expected to be made at the end of the week.

Postcards and letters come in -- trickle in, is a better way of putting it -- to the city from summer camps these days, saying that someone is having a fine time and the food is wonderful, or that it is a terrible camp and the food is awful (this to be followed next day by a postcard from that critic asking if he can stay another week, please?).
PRINCETON, N. J., July 26 -- The New Jersey conference of Seventh-Day Adventists is holding its annual Bible conference and camp meeting three miles north of here at Camp Kingston.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 28 -- "The Tender Trap," scheduled for its Broadway debut on Oct. 10 at the Longacre Theatre, has been purchased by Metro-Gold-wyn-Mayer for filming in 1955.
The country's third largest insurance company, the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, celebrated its ninety-fifth anniversary yesterday.

FOREST OF RAMBOUILLET, France, July 26 -- The Supreme Allied Command in Europe moved into tents today in this oak forest thirty miles west of Paris to test wartime plans for the evacuation of its permanent headquarters in Rocquencourt.
Korean craftsmen, who returned to their peaceful pursuits at the close of the war, have produced a quantity of their exotic, traditional wares, some of which recently arrived here.
Governor Dewey made clear yesterday that he was backing up Robert Moses, chairman of the State Power Authority, in the wrangle within the agency over the chairman's methods.

Ann Sothern will be the star of the first of Max Liebman's Saturday night ninety-minute color productions over N. B. C.-TV on Sept. 25, when she plays the leading role of Jenny in "Lady in the Dark," the part made famous by Gertrude Lawrence in the original musical comedy.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Senate passed tonight the bitterly contested atomic energy bill after a thirteen-day filibuster that had blocked major portions of the Administration's legislative program.

CHANNEL 7 has entered the early morning sweepstakes with a program of music, news and weather reports from 8 to 9 o'clock. Entitled "Good Morning," it is a decidedly lightweight show, which makes no pretense of being of championship caliber, which might be a virtue in itself.
WINNIPEG, Man., July 27 -- With a new crop year about to begin, Canada's wheat harvest this year is expected to be the smallest in a decade.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company reported yesterday an estimated net profit of $88,000,000 for the first half equal to $2.51 a share. This was identical with the result reported by the company for the first six months last year.

LONDON, July 27 -- Britain demanded tonight that Communist China discipline the pilots who shot down a British airliner. She also protested against China's refusal to allow more than one aircraft to search for wreckage after the incident.
The amazing descent of the Giants was still moving at an alarming rate of speed last night.

FREEPORT, L. I., July 27 -- Though drought-caused water famines are reported daily in many low-pressure areas in Nassau County, a water official of this village urged its residents yesterday to use more water on their parched lawns and shrubs.

PARIS, July 27 -- An editorial in the newspaper Le Monde, which dislikes United States foreign policy, today denounced "American nervousness" over the plane attack near Hainan Island in China. It had no criticism of the Chinese who attacked both a British airliner and United States naval planes that went in aid of possible survivors.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 27 -- The World Presbyterian Alliance called today upon the people of the United States to "exercise forbearance" in their criticism of religious leaders from behind the Iron Curtain.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Tariff increases up to 50 per cent on certain imported watches were ordered into effect at midnight tonight by President Eisenhower.
A sound advertising promotion stunt can have a long life. Willoughby's, a camera shop, which advertises regularly in newspapers in this area, offers this story:

LONDON, July 27 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of Communist China's protest to the United States today, as issued by Deputy Minister for Foreign Affairs Chang Han-fu and reported by the Communist New China News Agency:

PARIS, July 27 -- The French Government will decide this fall on a new trans-Atlantic liner to replace the Ile de France in service to New York, Jacques Chaban-Delmas, Minister of Transport, told the National Assembly today.

A colony of split-level dwellings is planned for a thirteen-acre tract of land on Walnut Avenue in Cranford, N. J., which was bought by United Homes, Inc., through the Boyle Company, broker. The seller was the Hess Estate.
CAIRO July 27 -- Following is the text of an agreement initialed today by Britain an Egypt on the Suez Canal zone:

Net income of the Kennecott Copper Corporation for the first six months this year declined to $42,149,193 from $45,293,064 in the 1953 period. While earnings this year benefited by the elimination of the excess profits tax, they suffered by reason of decreased earnings from the company's Chilean operations, C. R. Cox, president, explained yesterday in the midyear report to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Colombian Government has approved a plan worked out by David E. Lilienthal for a development in the Cauca Valley of Colombia along the lines of the Tennessee Valley Authority.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 27 -- Iran's Premier has urged her to end her isolation in international affairs and develop strength, "command the respect of the free world and enjoy its support."

Once more the long-overdue admission of Hawaii as a state of the Union has come a cropper. Apparently the last lingering hope of action at this session of Congress died in Washington on Monday, when the House Rules Committee tabled a request to let separate Senate and House statehood bills go to conference to resolve differences between them.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., July 27 -- A three-time president of the Screen Writers Guild who was named in the 1948 report of a California legislative committee among persons identified as "outstanding fellow-travelers and Communists" testified today that she "would rather be dead than be a Communist."

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, July 27 (UP) -- Chilean delegates to the World Power Congress suggested today that Bolivia, Chile and Peru move promptly toward joint harnessing of the power potential of Lake Titicaca (cross on map), 10,000 feet above sea level in the Andes.

The average market price for bonds on the New York Stock Exchange rose to $100.71 in June, the Exchange reported yesterday. This compared with $100 on May 31 and was the highest since $101 on April 30 of this year.
George T. Piercy has been named assistant general manager of the supply department and J. M. Shivers manager of the refining coordination division of Esso Standard Oil Company.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27 (UP) -- Home runs by Danny Schell, Bobby Morgan and Del Ennis, plus the six-hit pitching of Robin Roberts, paced the Philadelphia Phillies to an 8-2 victory over the Cincinnati, Redlegs tonight.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 27 -- Legal barriers that have long prevented preferential treatment for Westchester residents at county parks fell today.

The Toledo Edison Company, which provides electric, gas and heating service to a 2,500-square-mile territory in northwestern Ohio, reported yesterday a net income of $5,377,346 in the year ended June 30, 1954. This was equal to 94 cents a share on the utility's common stock, and compares with $5,270,171, or 91.6 cents a share, in the preceding comparable twelve months.

Recognized as a talented short story writer and novelist, Angus Wilson has branched out into the playwriting domain. His first effort, "The Mulberry Bush," has been purchased by Peter Glenville and Hardy William Smith, a new London producing team with Broadway aspirations.

A permanent display of old automobiles has been opened on Broadway near Forty-fifth Street, nostalgically driving us back to the days of the duster and the cry, "Get a horse!" But all is not placid and serene.
The Texas Company has elected M. Halpern senior vice president and elevated three others to vice presidencies, J. S. Leach, board chairman of the oil company, announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27 (AP) -- Roy Mack, who previously remained in the background of the House of Mack, made a determined bid today to take over complete control of the Philadelphia Athletics and keep the team here.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 27 -- The trial of 71-year-old Arsenije Bradvarevic, Orthodox Metropolitan of Montenegro, opened at Cetinje today. He is indicted on a series of counts in the new Criminal Code alleging various activities hostile to Yugoslavia's Communist state.

The Suez Canal, whose British garrison is to be removed under an agreement reached yesterday, has been a source of international tension since 1882. Seven years earlier Britain obtained control of the 100-mile waterway connecting the Mediterranean with the Gulf of Suez of the Red Sea by purchasing the interest of the extravagant Ismail Pasha, the Egyptian Khedive, in the Suez Canal Company.
Two former college professors denied yesterday charges made earlier by Louis Budenz, once the editor of The Daily Worker, that they had been members of the Communist party.
PHILADELPHIA, July 27 -- For the third straight month, the Pennsylvania Railroad operated in the black in June, but not enough to overcome first-quarter red figures.

Cocoa prices climbed the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange in all positions except the nearby September contract, which was up 95 points. Commission house buying and manufacturing purchasing absorbed light trade selling.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 27 (AP) -- State Senator Raymond Gary of Madill apparently won Oklahoma's Democratic nomination for Governor tonight on the basis of nearly complete returns from the run-off primary.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Witnesses testified today a "pattern of segregation" existed on trains in interstate travel in the South -- whether admitted or not.

" A Philosophy for Our Time," Bernard M. Baruch's summing up of the lessons of eighty-four years, will be issued Aug. 19 by Simon Schuster. The volume contains the three lectures Mr. Baruch gave last May before the students of his Alma Mater, City College of New York, and his address when the School of Business and Public Administration was named in his honor.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The whole tone and climate of the Eighty-third Congress has been altered sharply in the Senate's long fight over public versus private power.
While domestic watch manufacturers praised President Eisenhower's action in increasing watch tariffs, the import trade was stunned by yesterday's decision.

COSTA RICA, July 27 -- Claudio Mora Molina, leader of a rebel group, escaped across the Nicaraguan frontier after yesterday's "battle" with Government troops at the mouth of the Sarapiqui River, the Government announced today.
A thirty-year report on New York State parks, issued yesterday, urged greater use of the state's 2,500,000-acre forest preserve for camping and recreation.

I have read with much admiration and general concurrence your editorial of July 22 entitled "After Geneva." There are, however, certain additional slants on the Asian problem which I should like to point out.
ST. PAUL, July 27 -- Melvin (Chick) Harbert, 39-year-old Detroit district representative, won the Professional Golfers Association championship today after failing in two finals.
Homeowners and tenants in New York are becoming increasingly conscious of burglary, which was second only to larceny as the leading crime in this city last year.
PARIS, July 27 -- "Grande couture'' is the expression most applicable to Pierre Balmain's collection.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Soybeans showed independent strength on the Board of Trade today, closing with gains of 6 3/8 to 10 cents. But the rest of the list lost ground. Net losses were: wheat, 2 3/8 to 3 3/8 cents; corn, 1/4 to 3/4 cents; oats, 1/8 to 1/4 cents, and rye, 1 3/4 to 3 3/4 cents a bushel.

Events tonight: Stadium Symphony Orchestra, Thomas Scherman conducting, Anahid Ajemian, violinist, and Maro Ajemian, pianist, Lewisohn Stadium; Goldman Band, Guggenheim Memorial Concert, Central Park; "Murder in Three Keys," Cherry Lane Theatre. All at 8:30.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Fall campaign material is being written on sensitized paper at the White House these days.
OLMSTED FALLS, Ohio, July 27 -- Juvenile delinquency has been virtually eliminated in this Cleveland suburb, population 1,400.
CHICAGO, July 27 -- The third largest crowd in Comiskey Park history, 53,067 fans, saw the Chicago White Sox, with Virgil Trucks spinning a five-hitter, blank the Yankees, 4 -- 0, tonight.

A special counsel will be appointed today by the Tompkins-Rabin Joint Legislative Committee to investigate alleged subversion in vacation camps. This will leave the committee's regular counsel, Charles T. Corey, free to continue his questioning of witnesses about charity rackets and other problems of philathropic fund-raising.

In his special message to Congress on March 30 dealing with foreign economic policy the President called, among other things, for reform of tariff classifications, for a more satisfactory method of evaluating imported articles and for a modernization of procedures for administering the customs laws.

Ten years after the Battle of Stalingrad, that marked one of the turning-points of the Second World War, our correspondent in Russia has paid another visit to that Volga city. He first saw it, he recalls, when it was little more than the rubble heap from which a thoroughly defeated von Paulus crawled to offer his surrender.
HANOI, Vietnam, July 27 -- French Union troops began redeploying for movement into armistice zones less than an hour after a cease-fire order ended seven and a half years of war in North Vietnam.

TRENTON, July 27 (AP) -- Archibald S. Alexander, New Jersey Treasurer, today announced the state's take from pari-mutuel betting during the first thirty-five days of horse racing at Monmouth Park was almost half a million dollars more than last year.

Deposits in the nation's 528 mutual savings banks rose above $25,000,000,000 for the first time at the end of June, according to a report yesterday by J. Hamilton Cheston, president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

The recent announcements that the Russians now possess the hydrogen bomb and that greater and more powerful bombs appear to be in the offing point with great significance to the inadequacies of civil defense measures.
GENEVA, July 27 -- The first effort to do something on a regional basis about the economic backwardness of European countries bordering on the Eastern Mediterranean is under way.
CHICAGO, July 27 (UP) -- The grizzly bear had his jaws clamped on Leonard Rademacher's right hand, so the only thing for the 9-year-old boy to do was sock the beast on the nose.
One of the choicest private music libraries in Europe reached Ann Arbor, Mich., several days ago in ninety-four large packing cases.

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 28 -- Communist China bitterly at-I tacked the' United States today for shootin down two fighter [)lanes close to Hainan Island Sunday and warned WashingtorL to desist immediately from such "aggressive acts."
Hold-up men made off with $6,219 in two payroll robberies within ten minutes in West Side office buildings yesterday, but the two crimes were apparently unconnected.
Stocks gave another display of strength yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Pushing ahead from a wobbly start, they registered 177 new 1954 highs. There were only three new lows.
Mayor Wagner moved yesterday to learn the facts about one batch of "sinecure" city posts -- hydrant inspectors who get $5 a day for looking over hydrants when they are used by contractors.

POINT PLEASANT BEACH, N. J., July 27 -- Six men and six women on a small fishing boat had a narrow escape seven miles off shore from this community. early today when a 5,226-ton Norwegian freighter rammed their craft in a fog.

PITTSBURGH, July 27 (AP) -- The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth largest steel producer, announced today that net income for the second quarter was $6,326,000, or 96 cents a share, compared with $10,,721,000, or $1.67 a share, for the second quarter of 1953.

LONDON, July 27 -- Chang Han-fu, Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Chinese Communist Government, protested the destruction of two Red fighter planes in a statement broadcast by the Peiping radio and transmitted to London by the British legation in China.

A contract for the construction of a low-rent housing project for a hundred families now dwelling in sub-standard areas of Middletown, N. Y., was signed yesterday by Herman T. Stichman. State Commissioner of Housing, and the Middletown Housing Authority at the offices of the State Division of Housing, 270 Broadway.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., July 27 (UP) -- Seeded players had little trouble today as all survived second-round play in both the national junior and boys' singles championships.

Mayor Wagner descended into a Long Island City underground shaft of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity yesterday and turned a valve that put into use a new $1,840,000, seventy-two-inch water main.

It is incredible that Reinhold Neibuhr should state in his letter which appeared in your July 19 edition that "finally no one seems to point to the absurdity of setting up moral tests for admission to the United Nations, of regarding it as a conventicle of 'good' nations; and doing all this when Russia is a member of the United Nations."

IN an ideal travel book the most interesting character should be the author. He -- or she -- may encounter all kinds of stranger, wild and wonderful people. They can be Tibetan sages, Parisian taxi drivers, Amazonian savages, Hollywood producers, Australian bushmen, British diplomats, African chiefs or Spanish mountaineers.

In Vienna, it seems, telephone subscribers may dial for menu suggestions, puzzles, stock market reports, lottery results, bus schedules and that constant desideratum among musicians -- the A-note. The most popular of the more than fifteen special services for amusing children, however, is the Fairy Tale Aunt, to whom more than 100 Wienerkinder may listen simultaneously.
WASHINGTON. July 27 (AP) -- Following is the 57-28 vote by which the Senate tonight passed the Atomic Energy Bill:
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The British-Egyptian agreement on the evacuation of Suez Canal zone is almost as important to the United States as it is to Britain, State Department officials said tonight.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 27 -- Allied Artists announced today it would co-produce "The Big Combo" with Cornel Wilde's Theodora Productions and Security Pictures.

The United Corporation, a onetime major untiltiy holding company now completing its transformation into an investment company, showed increases in both net income and asset value in the first half of this year.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, who wants to achieve a unified Korea by any means, sees no chance of doing it peacefully.

FOR a game that keeps thriving year after year baseball seems to have an extraordinary faculty for losing things. Years ago it lost what they called the art of base stealing. Currently, wherever you go, the game's foremost thinkers are pondering the lost art of pitching.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Wednesday, July 28 -- Senator John L. McClellan held a steady lead early today in his bid for renomination in the Democratic primary.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 -- The San Francisco Opera Company announced today the engagement of Dorothy McGuire for the dramatic role of Joan of Arc in this fall's production of Arthur Honegger's "Joan of Arc at the Stake."
Federal Judge Mortimer W. Byers refused in Brooklyn yesterday to revoke the citizenship of Joseph A. Tarantino, 39-year-old plumber's helper, who was dishonorably discharged from the Army.
The marked decline in the number of contracts for new ships in all parts of the world in the last year indicates that merchant tonnage has reached the saturation point, it was said yesterday.

HEAVY tuna catches in this year's Bahamas tournaments, reports of 400 and 600 pounders taken in traps off Newport, R. I., and of big hauls in Maine and Maritime Province waters have led officials of the forthcoming United States Atlantic tuna tournament to predict that "it will be different this year."

The Statue of Liberty, United Nations headquarters, Rockefeller Center, the Empire State Building and Times Square are certainly five of, say, our city's dozen wonders. They deserve, as the Convention and Visitors Bureau says they are, to be the most popular points of interest for out-of-towners.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Representative Dwight L. Rogers, Democrat of Florida, urged Congress today to go on record against paying back salary awards to eleven American employes of the United Nations who declined to testify before the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 27 (UP) -- Willie Hartack delighted his backers at Monmouth Park today by riding four winners, including William Helis' Rippish in the feature.

The New York State central school district composed of Elma, Marilla, Wales, Lancaster, Aurora and Bennington sold yesterday an issue of $3,660,000 of bonds maturing serially from 1955 to 1983 to a banking syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co.
SAN JUAN, P. R., July 27 -- The open-shop issue -- no discrimination in favor of any union members -- was thrown into the Puerto Rican dock situation today.
MANILA, July 27 -- President Ramon Magsaysay said tonight that the Philippines must take sides in the struggle between democracy and communism.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The House of Representatives voted down every move to deepen cuts as it tentatively approved a $5,208,419,979 foreign aid appropriation bill today. The bill already had been pared 13 per cent below Administrative requests.

GUATEMALA, July 27 -- The Government announced today a temporary agrarian law. It replaced the reform measure enacted in June, 1952, by the regime of Jacobo Arbenz Guzman, under which landless peasants had received uncultivated private and national land.

All efforts of United Nations and city officials to give the United Nations an undisturbed view of the Queens side of the East River failed yesterday. The international delegates soon must read large luminous letters spelling out "Jack Frost Sugar."

DETROIT, July 27 (AP) -- Bill Tuttle's two-out single in the ninth gave the Detroit Tigers a 3-2 victory over Philadelphia tonight in the opener of a twilight-night double-header, but the Athletics, behind Marion Fricano, captured the second game, 8 -- 3, with a thirteen-hit attack.

The International Business Machines Corporation set an earnings record in the first six months of $21,600,314 after taxes and all charges. In the initial half of 1953, the giant manufacturer turned in a net of $15,575,997.

Large space in the three-story building at 72-78 Nassau Street and 33-39 John Street has been leased by Wally Frank, Ltd., tobacconists, for a downtown branch. The quarters were obtained from Anton L. Trunk and Duncan M. Findlay, owners, in a $300,000 deal negotiated by Braislin, Porter Wheelock, Inc., brokers.
TOMS RIVER, N. J., July 27 -- Roadside stands and an exhibit hall that will prove New Jersey's right to the title "Garden State" were proposed today by Gov. Robert. B. Meyner.
CLEVELAND, July 27 (AP) -- Homers by Al Rosen and Vic Wertz powered Cleveland to a 6-to-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight as the Tribe opened a fourteen-game home stand.

LONDON, July 27 -- The Royal Commission appointed two years ago to study the functioning of the Government with regard to Scotland, recommended today that greater powers be given to the Secretary of State for Scotland.

Local legislation changing the city's method of estimating its general fund each year is being prepared by the office of Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa. The proposed local laws are to be ready for the City Council in a month.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture estimated today that 13,700,000 bales of cotton would be needed for domestic and export purposes during the 1954-55 season, which starts next Sunday. This is 1,400000 bales more than the estimates of needs for the 1953-54 season.

JERSEY CITY, July 27 -- Public Safety Director Lawrence A. Whipple ordered today the suspension of a fire captain accused of issuing counterfeit tickets to a water carnival the Fire Department held last week.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, July 27 -- Startling Soviet figures on success in the detection and cure of cancer aroused skepticism here today.
LONDON, July 27 -- English fashion matched English weather on the second day of the London collections, switching from dull to what the British Broadcasting Corporation calls "bright intervals."
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 3 points off to 3 points up.

DEL MAR, Calif., July 27 (AP) -- The Del Mar Turf Club today received official approval from the State of California to become the only race track in America whose net profits will be dedicated in a drive against juvenile delinquency.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- An intensive organizational drive to bring into the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., an estimated 30,000 unorganized waterfront workers in the Great Lakes area -- about 8,000 of them on the Illinois waterway -- will get under way soon.

COME Saturday, most of the farriers who shoe race horses at Belmont, Aqueduct, Jamaica and other Eastern courses will toss their equipment into trunk compartments in their cars to head for the last stand of summer at Saratoga.

Mrs. Frank Dougherty's Turf Sun won the main event at Jamaica yesterday, to the satisfaction of a large part of the crowd of 18,713. Installed the favorite in the race of a mile and a sixteenth, Turf Sun came through to win by a half length over Philip Godfrey's O'Alison, with Hill Rose of the Wheatley Stable third.

BUFFALO, N. Y., July 27 (AP) -- A former vice president of Remington Rand, Inc., charged in State Supreme Court that stockholders had been denied "a free and intelligent choice" in voting for directors at the annual meeting today.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The United States demanded today that Chinese Communist aircraft stop attacking Allied planes flying peaceful or humanitarian missions over international waters in the Far East.

TRENTON, July 27 -- State Treasurer Archibald S. Alexander announced today that he had withdrawn $1,200,000 from a non-interest bearing account in the Trenton Trust Company for the purchase of interest-bearing securities.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- An American agriculture specialist who took a job under the Communist Chinese regime after serving United States agencies in the Far East refused to testify today whether he had returned home to spread Communist propaganda.

Over a charred, outside slice of roast beef and a goblet of cool beer, Ray Hopper, the New York restaurateur, talked recently about his busman's holidays. Weekdays Mr. Hopper may be found at Whyte's, the downtown eating place he manages and the scene of the interview.
Howard E. Seymour has been elected personnel director of the Franklin National Bank, Long Island.

LENINGRAD, July 27. (AP) -- The world-famous Leningrad International Fur Auction this year celebrates its twenty-fifth jubilee with more than three million pelts for sale. For the first time the auction is selling the "fur treasures" of China, more than 100,000 Chinese mink pelts being offered.
CAIRO, July 27 -- Britain and Egypt tonight reached agreement on broad terms for ending seventy-two years of British military occupation in this country.

The sixth and final week of the Lewisohn Stadium concerts opened last night with an all-Brahms program that attracted 5,000 persons. Thomas Scherman conducted and the soloists in Concerto for Violin, 'Cello and Orchestra were Michael Rosenker and Carl Stern, who are leading members of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony.

Although they are watching the color picture situation closely, television set manufacturers are continuing to spend considerable sums on improving their black and white units. This was demonstrated here yesterday at showings of new models by two of the country's leading set producers.
CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) -- The sale of Society Brand Clothes, Inc., 52-year-old Chicago manufacturer of men's clothing, to Hart, Schaffner Marx was announced today.
Despite a 14.7 per cent drop in operating revenues, the New York Central Railroad managed to stay in the black last month. For the first half of the year, however, it suffered a $6,701,856 loss.

THREE MILE HARBOR, L. I., July 27 -- After two days of fickle zephyrs, the squadron finally got some spirited breezes today on the third run of the American Yacht Club's five-day cruise to various stop-overs between Rye and Block Island.

Two important steps which should strengthen the bulwarks of the free world in the Middle East and open up a new era for that region are now well on the way toward successful conclusion. One is the agreement in principle hammered out in Cairo between Britain and Egypt for the evacuation of British troops from the Suez Canal Zone.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today denounced proposals that would abolish one-man Congressional committees and otherwise circumscribe their power.

BAY SHORE, L. I., July 27 -- George Petit LeBrun, who is celebrating his ninety-second birthday here today, feels like a man who has made good investments and now watches eagerly as they pay off. His investments were thought and work in behalf of safety, and they are paying off in making people conscious of the menace of violent deaths.
LONDON, July 27 -- Far Eastern events had a dampening effect on the stock market business today and prices declined in most groups. However, losses were generally in the order of a few pence.
The Tobacco Industry Research Committee is planning extensive research on why people smoke.
Bonn, July 27 -- A United States Army spokesman in Berlin announced today that a civilian employe in the administrative section of the counter-intelligence corps died of a pistol wound last Friday.

LONDON, July 27 -- Speculation about the imminence of a major shake-up in the British Cabinet and the retirement of Prime Minister Churchill was revived here today following authoritative reports that Oliver Lyttelton planned to resign as Colonial Secretary.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 27 -- The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's twenty-seventh annual mother-and-daughter championship was won today by Mrs. E. B. Coxe 3d of Hulph Mills, Pa., and Mrs. Charles F. Spalding of Round Hill

WESTBURY, L. I., July 27 -- Frank Strafaci of the Garden City Country Club and Tim Holland of the Rockville Country Club showed the way with thirty-six-hole totals of 145 as fifteen players qualified for the United States Golf Association amateur championship in the metropolitan district's competition today.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 27 (AP) -- A chestnut colt by Nasrullah-Lurline B. was sold at the Keeneland auction tonight for $86,000, the highest price ever paid for a thoroughbred yearling at an American auction.
A triumvirate composed of a textile converter, an attorney and a coal company executive gained control of the harness racing track at Yonkers in a merger announced yesterday.
BALTIMORE, July 27 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles came home from a woeful trip to snap the six-game winning streak of the Washington Senators tonight, 7 -- 5, before 13,787 fans.

Department stores generally fared poorly in the quarter ended on April 30 but a few set examples of profitable operations under "normal" conditions of competition, according to the National Retail Dry Goods Association. All department stores and many other retail stores operate on a fiscal year beginning Feb. 1.

GENEVA, July 27 -- The president of the Swiss Federation of Watchmakers asserted tonight that the Eisenhower decision was the "first decisive break in our historic trade friendship with the American people dating back to 1850."

INDIANAPOLIS, July 27 (AP) -- Pat Lesser of Seattle, the medalist in the women's Western amateur golf tournament, had to go eighteen holes today to defeat 16-year-old Anne Quast of Everett, Wash., 2 up, in the first round of the fifty-four-year-old event.
Two new buildings of the Bellevue Schools of Nursing, designed to make the profession more attractive, have opened their doors this month to 450 students and supervisors.

VICTORIA, B. C., July 27 (Canadian Press) -- Frobisher, Ltd., yesterday took the first step toward converting a northern wasteland into a power supply for a multi-million-dollar Canadian metallurgical industry.

The Hotel Association of New York City is reported to be discussing with the Hotel Trades Council of the A. F. L. steps that might be taken to cope with the avalanche of charitable appeals that continues to descend on both managements and employes.
LONDON, July 27 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden promised tonight that the House of Commons would have a chance to debate the new Suez agreement with Egypt as soon as practicable.

The New York Civil Liberties Union has intervened in an effort to nullify the "undesirable" discharge of an Army inductee. It has termed the action arbitrary, discriminatory and in violation of the First, Fifth and Sixth Amendments of the Constitution.
The narrow lead piled up by the old International Longshoremen's Association in the waterfront labor election here last May was cut to 263 votes yesterday.

A curious footnote to local history was added recently to the collection of the New York Historical Society as a gift.
