It is a wooden leg, the prop for years of one of New York's illustrious Revolutionary era citizens -- Gouverneur Morris, statesman and delegate to the Constitutional Convention of 1787.

Recognizing, of course, that The Times has long advocated use of ordinary automobiles as taxicabs and that I cannot hope to influence a change in that position, may I presume nevertheless to take issue with your editorial of July 19 entitled "The Shorter Taxi."
WESTBURY, L. I., July 27 (AP) -- Stanley Dancer drove three winners at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, including Prospectus in the featured Northport Trot.

GOODWOOD, England, July 27 -- Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh drove over to Goodwood today from Arundel Castle, where they are staying as guests of the Duke and Duchess of Norfolk, for the opening of the annual four-day meeting.
HONG KONG, July 27 (AP) -- Three airline pilots reported encounters with jet fighters of Red-held Hainan Island today -- two with United States planes and the other with unidentified jets.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Chan Gurney said today the Civil Aeronautics Board objected to proposed legislation giving local service airlines permanent operating certificates.

A moderate pick-up in steel business beginning in late August or early September was predicted yesterday by Benjamin F. Fairless, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest producer.

ALBANY, July 27 -- Governor Dewey today appointed nineteen members to the Joint Legislative Committee for the American Jewish Tercentenary, to mark the 300th anniversary of the arrival of the first Jewish settlers in America.

LENOX, Mass., July 27 -- Three operas, two of them little known, one a work nearly four centuries old, and given a stage presentation for the first time in the United States, were presented tonight by the Opera Department of the Berkshire Music Center in the Theatre Concert Hall as the first operatic offering of the present season of the Berkshire Festival.
Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates are offering a new issue of $25,000,000 of 3 per cent debentures of Consolidated Natural Gas Company.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "On the Waterfront," a Columbia melodrama with Marlon Brando, Karl Malden, Lee J. Cobb and introducing Eva Marie Saint, is at the Astor. Sam Spiegel produced and Elia Kazan directed from a screen play that Budd Schulberg based on the Pulitzer Prize-winning newspaper articles by Malcolm Johnson.

Full of bounce after their decisive triumph of Monday night over the Giants, the Dodgers applied more pressure on the faltering Polo Grounders by out-slugging the Cubs, 7 -- 6, at Ebbets Field yesterday.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 27 -- A goal by Devereux Milburn in the closing chukker enabled the Meadow Brook polo team to defeat Brandywine, 9 -- 8, in the final round of the Hempstead Cups twelve-goal tournament on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

I regret that I find it necessary to ask for space for this letter in order to correct some statements and figures in Mr. Arthur Krock's article on Sweden, dispatched from Stockholm on July 20 and appearing on the editorial page of The New York Times July 27.

Marijuana grew in the ballroom foyer of the New Yorker Hotel yesterday and, off Battery Park, a man dangling from a police helicopter was carried across the waters of the Upper Bay. The annual meeting of the New York State Association of Chiefs of Police was in session.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The American Veterans Committee urged other veterans' organizations today to withdraw their sponsorship of a testimonial dinner to Roy M. Cohn, who recently resigned as chief counsel of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 27 (AP) -- Taltohna, a 45-foot cutter, today slid in with a rain squall to win the slowest Chicago-Mackinac yacht race since 1920.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay endorsed today a proposal for an educational program that eventually would permit the states to take over the Federal Government's mine inspection chores.

The Caribbean Baseball Confederation met with Ford Frick, commissioner of baseball, here yesterday and agreed to end its season and play-offs, including its world series, by Feb. 15. The Confederation also agreed not to use more than five players from each major league club.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- It's against the rules to introduce any gallery visitor, but the House of Representatives neatly got around that today for Mlle. Genevieve de Galard-Terraube.
Temperatures were on the warm side yesterday, but not enough so for the day to be considered really hot. A high of 84.4 degrees was recorded at 4:10 P. M. The humidity ranged in the 40's.

A disturbing economic question is raised by your recent news item that the city of New York is now disposing of abandoned automobiles by throwing them into the public dumps. It was stated that 672 jalopies, so worthless that even junk dealers would not bid for them, have since May 21 been buried in landfills along with the rest of the city's refuse.
BOSTON, July 27 -- Textron Incorporated placed a director on the board of American Woolen Company today at a meeting of American stockholders that had been delayed four months by litigation.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee called on President Eisenhower today to grant sovereignty to West Germany by direct action unless France ratified the European Defense Community treaty.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 27 -- Jules Moch of France declared today that differences between the East and the West on atomic control and disarmament plans were not insurmountable.
Three patrolmen -- one in Manhattan and two in Brooklyn -- were assaulted last night by persons they tried to take into custody.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The text of a State Department statement on its protest to Communist China about the plane shooting incidents near Hainan Island:

PITTSBURGH, July 28 (UP) -- Hank Aaron drove in three runs with a pair of singles and a triple tonight to pace Milwaukee to a 6-4 victory over Pittsburgh and extend the Braves' winning streak to six games.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Following is the 59-21 roll-call vote by which the Senate tonight passed and sent to the White House a compromise omnibus housing program:
WALGROVE SNOOD, the literary banker, sat on the flagged terrace of the Debenture Bay Yacht Club at Niblickdale, giving his whole-hearted attention, apparently, to a drama on the darkening water.
Watch company issues were market favorites yesterday in the wake of President Eisenhower's action on Tuesday of raising tariffs on watches by 50 per cent.

ROSTOV-ON-DON, U. S. S. R., July 20 -- Although two years have passed since the canal's opening, traffic on the famous Volga-Don Canal, except for excursion boats, is relatively light compared with that of the Volga River itself.
The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., has quietly reached general agreement on a new contract with the Todd Shipyards Corporation, it was learned yesterday.
Despite the resignation of two of its principals, the new stage group called The Ensemble intends to proceed with plans for a repertory program here this season.

Mayor Wagner approved yesterday a program under which the services of the five New York chapters of the American Red Cross would be used to supplement the work of city agencies in meeting peace-time emergencies and disasters.
New York's forty-five-year-old Manhattan Bridge may undergo a $30,000,000 repair job to enable it to withstand the rigors of the modern age.

Juvenile delinquency in New York City increased 17.2 per cent during the first six months of this year, as compared with the same period in 1953, Mayor Wagner told the New York State Association of Chiefs of Police last night.
A new method of expediting customs clearance here was announced yesterday by Aleer J. Couri, United States Appraiser of Merchandise at the Port of New York.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:

Two members of the Fire Department pleaded guilty yesterday to departmental charges of having accepted and shared "fees" from business places to which they had pretended to provide legally required safety services.

DETROIT, July 28 (UP) -- Steve Souchock cracked out a pair of three-run homers and Al Aber pitched the distance for the first time this year today to lead the Detroit Tigers to a 10-2 victory over the Philadelphia Athletics.

LONDON, July 28 -- Britain and Saudi Arabia have agreed on arbitration of the long standing dispute about a remote area of the Arabian peninsula, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the Commons today.

BALTIMORE, July 28 (UP) -- Joe Coleman, who had lost six straight games while attempting to gain his tenth victory of the season, finally achieved it tonight with a brilliant three-hit effort that gave the Baltimore Orioles a 2-to-1 triumph over the Washington Senators.

LONDON, July 28 -- The Government announced today it intended to give Cyprus a new constitution on the pattern of those of Britain's African and Asian colonies. The move ran into immediate criticism from Laborites.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 2,942,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. On last Friday, total supplies were 158,844,000 barrels, compared with 161,786,000 a week earlier and 141,708,000 a year ago.

Factory relocations are rapidly becoming a pressing national issue. Two articles by A. H. Raskin in this newspaper marshaled enough concrete details of what is going on to disclose the magnitude and complexity of the problem they present.

LONDON, July 28 -- Clement R. Attlee, leader of the Labor party, said today he hoped his tour of Communist China next month would answer the "big question" of whether or not the Peiping Government sought the establishment of an "imperial hegemony" in Southeast Asia.
LOS ANGELES, July 28 (UP) -- John Landy of Australia, holder of the mile record of 3:58, will receive the Miracle Mile Trophy in Vancouver, B. C., next Sunday at the British Empire Games.

COPENHAGEN, July 23 -- Ever since the rising birthrate of aggressive neighbors and the development of modern war weapons have required them to substitute compromise for conquest the Danes have perfected this adjustment of differing governing philosophies which has been described as the science of politics. An illustration of their progress is the fact that Denmark is quietly governed by a minority party, the Social Democrats.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 28 -- Nassau County, which has beenI seeking someone to dig a basinI in Levittown that will require theI removal of 50.000 cubic yards of{ dirt, had an offer from a con-[ struction company today to do the job for one cent. Other bids ranged up to $13,975.

THE chances are that if you look at the yachting report of any week-end Long Island Sound regatta you'll find a statement like "Cornelius Shields won with his International Aileen," "Bus Mosbacher and Shields had a brisk windward duel for the finish" or "the uncertainty of the wind conditions was reflected by the fact that Shields finished eighth."

In an unfortunate speech which will alarm the free world and provide fresh grist for Communist propaganda mills President Rhee of Korea has urged the American Congress to launch what amounts to a preventive war against Communist China and, if necessary, an atomic war against Soviet Russia.
An Army barge sank last night in the Passaic River, near Newark Bay, after having been in collision with a harbor tanker. No one was injured.

The performance of the hew{ production of the musical comedy{ "On Your Toes" on the night of{ Nov. 5, has been taken over by/ members of the Women's Auxiliary of Union Settlement to raise funds for the organization. Mrs. Philip Bastedo heads the arrangemerits committee for the event.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 28 -- Officials of the United Nations said today that no residents of Iron Curtain countries had been sent out on technical assistance missions.

CLEVELAND, July 28 (AP) -- Making the most of five hits off a Boston rookie, Russ Kemmerer, Cleveland defeated the Red Sox tonight for the second straight time in a 2-1 game that kept the Indians in first place in the American League by two and a half games. Early Wynn yielded eleven hits, but the right-hander posted his fourteenth victory.
Plans for a new twelve-story apartment building with stores for Greenwich Village were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) The Department of Justice said today that Immigration Commissioner Joseph M. Swing had recommended that Ellis Island be abandoned as an immigration station and its operations transferred into New York City proper.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Secretary of the Navy, Charles S. Thomas, today challenged a charge that the Navy had failed to recognize the urgency of eliminating racial segregation in its ranks.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, President of the Republic of Korea, went before Congress today to urge that the United States join Asians in a full-scale war on Communist China to halt the Soviet drive for world domination.

Two Brooklyn teen-agers were arraigned yesterday in Kings County Court on an indictment charging first-degree murder. The charges stemmed from the fatal beating last July 10 of Thomas A. Condon, 40-year-old father of four children.

STONINGTON, Conn., July 28 -- Commodore Arthur P. Davis of the Beach Point Yacht Club, Mamaroneck, N. Y., sailed his Rhodes-27 sloop, Patricia, to a fourth consecutive victory today as the American Yacht Club's twenty-third annual invitation cruise moved to this port.
SAN JUAN, P. R., July 28 -- Gov. Luis Munoz Marin seized thirteen Puerto Rican docks at 9 A. M. today in an effort to end the thirty-four-day-old longshore strike.

NOROTON, Conn., July 28 -- The Pequot Yacht Club crew of Southport, Conn., with Julia Evans as skipper, won the girls' sailing championship of Long Island as the five-race seines for the S. Gregory Taylor Trophy was concluded today.

Refusing to give ground at any time, George Johnson, Trenton, gained a unanimous decision over Bobby Jones, fifth-ranking middleweight from Oakland, Calif., in the main event of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.
OTTAWA, July 28 -- Canada announced today her agreement to serve with India and Poland on the international commissions to supervise the truce in Indochina.

A sharp increase in air pollution, accompanying heat that reached 91.4 degrees, made New Yorkers' eyes smart yesterday. Dr. Leonard Greenburg, Commissioner of Air Pollution Control, said there was no cause for alarm, however.

An apartment house site consisting of one and one-half acres of land in Great Neck, L. I., has been purchased by the Sunron Building Corporation, headed by Frank Seligman, builder of garden-type apartment developments.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)--Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse as required by conference rules:
Five 2-year-old fillies raced in the $12,050 Adirondack Stakes at Jamaica yesterday. The winner was the Starr Ranch's Hidden Ship, the 17-to-10 second choice. She led from shortly after the start.

Having exhausted all other means, Leo Durocher went back to fundamentals at the Polo Grounds yesterday in a desperate bid to snap the Giants out of their losing streak. Resting the brain, he decided to let brawn do it and, surprisingly enough, it worked like a charm.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 28 -- Thomas J. Goodwin of the Westchester Country Club took the medal in the thirty-fifth annual Westchester County amateur golf championship over the Metropolis course today.
A New York County grand jury indicted seventeen lawyers yesterday in an ambulance-chasing inquiry that had been under way since last March.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The House Subcommittee on Military Operations criticized the Defense Department and the armed services today for inept handling of civilian scientists in a period of peril.
BANGKOK, Thailand, July 28 -- Thailand is looking uneasily for some hope that she will not be the next victim of Communist aggression.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., July 28 (UP) -- A rancher, who was a political unknown until he mailed anti-Eisenhower postcards the Post office Department labeled "obscene," scored a surprise victory in the race for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor of Oklahoma.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 28 (AP) -- Tim Coss, Eastern intercollegiate tennis champion from Washington, D. C., headed a list of sixteen qualifiers today for berths in the first round of the sixth annual Meadow Club invitation tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended July 21:

LONDON, July 28 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told a restive, noisy House of Commons today that he hoped the new British-Egyptian agreement on the Suez Canal zone would lead to an era of "friendship and understanding" and to a lowering of Middle East tension.

GUATEMALA, July 28 -- One month after the overthrow of the Arbenz regime, the new Government is still confronted with the problem involving hundreds of refugees awaiting safe-conducts in embassies here.

The threat of rain probably kept a good many people away from Lewisohn Stadium last night. They missed a good concert. The Ajemian sisters -- Anahid, the violinist, and Maro, the pianist -- shared a program devoted to French music and came up with a couple of pleasant novelties.

Last February the Tariff Commission listened to arguments advanced by American producers of watch movements for tariff relief under the so-called "escape" clause of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act of 1951. In May the commission, by a vote of four to two, recommended tariff increases ranging up to 50 per cent on certain types of imported watch movements.
As Manhattan office workers poured into the hot streets for their lunch hour yesterday, three happy newcomers to this country sank into their first peaceful sleep in years.

Television set production during the first five months of this year was 44 per cent less than in 1953. This was ascertained in a study by the National Credit Office, Inc., of the financial statements of forty companies making TV sets, radio receivers and electronic equipment.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, July 28 -- It costs nearly $4,000 to discover an early case of cancer, a United States expert estimated here today. Cancer specialists from all over the world attending the sixth International Cancer Congress here, consider the results are worth the cost.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 28 (AP) -- The Darby Dan Farm's Clear Dawn moved up among the contenders for 3-year-old filly honors at Monmouth Park today by scoring an easy victory in the $24,600 Miss Woodford Stakes.

Electric power production in the week ended last Saturday rose to the record high of 9,103,000,000 kilowatt-hours from 8,951,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended July 25, 1953, was 8,460,000,000.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 28 -- Deep concern over the use that Egypt will make of her new strength was voiced today by Prime Minister Moshe Sharett. He added a warning that if the United States now granted arms aid to Egypt after having decided to give arms to Iraq it would be "an addition of crime upon crime."

Russ Meyer, a sensitive soul, was caught in a crossfire of complexes last night. He hates to pitch in Ebbets Field. Working in the Brooklyn bandbox gives him claustrophobia, he says. On the other hand, the sight of the Cubs causes Russ to feel invincible.

Newspaper advertising linage for the first half of 1954 was 2.3 per cent behind the 1953 figure, but the latter part of the period showed a gain, with June's total edging across the line between black ink and red for a gain of 0.3 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- President Eisenhower defended today his order raising the tariff on certain imported watches and watch movements up to 50 per cent. Considerations of national defense as well as the plight of the domestic watch industry prompted his action yesterday, he said.

Robert Moses cemented his control of the State Power Authority yesterday by effecting the election of William Wilson as vice chairman. Mr. Wilson, an architectural engineer who is a close friend of Mr. Moses, succeeds Hickman Powell, who resigned Friday in protest over Mr. Moses' methods.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 28 -- A Foreign Office official foresaw today an early alliance between Egypt and Pakistan following the announcement of the British-Egyptian agreement for the withdrawal of British troops from the Suez Canal zone.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 28 (AP) -- The Asian-Arab bloc in the United Nations formally asked today that the General Assembly take up the question of more freedom for Tunisia and Morocco.

Operating revenues of the Southern Pacific Transportation System and its separately operated but solely controlled affiliates fell to $304,321,547 in the first half of this year, the Company announced yesterday. This was a decline of $46,816,239 from year-ago levels and brought net income of the road down to $22,603,405, or $2.50 a share.

The Standard Oil Company (N. J.) yesterday estimated consolidated net earnings for the first half at $293,000,000, or $4.84 a share. This compares with earnings of $268,000,000, or $4.42 a share, in the similar period of 1953.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., July 28 -- A drive to free Sullivan County of ragweed and its pollen started at the County Court House here today.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., July 28 -- A civilian engineer employed by the Armed Services Electronics Standard Agency here has been suspended under security charges, his attorney, Ira J. Katchen of Long Branch, announced today.

There are two points of view about the summer bachelor. The first is hers, and it is indeed a weird one. It holds that the moment she has gone away, he will starve to death for lack of a cook, he will live in squalor for lack of a cleaner.

Fairfax County, Va., sold yesterday $10,000,000 of sewer bonds due annually from 1958 to 1989 to a syndicate of investment houses headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at an interest cost of 2.95 per cent. A syndicate headed by Eastman, Dillon Co. bid a cost of 2.98 per cent.

CETINJE, Yugoslavia, July 28 (Reuters) -- Bishop Arsenije Bradvarevic, 71-year-old Orthodox Metropolitan of Montengro, pleaded guilty to charges of "conspiring against the Yugoslav state" at his trial here today. He will be sentenced tomorrow.
The first public offering of new securities of the United States Steel Corporation since 1940 will go on the market today.
LONDON, July 28 -- Prime Minister Churchill announced tonight seven new ministerial appointments, including those of two Cabinet members.

Two new films open today at first run theatres. At the Roxy is "Broken Lance," a Twentieth Century-Fox western drama, starring Spencer Tracey, Richard Widmark, Katy Jurado and Robert Wagner. The screen play was written by Richard Murphy from a story by Philip Yordan.

The billion-dollar Westinghouse Electric Corporation, oldest and second largest manufacturer of electrical apparatus and appliances, reported yesterday the highest six-month sales and earnings in its history. Net sales, $811,709,000, were 4 per cent higher than the 1953 first-half volume of $780,489,000, Gwilym A. Price, president, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UP) -- The House of Representatives tentatively approved today President Eisenhower's request that funds for financing the farm price support program be raised to $10,000,000,000.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- A price was fixed today on the property where Mrs. O'Leary's cow is said to have started the Chicago fire in 1871 by kicking over a lantern. But any historical or sentimental value for the land was officially ruled out.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 28 -- Michael Kidd, who created and staged the musical numbers for "Guys and Dolls," will repeat the assignment for Samuel Goldwyn's film version of the hit play.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., July 28 -- Immediate formation of a new State Guard of older men to be ready to take the place of the New York National Guard in wartime was advocated today by Maj. Gen. Karl F. Hausauer, commander of the National Guard in this state and Chief of Staff to Governor Dewey.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UP) -- A former Interior Department official denied repeatedly today that he had been hired, while still working for the Government, by an Alaskan tin mining company for which he promoted a Government loan.
General Foods Corporation spent $62,000,000 for advertising in fiscal 1954, or $12,000,000 more than a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A shutdown of close to half the country's aluminum output is threatened for this week-end.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- A lot of suppers got cold and a lot of fans -- 38,056 of them -- got old today before the Yankees were able to claim a 7-5 victory over the Chicago White Sox. The game, twice delayed by rain, was decided, at long last, by Mickey Mantle's three-run homer in the ninth.

AURORA, N. Y., July 27 -- The appointment of Dr. Grace Loucks Elliott as Campbell Visiting Professor of Sociology at Wells College for 1954-55 was announced today. Dr. Elliott is general secretary and a former national president of the Young Women's Christian Association.

" Man Against Nature: Tales of Adventure and Exploration," edited by Charles Neider, will be issued Aug. 25 by Harper. It comprises forty-five selections about persons who have conquered mountains, fought wild animals, killed whales, battled head-hunters and braved Arctic blizzards. Among the authors are George A. Custer, Charles A. Lindbergh, Robert E. Peary, Pliny the Younger and Sir Edmund Hillary.

Admiral Jerauld Wright, Atlantic Fleet Commander in Chief, will speak on "N. A. T. O. and Mutual Defense" at the opening today of the thirty-sixth annual state convention of the American Legion at the Commodore Hotel.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Following is the text of an address to Congress today by President Syngman Rhee of South Korea:

LONDON, July 28 (Reuters) -- Free exchange of British pounds with dollars and other currencies may "perhaps" be brought into effect within the next twelve months, Minister of State Derick Heathcoat Amory said today.
BOSTON, July 28 -- The New England Electric System reported today consolidated net income of $6,334,558 for the first half of 1954.
" Tanglewood on Parade," the annual performance for the benefit of the Berkshire Music Center, will be held at Tanglewood, Mass., on Aug. 13.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., July 28 -- A big chunk of Prospect Point, a favorite spot of honeymooners, fell into the Niagara River gorge today. A huge, pie-shaped bite of the American falls went with it.
The 50 per cent increase on tariffs on some watch movements sent clock and watch issues driving ahead in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange.

Trading on the New York futures markets was extremely light yesterday. Only coffee, cocoa and potatoes approached normal activity. Prices moved irregularly, with cocoa, coffee, hides and zinc higher; potatoes, wool, rubber, cottonseed oil and soybean oil lower, and sugar mixed.

HOBOKEN, N. J., July 28 -- The American Export Lines, one of the country's leading passenger and cargo shipping companies, became the sole tenant here today of the new $15,000,000 marine terminal being built by the Port of New York Authority.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Following is the 266-128 vote by which the House today passed and sent to the Senate a bill appropriating $5,208,419,979 to finance the foreign aid program for the present fiscal year:
ALBANY, July 28 (AP) -- The licenses of 57,452 motorists who apparently carried no liability insurance were suspended in the first six months of 1954 after they had been involved in accidents.

PARIS, July 28 -- Patou showed a collection this morning that was in the tradition of its founder. It was done with a modern touch by the young designer Marc Bohan, in his early thirties, with the assistance of two younger men, both barely turned 20.
TOKYO, July 28 -- The Japanese Government has made known its intention to press vigorously for expanded trade with Communist China and the Soviet Union.
The Public Service Commission approved yesterday a request by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., to convert from mixed gas to straight natural gas in Manhattan and the Bronx.

BONN, Germany, July 28 -- Dr. Otto John, West German intelligence chief who vanished into East Germany last week, broadcast tonight a political attack on the regime of Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor.

J. Spencer Love, chairman of the board of Burlington Mills Corporation, yesterday disclosed tentative plans for the disposal of the Palm Beach operation of Goodall-Sanford, Inc. He estimated that it would take about $10,000,000 to buy the fixed assets and current inventories of the Palm Beach Company.

EDMONTON, Alta., July 28 -- Here in this booming city of capitalist competition, Canada's Cooperative Commonwealth Federation, dedicated to the principle that only democratic socialism can save the world from poverty, injustice and war, is holding its national convention.

The American Gas and Electric Company announced yesterday the election as directors of Dr. Courtney C. Brown, dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Business, and John S. Battle, former Governor of Virginia.
Color in new shades and combinations was emphasized in fall accessories presented yesterday. They were shown by the Fashion Group in the Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Administration omnibus tax reform bill was approved by the House of Representatives today on a final ballot of 315 to 77. The measure, providing $1,363,000,000 of relief this fiscal year for most businesses and many individuals, was labeled by President Eisenhower as the "cornerstone" of his legislative program.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Senate and House conferees were named today to work out a final version of the atomic energy bill and there were prospects of another lively fight over public versus private power.

In Charles Grutzner's series on philanthropic fund-raising Leo Perlis, national director of the C. I. O. Community Services Committee, is quoted as saying that the March of Dimes received more money for polio than organizations in the heart and cancer fields, even though those diseases kill many more people than does infantile paralysis.

LITTLE ROCK, July 28 -- Senator John L. McClellan today had won renomination to a third successive six-year term on the basis of unofficial returns tabulated from yesterday's state - wide Democratic primary election.
Alfred B. Babcock, Jr., formerly with the United States Atomic Energy Commission, has been named chief project engineer of the chemical division of the Borden Company.

The Mayor's Advisory Council! is working on a plan to raise $15,000,000 to $25,000,000 in additional city revenue in the next two years through speedier salesi of property taken over for un-I paid taxes.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 28 -- A prominent Protestant spokesman called upon his co-religionists here today to endure "ridicule, suffering and persecution" in defending freedom of religion from the encroachments of state or society.

One of two barges holding the 1,000-ton center span for the new Welfare Island bridge sank yesterday. The mishap occurred twenty-four hours before the 420-foot steel span was to have been floated into position and set upon its concrete piers.
The executive committee of the New York County Democratic organization endorsed yesterday two Republican jurists for re-election but denied endorsement to a third.
MEXICO CITY, July 28 -- Former President Lazaro Cardenas announced today he had severed his only official connection with the Government.
GOODWOOD, England, July 28 (AP) -- Queen Elizabeth's Landau was off to a good start and led all the way to win the one-mile Sussex Stakes by five lengths today.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- President Eisenhower took a moderate line today in discussing the recent attacks by Red China on Allied planes in Southeast Asia. He said at his weekly news conference that the United States would defend its rights, but that it did not mean to be impulsive or truculent in doing so.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders warned his colleagues today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy might be using Congressional funds to obtain derogatory information against them.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 28 -- The Communists have now created an "action council" of the Congress of the People here. This council will be the supreme command of the new resistance effort of Negroes, Indians, Cape colored (persons of mixed blood) and anti-racialist Whites.

The Capehart investigation into F. H. A. scandals is rendering a public service in exposing the unbelievable windfall profits made in housing operations. But the builders are far from the only culprits, nor can they all be blamed for cashing in on a policy which made it so easy.

LONG BEACH, L. I., July 28 -- Nassau County and Long Beach police are looking for the culprit who for some strange reason opened a valve on a long-unused water main and diverted 500,000 gallons from the city's water supply.

CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- The Inland Steel Company today reported a record net income of $19,417,669, equal to $3.92 a share, for the six months ended June 30. The previous record was $18,288,446 in the first half of 1950.

CHICAGO, July 28 (UP) -- Lavender Hill, Mrs. Charles Silvers' 5-year-old chestnut mare, posted a galloping victory today to become the oldest horse ever to win the Arlington Matron Stakes. She earned top prize money of $20,880.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 28 (AP) -- Mighty Storm, a 3-year-old bay colt owned by Morris Pivnick of South Orange, N. J., was driven to a three-length victory over Super Fine tonight at Roosevelt Raceway in the featured Stony Brook trot.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., July 28 (AP) -- Unheralded Robert Riley of Kansas City staged a major upset in the third round of the national juniors' and boys' tennis championships today.
The regional Red Cross blood program received 424 pints of blood Tuesday. At Fort Monmouth, N. J., 212 pints were donated on the first day of a $100, too -- as a deposit.
Jacob J. Rosenblum, former rackets prosecutor, was appointed yesterday as special counsel to the Tompkins-Rabin Joint Legislative Committee for its investigation of vacation camp subversion.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UP) -- The House Veterans Committee, ignoring a "go slow" sign from the House leadership on extra GI benefits, approved today a bill to raise all veterans' pensions by 5 per cent.

The Federal Government filed a suit in the Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday against the Sperry Corporation of Great Neck, L. I., and its vice president and chief engineer, Wilmer L. Barrow. The Government, seeking to recover its interest in a radar patent, contended that Mr. Barrow has assigned his patent rights to the corporation.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 28 (UP) -- The defending champion, Claire Doran of Cleveland, the medal winner, Pat Lesser of Seattle, and Jane Nelson of Indianapolis were among the players who gained the quarter-finals in the fifty - fourth women's Western amateur golf tournament today.
NEW YORK sportsmen are to play a key role this fall in an unusual game management plan to "harvest" surplus deer from two remote sections of the Adirondacks.
Unemployment in the state, in terms of insurance benefit claims, dropped sharply last week to a new low for 1954.

PHILADELPHIA, July 28 (AP) -- Earl Torgeson tripled in the eighth inning and scored on Smoky Burgess' long fly as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Cincinnati Redlegs, 3 -- 2, tonight to move into fourth place in the National League.

LONDON, July 28 -- The stock markets here rallied modestly today, influenced by firmness in Wall Street yesterday. Improvement was led by British Government securities, which closed around one-quarter per cent higher.

Prof. Arthur Upham Pope, vice chairman of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship from 1943 to 1949, testified yesterday that he could not recall any discussions at council meetings involving the Communist party or its members.

ALBANY, July 28 (AP) -- Governor Dewey today called for action on three fronts to reduce traffic hazards on Route 17 at Liberty, where a runaway tank-truck killed three persons and injured twelve others last Saturday.
PARIS, July 28 -- Suggestions for the program of Premier Pierre Mendes-France for the "reconversion" of the French economy will be discussed at a Cabinet meeting tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The British-Egyptian agreement on the Suez Canal zone drew high praise from President Eisenhower today.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 28 -- First place in a child's heart is won by adults who "pay attention to me," according to a description of the ideal grown-up. The description was presented here today at the closing session of Vassar College's twenty-ninth annual summer Institute for Family and Community Living.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The House of Representatives approved today, 266 to 128, a $5,208,419,979 foreign aid appropriation bill.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 28 (AP) -- Directors of Foremost Dairies, Inc., raised the dividend on common stock today from 35 to 45 cents a quarter and proposed to split the common stock three for one.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 28 -- Dispatches from the Celebes report that heavy fighting has broken out in the southern part of the province. The Indonesian Army has been conducting long-promised and widespread clearing actions in the bandit-infested regions there.

CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- Receipts of hogs again fell below expectations today and prices climbed 25 to 50c on both butchers and sows. Trading was active. Arrivals totaled 7,000 head. 1,500 below the advance estimate. Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

ONE of the earliest of fall fashions registering importance is the jumper. Long a favorite of the young, this season its popularity has spread far beyond the schoolroom and college campus. It will be seen in high fashion versions for wear in town by day and dining out at night. It can be bought at the luxury level or at prices that stay well within the budget of a college or career girl.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 28 -- Mrs. Martin Victor of the Creek Club and Joan Hamill of the Rockaway Hunting Club blended their games perfectly today to score 33, 35 -- 68 at Sands Point to win the Women's Long Island Golf Association best-ball tournament.
Manhattan College will make six appearances in Madison Square Garden during its twenty-two-game basketball campaign in 1954-55, Ken Norton, coach and athletic director, said yesterday.

The city's study of sinecure political jobs was widened by Mayor Wagner yesterday to include corporation inspectors. Those functionaries are assigned to see that streets are repaired after they have been opened for underground utility work.

Bini Primo, chef of the new Italian liner Cristoforo Colombo, is an unhurried gentleman in his sixties whose personality reflects little of the frenzy of a professional kitchen. One really should say kitchens, for Mr. Primo supervises four of them on the handsome vessel -- one for each class and one for the ship's personnel.
The platform committee for the Democratic State Convention will hold three public hearings in advance of the convention to give all groups a chance to express their views.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Senate passed and sent to the White House tonight an omnibus housing bill that closely approximated, in all features except public housing, what President Eisenhower had asked.

LONDON, July 28 -- The curviest London look in years has emerged from the autumn fashion collections of Britain's top twelve designers. Not one sharp corner was seen in the press showings that ended today.

FORT DIX, N. J., July 28 -- A three-member special court-martial decided here today that Sgt. 1/c Richard J. Witbeck was not guilty of "cruel and unusual mass punishment" to 225 Army trainees under his charge.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy disclosed last night that he had asked Roy M. Cohn to join his personal staff and act as his representative on the Senate Subcommittee on Investigations in all investigations involving communism.
i WASHINGTON, July 28 IUP)-- The Senate confirmed today the nominations of some 200 postmasters after a partisan dispute over the way individual Senators had "cleared" the nominations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 28 -- Moorhead Patterson, United States spokesman in the Disarmament Commission, disparaged today any tendency toward optimism regarding the recent London talks on arms reduction.

LENOX, Mass., July 28 -- Ernest Bloch's String Quartet No. 4 composed last March had its world premiere at the Chamber Music Concert, the thirteenth of the Berkshire Festival, given this evening by the Griller Quartet in the Theatre Concert Hall.
CAIRO, July 28 -- Egypt today greeted the accord for the evacuation of British forces from the Suez Canal zone with patriotic fervor and approval.

One factor which bedeviled the Indochina situation and contributed to what Premier Mendes-France calls the "cruel" armistice terms was the issue of colonialism. Because of French delay in granting genuine independence to the Indochinese states this issue could be exploited by the Communists to stir up a revolt in the name of nationalism for the imposition of a Communist colonialism.

Sales of the Radio Corporation of America and its subsidiaries attained the record volume of $444,369,000 in the first six months of this year. This exceeded by $33,683,000, or 8 per cent, the previous peak established in the first half of 1953, Brig. Gen. David Sarnoff, chairman, announced yesterday.

The General Motors Corporation, world's largest manufacturing enterprise, rolled up a record $883,198,383 in earnings before taxes in the first six months of this year. This exceeded the previous peak of $803,673,389 reached in the initial half of 1950.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was a little more active yesterday and prices declined 10 to 15 points.

MOSCOW, July 28 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, Communist party secretary, declared tonight that there was one question on which he and Prime Minister Churchill were in full agreement -- coexistence of the capitalist and Communist worlds.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- The grain markets showed signs of being over-bought in the early trade today, and sharp declines were registered as bulls tried to take profits. Later corn and soybeans started a brisk rally which pared down early losses and helped steady the other gains.

CLAYTON, Ala., July 28 (AP) -- Circuit Judge George Wallace threw out embezzlement indictments today against Royal Reynolds, former Clio banker, and Bill Knight, cashier at the Merchants Exchange, which Mr. Reynolds operated.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- President Eisenhower said today that while he would not stump for any candidate he would do some traveling and he hoped this would not damage anyone who had supported his legislative program.

SAN JUAN, P. R., July 29 -- The thirty-five day pier tie-up ended in Puerto Rico today when American Federation of Labor Longshoremen began unloading the freighters here at 2 P. M. docks were formally seized the Commonwealth Government twenty-nine hours earlier. When expected peace agreement between A. F. L. dock workers the Puerto Rico Steamship Association had stalled on secretary issues early in the morning.

The steam-bath climate of high humidity, which has transformed most New Yorkers into bent frames of damp laundry, is due to continue today. But tonight, the weather man said yesterday in a cautious whisper, we can look for some solid relief.

In the press the question is often raised whether there is any parallel -- and if so, to what extent -- between Munich and the Geneva agreement on Indochina. While not attempting to draw a comparison I would, nevertheless, like to submit a number of points for evaluation.

" Pipe Dream," the next Richard Rodgers-Oscar Hammerstein 2d musical, based on John Steinbeck's novel, "Sweet Thursday," has been scratched as a late entry for the 1954-55 season. This was confirmed yesterday by Mr. Hammerstein, who is stationed in Nogales, Ariz., working with Mr. Rodgers on the filming of "Oklahoma!"

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., July 29 -- New rock slides that might change the aspect of the American side of Niagara Falls, from which 185,000 tons of rock and dirt fell away yesterday, were threatened today.
PRINCETON, N. J., July 29 -- The Rev. Dr. Marcel Pradervand of Geneva, Switzerland, was unanimously elected here today to the new post of general secretary of the World Presbyterian Alliance.

TUNBRIDGE, Vt., July 29 -- A, Dexter Best, formerly of Brooklyn, was found dead in the woods near his home here last night. Constable Wayne Rowell said it apparently was suicide and that a note had been found.

Who among us had not fancied himself, at some time in his life, a stowaway on a vessel bound for some romantic far-off place? Almost all of us, however, have this rather common form of the impulse "to get away from it all" under firm control.
LONDON, July 29 -- Remains of a "colossal" palace destroyed by a holocaust about 1,400 B. C. on the coast of what is now Turkey are described in a dispatch from a British expedition.

Tree-ripened fresh peaches are now arriving in local markets from the Southern states, California and near-by New Jersey. Receipts of this popular fruit, which tops all fruit sales during July and August, are increasing daily and the flavor improves as the peaches mature.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Eisenhower pinned the bronze United States Medal of Freedom on the white uniform of Genevieve de Galard Terraube today.

The Clinton, Iowa, Bridge Commission sold yesterday $6,800,000 of Mississippi River bridge revenue bonds, due serially from 1959 to 1979, to a banking syndicate headed by John Nuveen Co. at an interest cost of 3.996 per cent. A bid designating a cost of 4 per cent was submitted by A. C. Allyn Co., Inc.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 29 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi approved tonight an oral report on the progress of negotiations with the consortium of eight international oil companies for resumption of large-scale Iranian oil exports.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 684,287 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

If Senator Ralph E. Flanders of Vermont had been a cold and calculating political strategist he would not have chosen the hectic tag-end of a session in an election year to introduce the resolution which declares that Senator McCarthy's conduct "tends to bring the Senate into disrepute and * * * is condemned."
GENEVA, July 29 -- A United Nations agency reported today that East-West trade in Europe stopped shrinking in 1953 and seemed to have entered a period of growth in early 1954.
Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams announced yesterday the transfer of three Police Department units and the establishment of a school crossing guards bureau.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The conduct of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, long a matter of national controversy, will be brought home to the Senate tomorrow for possible disciplinary action.
LONDON, July 29 (Reuters) -- Moscow radio told its listeners today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, and his followers planned to seize control of the United States by 1956.

Aircrafts, utilities, coppers, golds, retailing establishments, papers and communications shares moved forward in yesterday's stock market. The price level touched the highest point for The New York Times combined average since June 5, 1930.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 29 (AP) -- Tony Trabert, America's No. 1 tennis player, subdued unseeded Tim Coss, Washington, and gained the second round of the sixty-fifth annual Meadow Club invitation tennis tournament today.

Wigwam and Sun Warrior finished in that order in the main attraction at the Jamaica race track yesterday. There were four others in the event, entitled the Kingfisher Purse, but only these two were in the fight at the finish of the six-furlong sprint.

Net income of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the first six months of 1954 totaled $3,300,114, as compared with $4,417,378 in the same period last year, the utility reported yesterday. Gross revenues also declined, falling from $111,663,284 to $106,919,075.
Directors of the General Dynamics Corporation yesterday elected Gordon Dean, former chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, as a director.

If history repeats itself the present bull market won't spend itself next month. In the forty-three years that The New York Times has compiled its stock averages, highs for the composite index of fifty issues, or for the twenty-five industrials have been reached in every month except August.
ALBANY, July 29 -- Dr. Henry Townley Heald, Chancellor of New York University, was appointed today as chairman of a Temporary State Commission on Educational Finances.

Admiral Jerauld Wright, Supreme Allied Commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's Atlantic forces, declared yesterday that Soviet Russia was making "a bold challenge" for control of the seas.
Business lending by the New York banks continued to taper off in the week ended Wednesday, according to the report of the Federal Reserve Bank here yesterday.

During 1953, 297,000,000 pairs of shoes, or 59.3 per cent of the year's output, was manufactured to retail for $6 or less, according to a study prepared by the Bureau of Census for the National Shoe Manufacturers Association and the New England Shoe and Leather Association.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., July 29 -- The American Yacht Club's twenty-third annual cruise, a five-day affair, ended in near calm here today with the choicest series silverware being collected by two Beach Point Y. C. skippers, Commodore Arthur P. Davis, and Harold M. Lane, for their splendid sailing on the entire trip.

BOSTON, July 29 -- A resolution condemning Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's "anti-labor voting record" and questioning his sincerity as an opponent of communism will be presented to the convention of the Massachusetts Federation of Labor.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- The Air Lines Pilots Association today announced that it had reactivated its strike action against the American Airlines and had alerted all the company's more than 1,200 pilots to a strike deadline of one minute before midnight tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- More than 150,000 "wetbacks" have been helped back to Mexico from the Southwestern Border states in the last two months, the Immigration and Naturalization Service announced today.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 29 (AP) -- Barbara McIntyre, a 19-year-old Toledo player, overcame a three-hole deficit and defeated Pat Lesser of Seattle, 1 up, in the quarter-finals of the women's Western amateur golf tournament today at Broadmoor Country Club.

" The Communist Party of India," a history by Minoo R. Masani, will be issued early in September by Macmillan. It traces the Communist movement from 1917 to the present and includes documents smuggled from the last big Congress of the Indian Communist party. The author, former Ambassador to Brazil, is a Socialist, a Parsee and a business man.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives recommended today a floor test of immunity laws. The committee sought a decision on whether balky witnesses, who invoked the constitutional privilege against self-incrimination, should be forced to talk.
The merger of the Consolidated Gas Utilities Corporation of Oklahoma City into the Oklahoma Natural Gas Company of Tulsa was approved yesterday by the directors of both companies.

American Federation of Labor unions in this state are planning a determined bid to get one of their members on the Democratic state ticket this year. They are expected to get strong support from the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- In the week ended July 28, member bank reserves decreased $5,000,000, the Federal Reserve reported today.

CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- Hog receipts again fell short of expectations today, but the market could not continue with its advance of the past three sessions. Butchers and sows sold steady to 50 cents down.

President Eisenhower made it plain at his Wednesday press conference that he would ask Congress to restore the $17,958,000 for the United Nations technical-assistance program which the House cut out of his foreign-aid proposals.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 29 (AP) -- Dick Adam, three-year old Chestnut gelding driven by Sanders Russell, won his sixth straight race tonight in capturing the Amityville Pace at Roosevelt Raceway in 2:04 3/5.

FORT DIX, N. J., July 29 (UP) -- Col. Earl L. Ringler, who ordered a lieutenant and his first sergeant court - martialed on charges of maltreating trainees, will review their acquittal, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee today approved legislation to authorize construction of 11,967 military housing units. The House of Representatives later today voted for 13,583 units.

ROMANCE, which thrives on city pavements as lushly as on moonlit hillsides, sometimes moves in a mysterious way, too. For more than thirty years two gentle sisters in New York have taken their summer holidays with a kindly, conservative gentleman on the theory that no scandal could attach to that.

The main objective of my letter in The Times of July 13 was to point out "the existence of the implacable war which has been waged between the Russian people and international communism," and to the fact "that Communist policies are in constant contradiction with the interests of the Russian people."
SAO PAULO, Brazil, July 29 -- A new chorus of complaints about United States policy toward Latin America has arisen among Brazilians, as evidenced in Congress and the press.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Navy announced today that its fourth supercarrier of the Forrestal class would be built at the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 29 (UP) -- Senator Homer E. Capehart said today he found nothing improper in the connection between Wilson Wyatt, former Federal Housing Expediter, and an apartment house project that was investigated by Senator Capehart's Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee.

The American Civil Liberties Union deplored yesterday Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's accusation that Miss Dorothy Kenyon, former New York Municipal Court Justice and delegate to the United Nations, was a Communist.

The Administration's omnibus revenue bill, which has been called by President Eisenhower "the cornerstone" of his domestic legislation program, has now taken the last hurdle on its appointed course. Last week a Joint Committee of the two houses of Congress worked out a compromise bill reconciling the differences between the House and Senate versions of the legislation.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Government is speeding up planned Federal expenditures in the hope of prodding the national economy into greater activity, Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, said today.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (UP) -- Dr. Syngman Rhee conferred with President Eisenhower for ninety minutes today, but the Korean President did not bring up his proposal for the United States to join in a war of liberation in Asia.

" Upon This Rock," a new oratorio by Harry R. Wilson, based on episodes in the life of St. Peter, had its first New York Performance at the Riverside Church last evening under the composer's direction.
Despite severe droughts in many parts of the country, produce is abundant in the groceries here this week.
The Housing and Buildings Part of Municipal Term Court, 455 West 151st Street, keeps getting busier and busier.

A champagne supper dance will be held on the night of Sept. 1 aboard the new Italian liner Cristoforo Colombo as a benefit for the Musicians Emergency Fund and the Casa Verdi in Milan. Mrs. Lytle Hull and Mrs. Vladimir Horowitz are co-chairmen of the fete, and Mrs. T. Markoe Robertson is executive chairman.

J. Russel Sprague, Republican leader of Nassau County, has sold the last of his harness racing stock which, in eight years, reportedly brought him a profit of more than $500,000 on an original investment of $2,000.

CLEVELAND, July 29 (UP) -- Jackie Jensen hit two homers and drove in six runs today to help the Boston Red Sox turn on their season-long tormentors, the Cleveland Indians, for a 10-2 victory that snapped Bob Feller's seven-game winning streak.

BONN, Germany, July 29 -- The Federal Prosecutor opened proceedings today in absentia against Dr. Wolfgang Wohlgemuth, the Berlin physician, and other persons connected with the disappearance of Dr. Otto John, former West German intelligence chief.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Senate Public Works Committee today approved a bill to authorize construction of flood control, navigation and beach erosion projects with a Federal cost estimated at slightly more than $1,000,000,000.

BONN, Germany, July 29 -- A bill approved by the Senate Judiciary Committee authorizing the return of seized property to its former German owners has caused misgivings among Western allies of the United States.

The vote of the Appropriations Committee of the House to eliminate entirely the proposed $17,958,000 for technical assistance through the United Nations and the refusal of the House to restore this appropriation is amazing and almost unbelievable to all who are interested in improving social, cultural and economic conditions in undeveloped countries.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned somewhat irregular yesterday and active months closed 8 points higher to 5 points lower than on Wednesday.

Despite a 13.5 per cent drop in sales, earnings of the United States Rubber Company for the first half of this year were little changed from a year ago, because of lower taxes and the renegotiation of defense business.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29 (UP) -- A rookie, right-hander, Corky Valentine, pitched a four-hitter and hit two doubles that led to Cincinnati's first two runs as the Redlegs defeated the Phillies, 3 -- 0, tonight.
Ten thousand unionized painters in this city will receive a pay increase of 16 cents an hour this year and an additional 2 1/2 cents next year under the terms of a contract signed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Government announced today a $65,800,000 shipbuilding and ship-buying deal with the American President Lines.
SALT-WATER fishing is good everywhere.

Fifty-four Americans who have made names in the fields of business, diplomacy, labor and education will meet this weekend to talk about what the United States and the United Nations mean to each other.

Commodity prices closed generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges in slightly more active trading. Hides established new lows for the life of the contract in all positions. Cocoa, potatoes, rubber, zinc, lead, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and wool also eased. Coffee, burlap and silk were higher, and sugar ended mixed.

The Standard Oil Company of California reported yesterday for the first half of this year a consolidated net income of $104,043,923, or $3.63 a share on the capital stock. This compares with $91,373,736, or $3.19 a share, for the similar period in 1953.

Following are excerpts from an address to the New York State convention of the American Legion yesterday by Admiral Jerauld Wright, U. S. N., Supreme Allied Commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's Atlantic forces:
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 29 -- The film capital, experiencing its annual summer-time influx of tourists, stopped today to take notice of its importance to foreign visitors.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The National Security Council approved today in principle a revised Defense Department plan for compulsory participation by veterans in Reserve or National Guard units.

TRENTON, July 29 -- The inquiry into Harold G. Hoffman's $300,000 embezzlement revealed today that New Jersey's late Governor had precariously juggled almost $16,000,000 from one state fund to another to hide his crime over a period of thirteen years.

Guatemala's new Government recently gave all labor unions in that country three months in which to rid themselves of Communists and to select leaders without Red political ties. Word now comes of the formation of a national committee in Guatemala to hasten that process and to reorganize the entire labor movement.

CALGARY, Alberta, July 29 (Canadian Press) -- N. E. Tanner, president of Trans-Canada Pipe Lines, Ltd., announced today that a new company, Bechtel-Mannix-Hester, would be in charge of design, engineering and construction of the 2,200-mile natural gas line from Alberta to Montreal.

In a display of statesmanship which triumphed over the temptations of politics, the House of Commons approved last night the agreement with Egypt for the evacuation of British troops from the Suez Canal zone. It thereby confirmed a settlement which Secretary Eden, together with President Eisenhower and Secretary Dulles, has hailed as the promise of a new era in the Middle East.

Examples of a wide variety of prints may be seen in an exhibit that opened yesterday in the Scalamandre Museum of Textiles, 20 West Fifty-fifth Street. The exhibit will be on view until the end of October.

A hint that the Philco Corporation was preparing for a sales battle in color-television receivers by developing its own color system was given at the annual stockholders meeting in Philadelphia yesterday.
The chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation confirmed yesterday that his company had been discussing for some time a merger with the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company.

HANOI, Indochina, July 29 (Reuters) -- Foreign correspondents learned here today that their news cablegrams from the Red River delta passed through three separate screens of censorship before leaving Vietnam.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., July 29 (AP) -- Joseph Cowley, Los Angeles, was the highest ranking player eliminiated today in the fourth round of the national junior and boys' tennis championships.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 29 -- Paul Kelly of Sleepy Hollow had little trouble winning today as two rounds were completed in the thirty-fifth annual Westchester County Golf Association amateur championship at the Metropolis course.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The first major test in the Senate on the $3,100,000,000 foreign aid program produced a clearcut victory today for the Administration.

A new approach in newspaper advertising to carry a promotional message to regional markets -- the twenty-one major trading areas -- is planned by the Trimount Clothing Company of Boston. Trimount makes the Clipper Craft line of men's clothing.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 -- Caryl Chessman, condemned author of "Cell 2455, Death Row," won another reprieve today.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Only one problem confronted Casey Stengel today as his Yankees walloped the Chicago White Sox, 10 -- 0, and moved to within a game and a half of the league-leading Cleveland Indians. In a "rocking-chair" game, such as this one, the victorious manager had only to avoid getting dizzy from too much "rocking."

SAO PAULO, Brazil, July 29 -- The most effective weapon against cancer is still to prevent it, but science has made such advances that doctors can cure permanently at least one-fourth of the cases they fail to prevent.
The Illinois Central Railroad arranged yesterday to reduce the interest charge on $25,000,000 of its bonded debt from 4 1/4 per cent to 3 l/4 per cent.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Legal complexities have slowed merger negotiations between the Traux-Traer Coal Company of Chicago and the Sinclair Coal Company of Kansas City, Mo., Truax stockholders were told at their annual meeting today.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- T. Coleman Andrews, Internal Revenue Commissioner, reported today that the Government was getting tougher with taxpayers who deducted such items as yachts and honeymoons as business expenses in figuring income taxes.

The Air Force, the only one of the armed services to increase in strength in the current fiscal year that started July 1, will add 15,000 men and five aircraft wings during 1955. It will maintain at the end of the fiscal year June 30, 1955, some 22,927 aircraft of all types in its active aircraft inventory.

The Military Air Transport Service has completed eighteen months of world-wide flying operations without a single passenger fatality. This perfect record of air safety was achieved while carrying 700,000 passengers and 89,000 patients in every type of American military transport aircraft.
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 29 -- The Soviet Union was reported today to have offered Afghanistan, as a "potential Communist ally," $250,000,000 of technical aid of the Point Four type.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Dr. Carlos Davila, former President of Chile, was installed today as secretary-general of the twenty-one-nation Organization of American States.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Eisenhower offered today to send surplus United States food to Danube River flood areas behind the Iron Curtain.
Purchase of the main plant of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation at Farmingdale, L. I., by the adjacent Republic Aviation Corporation was announced yesterday.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 27 -- Alaskans are determined to continue their crusade for statehood. The realists among them knew weeks ago that their cause had been lost at this session of Congress, although some diehards were still hopeful until the House Rules Committee killed all chance of statehood at this time.

BALTIMORE, July 29 (AP) -- The Washington Senators chased Baltimore's rookie bonus left-hander, Bill O'Dell, from the mound in the initial inning of his first major league game today, then coasted to a 6 -- 0 triumph behind Chuck Stobbs' five-hit pitching.

For a while it seemed doubtful if there would be a concert at Lewisohn Stadium last night. Shortly before 8 it started to drizzle, and the audience ran for shelter. But the sprinkle soon let up, the audience trickled back and the Bizet program began as scheduled.

What with the heat, the humidity and a lot of other things apparently plaguing them, the Giants, who on Wednesday thought they had shaken themselves loose from their slump, slid right back into it at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
Although the curtain and almost everything else recognizable have been razed at the Center Theatre, there were at least two performances there yesterday.

LONDON, July 29 -- The Conservative back-bench "revolt" against the Government's new agreement with Egypt fizzled out tonight and the Government won overwhelming approval for its plan to evacuate the Suez Canal base.
In the face of a glowing opportunity to gain ground on the faltering Giants, the Dodgers dropped a 6-5 decision to the Cubs at Ebbets Field yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, July 29 (UP) -- The Milwaukee Braves scored two runs in the tenth-inning today to extend their winning streak to seven games with a 5-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
LORD BYRON, who hasn't appeared on the sports pages since he played cricket for Harrow, knowingly rhymed:

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Speculation on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange by Brazilian and United States interests, as well as excessive inventory buying by American importers, were among major causes for the coffee price spiral of 1953-54, the Federal Trade Commission said today.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Republican leadership of the House of Representatives was defeated today on a resolution calling for final adjournment of that body next Saturday.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Wayne County, Mich., has accused the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company of keeping the Detroit area "starved" for natural gas "to chastise" the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company, data filed with the Federal Power Commission revealed today.
The city faces a legal test of its approval of an illuminated advertising sign across the East River from the United Nations.
VANCOUVER, B. C., July 29 (UP) -- The fifth British Empire Games open here tomorrow, culminating months of planning and an expenditure of $2,500,000.

KANSAS CITY, July 29 (UP) -- While the spectators swarmed around the nation's "big name" players, an unknown professional from Louisville, Mike Krak, stepped up to the eighteenth tee today and shot a hole-in-one for a 34, 31 -- 65 and the first-round lead in the $20,000 Kansas City open golf tournament. Krak's total was eight under the par of 36, 37 -- 73.

COPENHAGEN, July 25 -- Two generations ago the school children of the United States got their introduction to Scandinavia mainly through the Norse legends put into English verse by Longfellow -- "The Saga of King Olaf" and "The Skeleton in Armor."

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Department store sales in the United States for the week ended last Saturday were 1 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Both a former and a present officer of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship testified yesterday that they knew of no Communists among the organization's officers.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Kenneth J. Kadow, former president of the United States Tin Corporation, today urged investigating Congressmen to support approval of a new Government loan of $403,000 to finance operations by the company at its tin mine at Lost River, Alaska.

JERUSALEM, July 29 -- Thirteen persons were killed and twenty-three others injured this afternoon when a plane crashed into a crowd gathered on the shore of the Sea of Galilee to commemorate the heroic death of a Jewish parachutist.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Following is the 61-to-26 roll-call vote by which the Senate tonight sent to President Eisenhower the omnibus tax revision bill:

TOKYO, Friday, July 30 (AP) -- A former Premier of Thailand, who is expected to head a Communist "Free Thai" movement from his refuge in Communist China, called today for the overthrow of the Thai Government.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Following are the major provisions of the omnibus tax bill on which the Senate completed Congressional action today, sending it to the President:
LONDON, July 29 -- Jacob A. Malik, Soviet Ambassador to Britain, expressed surprise today at the difficulties the Soviet Union was having in buying ships here.

A flat, moon-like object shooting straight up at great speed from near sea level to about 5,000 feet was sighted at 8:15 P. M. Wednesday eighty miles east of New York by officers of the Netherlands Government vessel Groote Beer.

In your editorial of July 26 "Watch the Signal" is undoubtedly important advice. What interested me particularly was the advice to motorists to give pedestrians right-of-way and not to encroach on walkers' time by blocking their passage. Such courtesy to pedestrians, by both private and taxi drivers, was observed by me in a recent trip to California.

CHICAGO, July 29 (UP) -- A coroner's jury found today that Montgomery Ward Thorne, 20-year-old mail order heir, had died of natural causes, but recommended that the "unusual circumstances" of his death be further investigated.
LONDON, July 29 -- The stock markets here continued cheerful today, with gains registered in almost every important section.

Since the continent of America was discovered our forebears have fled to it for refuge from many kinds of oppression. With hopeful hearts and courageous spirits they came to carve out new lives for themselves and their children, lives possible only in a land of freedom of thought and opportunity.
SAIGON, Vietnam, July 29 -- A plan for the evacuation from the northern regions of Vietnam of 700,000 persons has been worked out here by Premier Ngo Dinh Diem's Government.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Senate completed Congressional action tonight on the Administration's omnibus tax reform bill, providing $1,363,000,000 of relief this fiscal year for most businesses and many individuals.
One of two men arrested as participants in a $4,302 Brooklyn payroll robbery found the District Attorney's office on his side yesterday.
Rocky Marciano, the champion, and Ezzard Charles, the challenger and a former titleholder, are going to meet again for the world heavyweight title.
PARIS, July 29 -- The first stage in a program to expand the productivity of the stagnant French economy was approved by the Cabinet today and will be submitted to Parliament next week.

The Union Pacific Railroad Company reported yesterday a net income of $29,530,697 for the first half after charges and taxes, compared with $30,549,668 in the similar period of 1953. Operating revenue declined to $225,486,390 from $250,807,755.

EDMONTON, Alta., July 29 -- Canada's Socialists voted today at their convention to urge the Liberal Government to recognize Communist China immediately and support its admittance to the United Nations.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 29 (AP) -- A woman pediatrician took issue last night with the argument that mothers seek employment outside the home because duties that once kept a housewife busy "are done better and more quickly by mechanized gadgets."

The final rounds of play in two important golf tournaments will be televised over the A. B. C. network from the Tam O'Shanter golf course, near Chicago, on succesive Sundays. The finals of the All-American tournament will be seen on Aug. 8, from 6 to 7 P. M., and the finals of the World Championship of golf will be covered on Aug. 15, from 8 to 9 P. M.

MEXICO CITY, July 29 -- Many things that had only been muttered privately in Mexican political circles were being said openly today in the aftermath of Gen. Lazaro Cardenas' resignation from his Federal job.
DNIEPROPETROVSK, U.S.S.R., July 21 -- Two days of travel by automobile through the Donets Basin, the industrial heart of the Soviet Union, is an awesome and thought-provoking experience.

HONG KONG, July 29 -- Father John B. Maye of Scranton, Pa., arrived here today from Changsha, China. He is the first of four United States Passionist priests whom Chinese Communist officials at the Geneva conference on Far Eastern affairs promised to release.

Thousands of tourists who saw a huge fragment of Prospect Point at Niagara Falls topple into the chasm below received a lesson in geology they will never forget. The escarpment over which water from the Great Lakes tumbles into a gorge with walls 170 feet high is composed of soft shale covered with hard dolomite.

OTTAWA, July 29 -- The Duke of Edinburgh arrived in Ottawa this morning to start a three-week tour of Canada. His trip of more than 8,000 miles will be mostly by plane and will be utterly unlike the formal visit he made here three years ago with Queen Elizabeth II, then Princess Elizabeth.
The city is cleaning up thirty-four vacant lots it owns in Harlem to give children a safe place to play.

Further expansion of the Italian merchant marine, which has staged an amazing revival since the war, is now being planned, Italian maritime authorities said yesterday. They are in New York in connection with the maiden voyage of the new liner Cristoforo Colombo, which arrived a week ago. She will sail tomorrow.

PARIS, July 29 -- A salvo of bravos burst forth when the last dress, an enchanting bridal creation, came into the Dior showroom, this morning. There were cries of "divine," for this was unquestionably the best collection Christian Dior has made since his first of new look fame.

OFFBEAT drama with a light touch slipped into the spotlight on "Center Stage" last Tuesday (A. B. C.-TV, 9:30 to 10:30 P. M.) and brought welcome divertissement. The type of play was a rarity for television, a comedy fantasy entitled "Lucky Louie."

DETROIT, July 29 (UP) -- The Detroit Tigers regained fourth place in the American League today by sweeping a double-header with the Philadelphia Athletics, 4 to 2 and 7 to 3. Washington dropped to fifth place as a result.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (UP) -- Fred Carpi, vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, urged the Interstate Commerce Commission today to permit Eastern lines to continue experiments with "piggy-back" hauling of loaded truck trailers on railway flat cars.
Higher maximum fines for irresponsible drivers were urged yesterday by the New York State Association of Chiefs of Police.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Communist China has refused even to consider the United States protests against attacks by its fighter planes on a British airliner and United States aircraft in the South China Sea.

JERUSALEM, July 29 -- The 1953 Stephen S. Wise award for an outstanding contribution to Jewish welfare was presented today to Youth Aliyah. The citation described the organization's work as "rescuing more than 65,000 children from over seventy-two lands during the past twenty years and educating them for creative citizenship in the land of Israel."
Columbia Records demonstrated yesterday a new Kilosphere loudspeaker system for use with the company's "360" table-model record player.

The importance of good design in playground equipment and the need for more community cooperation in planning creative play areas was emphasized yesterday in a meeting held at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.

Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg approved yesterday a plan for transferring the life, health and accident insurance policies of the left-wing International Workers Order to the Continental Assurance Company of Chicago.
There were 1,171 new cases of polio reported in the nation last week, 115 more than in the previous week but 177 fewer than in the corresponding week last year.

CAIRO, July 29 -- British and Egyptian representatives met today for the first time since the signing of the general agreement for the withdrawal of the British forces from the Suez Canal zone to plan in detail the implementation of the agreement.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Wheat rallied sharply from a decline early today, with both commission buying and short covering some investment buying was noted on the early declines, wheat prices being off as much as 8 cents from the high spot of early in the week.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Pushover," a Columbia melodrama starring Fred MacMurray, is at the Globe. Jules Schermer produced and Richard Quine directed from a screen play that Roy Huggins adapted from stories by Thomas Walsh and William S. Ballinger.

D. Allan Locke, treasurer of the Board of National Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A., yesterday reported total receipts of $2,465.769 for the six months ended June 30. This was an increase of 6 per et over the same priod last year. Gifts' from Presbyterian women's organizations of $624,889 were included.

The City of New York tried yesterday to throw another road block in the way of plans to increase the fares of the Long Island Rail Road by 20 per cent and return it to the control of the Pennsylvania Railroad.
