WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today created an interdepartmental committee to study the "continued development of energy supplies and resources and fuels."

PITTSBURGH, July 30 (AP) -- Hank Sauer, Chicago Cub outfielder, hit a homer in each game tonight as the Cubs and the Pittsburgh Pirates split a twin bill. The Pirates won the first game, 8 -- 6, on a thirteen-hit attack, with the Cubs striking back to take the second, 8 -- 5, as they collected fourteen safeties.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 30 -- Politics and cheese made festive souffle today, when the Mayors of Europe's cheese centers sat down a three-hour banquet in the town of Alkmaar.
New financing declined slightly in July from offerings in recent months, but was well above a year ago.

Sizable increases in both gross revenues and net income were reported yesterday by the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago. For the year ended June 30, 1954, the utility, one of the largest in the country, showed a net income of $39,417,083.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- From about 11 A. M. until 2:45 P. M. today the largest crowds of the session jammed the Senate galleries in anticipation of Senator Ralph E. Flanders' kick-off speech asking censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

I am an ardent reader of The New York Times and quite frequently depend upon your extremely accurate reporting to aid me in making decisions. Therefore, I feel I should call your attention to certain factual errors in your editorial entitled "After the Filibuster Ends" of July 27.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., July 30 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway delivered an indirect warning here tonight against basing the entire military strategy of the United States on nuclear weapons.
WESTBURY, L. I., July 30 (AP) -- Katie Key set a world record of 1:37 1/5 for six and a half furlongs in winning the Milestone Trot tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.
" The Iron Gate," a comedy by John T. Chapman, has attracted the attention of John Golden, who may present it on Broadway this season.
TOKYO, July 30 (UP) -- A group of Japanese scientists said today they had produced goldfish with "hideous deformities" by introducing ashes from a hydrogen bomb explosion to the eggs.
FRANKFURT, Germany, July 25 -- Students duels have been resumed on a mass scale. Thousands are fought every year.

CHICAGO, July 30 (UP) -- Bob Keegan, who had tried three times for his thirteenth victory, took care of matters himself tonight as the White Sox' right-hander won the elusive jinx game by driving in two runs with a double and sacrifice fly to beat the Philadelphia Athletics, 4 to 2.

The current rash of bills to legalize wiretapping, to grant immunity to those who waive the Fifth Amendment, to revoke the citizenship of "subversives," to suspend the collective-bargaining rights of "subversive" trade unions, etc. -- are justified as safeguarding our national security.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Increases in retirement and unemployment benefits for railroad workers estimated at $82,000,000 a year were voted today by the House of Representatives.
The Hotel Astor, New York's most rumored-about landmark, isn't coming down.
The Borg-Warner Corporation's half-year sales and earnings were down from a year ago because of a decline in demand for automotive supplies and a reduction in sales to farm equipment producers.

Richard H. Balch, Democratic state chairman, demanded yesterday that Governor Dewey order an investigation on how J. Russel Sprague, Republican leader of Nassau County, had been able to reap a $500,000 profit on an original investment of $2,000 in harness racing stock.

LONDON, July 30 -- Selwyn Lloyd, Minister of State, told the House of Commons today that if the Soviet Union and its allies accepted the system of international disarmament control proposed by the Western powers, any recourse to a world war would be most unlikely.
BALTIMORE, July 30--"Some birthday."
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UP) -- Republican leaders agreed today to give the House of Representatives another chance to act on a bill to raise the mailman's pay. They predicted it would pass.

Net earnings of oil companies which have reported so far on operations for the first half of this year -- and they represent close to half of the nation's refinery capacity -- have averaged around 7 per cent more than those for the like period of last year.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today, with modifications, the stockholders' "agreed system plan" for reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad.

TOKYO, July 30 -- Japanese sources said today the South Koreans had seized and occupied the Takeshima Islands in the Sea of Japan. Title to the islands long had been in dispute between the two nations.
TRENTON, July 30 -- Federal Judge Philip Forman refused today to absolve the Federal Government of all liability for the South Amboy munitions explosion that killed thirty-one persons in 1950.

Thailand has decided to withdraw at this time the call for a session of the United Nations General Assembly to consider the sending of a peace observation team to her threatened area. Apprehension in Thailand, however, has not been lessened by the terms of the Indochina armistice.

There is a news report in your paper of July 28 which should arouse the free press that can remain free only so long as the public it serves is protected in its basic freedoms. I refer to the Army's discharge of an inductee from the Bronx as an "undesirable," and especially to the reasons given by the Adjutant General's office for this action.

WASHINGTON, N. J., July 30 -- A 4 1/2-year-old boy, object of an intense search in the rugged hilly area near here last night, was found drowned this morning at the bottom of the Mountain Spring Camp pool.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The perpetual twinkle that Senator Ralph E. Flanders wears behind his rimless spectacles was still there as he took the floor tonight to do battle against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, and closing prices were 3 points lower to 2 points higher.
Twelve hundred pilots went on strike today against American Airlines, largest airline in the nation.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement issued tonight by President Eisenhower and President Rhee:
VANCOUVER, B. C., July 30 (UP) -- A blaze of color and pageantry launched the British Empire and Commonwealth Games tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UP) -- President Eisenhower said today that freedom and tyranny were fighting for the minds and souls of men.
A spokesman for retailers yesterday praised the tax law that Congress has just passed, but a tax expert asserted that it might cost the Government a great deal more revenue than had been expected.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Corn and soybean futures registered sharp gains on the Board of Trade today. The yellow cereal was helped by a bullish railroad estimate and the soybeans by the Department of Agriculture estimate of soybean stocks in all positions on July 1 at 33,200,000 bushels, compared with 62,200,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Following is the 49-to-40 roll-call vote by which the Senate today adopted an amendment by Senator George W. Malone, Republican of Nevada, to the foreign aid bill, forbidding use of aid funds to stimulate strategic minerals production abroad:
MOSCOW, July 25 -- Russia's 1954 grain harvest has been gathered almost as far north as the Moscow line and generally speaking it appears good.
LIVERPOOL, England, July 30 (AP) -- The Cunard Steamship Company today identified a woman missing from the liner Queen Elizabeth as Mrs. Margaret Poser, 52, a United States citizen from New York.

LENOX, Mass., July 30 -- It is difficult to write of the fourth concert of the so-called Mozart-Bach series, given this evening by Charles Munch and a small orchestra of the Boston Symphony players in the Theatre Concert Hall, and avoid superlatives.

MANILA, Saturday, July 31 (AP) -- The massed firepower of ten United States Navy planes blasted two Chinese Communist aircraft into the South China Sea in three minutes last Monday, a ranking Navy officer said today.

With their regular line-up back in action the skidding Giants reversed themselves and took a big forward stride last night by defeating the Redlegs, 6 -- 1, before 13,153 spectators at the steamy Polo Grounds.

City Magistrate Phillip B. Thurston, a Republican, will be sworn in by Mayor Wagner on Monday at 2:30 P. M. for a full ten-year term as a justice of the Court of Domestic Relations. The post carries an annual salary of $19,500.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 30 -- A project to restore historic Calvin Auditorium in Geneva, Switzerland, as an international Presbyterian and Reformed memorial center was unanimously approved here today by the World Presbyterian Alliance.
TARRYTOWN, N. Y., July 30 ---Greenburgh's slum clearance and public housing program, defeated, 3 to 2, by the Town Board on July 16, was reconsidered at a special meeting today and adopted, 3 to 1.

MONTAUK POINT, L. I., July 30 -- If you'd like to go fishing at Montauk, where they're catching everything from minnows to whales, you'd better phone for reservations. The seas all about are jumping with fish and the shore community is jumping with fishermen, especially on these weekends.
IPSWICH, Mass., July 30 -- In a land of rapid change and growth it is almost incredible that so many of the frontier houses have survived, in whole or in part.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in July was the largest for any month since January, 1951. It was the biggest turnover for a July since 1933.

An innovation in supermarketing, shore-to-ship grocery service, is offered by the Daitch Crystal Dairies store, which opened recently at 430 Pelham Road, New Rochelle, N. Y. Landlubbers arrive conventionally by car or on foot to do their shopping, but yachtsmen may moor their boats at a slip on New Rochelle Creek directly in back of the establishment.
GUATEMALA, July 30 -- The ruling junta that succeeded the deposed leftist regime of Jacobo Ardenz Guzman was formally presented to the diplomatic corps today at a ceremony in the National Palace.
THURMONT, Md., July 30 (AP) -- President Eisenhower encountered an old comrade in arms unexpectedly while motoring to his Catoctin Mountain lodge today and they got together for a luncheon reunion.

PARIS, July 30 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France obtained the Cabinet's backing today for a program of reform for Tunisia. While safeguarding the interests of French nationals in Tunisia, it would progressively establish virtually complete Tunisian control over internal affairs.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Chances of Congressional action to impose Federal restrictions on coffee trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange at this session appear remote, legislative leaders agreed today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 30 -- World mine production of tin-in-concentrates during May was 14,800 long tons, compared with 13,500 in April, the International Tin Study Group reported here today. The increase was mainly due to a sharp rise of Bolivian exports, from 1,497 tons in April to 3,128 in May.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30 -- The Marian Anderson recreation center, a $700,000 facility named in honor of Philadelphia's celebrated contralto, was formally dedicated this afternoon at Seventeenth and Fitzwater Streets.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Congressional aides said yesterday that it would take them ten days to get the Administration's omnibus tax reform bill in shape for President Eisenhower's signature.

GENEVA, July 30 -- The United States has formally advised its principal trading partners that the Eisenhower Administration will ask Congress, early in 1955, to give legislative sanction to a revised General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).
LONDON, July 30 -- The stock markets finished the week buoyantly, with business spurred by good industrial production figures and several favorable dividend announcements.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Railroad engineers are already the highest paid carrier workers and should not receive greater wage increases than those for other operating employes, Howard Neitzert of Chicago, counsel for railroads, today told a six-man arbitration board in hearings on the 22 1/2 per cent wage increase demand of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers.
In a sharp rebuke to its fun-making society, the Forty and Eight, the New York State Department of the American Legion registered yesterday its repudiation of that body's racial policies.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- An improved tank with which a vender can carry iced pop right to the patron in the bleachers and serve it from a hose was patented this week.

The $25,000 added Merchants' and Citizens' Handicap, with six older horses competing over the mile-and-three-sixteenths course, will mark the closing day of the three-week Saratoga-at-Jamaica meeting today.

Two stories about offers of assistance to the needy came out in the news yesterday. They offer an interesting and enlightening contrast. In Washington, President Eisenhower offered shipments of food to flood-devastated areas on the Danube behind the Iron Curtain in Eastern Europe.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The House of Representatives passed and sent to the Senate today a bill to make the Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, N. Y., a permanent institution.

SEATTLE, July 30 (AP) -- Don Cockell, British Empire champion and third-ranked heavyweight of the world, whipped Harry (Kid) Matthews tonight. The Seattle Kid was unable to appear for the eighth round because of a back injury.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday was 41.2 per cent below that of the like week last year, according to reports received by The New York Times from regional associations. Shipments were down 35.5 per cent and orders 38.1 per cent.

It is most encouraging to read in The Times of July 25 that General Gruenther's staff has concluded that the first targets in a future war would be enemy forces rather than population centers. At the same time, the immediate use of atomic weapons -- presumably primarily tactical weapons -- is assumed.

Dr. Hollis L. Caswell, president-elect of Teachers College, Columbia University, became head of the institution yesterday upon the retirement of Dr. William F. Russell, who had served as dean or president for the last twenty-seven years.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 30 (AP) -- Mrs. C. E. Adams' smooth-jumping Escargot outgamed L. R. Triano's King Commander in the last sixteenth to win the $11,025 Midsummer Hurdle Handicap before 18,750 fans at Monmouth Park today.

The market for new capital is heading into midsummer on a strong note after weeks of unusually heavy activity. Prices of new fixed-income securities are firm and the supply of forthcoming prime investments seems to be outbalanced for the first time in months by accumulated savings in search of investment.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Federal Housing Administration said today it would reject the land valuation proposed by Manhattan Town, Inc., sponsor of a major slum redevelopment project in New York City.

There are only two books published today. Vantage is selling at $3 "Rough and Tumble: The Autobiography of a West Texas Judge," by William Paul Moss. Prentice-Hall has at $4.95 Andreas Feininger's new work, "Successful Color Photography."
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Atomic Energy Commission reported good progress today in its efforts to assure the United States of continued superiority over the Soviet Union in nuclear arms.
A police task force descended on the Times Square "honky-tonk" area late last night in a major week-end offensive against undesirable persons who have turned the district into their ...

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 30 -- The Ministry of Interior's visa department stated today that thirteen United States tourists, including two Negroes, members of a study group now in Bulawayo, Southern Rhodesia, have been refused visas because sufficient data has never been submitted.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., July 30 (UP) -- Straight Clark and Hamilton Richardson, the nation's fifth and sixth-ranked tennis players, defeated Cuba's Garrido brothers in two singles matches today to put the United States Davis Cup team within one match of victory in the American zone semi-finals.

Thanks to the steady rains of late spring the city has reached the end of July with its reservoirs in fair shape, despite the extreme heat of the past several days. Water storage is a little less than 80 per cent of capacity, compared with around 82 to 83 per cent at this time last year.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The index of primary market prices declined 0.5 point to 109.7 over the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. A dip in average prices for farm products and processed foods accounted for the decrease, as average prices of industrial materials remained unchanged.

Each year, it would seem, the shortage of teachers becomes more acute. The situation is viewed with regret by educational organizations at their annual meetings; suggestions are made regarding the need for increased salaries and more vigorous attempts to recruit capable young people for teacher education; plans are laid for special adjustments and other temporary means to alleviate current shortages.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board set final helicopter mail rates -- including an annual subsidy payment of $1,329,000 -- for New York Airways today.

HANOI, Indochina, July 30 (AP) -- Vietnamese Roman Catholics streaming into Hanoi ahead of Communist-led Vietminh occupation forces said today Red sympathizers had stripped many of their money and valuables.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 27 -- The Republicans have written off Alaska in the 1954 campaign. Realistic politicians all over the territory foresee a smashing Democratic victory in the general election on Oct. 12.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 30 (AP) -- With third-seeded Bernard Bartzen the lone casualty, Tony Trabert led a parade of favorites into the semi-final round of the sixty-fifth annual Meadow Club invitation tennis tournament today.
Four hold-up men employed three vehicles yesterday to carry out a Brooklyn robbery and kidnapping in which they made off with an $18,000 payroll.

One good man has succeeded another as secretary general of the Organization of American States and director general of the Pan American Union. Since the Bogota conference in 1948 the Pan American Union has functioned as the general secretariat of the O. A. S., which was formed at that nearly disrupted meeting.
Apartment properties purchased for investment figured in most of the realty transactions reported in the Bronx yesterday.

The one-story taxpayer building containing six stores at 90-12 Roosevelt Avenue in Jackson Heights, Queens, has been purchased by Goldenberg Schwebel, investors. The property fronts 240 feet on Roosevelt Avenue and runs through to Case Street. It is assessed at $201,000.

The Milwaukee Braves were as hot as the weather at Ebbets Field last night. They ran their winning streak to eight games by knocking off the Dodgers, 9 -- 3, and dropped the Brooks three games behind the pace-setting Giants.

A maximum sentence of five years in the penitentiary was imposed yesterday on Louis B. Saperstein, a Newark insurance broker, convicted of criminal contempt for refusing to testify about racketeering in labor welfare funds.
SAYREVILLE, N. J., July 30 (AP) -- The New Jersey Highway Authority today opened a new link in the Garden State Parkway -- the high-level bridge over the Raritan River for northbound traffic.

CLEVELAND, July 30 (AP) -- Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard was arrested on a charge of first degree murder tonight in the July 4 bludgeoning death of his wife Marilyn, 31 years old. Pleading innocent, he was taken in handcuffs to the county jail.
CHICAGO, July 30 -- A 39-year-old woman narrowly escaped death today when she was dragged about 4,000 feet under water behind a motor-boat in Fox Lake.

GLASGOW, July 30 (UP) -- A Scotsman was fined $70 in Paisley Sheriff's Court today for endangering the safety of an airliner by hitting an American passenger as the plane landed at Renfrew airport, Glasgow.

A good many people will be finding this morning one of the macabre truisms of nature. That is, on the first of any seaside vacation there is either a dense fog or a drizzle of rain. Sometimes nature rears back and, with a contented chuckle, tosses over both of them alternately.

Today's new film program is a double bill of two Russian-made documentary features in color at the Stanley Theatre. "A Kingdom on the Waters," which traces the four seasons through a depiction of wild animal life, was written, photographed and directed by Istvan Homoki Magy and produced by the Hungarian Newsreel and Documentary Film Studios of Budapest.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Following are the texts of speeches today by Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, on his motion of censure against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, and by Senator William F. Knowland of California, the Majority leader:
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- President Eisenhower and Dr. Syngman Rhee, President of the Republic of Korea, described as fruitful tonight their meetings over the last four days.
LONDON, July 30 -- The United States has approved British proposals for close collaboration in the development of guided weapons.

PARIS, July 30 -- This morning saw the lowered waistline firmly established as a fashion when Jacques Fath approved it from the beginning to the end of his collection. He is the third of the great couturiers to insist on it. Dior and Balenciaga preceded him.
The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York purchased the eleven-story Charms Building at 601 Bangs Avenue in Asbury Park, N. J., in a three-way sale and lease-back deal completed yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (UP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals exploded with six runs in the seventh inning tonight to help Harvey Haddix gain his fifteenth victory of the season, 12 -- 3, over the Phillies.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 30 (AP) -- Sidney Wood, president of the Tennis Players League, said today that the organization was recommending a five-man committee to oversee "activities" of players on the tournament circuit.
LONDON, July 30 -- The Edinburgh Festival, Britain's leading musical event, is in search of a new artistic director, and is advertising in newspapers all over the world.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The National Lawyers Guild asserted today that the Federal District Court should hear evidence on whether Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. prejudged the guild in publicly announcing he would list it as a subversive organization.
VANCOUVER, B. C., July 30 (UP) -- The schedule of events for the fifth British Empire Games:
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Abandonment of the Christopher Street ferry, which links New York with Hoboken, N. J., was proposed today by an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner.
BONN, Germany, July 30 -- Labor, which accepted low wage scales in 1948 to help West Germany's economic recovery, has spread its agitation for increases to the center of the Ruhr industrial basin.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 30 -- Howard Miller 3d of Wykagyl and Lloyd Ribner of the home club will meet in the thirty-six-hole final of the Westchester amateur golf tournament on the Metropolis course tomorrow.

Stockholders of the First Bank and Trust Company of Utica will vote a special meeting Aug. 23 on increasing the common stock and retiring the preferred shares that have been held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation since 1940.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 30 -- The Thai Government declined to comment today on an article by former Premier Pridi Phanomyong in the People's Daily, Chinese Communist newspaper, calling for the overthrow of the present regime.
LONDON, Saturday, July 31--Dr. Joseph Cort and his wife, both American physicians, sailed aboard a Polish freighter early today to seek asylum in Red Czechoslovakia.

SEOUL, Korea, July 30 -- A high South Korean Army officer today threatened undisclosed action against Polish and Czechoslovak members of the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission unless they left "immediately."

One of our state's most popular parks, Jones Beach, quietly passed a milestone this week -- a quarter century of operation. During this time attendance at the park has increased nearly sevenfold to almost eight million persons annually. Facilities here have not remained static.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- President Eisenhower expressed the hope today that a conservative Republican candidate, who had given his program only qualified support, would be elected in the fall.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Prices received by farmers declined four-tenths of 1 per cent during the month ending July 15, the Department of Agriculture reported today.
The stimulating exchange of views relative to automobile speeds between Robert Moses and David Baldwin of the National Safety Council is apt to provoke some extensive comment.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., July 30 -- Wednesday's rock slides at the American Falls was today attributed to "a normal cliff recession which can be expected in the Gorge."

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Rewards up to half a million dollars were recommended by the Eisenhower Administration today for tips on any enemy agents or other persons seeking to smuggle atomic weapons into the United States or to manufacture them here.
NEW DELHI, India, July 30 -- India served notice today on the Portugugese Consul General and Consul stationed in Bombay to leave Indian territory within the next forty-eight hours.

Prices of commodities on the New York exchanges drifted irregularly higher yesterday in dull trading. The normal week-end lull was noted in most markets. Lead, hides, soybean oil, cottonseed oil, rubber and wool ended higher; cocoa and potatoes closed lower, and coffee, sugar and burlap were mixed.

Although most of the traditional leaders among the "blue chips" were sluggish, the balance of the market pushed forward yesterday under the leadership of aircrafts, steels and motors. Rails held about even and showed a small net loss.

DETROIT, July 30 (UP) -- Ned Garver, pitching with two days' rest, fired a four-hitter at the Boston Red Sox tonight to pace the Detroit Tigers to a 5-to-0 victory before 29,402 fans at Three of the four hits off Garver were doubles but he walked only two batters and allowed only one runner to advance as far as third base.
LONDON, July 30 -- Parliament adjourned tonight for its eleven-week summer recess aware that British politics are moving toward a period of maximum tension.

New York's waterfront, which could easily confuse an Eagle scout, what with West Street on the North River and South Street on the East River, got two travelers off to a rocky, but successful, start yesterday.
New Yorkers, already wilted by four successive days of temperatures near 90 degrees, can brace themselves for at least two more days of scorching sunshine.
The departmental trial of Capt. Philip Weinstein will begin at 10 o'clock /Ionday morning at fire headquarters in the runical Building, Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. announced yesterday.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 30 -- The Nationalist party press of Premier Daniel F. Malan is warning South Africans that withdrawal of the British from the Suez Canal zone means the end of any hope of isolation for South Africa.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- How President Eisenhower helped stimulate the settlement of the Suez dispute with a pledge of "simultaneous" aid to Egypt was disclosed in diplomatic circles today.
LONDON, July 30 (Reuters) -- The news that United States industrial and trade profits are at near-record levels came as a surprise to financial experts here today.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Senate debate on the conduct of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was well under way tonight in an atmosphere of personal and partisan bitterness.

CHICAGO, July 30 (AP) -- Sir Mango, top weighted at 125, must yield four pounds to Iceberg II tomorrow as they renew their rivalry over the grass in a field of fourteen primed for the $156,000 Arlington Handicap.
Greensboro, N. C., has no welcome mat out for companies that are unwilling to pay their own way, according to Herbert G. Bailey Jr., executive vice president of the Greensboro Chamber of Commerce.

Several large industrial and utility refundings swelled the total of bonds called for redemption in July before maturity to $209,865,000, the largest for any month since March, 1952, and for any July since 1950. The total compared with $147,258,000 in the preceding month and $40,790,000 in July, 1953.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 30 -- Negotiations to insure the continuation of Leonard Goldstein Productions are under way. The producer's sudden death a week ago left the company's future in question.
An Anglican Congress will be convened Wednesday night in the municipal auditorium in Minneapolis. Its sessions will continue through Friday, Aug. 13.

TOKYO, Saturday, July 31 -- Government prosecutors have announced they will not indict leading business men and Government officials whose cases still are pending in connection with Japan's shipbuilding scandal.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)--Counsel for a Senate Judiciary subcommittee said today the group would conduct public hearings this fall on alleged tie-ups between small loan companies and insurance concerns.

PURCHASE, N. Y., July 30 -- Mr. and Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells successfully defended the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's twenty-third husband-and-wife Scotch foursomes championship today at the Century Country Club.

ATHENS, July 30 (AP) -- Greek Foreign Minister Stephan Stephanopoulos said at a news conference Wednesday night that Britain's offer of a constitution for Cyprus was "less than an improvement over that presented in 1948 and less democratic than in 1948."

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UP)--The Department of Agriculture announced today it will support the price of the 1954 cotton crop at a national average of 31.58 cents a pound, up slightly from last year's 30.80 cents a pound.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Senate called on President Eisenhower today to take direct action to grant sovereignty to West Germany unless France soon ratified the European Defense Community treaty.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UP) -- The House Judiciary Committee approved a bill today to give the Federal Bureau of Investigation clear authority to investigate charges of bribes or other fraud involving any Government officials.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- There was very little evidence tonight that Senator Ralph E. Flanders of Vermont had the votes to pass his resolution of censure against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 30 -- Four store front and the General Motors exhibit at the Steel Pier, at the foot of Virginia Avenue, were burned in a late afternoon fire along the Boardwalk here today.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The State Department said today it was watching with "particular interest" the border tension between Nicaragua and Costa Rica, but it minimized the prospect of conflict.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Dividend payments by corporations issuing public reports amounted to $1,252,000,000 last month, a gain of 1 1/2 per cent from June a year ago, the Department of Commerce reported today.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., July 30 -- The $60,000,000 Hudson River bridge here for the New York-Buffalo Thruway began to resemble a traffic artery today for the first time when a 250-foot steel span was floated into place.

Detectives of the Police Commissioner's confidential squad said last night they had broken a $1,000,000-a-year Chinese lottery ring with the arrest of two men described as bankers for a policy numbers game known in Chinatown as "Bok-A-Pu."

BONN, Germany, July 30 -- The East German Reds quoted Dr. Otto John today as having said that the United States Counter-Intelligence Corps employe who committed suicide last Friday had been assigned to spy on him.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Treasury Department today announced plans for refinancing $7,512,000,000 of one-year 2 5/8 per cent certificates of indebtedness maturing over the next six weeks.
CHICAGO, July 30 -- President Eisenhower's message was welcomed here today by Mr. Meek, 50-year-old former teacher and store proprietor, as a "real lift" in his campaign to unseat Senator Douglas.

CLEVELAND, July 30 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians, with a five-run rally in the second inning, whipped the Washington Senators, 8 -- 3, tonight in the opener of a four-game series. Larry Doby and Jim Hegan hit home runs in the game.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Dr. Wilbur Lee Mahaney Jr., one of twenty-six House Un-American Activities Committee witnesses recently cited for contempt, made a bid today to purge himself by cooperating with the committee.

SAN JUAN, P. R., July 30--Puerto Rico sought increased shipping and new life for its industry today as the Government continued operating docks that had been tied up thirty-five days through yesterday by a longshore strike.

Some of the luster can be rubbed off a wonderful vacation if on your return home you find the silver drawer empty, furs and valuable papers missing and the house thoroughly ransacked. Added to this situation is the most unwelcome thought that only 15 per cent of the city's thefts, burglaries and robberies are ever solved, with little chance of ever recovering the stolen articles.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Senate consideration of the Administration's foreign aid program was sidetracked again tonight as final passage of a $3,110,000,000 authorization of new funds seemed within grasp.

A. HYATT VERRILL was born at New Haven in 1871. In that day even to a New England boy there was opportunity for a first-hand acquaintance with Indians. In Maine he listened to the stories of his grandfather, who had been a pioneer on that last Eastern frontier, and of old Indians, who had known the land before the white man came.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 31 -- The nation's stockpile of domestic-produced mica is short, but a new way to get tons more may be to just dip down for it.

BY the end of July the problem of controlling plants that self-sow is apt to loom wherever there is a flower border. Self-sowing is a mixed blessing. With some plants it is a distinct nuisance, but with others it can be turned to excellent advantage for extra plants or replacements.

BOSTON, July 31 -- Department store sales for the last several months have held very close to the figures of a year ago. Lately the tendency has been towards mild improvement. This has encouraged some local merchants to raise their sights slightly in respect to the outlook for fall business.

GREAT HUCKLOW, England, July 31 (AP) -- Stanley Smith and Robert Kidder, United States pilots, navigated their all-metal sailplane seventy-eight miles to take second place in today's world gliding championship flying for multi-seater machines.

KHARKOV, U. S. S. R., July 22 -- A two-year-old powder-blue Chevrolet has stirred up almost as much interest in its passage across the Ukraine as Halley's comet or, as it sometimes is called in the Soviet Union, Ivanov's comet, in honor of its first Russian discoverer.

GILBERT STUART portraits of Washington and Jefferson, and a posthumous painting of Lincoln by Douglas Volk, will be copied for the designs of the next three stamps in the new ordinary U. S. series, Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield has announced.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 31 (AP) -- Meadow Rice, a 5-year-old brown horse owned by W. G. Reynolds of Louisville and driven by Harry Harvey, took the $7,500 Babylon Free-for-All Pace in 2:00 3/5 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

Western medicine received one of its rare glimpses behind the Iron Curtain recently when Dr. Karl Evang, director general of Norway's Public Health Services, reported on a three weeks' study trip he had made last spring to the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) -- Arthur E. Summerfield, Postmaster General, has advised the House Post Office Committee that he is almost powerless to stop use of the mails for sending "hate propaganda."

TO BRING up an age-old question -- the TV age, that is -- why doesn't someone be daring and put on a panel quiz program that isn't just another stray chip off the old block? The C. B. S.-TV network is presenting a new program (Thursdays, 8 to 8:30 P. M.) entitled "What's In a Word," which, in striving to offer a few variations, succeeds mainly in being an awkward copy of other quizzes.

" SEX ON THE BAYOU" might be the subtitle for this genre work, a study of life and love (or loves) in the watery land of South Louisiana. For a variation on a theme that has provided the pattern for a number of earlier novels of the Cajun country.

LINCOLN, Neb. July 27 -- Two of Nebraska's top political nominations and the eventual leadership of the state's strong Republican forces will be at stake in the August 10 primaries. Vigorous campaigns are being waged.

DR. CAREY'S tomboy daughter, the plump and ever-hungry Rowena, changes roles this year. Impulsively abandoning her true love, baseball, for sailing, and her good friend, Doody McGuire, for the tolerant attention of a teen-age summer visitor.

SEATTLE, July 31 (AP) -- Don Cockell dreamed today of an early meeting with Rocky Marciano for the world heavyweight title after his fists -- with an assist from a slipped sacroiliac -- disposed of Harry (Kid) Matthews last night in the eighth stanza of a scheduled ten-round fight.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Today is the first anniversary of the service of William F. Knowland of California as the Republican leader of the Senate. He is now driving the chamber remorselessly so that the Eighty-third Congress can adjourn at some date reasonably near the original Aug. 1 "deadline."

PARIS, July 31 -- Within a week or so Premier Mendes-France will face a problem that his three predecessors successfully dodged -- the problem of rearming Western Germany within a European army or outside it.

MOSCOW, July 31 -- Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, today gave Russian athletics a clean bill of health as far as amateur status was concerned and said the United States would have to pay more attention to physical culture if it was to keep ahead of the Soviet Union.

THE American cataract of Niagara Falls shows a new face to the world now as the result of last week's cave-in of a segment of the brink and adjoining Prospect Point. But it may be months before visitors can get a close look.

CAP DE LA MADELEINE, Que., July 30 (Canadian Press) -- Work is going ahead feverishly on preparations for a ten-day Marian Congress, expected to attract more than 1,000,000 Roman Catholics to a humble shrine in this industrial community.

The diagnostic and medical facilities of Long Island Jewish Hospital, Glen Oaks, Queens, are now available to indigent residents of that borough and Nassau County, Saul L. Epstein, president of the new $7,000,000 hospital, announced yesterday.
ALBANY, July 31 (AP) -- Roy Cohn and Pvt. G. David Schine flew here today from New York and left immediately by auto, presumably for the Schine summer home at Caroga Lake, near Gloversville.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Senate Republicans resumed today their concerted effort to prevent censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, but were confronted with a bill of particulars that strengthened the anti-McCarthy forces.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., July 31 -- About sixty Americans spent the day here trying to figure out just what they would do if they were a collective Secretary of State.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., July 31 -- The United States clinched its American Zone semi-finals of Davis Cup tennis play today when Straight Clark of Pasadena, Calif., and Hal Burrows of Charlottesville, Va., defeated Reinaldo and Orlando Garrido of Cuba, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3.

NEW DELHI, July 31 -- India's iron and manganese mining industries are in a crisis following a slump in overseas demand. The principal ore-producing centers have closed down and close to 100,000 workers have been dismissed.

THE ninth volume of the monumental Princeton edition of the papers of Thomas Jefferson covers nearly eight months in the years 1785 and 1786, while he was Minister to France. During almost a fourth of the time he was visiting in England, for the first and only time in his life.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- In a shift of previously announced plans, the Senate Majority Leader, William F. Knowland, Republican of California, said today three anti-Communist bills would be called up after action action on farm measures.

MONTICELLO, Utah, July 31 -- Motor caravans staffed by United States Public Health Service doctors and technicians are criss-crossing the upland desert country of four Western states, conducting research vital to the continued growth of the nation's atomic energy and defense program.
The Seamen's Bank for Savings, which for the last 100 years has liberally sprinkled its counting houses with salty accessories, has a new exhibit that should appeal to sea-conscious New Yorkers.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 31 -- Lloyd D. Ribner of the home club won the thirty-fifth annual Westchester County Golf Association amateur championship today by turning back Howard Miller 3d of Wykagyl, 3 and 2, on the Metropolis links.

IN "Speaking of Books," DeLancey Ferguson, commenting on Kipling's short stories wrote "they (Somerset Maugham and I) almost join ranks in their opinions of Kipling's stories of the supernatural. Maugham wholeheartedly praises 'The Finest Story in the World,' 'Wireless,' and 'They'; Liebling is not sold on those three."
American Airlines, the nation's largest airline, was able yesterday to operate only thirty-two flights because of a strike of its 1,200 pilots. Today the carrier will not fly at all.
Two Bayonne, N. J., men were injured fatally yesterday afternoon when their small, single-engine plane crashed into marshland off Staten Island Airport.
LAST February the management of the Florence Music Festival wrote to ask if I would care to sing Minnie in its revival of Puccini's "La Fanciulla Del West." I cabled that I would be delighted.

The first published comprehensive official report on Soviet economic performance in 1954 indicates that heavy industry, the basis of the nation's military might, will again set new production records this year.

TO W. B. Yeats the poetry of Oliver St. John Gogarty was "heroic song," and Gogarty himself "one of the great lyric poets of our age." A. E. spoke of "his beauty and mystery achieved by precision." Readers of Gogarty's "Collected Poems" will find them even more important and beautiful than they seemed to his fellow poets of some years ago, because their qualities of clarity and lyric grace are rarer now.

AT 73, Padraic Colum has published his book of flowers, thirty-six lyrics in loosely traditional and even more loosely rhymed verses, singing the beauties of the garden and of simplicity. From the start, Colum has made his career in simplicity.

Edgar W. Stewart is a business man who says that after more than forty years he still isn't interested in trying to sell out at the top. At sixty-two, he wants to see whether his twenty-two-year-old twin sons, now in the Army, will have under stress the "stuff" that he had when the going got tough.

The privately owned American-flag dry-cargo and passenger fleet was still on the downgrade at the half-year mark, the American Merchant Marine Institute reported yesterday. Active passenger shipping flying American colors today can carry little more than one-fifth as many passengers as the national fleet could handle fifteen years ago.

As the current session of Congress draws to a close the American Indians, our oldest, most basic national minority, are again confronted by still further assaults cloaked in the guise of "emancipation," "liberation" and "equality."

The nation's banks, the Federal Treasury and the Federal Reserve System are in the midst of a great month-end money swirl whose currents are sweeping hundreds of millions of dollars around as the surf does bathers on a summer beach.

An industry that has been in the doldrums since the early 1920's is again coming to life. It is the manufacture of dress forms used by housewives and dressmakers for sewing. The business is profiting from the do-it-yourself trend, as well as an aggressive ad campaign by the oldest company in the business, the Acme Dress Form Company of Brooklyn.

PHENIX CITY, Ala., July 31 (UP) -- The Mayor of this vice town was jailed today and the entire county slate of Democratic nominees was voided in an unprecedented action by the state party Executive Committee.

The Voice of America said yesterday that it was "doing more with fewer people for less money" since it was transferred from the State Department to the United States Information Agency a year ago today.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sunday, Aug. 1 -- The French High Command here was authoritatively reported yesterday to have agreed to turn over to Vietnam oprational command of the Vietnamese National Army below the line dividing the Vietminh in the north from the French Union in the south.

AN encouraging note at the start of this book might read: Any resemblance between these stories and education is purely coincidental. True, the reader is sure to learn about the New Kingdom in Egypt, but that is because the background is so integral a part of the stories; the people behave as they do because of their background, and because they are human.
SEOUL, Korea, July 31 -- While President Syngman Rhee stated his case in Washington this week, life went on here much as usual in the capital city of South Korea.

PARIS, July 31 -- North Atlantic Treaty Organization leaders have discerned a tendency to let down in the defense effort and a growing belief that the West can rely on negotiation instead of strength.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Organized labor is now impressing upon the working man's wife that her place is in politics.
In a press conference last November, President Eisenhower succinctly set forth his views on the dual role of the President -- as head of a Government and as leader of a party. He said:

ANY impression that Robert Fryer and Lawrence Carr were merely dabbling with the notion of having a musical version made for Broadway of the Oscar-winning film "Casablanca" is to be immediately put away in mothballs.

THE continuing incongruity of the scarcity of photographic galleries in this biggest city in the country, the center of American photographic activity, is pointed up again as the fall season approaches.

WATER, water, water is the never-ending need of birds during the summer, and the thoughtful gardener would keep this in mind. The birds that visit my back yard, however, are probably spoiled. For I not only supply two bird baths but food as well, and so the birds feel welcome to visit the garden regardless of the bounties nature has set before them.

I FOUND Kermit Hunter's article, "Outdoor Dramas," in your section on July 18, extremely interesting. I agree that much of "the American theatre" is found in community drama groups and in colleges and universities throughout the country.

SPAIN has begun to issue piecemeal a nine-stamp series commemorating the Marian Year and the Centenary of the Dogma of the Immaculate Conception. Each stamp will show a different image of the Virgin Mary.
HARTFORD, July 31 -- Connecticut Democrats held Congressional nominating conventions today to complete their slate of nominees for the United States House of Representatives.
The man who played a major part in making the grocery store coupon pretty nearly as important as money told the other day how the coupon got that way and what it could do that money couldn't.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) -- Senators investigating the Army-McCarthy dispute have been supplied with seven bulky volumes digesting and classifying the evidence heard during thirty-six days of stormy televised hearings.

BONN, Germany, July 31 -- Twenty-two of West Germany's leading industrialists have agreed to support the Federal Government's so-called anti-cartel bill. They have received assurances that the cartels they are interested in will not be prohibited and will not be subject to the law.

AT the present moment a new interest is being taken in history. The taste of readers seems, to some extent at least, to be turning from fiction to non-fiction, especially historical works and biographies. There is curiosity as to how such works are planned and written, the public has become interested in research and today the historian receives a fan mail of respectable proportions.
A supply of cheap power through atomic energy could start a modern revolution that could ease poverty in India, one of Asia's leading physicists predicts.
WHEN the family moves to seashore or lakeside for the summer it finds available an abundance of fish fresh from the water. One way to take advantage of this thrifty, tempting supply is in a stew.

The last of the Saratoga-on-the-L. I. R. R. racing shows was run at Jamaica yesterday, and the feature was the $27,650 Merchants' and Citizens' Handicap. It was won by the Brookmeade Stable's Capeador, the $4.90-for-$2 favorite.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, senior Republican Senator from Wisconsin, roamed the Senate floor today making certain that those who spoke in debate on the proposal to censure Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, made it clear they were speaking of the "junior Senator from Wisconsin."

" A FABLE" will strike many readers as a new departure for William Faulkner in subject, structure and setting. The novel is set in France during World War I at a time when private soldiers of both sides, ready to lay down their arms and fraternize in common humanity between the Allied and the German wire, must be forced back into hatred by their high commands.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M. -- The Southwest finds itself, as summer moves along, on the business end of a paradox -- to get tourists to stay longer, you have to make it easier for them to hasten on. Or to put it another way -- poor roads, instead of slowing travelers down, seem to impel them to step on the gas to get where there are good roads.
JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., July 31 -- Missouri's dullest primary campaign in many years closed tonight with indications that an unusually light vote will be cast in the election Tuesday.
PRINCETON, N. J., July 31 -- The World Presbyterian Alliance charged here today that the Roman Catholic Church in Colombia had reduced Protestantism in that nation to a "ghetto existence."

HAVING finished the Italian-made "Mambo," Robert Rossen checked into town last week for final distribution huddles with United Artists on "Alexander the Great," which the writer-producer-director will place before the cameras overseas "in several weeks."

GENEVA, July 30 -- The United Nations is trying to figure out how to tell whether its technical assistance work in underdeveloped areas does or does not do what it is supposed to: contribute to economic and social development.

AN open mind, interest in people and comfortable old clothes and shoes are the only prerequisites for travel by bus, the best way to see more than the monuments of a foreign country. The only thing that remains is to find the bus.

INTO the great, white, towering cylinders of the grain elevators -- "the skyscrapers of the prairies" -- there is now pouring a torrent of grain. Truckloads, carloads, tons, bushels of the produce of the fertile land flow steadily and relentlessly into storage. Of wheat alone, the headlines in the Kansas papers say such things as: "Bins Spill Over" and "Thousands of Box Cars Filled With Harvest Yield Jam Terminals Here."
GOSHEN, N. Y., July 31 (AP) -- Twenty or more of the fastest 3-year-old trotters in the land are expected to go to the post at Good Time Park Wednesday in the twenty-eighth Hambletonian Stake.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Following is the McCarthy issue before the Senate as stated by the censure resolution of Senator Ralph E. Flanders, the texts of proposed substitutes offered by Senators H. Alexander Smith and Prescott Bush and a "bill of particulars" offered as amendments to the Flanders resolution by Senator J. William Fulbright:

MOSCOW, July 27 -- Jet aircraft on training flights are a frequent sight over the Volga and Ukrainian cities. An equally frequent sight both in the cities and in the countryside is that of plodding ox-carts.

In its latest semi-annual report the Atomic Energy Commission gives us the benefit of what it calls "our preliminary thinking and speculation on the probable pattern of industrial development and economic benefits that atomic power plants must face." Some of this preliminary thinking and speculation was presented in June by Chairman Strauss of the commission in a statement filed with the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy.

In your picture feature, "Eight Key Ambassadors" (July 11), you included Sadao Iguchi, the Japanese Ambassador who, your caption said, "respects Japanese traditions, as exemplified by the centuries-old water-color in the background. * * *"
New light on the elasticity of Communist statistics was supplied yesterday by the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.

GUATEMALA, July 31 -- The President or Guatemala's Junta, Col. Carlos Castillo Armas, said today that his Government, faced with the country's economic needs, is willing to accept economic assistance offered by other countries, especially the United States.

WHEN Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, acquired an apartment in New York City's East Seventies, he planned the decoration and selected the furnishings himself. This is not surprising, since Mr. Hammarskjold comes from Scandinavia, a section of the world where knowledge of the decorative arts and crafts is considered essential in the education of a man of culture.

NEW DELHI, India, July 31 -- The only non-Congress leftist Government in India, which has been functioning in the southern state of Travancore-Cochin, has been defeated, the All-India Radio reported tonight.

ROME, July 31 -- The Government's European Defense Community treaty ratification bill was made ready for debate on the floor of the Chamber of Deputies when it was approved by the Foreign Affairs Committee today.
The national commander of the American Legion, Arthur J. Connell, exhorted legionnaires yesterday to "fight" the American Medical Association's "anti-veteran crusade."
CHICAGO, July 31 (UP) -- The Chicago White Sox turned four singles into four runs in the first inning today and went on to defeat the last-place Philadelphia Athletics, 7 to 1, before 4,581 fans.

The United States contribution of $17,958,000 to the United Nations technical assistance program, which was cut out of a House appropriation bill last week, seems certain to remain in the Senate Foreign Aid Authorization bill. It will probably also appear in the subsequent appropriation bill.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- A new golfing award, the President Eisenhower Trophy, will be at stake here in September as part of the $40,000 National Celebrities tournament.

NEWARK, July 31 -- In its seventh legal proceeding in four years, including one in the United States Supreme Court, the New Jersey and New York Railroad Company tried again this week to establish its right to discontinue old 613, a commuter train between Jersey City and Spring Valley, N. Y.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- A wind tunnel especially designed for heat transfer studies just below the speed of sound will be constructed at Illinois Institute of Technology here under an Air Force research contract.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., July 31 (AP) -- Two former boys champions, Jerry Moss, Modesto, Calif., and Mike Green, Miami Beach, Fla., will meet tomorrow in the junior singles final of the national junior and boys' tennis tournament.

THE disappointing character of Kenneth Patchen's work, considered as a whole, is in the degree it fails to fulfill its promise. Patchen is a "natural" poet in the sense that Frank Kovacs was a "natural" tennis player -- neither has to try very hard to look good and much, much too often both look terrible.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Senator Morse said tonight Senator McCarthy should be censured by the Senate on seven specific grounds.

MONTAUK POINT, L. I., July 31 -- Fishing for the big fish and the fighting fish of the sea is an ever-changing and interesting game. For fish are ornery critters. Just when you think you have found the right lure and the right place to catch them they go off to other grounds and refuse to have anything to do with the bait that had them swarming around your boat only yesterday.

World shipbuilding was highlighted the first half of this year by the delivery of a quintet of "big ones," led by the 60,000-deadweight ton Ore Chief, the largest vessel ever constructed for the transportation of cargo.
PITTSBURGH, July 31 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates, spurred by homers from the bats of Sid Gordon and Toby Atwell, rallied to defeat the Chicago Cubs, 5 -- 3, today.
The City Island Yacht Club yesterday re-staged its annual regatta, which produced no finishers when attempted on June 19.

IT is difficult to establish grass on a sunny bank, but it is almost impossible to do so on a shaded one. The shade also outlaws the use of flowering, sun-loving plants like the trailing roses as a groundcover. It is a question of finding plants that will hold the soil as well as thrive in the shade.

MANHASSET, L. I., July 31 -- Malcolm Oliver Brewer, 44-year-old business executive, was killed by electricity today while installing an exhaust fan in the attic of his new $40,000 home at 266 Thompson Shore Drive.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Workman's compensation laws, particularly in New York State, have given rise to a remarkable experiment by the United States Public Health Service -- tests of the effect of industrial noise on inmates of four Federal prisons.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Senator M. Alexander Smith told the Senate today that Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation J. Edgar Hoover had both praise and criticism for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.
ST. PAUL, Minn., July 31 -- More than 100 candidates for State and Congressional offices have filed for Minnesota's Sept. 14 primary election.
TRENTON, July 31 -- Four Jersey heifers and one bull calf are making a trip by train and ship of almost 8,000 miles from New Jersey to Japan.

HANOI, Vietnam, July 31 (AP) -- A "battle of flags" has broken out in the Red River delta. It is part of a growing struggle for the loyalty of Vietnamese who, under the Geneva agreement, can choose Communist-led Vietminh rule or evacuation to the south.
President Syngman Rhee of South Korea said here yesterday that because of the "shortsighted" United States policy his army was incapable of unifying Korea by force of arms.
Two firemen were killed and at least nine injured late last night when two fire trucks, one returning from a false alarm, collided in Queens.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 31 -- A unique promise by a contestant to protest the race committee, a finishing buoy that sank out of sight, a race by the committee boat to reach the line ahead of the first finisher and a southerly that piped up to thirty knots gave spice to today's Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta.

A joint statement deploring the military threats by President Anastasio Somoza of Nicaragua against Costa Rica is being processed by the American Federation of Labor, the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the United Mine Workers of America.
DUBLIN, July 31 (AP) -- American athletes cracked two Irish records and equaled a third at the Clonliffe international track and field meet today. It was the first European stop for the Americans.

BUENOS AIRES, July 31 -- With an almost complete lack of publicity in the controlled press, President Juan D. Peron has begun a major campaign against the Communists, according to the latest issue of the party newspaper Nuestra Palabra (our word).

IT is now forty years since the outbreak of the first World War. The assassination of a Hapsburg Archduke in a Slav province gave the signal; the Austrian ultimatum to Serbia which followed began the series of international menaces; the German General Staff launched the war.

ALGIERS, Algeria, July 23 -- The Jewish community in Tunisia has, over the past three years, obtained for itself a framework of basic social services unlike anything previously known in this part of the world.

A FELICITOUS combination of collaborators produced this treasure of old folk tales from France. The original authors, poet-peasants, perhaps of troubadour stock, composed them with "malice, freshness and sparkle"; generations of listeners in farms, castles, priories and convents, handed them on "from everywhere, for everyone."
MY attention has been drawn to a letter, published in the Book Review, about a suggested error in my book "The Man Who Never Was."
LONDON, July 31 -- A 120-man squad of Scotland Yard men late tonight searched the Polish freighter Jaroslaw Dabrowski and removed a Polish stowaway, Antoni Klimowicz.
TOKYO, July 31 -- Japan will offer the United States $450,000,000 in repayment of occupation loans and credits of about $2,000,000,000 according to reports current here today.

JONES BEACH, L. I. -- On Wednesday Jones Beach will be twenty-five years old, having confounded in its quarter of a century the critics who, in the teeth of a howling sandstorm at the opening ceremony, predicted that few people would ever visit the place. On July 18 last year the state park was visited by 184,700 persons, the largest crowd in its history.

A GREAT deal has been heard recently in praise of free inquiry in institutions of higher learning. It seems to me -- working at the bottom of the educational scale, the nursery school -- that the spirit of free inquiry manifests itself concretely among very young children.

Lawrence Fertig of Great Neck, L. I., and Albert Schoenfield of New York won the final doubles match to enable the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association to score a 5-4 triumph over the Middle States Association at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday.
I AM most heartily in accord with your lamentations for the TV fare we are being offered this summer. It is stupid, banal, aggravating and a waste of money and time.

Today is Switzerland's Independence Day. It marks the founding of the Alpine nation in an "Everlasting League" formed by men from three of its valleys on Aug. 1, 1291. This covenant was "for self-defense against all who should attack or trouble them."
The man who piloted labor relations for the giant Consolidated Edison System through seventeen strike-free years is convinced that most companies can get along well with unions if they want to.

The Hospital for Joint Diseases, 1919 Madison Avenue, treated 5,567 bed patients in the main building and sixty-three patients in the country home at Far Rockaway, according to the 1953 report of Raphael B. Malsin, president of the hospital. The patients received 101,752 days of hospital care.

SAN JUAN, P. R., July 31 -- Puerto Rico has been both lifting its people's incomes and narrowing the gap between rich and poor. But it still has a long way to go to the $1,500 minium goal for 90 per cent of its families set for 1960 by Governor Luis Munoz Marin.

ALMOST $500,000 worth of motor vehicles is on the way to the Republic of South Korea to help put that country on wheels. All the vehicles, ready to take to the road, were donated by automotive and bus companies in the United States and comprise the first quota of this type of transportation under the aid program of the American-Korean Foundation, 345 East Forty-sixth Street.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 31 -- An investigation team of the American and Tennessee Medical Associations has reported conditions of medical poverty in Clear Fork Valley, near the Tennessee-Kentucky coal-mining border region.

The shrill sibilance of the cicada, insistent but almost drowsy, is the obvious theme song of August, characteristic as the smell of corn pollen and the yellow flare of squash blossoms. For August is the purpose that inspired April and May; August is fruition, ear on the corn stalk, pod on the bean vine, ripe head on the oat, flush on the early apple, fledgling on the wing, the young rabbit foraging all day long.
MONTREAL, July 31 -- Canada's deep-sea merchant marine, once the fourth largest in the world, has dwindled almost to the vanishing point.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 31 -- More than 150 persons are reported to have perished in the worst floods in recent Iranian history.

Heat-weary New Yorkers suffered through the hottest day of the year yesterday as the temperature reached 96.3 degrees in the late afternoon. It was the fifth successive day with the mercury near 90 or above, but the Weather Bureau promised a break in the hot spell by tonight.

WHO gains by time -- Soviet Russia or the United States? Is Spengler's "Decline of the West" prophetic: does Toynbee's "time of troubles" -- the era in which we are living -- foretell the doom of our civilization ?

A nation-wide study to determine how best to safeguard the health of teachers was proposed last week by Dr. Jacob Greenberg, deputy superintendent of the New York City school system. Dr. Greenberg urged that the study be undertaken by psychiatrists, social workers and welfare agencies as well as teacher organizations to see how best to overcome the tensions under which many teachers operate.
More patients were admitted to New York Hospital last year than ever before, but they spent an average of 1.2 fewer days there than patients did in 1950.

THE first part of a triple bill offered by the opera department of the Berkshire Music Centre last Tuesday night was a mimed version of a score celebrated in music history, but honored more often in the breach than in the observance, where performance is concerned.

WEST SAYVILLE, L. I., July 31 -- A series of biological, chemical and hydrographical tests to determine the reasons for recent improvement in the condition of the waters of Great South Bay was completed here today.

FOR many years musicians have been fighting the competition of what they term "canned music." A survey of recent recordings featuring the spoken word suggests that sometime in the future professors might be banding together to fight "canned lectures," or authors "canned books."
The temperature last week was only slightly higher than a year ago, but the humidity kept customers from the stores. After starting the week at an encouraging pace business sloughed on Thursday.
FRANKFURT, Germany, July 25 -- Quietly, and often secretly, Germany's old student dueling societies have been regaining their prewar strength. Their protagonists say they will soon exceed it.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 31 -- President Carlos Ibanez has set up a consultative commission to study changes in the Constitution. He said that the democratic base would not be weakened but that important modifications must be introduced to strengthen the President's powers in running the country's affairs, without what he termed the retarding influence exercised by Congress.

With the state nominating conventions scheduled by law to convene seven weeks from Thursday, uncertainty exists in both major parties as to who will head the respective slates. The field of potential Governors has narrowed, however, in the last few weeks.

FOR the best part of a quarter century, the Four-Minute-Mile stood as sport's Mount Everest, a beckoning objective which remained defiantly impregnable. One expedition after another faltered at the base of the final peak, unable to push all the way to the summit. Then, Roger Bannister of Great Britain made it. On May 6, the 25-year-old London medical student ran an electrifying 3:59.4 mile.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee cleared today for floor action a $2,015,771,000 supplemental money bill, including almost a billion dollars for military construction.

THE powerful Chamber of Commerce of Houston, employing the accepted gadgets of the honest statistician, figures that on July 3 the so-called metropolitan area of Houston reached the 1,000,000 population mark. The event was duly observed, though with little excitement, and the city now turns its attention to gaining its second million -- much easier, say the experts, than the first.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 30 -- Chile's decision to open oil exploration and exploitation to foreign capital is rapidly becoming a political issue.

AARHUS, Denmark -- Second cities in the Scandinavian countries have a relatively difficult time making themselves known to foreigners. Bergen, Norway, has made some progress; Gothenberg, Sweden, has begun to blow its horn, but Aarhus is still overshadowed by the irresistible popularity of Copenhagen.
Borough President John Cashmore told Mayor Wagner in his annual report yesterday that Brooklyn was booming from expanding industrial activity even though there had been an economic recession.

Bursting at the seams in a narrow, ten-story building on Manhattan's Fifteenth Street is a thriving company whose operations illustrate how complex the job of the chemical consultant has become in modern society.

INDUSTRIAL activity in July was sustained by the heavy rate of building construction and consumer-buying at the retail level. A slight let-up in inventory - contraction policies by manufacturers and wholesalers helped the general situation.

DETROIT, July 31 -- Fewer than 25 per cent of Michigan's 3,825,000 registered voters are expected to cast their ballots Tuesday in selection of Republican and Democratic candidates for the two top places on the state ticket, for one United States Senate seat and for eighteen seats in the House of Representatives.

SEOUL, Korea, July 30 -- South Korea's agricultural crisis, which has been kept in the background for several years by military manpower demands and economic rehabilitation programs, came into the open this week.
WHITESBURG, Ky., July 31 -- Eleven persons, seven of them children, died today when the auto in which they were riding struck a cliff near this community.
JOSE LIMON and Dance Company will be featured in the seventh American Dance Festival at Connecticut College, New London, Conn., which opens Thursday, Aug. 19, and ends Sunday, Aug. 22.

LONDON, July 31 -- From the Communist standpoint a true Bolshevik is always on the attack, undeterred by failure, unsatisfied by success. The present Russian campaign to arrange a European conference on security shows how this tactical principle continues to guide the foreign policy of the Soviet Union. The Russians have begun another diplomatic offensive.

Twenty-three new arrests were made in the Times Square area last night and early today as the police offensive against undesirables in the city's amusement district went into its second round. In the first series of raids, which be gan Friday night, more than one hundred persons were caught in the police net and fifty-eight of them were booked on disorderly conduct charges.

HERE is another chatty account of the life of Mamie Eisenhower from the time she was born in Boone, Iowa, until she became First Lady. Alden Hatch brings to his readers a lot of fresh material about Mamie's early years and the background of both her parents' families.

American pigeons will give a heroine's welcome today to Leaping Lena, German carrier pigeon who hedge-hopped Soviet censors to carry an anti-Kremlin message through the Iron Curtain, the Crusade for Freedom announced yesterday.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland -- The very name of Iceland sounds like a glacial rock out in the North Atlantic, no place for a tourist and out of the way at that. But Iceland should be seen and not heard. It has a good climate, striking scenery and excellent fishing. And it is on the shortest air route to Europe, making it convenient to reach and an excellent stop-over point on the way to the Continent.

VANCOUVER, B. C., July 31 -- Australia's mighty British Empire Games team met surprising competition from Canadian and West Indies athletes today as the fifth edition of the Games opened with a flurry of broken records and upset finishes.

When a large plant shuts down and moves its operations to some other place the hardships are great -- for those who lose their jobs and also for the community in which they have been accustomed to spend their income. Several recent near-by cases have dramatized this situation.

The danger to the United States and to the Grand Coalition of the West of the unification of Asia under the Communist aegis which was forecast by the triumph of communism in Indochina was emphasized last week by the tension in the South China Sea.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- President Rhee of South Korea left Washington for New York this morning, a very tired, very old and very disillusioned man. He got everything here but what he wanted: a gaudy bunk at Blair House, a glittering dinner at the White House and an audience of the whole Congress.

CAIRO, July 31 -- Britain's agreement this week to withdraw her military forces from the Suez Canal zone, keystone of Western defense in two world wars, caused profound political and diplomatic reverberations in Britain and Egypt.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- The credit situation in the Chicago area showed improvement during the three months ended May 31, but collections are still slower than in the same period last year, the Chicago Association of Credit Men survey indicated.

KANSAS CITY, July 31 (AP) -- Gene Littler of Palm Springs, Calif., shot a sizzling eight-under-par 65 and Wally Ulrich a 67 to tie for the third-round lead in the $20,000 Kansas City open golf tournament today.

I wish to commend the New York Times, and especially A. H. Raskin, for the thoughtful and informative article, "Public Welfare Issue in Strikes Is Weighed," recently published in the "News of the Week" section.

ROME, July 31 -- Pope Pius XII drove just before sunset this evening to his summer residence of Castel Gandolfo, about fifteen miles southeast of Rome, where he is expected to stay the next three or four months.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Conference on Economic Progress proposed today a program of further Government spending, income tax reduction, and other measures to achieve full employment and full production.
Rarely has progress in the development of a metal been watched with as much impatience as is being displayed toward today's intensive research on titanium.

Since the February day in 1950 when Senator Joseph R. McCarthy stood before an audience in Wheeling, W. Va., and said, "I hold here in my hand a list of * * * Communists * * * who are known to the Secretary of State * * *," the Senate as a whole has tried to avoid taking a position on the McCarthy issue.
NEWARK, July 31 -- The sale of wine in New Jersey set a new record in the fiscal year ending June 30 and liquor and beer sales maintained the level of last year.

THE other morning I received a letter in which a friend wrote: "Our time is not an avant-garde time, it's a 'keep your shirt on time, it's a cautious time, a serious time, a non-brittle time, and a profoundly disturbed and as a result conservative time."

WHEN Columbus reached Cuba in 1492 he immediately found the real treasure of the New World. Understandably, however, his preoccupation with the spices and precious metals of the Indies caused him to give maize or Indian corn only a passing glance.

TRENTON, July 31 -- The New Jersey Legislature will return Monday for a midsummer meeting at which it is expected to sanction a $200,000 emergency appropriation ot cover the cost of the state's investigation into the finacial manipulations of former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman.

POISON ivy has few peers when it comes to marring a vacation or menacing the pleasure of gardening. But, fortunately, poisoning by this plant can be prevented in two simple ways -- learning to recognize it (and thereby avoiding it) and eradicating it.
John Q. Public is the hero in the recovery from the business setback, in the eyes of retailers.

THE faint whisper some five years ago that the story of the crimes against the workmen of our wharves was to be filmed, gradually grew to what amounted to a tumult of tub-thumping and was climaxed last week by the opening of "On the Waterfront."

RICHMOND, July 31 -- The Fifth District's important hosiery mills report the industry in better shape than in several years. Many mills are on a full work schedule and some deferred their usual summer vacations because of the pressure of orders.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., July 31 -- More than 200 members of Army Reserve units from New York City will "occupy" Syracuse, Utica, Rome and Oneida next Tuesday and Wednesday in a Military Government field problem.

The enthusiasm with which cruising yachtsmen have been plying their pleasure this summer is reflected in the entries for the New York Yacht Club's annual cruise. Seventy-seven owners have listed their boats for the event that will begin making up at New London, Conn., today.

FOR the past twenty years Art Tatum has been playing his particular brand of jazz piano with amazing consistency. Generally recognized as one of the outstanding performers in the jazz world, he has not suffered the creatively lean periods which have afflicted such of his peers as Louis Armstrong or Duke Ellington nor, on the other hand, has he enjoyed the sudden flushes of creative fertility which have marked their careers.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- A sweeping new military manpower plan, aimed at military duty for "all qualified young men" followed by compulsory service in a new reserve set-up, has been approved by the Eisenhower Administration, it was disclosed today.
CLEVELAND, July 31 -- Bob Lemon pitched a three-hit shutout today and Larry Doby and Al Rosen contributed home runs in leading the Cleveland Indians to a 6-0 victory over the Washington Senators.
The future for teachers in the United States is bright, according to the latest report prepared by the University of Wisconsin Teacher Placement Bureau.

The old law of supply and demand is being distorted by industry. By gearing production to meet demand at a predetermined price level, the supply factor is being emphasized. This has caused a change in the pattern of determining prices.

I SUPPOSE Mr. Joyce had some idea in mind when he gave his book the title of "A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man." But the critics seem to want it their own way and say, "Mr. Joyce paints the Irishman as he really is." . . . Irishman, doctor, lawyer, merchant, chief, I suppose.

Dr. Vannevar Bush, president of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, D. C., announces that the Carnegie Corporation has awarded $250,000 to Australia for the construction in three years of a radio telescope 250 feet in diameter. A similar radio "eye" or "dish" (so-called because of its parabolic shape) 250 feet in diameter and 62.5 feet deep at the focus is nearing completion at Jodrel Bank, England.

Premier Mendes-France has again acted with political courage and commendable speed in taking hold of France's thorny Tunisian problem. First he won a sharp struggle in his own Cabinet and was empowered by them to make a broad offer of internal autonomy to the Tunisians.
John M. Leavens, executive director of the Citizens Budget Commission, charged last week that 2,300 provisional employes of the city were holding their jobs illegally.
