LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 31 -- A listless air covers the approaches to the Aug. 7 primaries in most of Kentucky -- with the exception of the mountainous Eighth Congressional District.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 31 -- Punkin Vine, the longest priced horse in the race, made a thrilling finish to beat the favored Errard King in the $31,450 Choice Stakes at the Monmouth Park track today.

A BASIC course in photographic technology will be taught at Columbia University School of Engineering, Graphics Department, this winter by Lloyd E. Varden in addition to the course in advanced technology which he has given for the past several years.

THE elephant herd was on the move, one by one, two by two, soft as a breeze on a jungle night, walking along toward where elephants go. But Miriam Schlein tells, in her sometimes beautiful and always charming poetic prose, of two little milk tuskers who decide, instead, to be a herd of their own -- like the big, lone bull.

TUNIS, Tunisia, July 31 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France flew here today, walked through a corridor of troops into the palace of the Bey of Tunis and told him that internal sovereignty was his for the asking. He warned, however, that Tunisians had better quit shooting at Frenchmen.

PERCHED on a spectacular site, where a miniature ravine runs out onto a rough-fringed beach, and cradled all round by sky, sea, rock-face and stony vegetation, the new Museum of Art of Ogunquit seems to have alighted with some of the precarious stability of a sea gull.

THE acquisition of the Stellfeld Music Library by the University of Michigan for $100,000 is a coup for American music just as it is a saddening event for Belgium which made a last-minute, vain effort to keep the collection.

Sal Maglie and Marv Grissom combined on a four-hit shutout yesterday as the reawakened Giants defeated the Redlegs for the second day in a row, 7 -- 0, to draw four games in front of the second-place Dodgers.
PHILADELPHIA, July 31 -- Delegates and guests began arriving here today for the fifty-fifth national encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, opening tomorrow in Municipal Auditorium.

DEVOTEES of the bull-wrestling and whisky-drinking brand of small-town humor -- especially if they live in Danville, Ky. -- are going to be amused by this nostalgic account of one summer in the life of a 9-year-old boy, Harold Hines Jr.

A new infection resembling polio but distinct from it broke out in Iceland in 1948-49. Dr. D. Naldrett White of Queen's University, Kingston, Ont., and Dr. Robert B. Burtch of the Edward John Noble Hospital, Alexandria Bay, N. Y., have described in Neurology an epidemic of the same disease that occurred in the late summer of 1950, particularly in the northern area of New York State and across the line in Canada.

As inventories of summer goods shrink stores are beginning to press for deliveries of fall merchandise, resident buying offices report. Shipments on medium and better priced merchandise have already started.

OSLO, Norway, July 31 (AP) -- Public disinterest in American "super movies" has forced the Norwegian Municipal Cinema Association to cancel its agreements with United States film distributing companies, it was reported in movie circles here.

EASTERNERS who spend vacations in the West return with stirring visions of roiling prairies and sagebrush, fantastic Joshua trees and acres of succulents and cacti blooming after a sudden rain. Unfortunately such vistas must largely remain memories -- but there are exceptions.

Floyd Patterson of Brooklyn, beaten in his last start by the former light-heavyweight champion Joey Maxim, will oppose Tommy Harrison, Los Angeles heavyweight, in an eight-round bout at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Dr. Henry DeWolf Smyth, senior member of the Atomic Energy Commission, does not plan to resign now and any possible resignation "will be a long time away," a source close to the family said today.

BOSTON, July 31 -- Dr. Ruth Azniv Parmelee, who retired this month as a Congressional Christian medical missionary after forty years of service in the Near East, has received the Cross of Commander of the Royal Order of Beneficence from King Paul of Greece, for service to the people of Greece.

THE argument over the role of the submarine in war continues but there is no gainsaying that the very existence of submarines holds fascination for most people. They are mysterious and perilous vessels to most laymen.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The real test of the atomic energy bill centers in one big question: How much money is private enterprise willing to risk in the promise of atomic power?
SCENERY or stage setting? To most people, even to the professional of the theatre, this is one and the same thing. Yet, there is a difference.

PARIS, July 31 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France, in a broadcast tonight from Tunis over the French national circuit, appealed to the French and the Tunisians to accept his proposals and to bury their differences in newfound friendship.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Following are excerpts from the Senate debate today on the resolution of Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, to censure Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin:

A letter from Arthur Hunter, published in The Times of July 18 and relating to the monument erected by the St. Andrew's Society in 1806 on the site of the Hamilton-Burr duel in Weehawken, N. J., has just come to my attention.

THE reader will know by now that William Faulkner's new big novel is out on the street. (See Page 1 if you don't.) Our critic has said his say, and it is neither our province nor our desire to muscle in on that side of the thoroughfare, wide and deep and beckoning as it is.

ARCHITECTS have for some time been aware of the importance of placing a house so that it gets all the sunshine possible through the greater part of the year. But the landscape profession has lagged a bit in providing and placing trees for shading these homes through the hot summer months.

Many recent improvements in teaching in rural and semi-rural public schools in New York State are the result of "Central Ideas," a publication prepared quarterly by the Central School Boards Committee for Educational Research. The committee is affiliated with the Institute of Administrative Research of Teachers College, Columbia University.
LONDON, July 31 (AP) -- Queen Elizabeth is making her horse racing hobby pay -- to the tune of 35,800 pounds ($100,240) since March 22.
BONN, Germany, July 31 -- More and more West German unions were reported today to have joined the campaign for a "new deal" in wages.

In his article, "'The Danger of a Severe Recession Seems Over'" (July 18), Sumner H. Slichter includes me among a "sizable minority" of "alarmists" or "pessimists" who voiced "fears that the recession [in 1954] would be severe."

ELIZABETH, N. J., July 31 -- Under an agreement with the Board of Public Works here, aimed to relieve traffic congestion, the Port of New York Authority will start revising next month the Elizabeth approaches of the Goethals Bridge linking this city and Staten Island.

AN excellent double feature of a book, "Reach for the Sky" provides, first, a picture of a man overcoming a physical handicap that confines ordinary mortals to a wheelchair. The second picture is of this same man as an R. A. F. pilot in the Battle of Britain.

Detectives arrested an investigator for the Department of Welfare yesterday on a charge of having extorted $25 from a Bronx house painter. The suspect was identified as Goode Clark, 41 years old, of 114-30 Inwood Street, South Ozone Park, Queens.
LAKE LOUISE, Alberta, July 31 (AP) -- Four Mexican mountaineers, three of them women, plunged yesterday close to the snow-capped summit of 10,500-foot Mount Victoria near here.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 31 -- Eddie Moylan, making a comeback after two years of tournament inactivity, upset Tony Trabert, America's top-ranked tennis player, 3 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 8 -- 6, to gain the final round of the sixty-fifth annual Meadow Club invitation tournament today.

BALTIMORE, July 31 -- A ninth-inning rally by the Baltimore Orioles fell short and the Yankees toppled the home club, 6 -- 5, before 12,557 fans at Memorial Stadium today. Johnny Sain, in his thirty-third relief appearance, saved Bob Grim's thirteenth triumph of the campaign.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31 -The first shipment of iron ore from the new 400,000,000-ton Quebec-Labrador mines is scheduled to arrive in Philadelphia Thursday aboard the Hawaiian of the American-Hawaiian Line.

CORNING, N. Y., July 31 -- Two taxpayer suits are seeking to have declared unconstitutional the state's 1952 enlarged city school district law and to overthrow its first major application -- the consolidation of sixty-two Corning area school districts.

TWENTY-SEVEN years ago, when Ole Rolvaag published his still remembered "Giants in the Earth," reviewers were able to describe it (without self-consciousness) as "earthy." Now, alas, that once fine word has been bludgeoned to death by over-use -- and a pity 'tis for if ever there was one, this is an earthy novel.

CLEVELAND, July 31 -- The port of Cleveland has ample facilities to handle any volume of freight that might be shipped here after completion of the St. Lawrence Seaway, according to Vernon Williams, president of the Cleveland Stevedore Company, which has just opened its fourth dock here.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- A twelve-man commission set up early this year to study salaries of this city's employes reported yesterday that Chicago and Detroit pay higher salaries to municipal employes than New York, Philadelphia and Los Angeles.
New York University has named Dr. Lyle Borst chairman of the Department of Physics of the College of Engineering.

ON trial for the murder of his wife. Jacques Dongeres surveyed the crowded Paris court with an amused air, as if the law was putting on a show for him. In a way it was, for though he had killed Marie, he felt no sense of guilt.
DEL MAR, Calif., July 31 (AP) -- Closing fast on the outside, Spring Count raced to a two-length victory over Domingo Kid in the $11,425 Oceanside Handicap today. The favored Lucky Martin was third.

Concerning Barbara Berch Jamison's "Amazing Scripts by Animals" (July 18) about Walt Disney's true-life films, it may be said that this type of film is not new. For instance, the sequence of mountain sheep ramming horns is spectacularly portrayed in a United States Department of Agriculture film entitled "Realm of the Wild."

CHORE FOE THE WEEK: In hot midsummer cut flowers for bouquets only in the early morning or the cool evening. Picked at any other time, they simply do not last, no matter how well conditioned. Use a knife for cutting. Strip foliage from all stems and thorns from roses, and plunge all flowers in a deep container of cool water for several hours.

To meet the expected enrollment increase during the coming decade, the four New York City colleges -- Hunter, City, Brooklyn and Queens -- have embarked upon a large expansion program. Plans are now under way for the construction of more than $38,000,000 worth of buildings and other facilities.
Joe Adcock, the Braves' first baseman, hit four home runs and a double at Ebbets Field yesterday to tie three major league records and establish two others.
The August calendar of events for the Summer Festival was announced yesterday.
A modern version of river boat gambling was broken up yesterday aboard the Peter Stuyvesant, a Hudson River Dayline craft operating between the city and Atlantic Highlands, N. J.

The golden-voiced Caruso in twenty rare recordings from 1904 to 1920 will be the sole performer tomorrow between noon and 2 P. M. at the Bryant Park concert of the New York Public Library. The third annual all-Caruso event at the library, the program will include "Deh, ch'io ritorno" from "L'Africana," recorded in 1920, but not released until 1933.

COMMERCIAL TV with a monocle has arrived. After a Niagara of words and scores of amendments in both houses of Parliament, royal assent was given last Friday to the television bill which creates an Independent Television Authority to compete with the B. B. C.

" Might have been" stories have always been popular with investment houses. Suppose, the reader is asked to imagine, he had sunk $30 in General Consolidated Amalgamated, Inc., in 1907. Suppose, he is asked to imagine again, he left instructions, that all proceeds were to be reinvested. And suppose he then went into a coma.

BONN, Germany, July 31 -- The crisis in public confidence caused by the defection to the Communists of Dr. Otto John, West Germany's erstwhile intelligence chief, is indicative of the extent to which the unresolved struggle of the German problem has sapped the political structure of this country.

IF a substantial fraction of the American electorate would incorporate into their mental furniture the ideas contained in this book, we should in ten to twenty years be well over the hump toward a solution of the present world tension.

FOR several years Pablo Casals' 'cello had been silent. Living in self-imposed exile in the village of Prades, France, he was separated from his native Spain by the massive Pyrenees, a barrier symbolic of his moral protest to the Franco regime.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Developing United States plans for the security of Southeast Asia are beginning to emphasize the need for economic as well as military safeguards against possible future Communist aggression.
THE biggest bridge tournament of the year is under way today in Washington, D. C., where the American Contract Bridge League is holding its twenty-sixth annual summer championships.

GENEVA, July 31 -- By agreeing to raise United States duties on imports of Swiss watches, President Eisenhower convinced Western Europe that the United States, or at least the Republican party, has learned nothing about the facts of international economic life in the last twenty-five years.

THE primary value of "The Spirit and the Clay" is its study of the Basques, many of whose devotedly Catholic people fought bitterly against Franco in the Spanish Civil War, who suffered the bombing of Guernica (that preview of total war) and who were betrayed in surrender.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 31 -- South Africa is expected to demand the evacuation of Britain's Cape of Good Hope naval base following the announcement of the British decision to withdraw from Suez.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31 (UP) -- Stan Lopata's two-run pinch homer in the eighth inning tonight gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 6-to-5 victory in the second game of a twilight-night double-header after the St. Louis Cardinals had won the opener, 3 -- 2.

DETROIT, July 31 (AP) -- Ted Williams, who thrives in Briggs Stadium, hammered his seventeenth home run today and the Boston Red Sox blanked the Detroit Tigers, 4 -- 0, in a game twice delayed by rain.

IN 1947 the British Broadcasting Corporation commissioned Sir William Walton to compose a radio opera based on Chaucer's "Troilus and Cressida." The commission aroused considerable interest, for Sir William is one of the most distinguished composers in England and he had not previously written an opera.

IN town to put the finishing touches on his "Hansel and Gretel" puppet film feature, Michael Myerberg already is looking to the future. The producer hopes to have his opera with the extraordinary little people he calls, minikins, on the nation's screens by Labor Day.

FOR vigorous pansy plants next spring, seed should be started in August. It might be wise to order seed now, so that all may be in readiness at sowing time. I used to buy pansy plants, but a visit to a friend's garden opened my eyes to the money I could save -- and make -- by raising pansies from seed.
Possible therapeutic effects of a new series of more than fifty chemical compounds in the ethyl mercapto class against human tuberculosis were reported yesterday by the American Chemical Society.

SAN DIEGO, Duval County, Tex., July 30 -- South Texas' storied political baron, George B. Parr, is fighting to sustain his sway over the cactus-dotted empire that he has controlled for more than a quarter of a century.

IF the annual waves of tourists which flood Ireland should find the face of the country slightly altered in the future, the responsibility will have to be laid at the door of the motion picture industry.

IT is easy for the home gardener to care for his flowering deciduous shrubs all through the summer without too much exertion, if he does a few simple jobs at the opportune time. Just a few minor efforts here and there can change a mediocre landscape into one that is really attractive.

The stock market advanced in July for the seventh month in a row. The averages went to the best levels in nearly a quarter of a century. Bolstered by favorable mid-year earnings reports by some of the nation's largest corporations, prices rose to a new high for the movement and were at the top since June 5, 1930.

ADENAU, Germany, July 31 (UP) -- Onofre Marimon of Argentina, one of the world's top automobile racing drivers, was killed today when he lost control of his Maserati on the Wehrseifen curve at the Nuerburgring track.
SEVEN ISLANDS, Quebec, July 31 -- Canada's rich Ungava iron fields yielded their first ore to United States industry today.
HAVERSTRAW, N. Y., July 31 -- In spite of 98-degree heat, nearly all of the 6,000 local residents took part in the closing events today of Haverstraw's week-long centennial celebration.
Nat E. Herzfeld has been released from his ten-year contract as an official of the Yonkers Raceway. The contract had six years to run.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 -- The widely publicized sunshine of Southern California is largely responsible for the equally celebrated smog that reduces visibility, irritates eyes and throats, and severely damages crops in the Los Angeles metropolitan area, the Stanford Research Institute reported this week.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 31 (AP) -- Boardwalk Billy Smith, Atlantic City fighter, gave away 29 1/4 pounds tonight and knocked out Willie Bean, the California heavyweight champion from Los Angeles, with a right to the jaw in 2:16 of the fifth round at Convention Hall. Smith weighed 176 1/4 pounds and Bean 205 1/2.

Lieut. Gen. Withers A. Burress, commanding general of First Army, announced yesterday that the thirty-sixth anniversary of its establishment would be marked on Aug. 10 by ceremonies at Governors Island.
ALBANY, July 31 (AP) -- The State Crime Commission ended its three-year search for evil today by urging the man in the street to get into politics and insist on good government.
ROME, July 31 -- The Government expects to give the Italian economy a considerable fillip by building in the next five years 1,100 miles of new modern speedways.
CHICAGO, July 31 -- Stan, a big bay gelding, came from far back in the stretch today to nip Brush Burn at the wire and win the $156,000 Arlington Handicap.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 31 (AP) -- Claire Doran sank a 20-foot birdie chip and a 4-foot birdie putt on the last two holes to defeat Beverly Gammon, 5 and 3, today for her second straight women's Western amateur golf championship just as the sun went down on Broadmoor Country Club.

THE most dazzling success story in American history is that of Benjamin Franklin. Without benefit of inherited wealth or position the young printer's apprentice not only set about the speedy acquisition of a fortune, but went on to achieve greatness in a half-dozen different fields.

MOSCOW, July 31 -- The newspaper Agriculture, published by the Ministry of Agriculture, carried a four-column article today by Academician Trofim D. Lysenko advising farmers on fertilizing methods. The article is devoted to practical farming problems and is similar to several others by him on the same subject that have appeared in the last year.
The airline industry of Italy is in an advantageous position for "tremendous" expansion of air transport in the future, according to Gen. Luigi Gallo, managing director of Linee Aeree Italiane.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 31 -- President Jose Figueres said today he was completely unmoved by threatening notes from Nicaraguan President, Gen. Anastasio Somoza and reports that General Somoza was mustering armored forces on the frontier.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., July 31 -- This bustling Choptank River port just off Chesapeake Bay stops the clock for a midsummer week-end each year while its yacht club plays host to scores of speed boat daredevils.

As everyone expected, the relation of cigarette smoking to cancer was discussed at the International Cancer Congress in Sao Paulo, Brazil, last week. And also, as expected, the experts could not agree.

TO honor the World Council of Churches, which will meet this month at Northwestern University, the Art Institute of Chicago has put on a great loan exhibition, "Masterpieces of Religious Art" Covering nine centuries, the paintings were chosen, as Prof. Paul Tillich says in the catalogue foreword, because they were "authentically artistic" and "significantly religious."

WITH zeal and scholarship not unlike that which prompted Schumann and Mendelssohn to revive the long - neglected works of a Leipzig cantor named Bach, Paul Callaway and the Chamber Chorus of Washington have recorded for Vanguard the sixteenth-century Great Service of William Byrd.

TOKYO, Sunday, Aug. 1 (AP) -- More than a million peasants and soldiers in Red China are battling to hold back the Yangtze and Hwai Rivers after "the heaviest rainfall in a hundred years," the Peiping radio said today.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 27 -- Modern prospectors, armed with magnetometers and scintillometers, traveling by airplane and motorboat, have succeeded Alaska's sourdough gold prospector with his pickaxe and pan.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 31 (AP) -- Tennessee State University today set an American 800-meter relay record of 1:45.2 on the homestretch sprint of Mae Faggs in the women's National Amateur Athletic Union senior track and field championships.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 31 -- The Cabinet was reported tonight to have approved a draft agreement with a consortium of eight international oil companies for reactivation of Iran's long-stalled petroleum industry.
There'll hardly be a cove, river, lake in America or even damp, swampy place without a regatta this week. The country has gone ga-ga over pleasure boating as a participants' sport this summer.

DETROIT, July 31 -- Whether the vista of the automobile industry back down the highway of the first six months of 1954 is pleasing or otherwise depends on the office window from which the view is noted.

Thousands of tons of rock slipped from Prospect Point at Niagara Falls on Wednesday and crashed into the gorge below with a mighty roar. Such collapses have occurred frequently in the past. The most recent is said to have been surpassed in our time only by that of Jan. 17, 1931, which formed a deep crevice that changed the aspect of the Falls.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 31 -- The Bangkok. Post said today Thailand's Director General of Public Relations, Lieut. Gen. Momluang Kharb Kunchorn, had called the appeal of former Premier Pridi Phanomyong to overthrow the Pibul Songgram Government the first step toward a Communist attack here.

THE Guatemalan case has emphasized the concern of the United States lest communism gain a foothold in the Western Hemisphere. It has at the same time left open the question whether Washington is as much concerned with New World dictatorships of the Right as of the Left.

THE life of a golden eagle from fledgling days on the Island of Skye to full maturity is sketched in this book. Greeka's hunting, mating, capture, ultimate escape and triumphant return home are filled with interesting and little-known bird lore.
BUFFALO, July 31 -- State engineers here are confident that Erie County's main stem of the New York State Thruway will be completed "well in advance" of the Aug. 26 target date.

CLIFTON, N. J., July 31 -- Mayor John W. Surgent has called for a study of possible uses for a fifteen-acre portion of the Department of Agriculture quarantine station that new legislation permits the city to buy. A bill permitting the city to acquire the tract for community use was signed Wednesday by President Eisenhower.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31 -- A slight upswing in manufacturing employment in the Philadelphia area occurred in June, ending a decline of nine consecutive months. Reports from employers showed that jobs in manufacturing plants here advanced from 547,800 to 551,000 in June.

EVA MARIE SAINT is a striking young blond actress who is currently standing on the edge of the jungle of the "Big Time." Her performance as a sheltered, innocent girl who becomes emotionally entangled with Marlon Brando in "On the Waterfront" undoubtedly will be the happy occasion of her full-fledged entrance into that lofty echelon.

IT looks as if our superefficient molder of world championship teams, George M. Weiss, is getting to be a bit difficult to get along with these days. Last spring he sold one of his ace pitchers, Vic Raschi, because, as he expressed it, Big Vic had become "too complacent."

Eduardo Andrade is chairman of the committee for the fete.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- Dictionary makers are no longer shocked by words in common usage, because they now believe it is not their job to set up standards for a language, according to a University of Chicago language expert.

NO aircraft is ever considered ready for regular operations with the commercial airlines or the military services until it has completed a series of high and low-altitude flight tests to prove it is airworthy. There are reasons to believe, however, that the aerial trails of this country's first jet transport may be completed with unique speed.

WELLINGTON, N. Z., July 31 (Reuters) -- Swept by freakish winds out of their southern ocean feeding grounds, hundreds of Antarctic sea birds have been landing, and dying, on the west coast of New Zealand.

CHARLESTON, West Va., July 31 -- A political campaign devoid of personalities but marked by one big issue comes to a close in West Virginia next Tuesday. On that day about 1,200,000 citizens are elegible to vote.

CLEVELAND, July 31 -- Claims for unemployment compensation have been declining slightly but consistently, and over a tenweek span approximately 2,600 claims have been dropped. New and continued claims for this week totaled 20,864, against a level of about 23,750 in April.

Conservative estimates by Washington officials indicate that the Soviets will conclude at least twenty trade agreements with free nations this year. This would increase by eight the number of bilateral commercial pacts negotiated in 1953. ALBANY, July 31 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission announced today a reduction of 2,420,000 customers in New York utilities supplying gas service to $2,420,000 customers in New York City and Westchester County.

SEATTLE, Wash., July 28 -- A working partnership among traffic officers in helicopters and spotter planes, at radar stations and in camera-cars, in unmarked police cars and on motorcycles, is helping to cut the death rate on Washington State's highways.

SACRAMENTO, Calif. -- The taxpayers of the Golden State have just lavished the better part of a million dollars in refurbishing one of the State's most picturesque landmarks, its eighty-two-year-old Capitol building. And they are not through yet.

WICHITA, Kan., July 29 -- The latest version of an Air Force reconnaissance bomber today flew from Oklahoma City, Okla., to this city in 15 minutes and 20 seconds.

NEWTON, N. J., Aug. 1 -- One of dogdom's great boxers, Ch. Bang Away of Sirrah Crest marked his return to the East Coast after two years of campaigning in the Far West by carrying off top honors today in the eleventh annual show of the Lake Mohawk Kennel Club.
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Aug. 2 (UP) -- The Communists reported yesterday that two United Nations soldiers were killed and a Communist military policeman wounded in a clash in the truce zone.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- Two firemen, one the father of four children, were killed early today in a fire that destroyed a three-story brick building at 112 Main Street. The fire started shortly before midnight and routed four families who lived in the rear of the upper two floors.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 -- Dr. Syngman Rhee called on the United States tonight to overcome any fear of atomic warfare and stand up against Russia as the "positive and fearless" leader of the free world.
HAARLEM, the Netherlands, Aug. 1 -- Two thousand enthusiasts for a world language gathered here today in the thirty-ninth Universala Kongreso de Esperanto.

LONDON, Aug. 1 (Reuters) -- The Polish freighter Jaroslaw Dabrowski steamed toward Gdynia in Communist Poland today, tak-Dr. Joseph Cort, an American, to sample a way of life from which a former stowaway, Antoni Klimowicz, wished to flee.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Aug. 1 (UP) --Senator McCarthy told a cheering crowd of 15,000 persons today that he had "no intention" of resigning from the Senate. He said that if he made any mistakes in tracking down Communists, the public would be the first to know.

Improved methods of helping the physically handicapped will be discussed at the sixth world congress of the International Society for the Welfare of Cripples Sept. 13 to 17 in The Hague, the Netherlands, the society announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Republican Congressional leaders will begin this week final efforts to complete a legislative program on which they believe their party will stand or fall in the November elections.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- An Administration decision to halt the cutback in Army strength has spurred an intensive search for the right sized division to fight and survive in an atomic war.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Political developments in Southeast Asia injected a bullish element into the grain market again last week, and sharp price advances featured the early trade.
HIROSHIMA, Japan, Aug. 1 (AP) -- A new Roman Catholic edifice, the World Church for Peace, will be consecrated here Friday, the ninth anniversary of the atomic bomb explosion that wrecked Hiroshima.

Plans for a housing development on the north coast of Puerto Rico, twenty-five miles west of San Juan, have been announced here in connection with the purchase of 225 acres by Laurance S. Rockefeller from Miss Clara E. Livingston.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser drove in the deciding run with a seventh-inning single today as the Cleveland Indians won the second game of a double-header from the Washington Senators, 5 -- 4, after capturing the opener, 3 -- 1.

The existence of the relatively useless but in some cases politically lucrative jobs of hydrant inspector and corporation inspector is not something newly come to light. Corporation inspectors, who are supposed to see that streets are patched up after they have been opened for underground utility repairs, have been around since 1899.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 (AP) Curt Simmons snapped out of a three-game losing streak today as the Philadelphia Phillies backed him up with a 16-hit barrage to trounce the St. Louis Cardinals, 8-3. It was the left-hander's ninth triumph against the same number of setbacks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- The Democratic National Committee jokingly proposed today a "great debate" between President Eisenhower and Joseph T. Meek, the candidate the President has endorsed for the United States Senate.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 1 -- July steel activity will probably be recorded as the low month for the year. Some sources had looked for a steeper fall-off but final figures will show it was low enough. It was expected that August steel production would top July's but would not match the June level.

The progress of the world rests on the influence of obscure people through whom God fulfills His divine purpose, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, Professor of Religion at George Washington University, said yesterday.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Nationalists seeking merger of Portuguese territories with India today took control of Selvassa, headquarters town of the Portuguese Colonial District of Nagar Aveli, 100 miles north of Bombay on the West India coast.
CAMBRIDGE, Md., Aug. 1 -- W. Curtis Martens of Hampton, Va., was the headliner on a long program today of inboard events on the second half of the Cambridge Yacht Club's regatta.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- The United States Information Agency said today it now reaches an extra 200,000,000 foreign persons each week by releasing motion pictures through overseas commercial channels of the American movie industry.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 1--Pakistan has ended her seven-year-old water dispute with India.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- Completing its annual weekend as host for the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, the Echo Bay Y. C. regatta committee had to wait an hour today before starting a fleet of 104, the same count as yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 1 -- Iran announced today that she would pay "less than 30,000,000" ($84,000,000) in settlement of all claims advanced by the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company as a result of nationalization of its vast properties here in 1951.

ADENAU, Germany, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Juan Manuel Fangio of Argentina won the Grand Prix of Europe race today, driving his German-made Mercedes-Benz over the tricky 311-mile route in 3 hours 45 minutes 45.8 seconds.

DETROIT, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Ted Williams went wild in Briggs Stadium again today, smashing a single, a 420-foot double and his eighteenth home run, and led the Boston Red Sox to a 10-to-8 victory over the Detroit Tigers.
First Army units in eight northeastern states cut expenditures $1,239,015 in the first nine months of the fiscal year ended June 30, First Army headquarters reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Eleven hundred and forty-eight tournament contract bridge players this afternoon shattered all national championship attendance annual summer national championships opened at the Mayflower Hotel.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 1 -- Senator Estes Kefauver, whose political future holds vital interest for the Democratic party in the selection of a Presidential nominee in 1956, is engaged in a bitter struggle to win renomination in a primary election next Thursday.

PARIS, Aug. 1 -- When the first number of the Lanvin-Castillo collection appeared yesterday morning, it was evident that this house would follow the middy, pull-over trend so prevalent in Paris this season. Also, it was plain to see that Castillo, designing for Lanvin, was doing it with a light hand that did not ignore the natural curves of the body.
George E. Roosevelt and Tracy S. Voorhees of the Long Island Transit Authority have accepted directorships in the reorganization of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 27 -- Oil companies are sinking millions of dollars in the sub-surface of Alaska. Major outside companies as well as Alaska concerns, some of which sell dollar-a-share stocks through newspaper advertisements, are gambling on finding gushers in several parts of the territory.

Leaping Lena, a German carrier pigeon credited with flying an anti-Communist message through the Iron Curtain, was hailed yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, by several hundred American pigeons, released in her honor by fanciers at the airport.
